feedback_msg_text: The eKYC and Identity Assurance Working Group (eKYC & IDA WG) of the OpenID Foundation welcomes the proposal of the Commission to extend the scope of eIDAS trust services by introducing a new trust service for identification, authentication and for the provision of attributes, credentials and attestations and allowing the provision of identification for devices (Option 2 in the EC Revision of the eIDAS Inception Impact Assessment). This will allow companies operating identity solutions to contribute to securing digital transactions across the EU.   The eKYC & IDA WG is a dedicated working group of the OpenID Foundation (the technical standardisation body specifying OpenID Connect and accompanying extensions). The OpenID Foundation delivers specifications for interfaces that enable interoperability between implementations, and the eKYC and Identity Assurance Working Group is focusing on use cases and extensions to OpenID Connect for communicating strong identity assurance (https://openid.net/wg/ekyc-ida/).   Most commercial identity providers have built their solutions on OpenID Connect because of its strong support for mobile platforms, ease of integration, formally proven security, and the ability to have users explicitly consent. Billions of transactions are performed every day using OpenID Connect. A significant number of identity providers, e.g. financial institutions or telecommunications operators, are also able to assert digital identities on a level comparable to eIDAS trust level substantial or high. A significant number of relying parties and their developers are familiar with OpenID Connect as it is used for Open Banking as well as their own use cases. In order to leverage the respective digital identities for the EU Single Market, we recommend the commission to endorse OpenID Connect beside SAML (which was already endorsed under Implementing Act 2015/1501) as a technical standard for eIDAS.   We would also like to mention that several Identity Providers provide access to government issued identities via OpenID Connect and even eID systems use OpenID Connect, namely itsme (Belgium), BankID (Norway, Sweden, & Finland), and France Connect (France). We think this is a strong evidence that OpenID Connect could facilitate the implementation of all options given in the inception impact assessment document.   Please find the full comment in the attached document.  Feedback from: OpenID Foundation (eKYC & Identity Assurance WG) (86.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU digital ID scheme for online transactions across Europe

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sir/Madam,  With regard to the commitment of the European Commission to revise the eIDAS regulation (910/2014) and the current “roadmap consultation”, the Royal Dutch Association of Civil-law Notaries (KNB) would like to inform you about its concerns and recommendations.   Just like the European Commission we also believe that sufficient choices for citizens for an identity service provider established within the EU will give the citizens more sovereignty to decide to which third party they would disclose personal data or not. A clear separation between the collection of personal identity data and the collection of other data for commercial exploitation would reduce the possibilities of online platforms to make use of personal data for profiling of citizens or to obtain a monopoly in a certain area.   According to us an enormous need exists for a strong eID for EU citizens with an extension of eIDAS level ‘high’, issued by an independent organization like public authorities or notaries. The extension should consist of en vivo face to face identification, biometric aspects and additional safeguards to prevent fraud and to protect the EU citizen as much as possible. We are willing to discuss the possibilities and our ideas for this eID with eIDAS level “High Extended” with you.   Regarding your intentions to launch an European Digital Identity scheme (EUid) we would like to emphasize that it is important that besides public eID’s also private suppliers are allowed to offer eID services to public and private online service providers. In general, private companies are able to offer innovative and cost-effective eID solutions. The development of eID’s should at least partly be left to the market. We assume that also private providers will have the opportunity to become certified and registered in accordance with the EUid scheme and this will not become only a public eID.   It is furthermore important that the schemes to obtain a registration as trusted service provider are equal throughout the EU to prevent unfair competition. For example currently compliance of eID’s with the eIDAS requirements differs between member states, which might cause unfair competition.   Whichever option mentioned in the Inception Impact Assessment is chosen, it is important to realize that several public and private eID providers are already developing and investing for years now. For this reason the (technical) requirements for eID suppliers with eIDAS levels “substantial” and “high” should not change significantly to prevent additional costs or investments for eID providers and discouraging in stead of encouraging the development of eID products.   Another important concern is the lack of a system for acknowledgement of advanced electronic signatures. Advanced electronic signatures are frequently used in business, real estate and business to consumer relations. However in contrary to qualified electronic signatures there is no ‘EU Trusted List of Trust Service Providers’ for advanced electronic signatures. For companies and citizens it is almost impossible to determine whether such a digital signature is reliable or not. We advise to develop an acknowledgement system comparable with the EU Trusted List for qualified electronic signatures.   At last we would like to mention that the KNB is involved in the development of an eID with eIDAS level “high” called ‘NotaryID’ for the notaries in the Netherlands, which will be used for access to digital systems of notaries and KNB and for signing of digital notarial deeds (qualified electronic signatures). This eID will only be issued after en vivo face to face identification at a notary office. In the future this eID might become available for digital identification outside the notarial environment.
Initiative: EU digital ID scheme for online transactions across Europe

feedback_msg_text: Finance Denmark welcomes the initiative to revise the 2014 eIDAS Regulation, extending it to the private sector and promoting trusted identities, in general, across Europe.  In Denmark, we have had a well-functioning public/private digital ID solution since 2010 called NemID. It is a public private partnership collaboration between the Danish banks and the public sector. It is used extensively, by more than 90 % of the population between 16 and 90 years, both for public and private services, including electronic banking solutions and in a vast number of other financial e-services that requires the security of an eID solution. Public services are almost all digitized, physical mail close to non-existing, and electronic banking is used by nine out of ten bank customers.   The NemID solution will be replaced by a new solution in 2021 called MitID, which again is a public/private partnership collaboration between the Danish banks and the public sector. The Danish Banks have therefore made large investments in both the current and next digital ID solutions.  The Danish financial sector has realized the benefit of working together with public institutions to ensure solutions which would be widespread in the Danish public, and therefore been a key player in reducing cost and advancing the digitization of society as a whole.   Within banking, there is a 40 year plus history of building solutions together in areas which are not competitive, e.g. the Danish Central Securities Depository, VP Securities, and three data centres servicing smaller and mid-sized banks. In the public/private space, other advanced solutions are the Digital Land Registry and e-Skat, a solution giving financial institutions insight in a citizens’ tax information based on individual authorizations.  Based on the domestic experience, Finance Denmark sees great opportunities for an extension of the eIDAS framework based on interoperability of secure domestic solutions. While the Danish NemID solution (and the coming solution MitID) are national schemes, they are built in collaboration with the public sector and are also subject to the eIDAS regulation. The Danish government has notified NemID with the Commission in accordance with eIDAS to ensure that the solution is recognized in other member states. This will also be the case for the coming solution (MitID).  We have noted that DG FISMA is also looking into the possibility of establishing a digital (financial) ID scheme to be used across the EU. Therefore, we encourage the Commission to ensure that the two initiatives are coordinated to avoid duplication of work and/or have possibly conflicting requirements.  Finance Denmark  Amaliegade 7 DK-1256 Copenhagen Denmark www.financedenmark.dk
Initiative: EU digital ID scheme for online transactions across Europe

feedback_msg_text: The concept of combining the three options makes a lot of sense, although it may require a longer migration period to move from the current eIDAS to the next phase.  Option 1 includes identity verification for issuing qualified certificates. Identity verification should include remote identity verification solutions. The international standards organization, Fast Identity Online (FIDO) Alliance is currently developing possession-based identity verification and binding performance requirements along with certification assessment criteria for those requirements. Depending on the timing, eIDAS could leverage FIDO’s work and include it in the updated eIDAS regulation. In addition, a recent trend is utilizing databases maintained by member state governments to verify attributes voluntarily with auditable and recorded user consent. Attributes could include such as name, address, driver license number, date of birth, and social security or health ID numbers.    Although facial recognition technology has been negatively reported on primarily when used in law enforcement and border control applications. However, when used for online authentication into a web site or mobile application, facial recognition technology has been well received by the general public for its balance of security and user experience benefits. Since they are distinct use cases for the technology, the Commission should not omit facial recognition for authentication in the update.  Option 3’s European Digital Identity scheme (EUid) is a worthwhile endeavor. On the surface the initiative is similar to the Pan-Canadian Trust Framework currently under development by the Digital Identity and Authentication Council of Canada (DIACC). If the EUid scheme moves forward, we recommend that member states follow the Government of Canada’s lead and collaborate with vendors and relying parties such as financial institutions, healthcare institutions, e-commerce companies, and naturally representatives from member states.
Initiative: EU digital ID scheme for online transactions across Europe

feedback_msg_text: General We concur with the assessments on the description of the current situation. Especially interoperability and extensions to digital validation is crucial if Europe is to have a sovereign common market in 10 years based on the pace of digitalization. There is a clear trend of entrenchment of national walled garden development in this area currently.  As digitalization is happening at different pace in EU we find several member States already implementing digital validation on top of identification. As this happens within the national boundary, we are facing the development of digital islands further weakening the fundament for a single digital market unless common solutions are developed. In our view this is urgent as the resistance will increase dramatically once these islands are entrenched.     We understand that the outlined options are not mutually exclusive and should in all likelihood be combined in order to achieve a satisfactory outcome - for example implementing option 3 appears difficult without inclusion of parts of options 1 and 2.  Conclusions The current eIDAS regulation update will significantly impact EU and national digital developments, related investments and digital environment role within EU and Member States during upcoming years. Therefore, eIDAS regulation update should incorporate the major aspects from all options and if necessary, updated with the reasonable new options proposed during the current consultations. In terms of enabling a deep single digital market the addition of attributes and defining cross border data sets is crucial for enabling digital verification at the European level and to avoid the member states turning into digital islands. This is fully inline with the recommendation in the CEPS report but will require a deployment of solutions to happen at scale in the MS where standardisation and harmonisation are key enablers. This would be instrumental in promoting the same goals as the single digital gateway and the only once principle also for the private sector. Organisation: Association for promotion of digital verification

feedback_msg_text: Yubico’s feedback to the eIDAS inception impact assessment document is summarized below.  As regards to Option 1, the reinforced baseline scenario, Yubico recommends the following improvements of the eIDAS EU regulation 910/2014 with respect to eID schemes:  * The eIDAS regulation should specify well-defined rules for remote identity proofing  * The eIDAS regulation should be harmonized with the eID scheme requirements in the EU Cybersecurity Act, EU regulation 2019/881  * The Commission Implementing Regulation EU 2015/1501 should require credential phishing resistance at Level of Assurance (LoA) High A framework for re-using pre-approved eID products could simplify the approval and notification processes of eID schemes  * Backup eID schemes with simplified processes for distribution and remote identity proofing could be allowed during emergency situations such as pandemics; such eID schemes may therefore go beyond traditional X.509 PKI smart cards  * LoA High should be mandatory for secure access to QTSPs with remote signing services in order to cater for sole control of remote creation of Qualified Electronic Signatures  When it comes to Option 2, the extended scope of eID regulation under eIDAS to the private sector, Yubico has the following comments:  * In general, it would be beneficial to extend the scope of eID regulation under eIDAS to the private sector; this would increase the use of eID schemes across the EU  * Existing large scale identity providers, such as technology companies, identity providers, banks and telecom providers with billions of users, could get their high-end authentication solutions notified as eID schemes  * The current eID approval process, which is based on national agencies’ approvals, would have to be adopted for private identity providers, which may require new or complementary procedures in addition to the national approval procedures  * The architecture of national eIDAS-Nodes may have to be adjusted for private identity providers; in particular OpenID Connect may be allowed as an alternative to SAML v2 for eIDAS-Nodes  * If banks in the EU would create approved eID schemes, they can be aligned with the PSD2 EU directive 2015/2366 for meeting the requirements on Strong Customer Authentication and Dynamic Linking for authentication of financial transactions  Finally, with respect to the European Digital Identity scheme (EUid) in Option 3, Yubico would like to make the following comments:  * A European Digital Identity scheme (EUid) is not preferred in our view  * There are existing systems in various EU member states that may not be compatible with an EUid  * A pan-European EUid may be viewed as too regulated in various EU member states  * Technical innovations, in particular in the private sector, could be suppressed or mitigated by an EUid  * Local support can be problematic with an EUid, with respect to physical identification, helpdesk support in local languages, and distribution of eID tokens  * Instead of an EUid, federated solutions could be considered instead; such federations will allow for better international interoperability, higher scalability, and be based on modern technology  More information is available in the attached document "Feedback on the eIDAS inception impact assessment - Yubico’s response to the EU Commission". Feedback from: Yubico AB (154.1 KB - PDF - 11 pages) Download
Initiative: EU digital ID scheme for online transactions across Europe

feedback_msg_text: Hi: thank you for great step forward. Observing various EID schemes so far which the paper categorize them as moderate success but i have to say it has a long way to go to serve its core purpose which is cross border transactions and ease of business. While 15 member states have developed their own EID schemes and launched it at various levels in their own countries either in public sector usage or private sector usage but there is is little to no evidence that there is any motivations for local companies or states to offer authentication on their own sites/apps. A German citizen living in France will hardly find any local companies offering authentication via German EID. I am sure same is true for most member states.  Combination of option 2 and 3 seems like a best way to to go but the guideline has to be more direct and possibly prescriptive (perhaps including form factor) else one of the biggest issue is overlooked which is end user experience which is one of the biggest weakness of current EID schemes. Another prescription has to give important to higher level of assurance (allowing any guidance where such wallets can be filled by simply a picture of document can have vey low fraud tolerance).   Allowing private sectors to contribute towards global EID schemes will bring the best out of every thing including building some thing which is thought with not only business but also end users in mind. The services need to be free for end users where as private IDP providers shall have some motivation/reward to offer such services in the interest of end users, perhaps monetized through business that offer such services.
Initiative: EU digital ID scheme for online transactions across Europe

feedback_msg_text: By way of background I have been working for Tier 1 firms for 20 years and have set up many tax structures. The basic idea of the European Commission that there are no substance requirements is untrue. It is rather correct that there each country has its own substance requirements. These requirements differ from country to country.  A taxpayer is thus obliged to meet many different requirements when he/she/it goes abroad. For instance when he/she/it goes from country A to country B and then country C, he/she/it would need to meet the requirements of country A, B, C in country A (rather than just meeting the requirements of country A). He/she/it would also meet the requirements of country A, B, C in country B (rather than just meeting the requirements of country B). Etc.  And usually, if well advised, these requirements would typically be met in practice.   International taxpayers thus face different difficulties:  - Knowing which substance requirements need to be met in which country. Given that most of the time this is driven by judgments rather than a clear law provision, knowing the substance requirements is not easy. And costs a lot of advisory fees. - Keeping up to date with the substance requirements which need to be met in each country. Given that most of the time the requirements are driven by judgments rather than a clear law provision, keeping up to date is not easy either. And costs again a lot of advisory fees.  As such it would be great if the substance requirements were unified in Europe. It would be much easier for taxpayers to meet substance requirements in Europe if the rules were clearly laid down and would be valid for all European countries.
Initiative: Tax avoidance – fighting the use of shell entities and arrangements for tax purposes

feedback_msg_text: La lotta all'uso di entità e meccanismi di comodo a fini fiscali è importante. Resta però da approfondire la questione delle cd. "strutture leggere", tema sul quale non si è mai posta in passato la doverosa attenzione e che costituisce motivo di continue controversie. Una cosa sono le strutture manifestamente fittizie (le c.d. società fantasma), altra le "legal entities" che operano concretamente. Occorre precisare che la “presenza fisica” della società in termini di locali, di personale e di attrezzature, è salvaguardata anche se quest’ultima ricorre a servizi o a prestazioni di terzi, anche in outsourcing, o tramite strutture contenute. In definitiva si deva trattare di una entità funzionante in normale regime d’impresa, compenetrata nell’economia dello Stato membro di residenza, a nulla conferendo le eventuali decisioni connesse al risparmio degli oneri di gestione. Diversamente interpretando, si avrebbe che solo con l’assunzione diretta di personale, la stipula di un contratto di affitto, l’acquisto o il noleggio di attrezzature, sarebbero soddisfatte le condizioni di un insediamento effettivo della società interessata nello Stato membro e l’esercizio di un’attività economica reale; non è questa la definizione di “collegamento stabile” inteso nell’orientamento consolidato della Corte di Giustizia. La nozione di stabilimento di cui alle disposizioni del Trattato relative alla libertà di stabilimento implica l’esercizio effettivo di un’attività economica per una durata di tempo indeterminata, mercé l’insediamento in pianta stabile in un altro Stato membro. L’elemento determinante è, dunque, identificare il centro degli interessi principali della società, ove per “centro degli interessi principali” si deve intendere il luogo in cui la "legal entitiy" esercita in modo abituale, e pertanto riconoscibile dai terzi, la gestione dei suoi interessi. Quindi, il luogo in cui una società svolge la sua prevalente attività direttiva ed amministrativa per l’esercizio dell’impresa, cioè il centro effettivo dei suoi interessi, dove la società vive ed opera, dove si trattano gli affari e dove i diversi fattori dell’impresa vengono organizzati e coordinati per l’esplicazione ed il raggiungimento dei fini sociali. Risulta, pertanto, necessario circoscrivere i parametri di “vitalità”, fermo restando che sarà onere delle amministrazioni fiscali provare una diversa realtà. Su quest’ultimo punto, mi soffermo solo per osservare che bisogna comunque rispettare principi di civiltà giuridica eliminando l’illegittima prassi delle amministrazioni fiscali di porre carico dei contribuenti l’inversione dell’onere della prova, spesso a tal punto difficile da soddisfare, da risultare “diabolica”. La deriva “patologica” che ne consegue è quella di consentire agli organi preposti all’accertamento un’ampia discrezionalità di valutazione dei fatti e delle prove fornite dal contribuente, con il pericolo che questa discrezionalità si traduca, mediante l’uso delle presunzioni, in una messa in opera del “libero convincimento” del funzionario preposto al controllo, quindi, senza che l’amministrazione finanziaria fornisca la concreta ed oggettiva prova di frode, abuso, e/o evasione, essendo sufficiente avvalersi del dettato delle disposizioni vigenti fondate, come detto, su presunzioni generali di evasione. Secondo il costante orientamento interpretativo della Corte di Giustizia dell’Unione Europea, spetterebbe all’amministrazione finanziaria dimostrare, in base a elementi e circostanze probanti, che contribuente ha eluso/evaso l’obbligo tributario. Occorre, pertanto che le nuove norme siano conformi ai principi Carta dei diritti fondamentali dell’unione, che dal 2009, a seguito dell’entrata in vigore del trattato di Lisbona, ha lo stesso effetto giuridico vincolante dei Trattati, e si aggiunge ai principi e diritti derivanti dalle tradizioni costituzionali degli Stati membri come sancito nel Preambolo.  Cordiali saluti Alessandro Savorana
Initiative: Tax avoidance – fighting the use of shell entities and arrangements for tax purposes

feedback_msg_text: En temps qu' organisation professionnelle représentant les intérêts des acteurs économiques du secteur de la chasse, du tir sportif et des équipements de sécurité en France, le SNAFAM a étudié les propositions et orientations envisagées au travers de cette introduction d'étude d'impact. Nous avons exprimé des opinions qui sont parties prenantes de l'analyse délivrée indépendamment par l'IEACS.  Nous y ajouterons des considérations plus globales :  Il est difficile de donner des avis précis sur chaque point sans connaître les motivations engendrant ces velléités d'évolution. Nous comprenons et applaudissons à toute simplification administrative permettant de gagner du temps  de traitement  mais la plupart de ces intentions semblent accompagnées d'accroissement de contrôles. Sans préjuger du résultat, nous avons peur de ne pas en percevoir le bénéfice .  Ce qui interpelle en premier lieu est l'interférence  des propositions du Règlement 258/2012 régissant les règles d export et d import avec le périmètre défini de la Directive Armes. Cela engendre donc des difficultés pour analyser les propositions comme celles sur les marquages, sur les armes d' alarme et signalisation telles que définies par les différents Règlement d'exécution, sur les armes démilitarisées classées en C (!) ... malgré le Règlement d'exécution qui en sécurise l'irréversibilité. Et cela nous interpelle sur les buts recherchés par cette évolution qui ne vous aura pas échappée .   Nous nous interrogeons sur cette nouvelle nécessité de rouvrir le dossier d'une définition différenciant les armes civiles des militaires que de longues commissions d' experts n'ont pu résoudre à ce jour ! Serait-ce lié à la proposition d'aligner les procédures  concernant les armes civiles à celles des militaires en cas d'échec ?  Une telle idée montrerait une méconnaissance des différences fondamentales des besoins de ces 2 types de commerce très différents en termes  de réactivité commerciale et  d'anticipation des besoins et serait très néfaste à l'activité de nos entreprises de distribution et de fabrication.   Que les MS  améliorent les échanges d' informations sur les  mouvements d' armes grâce aux numérique nous semble évidemment positif  ,mais  du ressort de la Directive Armes comme le marquage du premier MS  metteur sur le marché ( mais ce n' est pas l' option déterminé à ce jour puisque c' est le pays producteur qui est à marquer ).  Il est louable de prendre les mesures utiles pour éradiquer le commerce illicite  mais pour ce faire, il est nécessaire de le faire en harmonie avec les acteurs économiques concernés qui sont déjà parfaitement identifiés par les autorités nationales respectives - et pour beaucoup d' actes,  identifiés comme "tiers de confiance" par  l' Etat - afin de ne prendre que les mesures appropriées. Pour cela, il est indispensable de comprendre la nature des problèmes rencontrés afin de pouvoir analyser les propositions que la Commission va porter à notre connaissance au travers de l'étude d'impact à venir.
Initiative: Firearms – review of export rules and import & transit measures

feedback_msg_text: The revision should perfect import procedures, to protect and not discriminate European products. We agree there is a need to streamline bureaucracy and reduce costs, but we are used to expecting the exact opposite whenever there is talk of “streamlining”. The revision could cause more work for the public administration: who will pay the price for this extra work and the inevitable delays, if not companies? Changes like the marking of semi-finished essential parts means exactly the opposite: if a part is not finished and not fire-ready, why should we regard it as a finished part? MSs follow European regulations for deactivation. We have to focus on imported products which are not subject to European regulations and may not be manufactured or deactivated safely. We have asked several times that firearms, signal guns and deactivated guns imported from other countries should go through CIP Proof Houses before reaching their importers (there should be a unified marking standard). If an exporter country is not part of the CIP, the above products should be shipped to the Proof House of the MS of destination, if existing, or to the Proof House of a fellow MS. There they will be properly marked. Unfortunately, some MSs require a transit permit even if the license has already been issued by another MSs. The majority of Italian manufacturers has been sharing digitalized data with Italian authorities through the SIGMA portal for almost 7 years: digitalization is not an issue, as far as it means simplification. Treating non-military firearms in the same way as military firearms it is conceptually very wrong and it also dismisses the separation of competences between our Ministry of the Interior and our Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Applying the same export approval procedures of military firearms, long and expensive, would be just a complication. The only way for this revision to bring simplification and efficiency is to allow for the Commission to be formed by professionals who truly know our industry and its daily needs, rather than bureaucrats. We summarized the concerns of over 100 companies we represent into 4 major groups: 1.Italian Authorities mandate that personal information (first and last name, citizenship, place and date of birth) of the owner of the importing company or of the license holder is disclosed. This is not always possible because many import licenses issued by the importers’ countries are not issued in a specific person’s name, but in the name of a company. As Reg. 258 speaks of a generic “Consignee” (Article 8, point f), is it possible and correct to waive the mandatory requirement of these personal information in licenses that are not issued in a specific person’s name and make it an optional requirement?  2.Reg. 258 (Article 2, point 11) makes a provision for temporary exports with a 24-month validity window. However, it does not take the opposite scenario of “temporary imports” into consideration. As temporary imports perfectly mirror temporary exports, we believe there should be a provision for them as well. As Reg. 258 is not clear about this point, the window of validity of temporary imports is never the same, which creates many difficulties for all those who need to import and subsequently export them after the work on them is completed. 3.Reg. 258 (Art. 8) includes a list of mandatory information required for the purpose of obtaining an export license; such list does not include either the currency nor the value of the goods. However, field 15 of the form attached to Reg. 258 specifically requires these two pieces of information. If the objective is to fight illegal firearm manufacturing and trade and global crime, what is the significance of these two  pieces of information? Are these two pieces of information mandatory? 4.The document formats should be the same for all MSs; by doing that the data used to fill the different fields/numbered cells will be readable and unequivocally understandable by anyone Feedback from: Consorzio Armaioli Italiani (201.7 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Firearms – review of export rules and import & transit measures

feedback_msg_text: While we support the principles, embodied in the UN Arms Trade Treaty, which are designed to prevent illicit transfer, trafficking or diversion of firearms, we maintain that a strong, viable network of lawful and registered firearms dealers is fundamental to preventing illicit trade.  We also note the text, as cited in the CSP7 preparatory meetings (April 26-30, 2021) that: “ATT stakeholders should formalise discussions concerning post-delivery cooperation experiences from both exporter and importer perspectives and should consider developing guidelines on cooperation and assistance to ensure ongoing compliance with export documentation, including authorised end-use.”  We therefore understand the rationale behind the EU adoption of 'authorised' End Use Certificates (EUCs). This is, however, causing difficulties for importing countries such as the UK, and is putting shipments at greater risk than is necessary. The reason for this is that UK legislation does not require authorised EUCs and there is therefore no competent UK authority willing to endorse such documents. Neither the UK Department of International Trade, the Home Office nor the Police have at present the mandate to endorse these certificates.  Shipments which formerly came from Austria to the UK through Germany and France are now being trans-shipped by sea via several ports on the Atlantic and Mediterranean, as Germany now requires an 'authorised' EUC in order for a transit permit to be issued. (We understand that even with an 'authorised' EUC, the time taken to obtain a transit permit has increased from 4-6 weeks to 10-12 months.) The costs of shipment have tripled or quadrupled and the shipment time has increased from a few days to about a month, greatly increasing the exposure of shipments to the risk of theft or illicit diversion.  UK dealers are in consequence finding alternatives to EU vendors.
Initiative: Firearms – review of export rules and import & transit measures

feedback_msg_text: Position of ESFAM regarding certain measures proposed by the EU Commission to amend/clarify Regulation (EU) No 258/2012 on exports, imports and transit of civilian firearms (“the Regulation”)  As a preliminary remark, ESFAM (https://www.esfam.eu/) which represents the interest of the most important European civilian firearms manufacturers considers the delay to react to the various measures proposed by the EU Commission (until 2 July 2021) as being very tight. ESFAM insists on the necessity to involve industrial major players before proposing amendments to the Regulation (EU) No 258/2012 which would have direct consequences in the national legislation of the Member States. ESFAM is willing to be involved in this process.  Amongst the four scenarii proposed by the EU Commission, clarification and/or new legislation provision are envisaged. ESFAM considers the legal framework concerning civilian arms trade as being rather unstable with frequent changes and sometimes different interpretation and/implementation measures by the Member States (eg.regarding the marking of essential components). Although ESFAM fully support the objectives of those amendments (ie., detecting and prevent the trafficking of firemars), it is sometimes difficult for the industry to adapt its process in due time. Reasonable transition period is therefore necessary. ESFAM fully supports the objective of the EU Commission to facilitate legitimate international trade of firearms and support the European industry by providing a sound regulatory environment with as little regulatory burden as possible.  Taking the above into account, the opinion of ESFAM on some of the envisaged measures can be summarized as follows:  1. Having more (import) controls of semi-finished unmarked components  Position of ESFAM :   - the term of “semi-finished” components is vague and could raise many problems of interpretation in each Member State;  - controlling the importation of such components would most likely increase the administrative burden of the manufacturers;  - it is unclear what kind of controls would be required (marking ? license?); - the traceability of firearms and components (including marking), are all matters that fall within the competence of the Directive 91/477/CEE and outside the scope of the Regulation   2. Having the same procedure for civilian and military firearms (including more stringent controls of the actual end-user of exported civilian firearms   Position of ESFAM :   - Civilian and military product are very different products with different end-users > proportional measures are therefore required - National legislations of several Members States do already regulate the control of end-users of civilian firearms end-users which would duplicate the controls measures;  - imposing heavy administrative control measures of the end-user outside the EU would undermine fair competition with Non-EU competitors.  3. Imposing post-shipment controls   Position of ESFAM :   - This is a politically sensitive issue : why controlling one State instead of another ? - Who would perform such controls?  4. Fully digital and export license Position of ESFAM :   - No problem with this measure provided Members State are free to decide not to implement this digital treatment (cfr article 346 TFEU – essential interest of Member State security related to trade in arms)  5. No measure envisaged for the transport of civilian firearms (no measure   Position of ESFAM :   - Transporting firearms on the EU territory is a real issue and it is very difficult to find out professional transporters : measures should be envisaged to facilitate such activity in order to allow and facilitate such transportation.
Initiative: Firearms – review of export rules and import & transit measures

feedback_msg_text: We appreciate that one of your objectives is to facilitate the legitimate international trade of firearms and support the EU industry with as little regulatory burden as possible since unfortunately, it has not been the case so far as the regulations are stricter but most of all, they keep changing and it is thus really hard to adapt our industrial and internal processes each time (e.g: marking; REACH). Yet, we find that the policy options envisaged are fulfilling the complete opposite of such objective.  Marking of the first country of import: It shall only be put on the barrel to reflect the practice of national proof houses – otherwise it would be an additional marking, so additional costs and a slower industrial process. As provided for in Article 8.1(b) of the UN Firearms Protocol, it shall be specified that it is not needed for temporary imports. Exclusion of military firearms or firearms destined for the armed forces/police/public authorities of the MS shall remain unambiguous. Fully digital licence procedures: this should not impede the relevant authorities to analyse such requests at their sole discretion (cf. Article 346 TFUE) since the protection of the essential interests of the MS security can be connected with the production of/trade in arms and munitions. There shall always be a free section to provide any useful information. Only acceptable if it means shorter/quicker process.  Having the same procedure for civilian and military firearms: this clearly cannot facilitate the international trade of civil firearms. Civilian and military firearms are distinguished for a reason – they do not have the same technical specificities nor the same end-use and that is why we need to have proportionate procedure depending on the type of products. For instance, civilian firearms would become subject to military embargos and the EU industry of hunting/sport shooting firearms would thus loose important markets, which would result in unfair competition. Each country has already its own local regulations regarding who can own a firearm and how. More stringent controls on the end-use would thus duplicate the work already done at the national/local level. If such EUC are to be imposed, their format should be free. Better controls of semi-finished unmarked components: confusing wording : better controls means a marking of such components or a need for export/import/transit licences ? It has to be limited to essential components only. Difficult to agree on a definition of “semi-finished”. Some semi-finished components can be used for other products – it would thus impact other types of industries. Authorizing such imports only to arms dealers should be an acceptable solution and declaring it in the relevant invoice shall be sufficient (without further marking or licensing imposed).  Post-shipment controls: significant political/trust issues if a country decides to do inspections in one country and not another. Not clear who would be in charge of such controls. Article 4 of EU Directive 2021/555 on national computerized data-filing system is already enough. Compulsory upload of refusals: this should not lead to the impossibility for a MS to grant an authorisation if such request has been denied by another MS as it could provoke sensitive political issues and a barrier to trade.  It is important for the wording to be clear/unambiguous to avoid room for different MS interpretation. We are afraid that once again such a revision will impede compliant EU industries to do their business and European citizens to continue their leisure activities. We do not see how the envisaged measures would help to tackle illegal firearms traffic. Finding professional transporters and banks is becoming increasingly complex in our field of business which is a huge barrier to trade as we are legally allowed to manufacture/trade. Finally, such revision shall be discussed beforehand with firearms experts and enough time for consultation shall be given.
Initiative: Firearms – review of export rules and import & transit measures

feedback_msg_text: Having been given the opportunity, the International Practical Shooting Confederation would like to make the comments set out below on the Inception Impact Assessment regarding "Review of rules of export authorization, and import and transit measures for firearms" Ref Ares (2021) 3677254.  Firstly, the vagueness of the proposal makes it difficult to assess exactly what is being proposed and thus to evaluate what consequences the proposals would have. That is a shortcoming in itself. We note that the impact assessment does not mention consequences for sport at all - despite the promotion of international sport being one of the Union's objectives under the Lisbon Treaty.  Rules concerning the import, export, transit, trade and classification of firearms have a direct impact on sport shooting. Those who practice our sport are dependent on being able to possess, import, export and travel with firearms, parts of firearms and ammunition – of the same types and in the same manner as other competitors from outside the European Union.  Next, we would like to draw particular attention to the fact that, in its original proposal for an amending directive for the Firearms Directive, the European Commission proposed to reclassify many common sporting firearms, - including those used in our sport, - as banned (category A). This proposal was deleted as part of the compromise that was the result of the trialogue negotiations and thus our sport could continue to be practiced. The proposed change in the classification of weapons must not be allowed to constitute an introduction of these rules ‘through the back door’.  The modern sporting rifles and other firearms that we use in our sport are not, and should not, be categorized as military equipment such as anti-aircraft missiles, machine guns and anti-tank guns.  As part of your ongoing work, we urge you to consider the following: • That no firearms currently used in sports in the European Union should be reclassified as ‘category A’. • That no firearms currently used in sports in the European Union should be classified as “military”. • That the rules for importing and exporting firearms, and parts for firearms, currently used in sports must be designed so that individuals can continue to import such goods into the European Union.    We would also like to emphasize that the sharing of databases on firearms and firearms’ owners between countries significantly increases the risk of data breaches, with potentially serious consequences for national security and increased crime.  Finally, we would like to point out the importance of any impact assessment incorporating the consequences for national and international sport.  Best Regards Mr. Roland Dahlman Regional Director   Swedish Dynamic Shooting Sport Federation  IPSC Sweden rd@sdssf.se Feedback from: Swedish Dynamic Shooting Sport Federation (140.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Firearms – review of export rules and import & transit measures

feedback_msg_text: Review of rules of export authorization, and import and transit measures for firearms - Ref Ares(2021) 3677254.  Having been given the opportunity, the Swedish Multisport Federation would like to make the comments set out below on the Inception Impact Assessment regarding "Review of rules of export authorization, and import and transit measures for firearms" Ref Ares(2021) 3677254. The vagueness of the proposal makes it difficult to assess exactly what is being proposed and thus to evaluate what consequences the proposals would have. That is a shortcoming in itself.  We also note that the impact assessment does not mention consequences for sport at all - despite the promotion of international sport being one of the Union's objectives under the Lisbon Treaty. Therefore, we must point out the importance of any impact assessment incorporating the consequences for national and international sport. The proposal have potential serious implications within this area.  Those who practice shooting sports –within our federation such as Biathlon Orienteering, Modern Pentathlon and Military Pentathlon, as well as in other sports federations – are dependent on being able to possess, import, export and travel with firearms, parts of firearms and ammunition – of the same types and in the same manner as other competitors from outside the European Union. Therefore, rules concerning the import, export, transit, trade and classification of firearms all have a direct impact on sport shooting.  We would also like to draw particular attention to the fact that, in its original proposal (from 2015) for an amending directive for the European Firearms Directive, the European Commission proposed to reclassify many common civilian sporting firearms, as banned (category A). This proposal was deleted as part of the compromise that was the result of the trialogue negotiations, the sport shooting with the firearms concerned could therefore continue be practiced within the Union. The proposed change in the classification of weapons must not be allowed to constitute an re-introduction of these rules ‘through the back door’. The firearms used in sport shooting are not, and should not be categorized as, military equipment together with such as anti-aircraft missiles, machine guns and anti-tank guns. As part of your ongoing work, we urge you to consider the following: • That no firearms currently used in sports in the European Union should be reclassified as ‘category A’. • That no firearms currently used in sports in the European Union should be classified as “military”. • That the rules for importing and exporting firearms, and parts for firearms (including “unfinished parts”), currently used in sports must be designed so that individuals can continue to import such goods into the European Union.  Finally, we would like to emphasize that the sharing of databases on firearms and firearms’ owners between countries significantly increases the risk of data breaches, with potentially serious consequences for national security and increased crime.  Stockholm June 24, 2021  ________________________________ Anders Emanuelson Chairman of the Board Swedish Mulitsport Federation
Initiative: Firearms – review of export rules and import & transit measures

feedback_msg_text: Wing is an Alphabet company that delivers food, medicine, and other supplies by drone. Wing provides commercial drone delivery on three continents, with tens of thousands of flights directly to homes across Finland, Australia, and the US. Wing is also a U-Space Service Provider, demonstrating and developing capabilities to help all drone operators share the skies. Wing is working with authorities in Europe, Australia, and the US, to help lay the groundwork for a safe, open, and secure U-Space ecosystem that supports diverse operations at scale.  Wing welcomes the Drone 2.0 roadmap and shares the EC’s view that the development of a thriving and competitive drone industry can accelerate Europe’s transition to green and digital economy. At scale, drones can help to support safer, better connected, and more sustainable cities:  -Wing drone delivery is safer than driving, flying, or walking a package to a customer’s home. In a single US city, drone delivery could avoid up to 580 road accidents per year in a single metropolitan area. -At scale, drone delivery could place 3-8 times as many local businesses within reach of a household in Finland, generating 13 m€ in new sales for local businesses, and improving access to food and healthcare for 37,000 senior residents who need assistance with shopping.  -Drones can produce 94 % lower emissions per package than delivery by car in the US, and lower emissions than a gas or electric van carrying multiple time-sensitive packages. At scale, drone delivery could help to reduce 2,000 tons of CO2 emissions per year in Helsinki, equivalent to 250 ha of forest, or 100,000 tons of CO2 emissions per year in a single Australian state.  Realizing these benefits will depend on policy frameworks that promote safe and responsible drone operations at scale:   1) Safety. Supporting diverse operations will depend on performance-based approaches to regulation, recognizing new and innovative ways to achieve a high level of safety. Wing welcomes the recent decision by EASA to adopt the risk-based SORA process for evaluating complex operations, helping to ensure that different operations meet a common target level of safety. Noting the recent findings of EASA’s survey on social acceptance, Wing encourages the EC and EASA to invest in proactive communication campaigns that explain drone safety to the public.     2) U-space. Airspace integration will depend on enabling millions of operators to obtain and share information with authorities and other airspace users. To that end, Wing welcomes the regulation for U-space in Europe, which will help to lay the groundwork for a competitive U-space model that supports the volume and diversity of airspace users. The EC can play a role in encouraging Member States to implement the regulation in a way that will ensure safe, secure, open, and scalable access to airspace.   3) Trust. Industry must earn public trust with responsible operations. Wing works closely with regulators, local governments, and communities wherever we fly, and engages local communities, understanding emerging challenges, and developing best practices for neighborly operations. E.g, after a year of operations, 87 % of residents in our US city of Christiansburg support drone delivery. The EC can help to amplify best practices for community engagement, and invest in proactive campaigns that highlight the benefit of drones for safe, connected, and sustainable cities. Further, Wing encourages the EC to carefully distinguish the civil and military use of drones in the strategy. Mixing military and commercial use of drones could be counterproductive for social acceptance.  We are helping to show that safe and responsible drone operations are possible today, and welcome the EC’s commitment to accelerating the safe integration of drones. Going forward, industry and authorities will need to work together to promote integration across these three areas, and to extend the benefits of drones to more communities.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: Skyports Air Mobility Ireland Limited (hereby Skyports) is interested in and fully supports the development of a Drone Strategy 2.0 for Europe. We welcome the opportunity to provide our feedback on the proposed roadmap and look forward to assisting with future stages of its development. Skyports designs, builds and operates take-off and landing infrastructure for air taxis and, through our logistics arm, Delivery by Skyports, is a leading drone delivery service provider in the medical, e-commerce and logistics sectors.  Skyports is particularly keen to see focus placed on the further development of the rules framework to enable permanent, commercial drone delivery operations at scale as well as addressing all aspects of advanced air mobility.  We welcome the progress that EASA been making to further the regulatory framework for the Specific and Certified categories of unmanned aircraft through Rule Making Task (RMT) 0230, which will go a long way to paving the way for the routine deployment of more complex unmanned aircraft operations as well passenger-carrying unmanned aircraft. We are pleased to have had the opportunity to date to assist EASA with the development of this framework and we will continue to play an active role.  We recommend that the Drone Strategy 2.0 for Europe should focus on:  • Further development of the conditions and framework for the operation of UAS in the Specific and Certified categories, which are essential to enable the safe expansion of complex operations such routine beyond visual line of sight (BVLOS) and drone deliveries.  • Exploring how manned and unmanned aviation can coexist in the same airspace in the short term, particularly at low levels. This should include maximising the potential of existing airspace structures like Transponder Mandatory Zones (TMZ) and existing technologies like ADS-B, until the full suite of U-space services are in place. Continued segregation of manned and unmanned aviation is unsustainable even in the interim.  • Ensure that the regulatory framework remains risk-based and simple in approach and application regardless of the complexity of the types of unmanned aircraft involved and the operations they are involved in. For a burgeoning but early industry, unnecessary cost creates barriers to entry and hinders scale-up.  • Promoting social and community acceptance of drones in the broadest sense, from small-scale UAS to unmanned passenger air taxis, with particular emphasis on use cases that are proven to have some support by the general public, such as medial drone delivery.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: This feedback is submitted on behalf of IAOPA Europe, the European branch of the International Council of Aircraft Owner and Pilot Associations.  IAOPA has been very much active in matters of integration of drones into airspace systems, advocating not only for its safe and fair integration, but also for the recognition of societal aspects. As such, IAOPA praises the Commission’s ambitions to develop a safe and efficient drone ecosystem under the forthcoming Drone Strategy 2.0., to ensure the right balance between safety, security, and other societal concerns.   Manned and unmanned aircraft must be able to coexist in the same airspace, even at low altitudes where General Aviation, search & rescue, air sports, rotorcraft and the armed forces conduct a lot of manned aircraft operations, in controlled as well as in uncontrolled airspace. IAOPA welcomes the Commission’s objective to address a safety aspect, to avoid collisions between manned and unmanned aviation vehicles (UAV), ensuring the safety of people who have the right to enjoy common airspace. IAOPA believes that, for UAVs to be correctly integrated into the airspace, the drone strategy should introduce specific requirements for UAVs to be equipped with the detect and avoid system. The application of minimum height requirements and minimum distance from settlements and open-air assemblies of persons shall also be considered to protect the safety of those on the ground, even in the event of contingencies and emergencies.  When developing a policy environment for drones, the Commission should apply an approach of integration of air mobility rather than airspace segregation. Airspace segregation would exclude many operations of general actors, for example, gliders and helicopters, and render large pieces of airspace off-limits for its current users.  Further to that, the Commission should address the liability aspect of drone integration. Currently, a serious lack of liability persists when a UAV causes damage. If a drone is involved in a collision, strict liability for its operators needs to apply, regardless of the background of the accident. This will prevent society from potentially bearing the burden of drone operations. The concept of strict liability also applies in manned aviation, where an airline always will have to take responsibility and pay for any damage to transported passengers and goods. The same principle should be applied as regards drones, on the ground as well as in the air.  The 2019 Regulation of the rules of procedures for UAV  requires drone operators to comply with European legislation around privacy and data protection. Regardless of whether the operation of the drone occurs in the professional or recreational space, privacy rules must be fully followed. Against this background, the strategy should put forward specific measures to enforce the respect of European citizens’ privacy outlined in the adopted legislation.   Finally, IAOPA believes that the Commission should further address education aspects for UAV operators. Throughout aviation history, education has proven to be key in reducing aviation incidents. As drone operators, be it commercial or private, are looking to make use of airspace, a consistent training program should be put in place. With the aim of maximising the safety of people in the air, this is the only way to create thorough knowledge and respect for existing aviation laws.  IAOPA, as the European voice of general aviation, looks forward to discussing and elaborating on the aforementioned aspects of the Drone Strategy 2.0 as part of targeted stakeholder consultation in the context of a preparatory study.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: The Alliance for New Mobility Europe (AME) welcomes the initiative for a Drone Strategy 2.0 and supports it strongly. The Roadmap for a Drone Strategy 2.0 generally sets the right frame. Following the adoption of the EASA Basic Regulation – Regulation (EU) 2018/1139 –, the European Union has so far set a regulatory framework that puts the EU in the lead for opening a functioning drone market across Europe by means of not only Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/945 and Implementing Regulation (EU) 2019/947, but also Implementing Regulation (EU) 2021/664 on U-space, as well as the necessary amendments to Implementing Regulations (EU) 2017/373 and (EU) No 2012/923.   However, there are still some major issues left that need to be tackled: ● common electronic conspicuity methods (e.g. ADS-B, FLARM etc.); ● a higher level of automatisation in relation to, for instance, data machine readability; ● more coherence between Member States’ room for discretion in the definition of UAS geographical zones and designation of U-space airspace(s) as regards security, privacy, and environmental requirements, to enable more cross-border operations and easier scaling of UAS operations.  Overall, we are entering a new phase where issues of properly integrating UAS and their services into existing infrastructures and regulatory frameworks are at the forefront. AME therefore urges the European Commission, while further elaborating regulations on Innovative Air Mobility, to create mechanisms and rules to coordinate with other autonomous mobility systems (e.g. land, water) to the extent that these systems will eventually interact in the framework of, for instance, smart cities or smart ports. This concerns first and foremost joint communication standards and harmonised data exchange formats. The positioning of the Drone Strategy 2.0 as part of the Smart and Sustainable Mobility Strategy is encouraging in this context.  AME is also convinced that additional focus needs to be given to higher levels of automation and digitalisation. On the one hand, they are indispensable for economies of scale and the overall modernisation of aviation. On the other hand, addressing issues of cyber and supply chain security in the context of the growing digitalisation of mobility in general needs to go hand in hand with increasing automation and digitalisation. Potentially, major lessons can be drawn from industry 4.0 and IoT applications and subsequently implemented.  Furthermore, AME recognises that regulatory competences are distributed in the EU’s multi-governance system. However, for a well-functioning drone market a maximum of coherence of rules across all the EU is paramount. AME also recognises formats such as the UAM Initiative Cities Community (UIC2) as a useful platform for exchanging and creating coherence between major cities. Going beyond that, AME suggests to the European Commission to facilitate further formats that will inform all kinds of cities and local authorities on drone regulatory developments, foster their understanding of the regulatory needs at the local level and allow to keep a maximum of coherence between rules of local communities across the EU.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: Boeing welcomes the chance to provide input into the Roadmap of the Commission’s Drone Strategy 2.0.  The wide spectrum of unmanned aircraft systems represents an important area of growth for the aviation industry, and it is appropriate that the Commission focuses on how best to facilitate the safe and sustainable integration of these new technologies into the wider airspace. An updated strategy which supports the development of an enabling framework for this sector can play an important role in ensuring that these new services can thrive in the EU internal market and beyond.    Boeing’s diverse portfolio of products and continuous investment in innovation means we have a broad perspective on the challenges and opportunities presented by these new and evolving forms of mobility and services – from cargo drones, to advanced air mobility, through to the provision of U-Space (UTM) services. Our investments in these areas span both Europe and further afield, and as such we are committed to supporting the development of rules and guidance which can ensure the appropriate safety and environmental path forward for the sector.   Given the collaborative nature of aviation safety, we firmly believe that an international perspective is also key, so as to ensure the greatest levels of harmonisation possible – ensuring that any framework facilitates the free flow of products and services. In this way, the Commission can assist in providing the necessary certainty to the industry to continue its significant investments in this area.  We stand ready to contribute to the Commission’s analysis and consultation exercises.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: Royal Netherlands Aeronautical Association (KNVvL)  The KNVvL strongly supports the initiative for a drone Strategy 2.0 for Europe. Hereby the input of the Royal Netherlands Aeronautical Association First of all we would like to emphasize that the acceptance of drones depends on two  aspects: 1. privacy of residents, 2. the shared use of airspace. As this aspect is a general aspect we suggest to involve the GA in the developments of the airspace as well. Secondly, within the current EU regulations, there is still uncertainty regarding test areas for drones. The full list of requirements one must meet, is not yet finalized. We trust that you will manage this issue. Then there is the implementation of the current EU regulations. Due to delay many companies who depend on the implementation of these new rules, fall between two stools and innovation slows down. We suggest to take more time to prepare and implement new the regulations or any change for that matter in the future. For many companies in the Specific category, the new regulations are not SMARTLY defined and therefore unclear or difficult to interpret. We suggest to simplify and define the regulations SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant and Time-bound). It takes far too long for the national authorities to check and interpret the rules correctly. Time is money for many companies, now they have to wait months for approval without any compensation. Differences between countries will not be solved with the new rules. This wasn't the goal to implement those rules in the first place - au contraire: • Each country still implements their own local rules therefore differences between the countries still exist, especially in the zoning. • The prices of the various applications also differ widely between countries. Please uniform these differences as this was the intention of the new rules. For drone builders, the problem is only getting bigger. What requirements must be met? Clarification is desperately needed, especially for starters this is a must. Else many start-ups will go down. Last but not least we suggest a close cooperation between military and civilians on a European level. Unfortunately, this is very fragmented between the countries. We would like to join you to brainstorm about using U-space as this will stimulate innovation in all areas and Europe will be able to maintain a leading position regarding this matter.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: First important steps have been undertaken to make operations of UAS safe and socially acceptable, and to establish a safety culture in the drone community. This should be the foundation for fair coexistence of all aircraft in the same shared airspace. We therefore welcome the release of a Drone Strategy 2.0 considering the next steps to integrate UAS. We suggest that the following points be given special consideration. Integration instead of segregation: The integration of UAS into existing air traffic must be further advanced. Segregation is not a permanent solution and promotes the exclusion of air traffic participants. Accordingly, the next steps to be taken should aim at a joint and fair use of airspace by manned and unmanned aircraft.   Greater focus on users: For the development of the new drone strategy, it is advisable to pay special attention to the users and their UAS applications. In other words, it must be worked out which current and future fields of application exist, which number of daily flights in a given airspace can be derived from this and how the operators can be meaningfully supported in their work.  Back to the risk-based approach: With the proposal of a risk-based approach, which was based on the assumption that there are different levels of risks depending on the size and use of the drones, EASA headed in the right direction. This assumption should be continued. Unfortunately, in some areas we see that this approach is being deviated from, e.g. in the requirement that UAS operated BVLOS over populated areas must be certified.  Simplification of certification: Certification of UAS should be based on product life cycles in terms of time and the value of the UAS in financial terms. The certification processes of manned aviation may be tried and tested, but they need to be adjusted to the needs of smaller aircraft. For example, the product life cycle of smaller drones -  < 25 kg in particular -  is 2 to 3 years. This should be contrasted with a certification period of a few weeks, which is appropriate in terms of time. To achieve this, it is recommended to set up automatic certifications, e.g. in the form of automatic software test suites. In the end, this would also keep the costs within a reasonable range.  Promote social acceptance: The social acceptance of drones is currently a major challenge. At present, the population is still sceptical about drones. We can all contribute to reducing reservations by, on the one hand, paying attention to an appropriate choice of words in communication. And on the other hand, assessing the dangers that drones can pose to a realistic degree.  Front runner in decarbonization: The Member States of the European Union are making every effort to make flying environmentally and climate-friendly. This means to using propulsions which sustainably reduces the emissions of carbon dioxide (CO₂). The long-term goal is to create a CO₂-free global aviation. UAS are a leader in decarbonization and should gain government incentives.  For a successful integration of drones into the existing transport system, it is important to look at the task holistically. In addition to technical and regulatory issues, aspects such as social acceptance and climate are crucial for a thriving drone market.  We are very pleased about the initiative of a new drone strategy and offer our support and expertise in its development.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: Urban air mobility is a new, almost unexplored field, driven by the extensive technological offer around the drones and the electric vertical take-off and landing vehicles, otherwise known as e-VTOL. In fact, more than 250 manufacturers projects exist worldwide, the vast majority being centered around electric vehicles. But, while vehicle technology is advancing very rapidly, a number of challenges raised by this new form of mobility in terms of use, acceptability, regulations, technologies and industrialization are still to be addressed. In order to respond to these challenges, and better prepare for a commercial deployment, we believe that testing all the Urban Air Mobility ecosystem's components is key to a successful launch of the industry.  New governance models are needed to set to launch the Urban Air Mobility industry and address its complex and interdisciplinary needs. Collaboration between manufacturers and industrial partners, urban public transport operators, infrastructure providers and regulatory authorities and urban policies makers is a must. These open pluri-disciplinary collaborations are key in ensuring the ecosystem launch based on the safest and most secure operational levels. In order to transition between testing vehicles prototypes and flight demonstration into operating a network of vehicles at scale in the horizon of 2030, we believe that this type of collaborations requires real life areas or incubators in order to thrive.   This kind of incubators would serve as a support for the local and European authorities to pursue their work on the regulatory framework on the airspace and infrastructure guidelines. EASA and local authorities are offered this opportunity to confront and validate the regulatory work in-progress and test the many unknowns on concrete grounds with regards to vehicles' technology, operations and infrastructure requirements based on operational processes and data within an experimental framework.  Prior to scaling up urban air vehicles deployment and assuming their integral part within a multi-modal transportation ecosystem, the social acceptability of this new ecosystem is crucial. By effectively engaging and consulting incubators local communities from the outset and integrating their feedback into the development of this transportation solution, UAM stakeholders, from governments and regulators to vehicles designers and system’s operators, would bring the ecosystem a step closer to achieving public acceptability and accelerating the ecosystem’s implementation in cities. This is what the Drone strategy 2.0 could support and include in the several financing programs (notably Horizon Europe, Digital Europe and the Connecting Europe Facility) which support the Sustainable and Smart Mobility Strategy.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility
