feedback_msg_text: EU Drone Strategy 2.0 should be based on a European ambition for the role of unmanned systems technology in our economy and broader society. An ambition that encompasses an inspiring vision, ambitious goals and the courage to make clear choices.  We propose updating the 2016 SESAR European Drones Outlook study and suggest to explicitly start from a broader perspective for drone usage than ‘mobility’ and ‘defence’. As stated in this roadmap, drones can be used to replace or complement workers and assets in a variety of activities and markets, thereby contributing strongly to the digital transformation, an important aspect of Europe’s (Digital) Strategy.  Closely linked is being digital autonomous. Europe is increasingly dependent on externally developed technology. What does that mean for our economic independence? Our privacy and our safety? These are urgent themes for drones, the robots that in a few years will operate by the thousands among our cities and collect terabytes of data. Europe should be aiming to strive after self-reliance to remain in control of its own data and prosperity and the opportunity to generate worldwide market leaders in the industry.  The development of an effective innovation ecosystem, addressing technology, economy and related ethical, legal and societal concerns (T+B+ELS), is crucial for the European drone technology industry to grow. To do so, it is essential to unite SMEs, larger companies, knowledge institutes and (local) NGOs and governments to explore and exploit opportunities together, to share risk, capabilities and knowledge. Cooperative projects result in highest value for money: when cooperation is stimulated, innovation is accelerated and numerous possibilities can be turned into reality. Also, dissemination -and thereby societal awareness- is more effective when operating in a ‘drone ecosystem’. Effective integration of drones in society can be stimulated by conducting empirical studies on impact and social acceptance, together with testing and experimentation in controlled areas with safe and secure circumstances are requirements for this. It takes time for such a drone ecosystem to work. European funding is required, as the drone industry not yet has the capacity to organise this professionally on its own. Facilities, coordination, and a (regional) shared strategic mindset for research and development are required. As one of the most dynamic growth industries, the drone industry demands the capacity to act quickly. Drone Strategy 2.0 should make use of the drone hubs already established in Europe. Building on this base, would lead to effective further steps. There is an opportunity to address drone related challenges (in terms of new regulations, technologies, social acceptance) to local or regional drone hubs. Once validated in those controlled circumstances, it can be accepted and integrated on a larger scale. A true level playing field in the EU is of the utmost importance for the European drone technology industry to scale and grow into worldwide market leaders. Drone Strategy 2.0 should be focussed on equalising and minimising drone related rules and legislation across the EU. The current EU regulation leaves too much space for national governments to divert from the EU principles. This can be seen from striking differences between different EU countries regarding for instance licensing costs or operational procedures and restrains for professional users. Regulations should be used to create a climate for innovation and leadership. Keywords like “safety”, “privacy” used by authorities to regulate or restrict drone operations should be substantiated by facts and figures instead of being considered as self-explanatory and undisputable.  Feedback from: Stichting Space53 (179.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: The Drone strategy should be end-user driven, so that proposals have a user case and a business case in the near/medium future.  It could cover: - The positive impact on end-users' industries. Both as a tool to collect data - and door opener to novel applications with data analytics, AI for data exploitation. And as a means of transport for logistics. - Their positive impact on citizens. For example reduction in CO2 emissions, reduction in traffic jams in cities, contact-free logistics. - The technological hurdles: detect and avoid functionality, airspace integration, U-Space (air risk), airworthiness (ground risk). Noise level and quiet by design. Cybersecurity. Clean power.  - The non technological hurdles: societal acceptance. Stakeholders engagement. Training. Education. Skills. - the user case of medical drone logistics, in rural areas and in cities, could specifically be covered. Several studies showed that its merits are recognised by the public, the EU hosts strong players in that segment, and the timeframe fits within the strategy 2.0.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: In general, we are supportive of the further development of UAV and Manned Aerial Vehicles. We would like to differentiate between manned and unmanned and commercial and non-commercial activities. We would also like to prevent different modus operandi in different EU countries. U space is left to the MS and by doing this creating competition between operators because of the different National legislation. In some countries substantial aera's have been reserved for drone activities in U Space whilst in others there are no activities visible. More central guidance would be needed. In general, we do feel that creating U space without integration of drones in the current airspace activities should be reconsidered. It limits the use of airspace for other space users and can be very disruptive. We would advocate integration by using E conspicuity in an affordable manner. In the USA ADS-B has been introduced and is working quite well. We should consider this technical solution for drones and GA aircraft. You may have heard that in the Netherlands our Ministry of defence has registered in one week 1000 drones over 120 meter in the EHAA FIR. This is posing a serious risk to the safely of commercial and non-commercial aviation. We need to make sure that drones and manned aerial vehicles are integrated in the available airspace. Segregating them would look more easy but does not solve an already existing safety issue.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: The Association of Modellers of the Czech Republic r.a. is an organization uniting more than 7,000 modellers in the Czech Republic, of which more than 1,000 are under the age of 18. The aero modellers of the European Union are currently fully competitive in the international comparison. Will it be the same in the future?  EC Regulations 2018/1139, 2019/947 and 2019/945 primarily brought a workload to the aeromodellers of the European Union without gaining anything for it. The regulation merged drones and aircraft models under the same rules, not considering that model aircraft has been here for a long time. Aero modellers have been flying their models for decades, safely and with significant educational influence. Even if Regulation 2019/947, through its article 16, makes the activities of modellers who are members of modelling clubs possible and allows by the authorization from the competent body to continue the operation of model aircraft, the actual flying is strongly affected by these rules. And this has happened without assessing the impact of such regulations on thousands of European citizens. The biggest problem is young people under 16, who got the most brutal hit.  We believe that a less strict regime for aircraft models should be part of the Drone 2.0 Strategy plan. Here are some reasons:  1) The future of any field depends on education. For example, model aircraft is a school subject in Israel. This approach helps maintain a high level of aircraft modellers, and not coincidentally, also a high level of drones.  2) You may ask your friends who work in the aviation industry, pilots of airliners, if they have built aviation models in the past. You will find that the vast majority are former or even current aircraft modellers. Just a few examples: the Montgolfier brothers first tried a balloon model, the Frenchman Alphonse Penaud tested stability problems on an aero plane model in 1871, Czech cosmonaut Vladimír Remek (former MEP) built aircraft models in his youth, etc..  3) Aircraft models do not carry recording devices or cameras on board and thus do not endanger the personal rights of individuals. The safety of aircraft models is high, which the EC is aware of and states in Regulation 2019/947 or Regulation 2021/664.  Drones, especially aeronautical drones, are undoubtedly the future of sustainable and intelligent mobility in EU. And Europe needs to be competitive in this field, or better, a leader in this field. Promoting model aircraft as a fundamental step in the aero industry and especially drones will guarantee that EU will be a user and only buyer of non-European drones but will be at the forefront of developing and producing drones in the world. It is also necessary to think of developers of drone support systems who will benefit from the experience of model aircraft when applied in practice for drones.  The easiest and cheapest way to support model aircraft in Europe will be to create very accessible and supportive conditions for the operation of model aircraft. It's time to maintain the knowledge and practices we have here in Europe .  We believe that it would be very appropriate to exclude aircraft models from the legislation focused on drones entirely or create a particular category for aircraft models' operation to take into account their free and educationally accessible principle. Of course, setting some limits is necessary to avoid the abuse of the institute of model aircraft. For example, the absence of a camera, a weight limit of 25 kg, no systems allowing automated flight, etc.  We believe that this view of the future of aviation in Europe will be reflected in the Strategy for Drones 2.0 to promote sustainable and intelligent mobility in Europe.  The Association of Modelers of the Czech Republic r.a. is ready to cooperate widely with the European Commission, the relevant committee on this key topic for the future of aviation.  Tomas Ciniburk Association of Modelers of the Czech Republic r.a. Feedback from: Association of Modellers of the Czech Republic r.a. (1.5 MB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Organisation: Association of Modellers of the Czech Republic r.a.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: The strategy properly sets the scene for the future, but there are many steps to be taken before we can reach the objective of having unmanned drones flying over our heads.  As a first step we should facilitate manned aircarft to operate in that same airspace that unmanned aircraft will.  In order to do so, current regulation could easiliy be adapted to introduce in a phased manner more and more operations with pilots in the aircraft.  These operations will help to learn how to transit to an unmanned airspace in a safer and more socially accepted way.

feedback_msg_text: The practice in larger aeroplanes (CS23 "Normal Aeroplanes", CS25 "Large Areroplanes") is to design the aircraft including its functions, which are to be installed as prescribed and shown to operate as intended (para 25.1301, CS 23 equivalent). Obviously it is not limited to that, but the essence counts for the present drones related subject.  Any such function mentioned above is then to be asssed in terms of its failure effect, as it could potentially compromise safety. Dependent on that effect, in other words dependent on the potential safety penalty, a corresponding not to exceed proability for the failure to occur is required and must be demonstrated, in order to be compliant (para 25.1309, CS 23 equivalent)  The approach is utterly elegant. It does not prescribe functions and thus does not limit innovation. At the same time it does prescribe how to manage functions, existing or innovative, including any related reliability requirements, necessary to achieve a defined level of safety.  It is suggested that the drones regulatory framework would adopt a similar or even the same approach.  The aviation industry is experienced to work with it, authorties are used to apply the framework and the achieved level of safety is excellent. If certain new industries, start-ups, etc. would not be experienced with the approach, then the very nature of the situation would demand a quick learning profile. That should not be prohibitive in any way, since the approach is totally logical and has been demonstrated to work very well. It should thus qualify the new entrant for aviation-related work, not even limited to drones as an incentive.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: The growth of the UAV activity must be addressed urgently in order to preserve the safety of manned aircraft as indispensable and, therefore, indisputable top precondition, above all other considerations regarding the promotion of the drone industry.  Chiefly, para-public helicopter operations, particularly HEMS, Search and Rescue, firefighting, are very often related to emergencies to address at low/very low altitude, in such conditions that do neither allow them to identify potential incoming and potentially colliding drones nor engage safe avoidance maneuvers, the safety and the priority of these flight operations must be possible to maintain in a reasonable way, irrespectively of the U-Space principles. Therefore, we, the European Helicopter Association (EHA), call forcefully to amend the regulations by implementing the following principles: 1. Outside of U space, the absence of drones must be legally guaranteed.  2. To provide the population with various sustainable services, chiefly para-public and other emergency and security services executed by helicopters, in a safe manner for the people, potential passengers and the crews, helicopters need to be able to fly safely through the U-space. Thus, these helicopters operating at low altitude must be protected from any potential conflicting drones respectively UAM/RAM vehicles. That could be achieved by real time traffic information of drones in the helicopter cockpit as well as by electronic protection measures against the collision with drones or UAM/RAM. Else, U-space areas would have to be considered non-flyable zones due to an inherent collision risk.
Initiative: A Drone strategy 2.0 for Europe to foster sustainable and smart mobility

feedback_msg_text: Airborne Wind Europe, as the association of the European Airborne Wind Energy (AWE) sector, represents the interests of the airborne wind energy industry as well as academia to decision makers in politics and business. We are also members of Wind Europe, eawe and the IEA Wind Technology Collaboration Program (with the newly established Task 48 on AWE).  Airborne Wind Energy (AWE) is an emerging renewable energy technology that aims to replace the use of fossil fuels for energy production on an economical basis. A characteristic feature of the various AWE concepts is the use of tethered flying devices to access wind energy at higher altitudes where the wind is more consistent. Over the past decade the AWE scientific and industrial community has grown considerably. While certain concepts use soft materials as flying devices (kites), others have fixed wings similar to unmanned aircrafts or drones with potentially several dozens of meters wing span, some with propellers allowing vertical take-off and landing (VTOL).   It is not unlikely that at least the fixed-wing concepts will fall under the Implementing Regulation 2019/947 and the respective legislation in the Member States, even though there is still no full clarity on the subject. However, after consultation with EASA (in November 2020) and other aviation experts, we assume that the “specific” category might apply to several AWE concepts. As the first companies have already started to market their systems in Europe and world-wide, it is therefore important that AWE systems are taken into account in the “Drone Strategy 2.0” and any other aviation regulations (including U-Space) in order to avoid or largely minimise conflicts with other airspace users.  Current Airborne Wind Energy Systems demonstrators have power output capacities between 100 and 200 kW. Developing this technology further could increase the potential output to megawatts, making it attractive for use at large wind farms and play an important role in the future energy mix. Airborne Wind Energy has thus the potential to make a significant contribution to the energy transition on saving material and costs and opening up additional wind resources on- and offshore at higher altitudes (see also the “Study on Challenges in the commercialisation of airborne wind energy systems” commissioned by the European Commission DG-RTD and published in 2018).  We therefore hope that our feedback will be taken into account in the planned Roadmap process and that Airborne Wind Energy will be considered in the Drone Strategy 2.0. Please find more information on AWE under www.airbornewindeurope.org and in the 2-page document attached. We are prepared to provide further information and support. feedback_msg_text: OpenAIRE welcomes EU's initiative to develop a comprehensive framework for Data Sharing both in the B2B and the B2G context and would like to thank the European Commission for the opportunity to provide feedback at the stage of inception of such policies. The EU Data Act is an instrumental policy for fostering not just EU's developmental initiatives but also supporting participation to socio-economic life, furthering research and enhancing innovation across the Union. For that reason, it is necessary to support not just sharing of data, but also opening up data and ensuring their reuse with the minimum possible transaction costs. The absence of any reference to open science in the EU Data Act and the lack of clear references to copyright limitations and exceptions, particularly in relation to the Text and Data Mining exceptions, is something that needs to be rectified in the Act. More specifically, we would like to support the following key policy directions: (a) development of a framework for the obligatory sharing of data sets, by private entities (e.g. publishers) that operate as essential facility in the area of scientific research. There needs to be access to data-sets that are essential for the development of different open science applications (b) extension and expansion of the Copyright TDM provisions (c) re-assessment of the Sui Generis Data Base right in relation to the reduction of transaction costs in data-sharing and open data (d) harmonisation of the Copyright limitations and exceptions (e) introduction of a positive right to the public domain (f) development of provisions for the opening up of research data produced by personal data. In addition to legal reform suggestions, it is necessary to further enhance policies and programmes that support the opening up of data in the context of research and scientific work. Such programmes should include specific initatives for: (a) clearance and documentation of IPR status in all research publications (b) linking researchers' and academics' professional development with the open publishing of data, research and publications (c) development of smart licences allowing the simple and seamless processing of licensing information (d) development of licensing interoperability frameworks (e) development of model IPR policies including open science and exploitation policies (e) support the operation of open science business models (f) support the development of pan-european organisations fostering open science and innovation.
Initiative: Data Act & amended rules on the legal protection of databases

feedback_msg_text: The Data Act is an important addition to the Data Governance Act (DGA), that further completes the European Data Strategy. While the DGA provides the framework for data sharing to take place in the first place, the Data Act seems to be designed to provide the economic conditions to foster the emergence of sectoral data spaces.  This economic and market-focused perspective needs to be complimented by a strong focus on public interest and rights of individual end-users. After all, data sharing rules will not only apply to data-driven markets, but beyond them. And it is fundamentally important that European data sharing rules secure not just market competition and innovation, but also data use in the public interest.   In the remainder of our submission, we discuss  the proposal from a perspective that acknowledges public interest data use, and the fundamental role played by Open Data and Open Access Commons data sharing in the overall data ecosystems. We have addressed these issues also in our previous submission on the proposal for the DGA.  Please find our full feedback in the enclosed PDF document. feedback_msg_text: CLEPA appreciates the intention of the Commission to provide with the Data Act a robust regulatory framework as general guidance for data sharing and to raise the awareness of businesses on the benefits of data sharing is a pre-requisite to allow all parties to benefit from data-driven innovation.  CLEPA recognises that B2B data sharing currently may have data holders with stronger negotiating power which might impose unfair terms and conditions to the detriment of different market players, potentially pushing existing ones out and preventing new ones from entering it. Therefore, CLEPA supports the Commissions’ findings regarding the necessity of guidance for contracts to mediate negotiation power between market players. An effective data economy will need specified guidelines regarding a fair market value of data.   While the Data Act is a horizontal regulation, we appreciate that it leaves room for sector-specific regulations which CLEPA sees important especially for the automotive sector regarding fair access to in-vehicle data. In our position paper attached, we argue that such regulation can and should help ensure fair and equal access to data and resources. CLEPA appreciates the intention in the IIA to reflect specific characteristics of the automotive sector regarding rules on access to data to be assessed as part of the type-approval regulation.   Vehicle manufacturers are currently deploying services based on data, functions, and resources to which third parties do not have competitive access, and existing communication interfaces such as OBD-connectors are increasingly limited in the data and functions and restricted to authorised access only, granted by the vehicle manufacturers. Although some progress was made regarding the provision of in-vehicle data to third parties via data marketplaces CLEPA sees a sector specific regulation as essential to avoid the risk of further competition distortion in the market for new mobility services as well as in the existing repair and maintenance market (aftermarket).  CLEPA supports the intention to provide clarity on rules for B2B access to and sharing of personal and non-personal data. We encourage the Commission to provide further clarification on the definition of personal and non-personal data to ensure that both can be shared safely. CLEPA has recognised during the deployment of first use cases that the provision of user consent has substantial impact on the competitive situation of service providers and consumer acceptance. CLEPA would like to see general guidance in the Data Act on the way how user consent and user details must be provided along the value chain. CLEPA would like to see ensured in the Data Act that any gatekeeper who could act also as competitor does not need to get access to consumer details derived from GDPR requirements.   For a fast deployment of a data economy and leverage of innovation it will be essential that potential roadblocks generated by other regulations will be detected and eliminated. CLEPA supports the initiative to investigate the Database Directive which should not limit the use of sensor generated data in vehicles.   CLEPA also appreciates the intention to improve the technical standards for portability of data generated by individuals. A prerequisite for wide acceptance at consumer level to share data is the freedom to decide with whom vehicle data get shared with.  CLEPA is convinced that standardised governance data will help to accelerate the deployment of services in B2B and B2G use cases. Good examples are On-Board-Diagnostic (OBD) data, eCall or data standardised by SENSORIS which enabled the fast and large-scale deployment of diagnostics, safety, or traffic related information services. CLEPA would like to see general guidance on such standardised governance data to be provided in the Data Act. feedback_msg_text: About the GFII: created in 1979, the GFII, the French organization of information professionals, is a unique association in the data landscape that brings together private and public data producers and re-users, such as the French Ministry of Interior, Total, Crédit Agricole, BNP Paribas or The French Ministry of Environment. The GFII aims to promote the economy of data, that means the recognition of the costs necessary for their manufacture, maintenance, development and dissemination in an assumed commercial environment, which does not exclude free of charge data sharing, but which puts more emphasis on the interoperability of data, their valorisation and their reusability. Our 10 working groups produce positions papers and white papers in order to help shaping the future of data policy in France and in the EU by offering balanced point of view about data and digital issues. The GFII promotes a sustainable and ethical use of data and we work closely with our members for offering the most expert and efficient feedback about the implementation of data policies. feedback_msg_text: In general, Pex welcomes the Data Act Initiative which focuses on fair distribution of data in the economy. Many copyright stakeholders encounter imbalances on a daily basis when dealing with platforms which, in addition to copyright-protected content, store great quantities of metadata related to the said content. This information asymmetry has also been noted by the EU legislator who addressed the issue in Article 17 (8) of the DSM Directive. Unfortunately, the only party entitled to receive the information on the use of content is the rightsholder.    At the same time, the information on the use of copyright-protected content can be easily gleaned from the publicly available data on the platform without imposing any burden on the platform. The paradox consists in the fact that while the platform is perfectly fine with anyone accessing the information on use of individual pieces of copyright-protected content, it rebuts any attempts to collect the data by means of technology by imposing technical restrictions or contractually excluding the collection of such data. In such a manner, it impedes the development of the whole segment of the data economy which focuses on digital copyright management.  Feedback from: Pexeso Inc (85.9 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Data Act & amended rules on the legal protection of databases

feedback_msg_text: The Data Act and its roadmap a) Access to Data: Concerning B2B data exchanges, there should be sector specific regulations, but no general obligation to grant access to data. Contractual arrangements should be the preferred option. However, in certain industries such as the automotive sector, sector specific regulation is required in order to ensure fair competition between market participants. In order to drive innovation through the use of AI, we need to stimulate the availability and exchange of data without being or becoming a “dominant” platform player. The framework of GAIA-X points exactly into this direction, which is the reason why we as Bosch support that initiative.  Furthermore, the EU has to foster awareness raising among businesses on the benefits of data sharing and provide practical advice on how to share data in a voluntary manner. Please see above.  Companies should be encouraged to share industry data, as they do not undermine the capacity of companies to enjoy mutually beneficial data partnerships. In a contractual relationship, the questions that need to be regulated are, e.g. questions on the data to be provided, on the type of data, duration and technical requirements for data access, on data quality, on any necessary granting of rights and on charges that can be agreed upon according to the requirements of the parties.   b) Data Sharing: The EU has to encourage the definition and use of interoperable data formats to ensure that sharing is not obstructed by lack of compatibility. The EU has to raise awareness among businesses on the benefits of data sharing and provide practical advice, for instance by developing the concept of Support Centre for Data Sharing.  • Clear, simple and user-friendly guidance tools would provide more certainty to businesses concluding data sharing contracts, particularly SMEs.  • Non-binding models and templates could be developed to facilitate data exchanges.   c) Common European Data Spaces:  Bosch is looking forward to the envisaged dialogue with the EU Commission on how to further boost data generation and exchange, notably via smart connected products and corresponding services. However, one should bear in mind, that the EU Commission should support and enable promising and market driven business models. This goes especially for the automotive sector. In practice, the EU should aim for a proof of concept phase first, before investing in an infrastructure, that would eventually not been used due to the lack of viable business models.    d) Development of data platforms and market places:  The EU has to support the development of data platforms and marketplaces allowing private and public sectors alike to sell, trade and access quality datasets.  • Security of data and data exchanges should be of the utmost importance to ensure that the industry could safely take part in any data spaces initiatives.  • Data spaces should protect intellectual property, confidential information and personal data, security and legitimate commercial interests.  • GAIA-X should be an integral and driving part in this respect   e) Cloud infrastructure in the EU – GAIA-X:   In order to be successful, GAIA-X has to be an integral and driving part of the European cloud foundation. In our view, GAIA-X is partly a technical infrastructure but more widely a framework including regulations to ensure data sovereignty for the EU that enables access to data as well as its storage, exchange and use in accordance with predefined rules. A unique selling point of GAIA-X can be the possibility of interoperable data exchange, for example for multi-party computation (MPC) and data analytics. Creation of Digital Trust is thereby of particular importance for Bosch, because here we see an opportunity to differentiate from other, less trustworthy solutions. In order to be successful, the GAIA-X project must always take this claim into account, for example with regard to data privacy, robustness and ethical issues.
Initiative: Data Act & amended rules on the legal protection of databases

feedback_msg_text: AI adoption in Europe has barely started as European companies are stuck in the GDPR trap. While the European commission is writing the standard contract clauses to give legal security to non-EU companies no European company can get legal security with respect to GDPR. The certification especially for European SME's as mentioned in 42(1) GDPR is not available until today. While the GDPR is supposed to be a legal framework for Europe its regional application is highly fragmented. Just Germany has 16 data protection officers with partially contradicting views on the regulation. As a consequence a data transfer between Munich and Berlin can impose a significant legal risk to any German company. There is no German rather than a European harmonisation available. Just a simple example from the health sector:  Are unique implants in X-ray images considered personable identifiable information (PII)? While threatening European companies with penalties of up to 4% revenue, it is currently impossible to just answer this very basic question. As a consequence 85% of companies do the only thing that is legally safe. Not exchanging data at all.   So far the GDPR has been a complete desaster for the European data economy.  So the single most important thing to boost the European data economy is to give legal security to its participants based on a true EU wide harmonised regulation. This applies also to blockchain based solutions such as Ocean Protocol which is providing open data markets, dynamic price finding for data assets, fair and non-discriminatory access, full control over the data, governance and transparency. But most important Ocean Protocol provides Compute-to-data which allows data monetarisation by bringing algorithms to the data instead of transferring data to the algorithms. This is all based on blockchain technology which is currently regulated by the finance authorities which imposes a significant legal threat to all participants.  It is sarcastic that European politicians claim to give any kind of legal security with their regulation. While Europe is regulating its high tech companies to death it is increasing the technological dependency  and protecting the market for non-EU companies. feedback_msg_text: Xiaomi, founded in 2010, is an internet company with smartphones and smart hardware connected by an IoT platform at its core. With the vision of letting everyone enjoy a better life through innovative technology, Xiaomi builds quality products with honest prices and is committed to continuous innovation, with an unwavering focus on quality and efficiency.  We welcome the opportunity to contribute to this consultation and provide our perspective on how to ensure smartphones are designed to be more resource efficient, in line with the Circular Economy Action Plan. Xiaomi recognises that resource efficiency measures such as those aimed at extending the average lifetime of a device, including its battery, will help to further reduce the environmental impact of smartphones. We believe that regulation should be designed to achieve environmental benefits, while ensuring that companies can innovate to deliver the best possible user experience. Ecodesign requirements seem the most appropriate policy option to achieve this objective.   Xiaomi is committed to reducing environmental impact and saving valuable resources. For example, to extend the longevity of our products, we have invested into the latest technologies to increase the battery endurance and the overall durability of our smartphones. Xiaomi will shortly roll out a trade-in service in Europe to encourage consumers to deposit their old products with us, rather than keeping them at home, allowing us to recover materials from those devices.   We also recognise the importance of software updates in maintaining the longevity of our products. We ensure regular software updates as well as security patches. It is important to note, however, that Operating System support often depends on third parties who may sometimes fail to provide software versions which are compatible with all maintained versions of the operating system. Finally, Xiaomi has cooperated with European telecoms operators as part of the Eco-rating scheme pilot programmes in 2020 and the full-scale engagement will continue in 2021. This scheme covers criteria such as durability, repairability, recyclability, packaging, etc.  Xiaomi is committed to providing access to quality repair services as these form an integral part of ensuring customer satisfaction and trust in our brand. It’s essential that we have the ability to control this process to ensure quality service delivery. For this reason, the repair of our products has to be within our authorised repair network and using original spare parts to ensure the quality and reliability of repair. We prefer regulatory solutions that would avoid unintended consequences for consumers. Rules obliging manufacturers to provide spare parts and repair manuals to third-party professional repairers whose level of technical skills, repair time and cost as well as success rate are beyond the manufacturer’s control, would create serious risks for consumers in terms of quality, safety and security. Rather than introducing such obligations, we believe that informing consumers about repairability, in the form of an index or a score, would bring more benefit to consumers. Establishing a repairability index solely based on criteria such as ease of disassembly and availability of spare parts, without taking the quality of service into consideration, would only mislead the consumer, without providing him/her the assurance that they seek.   Xiaomi stands ready to continue providing insights to inform the debate and the Commission’s decision on how to regulate smartphones. feedback_msg_text: Az Európai Zöld Megállapodás támogatása érdekében az EU 2020-ban új körforgásos gazdaságra vonatkozó cselekvési tervet fogadott el, melynek egyik fontos célja az erőforrások felhasználásának csökkentése és a felhasznált erőforrások megőrzése az Európai Unión belül. Ez magában foglalja a felesleges pazarlás és az elavulás elkerülését azáltal, hogy olyan termékek tervezésének ösztönzését, amelyek energiatakarékosak és tartósak, élettartamuk alatt karbantarthatóak, javíthatóak, valamint életciklusuk végén újrafelhasználhatóak vagy újrafeldolgozhatóak.  Fontosnak tartjuk, hogy a vásárlók számára a csomagoláson feltüntetett tájékoztatás teljeskörű legyen a vásárolt mobil eszköz energiafelhasználását, javíthatóságát, várható életciklusát tekintve. A mobil eszközök azon részei esetében, melyek a használattól esetleg a vártnál gyorsabban elhasználódhatnak (ilyen például az eszköz kijelzője és akkumulátora) a tervezés során gondoskodni kell ezen részegységek minél hosszabb élettartamáról. A kijelzőt a tervezés során erősebbé kell tenni, valamint elérhetővé kell tenni a hosszú élettartamú akkumulátor felhasználók részére a csere lehetőségét is. Továbbá megoldást kell találni a szoftverfrissítések tekintetében is, hogy azok ne okozzák a mobil eszközök lassulását, ezáltal ne kényszerítsék a felhasználót az mobil eszközök lecserélésére.            Összességében előremutató a mobil eszközök olyan környezettudatos tervezése, amely jelentősen csökkentheti az elektronikai hulladékok mennyiségét és hozzájárul a szükséges erőforrások felhasználásának csökkentéséhez.
Initiative: Energy labelling of mobile phones and tablets – informing consumers about environmental impact

feedback_msg_text: Wir begrüßen die Initiative der EU-Kommission, Umweltauswirkungen von Mobiltelefonen u. Tablets zu reduzieren.  Die Verlängerung der Lebensdauer ist der wichtigste Aspekt zur Verringerung von Umweltauswirkungen von Produkten, insb. bei mobilen Hightech-Produkten. Ein Großteil der Umweltbelastung von Smartphones entsteht bei Herstellung, Vertrieb und Entsorgung. Die Verlängerung der Lebensdauer kann deshalb einen großen eitrag zum Einsparen von Emissionen und Ressourcen leisten. Auf dem EU-Markt verkaufte Smartphones u. Tablets sollten Mindestanforderungen an Reparierbarkeit und Aufrüstbarkeit erfüllen sowie Informationen für Verbraucher*innen bereitstellen, auf deren Grundlage umweltfreundliche Kaufentscheidungen getroffen werden können. Verbindliche Ökodesign- und Informationsanforderungen sind dafür das beste Mittel. Selbstregulierungsinitiativen anstelle von verbindlicher Standards lehnen wir ab. Die freiwilligen Vereinbarungen, die unter der Ökodesign-Richtlinie bisher gebilligt wurden, sind nicht ehrgeizig genug, um die Umweltauswirkungen von Produkten tatsächlich zu verringern.       Deshalb schlagen wir folgende Mindestanforderungen für das Ökodesign von Smartphones u. Tablets vor:      • Austauschbare Batterien (von Nutzer*innen mit Werkzeugen, reversiblen und/oder wiederverwendbaren Verbindungselementen entnehmbar)     • Verbindungs-, Befestigungs- oder Versiegelungstechniken dürfen das Austauschen folgender Komponenten mit handelsüblichen Werkzeugen nicht verhindern: Bildschirm/Displayeinheit, Kameras, Glasrückwand, Ladeanschluss, Hauptplatine, Tasten, Audioausgang, Lautsprecher, Mikrofon.  Der Austausch dieser Teile durch unabhängige Reparateure darf nicht durch andere Konstruktionsentscheidungen wie z. B. die Serialisierung der Teile verhindert werden     • 6-7 Jahre Ersatzteilverfügbarkeit         ◦ Komponenten, die Nutzer*innen zur Verfügung gestellt werden müssen: Batterie, Bildschirm/Displayeinheit, Glasrückwand;          ◦ Komponenten, die professionellen Reparateuren zusätzlich zur Verfügung gestellt werden müssen: Kameras, Ladeanschluss, Hauptplatine, Tasten, Audioausgang, Lautsprecher, Mikrofon     • Der Preis der Ersatzteile muss in einem angemessenen Verhältnis (z.B. nicht mehr als 30%) zum Neuverkaufspreis des Produkts stehen und transparent kommuniziert werden     • Bereitstellung von Informationen zur korrekten Nutzung und Reparatur für Nutzer*innen, unabhängige und professionelle Reparateure, einschließlich Reparaturanleitungen und Diagnosetools     • 8 Jahre Betriebssystemunterstützung (OS-Support). Das Einstellen von OS-Support stellt einen Hauptgrund für Sicherheits- und Leistungsprobleme dar.     • Software-Sicherheitsupdates werden getrennt von Updates zur Funktionserweiterung zur Verfügung gestellt, die Nutzer*innen auf Funktionsbasis zulassen oder ablehnen kann     • Zugriffsrechte auf notwendige Schnittstellen für Nutzer*innen nach Ende des OS-Supports Die wichtigsten Nachhaltigkeitsinformationen sollten Verbraucher*innen leicht zugänglich und verständlich zur Verfügung gestellt werden und sowohl vergleichbar als auch leicht überprüfbar sein – sowohl durch die Nutzer*innen selbst als auch durch die Marktaufsichtsbehörden. Dies wird am besten durch eine verpflichtende Kennzeichnung erreicht. Wir unterstützen die Einführung eines speziellen EU-Labels für Reparierbarkeit, das Verbraucher*innen ermöglicht, die langlebigste und reparatur-freundlichste Option auf dem Markt zu wählen. Die Reparatur-Freundlichkeit der Geräte muss an den Kriterien Zugang zu Informationen für Nutzer*innen und unabhängige Werkstätten, einfache Demontage ohne Werkzeug/mit handelsüblichem Werkzeug, Zugang zu Ersatzteilen für Nutzer*inenn und unabhängige Werkstätten und Preis der Ersatzteile gemessen werden. Zusatzpunkte sollte es für jedes Jahr geben, in dem Ersatzteile und Betriebssystem-Unterstützung über den vorgeschriebenen Zeitraum hinaus bereitgestellt werden sowie für die Reversibilität von Updates.

feedback_msg_text: About Closing the Loop  Closing the Loop is a circular service provides that offers users, buyers, and sellers of tech devices an easy way to compensate the waste related to purchasing and using products. We collect end-of-life phones and tablets in developing countries on behalf of our customers, thereby compensating their IT devices (making the products ‘waste-free’). The service delivers commercial value, a positive environmental impact, a great story, measurable results, employee engagement, and stakeholder value.    Context  We want to thank the European Commission for the opportunity to comment on these crucial initiatives. The momentum to do something about the environmental impact of mobile phones and tablets is more urgent than ever. The world generated over 53 million metric tons of e-waste in 2019, much of that coming from phones and tablets, and that number is expected to increase by another 40% by 2030 if left unchecked. Furthermore, the value destruction is highly worrying: Only about US$10 billion of the US$57 billion is currently recycled properly (Source: 2020 Global E-Waste Monitor).    The minerals and metals in the phones and tables that are thrown away are not just valuable, they are also toxic: They are arsenic, and contain lead, zin and cadmium. There are therefore numerous reasons why they should be kept out of landfills, let alone be dumped in developing countries.    Specific comments on the objectives and policy options  We at CTL fully subscribe to the objective to make mobile phones and tablets more energy efficient and improve their material efficiency. This is a great aspiration as we move into the future, and if it works, our job is done.     And until that moment arrives, we in Europe need to do something about the e-waste that we have created in the past and that we will continue to generate as we move towards that ideal. This “e-waste debt” is still growing by the day as mobile phones and tablets keep on being landfilled. We must ensure that the consumption of new devices is a trigger to ‘go circular’ and in addition to take care of this e-waste debt! We call this “practical circularity”, because it shows that circular elements are available today.    Therefore, we would like to strongly encourage the European Commission to make sure that in its impact assessment, the Ecodesign for mobile phones and tablets also includes a role for historical e-waste, for example by promoting ‘waste compensation’, which makes the purchase of new phones and tablets ‘waste neutral’. Waste compensation has been adopted by NGOs (e.g. TCO Certified), the United Nations International Telecommunication Union (ITU), and is used and promoted by national governments (such as the Dutch government). With this, historical e-waste is reduced as the waste compensation fee is used to fund the proper collection of e-waste in the emerging world. We would be happy to elaborate on these points with policymakers and other stakeholders.       Feedback from: Closing the Loop (139 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download

feedback_msg_text: The French Banking Federation (FBF) welcomes the opportunity to express its views on the inception impact assessment of the DMFSD. The current Directive proved to cope well with evolutions both in the market and in technologies, thanks to its principle-based nature and in protecting consumers. Therefore, we are supportive of policy option: 0) The baseline scenario (no policy change). We believe that this option is the best as the Directive fulfilled its purpose of ensuring a high level of consumer protection, through a clear regulatory framework and especially information to be provided about the provider and the financial service in addition to the existence of a right of withdrawal. A revision or a repeal of the Directive will not resolve the problems mentioned in its evaluation. Also, we need regulatory stability more than any simplification. Finally, we trust option 0 is fit to tackle the possible problems identified in the IIA. The focus should be placed on regulatory implementation and level-playing field.   The directive is efficient as its principled-based requirements can be interpreted and adapted to the evolving products and technologies. Possible loopholes or problems arising from the Directive derive from an incorrect implementation and enforcement of the text by some service providers, but not from any strong shortcomings in the text per se. On the specific issue of the time granted before signature, we consider that withdrawal rights are effective and have been used by unhappy consumers. To the contrary, establishing a specific minimum timing before being able to conclude the distance purchase would create unfair terms for financial services compared to a direct purchase and would be against customers’ interests. Customers purchasing products online do it specifically for speed and smoothness. Limiting it may be detrimental to their interest and satisfaction.    Regarding product-specific legislation, we agree that their progressive introduction has reduced the relative relevance of the Directive. However, as new products and new sale channels can arise, we consider the safety net role of the Directive is still relevant and there are more benefits in keeping the Directive rather than repealing it.  The Directive is short, simple, agile and has a technology-neutral approach, which is important as trying to adapt the regulation to new technologies and new consumers’ expectations would be a never-ending and very costly process. We fully support the desire to develop technology-neutral legislation that is overarching and sufficiently versatile to protect consumers irrespective of new technologies that may arise in the market. It should be up to the client to decide whether to engage in an online or offline relationship. The legislation should be neutral and enable a bank relationship that can be:100% offline; online or a hybrid.  We consider that the limited cross-border provision of financial services is due to reasons that go beyond the scope of the Directive, and therefore we deem that a review of the Directive would not have meaningful impact. In particular, it would be more relevant to support harmonised implementation of existing EU regulatory framework by reducing national gold-plating which is a main root of market fragmentation. These can be overcome with coordinated implementation and supervision, rather than with changes in the Directive. To the contrary, more detailed or rigid requirements would affect the valuable flexibility that allowed the Directive to remain relevant and adapt to the changes in markets and technology. Other obstacles that can’t be addressed by the Directive are linked to common home-biases, language barriers, culture, etc.
Initiative: Distance marketing of consumer financial services – review of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: BEUC considers that the Distance Marketing of Financial Services (DMFSD) Directive contains rights which are fundamental to ensure the protection of consumers purchasing financial services at a distance, including (i) pre-contractual information that consumers must receive before concluding a contract (ii) a 14-day right of withdrawal (iii) and a ban on unsolicited distance sales and communications. BEUC fully agrees with the conclusions of the Evaluation Study, finding that the DMFSD is a useful “safety net” both for products not covered or only partially covered by product-specific legislation, and for any new products which may come into the market.  The DMFSD ensures a uniform, high level of protection for consumers across the EU. In that respect, BEUC urges the European Commission not to repeal the DMFSD, but to revise the Directive to ensure a high level of consumer protection in the face of the increased digitalisation of the financial services sector. Examples of products and services covered by the DMFSD would include consumer credit that fall above the maximum ceiling set by the CCD (such as loans for car purchases or higher education purposes contracted online), elderly or vulnerable consumers who may be mis-sold financial products over the phone, or consumers contracting payment accounts online (who may face disproportionate cancellation fees if they change their mind).   Existing rights contained in the DMFSD should be updated or improved:  - BEUC supports the EBA’s Opinion on digital disclosure to consumers of banking services, which advocates for more precise rules on the form, prominence and timing of information disclosure. Information should be clear, accessible and understandable for consumers and the EBA should issue Regulatory Technical Standards (RTS) on the format and presentation of the information; - Several definitions contained in the DMFSD should be clarified and updated (the need to provide information 'in good time' and on a 'durable medium'); - The DMFSD should regulate pre-contractual information and advertising separately, making sure that the promotional nature of the communication is clear, that information about risks is presented prominently;  - The DMFSD should ensure that the procedure to exercise the right of withdrawal is simple and straightforward for consumers. The consumer should be clearly informed about the procedure and provided the relevant withdrawal form when signing the contract; - The Commission should consider whether a mandatory reflection period before signing the contract (i.e. an opt-in approach) would be more effective in protecting consumers from quick and ill-informed decisions; - The ban on unsolicited services does not apply to the tacit renewal of distance contracts. We consider that all unsolicited sales should be banned. We also consider that unsolicited communications should be forbidden, in line with the ePrivacy Directive.  In addition, given the low level of enforcement of the DMFSD which was highlighted in the evaluation study, it is very important to enhance the cooperation and coordination of the various authorities in charge of enforcing the DMFSD. The Directive should also contain provisions ensuring that the national authorities in charge of enforcing it have sufficient powers and resources available. Additional safeguards should also be added in the revised DMFSD, including: - Strictly regulating comparison tools in order to ensure that they are truly objective and independent. Comparison tools that do not meet these requirements would need to identify themselves clearly as financial product brokers or sellers; - Consumers should be protected against the inertia selling of add-on products. Consumers should be required to take an active and informed decision whether they need or want an add-on product that is being offered to them. BEUC supports the EBA’s recommendation to prohibit the use of pre-ticked boxes under the revised DMFSD.
Initiative: Distance marketing of consumer financial services – review of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: Stand.earth is an international nonprofit environmental advocacy organization headquartered in San Francisco, California, USA. Our work encompasses a broad range of environmental and public health issues related to both air and water pollution from the maritime sector. We also work in close partnership on maritime pollution issues with organizations based within the EU.   On behalf of our hundreds of thousands supporters from multiple countries, we welcome this timely European Commission initiative to revise EU rules regarding illegal discharges from ships. The protection of public health, the climate, and the marine environment requires comprehensive coverage of all MARPOL annexes within EU regulations, including robust monitoring, maintenance, and performance standards to ensure compliance.   We applaud the zero pollution vision and climate commitments of the EU. In order to achieve these goals, air and climate forcing pollutants, including black carbon, must be included as illegal discharges from ships.   Stand.earth commissioned faculty at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health to conduct onboard air testing on passenger vessels while the ships were underway. The findings of that study showed that particulate matter air pollution onboard at the stern of these ships could be as bad or worse than some of the world’s most polluted cities, including Beijing, China and Santiago, Chile. All vessels in this study had Exhaust Gas Cleaning Systems (EGCS or scrubbers) installed and were within the North American Emissions control area at the time the study was conducted.   Our findings were consistent with similar testing conducted in EU ports, which have shown similarly high levels of air pollution from ships. These findings were also supported by a report commissioned by Environment and Climate Change Canada and released in November, 2020 which found that the use of scrubbers with heavy fuel oil not only created a significant and avoidable water pollution wastestream, but worsened both air and climate pollution from ships as compared to distillate fuel.   Further, performance and maintenance standards must be included in the revisions of the Directive to protect the marine environment. A study from the Netherlands of advanced wastewater sewage treatment systems onboard 120 merchant vessels since 2012 found that “97 percent of the sewage treatment plants did not meet all the discharge standards.” Pollutants such as suspended solids and faecal coliforms often exceeded their limits by 10 and 10,000 times respectively. These ships were “discharging virtually untreated sewage” (MEPC 71/INF.22).  Oily discharges including bilge water and tank washings, scrubber wastewater, ballast water management, sewage waste (grey and blackwater), garbage waste and container loss must also be included in the scope of the revisions. Finally, there must be effective, dissuasive and proportionate penalties for all pollution offences involving substances covered by MARPOL Annexes I, II, IV, V and VI.
Initiative: Maritime sector – revising the EU rules on illegal discharges from ships

feedback_msg_text: Bretagne Vivante est une organisation de protection de l'environnement sise en Bretagne, à l'ouest de la France. Notre organisation a été témoin de nombreux événements de mer conduisant à des pollutions sur nos côtes. Citons par exemple en 1978 le naufrage de l'Amoco Cadiz d'où se sont échappées plus de 200 000 tonnes de pétrole brut qui ont souillé les côtes du Nord de la Bretagne ou, en 1999, celui de l'Erika dans le golfe de Gascogne qui a précisément donné le nom de "paquet Erika" à l'ensemble de règlements et directives adoptés par l'UE dans les années qui ont suivi. Malgré ces textes qui forment un ensemble très consistant, notamment pour ce qui concerne les mesures de prévention édictées par la Convention MARPOL, la pollution causée par les navires reste un problème préoccupant. Aussi, dans le cadre de la présente consultation, notre organisation souhaite-t-elle faire part à la Commission de diverses observations qui figurent dans le document ci-joint. Merci. feedback_msg_text: Algen, algal technology centre ltd is an SME specializing in engineering and system integration of algae based systems, including R&D activity in algae cultivation, wastewater nutrient and energy recovery systems, biostimulants and biopesticides.  We would not like to repeat many arguments in already posted feedbacks. We specifically support the claims of high potential of algal technologies, need for further developments enabling the economic feasibility of the technology at large scale, need for more practical regulation in the area of novel food, biostimulants and biopesticides and fertilizers. We also face regulatory barriers in accepting advanced nutrient and energy recycling solutions from wastewater, namely uneven implementation of the end-of-waste directive in different member states.  We do acknowledge the need to develop macroalgae cultivation systems (as opposed to macroalgae harvesting), specially in the realm of multi trophic aquaculture systems that would close the nutrient, carbon and oxygen cycles. But macroalgal technologies in marine environment are well advanced compared to microalgae marine based cultivation technologies, so these need regulatory, innovation and financial boost.  Specifically, the new EU organic certification of algal products has significant flaws, and it presents a threat that products of EU origin will face significant market disadvantage – this is an urgent and serious problem of our industry.  We certainly acknowledge the need to move large scale microalgal to the sea, as this seems to be the most feasible environment to reach significant economic impact. Sea environment presents some qualitatively different challenges, so we believe that any significant microalgae cultivation effort in the sea environment is still in the domain of R&D and needs to be supported by innovation and development funds. We do believe there are presently unexplored options to cultivate high quality microalgae in marine environment at large scale that need multidisciplinary approach. There are options of anchored and semi anchored systems, floating or submerged that need to be developed to reach seaworthiness. Industrially prepared systems using suspension or biofilm cultivation seem to be the way to reach economic sustainability. Algal bacterial systems connected to biogas are one of the few technologies enabling nutrient and energy recycling from wastewater streams. They enable reuse or energy content of WW streams (estimated at 5 kWh/m3 for municipal wastewater) and prevent eutrophicating nutrients and micropollutants to reach the environment; all this at positive energy balance (compared to average use of energy for wastewater treatment at 0.5 kWh/m3 in conventional systems). The only disadvantage of such systems seems to be mentionable use of surface area required to collect solar energy for photosynthetic processes. It is therefore very natural to propose the move of such systems to marine environment, of shore to take advantage of marine surface area. Only very limited research and development has been done in this area so we strongly encourage allocation of innovation and development funds for large scale project of this type.  Summarizing priorities from our standpoint: - Algal-bacterial nutrient and energy recycling from WW - As above, but in marine environment at large scale, - New mid-value application areas for algal biomass: biostimulants, bio-pesticides, bio-plastics, - Any microalgae cultivation in marine environment, - Regulation: novel food, organic certification, biostimulants, biopesticides, end-of-waste implementation in member states - Biofilms (in any environment, for any application) - Industrially produced seaworthy microalgae cultivation systems  - Integrated multi trophic aquaculture, - Biorefinery, novel ingredients, - Funding of clinical and nutritional testing of bio based products (as there is lack of commercial interest in such testing as they are not sufficiently IP protected)
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: We welcome this initiative and are keen to participate in order to foster the development of the algae sector in Europe, namely in Portugal. PROALGA currently leads the Portuguese mirror technical commission of the EU “CEN/TC 454-Algae and algae products”.  PROALGA formalized in 2018, has the objective to promote, defend and foster the interests of algae producers (micro and macroalgae), as well as their representation at the decision levels, public administration and other public or private national, community or foreign institutions.  To fulfil its objectives, PROALGA has the following roles: a)To develop actions, that directly promote and defend the interests of its members before public or private entities; b)To coordinate and promote the initiatives of its members to defend the quality of produced algae, as well as the expansion of their production and consumption on different markets; c)To participate together with members and external entities in activities to develop the algae business; d)To listen to its members in what refers to more urgent questions in the algae sector; e)To identify negative impact drivers in the algae sector and to propose ways to overcome them to members and public officials; f)To cooperate with national and community official entities and organizations in the development and assessment of legal documents and technical standards, directly or indirectly related with the sector; g)To act as main representative of the sector near the political decision makers; h)To assure membership and participation on relevant international associations of the sector; i)To support directly the members in the development of their industrial and commercial activities, including initiatives to strengthen their presence at international markets; j)To develop research oriented actions, as well as a wide dissemination of the outcomes of those activities. Between PROALGA founding members are ALGAPLUS (Ílhavo), NECTON (Olhão) and Allmicroalgae (Leiria), pioneers in EU algae farming, responsible for several axis of development of the sector.

feedback_msg_text: ALGAplus farms seaweed in Portugal since 2012. In a land-based/on-shore IMTA system (fish+seaweed) and organic certified. Sells for food & cosmetics. Great initiative. Crucial to involve the largest number of companies and countries that have lead the development of the sector,  already producing and selling algae, facing real bottlenecks to survival/development. Some notes: CONTEXT: some seaweed species can be sustainably wild-harvested BUT the need is to increase farming operations in Europe as it is the ONLY way to provide this valuable biomass to a growing market demand, looking for consistency and quality in supply; There are large seaweed species that can only be grown at sea (e.g. kelp) but there are others that need to use ponds, raceways on-shore (e.g. sea lettuce, nori, ogonori,..); Algae are more than a source of protein – they have a crucial role for fighting global deficiencies of Iodine and Iron and show several benefits for prevention of CVDs; Reporting on biomass production has lacks due to confidentiality issues when there are less than 3 operators/farmers in a given country – this needs to be tackled otherwise numbers are wrong! The total turnover between microalgae and seaweeds should not be the same? Which sectors of the algae value chain are included in this economic analysis? REGULATORY GAPS – there is already a CEN working group on algae that is not mentioned anywhere? – it involves serious voluntary efforts from several players of the sector and needs to be accounted for!! An effort should be done to get the most out of it before initiating a new movement for regulations; It is important that algae aren’t looked at as very different from other food sources. There are EU food regulations that can be easily applied. We must also learn from countries where seaweeds have been consumed for centuries; this would increase the list of edible species and stop the fears on aspects like iodine consumption… FUNDING: biorefineries are possibly the way to long-term development but we should think of algae as a whole, that can be used directly as ingredients. Funding is needed to improve production technologies that can allow a serious upscale of biomass production with low operational costs. the key is to make more algae and more affordable; Funding for national seaweed/algae processing cooperatives! OBJECTIVES & POLICY OPTIONS. Option 3 is what could be done, fill the gaps but at the same time start to control some aspects. There is science and practical experience available to do so. Regarding objectives in option 2:  •Obj. 1 - a key issue is the denomination of species. For instance, taxonomists have shown that there is no Ulva lactuca in Europe…But legislation says Ulva lactuca is the edible species; so even if we know that we are providing a different Ulva species, to sell we must state Ulva lactuca OR Ulva sp. Novel Food/Cosmetics legislation should state just the genera (e.g. Ulva sp.) to make communication clearer and more truthful. •Obj. 1 – algae farms should be considered in inland and transition waters planning, besides the maritime. The extractive effect (bioremediation) of these units should be looked at as advantageous and suitable for sensitive areas. Besides Carbon, Nitrogen credits should be looked at; tax benefits for companies that implement algae farming or IMTA approaches could be an easy and attractive measure to foster the development of the sector – value ecosystem services. •Obj. 2 – the list should be increased not only by historical consumption at the EU level but also by including species consumed in Asia. Other notes: •Farming exotic species (non- Atlantic) should be forbidden; however, the definition of “local” must be done in such a way that does not hamper the development of the sector. •Important to look and contact EU projects that have also seriously contributed to the advance of the sector: SEABIOPLAS (end-2015), INTEGRATE (end-2020), GENIALG (end-2021).

feedback_msg_text: Corbion is a Netherlands-based global market leader in lactic acid and its derivatives, and algae-based ingredients.  We thank the European Commission for providing us with the opportunity to comment on the Inception Impact Assessment for the “Blue bioeconomy - towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector”.   Algae have tremendous potential to deliver nutrient-dense food to address global challenges in food and feed production and health.  In addition, algae products can support a transition to a bio-based economy including products for biomaterials, textiles, cosmetics, biopolymers, biofuels, and fertilizer/bio-stimulants.  Algae produce high-quality proteins, carbohydrates, and oils in an efficient and scalable manner.  Production systems for algae often have low environmental impact reducing the use of potable water, arable land, and fossil-based energy.  Algae have been in our food system for millennia with a few varieties popularized in the last few decades including seaweed, spirulina, chlorella, astaxanthin and omega-3 fatty acids (DHA & EPA).  Although algae offer enormous potential for food production, additional development and infrastructure buildout, as well as the introduction of policies and regulations supportive of the algae industry are required to scale and enable economic production of algae-based products.    Scope for comments:  1. All future algae policy and regulation should be inclusive of all methods of microalgae production, including open pond, photobioreactors, and fermentation 2. All future algae policy and regulation should be developed with reference to “EN 17399:2020 Algae and algae products - Terms and definitions” 3. Whenever feasible, consumer friendly language should be used, particularly in policies and regulations related to increasing social awareness and acceptance of algae.  Specific comments  Corbion supports action on measures listed in both Options 2 and 3 and believes these efforts will ensure a significant contribution by the algae industry in promoting the availability of sustainable biomaterials, textiles, cosmetics, biopolymers, biofuels, and fertilizer/biostimulants.    1. Improving regulatory and governance framework: In order to support the standardisation of algae product specifications (built on existing standards and standards under development), we support the efforts currently underway via CEN, specifically the work on “Algae and algae products standardization (CEN 454)” and use of the terms and definitions in EN 17399:2020.   2. Supporting functioning of the market: Europe needs industry support measures to bring new algae species to the market under the Novel Food Regulation, for example by identifying and sharing best practices or identifying species that do not require Novel Food authorization procedure. We therefore support the initiative by DG MARE to map knowledge on the use of different algae species in and outside the EU to facilitate Novel Food assessment via a JRC action.   3. Improving business environment: Many benefits and added value can be accrued via a web-based one-stop-shop for EU algae stakeholders for knowledge, good practices sharing, information on funding and algae project results (by considering existing national, regional or industry/NGO one stop shops).   4. Increasing social awareness and acceptance: There is a need for an EU-wide communication campaign including scientifically supported health, environmental, social and commercial benefits of EU algae products. Consumer expectations around health and sustainability are higher than ever and the plant-based market shows no signs of slowing down. Algae food products can be a sustainable, vegan source of many important nutrients that are typically consumed below recommended intake levels.  More detail can be found in the attached contribution - to which we refer and which forms part of our consultation input.  We look forward to further engagement on this topic.
