feedback_msg_text: BioAtlantis Ltd. (Ireland), manufactures products for the plant, animal and human health sectors. The company develops novel technologies that mitigate against the effects of climate change and improve sustainable practices in agriculture. In particular, BioAtlantis manufactures products proven to enhance crop tolerance to abiotic stresses such as cold, drought and heat. The company is also a leader in the development of immune priming technologies to replace the usage of in-feed antibiotics in agriculture. The raw materials used to manufacture these technologies are sustainably derived from renewable raw materials such as seaweed. BioAtlantis has the largest seaweed extraction factory in Britain and Ireland. To ensure a strong and sustainable algae sector in the EU, BioAtlantis make the following recommendations:  1. Commercially important seaweeds cannot be grown by aquaculture: It is not technically feasible or profitable to culture certain seaweed species such as Ascophylum nodosum or Laminaria hyperborea. As A. nodosum and L. hyperborea are essential to the EU seaweed industry, it is recommended that wild stocks continue to be harvested in a sustainable manner.  2. Certain seaweeds cannot be hand harvested: As L. hyperborea grows in exposed subtidal waters between 3-30 meters, it cannot be hand harvested and is only accessible by boat. As L. hyperborea is one of the most commercially important seaweeds in the EU, sustainable mechanical harvesting of this renewable resource by boat must continue.  3. Harvesting of wild stocks cannot be replaced by aquaculture: Most seaweed-related products in Europe are derived from wild stocks. While aquaculture may be suited to growing certain species, it faces many challenges. For aquaculture to meet industry needs, entire coastlines would need to be occupied with infrastructure. However, aquaculture units are vulnerable to storm damage, leading to significant pollution associated with equipment being washing ashore or deposited on the seabed (e.g. plastic buoys,  ropes). The sustainable harvesting of wild stocks must continue, as it cannot be replaced by aquaculture.   4. Seaweed is not a carbon sink: Commercial harvesting of wild seaweed is a renewable and sustainable process and has operated in the EU since the 1970s, with no significant environmental impacts. However, it has been falsely claimed that seaweed is a carbon sink. In fact, marine plants/seaweeds account for <1% of the total photosynthesized carbon in the world annually (ref: Field, 1998, Science. 281.5374, 237-240), most of which is not sequestered for long term storage. In contrast, non-seaweed sources (e.g. marine phytoplankton) are the main contributor to carbon sequestration, accounting for >97% of total photosynthesized carbon in the ocean annually (Field et al., 1998). As seaweed is not an effective carbon sink, its role in this area should not be considered further. It has been suggested that seaweed grown via aquaculture may sequester carbon. However, most seaweeds grown by aquaculture have low yields and are destined for use in end products and are not added to carbon sinks.   5. Environmental benefits of harvesting seaweed: When designed correctly, harvesting can have environmental benefits, e.g. by harvesting older L. hyperborea, younger plants continue grow faster as they have increased exposure to sunlight. Older Laminaria is susceptible to storm damage with up to 20% of stocks washed ashore annually, where it rots, emits toxic gases and provides a protected environment for E. coli. Harvesting older Laminaria before it is washed ashore prevents such negative impacts.  6. Public benefits: This initiative should support EU companies specializing in the development of technologies from algae with proven ‘public benefits’, e.g. products that enhance human, animal and plant health, enhance resilience to climate change, increase agricultural sustainability and reduce pollution.   BioAtlantis Ltd. (Ireland)
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Biosyntex S.r.l (BSX) is an italian technology & service provider active in the algae sector since 2018.  As BSX we greatly appreciate the "Blue bioeconomy - towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector" initiative.  After years of intense R&D and EU funding for this sector, algae have not yet expressed their real potential. Many are the aspects that still today limit the full exploitation of algal bio-technologies. The main ones are well highlighted in the document accompanying this initiative.  As BSX we are in favor of option 3 « Targeted activities to support the sustainable growth of the algae sector including regulatory measures » It is our opinion that the "Regulatory gaps" represent one of the main limitations of this sector. "Novel Food" regulation, although necessary to avoid the placing on the market of new unsafe products, undoubtedly represents a great obstacle, especially for small and medium size companies that can hardly bear the costs of the dossier. Even the Organic Regulation (848/2018) as well as Reg. 1009/2019 do not seem to have taken into account the specificity of algae cultivation and if not appropriately modified will represent a problem for the expansion of this sector in the next years. The harmonization of national regulations for food supplements into a European regulation would also help to clarify one of the sectors that see algae largely used Environmental benefits generated by algae production (eg. CO2 savigs, nutrient recycling) should be also considered and valorized.  .
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: As a preferred partner of farmers and distributors all around the world, Olmix works to create an ecosystem gathering science and agricultural actors in a plan for agro-ecological transition. In this context, we are developing an international ecosystem of partners to raise animals and grow plants in a better way. Our role is to bring natural solutions to farmers to improve plants’ health and nutrition and to breeders to improve animals' health and welfare. To do so, algae are a key raw material from which, through various steps of innovations, we have been able to develop solutions for worldwide agricultural transition towards better practices. It enables to produce with a more respectful and a positive impact on the environment, with less use of synthetic chemical products while in capacity to feed the world population and to ensure farmers or breeders a decent living.  Through this impact assessment, the European Commission recognizes the potential of algae-based solutions and illustrates its will to tackle the key challenges to foster their development. It appears that the main working lines are both on developing recognition and acceptance but also on simplifying and clarifying the regulatory environment. First, to be concrete, algae have a historical use which recognition should be facilitated to alleviate the impact on their present use with regulations such as Novel Food. Algae also have many benefits that could be further promoted, from their ecological role to their applications. Then, regulatory framework regarding algae classification and potential applications, methods of extraction or processing could be either clarified, simplified or harmonized. The latter also applies to seaweed farming that could benefit from that kind of support and clarification approach regarding growing methods or varietal selections.   In agricultural related applications, the current European regulation could be modernized or simplified without compromising health and feed/food safety and its effectiveness and efficiency could be also improved. Two examples:  In the feed applications, seaweeds are composed by many active molecules which have a real potential in animal nutrition, performance and welfare and can contribute to the reduce to use of antimicrobials.  For feed additive regulations (CE n°1831/2003 and 429/2008), the procedure of scientific evaluation, assessment and authorization is essential for global food safety. However, regarding the assessment of efficacy, the number of in vivo trials can be restrictive for small compagnies and the level of investments they require could be high for small and medium companies.  In the fertilizers / biostimulants sector: biostimulants have very positive impact on environment and natural resources preservation. Thus, they contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. And, by ensuring better absorption of certain nutrients, biostimulants help preserving non-renewable resources. The new harmonized regulation (UE n°2019/1009) is a real opportunity for innovation for biostimulants but can also afraid compagnies because of new obligations, such as the elaboration of technical documentation including efficacy evidences and because of other applicable regulations, such as REACH (CE n°1907/2006).   As mentioned above, this assessment is a really good sign for algae actors and, as a whole, for building tomorrow’s alternative solutions for the European consumers and citizens. The entire seaweed sector, among them pioneer companies, need stimulation and support to develop further.   What's at stake is to create the conditions to enable the seaweed sector scale change necessary to meet today’s challenges and build effective solutions for the agricultural and ecological transitions.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: The Algae Biomass Organization (ABO) is the non-profit trade association for the algae industry operating in the United States. Our mission is to promote the development of viable commercial markets for renewable, sustainable and nutritious products derived from algae. Our membership is comprised of individuals, companies, and research organizations across the algae value chain.  ABO has a number of EU-based members companies with production and commercial operations in the EU.  Please see attached PDF for full comments.  As the European Commission considers a range of supportive measures, there are several key principles ABO believes are important for building the sector.  1. Algae policy and regulation should be inclusive and support the full diversity of macroalgae and microalgae production, including open ocean, coastal, open pond, photobioreactors, fermentation and hybrid systems Globally, macroalgae (seaweeds) represent one of the world’s largest crops by volume. They can be harvested in the open ocean and grown in coastal areas.  In coastal areas, there are typically two production systems: (i) open pond; and (ii) offshore longline.  For microalgae, a number of algae production technologies are currently in use, from open ponds and closed photobioreactors, from fermentation tanks to hybrid systems, to some that combine these various methods. Simply put, there is no one single way to grow algae at commercial scale, and this versatility and diversity is one of algae’s strengths.  2. All future algae policy and regulation should be developed with reference to “EN 17399:2020 Algae and algae products - Terms and definitions” The European Commission understands the importance of definition standardization in promoting the use of algae and algae products.  As a result, the European Commission requested the European Committee for Standardization (CEN) to draft European standards, or European standardization deliverables, to support the implementation of Article 3 of Directive 2008/28/EC for algae and algae-based products of intermediates. To ensure consistency, it will be important to use those standards for EU policies and regulation. The first standard, EN 17399:2020 "Algae and algae products – Terms and definitions" was published March 2020 and defines that algae include macroalgae, microalgae, cyanobacteria and Labyrinthulomycetes.  3. Spur market demand with EU procurement policies that incentivize purchasing of algae-based products and services Many of the strategies outlined in Option 2 and 3 focus on the development, production and supply of algae-based products.  The recommendation in Option 2 to increase “Social Awareness and Acceptance” and to set “Binding targets for substitution of fish based fish feed” in Option 3 are important first steps in creating market demand.  Considering the purchasing power of government agencies, there is also an opportunity to jump start demand through purchasing policies.  For example, targets for government agencies to purchase algae-based food products, biofuel or materials could be implemented.  This could also include focusing  educational efforts directed at the agricultural sector around algae solutions for animal feed and fertilizers/biostimulants that can help to meet member state greenhouse gas reduction targets while stimulating demand for algae products.  ABO is supportive of the range of activities outlined in Policy Options 2 and 3 and for the European Commission moving forward with building out a strategy to support the EU algae sector.  Please see attached PDF for full comments on specifics within these options. Feedback from: Algae Biomass Organization (122.6 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: We use an innovative, highly technical, green and clean biorefinery method to process sustainably farmed seaweed home compostable, bio-packaging, food and nutrition ingredients.     From our perspective of operating within the sector there is a need for greater collaboration and support for this emerging, environmentally and economically positive industry   The role for bio refiners is a critical as our mission is to help make the market for farmed seaweed.  Yet support structures and services for businesses like ours are limited, and there are substantial barriers to entry. To aid the growth and development of seaweed farming and seaweed biorefinery there is a requirement for greater levels of provision i.e. financial, advisory, regulatory etc, and the creation of channels to aid cross industry cooperation. feedback_msg_text: Seaweed for Europe welcomes the launch of the initiative Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector and wishes to share its contribution to this process.   We are a coalition comprised of over 70 European players from across the seaweed sector with the aim of accelerating the growth of a sustainable seaweed industry in Europe.   Seaweed for Europe fully agrees with the Commission and indeed believes that seaweed cultivation has a vital role to play in supporting the EU Green Deal, but will need regulatory support to develop this nascent but promising industry.   While Europe’s seaweed sector today remains small, the conditions are favourable to enable the growth of a vibrant and sizeable industry. Modelling by Seaweed for Europe reveals that the seaweed market in Europe could worth up to €9.3 bn in 2030 in an ambitious sceanrio, driven by the growing demand in seaweed-based products such as food, feed, bio-stimulants, nutraceuticals, bio-packaging, etc . With the right enabling conditions, our modelling suggests that 30% of this market could be captured by European aquaculture, bringing up to 115,000 jobs.  Crucially, the sector would also bring significant environmental benefits. By 2030 the industry could offset 5.4 million tonnes CO2e p.a., showcasing its potential to contribute to the EU Green Deal target of achieving net zero by 2050. Furthermore, seaweed offers a diverse set of other ecosystem services to marine environments. Seaweed could remove 20,000 tonnes of nitrogen and 2,000 tonnes of phosphorus from European oceans each year by 2030, thereby contributing to mitigating eutrophication. Seaweed also supplies oxygen to and increases the pH of the water it grows in, and so reduces both the hypoxia that occurs with eutrophication, and ocean acidification. Other benefits include the removal of heavy metals and suspended solids. Together with the habitat offered by seaweed aquaculture, these water quality improvements can support biodiversity both for marine life – as seaweed farms can serve as nursery grounds for fish and shellfish species – and as overspill benefits for seabirds, for which seaweed aquaculture can offer resting points and feeding grounds. Furthermore, if seaweed farms limit other environmentally disruptive human activities from taking place in a marine environment, they can effectively perform the same function as Marine Protected Areas, which is likely to benefit benthic habitats and organisms.   If Europe is to realize the potential from a domestic seaweed industry, the sector must transform and scale rapidly. Seaweed for Europe identified with its members and is currently working on 6 priority areas to address systemic barriers currently slowing this sustainable growth (see details In the attached document).  Most of these priority actions align very well with the working assumptions laid out in document Inception impact assessment (Ref. Ares(2020)7837750 - 21/12/2020), and Seaweed for Europe is extremely eager to engage with the Commission and relevant stakeholders to maximise synergies and avoid duplication of efforts towards these goals.  Regarding the options for EU interventions, current preference for Seaweed for Europe would be option 2 or 3, recognising that the development of the algae sector in Europe will require significant support and reforms from policy makers and regulators, at national level but also at the European one.   In conclusion, Seaweed for Europe is highly supportive of this EC initiative and is available for any further working session, interview, joint problem solving if considered relevant by the Commission. feedback_msg_text: The EU funded H2020 project MacroFuels has achieved numerous breakthroughs along the seaweed-to-bioenergy values chain and identified key areas with further development needs, mainly in seaweed cultivation (and processing). The project further provided policy recommendations for a future sustainable algae industry in Europe with special attention to environmental and social impacts. These recommendations can be found on the MacroFuels website as Policy Briefs and Fact Sheets.  MacroFuels has demonstrated the technical feasibility of producing bio-ethanol, bio-butanol and a furanic-based diesel additive from seaweed. In each of those cases, a seaweed species and a project-specific cultivation system and conversion technology were chosen, further developed and assessed in terms of conceptual economic viability. In addition, an overall environmental assessment was performed for each value chain. MacroFuels made the first steps towards a seaweed-bioenergy chain at larger scales, so naturally several areas have been identified for which major improvements are needed and can realistically be achieved, either by optimizing processes, by upscaling or by making adjustments to the systems of choice. Especially with respect to the cultivation of macroalgae, major improvements in terms of environmental impact can be achieved by optimizing the design and materials of the cultivation system, by improving the productivity of the selected seaweed, and by selecting adequate species-specific cultivation areas/zones. Processing methods that avoid the use of acids and/or base can greatly improve the overall sustainability performance of the conversion process. The MacroFuels sustainability assessment excluded the potential benefits of carbon sequestration (by the seaweed), ecosystem restoration (by removing excess nutrient for instance) and ILUC, which may add to an improved overall sustainability of algae cultivation and need to be further assessed in the future. These factors can potentially make significant contributions to the overall positive environmental impact, but could also be of interest for the economic feasibility of algae cultivation, for example if (public) incentives for ecosystem services are considered as business models of the future.   The MacroFuels project based on its research findings supports Option 2 of the consultation. Feedback from: MacroFuels (H2020 Project) (3.7 MB - PDF - 65 pages) Download
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Although we understand the notion to place rules onto seaweed industry, it is important to mention that this industry is unique to each country. Seaweed utilization might be growing industry in Sweden, however the scale is very small compared to other counties.  In Sweden is the seaweed industry relatively young, with wild picking sector and sea-farming sector.  The wild pick is done on a very small scale, exclusively BY HAND and by a handful of small companies due to the difficult conditions. It is unlikely that the scale will rise exponentially.  The seaweed is mostly picked for high-end restaurants, and as an exclusive goods for private sector. The seaweed is always collected with regard to sustainability and to the environment, keeping in mind how important the seaweed ecosystem is to the coastal ecology. We cannot see that the wild harvest is harmful to the wild seaweed population in Sweden. The scale of the harvest very unlikely disrupts the ecological roles and benefits that seaweed provides.  Seafarms in Sweden DO NOT use fertilizers in seaweed cultivation. Using fertilizer in Seaweed is an outdated practice from Asia. However, the potential of using Seaweed AS a natural fertilizer is one of the possible outcomes of future sea-farming.
Organisation: Svenskt vattenbruk och sjömat/ Swedish aquaculture and Seafood

feedback_msg_text: EABA Presentation The general objective of the European Algae Biomass Association (EABA) is to promote mutual interchange and cooperation in the field of biomass production and use. It aims at creating, developing, and maintaining solidarity and links between its 130 members. The document entitled: Blue bioeconomy - towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector is extremely comprehensive. It demonstrates both an unfailing understanding of our profession and proof of fruitful exchanges. EABA is of course in favor of point 2 extended to point 3.  Continuing in this logic of bringing together all the players. The main failure that threatens emerging areas is the emergence of fragmented ambitions that arise from encounters or easy dreams of opportunity.  Top 10 most relevant growth factors for this sector 1 - Public awareness about algae biomass: Impact VERY HIGH.  A communication strategy declined at various level. This point is a crucial one. The tentative and pending tender FORalgae offered a large hope and should be reconsidered. 2 - Novel Food approval for new product development: Impact VERY HIGH.  EABA welcomes the capacity or the European Union to structure this protective policy. The stakeholders cannot understand the spending of millions in research projects in algae projects without a share in getting novel food approvals. Novel Food approval should be included in pre-market projects. 3 - Unknown approval and regulatory status of many species: Impact HIGH.  Totally linked with point #2, an equal protection should be thought to make the imports into EU respecting the same rules protecting the European consumers. As such, the EU Food catalog is probably outdated and regulatory issues could be simplified.  4 - Standardization related with Algae Biomass: MEDIUM The initiative taken at the European level and coordinated by the CEN will help in getting a common framework and allow a more precise exchange. This process will require future financing for extension and widening of scope. The pending tender FORalgae should be reconsidered as already stated. 5 - Production licensing: Impact HIGH.  This is especially important for seaweed cultivation. The lack of a regulatory framework and environmental impact assessment studies across Europe are a major constrain. The EC could sponsor a comparative study of regulatory frameworks with SMART evaluation of algae biomass production facilities. 6 - Research, Development, and Innovation: Impact MEDIUM The EC has been very active in fostering the R, D and I. The ideas toward favoring jobs (incubators) could help promote more qualified jobs for the industry. A better integration with the EIT and BBI related projects will have a relevant impact in the sector, with special focus on food related applications. 7 - Taxes and related trade complexity: Impact MEDIUM. Through equivalence or bilateral agreements, certain trade flows suffer from an imbalance. Import-Export remain complex for European products. The EC could sponsor a comparative study of regulatory frameworks with SMART evaluation of algae biomass tax framework. 8 - Unequal and unfair regulations for imported algae: Impact MEDIUM. Imported algae are not subject to the same constrains as European Algae. A wide range of algae products, not approved for food consumption in Europe, are imported. The same happens with certifications, as organic certifications, that have unclear rules of approval in the countries of origin. 9 - Technology bottlenecks: Impact HIGH  Many bottlenecks remain and which will have to be undertaken in order to bring in the seaweed world in an even more professional and profitable era. 10 - Carbon credits for the algae biomass sector: Impact HIGH Algae are the major players in the carbon cycle at the planetary level. Microalgae technology could be competitive for this purpose if the emission rights market reaches expected costs of approximately 50 €/tn CO 2 in the near future (2030).
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: La Chambre Syndicale des Algues et des Végétaux Marins, organisation professionnelle, regroupe 232 entreprises françaises de valorisation et de transformation des algues. Elles les achètent auprès des récoltants, les récoltent ou les cultivent elles-mêmes. Elle représente près de 1000 équivalents temps plein pour un chiffre d’affaires cumule cumulé de près de 300m€ par an. L’ensemble de ces entreprises revendique un savoir-faire et une capacité d’innovation de pointe dans des domaines aussi divers que l’extraction de polymères gélifiants, l’alimentation humaine, la nutrition, la cosmétique, la thalassothérapie, l’agriculture, la pharmacie.  Les axes de travail de la chambre sont :  Gestion de la ressource/ Développement de l’algoculture.  La France produit plus de 70 000 t de macro-algues par an. Elle est le dixième pays producteur d’algues dans le monde et la majorité de sa biomasse algale provient de ressources sauvages. Environ 5000 tonnes sont actuellement récoltées à pied sur l’estran lors des grandes marées, par des récoltants professionnels. Cela représente 78 entreprises et près de 300 récoltants chaque année.  Face à la montée en puissance de la demande d'algues en France mais aussi à travers le monde, l'algoculture apparait pour beaucoup comme la solution d'avenir pour fournir des algues en quantité et de manière durable. La production issue de l’algoculture est destinée à des marchés à fortes valeurs ajoutées ainsi qu'à l'alimentation. L’algoculture est une activité durable et son développement doit ainsi permettre de préserver les habitats, d’anticiper les impacts du changement climatique, et de soutenir la croissance des territoires. Il s’agit de porter collectivement ce message afin de faciliter l’émergence de projets durables et concertés. La chambre souhaite pouvoir travailler sur le développement de l’algoculture avec les groupes de travail européen. La réglementation bio  Le marché de l’alimentation bio se développe dans toute l’Europe. L’entrée en vigueur du règlement européen Bio 710/2009 en juillet 2010, a permis à des entreprises de récolte et de culture de se convertir au label Bio, demande très forte de la profession. Cependant, la révision actuelle de ce règlement apporte de nombreuses inquiétudes et pourrait mettre à mal la récolte labelisée Bio. La Chambre syndicale a déposé un avis sur la plateforme de l’EU (Avis sur le futur de la production biologique dans l’UE – Sollicitation de la commission Européenne).  Le marché Les algues européennes sont concurrencées par les algues d’importation (moins couteuses). (Chili, Argentine, Pays asiatiques). Les algues d’importation sont souvent riches en métaux lourds et ne répondant pas toujours aux exigences européennes. La CSAVM a lancé depuis 2 ans une étude cofinancée par la région Bretagne et des fonds européens qui afin d’améliorer les connaissances tant au niveau de la consommation que de la contamination des algues alimentaires.  Les algues françaises sont gage de sécurité pour les consommateurs. Il faut que l’Europe continue à promouvoir l’algue en aidant au financement des projets de recherche. Les cadres réglementaires mis en place dans de nombreux secteurs ont paralysé de nombreux projets industriels innovants  Il est important que l’Europe lève les freins en matière de réglementation et obstacles administratifs afin de permettre le développent de la filière Algues en Europe et permettre ainsi d’être plus concurrentiel face aux algues d’importation.   Le caractère local doit être pris en compte dans son substrat, sa qualité d’eau, son environnement économique pour ajuster le « COMMENT » localement même si les termes sont communs à l’union. Les pratiques traditionnelles ancrent le métier, le justifient. Le cadre commun permet d’orienter l’innovation et d’adopter le même langage.  La Chambre syndicale opte donc pour l’option 2 afin d’harmoniser la réglementation européenne sur les algues et ce dans le but vde promouvoir et développer la filière Algues.
Organisation: Chambre Syndicale des Algues et Végétaux Marins
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector
organisation_lower: chambre syndicale des algues et végétaux marins

feedback_msg_text: APG group is active in microalgae production since 2009; the integrated facility in Camporosso (Imperia – Italy) with one hectare microalgae facility is an example of circular economy including renewable source CHP (combined heat and power) and vegetable oil biorefinery in the same site where the biggest italian microalgae farm is located. With the subsidiary Archimede Ricerche, APG through AeA Fratelli Parodi Spa invested 12 M€ in microalgae industrialisation, also benefiting from EU FP7 and H2020 projects, and building proprietary microalgae processing technology, together with a relevant contribution to european landscape of microalgae industry development and youth training. We believe microalgae farming and processing will play relevant role in european blue bioeconomy with threefold applications: 1. Food and feed, 2. Natural active principles, 3. Biomass for renewable energy. APG is working hard to make microalgae industry in Europe competitive; to this goal, it is mandatory to make biomass affordable through its strenghts (ability to grow without fertile land, to absorb CO2 and grow with a few salts), fixing its weaknesses (high capex of farming and processing technology, which is still at infant stage making it labor intensive), taking opportunities (aquaculture needs fishmeal substitutes, climate crisis) and addressing weaknesses (regulatory constraints, unfair global competition). However to foster scale up of microalgae farming, industrial developments call for progress in technology in order to reduce production cost; therefore APG is in favour of option 3 addressing three goals: 1. valorization of the CO2 savings generated by the production of microalgae, encouraging the purification and reuse systems of the CO2 emissions of electrical or thermal energy production; 2. increase of the number of microalgae species authorized as novel food by action and at the expense of EU bodies, such as JRC and EFSA, to enlarge food applications; 3. enhancement and incentive of innovative production systems that allow a reduction in production costs (today one of the main obstacles to the commercial development of the sector) and an increase in productivity. Carbon footprint of microalgae biomass should be evaluated in comparison with conventional crops and especially fossil resources along the full production cycle, including all externalities, and not only with reference to CO2 fixed in biomass by photosynthesis. Indeed CO2 must come from emissions to make sustainable microalgae, otherwise the full process generates more CO2 then the fixed amount because of the unavoidable needs of energy of farming and harvesting, which generate additional CO2.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Being a stakeholder of the microalgae scene since 2013 we observed that the scene is still highly academic driven. Several micro algae cultivators which are using closed photobioreactors are spin offs from academic institutions or they are close related to them. It is obvious that a continuous and significant academic input is required to improve the cultivation strands as well as the bio refinery processes. To increase the production of microalgae and open that business to a large group of stakeholder it is essential that all over Europe farmers and further interested persons should have the chance to create business opportunities in this field. Hence micro algae cultivation systems are needed which allows a high efficiency, being long lasted, manageable from farmers and affordable to finance from them.  Typically farming is a seasonable business and therefore the farmers would be able to take over installation work of a cultivation reactor especially if this can be shifted in those periods where the farmers core business do not require that much attention. If the farmer participates during the assembly of a microalgae cultivation system which they will operate afterwards by themselves, the following benefits will take part: - The farmers can provide a high valued work also outside of their season - Participating on the assembly process they can reduce the procurement costs and consequently the amount of loans they have to take to finance the cultivation system - Due to their participating at the assembly process they will also learn how to operate and repair the systems later on. Integrating access CO2 and nutrients from biogas systems allows in many cases to establish a circular economy. Biogas systems are spread all over in agriculturally areas and can very often be integrated in such approaches.  We cannot deny that the microalgae cultivation is complex and requires a complex controlling system. Additionally the cultivation reactors are different in respect of the geographical location. While the cultivation in southern regions can be made outdoors, in northern areas it will be more indoors. For southern regions the microalgae cultivation in closed systems is very attractive because of the low amount of water but the cultivations must be cooled very often to avoid overheating. In northern areas the overheating is a smaller problem but the production period can be elongate by cultivating in greenhouses. Additionally different microalgae species can be used to adapt to the appropriate geographic and thermal conditions.  Even that it is difficult to define one and only type of photobioreactors for every task; we managed to create a modular construction system where completely different systems can be realized but always using the same components. The nature of our on-site production of the required pipes allows the farmers to participate onto the assembly of their photobioreactor systems by taking over the installation of the holding devices and others. Compared to classical crop, microalgae cultivations provide a much higher efficiency. However this requires very controlled cultivation parameters. Even small deviations from them lead to a large degradation of the results. Many different parameters have to be controlled to ensure to reach an optimal result. Therefore it is for the stakeholders still a high financial risk because it is difficult to operate a large scale reactor in an optimal range. Hence the farmers as potential customers should have the chance to validate a system upfront with pilot scale reactors and/or the financial risk to fail should be part wise covered.  The farmers in question are our potential customers and we are confident that many of them would step into the challenging microalgae cultivation if either we would guaranty for the cultivation results or there risk would be part wise covered from public assistance. Both approaches require a public co-funding. Feedback from: Algoliner GmbH & Co. KG (2.9 MB - PDF - 19 pages) Download
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Severino Becagli is a SME producing Organic Spirulina in Tuscany since 2016. In 2018 we started cooperation with selected partners to produce spirulina based or erniched food (i.e. chocolate, pasta, honey, beer, pecorino cheese..). We believe algae could be the food of the future helping an eco-sustainable economy. Referred to the problems enlighted by the document, it should be specified that the “Regulatory gaps” are only a part of the regulatory problems, in the sense that the simple application of already existing Regualtions could help EU algae producers. For example, no EU or Country Member Authority check the application to the algae products of the REGULATION (EU) No 1379/2013 estabilishing in particular in art.35 that the information regarding “the area where the product was caught or farmed…” is MANDATORY. This could strongly help European producers ensuring consumers that EU health regualtion and organic regulation (where needed) are applied. Infact, the main problem in gaining space in the market for EU microalgae producers is that the extra-EU producers usually have low price (often paired with very low quality products) since they don’t follow EU Regulations. Following the actual general EU labelling Regulation 1169/2011 there is no need to give any information regarding the place of farming. Particularly, we think that Organic Regulation (EU) 2018/848 makes the production of organic micro algae barely impossible (i.e. use of high soluble nutrients is not allowed) meanwhile non-EU manufacturers can export organic microalgae to the EU market under the equivalence regime. We agree with “Objectives and Policy options” - Option 2 even if it is not clear how point 1) “Improving regulatory and governance frame work”, that we strongly recommend, matches with the last paragraph of the same option 2 (The option does not include potential regulatory measures).
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: We will soon find in our kitchen tables tarmae, insects, and algae. Especially the algae are considered by FAO as the food of the future. Let’s focus on the microalgae, visible through a microscope, find their habitat both in brackish and freshwaters. Rich in proteins and vitamins, they are certainly of great interest, finding application both as food supplements and as a source of important raw materials for human and animal nutrition. Microalgae can be grown in open tanks or in closed reactors, also called photobioreactors. The strong point of their cultivation is environmental sustainability, as they can be grown in brackish water that cannot be used for agricultural or civil purposes.  Microalgae transform their nutrients – also known as medium -  into biomass, from which protein feed, fertilizers, biofuels, and bioactive molecules are obtained. These molecules can be sources of dyes, antioxidants, antibiotics, anticancer, antiviral, and immunostimulants.  Although the properties of the microalga Spirulina Arthrospira platensis are renowned, those of the chlorella species - Chlorella vulgaris e C. pyrenoidosa, still not well known to the general public, have been discovered only recently and in the last decades its production is intensifying. According to a study conducted by HTF Research, the global microalgae market is worth 600 billion $, estimated to reach 1 billion in 2025. Italy is taking interest in this market, diverting public funding to support start-ups and projects aimed at the production of microalgae. This is the case of CALL HUB sPATIALS3, a project funded in the context of the POR-FESR 2014-2020: Call HUB Research and Innovation of the Lombardy Region, with the aim of improving agri-food production and promoting technological innovation for healthy, safe, and sustainable food, involving companies, universities, and research institutions in Lombardy.  Among them, our company, Eco-Zinder, one of the main companies producing raw materials from industrial residues, aims to optimize the production of microalgal biomass in a pilot plant, intended for the development of bakery products and evaluate the possibility of developing a plant for the production of Chlorella algae at food-grade. However, although the objectives of the project are remarkable, the authorities find it difficult to keep up with new technologies, the advancement of scientific research, progressively apply clear, uniform, and appropriate legislation, facilitating interpretation, stimulating integrated action between authorities, companies, research organizations, and consumers. Only by providing a uniform voice to all components of the market, with a legal and defined framework, it will be possible to rationally address the food challenges of the future without affecting the delicate ecosystems of the earth.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: GNT is a Dutch family-owned company producing Coloring Foods. GNT´s EXBERRY brand is the leading brand of Coloring Foods for the food and beverage industry.   Coloring Foods are made from fruits, vegetables, and edible plants using a physical manufacturing process only and water as extraction medium. GNT has 390 employees working in 11 countries worldwide serving customers in around 60 countries.  EXBERRY is produced in GNT´s two state of the art production facilities in the Netherlands and Germany.   GNT`s first Exberry Blue based on Spirulina (Arthrospira platensis) hit the market in 1994. With its new EXBERRY® spirulina factory in Mierlo, opened in 2018, GNT owns the largest Spirulina processing line in the world.   Based on our very own company mission “Nature has so much to give – we make it available to our customers providing food ingredients consumers trust “we want to exploit the full potential and color palette of nature.  As one of the forerunners in Spirulina and industrial algae biomass processing, GNT is a proud member of the EABA.   We as company see challenges in the following fields:  - Regulatory barriers, especially in the food sector. Many interesting species and strains are waiting to unleash their potential but fall by the wayside because approval as a Novel Food can be too lengthy and cost intensive. It must be possible to simplify the process while still guaranteeing safety.    - Lack of networking and utilization of potential industry synergies due to a missing blue bioeconomy strategy in the EU   Whereas the advantages of a blue, microalgae-based bioeconomy are obvious:  - Huge potential of economic cascade use/ extraction of valuable compounds, if other proteins (even if bulk proteins) and poly unsaturated fatty acids are utilized as well  - Incorporation of the whole biomass and/ or purified(e.g.) proteins and fibers in high moisture extruded meat analogues  - Circular economy: Use of food production side streams for cultivation; with a significant waste reduction along the food value chain   - No competition with conventional agriculture for arable farmland  - Strongly increasing consumer acceptance   - Sustainability – Carbon benefits   - And many more
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Synpa, the French Specialty Food Ingredients Association thanks the European Commission for this public consultation and welcomes the proposal of EU for developping the production of algae and their use.    The Synpa gathers 22 companies either small (SME) or large which produce specialty food ingredients. These ingredients are used for their technological, nutritional, environmental or organoleptic properties. Most of specialty food ingredients have to go through an authorization procedure before they can be put on the market. These procedures aim at checking the safety and the benefits of the ingredients.  Some of our members use seaweeds and microalgae as starting materials.  We are in favor of option 3 « Targeted activities to support the sustainable growth of the algae sector including regulatory measures ».   We would like to share the below comments:   • Firstly it seems important to us to describe in the preamble that the blue bioeconomy deals with both sectors: seaweeds and microalgae.  • On the regulatory aspects:  - In the food area, sectoral regulations already exist to regulate the use of algae in the food chain such as Regulation (EC) N°1333/2008 on food additives, Regulation (EC) N°2015/2283 on novel food, Regulation (EC)N°1332/2008 on food enzymes or Regulation (EC)N°1924/2006 on nutrition and health claims made on food...  - We agree with the fact that it’s important to set up guidelines for good production practices.  - Then it’s important to support the competitiveness of small algae-producing companies, through assistance or a support system by facilitating the construction of dossiers (novel food, health claim…).  • On the environmental impacts aspects and in particular on decarbonisation issues: - Growth of algae requires carbon dioxide.  In order to target the food market, these carbon dioxide inputs must be food grade quality. For microalgae producers to be able to capture CO2 from emitting industries, innovation programs should be set up to develop gas treatment systems at the factory outlet to make them food grade quality. - It could be interesting to consider decarbonizing the energy necessary to run industries by coupling these activities with carbon-free energy production systems such as the installation of wind turbines, photovoltaic panels, methanizers, etc.  • On the social impacts aspects: - The establishment of a web portal providing information and strengthening this by the development of a harmonized European communication project could be a very interesting initiative to promote the algae sector.
Organisation: Synpa, the French Specialty Food Ingredients Association
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: The potential of microalgae-based products and their environmental impacts are well known. Focus is required on measures to unlock the industry, rather than proving its value.  SuSeWi Ltd has developed and proven a breakthrough technology that produces microalgae on ultra-large scale. It is a completely natural process, using only sunlight, seawater and CO2 in desert locations. A full life cycle analysis shows that substituting our algae for an equivalent unit of fishmeal or plants would reduce carbon footprint by 95%. We have the technology and sufficient land to build a 70,000 ton/annum system.  As with most other companies innovating in microalgae, we are an SME. The EU initiative must recognise the challenge inherent in this and  take measures to actively support SME innovation: stimulate the availability of capital from risk-averse capital markets; reduce lengthy regulatory processes and complexity in bringing products to market; stimulate food and feed industry support; and introduce carbon pricing into food and feed.  There are some specific barriers to delivering the promise of microalgae, which this EU initiative could address: 1. Regulatory barriers: the approval process to use (completely natural) algae as an ingredient is burdensome and lengthy. The adjusted approval process for the Covid vaccine proves that, where there is the will, regulatory processes can be sped up and simplified without compromising safety. If the EU's attitude to the climate change emergency was the same as Covid (which we believe it should), the EU should streamline, speed up and simplify the regulations regarding the use of algae in food and feed. Our products could reach market in 50% of the time and at far lower capital cost. Part of this is the regulation, but a part is also the ultra-slow bureaucratic approvals process. 2. Carbon Pricing: We know that agriculture produces 26% of total carbon emissions. Industrial customers buy ingredients without carbon impact pricing, negatively impacting the competitiveness of algae products. The carbon emissions caused, for example, by soya and fishmeal are not paid for by the feed/ food industry and are borne entirely by the environment. The carbon benefits our algae delivers - the 95% saving on emissions - therefore gets no recognition in price. The EU should fix this immediately (not just for algae) by introducing full carbon pricing/tax on commodity ingredients. Alternatively, if a carbon tax is considered politically unacceptable, then the fiscus should give a rebate on the use of algae-based products. The same is true for ocean-degradation impacts (like over-fishing). 3. SME support pricing: we have proven a fishmeal substitute product which grows salmon better than fishmeal. However, industrial feed customers expect us to provide that product at Least Cost Formulation pricing. In other words, at a price competitive with existing commodities - like fishmeal and soy protein concentrate - being produced at massive scale by mature industries already down the cost curve. This is true also in human food products. This causes the algae industry to reach profitability via higher value, niche products. This causes the algae producers to become low volume, high technology producers, negatively impacts scaling. The EU should offer incentives to food and feed companies supporting high-volume algae substitutes (perhaps via tax breaks). 4. Unlocking Capital for scaling: The EU has significant capital available to invest. However, it is mostly locked away from SME's in the DFI's, which are not supporting the industry because they are limited to investing in mature, profitable companies. The World Bank's funds are risk averse; and the GCF has complexities. Create an algae fund to co-invest or provide guarantees alongside private sector investors.  5. Cluster building: China, in a few short years, has out-grown the EU industry by orders of magnitude as a result of systematic support to the cluster as a whole.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Production of micro and macro algae whilst technically challenging on many fronts offer great commercial, social and economic benefits.  As with all emerging industries there are many more questions than answers however; the ongoing support of the EU and bodies such as the EABA, Algae UK etc bring together a collective consciousness and a drive to resolve the key barriers to the establishment of a robust emerging industry.  On going multi agency support is fundamental.  Improved social and consumer awareness, academic innovation and committed entrepreneurialism are steadily enhancing the viability of this sector.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: In our opinion, the main reason for the “under-exploitation of expertise…despite the significant support by EU funding” is due to the EU IP system. The actual IP policy not only is unfair for taxpayers that finance the research but creates protected knowledge boxes that remain not generating value for the patent protection time. Patent filling was converted into a business where every idea is patentable, the field is full of non-sense patents filled by universities and research centers (payed with public money), laying in a shelf. The industry is still moving to much around R&D, everybody is pushed to patent, professors and researchers need to patent, start-ups think they need patents to build the business, EU tell us that we must patent,…, at the end we are full of useless patents that delay the industry development. The same is happening with the strains, very few are domesticated to fit intensive production systems, a lot of people is working with the same species and improving it, but unfortunately, nobody share the strains. The taxpayers are paying for strains development but not profiting from it. It is dramatic when a public money payed institution, with 100% subsidized research from EU, produce a valuable result that is a tradable good and nobody will be able to use it due to IP protection. In our opinion, patents generated from public money, should be public, the EU should create a patent holding office and fill all the patents in the name of EU, for EU companies to use; the patent author is the same researcher (ok for CV) but the patent ownership is the EU; the same with the organisms. We agree with the proposed activities, option 2, nevertheless we would like to add: - Be careful with organic microalgae. Unlike superior plants, microalgae live within the culture media, so as the product is in direct contact with the nutrient, the use of manure and organic matter can induce uncontrolled microorganisms’ blooms that will be harvested with the microalgae. Also, consumers will buy a product that was in direct contact with manure. This is most important when importing biomass from outside EU;they use the normal agriculture organic certification standards.  - Caution should be taken when talking about sustainability in microalgae production as there are a lot of biomass that is produced by heterotrophy and not by phototrophy; the difference should be noticeable. - It is of most importance that all the imported algae biomass also follow EU Regulations. Without that EU producers will be outcompeted. This is most important for online sales as a lot of packed product in small volumes are getting into EU. - The EU support for Novel Foods application is the most important issue in our opinion. Support, in the form of grants, should be given to producer associations rather than to individual companies. Novel Food also give protection for those that make the application, nevertheless if the support is from public money, it should serve all the companies through the producer associations. - An important issue that is missing, is the support for the approval of the innovations regulatory framework. The time to the market is so long, that it will not be an innovation when regulation is done; it is probable that some Chinese company, get the product into EU, before an EU company to be authorized to produce it. This happens in every activity, a “fast track for regulation of innovations” mechanism is necessary. - In Option 2(5), an important issue is missing, a bottleneck that the industry face, the contamination management and control. It is desirable to have specific framework to deal with this issue. We also agree with the proposed actions in Option 3, those are very important, specially the “Binding targets for substitution of fish-based fish feed”; without targets and strong pressure to replace fish meal, that will never happen, as it is almost impossible to compete with fish meal in terms of price and nutritional profile.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Algae, micro and macro algae, including sea grass are an important renewable resource for pharma, food, feed, cosmetic and technical applications. They can act also as CO2 trap and source for oxygen. They are playing also a major role in “water cleaning” and protecting costal shore line by fixing the ground. Also macro algae are an important habitat for small marine live stock. It is necessary to find a good balance between protection of environment, seaweed farming and using natural, wild resources as well. For industrial process and investments it is necessary to have security to continue ongoing activities like harvesting and the options to grow business. Many properties and opportunities of Algae are still unexplored, it might be good not to restrictive to continue this research and the industrial use after.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Dear, we are starting the microalgae production on our farm, to recycle the CO² (produced by combusting the methane) of the farm and grow microalgae with it. Most people do not have an idea why we do this. It would be better for sales, if they did! We want to produce food with our chlorella ingredients. Developing  improved  algae  processing  systems  (biorefineries),processing algae into multiple  products and for multiple applications, would be necessary because right now it costs so much to do this, that we can not do this profitable. Furthermore even only drying the algae (to be able to preserve them for a longer time) costs way to much. And the drying process has a huge electric consumption. The latter shows that better down stream processing will be necessary for a sustainable blue economy! Kind regards, Kris Heirbaut.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Tang Det er en udfordring at i gangsætte et nyt erhverv som tangdyrkning i Grønland. Det er ikke gennemsigtigt hvad en producent skal gøre, og tager mange ressourcer fra hvervets egentlige mål om at dyrke, producere tang og sælge tang. Det ideelle ville være at myndighederne havde en transperent tilgængelig service, så producenten kan koncentrere sig om sin kerneopgave, nemlig at producere og sælge tang. Meget forskning har vist at tang er en sund fødevare, men at få kundens interesse i tang er meget svær. Så derfor vil det være en stor hjælp at der bliver sat fokus på tang, på linje med andre kampagner om at spise mindre kød, at spise varieret og at spise mere grønt. Så kan EU hjæpe med at gøre tang tilgængeligt og mainstream, så den enkelte lille producent ikke skal stå alene med det.  I Sselvstyrets egen hjemmeside, står der at - Ansøgning om høsttilladelse sker ved henvendelse til APNN landbrugsafdeling - Ansøgning om produktion sker ved hendvendelse til veterinærafdelingen - Ansøgning om eksporttilladelser sker ved henvendelse til Departementet for erhverv Ved dyrkning af tang skal man endvidere sørge for at indhente tilladelse i kommunen. - Ansøgning om arealtildeling for dyrkning af tang sker til pågældende kommune Egne erfaringer fra diverse seminarer og workshops i EU sammenhænge og nordisk samarbejde sammenhænge kan sammenfattes til nedenstående tabel om EU lovgivninger der skal tages i betragtning. feedback_msg_text: The future of the world's food is algae. Algae will not replace the terrestrial counterpart. They will complement and allow a strong increase in the production of edible biomass. Land plants are a small part of the global plant family. In the aquatic world, a greater diversity has remained with families of photosynthetic organisms that have never reached the emerged landscape. Red algae, brown algae, golden algae and many more are plant groups that never reached the emerged landscape. This diversity of algae is still under-explored and for the most part unexploited, offering vast possibilities of application. In addition, in a global context where the climate challenge is becoming more and more critical, marine resources can offer many solutions to reduce our environmental impact. The farm-to-fork strategy for sustainable food expressed in the European Green Deal strategy provides a clear overview of the future path for algae. The key words are safety, sustainability, climate change, environmental protection, preservation of biodiversity, waste recovery, nutritional value. Algae answer ALL of these statements. Safety, with many algae considered in the food list. Sustainability because the algae are cultivated at sea or the culture is carried out in controlled terrestrial ponds or very large photobioreactors. In the case of harvested algae, the management of offshore fields has been very effective for decades and has shown our ability to use this wild supply very effectively. Climate-friendly, because algae consume CO2 and capture it to build their own structure. Protect the environment and biodiversity: Either because oceanic forests are shelters, because the strains are protected in numerous crop collections, or because culture of algae does not steal arable land. The cultivation of algae downstream of industrial or municipal wastewater is one of the most promising means of bioremediation, as several research projects funded by the EU prove today. Finally, algae, in bulk or as a functional feed (replacement for fish meal) or food (nutraceuticals) will be the major players for centuries to come. This industry is now about to strongly take off and needs continuity in support from the European Union. After the huge help to develop production capacities, the EU can help create a processing and formulation industry, as well as thoroughly reconsider the administrative obstacles and regulations (Novel food, Organics, Biostimulants……) which not only hamper development in Europe but too often offer a competitive advantage to foreign countries outside Europe. In light of this extraordinary set of possibilities and the important scientific output that goes with it, the world of algae clearly has a tangible future ahead of it. This future, companies like ALGAMA will play their full part thanks to a winning combination. Supporting the EABA effort in the gathering of the European forces. Building a powerful platform allowing the implementation of flagship projects and commercial successes conferring to Algama a unique position. https://algamafoods.com/
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Monokultivering i stor skala på land har vist sig at have massive negative følgevirkninger for miljø, dyrevelfærd og sundhed. Det forholder sig ikke anderledes i havet. Afgrødeproduktion kan imidlertid - på land såvel som i vand - tilrettelægges i mindre dyrkningsenheder med kultivering af flere forskellige afgrøder. Herved opnås et mindre miljøaftryk, styrkelse af lokale værdikæder og en højere kvalitet.  Havhøst foreslår som følge heraf, at man i forbindelse med øget fokus på anvendelse af makroalger til en lang række formål, sætter fokus på kultivering af ressourcen i mindre skala, hvor mange mindre producenter knyttes sammen i netværkslignende produktionsfællesskaber omkring en fælles hub, der kan aftage havbøndernes afgrøder, stå for eventuel forarbejdning og videresælge til forskellige markeder. På den måde opnår vi fordelene ved lav-intens kultivering og får samtidig fordelene ved at kunne afsætte i større skala.   Det giver god mening at dyrke tang i samme anlæg, der også anvendes til kultivering af andre "regenerative" afgrøder som muslinger og østers. Og hvis man hjælper små fiskere i gang med at etablere havkultivering i lille skala som supplement til deres fiskeri, så får man også løst en stor udfordring for det kystnære fiskeri, der er ekstremt presset af den europæiske kvotepolitik, dalende fiskebestande og problemer med rekruttering ind i erhvervet.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: Algae and in particular Seaweed are the biomass of the future! There are not many equivalents to seaweed resource in terms of raw material for, at the same, sustaining food production, enabling strong innovation for many markets and in parallel, reducing carbon print. Seaweeds are all from natural strains, capturing carbon dioxide to produce organic matter and releasing dioxygen in coastal shoreline that are crucial for marine life but also many coastal communities. In addition seaweed do not require arable land, nor water, nor fertilizers or pesticides in order to grow and reproduce. in addition, the reproduction cycle of several valuable seaweed species has been domesticated and is now well used to develop a new aquaculture economy in Europe. In the past 30 years, marine ecology, processing techniques, analytical practices and novel lifestyles have created the right environment to take this very valuable biomass existing for millions of years at the European doorsteps and bring it to a very valuable biomass. The agrifood industry can grow and diversify from this resource based on the hydrocolloid compounds already produced and commercialized in many daily formulations but also via polysaccharide prebiotics, extended nutritive value and new vegetable proteins. Indirectly, through the agrobusiness development such as plant biostimulant or animal feed, seaweed will also greatly contribute to higher production quality with less chemical intrants and more natural active compounds towards immune system enhancement in particular. Applications in green fibers, biodegradable bioplastics, 3D printing, microencapsulation and water treatment are also growing for a good share of the seaweed industry residues in particular. Finally, as only a small share of existing species has been studied and commercially used, a huge gap in innovation remains to be done to accelerate the discovery of the coming novel food ingredients, new natural bioactives and antimicrobial products, including antiviral products and the pharmaceuticals of tomorrow. So far, if the EU has funded and helped in the structure of an emerging algae value chain in Europe especially at the research level, helping many different low TRL projects. Now, the need to accelerate with interdisciplinary sectors to drive those evolutions is very strong. The regulatory frameworks in place, which are mandatory for an impartial and healthy long term activity in all those sectors, has however paralyzed many innovative industrial projects. Indeed Reach requirements, Novel Food requirements, National regulation limitations have indeed limited those developments at industrial and commercial scale. Algae can be the best example of local circular and biobased industry but the lack of support to sustain commercial technical development directly in local coastal communities where the first value is created has led to a great uncertainty among all the actors of the value chain and in particular, the industrial groups which can create and sustain the demand.  An EU Algae sectors has therefore emerged from the Eu research projects but the real economy creating value for all local communities and benefiting to all Europeans have to go now by a structured value chain development on which SME's and ETI which can drive the growth of this very remarkable example of valuing an extraordinary biomass under the biobased circular economy. this is where EU has definitely a role to play.
Initiative: Blue bioeconomy – towards a strong and sustainable EU algae sector

feedback_msg_text: V otázke určovania rodičovstva vychádza právny poriadok Slovenskej republiky, ako i mnohých ďalších krajín EÚ, z biologickej reality. Dieťa má dvoch rodičov, otca (ktorým je vždy muž) a matku (ktorou je vždy žena). Matkou je žena, ktorá dieťa porodila, a otcom je muž, ktorý dieťa splodil. Pre dieťa je najlepšie, ak môže vyrastať v nenarušenej rodine (intact family) so svojimi biologickými rodičmi, ktorí sú zosobášení. Každá iná forma rodičovstva nedosahuje také dobré výsledky, ako práve nenarušená rodina založená manželstvom. Muži a ženy prinášajú do vzájomného vzťahu i do výchovy dieťaťa osobitné dary. Je v najlepšom záujme dieťaťa, aby mohlo vyrastať s oboma svojimi rodičmi, teda s matkou i otcom.  V prípade ak dieťa nemá rodiča/rodičov (z dôvodu smrti, straty rodičovských práv, alebo z dôvodu, že sú neznámi), právo umožňuje tzv. náhradné rodičovstvo, teda adopciu dieťaťa. Vychádza pritom z najlepšieho záujmu dieťaťa, ktorým je stabilná rodina s otcom aj mamou. Pri adopcii ide o to, aby sa pre dieťa našli vhodní náhradní rodičia (hľadáme rodičov pre dieťa, nie naopak). Pri tom sa právo snaží čo najviac odzrkadľovať štruktúru skutočnej biologickej rodiny, teda zabezpečiť prítomnosť matky aj otca. Žiaľ, niektoré krajiny EÚ neuznávajú tieto oprávnené záujmy dieťaťa a priznaním rodičovského statusu pre dve osoby rovnakého pohlavia ochudobňujú dieťa buď o matku, alebo o otca, ako aj o možnosť vidieť rodinný život muža a ženy. Zamýšľané nariadenie by zásadným spôsobom zasiahlo do práv národných štátov určovať svoju rodinnú politiku, no najmä by znamenalo rozšírenie problémových foriem adopcií osobami rovnakého pohlavia do krajín, ktoré takúto legislatívu úplne legitímne odmietajú. Európska únia by sa tak stala nástrojom na šírenie ideologicky motivovaných deformácií rodinného práva. Ak niekto nie je rodičom dieťaťa, Európska únia nemôže od členských krajín vyžadovať, aby takéto akože rodičovstvo uznali len preto, že v inej členskej krajine nerešpektujú základné normy rodinného práva.   Inštitút pre ľudské práva a rodinnú politiku, o.z. je občianske združenie, ktorého cieľom je najmä podpora a ochrana základných ľudských práv a slobôd, podpora a ochrana rodiny založenej na manželstve jedného muža a jednej ženy, ochrana náboženskej slobody, slobody svedomia a práv rodičov na výchovu svojich detí.
Organisation: Inštitút pre ľudské práva a rodinnú politiku, o.z.
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood

feedback_msg_text: EVS ADHESION STATEMENT FOR THE COMMISSION 'S INITIATIVE CONCERNING "Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood"  The EVS e.V. (European association of civil registrars - Europäischer Verband der Standesbeamtinnen und Standesbeamten, www.evs-eu.org) was founded in 2000 and is a network organization which focuses exclusively on the exchange of information and best practices related to the fields of civil registration, family law, identity management and civil justice, between legal, judicial and administrative authorities.   Present members are the associations of civil registrars from Belgium, Estonia, Germany, Italy, Poland, Romania, Scotland, Slovakia, Slovenia and the Netherlands, although the EVS congresses actract registrars from many other member states as well. The EVS encourages further European integration in order to improve the administrative life of European citizens.  EVS has made several declarations and policy proposals on:  - marriage law (Declaration of Graz) - the exchange of civil status records (Declaration of Noordwijkerhout) - name law (Declaration of Engelberg) - parental law (Declaration of Gent) - cross-border civil status events (Declaration of Leuven).  These declarations are all published on our website https://evs-eu.org/erklarungen/. They were a product of the congresses and time in which they were elaborated. Some of the proposals are already realised, others are still to be put into practice and some need to be actualized and broadened. It is a fact, however, that the European dimension was and is the constant factor in the EVS declarations and activities.  The EVS acknowledges that our citizens are in need and cannot make sufficient use of their right of free movement: - judicial and administrative facts and decisions on civil status made in one member state are still not always acknowledged or are treated differently by another member state - there is no direct exchange of information on the civil status of our citizens between countries which results in a greater risk of identity fraud and citizens themselves have to carry their paperwork around.  The EVS welcomed the Public Documents Regulation since it cut red tape, lowered administrative burdens and fostered free mobility. Further steps are needed though: - an expanded exchange of civil status information between the competent authorities of EU member states regardless of citizenship, residence status or nationality of the people concerned - and the creation of a European code of Private International Law, common conflict rules, which would solve any cross-border complexities and would certainly be an incentive for more harmonization between material law as well.  The EVS adheres therefore to the initiative of the European Commission concerning the recognition of parenthood, where we worked already on in 2007 (the declaration of Gent, mentioned before).  Current family law and private international law within the member states is both incomplete and insufficient in cross-border relations concerning civil status events in general and parenthood in particular. Soft measures will not be sufficient.   The European institutions have therefore the key to solve cross-border civil status conflicts by taking legislative measures for the reasons explained in the “Inception Impact Assessment”. Common conflict rules on a European and not a national government level are needed indeed.  The EVS has the expertise in this field and if needed we are standing by to give further advice and insights in the elaboration of solutions for our citizens.
Organisation: EVS e.V. (Europäischer Verband der Standesbeamtinnen und Standesbeamten - European association of civil registrars)
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood
organisation_lower: evs e.v. (europäischer verband der standesbeamtinnen und standesbeamten - european association of civil registrars)

feedback_msg_text: La CIAMS, Coalition internationale pour l’Abolition de la Maternité de Substitution est une association internationale de droit français créée au mois de mai 2018 et comptant comme membres actives 40 associations de plusieurs pays (Japon, Australie, Canada, Colombie, Ukraine, Roumanie, Suède, Royaume-Uni, Belgique, Autriche, France, Italie, Espagne). Elle a pour but, sur la base de positions féministes, de contribuer à l’adoption et à la mise en œuvre de législations et politiques publiques visant à l’abolition du recours à la maternité de substitution au niveau, national et international. Les efforts visant à réglementer la reconnaissance de la parentalité transfrontalière, tels qu'annoncés par la présidente de la Commission Européenne, madame Von der Leyen, en septembre 2020, suscitent la plus vive inquiétude de notre part. En effet, la question de la reconnaissance de la parentalité transfrontière va immanquablement toucher à la question de la filiation dans le contexte des contrats transnationaux de gestation pour autrui.   L’initiative de la Commission Européenne, similaire aux travaux actuels de la Conférence de la Haye auxquels nous nous opposons, aura pour effet rendre la pratique de la GPA socialement acceptable au détriment des femmes et des enfants.     Nous attirons donc l’attention de la Commission Européenne sur l’impact de sa démarche au plan des droits fondamentaux auxquels elle portera atteinte si elle n’exclut pas spécifiquement de ses travaux la question de la filiation dans le contexte de la GPA :  • Les droits fondamentaux des enfants qui consistent à n’être ni achetés ni vendus.   • Les droits fondamentaux des femmes, qui, comme pour tous les êtres humains,  comportent un droit à l’intégrité physique ce qui devrait donc les protéger des tentatives d’appropriation de leur capacité reproductive par la GPA, qui plus est, au prix d’un risque aggravé pour leur santé et d’une pratique qui s’analyse en violence à l’égard des femmes, que ce soit sur le plan physique, psychique ou économique.   Malgré que presque partout en Europe les contrats de GPA sont illégaux, organiser à l’échelle européenne la reconnaissance automatique, en faveur des parents commanditaires, de la filiation des enfants nés par GPA,  ouvrira la voie à la filiation à toute personne qui contourne la loi de son pays pour acheter un bébé dans un autre pays où l'exploitation reproductive des femmes a été légalisée, ou est tolérée, et où la vente d'enfants a cessé d'être un crime pour devenir un commerce très lucratif.  La seule alternative à l'exploitation reproductive des femmes - toujours économiquement vulnérables - et à l'achat et la vente de nouveau-nés ne passe pas par sa réglementation directe ou indirecte par le biais de l’organisation de la filiation, mais par l'abolition mondiale de cette pratique contraire aux droits humains les plus élémentaires. À cette fin, notre Coalition a rédigé un projet de convention internationale abolitionniste à laquelle tous les États devraient adhérer afin que cette pratique inhumaine et cruelle soit renvoyée à l'histoire comme un mauvais souvenir du passé, tout comme l'esclavage le fut en son temps. Ce projet de convention internationale accessible sur notre site, http://abolition-ms.org/actualites/projet-de-convention-internationale-pour-labolition-de-la-maternite-de-substitution/ recense tous les textes internationaux,  pourtant ratifiés par les pays membres,  protecteurs des droits des femmes et des enfants, auxquels cette pratique porte atteinte.  Notre Coalition souhaite instamment que la Commission Européenne élimine spécifiquement de ses travaux la question de la filiation dans le cadre de la GPA, sachant que les états ont chacun pris des dispositions pour résoudre ces questions de filiation au mieux de leur cadre éthique et législatif, et sans présager de disposition plus progressistes ultérieures qui consisteraient à éliminer le recours à la GPA.  Feedback from: CIAMS- International Coalition for the Abolition of Surrogate Motherhood (75.8 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Organisation: CIAMS- International Coalition for the Abolition of Surrogate Motherhood
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood
