feedback_msg_text: Vážená EK,  tímto krokem EU překročí své pravomoce, protože oblast rodinného práva patří do výhradní kompetence národních států. V čl. 7 Úmluvy o právech dítěte je navíc jasně řečeno, že dítě má právo znát své biologické rodiče a právo na jejich péči. Překročíte tak i mezinárodní právo, kdy se opravdu nedá srovnávat právo volného pohybu v EU s tím, že se budou děti vyrábět na zakázku a jedno vždy bude připraveno o část své biologicky dané identity, vzpomínek a rodinné historie. V západních zemích, kde už delší dobu funguje možnost "koupit si dítě", už i existuje hnutí thembeforeus.com (oni před námi - sobecké zájmy dospělých před zájmem dítěte), kde děti z duhových rodin sdílí, jak dobrá péče prostě není všechno. Krev není voda.  A není to nic nového, ty pocity absence "poloviny identity" znají i děti samoživitelek nebo osiřelé děti. Děti, co přišly o rodiče třeba během války nebo kvůli nemoci, a i když je s veškerou péčí a láskou vychovali různí otčímové, macechy, tedy, babičky, strejdové apod., pořád se na tyto děti díváme jako na ty, co jdou do života s určitým hendikepem. Nevím, proč se u LGBTIQ+ dělá, že tyto neexistuje a vše se jen lakuje na růžovo.  Jsem pro, aby si LGBTIQ+ menšina mohla adoptovat dětí z dětských center (jsou-li právně volné, což prakticky nejsou - proto je vhodné pěstounství, čehož se zase prakticky nevyužívá, ač je třeba v ČR povolené už dávno), ale červená linie je náhradní mateřství.  EU by opravdu měla ubrat na aktivismu a starat se skutečně jen o to, k čemu byla založena - a to spolupráce států, mír a ekonomická stabilita. Tlačením návrhu na sjednocení rodinného práva ve všech zemích EU se ale spíš jen posílí ve společnosti tlaky, které nazýváme "kulturní válkou". A to nepomáhá nikomu.  Jitka Fialová
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood

feedback_msg_text: Zásadně nesouhlasíme s návrhem této iniciativy.  Rodičovství je základním stavebním kamenem rodinného práva, které je ve výlučné kompetenci členských států. Výlučná kompetence členských států v oblasti manželství, rodičovství a rodinného práva je opodstatněna rozdílnou sociální a kulturní podmíněností v daných členských státech, ve kterých neexistuje shodná definice rodičovství.   Navrhovaná iniciativa by vedla k narušení vzájemné důvěry mezi členskými státy, na jejímž základě je projekt Evropské unie vybudován. Z práva na volný pohyb osob nelze odvodit právo na uznávání přeshraničního rodičovství. V žádném případě nelze směšovat nejlepší zájem dítěte s právní a faktickou realitou v některých členských státech EU, které zbavili děti práva na otce a matku. Naopak si dovolujeme připomenout, že Úmluva o právech dítěte svým článkem 7 odst. 1 uvádí, že (dítě) má právo znát své rodiče a právo na jejich péči. Toto ustanovení je třeba interpretovat na základě Preambule Úmluvy, která uvádí, že „rodina je základní jednotkou společnosti a přirozené prostředí pro růst a blaho svých členů, zejména dětí." Taktéž mají být články Úmluvy aplikovány s ohledem na význam tradic a kulturních hodnotkaždného národa pro ochranu a harmonický rozvoj dítěte. Potenciál být rodiči a přivést na svět dítě mají pouze muž a žena. I proto děti nejlépe prospívají se svými biologickými rodiči žijícími v uzavřeném manželství (Ribar, D. C., 2015).  Uznávání přeshraničního rodičovství povede k harmonizaci rodičovství ve prospěch uznávání stejnopohlavního rodičovství. A to v rozporu s se zákonem mnoha členských států EU, které jasně garantují, že rodičem mohou být pouze muž a žena. Zároveň iniciativa sekundárně vede k zvýšení tlaku na redefinci manželství, jelikož manželství a rodičovství je právně velmi úzce propojeno. Navrhovaná iniciativa by se dostala do konfliktu s ústavním pořádkem mnoha členských států. Ten definuje manželství jako svazek muže a ženy na ústavní úrovni (například v Polsku, Maďarsku, Bulharsku).  Zároveň by iniciativa Evropské komise výrazně posílila právní jistotu problematické a eticky velmi sporné praxe surogátního mateřství, která je v několika členských státech EU legalizována (Portugalsko, Řecko, Velká Británie). Iniciativa otevírá možnost expanze této praxe do jiných členskýh států, ačkoliv je v mnoha členských státech nelegální. Zároveň je postihovaná i trestněprávně (například Německo, Itálie).  Surogátní mateřství nejenže činí z dítěte předmět obchodu, ale taktéž vykořisťuje ženy v oblasti tak intimní, jako je mateřství. Je již prokázáno, že většina žen podstupuje surogátní mateřství z ekonomických důvodů (Wendel Report 2016). Praktiku surogátního mateřství odsoudil i Evropský parlament ve Výroční zprávě o lidských právech a demokracii ve světě za rok 2014 a o politice Evropské unie ([2015/2229 (INI), § 114]. Institucionální podporu surogátního mateřství odmítla i Rada Evropy v roce 2016.  Iniciativa je nadbytečná, zasahuje do výlučné pravomoci členských států EU a podrývá prostor důvěry, na jehož základě funguje Evropská unie. Ta je založena na principu sjednocení v odlišnosti, což navrhovaná iniciativa popírá.
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood

feedback_msg_text: Association Society and Value unites tens of thousands of Bulgarian citizens to protect and promote human dignity and freedom, marriage and family since 2007.  We are deeply concerned about the guidelines the European Commission (EC) has published in the Roadmap for “regulation on the recognition of parenthood between Member States”. If the measures proposed by the EC are adopted, this will lead to a redefinition of marriage, parenthood and to rough violations of human dignity and the best interests of the child throughout the European Union (EU).  The imposed measures are a gross interference with the family law and the legal status of persons who, under the EU Treaties, fall entirely within the competence of the Member States. The European Commission inception impact assessment confirms this fact.  The right to free movement cannot be used to oblige Member States to adopt legislation that is contrary to our Constitutions and the principle of subsidiarity.   In Bulgaria, as in other EU Member States, marriage is defined as a union between man and woman. The Constitution connects parenthood with the father and the mother, with the binary understanding of gender, as male and female, related to the biological sex.  Parenting is not a "right", but a gift and responsibility that is built on accepting the child and respecting his/her best interests. Not every couple has a child, but every child has a father and a mother. Every child is a human being with its own rights, including the right to have and know his/her mother and father. The EU should respect it. Ignoring these facts undermines the best interests of the child and will have serious consequences for the EU's legal harmony.  At the international level, the definition of parenthood is based upon the Art. 7 of the International Convention of the Rights of the Child - the two parents of the child. All EU legislation must fall under this binding definition. The term "parents" can only be interpreted as referring to the father and the mother of the child, "according to the ordinary meaning to be given to the terms".   One often used reason for a new legislation on cross-border families is that children born from parents of two different Member States would then become stateless, if parenthood is not established in the same way in both countries. This is not true as the child always holds a civil registration and is granted a country of birth and a country of residence.  Moreover the proposal to recognize parenthood in EU will lead to the recognition of surrogacy, which is banned in many Member States.  The practice of surrogacy does not respect the rights and the human dignity of the children and it turns them into a commodity. It undermines the child's right to know his/her origin and to develop a family identity. A child born after a surrogacy agreement is deliberately placed in a situation of planned abandonment by his biological mother, as well as potentially by his two genetic parents, which has negative consequences in the future. Surrogacy undermines women's human dignity, turning their bodies into a commodity and an object of exploitation.  The EU cannot and must not be used as an instrument in favor of the desire for parenthood, at the expense of the rights of the children and the women.  Such measures, which are alien to domestic legal systems, are contrary to the EU Treaty and the principle of subsidiarity. They disrupt democratic processes, create tensions and lead to regulatory chaos and interference in the competence of Member States on these issues.  If Member States are forced to recognize parenthood established abroad they will not be able to maintain their legal provisions and definitions on matters of marriage, family and parenthood.  In this regard, we call on the EC to respect the national competence of the Member States with regard to marriage, the family and parenthood and to withdraw the foregoing controversial draft regulation.
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood

feedback_msg_text: Dear European Commission,  The March for Family National Association is a Bulgarian non-governmental organization that carries out activities in public benefit for the affirmation and the support of the marriage, as a voluntary union between one man and one woman, and the traditional family values and virtues, to achieve a better and a fuller life for all citizens in the society.  We would like to express our concern with the recently published guidelines of the European Commission for the draft of the regulation on the recognition of parenthood between the member states. Once passed, it will have binding power for all member states of the European Union to comply.  It includes each country as a member state to recognize the adoption of children by homosexual couples whether it is legal in the respective country or not. For the majority of these member states such a regulation will be in direct opposition to their national Law regarding the family.  Under the Union Treaties, the substantive law on family matters and the legal status of persons falls within the competence of the member states. That includes the establishment of the parenthood and its control by the NATIONAL law of each country.   We disagree with any EU country being forced to comply with regulations which are opposed to their respective Constitution. As such the Constitution of the Republic of Bulgaria defines marriage clearly as a “voluntary union between a MAN and a WOMAN”, (Art. 46, 1).  For our citizens, as part of a traditionally Orthodox Christian nation, it is of a primary importance to protect this definition.  We must emphasize that the above is also valid for many other member states of the EU, not only Bulgaria, and it must be taken into serious consideration. These new regulations are in direct contradiction to our established laws and our centuries-old traditions.  For example, the national laws of many EU member states expressively prohibit adoption of children by homosexual couples. Even more so, these provisions are in full conformity with the applicable international laws, including the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.  Taking into account the Constitutions of the individual countries and the fact the substantive family law is completely in the jurisdiction of the member states of the EU, our position is that this proposal is interfering with the national sovereignty, the national competence and traditions of the countries concerned.  We insist the draft to be withdrawn because it goes against the Treaties of Accession to the European Union.   Sincerely, Ivaylo Tinchev Chairman of the Managing Council March for Family National Association Bulgaria Feedback from: March for Family National Association (132.7 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood

feedback_msg_text: Onorevole Presidente Ursula Von der Leyen,   vorremmo esprimere il nostro sconcerto e la preoccupazione di milioni di cittadini europei nei riguardi delle politiche che state discutendo in Commissione Europea, in particolare nell'ambito dell'iniziativa "Situazioni familiari transfrontaliere - riconoscimento della genitorialità".  Durante il suo discorso sullo stato dell'Unione (Settembre 2020) lei ha affermato che "Se sei genitore in un paese, sei genitore in ogni paese". Sappiamo che il suo discorso fa riferimento agli ordinamenti interni degli Stati membri che non riconoscono l'omogenitorialità come un diritto. Per questo riteniamo la sua affermazione pericolosa e la politica che intendete promuovere con il sostegno della Commissione inaccettabile.  La nostra preoccupazione e quella di milioni di cittadini europei risiede nell'importanza  dell'Art. 2 del TFU nel quale viene citata la base fondante dell'Unione europea, ovvero il rispetto della dignità umana, dal quale scaturiscono poi tutti i diritti e principi fondamentali. Un bambino non è un diritto e la genitorialità non è un diritto, piuttosto un bambino è un soggetto avente diritto e la genitorialità non può rappresentare un capriccio, ma una responsabilità.  Con tale iniziativa della Commissione si mette in secondo piano il superiore interesse del bambino e si rischia di aprire le porte alla terribile pratica dell’utero in affitto e ad una sua regolamentazione negli Stati membri.  L’UE ha il diritto di legiferare solo nei settori in cui i trattati le danno la competenza specifica per farlo. Legiferare su temi quali matrimonio e genitorialità o regolare l'accesso alla procreazione medicalmente assistita, all'adozione e alla maternità surrogata spetta agli Stati sovrani. Denunciamo con forza qualsiasi iniziativa della Commissione europea che cerca di violare la sovranità degli Stati membri e il principio di sussidiarietà.  L’articolo 3 (1) della Convenzione sui diritti del bambino (qui, "CDB") richiede di considerare sempre il "miglior interesse del nascituro" in tutte le azioni riguardanti la tutela legale dei bambini. La premessa fondamentale della maternità surrogata è dannosa per i bambini, compromette la loro dignità e minaccia i diritti umani sanciti dalla CDB. La maternità surrogata priva i bambini di chiare linee di filiazione e in definitiva mercifica le loro vite, ponendoli  in una situazione di abbandono pianificato dalla madre biologica (gestante), così come, potenzialmente, da entrambi i suoi genitori genetici e riducendolo ad un oggetto di desiderio commerciale.  La pratica della maternità surrogata espone inevitabilmente i bambini a livelli inaccettabili di incertezza giuridica, minando il loro diritto a conoscere le loro origini, il loro diritto a sviluppare un'identità familiare e qualsiasi aspirazione alla riunificazione familiare.   CitizenGO e i suoi più di 15 milioni di membri invitano la Commissione a ritirare questo provvedimento che scavalca le competenze proprie degli stati membri e impone l'accettazione della pratica dell'utero in affitto e la compravendita di esseri umani, violando diritti umani fondamentali.    Cordiali Saluti  Ignacio Arsuaga, CEO CitizenGO Feedback from: Fundacion CitizenGO (319.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Cross-border family situations - recognition of parenthood

feedback_msg_text: Aba Béla, mint uniós állampolgár és mint a Magyar Páneurópa Unió elnöke tisztelettel közlöm a magam, valamint a 250 tagot számláló civil szervezetünk véleményét; mely szerint a család fogalmát Magyarországon az Alaptörvény véleményünk szerint helyesen szabályozza. Ez egyértelműen kimondja, hogy a család az apa, az anya és a gyermekből áll. Mivel nemcsak a szülőknek, hanem a gyermeknek is vannak jogai, az sem hagyható figyelmen kívül. A gyermeknek joga van éppúgy az apához, mint az anyához, attól függetlenül, hogy a szülők képesek-e feladatuk (családban betöltött szerepük) ellátására. A józan ész azt diktálja, hogy a gyermek egészséges neveléséhez szükséges mintákat elsősorban a családban szerzi meg, ezért a mi felfogásunk szerint nem mindegy, hogy a nevelő szülők egyneműek-e vagy sem. Természetesen tudjuk, hogy kromoszóma-eltérések okozhatnak nem-beli különbségeket, azonban ez nem ok arra, hogy a gyermeket módosult identitáson belüli minták vegyék körül. Ebben a témában nem kerülhető meg az egyes tagállamok önálló törvényalkotása. Az egyes esetlegesen átköltöző - más véleményen levő - családi közösségeknek is - adott esetben - az érvényes, helyi törvényeket el kell fogadniuk, azt tiszteletben kell tartaniuk. A jelenleg érvényes, elfogadott EU-s jogszabályokban rögzített családjogi törvények nemzeti hatáskörben való meghagyását kérjük tiszteletben tartani és az ennek megváltoztatására irányuló rendelet-tervezetet kérjük visszavonni!  Ezt az állásfoglalást tagságunknak is megküldöm. Köszönöm megtisztelő figyelmüket.

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the European Commission’s initiative to include a set of digital principles as a key part of the European digital strategy. We agree that these principles are needed for the digital strategy to secure the growth and wellbeing of the European digital society, and not just of the digital market.  In 2019, together with the Commons Network, we developed the digital policy framework “Vision for a Shared Digital Europe” This  document is a result of a co-creation process involving experts from over twenty key European digital civil society organisations.  The framework provides a foundation for policies leading to a more equitable and democratic digital environment, where basic liberties and rights are protected, where strong public institutions function in the public interest, and where people have a say in how their digital environment functions.  At the heart of this vision are four policy principles: Enable Self-Determination, Cultivate the Commons, Decentralise Infrastructure and Empower Public Institutions. These principles can contribute to creating a European digital space that embodies our values: strong public institutions, democratic governance, sovereignty of communities and people, diversity of cultures, and equality and justice.   We note that these high level principles of sovereignty, decentralization, empowerment of the public sphere and public institutions, and cultivation of the commons are missing from currently presented proposals for European digital principles, including the recent “Contribution for a common framework on digital principles” that is part of the Lisbon Declaration “Digital Democracy with a Purpose”.   We encourage European policymakers to include these high level principles in the Digital Decade policy framework. Enclosed please find the “Vision for a Shared Digital Europe” report.  Feedback from: Open Future (2.4 MB - PDF - 23 pages) Download
Initiative: Declaration of Digital Principles – the ‘European way’ for the digital society

feedback_msg_text: 1.- Sobre la forma de la iniciativa propuesta: necesidad de replantear la “Hoja de ruta”.  Si bien en el encabezamiento de la “Hoja de ruta” se señala como tipo de iniciativa probable una Comunicación/Recomendación de la Comisión, posteriormente se pone de manifiesto que dicha iniciativa en la que se propondrán “un conjunto de principios digitales que deberían conformar la sociedad digital de Europa” será objeto de una “declaración solemne interinstitucional conjunta de la Comisión Europea, el Parlamento Europeo y el Consejo, basada en una propuesta de la Comisión Europea”. En cualquier caso, el objeto de la iniciativa y la evidente repercusión normativa que puede tener hace recomendable que se opte por otra forma de iniciativa para impulsar la “Declaración de Principios Digitales”, cualquiera en la que se le dé forma de norma jurídica.  Estos mismos problemas, en relación con la importante confusión sobre su posible impacto normativo, los hemos puesto de manifiesto en España con relación a la iniciativa impulsada desde el Gobierno español con la denominada como “Carta de Derechos Digitales”1 que está siendo elaborada por un Comité de Expertos constituido ad hoc, que fue objeto de un trámite de consulta pública2 a finales de enero 2021 y sobre la que parece, podría producirse una inminente publicación, conforme a lo comentado públicamente por miembros del Gobierno. En este caso, la iniciativa de la “Carta de Derechos Digitales” se ha impulsado y parece que se pretende aprobar sin darle forma de norma jurídica en particular, como parece que se va a hacer con la “Declaración de Principios Digitales”.  La cuestión es que la “Carta” viene a recoger el contenido que ya ha es objeto de regulación expresa en normas jurídicas promulgadas como tales. Es el caso, sobre todo, de la Ley 3/2018, de 5 de diciembre, de Protección de Datos Personales y garantía de los derechos digitales que, en su Título X – “Garantía de los derechos digitales” –, reconoce y garantiza de modo expreso una serie de derechos digitales de los ciudadanos (i.e. derecho a la neutralidad en la red, el acceso universal, el derecho a la seguridad, la protección de menores, la libertad de expresión, y derecho de rectificación o el derecho al olvido en búsquedas) que, en gran parte, son los contenidos en la Carta. También de otras normas como la Ley 11/2007, de 22 de junio, de acceso electrónico de los ciudadanos a los servicios públicos, la Ley 14/2007, de 3 de julio, de investigación biomédica, la Ley 8/2019, de 13 de diciembre, de Participación de Castilla-La Mancha o la Ley 7/2017, de 27 de diciembre, de Participación Ciudadana de Andalucía.  En el caso de la iniciativa “Declaración de Principios Digitales” que se nos somete ahora a consulta pública por parte de la Dirección General de Redes, Contenidos y Tecnología de las Comunicaciones podría suceder lo mismo con otras normas ya publicadas (como podría ser el Reglamento (UE) 2016/679 general de protección de datos) o las propias normas integradas en la iniciativa del Digital Services Act Package que se encuentra ahora mismo en desarrollo. Es importante, en consecuencia, que una iniciativa de este tipo adopte forma de acto jurídico vinculante para los Estados miembro y la ciudadanía de la Unión Europea en los términos del artículo 288 TFUE. feedback_msg_text: IT4Kids ist ein sozialer, gemeinnütziger Verein aus Aachen, der sich zum Ziel gesetzt hat, allen Kindern digitale Bildung zugänglich zu machen.  Wir sehen die Notwendigkeit, dass Informatikunterricht und digitale Bildung bereits im frühen Kindesalter unterrichtet werden sollte, um Kinder bestmöglich auf die digitale Zukunft vorzubereiten.   Das Problem fehlender Digitalisierung in der (Grund-)Schule wird bereits in Deutschland, aber auch europaweit, diskutiert. Viele Schulen sind mit dem Thema Digitalisierung überfordert. Es mangelt nicht nur an der Möglichkeit eines digitalen Unterrichts, sondern auch an ausreichender Infrastruktur für eine digitale Bildung. Die technische Ausstattung ist unzureichend und ihre Wartung und Verwaltung wird meist von den eigenen Lehrern übernommen. Während der Coronakrise war der Unterricht oftmals vom Engagement einzelner Lehrer abhängig. Ohne ausreichende Ausstattung ist der Zugang zur und die Vorbereitung auf die digitale Welt nicht möglich.    Informatikunterricht in Grundschulen gibt es bisher kaum. Gerade in der sich immer schneller digitalisierten Welt zeigt sich, dass Programmieren im Schulunterricht nicht weiter vernachlässigt werden darf. Kinder sollten an die Themen des logischen Denkens und Lösen komplexer Problemstellungen schon früh herangeführt werden, um sich besser in der Informatik und digitalen Welt zurecht zu finden. Selbst an weiterführenden Schulen bereitet der aktuelle Informatikunterricht nicht ausreichend auf eine digitale Zukunft weltweit und in Europa vor. Um Europa im IT-Bereich konkurrenzfähig zu halten, ist es wichtig, Talente im frühen Alter zu entdecken und zu fördern.   Anhand der beschriebenen Probleme wollen wir einige Lösungsansätze vorschlagen.  Schulen müssen europaweit mit finanziellen Mitteln versorgt werden, um wichtige Ausstattung, wie Computer, Tablets oder Smart Boards in den Unterricht integrieren zu können. Eine stabile, schnelle Internetverbindung für Schulen und deren Schüler*innen ist zur Erreichung dieser Ziele notwendig. Lehrern müssen verpflichtende Schulungen angeboten werden, um selbst mit der Digitalisierung Schritt halten zu können und eine digitale Lehre zu gewährleisten. Einige von ihnen brauchen zudem nicht nur Unterstützung, sondern auch Ermutigung, sich an neue Technologien und Lehrmethoden heran zu wagen. Durch gute Konzepte können gerade diese Lehrer*innen mit dem Thema Digitalisierung vertraut gemacht werden. So werden die neuen Möglichkeiten als Fortschritt wahrgenommen.  Durch die ersten Erfahrungen von IT4Kids in Europa hat sich gezeigt, dass digitale Bildung auf europäischer Ebene zielführend ist und als gemeinschaftliche, länderübergreifende Problemstellung angesehen werden sollte. Unsere Schulen sind dabei nicht nur an dem digitalen Unterricht, sondern auch an der europäischen Vernetzung interessiert. So arbeiten wir bspw. in der Region Aachen mit Schulen in Deutschland, Belgien und den Niederlanden zusammen. Diese Kooperationen könnte langfristig zu interessanten Exkursionen oder Schüleraustausche führen und die Vernetzung fördern.  Durch Bildung im Grundschulalter ist das Verständnis von abstrakten Problemen spielerisch erlernbar. Kinder können die Grundzüge der Informatik und damit Logik- und Prozessdenken bereits im frühen Alter lernen. Wir konnten in unseren Kursen ausschließlich Freude und Interesse bei den Kindern wecken.  Digitale Bildung im Grundschulalter fördert die Geschlechtergleichheit in technischen Berufen. Jedes Kind sollte für sich entscheiden dürfen, ob es digitale Bildung und Informatik erhalten möchte. Deswegen starten wir spielerisch schon in der Grundschule, in der es noch keine Nerd-Stigmata gibt. Kein Kind muss Programmieren, aber jedes Kind sollte die Möglichkeit dazu haben.   Wir möchten uns bei der Europäischen Kommission bedanken, unsere Sichtweise auf die Digitalisierung in europäischen Schulen darlegen zu können und würden uns freuen, wenn unsere Lösungsvorschläge berücksichtigt werden.   IT4Kids
Initiative: Declaration of Digital Principles – the ‘European way’ for the digital society

feedback_msg_text: En la defensa de los derechos que nos han sido encomendados deseamos hacer los siguientes comentarios a la Hoja de ruta relativa a la Declaración de principios digitales: la vía europea para la sociedad digital:  En primer lugar, valoramos muy positivamente toda referencia al derecho de libertad de expresión. Todo ciudadano tiene derecho a expresar libremente sus pensamientos, ideas y opiniones; no obstante, en el ejercicio de este derecho se deben respetar los derechos de terceros, entre otros, los de propiedad intelectual.   Igualmente, es importante resaltar que el derecho de información implica el derecho a recibir información veraz sobre los hechos noticiables, pero ello no quiere decir que bajo el paraguas de un derecho constitucional se vulneren otros. En este ámbito, se deben encontrar mecanismos que aseguren el equilibrio entre unos y otros, garantizando la realidad y la efectividad de todos ellos.  Precisamente por eso, consideramos que es indispensable el refuerzo de la protección de las creaciones intelectuales y de aquellos que las crean e intervienen en su creación.  Además, entendemos que resulta necesario el refuerzo de la formación e información que deben recibir los ciudadanos y muy especialmente los menores. De esta forma, a través de la formación se evita que los menores, colectivo especialmente vulnerable y merecedor de la máxima protección, puedan cometer comportamientos ilícitos en las redes, bien iniciados por ellos mismos, bien por terceros o, incluso, ser ellos las víctimas de actividades ilegales en ese entorno virtual.   Nuestros menores son el público más vulnerable ante la divulgación de noticias falsas, bulos, contenido obsoleto o de escasa calidad, contenido creado, en muchas ocasiones, por usuarios y que no ha sido sometido a un control o verificación, etc. por parte de un tercero que se haga responsable del mismo. Por ello, resulta imprescindible dotar a los menores de información sobre la realidad, funcionamiento ventajas y riesgos de la red ofreciéndoles pautas de actuación segura y unas reglas mínimas para que desarrollen el espíritu crítico en todo lo relacionado con su acceso a noticias a través de esa vía.  Solo a través de la erradicación de bulos, noticias falsas, contenido obsoleto, material que infringe derechos de propiedad intelectual o piratería y a través de una buena formación e información, los usuarios van a poder tener la tranquilidad de estar actuando de forma legal y accediendo a contenido legítimo, veraz, verificado y de calidad.
Organisation: ENTIDAD DE GESTIÓN DE DERECHOS DE PROPIEDAD INTELECTUAL
Initiative: Declaration of Digital Principles – the ‘European way’ for the digital society

feedback_msg_text: Századvég Group highlights below its key points for the feedback process – for a more detailed feedback, please see the attached document.  1. Recent studies conducted both by international organisations and Member States have concluded that countries with a more focused attention on digitalisation are at an economic and social advantage over their competitors. 2. The data also indicate that in each Member State different elements of the digital ecosystem require special governmental attention. Nevertheless, we believe that for economic and social considerations (i.e., competitiveness and social inclusion), all Member States should give priority to developing the digital preparedness of their citizens (including people with some form of disability), as well as the micro-enterprises.  3. Digitalisation also accelerates the automation of repetitive and low value-added jobs, replacing humans with robots, hence increasing the number of employees who are unable to find a job due to a lack of digital and other competences. Simultaneously this would also increase the labour market demand for workers with a high level of digital and IT skills (able to operate modern-day machineries).  4. In our opinion, digital development of individual entrepreneurs and micro-enterprises deserves special attention because they are typically not at the forefront of interest in development policy (and statistical enumeration) at Member State level, even though they account for 85-95% of all enterprises in the EU, playing a significant role in the competitiveness of the Union. Their digital development requires unique solutions, mixing the elements of training programs for private individuals and development programs for SMEs. 5. Although closing the digital divide, avoiding the proliferation of labour market mismatch and the digital development of micro-enterprises are the primary tools for Member States, we think governments should also put emphasis on individual entrepreneurs and micro-enterprises when calibrating other elements of their digital development policy.  6. We believe that it’s in the common interest of employees, employers, trainers and the state to train and fund the training of those with average and above average digital skills - it is therefore advisable to design programmes based on proportionate sharing of costs and risks. 7. In the case of both individuals and companies, the need for training often arises only under the influence of clear external pressure; to combat this, the state should play a role in recognising the need for training and in raising the awareness for life-long learning, as demand for adult education decreased due to fact that low unemployment rates and high fluctuation did not encourage employers to support the development of the competences of their employees.  8. According to international experience, full and direct state support for employee training is not effective, because if the selection is not made by the trainer and the risk is borne entirely by the state, the risk-bearing -and thus motivation- of both trainers and trainees is reduced. Therefore, the sustainable, long-term interest of the employee and the employer must be created. 9. In the case of training for the acquisition of higher-level digital competences and IT skills, which are of particular relevance to the labour market, the use of financial instruments can be a more effective form of training funding that allows costs and risks to be shared between the actors.  Feedback from: Századvég Group (268.7 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Declaration of Digital Principles – the ‘European way’ for the digital society

feedback_msg_text: The Southeastern Europe Security Center (SESC) welcomes this European Commission initiative on Europe’s digital transition and looks forward to the publication of the Declaration of Digital Principles. It is still premature but SESC would stress two aspects: the ‘European way’ for the digital society should guarantee the digital transition does not interfere with the main principles of free market economy and fair competition, and, on the other hand, must lay the foundations for increasing security and data protection. Security is nowadays a general concern linked to 5G while personal data protection must cover the widest range possible, including national and transnational authorities, enabling mechanisms that should ensure the DDP applicability and enforcement, if needed.
Initiative: Declaration of Digital Principles – the ‘European way’ for the digital society

feedback_msg_text: CRNI is a member of RREUSE, an international network representing social enterprises active in re-use, repair and recycling. RREUSE members divert around 1 million tonnes of goods and materials on an annual basis from landfill. We fully support the RREUSE feedback on the EU Strategy for Sustainable Textiles Roadmap. Our members are retailers (the Irish Charity Shops Association (ICSA)), upcyclers (Rediscovery Centre, Roscommon Women’s Network), lenders (Cloth Nappy Library Ireland), online marketplaces (thriftify, FreeTrade Ireland) and educators (Rediscovery Centre, Cloth Nappy Library Ireland, the UseLess Project). In addition to the RREUSE position on protecting re-use operators of the social economy, we would like to propose two further measures to protect the social impact of textile prevention and reuse.  1. A balance must be struck between supporting local reuse and facilitating the export of textiles  While textile exports for reuse will continue to play an important role in the future, both in Ireland and across Europe, they represent a loss in the value of the reusable item and associated social impact to the local market.  The export of goods can also have negative social and environmental impacts on receiving markets. Some countries have been pushing back more recently on textile imports particularly where these are lower quality. The EU is facing new requirements under the Waste Framework Directive to separately collect textiles by 2025. This could see a significant increase in the quantity of textiles passing into the reuse sector and - if not well managed - significant increase in volumes exported.  We believe it is therefore critical at this time to build into the roadmap support for greater levels of local reuse and repair through investment in infrastructure (particularly in partnership with social enterprises) and other measures. This will not only support the social benefits of reuse but will also improve the environmental benefits of textile management (through reduced transport), support the local economy and build local resilience. A Just Transition plan is required to support textile workers who are dependent on the existing system of overconsumption in order to support a fair circular economy. The Covid-19 pandemic has had an important impact on the whole textile sector. The impact has been particularly severe on garment workers, as the fallout from cancelled orders (due to reduced consumption) has taken its toll. Any future policy that aims to reduce the current levels of overconsumption in favour of a more circular economy model - as is required to support climate goals and social good - must also take into account these workers and the potential impact on their livelihoods. On the theme of ecodesign, we believe stronger measures such as legislation, are required to halt the destruction of returned goods. Alternatively, it should be made more cost effective to clean, repack and resale items than to destroy or prematurely recycle them. Measures are also needed to incentivise the reuse, repair and upcycling of waste fabrics - in the form for example of gift aid or other such incentives. Finally better labelling transparency is required to facilitate better management of textile waste. Feedback from: Community Resources Network Ireland (182.6 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: There seems to be good coverage regarding circular systems, textile recycling, digital solutions. Very much commend the focus on EPR.  What we find is lacking: tier 4 raw materials cultivation and its environmental and social impact: Naturebased solutions such as regenerative  agriculture can have a hugely positive impact on nature and communities, helping to reverse climate change and biodiversity loss. It seems the current proposed ideas do not take into account the huge potential positive impact the fashion industry can have:by using regenerative agriculture co2 emissions can be sequestered to a significant degree while cultivating fibres and rearing animals for apparel.  Given the urgency and 2030 the year we need to have halved our greenhouse gas emissions it makes sense to look beyond recycling and waste and focus on tier 4 more, incentivising the sector to use raw materials not grown in industrial intensive farming systems but in regenerative and restorative farming systems. This means EU agricultural policy needs to be shifted away from intensive industrial farming systems. We also note that many of the recommendations of UK's Env. Audit committee report Fixing fashion have not been included here notably cultural and consumer behaviour changes, by for example going right down to teaching primary school children again how things are made, care for and mend things. This all translates into better product care with its huge potential to reduce emissions!
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: The European Network of Social Integration Enterprises, ENSIE, represents the interests of national and regional networks of ‘Work Integration Social Enterprises’ (WISEs) striving for more inclusive and integrated forms of employment at European level. WISEs are defined by three identifying principles: they are enterprises whose main objective is the social and professional integration of disadvantaged people; they are enterprises at the core of the economic system, and they developed a strong pedagogical dimension. Throughout Europe, you can find WISEs active in the reuse and repair activities as well as in the recycling ones, as clearly demonstrated in the study Impact-WISEs. The Commission's roadmap emphasises new strategies especially in the production of new textile products. ENSIE, together with its members, has been active for many years in the promotion and production of recycled and reused products, textile included. It is important to give prominence to this type of sustainable and innovative products and consequently to the enterprises working in the production of recycled textile products, many of which are WISEs. In the ENSIE database it is possible to have an overview of the big number of WISEs active in the field of recycled and re-used textile products. In this sector it results fundamental to promote and protect the role of social enterprises and WISEs as mandatory and essential support and added value for the integration of disadvantaged groups in labour market. This important role will be evident once the COVID19 crises effects on labour market are going to be clearer with a big increased in the rates of unemployed people. For this reason, in the actual critical situation, the social inclusion potential of WISEs appears an important instrument to guaranteeing to disadvantaged categories the access to labour market. The recent pandemic has also shown the great capacity of WISEs to design the textile sector in a sustainable and flexible way. During the crisis, many enterprises have adapted their production to the re-use of textiles and materials for the packaging of masks and other essential products. Thanks to these activities, an unnecessary and senseless overproduction and overconsumption has been addressed.  In ENSIE’s opinion, that it is shared with partners like RREUSE more experienced in the field, these social enterprises should be given primary attention in the Commission's roadmap exactly because of their social and environmental commitment. Sustainable production should therefore be emphasised and promoted when drawing up an EU textile strategy. Furthermore, this production must meet the unquestionable respect for workers' rights, the promotion of social inclusion and sustainable development goals. All these are founding principles and raison d'être of social enterprises and WISEs. Feedback from: ENSIE, European Network of Social Integration Enterprises (441 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Organisation: ENSIE, European Network of Social Integration Enterprises
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: In this submission, Animal Law Europe brings to the Commission’s attention the impacts of common practices in the textiles industry on the treatment of animals used for fiber production purposes. The level of treatment afforded to animals in the course of industrial activities is a crucial aspect of sustainability that the forthcoming EU Strategy for Textiles should take into account. Furthermore, issues related to animal welfare are oftentimes correlated with environmental justice issues – understood as both negative impacts on the environment and low-income human communities of the Global South. It is thus only fair and consistent that the EU Textiles Strategy also seeks to improve the treatment of animals, to achieve environmental and social goals, and for the sake of the billions sentient, living non-human animals that populate the planet.  There are five aspects to the issue of the industrial use of animals for fiber purposes: ➢ Leather from domestic, farmed animals, which often is a by-product of the animal agriculture industry (e.g. beef cattle, goats) ➢ Wool from animals who are usually farmed primarily for this purpose (e.g. rabbits, sheep, goats) ➢ Leather from exotic animals who are either farmed or caught in the wild (e.g. crocodile) ➢ Fur from wild animals who are either farmed or caught in the wild (e.g. minks, foxes) ➢ Feathers (geese, ducks)  Given their impacts on the treatment of animals, the environment, human health, and human rights, the production methods of animal-based materials for fiber purposes raise significant ethical questions. More fundamentally, living in a world where animal products are ubiquitous is a political choice that EU citizens should decide on, rather than being imposed by. Feedback from: European Institute for Animal Law & Policy (125.9 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Organisation: European Institute for Animal Law & Policy
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: -Recycling of textiles The challenges of achieving higher recycling targets for textiles will require clear regulation on production patterns with a view to reducing the number of materials in each product in order to increase the recycled contents.   -Interdependency between industries in a circular economy There will be no large scale textile recycling industry in the EU without a larger scale EU textile industry. If not, the demand for recycled material will mainly be determined by the textile industry in Asia, far from EU regulations and value creation.   -Expanding Ecolabelling  Expanding Ecolabelling to include clear and transparent consumer information on contents of textiles is vital. Today, the only required information is fiber-content and washing instructions. In the same way as CE labelling on products standards for meeting EU legislative requirements on health, safety and environment, labelling for textiles should include standards and requirements for increasing recycled content and reducing the number of materials.   On the demand side, measures to address over-consumption should also be addressed. The consumers need more and better information in order to be able to make informed choices. The challenges related to online sales and private import of textiles from outside the EU must also be addressed in this context.   -Use the taxonomy as a driver  Further on the supply side, the Commission should consider including value chains for the production of textiles in the ongoing work of sustainable finance and its regulations on taxonomy. Establishing effective screening criteria can contribute to curb the flow of capital aiming for short term profits. Taxonomy rules will contribute to better using existing materials and processes with low climate and environmental footprints. It will also incentivise use of sustainable products and production methods in the design phase.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Thanks European Commission for the opportunity to give feedback on the important and urgent EU initiative, the EU strategy for sustainable textiles.  I'll keep it short since obviously you have the general aspects all covered:  First of all I like to suggest to be very clear about one of the most important target groups: European SME companies – the solutions for a more sustainable textile and fashion industry must also be adoptable by SMEs and not just the bigger Stakeholders. This is especially important when establishing guidelines, criteria and standards – better not just fall back on existing tools. All existing solutions tend to A) disregard the true complexity and needed scientific scope when using LCAs, etc. and B) are not applicable for most real-life decision making processes within the global value and supply chains. We cannot rely all the investments of the next years to be done based on assumption based on incomplete data.  Second, please carefully look into the influence of marketing and greenwashing – false claims need to be called out with consequences and citizens should not be given the responsibility to first become expert consumers before they can do their shopping without automatically having to sub-consciously deal with the guilt of buying something that would have never been allowed to be produced in the same way within the EU.  Third, do consider the influence fashion has on nearly all other consumer goods industries – if sustainability becomes fashion it becomes mainstream faster than Boohoo.  Our 202030 Summit report is not ready yet – but happy to share it in the next weeks.  All my best regards, Max
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Refashion contribution to EU Strategy for Sustainable Textiles Contribution to Roadmap  Refashion is the eco-organization accredited by the French authorities to manage the Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) for Apparel and Footwear in France. Our vision : Make Fashion Industry 100% Circular Our mission : Bring together all the players of the sector to develop eco-design, reuse and recycling by optimizing the management of material, financial and human resources. Refashion welcomes the launch of this EU Communication and wishes to contribute to the consultation process. Refashion adheres to the EU New Green Deal objectives.  Refashion wishes to submit the below 4 contributions : 1. Engage brands towards eco-design:  As part of its mission, Refashion encourages brands to develop eco-designed products on three main criteria : reduce waste throughout the entire life cycle of textiles & footwear, improve the durability and recyclability of textiles & footwear and replace virgin materials by recycled materials. EU should promote eco-design initiatives.  2. Promote environmental labelling: As voting member of the PEFCR Apparel & Footwear Technical Secretariat, Refashion strongly supports the need for common sustainability standards. These guidelines are paramount to engage brands in assessing the environmental impacts of their products. Furthermore, as per French experimentation on environmental labelling managed by ADEME (French environmental agency), Refashion calls for a EU communication towards environmental labelling for textiles & footwear.  3. Speed up textile & footwear recycling industry: Efficient and economically viable textile & footwear recovery is a complex equation where collection, sorting and reuse/recycling stages need to be optimized. As EPR eco-organization for France, Refashion believes it is urgent to massively invest to create a successful industrialization of recycling solutions in Europe (ie. ReHubs project supported by Euratex).   4. Raise awareness among citizens: Citizens empowerment is a key driver to influence brands strategies and commitments. Refashion supports all communication initiatives to increase textile industry transparency from production to end of life. Facilitating access to accurate information on brands environmental and social impacts, financial issues on waste management or international policies contradictions will contribute to raise awareness among EU citizens.  In addition, Refashion fully supports the CSF Mode & Luxe feedback contribution. Feedback from: Refashion (63.9 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Martin Hojsík,  Veľmi vítam túto iniciatívu a o konzultácii so slovenskými výrobcami, združeniami, predajcami a dizajnérmi by som bol vďačný, keby Európska komisia zváži nasledujúce poznámky.   Plán poukazuje na rozdielne podmienky, ktorým čelí priemysel Európskej únie, spôsobené nižšími environmentálnymi a sociálnymi normami v tretích krajinách. Preto žiadam Európsku komisiu, aby sa zaoberala hlavnými príčinami problému naprieč zásobovacím reťazcom. Obávam sa, že prevaha neférových nákupných praktík v tomto sektore je prekážkou pre podniky, ktoré už teraz uprednostňujú spravodlivé obchodné podmienky a udržateľnosť. Stratégia sa musí zameriavať na nekalé nákupné praktiky, ktoré zaznamenali rozmach počas krízy spôsobenej ochorením COVID-19.  Textilný a odevný priemysel na Slovensku zaznamenal za posledných 30 rokov enormný výrobný pokles  Bol to výsledok nízkej efektivity a konkurencieschopnosti bývalého socialistického priemyslu, ako aj zvyšujúce sa mzdové a odvodové náklady.   Výrobné podniky tvorili v minulosti hlavnú zložku odevného priemyslu. Postupom času však strácali hlavnú výhodu, nízku cenu práce, kvôli čomu sa výroba pre export stávala nerentabilnou a mnoho zadávateľov začalo premiestňovať svoje výroby do iných krajín. S tlakom na mzdy v textilnom priemysle prišla aj menšia atraktivita daných pracovných pozícií, zvýšenie priemerného veku pracovníkov a pracovníčok a zastavenie modernizácie výroby. Pre absolventov a absolventky odevných škôl nie je textilný priemysel dostatočne atraktívnou perspektívou na uplatnenie, výsledkom čoho je nedostatok kvalifikovanej pracovnej sily. Zmeny v školstve reagujúce na potreby odevného priemyslu 21.storočia a edukácia v tomto sektore zaostávajú za potrebami trhu.    V pláne sa správne uvádza cieľ „udržateľného životného štýlu“. Preto vyzývam Európsku komisiu, aby dopomohla udržateľnému životnému štýlu stanovením globálneho cieľu zníženia textilnej výroby a spotreby v spojení so zavedením opatrení, ktoré zabezpečia zníženú produkciu a rovnomerné prerozdelenie hodnoty, ktorú daný produkt vytvára. Toto dosiahneme nastavením záväzkov transparentnosti a vysledovateľnosti, čoho dôsledkom bude zvýšenie podnikovej zodpovednosti. Taktiež apelujem na navýšenie a podpory pre odborové organizácie v tejto oblasti priemyslu.    Podpora lokálnych výrobcov, okrem zmenšovania negatívnych dopadov na životné prostredie, je potrebná a má zmysel najmä pri tvorbe nových pracovných miest v textilnom priemysle aj v ekonomicky slabších regiónoch Slovenska, ako aj pre udržanie mladých kreatívnych ľudí na domácom trhu. Uvítal by sme konkrétny plán ako podporiť kvalifikovanú pracovnú silu, ktorej je momentálne na Slovensku, ale aj v iných krajinách EÚ nedostatok. Taktiež plán ako komisia plánuje podporiť inovácie v tomto sektore najmä v krajinách, ktoré nie sú na rovnakej štartovacej čiare ako textilne vyspelejšie regióny.    Mám úprimnú radosť z tejto iniciatívy Európskej komisie a veľmi sa teším na ďalšiu príležitosť spolupráce!
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Covid-19 crises has had dire implications on the Albanian economy. While health and social protection take priority in such a context, the economy has undergone some major shocks, that will take years to overcome. This is unprecedented crises for many countries, including Albania, affecting simultaneously the aggregate demand and supply, domestically and externally. In such a context, where the impact of the crises is still unfolding, some industries are experiencing huge changes, such as loss of demand, decreased liquidity, limited number of contracts from internal and externals buyers etc.  The companies of the Garment and Footwear Production industry are considered as one of the main sources of women’s employment in Albania. Unfortunately, there are no official data about the employees of the textile sector, however it is estimated that around 70000 people are working in about 800-1000 companies. 95 % of the workers are women and girls. The numbers could be even higher, considering the high prevalence of informal employment in this sector. Italy, one of the hardest hit countries by Covid-19 in Europe, is the main export country of the goods produced in Albania (estimated 70 %). The reduced consumer demand in Italy might have a considerable impact on companies that export towards Italy, and the impact could still unfold during the beginning of 2021.  During 2020, GADC monitored the situation of some companies in the industry where they mostly report on lack of liquidity, especially not being able to pay the salaries of their employees. This applies to almost all enterprises that were operating in textile sector. Some enterprises were closed due to the cancellation of contracts or the reduced number and value of contract prospects during the year. Even for existing contracts, enterprises reported to not have received any payments from the buyers.  In the garment sector specifically, where GADC has over 5 years of experience, severe and structural human rights violations have been documented in factories. These violations include, but are not limited to, child labor, gender-based discrimination, violence and sexual harassment, excessive and frequently underpaid or unpaid overtime, lack of medical services, decent job working conditions, violation of health safety occupational.  The stories of women met, and many others stories collected by GADC during 2020, and through the years, show that women working in this sector come from very vulnerable positions.   GADC read carefully the Road Map of EU strategy for textiles and would like to bring the following recommendations forward while the impact of Covid-19 crises of the labour market unfolds: • EU should ensure that the companies that are established in the EU countries develop sustainable working places and decent job in the textile sector in Western Balkans countries.  • EU should ensure that this companies take responsibility that the workers are properly paid, they have a job contract and possibility to take annual or sick leave. In addition, should ensure that these companies respect the country legislation, approximated to EU acquis, on safety, labor and social rights compliance. In case of accidents, entitles victims and their families receive compensation. • Directly support reskilling or upskilling initiatives which ensure that women have the required skills and competences to respond to the demands in the entire value chain of the textile industry. • Ensure that the relevant governance structures in the pre-accession countries have the tools and capacities to monitor the adherence to the Labour Code and all the relevant legislation that protect and promotion human rights in the labour market. • Work directly with women and feminist organizations to ensure that women’s voices in this sector are part of the decision-making processes.   More information can be found at the attached document. Feedback from: Gender Alliance for Development Centre (87 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The transformation of our societies towards carbon neutrality and to achieve the SDG’s needs new innovative technologies in particular in the textile sector. Start-ups are a crucial element in the European innovation ecosystem. However, only around 1,4 % of the Start-ups in Europe scale to successful companies.  The Global Entrepreneurship Centre (GEC) powered by Flow gGmbH wants to change this situation and increase the amount of start-ups that scale. The GEC will support the world's best Sustainable Technology (SusTech) Start-ups and entrepreneurs through a unique scale-up service, thus creating sustainable jobs and some of the new unicorns. The GEC is the first global center to focus on sustainability and entrepreneurs with technologies for achieving the global climate targets of the Paris Accord and the SDG’s of the United Nations. One of the priority areas of the GEC is the textile industry as the innovation by start-ups and scale-ups is crucial for the transformation of the textile sector.  The GEC powerd by Flow gGmbH supports the outlines elements of the EU strategy for textiles and wants to add three important issues:  1. Considering the climate crisis and the pandemic, the Covid -19 aids of the EU and member states should be focusing on companies which are selected through a sustainability ranking. This would give priority to sustainable businesses and products in the textile sector. A sustainability ranking puts pressure on other companies to act circular. The EU should provide sustainability and circular guidelines and assessment schemes for the different businesses in the textile economy. The EU should also provide a legislative framework along the supply chain to push companies strictly towards a circular economy. This would also create a level playing field and new market opportunities for start-ups.  2. A clear communication to consumers is a key to achieve a circular economy. The EU should create a legislative framework for labels and consumer communication for the textile sector. Special focus should be given to the E-commerce to avoid the present green washing activities and to increase the transparency of certifications and other labels for the consumer. Otherwise, companies will continue to use labels and terms such as recycling, upcycling, reuse, CO2 reduced in a wrong context. Transparency and clarity in this context would also be of benefit for new companies in the market with a strict sustainability focus.  3. Distributive and value chain innovation will be most important to the future of the European textile industry. In order to achieve the SDG’s, disruptive innovations, for example, with regard to new materials and production methods, are urgently needed. The EU strategy on textile should have one clear focus on the support of start-ups and scale-ups in the particular conservative textile industry. Innovation by start-ups will provide new opportunities to bring production facilities for high class and tech materials back to the EU and will create new industrial growth. The digitalization of the textile industry should be an important area in the EU strategy as it will enable a faster innovation and transformation process and create additional business opportunities.   https://gec-europe.com
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: The U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol welcomes the opportunity to comment on the European Commission’s Roadmap for the "EU Strategy for Textiles". We endorse the direction that the European Commission is taking and the clear focus on improving sustainability throughout the supply chain. The U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol would like to highlight the following four key points in response to the roadmap:  1. Stakeholder consultation We are pleased that the European Commission is taking a holistic view to stakeholder consultation and to gathering views of all industry players. The list of stakeholders mentioned in the roadmap starts from fiber, yarn and clothing manufacturers. We would like to point out that the commitment to sustainability and continuous improvement starts before the fiber comes into existence – in the case of natural fibers such as cotton, with the cotton growers. Over the past 35 years, U.S. cotton has shown great improvements in key sustainability metrics – a greenhouse gas reduction of 40%, energy reduction of 54%, a reduction in soil loss of 37% and a 79% improvement in water use efficiency, among others. We have committed to further improvements by 2025 and will continue to set ambitious goals for the future. We would therefore welcome the opportunity to take part in future stakeholder consultations on the EU Strategy for Textiles.  2. Reinforcing human rights, due diligence and transparency We are glad to see the strong focus in the initiative on exploring “how to reinforce the protection of human rights, environmental duty of care and due diligence across value chains, including improving traceability and transparency”. As a new initiative committed to transparency, the U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol has invested a lot of effort into improving traceability of the cotton supply chain. The supply chain from field to clothes rack is complex, which is why full traceability will take time to achieve. We would welcome the opportunity to share our learnings about transparency and traceability with EU institutions to help you test the feasibility of your proposals and find constructive solutions in the interim as well as for the long-term goal of full traceability.  3. The importance of voluntary initiatives We welcome the focus on voluntary initiatives, including the focus on EU ecolabel measures.  We would like to highlight the importance of data and verification in the application and promotion of voluntary initiatives. In this context, a clear focus on data and third-party verification will be central, in order to ensure that end users can be reassured that they are purchasing and wearing sustainable materials.  4. A holistic life-cycle view The roadmap addresses all stages from design to material choice, to production, consumption and post-consumption. We welcome this view and would like to add the perspective that the textile value chain should not only be considered holistically for textile and apparel products, but also in its relationship to other connected systems. Many by-products of textile production form sustainable resources for non-textile industries such as for instance cottonseed as cattle feed. The scope of the ‘closed loop’ should consider such complexities and not solely focus on fiber-to-fiber recycling.   About the U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol The U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol sets a new standard for more sustainably grown cotton. It brings quantifiable and verifiable goals and measurement to responsibly-grown cotton production and drives continuous improvement in key sustainability metrics. The Trust Protocol underpins and verifies U.S. cotton’s progress through sophisticated data collection and independent third-party verification. Brands and retailers will gain access to U.S. cotton with sustainability credentials proven via Field to Market, measured via the Fieldprint Calculator and verified with Control Union Certifications. feedback_msg_text: As an independent brand Venustaswomen welcomes this initiative by the EU. After learning more about the initiative and the proposed plan by the civil societies we would like to add a few more ideas from a brand point of view.  - To boost the repair of already existing clothes, repair hubs could be established at least on national levels with special guidelines from brands who wish to participate. This would localise a process that would might take long way back to certain brands warehouses for repair. - It would be great to see some kind of centralised legislation on the biggest digital platforms where harmful fast fashion pieces are being advertised everyday. A future ban on the promotion of fast fashion brands by influencers could be a useful step to raise awareness about the issues around the current industry model.  - In terms of recycling, it would be great to see well organised collecting and sorting, and support recycling technology. However a big portion of "low-value second hand clothes" gets sold to emerging countries (Global South) mostly in Africa, where there is an even bigger lack of technology for recycling. The EU might consider taking a responsible role in that, form a comprehensive research on this topic, and might impose different legislative actions on this problem.  - To effectively implement this initiative it would be useful to establish departments for the implementation on national levels, financed and organised by the EU with regular meetings.  - We would encourage a comprehensive research on the possible amount of job cuts that could result after the shift into a circular model and explore the possible new jo opportunities for certain people affected along the value chains. Skill scaling programs could be useful.  - Lastly regulating marketing activities regarding the circular model would be great, as there is a potential of "greenwashing" by brands who rather state false actions and numbers than actually tackling the issues in their own value chain.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the European Commission’s call for a sustainable recovery of the European textile industry. As highlighted in the roadmap, the textile industry is a resource-intensive sector in terms of raw materials and water usage with long value chains and a certain environmental impact. However, it is important to take into consideration the different impacts of the various fibres. Especially natural fibres, which are renewable, biodegradable and not produced based on chemicals should be rated differently to synthetic fibres, which don’t have that benefits, are resource-intensive and can cause micro plastic problems. Also the longer life-cycle of luxury natural fibres compared to synthetic fibres should be noted here. Besides that, we welcome the promotion of the positive influence of certificates like EU Ecolabel and the importance of traceability, which definitely need to be enhanced.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: El Observatorio Iberoamericano de Desarrollo Sostenible y Cambio Climático de la Rábida, Huelva, surge por acuerdo de cooperación entre cuatro instituciones: la Secretaría General Iberoamericana (SEGIB), la Diputación de Huelva, la Junta de Andalucía, y la Secretaría de Estado de Cooperación y para Iberoamérica (SECIPI) del Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores y de Cooperación (MAEC).     Desde el observatorio consideramos de interés que la Comisión Europea tenga en consideración los siguientes aspectos para elaborar la estrategia de sostenibilidad del sector textil:  • Mayor colaboración entre diferentes grupos de interés y transfronteriza para definir sostenibilidad en el sector textil, sus impactos ambientales y sociales en toda la cadena de valor desde la extracción de materias primas.   • Considerar la importancia de los procesos regenerativos de ecosistemas y sociales para impulsar cadenas de valor justas y resilientes a lo largo del tiempo y de manera transfronteriza.  • Establecer marcos de cooperación internacional y herramientas de cooperación que sirvan para generar valor ambiental y social en diferentes cadenas de valor del sector textil.  • Impulsar la transparencia y la trazabilidad a lo largo de la cadena de suministro de los productos desde la materia prima para conocer las condiciones sociales y ambientales de cada una de las etapas de la cadena de suministro y la cadena de valor.  • Identificar mejores materias primas y técnicas que respeten valores ambientales, que preserven tradiciones artesanales y formas de vida que empoderen la diversidad de pueblos y culturas especialmente los ligados a aprovechamientos sostenibles.  • Conocer los riesgos en los servicios ecosistémicos y riesgos sociales que puede producir el sector textil más allá de las fronteras europeas.  • Estimular avances sociales y ambientales en la legislación de diferentes países para que la industria textil deje de tener impacto negativo sobre el planeta y las personas.  • Reconocer la importancia de la artesanía y los aprovechamientos tradicionales agrícolas, forestales, ganaderos y de los sistemas agroforestales respetuosos con el medio ambiente para conseguir materias primas en el sector textil con carácter transfronterizo.  • Establecer marcos de alianzas público-privadas con diferentes actores de Iberoamérica con tradición en el sector textil: marcas, fabricantes (con importancia en Perú, Colombia, Argentina, etc.), abastecimiento de materias primas para el sector (Brasil, Perú, etc.) para la regeneración de ecosistemas para establecer cooperación impulsar desarrollo sostenible. Etc.  • Estimular el conocimiento del consumidor final del sector textil en clave de sostenibilidad, de los atributos de sostenibilidad de su producto e involucrarlo en la compensación de la huella de carbono, en el conocimiento de las mejores prácticas en Economía Circular en las diferentes etapas de la cadena de valor y en su fin de vida útil.
