feedback_msg_text: La « Stratégie européenne pour le textile » est très attendue par le secteur de la réutilisation en Belgique, RESSOURCES accueille avec intérêt la publication de sa feuille de route. Néanmoins, RESSOURCES souhaite profiter de cette occasion pour soulever les points suivants : 1. Priorisation de la prévention et de la préparation au réemploi RESSOURCES estime que la feuille de route se concentre trop sur le développement du secteur du recyclage des textiles. Il est notamment stipulé que l'objectif de cette stratégie est censé remédier aux « faiblesses structurelles concernant la collecte, le tri et le recyclage des déchets textiles dans les États membres ». Qu'en est-il de la lutte contre la surconsommation ou du soutien aux activités de réparation au réemploi et de réemploi ? Rappelons que la réutilisation d’un vêtement d'occasion réduit considérablement l’empreinte carbone par rapport à la production d’un vêtement neuf. Réduire l’impact environnemental de l’industrie textile en rendant simplement le principe de fast-fashion recyclable ne suffira pas. Il existe un besoin pressant de politiques d'écoconception visant à rendre les produits textiles plus durables et réparables, ainsi que d'investissements durables pour financer les activités de réutilisation. RESSOURCES est rassuré de voir que la feuille de route indique que la hiérarchie des déchets sera prise en compte lors de l'étude du rôle de la REP. Cependant, qu'ils soient liés ou non à des programmes de REP, des objectifs concrets privilégiant la réutilisation au recyclage doivent être développés. Ces objectifs permettront aussi de garantir un développement économique local par la création d’emploi durable dans le secteur du textile. 2. Protection des acteurs de l’économie sociale actifs dans les activités de réemploi  Il est encourageant de voir que « l'impact environnemental et social » du secteur textile de l'UE sera abordé, surtout si cet objectif est appliqué à la production de nouveaux textiles ainsi qu'à la gestion du textile usagé. La protection du rôle des entreprises d'économie sociale actives depuis des décennies dans ce secteur est essentielle pour soutenir l'intégration des groupes défavorisés sur le marché du travail. Ce sera une étape particulièrement bienvenue dans le contexte de la reprise de la crise du COVID-19. La collecte, le tri et la vente de textiles d'occasion peuvent créer localement 20 emplois pour 1 000 tonnes de vêtements et chaussures usagés. Le développement de partenariats tout au long de la chaîne de valeur textile avec des entreprises sociales et circulaires maximiserait la production et la consommation durables. Une analyse d'impact devrait également être réalisée concernant les obligations de collecte séparée pour le textile au regard de la directive-cadre sur les déchets, en tenant compte des impacts environnementaux, sociaux et économiques associés sur les opérateurs de gestion des textiles usagés. 3. Les approches volontaristes et les nouveaux business model ne suffiront pas La stratégie décrite dans la feuille de route n'est pas suffisamment solide pour encourager le secteur du textile de l'UE à s'orienter vers une économie circulaire. Encourager de nouveaux business models tels que le principe d’écofonctionnalité (pour lequel la durabilité doit encore être démontrée), ou promouvoir l’utilisation de l’étiquetage volontaire ne permettra pas de rendre la vente de produits de mauvaise qualité moins rentable. La bataille contre la fast-fashion ne sera pas gagnée en donnant aux consommateurs plus de choix ou d'informations. Les mesures d'écoconception doivent rendre les produits textiles plus durables et réparables, la publicité doit être limitée, la destruction ou le recyclage prématuré des produits invendus et retournés doit être interdite et les prix planchers de certains articles emblématiques doivent être développés pour internaliser les externalités environnementales et sociales causées par la production des produits textiles.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: In der globalen Textilproduktion werden systematisch Menschen- und Arbeitsrechte sowie Umweltstandards missachtet und verletzt. Die Menschen in den verschiedenen Produktionsstufen arbeiten für Hungerlöhne, Arbeits- und Gesundheitsschutz sind mangelhaft, Frauen leiden unter geschlechtsspezifischer Gewalt, Flüsse werden durch Chemikalien verseucht etc. - sowohl Mensch als auch Umwelt werden ausgebeutet. Freiwillige Maßnahmen der Unternehmen haben bisher kaum zu Verbesserung dieser Zustände geführt. Wir brauchen eine umweltfreundliche und sozialverträgliche Produktion.  Die Unternehmen müssen dazu verpflichtet werden, bei ihren Geschäften im Inland wie im Ausland menschenrechtliche und umweltbezogene Sorgfalt walten zu lassen. Deshalb sind gesetzliche Maßnahmen unerlässlich, nicht nur auf nationaler sondern auch auf europäischer und internationaler Ebene. Unternehmen müssen in zivilrechtliche Haftung bei Verletzung ihrer Pflichten genommen werden können, Betroffene von Arbeitsrechtsverletzungen müssen das Recht erhalten, vor einem europäischen Gericht zu klagen. Die gesamten Lieferketten von Unternehmen müssen offengelegt und transparent sein.  Aus unserer Sicht sind insbesondere folgende Kernpunkte für eine gesetzliche Regelung wichtig: - zivilrechtliche Haftung von Unternehmen bei Pflichtverletzung - Klagerecht von Opfern vor einem europäischen Gericht - Transparenz der gesamten Lieferkette unter Einbeziehung des informellen Sektors, z.B. Heimarbeit, Wanderarbeit, Kontraktarbeit - Zahlung eines existenzsichernden Lohnes (Allgemeine Erklärung der Menschenrechte Art. 23, ILO-Vereinbarungen) - Geltung nicht nur für Großunternehmen, sondern auch für kleine und mittelständische Unternehmen. - Der Geltungsbereich der Produktion muss Europa mit einbeziehen, denn auch in EU-Staaten wie z.B. Rumänien und Bulgarien werden bei Weitem keine Existenzlöhne gezahlt.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: UFIMH (Union Française des Industries de la Mode et de l’Habillement) is standing for the 2 000 french apparel companies of the sector in all their diversity : mainly ready to wear brands, workwear companies and subcontractors. As an agent for reflection, propositions and initiatives, UFIMH is in constant relation with all relevant French and European institutions to assure the sector has a pro-growth legislative and regulatory environment. To achieve these goals, UFIMH relies on a professional network which includes Medef in Paris and Euratex (The European Apparel and Textile Confederation) in Brussels, as well as contacts with other federations and its own institutional relationships.  UFIMH welcomes the EU consultation on Textile Strategy as an important step toward an ambitious and comprehensive communication on all aspects of European policies for the textile industries.  This communication should be a great opportunity to clarify the European strategy for textiles and to develop new policies while avoiding new administrative burdens or obligations for the SMEs which are the main components of the sector.  UFIMH considers that the communication should address at least five main aspects of the textile competitivity and be based on clear principles :  - Access to the financial resources necessary for their development   Even before the Covid crisis, the sector, especially the young brands, had to face recurrent and important difficulties to secure an easy access to the banking sector and the EU financial instruments. Existing financial instruments should be strengthened, where necessary with direct intervention mechanisms, including the strengthening of equity capital through equity loans.  - Promoting the digital transition of the sector  The digital transition is one of the most challenging priority for the future of the European apparel. It must be encouraged and allow European companies to make full use of all the development possibilities offered by new technologies. The EU initiatives in this field have to take in account not only the industrial aspects but also the commercial developments, especially for the ready to wear brands, in B2B as well as B2C.  - Promoting a sustainable ecological transition  The ecological transition is the second main element to ensure the development of the European apparel in the next years : recycling, traceability and transparency, environmental labeling, green public procurement... This transition should be, as far as the EU policies are concerned, well adapted to the SMEs, their characteristics and possibilities. A successful transition should be based both on the need to promote a sustainable development and on economic realities.   - Improving market access  The market access efforts must be continued, on a bilateral and, if possible, multilateral basis to reduce tariff and non-tariff barriers and promote a fair and free trade for textiles. The export promotion efforts of the member states should be encouraged and an ambitious European promotion plan should be developed.  - Encouraging the Made in Europe productions and secure the Paneuromed partnership  Community policies must promote production within the EU and facilitate the fiscal, legislative and regulatory conditions of this production. In particular, the subject of public procurement must be carefully examined.  In the same time, the EU has to reinforce the paneuromed area of production and exchange (industrial partnership, rules of origin, review of the agreements…), which is a key for the competitivity of the European apparel.  Furthermore, UFIMH totally support the Euratex feedback contribution.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: A ATP – Associação Têxtil e Vestuário de Portugal, em nome das 500 empresas associadas que representa, de toda a fileira têxtil e vestuário, gostaria de saudar esta iniciativa da Comissão. Percebemos que a questão da sustentabilidade está no centro do debate e esta é de facto uma das questões mais importantes no desenvolvimento desta indústria no contexto europeu e mundial. Mas quando falamos de sustentabilidade é fundamental que os três pilares – social, ambiental e económico - estejam em equilíbrio em todos os agentes da cadeia de valor. A indústria têxtil e vestuário (ITV) portuguesa trabalha sobretudo numa lógica de business to business, fornecendo muitas das marcas europeias e internacionais, e o que temos vindo a assistir nos últimos anos é uma enorme pressão para adoção de boas práticas no domínio do social e do ambiental – e a nosso ver, muito bem – no entanto, estas boas práticas nem sempre são compensadas na vertente económica, em muito devido à enorme pressão concorrencial que vivemos neste setor, à escala internacional.  As empresas que representamos sentem que na UE há dois pesos e duas medidas: o que é produzido na Europa deve cumprir todos os requisitos sociais e ambientais, mesmo que isso implique elevados custos de ajustamento, no entanto, o que é importado não obedece aos mesmos critérios e mesmo quando obrigatoriamente tem de obedecer, como ninguém controla ou fiscaliza o mercado, os produtos vendidos atestam cumprir determinados critérios, nalguns casos, até de segurança, mas na verdade não cumprem. Ora, esta situação cria uma enorme injustiça social e económica para as indústrias europeias, com uma concorrência completamente desleal. Por sua vez, os consumidores continuam a não ser protegidos. Esta será uma excelente oportunidade para se desenvolverem políticas e mecanismos de controlo que resolvam definitivamente esta situação que já perdura há demasiado tempo, em prejuízo das indústrias e dos consumidores europeus, sem que a Comissão tenha de facto tomado medidas para resolver o problema. Consideramos ainda que esta iniciativa deve ter uma ambição mais ampla, que é abordar a competitividade e a resiliência da ITV europeia, sem a qual nenhuma estratégia de sustentabilidade pode ser implementada. A estratégia deve proporcionar crescimento e emprego à Europa, uma transformação sustentável desta cadeia de valor fundamental e garantir condições equitativas a nível mundial.  É igualmente fundamental que esta iniciativa esteja ligada com outros domínios, igualmente relevantes para este setor, como por exemplo, inovação, I&D, digitalização, competências, compras públicas, normalização, vigilância de mercado, tendências de consumo, alguns dos quais bastante desafiantes para o setor e para os quais deverão ser desenvolvidas políticas que promovam esta indústria e que a posicionem na liderança da transformação à escala global, sem esquecer que a maioria das empresas deste setor é de pequena e média dimensão, com alguns constrangimentos em termos sociais e financeiros. É por este motivo que esta iniciativa deve ser coordenada e estar em coerência com as diferentes políticas da EU devendo eliminar as contradições que existem entre as diferentes políticas.  Por outro lado, é fundamental perceber que este setor abrange um conjunto de atividades muito diversas, com produtos e serviços muito diversos, para mercados completamente distintos e dentro da UE existem países com interesses divergentes em função do tipo de indústria que representam. É essencial que a estratégia venha a considerar os interesses de toda a cadeia de valor da ITV europeia. É igualmente importante a realização de avaliações de impacto cuidadosas e realistas para qualquer nova proposta e deve ser reservado apoio para investimentos estratégicos (emblemáticos) que fomentem uma indústria inovadora e sustentável com visão de futuro e empregos de alta qualidade na Europa.

feedback_msg_text: ● Le DEFI est la plateforme de développement et de financement originale mi-privée/mi-publique au service des 3500 entreprises de l’habillement français. Il finance, anime et encourage des actions concrètes dédiées à la croissance des entreprises et des créateurs, à l’émergence d’une mode responsable, à la stimulation de l’innovation, à la promotion des savoir-faire et de la confection. Il travaille en lien avec toutes les fédérations françaises. Il permet une solidarité unique entre petites et grandes entreprises.  ● La Stratégie doit s’appuyer sur ses forces actuelles pour dégager des opportunités de croissance:  o Un secteur leader mondial grâce à ses marques de luxe,, l puissance de la création, de l’innovation immatérielle (fashion weeks, écoles...), ses enseignes mass-market  o Un tissu de savoir-faire d’excellence unique  o La mode constitue le secteur le plus important des ICC (40%) o Un dynamisme tiré par les marques et la distribution.  La fabrication représente encore 27% du chiffre d’affaires  o La mode européenne présente des niveaux de garanties et de sécurité parmi les plus élevées au monde  o Un secteur où les PME prédominent : 92% des entreprises ont moins de 10 salariés  ● La Stratégie de l’UE pour maintenir et renforcer son leadership doit garantir la compétitivité de la filière européenne, notamment ses PME. Quatre grands piliers sont à privilégier : la création, la mode durable, la transformation numérique, l’innovation technologique.  ● PILIER 1 : la création, la culture, l’excellence  L’Europe dispose en la matière d’un atout stratégique unique au monde. La Stratégie doit renforcer cet avantage concurrentiel.  ● PILIER 2 : la mode durable D’ores et déjà, les attentes des consommateurs constituent un puissant facteur de mutation des marques qui sont les moteurs de la filière. La Stratégie doit : o Intégrer les PME et s’adapter à leur réalité. :  ▪ Privilégier le recours aux labels. L’UE a un rôle essentiel à jouer en identifiant les labels les plus fiables. Les PME n’ont pas la capacité d’engager des analyses exhaustives de leurs chaînes de valeur : vouloir l’imposer conduirait à une distorsion flagrante de concurrence en leur défaveur alors même qu’elles ne sont pas à l’origine des principaux dysfonctionnements du secteur. Une approche par les labels permettra une information fiable des consommateurs et la flexibilité nécessaire pour les entreprises. ▪ L’inclusion effective des PME.  ▪ La lisibilité et la cohérence des diverses initiatives o Repousser toute forme de dumping environnemental :  ▪ Les problèmes majeurs en termes d’environnement, de changement climatique, d’éthique trouvent leurs origines en dehors de l’Union. ▪ L’UE doit être claire sur les règles qu’elle exigera pour l’entrée des produits en Europe.  o S’appuyer sur les atouts de la production Made in Europe  Celle-ci répond naturellement à toutes les exigences de la mode durable. Le premier axe d’intervention efficace de l’UE sera d’élargir les critères «green» des Marchés Publics en intégrant des indicateurs liés à la confection.  ● PILIER 3 : la transformation numérique Elle constitue une nécessité pour atteindre les objectifs de mode durable ainsi qu’un puissant levier de compétitivité par l’émergence de nouveaux modèles économiques et l’amélioration de l’efficacité de la filière. Pour autant, la transformation numérique n’est pas une réalité qui se développe indépendamment des spécificités des secteurs. La Stratégie doit donc favoriser :  o Un plan mode qui vise l’acculturation et le financement de projets, en incluant une approche PME o Un renforcement des rapprochements entre entreprises et startups afin de permettre l’éclosion d’un véritable écosystème de la mode.  ● PILIER 4 : La recherche et l’innovation technologique  Des progrès importants sont indispensables dans des domaines clés de la mode durable, en priorité les matériaux, la fabrication et le recyclage. La recherche et l’innovation méritent un plan majeur d’investissement Feedback from: DEFI (104.8 KB - PDF - 11 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: NordShield® supports the initiative and roadmap. NordShield® wishes to promote natural based and sustainable antimicrobial technology also for consumer textiles. In the new normal, we enable sustainable technology for creating antimicrobial textiles for consumers. The current field of regulation, however, is not fully supporting the market entry of novel technologies.  The new normal is a vulnerable, globalized world with challenges from viruses, bacteria and fungi like we have never seen before. Current state-of-the-art antimicrobial solutions used e.g. in textiles offer adequate efficacy, however, their efficacy is based on non-sustainable and toxic chemicals and substances, such as heavy metals. These substances pose a huge threat to life and environment due to their toxicity and persistence in nature. Yet, these substances are approved - and used by industries daily, allowing them to leach into our nature and even the bodies of those wearing those textiles. The textile industry is faced with a new challenge and at the same time a big opportunity for everyday protection of people. With the right support, novel technologies can provide an environmentally friendlier solution.  We would like to raise the topic of needing to promote and reward companies that use new, safer and ecologically better options with less harmful chemicals. Renewable raw materials, and innovations developed from those, undoubtedly provide answers and tools for this challenge, while also offering sustainable solutions for people and the planet. Textile products are not anymore seen as materials that only provide cover and performance to their wearer, but also attention has to be paid to other possible protection, such as antibacterial and antiviral protection. In an environmental and sustainable way of operating, efforts should be focused on an antimicrobial protection in textiles that is not based for instance on QUATs or heavy metals such as silver, copper and zinc as current market standards, but are resulting from innovations provided from nature, such as the forest industry.  Thus, more impact is needed to tackle the presence of hazardous chemicals and the effort should be more focused on solving this dilemma. Although the initiative proposes actions to promote more sustainable production processes, it is of importance to ever stronger promote new novel antimicrobial innovations, which are not only the solution to avoid use of harmful chemicals but are also natural based and thus supporting the textile strategy’s main aims. We believe this view is not yet considered in the textile strategy but has drawn the attention of business development of many companies and textile manufacturers. Many of the biggest companies already refuse to use biocides and heavy metals for antimicrobial protection, a healthy development that should be supported and rewarded by regulators.  As a conclusion, we see that it is of utmost importance that the roadmap puts effort on research and innovation, as the need for new novel technologies in textile industry has been identified, and these also have already been brought to the market. This support should also materialize through regulatory support for novelties that do not fall into earlier categories of regulation, and by seeing the need for flexible regulation to enable these technologies entering the market and thus speeding up the adaption of sustainable alternatives.  The full feedback can be found in our attached document.  Feedback from: Anonymous (147.5 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: I am the General Delegate of the textiles division at the Bureau of International Recycling (BIR).  The views expressed here are my own, but I recommend the EU fully consult the BIR.   I would like to see the following matters considered.   1)            Support the development of robust collection system by 2025   This should be underpinned by implementing the principles of the waste hierarchy. Spending on new clothing has risen 3 x in the EU since 2000. Consumer awareness should be enhanced to limit consumption,  products should be designed to last longer & when collected, it is vital that the systems in place keep used clothing in use. Items that need to be recycled should be separated efficiently & moved into new mechanical or chemical recycling outlets, the research for which could be funded through EPR. Collection systems that are implemented must also prioritise the minimisation of contamination. There is no point implementing collection systems that pick up larger amounts of contaminated textiles that are then thrown away.   2)            Develop a series of proposals for member states wishing to implement EPR   The EU needs to go further than only considering the role of EPR. Fashion accounts for 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions & 20% of all freshwater pollution, is a major consumer of freshwater suppliers & a source of micro-plastics.There needs to be a commitment across the EU to review producer responsibility and after this should it be considered appropriate then I would welcome implementation of an EU directive for EPR on clothing. Member states need to move beyond being reluctant to impose producer responsibility obligations on those that put harmful products onto the market. The impacts of the fashion industry are far to big to ignore.   France already has an EPR scheme & Sweden has committed to introducing EPR in 2022.  In addition, the Dutch Government is introducing a framework to parliament in the spring. Furthermore, although now outside the EU, the UK has also committed to a review on EPR on textiles & the Textile Recycling Association has published its own paper on EPR (https://www.textile-recycling.org.uk/press-release-textile-recycling-association-publish-position-paper-on-extended-producer-responsibility-for-clothing-and-textiles/)   It is important that such schemes help to develop collection and sorting infrastructure, fund R&D projects to develop new markets, promote collections through communications campaigns & ultimately deliver improvements along the entire supply chain. Improve product design can be funded through EPR or they can be addressed through separate legislation. The radical chemical tax being implemented in Sweden is a case in point. This roadmap should look at what is being delivered elsewhere.   Additionally if EPR schemes (& the roadmap) can be supported by the setting of meaningful & challenging targets this may help to deliver the necessary investment and actions required.   3)            Support the establishment of more re-use and recycling markets in the EU.   Again industry could be made to fund R&D  through EPR or it could be funded directly by the EU and its tax payers.   4)            Help to develop design protocols to facilitate re-use and recycling.   With common high professional standards in place this will help facilitate the free movement of goods & wastes (for recycling) both within the EU and in other countries.   Finally, it is important that the accuracy of information provided in documents is checked. E.g. In the consultation the claim that less than 1% of textiles is recycled back into textiles is NOT true. Less than 1% of clothing is recycled into clothing (this is not the same). A much higher percentage or textiles is recycled into insulation, filling material etc. Also the consumption rate of new clothing of 26kg per head needs checking. A report for the European Clothing Action Plan only put the UK at this rate.  Other countries consumed much less.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: The international traceability and transparency framework initiative led by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) and its working party the United Nations Centre for Trade Facilitation and Electronic Business (UN/CEFACT), emphasizes the key enabling role of transparency and traceability in advancing sustainability and circularity the textile industry. To support this, the initiative has developed a Policy Recommendation to Governments on Traceability and Transparency in Garment and Leather Value Chains, Guidelines for implementation and a Call to Action with reporting mechanisms. p  To be cost-effective and support the widest possible implementation, traceability approaches need to be standardized, building upon existing standards to ensure interoperability with existing data management systems. So, in addition, the UNECE is in the process of finalizing data content standards for the exchange of traceability and sustainability (transparency) information and, during 2021 will develop messaging standards for the exchange of this information. The standard that maps the key business processes, actors and sustainability information to be traced along the value chain so that all actors speak the same language about product claims.   We are convinced that traceability, when linked with exchanges of sustainability information, is a major tool for customers and industry actors to use when assessing product characteristics and, substantiating claims about sustainability and circularity. A global standard for transparency information, which builds upon existing traceability standards, such as that being developed by the UNECE, can foster reusing and recycling practices by providing reliable product information to consumers, disposal, and recycling facilities.   Additionally, traceability  and transparency can enable processes for closing the loop downstream and upstream in support of circular production processes, business models and sustainable investments. This means supporting upstream activities such as eco-design, product lifespan extension and resource efficiency as well as downstream activities such as recycling, repairing and remanufacturing services. Most importantly, traceability, when linked with sustainability information, can support a circular economy by allowing the recovery of data needed to implement better waste management and circularity, such as product content, and can help identify the impacts of products and processes on people and the planet (e.g. by quantifying CO2 generation, the use hazardous chemicals and water, etc.)   Regulators and standard-setting entities have an important role to play in promoting and supporting stronger policy coherence across national and regional levels. The UNECE Recommendation to Governments supports this policy coherence which is essential for creating a level playing field with incentives that encourage the use of sustainable textiles (e.g. preferential tariffs, green public procurement).  Policy coherence is also critical to advancing the transition to a circular economy through a holistic approach that supports the use of credible environmental and social claims.   Other key enablers for a circular economy identified by the UNECE are technology (e.g. confidence-building solutions like blockchain), research and development (e.g. sustainable and circular production processes), awareness and education (e.g. on recycling, reusing, repairing) and multi-stakeholder collaborative initiatives. The UNECE Recommendation’s Call for Action looks to support the movement toward a circular economy by providing a forum for highlighting the achievements of governments, the private sector and other stakeholders in supporting more transparent and sustainable textile and leather value chains.  For more contact Maria Teresa Pisani (maria-teresa.pisani@un.org) or visit:https://unece.org/trade/traceability-sustainable-garment-and-footwear

feedback_msg_text: The Plastic Soup Foundation congratulates the EU for finally moving forward in reducing the environmental and social impacts resulting from the textile sector. A drastic, systemic change is needed in order to swiftly tackle the environmental and health problems caused by the textile sector.  As stated in the roadmap, the textile sector is responsible for important climate and environmental impacts. One of these impacts is plastic microfiber pollution as a result of manufacturing, washing, wearing, and drying clothes that contain plastic materials.  Plastic particles washed off from products such as synthetic clothes and textiles contribute to 35 percent of primary microplastics polluting our oceans, according to a report by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Wastewater treatment plants cannot retrieve these microfibers and as a result they end up in the ocean. Thereby, just by wearing synthetic clothes, plastic fibers are constantly released into the air. Research has shown that polyester clothes pollute the air as much as the water, highlighting the importance of knowing the consequences of microfibers in the air.  Microfibers have also been analysed in the textile production chain showing a big abundance of particles flowing into the wastewater effluent, which proves that upstream stages in the textile production are also an important source of microfiber pollution.  Next to environmental concerns, there is also enough reason for human health concerns. Recent research has proven that we are eating and drinking plastic and that plastic fibers are even raining down from the sky. We are breathing in at least 13,000 to 68,000 plastic microfibers from our clothing, carpets, curtains, and other textiles per year.  Considering our concerns, we suggest the following:  • We strongly encourage a coordinated and harmonized response at EU level to address structural weaknesses when it comes to reducing and collecting of textile waste, in particular plastic microfibers. Considering our grave concerns of plastic microfiber release for the environment and human health, we emphasize the need for effective enforcement and binding regulations, based on the precautionary approach. • An EU standard that regulates microfiber emissions is needed. It is important that public authorities take the lead in setting this standard and monitoring it, and it should not be in hands of industry bodies. • Due to the fact that a majority of the textile products sold in Europe are manufactured outside of the EU, it is important to not only consider the final product but focus on the whole value chain when it comes to plastic microfiber pollution. • The strategy needs to be more ambitious and upstream solutions, including better design, prevention and re-use should be promoted. It is very important to give priority to improving the overall environmental performance and impact of products put on the market, and to not only look at the end-of-life phase. • Toxic, wasteful and polluting products should be removed from the EU market. • Mandatory requirements for textiles sold in the EU must cover plastic microfiber release from textiles by going beyond measurement and towards prevention measures such as controlled industrial pre-washing (under the condition that the water is filtered).  • Design needs to be focused on durability, reuse and repairability. • We strongly encourage mandatory standardized labelling and claims on sustainability and circularity in order to prevent industrial bodies from ‘greenwashing’ and to ensure the right of consumers to know about polluting and hazardous substances, including microplastics, in the products they buy. feedback_msg_text: In order to achieve true circularity in the textile industry, there is a need for cross-pollination with other industries, such as agriculture, science and technology. An example is the use of wool –which is a byproduct of the meat industry– as a great-performance fibre that can have a variety of applications. At present, the price of wool is cheaper than the cost of shearing sheep, which leads to economical stress on farmers and a waste of a valuable, underused resource. The EU needs to help create bridges between different industries in order to create more resilient economies and turn “waste” into raw materials. Circularity also involves looking at the social impacts of textile production. The full cycle of the raw materials should be taken into consideration, from source to end of life.  The use of natural fibres must be incentivised above synthetics, as they are proven to be longer-lasting and biodegradable at the end of their lifecycle. Natural fibres can also contribute to climate change mitigation and carbon sequestration if grown with a focus on soil regeneration. Soil has the capacity and ability to deliver mitigation, balance and solve the effects of climate breakdown as it affects us economically, environmentally and socially, by restoring and enriching many of nature's invaluable assets. When we regenerate our soils, we restore our planet. Only 5,000 hectares are required to impact any given microclimate. Nature has value in combatting Climate Breakdown and building rural community wealth. Therefore, the services that contribute to soil health and resiliency have an intrinsic market value. Sustainability is not enough at this point and the focus must instead be shifted towards regeneration. Fuel-based textiles are usually marketed as “greener options”, but in reality they are still based on an extractive, rather than a regenerative process.  The Strategy for Sustainable Textiles must seek to educate small and big textile companies to start buying products that are regenerative or organically grown. As well as informing the general population about the environmental benefits of choosing such products.  In order to really tackle the problem with micro plastics in our water systems, their production should really be eradicated. As for the plastic-based fibres already in circulation, incentives to keep them from entering our waterways by washing only when necessary and using a micro plastic bag, mending, repurposing and passing on to others should be clear and consistent. Recycling should be the last option after all other alternatives have been exhausted.  The EU Strategy for Sustainable Textiles must be a framework that places more value on quality over quantity. As we have learned, focusing on increasing quantities of production brings forth unmeasurable environmental and social damage. Placing more emphasis on smaller, regional economies is also a great strategy for creating true circularity and achieving better solutions for the environment and the communities, both within the EU and abroad.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Thank you for the opportunity to comment the EU strategy for sustainable textiles. On behalf of Lounais-Suomen Jätehuolto a public waste management company, I would like to emphasize the importance of the need of holistic guidelines for the whole industry from designing and production to consumption and reusing and recycling. Roadmap could include concrete targets with timelines, on that way the common understanding would be clear for all the actors in the industry.   To make sure the planned targets can be reached the focus should be in the quality of the primary raw-materials and products, in creating the markets for recycled raw-materials and also in shared risks of new investments, which are urgently needed.  To ensure long life cycle, reusability and recyclability the quality of used materials and products have to be better than today in many cases. Also to create the markets for recycled materials should be supported in many ways.   Various textile ecosystems, companies and governments are taking the actions towards sustainable and circular solutions. One concern is that we create many different standards and systems which are not fitted together. Sure every region is different and different systems work better in some countries than others, but the developed solutions should be linked together and should work for the same goals by supporting each others, not making new barriers. Best practices should be shared, already developed solutions should be implemented widely and the development should be as open as possible to ensure the best solutions found in EU.  Additionally I would like to add, that establishing an EPR system in the textile sector should be voluntary based. EPR should not interfere the collection mandate of municipalities and the commitment of non-profit organizations. The activation of producer responsibility must not replace municipal and non-profit collection structures, but should support them through financing mechanisms, as well as flank them with product design and recycling specifications. EPR model, if implemented, should tread national actors, exporters and web-stores with the same rules.   Its important that the responsibility of post-consumer textile waste belongs to municipalities. That enables that the collection and sorting systems and recycling solutions could be seen holistically and "cherry picking" can be avoided. It also enables that all textiles are processed with best solutions found and the focus will be in environmental protection, water protection and special focus could be paid on data collection, reporting of the textiles flows and other data needed for developing the solutions and also on measuring the impacts. However all parts of value chains should be developed and implemented in cooperation.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Texfor is the main Spanish textile industry association with more than 400 members mainly spinners, weavers, accessories producers, finishing processes, printing and dying for the apparel industry, home textiles and technical/industrial applications.  1. Take into account the industry as a key player to generate value for other stakeholder groups, because of its ability to scale solutions for different interest groups (FASHION, HOME TEXTILE, AUTOMOTIVE, etc.), in terms of decarbonization and circular economy.  2.  Provide positive discrimination strategies for those actors who work with high social and environmental performance as opposed to those who do not and can cause serious damage to the environment or people, regardless of where the products are manufactured.  3. Emphasise the importance of the European Textile Industrial ecosystem, which is world leader in decarbonization and circular economy. The industry is made up mostly of SMEs.  In Europe, there are hundreds of textile factories, highly specialized in different products, and in many cases with a long family tradition, mostly in the southern European countries (Italy, Portugal and Spain). They work with high social and environmental standards due to European regulations but see their existence in danger due to the difficulty of including their environmental and social performance in the price of their products. Promote production with a low carbon footprint at all stages of the value chain. (raw materials, spinning, weaving, dyeing and finishing fabrics, printing, making and finishing garments)  4. Encourage public-private investments to find systemic solutions for the European textile industry, as a tool to promote the circular economy and decarbonization of textiles industry. Most small and medium-sized companies are not very attractive to investors and often close without generational change, leading to an increasingly less rich and resilient ecosystem and more dependent on imports in Europe. Stimulate the criteria for investment funds ESG (Environmental Social & Governance) with a focus on supply chains and industrial manufacturing.. Also, to stimulate the criteria for investment funds ESG (Environmental Social & Governance) ASG (Environmental, Social and Good Governance) with a focus on supply chains and industrial manufacturing.  5. Homogenize at European level EPR (Extended Product Responsibility) with eco-design for recyclability and sustainability, and use the textile industry  as a tool to scale solutions, thanks to their capacity to make production from waste through upcycling (For example, currently just in Spain, 61,000tn of textile products are generated from post-industrial textile waste)  6. Considering the effects of pollution beyond European Borders, most textile products consumed in Europe come from countries with less evolved environmental and social legislation : wastewater discharges, waste, emissions, environmental impact assessments, environmental liability insurance, etc. as well as social conditions causing risks on significant environmental and social grievances outside our borders.   7. Generate specific studies that allow the consideration of social and environmental impacts and bottlenecks in the Circular Economy, key for the textile sector, that can help policy makers to have a holistic vision to promote real solutions.  8.  Develop tools for the traceability knowledge of the product by the end consumer.  9. Promote cooperation of different textile value chain stakeholders (suppliers of raw materials, industrial, Brands, intermediate and final customers, administrations, managers of textile waste, etc.), to generate business opportunities and a more resilient society.  Sabadell, 1st of February 2021 Feedback from: TEXFOR (159 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the European Commission’s call for a sustainable recovery of the European textile industry. As highlighted in the roadmap, the textile industry is a resource-intensive sector in terms of raw materials, energy and water usage with long value chains.  There is a huge untapped potential within the European textile industry. The pulp and paper industry has the capability to be part of the solution. We acknowledge that this potential needs to be tapped into through a coherent policy framework, that provides businesses with certainty to invest in long term sustainable solutions, that will benefit our European industry, citizens and environment. In the light of the EU-Next Generation Recovery Plan, it is essential that the European Commission encourages the development of a new kind of European textile industry, which will be able to increase European resilience. To ensure that the textile industry becomes more circular and less energy intensive, it is important to follow a holistic approach that will consider the necessary steps along the entire value chain. Wood-based cellulose fibres are already commercially available, having the same level of malleability as synthetic fibres, while retaining the comfort typical for natural fibres. This kind of fibres should be promptly promoted as a highly sustainable alternative. By incentivising the uptake of wood-based cellulose fibres, Europe could significantly decrease its dependence on imported raw materials and reduce GHG emissions. Wood-based cellulose fibres are 100% renewable, recyclable and biodegradable. They also have a low water footprint during the growth phase and do not lead to soil depletion but are rather capable of reversing soil degradation and erosion.  The pulp and paper industry is a key player in the transition towards a more circular economic model and is committed to retaining the value of the materials used in the loop for as long as possible. This effort can also be recognised in the different solutions our industry has developed to improve the circularity performance within the textiles industry. feedback_msg_text: IKEA Range and Supply welcomes the ambitions described in the EU Strategy for Textiles Roadmap. The objectives outlined align with our ambitions to promote a circular business model based on reuse, repair, refurbishment and remanufacturing of products.  By 2030, IKEA aims to become a fully circular business. With limited global resources, we recognize the role and responsibility we have to enable the prolongation of product and material life, through the four circular loops of reuse, refurbishment, remanufacturing, and recycling. To live up to our vision to create a better everyday life for the many people, we are shifting toward this sustainable business model to offer customers a better life within the boundaries of our planet.   We have already come a long way, but to reach our goal we need support and legal certainty. We are encouraged by several aspects of the Roadmap and would like to highlight the need for:  - An EU-wide infrastructure for textile waste collection, sorting and recycling. - Regulatory alignment on due diligence requirements.  - Harmonization of Extended Producer Responsibility systems across Member States. - Free and fair trade beyond the boarders of the EU. - Securing chemical safety of secondary raw materials from post consumer textile waste. - Investment in production processes, design, new materials and new business models   Please refer to the attached position for more a more in-depth analysis. We look forward to serving as a constructive partner in the European Commission’s process of developing a new strategy for textiles. feedback_msg_text: Le défi, c'est de concilier performance et soutenabilité de l’industrie textile Les fibres naturelles existent depuis les origines de l’homme. Grâce aux avancées dans le domaine de la chimie, les fibres synthétiques ont permis de répondre aux besoins croissants de la société de consommation et jouent un rôle clé dans le domaine des technologies avancées. Pour exemple, les masques de protection (PPE) faits  avec des polymères issus de la pétrochimie, s'avèrent irremplaçables avec la crise sanitaire. Il faut donc tenir compte de l’acquis amené par l’essor des fibres synthétiques et concilier complexité des matériaux textiles et circularité des matières.  Les matériaux secondaires, c’est-à-dire issus du recyclage, sont souvent de moindre qualité que le matériau primaire, ce qui affecte la valeur du produit recyclé et donc l’économie même du recyclage. Aussi, le recyclage des nouveaux matériaux est une préoccupation à la fois économique, énergétique et sociétale majeure, objet d’une complète reconsidération stratégique. Comment faire le meilleur usage possible de la matière ? Aujourd’hui, les stratégies de développement des matériaux visent à faire le meilleur usage possible de la matière pour remplir une fonction, voire plusieurs. D’où l’importance d’une approche comparatiste dans le développement des nouveaux matériaux, avec une possibilité de choix multicritères Pour exemple, certains grands papetiers ont réorienté leur production, la pulpe de cellulose servant à la fabrication de viscose, la viscose étant la fibre biosourcée qui connaît la plus forte croissance. Il convient d’optimiser la circularité des matières en combinant la dynamique de recyclage avec la recherche sur de nouvelles chaînes polymères biosourcées qui procureront aux matières des fonctions inédites, seules ou combinées avec des textiles recyclés.  Un préalable est d’organiser la filière de production des matières premières pour des biopolymères renouvelables et recyclables, en lien avec les groupes chimistes.  Il en est de même des nouvelles techniques de fonctionnalisation de surface.Dans le processus de la transformation de la matière, la mise au point de procédés éco-efficients est la clé de la durabilité. Il faut aussi développer des méthodes permettant l’industrialisation rapide de ces procédés. Réconcilier fibres naturelles et fibres synthétiques. Les cotons et laines deviennent techniques avec des effets lissés, froissés, lavés, enduits ou irisés. Les fibres longues sont appropriées pour stabiliser les matières naturelles. Même si une démarche biomimétique évidente est le développement durable et le recyclage des matériaux, les acquis des fibres synthétiques peuvent guider le développement de nouvelles fibres biosourcées, voire l’optimisation des caractéristiques des fibres naturelles. On assiste d’ailleurs à un retour du lin et du chanvre. En outre, des procédés ont été développés afin d’assouplir leur fibre qui est naturellement très raide. Un écosystème des industries utilisant les matériaux textiles. Pour favoriser l’interconnexion entre les filières matériaux, il faut miser sur les plateformes numériques. Actuellement, chaque filière matériaux met en place sa plateforme pour identifier/ caractériser les matières premières secondaires (MPS) issues du recyclage et mettre en relation les recycleurs générant les MPS avec les fabricants de produits susceptibles de les utiliser. Progressivement, les recycleurs verront le gisement de textiles usagés évoluer. Les volumes de fibres pétrochimiques diminueront au profit de davantage de  fibres biosourcées.  L’écoconception et le recyclage ne permettront une optimisation de la circularité des matières que si l’on se dote de dispositifs  pour décloisonner les filières matières. La caractérisation des matières textiles, primaires et secondaires,  est un prérequis indispensable. La « texturgie », nouvelle filière des matières textiles. Feedback from: T3NEL (59.5 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the roadmap to more sustainable textile strategy prepared by the EC and inclusion of Fair and Sustainable Textiles, European civil society strategy for sustainable textiles, garments, leather and footwear as a document to serve as an input for the preparation of the Comprehensive EU Strategy. The new textile strategy should focus on preventing textile waste as much as possible and boosting reuse, repair and circularity. Although it is very important to make the EU textile sector more sustainable and competitive, it is also necessary to protect everyone included in the global textile value chain. Due diligence of human rights and environmental protection in the whole textile value chain must become obligatory in due time and not be based on voluntary commitments anymore. We also welcome the intention to include as many stakeholders as possible in the preparation of the strategy, because the strategy will need a wide consensus in order to be implemented impactfully.   Ekologi brez meja, Focus, društvo za sonaraven razvoj & Zavod za pravično trgovino, 3MUHE
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: The Green Tone helps European fashion brands & Chinese manufacturers foster the right partnerships to enable impactful changes in complex value chains whilst delivering business results. We welcome the EU strategy for sustainable textiles, and wish to actively support the initiative in guiding local brands and manufacturers to reach:  - Transparency: Be efficient oversight of their supply chain and build credibility to their statements. - Competitiveness: Champion sustainability best practices and gain confidence in their expansion. - Loyalty: Strengthen partnerships between brands & manufacturers to escalate responsible operations. - Accountability: Share their sustainability agenda and integrate reporting systems to continuously elevate their offer.  Our 360-degree program is designed to lead transformational results in today textile landscapes: outsourced production, fragmented supply chain and cultural boundaries, in line with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. We specifically focus on Goals 8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth), 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production) and 17 (Partnerships for the Goals).   Businesses are not all wired the same way, yet they have similar pain points. This is why we craft tailored solutions to best accompany executives at every steps of the transformation whilst escalating responsible practices through the below key steps:  1- Identify their blind spots Real opportunity lies in looking within their business to understand how their practices impact their value chain, identify first actionable solutions and prioritize their goals.  2- Inspire positive changes Engage their team and business partners to re-think traditional processes together and co-create solutions that strengthen responsible practices within their operations.  3- Elevate their value chain Streamline their operations to enhance transparency and achieve their long-term sustainable vision, profits, and competitiveness.  By working on critical challenges along the textile value chain of European fashion businesses, we sincerely wish to join strength with the EU Commission to scale strategies and relevant solutions that will help local brands and manufacturers achieve their long-term sustainable vision, profits, and competitiveness.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Conau è l’associazione italiana, aderente a Fise UNICIRCULAR, che rappresenta raccoglitori, intermediari e selezionatori delle raccolte di abbigliamento usato. In Italia la raccolta differenziata della frazione tessile dei rifiuti urbani, senza obbligo, si è sviluppata in modo non omogeneo. Molti Comuni o soggetti delegati effettuano gare affidando la raccolta tramite cassonetti posizionati su suolo pubblico. I rifiuti restano di proprietà di chi effettua la raccolta, che con il ricavato della valorizzazione sostiene i costi della raccolta stessa. In questa attività si sono specializzate molte cooperative sociali che hanno sviluppato specifiche competenze, creando molti posti di lavoro per persone fragili. La raccolta è concentrata esclusivamente su abbigliamento e calzature e non sul tessile domestico. Negli ultimi anni l’aumento del fast fashion e il calo della qualità delle materie prime, l’incremento delle raccolte solidali per bisognosi e delle app per la vendita on line dei capi inutilizzati sta facendo calare la qualità dell’abbigliamento raccolto. Questo, con l’aumento dei quantitativi, fa scendere il valore del materiale rendendo difficile sostenere i costi delle raccolte con i ricavi. Le circa 150.000 t/a raccolte in Italia sono vendute ad aziende che selezionano il materiale da avviare a riuso suddividendoli in diverse fasce di qualità da vendere sul mercato italiano o estero. Questi “selezionatori” sono situati in Italia e altri Paesi (nord Africa, Est Europa, Emirati). I selezionatori italiani comprano materiale in Italia ed Europa in funzione delle esigenze dei loro clienti (grossisti) che a loro volta servono negozi e mercati. Oltre il 50% del materiale selezionato non è idoneo al riuso ed è ceduto a zero ad aziende collocate in India ed in Pakistan che lo riciclano con tecnologie obsolete. Fanno eccezione i capi non riusabili ma realizzati con materie prime pregiate che sono riciclati da aziende dell’area di Prato. Circa il 10% del totale viene smaltito in discarica. L’obbligo di raccolta aumenterà i quantitativi delle raccolte da vendere (comprendendo anche i tessili domestici) e peggiorerà la qualità dei capi conferiti, provocando un ulteriore calo del valore, con difficoltà a trovare compratori. Ciò potrebbe bloccare il sistema portando a dover smaltire questi materiali o avviarli a recupero energetico, con molte attività di raccolta costrette a chiudere con la perdita di numerosi posti di lavoro. Per evitare lo scenario descritto Conau propone di: 1. Supportare le cooperative specializzate nella raccolta e indispensabili per evitare un peggioramento della qualità causata da raccoglitori non specializzati. 2. Mantenere in capo a chi raccoglie la proprietà del materiale e quindi la responsabilità della sua valorizzazione, in caso contrario si avrebbe una loro deresponsabilizzazione. 3. Sostenere la nascita presso le cooperative di centri di “pre selezione” con l’obiettivo di eliminare tutto il materiale raccolto non interessante per i selezionatori commerciali. Così la frazione riusabile diventa più vendibile e si intercetta tutto il materiale non riusabile evitandone la dispersione. 4. Sviluppare “Recycling Hub”, con la partecipazione di produttori ed aziende del riciclo, per riciclare  in modo appropriato e sostenibile i materiali non riusabili provenienti dalla “pre selezione”. 5. Allineare codici ambientali e doganali per consentire regolari transazioni commerciali di raccolte da selezionare anche verso aziende specializzate fuori Europa. Stiamo parlando di economia circolare, non di autarchia. 6. Istituire regimi EPR per coinvolgere i produttori già dall’ecoprogettazione e creare le risorse con cui sostenere le iniziative sopra elencate. 7. Definire, per incentivare il riuso, un regime di esenzione IVA su capi abbigliamento, accessori e calzature usate reimmessi sul mercato. L’IVA su questi beni è già stata versata dal produttore o dall’importatore all’atto dell’immissione nel mercato la prima volta.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: This feedback is given by CirkelWaarde, a collaboration of three public waste companies in the Netherlands.  Overall, this roadmap contains a lot of good ideas. As a collaboration of public waste collectors, we have a few points of feedback to consider:  * The problem description focuses mostly on production, but in the 'basis for EU intervention', the focus is on collection, sorting and recycling. Then, under B. (aim), the focus switches back to production. We would like to see a strategy that gives a coherent view of the entire cycle. Naturally, the EU has more (direct) influence on some parts than others. Still, a comprehensive strategy would acknowledge all steps in the cycle.  * In the roadmap, 'Product as a Service' is mentioned as an example of more sustainable lifestyles to be incentivised. It is very important, when considering incentivising PAAS models, to consider the possible financial consequences for consumers. Currently, PAAS models are almost always more expensive than one-time buy models of the same product. They also burden consumers with a type of loan, which can cause financial problems. The past years, several governments have spent a lot of effort to discourage excessive loans. A strategy for sustainable textiles should not lead to more debt for low-income households.  * The mandatory separate collection by 2025 is a good idea. At the same time, attention should be given to the quality of the collected textiles, to prevent problems in the future.  * EPR on a European level is a very good idea. In the Netherlands, several organisations are already working on models for EPR for textiles. It is preferable to have this on a European level than on a national level, to keep a level playing field.  * As a collective of public waste collectors, we have published an 8-point plan for circular textiles in 2020. Unfortunately, it is currently only available in Dutch. This document is added. Feedback from: ROVA (639 KB - PDF - 15 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: The Policy Hub – Circularity for Apparel & Footwear welcomes the opportunity to comment on the EU Commission’s roadmap for the EU Strategy for Textiles. We endorse the direction developed by the EU Commission in the roadmap, and its objective to support the industry to be-come more sustainable, resilient and competitive. Overall, the roadmap reflects the dialogue the Policy Hub and the EU Commission have been engaged in for over two years. We are pleased to learn that the EU Commission intends to further collaborate with the industry, throughout the development of the EU Strategy for Textiles as clarified in the roadmap.  Over the past decades, the apparel and footwear industry has been working on addressing its sustainability challenges through various efforts. Progress has been made over the last years by the industry ranging across multiple subjects of the sustainability agenda, like innovating and using more environmentally friendly materials, implementing resource-efficient production technologies, introducing higher transparency and disclosure standards. Yet, the industry has been facing different obstacles, including legislative ones, to close the material loop of its value chain, e.g., due to the lack of collection, sorting and recycling technologies and infrastructures. Furthermore, the COVID-19 crisis has been a shock to the global economy: apparel and footwear industry is one of the industries that has been hit particularly hard , as recognised by the EU Commission in the current roadmap.   The EU Commission should set clear and ambitious objectives for the EU Strategy for Textiles in order to address the current challenges faced by the industry in its journey towards circularity. This should be done in very close collaboration with the industry. The overall target shall be to support the European industry through the right conditions (for instance, investments and funds for infrastructure, and R&D) and incentives to become more circular.   In light of the ambitions and the experience of the sector it represents, the Policy Hub – Circularity for Apparel & Footwear recommends the EU Commission to follow three key principles to develop a meaningful and effective EU Strategy for Textiles:   1. Addressing the missing concepts of the EU Commission’s Roadmap: Following a holistic approach considering social and environmental impacts in the value chain. 2. Creating an aligned framework for apparel and footwear: Translating the horizontal EU initiatives for the sector.  3. Developing a harmonised European framework: Coordinating Member States Initiatives.   The Policy Hub – Circularity for Apparel & Footwear and the affiliated members of its partners are ready to support and collaborate with the European authorities in the development of the EU Strategy for Textiles. We remain at the EU Commission’s disposal for any inquiries or questions and refer to our previous publications and contributions. Our full contribution can be accessed in the attachment. feedback_msg_text: Desde Proyecto Abraham entendemos que es necesario, que los Ayuntamientos paguen por el servicio de recogida de textil, ya que es un servicio que se presta a los ciudadanos, a pesar de que en muchas zonas no sea rentable la recogida de este residuo.  En la adjudicación de este servicio, el Ayuntamiento debe priorizar a las entidades sociales que desarrollan proyectos en la zona, e impulsar la economía social y solidaria. Así como proyectos que desarrollen iniciativas que fomenten la reutilización y el reciclaje, como el consumo responsable y consciente.      From Proyecto Abraham we understand that it is necessary for the municipalities to pay for the textile collection service, since it is a service that is provided to citizens, despite the fact that in many areas the collection of this waste is not profitable.  In awarding this service, the City Council must prioritize the social entities that develop projects in the area, and promote the social and solidarity economy.

feedback_msg_text: Wir vom Verband Second-Hand vernetzt e.V. wünschen uns Folgendes: Kaufprozess Es gibt ja bereits Qualitätskriterien für die Herstellung von Textilien, sei es im Bereich Umweltschutz, Soziales, Arbeitsbedingungen.  Wir regen an, dass Verbraucherinnen und Verbraucher durch ein noch zu entwickelndes Ampelsystem darüber informiert werden und ihnen so Orientierung gegeben wird, was der Hintergrund des Produktes ist. Second-Hand First  Online Unternehmen, die ausschließlich Neuware verkaufen, und Suchmaschinen sollten dazu verpflichtet werden, Gebrauchtes immer! mit - später bevorzugt - anzubieten. Praktisch könnte so laufen, dass Links auf gebrauchte Produkte zu anderen Plattformen als "ähnliche Produkte" gesetzt werden. Beispiel: Jemand bestellt online einen neue Jeans. Dann gibt es aktuell immer, bevor man bestellt, andere ähnliche Neu-Jeans des Anbieters. Wir könnten die online Verkäufer  dazu gesetzlich verpflichten in diesen Bilderfries von ähnlichen Produkten auch mindestens eine gebrauchte Jean anzubieten. Diese könnte vom Anbieter selbst kommen oder von einer Partnerplattform. Entsorgung:  Wollen Verbraucher*innen ihre Textilien "entsorgen", sollten sie diverse unkomplizierte Möglichkeiten angeboten bekommen:   Neben dem Verkauf im oder die Spende an Second-Hand-Betriebe vor Ort oder online, werden ihnen Upcycling- und Recyclingmöglichkeiten aufgezeigt. Wichtig ist hier die Entwicklung komfortabler Systeme, so könnten Second-Hand Agenturen die Lücke zwischen Anbietendem und Abnehmer schließen. Last but not least Re-Use geht auf jeden Fall vor Recycling! Lange Lebensdauer, Reparaturfreundlichkeit und eine umweltfreundliche Entsorgung gelten auch für Textilien. Schnelllebige Mode minderer Qualität sollte in 5 Jahren der Vergangenheit angehören.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Fashion Revolution is the world's largest consumer-led fashion activism movement. Our headquarters is in the United Kingdom and we have teams in over 90 countries, including most EU Member-States. We work towards a fashion industry that conserves and restores the environment and values people more than growth and profit – we do this through research, advocacy, awareness raising and education.   We welcome this roadmap and encourage the EC to establish a comprehensive, holistic and inclusive EU strategy for textiles that equally balances economic competitiveness, social fairness and environmental sustainability for this sector going forward.  We invite the EC to make the following considerations in the development of the roadmap as it is currently being proposed:  More emphasis and investment needed on repair  In 2020, we commissioned Ipsos Mori to conduct a survey among 5,000 consumers in the 5 largest markets in Europe – France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom and found that more people repair their clothes (40%) than recycle them (37%). Meanwhile, only 11% of consumers said that it's important to that they clothing they buy has been made with recycled materials.   Improved textile recycling is hugely important, and it is welcome to see the EC putting a strong emphasis on developing the frameworks, infrastructure and technologies for textile recycling in the EU. However, recycling (nor reuse) are not enough on their own to deal with the huge environmental impacts that are created by the textiles and clothes consumed and discarded in Europe. More investment, support and policy strategy should focus on repair as an important aspect of tackling textile waste.  The EU has taken several leading steps on the 'right to repair' movement in other product categories. These considerations should be made for textiles and clothing as well as other everyday products that we consume. Brands and retailers in the apparel sector in Europe are not prioritising repair as a solution to tackling textile waste because it is more difficult to make profit from repair compared to textile recycling and reuse.  We would echo the recommendations submitted by RREUSE in that there is a need for EcoDesign policies to focus on making textiles products more durable and reparable, as well as for sustainable investments to finance professional re-use and repair activities.  Stakeholder engagement must include rights holders and worker representatives   Stakeholder consultation must include trade unions who represent the textile, garment and recycling industries, as well as labour rights groups, to ensure that Currently, these crucial stakeholders are curiously missing from your list of stakeholders for consultation.   The textiles and garment sector is notorious for endemic working conditions and low wages. By involving worker representatives, worker advocates and rights holders, this will ensure that considerations have been made on the sustainable development of the sector, particularly of the textile recycling, reuse and new sustainable material markets.  The roadmap must explicitly address poor purchasing practices  During the Covid-19 crisis, major European brands and retailers cancelled orders, delayed payments and demanded retrospective discounts from their suppliers, often for products already in production or completed. This has a devastating impact on workers in the supply chain, who faced unpaid wages, reduced income, layoffs, union busting, non covid secure workplaces and food insecurity. However, unfair and abusive purchasing practices were already endemic before the pandemic. We urge the EC to ensure that purchasing practices are considered as part of this strategy, especially as the EC seeks to support the development of new materials, new sustainable business models and new markets for circular textiles and products.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Nouveau Modèle salue cette initiative menée par la Commission Européenne. La communauté de Nouveau Modèle - plus de 7800 entrepreneur·es et citoyen·nes engagé·es - partage le constat de la Commission et estime qu'il est désormais urgent de s’attaquer aux dérives sociales et écologiques de l’industrie textile.  Comme souligné dans la feuille de route, une action au niveau de l'Union Européenne est nécessaire afin d’avoir un impact sur un secteur hautement mondialisé. C'est pourquoi nous saluons et encourageons la stratégie de l'UE sur le textile durable.  La stratégie proposée soulève de nombreux points cruciaux. Malheureusement cette stratégie nous semble insuffisamment détaillée dans la feuille de route. Par exemple, comment l’UE prévoit-t-elle, concrètement, de promouvoir une économie circulaire ou l’utilisation de matières premières durables ?  Autre point essentiel : concernant les déchets, l’ancienne Secrétaire d’Etat à la Transition écologique en France - Brune Poirson - a permis l’émergence et l’application d’une loi anti-gaspillage, afin d’interdire la destruction des invendus non alimentaires, et donc des invendus vestimentaires. Qu’en est-il à l’échelle de l’Union Européenne ? Une application de cette loi - ou d’une directive équivalente - au niveau européen, permettrait de transformer radicalement les modèles de production et de consommation, de se détacher d’une économie “du déchet” et de promouvoir enfin une économie circulaire.   Par ailleurs, nous félicitons la volonté de l’UE d’inciter “la production à la demande”, afin de lutter efficacement contre le gaspillage, mais nous nous interrogeons sur les moyens (financiers et autres) mis en œuvre pour encourager cette pratique.  À la lecture de cette feuille de route, d’autres points semblent absents de la stratégie européenne. Des points qui nous apparaissent pourtant comme importants. Comment l’UE compte-t-elle encourager les géants de la fast-fashion, comme le groupe espagnol Inditex ou le groupe suédois H&M, à diminuer drastiquement les quantités de vêtements vendus ? La vente infinie de vêtements sur une planète aux ressources finies est contradictoire avec l’enjeu de durabilité. Pour lutter efficacement contre la pollution et le gaspillage, il est indispensable de moins produire (car continuer de produire des quantités astronomiques de vêtements en coton biologique ou en tissus recyclés n’est pas responsable).  Par ailleurs, nous nous interrogeons sur l’intérêt de la mise en œuvre de l'obligation légale d'introduire la collecte séparée des déchets textiles d'ici à 2025. En quoi cela va-t-il résoudre le problème des quantités ? S'agit-il d’une volonté d’encourager l'upcycling ? Une obligation légale de services de réparation nous semblerait peut-être plus judicieuse pour résoudre le problème des quantités.  De très nombreuses entreprises ont inventé et testé des solutions innovantes, positives et efficaces, de nouveaux modèles de production et de fabrication, que nous sommes prêt·es à vous présenter plus en détails. Or, une majorité de ces marques lutte pour être compétitives face aux géants de la fast fashion. Sur ce point, nous attendons donc des précisions sur l’enveloppe financière prévue pour soutenir ces entreprises de la mode responsable européenne. Car si l’UE envisage de construire une véritable stratégie de la mode durable, elle doit miser sur un maillage constitué d’une multitude de petites entreprises textiles locales. Feedback from: Nouveau Modèle (1.7 MB - PDF - 6 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles
