feedback_msg_text: Resortecs® welcomes the EU roadmap and the envisioned stagey for textile industry. The textile industry in Europe is highlighted as a key sector for the circular transition, and it represents 5% of world total emissions. Furthermore, in a recent report published by the World Economic Forum (Jan 2021)  highlighted the importance on addressing the complete supply chain to generate higher impacts on fighting against climate change and social injustice.  The scope of the road map covers the activities from cradle to grave, however the decarbonization of the fashion supply chain requires to focus on upper and lower stream activities to generate higher impact. As more than 85% of emissions are out of the direct impact of brand’s activities and are linked to the supply chain, both upstream and downstream of the textile industry. Thus, brands should be accountable (extended producer responsibility EPR) for their complete supply chain of their products form raw material sourcing to end of life.  An overlooked issue as a result of COVID-19 crises is represented by the sheer number of unsold garments that will require immediate attention before they end up in landfills and incineration centers. Overproduction and cutoffs in textile industry representing more than 30% of the total production volume and should also be in the scope of the roadmap.    The BCG report indicated 8 levers that represent an opportunity to harness in the supply chain from the most efficient to the lowest, namely circularity and recycling at the top of the list followed by material and process efficiency that should be the focus of any future initiative. However; the existing recycling and circularity process requires optimization. Efficient sorting and recycling are currently blocked by the fact that the fashion is not designed for effective disassembly and there is a lack of mature infrastructure for recycling material into high quality raw material and not destined for down-cycling where the raw material integrity ad value diminished. The current recycling practices only target 40% of the garment mass. The remaining 60% are incinerated due to the difficulty of disassembly and sorting due to the presence of multi-material and difficulty of separation. The efficiency of the current recycling processes can be enhanced by optimizing and automating the processes. Resortecs® stitching thread and disassembly oven can recover 90% of the raw material. The BCG report devised a guideline on feasible actions that companies can take to reduce the CO2 footprint, and here below further suggestions based on the recommendations per this report and the internal roadmap of Resortecs®: -Build a comprehensive baseline for emissions and this can be achieved by the mean of life cycle assessment (LCA). -Set emission reduction targets per brand to talk to the 1.5°C reduction of Paris agreement -Revising product design choices for example the choice of raw material, increase the recycled content, design garments to be disassembled  -Reconsider geographic sourcing strategy, COVID crisis highlighted the vulnerability of European textile market by relying on outsourcing of raw material causing disruption to the supply chain, there is an increasing need for European autonomy and raw material insourcing by relying on recycling to leverage the raw material requirements  -Create ecosystem where different stakeholder (Brands, manufactures, sorters and recyclers) to share information and resources. Case study Genesis (https://unspun.io/) -Put in place (financial) initiative to scale up disassembly and recycling process (e.g European REhubs from EURATEX) -Put in place EU governance to prohibit unsustainable practices and promote sustainable ones -Enforce classical LCA as a standard language to communicate the sustainability value of the products, and thus enhance transparency for EU bodies to effectively govern textile practices and end user to have informative and responsible purchasing decision. Feedback from: Regeneration BV (Resortecs) (93.3 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: INretail response to the Roadmap on the EU strategy for textiles  INretail welcomes the European Commission’s roadmap on the EU strategy for textiles. We fully support the European Commission to address textile policy issues at an EU level and are looking forward to work with you to further to realise an EU strategy for textiles.  The textile and fashion industry in the Netherlands is among the frontrunners in the industry. In the Netherlands we introduced a Sector plan for the fashion and textile sector, which set out an overarching sustainability approach which covers circularity, environmental issues but also human rights. We formulated  twelve different action points. A couple of those will be highlighted below.   Innovation and knowledge valorisation The transition to a more circular and sustainable fashion and textile industry cannot take place without sufficient support for innovation and knowledge valorisation. The roadmap rightly points out that there are challenges to overcome when it comes to reuse and recycling in the fashion and textile industry. Targets are suggested as a possible solution.   While we see many promising initiatives in the sector (many of them come from the Dutch Textile Valley), it hampers by scaling-up. Setting targets can be instrumental in increasing the urgency to act for specific parties, perhaps creating more demand for novel solutions, but this is by no means a given. Support for emerging techniques, business models and other solutions is therefore essential.  Similarly, while we in principle encourage the setting of eco-design requirements, it is essential to ensure that these do not hamper innovation or the uptake of novel solutions and business models.   Extended EPR scheme Adequate support could be provided by introducing a voluntary/sector-lead extended producer responsibility scheme that contributes to the transition to a more sustainable sector with respect for human rights by preference on EU level. This scheme should be based on the principle ‘think small first’ which means that it should be proportional and created in such a way that it can be applied by all businesses that are in its scope.  The benefits generated via this scheme should be attributed to the industry as a whole and should not only focus on the collection and recycling elements of it. Initiatives on design, production, use, end-of-life and research and innovation should all receive support from the scheme. Additionally, the allocated money needs to be invested in responsible business conduct in order to realize an overarching sustainability approach, which results in a sustainable transition.  An added benefit of the introduction of an EPR scheme is the transparency it creates towards consumers. This transparency will help consumers understand the impact of their actions and can contribute to behavioural change.  A more sustainable fashion and textile sector for workers  It is important to integrate the social human rights dimension at the heart of the concept of sustainability. As textile value chains are long, globalised and diverse, the industry works together with many partners in third countries. The textile industry has long been cooperating in national (e.g. Nederlands Duurzaam Textiel Pact) and international (OECD Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Supply Chains in the Garment & Footwear Sector) initiatives to address this social dimension.  INretail’s members are committed to fulfill their responsibilities in a textile supply chain that protects human rights and does not damage the environment across products’ life cycle. We strongly believe that cooperation throughout the supply chain is key to generate positive impact on groups that experience any negative impacts in respect of environmental, animal welfare and social risks.  We ask the Commission to support existing initiatives into account and aid the sector in expanding the impact of these initiatives.  Feedback from: INretail (495.3 KB - PDF - 29 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Towards a more sustainable fashion   A contribution from the Fashion and Luxury Sector Strategic Committee which brings together Federations, companies and more broadly all French players.   Ecodesign, reuse and recycling represent major opportunities for this highly relevant in Europe.   If technologies allowing to intensify sorting, treatment and recycling exist, the economic model of an industrialization of recycling must be specified, in particular by working in open loop with the various industry (construction, automobile ...). For most of the fabrics, the use of recycled material conditions the set up of fully local production chains.   The first step is to increase and automate the sorting and preparation capacities for recycled materials, while securing the collection and deposit aspects.   Secondly, the proportion of used products collected could be increased by rethinking the methods of collection; the consumer already performing a qualified sorting upfront.   In addition, the use of new materials would reduce the environmental impact and in particular:   Flax: France and Europe have development potential for flax, hemp and wool. Flax is a sector of excellence in which Europe is a priori very well positioned. They could develop fiber processing capacities. Unlike cotton, its cultivation does not require irrigation or pesticides and does not release defoliants into aquatic ecosystems. France, the world's largest producer of flax fiber, does not currently have the spinning capacity suited to its production, and exports 80% of its production to Asia, re-importing it in the form of fabric or finalized products.   Wool: Rethinking the European wool value chain implies changing farming methods and major investments. This involves the endorsement of economic models and product monitoring (improvement of quality among breeders in particular), an increase in processing and spinning capacities, the recovery of the material other than clothing (felt, isolation for buildings, etc.), recovery of fleeces, etc. Lanolin and other composites can be used in particular in cosmetics or food and have a higher value than wool. Today this material is lost during the cleaning process, which is to 90% done in China...   An in-depth study of the eco-responsible wool value chain by the Tricolor / WoolmarkTask Force could contribute to identify processing possibilities at European level. (mapping of European players; best practices benchmark for reducing the ecological footprint (CO2, energy, water, waste); support the development and transfer of sustainable technologies to improve productivity... This will also require the integration of a monitoring and traceability system.   Ultimately, professional training dedicated to natural and innovative materials (spinning, knitting, non-woven, etc.) would complete the actions.   The EU should also provide itself with the means to verify that there is no distortion of competition with products from non-EU areas, in particular by strengthening control on the conformity of products entering the EU.   Finally, all of these efforts should be enhanced by easy-to-use mechanisms for SMEs. The development of these tools requires support for innovation and research. feedback_msg_text: Confcooperative Federsolidarietà is the main national federation of social cooperatives, counting more than 6.250 associates, with about 229.000 individual members, more than 244.000 workers, out of whom 18.000 are disadvantaged workers (people with physical and mental disabilities, drug and alcohol addicts, prisoners). 2.000 social cooperatives (“B” social cooperatives) have as their purpose the gainful employment of the disadvantaged workers (who must account for at least 30% of the business total headcount).  Over 50 “B” social cooperatives members work with used textiles, collectively managing 50 000 tonnes across Italy annually.  Confcooperative Federsolidarietà welcomes the release of the roadmap. Nonetheless, supporting the RREUSE network position, Confcooperative Federsolidarietà would like to take this opportunity to raise the following points.   It is encouraging to see that the “environmental and social impact” of the EU textiles sector will be addressed, especially if this goal is applied to the production of new TGLF as well as the management of used TGLF. It is important to ensure that social enterprises are maintained as key partners in the value chain, notably in fulfilling the obligation for separate collection and providing specific know-how in the sorting, handling, re-use and repair of textiles as well as local policies and consumer engagement. Social enterprises and social cooperatives, municipalities and other actors of the value chain must have a role in the governance of the EPR scheme including decision making on EPR fee distribution.  Protecting the role of social economy enterprises in that sector is essential to support the integration of disadvantaged groups on the job market.  Collection, sorting and sales of second-hand TGLF can locally create 20 jobs per 1,000 tonnes of used clothes and shoes. Developing partnerships along the TGLF value chain together with social enterprises and social cooperatives would maximise sustainable production and consumption (e.g. reward systems for companies who partner with re-use/upcycling initiatives to use waste fabrics and materials). An impact assessment should also be carried out regarding separate collection obligations for TGLF under the Waste Framework Directive, taking into account the associated environmental, social and economic impacts on used-textile management operators.   It is essential to support the use social criteria and reserved contracts pursuant to Article 20 of Directive 2014/24/EU for social organisations (existing for public procurement) to provide more job opportunities to disabled or disadvantaged persons and weaker segments of the labour market in public procurement for textile collection, sorting and recovery in tendering procedures conducted by Producer Responsibility Organisations. This would ensure a positive social impact of the operations beyond the environmental impact. It is also important promotes the inclusion of award criteria of a social nature in the conditions for the execution of contracts.  It is important to give priority to prevention and preparing for re-use supporting repair and re-use activities. Concrete targets prioritising re-use over recycling must be developed, preferably in coordination with employment targets valorising the role of social economy actors.   It is important to align environmental and customs codes in order to allow regular commercial transactions of collections to be selected also towards specialized companies outside Europe, favoring the circular economy. We also suggest the application of a common VAT rate to all European countries for used clothing returned to the market
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: I am working as a strategist for Marketing Standard Limited based in the UK, providing growth strategies for our clients. My focus is digital production and inkjet technology and My personal lifework is to encourage industries to be more sustainable. We are working with multiple global corporates, encouraging investing in Digital technologies to transform the current way of how industries operate.   We are delighted to see the EU strategy for textiles, committing long globalised and diversified value chain to transform more sustainable shape.  We would like to express how digital technology can help the European Green Deal and the Industrial Strategy. Digital can help all 5 priority sectors including the textiles. Global key players have already realised the importance of investing in more sustainable technologies. Current sustainable issues are occurred by a crash between diversified consumer trends and old 20th-century style mass production system. As your roadmap mentioned, the textile value chain is based on the low-cost globalisation production model, which need to be modernised for the sustainable future. The current supply chain of the industry is fragmented, inefficient and long-distance, which causes the waste issue. Also, value is not distributed well – so this creates difficulties for producers investing in modern and more sustainable technologies. Digital technology can transform the old fashioned industry into a well-connected and efficient way. There are already a number of trials for creating the digital platform in order to transform traditional value chains. For example, we recently got involved in creating a textile supply chain platform model with a global technology provider, Ricoh Corporation. (introduction video: https://youtu.be/EiW6ipEH_4c) Digital can connect consumer trend, material producers, each production processes, logistics, consumers and waste management.  Digital technology can make the supply chain more visible and traceable. Digital can connect all players in the value chain. Digital can capture fast-moving consumer trends in real-time and can produce on-demand with much cleaner ways. This can reduce a large amount of inventory, the material waste during production, and can reduce the disposal of the items. Digital production doesn't require a large processing plant that means production can be done locally to the consumer market. Which can bring back the industry to Europe and the new technologies can create new skills and also help people reskilling. Also, the shorter and simpler supply chain can help reduce CO2 emission. The re-shoring also works well for third countries too, with the same reasons.  Recently we have done a webinar called “from Green to Blue” with a digital textile organisation called WTIN, encouraging traditional textile producers to invest into the digital, and informing EU’s strategy to support the industry.  More and more technology players introduce sustainable solutions, however, the approaches are rather individual and fragmented. We think it is very important to organise a digital platform by policymakers, multiple global corporates and technology providers are working collectively. We will be more than happy to help connect our corporate clients with the EU.  Thank you. Feedback from: Marketing Standard Limited (2 MB - PDF - 7 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Stellungnahme der Gemeinschaft für textile Zukunft zur Roadmap „EU strategy for textiles“  Aus Sicht der Gemeinschaft für textile Zukunft ist in der Roadmap eine Berücksichtigung einer erweiterten Herstellerverantwortung zwar erwähnt, aber deren Bedeutung und die Strategie als eine wichtige Grundlage für den Wandel wurde noch zu wenig berücksichtigt. Für einen Wandel im Umgang mit Textilien bedarf es folgender Veränderungen:  Entwicklung, Förderung und Unterstützung von neuen Prozessen und Recyclingtechnologien mit dem Ziel eines Recyclings auf einer hohen nutzbringenden Ebene (insbesondere Faser zu Faser Recycling),  Anpassung des Designs der Materialien und der Artikel für Faser zu Faser Recycling,  Fasergewinnung aus gebrauchten Textilien im industriellen Maßstab,  Stufenweiser verpflichtender prozentualer Mindesteinsatz von Recyclingfasern in neue Textilien,  Rohstoffgewinnung durch chemische Verfahren,  Stärkung, Förderung und Weiterentwicklung der bestehenden Infrastruktur.  Alle diese Maßnahmen regelt der Markt nicht von sich aus. Hierzu bedarf es neuer gesetzlicher Regelungen im Hinblick auf die Organisation und Finanzierung. Freiwillige Maßnahmen sind sicherlich eine sehr gute Grundlage um neue Initiativen und Pilotprojekte auf den Weg zu bringen, aber:   Da es keine gesetzliche Verpflichtung gibt, entscheidet jedes Unternehmen selbst, ob und wie viel es freiwillig in ein Projekt investieren möchte.   Nicht alle Unternehmen beteiligen sich an freiwilligen Maßnahmen und die sich beteiligen, haben durch ihren finanziellen Einsatz möglicherweise Wettbewerbsnachteile.   Aufgrund freiwilliger Initiativen gibt es keine langfristige Sicherheit zur Deckung der laufenden Kosten und damit auch keine Planungs- und Investitionssicherheit.  Auf freiwilliger Basis können keine Anforderungen z. B. zum Einsatz von Fasern vorgegeben werden.   Es gibt keine offiziellen Kontrollsysteme dafür, ob eine freiwillige Initiative die festgelegten Ziele erfüllt.   Eine freiwillige Initiative ist kein verlässliches Element für einen Wandel im Umgang mit Alttextilien.   Auf Europäischer Ebene und auf den nationalen Ebenen müssen die gesetzlichen Regelungen für eine erweiterte Herstellerverantwortung für Textilien getroffen werden. Auf dieser Basis werden die Organisation und die Mechanismen geregelt, die zur Finanzierung der Erfassung, Sortierung, Wiederverwendung, Verwertung, Information, Kommunikation und Kontrolle erforderlich sind.  Die erweiterte Herstellerverantwortung betrifft die gesamte Stakeholderkette von der Rohstoffgewinnung über die Produktion und Nutzung bis zur Phase nach Gebrauch (Wiederverwendung und Verwertung). Auf Basis entsprechender gesetzlicher Regelungen können konkrete Anforderungen an Design, Recyclingfähigkeit, Erfassung, Verwertung und den Einsatz von Recyclingfasern gemacht werden.  In vielen Ländern müssen sich bereits heute alle Hersteller und Importeure, die als Inverkehrbringer Waren dort vertreiben, mit allen ihren Verpackungen einem System einer erweiterten Herstellerverantwortung beteiligen. Da nahezu alle Textilien im Rahmen ihres Vertriebs verpackt oder zumindest etikettiert sind, unterliegen sie der jeweils national gültigen Verpflichtungen für die erweiterte Herstellerverantwortung von Verpackungen.  Eine Übertragbarkeit bestehender Systeme für Verpackungen auf den Bereich der Textilien ist zwar aufgrund der großen individuellen Besonderheiten nicht möglich, dennoch liefern bestehende Systeme, wichtige Ansatzpunkte zur Identifizierung und Bestimmung der Unternehmen, die für eine erweiterte Herstellerverantwortung für Textilien verantwortlich sein sollten.  Als Mitglied der „European Recycling Industries Confederation (EuRIC) unterstützen wir zudem die Positionen von EuRIC. Feedback from: Gemeinschaft für textile Zukunft (257.7 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: - Det er godt, at der sker noget på tekstilområdet. Det er på tide.  - Der mangler fokus på spild, overproduktion og overforbrug. Det er de største problemer, og de adresseres ikke meget.  -       Der bør indskrives et forbud destruktion af usolgt og nyt tøj. Det har været forventet. Det er demotiverende for forbrugere, at de skal lave en          stor personlig indsats for et grønnere forbrug, hvis erhvervslivet samtidig kan destruere store nyproducerede mængder tøj og tekstil. Det          hænger ikke sammen. Et forbud er en lavthængende frugt.  - Der er behov for, at det ikke blot er en række mindre indsatser, men at der reelt sker en strukturel ændring. Det er nu der er en chance for          reele ændringer.  - Der mangler fokus på retvisende oplysninger og korrekt markedsføring til forbrugere. Det er vigtigt at undgå greenwashing, der kan være          med til at udvande forbrugeres incitament til at yde en indsats.  -       Husk at det ikke hjælper at overoplyse-forbrugeren i håb om at adfærden så ændres. Hvis forbrugeren skal ændre adfærd, så skal strukturer          hjælpe forbrugeren i den grønnere retning, og det skal være nemt, praktisk og attraktivt for forbrugeren at omlægge sit forbrug. Der skal          være få, men gode oplysninger til forbrugeren.  - Fremme af reparation er ikke nævnt, selvom det er en central del af den cirkulære økonomi. - Der bør indføres et holdbarhedskrav eller et holdbarhedsmærke på tøj. Så bliver det mere gennemskueligt, hvad den reele pris for tøjet er.  - Det er helt essentielt for at genanvendelse, at uønsket kemi stoppes allerede i designfasen. Det er helt essentielt for at recirkulation og          genanvendelse kan fungere.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: The European Commission’s Circular Economy Action Plan 2.0 will accelerate the transition from a linear to a circular economy and constitutes an essential shift to a low-carbon industry. The European Carpet and Rug Association (ECRA) supports this transition and presents realistic objectives and adequate measures in its strategy paper “Leading the carpet industry towards circular economy: a 2030 strategic approach”.   You can download our strategy, executive summary and annex via this link: http://X-GUT-X.quickconnect.to/d/s/596838396891017603/ECzSiW2-BUtJLVLyMSM6DLur4xojekxt-FbngP0IFSQg_  How have we already set an example?   ‣ At GUT (Gemeinschaft umweltfreundlicher Teppichboden), we have developed industry specific rules on health and safety which ECRA members have complied with for over 30 years. These strict rules go far beyond EU regulations. ‣ At GUT, we have developed CRE (Carpet Recycling Europe), the first post-consumer recycling activity for carpets. ‣ ECRA is a founding member of CPA (Circular Plastics Alliance). ‣ ECRA is currently developing the first European standard for the transparent definition and labelling of the recycled, bio-based and renewable material content of textile floor-coverings.  EU strategy for textiles must:   ‣ Develop a full potential for a robust and consistent shift to circular economy in a standardised way ‣ Ensure innovation is driving the change ‣ Make new technologies and circular materials permanent features of the future ‣ Increase sustainable and renewable products in the market, adhering to circularity principles ‣ Create optimal value when the products reach end-of-life ‣  Make design for recycling a permanent feature of the future ‣ Ensure the availability of investments into the most advanced technologies Feedback from: European Carpet and Rugs Association (ECRA) (177.9 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Input EU Roadmap EU strategy for textiles Submitted by the platform for transformative technologies or P4TT  Overall assessment: The outline of the EU strategy for Textiles is comprehensive, and address most of the social, environment and sustainability issues associated with the textile industry. It is logically structured and easy to read. The outline could be improved through adding the following sections:  1. The strategy should do beyond carbon neutrality and circular economy and take a systemic and forward-looking approach. Systemic in the way that it does not look at the textile industry in isolation but links it up with systemic developments in e.g, the building sector, the transport sector etc. Forward looking by visualizing what the textile industry will be in 2030 and beyond when e.g., blockchain and 3 D printing are common practices. 2. The ambition of the strategy should be to make Europe a market leader in the sustainable textile industry of the future. A vision statement could be added to the strategy. 3. Much more emphasis should be placed on the cutting-edge innovations that are happening in the textile sector, including 3D printing, new fibres, and new raw materials development, use of ICT (IoT, big data, VR and AR etc), new business practices (blockchain, AI, shared platforms etc). Focusing on such transformative technologies and their applications could make EU a market leader in the textile industry in 2030 and beyond. Omitting these emerging areas from the strategy will lock in EU in outdated technologies and business models. 4. Improved visual presentation and use of overview diagrams/infographics e.g., depicting the classification of textile products ((1) Industrial/Technical use, (2) Household use, and (3) Apparel); the textile value chain (Fibre production, Yarn and fabric production, Textile production, Consumption, and End of Life),  the share of EU in the global textile industry etc.  (for example, see the UNEP 2019 publication Sustainability and Circularity in the textile value chain: Global Stocktaking). 5. A review of the current textile industrial capacity in the EU – who are the players, who are the innovators, who are the market leaders, who are the funders, and which organisations exist to drive the industry to new heights. Review who is doing what in the EU will assist in making the strategy operational.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: We, a network of Humana People to People organizations, being committed to global social and environmental sustainability, which we tackle – among other actions – through the collection, sorting and sale of second-hand clothes, in accordance with the EU Waste Hierarchy,  Welcome the identification of textiles as a priority industry to pave the way towards a carbon neutral and circular economy, as well as the various EU decisions and strategies aimed to greening the industry, including the upcoming EU Strategy on textiles.  In this context, we fully support the diverse EU initiatives outlined in the Roadmap, particularly the use of recovery funds and sustainable investments to boost the industry transformation towards circularity, the setting of targets to step up reuse and recycling efforts as well as green public procurement; and the improvement of traceability and transparency in the whole value chain.  As experienced actors in the collection, sorting and sale of second hand clothes across the EU, we would like to share the following recommendations, which we believe are key to maximise the potential of the Roadmap on EU Sustainable Textiles:  • Emphasize the need to respect the Waste Hierarchy and give priority to reuse over recyling, recognizing that the biggest potential in terms of environmental and economic benefits lies with waste prevention and reuse. This shall be reflected in different initiatives such as EPR schemes, reuse/recycling targets, etc. • Streamline the understanding of textiles collected for reuse / reusable textiles as non-waste across the EU, in accordance with the waste hierarchy, to facilitate uniformity in legislation and practices. • Recognize the size and importance of reuse in the textile industry. Already today 40% of the total consumed clothes are collected (latest available figures for Austria, Belgium, Germany, Denmark, Finland, France, Croatia, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Sweden and UK combined) and more than 50% of these are reused as clothes. • Recognize the significant role of social and non-for-profit actors in boosting sustainability in the textile sector, particularly through reuse (e.g. collection, sorting, etc.). • Recognize the contribution of the textile reuse sector in terms of job creation, as a labour-intensive sector, from the collection to the sorting and sales of second hand clothes.  • Provide support to the actors in the textile reuse sector. Support actions should include reducing VAT on second-hand goods and services; and securing appropriate funding for collection and sorting (e.g. for the treatment of the clothes that can’t be re-used). • Prioritise sustainability over competitiveness and resilience when boosting the transformation of the EU textile sector. • Set up a monitoring system to track the targets for re-use and recycling efforts. • In relation to the Sustainable Product Initiative, set targets for durability and reparability. • Provide platforms for dialogue and collaboration across the sector to ensure a smooth and coordinated shift towards circularity (e.g. increase transparency controls, protocols and standards, codes of conduct, etc.) • Engage citizens in the transformation of the textile sector, by raising awareness on the environmental impact of the traditional textile sector and the importance of repair, reuse and recycling. This should include information about how citizens can help boost circularity (e.g. how to sort textile for reuse and recycling).  • Recognize the dual benefit of international trade with reusable second-hand clothes, which provides affordable clothing to people in countries with textile shortage while enabling the highest possible reuse rates at a global level.  With regards to data and evidence, the ”Second Hand Counts“ survey of Humana Germany, provides the latest available data concerning the textile second hand market in EU, Norway, Switzerland and UK, classified by country.   About us: Humana AU, BU, GE, IT, ES & UFF DK, FI Feedback from: Humana / UFF (469.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Die Strategie für nachhaltige Textilien wird der EU helfen, zu einer klimaneutralen Circular Economy überzugehen, in der Produkte langlebiger, wiederverwendbar, reparierbar, recycelbar und energieeffizienter gestaltet werden. Mit der Roadmap wird deutlich, dass Ansätze zur Verbesserung des Designs für Nachhaltigkeit aufgezeigt werden sollen (u. a. Sicherstellung der Verwendung von Sekundärrohstoffen und Bekämpfung des Vorhandenseins gefährlicher Chemikalien) und auch Maßnahmen zur Förderung nachhaltigerer Produktionsprozesse vorgeschlagen werden.   Dies sind wichtige Themen, die in Zusammenhang mit Europäischen Normen gedacht werden sollten. Design-Ansätze können über Europäische Normen einer breiten Öffentlichkeit zugänglich gemacht und insbesondere der Textilwirtschaft als Orientierung, Hilfestellung oder auch als Mindeststandard zur Verfügung gestellt werden. Als strategische Maßnahme sollte daher die Erarbeitung von Europäischen Normen im Rahmen der EU-Strategie für nachhaltige Textilien berücksichtigt werden, denn Normen können die Langlebigkeit, Wiederverwendbarkeit, Reparierbarkeit, Recyclebarkeit und Energieeffizienz unterstützen.
Organisation: DIN Deutsches Institut für Normung e. V.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles
organisation_lower: din deutsches institut für normung e. v.

feedback_msg_text: There are very few tools for dismantling used or discarded clothing. Europe must financially support research investments. Why not propose bonuses for brands that offer eco-designed products in their collection, designed to facilitate recycling.  Recycling of industrial waste is not enough valued and if this is the case, they are recycle for a different functionnality (other than textiles, such as insulating materials). It is necessary to be able to recycle textile waste into textiles. For exemple, recycled Polyester from water bottles cannot be enough, if we assume that the first goal is to abolish the use of plastic bottles. It is therefore necessary to be able to recycle fibers into fibers, of such good quality.  The recyclability of a textile product should also be taken into account in the Foot Print Project Since sorting is a real barrier, it is crucial to provide collection systems that make it easier to industrialize the dismantling and recycling of the product. This in order to encourage brand to concieve a new product thinking is end of life.  It is also essential to promote brands that reject the need for recycling of their products by improving their lifespan (better quality, ease of repair)
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: As an independent consultant for textile and apparel supply chain with focus on sustainability, I have been working with European BRIs and Far Eastern mills and manufacturers for many years - currently on a project for textile-to-textile recycling. While I wish for new business models, "product as a service" and change of consumer habits - all certainly impactful ways in years or maybe decades to come -, the immediate focus should be on recycling with a clear commitment to value waste as a resource and to guarantee formal, fair and transparent business practices to attract investments into profitable infrastructure. To put a lid on future excess, BRIs must be urged to design with mono fibres for best end-of-life usage. If there is demand, mills will follow suit and research and develop. In addition, credible and authenticated LCAs on fibres must be initiated for BRIs to use. The current ones are too outdated. In the long run, I would like to pick up a statement by the co-founder of Materiom that nowads production is centralized and consumption is de-centralized while it should be the other way round with the goal of regional opportunities.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: This initiative is certainly worth of interest, and yet lacks outreach at this preliminary stage. Textile museums have been left out of the pictures. And yet, especially when liaising with manufactures and higher education institutions, Textile Museums can play an important role within a path to revive and develop sustainable textiles. That is because they preserve memory and knowledge, but can also foster creativity applied to a multifaceted world of textiles, encompassing art and design, craftsmanship and technology, research, development and social engagement.

feedback_msg_text: 1- Promoting the use of natural fibers is key to limiting the use of natural resources and extending the use time of clothes. 2- Engage with the natural fiber producers to transform/use regenerative agriculture principles and support carbon drawdown as well as soil health.  3- Advocate policies to mitigate use of synthetic fibers as they are a major cause of microplastics. 4- Synthetic fibers even though recycled are still harmful to human and environmental health.  5- Circular fashion originates from the farm and includes the make, use and after use stages.  6- Circular fashion education platforms for stakeholders. 7- Design out waste and dispose of waste where it is produced.  8- Track, trace and share openly the environmental and social impact of fashion production and use.

feedback_msg_text: G.F. Cascami SRL applauds the initiative. It is extremely important to give importance to the problem of pre-consumer textile waste and post-consumer textile waste. With our experience in the collection and management of textile waste and in the marketing of pre-consumer textile secondary raw materials, we believe that the actions to be taken are many and on different levels. First of all it is necessary to evaluate the production cycles and the products themselves: avoid microplastics and microparticles during the production and washing cycles, perhaps requiring the provision of filters and more; provide the Life Cycle Assessment values to the final consumer on the label; reward those who spend and invest to collect waste in the correct way, thus avoiding competition from production carried out in non-European countries without regulation. Secondly, it is necessary to reward the companies that collect, select and manage textile waste: it is a job without margins and if it is not helped to survive in a few years it will disappear in Europe: the reasons are many but can be summarized in the concept that there is no industrial application that adequately enhances the secondary textile raw material with respect to virgin material, or that is able to absorb all the textile material present on the market. Until a major revolution arrives in the field of industrial processes or products, we believe that Europe must subsidize and strengthen the activity of large and small recycling, fraying, garnetting and textile recovery plants that are facing a very difficult market crisis. By doing this, it will be possible to keep alive a sector where know-how is fundamental, and which has as its main purpose the removal and recovery of thousands of tons of material destined for landfills. Thirdly, it is necessary to take the companies that work in textile recycling by the hand and convey the results of research on innovative products, replacement of products made with virgin material, energy recovery, etc., towards them so that demand meets supply. . The fourth topic concerns the information and training of conscious consumers through active and passive teaching campaigns: textiles and plastics share a lot of information that ordinary people do not know, but which they need to know. G.F. Cascami SRL is committed every day in the search for potential customers for its products, so that the collected and processed waste can find a second life and do not end up burnt or in landfills.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: The umbrella organization FairWertung is a German association of non-profit organizations that collect used textiles. The organizations pass the textiles on in shops or sell them to high-quality sorting and recycling through orderly marketing. The non-profit clothing collections create local reuse cycles, provide a socially attractive range of second-hand goods, create jobs and generate important income for social work. The non-profit collectors are therefore an important part of the nationwide collection in-frastructure in Germany and pioneers of the circular economy.  Against the background of the negative effects of the linear production and consumption model in the textile sector, the umbrella organization FairWertung welcomes the “EU Textile strategy for sustainable textiles” and the Roadmap that has now been published. Nevertheless,   FairWertung would like to take the opportunity to point out the following points: It is important to overhaul the fast fashion model and support a shift towards circularity/reuse/recycling in the textiles sector. In our opinion, the Roadmap focuses too much on the development of the textile recycling. However, a circular economy is based on basic principles such as avoiding waste and reducing energy and resource consumption. Therefore, measures to reduce consumption should be given greater priority. In addition, waste and environmental impacts can already be reduced through product design. Accordingly, design for durability, repair and reuse should be mandatory in the strategy.  One of the goals of the strategy is to eliminate "structural weaknesses in relation to the collection, sorting and recycling of textile waste in the Member States", which we explicitly welcome. Because with regard to the introduction of the obligation to collect used textiles separately, the used textiles sector must also be further developed.  In this area, FairWertung demands: • Reuse before recycling: Textiles should be kept in the usage phase as long as possible. No measures may be taken to make recycling or destroying more attractive than reuse; • Ban on destroying usable textiles. A tax-free donation of e.g. overstock or deadstock to charitable organizations could make destruction unattractive and strengthen social work in the member states; • Consideration of the special roles of non-profit collectors and organizations in the field of collecting, sorting and reusing used textiles, e.g. in social employment or in the creation of local reuse cycles; • Establishing and strengthening, in particular, non-profit collecting structures in Europe; • Promotion of local collecting, sorting and reusing cycles; • Development of uniform standards for collection, sorting and recycling; • Development and expansion of capacities for high-quality material sorting and recycling in Europe in order to be able to handle the resulting quantities in a traceable way and under compliance with social and ecological standards (sorting and recycling plants); • Duty to label textiles in order to be able to efficiently recycle textiles at the end of their life cycle; • Promote research and development for real recycling practices in Europe (open and closed loop tech-nical procedures); • Measures to support the market introduction and demand for products and fibres from real recycling processes; • Development and introduction of effective systems of extended producer responsibility (EPR) for texti-les, including ambitious ecological and social goals (collecting and reuse goals, etc.); • Identification of the “true price” for textiles in order to make the externalized costs of an item transpa-rent for consumers.  With the "EU strategy for sustainable textiles" we combine the opportunity to convert the global value chain and the linear model of the textile industry into a sustainable circular economy. We are happy to take part in the further discussions.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: 29 January 2021 | Start-Up Circular Company  (The Netherlands) Circularity BV – Private owned SME company fully dedicated  to the production of new textiles made with 100% circular yarn.  Circularity welcomes the initiative of the EU regarding an EU Strategy for Textiles. We’d like to point out three relevant issues, regarding the transition of consumer behaviour, the redirection of textile waste to valuable raw materials and last but not least create the conditions / requirements that are necessary to finance SME companies.  1)   The transition of consumer behaviour can be effectively influenced by a framework of regulations regarding the use of claims and marketing statements as “recycled, circular, etc. The current use of these claims in advertising, marketing, branding and  social media is widespread and shows all the caracteristics and pitfalls of the food industry which uses all sorts of claims. Good for marketing and sales, but contra productive regardering the necessary turn around regarding the circular use of apparal.  There are several quality marks available which are easy to fit into the marketing of brands and retailers. The consumer has no references and can’t verify the validity of these claims. As long as there isn’t a solid framework, which is binding for all actors in the supply and demand chain, every brand, every company can apply the claims they seem most favorable and commercially attractive.   2) Regarding the waste management of used textiles and apparal there are still too many detour routes and loopholes to get rid of the waste. Burning the waste isn’t a sustainable option and landfilling is an easy way of transferring the problem to future generations.  The volumes are overwhelming. In our view the EU has the opportunity and the obligation to develop, implement, maintain and control a uniform policy regardering the pricing of waste flows. This will result in an urgent necessity to change and invest in alternatives because it will become too expensive to dump or burn textiles.  3) In our opinion the EU can grasp the momentum to influence, facilitate  and accomodate the necessary transition to creating production capacity in EU countries. Technically it is already possible (beyond the stage of proof of concept) to fabricate yarn that is manufactured within the EU made from 100% used textiles. The downside is that the financial and banking infrastructure ins’t yet ready for this new industry.  The “traditional” approach of lending obviously conflicts with the business model because a production facility of yarn and the production of ready made textiles (T-shirts, Polo shirts and sweat shirts) requires a large amount of CAPEX to start a production plant.  This new kind of industry which is at the starting point of a roll out to multiple EU countries is regarded as “old economy”, not sexy, not high tech and therefore is “under the radar” for banks, investors, private equity, etc. The challenge for the EU is:  Making sure that current grants, warranties and incentive programs are adapted to and made accessible for new SME companies which are dedicated to circular production of textiles and apparal.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: At TFS (The Fabric Sales) we welcomes this initiative and the opportunity to provide feedback about the sustainable textile’s roadmap.   10 years ago, we started as a basic fabric outlet, selling deadstocks of a few designers brand fabrics. Today we are equipped with an online database that manages textile inventory, storage, logistics and sales both in person and online. We are repurposing and extending the live of about 10 000 high end textiles references and counting.  Europe is home to a wide array of couture and high end fashion brands. Off course, designers textile do not represent the majority of textiles purchased and used in Europe, however they are often produced and transformed in Europe. We beleive that this is a very European asset that has if harnessed correctly has the potential to transform current consumption habits and mindsets. It is not directly referred to in the roadmap and might as well be leveraged to address at least two of the EU strategic objectives that are :   - Working on structural weaknesses regarding textile waste collection, sorting and recycling in the Member States - Changing consumptions habits   Combining with the necessary digitalisation of the textile industry in Europe (also highlighted in the road map,) we beleive that a European wide data base acting like an inventory of all existing designers fabrics currently waiting to be destroyed could activate quicker repurposing and reusing of those textiles.   Those fabrics can be repurposed and reused by a greater majority of people : emerging brands, students and the sewing community at large that is growing by the minute. (cf. #aboutsewing in all European languages on IG) and who represent a creative force for European businesses and cultures and ways of life.  Another one of the objectives talks about changing consumption habits off course, harnessing our collective creative power through European wide education program about transforming the way we dress and current clothes consumption models through promoting self made clothing, sewing, recycling, upcycling programs is mandatory.   However, it must be said that something has to change upstream as well, at the level of Designer Fashion Houses. At this stage, the concepts of durability, sustainability somehow oppose the primary sense of fashion ontologically meaning ephemeral. At TFS we have seen gradual changes in the past 5 years and specifically after Covid 19 crisis, more and more high end brands want to be open about recycling their fabrics and changing the way they do fashion. Yet, status quo still prevails at this stage and a new glamour based on sustainable models must be invented, and potentially be part of initiatives such as New Bauhaus as labeled in the roadmap.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: As an enabler for transparency and traceability of fibres we observe a certain insecurity of brands and retailers in defining "green KPIs". Sustainability is not a tangible controlling item yet and it needs a political framework with incentives to meet certain goals in textile business. The European Commission and the concept of the Product Environmental Footprint have to establish clear guidelines for what is considered sustainable.  This definition needs to comprise clear goals, preferred fibre portfolios and must go as far as benchmarking a good product quality. Poor quality products are a major obstacles for recycling not to mention circularity concepts.

feedback_msg_text: We should ensure that all the actors of the supply chain are involved.  Yes the textile sector is a resource- intensive sector with important environmental impact. Those impacts are different depending on the material (cotton, viscose, polyester…) and depending on the node of the supply chain .  We do need to take a global action.  How is the EU going to invest in production processes and new business models?  For some raw materials, we will keep on being dependent on producing countries (cotton for instance cannot be grown anywhere) – how do we improve practices ?  We do need to work on traceability – at a global level and tackle social issues at producing sites.  Also: we would like to relocalize in Europe – how do we also work with developing countries who are dependent on Europe importation to survive (eg: Bangladesh)   The way is long! But we can make the textile sector more fair and sustainable.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: For starters we would like to suggest not to use the word ‘waste’ in this policy. Disposed textiles is an important feedstock for re-use or recycling into new textiles. It is re-wearable or it can be used as resource for new material. In 20 years’ time the word ‘waste’ is outdated and belongs to a linear economy model instead of a circular economy model.   We recommend that the policy document should start with a clear description of its aim: In 2030 of all textiles produced in Europe or imported in Europe contains 50% recycled post-consumer textile content. Textiles should be produced according the European environmental laws and the OECD guidelines safeguarding both good care for the environment and for proper working conditions. These conditions should be checked/ verified by credible certification schemes, preferably with a multi-stakeholder set-up. Further peer group support will keep the supply chain transparent too.   In order to reach the goal of 50% recycled post-consumer textile content we need to embrace the globalized value chain.  It needs attention in Europe and worldwide otherwise the Green Deal will not reach its objectives in time. It is an URGENT matter.  In the document is mentioned that fast fashion is the cause of a non-sustainable value chain. Like fast food, fast fashion has some serious drawbacks. Many of these clothes travel nearly as quickly through our wardrobes and into the bin. However fast fashion is not the only problem. To slash the environmental and social impact of clothing, we need to buy less and wear what we do buy more often. In general the European wardrobes are stuffed with clothes of all sorts of qualities not only fast fashion. At what cost (environmental and social) do we want to proceed with the buying speed encouraged by the retailers now? Public appreciation of the need to apply the three Rs – reduce, reuse and recycle- to textiles is very much needed.  For example the average number of textile pieces in a Dutch wardrobe is 175. Annually we buy 40 and dispose 47 (Maldini*, I, 2019). In comparison to Malawi: the average number of textile items is 8 per person. Best way of saving resources and energy is buying less and washing less.  A significant challenge for textile recycling, both manual and chemical, is sorting collected textiles by fabric type. This is currently mostly done by hand -which is slow and also problematic if garment labels are unreadable or removed. Automated open source systems need to be developed. This enhances better and more recycling and improved tracking and tracing.    EU legal frameworks and laws need to be developed as soon as possible to bring about a sustainable circular textile value chain. An Extended Producer Responsibility is therefore a prerequisite. Such systems can help to generate the funds needed to make the recycling of the non-wearable garments and textile possible. The collecting, sorting and recycling of this material currently is not financially viable. It is too expensive. The market is not prepared to pay the price when virgin material is still much cheaper and legal obligations are not in place. Hence a serious value chain deficit.   We have inserted the link below to our EPR report, executed by FFact (2019), for reference. https://www.sympany.nl/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/FFact-report-TOR-result-2-5-final.pdf  We believe a properly designed and implemented EPR system can help key players (brands and retail) to move towards circular business models. Furthermore an EPR system can contribute to more supply (push) and demand (pull) on mechanical and chemical recycled (postconsumer) textiles.  *Maldini, I. (2019). Can design confront consumerism? a critical study of clothing volumes, personalisation, and the wardrobe.  https://research.vu.nl/en/publications/can-design-confront-consumerism-a-critical-study-of-clothing-volume
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: AITEX, the Spanish textile research institute, welcomes this initiative and the opportunity to provide feedback about the sustainable textile’s roadmap. Even the document is ambitious some precisions are necessary from the AITEX’s point of view.   First, we would like to highlight that the word “sustainability” generally refers to environmental, social, and economic sustainability. It is important not to use the term when it is intended to address only the environmental aspect.   On the other hand, it is important to measure and to set objectives for all the proposed actions. Of course, we understand that it is only the first step, but defining a standardized method of measurement and common metrics will help to assure more transparency to consumers. The strategy should include an absolute reduction of the overall environmental footprint of the sector.  About the coordinated response at EU level that will be addressed, we would like to consider that that each Member State is in a different stage at the policy regulation. For example, in France there already exist the role of extended producer. It is also important to define EPR schemes where the textile products affected are listed such as garments, footwear, household textiles, carpets, mattresses, or other textiles.  Regarding the voluntary approaches, we would like to include some other certifications in the field of textile ecology such as OEKO TEX®. Labelling should ensure that environmental claims are relevant, transparent, and reliable to avoid ‘greenwashing’.  We miss a deeper level of detail about the existing textile recycling technological barriers. Even with an improved collection of textile waste, some other problems will appear. The quality of the textile recycled fibres and the availability of textile technologies are essential features to be considered. The current methodologies used for recycling are mechanical or chemical. Although mechanical recycling is more affordable and simpler, the quality of the recycled fibres obtained is limited. Meanwhile, chemical recycling can transform lower-grade inputs and materials that are difficult to recover into higher-grade outputs suitable for a variety of applications. It enables textiles to be part of a sustainable open-loop recycling system, in which materials cascade up and down the quality ladder in response to market demand. AITEX is developing different projects to overcome those barriers.  Also, the impact of some materials should be addressed. The environmental impacts of natural fibres such as cotton (Gossypium) are consequence of excessive irrigation and water consumption often impacting on biodiversity. Furthermore, as plants require heavy application of insecticides/pesticides and herbicides, to ward off competing plants, can result in soil, water and air pollution and impact on human health. Moreover, impacts from silk and wool production can include land and fertiliser use for mulberry trees (for silkworms), or the overgrazing of native pasture which in turn negatively impact on biodiversity. Regarding synthetic materials (synthesised polymers) produced from fossil fuels, their extraction process causes land degradation, water pollution and waste generation.    Design for durability, repair, and reuse and other ecodesign techniques should be included as mandatory.   Thank you and we look forward to the next consultation.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Klaus Rosinski, experience in collecting, sorting and handling of used textiles in Sweden and EU countries since 1992. Now working as a private consultant mainly for municipal waste companies in Sweden. So far collection rates in Sweden have been relatively low, ranging at 25 % of yearly consumption.  Due to the lack of sorting companies in Sweden the main part of collected textiles is sold and exported unsorted to other EU countries. This will increase significantly once the EU directive for separate collection of textile waste will be implemented.  The geographical shape of Sweden makes long transports inevitable contributing to more unwanted CO2 emissions. It is highly unlikely that any sorting industry with the production capacity necessary will be established or exist in Sweden until 2025. On the other hand a fully automatic sorting plant for recycling in fibre categories has just started in Malmö. That means that for the first time there is a "customer" that wants only textiles for recycling, not reuse; contrary to all the other sorters that only look for reuse. With separate collection the volumes will increase at least threefold and at the same time consist mainly of textiles not fit for reuse any longer. Sweden, in tis situation,  risks to not finding any sorting industry any more interested in buying unsorted textiles (original). To avoid that of happening "cleansing" plants should be considered in Sweden. Regional plants that only concentrate on separating textiles in waste (taken care of for energy recovery locally), recycling (to be sent to Malmö) and reuse. In this way, "cleansed" collected and unsorted used textiles might still have a value good/high enough to be interesting on the European market and for traditional sorters. No unnecessary transport of waste (as part of original), no transport of recycling textiles to other countries, (they will be sorted in Malmö and made into secondary raw material for selling to recyclers), instead efficient transport solutions to reuse sorters. This solution should be considered in more detail as a project and will hopefully get resources and financial support from the commission. Västervik, the 28th of January 2021 Klaus Rosinski
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Fibershed is a U.S.-based NGO focused on establishing regionally-based fiber and textile systems that build soil and biosphere health, with 34 Regional Fibershed Affiliate organizations across North America, Asia, Australia and Europe. Policies developed through this Roadmap will affect environmental and social outcomes across the regions and communities where we work.   On Page 2 of the Roadmap Document, it notes that one of the aims of this initiative is “tackling the release of microplastics.” This can only be effectively addressed at the actual source of the problem: the current abundance of plastic fibers in the clothing and textile industry and the continual release of those fibers into the environment throughout their lifetime of use. Proposed solutions for filtration at individual washing systems or waste water treatment may at best serve to move the microplastic pollution into alternate pathways, but will not ultimately contain or remove this pollution from the biosphere. Policies focused on re-purposing, recycling and re-use of plastic textile materials will continue the inevitable ongoing release of microplastic into aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems.   A policy framework that internalizes the full human and environmental costs of plastic fibers and textiles is needed to shift incentives away from their use and  enable alternatives to succeed. The current marketplace’s artificially low cost of plastic fibers, including recycled polyester (rPET), has incentivized advocacy within the textile industry to establish misleading rankings of recycled plastic fibers as being more environmentally responsible than natural fibers. These rankings ignore the full costs and impacts of synthetic textiles, while basing their assessment of natural fiber textiles on incomplete data and exaggerated assumptions. We urge you to ground the EU Roadmap for Sustainable Textiles in robust science that considers the full costs and impacts of textile materials, from production/extraction and processing through the lifetime impacts of use.   Natural fiber and textile production can be paired with integrated farming systems based on conservation stewardship practices working to measurably improve soil and ecosystem health. True circularity can be achieved in such natural systems where the component parts of products can eventually (after an extended lifetime of use) be incorporated into compost that sustains healthy and productive landscapes where fiber animals or crops are grown. This textiles initiative can be guided by a vision for regeneration, by investing in and incentivizing the development of natural fiber and textile systems based on land-based production that enhances ecosystem and soil health.  We recommend that you specifically develop policies to promote regionalized and decentralized natural fiber textile production. Regionalized, decentralized natural fiber systems have the potential to nurture more resilient regional economies; reduce or eliminate greenhouse gas emissions across entire supply chains; promote environmental repair; and improve well being for communities and individuals involved at every level of fiber and textile production. Abundant natural fibers currently seen as waste products from the food system (notably wool) offer opportunities to make use of valuable, currently under-utilized, raw materials that are co-produced with food and responsible ecosystem management.  Strategies to shift the culture of textile production and use can generate multiple positive outcomes for EU communities. Robust cultural components of these strategies must target a significant reduction in overall textile consumption; design, manufacturing and use patterns that favor longevity of textile use; restored individual and community capacity for textile repair; and a holistic re-regionalization of textile systems. The Initiative should describe specific programs, policies and accountability measures to help enact all of these components.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the first public consultation of the EU strategy for sustainable textiles roadmap. We would like to highlight that the issue of reducing material and resource consumption is substantially missing within this roadmap. The terms 'sustainable lifestyles', ‘Product as a service’ and other 'sustainable business models' may hint at reduced resource consumption but they do not ensure it. These models should specifically drive increased product utilisation, and displace the production and consumption of new textiles.   Furthermore, we would like to suggest that certain terms should be further defined in the roadmap, in order to be more directive. For instance, what is meant by 'sustainable lifestyles', or how can sustainable textiles be embedded within 'green procurement practices'.  Finally, we recommend the inclusion of specific strategies pertaining to the integration of sustainable and circular principles in primary, secondary and tertiary education, as well as through life-long capacity building. The lens of education for sustainable textiles seems to be lacking strength within the current roadmap.  Thank you and we look forward to the next consultation.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Bonjour, La principale difficulté à laquelle je suis confronté est de trouver une boucle industrielle pour le recyclage. L'automatisation du TRI n'est pas encore vraiment opérationnelle et peu répandue. Cette opération manuelle est chère et pas forcément fiable à 100% d'où des traces d'impuretés dans les fils recyclés. De même, sur la partie recyclage chimique, peu d'industrie sont présentes sur le sol Européen. J'aimerais pouvoir livrer mes chutes de confection pour en refaire du fil mais peu de ressources à ce jour. Sachant qu'une grande partie de la production est basée au Maghreb, il serait judicieux de créer une filière de recyclage des tissus (preconsummer). Juste chez Promod, cela représenterait environ 1 million de mètres de tissus. J'encourage donc à développer toute une filière du recyclage et une synergie entre les producteurs, distributeurs et recycleurs pour enclencher la démarche.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Proposal from Danish Waste Association Clothing and Textiles - From Troublemaker to Circular Economy: Extended Producer Responsibility on Clothing and Textiles  The manufacture of clothing and textiles is one of the most environmentally harmful industries in the world. Therefore, it is decisive to create the crucial development and transition towards more efficient resource use and business models based on reuse, repair, and recycling.   The way forward is through the introduction of extended producer responsibility on clothing and textiles.  Danish Waste Association - business association for public waste companies in Denmark - has launched a proposal outlining the foundation for an extended producer responsibility scheme.   The proposal sets up targets for reuse and recycling for Denmark, but we also welcome EU wide targets, namely for reuse.  Additionaly, the proposal contains essential policy instruments for a sustainable EPR on clothing and textiles.  Despite the COVID-19-crisis, fashion and textiles industry aknowledge and welcome the urgent need for adapting to more circular business models. A well designed EPR is key to that transition - and we urge the Commission to require EPR on clothing and textiles in all member states.  Best regards Danish Waste Association https://danskaffaldsforening.dk/om-os/about-us-in-english Feedback from: Danish Waste Association (1.5 MB - PDF - 11 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Except for the part on “sustainable lifestyles” and “product as a service” the document is lacking the obvious reduction of environmental impact by simply reducing consumption. Focus should be on minimizing rapid consumption of virgin, low quality, or short life span (e.g. quickly going out of fashion) textiles. This aspect is especially important as a large part of the global impact of EU consumption is generated outside the EU. Reuse and circular trade should be stimulated to replace virgin consumption as far as possible.  The statement that “presence of substances of concern hampers future high quality recycling” should be revised. It has previously been generally perceived as a major obstacle, but recent studies (RISE, etc) show that harmful substances is present at very low or undetectable levels in post consumer textiles. That said, the issue must of course be taken seriously, and safety in recycled products must be proven.  High value recycling technologies of several textile material types are emerging and some are going commercial (SE, FIN, etc). The main issue in order to continue this is improving collection rates and sorting performance to supply recyclers with consistent, well defined, and reasonably priced feedstock. SIPTEX (SE) automated sorting plant is a good example which should be replicated Europe-wide. In longer term, digital information carriers for even more specific sorting, as well as other digital services, should be considered.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: In der globalen Textilproduktion werden systematisch Menschen- und Arbeitsrechte verletzt sowie der Umwelt massive Schäden zugefügt. Die Menschen in den verschiedenen Produktionsstufen arbeiten für Hungerlöhne, sie werden ausgebeutet.  Freiwillige Maßnahmen der Unternehmen haben bisher nur marginal zu Verbesserung dieser Zusände geführt, dies gilt ebenso für das deutsche "Bündnis für nachhaltige Textilien" oder für den "Grünen Knopf" der Bundesregierung sowie für ihren "Nationalen Aktionsplan für Wirtschaft und Menschenrechte".  Deshalb sind gesetzliche Maßnahmen, die Unternehmen zu menschenrechtlicher Sorgfaltspflicht verpflichten, unerläßlich. Dies kann nur erfolgreich sein, wenn es nicht auf nationaler, sondern auf internationaler Ebene geschieht. Deshalb begrüße ich ausdrücklich diese Intitiative der EU.  Mein Eindruck von der EU - Roadmap ist, dass das ökologische Thema stark im Vordergund steht, Stichworte sind green transition, waste management, recycling, circular economy. Dies alles ist wichtig und muss Teil der Roadmap sein. Doch gegenüber diesen Aspekten nehmen die der Sozialstandards bei der Textilproduktion nur einen kleinen Teil ein. Am Ende des Textes heißt es dazu : "Reinforce the protection of Human Rights".  Dies ist natürlich unerläßlich. Ich möchte mich sehr dafür aussprechen, dass die sozialen / menschenrechtlichen Aspekte der Textilproduktion ebenso stark gewichtet werden wie die ökologischen.  Eine gesetzliche Regelung zur unternehmerischen Sorgfaltspflicht würde für die Unternehmen ein "level playing field" schaffen, das unerlässlich für einen fairen Wettbewerb ist. Momentan sind die Unternehmen im Nachteil, die sich um eine öko-faire Produktion bemühren und dafür beträchtliche MIttel einsetzen. Tatsächlich setzen sich in Deutschland immer mehr auch große Unternehmen für eine solche gesetzliche Regelung ein.   Aus meiner Sicht sind folgende Kernpunkte für eine gesetzliche Regelung wichtig:   - zivilrechtliche Haftung von Unternehmen bei Pflichtverletzung - Klagerecht von Opfern vor einem europäischen Gericht - Transparenz der gesamten Lieferkette unter Einbeziehung des informellen Sektors, z.B. Heimarbeit, Wanderarbeit, Kontraktarbeit - Zahlung eines existenzsichernden Lohnes (Allgemeine Erklärung der Menschenrechte Art. 23, ILO-Vereinbarungen) - Geltung nicht nur für Großunternehmen, sondern für auch für KMU's - Der Geltungsbereich der Produktion muss Osteuropa mit einbeziehen, auch in EU-Staaten wie z.B. Rumänien und Bulgarien werden bei Weitem   keine Existenzlöhne gezahlt.  Es ist eine EU-Import-Regelung anzustreben, die die Genehmigung von Importen an die Einhaltung von ökologischen und sozialen Standards knüpft, die den Grundaussagen und Werten der EU entsprechen. Das REcht auf ein Leben in Würde gilt nicht nur für EuropäerInnen, sonden für alle Menschen.  Es ist nachdrücklich darauf hinzuarbeiten, dass in der öffentlichen Textil-Beschaffung (z.B. Uniformen der Armeen, Arbeitskleidung von Müllwerkern) innerhalb der EU auf allen Ebenen entsprechende Standards berücksichtigt werden. Hier werden sehr große Summen eingetzt, die  zu einer nachhaltigen Veränderung der Angebotsseite führen können. Außerdem haben solche - dann gut kommunizierte - Maßnahmen  Vorbildcharakter auch für den privaten Konsum.
Organisation: Evangelische Kirche von Westfalen, Vereinte Evangelische Mission
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles
organisation_lower: evangelische kirche von westfalen, vereinte evangelische mission

feedback_msg_text: Die ungeheuerliche Überproduktion an Kleidung, die sich von 2000 auf 2015 laut Ellen Mc Arthur Foundation von 50 auf 100 Milliarden Kleidungsstücke jährlich verdoppelt hat, muss gestoppt werden. Die unverkauften Stücke werden oft verbrannt, Produktion und Entwertung schaden immens dem Klima. Flüsse werden durch Chemikalien verseucht, vor allem Frauen leiden unter geschlechtsspezifischer Gewalt in den Bekleidungsfabriken und Spinnereien, Arbeiter*innen verdienen einen Hungerlohn, unter Corona wurden Löhne massiv gekürzt.   Deshalb begrüße ich die Ansätze der EU Strategie für eine nachhaltige Textilproduktion. Insbesondere muss ein EU-Lieferkettengesetz alle Unternehmen in die Pflicht nehmen, ihrer Vorsorge bei ihren Produzenten nachzukommen, freiwillige Maßnahmen wie der Grüne Knopf oder das Textilbündnis in Deutschland reichen nicht aus. Unternehmen müssen in zivilrechtliche Haftung bei Verletzung ihrer Pflichten genommen werden können, Betroffene von Arbeitsrechtsverletzungen müssen das Recht erhalten, vor einem europäischen Gericht zu klagen.   Auch gegenüber Produzenten müssen faire Einkaufspraktiken ausgehandelt werden. Corona hat gezeigt, dass die Produzenten oft in Vorleistung beim Einkauf von Materialien gehen mussten, das ist unfair, vor allem wenn die Einkäufer die Ware dann in der Krise nicht mehr abnehmen. Wir brauchen eine umweltfreundliche und sozialverträgliche Produktion. M.H. der Circular Economy können Ressourcen eingespart werden, schon beim Design muss daher umgedacht werden. Wir brauchen keine 12 Kollektionen mehr. Durch Nachverfolgbarkeitcodes an der Kleidung mit aussagekräftigen Infos zur Einhaltung von Umwelt- und Sozialstandards in der gesamten Lieferkette können Verbraucher*innen eine bewusste Entscheidung treffen, dies muss verbindlich gemacht werden. Auch die gesamte Lieferkette muss daher offen gelegt werden. Die öffentliche Hand muss mit gutem Beispiel voran gehen, Dienstkleidung muss fair und ökologisch hergestellt werden. Die Frauen die unsere Kleidung herstellen, müssen einen existenzsichernden Lohn erhalten, nicht einen Mindestlohn. Bei Produzenten europäischer Bekleidungsfirmen müssen Gewalt gegen Frauen am Arbeitsplatz, Frauendiskriminierung verboten und ein Klagerecht vor europäischen Gerichten muss geschaffen werden. Wir benötigen eine radikal veränderte Produktionsweise, weniger Kleidung und wenn sie auf den europäischen Markt kommt, muss sie sozial- und umweltveträglich hergestellt sein.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Unternehmen - von fossilen Brennstoffgiganten und der Agrarindustrie bis hin zu Modehändlern und Elektronikherstellern - operieren heute weltweit ungestraft. Zu viele von ihnen zerstören die Umwelt, beschleunigen den Klimawandel, missachten die Rechte von Arbeiter*innen und Gewerkschaften, vertreiben indigene Völker von ihrem Land oder unterstützen die moderne Sklaverei. Diejenigen, die sich gegen die Missbräuche von Unternehmen auf der ganzen Welt wehren, werden oft gefeuert, ins Gefängnis geworfen, verschwinden oder Schlimmeres. Dies geschieht vor allem in Ländern mit geringem Einkommen auf der ganzen Welt, die unsere Solidarität brauchen.  Wir wollen ein Gesetz, das Arbeiter*innen, Menschen und den Planeten vor schlechten Geschäften schützt! Aber es ist bei weitem nicht klar, dass die neue Regulierung der EU stark genug sein wird, um diese Aufgabe zu erfüllen. Sie muss stark sein, um Unternehmen wirklich zu motivieren, schlechte Praktiken zu beenden. Dazu müssen in der EU Strategie menschenrechtliche Sorgfaltspflichten von Unternehmen, faire Einkaufspraktiken, Transparenz und Traceability gestärkt werden. Insbesondere Frauen tragen oftmals die Kosten für Menschenrechtsverletzungen in globalen Lieferketten, ganz besonders in der Textilindustrie. Daher muss eine EU Strategie sich explizit mit Genderfragen befassen und sicherstellen, dass Frauen entlang der Lieferkette wirksam und systematisch geschützt werden.
