feedback_msg_text: IGI, The Global Wallcoverings Association, welcomes the EU strategy for textiles.  Wallcoverings use textiles in two ways.  Firstly, decorative textile wallcoverings use a wide range of yarns, woven fabrics, knitted fabrics, threads, ropes, braids, felts etc. to form a visually attractive surface attached (usually) to a paper backing to assist dimensional stability.  Secondly, textiles are used as backing to paper and paper polymer blend wallcovering webs to improve tear and tensile strength.  Commonly used in heavy duty wallcoverings  and consist (usually) of cotton or polyester or a blend of both.  In progressing to a carbon neutral and circular economy it is vital the sustainability of textile production is addressed as complex raw material procurement moves up the public agenda.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: EU textile policy affects us all, and whilst no longer an EU citizen, alas, as an analyst, I would like to offer some observations:  1. Sustainability is substantive; it can be defined and measured. Within the apparel sector it is neither.  2. ISO standards (and common sense) require that comparative assertions be made only using LCAs produced using the same methodology, boundaries etc. Such a suite of LCAs for textile fibers does not exist.  3. Sustainability includes socio-economic impact. For textile fiber production, this has yet to be considered let alone evaluated.  4. The EU's own scientists (EURATEX/SAPEA) recommend that the use of plastic be mitigated. The sustainability index used by the major brands -The Sustainable Apparel Coalition (SAC) Higg MSI - rates plastic fibers the most sustainable (example: silk's impacts purportedly total 1086/kilo of fabric, Polyester's, 36.2/kilo).  5. Clothes are not sandwiches. The sole valid metric for evaluating cost - economic or environmental - is cost per wear. If garments made of some fibers are worn more times than garments made of other fibers this must be factored into sustainability calculations.  6. Comparative sustainability indices cause economic harm to producers whose fibers are rated less sustainable. The MSI is controlled by a for profit, that it is neither open source nor transparent. The selection of LCAs, methodology and scores has never been informed by leading academic institutions. The ratings have never been peer reviewed. To use such an index in EU policy would be unethical.  Conclusion: If the EU wishes to include comparative fiber sustainability in its policies, it must first commission and fund the requisite studies.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Le meilleur moyen de rendre un produit textile plus durable est d'intégrer cet objectif dès la conception. Si les produits sont conçus pour rester en bon état et donc utilisables durant plus longtemps, le consommateur les conservera plus longtemps. La consommation de produits textiles se réduira en quantité et la question du recyclage sera moins problématique. Il faut donc aider les sociétés qui investissent pour mettre au point des textiles de meilleure qualité au sens large.  Cela peut vouloir dire plus durables, que l'on garde plus longtemps. Des textiles qui gardent leur aspect ou leurs propriétés (couleur, état de surface, dimensions, etc). Cela peut également vouloir dire plus innovants, plus performants, avec de nouvelles fonctions (smart textiles). Le recyclage doit faire partie du cahier de charges lors de la conception. Eviter les mélanges de fibres qui seront difficiles à séparer lors du recyclage. Choisir les accessoires (zip, boutons, rivets) en tenant compte du recyclage futur.  Les investissements en équipements permettant le développement de textiles durables et/ou innovants doivent être aidés. De même que les équipements permettant de vérifier la qualité ou les propriétés des textiles.  Favoriser les innovations qui participent à réduire la consommation en eau ou en énergie lors des processus de production. Favoriser les outils digitaux pour le prototypage et la mise au point des collections virtuelles. Favoriser les outils de fabrication à la demande. Aider la recréation de filières textiles afin de garantir l'indépendance de l'Europe pour certains produits critiques. Veiller à ne pas créer de concurrence économique entre les pays européens. Certains pays au sein de l'Union ont des coûts de production bien inférieurs et constituent des outils de délocalisation douce tout en restant en Europe.
Initiative: EU strategy for sustainable textiles

feedback_msg_text: Preliminary remark French banks have made great efforts to implement the various financial regulations and to improve the quality of services provided to their clients.   They are now calling for regulatory stability to focus on priorities such as the completion of the CMU or the financing of the post-Covid recovery.  Inducements have been regulated for several years and we do not note any increase in clients claims nor any major sanction pronounced by national supervisors related to that topic. This proves that investment firms have increased the quality of services offered to clients and duly manage potential conflicts of interest.  Inducements are key factors for maintaining a business model providing access to investment advice to a large number of clients.   Different rules Investor protection rules are set out in different legislative/regulatory texts (MiFID II, PRIIPs, IDD) which have common bases. For instance, the product governance rules, the definition of independent (vs n. independent) advice and the disclosure of costs and charges are similar under the MiFID II regime and the IDD one.  These different regulatory frameworks now constitute a consistent corpus of rules that are considered as appropriate by all stakeholders.  Thus, FBF believes that there is no need to merge, rewrite or deeply modify these texts. On the contrary, FBF calls for stability to facilitate the good understanding of existing rules by clients and industry.  Indeed, these regulations allow a consistent client journey and FBF does not agree with the assertion suggesting that consumers would have difficulties to make their investment decisions because rules can differ from one instrument to another.  In these conditions, after several years of implementation of MiFID II, IDD or UCITS which occurred high costs of organization/ IT developments, firms now advocate for a regulatory break or would accept slight legislative amendments relying on customer studies or real-life situations that would enable to eliminate certain administrative burdens.   Inducements FBF does not agree with the statement that advice provided by professionals would be biased toward products, due to the payment of inducements.   Under MiFID II, distributors are authorized to receive inducements as long as they provide clients with additional or higher-level services and/or other on-going services. Thus, clients are offered a wide variety of additional services from which they benefit greatly.  Moreover, the payment of inducements allows all retail clients, regardless of the amounts invested or the size of their portfolios, to access advice they otherwise could not afford (costs mutualisation).   Besides, the ban of inducements would ultimately go against the interests of all clients as the price of the advice would increase.  FBF observes that current MiFID II regulatory framework and banks’ practices already prevent potential risks of conflicts of interests. Claims received from clients do not relate to inducements.   At last, a ban of inducements might unsettle a large part of EU financial industry and its business model, which is not a compelling objective in the context of post-Covid recovery.  Consequently, FBF is strongly opposed to the reconsideration of the regulatory framework concerning inducements.  Suitability assessment FBF does not share the opinion that effectiveness of the suitability assessment has been questioned. On the contrary, we believe that this assessment is properly implemented and should not be modified in the context of the MiFID II review.  However, clients are often reluctant to answer to many questions and regard the assessment as intrusive. Thus, some simplification could be introduced to encourage them to answer questionnaires.   Certificate for advisors In France, financial advisors must pass the AMF exam before providing financial advice. This certification proves that they have the appropriate knowledge to provide advice to their clients. Feedback from: Fédération Bancaire Française (34.6 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for retail investors

feedback_msg_text: The Association of German Public Insurers welcomes the initiative of the European Commission to create a comprehensive Retail Investment Strategy in order to enable retail investors to make informed decisions while taking advantage of the European capital market. As Germany’s second largest primary insurance provider with a strong regional presence, the group is committed to constructive dialogue in the interests of all market participants and to a stable European and global insurance sector.   Europe’s citizens rightly expect uniform rules and disclosures for similar financial products. From both the customers as well as the sales representative’s perspective, it would be useful to harmonize certain aspects in the financial services sector, such as entry qualifications or general rules of conduct. Other areas, such as key information documents, tend not to be suitable for horizontal regulation. Consumer information tailored to the specifics of insurance products are more likely to create transparency than a one-size-fits-all key information sheet that is supposed to be suitable for all financial products.   In addition to that, especially within the area of financial products a horizontal regulatory approach would be rather detrimental since these products vary within their respective characteristics. For example, insurance-based investment products differ strongly in their tradability from pure investment products. The latter are usually tradable on the stock exchange and can be sold at short notice. Insurance-based investment products on the contrary have a significantly longer investment horizon and are not readily transferable. In our opinion, coherent regulations for financial products are therefore only appropriate insofar as these products are actually comparable.   It is self-evident that sales inducement must not lead to customers being sold products that are not suitable for them. Consequently, the requirements outlined within MiFID II and IDD have launched a variety of measures to prevent misaligned incentives. Both regulations include a clear definition regarding unwanted inducements as well as how to prevent them. Since parts of these directives have been implemented just recently into national law, their effect will only become visible in the further course of time. Therefore, it would be highly ineffective and maybe even counterproductive to adopt new measures before it is clear how the recent change is going to affect the market.  The situation is similar with regard to additional requirements for the suitability assessments. New rules have been established just recently and the effect on the market has not been fully assessed yet. Before any new requirements, and thus potential bureaucratic burdens, are imposed, the recent regulation must be reviewed first.   In addition, commission-based systems have proven their worth in many cases. They ensure that every person, regardless of income, receives targeted and comprehensive financial guidance. A unilateral focus on a system based solely on fee-based advice would severely discriminate against low-income households and further exclude them from financial markets. Yet, low-income households in particular are often most in need of financial advice. It is our concern that tougher regulations will lead to a significant decline in consulting services and to an increase of products being sold on an execution-only basis. Again, this would hurt financial illiterate households the most.   The public insurers are looking forward to continuing the exchange on the Retail Investment Strategy.
Initiative: EU strategy for retail investors

feedback_msg_text: Currently, investor protection rules are  set out in a number of sector specific legislative instruments at EU level, while general consumer protection frameworks remain  under national rules.    In order to better reflect the variety of issues across member states, it would be useful to target especially retail investors responses to the consultation. Could this be done through the traditional consultation process? Would it be possible to set up focus groups in each member states through your representation offices and work with local trade associations to collect the views from clients and investors ? CFA Institute who represents financial professionals holding the CFA charter has societies in 24 EU countries and would be available to help brainstorm together with local retail investor groups, for example.   Adequate protection of consumers’ interest has not yet been achieved. The dichotomy between EU legislation and transposition into national law at the jurisdiction level has resulted in a complex matrix of rules where investor protection is not considered on a level playing field across the Union.. An additional complication concerns the tendency observed in certain jurisdictions to goldplate EU directives, for various regulatory, political or competition reasons. In such a context, when considering that EU has little input into national consumer protection rules, one can understand the complexity of the overall framework whose primary objective should be to reconcile retail investors and individuals with financial markets. One example we can mention is that of investor education, which CFA Institute believes is a key consideration for financial services, yet remains managed at national level.  CFA Institute continues to be of the view that the marketing, distribution and sales process remains tilted towards the interests of the distributor or manufacturer, as opposed to that of the investor. In Poland, our members are pointing to the fact that the market may have regressed back to a closed model, away from the objectives of choice and quality sought through an open architecture approach, promoted notably by the CMU vision. IThe rules and disclosures can differ from one product to another, which may make it more difficult for investors to make investment decisions that correspond to their needs. The need is growing for a consistent single rulebook to govern retail investments around a core set of principles defining expected conduct for that specific investor category.  It is key to properly classify each financial product. This should not only concern products sold on a cross-border basis like UCITS, but also local specific financial product formats. An example of the latter category would be the “Livret A” in France which is a popular tax savings account, yet du yet due to its specific tax treatment, is only distributed in France by banks. We are of the view that there should a truly European classification of all financial products sold to European investors, in all jurisdictions, which would clarify and harmonise the eligibility criteria for retail investors across the Union. This European classification should mention why a local product can be sold on a cross-border basis or not.  Key for such a harmonisation endeavour will be the need to revise, simplify and align investor information documents along with the single rulebook. This should entail a review and alignment of calculations and presentation rules for costs and charges, performance and risk indicators.  We also believe the rules related to suitability assessments need to be harmonised and simplified. It still is the case that these exercises are executed by advisors and distributors rather as box-checking processes, which is not the intention of the rules.   Finally ,as a global educational certification body with significant ethical content, we would like to reiterate our support for the establishment of a EU-wide certificate for advisors   Feedback from: Anonymous (1.2 MB - PDF - 54 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for retail investors

feedback_msg_text: Dans le cadre de la feuille de route de la stratégie de l’UE pour les investisseurs de détail, le Groupe de réflexion des courtiers en assurances français recommande de tenir compte des éléments de différenciation entre la vente de produits financiers destinés aux investisseurs de détail et les produits d'assurances :   - un contrat d'assurance vie n'est pas un actif financier,  - et un courtier en produits d'assurance n’est pas un intermédiaire en placement financier.    L'intermédiaire en placement financier (ou le gestionnaire d'actif) ne prend aucun risque sur les actifs qu'il conseille à ses clients, car ces actifs restent la propriété du client. Au contraire, l'assureur vend une garantie réelle à son client moyennant une prime d'assurance (Ex : pour les contrats d'assurance vie : garantie en capital pour les contrats en euro, garantie de liquidité à tout instant pour les contrats en unités de compte). Le client détient ainsi via son contrat une créance sur la compagnie d'assurance. C'est le principe de mutualisation des risques entre les assurés qui permet de financer ces garanties au tarif le plus juste.      Les courtiers en assurances interviennent sur le marché de la distribution des produits d’assurance en se positionnant entre l’assuré et les sociétés d’assurance. Ils apportent un triple service aux assurés : un service de conseil pour les aider à déterminer les besoins et souscrire l’offre la plus adaptée, un service d’intermédiation et de négociation pour la souscription du contrat et la redéfinition périodique des supports financiers du contrat d'assurance ; enfin, ils liquident souvent les prestations du contrat pour le compte de l’assureur, via une délégation de gestion.    La rémunération des courtiers en assurances est depuis deux siècles une commission en pourcentage des primes d’assurance. Même si dernièrement certaines positions publiques affirment que ce mode de rémunération serait source de conflit d’intérêts et que sa suppression permettrait de faire diminuer le coût de l’assurance principalement pour les consommateurs, il n’en est rien. Dans un monde de plus en plus complexe, le rôle des courtiers en produits d'assurance est d’un apport sans commune mesure pour les consommateurs dont ils sont les mandataires légaux face aux sociétés d’assurance. Leur accompagnement se matérialise en France notamment par leur devoir de conseil qui est une obligation juridique qui fait obstacle à tout conflit d’intérêts.     Au même titre que la mutualisation des risques, la rémunération par commission en pourcentage des primes permet de mutualiser le coût du courtage. Les services des courtiers ne s’arrêtent pas le jour de la souscription d’une assurance par leurs clients. Les courtiers accompagnent leurs clients tout au long de la vie du contrat d’assurance et plus intensément lors des arbitrages et de la liquidation du contrat. Seule la commission peut permettre au plus grand nombre d’avoir un accès au conseil personnalisé, à l’accompagnement et à l’assistance d’un courtier en assurances puisque son coût est mutualisé et son prix par conséquent plus faible que s’il était individualisé via des honoraires.
Organisation: Groupe de réflexion des courtiers en assurances français
Initiative: EU strategy for retail investors
organisation_lower: groupe de réflexion des courtiers en assurances français

feedback_msg_text: 2° Investing Initiative welcomes the initiative on a Retail Investment Strategy for the EU. A comprehensive strategy is essential to match the environmental and social ambition of the Green Deal and support and progress the retail investment focussed activities which began under the 2018 Action Plan on Financing Sustainable Growth.  We consider that priority areas for focus include the following: Addressing greenwashing including through developing a responsible marketing framework for the finance sector. Currently there is no specific regulatory guidance governing the content of environmental impact claims in the financial sector. 2DII has conducted several reviews of the marketing claims of ‘sustainability funds’ available to European retail investors (see our website). We found that most environmental impact claims reviewed were misaligned with generally applicable regulatory guidance. A responsible marketing framework for the finance sector is required for consumer protection, legal certainty and developing best practices. Clarifying the concept of investor impact in the regulatory framework. Addressing greenwashing requires a sophisticated approach to the concept of investor impact (to be differentiated with the concept of investee company impact). There is an urgent need to build evidence on the environmental impact of different investment strategies and techniques and to ensure that the regulatory and policy framework is designed to reflect the scientific evidence. Clarifying the different categories of financial product articulated in Articles 8 and 9 of the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation. A clear example of the regulatory framework and/or market practice failing to reflect a proper concept of investor impact is apparent with the common practice of referring to Article 9 financial products as “impact products”. We support the request articulated in the ESAs’ letter to the Commission dated 7 January 2021, about the need for (broader) clarification in this area. Currently the market does not have a uniform interpretation, which is to the detriment of retail investor understanding of the financial products they are investing in. Ensuring proper regulatory oversight of the new suitability assessment requirements articulated in the MiFID delegated act. The requirement to consider a client’s sustainability preferences introduced in the recent delegated act will need a significant change in financial institution procedures. We consider that adequate regulatory oversight is critical to ensure this is operationalised effectively. Ensuring that financial advisors receive training and have the necessary expertise to advise retail investors in sustainable investment products. Training and certification schemes should be considered and, in addition, we consider that detailed guidance from financial regulators can assist here. In this regard, we consider that ESMA guidance on the suitability assessment should be as detailed as possible rather than continuing with high level principles-based guidance. Aligning voting practices in the investment chain. The profile of votes cast at the last European elections demonstrates many citizens support environmental objectives through political voting. And 2DII research shows that retail investors wish to have a positive impact with their money. But structural barriers in the financial system such as intermediation in the investment chain means that retail investor preferences on environmental and social issues are not reflected in votes cast at company general meetings. Addressing misaligned voting practice is a critical step to achieving the EU’s environmental objectives and securing a financial system which is accountable to its citizens. Ensure that the development of fintech benefits retail investors. Ensure that Fintech (online robo-advisors and apps) helps retail investors (among other things) better identify which financial products match their sustainability preferences.
Initiative: EU strategy for retail investors

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sirs, Ascofind is an Italian Association gathering investment firms and financial advisory firms that offer investment advice on an independent basis. A recent Report on financial investments of Italian households, published in December 2020 by the Italian Authority Consob, reveals that only 33% of Italian savers access the financial markets. The main deterrents from financial investment are the lack of trust, of information and of support to decision-making. About one third of italian household financial assets are held in liquid instruments, cash and bank deposits. The most frequently held products by italian households are mutual funds, insurance-based investment products and Italian government bonds. Out of the total financial assets held by households, UCITS funds amount to 10.7% while insurance investment products represent 17.1%. The excessive level of costs and charges of financial and insurance products constitutes a further brake on participation in financial markets by retail customers. A recent publication by Esma (Performance and Costs of EU Retail Investment Products, 2021) highlighted that in Italy the costs and charges of UCITS funds are among the highest among the various EU member states. Regarding pension products, about 40% of participants have subscribed to individual pension plans offered by insurance companies with average annual costs of 2.20%, six times higher than occupational pension funds. A major cause of the high cost lies in insufficient competition in the distribution and the mode of remuneration of distributors and financial advisors, based on the retrocessions of commissions from manufacturing companies.  Due to payments of inducements, advice provided by intermediaries may be biased towards products with higher rewards for intermediaries, consequently having a further negative impact on investor confidence and trust. Mifid II regulation has mitigated these negative effects, introducing rules relating to the legitimacy of incentives in investment services and greater transparency on the costs paid by retail investors. However, based on the results of the survey published by Consob, investors show a poor understanding of the remuneration scheme for the advisory service: 40% believe it is paid by the bank, 15% that it is free, more than 20% do not know answer. Only about 5% understood that the service is paid for by the customer. Three years after its introduction, the solutions adopted by the Directive to provide sufficient clarity regarding the incentives perpetrated by distributors and financial advisors evidently did not achieve the desired objectives. An increase in the participation of retail clients in the financial markets and a more consistent climate of investor confidence cannot be achieved if the transparency of the costs of the products and the advisory service provided to clients is not ensured. In the Technical Advice to the Commission of March 2020, ESMA proposes to improve clients’ understanding of inducements and the effect they have on the distribution of investment products and the existing MiFID II disclosure. The Commission should improve the comprehensibility and clarity of the existing inducements disclosures by introducing the obligation to include, in all inducements disclosures, an explanation of the terms used to refer to inducements (for instance, third-party payments).  Such explanation should be sufficiently clear and use simple terms to ensure that retail clients understand the nature and impact of inducements: “Third-party payments are payments received by the firm for selling this product to you and is part of the costs that you incur for the service provided by the firm, even though you do not pay such costs directly to the firm”. Ascofind strongly supports ESMA proposal.
Initiative: EU strategy for retail investors

feedback_msg_text: The Association of German Debt Capital Platforms welcomes the opportunity to comment on the Commission’s roadmap to a new EU strategy for retail investors. We are absolutely supportive of the Commission’s objective to develop a coherent regulatory framework to empower consumers to make investments in the EU capital markets with confidence and trust. Beyond, we share the view that there has never been a better time than today for Digital Private Debt (DPD) in the post COVID-19 era - as banks retract especially from unsecured SME financing it is up to the DPD investors to fill successfully the gap. This is also a unique chance for all European consumers to benefit from the investment opportunities offered by the capital market union. However, current developments in Germany are significantly reducing these opportunities.  In the context of the transposition of Article 23 (1) lit. 1 and Article 24 (1) lit. 1 of the ECSP Regulation, the German legislator passed drastic liability provisions two weeks ago. According to these, both project owners and platforms as companies as well as the respective management bodies shall already be liable for simple negligence. In addition, supervisory bodies and administrative bodies shall be liable for gross negligence. Germany has thus almost completely exhausted the regulatory framework provided by the text of the regulation, although it would have been admissible, too, to restrict the liability on only the project owners and platforms as companies. From a purely legal point of view, this is at least not a violation of EU law. Nevertheless, we take a critical view of this development, because the German retail investor has nothing to gain from it for several reasons.  The provisions adopted with the "Schwarmfinanzierung-Begleitgesetz" (law transposing parts of the ECSP Regulation) discourage SME and especially Start-up founders to seek ECSP funding from German platforms. In all likelihood, they will opt for the less stringent liability for capital market financing under the conventional German liability regimes. In doing so, however, the German legislator has created clear disincentives to the detriment of private investors: out of the senior loan within the scope of the ECSP and running into the qualified subordinated junior loan, where the private investor has the least favourable creditor position imaginable in the event of insolvency.   Besides, ECSP financing will be obtained from platforms in other EU countries with less strict ECSP liability provisions. Thus, the Commission's objective in proposing the ECSP is thwarted. It is to be feared that the ECSP will come to nothing in Germany. And SME and Start-ups will not be the only ones to suffer. Private investors will also be affected because the variety of ECSP products on the German market is likely to be very small. They will have to look abroad. The idea of the Capital Markets Union could not suffer any greater damage and is the complete opposite to the Commission’s Greenbook (COM(2015)63 final, page 2):  “We need to identify and remove the barriers which stand between investors' money and investment opportunities, and overcome the obstacles which prevent businesses from reaching investors.”  Another point of great relevance for retail investors in connection with the ECSP regulation is the topic of claims management. The ECSP does not stipulate any requirements in this regard. In Chapter IV, Investor Protection, various information obligations are named and, for example, the disclosure of default rates is required, but the private investor is left "alone" with regard to his receivables if there are actually delays in payment or other payment problems. The Regulation also does not contain any options for joint management of the claims, for instance analogous to the German "Schuldverschreibungsgesetz" (German act on notes), so that, for example, no joint declarations/measures can be taken vis-à-vis the issuers on behalf of the investors. Feedback from: Verband deutscher Kreditplattformen e.V. (395 KB - PDF - 9 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy for retail investors

feedback_msg_text: The right to access to medicines requires the implementation of complex mechanisms with the intervention of various actors, among which public institutions prevail as guarantors of collective health.  The role of the administrations around access to medicines cannot be limited to a passive position and that far from being exhausted with the material delivery of the medicine to those who need it, it imports a series of obligations that ultimately converge to an adequate protection of public health, translated into the formulation of health policies.  It is important to ensure the quality of medicines by having adequate controls, whilst ensuring rational use of these.  The rational use is related with information and educational policies. However, what is most relevant is the cost of the drug, a condition that becomes the main barrier to access. Although it is true that price is not the only obstacle to access.  To benefit from the incentives provided by the orphan drug regulations, a promoter must first obtain orphan drug designation for its product. Orphan drug designation may be applied for at any time prior to the marketing authorization application and applies to new chemical entities, new biological entities, existing drugs with new compositions, and existing drugs for new indications.  Therefore, administrative procedures are complex and expensive, often without providing any added value. That is why it is absolutely necessary to simplify them in order to facilitate and accelerate the development of research on orphan drugs.  Similarly, in respect of the two major areas of orphan drug development, such as the EU and the US, although attempts have been made to harmonize different procedures, including the designation procedure: such as the introduction of a common application form for designation; there are still some differences between the EU and US procedure. It would be, at this point, very interesting the unity in the procedures, which would guarantee a greater speed, simplification, lower cost, as well as stimuli in the investigation and placing on the market of orphan drugs.  On the other hand, there are real problems of access to orphan drugs in the different member States, making the effort in research useless and, most importantly, producing a clear violation of the rights of patients with rare diseases.  In this sense, although the powers to set prices and access belong to the different member States, it is necessary to establish unified rules and procedures under EU regulations, centralizing aspects relating to financing, price, access, fulfilment of deadlines in the dispensation, etc.  This would ensure that all EU citizens have access to innovative therapies under the same conditions of equity, without discrimination on economic grounds.  The unification in the access procedures and the guarantee that the medicines will be financed and available throughout the EU has, among others, several facets. Firstly, the right to health protection is guaranteed to all EU citizens; secondly, it would favour research, as the industry would know that access would be universal in the EU and therefore marketing is favoured, which encourages research into these therapies; and finally, it would reduce prices for two reasons: firstly because there is a single negotiation procedure and secondly because it would increase the number of patients with availability of the drug and therefore its price.
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Horizon Therapeutics plc (Horizon) appreciates this opportunity to comment on the European Commission’s (EC) initiative to revise the Orphan and Paediatric Regulations.  Horizon is a biopharmaceutical company focused on researching, developing and commercialising medicines that address critical needs for people impacted by rare and rheumatic diseases.  We applaud the EC’s efforts to explore new avenues and incentives that will stimulate the development of orphan medicines and improve patient access to new treatments.  While the Orphan Regulation has incentivised the development of rare diseases therapies, we are concerned that some proposals outlined by the EC could unintentionally stifle innovation.  Specifically, the orphan medicinal product (OMP) pathway relative to prevalence should not be further limited by reducing the threshold or by replacing it with incidence criteria.  Reducing the prevalence criteria would result in a reduction in the number of orphan designations, which would have a detrimental effect on the development of new therapies for rare disease patients considering that presently there are over 7,000 rare diseases and only 5 percent have treatments.  The OMP pathway relative to insufficient return on investment, which attempts to address a hurdle to rare disease medicine development, should be revised rather than eliminated.  The EC could explore the use of novel “pull” financing mechanisms to expand and enhance the OMP pathway to further incentivise rare disease innovation (for example, similar to the European Parliament’s proposal to combat antimicrobial resistance through market entry rewards).  Additionally, we welcome the EC’s intent to establish a clear and consistent definition of unmet need.  We propose a more inclusive definition that is narrowly defined to situations where no treatment exists, and situations where alternatives to current treatments would decrease mortality, improve the patient’s symptoms or quality of life, and/or ease the burden on caregivers.  We would also welcome an opportunity for stakeholders to further discuss and define the concept.  Market exclusivity is the principal incentive to attract investment in research and stimulate the development of treatments for rare and paediatric diseases and should not be diluted with new caps, conditions or other limitations.  The regulations have successfully stimulated the development of many rare disease and paediatric medicines for European patients, but much of that momentum could be lost if this important incentive is curtailed.  Complementing market exclusivity with other incentives, such as priority or expedited review, interactive regulatory support and technical assistance could further align the EU’s regulatory system with the U.S.’s regulatory system.  Regulatory convergence, in turn, could result in more efficient collaboration between the EMA and FDA and support global development of orphan products.  Finally, we welcome the EC’s intention to update its legal framework to fully exploit new scientific advances.  Regulatory authorities should be empowered to provide flexibility that allows them to keep pace with scientific and technological advances that will ultimately benefit patients.  To that end, regulatory review and approval processes for OMPs could be improved to address development challenges for rare diseases (e.g., greater coordination and guidance regarding the choice of biomarkers, acceptable clinical data, and greater acceptance of real-world evidence).  Thank you for the opportunity to provide feedback and for considering our comments in your evaluation of the Orphan and Paediatric Regulations.
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Insufficient development in areas of greatest unmet medical needs for patients:  the development of medicines is not covering all major therapeutic areas. In the area of medicines for rare diseases, the evaluation found that 95% of rare diseases still have no treatment option.  Unmet Medical Need (UMN) definition and criteria need to be well established and monitored. UMN should take in account several parameters as (1) availability of option of care (2) availability of a treatment (3) benefits of the new treatment vs existing (4) pharmaco-eco and QoL benefits of the new cure. Availability and accessibility vary considerably across Member States:  Accessibility and affordability are inequal across member states because depends on the fiscal opportunities. Furthermore, generic competition after the expiry of exclusivity periods does not happen or happens only with delay, which also affects access. Finally, the lack of generic/biosimilar competition raises questions on the long-term budgetary sustainability. Scientific and technological developments cannot be fully exploited: current legal definitions, used in both Regulations, are directly linked to the concept of a disease. They are not always adequate to cater for advances in science, such as the use of biomarkers in medicines discovery, advanced therapies, or the use of innovative clinical trials designs. Scientific developments, such as personalized medicine approaches and the use of biomarkers, may hold great potential for optimal tailoring of treatments to diseases, but they should not lead to unnecessary multiplication of rare diseases out of common diseases.   We have 4 key concerns that must be communicated across member states regarding to OMP regulation: • Move the Orphan Designation criterion from prevalence to incidence • Focus incentives on Ultra-RD will not serve the other RD developments • The way of adapting and reducing the Market Exclusivity (ME) period for multi-RD indications will not address the UMN issue • Modulating incentivization would not resolve inequality of access and affordability entirely. The real issue is on the revision of the current HTA systems by non-legislative proposals  There are three concerns regarding to PED regulation: • The Paediatric Regulation is in line with its best-case scenario impact assessment. • Reducing rewards to complete PIPs will not redirect company interest into areas of paediatric need but risks undermining Europe’s attractiveness as a region for innovation. • New incentives are needed such as research incentives, or improved pan-European infrastructure for paediatric development.  Likely economic impacts The initiative is expected to decrease the overall financial burden related to the provision of medicines for rare diseases and children on national health systems/budgets. At the same time, it will be assessed whether additional costs to national health systems may derive from possible extensions of regulatory protection periods. For pharmaceutical industry the options leading to a reduction of the current rewards and incentives could lead to a reduced financial compensation and the introduction of novel incentives and rewards is intended to compensate development in specific areas of unmet medical need. The possibility to adapt the areas where such novel incentives and rewards would be applicable is meant to avoid possible distortions in the systems and possible overcompensations and to focus on the right unmet medical need. A revised system of incentives may on the one hand boost research and innovation in new therapeutic areas in line with scientific progress. On the other hand, a variable duration of the market exclusivity for medicines for rare diseases depending on the type of products will lead to faster generic/biosimilar competition.  All options would introduce dedicated funding to support SME and academia, which will likely lead to more research in the realm of medicines for rare diseases and children.
Submitted by: Association of Innovative Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Hungary
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: HollandBIO, the Dutch biotech industry association, appreciates the opportunity to provide feedback on the inception impact assessment on the revision of the EU legislation on medicines for children and rare diseases.   We endorse the four objectives for the revision of the two Regulations. We acknowledge there is room to improve and strengthen the effectiveness of the legislation. However, let’s not throw out the child with the bathwater. The benefits of the regulations on the quality of life of patients and children outweigh the costs, for both industry as well as for society. Any future revision requires a balance between promoting innovation and ensuring availability and access to orphan medicines. The goal must be to make it even more effective to stimulate development of new treatments for rare disease patients.   In addition, regardless of the scenario that is being considered for this revision, we call for further measures that strengthen the incentives and innovation ecosystem and counterbalance the possible negative impact of incentives reduction. This approach should closely align with the recently published IP Action Plan by the European Commission, which rightly emphasizes the role of a strong IP framework in fostering competitiveness and innovation.  Please find the attached document for our full response. Feedback from: HollandBIO (83.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Alexion is on a mission to transform the lives of people with rare disease and devastating conditions through the research and development of innovative medicines.  Thanks to our commitment and sustained investments patients suffering from rare and ultra-rare conditions such as Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), atypical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (aHUS), generalized Myasthenia Gravis (gMG), Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD), Hypophosphatasia (HPP) and Lysosomal Acid Lipase Deficiency (LAL-D) have a treat option, where prior few and, in some cases, none existed.  Our pipeline of over 20 research programs has the opportunity to transform the lives of patients with conditions such as Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), AL Amyloidosis, Wilson Disease, or Warm Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (WAIHA).  Alexion and companies like ours can only make these investments that lead to improvement in the lives of  patients through the commitment of the European Commission in establishing and continuing to support the European Orphan Medicinal Product (OMP) Regulation. This regulation is a cornerstone of the global rare disease innovation ecosystem and has enabled companies, such as Alexion, to pursue a growing number of treatments addressing the continued unmet needs of the rare disease community. With 95% of rare diseases lacking authorized treatment, the need to continue and accelerate this ambition could not be greater.   The value of the OMP Regulation for orphan drug companies is multi-fold and it is important to understand that it has to cater to a very heterogenous industry, encompassing small start-ups, mid-sized focused enterprises such as Alexion, and global, fully diversified companies.   It is vital that the OMP Regulation continues to provide predictability in the environment to support the long-term research investments that are needed for rare disease treatments. Such conditions are essential for OMPs, which demand lengthy investment and planning cycles to adequately research such complex – often poorly understood - diseases and to develop effective, innovative biotechnology therapies. This includes research into active pharmaceutical ingredients which have the potential and ability to treat more than one condition that share pathophysiological mechanism. Orphan drugs that are valuable for more than one indication provide treatment options for patients who otherwise have no viable therapies. Alexion believes that the innovation and benefit they bring to those patients should be recognised and incentivised for each indication. Our experience with complement inhibition and researching its use across multiple rare and ultra-rare conditions exemplifies the benefits of such approach for the patients.  To address the challenge of 95% of rare diseases without available treatments, we encourage the European Commission to keep effective current incentives and to continue to strengthen the OMP Regulation in the following ways:   Enable orphan and non-orphan indications under one MAA to maximize potential of molecules that can treat multiple conditions, both rare and more common.  Facilitate access to accelerated assessment procedures like PRIME and conditional approval for OMPs   Establish regulatory flexibility (CMA and ECA) for indications for OMPs  Introduce a PIP waiver for OMPs for indications that occur primarily in adults, while keeping an attractive (current) reward as an option  Support global harmonization of regulatory requirements for OMPs   Finally, the planned revision of the OMP Regulation should avoid creating any disturbances or sending any mixed signals to the innovation community dedicated to rare diseases across Europe. Any changes to the Regulation, including potential improvements, must be thoroughly consulted with the entire community to make sure that they indeed will lead to an even stronger regulatory framework supporting increased R&D investments in the area of rare diseases.
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: PhRMA member companies share the goal of ensuring that patients with unmet medical needs in Europe have timely access to the latest cutting-edge treatments and cures. It’s been proven that innovative medicines help extend lives, lower hospital and overall health care costs and improve the financial sustainability of health systems. With this in mind, PhRMA’s members are concerned by the European Commission’s (EC) options for revising the incentives and rewards for the development of orphan and pediatric medicines, several of which would limit the very incentives that have proven to be effective to date. It is critical that the EC does not erode the significant progress made to date or consider policy solutions that would jeopardize the critical R&D that will enable tomorrow’s discoveries.   The lengthy and risky development process for new orphan and pediatrics medicines makes the research-based biopharmaceutical sector particularly reliant on the effective protection of patents, safeguards and incentives provided by intellectual property rights. Thanks to the Orphan Regulations adopted in 2000 and 2006, there has been an increase from eight authorized products before the entry of the regulation to over 160 treatments. Corresponding incentives in the United States have had similarly successful results. In 2018 alone, the FDA approved 34 new small molecule drugs – as well as several biologics – that brought significant treatment advances to patients with rare diseases. Of these 34 medicines, 15 were first-in-class treatments. These new medicines help patients across a variety of disease areas, including genetic disorders and rare forms of cancer.   In recent years some noteworthy rare disease treatment advances included: • The first approvals of gene therapies, beginning with landmark advances in treating rare cancers and an inherited form of vision loss; • The first treatments directed at treating the underlying causes of cystic fibrosis, based on rare genetic mutations; and • The first therapies available to treat many rare pediatric diseases, including Batten disease, hypophosphatasia, Chagas disease and neuroblastoma (a rare form of cancer that occurs in nerve cells and the brain).  As the EC notes, although researchers have made tremendous progress in advancing innovation for rare diseases, 95% of rare diseases still do not have a treatment option, representing a significant unmet need for patients. Reasons for this include that rare diseases are often biologically complex and much remains unknown about the underlying causes and the clinical course of many individual conditions. Even within a particular rare disease, there can be many variations or subtypes resulting in different clinical manifestations and disease progressions. As such, suggestions to limit incentives for a specific type of disease will not have any notable effect on tackling unmet need. Rather, they will serve simply to make Europe a less attractive place to invest.   Indeed, at a time when the EU is facing ever-increasing competition from the United States and emerging markets such as China (the EU accounted for only 25% of innovative treatments developed between 2014-2018 compared to 47% from the United States), the EU should be strengthening rather than undermining (including through new eligibility criteria), the protections it affords to foster biopharmaceutical investment in medicines to treat children and rare diseases.   It is critical that we do not underestimate the significant benefits that medicines for rare diseases have provided, or forget the promise for patients in the EU and beyond of the more than 560 medicines for rare diseases that are in the current biopharmaceutical pipeline. With this in mind, the innovative biopharmaceutical industry welcomes a continued dialogue with the EC throughout this review process to ensure that any reforms bolster our shared goal of addressing unmet medical need. feedback_msg_text: Le Leem et ses 260 adhérents sont pleinement mobilisés au regard des objectifs identifiés dans l’IIA. Toute révision des incitations devrait être conçue pour maintenir une Europe de l’innovation (un des enjeux de la Stratégie pharmaceutique de la Commission), cependant les options proposées ne permettent pas d’y parvenir. Besoins médicaux non-satisfaits (BMNS): De nouvelles incitations, en plus d'un financement dédié à la recherche et de voies réglementaires accélérées, peuvent stimuler la R&D dans les domaines des BMNS. Pour de nombreuses maladies, les connaissances scientifiques et les capacités de diagnostic doivent être développées. Tout processus d'identification des BMNS doit s'appuyer sur une définition et des critères précis issus d’une discussion multipartite regroupant les patients et leurs aidants, les organismes d'HTA, les payeurs et les entreprises. Cette définition ne concernant pas que les MR, elle ne doit pas être liée à la révision de cette réglementation. Changement des critères de désignation orpheline et de prévalence: La réduction des récompenses liées aux obligations des PIP ou les incitations à se concentrer sur les ultra-MR sans traitement ou sur les innovations de rupture, méconnait les spécificités de la recherche biomédicale. De telles mesures ne réorienteront pas la R&D vers les BMNS mais vont diminuer l’attractivité de l’Europe. Limiter les critères de désignation aux MR les moins répandues laissera de côté un nombre important de pathologies et de patients : 98,6 % des patients atteints de MR sont touchés par 10,9 % des MR les plus répandues. La diminution des seuils de prévalence, l'utilisation d’un critère de prévalence cumulée, le remplacement du critère de prévalence par un critère d’incidence pénaliseront l’innovation et les médicaments développés pour les maladies les plus mortelles.  Surcompensation ou accès des génériques: Les médicaments pédiatriques et orphelins ont un intérêt économique très marginal et ne sont donc pas attrayants pour les développeurs de génériques/biosimilaires. Le concept de surcompensation n'est pas établi, le SWD montre que 14 % des médicaments orphelins ont un chiffre d'affaires annuel > 100 M€. En France, la part du médicament orphelin dans les dépenses du médicament reste stable et marginale : 5 % en 2017 (vs 4 % en 2014). Accès dans tous les EM: Il est nécessaire d'identifier les causes profondes des inégalités d'accès pour trouver des solutions ciblées. Celles-ci sont multifactorielles et ne peuvent être réduites aux seules décisions des entreprises. Toute solution d'accès nécessitera une collaboration avec l’ensemble des parties prenantes des systèmes de santé nationaux, des évaluations HTA conjointes et de nouveaux modèles de prix. Conditionner les récompenses et les incitations aux obligations de lancement méconnait les aspects économiques de la R&D et la réalité des MR. Plus de 80 % des maladies sont ultra-rares et certains EM n’ayant aucun patient, une obligation de lancement dans l’ensemble des EM générerait des coûts réglementaires non justifiés du fait de l’absence de patient. La réduction des droits de PI n'est pas non plus une solution appropriée pour résoudre les questions d'accès-prix-financement. Ecosystème: Nous avons bien noté l’attention portée par la Commission aux TPE et PME indiquant qu’il y aurait un soutien sans précision quant à sa nature. Il est nécessaire de rappeler que 220 PME, responsables du développement de 51 % des médicaments orphelins, ont été créées après l’entrée en vigueur du règlement. Toute limitation des récompenses aura des conséquences importantes en termes d’attractivité pour ces PME. Nous appelons la Commission à examiner toutes les options dans le cadre d'une analyse d'impact approfondie et à reconnaître que son SWD est basé sur des données anciennes, n’intègre pas les actions du plan d’action pédiatrique CE-EMA 2018, la communication de la Commission 2016/C424/03 sur le règlement orphelin ou les progrès scientifiques.
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Please see our full commentary in the attached file.  The German National Alliance of Patient Organisations of People Living with a Rare Disease (ACHSE – Rare Diseases Germany) agrees with the analysis of the Inception Impact Assessment (IIA) of the current problems with availability and accessibility of medicines for rare diseases in Europe. While ACHSE strongly supports the objectives of the IIA as summarized on page 3 and is willing to contribute to achieving those goals it wishes to stress at this point, that: 1. Reducing or complicating rewards for the development of rare diseases or even contemplating this reduces the willingness of the pharmaceutical industry to invest capital in the development of OMPs in lieu of other investment options and therewith deprives people living with a rare disease and unmet medical needs of future medication. 2. Reducing or improving those rewards will not have any influence on the actual access to authorized medication and should not be presented as such. Any – justified - concerns on the financeability and sustainability of the European health care systems should be addressed heads on. Indirectly reducing the development of medication in order to reduce costs should not be an option!  We strongly urge the Commission to broaden the analysis of the instruments the EU might have to foster improvements and achieve its laudable goals.   Berlin, 6th of January 2021 Feedback from: ACHSE - Rare Diseases Germany (94.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: As the Incept Impact Assessment notes, 95% of rare diseases currently have no available treatment, while many paediatric needs are unmet.   Unfortunately, the patent system discriminates often against commercial R&D into such diseases. Due to their complexity, R&D for these diseases typically takes much longer than for infectious diseases, frequently eating up most of the 20-year patent term before any commercial sales can take place.(Leitzan, Erika, The Drug Innovation Paradox (2017). University of Missouri School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper No. 2017-12.)   As a consequence, many companies have abandoned disease areas that require long-term trials because the patent system does not allow sufficient time to recoup research costs. (Budish, Eric, Benjamin N. Roin, and Heidi Williams, (2015) “Do Firms Underinvest in Long-Term Research? Evidence from Cancer Clinical Trials,” American Economic Review, 105(7): 2044-85)  The EU’s system of Supplementary Protection Certificates (SPCs) grants up to five years patent term extension to compensate for delays in regulatory approval process (and additional six months for paediatric drugs), but this is often not enough time to allow a sufficient period of market exclusivity for the most challenging diseases. The dilution of the SPC via the manufacturing waiver in 2019 further reduced intellectual property incentives to invest in rare and paediatric diseases.   It is concerning therefore that there is a suggestion of further weakening of the SPC regime for both orphan and paediatric designations. Rather, we would recommend the system is recalibrated to strengthen R&D incentives for these areas. That may mean a lengthening of the SPC period for diseases with particularly long R&D timelines (neurological conditions, some cancers etc).   If the EU incentive system is further weakened there is a risk that investment, jobs and economic value will head towards jurisdictions outside the EU, to the bloc’s economic and social loss. It is not clear either that the proposed solutions from the Commission would increase R&D into unmet needs – a lose-lose scenario.
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: The Proveca team has extensive experience in paediatric medicines, including 13 years with the PUMA process, gaining PUMAs for Sialanar® and Buccolam®. We observe 4 main challenges:  1. Market Protection for PUMA medicines.  o Only 6 PUMA route products approved in 13 years, indicates that the incentives are insufficient to attract significant the required investment o The 10 years data exclusivity only prevents cross reference to data contained within the PUMA. not the true market protection offered to Orphan medicines o Proveca is aware of at least one company repeating the work described and published in the PUMA product’s EPAR and entering the market via a national licensing route.    2. Competition from Extemporaneous and named patient special products.  o There are several member states where extemporaneous manufacture and off label use is commonplace and not actively discouraged, despite the existence of PUMA products. o There are still a large proportion of off-patent medicines being prescribed for children that are not of the appropriate strength or format and contain harmful excipients   3. Pricing & Reimbursement.  • Proveca’s experience is aligned with the Commission’s statement in the Inception Impact Assessment regarding “national pricing & reimbursement decisions does in fact determine whether a patient actually gets a medicine”.   o The EC and EMA have provided a harmonised approach to licensing paediatric medicines but the true benefit of this harmonisation is lost when the product enters the health technology assessment phase.   o Furthermore, the EMA-assessed and authorised dossier, whilst sufficiently comprehensive to gain centralised licence approval, is often considered to provide insufficient information to satisfy pricing and reimbursement authorities.   4. Return on investment.  o Companies face significant challenges in completing PIPs due to the burden of data requirements, despite lack of protection of the PUMA once granted. A number of agreed PIPs have not been converted into a PUMA, despite the extensive resource allocation of the EMA  In line with EC and EMA thinking, Proveca believes that all children deserve access to high quality, licensed medicines. Proveca proposes that this could be achieved if the revised legislation included the following:  • increased incentives for the development of paediatric medicines that improve the market protection offered to PUMA products.  This could be achieved by changing the 10 years data exclusivity to 10 years true market exclusivity as offered to Orphan drugs.  Specifically, it is proposed that the “data exclusivity” for PUMA mentioned in Section 19 of REGULATION (EC) No 1901/2006 would be replaced by the “market exclusivity” stated in Section 29 of the same Regulation.  • a requirement for member states to enforce the cessation of off label use and extemporaneous manufacture when a licenced paediatric product is available (unless there is a genuine, documented need for such a product which cannot be met by the PUMA licensed product).  • standardised pricing criteria for all member states that recognises and emphasises the value in having high quality, data backed, age-appropriate formulations for children i.e. the PUMA has the same ‘status’ as an Orphan drug.   In addition • Proveca recognises that pricing issues are under the control of member states and asks that the EC publishes data which illustrates the prices given (or not) for the adoption of PUMA medicines and the use of unlicensed medicines.   • Prior to full PIP submission, a short preliminary review process (with the EMA and HTA stakeholders), with an approximate view on the price (cost per country re patient numbers), would be of great benefit.  This would mean that Companies would better understand the return on investment prior to entering into the full PIP submission process and consuming significant EMA resource. feedback_msg_text: Comments on the EC- Inception Impact Assessment  Ref. Ares (2020)7081640 - 25/11/2020  From  European CRO Federation (EUCROF), Paediatric Working Group of EUCROF        EUCROF is welcoming the opportunity to comment on the Inception Impact Assessment from the EC in view of the Revision of the EU legislation on medicines for children and rare diseases.  The development of therapies for rare diseases and for the paediatric population share similarities and thus it is appropriate to review the two regulations, for Orphan Drugs and Paediatrics, together.  1. Unmet Medical Needs The aim to better identify unmet medical needs and to include criteria to determine unmet medical needs for children is very welcome and will certainly improve research in those therapeutic areas. In respect to the establishment of definition and identification of unmet medical needs, it will be important to consult the concerned stakeholders including paediatric experts, physicians, academia as well as patients/patient advocacy groups.   2. Regulatory Development To have the products identified by the system of unmet medical needs, benefit from a process similar to the current PRIME scheme will definitively help for a more streamlined product development. It would be important that all key stakeholders get involved, e.g., EMA and all relevant Committees, PDCO, Enpr-EMA, and patient representatives.    3. Reward System Planned The proposal to link the 6-month SPC extension to PIP completion and placing the product on the market in Member States is a positive step towards a timely completion of PIPs and getting all patients in the EU access to new therapies. Linking the rewards to placing the drug on the market could lead to an improvement of the current situation in which we face the fact that approved therapies are not accessible equally to patients in all EU Member States.     Additional reward for drugs for unmet medical needs is an important proposal and will certainly contribute to meeting the objective to get drugs and therapies developed for these conditions.   Novel rewards such as different types of transferable “vouchers” (e.g., priority review or regulatory rewards vouchers) would be a notable manner to recognise the companies efforts for the development of medicines for children. There is the Priority Review Voucher system established in the US that one could look at.       4. Exemptions from Paediatric Studies and Mechanism of Action consideration The review of granting exemptions from paediatric studies and moving towards a Mechanism of Action based evaluation would certainly allow the development of further therapies for the paediatric population. For drugs for cancer, this would be in line with the RACE for Children Act from the US FDA and would support further global harmonisation and global drug development.   5. Funding The proposal is to limit funding to certain categories of developers, e.g., SMEs and Academia. All developers could deserve funding to develop drugs/therapies for unmet medical needs and rare diseases.   6. Further Suggestion Revision of the PIP process in terms of timelines, i.e., shorter process for the initial PIP.   EUCROF
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: ACCELERATE CONTRIBUTION TO THE EU INCEPTION IMPACT ASSESSMENT ON PROPOSED REVISION OF PAEDIATRIC AND ORPHAN REGULATION ACCELERATE, the international multi-stakeholder platform which aims to accelerate innovation in drug development for children and adolescent with cancer, welcomes the initiative of the European Commission to revise both the Paediatric and Orphan Regulations. Indeed, the unmet medical needs of children with cancer have not been appropriately addressed to date, while science-driven innovation and research and development (including precision oncology, immunotherapy, and targeted therapies) have profoundly changed and impacted the therapeutic landscape of adult cancers. ACCELERATE has demonstrated the value of multi-stakeholder cooperation, with representatives from academia, industry, regulatory agencies (EMA, FDA and agencies from other jurisdictions) and patient advocates collaborating to improve and accelerate the development of innovative therapies for children with cancer. Improving access to innovative medicines is also essential and should be addressed early in paediatric drug development plans; ACCELERATE aims to work with Health Technology Assessment agencies to achieve this goal. ACCELERATE supports the proposal to foster science-driven research and development of medicines devised for adult cancer in the paediatric population (including revising conditional exemptions to consider drug mechanism of action rather than adult condition) and prioritising products that address unmet medical needs.  Unmet medical needs should be defined in a multi-stakeholder setting rather than through fixed criteria in the regulations. ACCELERATE has demonstrated the feasibility and value of a multi-stakeholder initiative through the development of Paediatric Strategy Forums with EMA in collaboration with FDA to define unmet therapeutic needs in paediatric malignancies and to facilitate prioritisation. The legislation should provide a structure and framework where multi-stakeholder cooperation would be paramount to continually identify and evaluate unmet needs and prioritise medicinal products. Improving the system of incentives and rewards is required. The revision should build on the successes achieved so far rather than completely replacing the current system. Better tailored and optimised incentives should be established to reward early start of paediatric development and evaluation of products addressing unmet needs. An ACCELERATE multi-stakeholder working group has proposed to define interim and final deliverables within the Paediatric Investigation Plan (PIP), each attracting a reward on completion. There are numerous experimental medicinal products that are “shelved” after their development in adults is terminated, not always for lack of efficacy or safety concerns. Facilitating science-driven repurposing of shelved experimental drugs for paediatric development would contribute to accelerate innovation for children with cancer and other life-threatening diseases. In addition, novel rewards, such as transferable vouchers, would incentivise both the development of paediatric medicines addressing the specific biological alterations of paediatric disease (first in child product development) and approval of products for unmet needs. ACCELERATE highlights that international cooperation is paramount because each paediatric cancer is individually rare and developing innovative therapies is necessarily a global endeavour. ACCELERATE is currently working to identify current barriers for academic and industry sponsored international trials. FDA, EMA and agencies from other jurisdictions have already started to work together in the paediatric cluster calls. Reinforcing cooperation towards greater alignment is needed to accelerate approval of the global science-driven paediatric development of medicinal products that will address unmet therapeutic needs of children suffering from cancer or other rare life-threatening diseases.
Organisation: ACCELERATE - Innovation for Children and Adolescents with Cancer
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: The Danish The Danish Association of the Pharmaceutical Industry (Lif) is fully committed to ensuring that solutions to unmet needs are found and that treatments are made available to all European patients. Children and patients with rare diseases have greatly benefited from the developments made through the Paediatric & Orphan Regulations. The Paediatric Regulation is living up to best-case expectations from the impact assessment conducted in 2004. The Orphan Regulation has incentivised the pharma sector to deliver treatments for more than 6 million patients. Any revision of the incentives should be designed to preserve and further improve Europe’s strong basis for innovation and avoid measures aimed to address affordability issues which are best dealt with elsewhere.   Lif agree that new incentives, combined with dedicated research funding and accelerated regulatory pathways, can stimulate R&D in areas of unmet need. For many diseases, scientific knowledge and diagnostic capabilities must be built, and clinical endpoints developed. Any process to identify unmet needs to build on a multi-stakeholder discussion and include inter alia patients and their caregivers. Such a system must also spill over to and be recognised by downstream decision-makers, ie HTA bodies and payers.  Reducing rewards for fulfilling the PIP obligations or reducing incentives to focus only on RD where no treatment exists or on first in class innovation fail to understand the science behind biopharma research. Such measures will not redirect R&D into areas of needs but rather risk undermining EU’s attractiveness as a hub for innovation. Limiting the RD-designation criteria to less prevalent diseases risks leaving out a substantial number of pathologies and patients; reducing prevalence thresholds or using a cumulative prevalence criterion fails to recognize the importance of follow-on innovation to achieve meaningful patient outcome.  Developing medicines for children and RD patients only provides a very marginal economic case, which is why these areas are not attractive to generic and biosimilar developers. The concept of overcompensation is not established: the staff working document (SWD) showed that only 14% of OMPs have yearly turnover of >€100 million. Making rewards and incentives conditional on launch obligations fails to understand the economic rationale behind biopharmaceutical research and the complexities of launching medicines across the EU.  Lif encourage the Commission to work with stakeholders and urgently identify the root causes of differences access to find targeted solutions. Root causes are multifactorial and cannot be reduced to independent company decisions. Any access solutions will require close collaboration of national healthcare systems (eg HTA and P&R bodies) on issues such as pan-European evidence generation, meaningful joint clinical assessments, and novel pricing and payment systems. They require solidarity between Member States (MS), a recognition that wealthier EU MS should not benefit from the lower prices in less wealthier MS on the expense of patient in these countries. Lif welcomes the Commission’s intention to keep pace with the progress in scientific and technological developments and to ensure that procedures remain efficient. Regulatory authorities should be entrusted to ensure that the system works and keeps up with global regulatory and scientific developments. Key scientific and procedural developments can be consolidated in guidance, eg on issues such as biomarker-defined conditions, or class waivers for paediatric development. Lif call on the Commission to consider all options through a thorough impact assessment, including those identified as ‘baseline’ and to acknowledge that their SWD is based on data up to 2017, which neither reflects the actions agreed in the 2018 EC-EMA paediatric action plan, nor the Commission notice 2016/C 424/03 on the Orphan Regulation or scientific and regulatory progress.
Organisation: The Danish Association of the Pharmaceutical Industry
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules
organisation_lower: the danish association of the pharmaceutical industry
