feedback_msg_text: The European Joint Programme on Rare Diseases (EJP RD) thanks the European Commission (EC) for the opportunity to comment on this inception impact assessment regarding the revision of regulations on medicines for rare and paediatric diseases. EJP RD is a consortium born in the context of the H2020-EU.3.1.3. Programme and co-financed by the EC and participating Member States.  Here we share the proposals from researchers, clinicians and patients involved in the project. To note, the following statements do not necessarily represent the official views of every organization partner of the EJP-RD and therefore should not be interpreted as an official position of any member of EJP-RD. The tools issued by the Orphan Regulation have created a strong policy response to unmet medical needs and worked well together to support the R&D of new orphan medicines, so the first recommendation from EJP RD is to be very careful in the revision of the current mechanism, to avoid adding obstacles to the already challenging process of developing medicines for rare diseases.  We propose to: - Define the criteria for the identification of unmet needs.  - Introduce differentiated tools to incentivize R&D on most unmet needs. - Expand accelerated approval to all orphan medicines -> possibly creating voucher for “priority review” based on identified unmet needs that can be transferred together with the orphan designation.  - Lighten the regulatory validation approach in the preclinical phase by considering the concept of use of pre-validated technological platforms that apply agreed, regulatory compliant standards for development of new products. - Propose a pathway to define reimbursement conditions for specific rare diseases before drug development. - Increase the resources for a basic research and science that enables regulatory compliant pre-clinical and clinical development of orphan medicines in all age groups. – Include in the Orphan Regulation mandatory tax reimbursement/discounts for all the R&D phases of orphan medicines. - Implement monitoring systems of public funding orphans R&D and its impact on marketing authorization and availability to patients. - Assess the feasibility of a non-commercial R&D united to cost controlled manufacturing and distribution of orphan medicines abandoned or shelved by other entities for commercial reasons. - Include incentives for developers aiming to produce new studies to continue the development of orphan medicines abandoned by other entities for commercial reasons and also the development of shelved molecules. – Align all the EMA fees for academia and not-for-profit to the most favourable provisions already in place for SMEs. - Launch initiatives to support the interaction between developers (especially academic and not-for-profit) and EMA. - Harmonize the tools for data processing and sustain adequate models of governance coordinated structures for data sharing and access, taking into account paeculiarities of different type of data (e.g. paediatric, genetic). - Engage patients (including children) and patient/parent associations in developing studies on ethical/legal/social issues, quality of life and direct/indirect economic impact. - Enforce the provision on transparency of clinical trial data (already foreseen in the CTR (EU) 536/2014) by linking the publication of data with the maintenance of the orphan designation which could otherwise be suspended or even removed. - Make compatible the measures foreseen in the Paediatric Regulation and/or setup new ones. In line with the above proposals, EJP-RD endorses Option 3 stated in the Inception Impact Assessment for orphan medicines. Finally, EJP RD consortium expresses its interest in participating in the targeted consultation planned in 2021. In the attachment, a more complete discussion on these proposals and their linked gaps. Feedback from: European Joint Programme on Rare Diseases (144.2 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: As the leading international advocacy organisation dedicated to realizing the promise of advanced therapy medicinal products (ATMPs) and the global voice of the sector, the Alliance for Regenerative Medicine (ARM) welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on this inception impact assessment.   ATMPs address diseases with the greatest unmet medical needs: The potential of ATMPs in addressing the unmet medical need in rare and paediatric diseases is unprecedented. Significant progress in the fields of ATMPs - products based on genes, cells and tissues - have opened up the possibility of durably treating and potentially curing many rare diseases. In particular, rapid progress has been made in the treatment of monogenic diseases (caused by a defect in a single gene) which are paediatric diseases as well. Unlike the products already available, ATMPs address the root cause of the disease by adding or replacing the defect gene responsible for the disease. In other cases, ATMPs may provide or replace diseased or malfunctioning cells, tissues, or other structures.   As of the first half of 2020, the Alliance for Regenerative Medicine’s data shows that there were 434 companies worldwide active in developing ATMPs addressing rare diseases, of which 102 were based in Europe.   The clinical development of new medicinal products for rare conditions is challenging since randomised trials involving large series of patients is often impossible. Undertaking clinical trials in paediatric populations also encounters some challenges. ARM fully supports the EC proposed pharmaceutical strategy actions to increase the regulatory efficiency and approval times by providing additional flexibility for the timely adaption of technical requirements to scientific and technological developments and by revisiting existing regulatory tools such as priority review and scientific support to companies.    Incentives and rewards for the development of medicines for rare and paediatric diseases need to be predictable and sufficiently attractive to maintain Europe’s competitiveness:  The incentives provided for medicinal products in rare diseases in Europe have been instrumental and effective in significantly increasing the number of new medicinal products addressing rare indications.  Since the development of medicinal products typically represents 10+ years of investments, developers need predictability and clarity on the rewards.  Similarly, incentives for products addressing unmet needs in the paediatric population must remain robust and policymakers must avoid any regulatory changes that increase burdens for development.  As stated in the Commission Communication on “Making the most of the EU’s innovative potential – An intellectual property action plan to support the EU’s recovery and resilience”, the development of a flourishing health ecosystem in Europe requires a transparent system of IP incentives, boosting innovation, whilst ensuring effective access to affordable medicines.   In any revision of the legislation, ARM encourages the EC to carefully weigh any revision of development incentives and rewards.  Recent analysis showed that Europe is less attractive than other regions in the world such as North America and Asia for the development of ATMPs, gene therapies in particular (see on https://alliancerm.org/indication-data/clinical-trials-in-europe/). A reduction of the current rewards and incentives could be counter-productive by further reducing Europe’s attractiveness, running the risk that a number of potentially transformative treatments never reach European patients, with the resulting negative individual, healthcare, societal and economic effects.    Please see the attached document for more details.  Feedback from: Alliance for Regenerative Medicine (2.2 MB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Związek Pracodawców Innowacyjnych Firm Farmaceutycznych INFARMA reprezentuje 25 firm sektora farmaceutycznego, prowadzących działalność badawczo-rozwojową i produkujących leki innowacyjne. Misją firm członkowskich INFARMA jest dążenie do zapewnienia dostępnych terapii dla wszystkich polskich pacjentów, w tym pacjentów z chorobami rzadkimi oraz dla dzieci.  INFARMA docenia uznanie przez Komisję Europejską znaczenia sierocych produktów leczniczych (OMP) i leków pediatrycznych, jakie wskazano w Inception Impact Assessment (IIA). Z zadowoleniem przyjmujemy podkreślone cele stymulowania dalszego rozwoju w obszarach niezaspokojonych potrzeb medycznych oraz poprawy dostępu do innowacyjnych leków dla pacjentów europejskich.   Dzieci i pacjenci z rzadkimi chorobami odnieśli ogromne korzyści z postępu osiągniętego dzięki dotychczas działającym rozporządzeniom pediatrycznym i sierocym. Rozporządzenie, dotyczące leków sierocych zachęciło sektor farmaceutyczny do rozwoju terapii dla ok. 6,3 miliona pacjentów. Wszelkie zmiany zachęt powinny mieć na celu utrzymanie i wzmocnienie innowacyjności w Europie i nie powinny zmierzać w kierunku regulowania kwestii, dotyczących dostępności.   Popierając cel, jakim jest stymulowanie rozwoju leków pediatrycznych, uważamy, że zmiana rozporządzenia w postaci obecnie proponowanej w IIA nie doprowadzi do realizacji  tego celu. Rozporządzenie pediatryczne nałożyło na firmy, opracowujące produkty dla dorosłych obowiązek oceny ich stosowania u dzieci. Redukcja nagród za wypełnianie obowiązków nie doprowadzi do dalszego rozwoju leków pediatrycznych. Odpowiedzią na niedoskonałości sformułowane w IIA może być natomiast wdrożenie 3-letniego planu działania, dotyczącego rozporządzenia pediatrycznego sformułowanego przez KE i EMA w 2018 r. Przyspieszenie rozwoju terapii dla chorób pediatrycznych można rozwiązać w ramach rozporządzenia sierocego (OR), ponieważ wiele z nich to choroby rzadkie.  INFARMA podziela obawy KE dotyczące dostępu do leków w całej Europie i nie dotyczy to wyłącznie terapii stosowanych w chorobach rzadkich. Na główne przyczyny nierównej dostępności leków w państwach członkowskich mają wpływ różne czynniki i wielu interesariuszy. Członkowie INFARMA współpracują ze wszystkimi zainteresowanymi stronami, aby znaleźć trwałe rozwiązania w tym obszarze, tj. programy dostępu (access programmes) lub nowatorskie modele płatności. Kwestie te jednak nie mogą być rozwiązane za pośrednictwem regulacji w zakresie rozporządzenia sierocego.  Rozporządzenie to rzadko stanowi przeszkodę w wejściu na rynek leków generycznych. Często rynek leków sierocych jest po prostu zbyt mały, aby stymulować rozwój leków generycznych lub biopodobnych.  Zachęcamy Komisję Europejską do dalszej współpracy z zainteresowanymi stronami i pilnego zidentyfikowania głównych przyczyn różnic w dostępie do terapii oraz znalezienia konstruktywnych rozwiązań, które wymagają solidarności pomiędzy krajami członkowskimi.  Jako INFARMA, jesteśmy przekonani, że utrzymanie zachęt do innowacji jest ważne i z niepokojem obserwujemy inicjatywy, które mogą zagrozić inwestycjom w badania i rozwój. Jesteśmy gotowi do współpracy w celu wypracowania konkretnych propozycji, umożliwiających większej liczbie pacjentów w Europie szybki i równy dostęp do potrzebnych im leków.
Organisation: The Employers' Union of Innovative Pharmaceutical Companies INFARMA
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Amerykańska Izba Handlowa w Polsce (AmCham) jest organizacją zrzeszającą ponad 340 firm amerykańskich działających w Polsce, w tym kluczowe firmy rynku farmaceutycznego, reprezentujących jednocześnie jedną z największych grup inwestorów zagranicznych.   W związku z prowadzonymi konsultacjami do wstępnej oceny skutków rozporządzenia Komisji Europejskiej dot. leków pediatrycznych i leków sierocych stosowanych w chorobach rzadkich, wyrażamy opinię, że przegląd rozporządzenia OMP powinien w szerszym zakresie dążyć do utrzymania i zapewnienia innowacyjnego ekosystemu umożliwiającego i zachęcającego do badań i rozwoju w zakresie chorób rzadkich, co bezpośrednio przekłada się na dobro pacjentów oraz zapewnia ich efektywne leczenie.   Obecnie obowiązujące regulacje przyczyniły się w wielkim stopniu do opracowania leków dla dzieci oraz osób cierpiących na choroby rzadkie, a ich skuteczność potwierdza fakt opracowania ponad 180 metod leczenia w ponad 107 chorobach rzadkich w ciągu 20 lat obowiązywania regulacji. Jednocześnie w ciągu ostatnich 10 lat rozporządzenie pediatryczne zaowocowało rejestracją ponad 260 nowych leków dla dzieci.   Należy podkreślić, iż dotychczasowe przepisy zapewniają równowagę pomiędzy obowiązkami i zachętami związanymi z opracowywaniem nowych terapii. Naruszenie równowagi tego systemu może doprowadzić do istotnego ograniczenia innowacji w tym obszarze, dlatego wyrażamy nadzieję, iż w dalszych pracach Komisja Europejska utrzyma odpowiednie zachęty i zabezpieczy potrzeby pacjentów cierpiących na choroby rzadkie. feedback_msg_text: Lif Sweden’s member companies are developing and producing innovative medicines, including orphan and paediatric medicines, and are committed to patients’ access to innovative treatments and to meet unmet medical needs.    The EU regulations for orphan diseases and paediatrics (adopted in 2001 and 2006) have resulted in medical breakthroughs and new pharmaceutical treatments, benefitting patients suffering from orphan diseases as well as children.   An Impact assessment for the adoption of the paediatric regulation was performed in 2004 and the regulation is now meeting the best-case expectations. As the regulations were adopted the focus was on the development of new and much needed treatments. Today there is also a discussion on access and affordability. These are key issues but given that healthcare is a national competence within the EU, issues regarding pricing, reimbursement, treatment guidelines etcetera are decided by each individual country, or even by regions within countries. Changes in the EU regulations could affect the development of new pharmaceutical treatments in Europe and the number of treatments approved. Lif believes that access and affordability  need to be assessed and discussed in a wider context, and we therefore propose a high-level forum with representatives from the EU institutions, from the member countries and from the biopharmaceutical industry to take these discussions forward.   The Orphan Regulation has incentivised the pharmaceutical sector to deliver treatments for up to 6.3 million patients. Any revision should be designed to keep and improve Europe’s strong basis for innovation and should avoid measures aimed to address affordability issues which are best dealt with elsewhere, and that are primarily dependent on national policies.   In 1990, Europe was the leading continent in pharmaceutical R&D. But in the year 2000 the US had taken over the lead and in 2016 the US R&D expenditure was more than 50% higher than the European investment (Efpia Pharmaceutical expenditure in Europe, USA and Japan, 1990-2016). Today there is an East-bond wind as countries like Japan, China and India are increasing their R&D investments. Europe is still strong, though challenged. Therefore, changes in the regulations need to be assessed in an international context, in comparison with relevant countries.     We agree that new incentives, in addition to dedicated research funding and accelerated regulatory pathways, can stimulate R&D in areas of unmet need. For many diseases, scientific knowledge and diagnostic capabilities must be built, and clinical endpoints developed. Any process to identify unmet needs must build on a multi-stakeholder discussion and include inter alia patients and their caregivers.   Reducing incentives to focus only on ultra-rare diseases for which no treatment exists or on first in class innovation fail to understand the science behind biopharmaceutical research. Such measures will not redirect R&D into areas of unmet needs but rather risk undermining Europe’s attractiveness as a region for innovation. Limiting the rare disease designation criteria to less prevalent diseases risks leaving out significant numbers of pathologies and patients; reducing prevalence thresholds or using a cumulative prevalence criterion fail to recognise the importance of follow-on innovation to achieve meaningful patient outcomes.  We welcome the Commission’s intention to keep pace with scientific and technological developments. Regulatory authorities should be entrusted to ensure that the system works and keeps up with global regulatory developments.   We call on the Commission to consider all options through a thorough impact assessment, including those identified as ‘baseline’ and to acknowledge that their SWD is based on data up to 2017, which neither reflects the actions agreed in the 2018 EC-EMA paediatric action plan, nor the Commission notice 2016/C 424/03.  Anders Blanck, Director General Lif Sweden
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: About 500.000 patients are suffering from rare diseases (RD) in Belgium. The EU Orphan Regulation has highly incentivized pharmaceutical industries to develop new treatments for those patients. The number of clinical trials in RD in Belgium has increased by 13% over the past 4 years; more than 20% of the clinical trials running today are in RD. 35% of the Medical Need Programs/Compassionate Use Programs approved by the Belgian health agency since 2014 are dedicated to Orphan Drugs. While there were only 8 drugs registered nationally for RD before the implementation of the EU Orphan Regulation, about 120 medicines having benefited from an EU orphan designation are now reimbursed or in negotiation for reimbursement in Belgium.   The Pediatric Regulation has also delivered results. An upward trend of 19% has been observed in the number of pediatric trials in Belgium over the past 4 years.  Any revision of the incentives should be designed to keep and improve Europe’s strong basis for innovation and avoid measures aimed to address affordability issues which are best dealt with elsewhere.   We agree that new incentives, in addition to dedicated research funding and accelerated regulatory pathways, can stimulate R&D in areas of unmet need. For many diseases, scientific knowledge/diagnostic capabilities must be built, clinical endpoints developed. Any process to identify unmet needs must build on a multi-stakeholder discussion, including patients/caregivers. Said system must also be recognized by downstream decision-makers.   Reducing rewards for fulfilling the PIP obligations or reducing incentives to focus only on ultra-RD where no treatment exists or first in class innovation fail to understand the science behind biopharmaceutical research. Such measures will not redirect R&D into areas of needs but rather risk undermining Europe’s attractiveness as a region for innovation. Limiting the RD-designation criteria to less prevalent diseases risks leaving out significant numbers of pathologies/patients (80% of rare disease patients are affected by less than 150 rare diseases with a prevalence of 1-5 in 10,000); reducing prevalence thresholds or using a cumulative prevalence criterion fails to recognize the importance of follow-on innovation to achieve meaningful patient outcome.  Making rewards/incentives conditional on launch obligations fails to understand the complexities of launching medicines across the EU. We call on the Commission to work with stakeholders and identify the root causes of access differences to find targeted solutions. Root causes are multifactorial and cannot be reduced to company decisions. Access solutions will require a close collaboration of national healthcare systems on issues eg pan-European evidence generation, meaningful joint clinical assessments, novel pricing/payment models & clinical networks.   In Belgium, the median period between market authorization and access was 435 days in the Patients W.A.I.T. Indicator 2019 Survey. Following measures could help accelerate access: horizon scanning & early dialogue, creation of an expert outcome-based agreement platform, mandatory reuse of the EU relative therapeutic value evaluation, immediate temporary reimbursement of orphan drugs with possibility to collect health data, a FAIR health data ecosystem.   We welcome the Commission’s intention to keep pace with scientific/technological developments and ensure that procedures remain efficient. Regulatory authorities should be entrusted to ensure that the system works and keeps up with global regulatory/scientific developments. Key scientific and procedural developments can be consolidated in guidance, eg on issues such as biomarker-defined conditions or class waivers for pediatric development.   We call on the Commission to consider all options through a thorough impact assessment including those identified as baseline; industry stands ready to work with the Commission to ensure future development of medicine. feedback_msg_text: Newesko Ltd is a consultancy company collaborating with several international pharma companies especially in the field of rare diseases. We would like to raise the following concerns regarding the EU Pharmaceutical Strategy. Addressing unmet needs of patients is of vital importance. All the intentions of the Commission to increase health and ensure accessible and affordable drugs for patients are appreciated. However, we have identified some concerns regarding the Pharmaceutical Strategy for Europe.  Our main concern is related to rare disease patients. Specifically, the concern is the proposed changes regarding prevalence related to Orphan Drugs. Limiting the incentives to only ultra-rare diseases with no therapies may not redirect investments according to the best interest of Europeans. In the worst scenario it would further reduce the attractiveness of Europe as a region for innovations. The additional concern is: Would Europe still seek a position as an innovation leader or has this position been permanently handed over to the USA? Innovation should be at the heart of the Pharmaceutical Strategy. In our opinion, the proposed change from prevalence to incidence may significantly decrease the interest in developing rare disease drugs among the pharma companies. The R&D investment and manufacturing costs of rare disease drugs remain on a very high level despite the small number of patients. This is a known fact which the EU Pharmaceutical Strategy document itself states: “The Commission Staff Working Document claims that 14% of orphan medicinal products have annual turnover of over 100 million euros in the EEA. The fact does not support the concept of overcompensation.”   It is a known fact that new innovations benefit patients. Open dialogue is needed between the Commission and the pharmaceutical industry. Additionally, public-private partnerships most likely contribute to new innovations and speed up the process. Reducing incentives and increasing obligations will not solve the issues. Pharmaceutical companies are willing and able to find solutions that benefit patients and at the same time increase the adherence of the patients. The importance of availability of medicines is crucial for a small country like Finland. We understand the Commission is responsible for availability and competition in all therapy areas and all drugs. Therefore, the need for biosimilars and generic competition after the patents of the drugs have expired is understood. However, austerity measures are seldom the way to success while controlled collaboration with increasing incentives may well be. The Commission should work with all stakeholders since the root causes of current issues are multifactorial. Matters related to accessibility and market access such as novel drug pricing, HTA assessments and payment models are currently challenging and have been challenged. Therefore, close dialogue will be needed and all opinions should be heard before the Commission finalizes the Pharmaceutical Strategy for the EU.
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Desde La Asociación Española de Laboratorios de Medicamentos Huérfanos y Ultrahuérfanos (AELMHU) consideramos que el Reglamento 141/2000 y el Reglamento 1901/2006, han contribuido a mejorar la calidad de vida de los pacientes con enfermedades raras.  La mayoría de los medicamentos innovadores son aprobados por procedimiento centralizado por la Agencia Europea de Medicamentos, de la que todos los Estados miembro forman parte con sus evaluadores delegados en los comités, que evalúan y toman las decisiones. En este sentido, en Europa competimos con otros focos igual de importantes en atraer la inversión económica y de talento científico hacia este campo, como puede ser Estados Unidos o Japón. Si los Estados miembro no tienen todos las mismas reglas del juego, algunos podrían quedar en una desventaja con consecuencias indeseadas. Pese a existir un procedimiento centralizado y por mucho que el Reglamento 141/2000 haya dado un importante impulso al desarrollo de medicamentos huérfanos en la UE, el 95% de las enfermedades raras aún no tiene opción de tratamiento.  Y para las que existen, sus tratamientos tienen importantes diferencias de acceso entre los Estados miembro y dentro de ellos a este respecto.  En algunos Estados miembro, el acceso a determinados tratamientos se retrasa o no entran en el mercado. En este sentido, cabe destacar el caso de España, donde sólo se comercializan el 48% de los medicamentos huérfanos con Autorización de Comercialización en la UE. Esto se traduce en que el 52% de los medicamentos huérfanos no están reembolsados por el SNS . Además, el tiempo medio de aprobación de los medicamentos huérfanos en 2019 tras recibir Código Nacional  fue de 15,2 meses.  En AELMHU damos la bienvenida a los esfuerzos de la Comisión Europea por incrementar el desarrollo de los medicamentos huérfanos y mejorar su acceso, por lo que proponemos las siguientes recomendaciones a la hora de revisar los reglamentos sobre medicamentos huérfanos y uso pediátrico: 1. Con el objetivo de poder atraer inversión y talento científico a Europa, dada la competitividad con otras regiones, la revisión del reglamento debería promover un ecosistema que fomente la I+D+i en las enfermedades raras.  2. Para conseguir un mayor desarrollo de medicamentos huérfanos y promover nuevas soluciones, se requerirá de financiación e importantes inversiones por lo que los incentivos jugarán un papel fundamental y será crucial poder mantenerlos y desarrollarlos.    3. Garantizar una mayor equidad entre los Estados miembro en el acceso a los medicamentos huérfanos, con un marco legislativo estable y predecible que contenga procedimientos claros, objetivos y con unas reglas de juego homogéneas y equilibradas para todos los actores que participen en el ámbito de las enfermedades raras. Para ello es imprescindible poder desarrollar un diálogo que abogue por encontrar el mayor consenso posible entre todas las partes interesadas incluyendo a los pacientes, profesionales sanitarios, administración pública, reguladores, pagadores y la industria.  4. Es necesario poder establecer un consenso sobre lo que significa “necesidades insatisfechas”. Somos conscientes de la importancia y necesidad de poder desarrollar nuevos tratamientos, sin embargo, en el ámbito de las enfermedades raras, la gravedad de la enfermedad y la calidad de vida de los pacientes juegan un papel fundamental, teniendo que poder desarrollar una definición común que tenga en cuenta estos elementos y la opinión de los diferentes agentes y actores involucrados. 5. Mejorar y agilizar el proceso de aprobación y revisión regulatoria de los medicamentos huérfanos fomentando una mayor aceptación de la evidencia del mundo real (RWE), así como una mayor alineación entre los reguladores y los requisitos de los pagadores.  Para resolver los desafíos actuales, es necesaria una estrecha colaboración de los actores implicados. Desde Aelmhu estaremos encantados de participar activamente y contribuir en en esta tarea.
Submitted by: Asociación Española de Laboratorios de Medicamentos Huérfanos y Ultra-Huérfanos AELMHU

feedback_msg_text: The Irish Pharmaceutical Healthcare Association represents 47 global companies that research, develop and bring to market innovative medicines. We partner for better healthcare and economic development in Ireland and, by extension, in the European Union.    We support key goals in the proposed EU Pharmaceutical Strategy. We welcome the opportunity to input to the Inception Impact Analysis (IIA) for the revision of EU legislation on medicines for rare diseases and for children.  We believe there is a fundamental problem, in principle and in practice, with seeking to improve equitable access to medicines for all European citizens by reducing intellectual property (IP) rights, envisaged in Options One and Four for orphan products and Options Two and Three for paediatric products.    Here, we are briefly sharing the experience of Ireland on a recent track record of delayed access to new medicines. It is a case in point about the root causes of inequitable access and delays. The reduction of IP rights would not have addressed these causes. It will not address them in the future, either.   According to data produced by IQVIA for the European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations, Ireland ranked 19th of 34 European counties in the rate of availability and the timeliness of access in 2019. Ireland has been near last in the former EU15, despite being much higher in that ranking in terms of income per capita and, therefore, affordability. Timing for access from EMA authorisation was 521 days on average - far beyond the 180 days envisaged in the Transparency Directive. This is despite having list prices which, by agreement between industry and the State, are externally referenced and limited to an average of a basket of 14 Members States since 2016 (including the UK, until recently).    Irish authorities carry out demanding Health Technology Assessments (HTAs) of nearly all proposed new medicines. Suppliers commonly offer discounted prices after the HTAs. However, even when a price is agreed, significant delays of even a year have occurred before a decision is made to provide and reimburse a medicine.  The root cause of recent delays in Ireland has been insufficient funding and a structural absence of appropriate multi-annual budgeting to manage medicines expenditure. No new funds were provided from the Exchequer in 2020 for new medicines. Budget 2021 corrected that, with a welcome €50 million allocation. A reduction of IP rights for orphan medicinal products or any other product would have made a negligible or no impact on achieving timely access within the benchmark of the Transparency Directive. In industry-State negotiations, it has never been suggested that it would.   Access, pricing and funding are linked. They should be addressed in their own terms. From experience in Ireland, the best way to enable the equitable and timely provision of medicines is by an open, outcome-focused negotiation between industry and the State on pricing, funding and efficient processes to evaluate new medicines, with competition in a sustainable off-patent market. Reducing IP rights is not an appropriate proxy for an access-pricing-funding discussion that addresses root causes and aims to deliver new medicines to patients. We do not see the IIA proposals as a reliable way to achieving that outcome. The proposals are not grounded in the practicalities of access, pricing and funding interactions between national authorities and medicines providers.  As a member state of the European Union that hosts the manufacturing base for the European and global supply of many medicines, we are strongly of the view that further investment and production of new medicines and therapies in Europe is unlikely to be helped by a European policy to reduce or weaken IP rights for medicines.    ENDS
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Przedstawione propozycje Komisji Europejskiej wychodzą naprzeciwko społecznemu zapotrzebowaniu dalszego rozwijania aktywności mającej na celu możliwość rozwijania działań w zakresie tzw. leków sierocych stosowanych w chorobach rzadkich. Cieszy nas fakt, że poprzez wspólne działania unijne polscy pacjenci będą mieli ułatwiony szerszy dostęp do leków, z których dotychczas korzystała tylko niewielka ilość chorych.  Choroby rzadkie obejmują średnio nawet 6-8 proc. populacji danego kraju, stanowiąc poważny problem zdrowotny i społeczny. W 50 proc. przypadków ujawniają się w wieku dziecięcym. Ich przebieg może być gwałtowny i grozić wczesnym zgonem. Nawet 26 proc. dzieci z tego rodzaju schorzeniami umiera przed osiągnięciem 5. roku życia. Z drugiej strony, m.in. dzięki wprowadzeniu do leczenia skutecznych terapii, choroby rzadkie mogą mieć przebieg przewlekły. Wtedy z chorobą żyje się wiele dziesięcioleci.   Wytyczne Parlamentu Europejskiego i Rady z dnia 16 grudnia 1999r. doprowadziły do poprawy warunków prac badawczo-rozwojowych w zakresie leków stosowanych w chorobach rzadkich, przyczyniając się do znaczącego wzrostu inicjatyw w tej dziedzinie, angażując zarówno środowisko akademickie jak i przedsiębiorców. Cieszy nas fakt, że liczba produktów leczniczych wzrosła już do 164 w roku 2018. W wielu krajach odnotowano również istotne skrócenie czasu faktycznego wprowadzenia tych produktów na rynek.Kluczową sprawą pozostaje dalej opracowywanie narodowych strategii i planów dot. chorób rzadkich kładących nacisk na diagnostykę i leczenie. Stwarza to wyrównanie szans z innymi chorymi.   Izba Gospodarcza „FARMACJA POLSKA” wielokrotnie postulowała konieczność stworznia efektywnego systemu zapewniającego terapię i opiekę zarówno dla pacjentów jak i ich rodzin. Naszym celem w dalszym ciągu będzie przekazywanie informacji i podnoszenie kompetencji środowisk pacjenckich oraz społeczeństwa na temat badań nad nowymi lekami a także wzmocnienie zaangażowania pacjentów w proces badawczy we współpracy z firmami farmaceutycznymi ośrodkami naukowymi, komisjami bioetycznymi a przede wszystkim władzami odpowiedzialnymi za ochronę zdrowia.  W obecnej sytuacji widzimy trzy istotne problemy.  1. Obecnie obowiązujące przepisy zachęcające do opracowywania leków dla dzieci i osób cierpiących na choroby rzadkie zapewniają względną równowagę pomiędzy obowiązkami i nagrodami związanymi z opracowywaniem nowych terapii. Naruszenie tej równowagi może mieć skutki odwrotne do zamierzonych i doprowadzić do zahamowania rozwoju nowych terapii w tych obszarach oraz sprawić, że Europa stanie się mniej atrakcyjnym miejscem do prowadzenia działań z zakresu badań i rozwoju.   2. Chociaż potrzeba więcej badań nad nowymi terapiami stosowanymi w leczeniu chorób rzadkich oraz dzieci, należy docenić niezwykły sukces obecnych regulacji zachęcających do opracowywania leków dla dzieci oraz osób cierpiących na choroby rzadkie. Skuteczność obecnie obowiązujących rozporządzeń potwierdza fakt opracowania ponad 180 metod leczenia w ponad 107 chorobach sierocych w ciągu 20 lat obowiązywania regulacji. Jednocześnie w ciągu 10 lat rozporządzenie pediatryczne także dowiodło swojego sukcesu i zaowocowało ponad 260 nowymi lekami dla dzieci.  3. Wprowadzenie potencjalnego ograniczenia wyłączności rynkowej na dalsze innowacje w rzadkich chorobach mogłoby negatywnie wpłynąć na badania i rozwój terapii w zakresie rzadkich nowotworów. Badania i rozwój terapii w rzadkich chorobach nowotworowych często polegają na rozszerzaniu wskazań, gdzie ryzykowne i trudne badania pozwalają na uzyskanie informacji o tym, że znana już cząsteczka może być również skuteczna w terapii pacjentów z rzadkimi nowotworami. Bez zachęt wynikających z rozporządzenia OMP prowadzenie prac badawczo-rozwojowych może skutkować znacznymi ograniczeniami.  Mamy nadzieję, że działania Komisji Europejskiej powinny prowadzić do przekonania krajów członkowskich UE do konieczności pilnego przyjęcia i wdrożenia NPChRz. feedback_msg_text: The German Medicines Manufacturers´ Association (BAH) is the leading trade organisation of the pharmaceutical industry in Germany. It represents the interests of about 400 member companies. Both globally operating medicines manufacturers are involved in the manifold activities of the association as well as the broadly represented medium-sized businesses. Besides medicines manufacturers, BAH membership is also comprised of pharmacists, lawyers, publishing houses and agencies, as well as market research and opinion research institutions.  BAH appreciates the opportunity to comment on the EC’s Initial Impact Assessment on EU legislation on medicines for rare diseases and paediatric medicines.   The availability of both paediatric medicines as well as treatments for rare diseases is very important and legitimately is supported by specialised regulations.   As regards to the discussed measures and envisaged changes to the legislation though, and while it is yet unclear, how certain measures are planned to be actually executed, we would like to suggest that EC takes into account the following:   From a purely regulatory perspective, a paediatric drug is available as soon as the medicinal product is authorised for its use. Still, this does not reflect reality as the drug is often available sooner, i.e. the medicinal product may already be authorised for adults and healthcare professionals will be able to prescribe or administer it to children. Unfortunately, this is done as a so-called Off-Label Use We understand it is the intent of the revision of the paediatric regulation to minimize or even stop off label use, but we believe the proposed measures are not adequate to encourage the development of authorised paediatric indications as the proposed incentives even seem to become smaller while generic competition is encouraged and supported at the same time. This makes it even more difficult for pharmaceutical companies to take a balanced decision both from an economic and ethical point of view – at the same time willing to support further production and conduct of studies in EU – to invest in paediatric development programs. Being forced to do studies in children, beyond the already specified measures which allow for both PIP waivers and deferrals, may even lead to decisions not to invest in certain developments. In addition, we strongly recommend that the decisions in which indications business is done (as there is more than just developing a drug) should continue to be voluntarily taken by companies.   As to both the proposed revisions of the orphan and paediatric regulation it is also not clear how unmet medical need is to be defined.   The recently released regulatory flexibilities in the context of Covid-19 vaccines as well as for relevant treatments may show some first ideas how to facilitate decisions to market products in additional markets (harmonised packs in English language while additional information is handed over digitally). Still, companies may still need further support in selling products in markets for which the refund of costs cannot be expected, especially, if at the same time, generic competition is further supported.

feedback_msg_text: ORPHELIA Pharma is a pharmaceutical company involved in the development and marketing of paediatric medicines. Our first product, Kigabeq®, is the paediatric formulation of the antiepileptic drug vigabatrin, to treat a rare and very serious condition: infantile spasms, also known as West syndrome. Vigabatrin is an essential medicine and was listed twice in the priority list of paediatric medicines of the EMA.  Kigabeq® was granted a Paediatric Use Marketing Authorisation (PUMA) on September 20th, 2018. Following the granting of the PUMA, we, at ORPHELIA Pharma, have worked hard to place Kigabeq® on the market. Today, Kigabeq® is marketed in Germany, France and the United Kingdom.  From our experience with paediatric medicines, we would like to stress the following: 1. Pricing harmonization for PUMAs across EU This is probably the most important topic to ensure that paediatric medicines are swiftly developed by specialized SMEs and made available across EU countries. For instance, Kigabeq® is reimbursed in the 3 above-mentioned countries. There are, however, huge discrepancies among those 3 countries, with France and UK having understandable pricing policies, whereas Germany does not. As for Germany, despite huge and money and time-consuming efforts including an arbitration board meeting with the Federal Joint Committee (G-BA) held on April 24th, 2020, the G-BA considered that Kigabeq® would get a reimbursement price corresponding to only about one tenth of the French and UK prices, and only one third of the reference product price, Sabril®, which is unreasonably low. This reimbursement price for Kigabeq®  is not economically-sustainable, and as a consequence Kigabeq® will be definitively withdrawn from Germany in 2021. As the above example points out, there is an urgent need for a more rationale and homogeneous way of fixing prices across EU for PUMA medicines.  We understand that pricing and reimbursement considerations are the sole competencies of EU member states. However, one mechanism by which PUMA medicines could be priced on a reasonable basis would be to ensure that they are granted prices that are no lower than those of originator products (approved in adults) on a daily treatment cost basis. (Daily Treatment Cost)PUMA ≥ (Daily Treatment Cost)Originator This approach was adopted by the CEPS for Kigabeq®, and it was pivotal in finding an agreement that allowed ORPHELIA Pharma to launch this medicine in France. 2. Market protection Market protection is another topic of importance. Though orphan drugs are granted a 10-year market protection, PUMAs are only granted a 10-year data protection. Hence, there is little protection barriers for paediatric medicines. Aligning market protection between orphan and paediatric (PUMA) medicines would be a significant step forward. In addition, some paediatric medicines are manufactured in hospital pharmacies from adult pharmaceutical forms. We request that, as soon as a PUMA medicine containing the same active ingredient is approved, these extemporaneous preparations are no longer authorized. 3. Education of HTA  Sensitization of HTA committees members is another subject which could be extremely useful and is somehow related to price fixation in EU (point #1). From our experience, medicines for children are often considered as generic medicines and HTA committees members are reluctant to evaluate them on their own merit or on the medical benefit for children. This is especially true since paediatric medicines are often developed on the basis of existing efficacy/safety data and their dossier are thus devoid of any specific efficacy data. ORPHELIA therefore appeals to politicians and administration in the healthcare system to accompany and support manufacturers of paediatric drugs on their way to improving therapy for sick children. Closing ranks would help children and parents alike, that should be the goal and credo in the treatment of children.  With kind regards,
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: The Regulations that the European Union adopted through the Regulation for Medicines for Rare Diseases in 2001 gave a strong boost to the work of pharmaceutical laboratories in this field, and today more than 160 new drugs are available to treat 90 diseases. But much remains to be done, as 95% of rare diseases need treatment.  We are convinced that continuing to ensure stable regulation with incentives and rewards for the pharmaceutical industry will further encourage research and development of new treatments for rare diseases not yet covered. Reducing the period of market exclusivity for multi-indication drugs will not solve the problem of unmet medical needs and dedicating incentives only to Ultra-Rare diseases will not improve the development in other rare diseases. We are concerned about the criterion for changing the designation of orphan drugs from prevalence to incidence, as the development of new treatments for rare diseases with higher mortality will be penalised.  We also believe that further work is needed to make these treatments equally available and accessible in all Member States. The real problem lies in the revision of Health Technology Assessment (HTA) systems by non-legislative proposals, it leads to great differences in policies and assessments of price and reimbursement between EU countries.
Initiative: Medicines for children & rare diseases – updated rules

feedback_msg_text: Notre analyse du règlement sur les médicaments à usage pédiatrique montre que sa révision doit se concentrer sur 6 points majeurs - Dans les cas où le cadre actuel de détermination de la condition PIP en utilisant le développement de l'adulte comme point de départ ne répond pas aux besoins non satisfaits chez les enfants, il faut s'assurer d'avoir  *un argumentaire scientifique solide démontrant la validation des modèles précliniques reliés à la pathologie concernée et une attention particulière portée aux effets sur la croissance et la puberté *la présence d'une altération génétique (germinale ou tumorale ou des tissus/organes affectés par le processus pathologique) ou moléculaire permettant de présumer de la haute probabilité d'efficacité de la nouvelle molécule en raison de son action inhibitrice ou stimulante sur des circuits métaboliques ou immunitaires intervenant dans la pathologie concernée *une pathologie grave et invalidante sans traitement de référence à l'heure actuelle *un pronostic vital engagé à court/moyen terme mais une durée de vie escomptée permettant de justifier l'administration d'un nouvel agent thérapeutique pour évaluer la balance entre le risque et le bénéfice thérapeutique potentiel De plus il est impératif que le protocole de recherche précise la stratification dans le temps pour l’inclusion majeur/mineur : la première administration chez les adolescents 12-17ans ne peut se faire qu’après la validation des données de la 1ère dose chez l'adulte. - Analyser les besoins en médicaments pédiatriques dans tous les pays de l'Union européenne et les confronter avec les études de marché pour chaque domaine thérapeutique - Donner au PEDCO des moyens humains et financiers pour fonctionner. Il est inadmissible que les experts du secteur pédiatrie n'aient pas les mêmes traitements et avantages que ceux travaillant pour le secteur des médicaments adultes. - Renforcer les pouvoirs du Pedco afin que lors de toute l'instruction du PIP, les experts puissent revenir sur leur décision  et aient aussi la possibilité de refuser cette instruction dans le cas où des règles déontologiques ou éthiques ne sont pas respectées par le demandeur. - l’encombrement des dossiers ne veut pas dire que toutes les pathologies d’un domaine ont des solutions thérapeutiques ou que ces solutions soient totalement étudiées. La solution de faire des priorités provoquera obligatoirement la mise à l'écart de besoins identifiés pour les maladies pédiatriques ayant ou non des traitements. Par exemple les effets secondaires, les formes galéniques spécifiques, la pharmacovigilance et les effets à long terme...ne seront pas retenus comme éléments importants d'analyse et de décision. -  Les incitations ne doivent pas être financières mais organisationnelles et scientifiques. A savoir * de nouvelles techniques de recherche sur les essais cliniques (cohortes européennes, petits échantillons..) doivent être validées par l’EMA pour favoriser cette recherche auprès des industriels qui pourraient ainsi faire baisser les temps et les investissements des études. Les connaissances déjà acquises (suivis de cohortes, hors AMM, études académiques..) sont des éléments de preuve à inclure pour permettre de simplifier les études et les inclusions. * Il y a déjà de nombreuses incitations pour que les médicaments soient développés pour les enfants (6 mois de brevet supplémentaires pour des médicaments innovants garantissent largement le retour sur investissement). De plus, nous savons depuis longtemps avec des exemples précis que les incitations économiques, de quelques natures qu’elles soient, ont parfois des effets pervers en terme d’inflation des prix. Envisager des contraintes  * Une nouvelle voie pourrait être explorée : créer un label/sigle reconnaissant publiquement la responsabilité sociétale des industriels dans le développement des médicaments pédiatriques et les autorisant à une communication grand public encadrée sur une période donnée. feedback_msg_text: Desde la asociación Hipofam, celebramos los cambios propuestos y la voluntad de mejorar el acceso y el desarrollo de medicamentos dirigidos a los pacientes pediátricos, así cómo las mejoras en el sistema de incentivos para los medicamenteos para enfermedades raras.  A pesar de que la inclusión y el rembolso sean competencia de los estados, deberían de estudiarse medidas que mejoren la equidad en el acceso en toda la UE. Productos ya comercializados que no se consideran medicamentos para el público en general,  pero si lo son para enfermedades raras, cómo por ejemplo los suplementos minerales (potasio, magnesio, etc) en algunos síndormes renales. Pero no todos los estados lo reembolsan. Es un claro ejemplo de inequidad en la UE y se debería de regular para evitar estas diferencias.

feedback_msg_text: En el año 2000 la Unión Europea adoptó un Reglamento sobre Medicamentos Huérfanos que supuso un punto de inflexión al establecer incentivos para la investigación y desarrollo de tratamientos para las enfermedades raras. Así se estimuló el trabajo de los laboratorios en este campo llegando a disponer adía de hoy de 169 fármacos que tratan 90 patologías (5% del total de las enfermedades huérfanas). Se ha logrado un mayor conocimiento de estas enfermedades, se han creado redes de referencia, planes nacionales en estados miembros y se ha favorecido el movimiento asociativo. Podemos afirmar que Europa se ha beneficiado del actual Reglamento sobre medicamentos huérfanos. En todo caso, queda mucho por hacer porque a pesar de estos logros, un 95% de las enfermedades necesitan tratamiento.  La normativa de medicamentos huérfanos y pediátricos debería asegurar la equidad en el acceso a los medicamentos huérfanos en toda la Unión Europea. Hay un aspecto de las propuestas del IIA que nos inquieta especialmente. Cambiar la designación de huérfano de la prevalencia a la incidencia. Las enfermedades con una alta mortalidad pueden dejar de ser consideradas raras y que se deje de incentivar la investigación en ellas.

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the initiative of the European Commission to review the legal frameworks for medicines for children and rare diseases to address their shortcomings.  As identified, it is important to stimulate development of medicines for unmet needs and ensure equal access for patients in all EU countries. We invite the EC to also include affordability and improved transparency in the pharmaceutical sector as end goals of the revision. Herewith we offer our recommendations to lead on the selection of the proposed options proposed and suggest possible additional ones.  LIMITS TO EXCLUSIVITIES: Enforcing intellectual property rights to control knowledge and access can be a key barrier to the progress of research itself, large-scale production of affordable health technologies and equitable access. The use of patents, moreover, encourages pharmaceutical companies to prioritise R&D that responds only to profitable markets rather than unmet medical needs (WHO, Public health, innovation and intellectual property rights). The revision of the legislative frameworks should take into consideration the impact of IP-related exclusivities and monopolies on the accessibility, affordability, and availability of medicines and health technologies. The revised frameworks should opt for alternatives which do not consolidate monopolies, do not deter nor distort competition and reward truly innovative and needed products. A scale back of existing incentives, revision of the eligibility criteria - in particular strengthening of the ROI criteria -, introduction of an effective “withdrawal clause” mechanism must be considered. In addition the revised legislation must prevent - and include mechanisms to address - any possible abuse, linked for instance to common practices as “salami- slicing” and abuses of dominant position and lack of competition.  ADDRESSING REAL UNMET NEEDS: Research priorities should be driven by the public interest and real unmet medical needs, not by profitability or the interests of the private sector. Inclusive and transparent mechanisms to decide in a coordinated and informed manner EU and national R&I priorities should be set up in order to steer both public and private investment in R&D. Moreover, the role of public support - in multiple forms such as grants, tax breaks and market entry rewards to mention few - into the medicines cycle needs to be further acknowledged and taken into account by translating public return consideration into concrete elements within the revision. We would also like to highlight the results of studies that demonstrate that the expansion of patent and market exclusivity protection on medicinal products worldwide has not addressed unmet medical and public health needs (MSF - Lives on the Edge).  TRANSPARENCY: In our opinion transparency must be the underlying principle of every EU or national level action in the pharmaceutical sector. From the share of public contributions and cost of R&D to clinical trials data, pricing and net prices: appropriate measures and mechanisms should be in place to ensure full transparency across the pharmaceutical cycle.  The EU revision must include measures requiring transparency as a condition of obtaining orphan and/or pediatric indication and any supplementary protection.  BUDGET IMPACT: New therapies, including orphan medicines, are increasingly associated with high prices. Limited public health budgets have to cope with growing difficulties to absorb the cost of expensive therapies arriving into the market. These difficulties could lead to questionable choices in terms of access to medicines and public health. Indeed, they could lead to restrictions in access policies, reducing the number of patients entitled to receive certain expensive drugs. The revision of the EU legislative framework should take the increasing burden of high prices on healthcare budgets into consideration and propose measures to limit those detrimental developments and ensure affordability. Organisation: European Alliance for Responsible R&D and Affordable Medicines

feedback_msg_text: FEPORT welcomes the opportunity to provide a feedback on the Commission’s roadmap regarding the White Paper on Foreign subsidies.  FEPORT believes that it is essential to tackle the fundamental regulatory gap in existing EU legislation on competition, trade, public procurement and in EU funding as regards distortions arising from foreign subsidies in the Internal Market, which the White Paper itself recognised.   With respect to the policy options presented in the Inception impact assessment, FEPORT believes that taking legislative action at EU level (Option 2) would be the most effective response.   This approach would promote the long-awaited adaptation of the EU acquis on competition, trade and public procurement, which FEPORT considers to be necessary as the acquis Communautaire should reflect the current situation in the EU Internal Market.  Moreover, Option 2 would require the review and refit of State Aid guidelines to factor-in foreign subsidies when assessing aid intensities, a change that FEPORT has been advocating and asking for since a long time.  Finally, this option would develop new legal instruments complementing the existing EU acquis, such as compulsory notification mechanisms of foreign financial contributions; assessment mechanisms to establish potential distortive effects of foreign subsidies; adequate redressive measures to guarantee a level playing field for all economic operators and the institutional set up for the implementation and enforcement of the mechanisms.   FEPORT believes that indeed there is an enforcement gap relating to the distortive impact of foreign subsidies on the EU’s internal market and that new measures are needed.   Nevertheless, these new measures should be complementary to EU merger control and EU antitrust rules, as well as to EU trade defence instruments, FDI screening mechanisms and WTO Agreements.   Additionally, the European Commission should undertake a thorough review and refit of all EU-Third countries trade agreements to make sure that will take into account the new rules once adopted.  Last but not least, FEPORT believes that there is a need for a more effective response. Europeans must acquire a better capacity to anticipate potential risks from FDI, including a common perspective regarding strategic assets and ecosystems.   FEPORT hopes that the inclusion of the port sector as part of the ecosystem “Mobility-Transport-Automotive” will translate into policies that recognize the strategic nature of ports.  Feedback from: FEPORT (133.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Trade & investment – addressing distortions caused by foreign subsidies

feedback_msg_text: Acknowledging growing concerns about the distortions caused by foreign subsidies within the Internal Market, the initiative undertaken by the Commission to present proposal of regulation in order to address these interventions generally and also in the specific cases of acquisitions and public procurement is highly welcomed. Since the details of proposed solutions have not been presented, it suffices to support this initiative and provide general remarks on the directions for further steps of its development.  Effective functioning of measures addressing distortions caused by foreign subsidies will be enhanced by the implementation of following aspects:  o Consistent and ambitious legislative action;  o Ensuring holistic approach towards multiple distortions caused by foreign interventions, in particular consistent enforcement of current EU legal framework;  o Addressing foreign legislative solutions which might adversely influence competition in the internal market.  European Commission’s White Paper on levelling the playing field as regards foreign subsidies indicated significant regulatory gaps in current EU law system concerning subsidies which are being granted by foreign states. As repeatedly emphasised, foreign subsidies might lead to significant distortion of competition as well as adversely affect the creation of level playing field for all undertakings active on the internal market. Due to very significant risks posed by foreign subsidies it is indispensable to introduce adequate measures which are capable of preventing unwanted interferences in the internal market. The only suitable, effective and proportionate measure to address these threats for functioning of the internal market is to take legislative action at EU level. Both non-regulatory approach and international rule making are not adequate and will very likely fall short of meeting expectations. Therefore the introduction of one or more regulations containing the solutions provided in White Paper will be very welcomed. Introducing legislative measures constitutes the only real impact capable of filling in current regulatory gaps in regard to acquisitions of EU undertakings, public procurement procedure and other market distortions. Initiative: Trade & investment – addressing distortions caused by foreign subsidies

feedback_msg_text: EuropaBio sees the Directive on cross-border healthcare as an important tool to ensure patient access to the best available care. The Directive is particularly relevant for advanced therapies and medicines for rare diseases. Cell and gene therapies require highly specialised physicians and hospitals working in networks of reference centres. For rare diseases with limited patient numbers, it is impractical for each Member State to have a dedicated treatment centre. Well-functioning EU cross-border healthcare legislation can ensure patients have access to specialised treatments and novel therapies when these are not available in their home country. EuropaBio has identified the following challenges for accessing care abroad and recommendations for improvement: -Approval timelines for cross-border treatment are sometimes very long; they should be capped. -In many countries, the approval process is opaque with no possibility to appeal denials. The process should be more transparent and open to patient representatives. -Where a Member State does not have a treatment centre, cross-border treatment of rare diseases should get a defined and accelerated pathway for approval. Pan-EU funding would help, or accelerated reimbursement once a rare disease therapy is available in enough Member States. -Many hospitals discriminate against cross-border patients with mark-ups on the fees charged to local patients. This practice should be banned. -Hospitals often need to wait months or years for reimbursement and face significant budget impact when not paid. Such disincentives for treating cross-border patients should be eliminated and mechanisms to allow innovative payment models to function across borders implemented. -Healthcare providers often do not know how to request reimbursement for cross-border treatments and ask therapy developers for support. Some Member States refuse reimbursement for treatments not available domestically. Better and practical information should reach all stakeholders (HCPs, patients, companies, social security entities) to secure the best treatment. -Difficulties in cross-border participation to clinical trials despite high need remain barriers to innovation. Reliable and accessible information is needed, e.g. through multi-stakeholder, multi-national recommendations with information about existing options and best practices. Establishing Europe-wide patient registries to facilitate long-term patient follow-up would help. -Due to the upfront payments imposed by the Directive, cross-border treatment with advanced therapies appears possible only through the ‘S2 route’. Patients cannot bear the total costs of their treatment and subsequently seek reimbursement. Processing timelines for obtaining prior authorisation using the ‘S2 Form’ vary greatly. Alignment across the EU is needed. -Difficulties in approving advanced therapy applications if not reimbursed in the home country despite being reimbursed in the country of treatment should be addressed. Special access funds should be allocated to countries with restricted budgets. EU guidelines on which advanced treatments should be approved to ensure harmonised access across EU would be helpful, with clarification on process for prior authorisation, clear timelines for decision making and reimbursement. The EU Pharmaceutical Strategy for Europe has identified unequal access to care as one of the most significant healthcare challenges for the EU. EuropaBio believes that proper implementation of the EU Cross-border Healthcare Directive would go a long way to address this problem.   The COVID-19 crisis has shown that Member States can work together to provide efficient patient care across borders. The Commission stimulated cross-border treatment of Covid-19 patients through issuing facilitating guidelines in 2020. If the same spirit of collaboration were applied to cross-border healthcare in general, it would help ensure all EU patients have equal access to to novel treatments
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: Childhood Cancer International - Europe (CCI-E) welcomes the initiative to evaluate the functioning of the EU Cross-Border Healthcare Directive (CBHD).  Cross-border collaboration is crucial to share expertise on rare and complex diseases and ensure best possible standard care to youngest cancer patients, and there originating from CBHD - the European Reference Network on Paediatric Cancers (ERN PaedCan) holds great potential.  CCI-E involvement in ERN PaedCan is three-fold. First, it had a prior longstanding relationship with the coordinating institute and other centres of the network through SIOP Europe community and EU projects. Second, the head of CCI-E Committee is directly represented in the Oversight Committee of ERN PaedCan and thus is integrated in the decision-making structure of the network. Third, CCI-E has four committee members elected to ERN PaedCan ePAG, a participative patient structure affiliated with ERNs.  CCI-E shares recommendation on ensuring the sustainability of ERN model as a clear priority. Another overarching aspect of treatment and care delivery in a cross-border setting is the availability of information on the protocol, surrounding environment and follow-up in a language that the parent/patient can understand. Being underserved area that demands attention.   In this framework, recommendations from the European paediatric cancers patient representatives on improving the policy environment for cross-border healthcare are summarised below.  • Support the eradication of inequalities in paediatric cancer outcomes. At present, childhood cancer survival is estimated to be approximately 20% lower in countries with LHEAR than elsewhere in Europe. ERN PaedCan emphasizes movement of expertise, as well as patients when needed, based on disease-specific European roadmaps. Full or affiliated ERN PaedCan membership of at least one centre in each EU country and twinning activities with centres in LHEAR countries should be encouraged and appropriately supported by EU and MSs.  • Support patient organisations acting as PASOs and European level facilitators. Within ERN PaedCan, PASOs subnetwork is being built by CCI-E. National contact points support local families and share information about ERN PaedCan. These points are linked with CCI-E and from there on to ERN PaedCan centre. Mapping, training and coordination of patient organisations at all levels are critical to ensure that patients can effectively access the European network. Building cooperation with parent organisations in LHEAR countries is also important. These activities performed by CCI-E and parent organisations at all levels require appropriate resource allocation to be able to fully benefit from ERN model.  • Reimbursement of cross-border healthcare including early clinical trials and related travel and accommodation for children and their families. ERN PaedCan prioritizes mechanisms to move information and knowledge rather than patients. But as cross-border travel might be required to receive highly specialized care appropriate reimbursement is needed for parents and their child. Exchanges between MSs are needed to streamline current rules for cross-border healthcare reimbursement and their implementation, to foster reimbursement predictability, avoid unnecessary burden on families and ensure access to life-saving clinical trials.  • Development and implementation of long-term follow-up facilities for survivors of childhood cancers. ERN PaedCan calls for European long-term quality of care models for cancer survivors across MSs including: transition from paediatric to adult care settings; appropriate surveillance of late effects; empowering survivors with intel about future risks and available care settings and guidelines. Development of further surveillance and care organisation guidelines for childhood cancer survivors requires sustained funding and Survivorship Passport model deserves inclusion in national and cross-border programmes.
Organisation: Childhood Cancer International - Europe (CCI Europe, CCI-E)
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: Participation in a clinical trial is an important element of healthcare, especially for patients with life-threatening and/or rare diseases for whom a medicinal product under investigation might be the only therapeutic option. Directive 2011/24/EU on cross-border access to healthcare does not foresee for European patients the option of participation in a clinical trial organised in another member state. Especially clinical trials with very innovative, complex new treatment options are often organised in a limited number of hospitals (sites) in a limited number of countries, most frequently in well-equipped Western European hospitals.  Trial participation and investigated treatments are paid by the trial sponsor and free of charge for patients. But travel to the site to check the patient’s eligibility for the trial, potentially the travel for extra visits to the site, the costs for a certain type of baseline therapy as pre-requisite for trial eligibility, or the costs of long-term follow-on treatment with a medicine that is not reimbursed in the patient’s home country are not covered by the trial budget. They create a big hurdle for patients who have no other option than participating in this trial cross-border. In addition, there is lack of clarity concerning rights and obligations of the stakeholders involved: the patients, the trial investigators/hospitals, the trial sponsor, and the national healthcare insurer. There are a few bilateral agreements between a few neighbouring countries or cross-border hospitals and a few member states define the reimbursement conditions for cross-border trial participation in their legislation, but these are exceptions. Thus, there is currently in the EU a lack of fair access to innovative treatments for those patients who are most in need.    Initiated by the EFPIA Oncology Platform and supported by an unrestricted grant, EFGCP (European Forum for Good Clinical Practice) convened a research group with EORTC, KU Leuven and Patvocates to investigate the current situation of cross-border access to clinical trials. The study consisted of over 40 semi-structured interviews with different stakeholders and a pan-European multi-stakeholder survey aiming at identifying needs and hurdles for patients, investigators and trial sponsors for cross-border trial participation and at detecting best practice examples. The results are presented in the attached publication. Researchers from organisations that collaborated in the above-mentioned study (EFGCP, Patvocates, KU Leuven, and MSD), recommend to consider improving the options for cross-border access to clinical trials within the review process of Directive 2011/24/EU to strengthen fair and barrier-free access to innovative treatment options for patients in need. Our study revealed that the availability of an EU guideline on cross-border access to clinical trials for patients and the other above-named stakeholders with best practice examples, an amendment to Directive 2011/24/EU and a legal provision for an extension of the remit of the ERNs (facilitating logistics, patient consent, connecting healthcare teams of both countries) could provide options to improve the conditions for concerned patients and for patients at large due to faster recruitment in clinical trials and thus faster access to new, authorised treatments. Organisation: European Forum for Good Clinical Practice (EFGCP)
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: Κάθε παιδιατρικός καρκίνος ανήκει στους Σπάνιους Καρκίνους αλλά όλοι μαζί οι παιδιατρικοί καρκίνοι αντιπροσωπεύουν την κύρια αιτία θανάτου των παιδιών και συμβάλλουν σημαντικά στη νοσηρότητα των επιζώντων στην Ευρώπη. Οι διαφορές στην πρόσβαση στην καλύτερη δυνατή διάγνωση,  θεραπεία, καινοτομία και έρευνα οδηγούν σε εκτιμώμενη διαφορά 20% στην επιβίωση σε ολόκληρη την Ευρώπη.  Απαιτείται διασυνοριακή συνεργασία για την υγειονομική περίθαλψη, για την ανταλλαγή εξειδικευμένης επιστημονικής γνώσης σε σπάνιες και πολύπλοκες περιπτώσεις και για την εξασφάλιση της καλύτερης δυνατής  φροντίδας σε όλα τα παιδιά και τους εφήβους με καρκίνο, ανεξάρτητα από το πού ζουν στην ΕΕ. Τα Ευρωπαϊκά Δίκτυα Αναφοράς για τους Παιδιατρικούς Καρκίνους  (ERN PaedCan) συνδέουν εξειδικευμένους παρόχους υγειονομικής περίθαλψης σε όλη την Ευρώπη για να μειώσουν τις ανισότητες στην επιβίωση των παιδιών.   Τα ERN PaedCan δίνουν ιδιαίτερη έμφαση στην ανταλλαγή εμπειρογνωμοσύνης με τα visual tumor boards μειώνοντας τα ταξίδια των οικογενειών για την καλύτερη δυνατή διάγνωση και θεραπεία. Διευκολύνουν ακόμη ,την «αδελφοποίηση»  μεταξύ των νοσοκομείων για την αύξηση των προτύπων περίθαλψης σε όλη την Ευρώπη και τη συνεργασία με την SIOP-E για την παραγωγή ενημερωμένων οδηγιών κλινικής πρακτικής για όλους τους παιδιατρικούς καρκίνους. Σε αυτό το πλαίσιο, οι συστάσεις μας, που ευθυγραμμίζονται με τις συστάσεις της SIOPE για τη βελτίωση του περιβάλλοντος πολιτικής για τη διασυνοριακή υγειονομική περίθαλψη συνοψίζονται παρακάτω.  • Πρέπει να ενθαρρυνθεί η καλύτερη ενσωμάτωση και η επίσημη αναγνώριση του ERN PaedCan από τα εθνικά συστήματα υγειονομικής περίθαλψης.  • Απαιτούνται επειγόντως λύσεις για να διασφαλιστεί η απρόσκοπτη πρόσβαση σε πληροφορίες σχετικά με τη διασυνοριακή επιστροφή υγειονομικής περίθαλψης και την αποτελεσματική εφαρμογή της για παιδιατρικούς ασθενείς.  • Οι τρέχοντες κανόνες διασυνοριακής επιστροφής υγειονομικής περίθαλψης θα πρέπει να προβλέπουν τις ανάγκες του παιδιού να συνοδεύονται από μέλη της οικογένειας ή φροντιστές.  • Οι τρέχοντες κανόνες διασυνοριακής αποζημίωσης υγειονομικής περίθαλψης θα πρέπει να προσαρμοστούν στις ανάγκες μιας εικονικής διασυνοριακής περίθαλψης βασισμένης στην ηλεκτρονική υγεία, όπως τροποποιώντας τους τρέχοντες μηχανισμούς για την αντιστάθμιση επίσης του εικονικού χρόνου φροντίδας που παρέχεται από εμπειρογνώμονες μέσω τηλε-διαβουλεύσεων.   • Η αποζημίωση διασυνοριακής υγειονομικής περίθαλψης πρέπει να καλύπτει τη συμμετοχή σε κλινικές δοκιμές πρώιμης φάσης για παιδιά με υποτροπιάζουσες ή πυρίμαχες μη θεραπευτικές κακοήθειες.  • Για τους ασθενείς, η παρούσα οδηγία σημαίνει ενδυνάμωση: μεγαλύτερη επιλογή υγειονομικής περίθαλψης, περισσότερες πληροφορίες, ευκολότερη αναγνώριση συνταγογραφιών διασυνοριακά.  Η οδηγία είναι επίσης καλά νέα για τα ευρωπαϊκά συστήματα υγείας, βελτιώνοντας τη συνεργασία μεταξύ των κρατών μελών σε διαλειτουργικά εργαλεία ηλεκτρονικής υγείας, τη χρήση της αξιολόγησης της τεχνολογίας υγείας και τη συγκέντρωση σπάνιων εμπειρογνωμόνων.  • Η πρόσβαση στις καινοτόμες θεραπείες και συμμετοχή σε κλινικές δοκιμές να αποτελέσουν μέρος της διασυνοριακής υγειονομικής περίθαλψης. • Τα κέντρα αναφοράς θα πρέπει να διευκολύνουν τις οικογένειες των ασθενών στην συμπλήρωση του φακέλου που απαιτείται.
