feedback_msg_text: At the Anticancer Fund, we have a free personalised information service, called “My Cancer navigator”. Through our interaction with patients from all over the world, we are confronted with the still existing barriers regarding cross border access to health care.  Patients should get easy accessible information on cross border health care, especially on the services they are entitled to. Health care providers are often also unaware of all options and will not encourage patients to explore cross border health care.  Lack of transparency and good information is not only a problem at the European level but also at the national level. NCPs should provide easy to access and understandable information regarding cross border health care, ensuring patients’ rights are conveyed to the general public. Unfortunately, there is large variability on the quantity and quality of information that NCPs are providing. Also, on a national level, despite the European initiative on cross border health care, national reimbursement limitations will often still exclude patients from other countries. Another problem with the Cross Border Health Care Directive is the process of prior authorization, which, if not organised smoothly, can be an obstacle for many patients.  Most countries explicitly exclude clinical trials from their programs. This should be covered in larger detail. Study specific treatments and procedures are covered by the sponsor of a trial, nevertheless standard procedures are often paid by the healthcare system. These cost should be reimbursed for all patients. Also reimbursement for travel and accommodation should be envisaged.    The financial burden remains an important barrier. To pay upfront, or “unreasonable time” for reimbursement (the directive mentions reasonable time but in practice this is not the case), places an unacceptable burden on many patients and their families. Also, treatment abroad often requires a deposit which again is an additional barrier for patients.   Moreover, if a European HTA responsible for common evaluation of added therapeutic value of  approved drugs would be installed it would facilitate cross-border access and might put pressure on MS towards equal access by reimbursement of treatments abroad.      Finally, the directive has potential to encourage better European cooperation by ensuring sufficient development of the European Reference Networks.
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: bluebird bio response to the EC Evaluation / Fitness check Roadmap - Patient Rights in Cross-border Healthcare   Cross-border healthcare is critical to enable access to Advanced Therapy Medicinal Products (ATMPs) in the EU and meet patient needs  bluebird bio is a biotech company entirely dedicated to the development of gene therapies for severe genetic and rare diseases by addressing the underlying genetic cause of disease. We are working to provide the best possible access to gene therapy treatments across the EU for patients with few or no alternative options.   Gene therapies and other ATMPs require specialist patient treatment processes. Typically, they cannot be administered in an average hospital setting. Instead, highly specialised and accredited treatment centres are needed, staffed by specialist doctors and nurses who need dedicated training. The disease expertise and specialist skills that are required may not be widely available in every European country due to, for example, the rarity of the disease.  We firmly believe therefore that cross-border healthcare in the EU is a critical part of patient access to gene therapies and ATMPs. Currently launching its first gene therapy in the EU whilst preparing for the marketing authorisation of its second, bluebird bio is pleased to share its views on the EU’s framework for cross-border healthcare.   Whilst the evaluation will assess the performance of Directive 2011/24//EU on patients rights in cross-border healthcare including its interactions with Regulation 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems, we strongly encourage the European Commission to examine the current and future needs of patients in cross-border healthcare with both pathways in mind. This is particularly critical for patients with a severe genetic and (ultra) rare disease, who need access to life changing and potentially curative treatments, regardless of their Member State of origin.  As highlighted in a recent report by the RARE IMPACT group chaired by EURORDIS , the use and scalability of both the Directive and Regulation for planned ATMP treatment abroad remains very uncertain. bluebird bio therefore welcomes the forthcoming evaluation and calls upon the Commission to enable better coordinated and optimised access for cross border ATMP treatment in the EU, irrespective of a patient’s native location.   For bluebird bio's full response to the consultation, we would like to refer you to the attached document. Feedback from: bluebird bio (148.2 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: The European Reference Network (ERN) ITHACA / Congenital Malformations and Rare Intellectual Disability has highly contributed to cross-border Rare Intellectual Disability associations from different countries. The problem is, however, for our Rare Disease patients association, MED13L syndrome association, we have to face different levels of access to health services . In short, some families are unequal face to access to a diagnosis, a  treatment or national reimbursement.  As financial support is regional competency, the need should be alignment  between EU health and national social security bodies, and also national/ regional finacial centers. Poorer patients cannot afford the extra associated costs of therapies like makaton, ergotherapy...
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: This submission reflects our experiences with access to cross-border healthcare within the Melanoma Patient Network Europe as a European Cancer Patient Community, notably access to a) drugs b) medical devices/ procedures c) clinical trials/ CU/ EAP and d) particular challenges for patients with rare Melanomas.  Access to drugs: Since 2011, the approval of 10 new therapies has dramatically improved the survival in advanced Melanoma from 5% at 5 years to a situation where about half of all patients survive long-term. The high price of the products and new modes of actions with unexpected patterns of response with which HTAs struggled led to a high variability in the introduction of these products between countries, with an additional delay for CEE. Access to medical devices and procedures: Uveal Melanoma predominantly metastasises to the liver, this is the main driver of mortality. Liver-directed treatments (involving medical devices) are not consistently available across Europe, patients pay privately for cross-border access. Clinical trials and Compassionate Usage: Most countries explicitly exclude clinical trials from their S2 programs. Even those who do offer the possibility (some of the Nordics) have in our experience established administrative hurdles to effectively impede access, such as refusing a trial ‘for lack of evidence’. Due to the common mixed financing model, with the trial sponsor paying for the experimental treatment and all additional procedures and the healthcare system paying the standard procedures, a patient will be liable to pay for the latter, even if these procedures were reimbursed in his home country, in addition to costs for travel and accommodation abroad as most trials only cover limited travel costs. As Compassionate Usage and Early Access Programs are:  in strange contrast to a common market authorisation- not centrally regulated, patients are normally unable to access these cross-border, increasing the disparities in access to novel therapies.  Particular challenges for rare cancers: ERNs currently do not show geographic representativeness and resulting in an overall limited access for EU patients. Despite their existence, accessing their services for patients outside their system is difficult to impossible. Rare and ultra-rare conditions, such as spitzoid Melanoma, where already the expertise for a correct diagnosis is rare, would benefit from a European-wide approach.   In our experience, it is only educated and proactive patients with sufficient financial means who are able to access healthcare abroad. Treating oncologists are often unaware of options abroad and actively discourage patients from exploring these. Administrative procedures for pre-planned healthcare are in our experience designed to prevent access as time lines are incompatible with a progressing cancer or require approval/ recommendations by those very physicians whose opinion a patient wants to validate abroad or whose local budgets will be impacted by the decision. Clinical trials represent treatment options for patients who have exhausted all available lines of treatments or for those where no effective standard of care exists, such as most rare Melanomas. Each clinical trial is only ever available in a certain number of countries, in particular if the cancer is rare, making cross-border access to clinical trials particularly important for those patients out off options.    Treatment abroad often requires a considerable upfront deposit that can already be prohibitive for some patients. Only patients who are persistent enough to take on the often deliberately cumbersome administrative procedures have a chance of claiming those costs back from their home country’s insurance, often many months later (and should they still be alive). Cross-border health as it currently stands has no effect on inequality in access to drugs and limited effect on access to medical devices.   To note: we are a network of volunteers, not employees.
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: The current system does not work - if you need access to experimental treatments in other countries because of limited clinical trial centres (often the case in Rare Disease) you are excluded by national reimbursement limitations/exclusions and restrictions that exclude all but national patients.  If you need to access a treatment that is not available because there is no approval for an innovative treatment in your own country or you need it off label for a related indication, national health rules prevent access. If you can travel (and fulfil the informed consent regulations in the country, not always easy !) the ancillary costs (travel, accommodation, companion diagnostics etc) are too burdensome. As health is national competency, there needs first to be agreements/alignment  between EU health and social security bodies, which there currently is not and then there needs to be intelligent reciprocal systems for Rare Disease patients. Management of side effects back in home countries without experience of the treatment means there needs to be efficient mentoring and expert information channels between countries that prescribe and those that dont. Poorer countries and poorer patients cannot afford the extra associated costs EVEN if the investigator pays for trial products - a solution needs to be found to mitigate this.
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: Europäisches Recht lässt grundsätzlich die Kostenerstattung durch die nationale Krankenkasse für im EU-Ausland erworbene ambulante Gesundheitsleistungen zu. Dabei kommt es regelmäßig zu Umgehungstatbeständen der nationalen Qualitätsstandards. Denn die Rückerstattungen an den Versicherten richten sich nach den jeweiligen nationalen Erstattungssätzen, die im jeweiligen EU-Mitgliedsland vergleichbar bezahlt werden. Dieser Vergleich ist aber regelmäßig nicht möglich, da die Anforderungen an die Leistungserbringer in den Mitgliedsstaaten höchst unterschiedlich sind. Lässt sich also ein EU-Bürger in einem anderen EU-Mitgliedsstaat versorgen und sich die Kosten dafür von seiner Krankenkassen nach seinen nationalen Erstattungssätzen zurückzahlen, so kann das zu Inländer- Diskriminierung der nationalen Leistungserbringer führen. Denn diese müssten für die gleichen Erstattungssätze deutlich mehr gesetzliche Anforderungen erfüllen. Gleichzeitig besteht das deutliche Risiko, dass dem Versicherten für schlechtere Qualität zu viel Geld erstattet wird.  Eine Lösung kann sich nur dort finden, wo nur vergleichbare Leistungen zwischen den EU-Mitgliedsländern erstattungsfähig sind. Erhält der EU-Bürger nämlich eine Schlechtleistung in einem anderen EU-Mitgliedsland, so muss die nationale Solidargemeinschaft für die Rehabilitation aufkommen.
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: The biggest problem of the Cross Border Health Care Directive in the point of view of patients with rare diseases is the requirement of prior authorisation and the process of clinical evaluation. For patients affected by rare diseases, the actual process of prior authorization may be an obstacle. Such authorization usually involves a clinical evaluation by a doctor(s) designated by national authorities, who often lacks the necessary expertise on the specific rare disease.
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: La asistencia sanitaria transfronteriza es un derecho fundamental que debe de tener todo ciudadano de la UE. Ya que este debe de tener derecho de acceso a la asistencia sanitaria en cualquier Estado Miembro de la UE, además de que su país de origen le reembolse la asistencia sanitaria en el extranjero. Existen actualmente, muchos países que están poniendo obstáculos para poder reembolsar a los pacientes la asistencia sanitaria en el extranjero.  Es por este motivo, por el cual en Europa se necesita seguir una serie de protocolos sobre la prestación de atención médica completa en el país que ha seleccionado el paciente, además, se deben de enfatizar que actualmente en muchos países europeos existe una lista de espera de más de dos años, esto hace que el acceso a la atención médica no esté disponible para muchos pacientes y por este motivo, muchos ciudadanos acabaron demandando en los Tribunales a sus países.  La asistencia transfrinteriza debería de garantizar que cada paciente pueda elegir cualquier clínica europea para el diagnóstico y el tratamiento, además de que la Directiva de la Comisión Europea deberá de prohibir las restricciones del seguro médico nacional, ya que ahora existe una situación en la que algunos países han restringido los tratamiento de otros países de la UE o se necesita de una aprobación especial, lo que hace que el paciente pierda tiempo. Es por este motivo, por el cual la Comisión no debe de permitir este procedimiento.  La asistencia sanitaria transfronteriza debe ser única sin discriminación alguna por parte de los países miembros de la UE.  Carolina García  Public Affairs Relations Manager European Poditry LLP  www.europeanpodiatry.org cgarcia@europeanpodiatry.org Feedback from: European Podiatry LLP (1.8 MB - PDF - 15 pages) Download
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: Cross-border healthcare is a fundamental right for all citizens. Unfortunately, EU 24/2011 Directive is almost unknown among the European population.  Citizens who are aware of the Directive are a small percentage. If you look at the recently published report of the European Commission on 2018 data, the total of all European citizens who have requested information from their NCPs is 95,565 requests for information.  Out of a total of 446 million inhabitants, it appears that 0.02% of Europeans have contacted NCPs!  Not only that, the total requests for authorization for treatment with cross-border healthcare in all EU countries, both those accepted and those subsequently rejected, were only 7,279. Here the percentage drops to 0.002% of all citizens.  This happens because the Directive is unknown to most people, and those who are aware of it are often discouraged by the bureaucracy of public offices for authorization and reimbursement applications.  In our personal experience with NCPs, having written to all of them to make a survey on prices remboursement in all EU countries, we have not received much information. On 30 requests sent by mail, after one week we received: only 3 NCPs replied with prices info, others replied saying that they were not authorized to give this info, others asking us to ask the insurance companies the question. Someone just didn't reply to our email.   This is not appropriate and one question raises: do many countries try to obstacle to provide information and reimbursement to the patients? We have experienced a lot of obstacles/barriers, from the lack of information among the population, to a complicated system of prior authorization (in Italy) with little or denied reimbursements, after having spent time in documents and burocracies.
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: ERFARING MED DIREKTIVET  NETKU’s synspunkter på og foreløbige erfaringer med direktivet blev allerede i juni 2015 fremsendt til EPF, notatet er vedlagt her som bilag.  Selv om der siden er forløbet over 5 år finder vi stadig i bestyrelsen for NETKU at synspunkterne er aktuelle: - Styrelsen for Patientsikkerhed kunne oplyse bedre og bredere om mulighederne for behandlinger i udlandet, således at flere danske patienter fik kendskab til mulighederne for behandling i udlandet. - Danmark har valgt en restriktiv forhåndsgodkendelse – som vi gerne ser fjernet – i det den forsinker og besværliggør patienters behandling i udlandet. - Patienter skal selv lægge ud for betalingerne, og der er ingen dækning af rejseudgifter, som f.eks. i Sverige, og dette øger den sociale ulighed.  Når vi skal vurdere hvor mange og hvem, der gør brug af direktivet har vi stadig et mangelfuldt datagrundlag. Vi har nogle få informationer fra 2014, men har endnu ikke tal for tiden herefter. Der foregår i øjeblikket imidlertid en dataindsamling, hvor Kræftens Bekæmpelse forestår og koordinerer data fra de 5 regioner, og den venter vi os meget af i NETKU’s bestyrelse. Vores tal vedrørende 2014 er: - Ca. 40000 ansøgninger på baggrund af direktivet - Ca. 31000 udbetalinger, hvor 98% vedrører tandbehandlinger - 61 forhåndsansøgninger, hvoraf 5 er imødekommet. Det vides ikke om nogle af tallene vedrører kræftbehandlinger.  Med hensyn til direktivets anvendelse inden for kræftbehandling i udlandet må vi konkludere, at i 2014 bliver det stort set ikke anvendt og virker derfor i nuværende form uden relevans for kræftbehandlingen af danske patienter. Og det hænger blandt andet sammen med, at patienter der tager til udlandet typisk ønsker og behandles med en anden behandling end den, man kan få i Danmark, og dermed bliver denne behandling ikke vurderet som samme eller lignende behandling som i Danmark. Vi har via vores medlemskreds kendskab til enkeltsager, hvor der er givet afslag med netop denne begrundelse, selv om det i så komplicerede sager som kræftbehandling som regel vil kunne diskuteres, hvorvidt behandlingen er ”lignende”. Her er der en gråzone i direktivet og den danske vejledning hertil, hvor myndighederne opleves restriktive, og hvor der er behov for større klarhed efter vores opfattelse, og justeringer af den restriktive danske fortolkning. Et eksempel på typisk behandling, der ikke er standardbehandling i Danmark men i Tyskland er kræftbehandling i leveren med regional kemo-embolisering. Siden 2009 har der i Danmark været udført forsøgsbehandlinger i særlige protokoller, som patienter skal opfylde for at være med, men det er ikke nok til at få refunderet udgifter via direktivet. For patienter virker det ulogisk, det er jo især derfor man tager til udlandet, fordi man ikke kan få behandlingen i Danmark. Et andet eksempler er pallierende behandling med såkaldt gammaknife (en særlig form for stereotaktisk strålebehandling), som gives i bl.a. Uppsala til patienter med mindre hjernemetastaser. Behandlingen er mere skånsom end den helhjernebestråling, som tilbydes i Danmark, og søges derfor af danske patienter. Der er dog stadig, teknisk set, ligheder i forhold til den danske behandling, så også her virker det ulogisk, at danske patienter får afslag, når de søger refusion efter Direktivet.   SYNSPUNKT PÅ SAMARBEJDET OM SJÆLDNE SYGDOMME OG REFERENCENETVÆRK.  Det er med stor glæde, at vi nu kan læse om et voksende samarbejde mellem danske og udenlandske læger og mellem sundhedsmyndighederne i EU, herunder etableringen af europæiske referencenetværk samt en øget fokusering på samarbejde om sjældne sygdomme. I Danmark er vi i alt kun ca. 5,8 millioner indbyggere, og det er vigtigt, at man også for sjældne sygdomme kan få opbygget og vedligeholdt en høj lægelig kompetence og anskaffe kostkostbart udstyr. Ved at samarbejde i EU kan der etableres en kritisk masse af patienter, således at den bedste behandling bliver muliggjort for patienterne. Feedback from: NETKU (502.3 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Cross-border healthcare – evaluation of patients’ rights

feedback_msg_text: I diritti delle persone bisognose di cure dovrebbero prescindere da ogni altro stato giuridico della persona come ad esempio lo stato di detenzione in altra nazione. Anche in questo caso dovrebbe essere considerato lo standard migliore delle cure e il rimborso da parte della nazione di residenza su quella di domicilio temporaneo (carcere). Il problema non è di piccole dimensioni in quanto ad es. in Italia più del 30% delle persone detenuto sono di orgine non italiana e una buona parte comunitari. Su 53.364 detenuti adulti gli stranieri erano 17.344 (dati Ministero della Giustizia al 31 dicembre 2021).
Organisation: Coordinamento Nazionale Operatori per la Salute nelle Carceri Italiane (Co.N.O.S.C.I.)

feedback_msg_text: The Vereniging Innovatieve Geneesmiddelen (VIG) is positive towards the proposal of the European Commission to establish a European Health Data Space (EHDS). This proposal enables the EU to better grasp the potential of health data for research and innovation on new preventive strategies, as well as on diagnosis and treatment of diseases to improve health outcomes. The pharmaceutical sector welcomes the establishment of a legislative framework to support the exchange and use of health data and to promote harmonization of European digital standards. Also, R&D and innovation in the health ecosystem could improve with this proposal. Furthermore, it will support outcomes-based healthcare by measuring and enable improving the health outcomes for patients.  This framework should provide guidance on how stakeholders can gain access to health data and how they can make use of this data. The EHDS should promote data sharing through harmonization of rules and removing barriers. Also, the process to grant and maintain access to this EHDS needs to be made clear.  The VIG supports the proposal to establish competent bodies which can act as a gateway to national data resources. These national authorities should be harmonized at European level to prevent duplication at national level and avoid complexity. Furthermore, it is important that consent forms will also permit individuals to grant consent to broad use of their (anonymized) data.  Within the GDPR there exists special regulations for scientific research to stimulate innovation. Currently, interpretations are varying, therefore we propose to renew the efforts to clarify and harmonise these rules. Furthermore, we agree that it is necessary to review the ability of people to exercise their right to data portability. We need to demonstrate how health data is valuable for research to improve the understanding and trust in their use. To realise this, the pharmaceutical sector wants to work with the European Commission and other institutions to jointly develop a code of conduct for our sector. This can further support harmonisation and ensure equal rights of people across Member States and Europe as a whole and reduce the complexity of cross-border collaborations. Also, the users of the EHDS should be enthused to develop frameworks for self-regulation for using data and establishing safeguards to prevent any harm to subjects.  A European cloud is indispensable to ensure using and analysing varying sources for data. To realise this, it is important to invest in an interoperable infrastructure and clear governance and financing. This is a prerequisite to prevent data to be stored in a single location and format but make it available through a network. Existing health data networks can be scaled up and connected across the European Union through a health data space. To overcome differences stemming from the use of various sources and enabling the creation of meaningful insight, while ensuring sufficient data protection it is necessary to create standardised outcomes and increase the use of common models and quality standards for data.  Strengthening the European coordination and revising the scope and mandate of the eHealth Network is something the VIG welcomes. In particular through the development of guidance for mandatory provisions. We support investing in a mechanism for coordination to ensure the output realises a maximum result. Furthermore, the VIG would like mandatory and transparent standards be set by European bodies for specific areas.  In conclusion, the VIG supports the proposal of the European Commission to establish a European Health Data Space. It can be supportive of the use of cross-border health data. However, it is necessary to develop a European framework and infrastructure to avoid complexity and build a European cloud.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: The following comments are issued by the members of the reasearch Project BioDat (http://biodat.proyectoscebes.es/): The impulse of a strategy to create an EHDS, in the frame of the European strategy for data, must be regarded as very positive, given the particular characteristics of the health sector and the sensitive character of the information handled in its context.  In the reference document, many of the current issues arising from access and exchange of health data are correctly identified. Among other:   - An insufficient health data exchange, which negatively impacts on the quality of healthcare services (primary use of health data). This does not only occur upon cross-border exchanges between Member States, but also within the borders of some countries themselves, as is the case of Spain, where the provision of health service is decentralised among its different regions. - Exercising access and control over their own health data is many times difficult for the citizens. Even in countries where the implementation of electronic health records is notable, as occurs in Spain (https://www.mscbs.gob.es/profesionales/hcdsns/contenidoDoc/Inf_sit_HCDSNS_octubre_2020.pdf), the possibility to access, control, and, over all, being able to transfer this data among different sanitary providers is limited.  - The lack of digital interoperability between healthcare services (and, in the case of Spain, also between the different regions of the country) is also a reality.  Voluntary initiatives promoted by the EU in the context of e-Health haven’t been effective enough in order to resolve these problems. Thus, and preserving the competencies of Member States, a specific legal framework (including mandatory provisions) is needed. Some ideas should be taken into consideration: - The re-use of public data is a requirement of good governance as much as an ethical requirement in terms of both common good and circular and efficient management of health data. Therefore, the strategy must include a specific management model of data re-use in the health system context, which must specify aspects such as which dates are accessible, or purposes that legitimate re-use of health data. We share some conclusions in this sense issued by the EDPS (in its Preliminary Opinion 8/2020, nº 32-34).  In this context, public structures of governance should be impulsed (be it for research, or for healthcare). Public authorities must adopt a leading position in the process of health data re-use, especially in countries like Spain. Firstly, because they are the main generators of health data. Secondly, because they will be able to guide re-use to the public interest. And thirdly, because they have the legitimacy needed to establish the criteria for the participation of private actors. To achieve this, we can refer some of the tools incorporated in the proposed Regulation on data governance, such as, among others the possibility to only allow the re-use of pre-processed data (aims to anonymize or pseudonymise personal data). - It is also necessary to put attention on the topic of secondary use of health data. Current legislative fragmentation must be resolved through the clarification (in accordance with GDPR) of concepts such as further processing compatible with scientific research purpose, among others.  - The previous actions must be paired with a legal reinforcement of both the right of access (in electronic format) and a real data portability (as of today, highly limited), and by assuring its exercise is effective in front of public health providers (when the treatment is legitimated upon a basis other than consent). Current provisions, such as article 20 GDPR, are clearly insufficient on this regard. - Another important aspect to be taking into account is the one highlighted by the EDPS in its Preliminary Opinion 8/2020, nº 29. However, these committees should receive specific training/composition to tackle complex projects based on the massive use of data Feedback from: Proyecto de Investigación BioDat (118.9 KB - PDF - 7 pages) Download
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: IDF Europe is a pan-European not-for-profit organisation, representing people living with diabetes and healthcare professionals in 70 associations across 44 countries in Europe. Diabetes is an incurable and complex disease, which currently affects more than 33 million people across the European Union. The COVID-19 pandemic has brought into sharp relief the different levels of digitalisation and preparedness to increased digitalisation of healthcare systems across different EU Member States, and the substantial inequalities in health outcomes within and between Member States this brings. It has also highlighted the need for more responsive, advanced and innovative healthcare systems and the lack of standardised data collection and data sharing across Member States. This lack of comparable data hampers the development of a collective and coordinated response across the Union in a time of crisis; in non-crisis times, it represents a major barrier to the development of more resilient health systems and to the implementation of effective policies to tackle non-communicable diseases.  Harmonised, Europe-wide data frameworks, which enable data to be translated into policy actions, have the potential to bring about significant improvements in the prevention, management and care of diabetes and other non-communicable diseases and a reduction in health inequalities. For this to be effective, data needs to be collected across the Union around a commonly-agreed set of indicators, including patient-reported outcome and experience measures. These are essential to support a move towards more patient-centred, value-based healthcare systems, which would allow for improved resource allocation, faster and easier identification of high value interventions and reduced expenditure, and ultimately improved health outcomes and well-being for healthcare system users. IDF Europe calls for this to be taken into account in any European Health Data Space framework.  IDF Europe welcomes the ambition to expressed in the European Health Data Space of leveraging the potential of “digital health to provide high-quality healthcare and reduce inequalities”. We support the three stated objectives, and in particular Objective 1, a - establishing an appropriate legal and governance framework to cover the access to and exchange of health data for healthcare provision, research, policy-making and regulatory activities. To support this, we urge the Commission to ensure that in-depth engagement with people living with diabetes and other conditions is fully integrated in the design of any future solutions. Reducing inequalities can only be achieved if digital health is accessible to all and we also recommend that the European Health Data Space work in concertation with other initiatives to ensure that all EU citizens have the means and knowledge to avail themselves of the digital health revolution through improved digital literacy and access to digital tools.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: NFDI4Health Input to the European Health Data Space initiative   Summary: NFDI4Health – the German National Research Data Infrastructure for Personal Health Data – strongly supports the goals of the European Health Dataspace (EHDS). We see the necessity to promote flexible, GDPR-compliant, and maximally privacy preserving sharing of data. Already existing European health research infrastructures will greatly increase its value by interactions through an EHDS. Infrastructures such as NFDI4Health provide technical solutions, but also an important link to the diverse communities whose requirements need to be fulfilled by an EHDS.  NFDI4Health represents an interdisciplinary research community by integrating major German research institutes experienced as health data collectors and holders, health data managers and analysts as well as methodology developers. Within the framework of the German National Research Infrastructure (NFDI), NFDI4Health will create a comprehensive inventory of German epidemiological, public health and clinical trial data. It has started its work in October 2020 and pursues the following main objectives: (1) the implementation of a federated health data infrastructure in Germany for searching and accessing health care data and health databases, (2) to enhance data sharing and data linkage of personal health data in compliance with privacy regulations and ethics principles, (3) to  develop and deploy new consent management mechanisms and augmented data access services, and (4) to foster data sharing and cooperation between clinical research, epidemiological and public health communities.  We would like to emphasize the relevance and the requirements of the NFDI4Health data types for EHDS: Cohort studies and health surveillance systems as well as clinical trials (patients) are characterised by a deep phenotyping of study subjects with questionnaires, medical examinations and molecular/genetic profiling. Their longitudinal nature and high quality make these data a valuable research resource for the development of preventive and therapeutic measures on the individual and the population level. In the majority of cases, these types of health data are hosted by distributed local data infrastructures. Information about these data is often fractured on local repositories and websites or, in various details, in journal publications.  Therefore, the following requirements are vital for the implementation of the EHDS: (1) Enhance the findability and public availability of these distributed resources through the publication of rich metadata of health studies including applied study instruments, questionnaires, data catalogues and study protocols. More specific, we need to support health data publications through a. Advancing and establishing domain specific publication guidelines  b. Incenting the application of existing health data and metadata standards for health data c. Establishing new standards for health data and their metadata, if needed, in close collaboration with domain-specific standardization initiatives and committees d. Providing incentives and support for publishing rich information about health data including study related information e. Supporting the harmonisation of common core (meta) data sets.   (2) Connect the European health data space to the national as well as local infrastructures and enable on site analyses as well as distributed data analyses. For this, we need to establish standardised interfaces and exchange formats, establish the legal and ethical framework and work on further development and establishment of distributed analysis systems such as DataShield  and Personal Health Train . Within this framework, we need to establish training and test environments for applications of artificial intelligence to be able to evaluate their performance. Feedback from: NFDI4Health – the German National Research Data Infrastructure for Personal Health Data (317.6 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: In light of increasing global cancer burden, with breast cancer estimated to be the most commonly occurring cancer in the world, a multi-stakeholder initiative Transforming Breast Cancer Together (TBCT) commends the European Commission's ambitious initiative - Europe’s Health Data Space (EHDS). We believe that cancer care would benefit from the effective exploitation of the momentum of digitalisation and access to real-world health data. Considering the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on the screening, diagnosis, treatment and follow-up, TBCT would like to emphasise the urgency of putting cancer patients and survivors at the centre of the digital revolution, driving meaningful value and change into cancer care. To maximise the EHDS potential, we would like to highlight areas where a real positive impact can be made and to stress the usage of big data across borders in this regard.  TBCT welcomes the merit of outcome-based healthcare and the establishment of a strong EHDS, one that will improve prevention, early diagnosis of breast cancer and will facilitate the optimisation of treatment and care, including for those with advanced or metastatic breast cancer. We support the access to interoperable electronic health data, patients’ health records and clinical information for primary and secondary use, the re-use and exchange of data when these actions are conducted in a transparent, efficient and secure manner. Thus, we welcome the proposal to build accountability in the system and create a legal and governance framework to ensure that health information is shared in full compliance with the EU data protection rules and that the use of AI and machine learning is regulated.  Most EU countries have national cancer registries. We believe that coordination is of utmost importance for ensuring that data, including both for the early and metastatic settings, are shared safely and efficiently across borders. We urge the EC to foster harmonisation of digital standards at the EU level and to invest in upscaling coordination and cooperation mechanisms that will enable registries to collect breast cancer, genomics and disease data in a homogenous way. It is crucial that all national cancer registries and any coordinated effort at the EU level include data collection on relapses and therefore start counting metastatic cancer patients. Currently, it is unknown how many advanced/metastatic cancer patients exist in Europe, and this is a discrepancy that must be corrected.  We see a valuable opportunity in lowering structural, legal and technical barriers to EU-wide data sharing and working with Member States to develop a common format for exchanging health information. We call the EC to guarantee interoperable data access infrastructures that will aim to reduce the complexity of cross-border healthcare provision and data storage. Besides, research projects aiming at establishing pioneering efforts on multi-national data sharing should be prioritised for funding under the different EC-coordinated calls.  It is in cancer patients’ interests to effectively use AI and machine learning. We urge the EC to utilise these new technologies to develop better-targeted screening mechanisms, to improve personalised medicine, accelerate and refine the quality of diagnosis by standardizing tasks and to monitor survivors’ conditions, follow-up treatments and quality of life, including reintegration into the workplace.  Lastly, to realise the EHDS’s full potential, the EC should strive to secure public trust in the process of accessing health data. This can be done by promoting transparency and providing clear guidance to all stakeholders in the data ecosystem, especially patients and citizens, on how to securely obtain and maintain access to data. To improve access and convenience for patients, we are calling on the EC to develop accessible, user-friendly digital tools to facilitate the portability of health data for the benefit of all patients.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: Forum’s views on the proposed European Health Data Space (EHDS)  Forum, the Slovenian innovative pharmaceutical association, which represents 21 global research companies, supports the Commission's efforts to generate a legal environment providing for a wide-ranging use, re-use and exchange of health data, acknowledging the value of such data and promoting the harmonization of digital standards, both at the EU and at national levels. It goes without saying that such legal framework shall be maximally secure and shall account for various risks that artificial intelligence may bring into data handling. Our members are devoted to research and innovation and strongly support outcome-based healthcare and evidence-based decision-making processes inside healthcare systems. They believe that EHDS would significantly contribute to developing and manufacturing better and more efficient medicinal products.  Given the obstacles that disharmonized legal systems pose to our members, which are all multinational companies, they warmly welcome the effort to harmonize the rules for access to health data. For this reason, they strongly support the Data Governance Act which shall pave the way to national data sources and supervise the secondary use of data. It is important to balance the right of individuals to protect their personal data on one hand and the benefits which the use of anonymized data in health research may bring to general welfare and improved public health on the other. Transparency in the use of health data in research should help building a trust of individuals that they can actually contribute to more efficient development of new medicinal products and other improvement in healthcare. Users of the Health Data Space should have the right and incentive to self-regulate the use of such data, providing for safeguards to eliminate harm for individuals and their data.   Considering the above stated we are convinced that the initiative for the Data Governance Act and European Digital Health Data Space will significantly contribute to the boost of innovation and development of new treatments for European patients. The digital reality of our society every day touches more and more healthcare activities and an additional centralized infrastructure which would allow using digital health data spread around existing health data networks, would in the opinion of our members help to improve the welfare of patients.
Organisation: Forum of International Research and Development Pharmaceutical Companies, EIG
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space
organisation_lower: forum of international research and development pharmaceutical companies, eig

feedback_msg_text: The European Molecular Biology Laboratory (EMBL) is supportive of the European Commission’s efforts to establish the European Health Data Space. EMBL-EBI (Hinxton, UK site) maintains the world’s most comprehensive range of freely available molecular data resources. Developed in collaboration with colleagues worldwide, our databases and tools help scientists share data efficiently, perform complex queries and analyse the results in different ways. Our work supports millions of researchers working in all areas of the life sciences, from biomedicine to biodiversity and agri-food research. It is within this context that we encourage the EC to make sure that the objective 1 listed in the current roadmap is included in the future legislative proposal towards the creation of the EHDS. We agree that the processing of health data in Member States is fragmented, leading to obstacles and limited access to researchers (GDPR has not led to systemic improvements). To address this, relying on existing European and International Research Infrastructures (RIs), that can share experience and help ensure that data standards and data interoperability are applied across the EU will be critical. We feel it would be beneficial for the future legislative proposal to recognise and build upon the key role played by RIs. An initiative focusing on this issue is the European Genome-phenome Archive (EGA), which provides a service for the permanent archiving and distribution of personally identifiable genetic and phenotypic data resulting from biomedical research projects. Data at EGA is collected from individuals whose consent agreements authorise data release only for specific research use. In this context, the Federated EGA will be a distributed network of repositories (nodes) for sharing human -omics data and phenotypes. Federated EGA gathers metadata of -omics data collections stored in national or regional archives and makes them discoverable across the EGA network. The Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GA4GH) will be one such nodes, aiming to enable responsible genomic data sharing for the benefit of human health. We encourage the EC and the signatory Member States to the “1+ Million Genomes” initiative to consider this approach as the project develops. Electronic Health Record systems are in need of equivalent efforts and bodies to make them more interoperable and therefore accessible for research. The lack of pan-European standards in this area is, and has been, a barrier to research and EU-wide collaborations that could turn into preventive strategies, better treatment, and innovation on medical devices. In the next decade, genomic medicine is likely to enable risk stratification for a variety of diseases (cancer and rare diseases) by integrating whole-genome information. EMBL has supported and enabled its member states to make substantial progress in designing, delivering, and operating genomic medicine services (e.g. strategic and technical support to the UK 100,000 Genomes Project, and the Danish Genomic Medicine service). EMBL aims to implement a bespoke Genomic Medicine Platform, which will develop data structures, and standards that promote: (1) the proactive sharing of technology from EMBL with member states, (2) the provision of key reference knowledge bases for interpreting genomes, and (3) the responsible secondary use of genomics data for research, with systems that respect national legal and cultural requirements. Finally, pan-European and international initiatives such as the European Open Science Could (EOSC) or the COVID-19 research data platform play an important role as enablers of health and related research data, though their role is not recognised in the current roadmap. Thanks to these initiatives, considerable progress has already been made towards greater availability of research data, therefore we feel that any future potential legislation should build upon their important work, and ensure complementary is achieved.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: Rare Cancers Europe (RCE), a 40-partner strong multi-stakeholder partnership, welcomes the EU efforts towards the creation of a European Health Data Space (EHDS). Rare cancers are a neglected area deserving dedicated attention as 24% of all new cancer diagnoses, including all paediatric cancers, are rare. Rare cancers belong to both cancers and rare diseases, and face challenges linked to their rarity, but their specificities make them closer to common cancers.   Additionally, rare cancers face challenges linked to late or incorrect diagnosis, lack of access to appropriate therapies and expertise, lack of commercial interest in developing new therapies, difficulties in conducting well-powered clinical studies, and few available registries and tissue banks. Thus, the creation of population-based registries interoperable with clinical registries is crucial for creating national cancer policies and informing regulatory, reimbursement and policy decision-making. Also, clinical registries would be a formidable tool to advance our knowledge about rare cancers (as sometimes even their natural history is poorly known, because of lack of clinical data). In addition to the abovementioned challenges and given the low number of cases, professional expertise in rare cancers is inevitably a scarce resource. Thus, the creation of interconnected European Reference Networks (ERNs) with the national centres of expertise is crucial to improve early access to appropriate pathologic diagnoses and fast-track referral pathways as well as to foster medical and professional expertise in rare cancers.   Considering the main problems the initiative aims to tackle, RCE would like to emphasize the following:  Ensuring access, sharing and optimal use of health data for healthcare: A harmonized implementation of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), especially for Recitals 33 and 157 among the EU Member States, is crucial.   Recital 33: if willing, patients should have the right to provide a withdrawable “one-time consent” to using their data and/or biological samples for future retrospective research, under the scrutiny of appropriate review bodies (institutional review boards and/or ethics committees). Recital 157: population-based disease registries (including cancer registries), that are crucial for the creation of health policies, are allowed to operate with a “no-consent” policy under the supervision of relevant public health bodies.   Unfortunately, the European Data Protection Board guidance seems to restrictively interpret these provisions, potentially jeopardizing the use of data and biological samples for observational retrospective research. We are concerned that this restrictive interpretation may lead to national Data Protection Authorities limiting the ability of cancer registries to record “all” cases.   The EHDS should be designed on the basis of flexible IT solutions which guarantee EU citizens’ privacy protection. For example, under “one-time consent” policies, flexible solutions should be available to EU citizens in order for them to be able to donate their data through a “one-time consent” and/or withdraw or modify it at their convenience for future research purposes, to foster scientific research and reduce GDPR’s barriers.  Fostering a genuine single market in digital health:  Administrative barriers to optimize the exchange of data for clinical research should be reduced. Thus, permanent data sharing agreements among research institutes, or at least agreed templates thereof, should be established to ensure an efficient implementation of digital solutions for exchange of health data among researchers. As a possible solution to some data protection concerns, RCE requests the European Commission to encourage the use of technologies such as “Federal learning”. RCE also requests the funding of research projects in order to optimize such technologies.   RCE will be glad to be consulted on this topic. feedback_msg_text: All.Can welcomes the European Health Data Space (EHDS) initiative which seeks to ensure access and optimal use of health data as well as digital health products and services.  Efficient healthcare systems that deliver the best possible outcomes for patients are evidence-based learning systems that incorporate meaningful input from healthcare users, make continuous assessments of products and processes, and report the results of healthcare interventions transparently. Robust data collection is a key driver to ensure that inefficiencies are systematically identified and remedied and health outcomes are continuously improved for the benefit of patients and their families.   In cancer care, systematic and holistic reporting of robust data is vital to create a cycle of continuous improvement and drive accountability across the entire care pathway. For a comprehensive EHDS that can help realise this goal and importantly, has patients’ needs at its core, All.Can calls attention to the following challenges and proposed recommendations to address them. - Data quality: Low quality and unreliable data often limits the ability to impact decision-making across cancer care and damage the trust of stakeholders.  o Applying various tools and techniques to improve data quality and strengthening quality control mechanisms can help generate and maintain high-quality datasets. - Data representativeness: Data not representative of entire populations result in inequities, hampering access to timely diagnosis and high-quality treatment. o Promoting collection of equitable and representative data is key to ensuring that all patient populations benefit equally from healthcare improvement efforts. - Data relevance: Data collected in our healthcare systems are often not patient-centred or aligned with patient values. o  Patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) and patient-reported experience measures (PREMs) data should be systematically collected and analysed to guide quality improvement efforts. - Data silos and interoperability: Data silos and poor interoperability of datasets hinder the measuring of healthcare services performance, and linking of health data across the care pathway for secondary uses. o Creating national and international data standards fosters database linking, through improved data standardisation and interoperability of key national health datasets. - Healthcare professional buy-in: Cooperation from healthcare professionals is key to continuous collection, use and sharing of clinical data. o A positive culture of data sharing should be promoted among healthcare professionals through incentives, including minimising the burden of  data collection by streamlining, integrating and standardising data collection systems. - Building trust: Lack of trust and transparency coupled with burdensome data collection systems disincentivise sharing of data. o Initiatives to build public trust in data and data sharing should be fostered. The burden of data collection on individuals should be mitigated to boost participation in data collection efforts. - Data governance: Countries remain slow in adapting approaches to harness big data in health, due to governance-related barriers such as gaps in funding, leadership, technical expertise and competing priorities within the health systems. o Strong data governance frameworks that can facilitate effective data collection, use and sharing should be developed, with attention to privacy confidentiality, privacy and security for system users. - Data analytics: There remains an unmet need in providing better linkages between health information systems and big data analytics that can transform healthcare by helping to extract insights from vast amounts of data. o To facilitate primary and secondary uses of data and tap into the potential of wide-ranging applications of AI and machine learning, countries should invest in data analytics and their integration in care pathways.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: The ERN RARE-LIVER welcomes the EU initiative to create a European Health Data Space (EHDS). Digitization has driven technological advancements over the past decade. Adopting to this development, facilitating the secure exchange of health data between EU member states is nothing but the next logical step. Facilitating the accessibility and availability of health data will inevitably increase the quality of healthcare and research.  ERN RARE-LIVER is a Europe-wide network for centres of excellence in the clinical management of rare liver disease in adults and in children. The network aims to improve the standards of clinical knowledge and of patient care in rare liver diseases throughout Europe. It is in the nature of rare diseases themselves that little data is available on these topics. Data sharing is essential for meaningful research in the field of rare diseases. Providing a framework for secure data sharing is necessary and must be built from scratch for each new collaboration. The ability to rely on an existing infrastructure would enhance such efforts and strengthen the overall European research effort on rare diseases.  We would also like to pay special attention to the GDPR. Originally created to protect EU citizens, its inconsistent interpretation among EU member states has made it an insurmountable obstacle to any efforts to build a health data-driven infrastructure within Europe. Such restrictions on data sharing threaten to have a negative impact on healthcare for the very patients it is supposed to protect. We therefore advocate a harmonized approach to the GDPR in relation to personal health data to reduce bureaucracy and promote transnational cooperation. Most importantly, adherence to European data protection regulations should enable transnational collection and sharing of health related data, unaffected by national regulations.  As we are aiming to establish a centralized European registry for rare liver diseases, we have witnessed first-hand the challenges that have to be overcome when trying to share health data across borders. But not only sharing data, the sole collection of data across several European countries reveals national data protection rules that take months to be overcome. Many of these issues remain unresolved to this day. We are happy to share our experience and help wherever possible in setting up the EHDS.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: EFHPA, the European Federation of Homeopathic Patients’ Associations, welcomes and supports this important initiative, which aims for patients to have greater access to their health records and allow researchers and policy-makers greater access to health data, which will ideally mean citizens receive the best and most appropriate care.   Better access to health data will allow EU member states to gain a greater understanding around the actual use of different treatments and interventions and allow policies and strategies to be adapted accordingly. It is therefore imperative that the information gathered relates to both new and established treatments. Complementary medicine is an important part of the healthcare system, and plays a significant role in integrated health care, in both prevention and in the treatment of disease to improve outcomes. The gathering and analysis of data reflecting the real world use of complementary/integrated treatments will allow their full potential to be better understood, so these treatments can be best utilised to provide improved healthcare outcomes for patients and reduce the burden on existing conventional health system’s resources.  We are pleased to see the emphasis is firmly on patients, ideally allowing citizens control over their own health data.  However, we were surprised that under ‘B. Objectives and Policy options’ there are three main objectives listed and patients’/citizens’ rights do not feature.  It is a concern moving forward on the individual ownership of the health care data that would be collected and the ability for any person to opt out of the data collection. It should be considered as the process moves forward, how citizens can opt in to provide their data and have control how it is used.  The impact of variances between countries in costs for health-care should also be considered particularly when regions are close to borders with other EU states where there is enough variation in cost to shift purchasing from the home country of the citizen to the neighbouring EU nation, thus skewing data collected.  We are pleased the EU is looking at the Health Data Space and are keen to follow the policy as it progresses.
Organisation: EFHPA - European Federation of Homeopathic Patients' Associations
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: DigitalHealthEurope is a CSA supporting the EC Communication on the DTHC. In 2020 DHE held multiple stakeholder consultations on the acceptability of reusing health data, especially for research, and on the potential opportunities from the EHDS. The key requests for the EHDS highlighted through the project are:   1. A large online citizen survey on attitudes on the use of data for research by different organisations for different purposes. 57% out of 936 Europe & US respondents did not know who could access their health data, but 80% felt their health data might be of use in disease and medicine research. The majority would consent to sharing their data with a research organisation (76%) or a health and care provider (72%). Few would share with commercial organisations (<1%; but 11,4% if company develops health services). 93% would share their data for common good, either freely (30%) or case-by-case (58%). Rather than monetary rewards (10%), most participants want to be notified if their data contributed to helpful research for society (63%) or their own condition (60%).  2. A virtual focus group of health-related industry spanning Pharma, MedTech, BioTech, BigTech, SMEs on potential opportunities and governance requirements for contributing to and using the EHDS. Industry calls for EHDS to be a  centralised access point to data from multiple EU countries, facilitated by the adoption of technical standards and consistent application of  data  governance rules, common principles and access agreements. This will accelerate research and crucially reduce costs. It will expand the market especially for SMEs to use data for innovation. Companies would contribute in return for access to the EHDS, through infrastructure support, in-kind services and/or in-cash contribution as an annual licence or pay-to-use fee. EHDS governance must enable safe, secure data sharing, empowering citizens, health authorities and companies to share insights under the highest ethical and technical standards.   3. A virtual focus group of patients and citizens to examine their ambitions to use their health data, for its use in European data ecosystems and assurances to make this acceptable. Patients and citizens want to combine their EHR with their self-management and lifestyle data, to make better informed decisions themselves and with their healthcare professionals and compare with anonymised data of similar patients. Participants strongly emphasised greater investment in digital and data health literacy for empowerment. They support the use of their health data to improve the quality of health services, for public health and for research, whether publicly or industry funded. Their main concerns are identity protection and that the use purposes must target benefits for healthcare, by approved trustworthy bodies with transparent rules and decisions. The majority supported individual contribution of  data to the EHDS.  CALL FOR ACTION The legislative framework needs to target in a bold and holistic way areas that are differentiated from other sectors: - sectoral aspects, beyond health specific “types of data and modalities for access” should be at the centre of attention. The “Do no Harm” imperative requires that a mindset for “data safety” drives the change  o accountability for harm induced by failure to use available data to save lives o enablers for provision of data that is suitable for its intended use  o interoperability to serve many use cases, beyond the implementation of the EHRxF, (e.g. real-time interoperable data)  o MS adoption is key but there is a need to leverage on more potential players to bring benefits to citizens (e.g. industry and innovators) - The Governance Framework in policy “objective 1 (a) health specific governance framework” should embrace the “data safety” imperative beyond its foreseen scope to address fully the governance for data safety. It should enable multi-stakeholder participation, including citizens and industry. Feedback from: Anonymous (2.3 MB - PDF - 36 pages) Download
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: EIT Health  European Health Data Space Consultation Response  • The EHDS will be an important part of Europe’s health research and innovation landscape which will support the development of many innovative treatments and interventions which will improve outcomes, health and quality of life. EIT Health welcomes the evaluation roadmap and inception impact assessment (IIA) for the European Health Data Space (EHDS) and in partnership with its network, stands ready and willing to help support the development and deployment of the EHDS. • The EHDS is an ambitious pan-European initiative which can contribute to the codification of the FAIR (Findable Accessible Interoperable and Re-useable) principles. EIT Health urges that EHDS creates an environment which fulfils the “spirit” of the FAIR principles. This demands that initiatives are adopted that help organisations collect data suitable for co-operative research, which meets common quality standards. • The European innovation landscape is diverse, multi-disciplinary and includes many SMEs. EIT Health and its network are able and willing to be involved and consulted throughout the development and deployment of the EHDS, to foster the engagement of academic partners, SMEs. • EIT Health welcomes the lowering of barriers to data use and re-use and calls for a strengthening of the eHealth Digital Service Infrastructure and a review of the mandate of the eHealth Network in order to provide the EU with a stronger regulatory remit in the field of digital health.  • EIT health calls on the Commission, to ensure equitable stakeholder involvement in the EHDS, ensuring that any EU level advisory bodies established are accessible to all stakeholders and draws on their wide experience. The Commission should also play a role in supporting Member States in ensuring similar representation within national digital health bodies. • Data access, sharing and use of health data for primary and secondary care are vital for improving the health and life science industries. This must be done in a fair and competitive way which supports the development of a strong and innovative European business environment. EIT Health calls for the Commission to actively promote positive examples of health data use and the value it brings and could offer its network to develop such a library of positive use cases, such as the app Sea Hero Quest, launched to collect data on early Alzheimer’s detection. • EIT Health looks forward to greater detail on potential health sector specific legislation to be proposed to complement the Data Governance Act and to providing comments on such proposals.  • Noting that European citizens and patients are often willing to share their data with organisations they trust, it is vital that the EHDS fosters trust, in particular with respect to data altruism. EIT Health offers its support and collaboration in building this trust, notably through education and showcasing of success stories from EIT Health’s network. Additionally, to support trust building, EIT Health urges the Commission to make the registration of data altruism bodies which handle health data is made compulsory in the forthcoming legislation.  • EIT health notes the reference of greater data portability for citizens and patients and hopes to see that this creates an actionable right beyond that provided for in Article 20 GDPR. • EIT Health welcomes the recognition of the importance of digital health tools and services, as well as the role of AI, in the European single market. EIT Health has a wealth of experience in this domain and is ready to support the Commission with insights and use cases. A sample of such use cases can be found in the report on the potential of AI for healthcare developed by EIT Health in partnership with McKinsey. • EIT Health looks forward to seeing the further development of the EHDS proposal and actively contributing to the foreseen targeted consultation activities. feedback_msg_text: The Association of Innovative Pharmaceutical Industry (AIFP) shares the EFPIA’s view expressed in its input into this Inception Impact Assessment. Further to this, we would like to stress some of our main concerns and observations.  AIFP welcomes the Commission’s intention to create the European Health Data Space, a sectoral and horizontal legislative framework, and supports all objectives which were identified within this Inception Impact Assessment. In particular, AIFP highly appreciates that, among other goals, the proposal aims at encouraging the access to and use of health data for research, policy-making and regulation, with a trusted governance framework and upholding data-protection rules.  The new policy framework should be patient-oriented and ensure the citizens have control over their data and exercise their data portability rights without any cross-border barriers. We also expect a thorough analysis of the existing cross-border collaboration framework in order to ensure maximum use of the already achieved outcomes and instruments.   The EU regulatory framework should also reflect the immense technological and medical development with the advanced therapies, digital and AI solutions significantly ahead of the current EU and national legislation to fully evolve the union´s R&D potential. It goes hand in hand with the Union´s priorities and objectives set in the new EU Pharmaceutical Strategy.  One of the lessons learned from the COVID-19 crisis has been the utmost importance of medical innovation in addressing global health threats as well as existing health challenges. Our industry is very well capable of bringing such innovations. However, in some cases, we experience delays and barriers to patients getting access to new treatments because the existing reimbursement schemes do not meet modern therapies' needs. To introduce new innovative pricing and payment models that will ensure timely access to care for all patients, well-structured and comprehensive data sets have to be made accessible for all stakeholders involved. The same goes with the secondary use of health data to stimulate and support the EU´s competitiveness and strategic autonomy.
Organisation: The Association of Innovative Pharmaceutical Industry
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space
organisation_lower: the association of innovative pharmaceutical industry

feedback_msg_text: EFPIA welcomes the proposal to create sectoral and horizontal legislative frameworks to unlock the value of data, support the use, re-use and exchange of health data at the EU level and ensure coherence between the operation of the different legislations contributing to the functioning of the Data Space.  EU policy should promote data sharing and harmonize applicable national rules removing technical and legislative barriers to the potential opportunities across Europe. Clear guidance on how each stakeholder may gain access to health data and for what purpose, needs to be transparently articulated and understood by all data partners participating in this data ecosystem. The associated processes to obtain and maintain access to this data ecosystem need to be clearly defined.   EFPIA welcomes the proposal in the draft Data Governance Act to establish competent bodies who may act as a gateway to national data resources.  As also noted in the Act, sectoral bodies dealing with secondary use of data, including data altruism, should be set up. We believe that the actions of such bodies should be substantially harmonized at EU level to avoid complexity and duplication of groups at Member State level, charged with data access requests, particularly regarding the secondary use.   EFPIA considers that it is important that other potential legal bases (beyond consent) in particular for secondary use of data for scientific research are considered and that any consent form (as proposed in the Act), as well as providing for subjects to exercise specific control over the use of their data, should also permit individuals to agree for example to very broad categories of use (e.g., health research), both for primary and secondary use.   The GDPR assigns a special regime to scientific research, intended to foster innovation.  However, in light of divergent interpretations amongst and within Member States, renewed efforts to clarify and harmonise the rules would be valuable. EFPIA agrees with the need to further review an individual’s ability to exercise their data portability rights and to invest in building public understanding and trust in how health data is used in research.  We are committed to working with the Commission and other relevant institutions to develop Codes of Conduct for the sector that would harmonize the rules across Europe, ensuring equal rights of citizens between countries. Users of the EHDS should be encouraged to develop self-regulatory frameworks for the use of the data, identifying the safeguards that should be deployed to minimize harms to subjects.   Investment in an interoperable data infrastructure is a prerequisite to allowing processing and analysis of different data sources.  Data should not have to be physically pooled into one repository in a single format, but instead can sit as distributed data networks provided appropriate safeguarding mechanisms are in place. A positive European health data space will scale up existing health data networks to connect them and ensure the system operates at scale across Member States. Standardised outcome measures as well as expansion of common data models and quality standards are fundamental in consolidating multiple datasets and overcoming differences between the sources while at the same time ensuring a high level of data protection and generation of credible insights for research.    EFPIA welcomes the proposal to strengthen coordination at the EU level. In order to ensure the validity of the proposed EU system and that the data to be collected can be used to achieve EHDS objectives including the establishment of (mandatory) common requirements covering certain key issues such as interconnectivity, comparability of the collected data, data quality and the promotion of data protection. EFPIA supports investment in a mechanism for coordination to maximize learning from outputs and its eventual upscaling in order to benefit all EU residents. feedback_msg_text: La Federación Española de Enfermedades Raras (FEDER), alineada con la Alianza Europea que representa a estas patologías (EURORDIS), aplaude esta consulta reconociendo, en primer lugar, la oportunidad que supone esta revisión para la investigación y abordaje de este colectivo.  Todo ello repercutirá de forma directa en enfermedades raras, cuyos datos son especialmente valiosos, ya que ningún país contará por sí mismo con un número de pacientes de una enfermedad poco frecuentes como para entenderla epidemiológicamente.  Compartir datos sobre enfermedades raras a nivel europeo permitirá ampliar la muestra de pacientes y suplir la dispersión geográfica, ampliando asimismo también el conocimiento y extrapolarlo entre países. Permitiría así mismo evitar duplicidades y reducir tiempos e inversión en investigación.  FEDER aplaude la iniciativa que permitirá reducir el peregrinaje de quienes conviven con estas patologías ya que su complejidad y baja prevalencia hacen necesarios un abordaje multidisciplinar y con alta experiencia que, a menudo, se concentra en los grandes hospitales y lleva a las familias a desplazarse. En España, casi el 30% de las familias se ha visto obligada a ello. Todo ello, además, repercutirá de forma directa en:  - la reducción del retraso diagnóstico, ya que la mitad de las familias esperan más de 4 años y un 20% más de una década para poner nombre a la enfermedad con la que conviven.  - el impulso de la investigación y el acceso a medicamentos, ya que sólo el 5% de las más de 6.172 identificadas en todo el mundo tienen tratamiento.  De esta forma, quienes conviven con enfermedades raras son uno de los grupos de pacientes para quienes la asistencia sanitaria transfronteriza es el tipo de asistencia más adecuado y accesible. No obstante, la movilidad transfronteriza de los pacientes conlleva algunos problemas, como la continuidad de la asistencia y el intercambio de información entre los profesionales sanitarios a ambos lados de la frontera. Además, existen barreras logísticas y administrativas que pueden afectar negativamente, de forma involuntaria, a la asistencia sanitaria transfronteriza de los pacientes.  Además, un marco legal europeo sobre datos favorecerá la equidad dentro y fuera de los Estados Miembros, estableciendo un equilibrio entre la protección de datos y la promoción de la investigación.   Adjuntamos documento desglosado.  Feedback from: Anonymous (122.3 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
