feedback_msg_text: The objevtives and policies outlined are a prominent need for boosting research, especially in case of rare diseases or emerging diseases and epidemics and are clearly defined. For what concerns adoption in clinical pracrice, besides the well known and well addressed issues of data interoperability and data reuse, the integration of new concepts in clinical research and in the conduction of clinical trials, that take into consideration the advantages offered by IoT and mobile technologies for large amounts of data capture and of Artificial Intelligence for the enalysis of such wealth of data should be consistently addressed jointly by the technical research and the medical research communities. In this sense initiatives offering guidance and recommendations such as CTTI and SPIRIT-AI should be sustained and promoted for new research trials design. In addition, wide actions should be promoted at the level of European and international scienticic and medical Societies to build knowledge and trust in AI-driven techniques, which may unvveil unexpected knowledge. This process should be sustained by sound verifications and validations and suspported by new pathways of learning and understanding of the use of these techniques by the medical communities. New ethics approaches also needd to be established.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: Governance – a shared vision based on trust  • The 24 ERN registries should be one of the fundamental building blocks of the EHDS  *  The former UK ERN Full Members are part of the ERN Registries and should therefore have access as well • The ERN CG can build on the recent experience of setting up registries to actively work with the EC to create the EHDS - we would like to be involved in the development, discussions and ERN registries could be the test case for new initiatives.  • The ERNs will organize their data sharing and integration efforts in the ERN Rare Disease Research Coordination and Support Action (ERICA). ERICA can serve as the primary point of contact to discuss the integration of the ERN Registries and related databases in the EHDS.  We welcome active engagement with the EC.  • In the same vein, the TEHDAS joint action of member states on GDPR governance is an excellent opportunity to involve stakeholders outside of national agencies in the decision making and knowledge sharing between member states. Healthcare professionals, professional medical societies, researchers and patients are critical stakeholders. Likewise, the targeted consultations mentioned in this inception impact assessment must include these groups in the decision making process. • The EHDS must find a way for discussing governance models for ethics committees across EU member states. A multi-stakeholder European level ethics committee which incorporates citizens, patients, healthcare professionals etc may be best placed to find uniform, EU-wide solutions to issues around confidentiality and use of health data.     Greater harmonization of GDPR • Greater harmonisation is incredibly valuable, but must not come at the cost of being prohibitive to necessary and currently allowable health research. • The Commission must conduct a full assessment to establish a clear legal pathway for a harmonized approach which will not add an additional layer of bureaucracy to national legislation on derogations. • The GDPR codes of conduct mentioned in Art 40 are a bottom up approach by different sectors. We strongly advocate for a bottom up approach for codes, working through issues identified by the particular community in question, rather than a top down approach.  • The EHDS needs to be grounded in a legal basis that acknowledges the complementarity of health and research and should not be restricted to informed consent as a legal basis.  In GDPR legislation, Article 9 provides for a number of legal allowances for the processing of special forms of data such as health data (9. 2. a consent, h – health and care purposes i public interest – public health j scientific research) in combination with a legal basis derived from Article 6 is important.     • The EHDS needs to work with EU Member States to build a European ecosystem of trustworthy health data sharing which may then allow for citizen opt outs for secondary processing.   Harmonising standards • For research purposes, the EHDS should ensure that the standards and ontologies adopted or developed by the EJP-RD and IRDiRC for rare disease data sharing and integration are added to the standards accepted and promoted by the EHDS.  • Incentivising data conversion: the cost of data conversion according to (meta)data models is significant. Substantial investment will be needed to streamline this process, which is a prerequisite for data sharing for research purposes according to the FAIR principles. Such investment should include funding for training and capacity building by the ERNs.   Capacity building and skills  • Specific funding will need to be available for digital health and digital literacy programmes for professional medical societies, ERNs and patients. • Encourage robust training methodologies   • Fund joint initiatives on standardization and certification of healthcare professionals
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: Indledningsvist takker Kræftens Bekæmpelse for muligheden for at komme med feedback til det fremlagte forslag til forordning om det europæiske sundhedsdataområde (EHDS).   Kræftens Bekæmpelse er en sygdomsbekæmpende patientforening, der blandt andet har godt 200 forskere, der gennemfører kræftforskning på højt internationalt niveau.  I Kræftens Bekæmpelse ser vi grundlæggende meget positivt på initiativet, og bakker herunder op om at fremme mobiliteten af sundhedsdata på en sikker måde.   Det er flere steder i dokumentet fremhævet, at initiativet vil fremme den enkelte borgers mulighed for at tage sine sundhedsdata med sig over grænserne. Borgernes muligheder for datadeling er relevante - ikke mindst i forhold til personlig medicin og kliniske studier, hvor data skal bruges for at tilgå og inkluderes i studier i andre lande. Vi mener dog, at EHDS bør anvise en løsning på, at nogle data, f.eks. diagnosekoder og patologikoder er internationale, hvorimod andre koder ikke er internationale.   Vi vurderer, at der aktuelt er et stort problem med sekundær brug af data på grund af fortolkninger af GDPR, som reelt forhindrer deling og dermed forskning og udvikling.  I det følgende gør vi opmærksom på nogle af de områder, hvor GDPR aktuelt udgør en udfordring i forhold til brug af sundhedsdata med henblik på forskning og udvikling, og som bør tænkes ind i EHDS.   I praksis er det vanskeligt at vurdere, om det er muligt at anonymisere data, der anvendes til sundhedsvidenskabelige forskningsprojekter, og i så fald hvilke foranstaltninger, der skal til. Det er for eksempel uklart, når det drejer sig om data bestående af biologisk materiale. I Kræftens Bekæmpelse vurderer vi, at der er behov for fortolkningsbidrag, der adresserer de mange ubekendte, der gør sig gældende i forhold til samfundsvidenskabelig forskning, i særdeleshed i forhold til biologisk materiale.  Det er også en udfordring i praksis at afklare de dataretlige roller i sundhedsvidenskabelige forskningsprojekter. I forskningsmæssige samarbejder er den samlede vurdering ofte, at parterne er fæles dataansvarlige, hvilket kan give anledning til en lang række komplicerede forhold, blandt andet i forhold til oplysningspligten. Det juridiske grundlag er kompliceret, og en forskningsinstitution som Kræftens Bekæmpelse har brug for bedre og mere konkret rådgivning og vejledning.   Derudover kan det konstateres, at eksisterende samarbejder er i fare for nedlukning som følge af mulighederne for overførelsesgrundlag. Med Schrems II-dommen er muligheden for at benytte Privacy Shield som overførelsesgrundlag forsvundet. SCC kan fortsat anvendes kombineret med særlige foranstaltninger. Men der uklarhed om hvilke konkrete foranstaltninger, der skal stilles krav om til forskningsinstitutter i et 3. land. I forhold til sundhedsfaglige forskningsprojekter er det også fortsat uafklaret, hvorvidt art. 49, stk. 1, litra d kan anvendes som overførelsesgrundlag. Vi vurderer, at der er et stor behov for specifik rådgivning på et højere fagligt niveau end de eksisterende vejledninger.   Vi kan i øvrigt tilslutte os EORTC's kommentar af 26. januar 2021.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: 1)Data governance, access, sharing, use and re-use The EHDS should build on F.A.I.R. (findable, accessible, interoperable, reusable) data principles to ensure maximum value and trust from the data collected.  Given the specificities of the health sector,  J&J welcomes the intent to complement the Data Governance Act proposal by establishing sectoral bodies, namely national digital health bodies and sectoral bodies dealing with secondary use of health data including data altruism but urges to provide a harmonised framework at EU level in order to avoid fragmentation. The role of national entities should be to provide controlled data services, like health information sharing and analysis. FinData in Finland and France’s Health Data Hub could inspire the creation of such health Data Permit Authorities in each country.  Most importantly, health Data Permit Authorities should promote the adoption of multi-stakeholder Compacts/Codes of Conduct (CoC) and harmonised interpretation of GDPR regarding responsible re-use of health data. The CoC should accelerate access and processing of such data within each, and across all, Member States in cooperation with all public and private stakeholders. For health data, there is currently no mechanisms through which data can be donated. Control over data generated by patients should remain with the patients, who should be empowered to access it and influence its ethical use. A secure opt-out model for sharing patient data, combined with an easily understandable way for patients to share their data, would unlock a wealth of data for the development of crucial health innovations.  EHDS should build on federated data networks, which can remove the barriers to accessing health data while ensuring the highest level of protection of personal data and commercial IP.  Data standardisation efforts must be dealt with at EU level with global alignment as a target. A good example is IMI EHDEN, which standardises data to OHDSI common data model.   2)Digital Health J&J is committed to foster a genuine single market in digital health covering health products & services enabling value/outcome-based healthcare.  This requires harmonisation of digital health national legislative frameworks and a significant investment in interoperable data infrastructure. Our proposal is to create regulatory sandboxes to develop an EU regulation framework for products & services interacting with EHDS. Creating a EHDS certification for health products & services will give guidance and build trust to engage with health data products & services and provide a structured harmonized process for market access purposes (e.g. monitored by a commission). 2 outstanding points should be addressed:  Digital literacy - Equip HCPs and citizens with the necessary skills to maximize the impact of digital health;  Acceptance & Market penetration - Facilitate acceptance and use of data by patients and professionals to harvest its full potential (e.g. eHR).  3)AI in Healthcare EHDS should: • enable access to high quality,representative health data ensuring robust, accurate and safe AI solutions; • facilitate HCP skill development, developing AI curricula integrated into education and long-life learning; • support AI integration in hospitals and healthcare systems, including PPPs and centres to test new AI technologies. Building trust with HCPs, patients and consumers requires: • a comprehensive risk-based approach across healthcare, based on the MDR framework and supported by MDCG guidance enhancing legal clarity and consistency in requirements and assessment; • considering how AI technologies with proven efficacy in healthcare bring benefits to patients (e.g. reducing risks); • supporting measures such as ethical guidelines and standards; • professional education and certification in high-risk applications; • clear interpretation and implementation of liability rules at EU level between AI manufacturers, deployers and users addressing specific risks. feedback_msg_text: RWE4Decisions welcomes the set up of the EHDS to enable the cross-border sharing of real-world data (RWD) by healthcare decision-makers (regulators, HTA authorities, and payers). The EHDS should take into account the potential of RWD for learning healthcare systems and thereby support the development of a multi-stakeholder EU Learning Network on Real-World Evidence (RWE). This Learning Network would be designed for Member States to implement evidence-based decision-making and clarify when, by whom and how RWD should be collected to generate RWE that meets the needs of patients and healthcare systems.   Digital and data are key for improved patient & healthcare systems outcomes. RWD can enable more effective and efficient research and development processes. For example, RWD can help to better characterise diseases, patient populations and understand current needs; it can provide evidence on the real world usage of innovative medicines (dosage, duration) and it may help the assessment of the patient outcomes in real life practice.  In order to ensure that the EHDS takes into account the potential of RWD/RWE for learning healthcare systems, it is key that the EHDS:  1. Puts in place the right legal and governance framework for data security and privacy of individuals, to cover the access to and exchange of health data for secondary use (research, policy & regulatory activities). In the interest of patients, there must be clear communication about the measures that policy-makers take to guarantee data security and privacy. The format and content of a so-called ‘one time consent’ needs to be worked out to enable people to indicate what they want to share and when.    2. Builds on existing or emerging initiatives such as the eHealth Digital Service Infrastructure (primary data), the Beyond 1+ Million genomes initiative (genomic data), the ERNs (rare diseases) and the EMA’s DARWIN (pharmaceutical regulatory data). RWE4Decisions welcomes EMA’s ambition to set up DARWIN (Data Analysis and Real World Interrogation Network), which should support better decision-making throughout the product life-cycle via its network of expertise/partnerships and databases. We urge the Commission to work closely with the EMA-HMA and to involve all stakeholders in the design and implementation of DARWIN.  3. Takes into account the use of data in the full lifecycle of technologies, from research to market authorisation. It is expected for instance that RWD should enable the generation of additional evidence post launch, inform dynamic price-setting in relation to the value of medicines, and optimise appropriate use in daily practice. Therefore, the EHDS should take an holistic approach, considering data generation in the post-authorisation phase in addition to data obtained pre-authorisation. This is particularly true when ‘highly innovative technologies’ - which are potentially transformative such as immunotherapies or cell & gene therapies - come to market early via expedited regulatory approvals to benefit patients and often only limited evidence from traditional clinical development programmes is possible.  4. Supports the quality, accessibility & interoperability of RWD, which involves the establishment of common data standards (in terms of accuracy, completeness and traceability) to ensure validity and consistency across sources. A key hurdle to the harmonisation of RWE use is the different sources and requirements for data collection. RWD can come in different formats (payer registry, claim database, company registry etc). This requires a minimum common data set and interoperability of different applied systems.  5. Supports collaboration and cooperation on RWD. The EHDS can provide the framework for cross-country collaboration on RWD studies underway across different jurisdictions to enable data amalgamation. The EHDS infrastructure should enable cross-organisational sharing of RWE generation plans and post-licensing evidence generation about RWD. feedback_msg_text: Die Spitzenorganisationen der Deutschen Sozialversicherung begrüßen die Absicht der Europäischen Kommission, einen europäischen Gesundheitsdatenraum zu gestalten, insbesondere durch:  - eine verbindlichere Zusammenarbeit der Mitgliedstaaten für eine bessere Verfügbarkeit und Interoperabilität von Gesundheitsdaten mit Mehrwert für die Patientinnen und Patienten sowie  -die Schaffung einer institutionalisierten Daten Governance Struktur, die Forschung und Entwicklung von Innovationen und die Anwendung Künstlicher Intelligenz (KI).   Ein Datenraum für Patientinnen und Patienten  Ein Datenraum, der den Zugriff auf Gesundheitsdaten von Patientinnen und Patienten in elektronischen Patientenkurzakten ermöglicht, unterstützt die Patientenmobilität in der Europäischen Union. Die Deutsche Sozialversicherung beteiligt sich am Aufbau einer europaweiten Infrastruktur zum Austausch von Behandlungsdaten (eHealth Digital Infrastructure, eHDSI). Eine stärkere Verbindlichkeit der Mitgliedstaaten und ihrer Sozialsysteme stützt deren flächendeckende Umsetzung. Die Ausgestaltung muss sich am Mehrwert für die medizinische Versorgung von Patientinnen und Patienten orientieren.  Für einen funktionierenden EHDS sind gemeinsame Standards für Datenformate und Semantik unerlässlich, um die Vergleichbarkeit, Kompatibilität und Interoperabilität der Daten zu fördern. Aus Sicht der Deutschen Sozialversicherung bestehen die wesentlichen Herausforderungen bei der europäischen Vernetzung in der eindeutigen Identifizierung und der verlässlichen Authentifizierung der zugreifenden Akteure, der Autorisierung von Leistungserbringenden im In- und Ausland und der Gewährleistung der Vertraulichkeit der Gesundheitsdaten. Die nationalen Systeme sind dabei so zu vernetzen, dass es nicht zu Eingriffen in die nationalen Telematik-Infrastrukturen kommt und die Anwendung der EU-Datenschutzgrundverordnung (EU-DSGVO) klar geregelt ist.   Ein Datenraum für Forschung, Innovation und Künstliche Intelligenz  Die Verfügbarkeit von Daten in der EU soll über eine institutionalisierte Daten-Governance-Struktur ausgeweitet werden. Das Zusammenwirken von Daten-Governance-Struktur und EHDS trägt einen entscheidenden Anteil daran, welche Daten zukünftig für eine Sekundärnutzung verfügbar sind. Der Vorschlag für einen EHDS muss Zugriffs- und Nutzungsrechte klar definieren sowie eine in den Mitgliedstaaten einheitliche Auslegung der europäischen Datenschutzgrundverordnung (EU-DSGVO) sicherstellen.  Die nationalen Sozialsysteme generieren und verarbeiten Daten zur Optimierung der nationalen und regionalen Versorgungstrukturen. Sie sollten daher nicht nur als Datenlieferant, sondern als Schlüsselakteur des EHDS betrachtet und von Beginn an eingebunden werden. Dies umfasst ebenfalls die Mitsprache bei der dezentralen Bereitstellung anonymisierter Daten, welche zielgerichtet für Forschungszwecke mit tatsächlichem Mehrwert in der Versorgung (z. B. seltene Erkrankungen oder Volkskrankheiten) und mit einem gesamtgesellschaftlichen Nutzen bereitgestellt werden sollten.  Der Zugang zu Daten ist für die Forschung und für die Weiterentwicklung und Nutzung von Anwendungen der KI wesentlich. Die Deutsche Sozialversicherung unterstützt die Forderungen des Weißbuchs KI, notwendige Bedingungen zu präzisieren. Dies umfasst die Formulierung allgemeiner Voraussetzungen für den Einsatz von KI, wie z. B. die Sicherstellung der Unversehrtheit von Leben und Grundrechten, das Gebot von Transparenz, Nichtdiskriminierung oder Letztentscheidung durch den Menschen etwa bei Therapie- oder Leistungsentscheidungen. Auch die Auswirkungen auf die Kompetenzen von Ärztinnen und Ärzten und anderen im Gesundheitswesen Tätigen müssen berücksichtigt werden. Wichtig ist dabei, die Sicherheit der Daten, die Datensouveränität der Patientinnen und Patienten sowie die Kontrolle und Nachvollziehbarkeit KI-gestützter Verfahren im Einklang mit der EU-DSGVO zu gewährleisten.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: The European Society of Cardiology welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to create a European Health Data Space for better healthcare, research, and policymaking. The COVID pandemic has clearly shown the weakness to overcome healthcare challenges and lack of collaboration between Member States and their data exchange due to national legal constraints. It has also shed light on the benefits that better sharing and use of health data can bring to healthcare in the EU. The EHDS shall allow to exploit the potential of ever-growing data in a trustworthy European framework where Member States are encouraged and supported to better align their use of health data, to stimulate research and enable data-driven healthcare for citizen benefits while protecting their privacy. The European Society of Cardiology fully endorses the vision for using and combining patient data for the continuous improvement of patient care and health outcomes. To this end it has developed over twenty registries covering a range of cardiovascular diseases within its EURObservational Research Programme (EORP) with more than 140.000 patients enrolled overall.Additionally, it has recently started a new initiative called EuroHeart, which aspires to a more comprehensive and unified patient registry approach across Europe. EuroHeart is designed for the continuous improvement of patients care, easier recruitment of patients in clinical studies, the conduct of pragmatic randomised clinical trials, the post-marketing surveillance of drugs and devices,  and supporting the planning of health care investments. It is a collaboration between national registries providing continuous data collection of standardised and/or harmonised variables in common cardiovascular diseases, including therapy, medical and instrumental interventions, and long-term outcomes. EuroHeart reports will be based on analyses of aggregated data sets originating from synchronised performance of identical analyses in the individual countries. Based on the development of the EHDS we also foresee opportunities to use federated databases allowing analyses based on anonymized individual data including AI methodologies.EuroHeart will make comparable real word data in cardiovascular disease available at European level, significantly contributing to the EHDS vision and ambition. Harmonised, comparable real-world data on cardiovascular disease would therefore be a huge asset for the realisation of the EHDS and therefore ESC supports the EHDS Nodes Concept, including research infrastructure and is willing to support its development with ESC expertise gathered in EORP and EuroHeart Programmes. The European Society of Cardiology puts forward recommendations to ensure that the European Health Data Space is deployed and delivered successfully: -Member States should be supported to increase the “digital maturity” of their systems. Adequate EU funding should be made available to support the development of digital infrastructures and facilities which will contribute to a strong EHDS -EU funding should also be made available to support ambitious projects aiming at unifying patient data across Europe thought the use of common datasets in key clinical areas, such as the EuroHeart project. -EU Codes of Conduct, especially for health research and secondary use of health data, should be adopted to facilitate cross-border exchange of data. Scientific societies, such as the European Society of Cardiology, should be closely consulted and associated to this process -Due to the sensitivity of the data to be processed within the EHDS, the boundaries of what constitutes a lawful processing of the data must be crystal-clear for all the stakeholders involved. Therefore, transparency on processing in the EHDS will be key to ensure public trust  - We call the Commission to assess GDPR level of fragmentation on research and address this problem with regulatory non-binding and when possible regulatory binding measures. Feedback from: European Society of Cardiology (484.1 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: EHDS is a profound step towards health data integration within the European Union, harmonising primary and secondary data use, constituent stakeholders and ensuring complementarity of expectations for patients and citizens across Member States. As a critical enabler for enhanced clinical outcomes via optimal digital linkage of health information and record systems, it must facilitate the utilisation of generated data for the good of society in supporting research and development, inclusive of public and private sectors. The EHDS will succeed if it embraces key principles, built on existing, open standards (so as not to obfuscate progress with irrelevant, new development), protocols and policies: • Incentives: specific attention on incentives at a local, national, regional, clinical to policy level for constituent stakeholders to adopt all components of the EHDS for primary and secondary uses of health data. This could include financial aspects, but also behavioural and sociotechnical drivers for adopting change, in particular with reference to the concept of trust. Emphasis on upskilling and education, with appropriate resourcing needs to complement EHDS adoption • Embracing variety via open interoperability: recognition of Member States relative maturity of healthcare systems with respect to digitalisation, allowing for national variation, but with an overarching standardisation layer for sociotechnical aspects inclusive of data harmonisation through to governance, ethics, and privacy law. The use of federated networks is likely furthermost in addressing this principle, with an interoperability layer of data held on patients (e.g. by institutions) and data generated by patients (e.g. digital biomarkers) via appropriate, internationally recognised open common data models (e.g. OMOP) and exchange standards (e.g. HL7 FIHR). Concerted efforts need to be in place to remove interoperability barriers • Universality of experience: for both primary use of data, specifically from a patient perspective, and from a secondary use of data, namely a researcher perspective, the EHDS needs to foster a similarity of experience with utilisation of health data irrespective of Member State, reducing barriers, inconsistencies, administrative bureaucracy and avoiding data localisation. The EHDS needs also to embrace FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable) international principles, with assessment of maturity in interoperability versus applicable standards,  • Adequate public health surveillance: in view of the SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 pandemic, and healthcare in general, it is not tenable for data on healthcare treatment, outcomes, resourcing, costs and value, and experience not to become readily available near real time. Therefore, EHDS systems need to be on top of data capture and interoperability layers to provide as such publicly, as well as for research use by bona fide public and private entities. Linkage with existing networks and programmes, as well as planned, e.g. EU DARWIN, is an imperative • Supporting innovation as an enabler: ensuring EU citizens can access theragnostic innovation, improving outcomes, survival, and longevity, the EHDS needs to enable the development, evaluation, adoption, and utilisation of progress in current therapeutics, digital therapeutics, and AI. Preferably predicated on an egalitarian layer of secondary use of data to meet innovation requirements with appropriate safeguards • EHDS should not be predicated on consent basis: in a mature, transactional system a recognition of the use of health data, whether primary or secondary, is a common, societal good, with appropriate sociotechnical safeguards. An opt out approach would be beneficial, versus a consent or opt in approach regarding use of health data where in the main, individual identity is of no value to any constituent stakeholder for secondary use. This would obviate the need for abstractions such as altruism or donation, which are likely unman

feedback_msg_text: McKesson Europe fully supports the European Commission’s initiative “Digital health data and services – the European health data space”.   We would like to use this opportunity to contribute to the ongoing roadmap consultation and flag areas where EU policy action can further be improved. These concern specifically: Patient electronic health records, e-prescription and general health data sharing among different supply chain players and public bodies.   1. Patient Electronic Health Records (EHR) • European Commission needs to ensure cross-border interoperability of EHRs so that EHRs are accessible by healthcare professionals (incl. pharmacists) across different European countries.  • Any IT framework allowing for exchange of EHRs must be interoperable and accessible between the systems of different healthcare professionals incl. pharmacists at national level. • Any IT framework allowing for exchange of EHR incl. for example development of an app facilitating exchange of EHRs needs to be user friendly allowing HCPs to support patient effectively throughout their journey.  • Any guidelines / rules at the EU  level should focus on achieving minimum essential requirements with regard to semantic, technical, organisational and legal interoperability between different national systems. • Any guidelines / rules at the EU level should focus on promoting security of patient data and enabling the rights of patients to have their health data deleted.    2. e-Prescription (e-Rx) • European Commission needs to insist with the EU MS on the full transition from paper based on e-Rx system by the end of this decade. • European Commission should focus on highlighting the benefits of e-Rx (with focus on time saving and increase in quality and safety) to EU MS to ensure that they adopt e-Rx in a timely manner and communicate e-Rx benefits to public.  • European Commission needs to urge EU MS to include all key HCPs in this communication activity (incl. pharmacists) and ensure that they are trained to properly use the system. • European Commission should facilitate discussions among EU MS and propose minimum technical standards for hardware and software, including data security encryption, interoperability for e-Rx exchange among EU MS. McKesson Europe recommends that this is built on existing IT systems rather than from scratch, and in such a way that stakeholders can talk with each other. • e-prescriptions should be fully linked to Electronic Health Records so that both prescribers and pharmacists can access and update all relevant patient information as required. This must be based on full consent of the patient and fully respect the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation. • e-prescription systems should allow pharmacists to communicate directly with prescribers. • The role of the pharmacist must not be negated or diminished. Community or online pharmacy must remain the dispensing route so that they can provide quality assurance, including services to monitor a patient’s progress, and also act as a point of contact by providing advice on the safe use of medication.  • Lastly, it is critical that there is a solution in place for emergency dispensing in case of any system failure or disturbances, e.g. having access to existing paper prescriptions to allow manual handling or allowing out of hours dispensing in emergency situations.     3. General healthcare data sharing  • Any information sharing needs to be based on GDPR principles and in conformity with the GDPR. • McKesson Europe and full-line healthcare distributors have strong anti-competition concerns with any requirements to share data with other supply chain players. An example of this is the proposal for a regulation on the expanded role EMA which requires manufacturers to incl. data shared by healthcare distributors when reporting shortages to the EMA.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: Sulla proposta di creare uno spazio comune europeo sui dati sanitari, un gruppo di osservatori impegnati politicamente nella formulazione di una nuova proposta politica denominata "Insieme" ( sito web:  www.insieme.per.it ),  che ha tra i suoi valori fondanti una visione europeistica, a favore del consolidamento e dello sviluppo delle istituzioni UE,  presenta all'attenzione della Commissione il seguente commento: "Il partito politico Insieme esprime il suo apprezzamento per la politica adottata dalla Commissione dell’UE di avviare consultazioni pubbliche durante l’iter di formazione di normative comunitarie, e si impegna a diffonderne la conoscenza, ritenendo la consultazione aperta al pubblico un importante strumento di democrazia, e di partecipazione di tutti alla costruzione dell’Europa dei cittadini.  Il trattamento di dati personali in materia sanitaria, nell’ambito dello spazio europeo va regolato tenendo conto delle conseguenze sulle libertà individuali e i diritti umani, tra cui il diritto alla vita privata, il diritto alla salute, il diritto alla pari dignità sociale, e altri diritti umani universamente riconosciuti che sono inviolabili, irrinunciabili, non negoziabili e indivisibili.  L’irrinunciabilità implica che il consenso al trattamento dei dati personali sia informato e libero e non comporti rinuncia di fatto da parte del soggetto interessato.  Vi è una esigenza di garantire la veridicità dei dati sanitari e l’uniformità nello spazio europeo delle modalità di raccolta, di uso e di trattamento degli stessi.  Meccanismi efficienti di controllo e di garanzia devono essere stabiliti nel rispetto dello stato di diritto.  A fronte delle nuove sfide poste dall’Intelligenza Artificiale, occorre un quadro normativo orizzontale che riaffermi i diritti umani già riconosciuti e tutelati nel TUE e riconosca altri diritti inerenti alla persona (DIRITTI UMANI DI QUARTA GENERAZIONE)".  Grazie per l'attenzione.

feedback_msg_text: The European Council of Optometry and Optics (ECOO) supports the objectives of the proposed EHDS. However, achieving these objectives will require significant changes by member states, health authorities and health professionals to ensure consistency of approach, practice and operation.  The EHDS should apply to all health data. It should be accessible to and used by all healthcare professionals, including all primary and secondary healthcare professionals. Optometrists and opticians are providers of primary eye care. As first points of contact for patients with eye health concerns, they will need to be able to access data from and provide input to the EHDS. While it is the ambition of ECOO members to have high quality, regulated optical services mutually recognised across the EU, at present the two professions are treated differently across the Member States – regulated in some but not in others, and with varying scope of practice. The ECOO Blue Book sets this out in detail.   Two examples show why it would benefit patients for optometrists and opticians to be part of the EHDS:  A very a common reason for a patient needing to be able to access their own data (including their prescription), or for another professional to access it on their behalf, when they are travelling (abroad) is that they have lost or damaged their spectacles or contact lenses and need to be able to replace them.  If a person seeks medical help because they have suffered a stroke, have complications arising from diabetes or are experiencing visual problems, data/information about their normal visual condition (visual acuity, contrast, colour vision etc) and previous eye health history can provide important indicators for the health professional treating them.  The definition of healthcare professionals, and how they are regulated, varies between countries. This creates potential problems in determining which professions can access the system. More importantly it raises questions about how to create a genuinely single market in health care: e-health solutions and AI are subject to regulation some member states but not others. The EHDS will need to agree some level of harmonisation, in particular in relation to how data is collected, aggregated and transferred. There will clearly need to be some level of compromise and balance with national regulations and norms.   It will be important that the system created is a simple to use as possible. This will be essential for patients to be able to make use of the it and access their own data, but also for healthcare providers, operating in a variety of different settings and at different scales. The EHDS must not exclude or disadvantage individuals or groups who have limited or no access to technology. This will not only apply to patients. Some professions and/or countries still rely heavily on paper based medical records. It may be necessary to include in the programme mechanisms to support and encourage health professions to move to greater use of digital record keeping. The system will also need to allow for immediate and automatic transfer of data between authorised users to ensure prompt and efficient healthcare can be provided.  Trust is an essential commodity between a healthcare professional and their patients. There will need to be clear and strong public messages about data protection and data sharing. The EHDS system will need to be transparent about what information is collected and stored, who can access it and how, and most importantly how it can be used. People will need to be reassured that data used for policy making and research is properly collected and used, and that it really is anonymised. There should be clear information about the distinctions between patient identifiable data used for healthcare purposes, and anonymised information used for research and policy making purposes. The proposed system must not only meet GDPR data security expectations, it must be seen to do so.
Organisation: European Council of Optometry and Optics
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space
organisation_lower: european council of optometry and optics

feedback_msg_text: En primer lugar, la Asociación Nacional Empresarial de la Industria Farmacéutica en España (Farmaindustria) agradece a la Comisión Europea la apertura del Inception Impact Assessment (IIA) on the forthcoming legislative proposal to create a European Health Data Space (EHDS) La necesaria transformación digital del sistema sanitario se ha puesto de manifiesto durante la reciente crisis de la COVID-19, habiéndose dado un gran impulso a soluciones de e-salud. En este contexto, el Ministerio de Sanidad en España trabaja en el desarrollo de una Estrategia de Salud Digital del SNS en la que se contará con la colaboración de las Comunidades Autónomas y con la participación de otros actores públicos y privados implicados. En esta Estrategia se han de resaltar dos grandes líneas de actuación relacionadas con el asunto de referencia. I) el impulso de la analítica de datos y la explotación de información del SNS con el objetivo de creación de un espacio nacional de datos sobre la salud que apoye y facilite la investigación y el análisis de grandes conjuntos de datos que será herramienta fundamental de la medicina personalizada; II) La segunda línea estratégica de actuación es impulsar la salud digital y la interoperabilidad electrónica de información sanitaria tanto en el ámbito nacional como internacional. En este ámbito resulta fundamental la armonización y trabajos conjuntos con el Espacio Europeo de Datos en Salud. El GDPR incluye determinadas previsiones relacionadas con el tratamiento de datos en el ámbito de la investigación clínica que son concretadas por lo establecido en la legislación española de protección de datos, siendo relevante el contenido sobre tratamiento de datos en el ámbito de la investigación clínica en salud. En efecto, el Espacio Europeo de Datos debe de tener en cuenta el valor de compartir, reutilizar datos para futuras investigaciones biomédica. En este sentido se han de adoptar criterios armonizados que conforme al GPPR y a la legislación nacional permita utilizar datos personales codificados para investigaciones futuras relacionadas sin necesidad de contar con el consentimiento de los participantes, pero siempre que se cumplan una serie de garantías para los pacientes. En particular, el equipo investigador de las investigaciones sucesivas no podrá, en ningún caso, acceder a la información del equipo que llevó a cabo la codificación inicial; deberá suscribir un compromiso de no llevar a cabo ninguna actividad tendente a la re-identificación y habrán de adoptarse medidas de seguridad específicas a dichos efectos. Teniendo en cuenta la especial trascendencia que en el ámbito de la industria farmacéutica tuvo la implementación del Código Tipo, hace más de 10 años, así como las indudables ventajas que la adopción de un sistema de autorregulación presenta para las entidades adheridas, Farmaindustria ha considerado imprescindible llevar a cabo una adaptación del Código Tipo actualmente vigente a las previsiones del GDPR y a la nueva legislación española de protección de datos. Por ello, se ha trabajado activamente en el nuevo Codigo de Conducta de protección de datos en el ámbito de la investigación clínica y la farmacovigilancia, que ofrece máximas garantías para los pacientes, resto de intervientes, y que se encuentra en evaluación por la Agencia Española de Protección de Datos. Asimismo, sería oportuno establecer un Observatorio de Resultados en Salud a nivel de país y en Europa, de acceso público, con indicadores únicos y homogéneos. El observatorio debe facilitar incluir indicadores de estructura, procesos, actividad, desempeño, calidad, valoración de resultados por los pacientes, resultados de enfermedad y costes por proceso. Este Observatorio debe permitir la comparación entre los diferentes servicios, hospitales y unidades asistenciales y avanzar en la mejora de la eficiencia, la calidad de la atención y los resultados en salud que interesan y valoran los pacientes.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: The 'Societal Impact of Pain' (SIP) platform is a multi-stakeholder partnership led by the European Pain Federation (EFIC) and Pain Alliance Europe (PAE). SIP aims to raise awareness of pain and to change pain policies. The scientific framework of the SIP platform is under the responsibility of EFIC, and the strategic direction of the project is defined by both partners.  SIP welcomes the European Commission’s Roadmap for A European Health Data Space, and we have outlined several points for the Commission to consider for inclusion in future iterations of the initiative. See our full response here: https://www.sip-platform.eu/resources/details/sip-response-to-the-european-commission-s-roadmap-for-a-european-health-data-space  SIP takes particular note of Objective 1: Ensuring access, sharing and use of health data for healthcare delivery purposes as well as re-use for research and innovation, policy-making and regulatory activities, in a privacy-preserving, secure, transparent and trustworthy way:  In terms of exchange of health data, interoperability, and health systems performance and improvement, SIP asks the Commission to ensure that the future policy and regulatory environment permits and promotes tools to develop, share, and measure data on pain and its societal impact.  Moreover, SIP calls on the Commission to ensure that the initiative includes:  1) Provisions to permit EU institutions and national governments to develop, share, and implement instruments to assess the societal impact of pain, namely, instruments to assess pain as a quality indicator within European health systems. As scientists, healthcare professionals, and patients in the pain field have identified various measurements and quality indicators which can help us better understand the societal impact of pain, including patient reported outcome measurements (PROMs) which could become a realistic aspect of electronic health records (EHRs). According to experts in the field, ICD-11 and ICF will not only contribute to the transformation of healthcare in the context of the Digital Single Market, but it will also be an important first step towards the practical roll out of the classification of chronic pain for morbidity documentation and health policy purposes (as embedded in ICD-11). This will enhance reporting in research by providing more precise definitions and would facilitate patient management through standardisation using these WHO classifications.  2) Provisions to allow European health systems to exchange cross border data on pain measurement (via standardised EHRs and/or common tools).Considering how the digital health infrastructure could benefit chronic pain patients is a key question. EHRs, for example, if standardised, should consider pain measurement. This is key to achieve comprehensive and resilient health systems. Digital technologies in health should be better prepared to provide remote care when and where needed in case of a crisis (such as COVID-19). Moreover, as stated in Article 8 of Directive 2011/24/EU, prior authorisation of cross-border healthcare should be based upon the degree of the patient’s pain. Pain measurement is therefore a legal imperative as defined in EU law. Cross-border healthcare may become increasingly important as Europe seeks ways to manage the burden upon their health systems caused by shocks such as COVID-19.  3) Provisions to ensure healthcare professionals and patients receive education and training on digital technologies as part of the educational curricula and training (via promoting access to education). As we transition to more digitalised healthcare systems, the healthcare sector (professionals and patients alike) will need to acquire new skills to use emerging digital health technologies. Member States should have access to the necessary education and training resources to establish integrated models of care and interdisciplinary teams that are known to aid treatment of conditions such as chronic pain.  Feedback from: European Pain Federation EFIC (324.2 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: Die Initiative der Kommission ist zu begrüßen. Insbesondere dann, wenn in den weiteren Ausbaustufen - über die Patientenperspektive hinaus - bei der Entwicklung des Handlungsrahmens ein friktionsfreier, strukturierter und semantisch interoperabler Austausch von Informationen auch auf die Perspektive der den Behandlungsprozess tragenden Ärztinnen und Ärzte erweitert wird. Sinnvoll sind insbesondere solche Maßnahmen, die geeignet sind, bestehende nationale Ansätze zu unterstützen und zu beschleunigen, mit denen Informationen zwischen allen am Behandlungsprozess beteiligten professionellen Berufsgruppen system- und einrichtungsübergreifend friktionsfrei ausgetauscht werden können und damit die Grundlage dafür zu legen, den Informationsaustausch auch über Ländergrenzen hinweg möglich zu machen.  Für eine weitere Steigerung der Qualität der Informationssysteme und zur Beförderung eines Wettbewerbs zwischen den einzelnen Anbietern dieser Systeme ist es darüber hinaus sinnvoll, im Rahmen der Initiative geeignete Maßnahmen in den Blick zu nehmen und zu entwickeln, die geeignet sind, die Möglichkeiten zu erweitern, mit denen die professionellen Anwender das für ihre Anwendungsperspektive leistungsfähigste und benutzerfreundliche Informationssystem nutzen und im Bedarfsfall einen aufwandsarmen, friktionsfreien und ohne Datenverluste versehenen Wechsel ihres Anbieters realisieren können.
Initiative: Digital health data and services – the European health data space

feedback_msg_text: GS1 Healthcare is a healthcare-specific, global user group bringing together both large and small healthcare stakeholders: pharmaceutical and medical device manufacturers, wholesalers and distributors, group purchasing organisations, hospitals, pharmacies, logistic and solution-providers, governmental and regulatory bodies and industry associations.   GS1 Healthcare has the mission to increase patient safety, drive supply chain efficiencies, improve the traceability of medicines and accurate data synchronisation in healthcare. We believe worldwide patient safety and supply chain efficiencies will be enhanced globally through a common approach for AIDC (Automatic Identification and Data Capture), global data synchronisation and traceability. We further are engaged in global harmonisation work for medicinal product identification (IDMP), as well as in the SPOR task force, the EU-UNICOM project and have a close collaboration with the WHO Collaborating Centre for International Drug Monitoring in Uppsala.  We believe harmonised implementation of an automatic identification (i.e. AIDC) via barcodes using global open standards throughout the entire Healthcare supply chain, right to the point of delivery to the patient, is an extremely effective tool in preventing medication errors and brings economic benefits reducing medication errors, preventing counterfeiting, saving costs and increasing the Healthcare supply chain efficiency and transparency.

feedback_msg_text: L'association 'Pierres et Marbres de Wallonie' a été créée en 1990 pour promouvoir les ressources minérales de la Wallonie. Dès 1999, elle a obtenu une Appellation d'origine locale 'Pierre bleue' (http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/cgi_loi/loi_a.pl) pour mettre en avant les relations étroites entre terroirs géologiques, géographiques et humains, avec la force incomparable d'une tradition plusieurs fois millénaire d'utilisation de la pierre. Cette qualité exceptionnelle a été reconnue en 2017 au niveau international quand cette même 'pierre bleue' a été admise par le projet Global Heritage Stone Resource parmi les rares 'pierres de l'humanité'. De façon plus proche du citoyen, l'association a fait enregistrer en 2016 pour le Benelux une marque collective 'Pierre locale', accompagnée d'un logo, qui constituent une garantie aisément reconnaissable pour l'utilisateur potentiel qu'il est en face d'un produit lithique original et naturel, extrait d'un gisement régional et façonné dans un atelier de proximité, en un circuit très court, peu impactant d'un point de vue environnemental et parfaitement respectueux de toutes les contraintes sociales et éthiques. La très longue tradition d'usage se traduit par une parfaite maîtrise de la sélection au cours du protocole de transformation et par une connaissance très approfondie des caractères physiques et mécaniques du matériau. Le développement de filières structurées d'Indications géographiques au niveau européen permettra d'intégrer ces produits hautement traditionnels mais toujours très contemporains dans une démarche globale de reconnaissance de l'excellence liée à cette longue aventure humaine. Par rapport aux produits manufacturés d'imitation et aux éléments importés de pays lointains, présentés rapidement comme des équivalents, les productions régionales bénéficieront d'une protection intéressante de leur image de marque. Si ces Indications géographiques peuvent être utilisées dans les prescriptions liées aux marchés publics, comme garantes d'une qualité intrinsèque que de multiples références authentifient, ces indications constitueront un argument important pour pondérer l'influence de différentiels de coûts, évidemment favorables aux succédanés bon marché. Dotées en plus de dimensions culturelles et patrimoniales évidentes, ces indications pourront être valorisées dans le cadre d'une stratégie concertée de développement touristique durable, résolument orienté vers les valeurs de terroirs et de proximité. Bref, une initiative très importante, qui se révélera gagnante sur tous les tableaux et permettra de doper l'emploi local, en favorisant une nécessaire réindustrialisation de notre société occidentale - bien indispensable, comme l'ont à nouveau souligné toutes les crises récentes. Donc, oui, un vibrant intérêt pour ces 'Indications géographiques' non-agro-alimentaires !
Organisation: Pierres et Marbres de Wallonie ASBL
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: I would like to make a submission in support of GI recognition for Connemara marble. Connemara marble is a unique stone found only in County Galway in the West of Ireland. There are five marble quarries. The marble contains unique banding that varies from light, dark green, Sepia and white. The beautiful green colours in the marble are often referred to as Irish Jade, and as such, it is recognised as Ireland’s national gem stone. Connemara marble is currently being proposed as a Global Heritage Stone Resource.  The first practical usage of Connemara marble dates back to the Neolithic period where it can be found in stone axes. Commercial use of the marble commenced at the Streamstown Marble quarry, Clifden, in the early 1820s. The marble was used as a decorative stone and can be seen in many important public buildings in Ireland, Britain and the USA.  During the 19th century the marble’s use in Jewellery and souvenirs made it one of Ireland’s most popular gift items and today it is recognised as one of Irelands oldest Indigenous Industries.  Connemara Marble Industries Ltd. is a family business established in 1962.  We operate from our factory and Visitor Centre at Moycullen Co. Galway and at the Streamstown quarry Clifden, Co. Galway. We have 24 employees. Our Company owns the Streamstown marble quarry and the Cregg marble quarry. We are Ireland’s largest manufacturer of Connemara marble jewellery and gift items made in Ireland.  In recent years, due to the outsourcing to third world countries, many of Ireland’s craft Industries have closed, with local crafts people being made redundant and much of the craft and ‘know how’ forgotten. There appears to be an acceptance that if a product is “designed in Ireland” it is okay to call it Irish.  In considering a GI protection for Connemara marble, I believe that the raw material should be genuine Connemara marble, and that the manufacturing of the product should be from the geographical area, Ireland.  Yours sincerely, Ambrose Joyce. Connemara Marble Industries Ltd.,
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: The Confederation of Danish Industry (Dansk Industri) welcomes the opportunity to submit comments on the Commission’s IP Action Plan. feedback_msg_text: The Asociación de Empresarios del Mármol de Andalucía – AEMA by its initials in Spanish, (Andalusian Marble Industry Association) is a non-profit organization that acts as a mediating instrument for all that concerns the natural stone activity in the region of Andalusia, Spain.  Among its actions, it works for the development and marketing of the sector with the aim of positioning the Macael Marble Brand in the architecture and design markets.  Our marble region in an important transformation center of natural stone in Spain that focuses its activity, not only on the extraction of local materials, but also, on the production of all types of natural stone from all around the world. It has a long tradition and know how that we must to protect and promote. Thus, this European Commission work, about the GI protection for non-agricultural products, with the objective of applying a protection system at European level to its members States, is successfully welcome.   From our point of view, the European intervention about the GI protection for non-agricultural products has multiple advantages:   • It lends value to the lands’ products, which represent the traditions and specific and unique characteristics of each region, as well as, the historical-cultural aspects and trades consolidated over time. Such improvement would also have a positive impact on tourism, -which combines the natural heritage and the territory’s excellence-, and on the new jobs’ creation, as a result of a possible increased demand.  • It protects the consumer, who will be able to count on a wider range of European products and make more informed choices.  • It would prevent unfair competition, misuse and falsification of products, guaranteeing traceability and quality. It would also protect products on the domestic market and on non-European markets where there may be safer commercialization, both for the consumer, and for the producer. Specifically, in our case, it would help us to avoid the unfair competition that we have from other markets at an international level. This would lend value to our local materials, which are characterized by excellent physical-mechanical properties.   • It would favor the internationalization of European products by the new markets’ penetration.   • It would solve the existing problems around the use of the trademark that, unlike the creation of a GI protection, does not allow producers of industrial and artisan products, to certify the link between quality and geographical origin.  The Asociación de Empresarios del Mármol de Andalucía – AEMA, for all the above, considers that it is essential to have a GI protection for non-agricultural products, which includes:  • The establishment of unique system at European level in order to avoid the excessive extension of the time required by harmonization.   • Since this is a voluntary system, it is necessary to give businesses the possibility of using this instrument immediately.   • The scope of protection for non-agricultural geographical indications should follow a sectoral approach, establishing specific rules for all the different product categories.  • Regarding to the production specifications, focused on describing the product essential and specific characteristics and its production process, in order to obtain the GI, without prejudice to the guarantee of product quality, there must be flexibility for further innovation in both, the production process and the product. The specification must allow possible improvements in production. Feedback from: ASOCIACIÓN DE EMPRESARIOS DEL MÁRMOL DE ANDALUCÍA (371.1 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: In a future driven by technology supply chain data is be one of the most a valuable assets and therefore must be protected. A digitally powered system of governance is needed for the management of GI data and to enable the sharing of authentic information between supply chain actors, from producer to consumer.  Foodchain S.p.A. is active in the blockchain technology field and see the potential to use blockchain to build the foundation of a uniform system that includes a grid of accountable autonomous entities, identified by the system through self-sovereign identities (SSI), that facilitates the role of governments of intermediating supply chains relationships via a transparent and collaborative public consensus.  In addition, blockchain-based applications placed at the core of a business structure enables the creation of new decentralised business models that have the potential to redefine economy. In a data driven system, a bottom up approach will give ownership of information to the actors that really create value within the supply chain to boost local production through authenticity of information and create new business opportunities.
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: Our company is located in a small seaside village on the north west coast of Donegal. We have been weaving Donegal tweed on this site since 1953. We are very much in favor of GI protection for Non-agri products.  Over the years the term Donegal Tweed has been used by weavers all around the world despite them having no connection or any part of their supply chain originating in Donegal.  This counterfeiting has undermined the ability of genuine Donegal tweed producers to survive.  Intellectual property protection under proposed new EU Geographic Indication schemes could provide essential protection and recognition for Donegal Tweed and other SMES in the craft and giftware industry across Europe which are a critical part of rural economies and help preserve local employment in many regions who are under threat from copying and counterfeiting. i believe the proposed new GI scheme for non-Agri products will provide consumers and tourists with a unique range of quality European fabrics and craft products which guarantees their authenticity, origin and traditional methods of production. William Mc Nutt.  Mc Nutts OF Donegal ltd.
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: Desde la Fundación Centro Nacional del Vidrio / Real Fábrica de Cristales de La Granja damos la bienvenida a este tipo de iniciativas ya que creemos que la creación de un sistema de protección específico para los productos de origen no agrícola se hace necesaria desde varios puntos de vista. En concreto pensamos que este sistema gira en torno a cuatro pilares básicos: a) Respeto histórico: existen zonas, como es el caso de nuestra región, que están indisolublemente unidas al desarrollo de las manufacturas artesanales del vidrio, desde hace tres siglos. La etiqueta “IIGGPNA” vendría a poner en valor esta historia, que a veces pasa desapercibida y fomentaría el interés histórico y la necesidad de conservación de este patrimonio singular. Somos conscientes, de que como en nuestro caso, otras regiones verían impulsados de manera indirecta, con la concesión de esta etiqueta, tanto en el sector turístico, como en el tejido empresarial de la zona. Normalmente estas zonas productivas se encuentran en entornos rurales, por lo que se ayudaría a evitar la despoblación.  b) Valoración cultural: la forma de entender o ver la vida de las regiones que están fuertemente unidas a la realización de un producto no agrícola, depende de esas tradiciones conservadas durante generaciones. La etiqueta “IIGGPNA” consolidaría esas tradiciones, en vistas a conservarla,  transmitirla y asegurar su continuidad en el tiempo. La globalización, ha traído consigo el olvido de estas tradiciones y la pérdida de valoración por parte del público de una manera de hacer las cosas, diferente a la inmediatez y rapidez que exigen los mercados actuales. Este tipo de iniciativas ponen el énfasis en el saber hacer y posibilitan (dando visibilidad) el mantenimiento de estas industrias tradicionales. La industria cultural es un elemento dinamizador que permite el desarrollo económico de una región.  c) Acción formativa: La etiqueta “IIGGPNA” ratificaría que el saber hacer, traspasado de generación en generación es digno de ser enseñado, ya sea de manera reglada o no, añadiendo a la zona geográfica en cuestión, un interés formativo, fomentando la creación de empleo en otras áreas económicas de la región. Esta formación garantiza la transmisión del conocimiento de las técnicas y de los recursos de unas generaciones a otras, y su pervivencia en el futuro. Además esta denominación ofrecería una garantía de la calidad y excelencia formativa. La concesión de estas etiquetas ayudaría a que los estados miembros fomentaran la creación de “Centros de Referencia” encargados de la impartición, innovación, investigación y certificación oficial en las materias correspondientes.  d) Visibilidad económica: Sin lugar a dudas, la etiqueta “IIGGPNA” supondría un espaldarazo y una proyección, a nivel nacional e internacional, del producto afectado por esta denominación. Benefician al productor, ya que su producto queda destacado sobre otros, con una etiqueta de calidad. Además, al establecerse unos estándares de calidad, estos ayudarían al crecimiento del producto manufacturado de manera artesanal. Por otra parte, la posibilidad de localizar varias zonas que trabajen el mismo producto, pero con diferentes técnicas y resultados, podría favorecer la competencia en igualdad de condiciones y un enriquecimiento mutuo. Y por otro lado benefician también al consumidor, ya que la etiqueta “IIGGPNA” conllevaría consigo una vigilancia de posibles fraudes, ayudando a la hora de adquirir un producto. Esta iniciativa respalda también la necesidad de la creación de una “Marca Registrada”. Como hemos señalado antes, los beneficios económicos no solo recaerían sobre el producto “IIGGPNA”, sino sobre otros sectores económicos de la región turístico, formativo y cultural.  P.D.: Nos gustaría señalar por último la  importancia que tuvieron las Manufacturas Reales creadas por Felipe V para las regiones en las que estaban instaladas. Por ello pensamos que a la hora de estudiar la implantación del si

feedback_msg_text: The Association of Swedish Patent Attorneys (SPOF) , being the Swedish association of patent engineers, design attorneys, trademark attorneys and IP lawyers at Sweden’s leading private practice IP firms, welcomes this opportunity to comment on the topic EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products.  It is important to have in mind that there are differences between agri and non-agri GIs, meaning that the need and use of agri GI protection cannot be used analogously with the idea of creating and improving non-agri GIs.  The Action Plan shall therefore, as a first step, be used to make an overview of the existing agri GI protection, with the goal to make sure that this existing system is also used and in force in the same way in all Member States.  Such overview shall include a possibility to organize and create a centralized authority for legal actions and investigations.  Once an improved agri GI protection is in place, a second step can be to revisit the idea of expanding into non-agri GIs.   Read more in our attached feedback. feedback_msg_text: QUI SOMMES-NOUS ?  Nous sommes le référent et le partenaire économique des entreprises de la branche ameublement, aménagement et décoration, basées en Région Grand Est. Nous les accompagnons vers l’excellence en réalisant des actions collectives et mutualisées dans de nombreux domaines (innovation, compétitivité, commercial, marketing, formation, promotion, communication, …). A ce titre, nous avons obtenu la 1ère Indication Géographique dédiée aux produits industriels et artisanaux, à savoir « Siège de Liffol ».  NOTRE DEMANDE  Nous demandons la mise en place d’une règlementation européenne harmonisée, protégeant les IG non agricoles, produits identitaires de nos territoires et générateurs d’emplois.  Les produits de nos territoires, s’ils sont artisanaux ou industriels ne peuvent se protéger correctement au sein de l’UE. Grâce à la mise en place des IG et au regard de leurs impacts bénéfiques bien connus sur le territoire de l’UE, des délocalisations pourraient être évitées ainsi que la désertification de certaines zones rurales, les filières pourraient disposer d’outils juridiques plus performants pour se protéger. Enfin, les consommateurs pourraient enfin avoir un vrai dispositif public de garantie des informations et des valeurs sur les produits artisanaux, ce qui n’existe pas aujourd’hui et laisse la porte ouverte à de nombreuses tromperies.   Le dispositif français s’est largement inspiré des règlementations des AOP/IGP pour les produits agricoles et agro-alimentaires. Il serait nécessaire, dans la mesure du possible, de privilégier une approche harmonisée entre les différents régimes : - sur le contenu du cahier des charges : il y a un besoin de transparence vis-à-vis des consommateurs sur les produits non agricoles car les secteurs concernés sont victimes de nombreuses tromperies. - sur les contrôles : la certification doit être privilégiée. Elle n’est pas onéreuse et permet de garantir un contrôle extérieur et indépendant. - sur la protection : les règles doivent être identiques pour que les produits et fabricants puissent être correctement protégés.  - sur les groupements porteurs de l’IG : leur donner un rôle fort pour la gestion et la protection de l’IG.  Nos IG ne sont protégées qu’en France alors que nos entreprises ont des marchés en Europe et à l’international. Cette protection n’est pas suffisante pour garantir une protection suffisante de nos entreprises. Nous constatons, depuis la reconnaissance de nos IG, un accroissement de la visibilité de nos produits, une amélioration de la situation vis-à-vis des contrefaçons et un développement de l’intérêt des consommateurs pour nos produits et nos territoires, notamment à travers le tourisme industriel. Faute d’une protection européenne, nous assistons au développement de « labels » privés dont les contours sont très flous et qui souhaitent jouer sur l’origine pour tromper les consommateurs.
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: LAINAMAC, association de filière, a été créée en 2009 avec l’objectif de structurer, développer et promouvoir la laine dans ses dimensions à la fois économique, agricole et touristique, à l’échelle de la Nouvelle Aquitaine et du Massif Central. Elle est implantée à Felletin, dans le Sud du département de la Creuse, au cœur d’une région historique, où cohabite toute une communauté professionnelle, héritière multiséculaire du tapis et de la tapisserie d’Aubusson.  Le pôle textile historique d’Aubusson-Felletin est le seul centre de production de tapisserie privé ayant produit sans interruption depuis cinq siècles. Ses produits sont protégés depuis 2018 par deux Indications Géographiques : « Tapis d’Aubusson » et « Tapisserie d’Aubusson », pour lesquelles LAINAMAC joue le rôle d’Organisme de défense et de gestion.  Nous demandons la mise en place d’une règlementation européenne harmonisée, protégeant les IG non agricoles, produits identitaires de nos territoires et générateurs d’emplois. Nos IG ne sont protégées qu’en France alors que les entreprises produisant des tapis et tapisseries d'Aubusson ont pour une grande partie des marchés en Europe et à l’international. Cela ne suffit pas à garantir une bonne protection de nos entreprises et de leurs produits. Le dispositif français s’est inspiré des règlementations des AOP/IGP pour les produits agricoles et agro-alimentaires. Il serait nécessaire, dans la mesure du possible, de privilégier une approche harmonisée entre les différents régimes.
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: una Politica europea armonizzata relativa al “know-how tradizionale”, costituito principalmente da micro e piccole imprese, nell’ambito di un’Indicazione Geografica, rappresenterebbe il potenziamento dello sviluppo e del consolidamento dell’intera catena del valore collegata al territorio, alle produzioni di eccellenza già esistenti (ad esempio quelle alimentari DOP e/o IGP). A livello internazionale, rafforzerebbe gli strumenti di contrasto della contraffazione e delle pratiche sleali, per una maggiore competitività sul Mercato Interno e sui mercati extra-europei.  CNA ass. di Livorno  valuta molto positivamente l’ipotesi di creazione di un sistema di protezione delle IG dell’UE efficiente e trasparente per i prodotti non agricoli da parte della Commissione europea che permetta di:  - Definire un sistema armonizzato di protezione delle IG dell’UE per i prodotti non agricoli consentirebbe di beneficiare appieno delle opportunità offerte dal sistema internazionale della legge di Ginevra per la registrazione internazionale delle denominazioni di origine e delle indicazioni geografiche gestite dall’Organizzazione mondiale della proprietà intellettuale;  - Valorizzare i prodotti del territorio che spesso rappresentano tradizioni e caratteristiche specifiche e uniche delle singole Regioni, aspetti storico-culturali e mestieri consolidatati nel tempo. Tale valorizzazione avrebbe una ricaduta positiva sul turismo che combina il patrimonio naturale con le eccellenze del territorio;  - Tutelare il consumatore che potrà contare su una gamma di prodotti europei più ampia e scegliere in modo più consapevole, certo che la produzione avvenga realmente nell’UE con una forte caratterizzazione locale (I vantaggi dei livelli di protezione IGP e DOP ad esempio sono evidenti);

feedback_msg_text: CONTRIBUTION DE L’ASSOCIATION PIERRE DE BOURGOGNE À LA CONSULTATION DE LA COMMISSION EUROPEENNE SUR LA PROTECTION DES IG POUR LES PRODUITS NON AGRICOLES AU SEIN DE L’UNION EUROPENNE  L’association Pierre de Bourgogne fait la promotion de la pierre de Bourgogne, mène des actions collectives, et regroupe une trentaine d’entreprises de la filière « Pierre de Bourgogne », de toutes les tailles, majoritairement des TPE, avec quelques PME, dont l’une compte 140 salariés. Les artisans et artistes travaillant seuls ou avec un apprenti, sont également nombreux à utiliser ce matériaux très renommé.  Les entreprises de la filière sont majoritairement situées en zone rurale. Elles permettent d’employer la population locale et compte de nombreuses entreprises familiales au savoir-faire ancestral.    La filière de la Pierre de Bourgogne, à travers l’association, est engagée depuis 2012 dans la demande d’extension de l’indication géographique aux produits industriels et artisanaux.  En effet, face à une recrudescence de copies, malfaçons, ou utilisations abusives de l’appellation « Pierre de Bourgogne » pour des produits qui n’en sont pas, obtenir une protection juridique forte devenait nécessaire.   L’Indication Géographique « Pierre de Bourgogne » a été homologuée par l’INPI le 29 juin 2018 et l’association Pierre de Bourgogne en est devenu l’Organisme de Défense et de Gestion.  Deux ans après l’homologation les retombées sont très positives puisque nous avons pu contraindre des dizaines d’entreprises d’arrêter d’appeler « Pierre de Bourgogne », leurs produits en céramique, travertin, ou encore pierre reconstituée.  Cela a permis d’épurer le marché, et nous continuerons ce travail de veille afin que les consommateurs ne soient plus trompés, que la filière soit structurée et les produits valorisés à travers une meilleure traçabilité.    Néanmoins, ces problèmes de malfaçons et publicités mensongères dépassent les frontières françaises et des entreprises européennes n’hésitent pas à appeler leurs produits « Pierre de Bourgogne » alors qu’ils n’en sont pas.  A l’échelle nationale il nous serait facile de les en empêcher mais, les IGNA n’étant pas reconnues au niveau européen, nos efforts restent vains dans les autres pays de l’UE. Les entreprises de la filière pierre de Bourgogne sont nombreuses à exporter en Europe et dans le monde. La mise en place d’un système de protection européen pour les IGNA est donc indispensable afin que les produits certifiés soient protégés sur les marchés à l’international.   Aujourd’hui, nous avons besoin que les IG non agricoles françaises et européennes disposent d’une protection commune à l’échelle de l’Union Européenne.  Cette réglementation européenne pour les IGNA permettra d’harmoniser le système de de protection et d’éviter aux IG non agricoles homologuées de réclamer la protection dans chaque pays de l’UE.  Les produits pourront ainsi être intégrés dans les listes d’IG annexées à certains accords commerciaux, et les entreprises protégées des abus existants.  Les IGNA sont une formidable occasion de protéger et valoriser des produits à haute valeur ajoutée, créateurs d’une véritable dynamique économique sur les territoires ruraux, en y préservant notamment l’emploi et un savoir-faire spécifique.   La Bourgogne est mondialement renommée pour ses vins. Nous attendons aujourd’hui que les produits en pierre naturelle de Bourgogne disposent de la même protection que les appellations viticoles.
