feedback_msg_text: I believe it will be difficult to register Donegal Tweed as a GI as this a term that has been used the world over for many years. (The flecked yarn that gives a “Donegal Tweed” it’s distinctive character was almost certainly originally developed in Yorkshire, to emulate a Hand spun and Hand Woven cloth which was produced along west coast of Ireland and particularly in Donegal as a local indigenous tweed cloth - I believe the newly developed fleck yarns and the cloths then produced from them, were termed in the trade over a hundred and fifty years ago as “Donegal’s” to market them. While obviously they were an industrial copy or emulation of a regional product they were not necessarily made in Donegal.)  However should “Donegal Tweed” be registered successfully as a GI then it will be good, but to make real use of it will also mean that clear country of origin will have to be implemented as otherwise the term will be abused by big businesses masquerading as small craft businesses to provide cover for garments and products they make abroad that they want to present to the retail customers as Irish. So for example when a garment is tailored abroad then the name of the country in which it is made should be displayed on the label - rather than labelling it loosely as woven in Donegal or made from “Donegal Tweed” - to distract from the fact that it has not been made or tailored here in Donegal or Ireland. Honesty I have always believed is the best policy - rather than using semantics to side step country of origin and the probable use of cheap labour, all of which in my opinion leads to a race to the bottom.  Likewise there needs to be a clear differentiation between Donegal Tweed which has been Hand Woven on traditional wooden looms by skilled weavers with generations of knowledge and big industry which is weaving cloth that is turned out on modern high production industrial machinery - which certainly requires a skill - but has no relevance to a craft industry.  Questions that need to be asked are for example; 1) What is going to qualify as a Donegal Tweed if the term is registered as a GI? 2) What is the fibre content going to be - ie is it going to local Irish wool or softer wools as the market demands? 3) Is it going to be 100% pure new wool or will there be toleration of man made fibre maybe 1% to 5% where a decorative effect is being produced with the incorporation of a fancy spun yarn.  4) What regions will be able to produce “Donegal Tweed” - for example someone in Donegal getting cloth woven in Tipperary, Dublin, Kerry or Yorkshire for their clothing range - will they be able to label it as a “Donegal Tweed”? 5) Will the use or incorporation of a yarn spun in Donegal in a cloth be enough for it to be classed as a “Donegal Tweed” under the terms of GI registration? 6) Who will police the use of the term “Donegal Tweed” if it is registered as a GI? Finally as you can see there are many questions and points which need to be considered in registering “Donegal Tweed as a GI. Even a brief look at a book called Textile Terms and Conditions published by The Textile Institute will verify much of what I have said above.
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: Alentejo Region (Portugal PT18), hereby represented by its Permanent Representation to the EU in Brussels, supports European Commission’s efforts to establish a European system for the recognition and protection of non-agricultural GIs. Alentejo is the largest Portuguese region with a territorial area equivalent to about 31.500 Km2, corresponding to approximately one-third of the country's territory and 711.950 inhabitants (2018, INE). Traditionally the region has been considered a rural territory. Over the past decades, the region has undergone an average negative population growth rate, which makes Alentejo a low-density region. However, the region is boosting R&I and R&D initiatives on regional territory and new trends have emerged in the regional economy. Alentejo recognises that GIs for non-agricultural products may contribute to unlocking excellence in local territories as it would be functioning as a scheme needed for guaranteeing the correspondence of the reputation of a local product to its quality and characteristics. This quality scheme would underline the exclusive relationship between a product and its place of origin to the specificities of the local environment, natural characteristics, and the local know how. In a globalized world, there is an increasingly close relationship between economic and traditional factors, where the circulation of goods and people promote multiculturalism, new and cross-cultural identities, it is, therefore, essential to look and identify the particularities, the diversities, and differences to mark local identities. Now more than ever Europe needs to establish the EU system for the recognition and protection of non-agricultural GIs for safeguarding the difference, the specificity, and the identity of local communities. Alentejo, for instance, is an innovative region full of traditions: music, handicraft (pottery and painting), clothing (Read more in the file attached)
Organisation: Alentejo regional representation to the EU
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: CONTRIBUTION DE L’ASSOCIATION IG PORCELAINE DE LIMOGES  À LA CONSULTATION DE LA COMMISSION EUROPEENNE  SUR LA PROTECTION DES IG POUR LES PRODUITS NON AGRICOLES  AU SEIN DE L’UNION EUROPENNE  L’association IG Porcelaine de Limoges assure la gestion, la protection et la promotion de l’IG Porcelaine de Limoges. Elle regroupe à ce jour 36 membres opérateurs, des entreprises de toutes les tailles majoritairement des TPE, soutenues par 19 membres associés.  Ces entreprises sont majoritairement situées en zone péri urbaine autour de Limoges ou rurale dans l’aire géographique de l’IG, qui est le département de la Haute-Vienne. Elles détiennent des savoir-faire d’exception et emblématiques liés à la fabrication et à la décoration de la porcelaine de Limoges, dont l’ancrage local des emplois, contribue à l’attractivité économique du territoire. Créée en avril 2014, l’association s’est positionnée en faveur du dispositif de l’Indication Géographique pour les produits industriels et artisanaux afin d’obtenir une protection pérenne de l’appellation « Porcelaine de Limoges » et de lutter contre les utilisations abusives. L’IG « Porcelaine de Limoges » a été homologuée par une décision de de l’INPI du 14 novembre 2017 et l’association en est devenue l’Organisme de Défense et de Gestion. Seuls les produits en porcelaine entièrement manufacturés, c’est-à-dire fabriqués et décorés dans la zone géographique (le département de la Haute-Vienne), qui respectent le cahier des charges de l’IG, sont couverts par l’IG et peuvent bénéficier de l’appellation « Porcelaine de Limoges ». Plus de 3 ans après l’homologation, les retombées sont très positives puisque 36 professionnels ont obtenu leur certification IG Porcelaine de Limoges et que plusieurs interventions ont été réalisées permettant de mettre un terme à des utilisations abusives de l’appellation. Le travail de veille mené par l’association est essentiel afin que les consommateurs ne soient pas trompés, que la filière soit structurée et que les produits soient valorisés. A ce stade, s’il est bien possible d’agir au niveau national, néanmoins tant que les IGNA ne sont pas reconnues au niveau européen, il s’avère impossible d’agir dans les autres pays, alors que la porcelaine de Limoges est exportée dans le monde entier, où des professionnels peu scrupuleux tentent de bénéficier de sa renommée par des pratiques commerciales trompeuses. C’est pourquoi, la mise en place d’un système de protection européen pour les IGNA est indispensable afin que nos produits certifiés IG soient à juste titre protégés sur les marchés européens et internationaux. Il est urgent que les IG Non Agricoles françaises et européennes disposent d’une protection commune à l’échelle de l’Union Européenne. Une réglementation européenne permettra d’harmoniser le système de protection et d’éviter aux IG non agricoles homologuées de réclamer la protection dans chaque pays de l’UE. Les produits pourront ainsi être intégrés dans les listes d’IG annexées à certains accords commerciaux.  Les IGNA sont un formidable outil de protection et de valorisation des produits emblématiques à haute valeur ajoutée, créateurs d’une véritable dynamique économique sur les territoires ruraux, qui contribuent au maintien de l’emploi local et des savoir-faire spécifiques. La Porcelaine de Limoges dispose d’une renommée internationale, qui doit être protégée au niveau européen, dans le cadre d’un dispositif égal à celui des IGP accordées aux produits agroalimentaires. feedback_msg_text: In line with its 20 years efforts to ensure sustainability and diversification of EU island’s economies, INSULEUR gives its full support to this proposal for regulation of EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products.  Indeed, the endemic fragility of islands which have been further severely hit by the pandemic, led to a significant reduction in their economic activity and Gross Domestic Product (GDP), and a substantial increase in unemployment, making them the ones suffering some of the most severe economic setbacks and therefore revealing even more the continued/growing presence of regional and intraregional inequalities, affecting the economies and the development of insular regions.   Therefore, such initiative would not only indeed help boost insular economies and insular producers stay competitive but would also: - Secure that Europe's traditional knowledge and cultural heritage does not vanish over time due to international competition of (misleadingly) similarly branded products in third non-EU countries - Secure jobs and empower the youth in particular that tend to leave the islands by giving them the incentive to be part of a potentially flourishing market as well as increased opportunities of professional development. - Ensure diversification of islands economies by giving them the opportunity to stay productive and competitive beyond the traditional touristic period of the year.   Over the past years, EU islands gained significant recognition and economic benefits from their PGI and PDO agri-food products as well as a prominent place on the international gastronomic scene. INSULEUR strongly believes that Handicraft and industrial goods deserve the same approach. To mention only a few of these insular non-agricultiral products: Kalymnos sponges (GR), Sifnos ceramics (GR), Lesvos soap (GR), Pag lace (HR), Murano glass (IT), Paros marble (GR), Corsican oeil de sainte lucie stone jewellery (FR), Majorcan albarcas hemp shoes (ES), Kithira Sempre Viva flower bouquets (GR), Burano lace (IT), Balearic pearl and jewelry industry (ES),  Majorcan Robes de Llengües  fabrics (ES), Tinos Volakas baskets (GR) etc.
Organisation: Network of the Insular Chambers of Commerce and Industry of the European Union -INSULEUR
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: Le Bureau National Interprofessionnel du Cognac (BNIC) représente et défend les intérêts collectifs des professionnels de la filière Cognac (viticulteurs et négociants). Sa vocation première est la protection de l’appellation d’origine contrôlée(AOC)/indication géographique (IG) Cognac et le développement économique de la filière.  Depuis sa création en 1946, le BNIC est investi d’une mission de service public, pour le compte de la douane française, au titre de laquelle il contrôle les expéditions de Cognac, tient les comptes de vieillissement et délivre des certificats Cognac. Reconnu ensuite en tant qu’organisme de défense et de gestion (ODG) en 2010, le BNIC contrôle et garantit également le respect du Cahier des Charges de l’Appellation, grâce à la mise en œuvre d’un plan de contrôle.  L’une des principales missions du BNIC est de promouvoir et défendre l’IG Cognac, patrimoine commun à l’ensemble de la filière, au sein de l’Union Européenne (UE) mais également sur les différents marchés d’exportation pour le Cognac.  Dans le contexte actuel, la protection des IG non agricoles au sein de l'Union Européenne est devenue cruciale pour soutenir le développement et la protection des IG (de manière générale) à l'international.  En effet, pour que les pays d’exportation protègent les IG de l’UE sur leur territoire, l’UE doit se montrer en capacité d’accorder un haut niveau de protection réciproque aux IG des pays d’exportation, sans distinction entre les différents types de produits sous IG.   A ce jour, l’Union européenne encadre la protection des indications géographiques uniquement pour les vins, les spiritueux et les produits agricoles/denrées alimentaires. Elle ne dispose pas pour le moment de dispositif de protection pour les IG non agricoles.  Il existe donc, à l’échelle de l’UE, un traitement juridique distinct selon la nature de l’IG et une protection plus faible accordée aux IG non agricoles, ce qui n’est plus tenable dans le contexte international actuel.   Les IG qu’elles soient agricoles ou non agricoles jouent un rôle fondamental non seulement pour le consommateur (garantie d’origine, d’authenticité, de qualité) mais également pour les producteurs permettant ainsi de sécuriser le patrimoine commun de ces derniers et de contribuer à la croissance économique et sociale des filières concernées. Par ailleurs, les indications géographiques, nonobstant leur nature (agricoles ou non) constituent un outil de développement économique local et régional et permettent notamment d’augmenter le tourisme et de valoriser un héritage culturel.   Le BNIC, en tant que défenseur d’indication géographique, considère qu’il est nécessaire de renforcer le régime de protection des IG non agricoles au sein de l’UE, en harmonisant la réglementation afin de faire bénéficier à ces IG d’une protection équivalente à celle des IG agricoles et d’autoriser ceux qui ne sont pas strictement couverts par la définition des « groupes de producteurs » au sein de la réglementation Européenne à protéger leurs IG - notamment lorsqu’il s’agit de produits agroalimentaires hors vins et spiritueux – en leur donnant un rôle fort pour la gestion et la protection de l’IG.  Le BNIC se positionne donc en faveur d’une règlementation sur les IG non agricoles au sein de l’UE, condition sine qua non pour assurer un haut niveau de protection des IG de l’UE (agricoles et non agricoles) sur les marchés à l’international. feedback_msg_text: Le Syndicat des Fabricants Aveyronnais de Couteaux de Laguiole (SFACL) réunit notamment les principaux fabricants de couteaux à Laguiole, issu de savoir-faire ancestraux et d’un territoire unique. Leur objet principal consiste à promouvoir l’origine et la qualité du couteau de Laguiole, en garantissant une fabrication artisanale et locale issue des professionnels couteliers du village de Laguiole et autour du village sur un rayon de 20 kilomètres.   Nous demandons la mise en place d’une règlementation européenne, protégeant les IG non agricoles, produits identitaires de nos territoires ruraux, générateurs d’économie et d’emplois .  Les couteaux de Laguiole ne peuvent être protégées correctement au sein de l’UE. Grâce à la mise en place des IG et au regard de leurs impacts bénéfiques bien connus sur le territoire de l’UE, des délocalisations pourront être évitées ainsi que la désertification et la désindustrialisation de certaines zones rurales comme la nôtre. Notre filière pourrait disposer d’outils juridiques plus performants pour se protéger correctement contre les fraudes. Enfin, les consommateurs pourraient enfin avoir un vrai dispositif public de garantie des informations et des valeurs sur les produits artisanaux, ce qui n’existe pas aujourd’hui et laisse la porte ouverte à de nombreuses tromperies. Faute d’une protection européenne, nous assistons au développement de « labels » privés dont les contours sont très flous et qui souhaitent jouer sur l’origine pour tromper les consommateurs.  Nous avons besoin que les IG non agricoles françaises et européennes disposent d’une protection commune à l’échelle de l’Union Européenne.  Cette réglementation européenne pour les IGNA permettra d’harmoniser le système de de protection et d’éviter aux IG non agricoles homologuées de réclamer la protection dans chaque pays de l’UE.   Les produits pourront ainsi être intégrés dans les listes d’IG annexées à certains accords commerciaux, et les entreprises protégées des abus existants.  Les IGNA sont une formidable occasion de protéger et valoriser des produits à haute valeur ajoutée, créateurs d’une véritable dynamique économique sur les territoires ruraux, en y préservant notamment l’emploi et un savoir-faire spécifique.   Nous constatons, depuis la reconnaissance de nos IG, un accroissement de la visibilité de nos produits, une amélioration de la situation vis-à-vis des contrefaçons et un développement de l’intérêt des consommateurs pour nos produits et nos territoires, notamment à travers le tourisme industriel. feedback_msg_text: L’Institut National des Métiers d’Art est une association reconnue d’utilité publique, organisme national menant une mission d’intérêt général au service du secteur des métiers d’art et du patrimoine vivant. Sous l’égide du ministère de l’Économie et des Finances et du ministère de la Culture, l’INMA porte la vision des métiers d’art et du patrimoine vivant ancrés dans leur temps, source de développement économique local et international, d’emplois qualifiés et d’innovation.  L’INMA soutient la position et l’argumentaire de l’Association française des indications géographiques industrielles et artisanales (AFIGIA) pour une protection européenne des indications géographiques pour les produits non-agricoles.  La majorité des IG françaises concernent aujourd’hui des produits issus des savoir-faire des métiers d’art et du patrimoine vivant, et pourraient bénéficier à de nombreux autres.  Ces savoir-faire sont détenus au sein de structures qui manquent de moyens pour les valoriser et les protéger, notamment à l’international. En apportant protection juridique, lisibilité et visibilité auprès des consommateurs et garantie de qualité, les IG constituent un outil nécessaire à la valorisation des produits et au développement des entreprises. En permettant une meilleure structuration des filières et/ou des écosystèmes territoriaux, les IG créent les conditions favorables à la transmission et la sauvegarde de savoir-faire emblématiques des territoires et vecteurs forts de rayonnement pour la France et l’Europe dans le monde.   Une protection au niveau européen est indispensable pour sécuriser ces savoir-faire et de les valoriser plus encore sur le plan international.
Initiative: EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the publication of the Inception Impact Assessment on the EU protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products.  As an association representing producers of non-agricultural products at the heart of Europe, we encourage the efforts of the Commission in better protecting geographical indications (GIs) for non-agricultural products, and we support the option of creating a single protection system based on a sui generis IP right at EU level.  EU Producers of industrial and handicraft products using GIs will contribute to the economic recovery post pandemic. However, they will be able to deliver their full potential only if they can benefit from an EU-wide system protecting their GIs, and by extension have access to protection in non-EU countries with which the EU has or will have trade agreements and through the Geneva Act of the Lisbon Agreement on Appellations of Origin and Geographical Indications.  Our experience in using trademark systems to protect GIs for non-agricultural products, notably with certification marks in the U.S. and in Hong Kong, has shown us that such systems are less effective, far more costly for the producers and more exposed to potential threats from free riders.  The implementation in Switzerland of a strong protection system for Swiss GIs in the watch sector has not had negative effects on innovation or competition between users. On the contrary, Swiss watch brands have never been more inventive than in the last couple of years. Many Swiss watch brands are using innovative technologies and materials to distinguish themselves from their competitors.

feedback_msg_text: Dutch drinking water operators increasingly face emerging substances, such as pharmaceuticals and industrial substances. To better protect our drinking water sources, improved waste water treatment, as well as other measures that prevent pollutants to reach drinking water sources, should therefore be a priority for the EU and its Member States. The Dutch drinking water sector calls for an ambitious revision of the UWWTD, which should prioritize a strong focus on emerging pollutants. Thresholds for emerging substances under the new UWWTD should have relevance for drinking water production. We believe that drinking water protection should become a priority in ‘sensitive zones’ and strict thresholds for contaminants needed. Strict permitting procedures for indirect discharges via UWWTP’s, in conjunction with transparent and improved monitoring requirements with drinking water relevant chemical substances, are key. Moreover, all UWWTD monitoring should be aligned with WFD/ EQSD parameters.  Feedback from: Vewin: national association of Dutch water companies (144 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Organisation: Vewin: national association of Dutch water companies
Initiative: Water pollution – EU rules on urban wastewater treatment (update)

feedback_msg_text: According to the Danish Ministry of the Environment and Food's national greenhouse gas (GHG) emission inventory, nitrous oxide (N2O) emission accounted for above 42% of the utilities total CO2 emissions. In May 2019, based on more than 250 new scientific studies IPCC chose to triple the N2O emission factor that forms the basis for the UN water sector GHG emission reporting and thus nitrous oxide emissions probably make up an even larger amount and share of total greenhouse gas emissions from the wastewater sector.  Today, sensor technology for both process and emission monitoring enables the wastewater utilities to measure and control their GHG emissions. Contrary to previous assumptions, the N2O emissions from wastewater utilities now reported at an accurate and economically sound level and hereby the preconditions are in place to establish a framework that stimulates true climate-neutral wastewater treatment and not just energy neutral wastewater treatment.   To truly address urban GHG challenges a new UWWTD ambition for nutrients recovery and energy efficient wastewater must consider better regulation to facilitate monitoring and mitigation of non-CO2 GHGs thereby contributing significantly to sector climate neutrality by 2050.
Initiative: Water pollution – EU rules on urban wastewater treatment (update)

feedback_msg_text: Micropollutants A large number of micropollutants is found in wastewater and in sludge. To avoid the substances to enter the water cycle and the environment we support:  - Extended producers responsibility - As described in the EurEau project - Removal of the micropollutants with “end-of-pipe” treatment. Set discharge requirements to different con-taminants of emerging concern such as pharmaceuticals and other micropollutants. The technologies are ready and the Danish utilities want to and can do this.   Sustainable sludge handling In the future, we need different innovative sustainable solutions in addition to bringing sludge to farmland. We suggest: - To include initiatives to make a more sustainable handling of sludge than bringing it to farmland, include the upcoming innovative solutions with due attention to the large variety of useful substances that can be attracted from sludge.  - Handling of sludge should include some requirements for phosphorus recovery.   - Continue to develop new technologies for the future sludge handling, because the future will call for different solutions and alternatives to bringing sludge directly on farmland. This is also important in order not to com-promise the quality of groundwater.  Overflow from combined sewers One very important issue, is to define what is an overflow (quantity, duration, etc.). We suggest: - A common definition of a CSO must be introduced in the UWWTD (quantity, duration, etc.) - If setting up requirements for measurement, the actual status of the recipient must be considered. Local conditions must be the decisive factor in the efforts that are being made.  - There must be proportions in the requirements, if any. CSO is only a smaller cause if the water quality in a recipient is poor. The biggest challenge is related to agri-cultural discharge and diffuse sources.  Energy efficiency, carbon and energy neutrality We suggest including a measurement of energy consumption and production in the UWWTD. This could be a setup, where the utilities / municipalities measure their energy consumption and set up a goal for how much they will reduce their energy consumption on a voluntarily basis. In addition, with this input, an overall goal is to be set for when the entire sector should go in zero and in plus. This model is known from the Paris-agreement on climate change and could be a starting point for The European wastewater sector to develop of joint targets for energy consumption and production.   The Danish performance benchmark has developed a method for calculation of gross and net energy consumption for both transport and treatment related to wastewater that can serve as inspiration for a European model.    When looking into the climate impact of the UWWTD it is proposed as Area of Improvement 13 that a baseline for Me-thane emissions is included. Methane is alongside nitrous ox-ide very harmful climate gasses. We propose that a baseline for nitrous oxide is also established and that targets for reducing these gasses are included in the revision of the directive.   Storm water handling The changing rainfall patterns due to climate change, is causing extreme events and increased instances of flooding and therefore the cities need to become more resilient. We suggest that the future UWWTD should include obligations to handle the storm water more efficiently and in the most sus-tainable manner, where WWTPs do not treat excessive amount of rainwater, and where urban stormwater solutions may contribute to improving urban liveability and biodiversity.   Research, innovation and digitalization Research and innovation will be needed within a range of areas. It is important that funds are set aside within Horizon Europe for improved basic research and innovation to ensure that needed technologies can be developed.   More knowledge on digitalization in the water sector and the gains from improved use and uptake of digitalization towards a smart water sector is also recorecommend.
Organisation: DANVA - Danish Water and Wastewater Association
Initiative: Water pollution – EU rules on urban wastewater treatment (update)
organisation_lower: danva - danish water and wastewater association

feedback_msg_text: Please find below the feeback provided by Suez Spain SL (Suez companies operating in Spain) on the revision of the UWWTD. Before entering into the specifics, we would like to express that Suez Spain endorses the importance of the topics addressed in the IIA and that we hope these topics will be maintained in the future revision of the UWWTD.  EMERGING CONTAMINANTS  For action on emerging contaminants, two stages should be distinguished:  a) First stage, that deals with characterization and risk assessment of each of the pollutants included in the lists defined by the EU should be included in the future revision of the UWWTD.  b) Second stage, implementation of specific remedies. It should be up to each Member State to specify the remedial measures within the Water Framework Directive.  PATHOGENS  The current pandemic confirms the importance of assuming the elimination of pathogens as a way to control the spread of possible diseases. To this end, it would be advisable to detect and treat the pathogens taking into account the subsequent application foreseen for the treated water (bathing, reuse, drinking water, etc.).  NUTRIENTS  It is important to remove certain nutrients from water, and this importance varies depending on the receiving environment and the intended uses of the water once treated (e.g. water reused in agriculture does not need to remove nutrients).  INDUSTRIAL DISCHARGES  It is advisable to establish homogeneous and comparable measures between Member States. This guarantees similar protection standards across the EU, discourages relocation based on environmental issues, respects the polluter-pays principle, and ensures that the water costs assumed throughout Europe meet homogeneous criteria without compromising the affordability of the supply.  SMALL AGGLOMERATIONS AND INDIVIDUAL SYSTEMS  It is important to promote the creation of small wastewater treatment plants in towns with less than 2000 inhabitants, as well as individual waste treatment systems.  When regulating this issue, we need to take into account the sustainability and resistance of these small wastewater treatment plants, along with their operation and maintenance and supervision by the relevant authorities.  The revision of the UWWTD should also consider the consequences of treatment (or lack of it) in rural areas.  STORMWATER OVERFLOWS AND URBAN RUN-OFF  We agree with the approach of the documentation provided in relation to this issue.  CIRCULAR ECONOMY  We agree with the approach of the background documentation in relation to this issue, although we believe that the principle of circular economy should be present in all the management of the WWTP, from its initial design to its possible dismantling, including of course O&M. And it should not only refer to the treatment of sludge, but to all types of inputs and outputs.  ENERGY  It is essential to link the concepts of waste reuse, circular economy and energy self-sufficiency. Waste must be considered as an environmentally valuable source of energy.  It is necessary that the new regulations promote self-sufficient WWTP, where the wastewater becomes a source of energy that guarantees the operation of the plants and can even be used for other purposes.  COSTS  The revision of the UWWTD must take account all the investment and financing needs, both public and private. In addition, tariff criteria must consider the need to rehabilitate or adapt the existing infrastructures to the new Directive, and the design of sustainable systems. Provisions must be taken to ensure that both private and public operators are compensated for the increased investment required in order to adopt the measures provided for in the revision of the UWWTD.  COMPLIANCE  The revision of the UWWTD should provide that the Member States incorporate alternative and subsidiary mechanisms for the implementation of the infrastructures required to comply with the Directive. Feedback from: SUEZ SPAIN (30.7 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Water pollution – EU rules on urban wastewater treatment (update)

feedback_msg_text: A THOROUGH REVISION IS MUCH NEEDED   The Danish Environmental Technology Association (DETA) welcomes the road map for EU’s Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive.   Environmental and health related effects of pollutants in the water environment are well documented, efficient technologies for wastewater treatment are available, and we see changing precipitation patterns due to climate change. Therefore, a thorough revision of the Directive, including ambitious goals and specific time frames, is highly needed.   A revision shall include measures supporting the waste water sector’s great potential in regard to SDG 6, EU’s New Green Deal, the Circular Economy Action Plan, the 2030 Biodiversity Strategy, the EU climate goals of CO2 neutrality, as well as the implementation of  the Water Framework Directive and the Marine Strategy.   Water must be cleansed for harmful chemistry - The Water Framework Directive’s goal of good ecological and chemical status in the European water environment is far from achieved. This applies especially to the chemical status. Therefore, all discharged wastewater should be treated for both nutrients and pollutants with harmful effects on environment and health. DETA recommends that all treatment plants within a realistic time frame must include a tertiary level of purification. This will significantly reduce the presence of amongst other plasticizers, drug residues, heavy metals and chloritized dissolvents in the water environment. Besides, it will contribute to a decrease in the discharge of phosphorus and nitrogen, which contribute to the eutrophicating of coastal waters.    Reduction of overflows - Climate change has led to a significant increase in cases of overflows from treatment plants and thus an increase in discharge of untreated wastewater. The consequences are major damages to biodiversity in water streams, an increase in eutrophication, and a deteriorated bathing water quality. Action plans for climate change adaptation should contain concrete goals and time frames to measure, monitor and significantly reduce overflows. Intelligent monitoring is the key to reduce combined sewer overflows in the most cost-effective way. To secure best practice and peer learning more transparency is needed and uniform data collection on overflows at EU level is a first step. A revised Directive should also support the reduction of infiltration in water pipes and thereby improve the efficiency of the water treatment plants.  A reinforced effort for improved treatment of wastewater and limitation of overflows will provide a significant contribution to the achievement of the 2030 Biodiversity Strategy.     The water sector has great potential in achieving energy and climate neutrality - It is crucial that a revision of the Directive supports the great potential of the water sector in achieving the goal of EU climate neutrality by 2050 at the latest. The potential of energy efficiency at water treatment plants, digitalization, reduction in water loss, increased use of heat pumps in the outlet of water treatment plants, reduction in emissions of nitrous oxide, and increased production of biogas is substantial and well documented. Advanced treatment plants should be conceived as modern resource facilities capable of utilizing the resources in wastewater - and thus contribute to a more circular economy – and at the same time they are capable at producing more energy than they use. The Danish Parliament has recently as part of achieving a 70 % CO2 e reduction decided that the Danish water sector shall be energy and climate neutral by 2030. Normally water facilities account for the largest part of the use of electricity at utilities. Besides, calculations have shown that 20 % of Danish households can be heated by using heat pumps on outlet from wastewater facilities. An energy and climate neutral European water sector should be promoted by targets and regulation at the EU level.
Initiative: Water pollution – EU rules on urban wastewater treatment (update)

feedback_msg_text: CEEP, the European Centre of Employers and Enterprises providing Public Services and Services of general interest, welcomes the opportunity to submit its input to the revision of the Urban Waste-Water Treatment Directive (UWWTD).   CEEP welcomes the Commission’s intention to closely link the revision of the UWWTD with the Green Deal and the Zero Pollution Ambition. In general, the UWWTD has been successful in protecting the environment. Nevertheless, CEEP supports the Commission’s intention to adapt the Directive to current developments, as the circumstances and environmental problems have significantly changed since its existence in 1991. This includes new challenges related to climate change, micropollutants, pharmaceuticals and other emerging pollutants. In this regard, CEEP highly welcomes the Commission’s intention to focus on measures aimed at reducing pollution at source. This requires a consequent implementation of the polluter pays principle. Therefore, CEEP welcomes the consideration of extended producer responsibility (EPR), as proposed by the European Commission, since the current political and legal framework offers only limited and non-binding possibilities for reducing pollution at source and implementing the precautionary and polluter pays principle. From CEEP’s point of view the evaluation of the directive should not lead to disproportionate costs for the waste-water disposal companies. Because of its support of the re-use of sludge and treated waste-water, CEEP calls for close links with the current evaluation of the Sewage Sludge Directive, and asks for a coordination and harmonisation of both Directives whilst encouraging energy and resource efficiency opportunities, with the priority to ensure full environmental protection first, as it will play a central role in its modernisation progress and work towards the objective of the EU Green Deal.   For this reason, CEEP would like to highlight the following recommendations:   -Take into account the new challenges of climate change, micropollutants, pharmaceuticals and other emerging pollutants, by reducing pollution at source and consequently implementing the polluter pays principle, when evaluating this directive as well as other Green Deal instruments to ensure it becomes part of the solution to reach the set goals of the EU Green Deal;   -Support the collection and treatment of waste-water to become climate neutral, whilst taking the principle of environmental protection first, through the use of measures and the circular economy approach;   -Coherence and combined approach with the Water Framework Directive will be necessary to address problem of contaminants of emerging concerns in the waste-water and treat it effectively and sustainably;   -A holistic approach for CSO whilst taking local and regional conditions and priorities into account and the principle of subsidiarity. CEEP does not support target performance values set at EU level to address overflows from collecting systems, yet we do understand that a holistic approach, including urban planning considerations and monitoring of CSO will be needed before actions can be considered;   -Before expanding the obligations for waste-water disposal companies, consolidation should be in the foreground and attention should be paid to sustainable design;   -Make better use of circular economy possibilities within the directive and facilitate energy generation and extraction of raw materials from waste-water;   -Apply the principle of “extended producers responsibility” efficiently to reduce and tackle pollution at source, whereby producers help and contribute to the removal of specific substances;  -Consider equal treatment for norther European countries in regard to Article 4.2 on biological treatment. CEEP calls to adjust this article to only consider temperature and not whether it is above sea level or not. feedback_msg_text: Svenskt Vatten supports the proposed Roadmap and highlights the need for stricter requirements on nutrients, requirements on emerging substances, on control at source of  industries connected to the public sewers, the need of banning hazardous non-biodegradable chemical substances in consumer products as e.g. PFAS, and an extended producers responsibility. One very important issue is missing though. The legal relation between the requirements in the UWWTD and the Water Framework Directive (WFD) must be improved to safeguard urban wastewater treatment plant’s (UWWTP) permissibility. Se example in indents below.  Example - an UWWTP emission show far better reduction when compared with the UWWTD requirements and there is no more technologies to introduce to improve treatment of phosphorus further or to reduce impacts from the discharge on other quality element defining ecological or chemical status, - all technical measures possible to take on the sewage system are already taken, - the population in the agglomeration continue to grow,  - the recipient’s status on phosphorus is good or moderate and is at risk to be deteriorated due to the inevitable increase of emissions from the growing population, and - there is no other recipient available to bear the emission.  The population may continue to grow even when the agglomeration’s UWWTP has made use of all possible treatment technology. The leakage of water into the pipes may also have been corrected as far as possible. If then an appropriate recipient is missing, it must be clearly stated in an EU directive that it will be permissible to extend the UWWTP even if the recipient's quality objective cannot be met. Today this is not legally possible due to the WFD or at least questioned due to the obligation to apply the non-deterioration-requirement and the exemptions when permitting a plant.  According to the EU Court's Weser-ruling, the requirements in Article 4 of the WFD shall be applied on all individual projects and activities. The waterbody’s chemical or ecological status must never be deteriorated due to the discharge of treated waste water, not even regarding a single quality element (parameter) including those caused by substances being untreatable in the plant. The UWWTP in the example presented in the box will not be permissible by application of the exemption “less stringent quality require-ments” (Article 4.5, WFD) on the recipient’s water. Such an application is prevented by condition c (no further deterioration of status occurs) in the article due to the ongoing growth of the population. The possibility to apply a “time exception” (Article 4.4 in the WFD) offers no solution as the population continue to grow. Article 4.7 in the WFD regulate a possibility to deviate from the Directive’s requirements but is only applicable when a discharge is made to a waterbody having high status.  But if needed an UWWTP must be expanded (Article 10 in the UWWTD) to fulfil the requirement in Article 7 on “appropriate treatment”. Article 2.9 defines “appropriate treatment” by referring to fulfilment of quality objectives in other Community directives, e.g. Article 4 in the WFD. If no explicit provision applies something else, all requirements in all Directives must be fulfilled as they stand. But the example and explanation above show that it is not possible to require the UWWTP to expand by reference to the UWWTD and at the same time prohibit such an expansion by referring to the WFD. If the scope of UWWTD will be extended to stormwater existing problems for spatial planning projects, climate adaption and facilities for stormwater (or urban run off water) emission control will increase. Since the WFD objectives are superior to the UWWTD the best solution had been a minor adjustment in Article 4.7 in the WFD. But since the EU-Commission decided not to revise the WFD it is now necessary to find a secondary best solution. See proposal for a sloution in annex 3 in the attached file. feedback_msg_text: La politique de traitement des eaux urbaines menée depuis plus de 30 ans par les organisations européennes a permis de diminuer les impacts et conséquences du dérèglement climatique. Cependant, de nouvelles problématiques liées à nos modes de production et de consommation ont émergé et ont des répercussions directes sur la qualité de l’eau et l’environnement.   L’association PachaGaïa est convaincue qu’il est primordial d’aller plus loin et de renforcer la politique actuelle en matière de gestion et traitement des eaux urbaines. D’abord, pour des raisons sanitaires, ensuite pour des raisons environnementales.   L’association PachaGaïa a pour but de référencer les préjudices écologiques sur le territoire français (Hexagone et Outre-mer) via un outil de cartographie intéractive. En référençant ces atteintes à la biodiversité, nous espérons pouvoir communiquer sur l’urgence climatique et les impacts de nos modes de vie sur notre environnement. Nos axes de recherches s’orientent principalement sur l’eau, le sol, l’air, la faune, la flore, les êtres humains.   La bonne gestion de l’eau et la garantie de sa qualité a des impacts sociaux, sociétaux, environnementaux, économiques sur les populations. L’association PachaGaïa recommande donc de préserver les ressources en eau de tout type de contamination tels que les perturbateurs endocriniens, les pesticides, les plastiques. Il est également primordial de se pencher sur la différence de traitement des problématiques entre l’hexagone et l’Outre-mer concernant les ressources en eau et d’agir franchement en Outre-mer pour un accès à tous.te.s à une eau potable et saine. feedback_msg_text: PATTO EUROPEO PER IL CLIMA – MOBILITA’ SOSTENIBILE  I trasporti rappresentano il 25% delle emissioni di gas ad effetto serra, all’interno dell’UE. Questo valore è evidentemente destinato a crescere se non adottiamo i giusti e necessari interventi.  La quota del 25%  del gas serra  è costituita da ben il 72% circa delle emissioni dovute al trasporto su strada.  Invece, la ferrovia produce soltanto un esiguo 0,5% di gas ad effetto serra.    Dunque, dobbiamo decidere se salvare la nostra Terra dalle inondazioni,  dal caldo, dalla siccità e se non vogliamo vedere l’estinzione della vita sul nostro pianeta.  Il caldo, la siccità sta provocando roghi in California, in Brasile, in Australia, distruggendo migliaia di ettari di foreste diminuendo la capacità di assorbire anidride carbonica dall’aria.  Avere gli occhi chiusi su questa situazione è imperdonabile, e ci sta conducendo ad un ciclo disastroso riguardo la fotosintesi clorofilliana.  La distruzione delle foreste significa innestare il cancro ai polmoni verdi del nostro pianeta. Se non attuiamo  le giuste misure il pianeta Terra è destinato alla distruzione.  La via maestra da seguire, nel piano dei trasporti terrestri,  è il trasporto per ferrovia, non esiste altra soluzione.   Dobbiamo investire in questo settore,  fare in fretta e senza indugi.   Intanto, a dispetto di quanto detto, la Tuscia rischia di rimanere senza trasporti ferroviari.  Infatti, la Roma-Civita Castellana-Viterbo chiude, per ben 15 mesi secondo le migliori previsioni.  Ma, possiamo anche ben immaginare come i tempi possono allungarsi.  Gli abitanti della Tuscia sarebbero soggetti ad inevitabili disagi e rischiare l’isolamento.  La nostra cecità, se non sblocchiamo le opere cantierabili ferroviarie, porterebbe all’utilizzo dei bus ed auto private, incrementando in tal modo l’emissione di gas ad effetto serra e faremo il contrario da quanto previsto dalla Mobilità sostenibile del Green New Deal Europeo. Ma, non dobbiamo dimenticare che la Tuscia fino a circa 30 anni fa era percorsa dalla linea ferroviaria Civitavecchia-Capranica-Orte.  E’ ora di rispondere all’appello: “Presente”.  E’ fondamentale, subito riattivare la Orte- Capranica  è un debito che la comunità nazionale ha nei confronti degli abitanti della Tuscia.  La riattivazione della tratta ferroviaria Capranica-Orte ha un costo, ma all’interno c’è un credito che non è possibile misurare.  E’ come la Vita che non ha prezzo.  Perché quando si parla di ambiente,  di diminuzioni di gas ad effetto serra il prezzo per la riattivazione è compensato dalla contribuzione dalle azioni necessarie per salvare il Pianeta Terra. feedback_msg_text: PROBLEM  Cross border volunteers currently are facing big challenges in terms of medical assistance. Conditions to access the European Health Card change a lot from country to country. Many EU members link the right to get EHIC to be employed or offer a coverage for a extremely short period of time (2-3 months). We, as hosting organisation, see very often how our volunteers don't have or lose the right to be assisted in the public health system due to this limitations.   CIGNA insurance suppose to cover all urgent medical assistance that is not under the services within EHIC. The problem is that in the last 3 years the company stablished a refusal policy that make us (Hosting organisation and volunteers) fight every reimbursement request (even for the most obvious cases). That causes stress on the coordinators and a feeling of vulnerability on volunteers.  SOLUTION  Erasmus programme for university students grants the right to get a valid EHIC for the whole mobility period. This right should be accessible for cross border volunteers in the Solidarity Corps programme. In such way National Security from all state members should accept a formal and signed Volunteering Agreement as a valid document to include volunteers under the EHIC schemme.
Initiative: Youth volunteering – working on projects in other EU countries (update)

feedback_msg_text: Increase in the use of industrial robots as well as the onset of collaborative robots in industry with requirements to increase their artificial intelligence and the use of digital technologies has a considerable impact and pressure on the revision of the existing Machinery Directive. In addition, the introduction of a better definition of scope and concepts  will enable a better understanding  and application of the Machinery Directive at all levels in the entities covered by the Directive (manufacturers, users, notify bodies, market surveillance authorities, etc.). The introduction and use of digital documentation should ease the administrative burden on economic operators (mainly machine manufacturers, users, etc.), while at the same time reflecting the positive impact on the environment. However, it is necessary to address the rules for the management of the digital documentation as well as the necessary accompanying safety information from the digital documentation to accompany the machine throughout its whole life cycle. For the reasons set out above, we are inclined to option 2 in conjunction with option 4 so that the rules and requirements in the amended directive were in line with the "new legislative framework" and could be applied in all EU countries in a uniform, effective and in the shortest possible time.
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: Wipotec GmbH, Kaiserslautern/Deutschland:  Wir unterstützen die Optionen 2 und 4.  Es sollten folgende Modifikationen in der Maschinen-RL vorgenommen werden:  - Harmonisierung der Kabelfarben mit dem National Electrical Code der USA.  - Harmonisierung der Warnhinweise mit Nordamerika (Kombisymbol seit ca. 12 Jahren bereits nach ANZI 535.4 und ISO 3864-2 harmonisiert, aber Kapitel 1.7.1 der Maschinen-Richtlinie erfordert stets Sprache des Aufstellortes --> ergänzende Hinweise zusätzlich zum Piktogramm sollte Hersteller in Sprache seine Wahl angeben dürfen  / supplementary information as additional hint to a pictogram should be allowed in a language as choosen by the manufacturer)   - Die Listen der harmonisierten Normen sollten periodisch in kürzeren Zeitabständen im Amtsblatt aktualisiert werden. Hersteller können heute oft die Vermutungswirkung nicht an aktuellsten Normenfassungen ableiten, weil laut Amtsblatt noch die alten, zurückgezogenen Normenfassungen gelten. Das ist Rechtsunsicherheit.)  - Die Sprache der Typenschilder sollte EU weit einheitlich werden. (Zum Beispiel als Nummernschlüssel wie in der Auto-Zulassung in Deutschland)  - Klarstellen, ob ein Kunde ein Anrecht auf die Aushändigung der originalen Konformitätserklärung bzw. einer Kopie hat.  - Es kommen immer wieder Produkte ohne CE-Kennzeichnung,  ohne CE-Erklärung und ohne Angabe der postalischen Anschrift in den EU-Markt. Importeure  kennen ihre Pflichten nicht. Eine zentrale Meldestelle für solche Auffälligkeiten wäre hilfreich, da die Suche nach einer nationalen Anlaufstelle oft schwierig ist.  - Die Umwandlung von einer Richtlinie in eine Verordnung würde zwar nachträgliche Modifikationen bei der Überführung in nationales Recht verhindern. Dieser Vorteil für die Gesetzgeber wird jedoch erkauft mit einem sehr großen Aufwand für die Hersteller bei der Umstellung unzähliger Dokumente auf die neue Nummer der Verordnung. (Betriebsanleitungen, Risikobeurteilungen, CE-Erklärungen, usw.)  - Die Niederspannungs-RL darf in der Konformitätserklärung der Maschine nicht angegeben werden. Die Schutzziele beider Richtlinien müssen aber eingehalten werden. Die vorgeschlagene Aufnahme eine Liste von ausgeschlossenen LV-Produkten kann hilfreich sein, birgt aber die Gefahr, dass die Liste als abschließend missverstanden wird. Eine klare Regelung in Worten statt als Liste wäre vorzuziehen, um keine ausgenommenen Produkte zu vergessen.  Es gibt derzeit unterschiedliche nationale Vorgehensweisen zur Frage, ob die Norm   EN 61439-1 für Schaltschränke (Niederspannungs-Schaltgerätekombinationen) für Maschinen vollständig anzuwenden ist.  - Neben digitalen Dokumenten sollten auch digitale Typenschilder erlaubt werden.  Mit freundlichen Grüßen  Dipl.-Ing. Bernd Zinke Wipotec GmbH Feedback from: Wipotec GmbH (23.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: 1. Pour une appropriation plus aisée par toutes les parties prenantes, certaines notions pourraient être plus explicites quant à leur champ d’application, et favoriser une meilleure compréhension des définitions (application définie, application spécifique, modification machine, analyse de risque ; usage attendu).  2. Pour une meilleure efficacité, le futur texte doit tenir compte, aborder et/ou mieux expliciter les points suivants : 2.1 Une prise en compte plus explicite de l’usage réel de la machine - Dans les principes d’intégration de la sécurité, nous souhaitons que la machine soit conçue en tenant compte des retours d’expériences des Utilisateurs concernant les modèles antérieurs ou des machines similaires. Cela peut concerner de nombreux sujets très variés comme par exemple l’amélioration de l’accès et de la visibilité au poste de conduite, l’amélioration de l’interface Homme/Machine par un recours plus important aux techniques de l’ergonomie, la désactivation volontaire des organes de sécurité … - Nous souhaitons également que la conception des machines prenne en compte la prévention de l’exposition des utilisateurs aux agents chimiques dangereux, dont les agents CMR en s’attachant à réduire le risque à la source. Cette prescription vise en particulier le respect des VLEP. Par exemple, les dispositifs d’aspiration des poussières et/ou fumées équipant une machine doivent être associés dès la phase de conception, et considérés comme composant de la machine. 2.2 Une meilleure prise en compte des risques pour les Utilisateurs - En matière de maintenance : accès aux organes à vérifier/actionner, protection des parties tournantes, écrasement … - Lors du fonctionnement de la machine en mode dégradé.. 2.3 La clarification des conditions d’apposition du marquage CE. 2.4 Amélioration du contenu et format de la notice d’instruction  3. Rester avant tout pragmatique dans la prise en compte de l’Intelligence artificielle et des Nouvelles Technologies de l’Information et de la Communication 3.1 Nous souhaiterions qu’un retour d’expérience concret de tous les Etats membres sur ces questions soit organisé en complément des discussions et travaux existants de nature plus conceptuelle. 3.2 La prise en compte, dans le texte à venir, des nouvelles technologies (outils numériques et connectés, robotique collaborative, et intelligence artificielle …) doit être progressive, et abordée de façon très pragmatique, par exemple pour ce qui concerne uniquement l’Intelligence Artificielle qualifiée de « faible ». Ces évolutions ne doivent pas conduire à écarter les pistes de progrès d’ores et déjà à notre portée sur les machines classiques, et à bouleverser les équilibres actuels entre Fabricants et Utilisateurs. 3.3 Les machines dotées d’IA doivent respecter, a minima, les mêmes exigences essentielles de santé et de sécurité que les machines prises en compte par la Directive actuelle, ce qui sous-entend de porter une attention particulière aux cas de fonctionnement en mode dégradé et à la sûreté des systèmes informatiques mobilisés. 3.4 Dans les débats actuels, nous constatons que le sujet de la « robotique » est très souvent considéré dans un milieu industriel de production. Les activités du BTP et les environnements dans lesquels elles s’exercent sont très différents à plus d’un titre. Dans le secteur de la Construction, la coopération Homme/Machine est fondamentale. Les exigences essentielles de sécurité appliquées aux machines « autonomes » doivent prendre en compte cette caractéristique. 3.5 L’évaluation des machines doit être, elle aussi, très pragmatique, en particulier sur les fonctions d’usage et de sécurité. Une référence humaine parait indispensable, ainsi qu’un jeu de données-test, reconnu par les parties prenantes, pour la réception des machines et les études de risque.  4. Ne pas sous-estimer l’impact de la révision de la Directive Machine en matière de Normalisation
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

Par exemple, les dispositifs d’aspiration des poussières et/ou fumées équipant une machine doivent être associés dès la phase de conception, et considérés comme composant de la machine. 2.2 Une meilleure prise en compte des risques pour les Utilisateurs  - En matière de maintenance : accès aux organes à vérifier/actionner, protection des parties tournantes, écrasement … - Lors du fonctionnement de la machine en mode dégradé.. 2.3 La clarification des conditions d’apposition du marquage CE.  2.4 Amélioration du contenu et format de la notice d’instruction  3. Rester avant tout pragmatique dans la prise en compte de l’Intelligence artificielle et des Nouvelles Technologies de l’Information et de la Communication 3.1 Nous souhaiterions qu’un retour d’expérience concret de tous les Etats membres sur ces questions soit organisé en complément des discussions et travaux existants de nature plus conceptuelle.  3.2 La prise en compte, dans le texte à venir, des nouvelles technologies (outils numériques et connectés, robotique collaborative, et intelligence artificielle …) doit être progressive, et abordée de façon très pragmatique, par exemple pour ce qui concerne uniquement l’Intelligence Artificielle qualifiée de « faible ». Ces évolutions ne doivent pas conduire à écarter les pistes de progrès d’ores et déjà à notre portée sur les machines classiques, et à bouleverser les équilibres actuels entre Fabricants et Utilisateurs.  3.3 Les machines dotées d’IA doivent respecter, a minima, les mêmes exigences essentielles de santé et de sécurité que les machines prises en compte par la Directive actuelle, ce qui sous-entend de porter une attention particulière aux cas de fonctionnement en mode dégradé et à la sureté des systèmes informatiques mobilisés. 3.4 Dans les débats actuels, nous constatons que le sujet de la « robotique » est très souvent considéré dans un milieu industriel de production. Les activités du BTP et les environnements dans lesquels elles s’exercent sont très différents à plus d’un titre. Dans le secteur de la Construction, la coopération Homme/Machine est fondamentale. Les exigences essentielles de sécurité appliquées aux machines « autonomes » doivent prendre en compte cette caractéristique. 3.5 L’évaluation des machines doit être, elle aussi, très pragmatique, en particulier sur les fonctions d’usage et de sécurité. Une référence humaine parait indispensable, ainsi qu’un jeu de données-test, reconnu par les parties prenantes, pour la réception des machines et les études de risque. 4. Ne pas sous-estimer l’impact de la révision de la Directive Machine en matière de Normalisation Feedback from: OPPBTP (91.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: EUROMOT, the European Association of Internal Combustion Engine Manufacturers, welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to consult stakeholders in the process of evaluating and reviewing the Machinery Directive (MD).   We would like to focus on one major issue underlined in the European Commission’s inception impact assessment: the “lack of legal clarity in the scope and definitions”, most notably in the definition of “Partly Completed Machinery” (PCM).   We would like to highlight the following point in particular: any possible modification related to the understanding of the current definition of PCM should not change the interpretation given in the European Commission’s Guide to the application of the MD, whereby “an internal combustion engine or a high voltage electric motor placed on the market ready to be fitted, i.e. with the connections necessary for the fitting, to machinery that is subject to the Machinery Directive are to be considered as partly completed machinery” (§46, page 49). Engine manufacturers have set up the relevant systems and processes according to such interpretation, which has provided us and our customers with the necessary legal certainty to operate at best.   EUROMOT would like to thank the European Commission for the opportunity to comment on this inception impact assessment and reiterates its willingness to contribute to the MD review process.   Feedback from: EUROMOT (100.8 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: Hallo, wir ein Anbieter von automatisierten und flexiblen Produktionssystemen in der Automobilindustrie.  Aus unserer Sicht machen Option 2 und Option 4 Sinn. Wir wünschen uns, dass die Möglichkeit geschaffen wird, Betriebsanleitungen rein in digitaler Form zu liefern. Dabei soll es möglich sein, sich mit dem Kunden auf eine EU Landesprache unabhängig vom Inverkehrbringungsort einigen zu dürfen. Einige Kunden wünschen sich rein Englische Betriebsanleitungen. Weiter muss im Zuge der Begriffserklärung einer Maschine dem Hersteller zugestanden werden, die Gesamtheit einer Maschine flexibler zu bewerten,  um für Teilbereiche von Anlagen mit sicherheitstechnischer Schnittstelle zu bestehenden Maschinenteilen eine Konformitätserklärung zu liefern, ohne das gesamte Gewerk neu zu zertifizieren. In diesem Zuge muss auch eine Wesentliche Veränderung von Maschinen genauer beschrieben werden. In der Realität wird häufig verlangt, aus alten Komponenten eine neue Maschine zusammenzubauen, oder in andere bestehenden Maschinen einzubauen. Die Voraussetzung für die eingesetzten Komponenten müssen genau beschrieben werden.
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the plan to bring the machinery directive into line with the NLF. We propose that the definitions used in the directives should also be adapted. Since the Machinery Directive and the Low Voltage Directive are virtually mutually exclusive, one might consider combining the two directives.  Furthermore, we propose a revision of the term " partly completed machine ": (g) ‘partly completed machinery’ means an assembly consisting of linked parts or components, at least one of which moves but which cannot or may not in itself perform its specific application in its existing condition. Partly completed machinery is only intended to be incorporated into or assembled with other machinery or other partly completed machinery or equipment, thereby forming machinery to which this Directive applies. A drive system is partly completed machinery. Equipment in this sense is any device which is necessary in order to complete partly completed machinery into machinery.
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: Caterpillar UK Ltd (UK) is submitting the consolidated feedback of Caterpillar, Inc. (US): 1. feedback_msg_text: 1. Da die MRL mit der Überarbeitung an die Digitalisierung angepasst werden soll, ist es dringend erforderlich, auch die Archivierung und insbesondere die Überlassung der Benutzerinformationen bzw. der Dokumentation an die Verwender an die Digitalisierung anzupassen (Stichwort "elektronische Bedienungsanleitung").  2. Zwar ist in Artikel 4 der Schutz von Personen, Gütern und Haustieren als Aufgabe für die Marktaufsicht genannt, der Schutz von Gütern und Tieren wird im Weiteren aber ausgeklammert. Im Zuge der zukünftigen Herausforderungen sollten - soweit möglich und sinnvoll - neben der Digitalisierung die weiteren großen Zukunftsthemen als Anforderungskatalog aufgenommen werden: - Umweltschutz (soweit nicht durch die Umweltschutz-Gesetzgebung abgedeckt) - Energieeffizienz (soweit nicht durch die Ökodesign-RL abgedeckt) - Tierschutz / Artenschutz  - Sachschäden - Abfallvermeidung (sofern nicht anderweitig geregelt)
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the necessity of the revision of the MD as new technologies are indeed emerging and are directly related to health and safety factors, environmental and rational use of energy approaches. Issues occur for new types of machinery seeking product certification according to MD, whilst it is not clarified if they are within its scope and other directives are partly applicable as well. An example case we came across recently regards the need of the manufacturers for certification of compact combined systems such as power and heat generators. If such products could be covered within the scope of MD and a combination of directives can be applied (e.g. MD, Gas Appliance Directive, PED , LVD etc.), then according to OPTION 2 of this initiative, the scope, the definitions and Annex I of 2006/42 should be revised. Alternatively the scope must exclude these products/systemsfrom the MD and link them with another directive/s (e.g. revision / extension of GPSD to include products with multiple directive applications not elsewhere covered). Another concern regards the lack of description regarding the definition of “partly completed machinery”.  This definition could be elaborated (e.g. examples may be given; obligations of CE marking affixation should be explained).
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: We prefer options 2+4 (Inception Impact Assessment). Option 2 will provide for better understanding and better addressing of specific developments, without having to use general (usually understood as ‘vague’) terms. Further, we propose the following improvements:  1. Modifying, or deleting, the (strange) requirement of an ‘authorised person to compile the technical file, who must be established in the Community’, Annex II.1.A.  Will be solved by aligning with the NLF.  2. Careful translation of the directive from the original language into other EEA languages. All (at least Dutch) versions up till now have many examples of incorrect and silly translations. 3. The user manual requirements (Annex I, 1.7.4) do not require integrated maintenance instructions. The manufacturer of an assembly (integrator) thus is allowed to refer to all component / unit manuals, and leave it to the user to find out when to do what and how. We propose a requirement to provide integrated maintenance schedule / instructions for integrated (assembled) machinery. 4. On the subject ‘modifications to machinery in use’, everyone have either their  own interpretation or no clue at all. Depending on the interest, one can easily explain the few given criteria to a desired conclusion.  Despite the fact that strict guiding is impossible on this matter, we recommend:  a) to revise the Blue Guide and the Application Guide MD by providing criteria and examples, like e.g. at the subject ‘assembly of machinery’; b) the national authorities to obtain European consensus. 5. Clear requirements for mobile control stations from which, via internet or general control stations, multiple machines can be controlled.  6. The ‘Declaration of Incorporation’ to our observation still is a very attractive construction, that ‘legally’ covers a transfer of responsibility to the user, for any machinery that will have other equipment upstream, downstream or next to it. The term ‘incorporation’ in the declaration title might be one of the reasons.  We would appreciate a limitation of the ‘free use’ by e.g. (strict) conditions in the directive and (concrete) examples in the Application Guide.
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision

feedback_msg_text: Proposed changes to directive 2006/42/EC: 1. New developments like IoT and AI should be incorporated in the essential health and safety requirements as these phenomena play a role in both threats and solutions. Think of machinery linked to the internet for remote control and data acquisition; this creates opportunities but simultaneously also major threats to health and safety of operators and consumers. Artificial Intelligence may teach machinery new functions but may consequently introduce new hazards.  2. Converting the directive into a regulation (like done on construction products) omits the need for national transposition. Such national transposition has no added value for most manufacturers as they tend to operate on an international level hence the whole industry uses de facto the text from the EU regulation already instead of national law. One point of consideration when converting the directive into a regulation; as also large assembled machinery (complex installations) are considered as “put into operation” at the day of the hand-over, the duration of such phase lasting 2-3 years is not uncommon. If legislative (or normative) requirements change within this realization phase a solution must be incorporated to allow manufacturer and end-user to set a different date for the conformity assessment of the design, the assessment on the hand-over date would then be an assessment against the legal / normative requirements applicable on the date of the finalization of the design phase. This may require two different dates on the declaration of conformity of the assembled machinery. 3. The current directive 2006/42/EC does hardly provide guidance for modification of large complex machinery / installations. Due to faster changing business models the need to adapt large complex machinery increases. Simultaneously more and more end-users want to re-use existing equipment / machinery (not only for financial reasons but also for reasons of sustainability) but find these initiatives blocked by regulation that leaves no room for equipment that would not fulfil the latest legislative and normative requirements. It would help users of large complex machinery / installations if modules or subsections of large complex machinery / installations could be maintained in their original state based upon their original declaration of conformity in case these units keep their original function and capacity (no increase in risk). In fact a more risk-based approach where new and old modules are combined to constitute machinery would allow for some more flexibility.  4. The CE marking of large complex machinery / installations is rather a formality than a recognizable sign for users; machinery bigger than e.g. a 40’ container could be exempted from the requirement to mark the equipment. If a visible sign is nevertheless considered necessary, the requirements on visibility marking should be increased to achieve the desired result (i.e. recognition).
Initiative: Machinery Directive - revision
