feedback_msg_text: We welcome the Commission's initiative to revise the NFRD, to achieve a greater degree of reliability, comparaibility of the information published. Regarding the Standards, we observe the need for globally accepted standards to guide the assurance process around Non-Financial Reporting. Indeed, the assurance (both internal and external) has a significant role in the adequacy and reliability of the information published and the credibility of information reported to the public, by an organisation, cannot be sufficiently strong without a level of assurance. More and more, we see the participation of external service providers in supporting organisation on its non-financial reporting journey . To maximise the benefits in the most cost efficient manner, it is crucial that the internal auditors partner with the external service providers in the realm of non-financial reporting services. The Standards must also cover the appropriateness, completeness, accuracy of the information disclosed. Regarding the cost of compliance, the production of Non-Financial Reporting should not be seen as an outcome realised solely once a year. It should be integrated in the organisation's sustainability mission, strategy and activities; and go beyond the first stage of compliance with relevant laws and regulations.The organisations should also, as a second stage, measure and monitor sustainability performance. The third stage is achieved when oragnisations actively manage and continuously improve sustainability performance. The goal should be to achieve this last maturity model as soon as possible for an effective impact. Again thank you for the opportunity and we look forward commenting the NFR Directive consultation. Kind regards P. Vandenbussche ECIIA Secretary General
Initiative: Corporate Sustainability Reporting

feedback_msg_text: Vielen Dank für die Möglichkeit zur Kommentierung des Fahrplans.  Wir halten eine Revision der CSR-Richtlinie in der Tat für dringend nötig, um die Schwächen des heutigen Zustandes auszumerzen.  Insbesondere muss Korruptionsbekämpfung ein fester Bestandteil jeder seriösen Sorgfaltspflicht sowohl bei finanziellen wie bei nicht-finanziellen Aspekten sein. Die ernsthafte Auseinandersetzung mit Korruptionsbekämpfung dient gleichsam als ein Indikator für die Glaubwürdigkeit der gesamten Berichterstattung. Dies ist auch im Hinblick auf den European Green Deal von besonderer Bedeutung.  Transparency Deutschland befürwortet die Policy Option 3 des Inception Impact Assessment. Wir möchte dazu folgende Anmerkungen ergänzen:  1) Es ist wichtig, dass für die Berichterstattung ein verbindlicher Standard vorgegeben wird. Nur so können die gesetzten Ziele erzielt werden, für Investoren und für die Öffentlichkeit relevante und vergleichbare Informationen bereitzustellen.  2) Eine große Schwäche des jetzigen Systems ist, dass große Unternehmen nur berichtspflichtig sind, wenn sie Aktiengesellschaften sind. Durch die Beschränkung auf Aktiengesellschaften wird für einen großen Teil der Wirtschaft auf die wichtigen Zielsetzungen dieser Richtlinie ohne Grund verzichtet. Die Unternehmensform darf auch nicht zur Flucht aus der Berichterstattung dienen. Für Investoren und für andere Stakeholder ist die Unternehmensform in dieser Hinsicht sekundär.  3) Zur Unterstützung der Prüfung der nicht-finanziellen Informationen sollte es dem Aufsichtsrat empfohlen werden, einen externen Prüfer heranzuziehen und so einen potentiellen Eindruck von Interessenkonflikten vorzubeugen und die Glaubwürdigkeit der Berichterstattung zu stärken.
Initiative: Corporate Sustainability Reporting

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sirs, ASSIREVI – the Italian Association of Audit Firms - is pleased to have the opportunity to provide some comments to your document “Inception Impact Assessment”. ASSIREVI believes the Non Financial Reporting Directive (NFRD) represents the first step aimed at implementing non financial information and disclosure culture all over Europe and appreciates any further developments that will be achieved in this respect. We agree there is a demand for better information driven partly by investors and partly by a wide variety of different organisations and stakeholders. Policy options proposed at this aim will have to be carefully analyzed, in order to meet the need for reliable, comparable and relevant information on sustainability risks, opportunities and impacts.  In this respect, we believe that the NFRD should represent a framework that focuses on the following issues: determining which categories of companies should be required to report, identifying  the reporting standards and implementing mandatory  Non Financial Information (NFI) assurance. A consultation aimed at identifying both the NFI to be reported (including a clearly defined consolidation perimeter), and the non financial reporting standards, would be indeed very useful. A deeper analysis of the existing reporting standards could also be a supportive approach, so as to identify the Standard Setter and the non financial reporting standards to be adopted all over Europe, in order to better address the reporting efforts of companies in scope of the directive.  More detailed reporting requirements could help companies both to solve uncertainties on whether or not a given NFI is to be reported, and to ensure that NFI available to investors are adequate, reliable and comparable within EU.  For the same reasons, the scope of NFRD could be modified adding certain categories of company not currently covered. In any case, a transitional period could also be defined to allow entities to implement non financial reporting processes. Furthermore, in our opinion, strengthening the provisions on NFI assurance and extending mandatory assurance on NFI to all European countries would represent additional important goals to be achieved.  At this stage, only 3 UE countries (Italy, France and Spain) provide for mandatory NFI external assurance, which has already proven to get many advantages, such as increased trust and reliability among stakeholders, increased reliability of information used in business decision-making, increased compliance to quality principles as stated by the GRI in relation of NFI, increased reliability with respect to the processes and procedures and improved reporting system. NFRD should clarify that assurance is carried out on the basis of ISAE 3000.  As to the harmonization of provisions regarding where NFI should be reported (in the management report and/or in a separate report), firstly, the limits and extent of referral to other sources of information through information by reference technique should be clarified .  Moreover, there is an emerging need of consistency between NFI under NFRD and other different forms of NFI-related communication, which are disclosed on a voluntary basis through several instruments targeted at specific stakeholders. All corporate reporting should use the same language: we deem important to investigate how to ensure that non-financial information is available in a digital format. Anyway, a step by step approach is to be preferred, since companies will shortly face the ESEF adoption for financial information, and some technical issues are yet to be solved in this respect, particularly with regard to qualitative information. We also believe that a taxonomy for NFI is important to be defined. According to ASSIREVI, the above issues should be solved with high priority, before strengthening the enforcement regime and promoting greater supervisory convergence. feedback_msg_text: Vi takker for muligheden for at komme med input til roadmap for eftersynet af Non-financial Reporting Directive.   I Danmark er vi generelt meget interesserede i sammenlignelig rapportering landene imellem. Det er vigtigt for de virksomheder der krydser landegrænser, men også for de mindre virksomheder, så der ikke er uligevægtige krav der skaber konkurrenceforvridning.  I forhold til de tre politikmuligheder Kommissionen fremlægger, bakker FSR – danske revisorer op om mulighed nummer tre, og dermed efterse og styrke bestemmelserne i NFRD. Det argumenterer vi for, fordi:  - Det vil i mange tilfælde hjælpe virksomheder, hvis de fik fastere rammer om, hvad de skal rapportere på. Det er naturligt, at der er en vis bekymring om for større byrde for virksomhederne, og specielt for de små og mellemstore virksomheder, men der er en stigende efterspørgsel efter mere og bedre ikke-finansiel information om virksomhederne. Dette kunne betyde, at rapporteringsbyrden potentielt ville blive endnu større, hvis der ikke blev udviklet et harmoniseret sæt af standarder i europæisk regi. - Særligt er der behov for skærpede rapporteringskriterier på klimaområdet, for at imødekomme det stærkt stigende behov der er for at benchmarke virksomheder og sektorer i deres arbejde med at håndtere klimaudfordringer.  - Det er centralt at sikre pålidelige data i den ikke-finansielle rapportering, som den eksterne regnskabsbruger kan have tillid til.  - Det vil styrke rapporteringen, hvis de regnskabsklasser der bliver indfanget af loven, gentænkes. Måske vil det give værdi at gentænke, om omsætning, antal ansatte og balancesum er de tre rette parametre for at vurdere virksomhedens regnskabsklasse.  - Vi ønsker at sikre en digitalisering af regnskabsmaterialet, så det er let tilgængeligt for brugeren. Digitaliseringen må dog aldrig reducere brugsværdien af informationerne, og der vil formentligt være behov for en pdf-fil mange år endnu.   Vi håber, at dette svar vil være til gavn for jeres videre arbejde. Tag endelig fat i FSR - danske revisorer, hvis I har brug for uddybning af argumentation.
Initiative: Corporate Sustainability Reporting

feedback_msg_text: Generally, we believe that before deciding on the appropriate policy tool, any perceived shortcomings of the NFRD need to be assessed against whether those deficiencies can indeed be addressed appropriately by any of the three policy tools. Taking into account the recent survey results by public interest law organisation Frank Bold presented in Brussels on February 17 (https://en.frankbold.org/news/analysis-companies-failing-report-meaningful-information-about-their-impacts-society-and-enviro), the evidence seems to suggest, inter alia, that:  •Company reports do not seem to have yielded results that stakeholders have hoped for (notwithstanding good reporting by some and on particular aspects); •The quality of information is perceived too low to draw conclusions, even though, for some aspects, there is an upward trend in terms of both, quantity, and quality of information; and •Firm size, location, and industry seem to play a role. One may therefore ask whether the Directive’s objective can indeed be met through company reporting alone and sufficiently quick enough. Our view is driven by the following two issues, which we suggest being considered when defining and selecting the policy options.  Firstly, on standards: We believe that one needs to differentiate between setting standards on the one hand and requiring adherence to those and defining scope on the other: Setting standards may be better placed with those that are closer to where the information deficiencies exist and information is being sought. Conversely, public policy seems better placed to address the scope as to who should be subjected to such standards as well as to enforce the quality of those companies’ reporting. So, with regard to setting non-financial reporting standards, we believe that market-led approaches are genuinely more suitable in contrast to public policy reporting requirements as the former are tailored more directly to address specific information needs. This would also contribute to avoiding creating compliance exercises and box-ticking approaches (which may also be a valid interpretation of the data yielded by the study mentioned above).   Secondly, we favour pursuing a global approach by considering internationally/globally accepted reporting standards that already exist or are under development. Whilst we concede that differing degrees of willingness to proceed with mandatory non-financial reporting exist around the globe, we do not share the view of those that believe Europe should be first, go regional and create its own non-financial reporting environment. The reporting requirements are primarily targeting companies that are sourcing, selling and doing business beyond Europe’s borders; further, the areas to be reported on are not genuinely limited by Europe’s territory, either – so what would be the perceived benefit of creating yet another non-financial framework to which only companies domiciled in Europe would be subjected? We admit that a European framework might bring consistency and comparability within that regional area; on the other hand, any regional approach bears the risk of creating competitive disadvantage to European companies vis-à-vis their non-European counterparts who would not be subject to these regional requirements. In light of these considerations we do see little merit in pursuing option 1. Whilst we admit that the European Commission may revise their non-binding guidelines quickly, we do not believe that the development of guidelines is in line with our two points mentioned above.  Regarding the other options mentioned in the Inception Impact Assessment we think that both options 2 and 3 have merits; however, neither option can appropriately and fully address the issue, which is why we recommend a mix of the two along our preceding comments.
Initiative: Corporate Sustainability Reporting

feedback_msg_text: With more than 10 billion euros yearly turnover, 45.000 staff members and 11 million people protected, Groupe Vyv, founded in 2017, is the leading French player in health insurance and the main national operator of care and support service.   As a mutual insurance company, we are a not-for-profit enterprise caring for long-term economic sustainability, resilience and societal values which have a direct impact on the way we manage our finance and investments.   The Groupe Vyv invests in specific areas to improve the quality of life at work, to contribute to inclusive and sustainable development and to promote environmental solutions that have a positive impact on health.   We are therefore particularly attentive to developments related to this directive.  Here are the main points that we consider important in this review of the NFRD directive:  1. First of all: we support the revision of the Directive (option 3).  2. Secondly: we would welcome an obligation to verify the content disclosed by companies. We believe that the monitoring obligations laid down in the directive are too weak. There is a need to strengthen the enforcement regime of the Directive and to promote greater supervisory convergence towards stricter models already in place in some Member States. Indeed, the reliability of the information depends on this verification obligation. Better control of this information would provide greater security for our investments.  3. Thirdly – The scope of the directive is not sufficiently broad as it only applies to listed companies. In our view, the scope of the directive should be extended to non-listed ‘large undertakings’ under NFRD review.  Whether a company is listed or not has no influence on its sustainability or management capacity. The NFRD review should focus on this scope.
Initiative: Corporate Sustainability Reporting

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sir or Madam, We appreciate the opportunity to give an early feedback on the Commission´s Inception Impact Assessment concerning its initiative with regard to updated rules on non-financial reporting by large companies. The Association for Participation in the Development of Accounting Regulations for Family-owned Entities (VMEBF) consists of German companies with a strong family shareholder background and represents a huge number of family-owned large and medium-sized entities in Germany, often legally organised in the form of partnerships. Our objective is to make the role of German family businesses as stakeholders in the development of financial and business reporting more visible and to act as a constructive partner for the standard setters and comparable authorities. Throughout the last few years, we observed a steady increase of entities preparing sustainability reports or at least providing non-financial information in their management reports. This development is not limited to large capital market orientated companies, but also true for an increasing number of non-listed family-owned companies, who often consider sustainability issues as an integral part of their business model. Even more, the volume of existing reports seems to expand every year. This indicates an increasing awareness of ESG topics amongst investors, executives and other stakeholders. On the other hand, we recently observed a continuing escalation of rules and regulations especially in the field of non-financial reporting requirements. As long as these rules are aimed at an objective, scientifically approved measurement of non-financial items, this should be generally appreciated by the reporting entities. But these regulations are also often driven by political ambitions to set quantitative limits for non-financial reporting items such as greenhouse gas emissions. Non-financial reporting may therefore become an instrument of observation, intervention and monetary fines imposed on the reporting companies by political authorities.  Having that in mind, we would appreciate the Commission revealing the data and sources supporting their assessment of current regulation not providing sufficient information on non-financial issues. As described above, we experienced an immense increase in volume and quality of non-financial data in the last few years. Hence, we do not unreservedly share the Commission´s evaluation. However, we agree with the Commission that sustainability information provided by many companies today is not always sufficiently comparable. On the one hand, this might be due to the numerous options provided by the Non-Financial Reporting Directive, e.g. with reference to the mode the information is published or made publicly available. On the other hand, there is only little harmonisation of reporting frameworks in the EU and worldwide, making the information provided difficult to compare. Summarizing our reflections, we would – in a first step – appreciate the Commission communicating details on their view on the shortcomings of current reporting and reporting requirements in order to increase transparency and replicability of the Commission´s appraisal processes. In a second step, we would prefer the Commission intensifying its deliberations on the proposed policy option 3. We believe that a selective and moderate revision of the Non-Financial Reporting Directive could further increase comparability and quality of non-financial reporting. This should also include the development of a principles-based set of reporting standards that can internationally be agreed on. However, the Commission should act with sound judgement when revising the Directive and carefully include also the feedback of non-listed preparers of non-financial reports reflecting the challenges and risks when implementing such regulation. If you have any further questions please do not hesitate to contact us.  Kind regards, The VMEBF Board
Organisation: Vereinigung zur Mitwirkung an der Entwicklung des Bilanzrechts für Familiengesellschaften
Initiative: Corporate Sustainability Reporting

feedback_msg_text: Objet du commentaire: Lieu d'établissement de l'importateur  Le CDU a modifié la notion d’« exportateur » réservant cette qualité aux seules personnes établies sur le territoire douanier de l’Union européenne, de sorte à avoir la mainmise sur la personne responsable de la sortie effective des marchandises du territoire de l’Union et du respect des restrictions à l’exportation.  Bizarrement, le CDU n’a pas fait de même pour l’« importateur » qui continue à pouvoir être établi en dehors du territoire de l’Union européenne. Le CDU exige que seul le « déclarant » soit établi sur le territoire douanier de l’Union européenne (article 170§2 du CDU), ce qui lui permet de protéger les intérêts financiers de l’Union. En effet, le paiement de la dette à l’importation revient au « déclarant » (article 77§2 du CDU) et donc au RDE si l’« importateur » est établi en dehors de l’UE. Les intérêts autres que financiers ne sont pas, quant à eux, protégés. Mettre la main sur l’importateur étranger relève de l’impossible et ce, d’autant plus, que la commercialisation des biens se fait aujourd’hui de plus en plus via des plateformes électroniques. De même, faire peser la dette douanière sur le RDE s’avère, dans ces cas, injuste, car il n’a pas plus de moyens d’action sur un étranger que les Etats membres.   Exiger l’établissement sur le territoire de l’UE de l’« importateur » est donc également souhaitable.
Initiative: Union Customs Code – mid-term evaluation

feedback_msg_text: The Danish Trade Union Confederation (FH) welcomes the good intentions in the Commission’s inception impact assessment. It is vital to provide equal access to adult learning for all workers in both the public and private sector. Adult learning is a key factor in ensuring a well-functioning labour market with convergence between workers’ skills and employers’ needs. Adult learning is important for the individual’s professional as well as personal development and formation throughout life and an important factor for strengthening career paths, employment rate and recruitment in areas with a shortage of labour. The Danish adult learning system contains a differentiated approach regarding funding. Basic adult learning is free for low-skilled workers, whereas adult learning for higher skilled workers is often co-paid by the work place or the workers. As part of the collective bargaining process, numerous collective agreements for skilled and unskilled workers in the private sector today include access to competence funds for the workers covered by the agreement. These competence funds in the private sector are a sort of collective learning account and cover a wide range of sectors. The competence funds have provided the workers with a right to a certain number of weeks of adult learning per year. Some workers have a right to two weeks, although it varies depending on the specific collective agreement. If the employee does not make use of their learning rights, then in some cases they can be transferred to the next year.  The workers themselves can often choose the training that they prefer. The workers have a right to participate in adult learning during normal working hours while most or even in some cases all of their lost wages are reimbursed. More specifically, the competence funds in the private sector typically cover the participant fee and the difference between reimbursements from governmental or employer financed support schemes and the worker’s salary. Thus, the competence funds do not cover all the expenses to adult learning. In the municipal and state area it is possible for some professional groups to have expenses for participant payment covered through competence funds. However, these do not give the same rights as the adult learning rights that apply in the private sector. Since access to adult learning is often strengthened through collective agreements, some groups on the Danish labour market have less beneficial rights and still many groups that do not have access to competence funds. There are many barriers influencing participation in adult learning, which individual learning accounts alone do not solve. Among other things, it is important to have a strong focus on quality guidance for workers on how to navigate in the adult learning system, and it is necessary to promote a culture from both employees and companies that adult learning is part of working life. FH have four recommendations for the Commission: •We believe that an initiative should take current practices in the Member States into account in order to ensure that an EU-initiative will support and strengthen current national practices. •Participation in adult learning is vital for all workers in both the public and private sector and across all education levels. However, we believe that it is essential that an EU-initiative focuses on ensuring better access to adult learning for the low-skilled and vulnerable groups that need it the most. •It is important that an EU-initiative does not release the employers and national governments of their responsibility to provide adult learning to employees and unemployed workers. The employers’ obligation to develop and maintain their employees’ skills and national governments’ obligation towards especially unemployed workers are key-factors in a well-functioning labour market.  •Adult learning should be an individual right, but it should in no case be mandatory for workers to make use of their right to training.
Initiative: Adult skills - Individual Learning Accounts: a tool to improve access to training

feedback_msg_text: Le CPF en France : des droits à la formation réservés aux salarié s En France, seules les personnes ayant travaillé et accumulé des droits à la formation peuvent bénéficier d'un compte personnel de formation (CPF). Les salariés sont donc les seuls citoyens à acquérir des droits à la formation sur ce CPF.  Les droits sont rattachés à la personne, plafonnés à 5 000 € et sont utilisables sans limitation de durée, ce qui constitue une évolution majeure par rapport au Droit Individuel à la Formation (DIF), qui était rattaché à un contrat de travail et limité dans le temps.   L'employeur crédite le CFP de 500 € chaque année pour les salariés ayant une durée du travail supérieure ou égale à la moitié de la durée légale ou conventionnelle du travail sur l'année. Pour les salariés à temps partiel, les droits sont proratisés en fonction de la durée du travail. Un calcul spécifique s'applique pour les salaires en forfait annuel en jours ou sans référence horaire. Un effort a été fait pour certains publics, puisque les droits sont majorés pour les salariés ayant un niveau de diplôme inférieur au CAP-BEP, de même que pour les salariés handicapés, à hauteur de 800 € par an.   Les demandeurs d'emploi qui ont déjà travaillé bénéficient d'un compte personnel de formation (CPF) et peuvent utiliser les droits qu'ils ont acquis en tant que salariés. Plus précisément, les formations éligibles sont les suivantes:  - Effectuer une formation sanctionnée par les certifications professionnelles enregistrées au répertoire national; - Être accompagné pour la validation des acquis de l'expérience (VAE); - Acquérir les connaissances de base (socle de connaissances et de compétences); - Effectuer un bilan de compétence en mobilisant les heures inscrites sur le CPF acquises en poste. Pour rappel, le bilan de compétence peut être effectué notamment dans le cadre du conseil en évolution professionnelle; - Préparer l'épreuve théorique du code de la route et l'épreuve pratique du permis de conduire des véhicules du groupe léger et du groupe lourd.  En revanche, nous devons ici soulever que le CPF n'est pas alimenté pendant la période de chômage et les personnes qui n'ont pas travaillé sont privées de CPF... ceci alimente les inégalités d'accès à la formation entre ces deux publics, les personnes ayant déjà travaillé d'une part, et celles sorties de formation initiale parfois avec un très faible niveau de qualification et qui n'ont jamais travaillé.  En conclusion, le CPF apporte donc des avancées notables par rapport au Droit individuel à la formation (DIF), bien qu'il évince de son accès une marge importante de la population des personnes à bas niveau de qualification n'ayant jamais travaillé.
Initiative: Adult skills - Individual Learning Accounts: a tool to improve access to training

feedback_msg_text: Initially, TCO/Saco/LO would like to emphasize the importance of the European Pillar of Social Rights Action Plan that sets the target of 60% of adults participating in training every year by 2030 and the right to build skills throughout life. We agree that both digital and green transitions together with drastic COVID-19 disruptions create significant structural change on labour markets and will fundamentally change the skills requirements of many jobs. This increases the importance of building skills throughout life to prevent skills gaps, support labour market transitions and prevent social exclusion.  Secondly, TCO/Saco/LO support the ETUC response to the initiative. Like ETUC, TCO/Saco/LO believe that it is possible to achieve this target if the EU initiative takes a broader standpoint and focuses on ensuring the right to access and better financing of adult learning and employee training with different financial tools instead of focusing only on individual learning accounts. There should be different solutions and different financial tools offered according to the different needs of the adults, workers who need upskilling and reskilling in companies, low-skilled adults and workers, the unemployed, atypical and platform workers, etc. We regret that the Commission confuses “access to rights/entitlements” and “access to individual learning accounts”. Like ETUC, TCO/Saco/LO believe that ILAs does not mean the same as ensuring the individual right for training. We suggest that the EU initiative differentiates between: 1. right and access to adult learning, 2. right and access to employee training, and 3. right and access to different types of paid education leave. It is also important to identify different financial mechanism of supporting adult learning, employee training and different types of paid educational leave when the course/training serves personal or labour market needs.  Overall, TCO/Saco/LO believe that the analysis lacks a clear separation of lifelong learning and "on-the-work training". Lifelong learning is a shared responsibility, workplace training is the responsibility of the employer (economically and to some extent legally). The employers are responsible for providing training that is necessary for the job and the skills required to adapt to changes within the job.   TCO/Saco/LO really want to emphasize the importance of this employer-responsibility. Employers and unions in Sweden improve opportunities and provision for education and training through collective agreements and bargaining. Social partners work together to foster transition and career paths between sectors, enabling conditions for reskilling and/or upskilling through collective agreements or funding agreements. This is the core of the “Swedish model” and any attempts to impose limits will not be supported by the Swedish unions.   Lifelong learning, however, can include a broader development of skills that goes beyond the responsibility of the employer. For example: skills or learning activities that (1) are not directly linked to the job or (2) reskilling. This learning is based on individual choices and responsibilities. In Sweden, over 40% of all university graduates return to higher education for lifelong learning. But for some groups, barriers to lifelong learning remain, due to the lack of relevant educational provisions and funding.  When we consider life-long learning TCO/Saco/LO believe that access to education needs to be open and flexible without “dead-ends”. It should be possible to continue studies on lower and upper levels of education independent of previous choices. Up- and reskilling can also increase by recognition of prior learning to avoid unnecessary overlapping studies. The educational system must also adapt to the needs of upskilling/reskilling, both in terms of educational provision and flexible admission rules. The funding systems also need to adapt to older students and professionals. feedback_msg_text: Confederation of Independent Trade Unions in Bulgaria (CITUB) admires the introduction of Individual Learning Accounts (ILA) to enhance the implementation of the right to take part in lifelong learning. Our expectation is ILA to cover the package of career guidance, motivation, and quality-assured training for up-and-reskilling and the twin green and digital transition of adults with certain educational and qualification backgrounds. This is a precondition for sharing the investment in skills – both, financial or in time outside the working hours.     The problem analysis is reflecting the state of play. Bulgaria has got recommendations to empower people in working age to take part in LLL. One of the barriers is the lack of financial mechanisms to enlarge the access. Different target groups have a variety of challenges to pay or to co-finance their training. This is the reason CITUB proposes keeping all effective tools like vouchers for VET and key competencies and sectorial funds for qualification parallel to the Individual Learning Accounts to be introduced and to accumulate rights during the upcoming years.  We expect a positive impact of ILA by enabling workers in atypical forms of labor, platform workers, for example, employed in SMEs and self-employed to get the needed skills. A combination with paid educational leave could motivate participation in continuing training.   The building blocks can include some successful patterns of functioning Individual Learning accounts and related schemes based on the impact assessment.  Social dialogue can create an appropriate climate for transparency and informed decisions for perspective skills development and validation. The interconnection between skills and wages is a strong motivating factor.
Initiative: Adult skills - Individual Learning Accounts: a tool to improve access to training

feedback_msg_text: In order to respond to the contemporary processes of transformation, oriented towards an ecological transition, innovation and digitalisation, it is necessary to define a strategy that focuses on work and its enhancement and that guarantees people adequate support, throughout their lives, to face this challenge. Therefore, the FLC CGIL considers it necessary to define a system of lifelong learning that aims both to improve and requalify skills and knowledge and to combat functional illiteracy, which becomes a fundamental element also for the concrete exercise of citizenship rights. From this perspective, although the European Commission considers individual learning accounts as an instrument of the right to continuous vocational training, the FLC CGIL believes, in general, that financial instruments (e.g. ILA) can only act as a support for training, but that it is instead necessary for the Commission to focus on how to guarantee the right of access to adult learning, employee training and paid leave to all adults and employees, including public sector and education workers. The Commission should motivate EU Member States to create or improve their financial mechanisms to support citizens'/workers' access to high quality continuing education and the inclusive development of these policies. More specifically, for all the Education sectors, we agree to what was perfectly expressed by the ETUCE in relation to ILO Recommendation 140 on paid educational leave, and the following passage is endorsed and quoted: “Recommendations to EU Member States to develop effective solutions to improve teachers' access to quality and inclusive continuing professional development within working hours and free of charge would be essential. However, the EU-wide initiative on the funding of continuing professional development (e.g. ILA) should be respected by national qualification systems and teacher competence requirements and not create a harmonised EU-wide system for funding teachers' continuing professional development”.
Initiative: Adult skills - Individual Learning Accounts: a tool to improve access to training

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the EU initiative on the Individual Learning Accounts (ILAs), because we hope that it can involves much more adults in training and because we believe that the possibility of using ILA can contribute to the realisation of the individual right to learn.  In particular, we would like to highlight some points.  We think that ILAs need a big campaign of communication for reaching all potential beneficiaires (promoting equal access and inclusiveness) which - precisely because they are often not involved or rarely involved in training activities - will also need appropriate guidance activities, that will support them in identifying training paths that are really useful for their personal and professional growth, now and in the future; therefore, the ILAs have to ensure that adults realize their training projects, thus giving a concrete response to the upskilling and reskilling they need.  We also believe that ILAs must allow access to personalized and quality courses, certified and recognized as training credits at national and European level, in order to promote the mobility of the beneficiaries.  So, it will be necessary for ILAs to have human and economic resources dedicated to.  In order to achieve all of this, it is essential:  - a responsible governance that involves all stakeholders who can make their contribution, including a strong involvement of social partners;  - a governance that is able to organise all the tools aimed at adult learning in a single framework and to rationalise the resources allocated to them.
Initiative: Adult skills - Individual Learning Accounts: a tool to improve access to training

feedback_msg_text: Adult upskilling is critical to the competitiveness of Europe and also to improve vocational mobility.  In order to  overcome thee many barriers influencing participation in training we must revolutionise the process and put the learner in charge.  Stimulation, engagement, retention and recognition are key stages in the learning process. Not all learners are the same and therefore the learning process must reflect this individual need, it cannot be a one size fits all. Whilst technology affords us the chance to do many things, it is essential to get the pedagogy (the theory and practice) right first. Ensuring the correct pedagogical structure for the process is the foundation of the learning process regardless of the delivery mechanism. This process must reflect the need of the learner. As such stimulation and engagement are key foundation steps  in the process. Individual Learning Accounts   Digitalisation is a game-changing strategy that will empower the learning processes and all sectors to thrive and deliver the expertise for the skills process and as a tool to stimulate demand. Most of the issues related to low demand for skilled workforce are due to: lack of a widely recognized and accepted international scheme of certified qualifications for sustainable construction and sustainable energy skills; lack of awareness and uptake by the industry of new methods and digitalisation; lack of mandate or incentive by public authorities for the use of such skills.   Digital technology is transforming our lives at an accelerating pace. Digitalisation can be disorientating, standard contexts and work processes that we are all used to are changing – technologists call this ‘context collapse’. On the other hand, digitalisation is recognized, by those who are implementing it, as a powerful enabler to enhance the effect of their work and as an enrichment of their professional skills.  Social interactions and our workplaces are changing and will change further. This is also the fact for upskilling interventions, due to digitalization, learning will become easier to access, digest and utilise.   When developing Individual Learning Accounts we must take full advantage of the digital transformation process and deliver Digital Learning Accounts - that empower the learner and remove barriers to vocational mobility. In order to empower the skills and learning process we can harness the digitalisation process to inspiring demand for skills by providing clear learning interactions, transparency of upskilling transactions, and recognition of qualifications achieved.  In our work we use digitalization as a learning tool to make the process accessible including new portal (through a mobile smartphone)  friendly web based platform. Our skills interventions are delivered in a scalable way, in bite-sized skills delivery. We implement digitalisation and the earning of learning credits in a "step by step" competence recognition, as an accelerator to empower demand for energy skills, and as an enabler of formal certification. This system for measurement and recognition of the advancement of acquired skills in digitalisation /embedded sustainable skills is employed, based on blockchain procedures to instill transparency and trust. Through our work we are seeking to revolutionise the skills process revolutionise the learning process by monetizing the skills and learning exchange with a system based on skills recognition rather than accreditation. The reward of acquiring a competence at a certain level will be CERTcoin – the innovative currency of skills and learning  embracing today’s digital transformation benefits. This reward based on skills and time credits will be stored in an Digital Individual learning Account ( a bank account of individual skills) and can be used as digital points accumulation for  skills account balance or for exchanging it into skills recognition certificates. feedback_msg_text: ALL DIGITAL (AD) welcomes the opportunity to input on the Roadmap for to develop a European approach to micro-credentials. AD is a pan-European membership organisation that represents 25,000 digital competence centres that work together to deliver digital skills training to help people succeed in the digital transition. The action to develop an EU approach to micro-credentials is both timely and represents a key example of the role the EU can play in supporting co-operation and a coherent approach towards skills, qualifications and enabling an inclusive labour market. The Roadmap rightly highlights the value of micro-credentials in a digital age: micro-credentials can support development of necessary skills to access new opportunities, new jobs, new careers and support civic, social and personal development. The Roadmap, however, appears to be solely concerned with the formal education and training sector. The Roadmap is not aligned with linked EC actions announced on the development of digital skills, including the European Digital Skills Certificate and does not reflect the role of the non-formal education sector in providing micro-credentials. Digital skills development is a priority across several flagship EC policy areas yet the potential for micro-credentials as a pathway to digital skills development is entirely absent in the Roadmap. The digital transition underpins the New Skills Agenda and the DEAP. The Action Plan on the Pillar of Social Rights and Communication on the Digital Compass both set out system-wide, ambitious targets for developing digital skills for citizens and the workforce as well as developing businesses and infrastructure. Micro-credentials for digital skills are widespread and respond to a key need to support development of digital skills of the workforce in a responsive and flexible way. Accordingly, the EU approach to micro-credentials must enable and support the ambitious goals set by the EC to increase the basic digital skills of Europeans and support development of digital skills, not just in the ICT sector but across the workforce. The Roadmap does not capture this potential. In addition, the EU approach to micro-credentials must be developed in line with the feasibility study on EDSC as part of the DEAP. The conceptual development, consultation and eventual governance and development of standards or guidelines for both actions must be closely aligned. The Roadmap rightly refers to the need for quality, standards, and transparency as essential parts of the approach to micro-credentials. However, the Roadmap does not provide sufficient detail of how the approach will reflect the provision and uptake of micro-credentials in the labour market and in non-formal settings. The popularity of short-courses, MOOCs is due to their flexibility and accessibility and the non-formal sector has played a lead role in providing these courses and micro-credentials. The approach to micro-credentials can only claim to be an EU approach if it properly reflects the reality of micro-credentials, including the central role of non-formal education providers and the needs and demands of learners. Micro-credentials issued by non-formal providers can facilitate learning pathways between formal and non-formal education, as well as job and other opportunities and should be recognised and valued for this role. A comprehensive approach to micro-credentials that recognises the role of non-formal providers is the only way that a true culture of lifelong learning can be developed in the EU thereby fulfilling the first principles of the Pillar of Social Rights. The upcoming consultation must properly reflect the voice of employers, HR professionals and training organisations outside of formal education and training. AD insists that the EU approach to micro-credentials must include a specific strand on non-formal education and training, including non-formal providers that support digital skills development, as represented by AD.
Initiative: Micro-credentials – broadening learning opportunities for lifelong learning and employability

feedback_msg_text: The Danish society of engineers welcome the intention of the European Commission to develop “European standards which address minimum requirements for quality, transparency, cross-border comparability, recognition and portability, building on existing tools, as far as possible”. European standards on micro-credentials can pave the way for a flexible learner-centred focus of lifelong learning. Micro-credentials can increase engineers’ possibilities to access flexible lifelong learning and can complement engineers’ upskilling and reskilling in the green transition.  Needed standards in a spiderweb of learning offers – high quality and transferability is key  Continuing Professional development for engineers is an entangled spiderwebs of both private and public learning opportunities making it impossible for the individual learner to identify and compare relevant Continuing Professional development. We see European standards on micro credentials as a much-needed agent for our members, making it easier for them to identify and compare relevant Continuing Professional development offerings and gaining the needed knowledge, skills and competences.  Transferability and enabling individuals to find the best fits for their needs We believe that recognition and trust in micro-credentials would ensure transferability of the micro-credentials between education and the labour market and among countries and would allow for them to be added to full qualifications.  Standards on micro credentials would allow individual leaners to construct the best leaning package from different universities and training institutions enabling them to find the best fit for their leaning needs.  Therefore, the Danish Society of Engineers see micro credentials as a good supplement to existing education e.g. master-degrees in a life long learning perspective.
Initiative: Micro-credentials – broadening learning opportunities for lifelong learning and employability

feedback_msg_text: We as experts of the Department of Educational Policy of Austrian Federal Economic Chambers welcome the opportunity to provide feedback on the Commission´s initiative and to contribute to the discourse on a microcredential system that is coherent with existing VET qualifications and European VET-strengths  while at the same time supporting the needs of the labour markets, companies and learning individuals.  While we fully agree with the premises of the initiative and the aim of ensuring re-skilling and up-skilling of workers, we would suggest putting more emphasis on labour market relevance.  In a business environment, very important for matching learning outcomes and actual labor market needs, the primary interest lies on the value of micro-credentials for employers and their contribution to improving the functioning of labor markets as well as individual employability. Given the importance of this aspect, the Austrian Federal Economic Chamber favours micro-credentials based on learning outcomes relevant for employability and established on the two pillars of trusted quality and demand-orientation.  We strongly support the view that “micro-credentials are not a goal in themselves, but are at the service of the full educational and professional development of individuals” as the survey report on Micro-credentials in EHEA countries aptly puts it.   Against the background of our experience as the largest provider of VET in Austria with approx. 360,000 participants in training formats in Austria and the central agency for designing and administering approx. 100,000 apprenticeships in some 30,000 companies in more than 200 well-defined professions we strongly suggest that European standards for microcredentials not fragment successful national systems of formal VET qualifications. We consider microcredentials to be useful where they complement or add to the formal VET system and the functioning of labour markets. Microcredentials should not fragment proven and high-quality formal qualifications in VET (e.g. apprenticeship qualification, master craftsman qualification).  As regards non-formal qualfications in VET, we see potential for establishing clear standards that would enable providers of VET to opt into a system of classification of qualifications as microcredentials. It has to be up to any qualifications provider to decide, whether, and if so, to what extent and with which specific qualifications, the provider wants to subject itself to the European standards to be developed under this initiative. However, European standards should not seek to follow an overly formal approach, likely to jeopardize the flexibility and speed essential in developing non-formal qualifications in VET. This aspect is highly relevant to individuals willing to acquire new skills and knowledge as well as enterprises with quickly evolving needs.  The Austrian Economic Chamber Network represents all enterprises in all industries of the Austrian business sector (approx. 400.000 individual company members). It is the largest provider of VET in Austria and a central VET stakeholder. It is tasked to administer apprenticeship and master craftsmanship exams on behalf of the Federal Ministry of Digital and Economic Affairs: It operates numerous VET institutions, several Universities of Applied Sciences and two Private Universities. Austrian Economic Chambers actively promote the attractiveness of VET qualifications and seek to improve the permeability between VET and academic education.  Department of Educational Policy of Austrian Federal Economic Chambers: Dr. Elisabeth Hassek-Eder (VET), MMag. Rudolf Lichtmannegger (Higher Education and Higher VET), Thomas Mayr (ibw Austria – research and development in VET)
Initiative: Micro-credentials – broadening learning opportunities for lifelong learning and employability

feedback_msg_text: EIS reply to European Commission’s Public Consultation on Micro-credentials – broadening learning opportunities for lifelong learning and employability  The EIS supports the common position taken by ETUC and ETUCE on micro-credentials in VET and tertiary education in July 2020. Furthermore, the EIS provides the following feedback on the Roadmap in the interest of safeguarding national requirements regarding qualifications to support the teaching profession, and the autonomy of educational institutions, including in regions beyond the EU and European Education Area.  The EIS believes that career-long professional learning for teachers and lecturers is an entitlement, and that it plays a central role in teacher and lecturer professionalism. We therefore believe that courses leading to micro-credentials can be considered as continuous professional development for teaching professionals only where they meet appropriate standards for quality, relevance, and where they are complementarity to full qualifications. On this basis we agree with the ETUCE position that micro-credentials should not replace any aspect of initial education of teachers, and that ongoing dialogue with the education trade unions is essential to ensure that the quality assurance of micro-credentials is appropriate to meet the career-long professional learning needs of teachers and lecturers.  The EIS is committed to innovation in pedagogy which is teacher-led and advanced on the basis of teachers’ and lecturers’ own professional development. This includes a commitment to the professional autonomy of teachers and lecturers, and their professional identity as leaders of learning. We disagree with the speculation in the Roadmap that increased availability and take-up of micro-credentials will in itself serve pedagogical innovation. We therefore agree with the ETUCE position that micro-credentials should not be seen as tools of innovation within teaching and pedagogy.  The EIS remains committed to lecturer professionalism, including for lecturers involved in the delivery of micro-credentials in VET and tertiary education. The move to provide skills-based solutions to labour market demands, including green and digital transitions and COVID-19 recovery, cannot serve as cover for casualisation or de-skilling of the workforce in VET and tertiary education. On this basis we disagree that provision of micro-credentials can increase the efficiency of the higher education, and vocational education and training systems. High quality, innovative and learner-centred learning and teaching can only be achieved through the work of professional and skilled teachers and lecturers, supported by appropriate public funding of VET and tertiary education which ensures autonomy for educational institutions and teaching professionals.  We echo the concern raised by ETUCE that the increasing policy focus on micro-credentials will risk public funding for universities and colleges being distributed, in particular, to for-profit private providers of micro-credential courses. The EIS continues to resist privatisation of VET and tertiary education provision in Scotland on the basis that private providers cannot provide the transparency, accountability and security for learners and teaching professionals which are essential to ensuring the current and future educational needs of communities are met. We therefore echo the ETUCE position that the European Commission’s Roadmap should also highlight that the EU policy on micro-credentials will not risk public funding to public providers of VET and tertiary education. Feedback from: Anonymous (14.3 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Micro-credentials – broadening learning opportunities for lifelong learning and employability

feedback_msg_text: Soutien de la CSC à la position commune prise par la CES et le  CSEE sur les micro-certificats dans l’EFP et l’enseignement supérieur en juin-juillet2020. feedback_msg_text: Digitalisation and decarbonisation are having an enormous impact on the European workforce. According to the latest Cedefop report , 46.1% of the adult population, approximately 128 million adults in the EU-27 Member States, the UK, Iceland and Norway, need upskilling and reskilling. Therefore, workers and the unemployed urgently need support not only in accessing upskilling and reskilling trainings, but also in validating their skills and competences. ETUC still believes that the increased policy focus on micro-credentials can be harmful for the acquisition and recognition of full qualifications. Due to the COVID-19 crisis full qualifications are more important now to fight against growing inequalities. Workers' unions experience high interest of the employers towards full qualifications than towards short-term courses which do not provide all skills necessary for a person pursuing a profession/occupation. This is why we question the statement of the Roadmap that "the demand for short learning options and their recognition and validation is expected to increase." We underline the importance of respecting national education and training systems and national regulations concerning qualification requirements on pursuing professions. Social dialogue with the trade unions is essential on this policy initiative which will have a significant impact on workers.  We welcome that the Roadmap identifies that micro-credentials and alternative credentials should not be mistaken as partial and full qualifications and they should not replace “traditional qualifications”. We believe that recognition and trust in micro-credentials would ensure transferability of the micro-credentials between education and the labour market and among countries, and would allow for them to be added to full qualifications.  According to the Roadmap: “In particular, more flexible learning pathways and a larger take-up of micro-credentials will serve social, economic and pedagogical innovation and will help people to gain and update their knowledge, skills and competences in all domains and for all purposes (employability, personal development, active ageing in the digital age, etc). This will notably contribute to more inclusive education systems and learning, and smoother labour market transitions in the greener and more digital economy of today and tomorrow.” We agree with the Roadmap that flexible access to and learner-centred focus of lifelong learning are important. Micro-credentials can increase workers possibilities to access flexible lifelong learning and can complement workers’ upskilling and reskilling. However, we do not agree that increasing access to micro-credentials can ensure greater inclusiveness and innovations within the education and training systems. At the moment there are diverse providers of courses leading to micro-credentials from which many are not quality assured or accredited. Greater quality and inclusiveness of education and training should be ensured with the effective implementation of the 1st principle of the European Pillar of Social Rights. Also, better access to employee training for all workers with different contractual situation need to be guaranteed by the companies within collective agreements. Equal access to adult learning for all people from different socio-economic background need to be ensured by the governments (public employment services) and within the effective implementation of the 2016 EU Council Recommendation on ‘upskilling pathways’.  We remind that that collective bargaining agreements focus on qualifications and credentials and not on micro-credentials. In general employers do not recognize micro-credentials, however in some countries and certain sectors macro-credentials are recognized due to collective bargaining agreements. The labour market needs full qualifications and micro-credentials should not push the responsibility of further learning from companies to employees. In addition, the greatest danger

feedback_msg_text: Our feedback is specifically addressing the Elevation data aspects of the INSPIRE Directive:  The Elevation of a terrain surface is one of the most important descriptors of the Earth‘s morphology. This has been stated in the INSPIRE Data Specification on Elevation (D2.8.II.1_v3.0; 2013-12-10) and the variety of applications for Elevation information prove this specific and important role. Height information is directly used for science applications (especially flood mapping and landslide prediction), civil engineering, defense and security, planning and resource management, topographic mapping und aviation (line-of-sight, airport database).  As key reference layer, the highly accurate, globally consistent and preferably high-resolution terrain information is used to improve the geolocation accuracy of satellite, aerial and drone imagery during the orthorectification process.Today’s possibility to acquire Pan-European satellite imagery (e.g. Copernicus, smallsat constellations) and the need for Pan-European datasets to analyze and solve global challenges (e.g. climate change, sea level rise, deforestation) requires the adaptation of the INSPIRE Data Specification on Elevation by considering up-to-date elevation standards such as e.g. the Defense Gridded Elevation Data (DGED; v1.2 from 3 May 2018) Profile. The current INSPIRE Data Specification on Elevation follows the Digital Terrain Elevation Data (DTED) Standard from the year 2000. The attached table summarizes the precise technical recommendations for the enhancement/refinement of the INSPIRE Data Specification on Elevation.
