feedback_msg_text: Regiunile rurale din întreaga Uniune Europeană sunt importante nu numai pentru că acoperă  peste  50%  din  teritoriu,  cu  o  populaţie  de  circa  113  milioane  locuitori,  dar furnizează alimente, materii prime, o gamă variată de bunuri şi servicii, ca şi biodiversitate, locuri  culturale, apă, sol, depozite de carbon. Zonele rurale furnizează peste 20% din locurile de muncă şi asigură în medie mai mult de 15% din valoarea adăugată brută totală a Uniunii Europene. În 24 h, producţia de CO2 rezultată din respiraţie este mai puţin importantă decât cea de O2 rezultat din fotosinteză pe timpul zilei. Astfel, putem afirma că plantele produc O2 și activitatea agricolă are un efect pozitiv asupra mediului. Sistemele alimentare sunt supuse la mari presiuni din cauza pandemiei COVID 19, dezastrelor naturale, precum seceta pedologică excesivă, a incendiilor, a inundațiilor, etc. Vedem de asemenea că apar noi boli și dăunători în U.E., iar unele deja existente cresc numeric extraordinar de mult. Trebuie să menținem sănătatea plantelor vegetale și sănătatea animalelor și avem nevoie de substanțe alternative, ca să putem să înlocuim substanțele care se doreșc a fi eliminate, pentru a evita ca o boală oarecare să vină și să afecteze întreaga populație vegetală sau să fie probleme mari în materie de sănătate animală. Este nevoie de o tratare diferențiată a statelor membre care folosesc 9 kg de pesticide la hectar și cele care folosesc 1 kilogram de pesticide la hectar. Nu e corect să se înjumătățească cu 50% la ambele, dar unele să poată folosi 4,5 kg, iar altele doar 0,5 kg. Același lucru este valabil și în cazul aplicării îngrășămintelor. Este obligatoriu ca standardele de producție să se aplice în mod echitabil, uniform, celor care se află în Europa și celor care se află în afara UE, în așa fel încât să avem exact aceleași garanții. Agricultorii își doresc un preț corect pentru produsele lor. Dacă există noi reguli pentru pesticide acestea trebuie să fie aplicate și importurilor.  Când vorbim  despre viitorul agriculturii europene, vă rugăm să țineți cont că agricultura oferă hrană unui număr de jumătate de miliard de cetățeni, aici venind interzicerea neonicotinoidelor, Green Deal-ul  și strategia Farm to fork, cu presiuni importante pe sectorul agricol, cu condiționalități de neimaginat și cu costuri sporite, nu doar pentru fermieri ci și pentru jumătate de miliard  de consumatori europeni. Se estimează o sporire a costurilor pentru producătorii europeni de 400% odată cu implementarea strategiilor menționate anterior. Trebuie avut în vedere ca cetățenii să își poată permite hrană de calitate, să nu se sporească sărăcia și să fragmenteze consumatorii europeni între consumatori de rang 1 și de rang 2.  Pentru o dezvoltare pe termen lung a zonelor rurale este obligatoriu nevoie de:   - Programe Naționale de Gestionare a Riscurilor în Agricultura prin intermediul tehnologiei digitale moderne;   - Comasarea terenurilor;    - Rețele naționale de perdele forestiere de protecție a câmpurilor    - Investiții în sistemul de irigații, desecări, drenaje existent și pentru creșterea suprafețelor irigate;   - Investiții prin INVEST EU pentru asigurarea necesarului european de proteină vegetală și realizarea de investiții în sisteme noi de irigații, desecări, drenaje care să funcționeze cu consum redus de energie și apă;   - Deciziile privind cultivarea soiurilor si hibrizilor obtinute prin intermediul noilor tehnici de ameliorare a plantelor sa fie decizii știițifice, să fie publicate în catalogul European al soiurilor și hibrizilor  și să rămână la potențialul și atitudinea fiecărui stat membru dacă vor cultiva sau nu, ținând cont și de consumul existent;   - Creşterea capacităţii de depozitare şi procesare locală a materiei prime agricole prin intermediul cooperativelor agricole.
Initiative: Sharing geospatial data on the environment – evaluation (INSPIRE Directive)

feedback_msg_text: the3million is the largest organisation representing EU citizens in the UK. Our youth wing, the Young Europeans Network, currently runs the #OurHomeOurVote campaign (www.ourhomeourvote.co.uk), encouraging EU citizens to register to vote in the May 2021 UK local elections.   The UK Government has guaranteed EU citizens’ voting rights for the 2021 local elections. In Scotland and Wales, different rules apply, whereby EU citizens can also vote in national Scottish and Welsh elections, like all residents with leave to enter living in these devolved administrations. We campaign for the rights of EU citizens to be maintained after 2021 and for voting rights to be expanded to all migrants in the UK.  Similarly to the “mobile citizens” mentioned in the Inception Impact Assessment, EU citizens in the UK are under-represented voters. According to the Electoral Commission, only 1 in 2 EU citizens are registered to vote. Recent EU Settlement Scheme estimates show over 4 million EU citizens living in the UK with either pre-settled or settled status. These residents should be mobilised in local politics and involved in the decisions affecting them.  The “Supporting broad and inclusive participation of mobile EU citizens in municipal elections in Europe and in the elections to the European Parliament” initiative does not mention the EU citizens in the UK who may lose their voting rights after the May 2021 local elections. While in Scotland and Wales voting rights are guaranteed for all residents, this is not the case in England and Northern Ireland. For these two parts of the UK, the UK has only yet secured bilateral voting rights agreements with Portugal, Spain, Poland, and Luxembourg. This means that in the future, some EU citizens in the UK will continue having the right to vote in local elections, while others may lose those rights if the UK does not enter bilateral agreements before the next local elections. It is with this context that we approach this roadmap.  Policy options 1 and 2:  Policy options 1 and 2 would not address the concerns of EU citizens in the UK or those of British citizens in EU member states.   Since the UK’s decision to leave the EU, EU citizens’ voting rights have been up for negotiation. Post-Brexit negotiations did not secure voting rights for EU citizens in the UK or for British citizens in the EU. Thus, a bilateral approach has been adopted. If residency-based voting rights had been agreed at the EU level, this approach could have been incorporated into the Withdrawal Agreement, thus ensuring reciprocal rights for EU citizens in the UK and for UK citizens in the EU. Instead, the bilateral agreement approach means that some EU citizens in the UK will have the right to vote in future local elections while others will not.   Policy option 3:  Policy option 3 offers the most comprehensive approach to ensure the rights of EU citizens to continue voting in UK elections will be protected.  As the UK continues to enter bilateral negotiations with EU member states, the UK will seek confirmation that individual EU member states will allow British residents to have local-level voting rights. In return, citizens from the respective EU member state will have voting rights in the UK.   Consequently, EU citizens in the UK would benefit if the EU implemented harmonised residency-based voting rights across the EU. If every EU member state adopts this, British citizens already residing in the EU will have voting rights in local elections. This will increase the likelihood of the UK delivering reciprocal rights for EU residents in the UK, thus ensuring EU citizens in the UK are not disenfranchised.  To ensure that EU citizens’ voting rights in the UK are maintained in the long term, we would recommend that Policy option 3 is pursued, considering our recommendations. The approach we offer would provide a straightforward path to guaranteed voting rights of EU citizens in the UK and British citizens in EU member states.
Initiative: Inclusive elections in Europe – enabling EU citizens who reside in another EU country to exercise their right to participate in municipal elections

feedback_msg_text: Voting Rights for all EU Citizenships   An increasing number of EU citizens live in a different Member State. These residents pay taxes and send their children to school in their new home country. They are often politically engaged, some are even members of a local political party and raise their voice. Although these are important features of democratic engagement, most of us lack the most fundamental democratic right: the right to elect our regional and national representatives and stand as candidate.  We feel that the right to vote (and stand as candidate) should be extended from local and European elections to include all elections, including regional and national ones. In the context of this consultation, we would like to share our opinion that voting rights should be expanded for EU citizens to vote in all elections of the Member State of their residence.  Having the right to vote and stand as candidate in all elections can either be granted directly, by enfranchising EU citizens, or indirectly, by granting them citizenship. In our opinion, the indirect method faces a major problem: some countries require people to give up their current citizenship. Our experience is that people feel strongly connected to their country of origin, which makes this a big practical and emotional hurdle. We therefore prefer the direct way of enfranchising residents. Granting temporary citizens the right to vote after a set time in a Member State and inviting them automatically to elections would be a cleaner solution to including the currently disenfranchised.  One of the EU´s fundamental rights enshrined in the Treaties is that we are all allowed to live in any Member State. That is the quintessence of EU citizenship. We believe that the right to vote is also a fundamental right. Requiring people to also acquire national citizenship to exercise the right to vote is a contradiction to EU citizenship and our right to move and live freely within the Union. Granting the right to vote as argued above would make EU citizens truly mobile. We would have the right to live, work, study and vote in the Member State of our residence and thus fully participate in the country we choose to make our home.
Initiative: Inclusive elections in Europe – enabling EU citizens who reside in another EU country to exercise their right to participate in municipal elections

feedback_msg_text: Background Ensuring the right to vote and stand for elections for persons with disabilities, including mobile EU citizens with psychosocial disabilities, is an obligation that the EU and its Member States have under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Improving political participation of persons with disabilities is emphasized in the EU Disability Rights Strategy 2021-2030. The Strategy aims to support full electoral participation and accessibility of the European elections, establish a guide of good electoral practice addressing participation of citizens with disabilities in the electoral process; and support inclusive democratic participation.   Problem Statement While the Inception impact assessment Ares (2021)1364261 outlines some valid challenges that need to be tackled to ensure the right to vote of mobile EU citizens, it fails to include the barriers still faced by mobile EU citizens with psychosocial disabilities. According to Mental Health Europe’s data, at the 2019 European Parliament Elections, around 500,000 persons with disabilities – including psychosocial disabilities – were not able to vote or stand for elections due to deprivation of their legal capacity. While we do not have the exact number of mobile EU citizens deprived of their legal capacity, it can be assumed that among the hundreds of thousands of people in Europe under full guardianship (a form of substitute decision-making where a person is deprived by law of their legal capacity), some fall within the category of mobile citizens and are thus deprived of their right to vote and stand as a candidate in European Parliament elections. This assumption is corroborated by a report of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights highlighting that 18 EU Member States still prevent people deprived of legal capacity from voting in the European parliament elections (https://fra.europa.eu/en/publication/2019/who-will-not-get-vote-2019-european-parliament-elections).  Roadmap Recommendations When looking into the matter more in details, it is clear that the Inclusive EU Parliament election initiative must tackle for mobile EU citizens with psychosocial disabilities: - Legal and administrative barriers; - Lack of awareness of rights; - Lack of accessibility of voting procedures, facilities and election materials; - Fewer opportunities for participation in political life. Unfortunately, none of the policy options in the inception impact assessment seems to include mentions to adequately address such barriers for mobile EU citizens with psychosocial disabilities. Our feedback to the European Commission is therefore to choose policy option 3 and include the revision of measures that prevent mobile EU citizens with psychosocial disabilities from the enjoyment of their legal capacity and the exercise of their right to vote and stand for elections. This can be achieved through legal revisions, policies and practices to encourage and established supported decision-making regimes. For more information on supported decision-making, please consult the attached report. We would like to particularly highlight our concern with the objective by the EU Disability Rights Strategy 2021-2030 to work towards ratification of the Hague Convention 2000. If adopted across EU Member States the Hague Convention 2000 could have serious implications on the legal capacity of mobile EU citizens with psychosocial disabilities.  ---  Mental Health Europe (MHE) is the largest independent European non-governmental network working in the field of mental health. We are committed to the promotion of positive mental health, the prevention of mental distress and improvement of care. We advocate for social inclusion and the protection of the rights of (ex)users of mental health services, persons with psychosocial disabilities, their families and carers. We also raise awareness to end mental health stigma and discrimination. Feedback from: Mental Health Europe (MHE) (522.8 KB - PDF - 36 pages) Download
Initiative: Inclusive elections in Europe – enabling EU citizens who reside in another EU country to exercise their right to participate in municipal elections

feedback_msg_text: Equal pay for women and men is one of the cornerstones of Gender Equality and goes hand in hand with closing the gender care gap and supporting work-life balance. Hence closing the gender pay gap must be one of the key components of the next Commission’s Gender Equality Strategy, based on core European values of social inclusion and non-discrimination.  This can only become a reality through comprehensive policies and legislation. Choices do not come out of nowhere. Legislation is important to change, to bring and to reinforce social rights. Therefore, COFACE Families Europe welcomes the European Commission public consultation on the revision of the Directive 2006/54 to strengthen enforcement mechanisms and increase pay transparency, as well as the call of the European Parliament to better enforce the enforcement of equal pay provisions, on the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation to bring it in line with recent EU legislation and corporate culture. This revision should include references to the recently approved Work-Life Balance Directive 2019/1158, the Council Recommendation of 8 November 2019 on access to social protection for workers and the self-employed 2019/C 387/01, and to the European Pillar of Social Rights, among other relevant EU policy and legal frameworks, and ensure that the definitions and legal concepts in the revised Directive 2006/54 are in line with those in the above-mentioned measures.   All of these measures contribute to closing the gender care gap, the gender pay gap, enforcing equal pay across Europe, and therefore to building a more social and fairer European Union.  You will find attached COFACE Families Europe's full response to this consultation. Feedback from: COFACE Families Europe (161.7 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Gender pay gap – transparency on pay for men and women

feedback_msg_text: E’ molto importante tenere l’attenzione su questo tema. L’Unione Europea deve prendersi carico della difformità, sempre più evidente, nella retribuzione data a professioniste donne e data a professionisti uomini, tra lavoratrici e lavoratori in genere, che a parità di ore lavorative, percepiscono salari differenti e non di poco, basterebbe di per sé come elemento a cui porre attenzione, ma bisogna considerare che tale dinamica è fonte di squilibri e difficoltà per le donne, lungo tutto l’arco della loro vita, sia sotto l’aspetto professionale ed economico, ma ancora più sotto l’aspetto più ampio, dello stato sociale e della dimensione personale, limitata nella sua individualità.  Le donne, fanno esperienze diverse in relazione al denaro, fin da bambine, nel corso dei percorsi educativi e nelle prime esperienze lavorative. Nello studio, le materie da approfondire e le scelte di indirizzo scolastico superiore e universitario, sono per tendenza statistica, non tecniche e non legate alla sfera finanziaria e economica. Quando da adulte vogliono e possono investire in una esperienza imprenditoriale sono vincolate, in tanti casi, alla garanzia di un genitore maschio e/o di un marito. Ed anche si sottolinea la difficoltà di accesso al credito.  Su grandi numeri di casi, nel ménage matrimoniale la gestione del patrimonio familiare è riservata all'uomo.  Mettiamo in evidenza, purtroppo, che si arriva ad inquadrare la disparità salariale come vera e propria discriminazione di genere, fino a leggerla come violenza. Accade infatti che una donna che subisce abuso psicologico e/o fisico, sia anche vittima di una violenza più sottile, che emerge a tratti, e che specie in caso di violenza conclamata rende ancora più difficile e travagliata, la possibilità di affrancamento e via d’uscita dalla vessazione. Si tratta proprio di violenza economica e agisce su queste leve: •non avere nessun accesso al reddito familiare •non poter usare i propri soldi liberamente •il controllo delle proprie spese da parte del partner •non conoscere l’ammontare del reddito familiare •non avere "il permesso" di lavorare  La mancanza di un reddito autonomo o la presenza di un reddito troppo basso, contribuisce ad azzerare la libertà di scelta, autodeterminazione e autostima. E’ quindi fondamentale attivare in modo non derogabile, formazione e percorsi di consapevolezza del proprio potere economico, come donne, come madri, come lavoratrici, come parte fondamentale delle nostra società. Percorsi e informazioni rivolti, al rafforzamento della capacità di capire e gestire competenze economico-finanziarie di base, all’avere informazioni teoriche e tecniche, alla consapevolezza che l’isolamento economico è isolamento sociale e che mette a rischio l’incolumità stessa delle donne, e a cascata diretta, si mette a rischio una società. Il tutto è funzionale se si parte dalla scuola. Se si consegna ai ragazzi, forse ancora prima alle bambine e ai bambini, l'opportunità di sapere.  Nel mondo cooperativo, non esente da squilibri legati al gap salariale e alla differente posizione occupazionale delle donne, anche se con percentuale di occupate vicina ai target previsti e nonostante un grande vantaggio dovuto proprio alla formula imprenditoriale cooperativa, dove la donna trova spazio ed espressione professionale molto ampia, si lavora per comprendere sempre meglio quali azioni possano colmare misure economiche non eque, in diverse aree geografiche, in diversi settori produttivi, e per la gestione della conciliazione vita/lavoro, per lo sviluppo imprenditoriale e le possibilità di finanziamento, ecc.; questo avviene attraverso indagini e studi, oltre che con la formazione e seminari ad hoc.
Initiative: Gender pay gap – transparency on pay for men and women

feedback_msg_text: Suomen Yrittäjät (“Yrittäjät) is an interest and service organization for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and their owners. As Finland’s larg-est organization, representing 115,000 enterprises, we work every day to support free entrepreneurship and an entrepreneur-friendly society.  First and foremost it is crucial to underline the importance of not mixing up the overall gender gap in overall earnings with the concept of pay discrimi-nation. As stated by Eurostat “[…] the unadjusted GPG [gender pay gap] does not capture discrimination as such. It combines possible differences in pay between men and women, for ‘equal work or work of equal value’, with the impact of differences in the average characteristics of men and women in the labor market.” By stating that “Gender pay discrimination is one of the reasons women in the EU earn 16 % less than men on average” the EU Commission suggests that discrimination is a common cause for the differences in wages between men and woman. However, reasons for differences captured by this number lie especially in factors such as the lower work volume of women and their different career choices (profession and sector). In reality, the gap measures a concept that is much broader than the concept of pay discrimination alone.  The principal reasons for current differences in pay between men and women in the Finnish labor market are:  • Differences in pay between profession and sectors, resulting from the gender segregation of the Finnish labor market. The same gender segregation of girls and boys can be seen on educational programs and courses, in particular STEM and care-related profession respectively. Answer to this problem would be a more even distribution of women and men in the different sectors of the labor market, including at the level of specific professions.  • Differences in working time between women and men, as women work part-time to a much greater extent than men, taking overall responsibility for family and children (e.g. parental leave and care leave), impacting negatively on career and wage developments. Answer to this would be a more even distribution of parenting responsibilities and domestic work between men and women as well as continuous efforts to change attitudes and views with respect to the roles of women and men in their professional and private lives. Also promoting women entrepreneurship should also be part of the solution.  Yrittäjät underlines that the current legal framework is sufficient to protect individuals from pay discrimination. The gender pay gap can only be durably closed if the causes of different involvement in employment by men and women are addressed and framework conditions are put in place which further upgrade the professional activity and career opportunities for women. This, however, cannot be achieved by introducing legislative measures as proposed in the EU Commission’s inception impact assessment. Neither bureaucratic pay transparency measures nor other interventionist equal pay rules can effectively support the changes needed to tackle root causes. Political action must now focus on initiatives strengthening work and career opportunities. Instead of creating new bureaucratic measures and legislation, the right solution would be to improve public understanding of the relevant legal concepts. We are also in favor of improving employees' knowledge of what the pay and salary consists of and how that can be influenced.   Yrittäjät wants to highlight that as the situation differs greatly between the member states of the EU, there are no one-size-fits all solutions. Priorities and measures have to be set according to the specific needs, conditions and prevailing culture and attitudes in the different national labor markets.
Initiative: Gender pay gap – transparency on pay for men and women

feedback_msg_text: Parenthood and equally compulsory leave to tackle gender pay gap       Wage differences between men and women have many causes, including different job participation rates, disparities between jobs and activities that still remain predominantly prerogative of either men or women. It often happens that women are forced to choose part-time working hours, in order to better balance between family care and their work. A comprehensive account of factors contributing to increasing the gender pay gap is provided by July Eurostat’s Statistics on "Wages and labour costs/it”:      The realities of the European Union Member States with regards to Gender Pay Gap are still highly heterogeneous. However, a common factor can be identified in relation to procreation and distribution of responsibilities. It is valid across the Member States that the birth of a child still affects employment rates and careers, severely penalising women.  As an example, we can look at the Italian case. Currently, in Italy “compulsory maternity leave” consists of 5 months of abstention from work, paid at 80% of the remuneration. On the contrary, “compulsory paternity” consists of 7 days, paid at the 100% rate. The use of the additional parental leave time is optional and paid at 30% of the remuneration received on the workplace.  The combination of this type of policies and deeply rooted stereotypes affects women in the workplace, particularly in the private sector. Hiring companies often opt for investing on workers who will not leave their job for months, even despite lower educational levels.  There is an additional level of discrimination to be added on this framework. Men’s right to play a key role in raising children is discriminated.  Attempts to tackle this discrimination had been done by the European Parliament and the Council. The European Parliament issued the resolution on the 2019/01/15, followed by the Directive 2019/1158 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2019 on work-life balance for parents and carers.   The Directive specifically mentions:     It is worth to add to the framework the jurisprudence of the EU Court of Justice, which in transposing the principle of equality of art. 23 of the EU Fundamental Rights Chart emphasises the need for State Members rules to provide for flexibility mechanisms that substantially avoid reverse discrimination and highlighting the minor’s right to have guaranteed a constant presence of both parents.    Considering the aforementioned references, Eumans (a paneuropean movement that engages citizens in nonviolent, trans-party, democratic initiatives) invites EU Member States to adopt incentive measures to encourage the use of equally compulsory leave. These measures should be coupled with disincentive measures to stop the protraction of direct and indirect discriminations.     Additional measures could be:     1- Considering the adoption of the wording“parenthood” as a substitute for “maternity” and “paternity” to ensure that both parents equally enjoy the compulsory leave. 2 - Adoption of control systems on the usage of parental leave, through reports that companies should provide annually
Initiative: Gender pay gap – transparency on pay for men and women

feedback_msg_text: EPSU welcomes the road map for the initiative “strengthening the principle of equal pay between men and women through pay transparency” because closing the gender pay gap is a matter of urgency and priority.   For a detailed description of demands and concerns on this matter, EPSU would like to refer to its response to the public consultation held in November 2019. However, EPSU would like to stress few points that deserve, in our view, a specific attention.  1. EPSU welcomes the inclusion in the roadmap of the notion of looking into “neutral job classification” and “work of equal value”. Pay transparency can play a crucial role in ensuring substantial progress in addressing the gender pay gap. It helps unveiling the systematic undervaluation of women’s work at the heart of the persistent gender pay inequalities. It highlights the feminisation-segregation of occupations and the insufficient appreciation and remuneration of the work performed by women in specific jobs or whole sectors.  2. EPSU welcomes and encourage the European Commission to introduce compulsory measures such as staff rights to information.  3. The upcoming initiative would need to require all employers, in both public and private sectors, to adopt pay transparency policies and practices.  4. The upcoming initiative should support unions to engage in discussions with employers to address the pay gap including through positive action. Pay transparency can support trade unions’ bargaining strategies to reduce unfair and/or unnecessarily large pay differentials between groups of workers, as well as to better tackle low pay in general.  Finally, pay transparency means that every worker knows how much they and their co-workers, managers and CEOs make. Pay transparency means that gender biases and discrimination, even if unconscious, are stripped away as everyone can see their effects laid out numerically in the cold light of day.  Pay transparency means that workers and their unions are provided with information about all the pay, bonuses and additional benefits paid throughout the  organisation, it provides information on the tasks and skills relevant to job evaluation for the purpose of establishing equal pay for work of equal value, it guarantees that workers are free to discuss their pay and gagging clauses and threats against workers who discuss their pay are prevented.
Initiative: Gender pay gap – transparency on pay for men and women

feedback_msg_text: The National Commission for the Promotion of Equality acknowledges that pay transparency should be mandatory as it enables employees to identify discrimination and to access justice. Binding measures providing for transparency in pay and pay systems will indeed strengthen the implementation of the equal pay principle.  Employees should have the right to request information about their pay and how it is reflected in the pay system. In this regard, a clear definition of the concept ‘equal pay for work of equal value’ is required.  The proposed Directive can recommend various measures that are applicable to organisations according to their size, as per the 2014 Recommendation.  This Directive can also strengthen the role of equality bodies to ensure that proper enforcement can be carried out for its effective implementation.  Besides the binding measures, other initiatives can be developed.  Particularly, training and sharing of good practices with different stakeholders is very valuable, including equality bodies, trade unions and employers associations, employers etc.  Further awareness on pay transparency and discrimination with clear examples of discrimination contributes to sensitise employees and employers.  The development of equal pay tools including audits, alongside guidance on the development of gender neutral job evaluation systems, can assist employers and social partners to ensure that equal pay is safeguarded.  Moreover, all developed and existing software should address the issue of stereotyping and algorithms particularly throughout the whole process of recruitment and employment.  EU funds to support these actions would strengthen the implementation of the proposed Directive.
Organisation: National Commission for the Promotion of Equality (NCPE)
Initiative: Gender pay gap – transparency on pay for men and women
organisation_lower: national commission for the promotion of equality (ncpe)

feedback_msg_text: Molto spesso , troppo,  negli annunci di lavoro - in Italia - la retribuzione non è dichiarata, viene detto che sarà "commisurata al reale grado di esperienza e competenza del candidato" e accade che se il candidato è di genere maschile al termine dei colloqui svolti l'offerta del datore di lavoro sarà maggiore rispetto a quella formulata per una candidata di genere femminile. Questo accade perché si ritiene che una donna non contratterà sulla retribuzione offerta, si considera che se andrà in maternità l'azienda dovrà sopportarne costi e disagi e si ritiene, infine, che il modello sociale accetta una retribuzione inferiore per una donna poiché il suo reddito è rubricato come integrativo di quello maschile in una gestione familiare. L'uomo rimane, nel modello sociale corrente, il capo famiglia anche se l'evoluzione delle dinamiche socio-demografiche registrano un significativo aumento di donne single, divorziate e uniche percettrici di reddito in famiglie in cui il partner è disoccupato/inoccupato. La possibilità di offrire sul mercato posizioni lavorative senza l'obbligo della dichiarazione dello stipendio offerto alimenta la disparità di trattamento salariale. Se una donna domanda - durante il primo colloquio  - qual è lo stipendio previsto le viene risposto che è aggressiva e poco orientata alle logiche aziendali bensì troppo concentrata sulle dinamiche personali, se la stessa domanda la pone un uomo la risposta che riceve è un numero, una cifra relativa a uno stipendio base che si parametrerà sul grado di esperienza, competenza, etc. Sarebbe utile - e auspicabile - prevedere l'obbligo di dichiarazione di uno stipendio base che, sebbene lasci aperta la porta alla possibilità di una differenza di remunerazione a seguito della valutazione delle competenze/conoscenze/abilità, garantisca l'equità nel livello di partenza. Allo stesso tempo è necessario creare strumenti di informazione/formazione affinché le donne imparino a contrattare le posizioni lavorative. Bisogna impegnarsi per andare al superamento del doppiopesismo per cui se una donna chiede di conoscere e stabilire le condizioni contrattuali è aggressiva e più interessata a se stessa che al lavoro mentre se la richiesta proviene da un uomo è normale e legittima, se una donna chiede l'equiparazione  - a parità di titoli/esperienza/mansioni - con un collega uomo viene liquidata come piantagrane femminista, se un uomo chiede il congedo di maternità è un "mammo". E' necessario lavorare al processo di cambiamento culturale attraverso una pluralità di strumenti, cogenti e non. Dichiarare il livello di retribuzione in una offerta di lavoro deve diventare parte integrante dell'offerta al fine di tutelare gli aspiranti lavoratori garantendone le pari opportunità.
Initiative: Gender pay gap – transparency on pay for men and women

feedback_msg_text: Blue Marine Foundation (BLUE) would like to encourage greater levels of compliance and transparency from the EU distant water fleet, specifically the EU purse seine fleet operating in the Indian Ocean where tuna stocks are overfished and subject to continued overfishing. Specifically, we request greater enforcement of the regulations governing the use of the Automatic Identification System (AIS) by those vessels that benefit from the EU’s Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs) in the Indian Ocean.  The attached report highlights widespread misuse of AIS by Spanish and French-flagged vessels operating in the Indian Ocean over a period of more than two years. We would therefore also like to ask that the Commission requests that the flag states make public the Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) data of their distant water fleets, especially those fleets benefitting from SFPAs. feedback_msg_text: We support the position of Copa Cogeca and AVEC.  The promotion policy is very important for EU agri-food products, including the poultry sector. Promotion programmes are an important tool for promoting the EU's value and the competitiveness of the EU's agricultural sector. We, therefore, welcome the review of the promotion policy, which aims to raise awareness of the quality of EU food products and increase the competitiveness of the EU agricultural sector, while enhancing its contribution to sustainable production and consumption.  Position on the policy options proposed in the Inception Impact Assessment.  For all the reasons set out in our opinion on the objectives of the Inception Impact Assessment, we would prefer a policy option similar to Option 1. 'Building on current success'. We believe that it is reasonable to continue the EU promotion policy on the basis of the current provisions and with the aim of aligning the operational priorities with the objectives deriving from other EU policies, taking into account improvements in certain areas (e.g. streamlining the process of programme evaluation, making the rules for clearing programmes under shared and direct management more coherent). The current legislative text on which the promotion policy is based could perfectly well allow it to enhance its contribution to the sustainability of the food system through guidelines for applicants and evaluators, and improved selection and evaluation criteria in favour of promotion programmes that are coherent with the aim of the Farm-to-Fork strategy.  We do not support option 2. "Focus the policy scope", as we believe that increasing competitiveness is important not only outside EU markets, but also within the EU internal market.   We strongly oppose Option 3. "Review conditionality/eligibility" as it may result in the complete exclusion of certain sectors from support, e.g. meat. We point out that the exclusion of any agricultural product would be absolutely detrimental both to EU and global sustainability and to the competitiveness of the EU agricultural sector.  Finally, we would stress that it is essential to maintain a consistent budget for the Promotion Policy. Since its inception, the Promotion Policy has been a key measure to ensure that EU agriculture remains competitive, with significant positive effects, as evidenced by the evaluation launched by the Commission (SWD (2020) 401 final of 22 December 2020) and many national agricultural organisations across Europe. Additionally, we would like to point out that agricultural markets have been deeply affected by the COVID-19 crisis. In addition, Brexit and the trade war with the US have increased the already heavy burden of the COVID-19 crisis.   It is therefore more important than ever to reap the benefits of a strong and well-funded promotion policy to enable EU farmers to cope and adapt to these difficult current times.  For the full text of the position, see Annex Feedback from: Krajowa Rada Drobiarstwa (168.2 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: We fully support Copa Cogeca position. We generally welcome a revision of the Promotion Policy that is aiming at increasing the agricultural sector competitiveness while also enhancing its contribution to sustainable production and consumption. Indeed, we believe that the Promotion Policy could be a good tool to both promote the EU already high sustainability standards worldwide and to encourage EU producers to increase even further the sustainability of their production. Nonetheless, we would like to underline some specific important elements to take into account regarding the objectives of this revision: Objective 1: refocus the policy objectives on increasing the sustainability of the food system and on nudging consumption to sustainable choices or healthy diets We believe that the Promotion Policy can actively contribute to increasing the sustainability of the food system. However, the following elements need to be taken into account: • Indeed, the contribution of the Promotion Policy can certainly be enhanced, but we need to underlined that thanks to the already high sustainability standards of EU products, the Promotion Policy is already contributing to food sustainability.  • Regarding the objective to nudge consumption to sustainable choices and healthy diets, we would like to insist on the fact that no product is unsustainable or unhealthy by definition. The sustainability of a product depends on its production method that can be more or less sustainable, while the healthiness of a food product depends on the way it is consumed and incorporated in an overall diet. Therefore, we strongly underline the fact that no agricultural good should be excluded from the Promotion Policy or benefit from a reduced support. We thus strongly opposed any reduction of support or exclusion of meat and wine.  • We also would like to state that currently the Commission does not provide a definition of sustainability, which creates some uncertainty regarding how promotion programmes can be understood as contributing to enhancing the sustainability of the food system.  Position regarding the policy options proposed in the Inception Impact Assessment For all the reasons detailed in our reflections on the objectives of this Inception Impact Assessment, we would favour a policy option similar to option the fourth one “Building on the current success”. Indeed, we believe that the current legislative text on which the Promotion Policy is based can perfectly allow to enhance its contribution to the sustainability of the food system through guidance to applicants and evaluators and enhanced selection and evaluation criteria in favour of promotion programmes that are consistent with the Farm to Fork Strategy objective. We do not favour option 2 as we believe that increasing the competitiveness is important not only outside the EU, but also inside the EU market. We strongly oppose option 3 considering that, as stated above, the exclusion of any agricultural product would be extremely damageable both for the competitiveness of the EU agricultural sector and sustainability at EU and global level. Finally, we would like to state that it is vital to maintain a consequent budget for the Promotion Policy in the future. The Promotion Policy has been a key tool to ensure the maintenance of the competitiveness of EU agriculture since its creation and has shown significative positive results as demonstrated by the evaluation commissioned by the Commission (SWD(2020) 401 final of 22 December 2020) and many national farming organisations across Europe. Moreover, agricultural markets have been deeply impacted by the COVID-19 crisis. In addition, the trade war with the USA and the Brexit have added to the already heavy burden of the COVID-19 crisis. It is thus more important than ever to benefit from a strong and well-funded Promotion Policy to enable EU farmers to survive and adapt to these difficult times.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: SCC / CLIAA est l’organisme de coordination en France de l’ensemble des interprofessions du secteur agricole et agroalimentaire. Nous remercions la Commission Européenne de nous permettre de nous exprimer concernant l’évolution de la future politique de promotion pour nos produits. Comprenant tout à fait l’objectif du défi du changement climatique de la politique de la Ferme à l’assiette, nos organisations travaillent sur ce sujet primordial depuis de nombreuses années. Faire connaître l’ensemble des efforts passée et futurs de nos professionnels doit être l’enjeu de la nouvelle politique de promotion que ce soit sur le marché Intérieur ou sur les Pays-Tiers mais la Commission ne doit pas se tromper comme sur l’appel à projet 2021 où un niveau élevé de budget a été octroyé sur les produits biologiques sur le marché intérieur et sur les pays tiers…  En effet, il faut prendre en compte des objectifs économiques raisonnables et mesurables... Les nouveaux programmes de promotion devront donc servir à mettre en avant une agriculture raisonnée et de développement durable et non pas uniquement un segment de cette dernière. feedback_msg_text: We believe that the EU policy for the promotion of agricultural products could play an important role to support objectives of the European Union (EU) related to agriculture, biodiversity, water, soil, climate change, food systems and public health. In order to reach this goal, it must be aligned with current strategies, especially the Farm to Fork and Biodiversity Strategy. The evaluation of the promotion policy and the current public consultation with three policy options opens an opportunity to move forward in this policy field. However, the Commission's recent report evaluating the application of promotion policy (COM/2021/49 final) in our view remains weak when it comes to “coherence”, as it shows that the overall EU policy objectives have not been sufficiently taken into account in the past.  We clearly welcome that the Commission has made a first important step this year to align the policy to the sustainability goals of the European Union by earmarking a relevant share of the budget to the promotion of organic products – this means a good start to support the 25% goal for organic agriculture also in the promotion policies.   However, we believe that in the long run, the promotion policy must further be aligned to sustainability and health objectives – therefore we consider policy option 2 “Focus the policy scope” as the most appropriate.  Promotion and information measures should clearly focus on support of sustainable agricultural production and consumption, in line with the Farm to Fork Strategy and Europe’s beating cancer plan, nudging consumers to healthier diets. Moreover, it should contribute to strenghten rural economies - adding value in the regions by fostering local food transformation should be highlighted as an objective. The focus of promotion and information measures on non-EU markets would be more centred on the international dimension of Farm to Fork. Of course the EU agrifood sector’s competitiveness is also an important objective, but this doesn’t mean it can be the single focus – because sustainability and high quality are the cornerstones for long term competitiveness of European food products on the world market.
Organisation: BÖLW – Bund Ökologischer Lebensmittelwirtschaft (Association of Organic Food Industry)

feedback_msg_text: Thank you very much to allow beneficiaries to give feedback on such an important review.  On behalf of European Garnacha/Grenache Consortium, I'd like to address the following matters:   - Possibility to collaborate with intermediaries (stakeholders) established in third countries appart from the implementing body and its subcontractors, as it'd increase the efficiency of the programs by cutting intermediaries (extra fees), as well as a optimized cultural implementation.  - Demand to increase the available budgets for multi programs in third markets, as such need bigger efforts.  - Budget increase third countries by requirement - Institutional campaing to improve both PDO/PGI and organic EU signs, as well as a mandatory inclusion in products produced under such GIs to increase awarenes of the symbols.  - Need for specific wine category due to the industry speciall characteristics. - Increase grant % for programs affected by COVID.  - Need to update Eurostat data more frequently for the sake of a good impact evaluation. - Include indicators (pdf) asked for in the financial report in the application form in order to already count on the information and avoiding having the need after each implemented period. It would be good if it's made it clear to include them from the proposal itself. - Improve the communications via portal as well as a platform template for ammendments or smaller modifications from the initial plan in order to save time to all involved parties and a better understandment.  - Need to correct EiFe guide/chart, including the complete regulations (f.i. min 1cm EU flag) as well as improving the examples, since most of them don't aplly the regulation correctly.  - Contacts/network/ database of suppliers with experience in the different acctions, programs (either multi or simply) and markets as it'd improve implementation, results and add transparency during the call for implementin/evaluation body tenders.  - Initial clarification on KPIs/outputs, meaning the evaluation of the impact of an action and economic proportional adjustment (e.g. a tasting of 10.000 € for 100 people and in the end it is only 40....).    Thank you very much for having the above under consideration,   Sofía González

feedback_msg_text: Jeremy Coller Foundation welcomes the revision of EU’s agricultural promotion policy Regulation (EU) No 1144/2014. In summary, we particularly support Option 3 which is the proposal for “introduction of new conditionality requirements and eligibility criteria that incentivise applicants to demonstrate support for the Farm to Fork Strategy relevant objectives through their proposed promotion programmes”.  There is a need to consider the policy’s contribution to other EU policy goals such as environmental sustainability, climate change, deforestation, health and antibiotic use, animal welfare, and pandemic risk (see below). In addition to the options currently on the table, JCF supports the addition of a further option on the removal of Regulation 1124/2014. feedback_msg_text: Die EU Absatzförderung ist ein wichtiges Instrument zur Förderung von den gewünschten Produkten.   Der Schwerpunkt auf ökologische Erzeugung im Jahr 2021 ist sehr wichtig, auch für die Folgejahre, um das Bewusstsein um die ganzheitliche Qualität dieser Produkte der Bevölkerung bekannter zu machen. Mit dem Ökolandbau besteht bereits ein bewährtes System, welches positive Klimawirkungen sowie artgerechte Tierhaltung und transparente Prozessketten abprüfbar integriert hat und sehr effizient ist.  Mit steigendem Verbraucherbewusstsein Hier gehört dazu, dass die Promotion in Synergie mit bewährten privaten Labeln wie Bioland, Demeter oder dem Ama Gütesiegel erfolgen kann - und keine regulatorischen Schranken vorgeschoben werden.  Auch sollten im Biobereich kleinere Initiativen zum Zug kommen können, die Hürde einen sehr hohen Marktanteil nachzuweisen, ist hier nicht sachgerecht, da die Arbeit im Rahmen vom bereits intensiv kontrollierten Öko-Kontrollsystem abläuft und somit eine vergleichbare Qualität gewährleistet ist. Das geförderte Marketing ist in besonderem Maße innerhalb der EU notwendig, da somit stabile Wertschöpfungsketten geschaffen werden können und die Bevölkerung hier aktiv zur Erreichung der Ziele des EU-Green Deals bzw. der enthaltenen Farm to Fork Strategie beiträgt.   Darüber hinaus ist die Förderung von Spezialitäten nach g.g.A., g.U. und g.t.S. sehr wichtig.   Hier ist der Fokus darauf zu legen, dass bäuerliche Organisationen als Antragssteller besonders gefördert werden sollten.   Die vorgesehene Sanktionierung stellt ein sehr großes Risiko und eine große Abschreckung für potentielle Antragssteller dar. Ob eine Maßnahme förderkonform ist, liegt allein in der Interpretation der prüfenden Behörde. Hier sollte es die Möglichkeit geben, dass Muster für Werbematerialien oder Maßnahmen im Rahmen der Erstellung auf freiwilliger Basis bereits von der Behörde geprüft und rechtssicher freigegeben werden können.  Im Falle einer Sanktion, bei der nicht nur die bereits erstattete Summe zurückgezahlt werden muss, sondern auch noch das doppelte als Strafe sowie ggf. noch eine Kürzung des Budgets erfolgt, kann dies eine kleinere Durchführende Organisation schnell in wirtschaftliche Schwierigkeiten oder gar in den Konkurs bringen. Die Organisation würde in Ihrer Berechnung z. B. für eine Maßnahme mit Kosten von 200.000 Euro davon ausgehen, dass sie 20% Eigenanteil zu zahlen hat, also 40.000 Euro. Bei einer Sanktionierung beläuft sich der wirtschaftliche Verlust dann auf 520.000 (200k voll selbst zahlen +2x160k Sanktion) bis 680.000 Euro (zzgl. Budgetkürzung um 160k). Also einem Betrag, der 13 bis 17 mal höher ist als die geplante Investitionssumme für die Marketingmaßnahme.   Man braucht sich hier nicht wundern, dass viele potentielle Antragssteller davon absehen, diese Förderung in Anspruch zu nehmen.  Des weiteren sind die Bearbeitungszeiten zu lang. Nur ein Antragstermin im Jahr ist zu wenig, die Erstellung eines Antrags der im Wettbewerb bestehen kann benötigt mehrere Monate - dazu kommen noch ca. 9 Monate Bearbeitungsdauer bei Chafea. Bis ein PRogramm dann direkt starten kann, vergehen weitere Monate. Hier sollten die Prozesse beschleunigt werden.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: ProVeg welcomes the Commission’s aim to undertake a review of the agricultural promotion policy “with a view to enhancing its contribution to sustainable production and consumption, and in line with the shift to a more plant-based diet, with less red and processed meat and more fruit and vegetables”.   We urge the Commission to promote the shift to plant proteins and to empower the public to make healthy and sustainable food choices. As such, we support a combination of policy options 2 and 3. Furthermore, we would like to highlight that policy option 1, which states that ‘the current policy would largely remain as it is’, is not a realistic option if the promotion scheme is to be in line with the EU’s Farm to Fork Strategy.  Policy Option 2: We agree with the Commission that the review of the EU agricultural promotion policy (Regulation 1144/2014) needs to be assessed in line with the Farm to Fork Strategy and Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan. In this context, the review should lead to projects being evaluated based on an impact assessment which takes into account the fact that the production of meat and dairy products is a leading cause of climate change and biodiversity loss and poses severe threats to human health.   The guiding principle of policy option 2 should therefore be that it ‘needs to support the public interest’ and thus promote foods that lead to sustainable lifestyles. It should certainly not support sectors that do otherwise, harming Europe’s public health and environment. We therefore propose zero-to-low carbon footprint, zero-to-low biodiversity loss and improving human health as three leading and mandatory requirements to apply for the promotion scheme.    Policy Option 3: We are delighted with the Commission’s aim to review the current agricultural promotion policy in order to align it with the shift to a more plant-based diet. However, such shifts can only be achieved if the plant-based sector receives sufficient support to grow and to produce alternatives that can adequately mimic the texture, taste, and price of conventional meat and dairy products. In this light, it will be of key importance to amend Regulation 1144/2014 to extend the list of eligible products and schemes to include (processed) plant-based alternatives such as veggie burgers, veggie sausages, and almond milk; to ensure that organisations active in the plant-based sector can qualify as ‘proposing organisations’ and for applicants to be required to demonstrate that their campaign will support the Farm to Fork Strategy, following the three impact criteria mentioned under policy option 2.  In addition, we call on the Commission to consider the scientific consensus on the adverse impact of meat and dairy on climate change, biodiversity loss, and human health. The conditionality requirements and eligibility criteria should be updated in such a way that promotional funding will no longer be provided for products such as meat and dairy that have such adverse impacts.  ProVeg calls on the European Commission to honour the scientific consensus on the environmental impact of meat and dairy in relation to food-related decision-making processes. It ought to prioritise the promotion of more environmentally-friendly farming practices (e.g. plant-based food production) by 1) assessing the environmental impact of eligible foods, 2) including (processed) plant-based foods as eligible products, 3) extending the list of ‘proposing organisations’, and 4) significantly reducing the promotion of meat and dairy. In this way, the Commission will ensure that the overall goal of the promotion scheme is in line with the public interest, empowering the public to make healthy and sustainable food choices as described in its Farm to Fork strategy.    Please find more background and details attached. Feedback from: ProVeg International (112.2 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: la pandémie de covid 19 touche après les personnes très âgées , les personnes souffrant de maladies issues de l'obésité . C'est troublant que l'UE axe son argumentaire santé sur la consommation de viandes rouge et viandes transformées alors que l'ultra transformation des végétaux ,des boissons est scientifiquement reconnue comme un vecteur important d'obésité et cancers liés . L'ultra transformation de produits végan , de part le process d'extraction élimine les micro nutriments et autres anticancers naturels contenu dans les végétaux .Idem pour la viande , d'une part concernant la viande rouge il y a des différences nutritionnelles entre les modes d'élevage .Par exemple l'élevage  à l'herbe  augmente les teneurs en oméga 3 ou vitamine B12 , B2 du produit final , contrairement à un élevage industriel confiné qui utilise en masse du soja et autres farines de céréales , ou ensilages de Maîs etc dans les rations .Ici on observe des saturations en gras cancérigènes . Quand aux charcuteries , si le mode d'élevage peut aussi avoir un impact nutritionnel , c'est surtout l'ajout de nitrites par l'industrie agroalimentaire qui caractérise le facteur cancérigène .L'étude de L'OMS est donc en soi très peu objective d'un point de vue scientifique .Plus généralement , les produits ultra transformés sont imbibés de sucre , sel, et autres additifs ou auxiliaires technologiques eux même classés cancérigènes ou mutagènes. Et pourtant l'argumentation de la CE sur l'aspect santé se concentre exclusivement sur la Viande rouge ou la charcuterie!?  Dans le même temps les importations de viandes du Mercosur ,Nouvelle Zélande , Canada etc s'accélère ce qui extermine le pastoralisme Européen .N'est ce pas une situation paradoxale ?   Pour preuve une étude de l'UE paru en décembre dit que " 30 %des zones agricoles de l'UE sont exposés à un risque d'abandon des Terres ". Ce sont ici essentiellement des zones de montagnes et zones défavorisées ,c'est à dire les zones Pastorales qui sont les premières atteintes par ce phénomène de concurrence avec les importations massives .Si en France et pour l'instant ,ces zones pastorales sont soutenues par la PAC , ce n'est pas le cas dans la plupart des autres Etats membres . D'où l'importance d'établir une politique publique de promotion qui encourage le maintien du Pastoralisme Européen PARTOUT .De même les produits de mer et des océans doivent bénéficier d'un soutien pour une pêche artisanale .Dans le travail en cours et français du retex de la crise du covid 19 , il apparait clairement que les territoires qui avaient mis en place des PAT(programme alimentaire territoriaux ) s'en sont très bien sortis pendant les confinements afin de proposer aux populations de ces territoires des produits frais LOCAUX  de haute qualité , que ce soient pour les végétaux comme les produits animaux .   Dans ce contexte de pandémie du sars cov 2 dont le mode d'alimentation est directement lié aux cas symptomatiques , et sachant que d'autres virus risque de se propager , il est crucial de promouvoir en Europe l'ancrage territorial de l'alimentation , en produits de saison et qualité BIO autant que possible et promouvoir la diversité nutritionnelle de l'assiette .Aussi pour l'ensemble de la restauration publique . Certes la diversité de l'assiette doit faire la part belle aux fruits et légumes et légumineuses ,mais c'est ici une question de portion ou grammage .Cette adaptation nutritionnelle permettrait de mieux  valoriser nos Terres et Océans /Mer Européennes ,aves des paysans et pêcheurs nombreux . Mais pour y arriver faut commencer par stopper les importations massives de viandes comme de soja ,et promouvoir les métiers de l'agriculture et de la pêche Européens .C'est d'actualité en France avec une vaste promotion publique "Nous paysans " à travers les médias télévisés ou radiophoniques ,et avec des rencontres citoyennes sur les fermes .
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: Invitiamo la Commissione a leggere tutto il documento che alleghiamo.   Come già scritto nella lettera inviata in data 15 febbraio 2021 dalle Interprofessioni di Italia, Francia, Spagna, Irlanda, Polonia e Ungheria ai Commissari europei, Mr. Frans Timmermans, Executive Vice-President for the European Green Deal, Mr. Valdis Dombrovskis, Executive Vice-President for an Economy that works for people, Mr Janusz Wojciechowski, Commissioner for Agriculture, M. Virginijus Sinkevičius, Commissioner for Environment, Oceans and Fisheries, con oggetto: “la Commissione europea deve garantire la coerenza tra le sue politiche pubbliche agricole, ambientali, commerciali e di promozione”, chiediamo che la zootecnia europea venga rispettata come tutte le altre produzioni agricole, che contribuiscono ad alimentare 500 milioni di cittadini europei.   La carne bovina è una componente essenziale per una corretta dieta alimentare e, negli anni, ha contribuito a migliorare le aspettative di vita.  Il consumo di carne, nell’ambito di una dieta regolare – poco di tutto – deve essere favorito dall’Europa continuando a finanziare la comunicazione e promozione, privilegiando programmi che valorizzino gli allevamenti sostenibili a livello ambientale, sociale ed economico.  L’Italia produce solo il 53% della carne bovina commercializzata, pertanto, l’autosufficienza alimentare va garantita e gli allevatori italiani, da anni, applicano nei loro allevamenti regole più rigide di quelle emanate dai Regolamenti europei in materia di Condizionalità, Benessere Animale, Qualità delle Produzioni (senza attendere posizioni come quelle espresse in Farm To Fork).  Gli allevatori italiani chiedono che la politica di promozione dell’Unione europea non discrimini la promozione della carne bovina, anzi, ne favorisca l’abbinamento con altre produzioni privilegiando la qualità, la sostenibilità ambientale, sociale ed economica.  Se le aziende di allevamento migliorano il loro reddito, potranno reinvestire i guadagni nell’ambito della propria attività, modernizzando gli allevamenti protetti a vantaggio del benessere animale e dell’ambiente.  Impoverire le aziende di allevamento, togliendo loro i fondi Pac, gli aiuti accoppiati, la promozione,  sarebbe un disastro per imprenditori e consumatori. Nessuno investirebbe nelle attività zootecniche, l’Europa sarebbe costretta ad importare quantitativi enormi di carne da Paesi Terzi e la sicurezza alimentare di 500 milioni di consumatori sarebbe a rischio con costi enormi per la salute (in Europa, vedi l’uso legalizzato di estrogeni negli Usa) e per l’ambiente (nel Mondo… vedi deforestazione amazzonica).  Ci affidiamo all’intelligenza del legislatore, non alle mode (vegan, vegetarian) o alle emozioni di chi sostiene che un bovino inquini più di un SUV.  Noi, con il progetto Life Beef Carbon (parteciopato assieme a Francia, Irlanda e Spagna) abbiamo dimostrato che la zootecnia italiana contribuisce solo per il 5,9% alle emissioni in atmosfera. Sarebbe quanto mai opportuno che la Commissione intervenga sul restante 94,1%. Feedback from: OI INTERCARNEITALIA (341.4 KB - PDF - 11 pages) Download
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: Somos uma OP portuguesa de produtores de porcos e estamos a levar a cabo uma campanha de promoção denominada “LET’S TALK ABOUT PORK “ que está enquadrada dentro dos programas europeus de promoção. Esta campanha de três anos entrou agora no segundo ano e tem sido muito importante para o setor uma vez que pela primeira vez estamos a passar ao consumidor o que fazemos e os nossos métodos de produção. Estamos assim a desfazer mitos errados que existiam em relação à carne de porco permitindo ao consumidor uma melhor decisão das suas escolhas. Não podemos compreender que hoje em dia se comece a falar de retirar a carne dos programas de promoção para diminuir o seu consumo. Isto parece-nos que vai contra todos os princípios de liberdade uma vez que deve ser dado a possibilidade ao consumidor de decidir. Para uma boa decisão temos de ter uma boa informação e este tem sido o nosso objetivo e não o conseguíamos fazer sem o apoio comunitário dos programas europeus de promoção.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: A Agrupalto é uma OP portuguesa de produtores de porcos que dispõe de estruturas de produção de ração e de preparação de carne. Há cerca de dois anos lançou-se na exportação para países terceiros de carne de porco devido a estar consciente que o equilíbrio de mercado deste produto baseia-se sobretudo na exportação. O maior importador de carne de porco a nível mundial é a China, país para onde começamos a exportar. Para o nosso sucesso tem sido fundamental a campanha de promoção que estamos a levar a cabo denominada de “FROM FARM TO FORK “ que mesmo apesar de todos os contratempos devidos ao COVID tem dado a conhecer ao consumidor chinês as características e a qualidade da carne de porco europeia contribuindo assim para aumentarmos as nossas exportações. Esta campanha não tinha sido possível sem o apoio da EU através dos programas de promoção. Este ano vamos candidatar-nos aos programas de promoção para os mercados da Coreia do Sul e Japão, países para onde vamos começar a exportar este ano logo que estejam terminadas as obras de uma nova estrutura de preparação de carnes dedicada para a exportação. Contamos com o apoio comunitário através dos programas de promoção para ajudar a pagar o investimento agora realizado.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: DELCOF SA, the cluster of the Greek fruit canning industry, has been beneficiary and coordinator in a number of promotion campaigns over the years. We can testify to the policy's effectiveness in promoting positive perceptions of European agri-food products around the world. We can also confirm the policy is a great boost for extrovert, exporting industries like ours.  The promotion of healthy diets and sustainable choices is definately the course towards which the policy will and should move. The consumption of fruits and vegetables daily should be one of the main messages. In this context, it is important to take into account that processed fruits and vegetables count the same towards the goal of 5 a day, while being the most convenient and affordable way of consuming fruits and vegetables. Convenience and affordability are of paramount importance if the goal is to really reach all the population, irrespective of their income or place of living. We believe that the best way to proceed is to maintan the basic structure of the policy that has worked so well for many years and adjust the criteria or/and budget towards more sustainable practices and more healthy choices. However, great care should be given to the definitions of sustainable and healthy. The exclusion of processed fruits from the healthy choices is unfair and not backed by science. In another issue, we strongly support the direct european mangement of all campaigns, simple and multi. A stable and pre-confirmed framework is necessary for the effective implementation of any campaign and this is guaranteed by european authorities.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: Les productions de viandes européennes doivent pouvoir bénéficier de fonds européens de promotion, tant sur le marché intérieur que dans les pays tiers, pour mettre en avant leur qualité, les modalités d’élevage respectueuses des normes européennes environnementales, de bien-être animal, sanitaires ou encore de traçabilité et apportant de nombreux bénéfices écologiques et sociétaux. INTERBEV appelle à une approche constructive pour la filière viande et éducative pour les consommateurs, plutôt qu’à une stigmatisation des productions animales.   Veuillez trouver en pièce jointe notre contribution complète.  INTERBEV est l’Association Nationale Interprofessionnelle du Bétail et des Viandes, fondée en 1979 à l’initiative des organisations représentatives de la filière française de l’élevage et des viandes. Elle reflète la volonté des professionnels des secteurs bovin, ovin, équin et caprin de proposer aux consommateurs des produits sains, de qualité et identifiés tout au long de la filière. Elle fédère et valorise les intérêts communs de l’élevage, des activités artisanales, industrielles et commerciales de ce secteur, qui constitue l’une des premières activités économiques de notre territoire. Afin de mieux intégrer les attentes de la société, les professionnels de cette filière se sont rassemblés autour d’une démarche de responsabilité sociétale, labellisée par l’AFNOR « engagé RSE confirmé » de niveau 3 sur 4 en juin 2018 : le « Pacte sociétal », qui vise à mieux répondre collectivement aux enjeux en matière d’environnement, de protection animale, de juste rémunération des acteurs de la filière et d’attractivité de ses métiers au service d’une alimentation raisonnée et de qualité. Aujourd’hui, cette démarche qui engage la filière dans la promesse responsable et durable « Aimez la viande, mangez-en mieux. », est portée par une campagne de communication collective du même nom, signée « Naturellement Flexitariens ». feedback_msg_text: L214 Éthique & Animaux welcomes the revision of EU’s agricultural promotion policy Regulation (EU) No 1144/2014.   It is paramount to shift from meat to a more plant-based diet, for environmental reasons, for health reasons, and for ethical reasons.   This fight against climate change is at the heart of the ambitions of the EU, which set the goal to reach carbon neutrality by 2050. This goal is out of reach if we do not change the way we farm and the way we eat. Greenpeace recently released a report stating that citizens of the EU need to reduce their meat consumption by 71% by 2030, and by 80% by 2050, if we are to tackle farming’s contribution to climate change. NGOs and the EU share the same goals. We now need to have a coherent policy to reach them together. And any support to the promotion of animal products goes against the objectives of the Farm to Fork Strategy. Therefore, as such, they should not be eligible for the policy, and the support should exclusively be directed towards plant-based products.   Banning the support of the promotion of animal products would also reflect the European citizens’s will: they have clearly indicated that the welfare of farmed animals is paramount to them (Special Eurobarometer 442, 2016). They have also indicated their willingness to eat more sustainably (BEUC, 2019). Interestingly, a majority of citizens also consider that marketing and advertising do not contribute to healthy, sustainable diets and that they should therefore be restricted (Special Eurobarometer 505, 2020). The promotion programme should be coherent with the citizen’s will.   Finally, we believe that a revised policy is a great opportunity to raise Europe as a beacon of the sustainable plant-based protein emerging market, and to enhance its competitiveness outside the EU.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: ETPOA, the European Trade Promotion Organisations' Association, is grateful for the opportunity to contribute feedback on the roadmap and will use the opportunity during the public consultation to outline our substantial views on the policy review.   Regarding the roadmap, we have outlined our  position in the attachment. In summary these are the key points:  - Eligibility criteria should consider all dimensions of sustainability – economic, social and environmental considerations should be taken into account. - Avoid unintended impacts on competitiveness of the different policy options. - No outright exclusion or stigmatisation of any specific sector. Should cover all sectors with a fair approach taking into account a level playing field and differentiation among different markets and their consumers. - Different conditions should apply for promotion activities intended to the internal market and third markets, reflecting the different market realities, especially recognition of the contribution of food exports on sustainability of our agricultural model and quality of our diet. - Increase the transparency of the decision-making process of European Commission own initiatives through increased engagement with relevant stakeholders, such as Trade Promotion Organisations (TPOs). - Broaden the scope of eligible entities to include all national and regional TPOs. feedback_msg_text: Choosing to give priority to programs that promote plant production and exclude animal production from the scope goes against European policies to support GI products which are mostly traditional products and emblematic of the gastronomy of European countries, and often processed meats (charcuteries) and cheeses. feedback_msg_text: The Dierenbescherming welcomes the revision of EU’s agricultural promotion policy Regulation (EU) No 1144/2014. We support the view that a revision is necessary in order to make sure the policy contributes to sustainable production and consumption, in order to support a shift to a more plant-based diet. In addition we see it as an opportunity to promote more high-animal-welfare products (including fish), which could help farmers and food industry to sell these products and thereby making investments in animal welfare more feasible.  Goals of subsidized campaigns should be clear and in line with the objectives of the Farm to Fork strategy. They should contribute to higher animal welfare, climate and environmental goals, and public health. How the campaigns contribute to these goals should be made explicit in the application procedure. Campaigns not contributing to these goals, or only one of the goals while having a negative effect on the others, should not be eligible for EU funding.    Less and better: less animal protein On the long term, we set the goal at 30% animal protein and 70% plant based protein, with an average recommended daily protein intake of 0.8 g/kg body weight. This reduction in animal protein intake is good for human health, requires less animals and is more sustainable than the current Western diet with a high animal:plant protein ratio. This is underpinned by studies such as those from Dr Hannah van Zanten and Prof Dr Imke de Boer (https://research.wur.nl/en/publications/defining-a-land-boundary-for-sustainable-livestock-consumption). We see potential for the revised policy in enhancing the profile of European produced sustainable plant-based protein, meat alternatives and production processes, both in the EU and on export markets. Campaigns that are designed to increase the consumption of animal protein should not be subsidized.   Less and better: better animal welfare European citizens have clearly indicated that they want the welfare of farmed animals to be better protected (Special Eurobarometer 442, 2016). In addition, many farmers indicate they are willing to invest in higher animal welfare, as long as there’s a market for these products. Therefore, the promotion policy should support farmers and food industry to transition to higher animal welfare systems. The revision of the policy should remove obstacles to improving animal welfare in food production across Europe. To this end it is crucial to determine criteria to ensure promoted products actually deliver on animal welfare or other sustainability claims, and to prevent false claims about animal welfare. Claims and labels should be scored at least on their level of ambition (i.e. how much do they actually contribute to animal welfare), level of transparency and the quality and independence of auditing. A tool that could aid in this is the proposed Method of Production+ labelling (MoP+) (https://www.eurogroupforanimals.org/sites/eurogroup/files/2020-10/E4A-AW-Food_Labeling-2020-web-version.pdf), a framework in which production systems and animal welfare labels can be categorized.  In addition, subsidized campaigns should be monitored to make sure they do not contain misleading information. E.g. in the Netherlands, the Advertising Code Committee judged the EU-funded campaigns about poultry meat (https://files.wakkerdier.nl/app/uploads/2020/12/18115422/advertentie-Nepluvi_tijdschrift-2.jpg?_ga=2.244527811.79978069.1614767904-645867865.1587045963)  and dairy (e.g. https://allesbegintmetmelk.nl/) as misleading for consumers, as they painted a more positive picture regarding animal welfare than is the case in reality. Therefore, an EU institution should approve campaigns on forehand, and have the mandate to require changes to be made to the campaigns.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU

feedback_msg_text: In the current EU agricultural promotion policy, attention is paid to fruit and vegetables and their place in a healthy and sustainable diet. However, other healthy and sustainable products (e.g. bread) should not be forgotten. It is known that most bread is plant-based and has a low carbon footprint. In addition, the beneficial health effects of (whole grain) bread are widely accepted. Intake of whole grain bread reduces the risk of colorectal cancer and other cancers of the digestive tract, mainly because of the high amount of grain fiber. Unfortunately, the intake of whole grain and (grain) fiber is still lower than the recommendations and therefore (whole grain) bread deserves attention as well.   Nevertheless, it is not without reason that an important part of the Planetary Health Plate consist of whole grain, which can also be seen in national dietary guidelines of member states. In our opinion, the EU agricultural promotion policy should evenly pay attention to fruit and vegetable as to (whole grain) bread and other products that fit in a healthy and sustainable diet.
Initiative: EU farm and food products – review of policy on promotion inside and outside the EU
