feedback_msg_text: FPAS (Portuguese Swine Farmers Federation) is a non-profit entity that represents the entire Portuguese pork sector, including local breeds.  We consider that in recent years, EU Promotion Programmes have demonstrated to be effective & efficient tools to inform with rigor and transparency about the European production model, based on high standards of safety, quality, traceability, animal welfare, animal health and respect for the environment. In addition, that allows to increase awareness and recognition of high-quality, safe and nutritious products not only in the internal market but also in third countries.  In this context, through the campaign “Let´s Talk About Pork From Europe” we are getting to reach and interact with consumers (including millennials) to show satisfactorily that the European model of pig production complies with the most demanding regulations in the world in food safety and traceability that results in quality and nutritious pork which is versatile and healthy to include in a balanced diet and healthy lifestyle following the proven nutritional guidelines and scientific recommendations.  For those reasons, we consider that EU promotion policies are necessary and very useful for our sector and we support the current need to reinforce the focus on ‘sustainable production methods’ in line with the Farm To Fork Strategy, but not on products and/or sectors. Consequently, we are not in favour to exclude any specific products or sectors on these policies.  We think that is essential to promote sustainable business practices implemented by food business operators as an incentive (e.g. protecting the animal welfare, fighting climate change, promoting the efficient use of resources…) and at the same time to communicate the main achievements in recent years on these matters to get added value of EU products. We strongly believe that promotion for sectors which are investing in these issues are of huge importance.  As pork sector is fully committed with sustainability and seeks to provide safe, nutritious and high-quality pork minimizing environmental impact, it must not be forgotten in this legal review.

feedback_msg_text: Unrecognizably, The European Agriculture faces future challenges, such as reducing the greenhouse gas emissions in alignment with Europe’s contribute to the objectives of the Farm to Fork strategy. In times of population growth and a high need of sufficient and safe food such as poultry meat (a growing market in consumer needs), Europe’s capacity to produce must stay sufficient.   The impact of the Farm to Fork Strategy to the food sector must focus on allowing the sector to adapt and thrive in the future; which is key for sustainability. Promotion for sectors which are investing in these issues are of huge importance. Without these kind of promotion sustainable EU sectors can be overtaken by sectors from other continents which are commonly less sustainable. In this respect we choose option 1, which can be a bit influenced by option 2.   Besides that it is good to promote the EU sector for agricultural products (especially compared to the the products which are produced outside the EU), we can imagine that the policy for promotion will take several aspects into account:  Nutritional value Promotion of products which are not healthy may be looked upon in a different way than other sectors. It is of great importance however that for this aspect science based facts are taken into account and not (political) opinions. For example; some people say that meat is not healthy, but scientist agree that meat and poultry meat contain essential vitamins and minerals which other products do not have in that way.  Environmental impact It is not wise to ban a product group or a sector from getting promotion, but it is more strategic to focus within a product group which products are more sustainable than others. For example when you look within in the meat sector you can say the poultry meat has by far the lowest CO2 footprint and besides that, it is also far lower compared to the CO2-footrpint of poultry meat which is produced in other continents.   Way of production in the EU compared to other continents In order to ensure that the EU can maintain its leading position and reach their goals in the field of sustainability, a level playing field between our (poultry meat) products and the imported (poultry meat) products is essential. Unfortunately, current imports from third countries do not meet the same sustainability requirements  with its additional costs. As a result, our sector suffers from the large import flows. Step one to tackle is to increase the awareness of the qualities of EU food products and the threats of imports from non-EU countries. Step two is to strengthen the position of EU producers so they can aligned with political priorities and contribute to the objectives of the Farm to Fork strategy. Promotion can contribute for sure within this aspect.

feedback_msg_text: Bizum is the value-added services A2A payments built over the SCT Inst rails by Spanish banks. Bizum has already developed a successful business model involving merchants (online and physical) leveraging instant payments (2021: +20 M consumers & +20.000 merchants). In order to achieve the same framework on an European level involving cross-border payments, establishing a legal and regulatory framework could provide a needed basis but it is not enough to make it feasible and successful.  From our experience, merchants would be interested in integrating new payment methods if there is a well established brand that consumers feel comfortable with and it is backed by a reliable institution (financial, credit...). This means investing money in a panEuropean brand to fulfill a proper level of awareness. Additionally, user experience must be homogenous among countries and comply with PSD2. Both consumers and merchants need to be protected and instant payments scheme should bring to the table operational processes involved in this kind of payments: dispute mechanisms, chargebacks, refunds... Last but not least, a business model should be put in place so both account issuers and acquiers benefit from it. This means a profitable way for the players involved to face the investments linked to the development and uptake of SCTInst.
Initiative: Instant payments

feedback_msg_text: The French Payments Committee gathers representatives from the offer and demand side of the payments industry, together with relevant public authorities. The CNPS had responded to the Commission’s 2020 consultation on its retail payments strategy.  A. The CNPS concurs on the necessity to guarantee a wide coverage of IPs at the EU level, to benefit from network effects. However we believe the percentage of reachable payment accounts to be more representative than that of reachable PSPs: hence, in case of mandatory adherence, we recommend specifying exceptions (depending on activities, number of payment accounts and business cases), and allowing for a sufficient rollout period taking into account the necessary changes in PSPs' systems.  Although progress has been made, SCTInst levels still remain limited as compared to SCT. Sectoral feedbacks and exchanges within the CNPS corroborate the Commission’s diagnosis: - PSPs cited concerns on regulatory and operational risks linked to the issuing and processing of IPs and the lack of harmonization.  - Slow end-user adoption can be explained by premium pricing, and a lack of awareness of IPs' benefits. There is a need for maturity, since value-added services in IP have recently been or are being launched.  We share the Commission’s concern regarding the need for a pan-European payment solution. The CNPS has been closely following the developments of the European Payments Initiative (EPI), which could generate large volumes at EU level and as such seems the most  promising initiative to achieve the Single market for payments.   Although primarily a national forum, the CNPS alleges the necessity of a clear objective and coordinated approach at the EU level. It welcomes the Commission’s intention to promote SCTInst as the “new normal”, and favors giving public institutions and administrations a leading role in supporting/accepting/using IPs, provided that a balanced business model can exist for each stakeholder.   B. Various degrees of intervention will most probably be necessary to make IPs the “new normal”. The CNPS would favour a combination of all three options: - Baseline option: consistent monitoring of IP  evolution remains indispensable to identify pain points and calibrate promotion efforts. Yet this option alone would fail to provide a “clearly coordinated approach”. - Non-legislative option: although there is indeed a need for active promotion campaigns, similar actions are planned by the Eurosystem and the ERPB, which will be relayed by nationational communities who also have their own communication agenda. Coordination efforts are always welcome, notably as regards the development of common technical standards for payment initiation (QRCodes, eID solutions, proxy registry, etc); yet in view of the deeper technical and competition hurdles identified, non-legislative policy options would not prove ambitious enough. - Legislative option: must be envisaged where relevant. Market analyses conducted by the CNPS highlighted obstacles which call for ambitious policy options as suggested by the Commission regarding: (i) IP value proposition for end-users in terms of pricing, balanced business model for all stakeholders and consumer protection measures; (ii) OS mobile NFC openness to ensure a level playing field for digital wallets; (iii) coordination of security and compliance efforts and requirements (including sanction screening); and (iv) coverage of IP services at the EU scale to ensure that most PSPs are able to receive IPs.   Additional measures on transparency, interoperability and standardization are welcome, though the CNPS sees them as closely related to the development of EPI.  C. From a French perspective, we would add that IPs coupled with additional services such as RTP could be an alternative for dated and less secure payment means such as cheques, which would benefit both PSPs and users. Specific advantages for each type of end-user should orient promotion initiatives.
Organisation: French Payments Committee - Comité national des paiements scripturaux
Initiative: Instant payments
organisation_lower: french payments committee - comité national des paiements scripturaux

feedback_msg_text: SIA, European leader in the design, creation and management of technology infrastructures and services for Financial Institutions, Central Banks, Corporates and the Public Sector is grateful to make available its competences and experience to the European Commission and provide a feedback to the inception impact assessment on policy options to support the development of instant payments.  It is clear that to really develop instant payments a substantial number of PSPs that have yet to adhere to the Scheme should become part of the instant payments community. Making sure that all PSPs offer the possibility to consumers and corporates to at least receive instant payments on their accounts would certainly greatly help its adoption, enabling counterparts to start exploiting the potential of the payment method.  Eliminating any instant payments transaction fees for the consumer would also make its adoption as a retail payment method more attractive; their elimination must be done in a way that guarantees a fair remuneration of the PSPs’ operating costs.  This should be associated to adequate fraud-prevention measures to lower the risk perceived by the end-users and to clear dispute processes to protect consumers (for example when the merchant fails to deliver an ecommerce purchase) that are already well-established best practices with other payment methods.  However, setting up the proper technical infrastructure and ensuring the full European reachability would not be enough for a widespread adoption of instant payments, if not complemented by a timely implementation of end to end standards at application level (including point of interaction standards) and ensuring the interoperability of the different initiatives. Delays in finalising an effective working framework could lead to a proliferation of local stand-alone solutions for the domestic markets, frustrating all integration efforts made on traditional payments with the SEPA programme. The deployment of technical solutions based on standards (e.g. request-to-pay) at the point of interaction and leveraging the APIs developed with the introduction of the PSD2 is likely to mitigate this risk and greatly help smoothen the path of adoption.  The development of instant payments would also be beneficial to the convergence with card payment (e.g. using cards to initiate instant payments or settling card transactions with instant payments), also with the ultimate goal of creating a pan-European card scheme.
Initiative: Instant payments

feedback_msg_text: The EPC supports the European Commission’s overall objective, i.e., “to foster pan-European market initiatives based on instant payments, which would ensure that anyone holding a payment account in the EU could be able to receive and send an instant credit transfer from and to any other payment account in the EU.”  The EPC believes in the market-led deployment of instant payments which has proven a success in several EU countries outside the euro area and more recently by the substantial progress of the SCT Inst scheme since its effective date (November 2017) as the latest SCT Inst scheme statistics below demonstrate: - over 2,300 scheme participants in 23 countries (March 2021 data) - more than 68% penetration in terms of adherence in the euro area (March 2021 data)  - 12 euro area countries with a very significant majority of payment accounts reachable for SCT Inst (March 2021 data)  - about 8% of total euro credit transfer (SCT + SCT Inst) volumes (Q4-2020 data) - over 99.5% of successful transactions completed in less than 5 seconds (Q4-2020 data) - maximum transaction amount increased to € 100,000 as of 1 July 2020 from the original scheme limit of € 15,000  The above metrics are expected to show further growth over the coming quarters.  The EPC:   - Continues to actively promote adherence to SCT Inst and pursues its efforts to foster the scheme’s attractiveness and reachability. - Supports the overall objective pursued by the Eurosystem’s interoperability initiative to facilitate full pan-SEPA reachability (with full market implementation understood to be completed early 2022). - Is of the opinion that there is only a potential need for limited, targeted, and proportionate legislative initiatives to ensure a regulatory level playing field among all payment instruments in similar use cases or to remove regulatory obstacles for instant payments. An example of specific area in which a targeted EC action may be needed is “sanction screening” as recently flagged by the EPC (see the EPC’s letter to the EC of 15 March 2021). - Supports the proportionality principle highlighted by the EC.  The extension of the exemption period granted in November 2017 to the SCT Inst scheme under Article 4, (4), of the “SEPA Regulation” for two more years, coupled with the reformulation of its second criterion by referring to a more concrete yardstick such as a majority of reachable payment accounts (instead of a majority of Payment Service Providers), would enable and support the smooth further development of SCT Inst. The EPC is not in favour of a mandate for SCT Inst adherence but if a mandate were nevertheless to be decided there would be a need for a reasonable deadline (e.g., a 2-year timeline for the euro area), proportionality (e.g., “carve-out” for “niche” players, a “receiving” only obligation) and a distinction between the euro area and the other EU countries (i.e., a two-step approach like for the “SEPA Regulation” implementation).  The EPC would welcome a leading role by public institutions, administrations and services in supporting/accepting/using instant payments. The EPC believes that fair access to “infrastructure” (e.g., NFC controller in mobile devices) and technology neutrality in any EC actions are key to foster the deployment and take-up of instant payments solutions. Given the substantial investment and operational costs required by the development, deployment and running of instant payment solutions, their economic sustainability for all actors involved needs to be enabled by the EC. Public authorities’ support for the industry’s efforts to prevent and fight against fraud would be welcome, as security is key for end-users’ trust in payment solutions.
Initiative: Instant payments

feedback_msg_text: Intesa Sanpaolo agrees that a lack of well-functioning instant credit transfer solution that could fully rely on European payments infrastructure obliges most of the European PSPs to be dependent on global players, being them cards or more and more Big Techs for EU cross-border card payments. We share the EC concerns on the still low level of adherence to the SCT Inst scheme by EU PSPs. On the adherence issue, we believe that there is a need to urgently act and take most effective measures to make Instant Payments (IPs) the ”new normal” across the EU. The most effective measure to make IPs the new normal across the EU would be an EU legislation making PSPs’ adherence to SCT Inst. Scheme mandatory within a very short timeline. The mandatory adherence to the scheme should be limited to the reachability. The choice whether to offer or not an IP should be, of course, left to each PSP. The widespread uptake of IPs in the EU is an essential element to deliver a successful pan-European payment solution, along with the following other conditions that should be satisfied: reliance on already existing EU payments infrastructures; leveraging on existing domestic solutions, and VAS to be added to the new scheme such as, for example, digital identity. Furthermore, we would like to share our preliminary comments on some measures the EC is considering under the legislative options: 1) Effective incentives for PSPs to offer instant credit transfers in euro, which could be constructed in a manner similar to that adopted in the past in the SEPA Regulation for SEPA Credit Transfers and Direct Debits: we agree that the best legislative option to make the SCT Inst. Scheme mandatory would be to construct it in a manner similar to that adopted in the past in the SEPA Regulation for SEPA Credit Transfers and Direct Debits. Consistency and coordination with other legislative measures should be ensured, such as the PSD2 (and its RTS) as it contains some provisions related to IP. 2) Tailored fraud prevention measures:  frauds referred to IPs is a crucial issue because of the increasing importance of this method of payment. However, this phenomenon is critical for digital payments in general. Considering the need of fostering digital operational resilience at European level, it is fundamental to strengthen the protection of citizens in an increasingly digital economy with a more effective operational response at EU level to the phenomenon of online frauds. In order to prevent frauds, there are, for examples, substantial obstacles when sharing cyber threat information, especially when these involve Personally Identifiable Information (PII), due to the number of requirements imposed by both national and EU regulators. It is therefore important to define cases of exception when information sharing can lead to high benefits, for example in the anti-fraud management, in compliance with competition rules, in which the difficulties related to the presence of data associated to physical people may been countered. These aspects should be addressed in the DORA proposal (Art. 40). In order to combat frauds, we call for more involvement by the public sector in the fight against frauds, for example by making available instruments both for the customers and the private sector to act promptly against cyber criminals trying to gain credentials or to impersonate the Bank/PSP (e.g. by shutting down or blocking fake websites, imposing stricter verification requirements for requests to open websites to Hosting Providers, giving the possibility of recovering data submitted by customers on fraudulent sites, etc.). Furthermore, from a regulatory perspective, we believe that the phenomenon of phishing should be classified as a specific crime at EU level (to this aim, a lever can be the EU Directive 2019/713). 3) Charges levied on consumers for instant credit transfers: charges for SCT Inst should not be regulated in order to ensure greater competitiveness on the market. Feedback from: Intesa Sanpaolo (104.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Instant payments

feedback_msg_text: ETPPA, the European trade association of bank-independent Third Party Providers (TPPs) under PSD2, very much welcomes the EC’s initiative in promoting instant payments and its Inception Impact Assessment, which we hereby would like to comment on:  We fully agree that instant payments shall become the new normal and agree to the EC’s Retail Payments Strategy supporting this objective. The full availability of instant payments for all consumers in the form of their ability in making outgoing SCT Inst payments is an underlying necessity for that and we therefore believe that all retail consumer banks, which are offering SCT today, should be mandated to offer SCT Inst in an equal form and at the same price.  Outgoing SCTs are usually debited instantly, whilst incoming transfers are credited the next day, which is particularly disadvantageous to consumers and SMEs. SCT Inst will bring this to an end and it will also give payers an additional payment instrument, which will be less costly than the handling of cash, and more available and possibly cheaper than cards.  PISPs stand ready to leverage the superior functionalities of SCT Inst and their huge investments into PSD2-related API infrastructure and connections. Their much lower non-execution risk vs. SCT initiations is likely to lead to a significant growth of PIS across Europe.  Only the legislative option can lead to SCT Inst adoption in the time and to the extend required for the European retail payments market to catch up and get ahead of the developments in other regions of the world. For that we are supporting legislative action for the following four measures on your list of considerations:  - effective incentives for PSPs to offer SCT Inst similar to SCT and SDD - addressing the issue of charges levied on consumers for instant credit transfers - exploring issues regarding fee structures for SCT Inst-based payment solutions - ensuring sound mitigation measures on the liquidity risk  The required interoperability and standardization work is already on its way via ERPB and EPC multi-stakeholder groups and the required fraud protection appears possible within the existing and already rather broad ranging legislation.  As with any new form of payment instruments, consumer protection must be a particular concern. Thankfully, we can look at two decades of experience with principally equivalent SCT-based payment methods in several member states and their best in class track record in comparison to any other payment method from a consumer point of view. The intrinsic advantages of push over pull payments in combination with the consequent application of Strong Customer Authentication (SCA) has ensured far lower fraud levels compared to card payments.  Disputed transactions must be handled according to existing legislation and not by introducing unilateral chargeback rights of buyers mimicking the outdated legacy of card payments caused by their increased risk and inefficiencies. Any buyer protection above the legal standard must remain a commercial activity allowing competition and the possibility to use superior technology in providing higher protection at a lower cost. Contrary to cards or direct debits, SCT and SCT Inst-based payments cannot be initiated by payees themselves and they cannot be executed without the payer’s authorization, incl. when a PISP is involved.  Also important to note: SCT Inst does not increase buyer risk in terms of “cancellation” or “reversibility” in comparison to SCTs, because SCTs are also instantly debited from the payer’s account. It does add a buyer benefit though: goods are released instantly, because merchants get the credit instantly and without having to pay an interchange fee for that.  In conclusion, we recommend legislative action as soon as possible to mandate the adherence to SCT Inst for all current and future adherents of SCT and as a minimum, the subset of these servicing consumer (retail) payment accounts.
Initiative: Instant payments

feedback_msg_text: According to Bitkom, instant payments offer added value across all payment use cases. As supporters of a technology-neutral approach, however, we also want to stress the merit of digital payment solutions in general. Hence, we consider instant payments as complementary to existing products and as enabler for new payment solutions and products (e.g. Instant Lending). The uptake of instant payments depends on several factors, such as pan-European market readiness (i.e. infrastructure), rules/alignment with existing rules, and consumer adoption of new solutions. To facilitate higher market penetration, several obstacles need to be considered when tackling instant payments, especially: high investment efforts to be stemmed by the payments industry, the need for viable business models in the context of instant payments, and the lack of standardization. Moreover, it is crucial to bear in mind the challenges which instant payments pose, such as security, consumer protection, competition, anti-money laundering, and combating the financing of terrorism.  The European Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment indicates potential measures linked to the uptake of instant payments. It is important to stress that instant payments need time to develop for achieving market-driven acceptance among consumers. Regulatory measures should only be taken cautiously, may not come premature, and shall follow the principle of technology neutrality to uphold fair competition. In this context, we want to emphasize the importance of regular exchange among political decision makers and the entire payment ecosystem, composed of incumbents, new players, European, and international players. Moreover, we suggest modernizing political governance structures: market participants shall be able to swiftly seek regulatory guidance when implementing new rules through a centrally organized body in addition to EBA’s Q&A tools.   Specific remarks on the Inception Impact Assessment  Alignment with existing rules, practicality thereof, and level playing field: any targeted political measures require close alignment with given rules and regulations. Particularly, upcoming legislative proposals for the revision of the AML/CFT framework, the extension of the eIDAS-Regulation to the private sector, or the planned PSD2 review will be of particular relevance in this context. Given the fast paced technological advance that generally alleviates both security as well as convenience, we want to stress the importance of outcome based rules and technical standards that allow for the ongoing improvement of the European payment landscape. Such an approach would also help to overcome market fragmentation. Requirements for SCA, for instance, are not harmonized for all types of payment instruments and underlying payment infrastructures. To instill trust among end users, it is important that instant payment transactions adhere to the same set of rules, security standards, and convenience levels independent from the entity offering the service.        Operating Business models under increased fraud risk: operating, innovating, and setting up an instant payment infrastructure requires ongoing investments. Fraud risk, for instance, is inherently higher for instantly settled payments, which encompasses additional costs for implementing the needed risk-mitigating technologies. Pricing shall thus not only be discussed as consumer charges and merchant acceptance costs but also as a mean for investments to further the European payments landscape. Allowing for viable business models for all members of a payment value chain on the basis of transparency is key for the uptake of instant payments.  To conclude, Bitkom would like to stress that potential political incentives shall not lead to market distortion or hazard fair competition. An equilibrium needs to be achieved among market participants which have already invested in instant payments vs. those who have not thus far.
Initiative: Instant payments

feedback_msg_text: P27 shares the European Commission’s vision about the opportunities and benefits instant payments can bring to the European payments market. While we agree there are a number of obstacles that businesses have to overcome in order to create pan-European cross-border payment products, we would argue that the basic conditions do exists – as showcased by P27’s example in the Nordics. The attached letter outlines this.  Feedback from: P27 Nordic Payments (240.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The ECSG (European Cards Stakeholders Group), a multi-stakeholder association promoting card harmonisation in the Single Euro Payments Area (SEPA) made up of representatives from all five sectors of the card payment chain, took note with interest of the European Commission’s inception impact assessment on policy options to broaden the current offer of payment solutions at the point of interaction for European consumers and merchants with the inclusion of “instant payments”- based solutions.  From our experience in the card payments area over a long period, we are convinced that in order to achieve an optimal European payments landscape for the benefit of all actors involved, three layers need to inter-operate smoothly:   a) private initiative (where competition and innovation act as two sides of the same coin),  b) standardisation groups for harmonisation and interoperability (like the ECSG, whose current scope is card-based payments), c) proportionate regulation  Therefore, from the ECSG we would like to express our wish that the European Commission encourages private-led pan-European standardisation groups involving all relevant stakeholders to bridge the regulatory and competitive layers. The outcome should in our opinion preserve the following fundamental principles:  1) market freedom and competition, 2) level-playing-field between all payment instruments in similar contexts,  3) broad and cost-effective acceptance at the point of interaction, standardised through harmonised functional and security requirements acceptable for merchants leveraging existing global standards,  4) consumer transparency, choice and convenience.
Initiative: Instant payments

feedback_msg_text: Polish Organization of Non-Banking Payment Institutions ("PONIP") supports pan-European market initiatives addressing instant payments. The design of any such initiative must consider as broad perspective as possible to bring the expected results. This includes in particular barriers at the national level that may essentially challenge the benefits of instant payment despite that they may be not linked with instant payments.   In Poland one of such obstacles is limited access of Non-Banking Payment Institutions (NBPIs) to payment (designated) systems operated by the National Bank of Poland (NBP). This difficulty could constitute a very serious barrier to NBPIs access to the systems referred to in the Commission's proposal.  The current mechanism for accessing the payment systems operated by the NBP depends on obtaining individual consent from the President of NBP in this regard. This cannot be considered legal certainty in this area, especially when PONIP is aware of cases of NBPIs which, despite efforts to open an account with the NBP, have not obtained such consent. This condition adversely affects the services that NBPIs can effectively provide. Lack of access to the most popular interbank clearing systems essentially excludes NBPIs from the market for credit transfer or other similar payment transactions, which are expected to benefit most from instant payments. Instead, they had to focus on services that can be provided without such access, i.e., issuance and acceptance of payment instruments and the most basic transfers of funds other than credit transfers.  The current situation is fundamentally unfounded. NBPIs introduce no unacceptable risks to the payment system, a fact that has been successfully and consistently demonstrated throughout their years of operation. They are continuously accepted as direct and legitimate participants of global payment system (VISA, Mastercard), which apply very strict criteria for membership and ongoing supervision.  PONIP is aware that NBPIs are not listed in Directive 98/26/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 19 May 1998 on settlement finality in payment and securities settlement systems ("SFD") as entities entitled to participate directly or indirectly in designated systems. National legislation follows this approach.   In light of the current plans of the European legislator to amend the SFD, but also of the approach of other countries that have chosen to open up access to payment systems and of market developments in this area, speeding up this process is absolutely essential to support instant payments. The current mechanism, if left unchanged, would make it practically impossible for Polish NBPIs to benefit from the solutions offered at the EU level. Any legal instrument addressing this issue should ensure unconditional harmonization across the EU. If SFD remains a directive, it definitely needs to be a maximum harmonization Directive instead of a minimum one, as it has been so far. The current nature of SFD allows Member States to take a different approach to the solutions they introduce. To ensure a level playing field, it is necessary to move away from this approach.  To recap, any initiative to create of pan-European payment systems must pay sufficient attention to the existing situation on national levels. Otherwise, it will not be possible to create a coherent and uniform system that will allow all NBPIs to efficiently discount and support the most promising developments such as instant payments.
Submitted by: Polish Organization of Non-Banking Payment Institutions PONIP
Organisation: Polish Organization of Non-Banking Payment Institutions (PONIP)
Initiative: Instant payments
organisation_lower: polish organization of non-banking payment institutions (ponip)

feedback_msg_text: The Polish Chamber of Commerce would like to present some comments as regards published Inception impact assessment and planned revision of Directive 2011/64/EU on the structure and rates of excise duty applied to manufactured tobacco.  Poland, as a border country of the European Union, is particularly exposed to smuggling of cigarettes from beyond the eastern border. Significant raise of existing minimum excise rates in the EU will increase the price of cigarettes and thus increase the profitability of smuggling and illegal production. In this regard, before determining the levels of taxation some measures have to be taken:  - the data presented in the report of the European Commission from February 2020 is out of date - this should be updated, - taking into account the purchasing power in individual EU countries, with particular emphasis on the less wealthy Member States, including Poland.  Regarding the harmonization of excise duty applicable to liquids for electronic cigarettes and novel tobacco products at the EU level, the Polish Chamber of Commerce believes that the adopted provisions in Poland as well as in other European countries may constitute a model for the European Commission during further works on the directive. Therefore, it is justifiable to take into account the regulations of the Member States that have already imposed excise duty on liquids and Heat-Not-Burn products.   In addition, we would like to point out that in addition to the above-mentioned new categories, on the Polish and EU markets there are also other products that deliver nicotine, which right now do not fall within the scope of the directive, e.g. tobacco pouches for chewing. Therefore, we propose that the Commission include also such new products.  What is more the lack of control of the supply chain notably for raw tobacco and the risk of fiscal evasion due to illicit within the EU remains a constant problem. That is why, the Polish Chamber of Commerce notices the need to address by EU regulations the absence of a harmonized definition of raw tobacco and supports the introduction of regulations in order to track movements of raw tobacco. Since 2011 Poland has been introducing in its internal law system provisions in order to prevent illicit trade of raw tobacco. So far, we may mention e.g. the introduction of definition of raw tobacco or the institution of tobacco traders.  In this regard, since Poland has experience in fighting raw tobacco illicit trade, this could be used in future works on revision of the directive conducted by the Commission.
Initiative: Tobacco taxation – excise duties for manufactured tobacco products (updated rules)

feedback_msg_text: The European Shisha Community Alliance (ESCA) welcomes the opportunity offered by the European Commission to provide input to the inception impact assessment on the revision of Directive 2011/64/EU on the structure and rates of excise duty applied to manufactured tobacco.   ESCA is a newly established and growing organisation that aims to represent the thousands of venues, manufacturers and retailers that are involved in the water-pipe sector in Europe. Our concern is that water-pipe, known commonly as shisha, has traditionally been a poorly understood category by regulators largely because it had not had any representation in the policy making processes. This has led to its regulation and taxation alongside other categories with which it has little similarity.   The key points that we believe should be taken account of for the impact assessment:  1. Shisha is very different from other tobacco and vaping products.  Its use is characteristically (and uniquely) social, occasional (infrequent), cumbersome and time consuming.  It is not a quick fix nicotine hit but a cultural and social experience suitable for adults only.  It has cultural roots in the Middle East, India and North Africa and therefore is more prevalent in European countries with higher concentrations of diaspora from those regions. 2. It is by definition a flavoured product with a comparatively low level of tobacco in a mixture which is heated rather than burned to produce a vapour that is 60% water.      3. It supports a large and diverse value chain in Europe of manufacturers, flavour suppliers, wholesalers, retailers and many thousands of shisha serving hospitality venues. 4. High tax rates and high tax differentials between countries, coupled with low levels of enforcement prioritisation have resulted in alarmingly high levels of tax avoidance thus posing an existential threat to the legal, duty paid sector.  It is the only tobacco product where illicit operators have gained a higher market share in Europe than legal businesses.  This jeopardises not only legitimate businesses but also consumers and of course, government revenues.  We believe that a mixture of tax reform that takes account of the nature and characteristics of shisha and its consumption patterns coupled with more enforcement attention and industry cooperation will provide the right mix of policy tools to improve the situation.      Please find attached our detailed submission for your consideration.  Feedback from: European Shisha Community Alliance (ESCA) (300.6 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Tobacco taxation – excise duties for manufactured tobacco products (updated rules)

feedback_msg_text: ‘Raising tobacco taxes to make […] deadly [tobacco] products unaffordable is the most cost-effective measure to reduce tobacco use and improve health outcomes for individuals and communities (World Bank) [1]  The European Respiratory Society (ERS) welcomes the revision of the EU Tobacco Taxation Directive. ERS recommends that any revision leads to increased tax on tobacco products, including alternative nicotine delivery products (such as e-cigarettes) and novel tobacco products (such as heated tobacco products) and highlights the need to minimise price differences within and between products so that it should no longer be possible to manipulate prices and maintain cheap cigarettes and cheap novel products in the market.   The Society was therefore pleased to read the Commission’s evaluation of the current directive. The review concluded that there is a need to have a more comprehensive and holistic approach, taking on board all aspects of tobacco control including public health, taxation, the fight against illicit trade and environmental concerns. The need of tobacco taxation to map to the EU agenda to fight against cancer was also emphasised and this is particularly the case for lung cancer the deadliest of all cancers.   Increasing the price of tobacco products is the most effective population-level intervention for reducing tobacco use [2-7,47]. It is recognised by the World Health Organization (WHO) as one of the key areas of tobacco control [8]. The potential public health benefits of tobacco tax increases depend on a variety of factors such as the availability of cheap tobacco products and smokers’ purchasing choices [47]. There is growing evidence that shows smokers would be more responsive to price increases if there were fewer opportunities to obtain cheap tobacco [1, 2,9-11,47]. Smokers of lower socioeconomic background are more likely to use cheap tobacco [1, 12-15,47], so its availability may also contribute to the widening socio-economic inequalities related to smoking. Availability and use of cheap tobacco products is also associated with reduced smoking cessation [10-12, 16,47] thus emphasising the importance of understanding the sources and types of cheap tobacco as well as the incentives encouraging their use.  ERS maintains that the revision of EU Tobacco Taxation Direction must take into account the harmful health effects of alternative nicotine delivery products and novel tobacco products including heated tobacco [46].   To read the full statement, please see the attachment. Feedback from: European Respiratory Society (234 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Submitted by: European Respiratory Society EUROPEAN RESPIRATORY SOCIETY
Initiative: Tobacco taxation – excise duties for manufactured tobacco products (updated rules)

feedback_msg_text: La mia proposta è che i prodotti liquidi da inalazione con nicotina dovrebbero essere tassati al 50% del costo di produzione e quelli senza nicotina al 25% del costo di produzione in quanto sono prodotti a basso rischio per la salute rispetto alle tradizionali sigarette. Inoltre non creano dipendenza come le sigarette tradizionali. Togliere la gestione del Monopolio di Stato e creare una gestione fiscale europea dove far confluire i soldi delle tasse per i tabacchi, liquidi da inalazione che poi serviranno per finanziare la sanità degli stati membri.

feedback_msg_text: Buongiorno, reputo una cattiva idea paragonare e tassare di conseguenza i prodotti liquidi da inalazione, in quanto sono completamente altri prodotti rispetto alle sigarette tradizionali a combustione. Parliamo di foglie di tabacco lavorate e bruciate, da cui ne vengono inalati i vapori (e sottoprodotti, tanti tantissimi tossici a vari livelli sull'uomo. Al contrario i liquidi delle e-cig provengono da industria chimica alimentare e farmaceutica. Reputo che assumere quotidianamente i prodotti da "svapo" sia alla pari di bere un bicchiere di bibita analcolica commerciale o uno dei tanti prodotti confezionati che praticamente tutti assumono con costanza per una vita intera, fumatori e non. La nicotina all'interno dei liquidi non ha niente a che vedere con la nicotina che viene assunta tramite sigarette analogiche, stiamo parlando di una rivoluzione come è stato da quando abbiamo iniziato a curarci con dei farmaci e non con delle piante infuse/fumate/applicate al nostro corpo. E' risaputo che le sostanza di origine naturale non sono SEMPRE meglio di sostanze di origine sintetica. Tassare i prodotti di questo settore contribuiranno a far spostare l'equilibrio sempre più verso i fumatori di sigarette tradizionali. La gente e la popolazione guarda spesso prima della loro salute, al loro portafoglio. Se a parità di costi, esempio 10€, posso acquistare quasi 2 pacchetti di sigarette tradizionali, che mi durerebbero circa 2-3 giorni. Con la stessa cifra posso acquistare circa, ad ora 1 flacone e mezzo, circa 15 mL, che a media potenza (30-50 W) durerebbero circa 2 giorni scarsi. Per non parlare se una persona (come il sottoscritto) tende a "svapare" tra i 60 e gli 80W, 10 mL durano una mattina intera, e basta. Si capisce quindi  che tantissima gente, a parità di spesa, vuole fumare di più. Questo fenomeno si è visto aumentare negli anni, nei negozi e nelle conversazioni tra amici, che tanti hanno preferito abbandonare la sigaretta elettronica, chi più, chi meno, chi totalmente, per andare ad acquistare al tabaccaio più vicino il tanto agognato pacchetto di sigarette perchè i liquidi costano sempre di più, nonostante i prezzi siano invariati negli anni ed aumenta solo la tassazione all'utente finale. Non possiamo permettere di vendere la salute delle persone per del denaro, i liquidi da inalazione contenente nicotina sono il futuro dell' assunzione della nicotina all'interno dell'organismo delle persone.  Reputo che una tassazione, per questioni economiche, possa esistere, ma che sia la più bassa possibile, e dobbiamo smetterla di equiparare il fumo tradizionale al fumo digitale, confonde le persone che siano la stessa cosa e abbia gli stessi danni. Non ostacoliamo il progresso scientifico e la salute delle persone, ogni centesimo che viene aggiunto ai liquidi in vendita allontana sempre più persone, questi soldi non credo valgano quanto il risparmio che avremmo nel corso dei prossimi anni in ospedali e cliniche di aiuto per i tabagisti. Questo dovrebbe essere il punto focale. feedback_msg_text: Revising the current Tobacco Excise Directive presents an opportunity to apply the right incentives for current smokers to improve their health; ideally by stopping the use of nicotine altogether, but also by switching to reduced risk alternatives where this is impossible or unlikely for the individual smoker.  The inception impact assessment rightly cites Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan as a driver of the current policy. Smoking is the leading cause of cancer in Europe and mass smoking cessation is the most effective policy tool to curb the disease. Some smokers can quit cold turkey; others are using nicotine replacement or other medications; but a significant majority struggle.  Vaping has been found to be significantly less carcinogenic than smoking and an acceptable replacement for cigarettes for many smokers. It follows that any policy designed to reduce cancer rates through prevention must focus on the needs of this particularly at-risk section of the population.  The harm reduction potential of vaping, in light of this scientific advice, can be enhanced or diminished by fiscal incentives across the nicotine category; we already see this with the decision of many countries to reduce Value-Added Tax on nicotine replacement therapies. The critical pathway to enhancing the benefits of tobacco harm reduction will thus be to ensure that any excise levied on any nicotine products is reflective of the harm that it causes to individual and public health. Any system should also ensure that commercial actors in the space are able to operate on a stable and sustainable footing.  We attach comments and preliminary evidence that we hope will help the Commission (and in time Member States) to design the optimal system to achieve the public health goals set out in the Beating Cancer plan. feedback_msg_text: The Federation of Polish Entrepreneurs welcomes the opportunity to provide our feedback on polices currently in development as regards the revision of Directive 2011/64/EU on the structure and rates of excise duty applied to manufactured tobacco and published Inception Impact Assessments.  When taking any steps in order to change the current rules of taxation of tobacco products, the European Commission should first of all review the validity of the data used to evaluate the functioning of Directive 2011/64/EU and formulate theses that will be decisive for future decisions on the scope of its changes. This seems to be particularly important as regards the market of new nicotine delivery systems, where changes are still dynamic. We need to emphasize that Poland, due to its geographical location, is a country particularly exposed to smuggling of illegal tobacco products from countries outside the EU, where the taxation of cigarettes, and thus their prices, are much lower. Any steps to increase excise duty minima may lead to an escalation of the problem. For this reason, we are at the position that future proposal should take into account  the situation of Poland as a country particularly exposed to illegal trade from the east, by taking into account the prices of cigarettes in the eastern countries neighboring with Poland and correspondingly correlating the amount of minimum taxation in the EU. It is also no less important to take into account the purchasing power parity, especially in less prosperous countries, including Poland, as this may also impact legal market of products.  In the context of taxation of novel tobacco products and e-liquids, it is legitimate to take into account the advantages of its innovation when considering the setting the level of excise duty rates. We need to remember that nicotine may be delivered in different ways and with a different harmfulness factor - in products where tobacco is burned, this factor is the highest. Therefore, it is justified to set the rates adequately. More harmful smoking products should be taxed with a higher tax, and smoke-free products should be burdened with substantially lower tax rate.  In addition, despite the lack of EU regulations imposing taxation rules for these products, half of the Member States including Poland have already provided for relevant regulations in their internal regulations, as regards of taxation of alternative products. Therefore, it seems obvious that the existing acquis of the Member States in this area may constitute an excellent basis for the development of new product taxation rules at the EU level. For this reason, during future works on the directive, the European Commission should take into account the achievements of the Member States in the field of the adopted classification and taxation rules for e-liquids and novel tobacco products. Our Federation is also at the position that lack of a control system for movement of raw tobacco and the risks of diversion to the illegal circuit should be addressed at EU level by establishing appropriate rules for that purpose. We need to point out that Poland long time ago has included raw tobacco in the EMCS system and has taken a number of other effective measures to prevent illegal trade in this material, like for example the definition of raw tobacco or introduction of institution of Tobacco Trader. As we believe that steps taken so far in Poland have positive impact on fighting illicit trade, it is justifiable to use Polish experience in this regard. feedback_msg_text: Despite longstanding and overwhelming evidence that smoking is the leading cause of premature death and disability, the European region still has the highest levels of smoking among adults and some of the highest prevalence of tobacco use by adolescents compared to the rest of the world.[1] Taxation is widely known to be the most effective policy measure to reduce tobacco use. By making tobacco products less affordable, they become less attractive, especially for younger consumers.[2] For tobacco taxation to better serve the goal of protecting and enhancing public health in the EU, Health Funds for a Smokefree Netherlands believes that revision of Directive 2011/64/EU (hereafter: the Directive) is much needed.   Health Funds for a Smokefree Netherlands would like to highlight the following specific points, some of which have also been addressed in the Inception Impact Assessment:  • Revision of the Directive should lead to inclusion of an objective of 30% reduction in current tobacco use by 2025 (in people above 15 years old) in the Directive. Including such a reduction target would create a clear benchmark to evaluate the success of the revised Directive.  • The revision should result in higher minima tax rates and therefore in upwards convergence of tobacco prices across Member States, towards the highest common denominator. Such convergence is essential to achieve a further reduction of tobacco consumption across the EU. Furthermore, it reduces the incentive for tax evasion through cross-border shopping.  • The gap between taxation of cigarettes on the one hand, and taxation of roll-your-own-tobacco, make-your-own-tobacco, cigars and cigarillos on the other hand, should be bridged through revision of the Directive. All these products pose similar risks to public health, so they should be taxed similarly at the EU-level as well.   • New products, such as e-cigarettes and heated tobacco products, should be included in the Directive. These products are harmful to public health, so it is important that minima tax rates are introduced at the EU-level for these products as well. Harmonisation at the EU level is key to protect EU-citizens across Member States equally against the harmful effects of new products. Harmonisation also helps to reduce the incentive for cross-border purchasing of new products.  • Lastly, a definition and tax category should be introduced for raw tobacco and intermediate products. These products can be diverted to the illicit manufacturing of smoking products or can be sold in small quantities to consumers for home processing. It is not clear how big this problem is and the scale likely varies across countries. Since raw tobacco and intermediate products are not covered by the Directive, some of the key tools to prevent and fight tax fraud, including the Excise Movement and Control System (EMCS), currently cannot be used to monitor the movement of the products.  [1]  “Data And Statistics” 2018. World Health Organization, https://www.euro.who.int/en/health-topics/disease-prevention/tobacco/data-and-statistics.   [2]  Bader P, Boisclair D, Ferrence R. (2011). Effects of tobacco taxation and pricing on smoking behavior in high risk populations: a knowledge synthesis. International Journal of Environmental Research & Public Health; 8 (11): 4118-4139; Mannocci A, Backhaus I, D’Egidio V, Federici A, Villari P, La Torre G. (2019). What public health strategies work to reduce the tobacco demand among young people? An umbrella review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Health Policy; 123 (5): 480-491.

feedback_msg_text: Aiduce answers this consultation about vaping products (and only vaping products) as we represent French and Belgian consumers of those products, mostly ex-smokers. We don't comment on taxation of tobacco products, which certainly is legitimate.  First of all the commission, in the Inception Impact Assessment, wrongly pretend vaping products are tobacco products. And makes an inacceptable amalgam with heated tobacco products that, despite being less harmful than tobacco cigarettes (and more harmful than snus and vaping) remain a tobacco products. Vaping products don’t contain tobacco, they don’t carry any comparable health-risks, and they are a leading option to quit smoking, which is the issue pretended to be tackled by specific taxation.   Reference (one in many) :  https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0304389420314060  The only relevant taxation issue regarding vaping is how to ensure it is NOT taxed in any way (except normal or ideally minimal VAT). Any excise duty or specific taxation is proven to protect the tobacco cigarettes market and send a wrong message to smokers, ex-smokers or to-be smokers concerning health risks, or even about the reasons to tax tobacco cigarettes in the EU. In the recent years, some countries in the EU tried to tax vaping products and proved the morbid effect of such action, killing the option for smokers to quit, protecting tobacco cigarettes market, and harming health. Some didn’t, and like France, or the UK, where vaping is now the main help to quit smoking, making literally millions of European citizen tobacco (and smoke) free, reducing the prospect of cancers and cardiovascular diseases, giving them years of life expectancy and reducing the burden on the national health systems.   Reference (one in many, here for France) : https://www.santepubliquefrance.fr/content/download/197752/2365558  On the question of the substitution effect, of course there is a substitution of smoking, which should be the health (and Cancer Plan, and European Commission) main goal. Nearly only this effect as the rate of vaping use in non-smokers is very low, and any impact on health not even shown after 10 years, except a slight reduction in daily smoking rate in the few non-smokers initiating regular vaping.  Reference (one in many, here for France) : https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/add.15330  On the question of impact on fundamental rights, setting up a taxation of vaping products is evidently unacceptable (reducing the price difference between tobacco cigarettes and vaping is opposing the tobacco cigarettes consumption reduction, which is against the promotion of health).  On the question of administrative burden, pretending to tax vaping products and put the same kind of limitations as on tobacco products is also detrimental and would put the market in the hand of actors currently familiar with those very specific procedure and constraints, i.e. tobacco companies (may we have to remind the commission that favoring tobacco companies is in violation of treaties signed by the EU?).  We will conclude by giving you the links to the last two consultation on the subject (but the European Commission doesn’t seem to have taken the clear citizen contribution into account, not even citing those past consultations on the subject).  https://www.aiduce.org/laiduce-repond-a-la-consultation-publique-de-la-commission-europeenne/ https://www.aiduce.org/aiduce-a-la-dg-taxud-nous-considerons-cette-consultation-comme-probablement-illegale-et-certainement-immorale/ Menaces de taxes sur le vapotage, le résultat des votes https://www.aiduce.org/menaces-de-taxes-sur-le-vapotage-le-resultat-des-votes/

feedback_msg_text: Dear ladies and gentlemen,   Combustible tobacco and non-combustible tobacco products, such as vaping, should not be put in the same regulatory category. They are not the same thing, with vaping being recognised as 95% less harmful than cigarettes [1], and helping millions around Europe and the world to quit smoking. Plans to equate the two, in terms of legislation and taxation are of great concern to the World Vapers’ Alliance and the thousands of vapers it represents and would harm public health.   For several decades, both governmental and non-governmental agencies have used various tools of public health to stem the tide of smoking, including education, taxes, age-restrictions, bans on advertising, or promoting various patches, gums, and therapies to deliver nicotine in less harmful form.  to. However, many of these alternatives have not proven to be entirely successful, especially when compared to the efficacy of vaping.  Making vaping less appealing to smokers will discourage current smokers from switching to less harmful alternatives. Studies show that increased prices on vaping products leads to higher smoking rates. Researchers in the United States [2] found that “a proposed national e-cigarette tax of $1.65 per milliliter of vaping liquid would raise the proportion of adults who smoke cigarettes daily by approximately 1 percentage point, translating to 2.5 million extra adult daily smokers compared to the counterfactual of not having the tax.” Consequently, a higher tax on vaping products will have a detrimental effect on public health in the European Union. Vape devices are not cigarettes. Rather, they heat a liquid into vapour. There is no tobacco nor tar in e-cigarettes and many of the toxins in cigarettes are not present in e-cigarettes. So, they should not be treated like traditional tobacco products.  A landmark report on vaping’s potential to save lives by Public Health England found that vaping is 95% less harmful than combustible tobacco and has thus become a recommended means of quitting for smokers in the United Kingdom. France, Canada and New Zealand’s governmental agencies also recommend vaping to smokers looking to quit. Many other studies have come to the same conclusion. Vaping is significantly less harmful than smoking [3]. In the best interest of its citizens and public health, the European Union should adopt an open regulatory approach towards vaping and abstain from anti-vaping policies.  The regulatory environment for e-cigarettes plays a key role in its efficiency as a cessation method: “Compared to unassisted quitting (i.e. no medications or ECs [e-cigarettes]), smokers who used ECs for quitting from countries with less restrictive EC policy environments were more likely, whereas smokers who used ECs for quitting from countries with more restrictive EC policies were less likely, to report sustained abstinence for at least 30 days.” [4]  Moreover, high taxes on vaping products are particularly harmful to the lower income brackets of the population, which make up the largest proportion of current smokers. Differentiated taxation of smoking and vaping products is essential for many people to switch.   For these reasons, it is so important that non-combustible products are not regulated and taxed the same way combustible tobacco is. We urge lawmakers to follow the scientific evidence and abstain from tighter regulation and higher taxation of vaping products. If we want to reduce smoking induced burdens on public health, access and affordability to vaping products need to be guaranteed.   Best regards,  Michael Landl Director World Vapers Alliance Feedback from: World Vapers' Alliance (83.6 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download

feedback_msg_text: Atentando à definição europeia de Imposto Especial sobre o Consumo (IEC), verificamos que se traduzem por impostos indiretos que incidem sobre produtos que prejudicam a saúde dos consumidores ou poluem o ambiente. Ora, no que concerne ao tabaco, o IEC tem um duplo objetivo financeiro. Por um lado, e tal como outros impostos, ele objetiva a obtenção de receita; por outro, é usado para penalizar o seu consumo, tendo em consideração que o mesmo gera custos sociais que não são tidos em conta na fixação dos seus preços pelos agentes económicos privados, mas que devem ser suportados pelos respetivos consumidores. Assim, este imposto serve um propósito extrafiscal, sendo um instrumento de políticas sectoriais, nomeadamente, no caso do tabaco, da área da saúde. Deverá ter sido esta a mesma ideologia que desencadeou a decisão de, em Portugal, se optar pela atribuição de carga fiscal ao líquido contendo nicotina, exclusivo e indissociável dos vaporizadores pessoais, vulgo cigarros eletrónicos. Aludindo, novamente, à definição do IEC e considerando a total ausência de investigação científica nacional, cremos que, em 2015, aquando da decisão legal de aplicação de taxação aos líquidos contendo nicotina, os legisladores se basearam em suposições de malefício, naturalmente relacionadas com a incorreta associação entre estes e o conceito lato do tabagismo. Acrescente-se ainda que, aquando da primeira introdução do IEC nestes produtos, em 2015, o estado da arte relativo aos vaporizadores pessoais ser bastante mais limitado do que o atual. Atualmente evidencia-se o seu papel na redução de danos, conforme demonstrado pela vasta resenha científica anexa. Neste sentido, deverá de se ter na devida conta a efetiva redução de danos, o que, naturalmente, se deverá refletir no ambiente legal e fiscal. Ao analisarmos a taxação do tabaco convencional, verificamos que, no que concerne ao produto mais comum - os maços de cigarros -, Portugal assume uma carga fiscal alinhada com a média europeia. Atendendo a esta linha de atuação, por média europeia, e analisando a carga fiscal Portuguesa inerente ao líquido contendo nicotina, especialmente considerando que, por entre a União Europeia, mais de 50% dos países não aplicam qualquer imposto especial nestes produtos, não é compreensível que Portugal lidere, de forma destacada, ao apresentar a taxa mais alta de todos os países membros (0,32€/ml), que são ainda alvo de dupla tributação, ao ser adicionado o imposto de valor acrescentado. Perante todo o exposto, torna-se da maior importância: • Que os impostos sobre os líquidos contendo nicotina sejam estabelecidos de uma forma racional, que reflitam a realidade de cada produto, a fim de evitar consequências indesejadas, sem comprometer as metas de saúde do Estado; • Realçar que atual tributação afeta significativamente o desenvolvimento do comércio ilegal; • Constatar que os consumidores se sentem encorajados a adquirir produtos ilegais mais baratos, incentivando-se assim a uma evasão fiscal e ao crime organizado, e à verificação de situações potencialmente perigosas em termos de saúde pública pela falta de controlo associada a estes produtos; • Considerar que o IEC inerente aos líquidos contendo nicotina, pela sua magnitude, se afigura como regressivo e, portanto, adquire uma maior carga financeira e maior impacto entre os consumidores com menor poder aquisitivo; • A visada carga fiscal incentiva compras transfronteiriças, reduzindo significativamente o tecido empresarial do setor, o número de postos de trabalho e, consequentemente, a receita fiscal.  Para tal, é sugerida:  • A adequação da carga fiscal à dimensão reduzida de dano provocado pelos vaporizadores pessoais;  • A aplicação de um IEC correspondente a 0,1€/ml, com o compromisso de um mínimo de 50% desse valor ser atribuído à investigação científica nacional do setor. Feedback from: APORVAP- Associação Portuguesa de Vaporizadores (3.9 MB - PDF - 52 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Directive 2011/64/EU needs to be revised as soon as possible in order to ensure a proper level of health protection regarding one of the major threats that EU citizens are still facing: tobacco.  EU Institutions and EU Member States have a moral duty with the next generation of citizens: a European Union free from Tobacco. This is the ultime goal that any EU initiative regarding tobacco control should pursue. Even though taxation is not the only approach for an effective Tobacco control strategy, it has a clear positive impact in smoking prevention and in decreasing smoking prevalence, and these two effects must not be neglected in any EU Member State.  Several weaknesses have been highlighted in the evaluation of the Directive mentioned and it is time for a new Directive on tobacco taxation to help Member States to follow the lead for a strong action in Tobacco control.  New products, such as e-cigarettes or heated tobacco, are challenges that must be dealt with. The differences among Member States in pricing of tobacco products and taxes  leads to inequality in the right to have the same level of health protection for all in the EU.  A new Directive must ensure, as a key element, the harmonisation of the taxation of all tobacco products (traditional and new), the higher the tax the better.

feedback_msg_text: The European Free Alliance (EFA) is a pro-European party that endorses the European Union’s values, namely the principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. Through its constituent member parties, the European Free Alliance represents peoples from over Europe. Together we work for self-determination, for a Europe of all peoples, for peace and linguistic justice, for a sustainable planet, for gender equality and for social justice. We do this with solidarity for all peoples and their right to decide.  These are the main issues which EFA would like to comment regarding the revision of Regulation 1141/2014 on the status and funding of European Political Parties and Foundations:  IFRS – We are strongly in favour of increased transparency, but a second audit in the form of IFRS is not the best way to do it. IFRS is extremely burdensome both administratively and financially, whilst providing little added value to EUPPs or the EP. Additionally, it is much more suited to the private sector, not political parties.   Non-EU income (Art. 20) – EFA would argue in favour of allowing income from its members outside the EU in order to continue our close relations with parties in the UK following Brexit, and in key areas such as the Balkans and with other non-EU partners.   Donations v Contributions (Art. 2, 20) – These ambiguous definitions have caused a number of difficulties over the years, and is difficult to report financially. ‘Contributions’ are defined as all income from member parties; ‘Donations’ are everything else. However, a lot of the income of an EUPPs does not neatly fit into either category, for example: joint-project contributions, book sales, participation fees (e.g. for training sessions), etc.   Budget Distribution (Art.19) – The annual budget for EUPPs is currently distributed as follows: 10% equally amongst EUPPs; 90% amongst EUPPs based on number of affiliated MEPs. EFA’s position is that a higher percentage (at least 15%) should be allocated equally amongst EUPPs. This would allow smaller parties to operate effectively which in turn reinforces political pluralism and a healthier European democracy. This has a marginal impact on the bigger EUPPs but is a lifeline for the smaller ones.   Legal recognition (Art. 12, 13, 15) – EUPPs are registered as Belgian non-profit organisations, and operate under Belgian law as such. This means that EUPPs are classed as foreign legal entities by many Member States in the EU, and as such, not even allowed to take out paid adverts on social media for example, being classed as ‘foreign interference’. Article 12 and 13 of the Regulation state that EUPPs shall have European legal personality and enjoy legal recognition and capacity in all Member States, but this is clearly - and unfortunately - not the case.   Right to appeal (Art. 35) – Currently, there is no realistic way to appeal decisions of the APPF. The only recourse is to go before the Court of Justice of the European Union. This is prohibitively excessive. There should be an intermediate step, which is higher than the APPF in case EUPPs need to contest a decision, but without going through the Court of Justice in Luxembourg.
Initiative: European political parties and foundations – review of rules on legal status and funding

feedback_msg_text: KEA – Klimaschutz- und Energieagentur Baden-Württemberg GmbH is a state-wide energy agency in southwest Germany. Founded in 1994, a team of 40 employees is working on topics like sustainable mobility, district heating, energy management, contracting, municipal climate protection and public relations concerning climate topics. Zukunft Altbau as a further department of KEA-BW is a regional partner to all actors and helping to answer questions concerning building renovation.  Shaping Renovation Wave and the EPBD-revision as central tools to improve Europe´s building stock is a crucial political task to reach climate targets especially in the building sector.  Building renovation creates green jobs and fosters resilience. Therefore Zukunft Altbau supports increasing renovation rates and depths. They have to accelerate fast to avoid further senseless waste of energy and CO2-emissions in the building sector. A combination of economic tools (like higher CO2-prices, ETS and cost optimization in renovation and construction), sufficiency (m² that are not needed are the best ones for climate and costs) and energetic optimization could lead to the desired output.  The main points to tackle for energetic improvements are regulation, financial incentives, and advisory services.   Binding Minimum energy performance standards are in our opinion an effective and essential tool to address waste of energy in the building sector. A considerable improvement in numbers of renovations in each member state is needed. Therefore the lower limit for energy performance (e.g. 180 kWh/m²a heat demand) must be fixed for all of them to also improve the activities on the renovation market. To prevent lock-in-effects in renovation projects the quality level of deep retrofit (<50 kWh/m²a) must be ambitious enough to challenge the markets and actors but not overwhelming in detail. In the long run all the members that aim at better standards must see an obvious advantage to do so. In any case cautious adaptions to the market and social fairness are important boundary conditions.  Energy Performance Certificates in combination with the announced Digital Building Logbooks are a central tool to make building data comparable and stock data transparent.  Therefore a new and binding definition of a energy-certificate based on the theoretical needs of a building has to be introduced all over Europe. The (public) access to the national EPC data must be facilitated to get a transparent monitoring with benchmarks and evaluations how far the national energy transition in the building sector has come.  Especially all demand and consumption values of public buildings should be published on an easy accessible website. This will be the case in Baden-Württemberg starting 2021.  Consumption values did not have to play a role within EPCs but on the other hand the actual energy consumption and reduction must be monitored properly to prove the successful decarbonisation of the building sector. Pay for performance concepts could be a good starting point for developing future and over-fulfilment can be additionally rewarded. feedback_msg_text: Architects for Future Germany appreciates the EU has set out the Green New Deal, the Renovation Wave and the New European Bauhaus. With the knowledge of the past years it has become clear that a solitary view on energy during building operation is not sufficient. While a worthwhile goal in 2010, the goal of “nearly zero energy buildings” during operation no longer meets current nor future benchmarks of the built environment. We need to extend how the EPBD considers energy performance of buildings, both new and existing, with new goals set: climate neutral or climate positive over their entire life cycles. We can do that! There are enough examples that show how!    To achieve that, we request these five important changes of the EPBD: 1. Consideration of the entire building life cycle with focus on CO2- emissions 2. Transparency 3. Retrofitting plans 4. Cost-optimal considering real costs (including climate impact) 5. Knowledge transfer  Each point is further explained in the full text.   Buildings and components have very long life cycles - therefore we need mandatory regulations NOW for the building sector that are built on the Paris Agreement. Architects for Future Germany is convinced that we need to strengthen the legal framework and amend the EPBD to increase ambitions. Addressing a reduction of the whole life cycle of building emissions and taking it as a responsibility of the society as a whole.   We want to encourage you to strive all your effort for these goals!   VerBAUT uns nicht DIE ZUKUNFT!  (Don’t obstruct the future) Engage with us to work for a climate friendly change in the building industry! Architects for Future Deutschland e.V.
