Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: RAKLI’s comments to the Consultation  RAKLI’s members the professional building owners have for a long time been in the forefront of driving sustainable Real Estate Investments forward in Finland. In the heart of this movement have been the volunteer non-regulatory Energy Efficient Agreements in Finland. The voluntary Energy Efficiency Agreements have been very effective in producing results. Energy efficiency measures implemented by participating companies and municipalities between 2008-2016 reduced carbon dioxide emissions by 4.7 million tonnes a year and energy costs in total by more than 560 million euros a year.  RAKLI emphasizes the following messages in this consultation:  • RAKLI supports implementing the current directives and backing them with the implementation of national GHG road maps.  RAKLI also supports financial backing for the transition to low carbon build environment. The national Road Maps for retrofitting the building Stock that were produced after the Revision of EPBD 2018 should be allowed time to work. The execution of those Road Maps has only just started. RAKLI emphasizes that now Is not the time to impose new burdensome and inflexible legislation. Instead RAKLI thinks there is a need to simplify administrative burdens and avoid overregulation. Lowering the GHG emissions in accordance with the EU 2050 goals should be the key target. It should be implemented through national measures and with the backing of the Financial Market supporting sustainability with criteria setting for investments as well as adequate pricing of carbon and energy through energy market policies.  • The Real Estate market needs time to adapt to the current regulations that was just put in place though the national implementation of EPBD and EED revisions of 2018. The sustainable development of Real Estate market needs stability and predictability and not new EU wide regulation that can easily lead to for example challenges regarding split incentives because of different Real Estate Markets technological and contractual policies in different parts of the EU. In other parts of Europe for example heat delivery is based typically on individual fossil fuel heating system (gas and oil boilers). In Finland over 90 % of apartment buildings are connected to district heating and the decarbonization of the district heating is in a key role in the decarbonization. Energy invoicing and rental contract cultures are also very different. That is why different measures are needed in different member states and too-detailed EU legislation is impossible when cost efficient solutions are considered.  • In general the base for regulation should be always technology-neutrality, only reflecting GHG-savings and sustainability of the energy sources and also take into account technology from a life cycle perspective. It's important to highlight that along with regulation, non-regulatory policy instruments are equally important. Such as technical assistance, guidance, awareness raising information campaigns, training, research and development, standards, and project financing.    Urbanization and demographic changes are constantly changing the Finnish building stock. Cities and local municipalities are rethinking how to use their building stock and what part of their building Stock is still needed with Real Estate strategies and Service Network Design thinking. Regulations on minimum energy performance standards fit poorly to the equation of changing cities and should therefore not be mandatory. Investments should be made based on calculated facts on which is the most effective way to lower GHG emissions and not based on regulatory needs to renovate buildings that do not have a foreseeable future. feedback_msg_text: The EPB Center contributes to the ambitious international goals to reduce to (nearly) zero energy in new or deep-renovated buildings; • offers information and technical support on the use of the set EPB standards (harmonized set of assessments methods); • will actively support the European vision on EPB related to reduction of greenhouse gases; • and stimulates, according to the holistic approach, reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in relation to creating healthy IEQ.   •       The EPB Center recommends to go for Option 3 •       The mandatory minimum energy performance standards (for renovation) should be harmonized, which requires that also the methodology to assess the energy performance should be harmonized. Especially this goes for the energy performance factors: leaving these up to national choice creates loopholes that hinder real energy saving and decarbonisation. •       The EPB Center recommends to increase the efforts to make a link between product data and input data for the EPB assessment. •       The EPB Center recommends to focus on digitization of the assessment methods  (software, link with product data) . EPB Center supports the development of a brand-independent, open-source software kernel meeting the requirements of article 3 of EPBD  to promote the harmonised application of the set of EPB standards and the harmonisation of national EPC calculation methodologies.  •       Primary energy is classified in total, non-renewable and renewable primary energy (see EN ISO 52000-1 and EN 17423 the reporting standard to describe the calculation methodologies for Primary Energy Factors). Among the EU policy objectives are the reduction of non-renewable energies and the increase of renewables. The actual EPBD does not precise the type of the primary energy. It is proposed to specify in the EPBD revision that the main indicator is the non-renewable primary energy. •       The EU taxonomy defines additional minimum safeguards to avoid negative impacts of one indicator (e.g. leave energy efficiency potentials untapped). Minimum safeguards in the building energy performance may be related to the (a) building envelope, (b) to the efficiency of technical building systems, (c) to decarbonisation. Examples of minimum safeguards are provided in EN ISO 52000-1 (the “hurdle-race”). It is proposed to add additional minimum safeguards to the main indicator (non-renewable primary energy). These minimum safeguards should be coordinated with the EU taxonomy. •       We see that the fragmentation of the EU due to national transposition of the EPBD, create barriers for the free circulation of services and know-how. There are no harmonised methods, no common professional tools as high-quality software, no common training and certification of professionals, no mutual recognition of skills on a common content. The EU added value is missing. It is proposed to allow the voluntary EU certification scheme EPC as an alternative to a national EPC. It could also be used as common metric for the European taxonomy. EPB CENTER Weena 505 3013 AL Rotterdam The Netherlands  www.epb.center
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Die Europäischen Union setzt auf dem Weg zu einer klimafreundlichen Wirtschaft auf übergreifende Zielformulierungen, EU-weite Maßnahmen und verbindliche nationale Klimaschutzziele. Im Dezember 2019 haben sich die Staats- und Regierungschefs der EU zum Ziel der Klimaneutralität bis 2050 bekannt. Bis 2050 sollen also alle Treibhausgasemissionen in der Europäischen Union reduziert werden. Die verbleibenden Restemissionen müssen durch entsprechende Prozesse über alle Sektoren hinweg ausgeglichen werden.  In Anlehnung an diese Ziele präsentierte die Kommission 2020 ihre Strategie zu „Renovation Wave“ mit einem Aktionsplan zur energetischen Sanierung von Gebäuden in der EU. Mit entsprechenden Anreizen, Regulierungs- und Finanzierungsinstrumenten soll dazu beigetragen werden, die Klimaziele zu erreichen und die Netto-Treibhausgasemissionen in der EU zu senken.  Insgesamt leisten historische Bauten bereits jetzt mit ihrem außergewöhnlich langen Lebenszyklus einen wertvollen Beitrag zum Klimaschutz und sind per se ökologisch, da sie die in Normen vorgegebene Nutzungsdauer bei Weitem überschreiten. Damit sind historische Bauten ein wichtiger Puzzle-Stein im Green Deal. Allerdings müssen geplante Anreizsystem dabei stets berücksichtigen, dass sie in keinen Widerspruch zu den Zielen der Erhaltung dieser Objekte stehen und damit die „grüne“ Weiterentwicklung gefährden.  Häufig sind Energieeffizienzmaßnahmen bei historischen Gebäuden äußert kritisch zu sehen, da diese mitunter mit massiven Eingriffen verbunden sind und die Substanz dieser Bauten enorm schädigen können. Folglich ist jeweils im Einzelfall zu entscheiden, ob ein entsprechender Eingriff (und mitunter sogar deren Zerstörung) einer historischen Bausubstanz gerechtfertigt ist. Demzufolge ist es erforderlich, Regelungen flexibler zu gestalten. Diese sollten stärker zwischen Gebäudebestand, insbesondere denkmalgeschützten und ensemblegeschützten Gebäuden sowie Neubauten unterscheiden. Ausnahmen und die Möglichkeit von Vorgaben abzuweichen, müssen so formuliert werden, dass sie eindeutig sind und damit zur Rechtssicherheit der Eigentümer führen. Im Mittelpunkt dieser Maß-nahmen müssen der Bestandsschutz und die zeitgemäße Nutzung stehen.  Genutzte und belebte historische Objekte stellen als kulturelles Erbe einen wesentlichen volkswirtschaftlichen Nutzen dar. Daher ist es essenziell, bei diversen Instrumenten und Anreizsystemen auf die Bedürfnisse von denkmalgeschützten und historischen Gebäuden gesondert einzugehen, da sie mit Neubauten nicht vergleichbar sind. Um langfristig das kulturelle Erbe Europas sicherzustellen, müssen Regeln, Verordnungen und Normen auf denkmalgeschützte und historische Gebäude angewendet werden können.  Notwendig wird es auch sein, eine breite Akzeptanz, Wertschätzung und Bewusstseinsbildung in der Gesellschaft für die Anforderungen zu schaffen, die private Eigentümer mit der Nutzung historischer Objekte und dem Erhalt des kulturellen Erbes erfüllen müssen. Denn gerade die historischen Gebäude tragen seit Jahrhunderten zu einem gesunden und sicheren Lebensumfeld der Bevölkerung bei.  Vor diesem Hintergrund unterstreichen die Land&Forst Betriebe Niederösterreich das ein-gebrachte Positionspapier der European Landowners‘ Organization (ELO): https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/have-your-say/initiatives/12910-Revision-of-the-Energy-Performance-of-Buildings-Directive-2010-31-EU/F2004775 Feedback from: Land&Forst Betriebe Niederösterreich (79 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: ORFEE project is a winning project of H2020 programme to establish the Office of Renovation and Financing for Energy Efficiency: the resource centre for Third Party Financing operators set up by 7 Regions and Cities in France.  ORFEE is honoured to comment on the EC's initial impact assessment on the "Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD) 2010/31/EU", regarding its impact on the renovation of the private residential stock.  EPBD objectives should be adapted to the different sectors, with private housing being an important stake, in terms of energy consumption but also social cohesion, and the need to move both the supply of and demand for renovation works, which are very diffuse, towards energy performance.  With this in mind, ORFEE recommends a revision of the EPBD (option 3), combined with option 2: strengthening non-regulatory instruments.  Today, the EPBD considers cost-effectiveness of EE measures as the guiding principle for public policies. However, this seemingly obvious criterion does not easily apply to private housing renovations: calculation methods used to evaluate payback times are often erroneous and counterproductive, and do not take into account the multiple benefits expected by households from their investment in improving their housing. Furthermore, they do not take into account the social and environmental cost of non-renovation.  The revision of the EPBD should be an opportunity to move away from these criterion and instead promote the integration of EE into the assessment of investment sustainability, as a guideline consistent with the taxonomy directive.  In this regard, the section of the technical annex of the TEG's taxonomy report regarding building renovation, relies on national regulations transposing the EPBD to set energy performance thresholds for major renovations. However in most Member States, and namely in France, these criteria are not demanding enough to be compatible with the 2050 carbon neutrality target. Similarly, the 30% reduction of primary energy demand in case of relative improvement, is not in line either with this objective.  Higher EE criteria should therefore be set in the EPBD. Furthermore, they should be expressed in terms of conventional energy consumption so that they can be assessed ex-post, and not in terms of % energy gain, as the energy performance level of the building before renovation is often a flawed and difficult to control data.  The Directive should also promote non-regulatory instruments (option 2) to ease the application of more stringent EE criteria: the adoption of methodological frameworks applicable to all sizes of buildings, to take into account air tightness, thermal bridges, risks of pathologies, etc. and to define a target for total primary energy consumption (expressed by the Primary Energy Coefficient) that is adapted to each building and takes into account the constraints and opportunities related to its configuration and environment. These methodological frameworks should be periodically evaluated to ensure that, at regional and national levels, renovations that are deemed to be compliant, based on the potential of each building and not on a uniform target for all, achieve effective results that are consistent with the trajectory of lower energy consumption by 2030 and 2050. It also implies that passports for building renovation make it possible to phase in renovations by stages with adequate measures in line with long term target.  Such methods could be deployed by one-stop shops for energy renovations, as local coordination of EPBD public policy instruments and facilitators of financing for energy renovations in housing. This implies specifying the criteria and conditions for public sector intervention to encourage the creation of these OSS as a Service of General Economic Interest (SGEI) in order to make it viable and attractive for the private sector, while limiting the deadweight effects.  https://orfee-project.com/
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Solo la energía de fuentes renovables ha de ser la impulsora energéticamente de cualquier edificio, casa, instalación, almacén, etc., público o privado, en una EU comprometida en mitigar el cambio climático, pero conjuntamente a esto, la naturización urbana adaptada al diseño de cualquier edificación tendría que ser también una opción a tener en cuenta en la eficiencia energética de cualquier edificio. Hablamos de crear edificios no solo sostenibles energéticamente, sino que produzcan parte o toda la energía que consuman en su vida útil, es decir crear edificios que utilicen menos energía, que sean más eficientes en su climatización e iluminación, que sean capaces de generarla gracias a sus azoteas verdes que actúen como barrera contra el calor o el frío, sumideros de carbono, zonas captadoras de energía con placas fotovoltaicas y/o aerogeneradores, zonas en definitiva útiles no solo para el edificio sino para la comunidad que lo habita. La fase de diseño de los nuevos edificios han de empezar considerando estas variables como imprescindibles a la hora de aprobar la obra por parte de las autoridades locales.  La naturización urbana significa integrar la naturaleza también entre los criterios de eficiencia energética y no solo en los de la salud y mitigación del cambio climático. Las azoteas generadoras de energía, sumadas a la capacidad de captación del carbono mediante la creación de zonas verdes, la climatización natural aprovechando la geolocalización en la bioregión, las horas de luz, los biomateriales, … todo esto no solo ha de ser una posibilidad, sino una obligación a la hora de diseñar nuevos edificios o regenerar y adaptar antiguos.   La eficiencia energética es un concepto ambiguo si no se define y se orienta hacia el objetivo deseado que no es otro que el de garantizar un desarrollo sostenible dentro de parámetros que contrarresten y mitiguen el cambio climático, es decir nada puede ser construido o diseñado que no contemple plenamente estos compromisos ineludibles de cualquier sociedad con ganas de preservarse manteniendo no solo su calidad de vida sino también la biodiversidad que la hace posible, porque la edificación como el urbanismo son parte de un metabolismo urbano donde el equilibrio entre entradas y salidas lo hacen ser catalogados de eficiente o ineficiente sosteniblemente. Es por eso que la dinámica de flujos y su control en los núcleos urbanos es el control, por definición, de la eficiencia energética de un núcleo urbano y por reducción de los componentes que lo constituyen, sus edificios.  Para eso, conceptos como la EPU (Ecología Política Urbana) son nuevas herramientas para abordar de manera crítica la relación entre el calentamiento global y los factores políticos, económicos y culturales, ya que la EPU se centra en los conceptos clave del problema que no es otro que el cambio socio-ambiental (socio-naturaleza), quien gana y quien pierde (Domene, 2006), creando así nuevos ambientes urbanos en donde nos gustaría vivir (Swyngedouw, 2006).  En todas las fases de vida de un edificio (planteamiento/proyecto, construcción, uso y mantenimiento y derribo e inertización), tendría que estar prevista en su memoria la huella ecológica y no solo la de carbono, a partir de ello una buena manera de fomentar prácticas de descarbonización seria la reducción impositiva de tasas e impuestos en función del cual fuese el impacto de esa huella. Para eso se tendría que crear una certificación que siguiesen patrones globales como los ODS.  Así mismo el uso de energías renovables tendría que ser la línea a seguir en todas las fases, para ello la directiva tendría que obligar la contratación de este tipo de fuentes de energía ya en la fase de construcción, es decir la energía en la construcción tendría que ser suministrada por fuentes renovables. No hace falta decir que hoy en día este tipo de contratación esta ofertada por casi todas las distribuidoras.  Todo ello y más es también es eficiencia energética.  D. Aragonès
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Better and more EE buildings are crucial for achieving the EU's energy and environmental goals, improve the quality of citizens' life, while bringing additional benefits to economy and society. The main legislative framework aimed to boost EPB includes the EPBD and EED; together, these two DIRs promote policies helping to: achieve a highly EE and decarbonised building stock by 2050; create a stable environment for investments; enable consumers/businesses to make more informed choices to save energy and money. We believe that the strategic measures and practices for implementing the DIRs into national law must be very well thought out, developed and implemented in a controlled manner. Bulgarian (BG) example – which cannot be applied for good practice – concerning the tool that is used to achieve energy savings in final consumption and which does not work properly – the program for free renovation of residential buildings: • The applied principle of 100% grant financing of the measures with money from the budget prevents the program from being wider by reaching more people, as the target financial resource is very limited and does not reach the funding of all target projects.  • Lack of financial self-contribution of homeowners in renovated buildings deprives them of motivation to realize and derive the maximum benefits from such a project, as well as their subsequent multiplication. In addition, financial resources are invested in a very limited circle of people but are paid by whole society. This comes to show that the mechanical implementing of set of measures (here EED) is often not a guarantee to successful achievement of high results related to energy savings and long and sustainable change of customer behavior, especially when selecting the right and adequate measures for a certain period and society is a valuable initial opportunity given to each MS.  Specifically regarding EPBD changes, we must remember that power sector decarbonisation truly will require significant investments not only in energy sector, but also in the sectors for which the energy system exists and functions. From where we get to the buildings we use for private, business or public needs. In this sense, a significant synergy in BG can be achieved and it is called “centralized district heating systems”. As a principle a replacement of existing CHP units with installations that incorporate RES and/or low carbon fuels (like gas) and high efficiency CHP should be encouraged, as they facilitate and accelerate the transition towards a zero-carbon economy, provide valuable assets for increasing energy system integration and help to achieve environmental goals (e.g. air quality).  Taking into account that BG is one of the MS with highest percentage of heating with electricity and direct combustion of cheap and polluting coal/briquettes we would suggest also to consider special forms of support (incentives within the framework of EU and nat. legislation) to projects for collective high-efficient and low-carbon H&C solutions/systems and associated networks – especially for existing ones, which do not involve electricity-only applications and would contribute to decarbonization and provide flexibility. In emission-afflicted urban communities in MS with GDP per capita below EU-average (like BG), investments in efficient collective H&C solutions and associated networks as well as alternative low carbon heating systems would help to tackle cost-effectively environmental problems such as poor air quality. The technical passport of buildings (TPB) in BG includes the technical characteristics of buildings with instructions regarding use and renovation. TPB also keeps record of all construction and renovation works done in the building. Important part of TPB is the energy passport, which rates the EE of buildings.  Large potential market – 3.8 mio dwellings in BG or 240.614.647 sq.m x 4 еuro = 962.458.588€ Public buildings – 104.923.286 sq.m x 4€ = 419.693.144€
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: La revisión de la EPBD supone una oportunidad para conseguir mayor reducción de energía y emisiones de CO2 y un retorno de la inversión. Apoyamos aumentar los objetivos de la EPBD y la opción 3, combinado con el refuerzo de la EPBD actual y las medidas de apoyo. Debe establecerse un objetivo claro de rehabilitación en línea con la Renovation Wave (25 millones de edificios rehabilitados en 2030). Para ello, consideramos necesario lo siguiente:  - Marco normativo coherente con un paquete completo de medidas legales que apoyen la implementación del Green Deal.  - Reconocimiento del principio Energy Efficiency First, priorizando la mejora del comportamiento de la envolvente de los edificios.  - Introducción de estándares mínimos de comportamiento energético (MEPS) como instrumento para conseguir edificios de energía casi nula en 2050 y la rehabilitación completa del parque edificado.  - Introducción de un estándar de rehabilitación de al menos el 60% de la demanda de energía (final). Una rehabilitación profunda requiere mejoras en la eficiencia energética del edificio que no se consigue sólo con la sustitución de equipos o fuentes de energía.*  - Mejora de los certificados de eficiencia energética, asegurando que se realizan por profesionales y con normas comunes.  - Uso de Pasaportes de Rehabilitación a gran escala para complementar la certificación, conseguir los objetivos y ayudar a los usuarios, priorizando su utilización en los programas de ayudas. Los Pasaportes deben ser digitales y de fácil utilización.  - Uso progresivo de mediciones reales que complementen los cálculos, facilitando la financiación de la rehabilitación unida a ahorros garantizados.  - En nueva edificación, mayor ambición del estándar NZEB. Debe evaluarse si el coste óptimo está en línea con los objetivos climáticos de 2030 y 2050 y los impactos socioeconómicos.  - Contemplar entre los objetivos de la EPBD la protección de bienes y personas, vigilando el criterio de no empeoramiento de lo existente, especialmente en el caso de edificios a rehabilitar. Actualmente, los incendios se están desarrollando mucho más rápido que en los años 50-60. La seguridad de los ocupantes depende, entre otras cosas, de evitar la propagación por el exterior y de eliminar/reducir/retrasar la liberación de humos. Para ello, se debe profundizar en los aspectos de seguridad contra incendios e introducir criterios que reflejen el riesgo derivado de la tipología y uso de los edificios y añadir como principio rector de cualquier acción en edificios existentes que las prestaciones de seguridad pasiva contra incendios no se debiliten tras una rehabilitación energética, sustituyendo las recomendaciones a los Estados miembros por exigencias sobre la adopción de unos mínimos de seguridad homogéneos en toda la EU  basados en un adecuado benchmarking.  * https://www.eceee.org/all-news/press/press-2017/epbd-must-focus-on-reducing-energy-needs-and-avoid-double-counting-of-renewables/
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Desde la Confederación Nacional de Asociaciones de Empresas de Fontanería, Gas, Calefacción, Climatización, Protección contra Incendios, Electricidad y Afines (CONAIF) consideramos que la descarbonización del sector de los edificios es vital para cumplir los objetivos climáticos y energéticos de la UE para 2030 y 2050, pues los edificios son responsables del 40% del consumo total de energía y del 36% de las de gases de efecto invernadero en la UE. CONAIF apoya el Plan de Objetivos Climáticos 2030, en el que la CE se ha propuesto reducir las emisiones netas de gases de efecto invernadero en la UE en al menos un 55% para 2030 en comparación con 1990. La eficiencia energética es un componente esencial para lograr este objetivo, y el sector de la construcción es uno de los ámbitos en los que hay que redoblar los esfuerzos.  La Comisión presentó el 14 de octubre de 2020 en su comunicación “Renovation Wave” una batería de medidas concretas de regulación, financiación y habilitación, con el objetivo de al menos duplicar la tasa anual de renovación energética de los edificios para 2030.  Desde CONAIF estimamos que la revisión de la Directiva sobre la eficiencia energética de los edificios (EPBD), se impone para cumplir con los objetivos de la iniciativa “Ola de Renovación” por lo que la opción 3, “Modificar la EPBD para traducir las acciones propuestas en la Ola de Renovación y la mayor ambición hacia la descarbonización de los edificios en legislación”,  descrita en los objetivos y opciones políticas del “INCEPTION IMPACT ASSESSMENT”, es la adecuada.   No obstante, la CE deber prestar una especial importancia en este ámbito, a la línea de inversión que se refiere al ecodiseño en las instalaciones de refrigeración, calefacción, climatización y agua caliente sanitaria.  El sector de calefacción español propone una serie de líneas de inversión y actuación para lograr los objetivos planteados por la Comisión:   • Aceleración del remplazo de los equipos de calefacción. Esta línea permitirá grandes ahorros ya que los equipos de calefacción representan la mayor parte de la energía utilizada en los edificios (85%). Acelerar su sustitución por equipos de última generación permitiría ahorros de casi un 40% de reducción de emisiones de CO2. Se propone sustituir los equipos de más de 10 años o de baja eficiencia energética. Hay 9.000.000 equipos instalados en España, de los cuales el 65 % son viejos e ineficientes-  • Programa de sustitución e hibridación. Se propone promover la hibridación de los edificios que ya están equipados con sistemas de calefacción altamente eficientes, es decir, la instalación de energía renovable adicional junto al sistema de calefacción eficiente existente.  En el caso de hibridar las instalaciones centralizadas con otras renovables donde esto fuera técnica y económicamente posible implicaría alcanzar % de renovabilidad superiores al 60% en el medio plazo. • Instalación de sistemas de control y automatización de instalaciones existentes. Fomentar la inclusión de sistemas de control y automatización en las instalaciones existentes, que permitan optimizar en tiempo real los consumos energéticos y el confort en función de las necesidades de los usuarios, tanto en instalaciones residenciales como colectivas. Cada grado de temperatura menos supone un ahorro de un 8% de energía • Campañas de comunicación sobre los sistemas de calefacción eficientes y sus ventajas económicas para los consumidores y para el medio. Es imprescindible concienciar a la población en general sobre el adecuado uso de las energías y aumentar el conocimiento sobre energías limpias, de forma clara y concisa además de venir unida a los conceptos de ahorro y confort.  • Aplicación de IVA reducido para las instalaciones de alta eficiencia energética. En definitiva, es el consumidor final el que soportará la mayor parte del coste de la transición energética, por lo que es necesario incentivar los cambios.  • Aplicación de desgravaciones fiscales.  Feedback from: CONAIF (932 KB - PDF - 10 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The building sector is already today recognized as the one with the greatest potential to decarbonize europe. As the requirements for new buildings are already today in many cases much higher the key is to improve the renovation and replacement of inefficient technology in the existing buildings. As Europe isn't one country and also facing different hurdles the requirements for the replacement must be applied feasible ideally connected to already today existing measures in the EU Member States. Many different measures have been provided in the long term renovation strategies, that were asked by the EPBD from 2018.  Thats why one general point is to keep the variety of feasible solutions to a level of a maximum of openness to techology as there will not be the one and only solution.   One approach could be to link the Energy performace certificates (for all buildings) to such measures. WIth these EPC's the worst performing buildings can be identified very easy. Often also the worst performing buildings have also the worst performing technologies. If the replacement of this old boiler takes place a building's CO2-Emissions will be reduced tremendous.  One other approach: The EPC must be linked with approaches like individual renovation roadmap (in Germany there is the Individueller Sanierungsfahrplan - ISFP) in place. WIth this roadmap a good possibility to drive deep renovation in defined and planned steps is given.  Additionally individual trigger points must be taken into account (rent of building/flat, sale of building/flat, major renovation due to focus on age-appropriate conversion etc.)  In Addition to link the ‘building’ as relevant energy consumer and producer in the general energysystem to the ongoing discussion on hydrogen and synthetic fuels must be considered and credited of this fuel based solutions should be permitted as this will be highly relevant in the years to come.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Der Bundesverband Pro Passivhau e. V. ist vor allem in Deutschland aktiv und vereint Planer, Dienstleister und Industrie. Der Verband und seine Mitglieder stehen im Austausch mit vielen europäischen Vertretern der Baubranche, die durch die Unterstützung des international gültigen Passivhaus-Standards in den letzten 25 Jahren zu einer wachsenden Community mit hoher Expertise im Bereich höchster Gebäudeenergieeffizienz geworden sind.   Die Renovation Wave wird von uns ausdrücklich begrüßt. Wir brauchen Sanierungen im großen Maßstab, um die Klimaziele der EU zu erreichen und die Zukunftsfähigkeit des Bestands zu sichern. In der damit verbundenen Revision der EPBD sehen wir vor allen anderen Rechtsvorschriften einen der größten Hebel. Dieser greift allerdings nur, wenn der Rechtsrahmen verstärkt und der Mindeststandard ausreichend ambitioniert gesetzt wird und nicht wie in der Vergangenheit durch die Überführung in nationales Recht aufgeweicht wird. Insbesondere die Forderung eines wirksamen Standards, der nicht bloß durch vereinfachte Berechnungsverfahren in der Theorie effizient erscheint, sondern der real mit geringen Energieverbräuchen auskommt, ohne nach kurzer Zeit einen erneuten Sanierungsbedarf zu erzeugen, wird für die Zielerreichung entscheidend sein. Mit dem lange erprobten und im Rahmen vieler EU-Projekte validierten Passivhaus-Standard, der mittlerweile vieltausendfach in sämtlichen Hochbauprojekten für real höchste Energieeinsparungen sorgt, steht eine geeignete Lösung für einen wissenschaftlich basierten, prägnant definierten und national flexibel anwendbaren, gesamteuropäischen Standard vor.   Ein erfolgreich erprobter, gut dokumentierter, gemeinsamer Standard, der klare, verbindliche und ausreichend flexible Regeln für die Mitgliedsstaaten einführt, wirkt sich zudem harmonisierend auf den europäischen Binnenmarkt aus, kann Innovationen beschleunigen, den Verwaltungsaufwand verringern, die Motivation zur Weiterbildung und Transformation erhöhen, durch seine Belastbarkeit das Vertrauen in Einsparmaßnahmen stärken, die Geschwindigkeit der schrittweisen Einführung beschleunigen und den Austausch von Wissen und Best Practice-Beispielen vereinfachen.   Unseren vollständigen Kommentar inklusiver aller Empfehlungen finden Sie im Dokument im Anhang. Feedback from: Pro Passivhaus e. V. (222.8 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Göteborg Energ’s response to the consultation of the Inception Impact Assessment for the revision of the Energy Performance in Buildings Directive 2010/31/EU   (EPBD) 10-2021-0369   • Göteborg Energi AB supports ambitious climate and energy targets in line with 2050 climate neutrality for the EU.  Focusing on greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction, targets on energy efficiency and renewable energy should be only indicative on national level. A technology-neutral and holistic view on energy systems is essential in order to reflect the different conditions between and within the Member States.  • A life cycle perspective on building materials is necessary. Much of a the GHG-impact of buildings is due to materials such as concrete and steel. The lack of this dimension in the EPBD means risking that the push for renovation and new energy-efficient buildings would go against the over-arching targets of decarbonising the EU building stock.  • It is necessary that Renewable energy should be equally treated within the EED and EPBD,  whether produced on-site at the building or supplied through energy-carriers, such as district heating, district cooling, the electricity grid or renewable gases, including hydrogen.   • On the policy options proposed in the consultation document, Göteborg Energi AB would support Option 1 – No policy change (baseline scenario) but adjusted to include renewable energy produced at the building (equally treated) in order to avoid sub optimizing and assure a proper view of a building’s need in energy.    • An in increased electrification and variable renewable production of electricity, peak power demands are rising and will become a crucial issue for the energy system. Member States should have the possibility to set minimum energy performance requirements on peak power demand (kW/m2) in their national definitions of Nearly Zero Energy Buildings (NZEB) and building codes, not only on energy use (kWh/m2*year). (Annex I and guidance (EU) 2019/786 on expressing buildings energy performance). • Demands on individual measurement and billing of heating in residential buildings in the EED should not be mandatory, as this would risk taking away the property owners’ incentive for energy efficiency measures and introduce energy poverty. There is good practice to draw experience from, such as a system of gross rent where owners guarantee a certain in-door temperature. [The EC partially imposed this on SE through an infringement procedure.]  It would be inefficient introducing split incentives between owners and tenants, as raised in the impact assessment. • A proper implementation is important; the current EPBD has not yet been fully evaluated, avoiding over-regulation and increasing administration burden on the Member States. Major revisions of the newly adopted directives should be done only after careful assessment of ongoing work.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: The Platform for Electromobility warmly welcomes the EC’s willingness to revise the Directive on the energy performance of buildings (2010/31/EU, EPBD). In light of the EC’s roadmap, the Platform does not only take a stand for the option 3 but points out that electromobility needs to be addressed as one of the key elements of the EPBD revision if the EU wishes to deliver the objectives set in the Smart and Sustainable Mobility Strategy, the Energy System Integration Strategy and the Renovation Wave Strategy.  The deployment of private charging is as important for the growth of electromobility and the decarbonisation of transport as that of charging accessible to the public, given that 90% of EV charging happens at home or in the workplace and 80% of the EU’s current building stock will still be in used by 2050. The EC must therefore revise art. 8 of the EPBD in order to tackle the outstanding barriers to the installation of EV chargers and collective charging infrastructure in all non-residential and residential buildings to ensure that all EV users have a “right to plug”. The Platform also thinks that the electric bicycles (incl. e-cargo bikes, e-two-wheelers, e-moped and e-cars) should be considered.  To that end, the Platform shares its key recommendations.   1) Set minimum infrastructure requirements for all types of buildings (new and existing) by:   - Putting in place minimum requirements for the pre-cabling of the installation of EV chargers and ensuring that all buildings will be pre-equipped by 2035.   2) Guarantee the right-to-plug to all EV users   The right to plug should be as simple as a subscription to other services like internet, phone provider, etc.    The Platform recommends:   - Aligning the provision of art. 8 on the ‘right-to-plug’ with the Spanish, Dutch and Norwegian legislations to facilitate the installation of charging infrastructure for tenants and properties under shared ownership.  - Tackling the remaining obstacles for the installation of charging points in buildings by removing the unnecessary exemptions applied to SMEs and addressing the administrative hurdles (e.g. EV charging as extralegal benefit for employees) as well as collective action problems (e.g. split incentives between EV and non-EV drivers, renters vs. owners, employee vs. employer, etc.).  - Ensure that the request for the installation of charging stations in collective properties does not exceed 3 months.   3) Introduce requirements for smart charging   Smart charging in buildings ensures a better charging experience, reduces the electricity bill  of the consumers and can create synergies with renewable energies by integrating them into the electricity grids and providing flexibility services to the system through smart charging.   We call for:  - Aligning the existing requirements of the EPBD with a definition on smart charging that the Platform urges to be introduced in the revision of the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive (AFID).  - Strengthen the existing requirements of art. 8 to support the deployment of smart charging in multi-family and non-residential buildings in order to provide flexibility services to the power system via EV connection to the grid and to buildings.   Finally, the EC needs to:   - Revise the EPBD in coherence with the AFID to ensure that there is a same level of ambition in both texts and guarantee a consistent framework for the deployment of charging infrastructure across Europe.  - In line with the Renovation Wave, ensure that funding and recovery plans tackle the roll-out of smart charging infrastructure in the building renovations. A long-term funding programme (about 10 to 15 years) for local authorities and governments could be developed for example and channelled through MS to support the cabling of residential and office buildings’ in all parking spots.    Please find the full recommendations of the Platform attached.  Feedback from: Platform for Electromobility (https://www.platformelectromobility.eu/) (136.4 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: A significant increase of the renovation rate plays a central role in Europe’s effort to tackle climate change. Consequently, we are strongly in favour of the Renovation Wave’s agenda and welcome the EPBD revision, which must be a core contributor to achieving the aim of carbon neutrality in the building sector. In detail, we suggest to focus on the following elements:  1) Introduce energy performance standards for “Worst Performance Buildings” (WPB)  Establishing binding minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for WPB is long overdue and presents an important step towards significant reduction of the sector’s CO2-footprint. A European MEPS framework should be ambitious (lifting WPB to EPC rating of B or above) while at the same time giving member states enough flexibility to adapt to local conditions. At the same time, it must be ensured that member states can embed their MEPS in existing and new support programmes in order to enable compliance and safeguard social fairness, in line with state aid rules and European assistance.  2) Upgrade Energy Performance Certificates (EPC) and enhance data availability  In order to tackle existing and future deficits in the building sector’s CO2-performance, the member states must be able to have access to reliable data on a large scale. Unfortunately, this is not given today – making it difficult for political stakeholders to measure the success of their programmes and to plan necessary reduction-paths years ahead. National EPC databases must be required to be a) far more accessible, and b) to be fed with profound and reliable data on energy demand in order to enable transparent monitoring, benchmarking and analysis. Additionally, energy and carbon performance data of all publicly owned buildings should be made available online.  3) Introducing mandatory indicator for building envelope  The building envelope plays a central role for the energy efficiency of houses. Yet, it has not been appropriately taken into consideration by the EPBD. We therefore urge the commission to change this.  This step could be based on Annex of DIRECTIVE (EU) 2018/844 of 19.6.2018 which allows member states to define additional numeric indicators for the purpose of expressing the energy performance of a building, like greenhouse gas emissions produced in kg CO2-e/m²a. However, none of these proposed indicators is directly related to the performance of the building envelope. Therefore, the EPBD is lacking an indicator reinforcing the “Efficiency First”- principle.  The mandatory introduction of a new indicator, allowing the member states to express the status – and set requirements - to the energy performance of the building envelope, would serve the “Efficiency First”-principle. Several types of indicators would be suitable, for example average “U values” of the building envelope or the specific heat transmission coefficient H`T, which are both already used in the German building energy law.  4) Using Building Renovation Passports for better planning Due to very long investment circles, buildings that are built or renovated today must be compatible with the climate 2050-goals. Home owners must therefore have access to appropriate tools in order to profoundly plan the renovation of their buildings. We therefore suggest the mandatory introduction of Building Renovation Passports within the EPBD that enable home owners to carefully plan next steps, bearing in mind necessary future investments in line with 2050 benchmarks. Such a mandatory scheme could have a huge impact on the sector’s CO2-footprint thus reducing it significantly in the decades to come.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: ISSOL is a Belgium manufacturer of solar glass and project developer of active glazing solutions. In collaboration with the world’s most famous contemporary designers we develop beautiful positive energy solutions for buildings that generate their own electricity using the free energy of the sun.   Together with AGC Glass Europe we develop a range of building materials that can transform façades into smart membranes, generating and managing energy, while integrating seamlessly into façades. Building Integrated PhotoVoltaic (BIPV) solutions’ environmental performances and efficiency ratings are consistent with nearly zero-building (NZEB) standards.   ISSOL and his partner AGC Glass Europe therefore welcome the revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD). For a swift decarbonization of the building stock, option 3 is the best option and the opportunity for the European Commission (EC) to give new impetus to massive deployment of renewable energy - solar in particular, and BIPV more specifically.   To achieve the ambitious GHG reduction targets set out in the Climate Target Plan 2030 and the Renovation Wave, the mass deployment of PV is essential. For this reason, we are very pleased to see that they are mentioned as a solution in all the recent initiatives issued by the EC, in particular in the Renovation Wave. However, until now, the EC consistently refers (also p.3 of the EPBD inception impact assessment) only to one application of PV: solar panels on roofs. Yet, we will need PV in all forms, applications, and innovations. Of course, that means we need panels on roofs - but we must go further: solar canopies, tiles, etc. We even have to look beyond roofs, to integrating PV into other building elements, such as façades, glazing, and others.   In a letter of 26 January 2021 sent to the cabinet of EVP Timmermans and the Commissioner Simson for Energy, we have asked the EC to concretely mention BIPV – in order to help build awareness and an EU market. We believe the EPBD could be the first EU policy to cater for that demand and make concrete reference to BIPV as demanded in our letter that has been signed by hundreds of European partners throughout the BIPV value chain. This letter is attached as Annex 1, and forms integral part of this consultation input. In this context, we ask the EC to be more specific about BIPV in the definition of ‘building envelope’, ‘nearly-zero energy buildings’, ‘energy from renewable sources’ and Annex 1 of the EPBD.   This way, the EPBD can help these innovative technologies, with serious EU-added value, find a way to market. Here we take the opportunity to raise more awareness of the potential of BIPV to power the built environment:   ·         In order to meet the Renovation Wave’s GHG reduction targets, we will have to look further than only roofs for PV: we will have to look at buildings as a whole to generate renewable electricity. BIPV can do just that.   ·         Photovoltaic cells are becoming more and more affordable. In many cases, the cheapest BIPV products can come at a lower cost than high-end conventional construction materials (slate tiles, stone). Also, the performance of BIPV is developing rapidly. On top of that, BIPV can be installed by way of non-intrusive renovations – in which the building remains in use, saving second-tier costs – meaning the integration of PV into buildings holds huge potential and offers a quick return on investment, satisfying the ambitions of the Renovation Wave.   ·         BIPV is also a component of the ecosystem of smart buildings technologies. The shift towards smart and sustainable cities will stimulate growth, create new jobs and is a productive investment in Europe’s future. Investing in promising innovative materials and technologies will also put Europe at the forefront of renewable energy production and reduce dependence on external actors.   Please be referred to Annexes. Feedback from: New Issol SA (432.2 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: PROPOSTE ANCE PER LA REVISIONE DELLA DIRETTIVA EPBD  (Direttiva Prestazione Energetica degli Edifici 2010/31/EU) al fine di raddoppiare il tasso di interventi di ristrutturazione degli edifici esistenti  In Italia le detrazioni fiscali in vigore, in primis il Superbonus 110%, rappresentano uno strumento strategico per lo sviluppo e per l’attuazione di un programma concreto di riqualificazione del patrimonio edilizio, in linea con gli obiettivi di sostenibilità e di riduzione del consumo del suolo definiti nell’ambito del Green Deal europeo. Il Superbonus, misura entrata in vigore da luglio 2020, ha già ricevuto buoni riscontri sul mercato, soprattutto negli ultimi mesi (i dati di marzo 2021 stimano in circa 800 milioni di euro il valore degli interventi realizzati e/o in corso e circa 6.500 i cantieri aperti), considerando la complessità di intervenire su interi edifici.  Alle potenzialità di tali detrazioni, però, si contrappone la complessità degli interventi che richiedono tempi lunghi per la definizione dei progetti e, in particolare, per le procedure autorizzative. Inoltre, su interventi così complessi e lunghi da  realizzare, le iniziative sono rallentate e rischiano di essere bloccate sul nascere per l’incertezza della durata limitata dei benefici fiscali, il cui termine a oggi è previsto nel 2022 mentre i cantieri di ristrutturazione pesante richiedono tempi lunghi. Serve quindi avere certezza e stabilità per un adeguato periodo temporale per dispiegare tutto il potenziale delle detrazioni fiscali anche in ottica di sviluppare interventi nel lungo periodo: dopo gli obiettivi europei del 2030, il traguardo a decarbonizzare l’edilizia è già fissato per il 2050. Al fine di raddoppiare il tasso di ristrutturazioni degli edifici e di conseguire gli obiettivi di riduzione delle emissioni di gas serra entro il 2030, L’Ance ritiene indispensabile aggiornare la Direttiva EPBD e integrarla con ulteriori indicazioni per gli Stati membri, riguardanti nuove misure da adottare o il potenziamento di quelle già in vigore. feedback_msg_text: The https://www.renewableheatingandcoolingalliance.org states:  • EPBD must focus on displacing fossil emissions from heating and cooling with renewable solutions combined with improving energy savings. There are no substantive technical barriers to enabling this change, just a lack of regulatory design and policy coherency. • The current EPBD and overall EU building policy framework lacks effective implementation measures to deliver this outcome. New implementing measures must be designed to accelerate investment in geothermal, heat pumps, solar thermal and renewable district heating in households and cities.  • Article 2a on Long-Term Renovation Strategies must be adapted to set a target of 100% greenhouse gas emission reductions by 2050 and accelerate the decarbonisation of the building stock through renewable heating, cooling and energy savings measures. The Long-Term Renovation Strategies should also evolve to integrated planning that combines the demand-side (energy efficiency) and the supply-side (renewable energy). Integrating the long-term renovation strategies with national and local heat transition plans helps to maximise the synergies between energy efficiency and renewable energy measures in the building sector. • The 2018 reform introduced carbon emission thresholds. This must now be aligned to Article 23 of the Renewable Energy Directive and be integral to renovation strategies and investment rates. The review must include strict thresholds for the overall carbon footprint of buildings, limiting the use of any fossil equipment in new and deeply renovated buildings. • Europe’s least affluent households are already the most likely to live in poorly insulated buildings consuming polluting fossil fuels. They are also the most exposed to energy poverty, spending the highest share of their income on heating and cooling. The EPBD must require Member States to include concrete plans to deploy renewable heating and cooling in, and improve the energy performance of, these buildings. • The EPBD must now include decarbonisation requirements for public buildings from 2021. • Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) should be phased in for all of the existing building stock to drive deeper and faster energy renovations at scale. A trajectory to achieve a decarbonized building stock by 2050 can be achieved by requiring existing buildings to meet a minimum performance standard by a given date or at a chosen trigger point in the building lifecycle. MEPS allow the uptake of renewable-based technologies such as solar thermal, geothermal, heat pumps and renewables-based district heating that work better with low-energy buildings and should also lead to an increased use of renewables-based, energy-efficient heating and cooling systems in buildings.  • The average lifetime of heating equipment is in the range of 20 years, which means that any new installation of fossil fuels-based heating systems locks in CO2 for decades to come. The ongoing process to take Ecodesign measures for heating appliances should set more stringent energy efficiency requirements to significantly accelerate the deployment of renewables-based heating systems.  • Subsidies for unabated fossil fuels, including those that promote the efficient use of fossil fuel-only equipment, are inconsistent with the EU’s climate neutrality target and must end immediately. • The definition of “Renewable heating and cooling” in Article 2 of the EPBD must correspond to renewable energy sources defined in Article 2 of the Renewable Energy Directive and exclude (low-carbon) fossil fuels. • The framework for evaluating the energy performance of buildings must be adapted to exclude fossil fuels from new buildings and deep renovations. To do so, the definition of NZEB in the EPBD Article 2 must be adapted to ensure that the residua • We recommend Articles 6, 7 and 10 are revised to exclude financial support for unabated fossil fuel-only equipment. feedback_msg_text: Reaction of Swedish Construction Federation to Inception Impact Assessment – EPBD Revision   We understand the need to revise the EPBD to ensure alignment with the Climate Law and to enable the implementation of the goals for deep renovations in the Renovation Wave. Therefore, we will engage positively with this process and we believe that Option 3 is the most reasonable for achieving the objectives. However, we would like to emphasize on the fact that we still have goals to reach within the current version of EPBD and therefore ask for measures to be proportionate and to ensure that the return in terms of impact is reasonable. There is a deep concern in how to raise the importance of energy efficient renovations among all stakeholders within the sector. Among the barriers that are mentioned we think that low awareness of the energy profile of the buildings, energy performance not being fully reflected in real estate prices and split incentives between owners and tenants are among the strongest. It´s important that the revision of the EPBD encourages deep renovations instead of “shallow”. Otherwise there is a risk that we lose the opportunity of achieving sustainable buildings and a huge risk that energy and climate targets will not be reached both on national and EU-level.  There is a big need to improve the link to circularity.  The new EPBD needs to include measures to address circularity, albeit bearing in mind the challenges we face – standards, lack of availability of such materials, toxicity, fire, and safety issues. A holistic approach is extremely important. Although the directive is about energy efficiency, buildings must be structurally safe, accessible, comfortable and have a good indoor climate for instance. Material and technical neutrality must be maintained.  Specific materials and technologies cannot be prescribed.  This must be selected by the designer, client and construction actors involved in the building or renovation process. It´s also clear that some further harmonization will be necessary, as there are wide variations in implementation by the Member States. Harmonization with other initiatives such as the Taxonomy and other directives mentioned in the Inception Impact Assessment is of course important. We have the following thoughts and concerns about EPC:s: • Certified experts who perform the EPC must always visit the property. • Detailed information about the recommendations for renovation must be given; we see a potential for improvement in this. Today it is hard for the tenant/real estate owner to fully understand what needs to be done to improve the energy performance of the building because the measures are often not described in enough detail. We see a need for a stricter requirement that the real estate owner performs the proposed cost-effective measures to improve the energy performance of the building. However, we also see the problem that cost effectiveness and technical feasibility must be considered in the process. • There should be better supervision of the audit that takes place before issuing the EPC. Today this is weak (and differs from country to country) with surveillance only checking that the EPC has been done, but not that it is correct.  Enforcement of this could be a measure under the revised EPBD. • As many countries do not maintain databases of EPCs, this could be a new measure under the revised EPBD.  This could also be linked to a central EU database. • The revision could look at improving comparability, e.g. via the EU database mentioned above, but also by harmonizing e.g. the methodology/calculation method and other aspects. • Digital EPCs could eventually replace the existing ones and the set of data should be incorporated into building renovation passports. There is some confusion between renovation passports and digital logbooks.  We believe that the confusion between these two passports need to be resolved.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: The Renewable Heating & Cooling Alliance welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback to the Inception Impact Assessment of upcoming revisions to the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive.  Objective: EPBD must focus on displacing fossil emissions from heating and cooling with renewable solutions combined with improving energy savings.    Effective implementation: The current EPBD and overall EU building policy framework lacks effective implementation measures to deliver this outcome. New implementing measures must be designed to accelerate investment in geothermal, heat pumps, solar thermal and renewable district heating in households and cities. These include:   Bringing the target in line with a decarbonized building stock by 2050: Article 2a on Long-Term Renovation Strategies must be adapted to set a target of 100% greenhouse gas emission reductions by 2050 and accelerate the decarbonisation of the building stock through renewable heating, cooling and energy savings measures. The Long-Term Renovation Strategies should evolve to integrated planning that combines the demand-side (energy efficiency) and the supply-side (renewable energy). Integrating the long-term renovation strategies with national and local heat transition plans helps to maximise the synergies between energy efficiency and renewable energy measures in the building sector.   Emission thresholds: The 2018 reform introduced carbon emission thresholds. This must now be aligned to Article 23 of the Renewable Energy Directive and be integral to renovation strategies and investment rates. The review must include strict thresholds for the overall carbon footprint of buildings, limiting the use of any fossil equipment in new and deeply renovated buildings.   Addressing fuel/energy poverty: Europe’s least affluent households are already the most likely to live in poorly insulated buildings consuming polluting fossil fuels. They are also the most exposed to energy poverty, spending the highest share of their income on heating and cooling. The EPBD must require Member States to include concrete plans to deploy renewable heating and cooling in, and improve the energy performance of, these buildings.   Public building exemplarity: Public buildings must lead the way in the decarbonising the building stock. However, much more is required. Therefore, the EPBD must now include decarbonisation requirements for public buildings from 2021.   Introducing Minimum Energy Performance Standards: Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) should be phased in for all of the existing building stock to drive deeper and faster energy renovations at scale. A trajectory to achieve a decarbonized building stock by 2050 can be achieved by requiring existing buildings to meet a minimum performance standard by a given date or at a chosen trigger point in the building lifecycle. MEPS allow the uptake of renewable-based technologies such as solar thermal, geothermal, heat pumps and renewables-based district heating that work better with low-energy buildings and should also lead to an increased use of renewables-based, energy-efficient heating and cooling systems in buildings.    Drastically decreasing the use of fossil fuels for heating and cooling in buildings: The average lifetime of heating equipment is in the range of 20 years, which means that any new installation of fossil fuels-based heating systems locks in CO2 for decades to come. The ongoing process to take Ecodesign measures for heating appliances should set more stringent energy efficiency requirements to significantly accelerate the deployment of renewables-based heating systems.    Ending ‘fuel neutrality’ and other fossil fuel subsidies: - definition of “Renewable heating and cooling” in Article 2 based on RED definitions - Ensuring all new buildings are both highly efficient and fossil free from 2025 onwards (NZEB) - Article 10 must be revised to exclude financial support for standalone greenhouse gas emitting equipment. feedback_msg_text: REScoop.eu - the European Federation of Citizen Energy Communities - welcomes the opportunity to respond to the EBPD Revision Roadmap and Inception Impact Assessment on behalf of over 1500 energy communities and 1 million citizens in Europe.    The Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD) and the related national long-term renovation strategies (LTRS) are crucial instruments in achieving the goals of the EU Renovation wave and a climate neutral Europe by 2050. Achieving a sustainable transformation of the EU’s building stock means that the homes of the EU’s 195 million households need to be decarbonised . This will be impossible without having those households - citizens and communities - onboard and actively engaged. Yet, the key principles of the Renovation Wave, and the EBPD, emphasize the technological and economic aspects of building renovation and seem to forget the end-beneficiaries: people. To reach our climate goals and ensure a just and inclusive transition we call on the Commission to undertake a complete revision of the EBPD to bring it in line with these goals.   Energy communities are increasingly involved in providing energy efficiency and building renovation services to their members. Ranging from performing energy audits and providing information to homeowners to guiding people through the entire renovation process from planning and financing to delivery (a 'one-stop-shop' service). As a trusted partner rooted in local communities and networks citizen-led renovation programs are well positioned to help address some of the barriers to increased uptake of sustainable renovations, especially in the residential sector. For example:   • Low awareness on energy savings and benefits of renovation • Lack of trust in quality of work/contractors • Lack of (local) skills • Accessibility of finance and complexity of procedures   A revised EPBD needs to:   1) Acknowledge the important contribution energy communities can make to reaching energy efficiency and renovation targets and help address barriers to increased building renovation rates  2) Provide an enabling framework for energy communities and citizen-led renovation programs  3) Connect with the Recast Renewable Energy Directive on energy communities.   Please find our response to this consultation attached. We would look forward to the possibility of discussing the needs and contributions of citizens and energy communities on energy performance of buildings in more detail with the Commission. feedback_msg_text: EuropeOn, the EU association of electrical contractors, welcomes the upcoming revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive. Buildings will be at the center of climate action and digitalisation in the coming years, as they are needed to support local deployment of renewables, to provide flexibility to power systems and enable the smart electrification of transport. Electrical contractors represent a key segment in the decarbonisation of buildings as they install, integrate and maintain the electrical systems and installations within buildings.   Since the revision of the EPBD in 2018, a renewed impetus for climate action, with the Green Deal and its key actions, and for digitalisation, as many EU citizens have turned to teleworking for the past year, has arisen to warrant a comprehensive revision this EPBD. While it is paramount to decarbonise buildings swiftly, this is also the opportunity to make our buildings smart.   Not only will smart buildings be more energy efficient and able to integrate their own renewable power, they will be able to act as a positive resource for the entire energy system. Grid operators will be able to count on a new source of flexibility, EV and heat pump users will be able to take advantage of the lowest power prices, and consumers can enjoy their own green energy while being remunerated for their grid services.   However, European buildings are old, designed for outdated energy consumption models, and the vast majority of the built environment is not smart in any way. Realising this potential entails a massive acceleration of renovation rates coupled with emphasis on electrification and connectivity.   - The main electrical systems within many older buildings will need to be replaced or modernised to support system integration and smart buildings. Designed at a time when electrified end-uses were rare, in-building wiring, cabling or fuse boxes need an upgrade to keep up with modern lifestyles and new climate measures while ensuring electrical safety. These necessary renovations will underpin the effectiveness of building electrification measures.   - Funding and incentives must be made available to support consumers and building codes must ensure that renovated houses are ready to become a hub for  system integration through electrification.   - The new EPBD must support the decarbonisation of transport to a much greater extent. E-mobility has taken off since the 2018 revision and the recharging provisions under art. 8 are already becoming obsolete in light of the projected increase in the market share of EVs. The new EPBD must already provide for the future needs of a fast-growing e-mobility market, counting on charging-ready buildings, which will in turn support electricity systems. It is necessary to match requirements for ducting and charging infrastructure with the projected growth of electro-mobility.    - A true ‘right-to-plug’ needs to be implemented in order not to deter potential EV buyers with stringent policies hampering the installation of charging equipment.   - Charging infrastructure fitted to multi-occupancy buildings must also be interoperable and feature open standards to remain adaptable and allow new chargers to be added in as a network throughout the life-cycle of the building.   - Approval and notification procedures need to be streamlined for electric installations such as EV charging equipment to avoid unreasonably long delays before receiving the green light from grid operators.  - BACS requirements must be strengthened to pave the way for smart homes and contribute to future-proofing our buildings.  - Finally, the Primary Energy Factor (PEF) for electricity must be reviewed in conjunction with the Energy Efficiency Directive and lowered to truly reflect the contribution of the fast-decarbonising power sector to our energy system, and to support system integration while harnessing the efficiency of electrification.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: The Inception Impact Assessment for the revision of the EPBD proposes 3 different pathways.    - Renovate Europe strongly supports Option 3 ‘Amend the EPBD’ as this will be crucial to achieving the Renovation Wave objectives, with a clear focus on 1) Introduction of MEPS 2) Updating of the EPC framework and 3) Definition of deep renovation standard.    - Renovate Europe strongly believes that the non-regulatory measures outlined in Option 2 (particularly technical and financial support measures and supply chain capacity) also have a key enabling role to play.   - Recent assessment of the Long-term Renovation Strategies and their non-compliance with the EPBD objectives of climate-neutrality by 2050, combined with the stubbornly low renovation rates in the EU, clearly preclude Option 1 ‘No policy change’ from being a responsible option.  Renovate Europe therefore emphasises that both regulatory and non-regulatory measures must be synchronised in the most effective way in the context of the upcoming revision of the EPBD.   See full response in attachment and on the Renovate Europe website: https://www.renovate-europe.eu/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/REC-Reaction-to-EPBD-Roadmap-2021_FINAL.pdf Feedback from: Renovate Europe Campaign (353.1 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The TIC Council welcomes the European Commission’s intention to amend the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD) so that it can contribute to the Renovation Wave and foster deep energy renovations of buildings.  We recommend that EPBD’s amendment leads to establishing a harmonized system for certification and comprehensive inspection of buildings’ performance across all Member States, not limited to heating and air-conditioning. The new framework should establish: • minimum harmonized criteria for the professional qualification, technical equipment, impartiality and accreditation of inspectors and certifiers. • minimum harmonized criteria for inspection and certification methodology based on international standards.  • a harmonized process to verify the improvement of energy performance of a building after a renovation, including controls regarding the proper implementation of the agreed measures during the renovation.  • the mandatory use of current data from the buildings instead of theoretical data from similar buildings.  • periodic inspections of the energy management systems, including all aspects of the technical building systems in a comprehensive framework that would enable auditing the building’s energy consumption, including relevant equipment. Ideally, this should be designed within a systemic approach of all rules relevant to energy efficiency and sustainability, as for example Ecodesign Directive and Construction Products Regulation.  Furthermore, the current system of national certification rules without obligatory accreditation often leads to sub-optimal inspections and certifications. Equally, often these activities are conducted by professionals who also undertake the renovation. As such, they lack impartiality when describing the potential technical solutions.   Therefore, we recommend ensuring that impartial and accredited inspection and certification professionals are only allowed to conduct such activities under the EPBD. These professionals, who are often part of our sector, have the necessary knowledge, access to equipment and experience to propose a wide range of recommendations for improving the building’s energy performance.   In particular, our sector can offer thorough services to assess buildings’ energy performance and to make optimization recommendations that adequately combine measures leading to highly energy-efficient, resource-efficient and decarbonised buildings. These span from the design of new buildings to the inspection and renovation of buildings with landmark architecture.  For example, our sector conducts: • audits of building designs to ensure that they comply with environmental performance requirements and users’ requirements, such as healthy work environment.  • inspection for equipment ranging from HVAC, smart metering solutions and integrated cogeneration solutions • development of guidelines enabling users to visual inspect the building and prevent energy performance risk. • thermographic inspections of buildings to identify mechanical, electrical or heating issues to be addressed. • material testing for construction products, including roofing, insulation, polymer, surface coating, rock and metal testing.  • certification of energy management systems based on international standards (such as ISO 50001)  Therefore, we consider that the EPBD’s amendment should ensure that the TIC sector can operate under strict and harmonised conditions across the EU in order to play its role in building’s energy optimization.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Solar Heat Europe strongly supports the idea that buildings decarbonisation will be key for the achievement of Europe’s 2030 and 2050 climate and energy objectives. In this content, the revision of the EPBD is necessary to ensure an effective renovation strategy and a smooth implementation of the Fit for 55 Package.  The amendment of the directive (opt.3) should be complemented with reinforced non-regulatory policy instruments and measures providing technical assistance (opt.2), to address key issues in the context of building decarbonisation like the lack of awareness on energy solutions and incentives, and the absence of highly skilled professionals.  Two thirds of heating and cooling (H&C) in buildings comes from fossil fuels showing that strong actions are needed. Solar Heat Europe advocates for a comprehensive Renovation Wave, with a strategy focused on an optimal combination of energy efficiency and initiatives to promote the modernisation of heating and cooling systems switching to locally produced renewable heat (RES-H).  To ensure that this switch happens in a timely and affordable way, the replacement of old and inefficient systems with renewable ones should be staged and planned in advance. When heating appliances break down unexpectedly, consumers will replace the old ones with similar products often powered with fossil fuels. Considering that H&C appliances have an average lifetime of 20 years, emergency replacement must be avoided to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. Consumers aware of the conditions of their current systems and the renewable alternatives available, would more easily plan this change and move away from fossil-based heating. For this, the planned replacement of H&C systems must be further promoted and supported in the revised EPBD.  The objective for the EU building stock is to be highly efficient and decarbonised by 2050, thus the links between the EPBD and REDII must be strengthened with the further development of the Long-term Renovation Strategies (LTRSs). The LTRSs shall design building renovation strategies to increase energy savings and decarbonise heating and cooling by implementing RES-H systems on-site or nearby the buildings. These measures will also improve transparency and planning at local level. In addition, stronger efficiency measures will also facilitate the integration of low temperature RES-H, like solar thermal.  To achieve a higher share of RES-heat sources is crucial to have solar-friendly building regulations, including an obligation for solar thermal collectors for heat generation and PV for power consumed in the building. Building renovation strategies and new codes shall promote, besides EE, the use of available space for solar thermal energy. This can be facilitated with regard to façades or rooftops, meaning that buildings must be designed to have suitable space for solar heat collector and sufficient indoor space for the technical equipment. For instance, chimney outlets and other elements should be on the perimeter of the north side of the roof. The integration of solar thermal solutions shall also be an important element of the New European Bauhaus.  In this context, art.7 must be revised to prevent the support to fossil-fuel based systems only, rather promoting the use of RES-heat or hybrid solutions, to ensure a gradual change towards a 100% renewable future.  Finally, despite the EED, Energy Labelling Directive (ELD) and EPBD being separate regulations, they should become more interconnected. As in the EED, the ELD is applying the energy savings concept (even though on product label), whilst the EPBD is looking into the same principles at system and buildings levels. The lack of a strong connection among these directives is a limitation and a gap that must be bridged to reinforce their connections. In particular, the EED can be an enabler for exploring further synergies between ELD and EPBD. Feedback from: Solar Heat Europe (190.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
