feedback_msg_text: Support for Option 3: Amend the EPBD  DENEFF – The German Business Initiative for Energy Efficiency – is the voice of Germany’s energy efficiency industry, which accounts for about 600,000 employees. Doubling the renovation rate of buildings is key for Europe to reach its higher climate targets, to kickstart a green recovery from the current economic crisis and to provide modern, healthy and comfortable places to live and work for all Europeans.   We therefore strongly endorse the Renovation Wave agenda and welcome the EPBD revision. The EPBD must be the core contributor to achieving the Renovation Wave’s aims, complemented by a strengthened EED and RED. While a new ETS for buildings could be an interesting addition to the policy mix, it is highly unlikely that it would make a significant contribution to increasing renovation rates or depths, especially for 2030. Most of the renovation demand increase will have to be triggered by regulation, financial incentives, and advisory services.   We particularly suggest focusing on the following elements of the EPBD which promise to have the highest impact on renovation activity and climate protection:  1. Minimum energy performance standards:  We unequivocally support the plan to introduce binding minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for the worst-performing existing buildings with the highest running costs and energy savings potential. A European MEPS framework should give enough flexibility to Member States to adapt to local conditions but must be robust enough to ensure a significant increase in renovation activity even if a Member State decides to implement only what is strictly required by the Directive. Rising levels of ambition over a longer period can enhance the signalling effect of MEPS and prevent lock-in effects produced by shallow measures. They also provide the predictability and clear framework needed to scale up solutions. It must be ensured that Member States can embed their MEPS in adequate financial and technical support programmes to enable (over-)compliance and safeguard social fairness, augmented by favourable State Aid rules and European assistance.   2. Energy performance certificates and data availability:  A revision of the energy performance certificates (EPCs) should upgrade their quality and comparability across Europe, allowing them to be widely used as tools to determine building performance for MEPS classification. National EPC databases must be required to be far more accessible to enable transparent monitoring, benchmarking, and analysis. Beyond the EPCs, up-to-date energy performance data of all publicly owned buildings should be transparently published on a central web portal in each member state for the same purposes.   3. Prioritising energy-efficient renovations:  In keeping with the “energy efficiency first” principle, we clearly recommend that the EPBD keeps its focus on significantly reducing the amount of operational energy required by Europe’s buildings as a prerequisite for successful decarbonization. Doubling the rate of energy-efficient renovations is the core idea of the Renovation Wave. The opening of any existing or the addition of new articles in the EPBD should be measured against their contribution to this goal to avoid losing focus or risking new loopholes under the guise of decarbonization.  This revision of the EPBD has the potential to give building renovation in Europe the boost it needs to excel as an engine of climate protection, resilience, and green, long-term jobs. We urge the European Commission to propose changes that are truly “fit for 55” and to guard against weakening any of the existing energy efficiency provisions in the EPBD. feedback_msg_text: Dear Sir/Madam,  to be in line with the Paris Agreement’s goal, the EU should reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 65% by 2030. This requires higher binding energy targets (at least 45% for energy efficiency and 50% for renewable energy) and to at least triple the current annual rate of energy renovations, increasing significantly their depth and moving towards a fully renewables-based energy supply. Hence, CAN Europe supports a broader revision of the EPBD, going beyond the limited scope of Option 3 and aiming at the full transformation of the building sector.  Still based on the outdated 2050 goal of reducing emissions by 80-95%, the EPBD’s current provision on the Long-Term Renovation Strategies needs to be strengthened and aligned with the climate neutrality objective. Setting future-proof strategies while addressing the shortcomings of the current plans is a prerequisite to ensure that the building sector contributes to the bloc’s decarbonisation efforts. Reducing buildings’ energy demand is a priority and a low-hanging fruit to achieve the climate targets. To this end, mandatory minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) are key to phase-out the worst performing buildings, bringing them to high performance levels, while tackling one of the root causes of energy poverty. MEPS should sit in a target-based framework that defines and prioritises deep renovations. They should aim at covering the whole stock, including the residential sector, through a progressive implementation that factors in the needs of the different segments and provides adequate funding and financial support. This also requires the revision of the cost-optimality approach in order to take into account the multiple environmental, economic and social benefits linked to energy efficiency.   To ensure consistent monitoring and comparability of results, Energy Performance Certificates should be better harmonised and accessible. The information displayed should always include the share of energy from renewable sources, coupled with recommendations on the measures needed to achieve deep renovation (e.g. Building Renovation Passports). Increasing rate and depth of renovations, in line with the energy efficiency first principle, should be complemented by the shift towards 100% RES supply, in coherence with the REDII revision.   New buildings’ requirements should be further developed in a way, that new buildings produce over a year more energy than they consume. Such „Plus-energy-buildings“ can become our power plants. Further, we need to prevent future lock-ins by banning new fossil installations, while progressively phase-out inefficient and fossil-fuel based heating systems from existing buildings. These should be replaced by alternative RES, such as renewable electricity that powers electric heat pumps and solar thermal heat. Buildings can also be connected to renewable district heating networks.   Strengthened regulatory measures must be embedded in an enabling framework that addresses also the non-regulatory barriers to energy renovation and the possible distributional impacts, aiming at reducing upfront costs, raising public awareness, fostering the upskilling of the construction sector and providing public support to the most vulnerable households. Provisions on advisory tools such as one-stop-shops should be strengthened to encourage their roll-out at national and local level, while public authorities should be supported through technical assistance in building capacity to scale up projects and develop integrated renovation programmes, coupling energy efficiency and RES deployment.   yours Johannes Wahlmüller Feedback from: GLOBAL 2000 - Friends of the Earth Austria (100.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

Doubling the renovation rate of buildings is key for Europe to reach its higher climate targets, to kickstart a green recovery from the current economic crisis and to provide modern, healthy and comfortable places to live and work for all Europeans. The EPBD must be the core contributor to achieving the Renovation Wave’s aims, complemented by a strengthened EED and RED. We particularly suggest focusing on the following elements of the EPBD which promise to have the highest impact on renovation activity and climate protection:  1. Minimum energy performance standards: We unequivocally support the plan to introduce binding minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for the worst-performing existing buildings with the highest running costs and energy savings potential. A European MEPS framework should give enough flexibility to Member States to adapt to local conditions but must be robust enough to ensure a significant increase in renovation activity even if a Member State decides to implement only what is strictly required by the Directive. It must be ensured that Member States can embed their MEPS in financial and technical support programmes to enable compliance and safeguard social fairness, augmented by favourable State Aid rules and European assistance.  2. Energy Performance Certificates and Data Availability: A revision of the energy performance certificates (EPCs) should upgrade their quality across Europe, allowing them to be widely used as tools to determine building performance for MEPS classification. feedback_msg_text: As buildings are expected to play a critical role in the decarbonisation efforts, it is important not only to ensure that EPBD is fully consistent with the entire legislative framework which is going to be addressed by the “Fit for 55 Package”, notably the EED, RED, ETD, ESR and a possibly extended EU ETS.   Annex I rightly refers to primary energy as the main performance indicator, based on primary energy factors to be set at national, regional or local level. Moreover, it allows to consider in the relevant calculations renewable energy supplied through the energy carrier as well as generated on-site, provided it applies on a non-discriminatory basis. Should minimum levels of RES be introduced for the building sector, or for some categories of buildings, it is essential to fully apply this principle and ensure a non-discriminatory treatment between on-site and nearby RES.   The decarbonisation of buildings should indeed be inscribed in broader decarbonisation plans addressing entire neighbourhoods and districts, necessarily linking renovations with decarbonisation actions that are part of local energy planning, in particular when it comes to heating and cooling. In this context, the availability and feasibility of solutions such waste heat recovery should be fully considered as one of the viable options to support buildings’ and districts’ decarbonisation.

feedback_msg_text: Verpflichtende Mindeststandards für Gebäude Ein verpflichtender Mindeststandard für Bestandsgebäude sollte nur für die ineffizientesten Gebäude als Energiebedarf je m² und alternativ als CO2¬Emission je m² definiert werden. Die Sanierung von Gebäuden oberhalb des Mindeststandards sollte durch Förderungen angereizt und nicht verordnet werden. Grund hierfür ist der abnehmende Grenznutzen energetischer Maßnahmen, sodass weitere Effizienzgewinne höheren Kapitalaufwand benötigen. Dies würde zur Verschärfung sozialer Konflikte durch Belastungen für Mieter führen. Wir schlagen ein Ziel zum Ende des jetzigen Jahrzehnts vor. Bis zum 31.12.2029 sollten alle vermieteten Wohngebäude einen Endenergieverbrauch von weniger als 200 kwh/m² (EPC G und H) vorweisen. Ein Mindestwert der CO2-Emission sollte als alternativer Standard definiert werden. Damit würden Investitionen in eine klimaneutrale Wärmeversorgung angereizt und Technologieoffenheit garantiert werden. Die Definition von „deep renovation“ sollte sich an Endenergie- bzw. CO2-Einsparungen orientieren. Eine Sanierungsmaßnahme wäre als „deep renovation“ zu bezeichnen, wenn durch sie mindestens 45 % der CO2-Emissonen kg pro m² eingespart werden würde. Die Zieldefinition als Emissionsreduktion ist wichtig, damit der Wohnungssektor Technologie-offen agieren kann.  Zusätzliche Restriktionen beim Neubau sollten eher auf niedrige Standards der CO2-Emissionen pro m² abzielen, als auf strenge Werte des Energiebedarfs. Damit würde ein Anreiz gesetzt zur stärkeren Einbindung von Erneuerbaren Energien bei der Wärmeversorgung.  Es besteht ein Zielkonflikt zwischen der Bezahlbarkeit von Wohnraum und der energetischen Sanierung. Es bedarf umfangreicher öffentlicher Hilfen, damit Mieter durch die Lasten energetischer Modernisierungen nicht überfordert werden. Gleichzeitig muss die Wirtschaftlichkeit von Sanierungen sichergestellt werden. Im diesem Sinne sollte die Europäische Kommission ihre Mitgliedsstaaten dazu auffordern, Programme zur Finanzierbarkeit energetischer Modernisierungen und Unterstützung von Mietern aufzubauen und zu stärken. Ein großer Schritt hierzu wäre, alle Maßnahmen im Zusammenhang mit der energetischen Sanierung von beihilferechtlichen Beschränkungen zu befreien. Damit würden über eine höhere Förderung auch Mieter entlastet werden.  Der Energieausweis ist ein wichtiges Instrument um Eigentümern und Vermietern den Energiebedarf eines Gebäudes transparent darzustellen. Im Sinne der Vergleichbarkeit wäre eine europäische Harmonisierung nützlich. Es darf hierbei nicht zu einer Absenkung der Standards kommen.  Zukünftig sollte auch bei Bestandsgebäuden nach Modernisierung eine Angabe zur erneuerbaren Wärmeerzeugung EU-weit einheitlich verpflichtend beinhaltet sein (Art und Anteil).  Weiterhin sollten Energieausweise die CO2-Emission an prominenterer Stelle ausweisen, wünschenswert wäre ein Vergleich mit potentiellen künftigen Anforderungswerten und einem nationalen Durchschnitt.  Der Energieausweis kann zu einem praktischen Dokument zur Nachverfolgung energetischer Modernisierungen weiterentwickelt werden („Renovierungspass“). Hierbei würden der Ausweis Informationen beinhalten zum gebäudetechnischen Zustand und zu vergangenen Modernisierungen. Die Verpflichtung zur Dokumentierung der Sanierungen sollte erst für Maßnahmen nach Einführung des Renovierungspass gelten.  Die grauen Emissionen bei Bau, Betrieb und Abbruch eines Gebäudes müssen multisektoral adressiert werden. Eine konsequente Dekarbonisierung der Zulieferindustrien (bspw. Zementproduktion) des Immobiliensektors sowie die Förderung nachhaltiger Baustoffe kann hierzu einen wichtigen Beitrag leisten. Das Bemühen um Vermeidung von grauen Emissionen darf jedoch nicht gegen langfristig sinnvolle Maßnahmen ausgespielt werden. Jede Neuregelung muss sorgsam abwägen, zwischen der Vermeidung grauer Emissionen und dem Bedarf von energetischer Modernisierung und hocheffizienten Neubau.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Le Groupement du Mur Manteau est une organisation professionnelle regroupant des industriels développant des systèmes d’isolation thermique par l’extérieur des bâtiments (ITE) désireux d’accompagner la transition écologique et de contribuer à une baisse drastique des émissions de gaz à effet du secteur. À cette fin, les ambitions portées par la Stratégie pour une vague de rénovations nous semble cohérentes avec l’urgence de la lutte contre le réchauffement climatique.   Considérant que les bâtiments de l’UE sont responsables de 36% des émissions de gaz à effet de serre, le Mur Manteau soutient une révision complète de la directive EPBD (Option 3) afin d'assurer qu'elle soit en mesure de contribuer aux objectifs du Pacte vert européen et puisse assurer l’atteinte de la neutralité carbone à l’horizon 2050.   Cependant plusieurs États membres n’ont achevé que récemment la transposition de la dernière révision de la directive datant de 2018. Afin d’éviter des changements législatifs trop récurrents qui pourraient inhiber la demande plutôt que de la stimuler, il convient d’assurer que la révision prévue pour cette année soit suffisamment ambitieuse. Celle-ci doit mettre en place des mesures plus contraignantes qui aideront les États membres à rénover l’ensemble de leur parc.   Le Groupement du Mur Manteau propose que la révision s’appuie sur les stratégies de rénovation à long terme des États membres et les plans de relance européens et nationaux pour donner une impulsion nouvelle à la rénovation énergétique.   Afin de répondre aux exigences présentées ci-dessus, la directive révisée doit notamment : • Mettre en place des normes minimales obligatoires de performance énergétique pour différents types de bâtiments (privé, public, résidentiel et non résidentiel) pour les rénovations comme les constructions neuves ;  • Garantir un séquençage des travaux en avec une priorité accordée à l’enveloppe globale et homogène des bâtiments avant l’installation de systèmes ;  • Introduire une définition de rénovation performante pour inciter au traitement des 6 postes de travaux suivants : isolation des murs, des planchers bas et de la toiture, remplacement des menuiseries extérieures, ventilation et production de chauffage/eau chaude sanitaire, ainsi que les interfaces et les interactions entre ces postes (bon dimensionnement des systèmes) ;  • Instaurer une obligation de diagnostic énergétique mené par des organismes indépendants afin de mesurer la qualité des travaux de performance énergétique ;  • Préparer une uniformisation des certificats de performance énergétique au niveau européen.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: European Association for Wastewater Heat Recovery representing inventors, manufacturers and distributors of wastewater heat recovery solutions is committed to support the decarbonisation of the building sector and supports amendment of the EPBD to translate the actions proposed in the Renovation Wave and the increased ambition towards building decarbonisation into legislation and wishes to bring the following elements to the attention of the European Commission:  Over recent years, the energy needed to produce hot water has become an ever-larger share of total household energy use at home due to the dramatic fall in energy required for domestic space heating. Every day, more than 22,000,000 m3 of hot water are consumed by European homes alone. It is the main source of energy consumption for new housing, and yet 80 percent of this heat ends up in sewers and is wasted. A wastewater heat recovery (WWHR) system can effectively recapture and reuse instantly up to 70 percent of the energy lost into the drain, reducing energy consumption in a cost-effective manner. It is a simple system, with no moving parts, no storage, no control system and requires no electricity to operate. A specifically engineered heat exchanger transfers heat energy from the waste hot shower water to the incoming fresh water supply, warming it from around 10 up to 30°C. When the cold water arrives at the mixing valve, it is much warmer, and therefore substantially less hot water is required from the water heater or solar array.   WWHR systems can be used in single-and multi-family homes, and non-residential premises with higher hot water consumption: sports facilities, hairdressers, hotels and swimming pools. Due to ease of installation, they can be applied in renovations as well. The benefits of WWHR in buildings are not yet adequately acknowledged in EU legislation, despite re-use of produced energy having a high potential in decarbonisation of sanitary hot water preparation. However, WWHR can contribute to the minimum requirements for renewable energy for all new or renovated buildings. National energy code for new buildings in France, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands have recognized WWHR for many years now, but the EBPD still falls short.   We support introduction of Building Renovation Passport (BRP) as a key element to overcome operational, financial, as well as social barriers of renovation, to support building owners with personalised advice, and to ensure coordination of works during staged renovations. Contribution of WWHR systems to decarbonisation of buildings should be part of improvement recommendations in BRPs. Contributing to resource efficiency and circularity objectives of the construction sector, WWHR systems have a long lifespan, require low maintenance and contain easy to recycle and highly recycled materials (copper, stainless steel).  Now is more than time to acknowledge this mature, European-lead technology to cut energy demand in buildings. Feedback from: European association for wastewater heat recover (1.4 MB - PDF - 25 pages) Download
Organisation: European association for wastewater heat recover
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: There are currently a huge number of buildings in the EU that use more energy and emit more CO2 than any other sector of the EU economy. Without addressing the EU’s biggest CO2 emitters, buildings, the 2030 climate goal will be unachievable. Today only 1% of existing buildings undergo energy efficient renovation every year.   Stronger energy regulations and increased renovation rate will; • Improve indoor climate • Improve thermal comfort (both summer and winter) • Reduce CO2 emissions • Reduce energy consumption and energy cost in buildings • Release energy to electrification of the society • Create new jobs within building sector  Without an increased renovation rate and stronger energy regulations for buildings, climate goals will never be achieved. Our recommendation is to go through with the revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, and make sure that all EU and EEA countries implement the Directive.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Una vez evaluado el documento Evaluación inicial de impacto (Ref. ARES(2021) 1397833), Andimat(Asociación  Asociación Nacional de Fabricantes de Materiales Aislantes) considera necesario adelantar la revisión de la EPBD para el presente año 2021 y apoya la Opción 3 Amend the EPBD to translate the actions proposed in the Renovation Wave and the increased ambition towards building decarbonisation into legislation. Los motivos expuestos en el documento de la Evaluación inicial de impacto justifican el aumento de exigencias relativas a la eficiencia energética en los edificios. Además, debe tenerse en consideración lo siguiente:   • El Plan del Objetivo Climático  para 2030 reconoce que para alcanzar el 55% de reducción de emisiones para 2030 respecto a 1990 los edificios y la generación de electricidad pueden realizar las reducciones de emisiones más amplias y rentables, equivalentes a un 60% como mínimo, en comparación con 2015. Así pues acelerar la transición energética en los edificios se muestra como una de las maneras más efectivas de alcanzar el objetivo del 55%, para lo que es necesario aumentar las exigencias a la edificación lo antes posible. • Para notar el efecto de las políticas en el horizonte 2030 se debe adelantar el proceso legislativo lo máximo posible, sobre todo teniendo en cuenta que el proceso de trasposición de la EPBD a los códigos de los EEMM puede ser largo. • La revisión de la EPBD puede otorgar a la sociedad civil y partes interesadas la capacidad de exigir a los gobiernos nacionales un mayor grado de ambición y de determinación en sus políticas nacionales.   Adicionalmente a  los temas considerados en la Evaluación inicial de impacto, se propone lo siguiente:  1. Establecer la obligación de Estándares Mínimos de Eficiencia Energética en la transmisión de inmuebles, según la tipología, año, uso… siguiendo el criterio de Energy Efficiency First de la UE.  2. Establecer una definición homogénea y/o metodología para la definición de Edificio de Energía Casi Nula, para la rehabilitación profunda y para rehabilitación parcial (o diferentes niveles de rehabilitación parcial). 3. Incentivar la monitorización y verificación de los valores reales de consumos y emisiones de los edificios, que permitan analizar el comportamiento real de los mismos. 4. En relación con lo anterior, deber reforzarse un control externo que garantice al usuario que se han implementado correctamente las medidas de eficiencia energética. 5. Establecer una hoja de ruta para la implementación obligatoria del Pasaporte del Edificio en los EEMM, cuyo primer paso deberá ser la obligación a los EEMM de desarrollar Libros del Edificio Digitales (Digital Logbook). 6. Incorporar el concepto de ciclo de vida completo de los edificios en esta directiva, y plantear estudios sobre energía embebida, carbono embebido, durabilidad y coste y valor que permitan establecer las bases para la futura legislación, como la Hoja de Ruta para la Descarbonización en 2023. El ciclo de vida de los edificios debe estar en línea con los planteamientos de economía circular en la edificación, que deben ser incorporados.  7. Incorporar la escala urbana, cuya legislación responde a las necesidades de desarrollo de la segunda mitad del SºXX y que ahora mismo supone una barrera para la regeneración y renovación urbana. Además el comportamiento energético de los edificios y su adaptación al cambio climático depende sobremanera de su contexto urbano.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Doubling the renovation rate of buildings is key for Europe to reach its higher climate targets, to kickstart a green recovery from the current economic crisis and to provide modern, healthy and comfortable places to live and work for all Europeans. We therefore strongly endorse the Renovation Wave agenda and welcome the EPBD revision.   The EPBD must be the core contributor to achieving the Renovation Wave’s aims, complemented by a strengthened EED and RED. We particularly suggest focusing on the following elements of the EPBD which promise to have the highest impact on renovation activity and climate protection:  1. Minimum energy performance standards:  We unequivocally support the plan to introduce binding minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for the worst-performing existing buildings with the highest running costs and energy savings potential. A European MEPS framework should give enough flexibility to Member States to adapt to local conditions but must be robust enough to ensure a significant increase in renovation activity even if a Member State decides to implement only what is strictly required by the Directive. It must be ensured that Member States can embed their MEPS in financial and technical support programmes to enable compliance and safeguard social fairness, augmented by favourable State Aid rules and European assistance.  2. Energy Performance Certificates and Data Availability:  A revision of the energy performance certificates (EPCs) should upgrade their quality across Europe, allowing them to be widely used as tools to determine building performance for MEPS classification. National EPC databases must be required to be far more accessible to enable transparent monitoring, benchmarking, and analysis. Beyond the EPCs, up-to-date energy and carbon performance data of all publicly owned buildings should be transparently published on a central web portal in each member state for the same purposes.   3. Prioritising Renovation:  The embodied energy, carbon and other resources contained in already existing buildings should not needlessly be discarded. That is why the EPBD should establish a binding requirement for public authorities to conduct building lifecycle assessments when considering whether to renovate the buildings they own or to demolish them in favour of new construction.   This revision of the EPBD has the potential to give building renovation in Europe the boost it needs to turn into an engine of climate protection and green, long-term jobs. We urge the European Commission to propose changes that are truly “fit for 55” and to guard against weakening any of the existing provisions in the EPBD.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: EDA Attikis S.A, the natural gas DSO operator in the region of Attica (Greece) welcomes the Commission’s initiative to enhance the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive  In this perspective we suggest a “Natural gas heating system/Appliance Recycling Program”. A “Natural gas heating system/Appliance Recycling Program” designed to save energy and reduce the environmental impacts by removing operable, albeit less efficient, old gas furnaces from service.  By providing incentives and disseminating information about the operating cost of less efficient gas furnaces, the program can be designed to encourage consumers to Prevent the continued use of less efficient appliances and replace them with new Condensing gas furnaces that achieve high efficiency levels, so that customers do not have to pay for more efficiency than they need.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: GBCe believes that this revision is necessary and stands for the Option 3 Amend the EPBD to translate the actions proposed in the Renovation Wave. Also: • The 2030 Climate target plan acknowledges that in other to achieve a 55% reduction of GHG buildings and power generation can make the largest and most cost-efficient emissions reductions, in the order of 60% and more compared to 2015. Accelerating the renovation rate is crucial to achieve the 2030 Climate target, thus an increase of requirements is urgently needed.  • The transposition of the EPBD to the Member States can take time. Speeding up the legislative process is needed if their impacts must be felt by 2030. • A strengthened EPBD can help civil society and interested parties to demand their Member States a higher level of ambition and action in their national policies. In addition to the proposals in the Inception Impact Assessment, GBCe proposes:  1. Including the whole lifecycle of buildings in terms of embedded carbon, energy, lifespan and value-cost. This can set the ground for future legislation like the Roadmap for Decarbonizing in 2023. The lifecycle must be aligned with the circular economy framework. 2. Including the urban level as a key point in the renovation process and energy performance of buildings. The legal framework for urban planning was conceived for expanding during the post-war era, thus a whole new legal framework for renovation is needed. Also, urban context determines the local climate of the buildings, impacting on their energy performance and climate change adaptation.  3. Setting MEPS for selling or renting of buildings, defining a calendar depending on typology, use… 4. Setting a common standard and methodology for the requirements of NZEB, deep renovation and partial renovation  5. Setting a common assess framework for the social aspects of buildings (liveability, right to housing, just transition, reduction of inequality…) that can be integrated in existing frameworks like the European Taxonomy, Level(s) or the New European Bauhaus. This is a key proposal to enhance economic return from renovation in the southern countries where energy savings are not enough to trigger renovation.  6. Setting a roadmap for the compulsory implementation of the Building Renovation Passport by the Member States. The first step should be the implementation as soon as possible of the Digital Logbooks. 7. Setting a roadmap for the voluntary implementation of the Smart Readiness Indicator for Buildings and the digitalization of buildings towards their integration in the electric system.  8. Including a communication plan for citizens in the LTRS activating the latent demand for renovation. 9. Allocating a percentage of the Energy Efficiency Obligation Scheme (Art. 7 Directive 2012/27/EU) for setting a Guarantee Fund for contingencies during the renovation works, avoiding their interruption. The cost could be returned after the work by the responsible of the contingency.  10. Setting a methodology to give value to the reduction of energy demand through concepts as the ‘negawatt’, giving emergence to a new market of energy efficiency and integrating in the existing energy market. To drive the market towards sustainability negawatts would get a higher value -double- than renewable-generated megawatts and much higher -ten times- than fossil-generated megawatts. 11. Fostering monitoring and verification (M&V) of the real values of consumption and emissions to assess the real performance of buildings. This can help to design future policies and requirements for the EPBD and national building codes. 12. Developing a report on ventilation in buildings that considers the indoor air quality and the energy efficiency. This report must do special focus on the local particularities such as climate and cultural issues (ventilation and maintenance behaviour) 13. Developing a report on the inclusion of the building sector in the EU Emissions Trading System
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: The Right to Energy Coalition unites a diverse range of stakeholders to tackle energy poverty across Europe. We fully support the revision of this directive, as outlined in option 3, to deliver on the Renovation Wave and drastically reduce Europe’s carbon emissions. Renovations can provide extensive co-benefits for tackling climate change, alleviating energy poverty and creating green, local jobs if enabled by a strong financial and legislative framework.   This revision comes at a pivotal time. As over 50 million Europeans live in unhealthy, leaky homes: inadequate housing is linked to 100,000 premature deaths a year  across the EU (WHO, 2019) and a public health burden of over €140 billion (Eurofound, 2019).  To this end, we welcome the proposed introduction of mandatory minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) as a key measure to prioritise worst performing buildings, particularly in the residential sector. If properly implemented, these have great potential for increased health, welfare and safe, decent housing. MEPS can drive deep renovation and should be introduced with financing schemes, updated provisions for Energy Performance Certification and a deep renovation standard to maximise impact. We can also consider circularity principles to reduce lifecycle emissions & resource extraction.  However our support of MEPS is under the provision that adequate safeguard measures are introduced to address any unjust distributional impacts. This legislation risks negatively affecting low-income households through rent increases and gentrification. These risks are evermore concerning with the potential extension of ETS to buildings. We call for comprehensive social measures and funding to be put in place to ensure affordability of housing; including an EU fund for low-income energy efficiency, rent caps and measures to address split incentives.   This roadmap would also benefit from a more explicit commitment to prioritise low-income households in alignment with the Renovation Wave. Although renovations are crucial for tackling energy poverty; it is not a given that these groups will benefit. Hence legislation is required from the Commission to guide member states to target renovations for: 1) social housing residents 2) low-income tenants and 3) low-income homeowners.  As noted, renovations require significant upfront investment which is a particular barrier for low-income households. Sufficient funding and financial support is crucial to ensure we see these benefits materialise. The introduction of an EU fund specifically for low-income energy efficiency measures would provide significant support to member states.  This is also an opportunity to forge clearer synergies with the RED to streamline renovations and renewable installations through a citizen-led, neighbourhood approach. Tailored One Stop Shops could combine renewable installations and renovations to provide holistic technical assistance. This service should be inclusive and actively reach out to vulnerable groups facing exclusion; enabling renovations and renewables to be accessible for energy poor households.  To conclude, we encourage the Commission to:  Prioritise energy poor tenants, low-income homeowners & social housing as primary target recipients for renovations  Include binding MEPS with comprehensive safeguards for the residential sector Provide an EU fund for low-income renovations Encourage tailored, accessible one stop shops and a ‘citizen-led’ renovation approach  Strengthen synergies between renewables and renovation programmes for energy poor households  Leaky roofs, unhealthy homes and wasted energy can and must be a thing of the past.  Renovations have the potential to change the lives of millions of Europeans but this is not a given; hence energy poor households must be adequately considered in the EBPD. We welcome a revised directive that sets ambitious measures and a strong financial framework for a healthier, more equitable, renovated Europe.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: EXPOSICIÓN DE MOTIVOS 1. La solución óptima coste-eficiente para convertir el parque edificado en EECN de acuerdo con las exigencias de la EPBD ya en 2012, revisada posteriormente 2018, es el uso de aislamiento en todos los edificios nuevos y existentes. 2. En el ámbito de  la UE, en 2050, entre el 75-90% de los edificios seguirán en uso y  solo serán rehabilitados, como máximo, una vez más antes de 2050. Por ello debemos aprovechar esa oportunidad ahora o la perdemos, pero ¿lo hemos de hacer de cualquier manera? Debemos pensar mucho en cómo y su impacto no sólo en las emisiones. 3. Cualquier reglamentación debe contemplar entre sus objetivos generales -independientemente de aquellos específicos para los que se crea-  proteger  bienes y personas. Para ello debe poner especial vigilancia en mantener el máximo nivel de seguridad viable frente al fuego, de forma que esté adaptado al nivel de riesgo existente, especialmente en el caso de edificios a rehabilitar. 4. Actualmente, los incendios se están desarrollando de 5 a 10 veces más rápido que en los 50-60’s. La seguridad de los ocupantes de edificios -sin olvidar a los bomberos- debe estar en el foco, y debe afrontarse y controlarse en su conjunto con medidas que pueden ser de control de propagación de incendios por el exterior, compartimentación, detección y extinción, así como otras posibles tecnologías que estén contrastadas. En junio 2018 -con la publicación de la revisión de la EPBD 844/2018- ya se recorrió cierto camino en el aspecto de poner mayor foco en la seguridad en los edificios: 2.7. Los Estados miembros podrán utilizar sus estrategias de renovación a largo plazo para hacer frente a la seguridad contra incendios y a los riesgos relacionados con actividades sísmicas intensas o incendios que afecten a las renovaciones a efectos de eficiencia energética y a la vida útil de los edificios. Art. 7.5. Los Estados miembros fomentarán, en relación con los edificios sujetos a reformas importantes, instalaciones alternativas de alta eficiencia, siempre que ello sea técnica, funcional y económicamente viable y tendrán en cuenta los temas de unas condiciones climáticas interiores saludables, la seguridad contra incendios y los riesgos relacionados con una intensa actividad sísmica. REQUERIMIENTO Los dos artículos transcritos fueron una novedad  en una Directiva focalizada en reducir consumos, fomentar renovables y por tanto, disminuir las emisiones de GEI (Gases de Efecto Invernadero), permitieron albergar esperanzas sobre la adaptación del código técnico nacional y sus exigencias a la realidad actual, con un foco en la seguridad. Pero a fecha de hoy es una línea de trabajo que necesita ser profundizada. Países como España -por lo que respecta al fuego- han optado por una revisión poco ambiciosa y con criterios que no reflejan el riesgo derivado de la tipología y uso de los edificios. No es motivo de esta solicitud pedir a la Comisión Europea que la Directiva sobre Prestaciones Energéticas de los Edificios regule  el comportamiento ante el fuego de estos, pero, dada la existencia de los riesgos y experiencias conocidos por todos, debería enviar las señales oportunas a los Estados miembros para que la seguridad esté en el top a la hora de definirse políticas y reglamentaciones. Por ello, para la inminente revisión de la Directiva,  ésta deberá contemplar : - mantener como principio rector de cualquier acción sobre los edificios la #EnergyEfficiencyFirst; - añadir que en edificios existentes las prestaciones de seguridad pasiva contraincendios sean controladas para mantener u obtener el máximo nivel de seguridad viable frente al fuego de forma que esté adaptado al nivel de riesgo existente  - sustituir “las recomendaciones” a los Estados miembros por “exigencias” sobre la adopción de unos mínimos de seguridad homogéneos en toda la EU;  - que estos mínimos de seguridad deben estar basados en un adecuada benchmarking y tomar de referencia a los paises mas exigentes
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Die Interessengemeinschaft Bauernhaus e. V. (IgB) begrüßt es sehr, dass die Bestandserhaltung mit dem Papier zur Renovierungswelle erstmals so deutlich als entscheidender Faktor zum Klimaschutz formuliert wird. Wir finden es aber besorgniserre­gend, dass ein ausdrücklicher Schutz des baukulturellen Erbes nicht thematisiert ist. Die IgB befürch­tet negative Auswirkungen auf das Erscheinungsbild von Baudenkmalen. Und insbesondere die nicht unter Denkmalschutz gestellte Bausubstanz, die aufgrund ihres historischen, ortsbildprägenden und/oder regionaltypischen Charakters außerordentlich wertvoll ist, sehen wir gefährdet. Gerade sie dürfte durch die geplanten Regelungen stark beeinträchtigt werden. Wenn denkmalfachlichen und bauhistorischen Aspekten keine wesentliche Bedeutung eingeräumt wird, ist ein Verlust jahrhundertealter, individueller Ortsbilder zu befürchten. Zu einer zukunftsfähigen Ortsentwicklung gehört unbedingt auch die Bewahrung der spezifischen Eigenarten des Baubestands.  Viele historische Gebäude sind Jahrhunderte alt. Mit ihrer lange andauernden Existenz und den meist lokal gewonnenen, natürlichen Baustofen und Materialien sind sie per se klimafreundlich und sollten in Bezug auf die Energieefzienz eine Neubewertung erfahren. Altbauten müssen ganzheitlich betrachtet werden – auch durch die Berücksichtigung ihrer Ge­samtenergiebilanz, also nicht mehr nur des reinen Energieverbrauchs in der Nutzungs­phase. Historische Gebäude und ihr baulicher Charakter könnten wichtige Erkenntnisse für klimaangepasste und nachhaltige Bauweisen bringen. Sie sollten dazu genutzt werden, um ökologisch und bauphysikalisch verträgliche Energiesparmaßnahmen für Bestandsgebäude zu entwickeln. Feedback from: Interessengemeinschaft Bauernhaus e. V. (513.7 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: The improvement of energy performance of buildings is of major importance. With 40% of total energy consumption stemming from the buildings, this is without a doubt one of the key goals.  However, so far, the EU addresses building efficiency only in relation to the building size, but not in relation to the occupants. The regulation has no reference to the occupants even though it is the well-being and comfort of the occupants that is the goal.  New technologies will bring comfort heating to persons in different ways than heating the entire building. In the literature these systems are also referred to as [Personal Comfort Systems, PCS, Zhang et al. 2015, Rawal et al. 2020].  To give an example of one technology, with the new highly efficient LED technology it is possible to focus infrared heating precisely at people within the building. Not only is it possible to direct heating at individuals, but it is also possible to direct heating to the specific body parts where we need the heating the most.  Especially hands are one of the first body parts to become cold, and they drive whole-body discomfort [Arens et al., 2006, Zhang et al. 2010]. In an office space, it is the comfort of our hands that largely trigger the need for a higher room temperature. Directed heating at the hands with a dedicated hand heater is an extremely energy efficient means to keep hands comfortable. With the hands warm and comfortable, we do not need to adjust the room temperature to the specific needs of our hands, instead we can reduce the room temperature and thus save a lot of energy from heating the entire building. See also attached file for impressions from users.  Indeed, personal comfort systems can be used for full body heating and it will then be possible to reduce room temperature further. If we could reduce indoor temperature setpoint for heating by 4 °C, the energy needed to heat buildings would be reduced with a whopping 40 % - and all other initiatives will still be effective too [Hoyt et al. 2015].  We need to make sure, that all possible technologies and instruments to bring down energy consumption are promoted through the regulation. The regulation should be amended with a new section whereby building performance per occupant is considered.   References Zhang, H., E. Arens, and Y. Zhai. 2015. A review of the corrective power of personal comfort systems in non-neutral ambient environments. Building and Environment, 91, 15-41.  Rawal, R., Schweiker, M., Kazanci, O. B., Vardhan, V., Jin, Q., & Duanmu, L. (2020). Personal Comfort Systems: A review on comfort, energy, and economics. Energy and Buildings, 214, 109858. Arens, E., H. Zhang, C. Huizenga, 2006, “Partial- and whole body thermal sensation and comfort, Part I:  uniform environmental conditions”.  Journal of Thermal Biology, 31, 53 - 59.  Hoyt, T., E. Arens, and H. Zhang. 2015. Extending air temperature setpoints: Simulated energy savings and design considerations for new and retrofit buildings. Building and Environment 88, 89-96. T. L. Madsen and B. Saxhof, “An unconventional method for reduction of the energy consumption for heating of buildings combined,” in Second International CIB Symposium on Energy Conservation in the Built Environment, Copenhagen, 1979. A. K. Melikov, “Advanced air distribution: Improving health and comfort while reducing energy use,” Indoor Air, vol. 26, Mar. 2015. Feedback from: Anonymous (325.3 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: When making amendments to the policies, the local governments should be stimulated to search for solutions that are long-term and that stimulate the creation of partnerships in the country that could lead to the systematic renovation of buildings. It is preferable that the government supports the renovations with a lower contribution, but defining clear and high standards for the renovations than it provides high financial support, but which is not sustainable through the years. Too high support would just reduce the demand for any more sustainable business model since residents would go for the high support. Once the support is over, nothing has been put in place.  The directive should also emphasize the importance that local governments develop clear and straight-forward processes related to the renovation (for example, related to documentation and financing). The residents need a clear and transparent enough to feel safe to commit to a renovation in these dimensions.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: We recognize the importance of this initiative, which is opportunity for scaling up current renovation rates and bringing benefits for citizens and businesses, from consuming less energy to healthier homes, and saving money. However, the initiative should keep in mind that the principle of technological neutrality when selecting a type of heat source should be preserved. The different conditions, for example various degree of district heating development or natural gas distribution grid coverage, in European countries create different starting positions. The Slovak republic can be characterized by the high coverage of natural gas grid with high percentage of population connected to it and the very developed district heating sector. This lays downs different ways for renewable energy integration. Existing gas grids and gas appliances are 100% compatible with biomethane, and recent tests show that condensing gas boilers can accommodate blends of up to 20% of hydrogen. With coal still representing a third of the EU energy mix for district heating, renewable and decarbonised gases have significant potential to curb emissions in that sector too. In 2017, inefficient boilers still accounted for 56% of the total stock of heating appliances in the EU. Therefore, the lowest hanging fruit in curbing emissions is the replacement of old heating systems with efficient and affordable appliances such as gas condensing boilers and hybrid heat pumps (not to forget the potential of gas solution for fast and efficient conversion from oil). We need to solve problem of air pollution with affordable solutions. Whilst single vector solutions are important, gas appliances can easily be combined with other technologies such as heat pumps or solar PV production. Such hybrid systems will be limiting the need for expensive electricity infrastructure expansion to meet peak demand or address intermittency constraints for the energy system. Hybrid solutions are the perfect example of how sector integration can help decarbonise our energy demand in a cost-efficient way. Feedback from: Anonymous (94.2 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Feedback from AICVF AICVF is the French association for HVAC professionals and is member of the European REHVA association. AICVF is supporting the REHVA position in the revision of the EPBD. Please find hereafter our feedback and proposals for possible solutions on the intended initiative. Our comments focus on three main topics: Building energy performance metric: Proposal: Non-renewable primary energy + minimum safeguards Energy Performance Certificates:       Proposal: ALDREN EPC as backbone of a common voluntary EU certification scheme Strengthen the EU added value:          Proposal:Consider the EU common EPC equivalent to national EPC       Building energy performance metric: non-renewable primary energy + minimum safeguards Decarbonisation of the building sector is a main topic of the EPBD revision. But it could be understood that the main indicator will be the CO2 emission.  CO2 reduction could have negative side effects on expected impacts, as the increase of primary energy use, the decreased use of renewables, and higher energy costs (energy poverty).     It is proposed to clearly state in the revision that the main indicator of energy performance in the EPBD remains the Primary Energy.  Primary energy is classified in total, non-renewable and renewable primary energy (see EN ISO 52000-1). Among the EU policy objectives are the reduction of non-renewable energies and the increase of renewables. The actual EPBD does not precise the type of the primary energy.   It is proposed to specify in the EPBD revision that the main indicator is the non-renewable primary energy.   The EU taxonomy defines additional minimum safeguards to avoid negative impacts of one indicator (e.g. leave energy efficiency potentials untapped). Minimum safeguards in the building energy performance may be related to the (a) building envelope, (b) to the efficiency of technical building systems, (c) to decarbonisation. Examples of minimum safeguards are provided in EN ISO 52000-1 (the “hurdle-race”). It is proposed to add additional minimum safeguards to the main indicator (non-renewable primary energy). These minimum safeguards should be coordinated with the EU taxonomy.    Update of Energy Performance Certificates: ALDREN EPC as backbone of a common voluntary EU certification scheme It is agreed that for the increase of the EPC’s quality, the inclusion of additional information is key. Information on climate resilience, health (Indoor Environment Quality), the reliability (gap between calculated and measured energy), financial valuation, the smart readiness Indicator (SRI), etc should be included in the EPC. All these indicators have been worked out in an EU funded H2020 ALDREN project (https://aldren.eu/) and resumed in the ALDREN EPC. Article 11 (9) EPBD request the Commission to adopt a voluntary common European Union certification scheme. It is proposed to make the list of ALDREN EPC indicators mandatory and to adopt a voluntary EU certification scheme (based on the ALDREN EPC and other H2020 project for residential and non-residential buildings).   Strengthen the EU added value by considering the EU common EPC equivalent to national EPC The EPBD did not reach the expected goals yet. Numerous barriers are responsible for this failure. Among them, insufficient technical expertise in authorities, shortage of a qualified workforce has been mentioned in the inception impact assessment itself. . We see that the fragmentation of the EU due to national transposition of the EPBD, create barriers for the free circulation of services and know-how. There are no harmonised methods, no common professional tools as high-quality software, no common training and certification of professionals, no mutual recognition of skills on a common content. The EU added value is missing It is proposed to allow the voluntary EU certification scheme EPC as an alternative to a national EPC. It could also be used as common metric for the European taxonomy. Feedback from: AICVF (176.3 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: Bonjour,  En premier lieu, il serait intéressant de connaître les différents parc immobiliers européens (par pays) :    - volumes    - types : industriels, institutionnels, logements, historiques (patrimoines)    - "qualité" : état physique et thermique  Ceci permettrait d'avoir une meilleur vision des urgences de rénovations, tant du point de vue des états membres, que des populations concernées.  En effet, compte-tenu des grandes différences de situations économiques des états et des revenus des populations, il pourrait être contre productif d'harmoniser une politique européenne sur l'énergie sans prendre en considération les spécificités de chaque état.  C'est pourquoi, il nous faut également connaître les engagements actuels des états envers des importations énergétiques, ainsi que recenser les coûts des énergies pour les populations vs leur pouvoir d'achat.  Une fois cette enquête effectuée, il sera plus "facile," pour la Commission Européenne, de définir des priorités ; lesquelles ne devraient pas uniquement s'appuyer sur la diminution des consommations énergétiques, mais également prendre en compte :    - les coûts des rénovations vs les typologies des bâtiments (ex. un bâtiment historique doit il (peut-il) être rénové avec les mêmes enjeux de performances énergétiques, qu'un immeuble ou une usine?).    - les coûts énergétiques de ces mêmes rénovations (est-il plus judicieux de rénover certains bâtiments que de les remplacer ?)    - la diversité architecturale  Ce dernier point est important si l'on souhaite que l'Europe, un des berceau de l'histoire moderne, conserve sa richesse patrimoniale et historique, qui attire tant de touristes (et créé de l'emploi).  La règlementation qui découlera des discussions de la Commission Européenne, devra éviter de s'inspirer de ce qui se fait en France, car malgré des règlementations thermiques toujours plus nombreuses et complexes à mettre en œuvre, et des aides financières de l'état, le bilan carbone n'y est pas.  Parmi les pistes qui pourraient expliquer cette contre performance française :    - règlementation hyper contraignante et non comprise par les professionnels    - pas ou peu de contrôles des performances avant et après rénovations    - incitations et primes fiscales qui ne vont pas dans la poche des utilisateur(trice)s des bâtiments    - complexité sans nom pour un particulier, pour rechercher des aides (organismes nombreux, critères avec de multiples seuils d'éligibilité)  Et dernier point, nous nous sommes focaliser que sur la conséquence d'une rénovation énergétique, à savoir la baisse des consommations, sans nous préoccuper des coûts d'investissements que cela suppose.  En conclusion, si je pouvais proposer des idées à la Commission Européenne, ce serait :    - prise en compte de tous les points (pas uniquement la baisse des consommations finales d'énergie)    - instaurer le diagnostique avant/après rénovation par des organismes indépendants (seule manière de connaître la qualité de la rénovation)    - un texte simple et compréhensible pour toutes les filières professionnelles (même si ce dernier venait à déconstruire des règlementations existantes)    - discuter avec des acteurs des professions concernées, de la pertinence et/ou faisabilité de certains points (les décrêter ne veut pas dire qu'ils seront suivis des faits dans la réalité)    - redonner un peu de liberté dans la conception architecturale ; nous sommes en train de construire des villes uniformes en France...  Espérant que mon propos vous sera utile, je reste à votre disposition pour en discuter autant que de besoin.  Cordialement.
Initiative: Energy efficiency – Revision of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive

feedback_msg_text: We think the main problem with the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive has been the neglect of the importance of the water-energy nexus in buildings. However, the problem must be approached differently in relation to other components of housing (climatization, household appliances, etc.), as water consumption in buildings has implications not only for energy consumption in the building (production of sanitary hot water), but also in public networks of water supply and drainage (in pumping, abstraction, treatment, etc.). (Please see chapter 2.2. in the attached file). The creation of an European water and energy efficiency label for sanitary products, which is underway through a Voluntary Agreement with the representative entity in the sector (UWLA), seems to us to be a measure that should receive great support and priority from the Commission, and be referred in the Directive. feedback_msg_text: Enel contribution to the Inception Impact Assessment on the revision of certain procedural aspects of EU merger control  Enel is a multinational Group and one of the main integrated operators in the electricity and gas sectors, with a particular focus in Europe and Latin America. We operate in the generation (RES and conventional) and distribution of electricity and in the trading and supply of gas and electricity. In the European Union, Enel is mainly in Italy, Spain, Portugal, Romania, Greece, Germany, Slovak Republic, Poland and France.  Enel welcomes the further simplification efforts by the European Commission to target and simplify the review in both simplified and non-simplified merger cases.   In order to reduce the administrative burdens and to optimise time, Enel highly supports the initiative of introducing fully digital notifications including digital signatures.   Overall, Enel fully agrees on the introduction of new categories of simplified cases for certain vertical links and on the introduction of a flexibility clause that gives the Commission the discretion to treat certain cases under the simplified procedure as long as this discretion is carefully measured in favor of clear criteria that guarantee legal certainty.   Furthermore, the streamlining of both simplified and non-simplified cases is encouraged if that means simplifying actual notification templates with tick-the-box forms and reducing information requirements and the need for pre-notification contacts on the assessment.   More concretely, to make full reference to the policy options proposed by the Commission, Enel agrees to:  • Option 1 and 2 for “categories of simplified cases” • Option 1 and 3 for “review of simplified cases” • Option 1 and 2 for “review of non-simplified cases” • Option 2 for “electronic notifications”
Initiative: Merger control in the EU – further simplification of procedures

feedback_msg_text: AFG:  1.Implement a binding European gas target based on a clear terminology for all green gases and an adequate guarantee of origins (GO) system  In order to accelerate the production and deployment of green gases in a long term vision, AFG calls for a binding European target. This target should be broad enough to give Member States the freedom to develop different types of renewable and low carbon gases according to their national potential.   As a prerequisite, AFG proposes to clarify the definitions of renewable and low carbon gas (only biogas is currently defined):  -Renewable gas: "gaseous fuels produced from renewable sources"  -Low carbon gas: “gas produced from non-renewables sources but providing significant GHG emissions reduction compared to fossil fuels, such as non-renewable hydrogen and synthetic fuels with significantly reduced full life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions compared to existing production".  Guarantees of Origin (GO): The EU should create a European market for renewable and low carbon gases via a well-functioning, interoperable system of Guarantees of Origin for both low-carbon and renewable gases, while providing information on whether the gas is renewable or low-carbon. In addition, a harmonized GO system at international level would be needed to facilitate import/export of green gases (including H2).   European Framework to promote low carbon gases: Harmonized technical standards, including blending rules, will be needed to prepare for a future use of parts of the existing gas infrastructure as well as dedicated pipelines for the transport and distribution of H2. AFG provides that non-discriminatory TPA rules need to be developed to reduce undue burdens to market access.   With regard to international energy markets: AFG notes that further to the assessment of importing renewable and low-carbon gases, the forthcoming impact assessment should also consider other import options, such as importing biomethane, synthetic methane, renewable H2, or natural gas and its subsequent processing within the EU into low-carbon H2 in combination with CCUS.    2. Further the integration of energy system for optimizing the gas, H2 and electricity infrastructures uses and development  The place of the gas network, largely European, responds to the three characteristics of a robust network: security, stability, cost control.  -Cost control: Policy makers and regulators should promote a framework enabling the most efficient and relevant investment choices among the options available (power line, installation of power-to-gas, etc.). On the consumer side flexibility solutions like hybrid heating should be promoted.  -Storage and Security: Gas infrastructure and storage can act as batteries of the new energy system. It will also enable the storing of large amounts of renewable (intermittent) power to ensure security of supply and act as a back-up for H2 furniture.    The gas infrastructure should enable the massive integration of renewable and low carbon gases. The existing gas network should evolve to smart grid able to maximize local renewable production of a higher diversity of gases. The regulation should evolve accordingly.   The energy systems planification need to be looked at from both volume and peak perspectives. Massive electrification can imply a sharp increase in peak demand, especially in winter. This could potentially pose challenges in terms of energy system stability and costly investments in network reinforcements.  3. Strengthen the role of distributors: a key point for developing a more decentralized system  A Gas DSO entity, next to the ENTSOs, should be created with a clear mandate and adequate representation of the sector.  To do so, a holistic approach based on the principle of technology neutrality must prevail in order to and to reconcile the economic and societal aspects, and environmental impacts, while ensuring robustness against the consequences of the chosen transition path.  Feedback from: AFG (Association française du gaz) (367.1 KB - PDF - 11 pages) Download
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: The impact assessment of  Direct Gasification of Waste (municipal waste or cellulosic biomass) may be included in the Hydrogen and Gas markets Decarbonisation Package.   100 mton of non-recyclable waste in EU represents more than 10 mton of Hydrogen and could replace 40 billion litres of fossil Diesel. Currently, waste to energy sector processes this 100 mton of non-recyclable waste with poor financial performance, high environmental stress to air, water & soil and climate stress.   With breakthrough solution approach (of Gasification), the industry can implement a H2 strategy, with existing infrastructure, and contribute in a completely new way in the Hydrogen transition efforts, on its own financial merit, with no government financial support needed. Direct Gasification offers cross disciplines system benefits with infrastructure stress reduction.   Hydrogen for local use could be made available from Waste, at LCOHD (Levelized Cost of Hydrogen, Dispensed ready) of 3 euro/kg or lower.   By including this approach in the ‘ combined evaluation roadmap/Inception Impact Assessment’ document, the European Commission could take a quantum leap not only with respect to the environment,  but also create new companies in EU with enormous potential to export such expertise globally. Feedback from: Boson Energy SA (1.2 MB - PDF - 10 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Grid operators are also challenged to seek for new ways of integrating the electricity and gas grid, and possibly even district heating grids. This integration of causes a major change of our role and function in the system, developing them from a traditional grid operator and towards an integrated system operator. To fully gain from the benefits of integrated system operators, we have the following suggestions for the European Commission: make legislation flexible and adaptive to unforeseen developments, take existing infrastructure into account while aligning strategies for energy carriers, data is essential to ensure system stability and facilitate the future energy market and involve local authorities and end users in the legislative process.  It is clear that the energy system of the future is based on system integration in which different energy carriers, including electricity, gas and heat, are integrated. The extent to which the electricity grid has to be expanded will depend in part on the choice of sustainable heat, gas, electricity or a hybrid form. It is necessary to give natural gas, green gas and hydrogen an important role in this system. The transition towards this system means that the existing energy systems must be renovated and expanded, while the current system must continue to provide the same level of security. The DSOs are faced with a major development task in which integration and optimization between the energy carriers will play an increasingly important role, but also has many uncertainties. Therefore, the existing infrastructure should play an important role in developing strategies per energy carrier. The transition towards an integrated system needs to be cost-efficient. This means the costs for grid adaptations must be included from the beginning, because it could affect choices in designing the energy system.  When hydrogen becomes an important energy carrier at system level, it is necessary that the natural gas distribution system operators may build and operate hydrogen infrastructure, using both existing and new gas pipes. This is comparable to the current gas tasks. The guiding principle must be that the most cost-efficient solution is given priority and that all relevant aspects – such as infrastructure - are taken into account.  DSOs can play an important part in the challenge of balancing the system. The access to data is an essential element for system integration to exist and function. Therefore, data is essential for grid operators to ensure the system stability, but also to facilitate the future energy market of renewable energy. This can only be managed by introducing a clear framework for data exchange, or a so called ‘Afsprakenstelsel’ (data-exchange framework). This is highly important for the markets and system to keep functioning. Grid operators must plan their operations present day, taking into account the energy infrastructure needed in 2050. This means that we are continuously working within a framework in which society still needs to make its final choices for energy carriers and the necessary infrastructure for this. Innovation inherently develops faster than legislation. This asks for legislation designed to be flexible. An overarching regulatory framework with separate directives per energy source underneath, can be found to be more flexible and adaptive to developing circumstances. Legislation on electricity, such as the Clean Energy Package, cannot be used directly for the gas and hydrogen market. Therefore, one must weigh off what kind of legislation is needed.  When developing legislation on energy carriers, not only DSOs but also all governmental authorities, from local to national level, are important stakeholders. Suppliers and facilitators, end users and energy communities can provide interesting input. When formulating policies, it is important to consider how this will take its turn on the necessary infrastructure, planning of the DSOs and spatial planning Feedback from: Anonymous (115 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: 2020 was a turning point for the discussion on environmental issues and in this context hydrogen received unprecedented attention, being recognized as a strategic energy vector to achieve the EU decarbonisation targets, together with other renewable and low-carbon gases such as Biogas and Bio-Methane. H2IT believes there is a strong need of regulation of the market to preserve competition, avoid unnecessary expenditures and protect consumers. For this reasons H2IT welcomes positively the upcoming review of the legislative framework related to gas markets in order for it to contribute to the overall energy system decarbonisation. The transition towards the use of green and low carbon gases inevitably requires the development of an adequate regulatory framework. The integration of different systems, such as the gas grid and the electricity grid, is fundamental to meet the objectives of reducing CO2 emissions and pollution; different solutions will contribute to achieve the EU target of decarbonisation in a complementary and synergistic way. In this context, hydrogen can play a pivotal role in multiple sectors. Hydrogen, indeed, represents a key solution, complementary with other technologies, for the decarbonisation of transport, industry and the residential sector, becoming an economic opportunity in various applications. H2IT would like to attract the attention of the Commission on some key points; 1.  A regulatory framework for hydrogen market is required, to guarantee the integration of renewable and low carbon hydrogen in the energy system and the alignment of the existing regulation with new rules specially designed. A regulatory approach at EU level would be beneficial to encourage investments, develop know how, R&D activities and innovative projects, enabling scaling up, system adaptation and optimisation for technologies at an early stage of development. The framework should be harmonized and integrated to other policies and directives at European level, but it should also consider the specific characteristics that renewable and low carbon gases has today, in the way they are produced, stored and distributed. 2. An EN Standard and/or Directive should be issued to determine and standardize the requirements for base materials, components, assembling and pressure-containing systems (including pipelines and storage systems) for the production, storage, distribution and use of Hydrogen. 3. TSOs and DSOs role is very important to regulate the market and ensuring a transparent, fair and non-discriminatory access to infrastructure. 4. The role of third countries—cooperation and imports; Investing in local production of green hydrogen is a priority but at the same time it is important to consider the opportunity to import green hydrogen produced in regions where electricity from renewable sources has highly competitive costs. 5. Supporting the growth of a hydrogen infrastructure enables the growth of the demand for hydrogen, however it is necessary to consider to support also final application creating an incentives framework and dedicated rules and standards. 6. An attention to the costs of the transition will help to design the right regulatory framework. However, it is important to consider that the development of such infrastructures will require investments. Supportive policy framework to bridge the cost gap of clean technologies with  polluting alternatives, should be developed. A new approach (“regulatory sandbox”) should be also taken into account by National Regulatory Authorities, taking into account that this transition will experiment costs of repurposing and retrofitting, and at the same time will need to speed up with innovation development. 7. A system to calculate the CO2 content of energy carriers considering life-cycle greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from renewable and low carbon hydrogen is necessary. The EU must develop a harmonised and distinct system of Hydrogen GO, enabling the trade of renewable hydrogen. Feedback from: H2IT - Associazione Italiana Idrogeno e Celle a Combustibile (418.3 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
