feedback_msg_text: EFET welcomes the publication of initial ideas on how to establish a suitable market framework for hydrogen and gas to support achievement of EU climate ambitions, and strongly endorses that this should be a central part of the Fit for 55 package.  The following is an extract from the more detailed response attached.  It is increasingly accepted that net zero emissions by 2050 will be impossible without molecules.  Not all industrial use of energy can be electrified, there are not yet efficient mechanisms for storage of electricity over weeks, months and seasons in the volumes that will be necessary, and the intermittency of electricity supply at higher levels of penetration of renewable generation are all challenges that the gas system is well-placed to help address.  However, gas must decarbonise in order to contribute to Europe’s objective to achieve climate neutrality by 2050.  In particular, it is important that a market framework is maintained in natural gas and created for hydrogen in a way that allows commercial enterprises to make the investment and operating decisions that will deliver policy objectives in a cost-effective manner.   It is noted that some member states have already embarked on publishing roadmaps and intentions with regard to hydrogen and decarbonisation of gas markets.  Disjointed and disparate national approaches will serve to weaken the ability of commercial enterprises and the market to facilitate achievement of the objectives efficiently and risk creating isolated national ‘island’ markets with accompanying reduced supply security and loss of the benefits from the existing internal gas market.  The Commission has an important role to design a common structural approach that initially allows some fine-tuning by individual member states, but ultimately provides for convergence and a coherent European market.   Natural gas networks will continue to be used for a considerable time, not only for transportation and storage of natural gas, but also increasing proportions of biomethane, possibilities of transporting hydrogen in natural gas networks either as a commingled stream for delivery of blended gas, or for co-transportation that may allow separation of products prior to delivery.  Nevertheless, use of natural gas infrastructure can be expected to change, and a review of existing legislation in the light of declining use and repurposing of assets is well-timed. To create a pan European market for hydrogen there must be some means to manage quality to ensure that cross border trade in gases is not prevented through national adoption of incompatible gas quality standards. A natural starting point is to consider the extension of natural gas market rules to hydrogen unless there are good reasons to do otherwise in specific cases.  There is already familiarity in commercial, technical and legislative areas for natural gas that a compatible regime will be less costly to implement and will carry fewer commercial and operational risks for network users.  Key issues on third party access, unbundling and the role of TSOs, interoperability, promotion of market principles, confidentiality and governance – which are cornerstones of the existing Gas Directive – should also form the basis of new legislation. The Commission should also be sensitive to risks of driving industrial production outside European borders if due regard for such effects is not properly considered.  Any impact assessment should consider not only the relative overall costs and benefits of proposals but also how these are distributed among different societal groups, such that redistributive effects can be considered. Consideration must also be given to existing hydrogen networks.  These generally function as business to business networks, enabling the supply of specific demands of industrial consumers in a competitive environment. These may require a different regulatory approach on a case by case basis.  Feedback from: European Federation of Energy Traders (EFET) (326.8 KB - PDF - 8 pages) Download
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: The Association of Energy Trading (TOE) response to the European Commission initiative ‘Hydrogen and Gas markets Decarbonisation Package’   In regard to the consultations on changes in EU regulations regarding access to the gas market, entitled: ‘Hydrogen and Gas markets Decarbonisation Package’, below we hereby present TOE’s suggestions and comments in order to provide directional support in the following regulatory areas: - competitiveness  – TOE supports the further progress of deregulation, the introduction of a free competitive market and the integration of gaseous fuel markets including H2 and biomethane. We pay attention to the need for further progress in the liberalization of the Polish gas market so that it is fully diversified, transparent and accessible to all market participants on an equal basis. More information is available in the TOE’s Report, Electricity and Gas Market in Poland - as of March 31, 2020. (link: https://www.toe.pl/pl/wybrane-dokumenty/rok-2020), in which, every year, we indicate regulatory issues requiring changes in the medium and long term perspective, related to the functioning of the gas market in Poland, - gaseous fuels market - TOE supports the decarbonisation process with the use of new renewable energy technologies and renewable gases (including H2 and biomethane). We see the need to create a regulatory framework enabling the development of new technologies and renewable gases, and in particular the possibility of wholesale trading in renewable gases, also on a cross-border dimension, - market transparency and unification – TOE indicates the need to eliminate barriers to cross-border trading in gaseous fuels (including renewable gases) and free access to storage services (in different countries for the purpose of creating mandatory stocks), in particular the need to support the development of cross-border gas hubs, also using renewable gases and guarantees of origin for renewable gases, - TOE supports the legitimacy of maintaining the directions of the Third Regulatory Package in preparing the legal framework for hydrogen and biomethane and adopting technological neutrality in market design and supporting infrastructure development, - we support the possibility of developing free trade in renewable gases (including H2 and biomethane), for which it is necessary to implement a regulatory framework for the quality management of renewable gases. To introduce a single market for biomethane and hydrogen, it is necessary to standardize the quality and trading conditions (creating conditions for commodity trading) throughout the EU. It is necessary to remove barriers to cross-border trading between individual Member States along with standardization of trading at the level of operator instructions, - as part of cross-border connections of gaseous fuels and renewable gases markets (including H2 and biomethane), we propose the use of market coupling formulas with electricity (trade in goods and capacity together), taking into account the possibility of connecting energy markets (gas and electricity, especially RES) along with the possibility of standardizing products on European markets. Additionally, on the part of TOE, we declare support and willingness to participate in further works on detailed changes to regulations in this area. The Association of Energy Trading (TOE), registered in Warsaw at the end of 2003, is a voluntary, self-governing, sustainable and apolitical association, which acts pursuant to the Polish Act on Associations. There are three types of Association Members: Ordinary, Supporting and Honorary. As at the beginning of Fabruary 2021 TOE had 250 Ordinary Members – natural persons, one Honorary Member and 36 Supporting Members – trading companies. It is notable that the above mentioned list of companies includes both companies with Polish capital, including companies belonging to the largest Polish energy groups, and the representatives of the largest foreign energy comp

feedback_msg_text: DEDA S.A. welcomes the proposal for a regulation updating common rules for the natural gas internal market and for the conditions for accessing natural gas distribution networks. In principle DEDA identifies the same problem areas, as well as the need for replacing coal in power generation, liquid fuels for heavy road and maritime transport. Natural gas can be complementary to the intermittent renewable electricity, while maintaining the context for current greenfield investments in building infrastructure, thus playing its essential role in the energy transition.  DEDA S.A. lies in the heart of Greece’s most ambitious development plan of gas infrastructure by 2024, aiming to connect 39 cities through 1.880km of new pipeline networks. We believe that this investment will benefit both Greece and EU in delivering targets and commitments for emissions reduction, the achievement of net zero, especially following the pioneering national plan to end lignite power by 2028, which equals to 4% of the EUs total of 152.000 MW.   We recommend that the following policy ideas may be considered: 1. There is significant uncertainty in the future pathway for current greenfield investments in natural gas DSOs. There is a clear need for maintaining a perfect balance in order to share the benefits of the transition. Clear distinction and build transition scenarios among the DSOs with varied hydrogen-readiness is required. Existing gas networks should not jeopardise capital cycle of greenfield investments and levels of ROI. Hence, the legislative proposal needs to incentivise repurposing gas infrastructure for hydrogen.  2. In the short term, injecting directly small volumes of hydrogen into the natural gas grid without the need for high investments (adapting pipelines and end-use equipment) is the effective way to start the integration of the energy carrier into the energy system. 3. Define a target market model compatible with the level of progress in shifting lignite power generation to gas power generation and gas usage. Natural gas offers significant advantages to reduce GHG emissions, it is a natural partner to an energy mix with renewable energies and we need the appropriate transitional balance along with hydrogen-readiness. 4. Decarbonised gases have an important role to play in the development of a net zero energy system. The opportunity for our respective market is how we develop such gases from small-scale energy sources in order to be significant contributors to the energy system. feedback_msg_text: St1 would like to thank the Commission for the opportunity to comment on the review of the Union’s rules and regulations to better support the decarbonisation of European gas networks.   We support a common gas strategy that can quicken the pace of the energy transition and would like to highlight the following points:  - St1 encourages the harmonisation of sustainability criteria for all energy carriers. - Regardless of how ETS and ESR will look like in the future, St1 urges EU to promote holistic mandates for all low-carbon energy carriers with a focus on CO2 reduction. - St1 considers Europe’s gas network to be the backbone of a common energy market driving decarbonisation. And the mass balance principles are integral to that.  The Commission writes the following in the problem description of the impact assessment: “The areas where decarbonised gaseous fuels are expected to come into play include today’s energy-intensive industry (e.g. refineries, fertilisers, steel making) and certain heavy duty transport sectors (maritime transport, aviation, long distance heavy vehicles)”.  As one of the largest refiners, producers and sellers of transport fuels in the Nordics, St1 very much agrees with the above statement. St1 operates a refinery in Sweden, fuel depots in Norway, Sweden and Finland, as well as some 1300 energy stations across the three countries. We serve customers in aviation, maritime transport and heavy road transport in addition to our customers in the B2C market.  We like to call ourselves one of Europe’s most mandated energy companies as we operate under very ambitious biofuel mandates in the Nordics. We understand the importance these mandates play in decarbonising the Nordic transport sector and we understand how they incentivise energy producers like ourselves to invest in the production of low-carbon energy solutions that need support to compete with their fossil cousins.  However, we also recognise that we have a global feedstock challenge, and that biofuels will not be the only solution to reach a low-carbon transport sector. In order to decarbonise road transport – and especially heavy-duty road transport, maritime and aviation – we must develop and promote the usage of alternative energy carriers. The transition from liquid diesel and other fossil energy carriers to alternatives (like liquified and compressed gaseous fuels) will require strong policy support.  As Commissioner for Energy Kadri Simson recently said: “By 2050 transport fuels will be a mix of electricity, hydrogen, biofuels, biomethane and e-fuels". For that very reason, we support a policy shift towards what can be called “holistic energy mandates”. Mandates should include electricity, H2 (liquid and gaseous), biogas, biofuels, synthetic fuels (liquid and gaseous) and other energy carriers that reduce CO2 compared to fossil alternatives.  We can already see a movement toward this way of thinking in Sweden and Finland. In Sweden, liquid RFNBOs is in the referral process for the 2021 update of the mandate and will likely be included in the Swedish transport mandate already by 2022/23. Finland has progressed even further and has decided to include both biogas and liquid RFNBOs into their mandates (respectively by 2022 and 2023).  St1 believes gas will play an important role in the future low-carbon energy mix, and we urge the EU to develop an “EU Green Gas concept” to apply to all EU member states. This should include some of the above mentioned ideas and should establish a common set of rules and regulations to allow gas to play an even more active role in the energy transition going forward.
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: Elettricità Futura welcomes the development of a Hydrogen and Gas markets Decarbonisation Package.  Direct electrification is a viable and efficient solution to decarbonize a large part of the energy demand, while hydrogen can play a significant role in specific hard to abate sectors. Other green gases and biofuels can also be part of a decarbonized energy mix.  Likewise, the new EU gas package should define a legal and regulatory framework that caters for the emergence of a European hydrogen market grounded on a shared understanding of its technological, industrial and economic context. Following a gradual approach, the EU strategy for hydrogen can ensure level playing field and competition as a compass and envisage a "preparatory phase" that focuses on research, pilot projects and regulatory sandboxes. Considering hydrogen production costs, availability and decarbonization potential, it should be first considered to foster green hydrogen production at or near the site of use. Whereas injecting hydrogen into natural gas networks could stimulate a market off-take, such application results less efficient than others, more focussed on hard to abate sectors. In addition, while hydrogen and synthetic gases will need time to disclose their potential, biomethane can offer, in some circumstances, an immediate alternative to natural gas. Once established a system of guarantees of origin, virtual PPA-gas could allow the virtual transaction of significant amount of clean gas. Renewable and low carbon gases should be qualified depending on production process and associated GHG emissions. The imported gas should also be included in a suitable classification, mirroring the import of renewable electricity.  Network planning should be carried out in a cross-sectoral perspective and based on cost-benefit analysis, pursuing the realization of a sustainable and efficient infrastructure at the minimum social cost. The regulatory framework should build on the key principles of unbundling, third party access and independent authorities should refer to them to correctly evaluate the development plans. Regarding the development of gas distribution and transport networks, sustainability criteria should be enforced, according to the proposal for TEN-E regulation, while the Energy Efficiency first principle should lead any project.  The development of a hydrogen network will probably start at decentralized level, to link the industrial users, and gradually expand, driven by market forces. In a scenario of increasing transport need, retrofitting existing gas networks is preferable to realising new networks. In fact, the first option can extend the life span of infrastructures, limiting stranded assets. The unbundling principle should anyhow be respected to avoid cross-subsidies. An integrated approach to network planning is crucial. Given the significant investment costs associated to both retrofitted and new networks, alternative solutions - such as using existing and/or new electricity transmission assets and promoting hydrogen valleys - must be carefully evaluated. An increasing deployment of electrolysers (up to 40 GW by 2030 according to the EC hydrogen strategy) will make gas, hydrogen and electricity networks more and more inter-dependent. Leaving room to the market actors and promoting competitiveness will lead to an efficient system integration, where hydrogen will be a wholesale product. Electrolysers should be considered as gas injection sources (in general terms, this should apply to every source of hydrogen or other gases), connecting gas and electricity markets. Their connection requirements and their role in the electricity markets should thus be properly defined, by amending Directive 2019/944 and Regulation 2019/943. Tariff frameworks should also be designed to minimize cross-sectoral distortions. Please find attached Elettricità Futura’s comprehensive positioning, with further details. feedback_msg_text: GENERAL COMMENTS: Energinet would like to thank the EC for the timely initiative for a revision of the gas legislation and legislative proposals for regulation of hydrogen infrastructure. Ultimately, the gas legislation will be a crucial piece in the comprehensive regulatory puzzle, which should ensure deliverance on long term political targets for climate and energy throughout the entire European economy.  Efforts are needed across all energy carriers and end-use sectors to ensure an effective green transition within the timeframe determined by the medium and long-term climate targets. We welcome the EC initiative to bring the EU gas regulation in line with the challenges ahead and encourages that future discussions on gas and hydrogen regulation are based on a system perspective, covering all energy carriers and end-use sectors. Alignment and correlation between existing regulation on transport, electricity, renewable energy, and climate based on technology neutrality is deemed necessary. A re-casting of the existing gas market regulation alone will not be sufficient.  SPECIFIC COMMENTS: The specific comments on the EC roadmap are included and explained further in the memo attached (as advised in template). To provide an overview of the content the following list includes our main priorities:  - Hydrogen: 1) Build on existing regulatory core principles from IEM legislation for electricity and gas (unbundling, 3rd party access and transparency), but allow for exemptions for point-to-point and cluster in line with current gas directive. 2) Financing of hydrogen infrastructure: EC must analyze further how to handle the inherent dilemmas and suggest possible models for appropriate financing and tariffication arrangements to ensure an appropriate level of infrastructure investments and mitigate risks -both from the side of the infrastructure developers and the hydrogen consumers/producers. 3) Adapted mirroring of consumer rights:  We  suggest that the EC specifically consider the differences in especially expected end-user segments and the level of market maturity at this point in time, when looking into a possible mirroring exercise via a vis existing electricity and gas regulation. - Regulation of gas storage: Current regime is ok, but close NRA oversight is needed in cases of regulated schemes - this to avoid competitive distortions across borders. Also in case of storage it will be important to take into account the specific differences of hydrogen vis a vis natural gas, notably the number and geographical location of supply sources, end user segments, security of supply issues, flexibility effects and the maturity of market and infrastructure development in general.      - Gas Quality: Biomethane injections into the natural gas grid is already a vital element in the transition of the Danish gas system (over 20% of national gas consumption in 2021) and hence Denmark is among the first countries to encounter issues with cross border trade due to varying gas quality standards. National regulatory standards on gas quality for the injection of biomethane and potentially hydrogen is a potential showstopper for the transitioning of the gas system and a future-proof internal gas market. Consequently, Energinet sees a need for the issue of gas quality to be addressed in the legal base for the gas package, with a mandate to ensure that the issue will not constitute a barrier. Integrated infrastructure planning: The TEN-E could be strengthened : 1)Priority corridors/regional groups: It is counter-intuitive to maintain the current silo structure and just add more silos for the new categories. More comprehensive and integrated infrastructure planning and project assessment would be possible if combining perspectives of onshore electricity, offshore grid and hydrogen infrastructure. 2) hydrogen should be a part of offshore grid plans on onshore-offshore planning be better synchronized in general. feedback_msg_text: In reference to the revision of EU gas rules, we would like to present our conclusions and observations from the perspective of an owner of companies selling ecological energy in Poland.   GAS MARKET The current provisions of the national law for the sale of gaseous fuels require a license from the enterprise, which involves high start-up costs and a long period of implementation of the necessary documents. The exceptions are enterprises whose total annual revenue from the sale of gaseous fuels does not exceed EUR 100,000. These regulations constitute a significant entry barrier for many companies and thus favor the monopoly of large companies on the market, and limit the promotion of ecological energy sources. In the coming years, gas prices in Poland will no longer be regulated by the government, which will result in their increase. Therefore, the turnover of EUR 100,000 will be too low in our opinion. The optimal solution in our opinion would be to increase the income limit without concessions to EUR 1 million per year.   ENERGY MARKET The current tax system on the electricity market does not separate energy producers in terms of source of origin (colors tax). As a consequence, a company that sells energy that comes 100% from ecological renewable sources incurs additional emissions fees. Due to such regulations, the price of ecological energy in Poland is at the same level as carbon energy. The price of energy in Poland is the main factor determining the change of energy supplier, so the above tax regulations in the field of colors limit the possibilities of promoting green renewable sources.
Organisation: Wide Horizons Sp. z o.o. Sp. k.

feedback_msg_text: The Gas Grid Group AISBL represents four German Gas TSOs in Brussels: bayernets, OGE, ONTRAS and GASCADE. We are fully committed to the objectives of the EU green deal and believe that kick-starting a hydrogen economy in this decade is crucial for becoming the first climate neutral continent.  Only infrastructure can create a European hydrogen market: It is important to boost clean H2 production and demand, but without an infrastructure connecting both, no European market can develop, neither a decent level of competition of producers nor security of supply can be guaranteed. In addition, an H2 grid, a European backbone, allows to locally disconnect consumption and production, so that H2 can be produced where it is most cost efficient, onshore as well as offshore.  Three key principles for a successful kick-start of a hydrogen economy are (1) allowing TSOs to transport H2, (2) including H2 in the EU regulatory framework for gas, (3) avoiding prohibitively high infrastructure costs by mutualisation in a combined regulatory framework for natural gas and H2.  (1) Allowing TSOs to transport H2: Since, as the EU Commission rightly says, the repurposing of existing natural gas pipelines will be the most cost-efficient way to build a hydrogen backbone, TSOs have to play a key role in developing the infrastructure. They have a unique experience and expertise in handling various forms of gaseous energy carriers and to run a grid. It is therefore crucial that the European legislation for gas and H2 explicitly defines that certified gas TSOs are able and allowed to finance, own and operate H2 infrastructure as combined network operators. TSOs operating H2 and natural gas networks together will facilitate the repurposing and retrofitting of pipelines enabling the transition from a natural gas grid to a H2 grid by realising synergies in the most efficient way.  (2) Including H2 in EU regulatory framework for gas: The developing European H2 market will have the same characteristics as the European natural gas market. Therefore, it is clear that a regulatory framework will be needed to enable competition. Given the short time the EU has to kick-start the H2 market it is important to establish a future-proof regulatory framework now. A wait and see or step-by-step approach without a clear destination does not provide a predictable investment framework and risks in the end to jeopardize the climate goals. The easiest, quickest and cheapest way is to incorporate H2 into the existing regulatory framework for natural gas. Broadening the scope of the gas directive and regulation would allow market participants and infrastructure operators to smoothly shift from one market to the other. This would ensure the highest level of predictability possible for investors.  (3) Avoiding prohibitively high infrastructure costs by mutualisation in a combined regulatory framework for gas and H2: To repurpose, to retrofit or if necessary, to build new H2 infrastructure, a long-term perspective is necessary for covering the costs, including operational costs. For initial projects, costs and therefore network tariffs are likely to be prohibitively high in the beginning for the first consumers and consequently will prevent infrastructure investors or consumers from moving to a hydrogen economy. This is why a long-term mechanism is necessary to finance the infrastructure. Subsidies are only a temporary solution and in itself not a sufficient basis for investments in infrastructure with depreciation periods of up to 55 years. A mutualisation of costs for H2 and gas with a joint cost recovery mechanism for TSOs and combined network charges would give consumers and infrastructure operators the necessary predictability. This solution would enable a smooth shift towards decarbonised gas and ensure affordable network tariffs in the short and long term - for hydrogen consumers in the beginning and for the remaining gas consumers in the phasing-out period of natural gas.
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: Plinovodi, the Slovenian gas TSO, is summarizing its feedback in bellow points: 1. Application of Internal Energy Market rules to H2 market as H2 system is interoperable with other systems, with additional elements that reflect the particularities of H2 business. However, it should be recognized that the H2 infrastructure is at the moment almost non-existent, so the regulation should be at the beginning flexible enough to provide room for incentives and to enable all variants of investments in order to foster take-off of the new infrastructure. Member states (MS) should be obliged to adopt clear national strategies for promoting development of H2 infrastructure. 2. Role of gas TSOs as central actors in the energy transition process. Certified TSOs shall be owners and operators of H2 networks, covering repurposed, retrofitted and new-built networks. Retrofitting and repurposing of their existing infrastructure should be incentivized and it should be harmonized on EU level that it does not require additional environmental and state permits, as there is the existing infrastructure that will be used. 3. Financing the development of the H2 networks should be carried out in an incentivized and clear regulatory framework that encourages the investments in new H2 networks. In earlier stages of the development of the H2 network, either network charges will be prohibitively high, or revenues will be insufficient to finance the infrastructure. We support pooling of H2 network costs with the gas network costs and to allow TSOs to invest in H2 projects. TSOs should be able to invest in the P2G infrastructure and offer transparent and non-discriminatory service of conversion from electricity to gas, especially in the conditions where they need P2G infrastructure for their own system services and enhancement of security of supply. 4. Recognition of cost for repurposing gas pipelines should be recognized by the NRAs. The planning of H2 infrastructure needs to be integrated into the ENTSOG TYNDP. Processes in place at national level for gas infrastructure should also apply for repurposing, retrofitting and/or building new H2 infrastructure. The gas regulation should give clear guidelines and principles in this regard. Increase in local production and energy communities of new gases might cause serious disruptions – the need of development of transmission/backbone infrastructure enabling its operators to act on the needs of the future systems, technical rules should be flexible and taking into consideration regional differences to enable efficient system operation. This should be applied when designing incentive schemes with regard to uptake of new gases into the networks. 5. Treatment of H2 injected into the gas network (blending) may rise some specific issues in need for dedicated provisions.  Blending of H2 and renewable gases should be supported (also financially) for early decarbonization of the gas flow. It shall be prevented that upstream MS fill the H2 up to the allowed concentration and thus ensured that downstream MS have the possibility to fully inject domestically generated renewable gas (should be prescribed as compulsory component of the Interconnection agreements between TSOs). The allowed concentration of H2 in the systems should be harmonized on the EU level. 6. Sandbox:  involvement of TSOs should be allowed in the development and operation of P2G installations in exceptional cases (e.g. system services) and for security of supply purposes.  TSOs/DSOs should be allowed to invest in P2G installations for secure, reliable and efficient network operations and if no other market participant is interested. For this, clear and limited conditions should defined by NRAs, after it has been proven that the market is not willing to invest in such installations and foreseeing a procedure to transfer such installations back to a market-based regime once the derogation expires.
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the approach of the European Commission that the reforms should enable fair competition between smart electrification, energy efficiency, and renewable gases in achieving decarbonisation targets. To maximise the potential decarbonisation effects of renewable energies, we regard it particularly important to define two basic principles: technology and source neutrality.   Facilitating local and decentralised production of renewable gases:  1. Smart adaptation of the infrastructure: A sustainable gas network needs to be able to handle all gases and needs to be optimized for renewable gases. Natural gas contains ethane, butane and propane and therefore has a high calorific value. This reduces the possibility of adding biomethane and hydrogen to the gas grid. There is a need to change; the gas standard needs redefining. Possible options to be considered: o Option 1: Converting the gas grid to support a mix of natural gas, biomethane or hydrogen: A lower calorific value allows for a blending of multiple renewable options. A value of around 10 kWh would be a reasonable starting point to blend in biomethane, biogas, or hydrogen at low cost. This would be a first step towards creating a gas grid exclusively for renewable gases.  o Option 2: Establishing entirely new grids for H2. When considering creating an entirely new hydrogen grid, it is important to take a European approach. We consider that hydrogen could play a crucial role especially for dedicated sectors where the special chemical attributes of hydrogen are needed, such as steel and chemical industry, refineries, fertilizer, CHP with fuels cells. o Option 3: Complete repurposing of the grid for renewable gases: It is necessary to evaluate the possibility of repurposing the existing network if certain parts of the gas infrastructure are no longer needed to transport natural gas.  o Option 4: Adapting the natural gas grid for methane: For this type of repurposing, methane as an energy carrier, regardless of the production method, is at the forefront. This would promote a mix of natural gas, biomethane, and PtG. Initial such projects already exist in Bavaria.  o Option 5: Regional solutions: An extended role of the DSOs combined with smart grid solutions for biogas or directly feeding biogas into the gas grid could result in good examples, such as in Schwäbisch Hall in Germany. A biogas grid, which is separated from the natural gas grid enables the transport of biogas from rural areas to CHP plants in urban regions. This solution is highly cost effective, as there is no need to upgrade the biogas. The potential of the solution was highlighted in the latest report of Gas for Climate Consortium “Market state and trends in renewable and low-carbon gases in Europe” P. 83-84.  2. Priorisation of BECCS and DAC in any CCS context:  We propose to prioritise and privilege CO2 taken from the atmosphere in CCS solutions. CCS is primarily used in connection with fossil energy carriers and gives a false impression about the potential of this technology. On the other hand, keeps fossil fuel plants alive longer than necessary. CCS can be used in connection with bio energy (BECCS) or by directly pulliCO2 out of the atmosphere (Direct Air Capture, DAC), a far more effective method of decarbonization, as it creates negative emissions by actively removing CO2 from the atmosphere. Moreover, we propose to define a minimum share of BECCS and DAC. It could give the right signal for investors and would foster the adaption of existing plants enabling CCS solutions.  3. Enable cross-border trade of renewable gases across Europe without barriers: Legal barriers prevent cross-border trading of renewable methane: Despite the European Court of Justice ruling in 2017, nearly all EU countries, especially Germany continue to uphold import restrictions that do not only put the current biomethane flow in danger but would also put any future power-to-gas and hydrogen flows at risk.
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: DEPA INFRASTRUCTURE S.A. (Greece)welcomes the initiative of the Commission to update the Directive and Regulation on the natural gas market and networks towards the deployment of renewable and low-carbon gases (including hydrogen and biomethane)- “new gases”, while recognizing the significant role of natural gas in the transition towards climate neutrality by 2050.As the existing regulation of EU energy deals, mainly, with the market liberalization that differs from the decarbonization issue, it must integrate the new gases to achieve the Green Deal goals.Our recommendations are: *provide a well-defined framework for all types of new gases through strengthening the role of biomethane and including H2 (blue and green one),  *provide technical and regulatory guidance for the integration of new gases in the existing infrastructure to avoid decommissioning issues and an enabling framework to stimulate the deployment of H2 applications and the use of existing gas infrastructure (e.g. certification, guarantees of origin), *Provide clarity on access to infrastructure through a well-defined set of rules about terms and conditions for the new gases’ injection into the gas networks, *Harmonized standards regarding the technical specifications to inject H2 within natural gas infrastructure are needed.A common EU approach about the levels of H2 concentration permitted in the gas network and the relevant gas quality is needed to strengthen H2 production and demand and facilitate the cross-border interoperability.The subject levels should be defined in terms of minimum and maximum H2 capacity allowed through the gas network, while flexibility at national level is necessary on the accomplishment of maximum capacity, *In the short term, injecting directly small volumes of H2 into the natural gas grid without the need for high investments is the more effective way to start the integration of the energy carrier into the system. In the medium to long term, converting part of gas networks to 100% H2 (re-purposing) can be considered, *Provide rules on whether H2 should be blended with natural gas (at least in a transitory period) or should be transported in dedicated infrastructure, *The H2 production and storage are classified at EU level as a hazardous activity and under a strict and complicated legal regime in relation with the licenses, the safety rules, and the environmental impact.Developing a favorable regulatory framework that would support the subject activity, based on less restrictions for land use and simplified procedures for environmental permits, but without compromising on health, safety, and protection of environment, is needed and contributes to the decrease of the relevant cost, *Enhance DSOs’ role as decentralized production of new gases requires them to undertake the activity of gas quality control.A set of technical rules and limitations for harmonized quality standards at a feedback_msg_text: VIK welcomes the opportunity to participate in the consultation on the roadmap and inception impact assessment hydrogen and gas markets decarbonization package.  VIK supports the goal of the Green Deal to change energy markets in a non-disruptive and cost-efficient manner. However, the industries concerned are exposed to international competition. Hence, cost-efficiency and availability of climate neutral energy carriers at competitive prices are absolutely relevant to prevent carbon leakage.  We support the Commission’s technology and cost-efficiency driven approach of fair competition to tackle climate neutrality and prevent any technological lock-ins. As laid down in the roadmap, gaseous fuels will continue to be used by 2050. The current European regulatory framework for natural gases and gas transmission networks has proved to be working and helped to establish a competitive and integrated European market. The expertise gained in the past decades of gas market development should be utilized to maximize regulatory effectiveness and efficiency for hydrogen regulation right from the beginning. The new hydrogen regulation must establish an extensive, unifying framework while at the same time providing enough regulatory freedom for member states to adapt to national requirements and developments.  This applies in particular to unbundling requirements, where we recommend translating and extending the existing framework of gas and electricity network regulation to hydrogen and low-carbon gases. For instance, transmission system operators should purchase balancing services on the market instead of directly operating dedicated electrolyzers or even H2 storage. Similar to gas and power storage facilities, hydrogen storages are neither producers nor consumers and therefore require dedicated regulation.   In terms of hydrogen infrastructure and markets, the presumably cluster-like development of infrastructure could lead to local unregulated monopolies. The possibility to exert market power could prevent cheap access of consumers to hydrogen infrastructure and thus significantly slow down the transformation towards low-carbon industrial processes.  In particular non-discriminatory access to grids and infrastructure has to be guaranteed by the regulation.  We recommend a dedicated hydrogen grid on transmission level to deliver pure H2. On distribution level, blending of small quantities of hydrogen into gas grids might be possible as long as sensitive consumers are not located close to the injection point. However, the stability of the blending is of paramount importance, as already small fluctuations can severely harm industrial production processes even creating safety concerns. Furthermore, blending of H2 into natural gas infrastructure creates additional challenges and complexities regarding accounting and taxation.  The current tariffication system already provides a certain degree of cost-effectiveness and transparency. Any future changes should at a least match the current level. Reporting obligations to increase transparency are welcomed but the operational effort – and thus expense – to comply with reporting duties have to be adequate. Small customers should thus be exempt or obliged to a reduced set of reporting duties. In order to cover the expected demand of hydrogen, the generation needs to be technology neutral. This necessitates an international classification system of hydrogen relying on the respective CO2-footprint of the generation technology. Transparency for end-consumers regarding the generation technology has to be created by using guarantees of origin harmonized across the European Union.  Representing the German Industrial Energy Consumer, VIK is convinced that with prudent European regulation that applies years of experience of gas market development, hydrogen as an energy carrier will be able to support and accelerate the EU’s ambition to reach climate neutrality within the agreed timeline.
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: Bosch Thermotechnik GmbH welcomes the proposed European Commission review of the EU gas rules to facilitate the market entry of renewable and decarbonised gases.   The decarbonisation of both gaseous fuel and electrical energy carriers is vital for the decarbonisation of buildings. “Renewable and decarbonized” gases and electricity all have an essential role in achieving a carbon-neutral building stock by 2050. The focus in this initiative is on Gas but that does not ignore the significant contribution which will be made by Electricity.   Buildings are expected to remain the largest source of final energy consumption in Europe, with high demands on the coldest days of the year.   “Renewable and decarbonized” gases have a vital role particularly in the renovation and decarbonisation of existing buildings. Because these buildings are surprisingly hard to decarbonize and no single solution is optimal for all buildings.  We believe that the best opportunity of hitting our net-zero target is by using integrated technologies, all working together with the same goal whilst accepting that “one size does not suit all”.  Various technology solutions can effectively heat renovated homes whilst minimizing the disruption to homeowners. The solutions include decarbonised gas boilers, hybrids, and “gas and electric heat pumps”, and heat networks but this is not an exhaustive list. The important point is that consumers’ buy-in will be necessary if we are to achieve our goals  and the best way to do that is minimize disruption, be aware of the end-cost to the consumer, and give choice - not force change  In the EU scenarios towards a climate neutral 2050: the share of electricity in heating for residential buildings will be a maximum of 34% (In depth analysis in support of Commission Communication COM (2018) 773 and Impact Assessment for the 2030 climate target plan). The remaining space heating will need to be generated by non-electric renewable solutions.  Gas heating appliances and other domestic appliances installed in European buildings are able to work with biomethane, synthetic methane, and bioLPG. Today’s condensing technology allow for the use of up to 20% hydrogen. These solutions are applicable for new-build and renovation properties, whilst making use of existing energy infrastructure. The gas industry is developing a wide range of products that operate using 100% hydrogen, this includes manufacturers of heating and hot water appliances e.g. boilers, micro-cogeneration appliances, thermally-driven heat pumps, hybrids. In addition there are fuel cells on the market today that are capable of functioning with 100 % hydrogen.  A retained gas infrastructure as part of the integrated EU energy distribution system will be available to store, transport, and distribute renewable and decarbonised gases for heating, because it connects most buildings in the EU. Gas heating technologies are most common in our buildings: in 2017, gas boilers accounted for 70% of the installed stock of hydronic heaters in the EU. About 44 millions of these installed gas boilers are old and inefficient, and thus will need to be replaced by future-proof technologies, such as hydrogen ready boilers, hybrids, electric heat pumps, and thermally-driven heat pumps.   This supports and is compatible with the Renovation Wave, which aims at accelerating the replacement of the installed stock of old and inefficient heaters to achieve EU climate targets by 2030.  The advantages of energy storage in the form of “decarbonised” gases to support the stability of the energy supply include:  • Line packing of gas - by compressing the gas and therefore packing more molecules into the same space stores energy. This gives flexibility over the day as the demand changes. Within a day, the system is operationally balanced by the gas-grid operators by managing pressures and temporarily storing gas (as “line-pack”) in the system. feedback_msg_text: L’Uprigaz  s’interroge sur le fondement de la Commission considérant l’électrification des usages comme la solution la plus efficace pour la plupart des secteurs hormis pour le transport,  l’industrie et regrette l’absence d’évaluation prenant en compte le principe de neutralité technologique. L’Uprigaz demande à la Commission une évaluation des coût-bénéfices d’une électrification dans le secteur du bâtiment vs un mix équilibré entre l’électricité & le gaz reposant majoritairement sur des gaz renouvelables & décarbonés afin d’assurer la maîtrise des coûts & une transition vers une économie bas carbone dont les coûts sont acceptables par la collectivité. Cette analyse vise à déterminer l’équilibre du mix énergétique & une transition énergétique au moindre coût  L’avenir du gaz est crucial pour garantir la sécurité d’approvisionnement, apporter une flexibilité au système à moyen & long terme.  L’UPRIGAZ souligne à ce titre que l’Union européenne dispose de réseaux de transport & distribution de gaz naturel & d’installations de stockage réparties sur tout son territoire. Cette logistique gazière est déjà largement amortie et doit pouvoir accueillir du gaz renouvelable – biométhane et hydrogène –dans des proportions qui permettront aux secteurs «techniquement ou économiquement» dépendant du gaz de «décarboner» leurs activités dans des conditions économiques optimales.      Les règles de fonctionnement du marché intérieur du gaz naturel déjà mises en place par les textes communautaires, y compris par les codes de réseau, pourraient faire l’objet d’adaptations marginales, en particulier au niveau des tarifs d’injection et de soutirage sachant que ces gaz renouvelables sont essentiellement injectés et soutirés des réseaux de distribution et que leur développement, tout au moins dans la phase de maturité, devrait conduire à des tarifs adaptés.Les règles devront être adaptées afin de favoriser la pénétration des gaz renouvelables et/ou décarbonées.   Par ailleurs, l’UPRIGAZ appelle la Commission à fixer des règles d’harmonisation des garanties d’origine sur les gaz renouvelables délivrées par les Etats membres, et à encourager la création d’un marché européen de ces garanties d’origine, condition indispensable au verdissement du gaz conformément aux objectifs du Green Deal. Ce mécanisme des garanties d’origine valable sur l’ensemble du territoire de l’Union doit encourager la production de gaz renouvelables sur les territoires offrant les meilleures conditions économiques intrinsèques pour leur développement.   Le développement du biométhane doit être envisagé en priorité car il bénéficie de technologies éprouvées & d’absence de contraintes sur les entrants. Il participe à la fois aux objectifs d’économie circulaire que la Commission souhaite promouvoir et au verdissement du mix.L’exemple du développement de cette filière au Danemark témoigne de son intérêt dans l’ensemble de l’Union. Nous relevons d’ailleurs que la Californie s’est fixée un objectif de 20% de biométhane injecté dans les réseaux en 2025 avec un soutien aux raccordements   Les plans de relance européen, nationaux ont fixé parmi leur priorité le développement de l’hydrogène. Ces orientations devraient conduire à une baisse des couts de production de l’hydrogène et à son injection dans des réseaux dédiés mais aussi dans ceux transportant du gaz naturel et du biométhane. Ces 2 voies –réseaux dédiés & de transport et de distribution traditionnels– ne sont pas incompatibles et doivent toutes les deux être encouragées dès lors que MARCOGAS aura arrêté les spécifications techniques   L’Union européenne devrait mettre davantage l’accent sur la promotion des gaz renouvelables & bas carbone afin d’assurer un mix énergétique équilibré avec l’électricité. Cette stratégie qui donnerait une place au gaz renouvelable permettrait d’améliorer la résilience du système énergétique européen dans son ensemble et d'atteindre la neutralité carbone en 2050 au moindre cout pour le consommateur
Initiative: Gas networks - revision of EU rules on market access

feedback_msg_text: The CFE Energies, a french union federation of employees in the power and gas sectors, welcomes the European initiative for a public consultation on Hydrogen and Gas markets Decarbonisation Package. This reflects the European Union (EU) willingness to be the driving force of the international community in the fight against climate change. From the CFE Energies point of view, the EU has to play a key role in promoting and putting in place policy frameworks and legislative measures that will contribute towards the greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) reduction and reaching carbon neutrality by 2050. CFE Energies is convinced that clean hydrogen is a key driver for achieving deep decarbonisation in an affordable and effective manner through an integrated sectoral approach using both the electricity, gas and heat infrastructures, considering clean means carbon free and guided by low carbon technological neutrality. As a clean energy carrier, hydrogen represents an efficient solution for many areas such as transport, heating and energy-intensive industries as well.  While gaseous fuels will still represent 20 % of EU total energy consumption in 2050 from 22 % today, the gas infrastructures will be transporting decreasing quantities of natural gas, making way for increasing quantities of renewable and decarbonised gases. Hence, CFE Energies believes that clean hydrogen and gas integration provide an opportunity to reduce the carbon footprint and ease the energy transition towards a decarbonisation through the emergence of European industrial players providing then beneficial impacts on the economic and social stakes. We should keep in mind that gas infrastructures are offering a key role to promote hydrogen technologies through conversion of gas grids to hydrogen and renewable gas (biogas) as it can be achieved via central and decentralised actions. This combination (hydrogen and biogas) provide an efficient storage and flexibility solution to the European energy system. In that respect, CFE Energies recommends to work on legal and administrative barriers which hinder the injection of hydrogen into the gas grid. In that regard, a full assessment is essential to define the pricing principles covering connection fees/charges and remuneration for hydrogen supplied/injected and the acceptable safety and operational threshold of end-user appliances. Even if the production costs of renewable energies have significantly reduced, the level of investments in hydrogen infrastructure (electrolyser, storage, etc.) and the cost of electricity are such that renewable hydrogen production is not yet competitive. CFE Energies believes that some measures have to be implemented to accelerate the deployment of power to gas, to decarbonise the gas grid sector and facilitate hydrogen penetration in energy extensive industry. Since the hydrogen infrastructures are depreciated over a long-term period, mechanisms such as Feed-in-Tariffs should be investigated through call for biding in order to enable the take-off of renewable/low-carbon hydrogen and for promoting visibility, securing pay out time of any industrial investments while taking into account the challenges of competitiveness and purchasing power of end users. CFE Energies believes that Feed-in-Tariffs can be adjusted as long as cost of hydrogen infrastructures production decreases and CO2 prices evolve.  CFE Energies would like to stress that European gas infrastructure is well spread and placed to play the role of hydrogen and gas market decarbonisation. Today, with 2,2 million kilometers of gas pipelines and 1,200 TWh of underground storage capacity, these infrastructures represent a valuable and essential asset. feedback_msg_text: A takarmány adalékok - egyéb funkcionális alkotóelemekkel kombinálva - mindamellett, hogy jótékony hatással vannak az állatjólétre, nagyon fontos szerepet játszanak különösen a tápanyaghatékonyság, a takarmányfelhasználás környezeti hatásainak minimalizálása és az antimikrobiális kezelés mértékének csökkentése terén. A jelenlegi adalékanyag rendelet mára elérte határait és komoly frissítésre szorul annak érdekében, hogy hozzájáruljon az EU szántóföldtől az asztalig stratégiájában megfogalmazott célkitűzések eléréséhez (klímaváltozás, antimikrobiális rezisztencia csökkentése, tápanyaggazdálkodás).  Az álláspontunk szerint a következő szempontoknak kell prioritást élvezniük a rendelet felülvizsgálata során: - A generikus takarmányadalékok engedélyezésének biztosítása, különös tekintettel a technológiai és tápanyag adalékokra A helyzet kritikus a kisebb mennyiségű felhasználás és bizonyos funkcionális csoportok tekintetében, mint pl. az antioxidánsok, amelyekből csupán néhány maradt. Csökkenteni kell az engedélyezési/újra-engedélyezési eljárás magas költségeit és ösztönözni kell a kérelmek beadását, különben a kulcsfontosságú adalékok gyorsan elérhetetlenné válhatnak. - Az innováció ösztönzése olyan kulcsfontosságú területeken, mint az antimikrobiális kezelés szükségességének csökkentése, állatjólét, környezeti kibocsátás Még egyetlen adalékanyag sem lett engedélyezve ezeken a területeken, leginkább az értékelési eljárás kimenetelének kiszámíthatatlansága miatt. - A 3. országoktól való függőség csökkentése A termelési költségek közti különbség miatt az EU túlságosan ki van szolgáltatva Ázsiának, különösen néhány nélkülözhetetlen, elsősorban fermentációval előállított takarmányadalék terén.  Egyetértünk az EU Bizottság által a problémákról felállított diagnózissal és üdvözöljük a javasolt szakpolitikai opciókat és egyéb intézkedéseket, szem előtt tartva, hogy a legtöbb esetben a status quo fenntartása egyszerűen nem életképes.  Számos téma van azonban, amelyeket az EU Bizottság „a kezdeményezés által kezelendő problémaként” jelöl anélkül, hogy konkrét intézkedést/szakpolitikai javaslatot tenne: - Hatékonyság: csak abban az esetben szükséges, ha a hatékonyság hiánya károsan hathat az állati egészségre, az állatjólétre; - A címkézési követelmények modernizálása: a javaslatnak kifejezésre kell juttatnia, hogy a digitalizáció amellett, hogy csökkenti az adminisztrációs terheket, segíti a vásárlók, ill. az ellenőrző hatóságok információhoz jutását az adott termékről; - Bizonyos takarmányadalékok stratégiai státusza: meg kell fontolni, hogy a vitaminok (ahol a 3. országoktól való függőség megoldandó problémaként van jelölve) „stratégiai takarmányadalék” státuszt kapjanak.

feedback_msg_text: I am giving this feedback on behalf of Pen & Tec Consulting SLU, an SME based in Sapin, serving EU & international clients & supporting registration of feed additives, novel foods, food enzymes & food additives as well as biocides & natural crop enhancers. We believe that the EU feed additive registration process plays an important role in assuring safe & effective approval & use of feed additives, but there has to be a balance between data requirements, protection of investment & intellectual property, as well as other considerations, such as animal welfare. Hence:  PenTec supports reduction in safety testing on live animals & use of in vitro alternatives where possible. PenTec suggests more common sense approaches on certain safety testing, e.g. proteinaceous substances are likely to be sensitising in some individuals &, where there are practical difficulties to test in vitro (e.g. due to lack of solubility), then the substance can be listed on the SDS as “potential sensitiser”, without further in vivo testing. PenTec supports shorter label texts, with safety information supplied in the SDS (Safety Data Sheets). PenTec supports extended extrapolation of safety & efficacy across species, & from food to feed use. PenTec supports holder specific authorisations for all feed additives & protection of intellectual property of applicants, which will also strengthen post-market monitoring, & this consumer & environmental safety. Such protection will also encourage innovation from SMEs, who will be encouraged to invest in registration of feed addtives, & enjoy good protection of IP as a reward for their efforts & investment. PenTec supports use of CLP legislation to ensure user/worker safety for both feed additive preparations & premixtures, thus avoiding duplication of different areas of legislation. PenTec supports reduction of efficacy testing across all feed additives, to a single conclusive efficacy test (or metanalysis of 2 or more pooled efficacy studies).   Many thanks for the opportunity to give this feedback,  Kind regards, Dr Elinor McCartney President Pen & Tec Consulting SLU
Initiative: Animal nutrition - modernisation of EU rules on feed additives

feedback_msg_text: MSD Animal Health welcomes this opportunity given by the Commission to provide feedback on the Roadmap for animal nutrition and the aim of modernising EU rules on feed additives.  MSD AH would like to encourage the Commission to also pay attention to the benefits provided by other disease prevention tools such as vaccines, in particular for addressing diseases such as coccidiosis in poultry farms.   Vaccines and sustainability: Vaccines highly contribute to the sustainability of farming activities and animal health, allowing a low carbon footprint and meeting strict environmental standards. With the use of vaccines, there are no toxic materials released into the environment and no residues, in addition to preventing antimicrobials residues.  Vaccines and enhanced farm management: Vaccination allows a facilitated and optimised control of Coccidiosis in the farming sector. For instance, vaccination simplifies rotation programs, with either no rotation or a single winter rotation. Vaccination decreases the difficulties of managing coccidiosis rotation program and provides producers with the flexibility in coccidiosis control program.  Vaccines and animal welfare: Allowing less manipulation of the animals, vaccines are an efficient way to convey high animal welfare criteria towards the poultry farm. The animals are less stressed and protected from the diseases throughout their entire lifetime.   Healthier animals live longer, better with less stress generated for the farmer and better general farming conditions.  To conclude, while the Commission plans to review the existing rules on food additives by encouraging innovation in the livestock sector, MSD AH underlines the importance for the Commission to also support the vaccination given its efficacy and relevance in the fight against antimicrobial resistance, ensuring animal health, welfare and sustainable livestock farming.
Initiative: Animal nutrition - modernisation of EU rules on feed additives

feedback_msg_text: I am making this contribution on behalf of the Association of Veterinary Consultants (AVC), a not-for-profit organisation registered in France. The AVC are independent veterinarians, working in the areas of animal & human health/nutrition, & frequently involved in advising regulators, governments and the human/animal health industries. The AVC supports evidence-based science & the 3Rs (Reduce, Replace, & Refine use of live animals in testing, wherever possible). Hence:  AVC supports reduction in safety testing on live animals & use of in vitro alternatives where possible. AVC suggests more common sense approaches on certain safety testing, e.g. proteinaceous substances are likely to be sensitising in some individuals &, where there are practical difficulties to test in vitro (e.g. due to lack of solubility of test substances), then the substance can be listed on the SDS (Safety Data Sheet) as “potential sensitiser”, without further in vivo testing. AVC supports shorter label texts, with safety information supplied in the SDS. AVC supports extended extrapolation of safety & efficacy across species, & from food to feed use. AVC supports holder specific authorisations for all feed additives & improved protection of intellectual property of applicants, which also strengthens safety in use via post-market monitoring, whereby approval holders are directly responsible. AVC supports use of CLP legislation to ensure user/worker safety for both feed additive preparations & premixtures, thus avoiding duplication of different areas of legislation. AVC supports reduction of efficacy testing across all feed additives, to a single conclusive efficacy test (or metanalysis of 2 or more pooled efficacy studies). With regard to environmental health, the AVC supports a balanced view of ruminant farming in the EU. Ruminants are a valuable source of highly nutritious food products such as milk & meat, as well leather & wool. Europe has many hill and marginal grassland areas, ideal for more extensive ruminant farming, which help safeguard those environments and support rural economies. Feed additives can also help reduce methane emissions from farmed ruminants, thus contributing to environmental health & sustainability. A few examples are listed below:  https://www.dairyglobal.net/Nutrition/Articles/2020/10/5-dairy-nutritionist-approaches-to-reduce-methane-653471E/   https://www.allaboutfeed.net/Raw-Materials/Articles/2020/9/Interview-Jan-Dijkstra-on-using-feed-to-reduce-emissions-636137E/   https://www.allaboutfeed.net/Feed-Additives/Articles/2020/9/Interview-Startup-Volta-Greentech-on-reducing-methane-643640E/   Many thanks for the opportunity to contribute,  Kin regards, Dr Elinor McCartney President Association of Veterinary Consultants.
Initiative: Animal nutrition - modernisation of EU rules on feed additives

feedback_msg_text: The Dutch Dairy Association (Nederlandse Zuivel Organisatie, NZO) is an association of the Dutch dairy industry, representing the interests of thirteen dairy companies. They process milk into a wide range of dairy products: from beverages, infant formula and children’s food, cheese and desserts, to ingredients for the broader food industry and the pharmaceutical sector.  The NZO aims to reinforce its members’ abilities to produce and market their products. To reach this goal, NZO can be found in The Hague and in Brussels, and it also participates in public dialogue.  On order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and ammonia,  a growing  interest in the topic of zootechnical additives is to be expected. Producers will try to commercially market these products which  demonstrably reduce emissions of, for example,  methane and/or ammonia. This can also be commercially interesting for other chain parties.  The dairy chain is interested  in an ongoing renewal and the introduction of innovations, including additives. It is important that these innovations meet strict preconditions when introduced.with respect to.:  - Food safety, quality and processability of milk  - Animal health and well-being  - Effectiveness and integrality  - Ethical and social acceptance   Priority is the additive   should not have any (negative) impact on the quality and processability of the milk. Another priority is effectiveness and integrality in the sense that the environmental effects must be clear in such way that an objective judgement can be done. For example, an additive has a positive effect on methane, but negative effect on ammonia, the person who wants to use the additive can weigh the positive and negative effect of the additive.   In order to achieve this, the NZO requests passages in existing regulations to be supplemented.  Feedback from: NZO (77.1 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Animal nutrition - modernisation of EU rules on feed additives

feedback_msg_text: The European dairy industry welcomes the Commission's effort to review the Feed Additives Regulation (Regulation (EC) No 1831/2003), with the aim of modernising the legislation to adapt it to the goals of sustainable farming and improve its effectiveness and efficiency without compromising health and food safety.  However – whereas we can agree in principle that feed additives, jointly with other measures, may contribute to the EU’s sustainability goals – we see the need to put forward the following aspects for further consideration.   • Feed additives for the reduction of methane or mitigation of other sustainability issues related to dairy cattle are increasingly being developed. They constitute both one of the challenges and opportunities that the dairy sector is facing. We are in favour of faster, less costly, and cheaper procedures to get these new additives into the market that would be accessible for any company, including SMEs. • Smaller companies are facing large difficulties to get an additive approved by EFSA.   • Regarding milk production, it is topical to assure that great attention is paid to milk quality and milk composition in relation with feed additives, keeping in mind that the safety of a product is different from its quality but equally essential. • We would prefer that the claims will not be established under Regulation No 1831/2003 because companies need to be able to include also feed components/ingredients in the claims, and this could be problematic if the claims are established under the Feed Additives Regulation. We would rather support their inclusion in Regulation No 767/2009 on the placing on the market and use of feed.  • Attention must be paid to feed additives that are added to products for human consumption but are no longer fit for that purpose. Those products should/could be used as animal feed, but their uptake is limited because often they contain additives that may not have been approved for use in animal feed. A solution should be found to facilitate the use of such products. • We agree that requiring the compliance of animal feed produced for export with the EU legislation poses a trade barrier. In fact, if the use of an additive is not allowed (in a certain quantity) in Europe but the receiving country allows it, producing companies cannot export unless they have a signed authorisation of the receiving country.  • Finally, we would like to point out another issue that is often encountered by companies: there are too many exceptions on additives that need to be specifically approved for each species or animal husbandry category. There is a specific limit, for example, for the amount that can be fed to suckling calves compared with their mothers. All additives need to get approval for a specific animal category and then can be used for 5 to 10 years. All approvals are summarised in a catalogue of three books. The first book contains all the additives, the second all additives that will be removed from approval and the third catalogue contains all corrections to the two other catalogues. This makes a very complex legislation and results in a large administrative burden for companies.   In the context of the European Green Deal and Farm to Fork Strategy, EDA supports the EU’s ambition to take leadership at European and global level in the ongoing transition towards a more sustainable EU food system – including livestock farming – as long as it is coherent and fully out fledged to a true long-term solution. The dairy industry would then be very certainly committed to play its role and further strengthen its full engagement into the efforts made at all levels of the supply chain. feedback_msg_text: SUMMARY More efficient use of resources will be key in the EUs Circular Economy Action Plan. Animal feed and feed additive have an important role to play and have great potential in being part of the transition to a circular economy.   EasyMining fully supports strong safety requirements to prevent risks of pathogens and contaminations in animal feed and feed additives. However, today´s legislation and the proposed Roadmap fails to open the legislation for feed additives derived from manure, from municipal or industrial waste water, even after incineration at high temperature, intensive chemical processing and purification, which can guarantee safety. Irrespective of quality and safety, such chemicals are currently excluded from use in feed additives because Regulation 1831/2003 (Feed Additives) refers to 767/2009, which specifies this exclusion in Annex III. Exclusion of such recovered chemicals from animal feed applications is an unnecessary obstacle to the nutrient circular economy.  Our most important feedback on the proposed Roadmap:  • it does not address a modern holistic sustainable foundation and fails to be part of the transition to a circular economy and the challenges in EU´s circular Economy Action Plan. • it does not connect more efficient use of resource to the possibility to use recovered nutrients in the future animal feed and feed additive products. • it´s lacking a change of focus from excluding on origin to focusing on quality; i.e. a reused product that fulfils relevant quality and safety demands should be accepted as animal feed and feed additive products.   ABOUT US EasyMining is an innovation company dedicated to closing nutrient cycles. We are owned by the Swedish environmental company Ragn-Sells. EasyMining is passionate about inventing new technology that uses intelligent chemical solutions and our objective is to create new circular material flows in an efficient commercial way. feedback_msg_text: Victim Support Europe (VSE) is the leading European umbrella organisation advocating on behalf of all victims of crime, no matter what the crime, no matter who the victim is. VSE represents 61 member organisations, providing support and information services to more than 2 million people affected by crime every year in 30 countries.  Founded in 1990, VSE has been working for almost 30 years for a Europe, and a world, where all victims have strong victims’ rights and services, whether they report the crime or not. We work towards this mission through advocacy to improve European and international laws, through research and knowledge development and through capacity building at the national and local level.  VSE has increasingly developed specialist knowledge in the field of victims of terrorism. Following the Paris attacks in 2015, VSE carried out a range of activities to ensure that policies, laws and services at the national, European and international level meet the needs of victims of terrorism.  VSE established the Terrorism Response Network, that stands ready to assist in connecting victims to support services and provide expert advice in the aftermath of a terrorist attack. It has responded to all large-scale attacks in Europe and involving European citizens since 2015, including attacks in France, Germany, Spain, UK, Sweden, Finland, Russia, Turkey, USA, Bangladesh, New Zealand and Sri Lanka. Since January 2020, VSE is also leading the consortium that is executing the tasks of EU Centre of Expertise for Victims of Terrorism (EUCVT), which is run by the European Commission.   VSE continues to push for a coherent and specialised EU policy and legal framework for victims of terrorism. In this respect, VSE welcomes the Commission’s Strategy on victims’ rights, which duly recognises the vulnerability of victims of terrorism and the need to ensure the necessary support, protection and recognition of these victims, particularly in cross-border situations.    In the document enclosed, VSE raises in brief a number of issues that the Commission should take into account in undertaking the evaluation to assess the added value of the Combating Terrorism Directive, in particular on the level of protection and assistance provided to victims of terrorism.
