feedback_msg_text: L’AISBL Life4Brussels souhaite apporter des éclaircissements quant à la mise en œuvre des directives européennes en Belgique dont la directive 2017/54.  Le 22 mars 2016 en Belgique, il est 7h58 quand une explosion survient dans le hall des départs de Brussels Airport, à Zaventem. Elle est directement suivie d’une seconde explosion quelques mètres plus loin. À 9h10, une nouvelle explosion retentit dans la station de métro Maelbeek. Ces attaques, directement identifiées comme d’origine terroriste, ont mis la Belgique en état de siège.  Le bilan est lourd. Les lésions physiques sont semblables à des blessures de guerre. Les lésions psychologiques sont bien réelles et beaucoup de victimes ont développé des troubles liés à des symptômes d’état de stress post-traumatique (PTSD), aussi bien pour les victimes directes que pour les victimes indirectes. Bon nombre de victimes ont vu des choses horribles, des scènes de chaos, des morceaux de corps, des personnes éventrées, brûlées, mutilées… Les enfants présents sur les lieux n’ont pas été épargnés.  La Belgique a été ébranlée par ces attentats sans précédent. Il ne s’agissait pas du premier attentat commis en Belgique , ni même du dernier . Toutefois l’ampleur des attaques de Bruxelles, en termes de pertes humaines et de personnes blessées, était tel que les dirigeants ne pouvaient fermer les yeux, sur l’absence de cadre juridique. En d’autres termes, la souffrance des familles et les pertes humaines qui ont existé, avant le 22 mars 2016, n’avaient malheureusement pas suffi à inciter le pouvoir législatif à légiférer.  Ainsi, au lendemain du 22 mars 2016, le bilan s’élevait à 32 morts et des centaines de blessés. Il n’y avait pas de cadre juridique, rien n’était prévu pour répondre aux besoins et à l’indemnisation des victimes d’attentats. La plupart des victimes n’ont pas pu bénéficier d’un soutien psychologique adapté, que ce soit dans la phase aiguë ou sur le long terme.  La multitude des démarches qu’elles ont dû accomplir pour faire valoir leurs droits en termes de reconnaissance, de soutien ou d’indemnisation, était telle que beaucoup ont vécu une double victimisation, allant jusqu’à abandonner leurs droits.   La Belgique fut recalée au rang des plus mauvais élèves, puisqu’elle n’avait pas pleinement mis en œuvre les règles de l’UE relatives aux droits, au soutien et à la protection des victimes de la criminalité, mieux reprises dans la directive 2012/29/UE sur les droits des victimes .  Et pourtant, cette directive donne aux victimes des droits clairs en matière d’accès à l’information, de participation aux procédures pénales, de soutien et de protection adaptés à leurs besoins. Elle garantit également, aux victimes les plus vulnérables, de bénéficier d’une protection supplémentaire au cours de la procédure pénale.   Analysons ensemble certains droits reconnus aux victimes par la directive européenne, en vérifiant la mise en œuvre de ces droits pour les victimes d’attentats commis en Belgique.  1. Droit à l’information   L’article 4 de la directive 2012/29/UE énonce un principe général selon lequel « Les Etats membres veillent à ce que la victime reçoive, sans retard inutile et dès son premier contact avec une autorité compétente, les informations » utiles afin de faire valoir leurs droits.   Le point 30 du préambule de la directive 2017/541/UE dispose que « les États membres devraient veiller à ce que toutes les victimes du terrorisme aient accès aux informations sur les droits des victimes, les services d’aide disponibles et les mécanismes d’indemnisation dans l’État membre où l’infraction terroriste a été commise. Les États membres concernés devraient prendre les mesures appropriées pour faciliter la coopération entre eux afin de veiller à ce que les victimes du terrorisme qui résident dans un État membre autre que celui dans lequel l’infraction terroriste a été commise aient un accès effectif à ces informations... (voir suite dans le rapport en pièce jointe) Feedback from: AISBL Life for Brussels (413.5 KB - PDF - 11 pages) Download
Initiative: Combating terrorism – evaluation of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: Les entreprises européennes ayant des activités internationales sont de plus en plus exposées à des réglementations extraterritoriales ou des actes de coercition économique de la part de pays non-européens. Il en est ainsi notamment en matière de lutte contre la corruption, de régimes de sanctions internationales, de contrôle des exportations, de recherche de preuves digitales par les autorités judiciaires ou de régulation, ou d’accès intrusif aux données sensibles d’entreprises européennes. Ces mesures peuvent poursuivre des objectifs de politique étrangère ou des intérêts économiques non européens. Cette situation : - est source d’insécurité juridique et de vulnérabilité économique pour les entreprises européennes et crée des distorsions de concurrence et des contraintes à leur détriment. - est condamnable lorsqu’un État s’en sert unilatéralement et à des fins de levier sur la politique étrangère et de captation d’informations.  - est lourdement pénalisante puisque ces mesures induisent des impacts financiers majeurs et peuvent aboutir à déstabiliser la gouvernance des entreprises européennes.   Se donner les moyens de dissuader et, si nécessaire, de contrer les politiques et pratiques coercitives est indispensable du point de vue de l’autonomie stratégique européenne et de l’exigence d’une concurrence équitable. Les principales mesures qui nous paraissent aujourd’hui devoir être prises sont les suivantes :  ● un rapport détaillé devrait être réalisé par la Commission ou le Parlement européen afin de prendre l’exacte mesure du sujet :  transversalité, impact sur les entreprises et, partant, sur l’autonomie stratégique et économique européenne.  ● formation à bref délai d’une “cellule politique de Résilience européenne”, rattachée aux plus hautes autorités européennes, qui pourrait agir comme tour de contrôle, constater les risques ou les actions coercitives au travers de l’ensemble des domaines concernés et au regard des spécificités de chaque écosystème (tel l'aérospatial et la défense), identifier les moyens de dissuasion ou de rétorsion possibles, également de manière transverse,  et le cas échéant permettre de mieux coordonner l’action des différentes directions générales et services de la Commission. Cette cellule pourrait agir comme interlocuteur privilégié vis-à-vis d’autorités étrangères en complément des administrations étatiques et d’assister les entreprises européennes faisant face à des pressions ou actions de coercition. ● adoption d’un instrument de défense commerciale approprié : l’Union européenne doit être en mesure d’adopter des actions dissuasives et, le cas échéant, correctives permettant de rétablir un équilibre des forces et de trouver une issue positive et négociée aux situations de coercition.   ● que ce soit par voie digitale (Cloud act) ou dans le cadre d’enquêtes ou de procédures judiciaires et administratives, les données les plus sensibles des entreprises européennes peuvent se trouver exposées. Il convient de mettre en place les outils qui permettraient de répondre à ce risque sans pour autant faire obstacle aux échanges économiques ou entraver la capacité des entreprises européennes à mener à bien leurs actions juridiques offensives ou défensives.      ● S’agissant du secteur aérospatial et défense, une attention particulière devra être prêtée aux règles de contrôle des exportations non européennes, qui peuvent constituer un moyen de pression ou de coercition très intrusif.        ● Le réglement de blocage européen N° 2271/96 (sanctions internationales extraterritoriales) doit être révisé. En particulier, les entreprises européennes devront être protégées et non pas placées au coeur du conflit entre les règles européennes et non-européennes, et ce d’autant que la Chine vient de se doter d’une législation comparable.  Ces mesures devront bien entendu s’appuyer sur un examen juridique des moyens à la disposition de l’Union européenne en droit international.  Feedback from: GIFAS (138.9 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Trade – mechanism to deter & counteract coercive action by non-EU countries

feedback_msg_text: Bonjour,  Merci de nous donner l'opportunité de donner notre feedback concernant ce sujet. On rencontre plusieurs cas de figure: - Chine: les négociations concernant les dossiers qui nous importent (ouverture du marché pour la viande bovine et levée de l'embargo sur la peste porcine africaine pour la viande porcine) sont visiblement bloquées par des négociations sur d'autres sujet (notamment des dossiers technologiques comme la 5G). La Chine utilise donc les négociations sur les dossiers agricoles comme levier pour les négociations sur d'autres matières. - Régionalisation: de nombreux pays, notamment asiatiques ne reconnaissant pas la régionalisation. Soit pas du tout (Japon, Corée du Sud, Chine,...), soit pas de la manière dont le présente la Commission Européenne (Vietnam, Malaisie, ...). Pourtant la régionalisation fait partie de nombreux FTA. De même, concernant le dossier peste porcine Africaine, la Belgique a été reconnue indemne par l'OIE en décembre dernier et de nombreux pays comme la Japon ou la Corée du Sud n'ont toujours pas levé leur embargo. - Lenteurs administratives: certains pays mettent énormément de temps à répondre aux demandes de nos autorités. Dans certains cas nous avons l'impression que ces lenteurs sont cependant volontaires et relèvent plus de mesures protectionnistes que du manque de personnes pour traiter les dossiers. L' un des exemples est l'ouverture du marche pour l'exportation de viande bovine   Bien à vous
Initiative: Trade – mechanism to deter & counteract coercive action by non-EU countries

feedback_msg_text: La digitalisation au service de coopérations résilientes, durables et équilibrées entre « smart urban et smart rural territories » RED (www.ruraleurope.org), association internationale créée en 1980, milite depuis 2015 (avec le soutien des organisations du Mouvement Européen de la Ruralité), en faveur d’un Agenda Rural Européen, en écho à l’Agenda Urbain Européen, pour dynamiser des coopérations intelligentes  entre des territoires ruraux et urbains qui se reconnaissent mutuellement en pôles de développement innovants.  Le recours à des processus de développement territorial intégré, avec en référence l’approche CLLD, ainsi que la reconnaissance des territoires ruraux en pôles de développement et d’innovation, tel que le promeut RED, sont en cela essentiels. C’est aussi ce qu’exprime la définition de « Smart village »* validée dans le cadre de l’étude européenne « Smart eco-social villages » initiée par la DG AGRI, menée par Ecorys, RED, et le Forum Origines, Diversité et Territoires.  Préconisations de RED  Accroître la connectivité au très haut débit internet et miser sur des smartvillages/Smart rural territories pour : - Accompagner l’amplification du télétravail dans les territoires ruraux, enjeux alimentaires en circuits courts… (Constat confinement Covid 19) - Favoriser de nouvelles méthodes de gouvernance et de coopération dans les territoires ruraux et entre territoires urbains et ruraux - Dynamiser la multifonctionnalité économique et énergétique (Mix énergétiques ..), la mobilité durable et les services publics, grâce à l’innovation digitale et sociale ; - Optimiser et renforcer l’investissement dans le capital humain et les capacités collectives par l’éducation et des programmes de formations accessibles tout le long de la vie   En nécessités : Le renforcement des coopérations transfrontalières, la réintroduction du FEADER dans le cadre stratégique commun, l’inscription, dans la politique de cohésion, d’une réserve minimale de 5% pour le développement territorial intégré des territoires ruraux; RED appelle à les inscrire dans le plan de relance et dans les corpus politique et réglementaire «2021-2027de l’UE  *Définition de Smart Village: « Les Villages Intelligents sont des communautés en zones rurales qui utilisent des solutions innovantes pour améliorer leur résilience, en tirant parti des forces et des opportunités locales. Ils s’appuient sur une approche participative pour élaborer et mettre en œuvre une stratégie d’amélioration de leurs conditions économiques, sociales et/ou environnementales, en mobilisant notamment les solutions offertes par les technologies numériques. Les Villages Intelligents bénéficient de la coopération et des alliances avec d’autres communautés et acteurs des zones rurales et urbaines. Le lancement et la mise en œuvre des stratégies des Villages Intelligents peuvent s’appuyer sur les initiatives existantes et être financés par diverses sources publiques et privées. »

feedback_msg_text: Colt Technology Services owns and operates fibre networks in nearly all EU Member States, and Fibre-to-the-Office networks in 13 EU Member States (https://www.colt.net/colt-network-map).  We agree with the Commission that the Broadband Cost Reduction Directive has not met expectations, notably by failing to materially improve permit granting procedures to construct infrastructure in Member States (Art. 7). It has also created legal uncertainty about access obligations to infrastructure for all parties involved (Art. 3&4), be they owners of infrastructure, access seekers, or both (as is our case). In addition, the Directive stands separate from the European Electronic Communications Code (EECC), which would logically be the text consolidating all rights and obligations applicable to electronic communications network operators.  The Directive should be refocused on the imposition of obligations on public authorities, making these more binding and precise. Obligations on providers of electronic communications networks should be removed from the Directive.  We formulate specific suggestions as follows: - Art. 3&4 (access to existing physical infrastructure and transparency) should be removed from the Directive, given that EECC Art. 72 (access to civil engineering) & 73 (access to specific physical network elements) already cover access to electronic communications civil infrastructure (ducts, poles, hand/manholes, etc.) and the wires of electronic communications network operators designated as having Significant Market Power. These are the entities that control by far the most relevant infrastructure (type of infrastructure + geographic extent). Utility infrastructure is not usually suitable for broadband networks (for instance, there are significant differences in timescales for roll-out, connection of premises, maintenance and repair processes, need for electricity, etc. compared to transport/gas/water/electric networks). Experience with Art. 3&4 shows that practical cases of application are rare, and that regulatory authorities have had to improvise to settle disputes, with widely differing results across Member States. Over the past 5+ years, we, Colt Technology Services have only once considered relying on the provisions of the Directive to gain access to city-owned infrastructure. We concluded that the set of rules in the Member State concerned was de-facto impracticable. We are available to provide further details.   - Art 5&6 (coordination of civil works and transparency) are relevant, but there is a need to differentiate between: (i) the procedures for wide-ranging network roll-outs in a geographic area (fibering-up areas) and, (ii) punctual connection of customers, e.g. office buildings, data centres, factories, hospitals, mobile base stations, etc. Administrative burdens need to be minimised, especially to avoid delays for customers which need fibre connectivity immediately. - Art. 7 (permit granting procedure) should be further elaborated to require a single harmonised minimum standard for administrative procedures relating to town and country planning, with unequivocal deadlines explicitly applicable to each step of all administrative processes (no tolerance for compounding delays). All steps should be entirely digitally administered (including mapping), irrespective of the type and size of the public authority. Common standards, including for the IT interfaces of digital administration processes, should be put in place, to work efficiently (reduce IT process burdens on authorities and on the companies that build fibre networks and that have to maintain uninterrupted connectivity). - Art. 8&9 (in-building infrastructure and related transparency) are clearly relevant, and can be enhanced by explicitly requiring fibre cabling. The transition to sustainable network deployment and operation, greening the ICT sector, and achieving a climate-neutral EU by 2050, is best ensured by explicitly focusing on end-to-end fibre net.
Initiative: High-speed broadband in the EU – review of rules

feedback_msg_text: Aludec S.A. como Empresa usuaria de productos químicos quiere valorar de manera muy positiva la propuesta de revisión de la regulación del REACH. Valoramos y apoyamos cualquier iniciativa proveniente de la Unión Europea en la búsqueda de una mejor protección de la salud de los ciudadanos europeos así como la protección del medio ambiente.  Consideramos que los objetivos planteados para la revisión propuesta son del todo acertadas, de manera que la aportación de claridad, simplificación de trámites, mayor conocimiento de los químicos usados, etc, pero no se puede perder la perspectiva actual del uso y de las medidas que se establecen para el mismo por parte de las Empresas usuarias de dichos productos químicos. Por este motivo, desde el grupo Aludec se considera que cualquier medida que se pueda adoptar en la línea de simplificación burocrática, incremento de la información útil y el flujo de la misma o los procesos de resticción del uso de los químicos no puede perder de vista los siguientes aspectos de suma importancia:  1. Cualquier reforma en el uso o restricción de los productos químicos debe estar basado en evidencias técnicas o científicas. Cualquier valoración genérica o que se base en suposiciones lejanas al uso práctico real de los químicos, puede llevar a una incorrecta valoración de su peligrosidad en los aspectos que se están planteando. 2. Las mejoras que se puedan plantear en términos de comunicación o flujo de información deben ir enfocadas desde un punto de vista también práctico y basadas en la experiencia que tenemos hasta la fecha en el uso de los productos químicos. Cualquier propuesta que se pueda hacer al respecto deber tener en cuenta el uso final que se da a dicha información por parte de los usuarios. 3. Las propuestas de cambio de productos químicos por otros que se consideren con impacto cero en los aspectos de seguridad a la salud y medioambiental, deben tener en cuenta también los procesos productivos de los que surjan dichas alternativas.  4. Antes de restringir el uso de un producto químico, es necesario evaluar si existen alternativas a dichos productos. Las consecuencias pueden ser catastróficas a nivel empleo, industria y competitividad si no existen alternativas suficientemente probadas o si simplemente hacen perder competitividad a las empresas. Cualquier decisión debería apoyarse en organismos técnicos cualificados como la ECHA contemplando los diferentes aspectos antes mencionados: Impacto en el empleo, calidad de los productos producidos con las alternativas, competitividad con la nueva alternativa y las medidas preventivas de las empresas durante el uso de los químicos a restringir 5. Es fundamental una harmonización a nivel europeo de las diferentes legislaciones y el apoyo económico de las instituciones. El coste de la búsqueda de alternativas no debería recaer en las Empresas y todos los países dentro de la Unión Europea deberían competir en las mismas condiciones. 6. Ningún sentido tiene ampliar restricciones en el uso de los diferentes químicos a nivel europeo si las alternativas a contemplar son la importación de productos de fuera de la Unión Europea. Dentro de este aspecto es fundamental basarse en los procesos productivos de los productos a importar. De nada sirve un Pacto Verde Europeo si deriva en el uso de químicos prohibidos en la Unión en países no pertenecientes a la Unión Europea. 7. Por último y aunque ya se ha mencionado antes, es fundamental que cualquier evaluación de riesgo de uso de un producto químico vaya de la mano de una evaluación de impacto económico y de competitividad de las empresas. Incremento de tasas, burocracia, etc van en una línea diferente y sus consecuencias pueden ser muy negativas para las empresas y el empleo. No podemos dejar de mencionar que tras la época vivida durante estos años 2020 y 2021, la industria juega un papel fundamental en la recuperación económica y social de la Unión Europa. feedback_msg_text: EDC-Free Europe coalition welcomes the EC plans for the revision of REACH so that the Regulation fully delivers on its objectives to ensure a high level of protection for human health & the environment, and on the commitments of the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability (CSS).   Inadequate control of endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) under REACH is one of the crucial areas of concerns. The multiple adverse health outcomes linked to exposure to EDCs have huge economic & social costs (see results of The EU Horizon 2020 EDC-MixRisk project) The health costs of exposure to EDCs are estimated to be at least 163 billion Euros per year in Europe.   We are concerned that the plan outlined in the Inception Impact Assessment (IIA) seems to be turning some commitments from the CSS into mere options, or even totally overlooking some of them. This is the case in particular with the option envisaging to remove the “Authorisation title”. This would remove the current provisions on Substances of Very High Concern (SVHC) while the CSS presented plans to extend the hazards covered by SVHC status: “introduce endocrine disruptors, persistent, mobile and toxic and very persistent and very mobile substances as categories of substances of very high concern”.  We stress the importance of replacing the substance by substance approach by a group approach to regulate related chemicals and avoid regrettable substitution. It is urgent to draw lessons from cases such as bisphenols (see report CHEM Trust report “From BPA to BPZ: a toxic soup?”). The proposal for the extension of the Generic Risk Assessment (GRA) approach is key, as this is proven to be a faster and more protective approach. The GRA approach should be expanded to cover the following hazard classes: EDCs, PBT/vPvB chemicals, and also PMT and vPvM chemicals.   Introduction of a generic mixture assessment factor (MAF) must be given high priority in the revision. It is essential to reflect in assessments the reality of our multiple exposure to chemicals, from the prenatal stage onwards (see results from EU research projects like HBM4EU, EDCMixRisk, or SOLUTIONS). EDCMixRisk has demonstrated that prenatal exposure to mixtures of EDCs was associated with numerous effects in children’s health and development & current regulations systematically underestimate health risks associated with combined exposures to EDCs or potential EDCs. This must also be complemented by the other important commitment of the CSS to “introduce or reinforce provisions to take account of the combination effects in other relevant legislation”.   As presented in the “Problem definition” of the IIA for the Revision of the registration requirements, current information requirements do not allow a sufficiently thorough hazard assessment, including for carcinogenicity, neurotoxicity, immunotoxicity and endocrine disruption. The updating of REACH annexes on information requirements must address the huge gap for endocrine disruption endpoints & data requirements. In addition, the new proposals must be linked very clearly to the CLP revision and new hazard classes so that sufficient data are available to make the hazard identification possible.   In conclusion, the CSS laid out clear commitments to up grade REACH in order for the Regulation to finally fully deliver on its objectives of health & environment protection against harmful chemicals, including EDCs. As indicated in recent EU Barometers survey & petitions, the expectations from EU citizens to live in a toxic free environment are very high and will most likely continue to increase. This revision of REACH is a critical opportunity for the EU to fix well known deficiencies in this cornerstone Regulation & finally deliver on its commitment for a high level of health and environment protection.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Vielen Dank für die Möglichkeit, Vorschläge zur Verbesserung von REACH zu machen. GLOBAL 2000, die österreichische Umweltschutzorganisation, sieht folgende Verbesserungsmöglichkeiten für REACH:  Artikel 33 sollte überarbeitet werden:  - Unternehmen müssen KonsumentInnen-Anfragen IMMER beantworten, auch wenn KEIN SVHC enthalten ist (sonst weiß KonsumentIn nicht, ob Unternehmen einfach nicht geantwortet hat, ob Anfrage verloren gegangen ist etc.) - Frist von 45 Tagen muss verkürzt werden. Unternehmen sollten Information über SVHCs sowieso vorliegen haben, daher sollten sie auch schneller, in einer konsumenten-freundlichen Frist antworten können (max. 30 Tage). - online Handel genauer definieren und online Händel müssen genauso alle REACH Vorgaben erfüllen wie "normale" Händler (zB sind online Verkaufs-Plattformen wie Amazon oder WISH angeblich nicht verpflichtet, Artikel 33 Anfragen zu beantworten! Woher sollen KonsumentInnen dann diese Information bekommen, und warum muss ein Verkäufer wie WISH oder AMAZON, der sogar Marken-eigene Produkte (zB ALEXA etc.) verkauft, diese Informationen nicht zur Verfügung stellen?) Artikel 33 Informationen müssen auch von online Händlern/Verkaufsplattformen erfüllt und zur Verfügung gestellt werden.  Bei Vorhandensein von SVHCs in Erzeugnissen sollten diese am Erzeugnis deklariert werden müssen, so wie Inhaltsstoffe bei Kosmetika oder Lebensmittel. Es widerspricht dem Vorsorgeprinzip, dass KonsumentInnen für jedes Produkt/Erzeugnis, das sie kaufen wollen, erst beim Hersteller/Verkäufer anfragen müssen, ob ein SVHC enthalten ist, und SVHCs sind ja bekanntermaßen ERWIESENERMASSEN besorgniserregend, daher sollte diese Info immer für KonsumentInnen verfügbar sein.  Gruppen-Ansatz bei Bewertungen forcieren (Substanzen einer Gruppe als ganze Gruppe regulieren, zB PFAS, aber auch Bisphenole etc.), um regrettable substitutions zu reduzieren.  Faktor für "mixture toxicity" bei Bewertung einführen (Mensch und Umwelt kommen immer mit Gemischen von Substanzen in Kontakt, daher ist der 1-Substanz/1-Höchstwert-Ansatz realitätsfremd.  Es sollten SVHC Kategorien für folgende Substanzen eingeführt werden:  - hormonell wirksame Substanzen - persistente, mobile und toxische Substanzen (PMT) - sehr persistente und sehr mobile Substanzen (vPvM) - Immuntoxische Substanzen - Neurotoxische Substanzen Wenn Substanzen unter CLP in Kategorien klassifiziert werden, die bestehenden SVHC-Kategorien entsprechen, sollten diese Substanzen automatisch als SVHC identifiziert/klassifiziert werden.  Entscheidungen und Abstimmungen im REACH Kommittee, inklusive das Abstimmungsverhalten der MS, sollten öffentlich einsichtlich sein.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Cruelty Free Europe sees the revision of REACH as an opportunity to move towards a modern EU regulatory system for chemicals based on non-animal methods. This would end the suffering of millions of animals and address citizens’ concerns while providing better information on chemicals for human health and the environment.  Cruelty Free Europe would raise the following points on the inception impact assessment:  1 ) Problem definition  The Commission's initial problem definition overlooks the limited uptake of non-animal testing methods and lack of compliance with the requirement to use animal testing only as a last resort in REACH, despite the fact that we are now approaching the ‘worst case’ scenario estimated in the initial the impact assessment on REACH 12 years ago (see attachment). The problem definition should be updated to include these aspects and that animal tests very often are unreliable, highly variable and provide little hazard information of relevance to humans (see attachment).  This would be in line with art. 13 TFEU, stipulating that full regard should be paid to animal welfare when formulating and implementing policies. It would also make the REACH revision consistent with Directive 2010/63/EU’s final goal of full replacement of procedures on live animals for scientific and educational purposes. Furthermore, EU citizens do not support animal tests (see attachment).  2 ) Objectives and policy options  Non-animal data generation, effective data sharing, use of existing data and read-across within groups of similar substances are important ‘alternatives’ that should be maximally used. However, the upcoming changes to REACH look set to massively increase the number of animals used (see attachment). The legislative changes arising from the REACH Revision are an opportunity to improve the quality of the information on the hazards posed by chemicals by the use of non-animal methods. It is also an opportunity to move away from the current ‘checklist approach’ based on in vivo test guidelines (see conclusion of EURL ECVAM 2020 report).   Non-animal methods are constantly evolving, and a policy option should be to introduce new mechanisms in REACH which promote their fullest integration to ensure that highest quality data is available to realise the objectives of the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability. 3) Preliminary assessment of expected impacts The preliminary assessment of impacts does not include potential increases in animal testing as a result of the policy options outlined.  This is despite the Environment Commissioner confirming in the reply to a parliamentary question (E-001215/2021) that the impact on animal testing will be considered in the REACH Revision.   It is vital that the full impact assessments (IA) for all relevant actions include the impact on animal testing as both a societal and an economic impact. Importantly, this should include an assessment of the most effective scenarios to reduce and replace animal testing whilst satisfying the objectives of the REACH Revision.  Estimates should be made for each proposed change to REACH, so it is clear which option will have the lowest impact on animals. For instance, the implications in terms of numbers of animals used in tests should be counted for each policy option -as a societal impact- as well as the cost of these tests- as an economic impact.  The IA must include the likely impact on the use and promotion of non-animal methods in the future, not just estimate their likely use now. 4 ) Evidence base The studies planned for 2021-2022 to support the development of options for REACH changes and the forthcoming impact assessments must feature analysis of animal testing implications in the near and long-term, in particular for the studies relating to Endocrine Disruptors; Mixture Assessment Factor; increased hazard information requirements; use and exposure; DMELs for non-threshold substances; and extended use of generic risk approach. feedback_msg_text: The 23 organisations forming this Coalition share a view on how the essential use concept (EUC) can be introduced in a way that will tackle actual risks and not slow down the regulatory process or lead to unintended, regrettable substitution.  The introduction of the EUC poses important challenges regarding its application to REACH as the approach described in the CSS fundamentally contrasts with the risk-based approach that characterises REACH.  Reducing the use of substances based only on their hazard profile without accounting for the risk and exposure would impact consumers and industry, while hindering the ability of the EU to meet its policy objectives (including those of the Green Deal). The suggested broad application of the EUC could for instance:  1) trigger unfortunate bans which would not deliver benefits to consumers or to society. This would, for instance, be the case for stainless steel in kitchen appliances and in construction materials.  2) impact industry competitiveness as it would reduce the availability of the technological toolkit for EU manufacturers and innovators leading to reduced performance of EU-manufactured products and hindering innovation.  3) impact EU regulatory objectives such as the EU’s GHG reduction ambitions or the transition to a circular economy. If the EUC were to be applied in a non-targeted fashion to all substances with certain hazard classifications, it would lead to regrettable substitutions and to an unmanageable need to review the essentiality of countless uses:  a. If the EUC were to be automatically applied on the basis of hazard classifications, it would lead to the substitution of products either considered beneficial or even ‘essential’ for consumers and professionals, for less sustainable and durable materials. The market would be pushed towards using alternatives that — taking into account, for example, the CO2 emissions during their life-cycle or their lack of recyclability — may be less sustainable. This would have a potentially serious impact on the EU’s capacity to meet its climate change ambitions.  b. The wide application of the EUC to all substances with certain hazardous properties, confirmed by a case-by-case assessment, would inevitably lead to the need for an assessment of the different uses of all these substances. The impact of this on the regulatory process and its length should not be underestimated.  We encourage the EC and Member States to carefully consider the scope of applicability of the EUC. The assessment should not be limited to a pure chemicals management perspective, but needs to be better integrated with other policy objectives (including in the frame of the Green Deal) and must consider the risk of negative trade-offs. The EUC should not be automatically linked to hazard classifications, but rather be applied in a targeted manner, i.e. where uses of a hazardous substance present an unacceptable risk that cannot be addressed by other risk management options. Those other options could, for example, be targeted restrictions/authorisations covering those uses which lead to an unacceptable risk. Restrictions, for example, could either regulate such uses more strictly (e.g. by setting protective release limits for articles and ensuring the safe disposal / recycling of these articles) or they could, if necessary, ban specific uses, the safety of which cannot be appropriately ensured. These targeted restrictions would spare other safe uses of substances and ensure proportionality of decision making. The burdensome essentiality assessment would only be triggered where justified. In this context, we encourage authorities to consider the role of RMOAs in the development of the EUC. RMOAs appear to be the ideal tool to identify the most suitable risk management option, including those cases where the ban except for all essential uses appears to be justified. feedback_msg_text: Como usuarios intermedios de productos químicos, queremos valorar de manera positiva la iniciativa de revisión de REACH. Consideramos que si se cumplen los objetivos planteados, se produciría una mejora en la salud de trabajadores y usuarios de productos químicos y del medio ambiente en general. Medidas como ampliar conocimiento de sustancias puestas en el mercado, información sobre medidas de protección a usuarios, mejorar la claridad de los requerimientos así como la simplificación de los trámites, son del todo aspectos positivos para nosotros. No obstante debemos remarcar algunos puntos con los que estamos en desacuerdo, los cuales argumentamos, para que sean tenidos en consideración: 1.- En los cambios introducidos  en REACH, se incluye un mayor control de productos químicos importados, de cara a proteger a los usuarios. Sin embargo, no se contempla un control de la importación de productos fabricados, en condiciones inseguras, tanto a nivel laboral  como ambiental. Si los requisitos exigidos por ECHA, solo se trasladan a Europa, muchas empresas tendrán que cerrar por no poder afrontar de manera inmediata esos requisitos, trasladándose los procesos productivos, bien por empresas europeas, bien por empresas extranjeras, a países donde los requisitos son laxos y tanto los trabajadores como el medio ambiente, quedarían desprotegidos. Europa tiene una estricta normativa ambiental y laboral que ya están cumpliendo las empresas. ¿Cómo debemos entenderlo?, los ciudadanos europeos si tienen que protegerse, ¿pero los no europeos no? 2.- Todos estamos de acuerdo con el beneficio que supone la sustitución de productos peligrosos para el medio ambiente o la salud humana, por otros que no lo sean, pero es necesario asegurarse de la viabilidad del cambio. ¿y si no se dispone de alternativa? ¿No se debería permitir trabajar a las empresas, hasta disponer de una alternativa viable? Las empresas son las principales interesadas en cuidar a sus trabajadores y al medio ambiente, por lo que aplicarán todos los requisitos necesarios. La alternativa que ofrece REACH lleva al cierre de las empresas, por no poder disponer de un proceso productivo efectivo. Volvemos a la conclusión anterior, producir en países sin restricciones, con las consecuencias que esto supone (ciudadanos no europeos en riesgo, daños al medio ambiente y una economía europea perjudicada. 3.- En lo que respecta al incremento de tasas, y su repercusión a las empresas. Se trata de un tema de salud global, por lo que la administración debe ser una parte esencial. Las empresas deben invertir en investigar como su proceso productivo puede ser cada día más humana y ambientalmente seguro. 4.- ECHA debería tener en cuenta que muchas empresas, especialmente PYMES, tienen que realizar una importante inversión, para seguir utilizando Cromo hexavalente, inversión que realizarán con la incertidumbre de no conocer el tiempo que podrán mantener su proceso. 5.- Finalmente reiterar que las empresas europeas cumplen estrictamente la legislación en materia de seguridad laboral y medio ambiente, por lo que no permitir utilizar cromo hexavalente en EUROPA, para que el proceso se traslade a países que no presentan garantías en este sentido, no tiene ninguna lógica. Pareciera que estamos  hablando de países de primera y de segunda.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: La volontà di proteggere e salvaguardare la salute delle persone e l’ambiente in cui viviamo non può che essere un obiettivo condivisibile da parte di chiunque abbia buon senso. Percepiamo tuttavia che i variegati meccanismi contenuti nei regolamenti europei, tesi a generalizzare, diano spesso luogo ad interpretazioni, e non tengano sufficientemente conto delle specificità e necessità operative di molti settori, specialmente per quanto riguarda piccole realtà. Rimaniamo sempre perplessi di fronte al "discutibile" concetto di basare strategie ed azioni da intraprendere in ambito di sostanze chimiche, valutandone il "pericolo" come elemento cardine, senza fare considerazioni sul "rischio", che invece dovrebbe essere l'elemento dominante della valutazione. Non tenere in considerazione quantitativi nonché utilizzi/pratiche e quindi una corretta "valutazione del rischio", riteniamo sia un approccio semplicistico e penalizzante per la chimica europea, per di più non crediamo che l'approccio attuale, basato sul concetto di "pericolo", porti vantaggi in termini di "sicurezza" oggettiva, visto che le sostanze incriminate spesso vengono impiegate fuori dall'Europa ed entrano nel territorio europeo sotto altra forma, ad es. negli articoli. Un altro aspetto più volte sollevato, soprattutto dalle PMI, riguarda la gestione dei SIEF, lasciati ad una sorta di autoregolamentazione sulla base del rispetto di criteri di trasparenza e non discriminazione. Ma chi controlla? I SIEF, con in capo: la gestione dei dati, la valorizzazione degli stessi, la scelta dei criteri di suddivisione dei costi, ecc. sono un aspetto fondamentale per la virtuosa attuazione del Reach, sia in termini “pratici” che “filosofici” per la buona attuazione dello spirito del Reach. A nostro giudizio sarebbe opportuno ri-valutare criticamente il sistema dei SIEF, in modo evidenziarne le criticità ed intervenire con una regolamentazione opportuna.

feedback_msg_text: PRODAROM member of IFRA welcomes the opportunity to comment on the EU Commission Inception Impact Assessment on REACH. Full comments are available in the IFRA response. The revision of the REACH regulation should be targeted and science based. The Commission should seek to build on the current solid and existing framework to make it more efficient, consistent and streamlined. Consistency in policy and regulatory stability are essential for innovation. When considering changes to the current regulatory framework, the possible impact on predictability, legal certainty and long-term investment must be considered. The fragrance industry invests around 8% of its net sales in R&D to provide differentiation through technology, understanding consumer trends and sustainable products. Innovative solutions and sustainable chemistry are vital to achieve a climate neutral, circular, safer, cleaner, and strategically autonomous Europe. The Mixture Assessment Factor should be targeted, rather than applying a generic one-size-fits-all approach. Scenario-specific factors or more refined methodologies based on scientific knowledge should take precedence over a generic/default approach. Fragrances are essential for our well-being, health, and hygiene as they are key elements of everyday products such as hand sanitizers, surface cleaners, anti-bacterial detergents as well as perfumes, Eau de Toilette and Eau de Cologne. The concept of essential use in the Strategy is vague and a concerning topic. The Montreal Protocol’s definition of essential use is very restrictive and not fit for purpose to be applied to all chemical products. If non-essentiality is retained as a concept, it should only be a supporting criterion based on scientific assessment, associated with a given use and backed up with a socio-economic impact analysis. IFRA would offer to work with the Commission to develop a definition of essential use as well as developing criteria to grant derogations for certain substances. The reform of the REACH authorisation and restriction processes should establish a transparent procedure to ensure that the best and most efficient risk management option can be chosen. A reasonable balance between scientific integrity and workable regulatory approaches should be maintained. The fragrance industry is concerned about the potential ban of entire groups of substances irrespective of the individual chemical risk and exposure. For more than 40 years, IFRA has carefully examined the safe use of fragrance ingredients and established the IFRA Standards based on a continuously refined risk assessment approach for fragrance ingredients. The Standards, which ban, restrict, or set criteria for the use of certain ingredients, are mandatory for all IFRA members and set the boundaries for fragrance creation. Introduction of new information requirements (IR) for substances at lower tonnages should be adequately justified and bring added value compared to the existing requirements. Most substances used in the fragrance industry are of low to very low tonnage, many of them being natural complex substances (NCS). More than 50% of the registered fragrance substances are within the 1 to 10 tonnage band and for NCSs, more than 80% fall within this range. The new IR will increase the administrative burden and related compliance costs. Assessing the impacts of these revised IR is of significant importance to ensure an appropriate screening of economic, social and environmental impacts, in line with Better Regulation Principles. The impact on animal welfare should also be an integral part of the Commission’s Impact Assessment. The introduction of further IR on critical hazards should be based on existing and validated assays with clear guidance for interpretation of results. The ‘One substance one assessment’ concept could be appropriate if it is only applied to the hazard assessment. However, the concept should not pre-empt sectoral risk assessment.
Organisation: PRODAROM Syndicat National des Fabricants de Produits Aromatiques
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: The remit of the CII targets exclusively cases in which the potential risks posed by chemicals are limited to the workplace environment. In light of this, we would like to provide our feedback to the EC Inception Impact Assessment on the upcoming revision of the REACH Regulation.  REACH is rightly established as the regulatory pillar of EU chemicals management and has contributed to unrivalled data collection about the use and effects of substances. However, other pieces of legislation are tailored to certain uses and categories of chemicals such as for the management of chemical risk in the workplace as OSH legislation plays an important role in the the prevention of work-related diseases.  A growing number of already adopted and still discussed REACH Restrictions are based on an obligatory DNEL value. These values cover the same scope as OELs and seem to be a substitute for the OSH directive.  We therefore welcome the Commission’s intention to use the revision of REACH to clarify its interface with other pieces of legislation, and we particularly encourage decision-makers to seize this opportunity to clarify the interface between REACH and OSH legislation.   We see REACH restrictions, REACH authorisation, and the OSH directive as complementary tools to protect human health and the environment, and we would like to highlight the fact that OSH directives were indeed established to define all important aspects of workplace risk management and are the correct legal route for setting specific OEL. REACH restrictions were not conceived to set exposure limit values by an alternative route. However, to complement OSH (and OELVs), restrictions can be sensible measures to address risks that cannot be addressed by OSH and in specific circumstances. For example, while OSH (OELVs) may be sufficient to address the risks of a substance in most workplaces, there may be individual uses in which the RMOA finds that the substance cannot be used safely and that the ban of that specific use by means of a restriction is proportionate. Additionally, if there are workers outside the scope of OSH (self-employed), then it may be beneficial to bolster the OELV with a restriction for those other workers. This combination of OSH / OELVs with a restriction would avoid regulatory overlap and confusion.   The CII considers that the revision of REACH offers an opportunity to build on the experience of the past 14 years and possibly standardise some of the tools that have been created for the implementation of the regulation. This could be the case of a more systematic and transparent analysis of the different risk management options, which to date have been carried out via the RMOA.  We also suggest that a better definition of the scope of REACH is introduced in Article 2, para. 4 of REACH. It should be ensured that while REACH and OSH may both apply at the workplace, REACH does not duplicate OSH procedures specifically designed for ensuring risk management at the workplace (OELs are the lex specialis for setting limit values at workplaces within the scope of OSH and the process under OSH ensures that specific expertise available in OSH-bodies (including the Working Party Chemicals (WPC) and Advisory Council on Safety and Health (ACSH)) is represented in the development of OELs). Using this definition could enable us to identify when the use of REACH is appropriate or excluded in relation to sector-specific legislation. This clarification could ensure coherence and complementarity and help avoid duplication and uncertainty at the REACH/OSH Interface.   The CII remains, however, convinced that the clarification of the Interface between REACH and OSH legislation could also be carried out without modifying the present regulatory framework. This modification would best occur through the publication of a common understanding document or a guidance document that highlights clear criteria as to when REACH or OSH should be used. feedback_msg_text: ESIA represents the European semiconductor sector where companies are operating and competing in Europe and globally. The landscape of the REACH regulation and the uncertainty it brings to their manufacturing process in Europe compared with other regions of semiconductor production is one critical area of consideration under a targetted revision of REACH. In terms of chemical usage, the industry is a downstream (end) user of some bulk chemicals and of critical specialty chemical materials, that are used predominantly at a very low volume in mixtures. These materials in many instances are of central importance for the innovation and manufacturing process and are required to be used due to their unique properties and critical functionality. These chemicals are used within highly sophisticated manufacturing closed systems where there is no worker exposure under normal manufacturing process conditions.   Semiconductors are a key enabler of low carbon and energy efficient innovative solutions that reduce our dependence on fossil fuels and minimize emissions. Semiconductor’s help reduce society's environmental footprint, by optimising energy usage in transportation, manufacturing, services, and consumer products. Semiconductors facilitate the transition towards a decarbonised economy while simultaneously contributing to an innovative and sustainable society to realise the EU’s Green Deal objectives. In March 2021, the European Commission President responding to European Council of Member states call for action proposed a ‘Digital Compass’ goal that by 2030, the production of semiconductors in Europe should be 20% of world production. The continued use of innovative materials by the European semiconductor industry will be essential to achieve this ambitious EU goal as the manufacture of semiconductors in Europe is not possible without them. A targetted revision of REACH should not negatively impact this EU goal. (this includes short chain PFASs that are under review)  ESIA outlines further inputs to this consultation in the attached document. Feedback from: Anonymous (273.9 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Derogations – Although the IAA does not propose to change the procedures to for adding substances to Annexes IV and V, the criteria to be fulfilled to amend Annexes IV and V remain unjustifiably burdensome. This means that it is hardly envisaged that new substances or groups of substances will be able to achieve derogations under the REACH regime. This is not the case under non-EU jurisdictions, where derogations are more feasible.   Reduced Regulatory Requirement (RRR)  - We would like to raise the example of polymers: we believe it should be possible to apply a Reduced Regulatory Requirement (RRR)  for Polymers (as it is the case in Canada) certainly when they are the same modifications as used in food and/or biodegradable. More specifically, the EC indicates that certain polymers will be subject to registration. There needs to be very clear criteria and rationale for deciding which polymers will be subject to registration, which polymers will continue to be exempt, and indeed a RRR would be more proportional for polymers (or at least the majority of those) that will require registration.  Restriction - The restriction process should be limited to carcinogenic, mutagenic or reprotoxic (CMR) substances and critical hazard classes, and not extended to products that are not classified as such.   Introduction of a Mixture Assessment Factor - The proposal for a Mixture Assessment Factor (MAF) can have significant unintended consequences. Without any indication of potential risks of combination effects, the introduction of MAF for all substances seems very hard to realize. A generic factor can cause major disruptions of trade of safe, sustainable uses of substances that are indispensable in many end uses. Timeframe for the proposed amendments– Starch Europe feels that the deadlines set for the changes in the current REACH regime are very ambitious. The extent and scope of the proposed amendments would require a much longer period for the corresponding actions to be properly implemented.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: EDRA (European DIY Retail Association) represents European DIY retailers. Our positon on the review of REACH is as as follows:   1. Establishing a policy mix to de-risk innovation and improve the business case for safer chemistries and technologies  Business and technology research indicates that innovation requires both willingness as well as capacity and opportunity to innovate. Government plays an important role in both aspects of innovation. In this respect. There are a number of policy actions that the EU could undertake that would also support and stimulate innovation and adoption of safer chemistries and technologies, helping to improve the business case. These policies need to be supplemented with data collection/metrics to understand whether policies are achieving policy goals and resulting in substitution with safer chemicals and technologies. Some possible actions include:   • Establish harmonised data requirements for substitution The EU can help to guide clarity and consistency about what information on chemical hazards, exposures, performance, etc., is needed to support informed substitution and avoid regrettable substitutions (e.g. no data, no substitution). The EU can also help to harmonise definitions of what is “safer” and “sustainable” to establish consistency in how progress towards safer chemistry is measured and compared across firms and sectors. This can also more effectively support the establishment of “positive lists” for particular chemical functions and applications.    • Need to create incentives/policies (tax breaks, research and development credits) Incentives are needed for investment in safer chemistries and technologies and to offset some of the costs for the manufacturer or adopter of those technologies (i.e. helping to de-risk the business environment for first movers).     2. Possibility to provide mandatory consumer information on chemicals by digital means   The European Commission announced in the European Green Deal that it will “look at exploring new ways to give consumers better information, including by digital means”, thus clearly recognising that digitalisation can help deliver a clean and circular economy.  EDRA very much welcomes this approach and would invite the European Commission to initiate a thorough reflection on the many possibilities that digital means can offer.  Particularly, mandatory consumer information on products containing chemicals (e.g. paints, glues, adhesives) can be overwhelming sometimes, in particular for smaller and/or multilingual products. The Commission should look into ways to allow provision of these information digitally. Digital provision of information has the potential to communicate more efficiently and in a personalized way information to consumers; but also, reduce packaging waste and shipping costs and help the free movement of goods in the EU Single Market.   3. Any assessment of a chemicals needs to be aligned globally and follow a scientific approach   Supply chains are global. Therefore, any assessment of chemicals should be coordinated on the global level, let alone the European level. It is unacceptable that certain countries move on with their own assessments and rules on chemicals (e.g. nanomaterials in France).   The principle of ‘one assessment-one rule’ should guide the EU in its work. Besides, the controversy around glyphosate illustrated the damage of a political approach. Science should prevail in this kind of matter.    4. More cooperation from manufacturers of articles and components of articles is needed   Innovation and development of green alternatives is always the result of a joint effort of all actors of the supply chain. However, experience proves that manufacturers (of both components and articles) are sometimes reluctant (understandably) to move to greener alternatives because they have invested massively in the incumbent chemicals and are waiting for a return on investment.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Mengend Nederland comments on the public consultation on the In-ception Impact Assessment on the revision of REACH  Mengend Nederland1 supports the objectives of the CSS to achieve a higher level of protection of citizens and the environment against hazardous chemicals. Amendments to the REACH Regulation in this regard should focus on risks above hazards, enable suppliers of chemicals to develop safer alternatives and provide downstream users with enough time to reformulate their products to achieve the same performance. When effective alternatives are not available it should be possible to use these substances in low-risk applications for the functioning of our modern society.  Essential Uses Mengend Nederland wishes to signal concerns regarding the introduction of the principle of ‘es-sential uses’ in reforming the restriction process. Given the dynamic and diverse nature of the chemical industry, the principle of what can be considered ‘essential’ would always need to be up-dated. A use that may be considered ‘non-essential’ may become essential in the (near) future. The speed with which science and technology progresses needs a chemical industry that has the flexibility to grow and innovate along with it. This will become very difficult if the chemical industry is limited to innovation with substances and uses (subjectively) deemed as ‘essential’ at one period in time.  Introduction of a Mixture Assessment Factor While Mengend Nederland supports the assessment of options to address the potential risks of combination effects, the proposal for a Mixture Assessment Factor (MAF) can have significant unin-tended consequences. Introducing a ‘blanket’ MAF for all substances and uses can cause major disruptions of trade of safe, sustainable uses of substances that are indispensable in our everyday life, without any indication of potential risks of combination effects.   Furthermore, in many cases the only option to comply with the MAF would be lowering the con-centration of a substance in the final product. This may lead to the unwanted consequence that the product loses its efficiency, causing more of the same product to be needed to reach the same result. The introduction of a MAF should therefore be limited to those substances, substance-groups and/or sites with substantiated indications of risks of combination effects – in other words, a tar-geted, risk-proportionate and effective approach.  Simplifying communication in supply chains To ensure the full potential of the REACH objectives are met, it is very important to keep working on improving supply chain communication, in particular regarding Safety Data Sheets and Exposure Scenarios. The introduction of a harmonized electronic format of the (extended) SDS in this regard can significantly improve communication in the supply chain. It is also important to keep working on the quality of Exposure Scenarios in particular, supporting the revision of outdated Chemical Safety Assessments and support the inclusion of sector use mapping tables.  Ambitious, risky deadlines The deadlines proposed for the changes in REACH are very ambitious. Mengend Nederland would like to voice their concerns about these deadlines. The changes will not only affect the chemical industry, but will require R&D challenges at every step of the supply chain. Mengend Nederland's member companies have to develop new formulations for the services we deliver, products that are crucial for the functioning of our modern society. The size and scope of the proposed amend-ments are too big to allow for a rushed process where the impact is not properly considered.  1 Mengend Nederland is a partnership of Dutch sector organizations for disinfection and cleaning agents (NVZ), cosmetics (NCV), aerosols (NAV), adhesives and sealants (VLK), and paint and printing ink (VVVF). The organizations join forces for sustainable and safe production in the Netherlands and for responsible use of their products. Feedback from: Mengend Nederland (138.2 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Addressing the REACH revision roadmap, the Polish Union of the Cosmetics Industry would like to highlight the following issues:  Revision of the registration requirements  The introduction of new information requirements (hazards of concern, documentation of safe use, registration of certain polymers, and information on the environmental footprint) should be consistent with the requirements of Article 13 of REACH and not lead to an increase of animal testing. Scientific progress made in the area of non-animal (eco)toxicology and risk assessment should receive full regulatory acceptance and promotion by ECHA.  New data requirements will result in significantly higher costs for chemical manufacturers that will in many cases render chemicals commercially unviable and no longer available to downstream users. Rather than introducing new data requirements in a ‘check-box’ approach, they should be assessed against the real added value they bring to chemicals safety. Increased data requirements should not lead to an increase of animal testing. State of the art scientific progress made in the area of non-animal (eco)toxicology and risk assessment should receive full regulatory acceptance for the classification of chemicals under CLP. Potential increase of animal testing as a consequence of the proposed new hazard categories should be an integral element of the impact assessment.  Reforming the authorisation and restriction process  Whatever the future process, it is very important that risk management under REACH remains based on scientifically sound risk assessments and safeguards are introduced to avoid unjustified generic bans and restrictions of uses that are safe for consumers and the environment. Restrictions/authorisations must remain conditional to a proven risk and not be based on ‘suspected’ effects. Furthermore, derogations must remain to be possible based on demonstrated safety of particular uses.  Introduction of a Mixtures Assessment Factor (MAF)  The MAF is proposed as a practical and workable approach to deal with unintentional mixtures. The chosen factor will directly define its impact on risk in environmental and occupational exposure scenarios. Consequently, the introduction of a generic MAF should be subject to impact assessment, any MAF should be carefully evaluated and should be based on the current scientific knowledge. A range of MAFs could be applicable depending on the exposure scenario.  Registration of polymers and additional requirements  Registration of polymers should be considered only for those posing a concern, the data requirements, tonnage cut-offs, testing schemes should account for polymer specificities and should be understandable, implementable, and transparent. The priority should be given to development of “fit for purpose” registration requirements that could fulfil REACH regulatory aims to ensure a high level of protection for human health and the environment.  Link of REACH to downstream legislations  CSS aims to create new links between the horizontal chemicals and downstream legislations, including the Cosmetic Products Regulation, CPR. CE supports that certain elements of chemicals’ management process (hazard identification and environmental risk assessment at the level of substances) should be done horizontally. However, risk management measures should be done under vertical regulations and not be split between REACH and sector legislation. Feedback from: The Polish Union of the Cosmetics Industry (91.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The Slovenian chemicals industry spent significant resources for the implementation of the REACH-regulation since 2007. Fundamental changes in chemicals management was necessary. For our industry this was in particular burdensome, because it is highly SME-structured. Looking back at these years with REACH, we are of the opinion that the complexity of the current chemicals legislation is too high for an average Slovenian company. Also we – the Association of the Slovenian Chemicals Industry (ZKI) – lack resources to cover all relevant aspects of REACH.  REACH is simply too much “paperwork” and too many permanent changes are happening at the same time. In this regard, we consider that a small industry, like the Slovenian one, is in a strong disadvantage compared to industries in larger Member States. This causes a disruption of the level playing field on the internal market. The concrete difficulties are diverse, but for example it starts with the permanent need to use a foreign language, having elevated translations costs and ends with not having sufficient domestic testing-capacities. We even observe that our authorities are not able to follow everything what could be relevant for our industry due to lack of resources, only one example is the CASG Polymers.  Over the years many of our companies, especially the small ones, developed the attitude that they have lost controle of what is going on around chemicals policy and that they are at the mercy of Brussels‘ bureaucrats, who, however, do not understand their needs. In this respect we urgently see the need for a general simplification of the Union‘s chemicals legislation and in particular REACH. We should 1) keep the existing exemptions, like for example no CSR for low-tonnage substances, 2) expand the data-/cost-sharing to the extend possible, 3) reduce the burden of registration and authorisation, 4) avoid politically driven regulatory experiments like the introduction of the essential-use concept or the extension of the hazard-based approach (generic risk-management) and 5) make communication in the supply chain simpler and hands-on.  As an associaton we require financial and organisational support to be able to further qualitatively support our companies. The support offered by the official helpdesk is not sufficient and/or is not case-specific enough. Considering the over-ambitious plans of the CSS, this aspect becomes even more pressing for small-structured industries like the Slovenian chemicals industry. For this we suggest that the European Commission establishes 1) an adequate financial tool and 2) a platform, where the EC and national associations can once/twice a year have a direct exchange. Especially the platform would allow the EC to better understand national specificities and to better explain decisions at EU-level, what would contribute to the acceptance of EU-law.
Organisation: CCIS-Association of chemical industries of Slovenia
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: We would like to give following comments on the issues relating to articles. Please also see attached comments for details.  (1) About “generic approach” and “grouping approach” – We believe that proper risk assessment needs to be kept as a fundamental scientific basis of chemical management. Grouping should be used only when the properties of substances are scientifically regarded as the same.  The Commission suggested extending the generic risk approach to restrictions. In our view, risk assessment is a core principle of chemicals management and must be kept for determining a proper level of regulations.  The proposed grouping approach is to skip all of these steps and simply jump to a conclusion on the basis of mere assumption without considering the information gathered in the registrations and differences of chemicals and each use of such compounds. We would like to strongly encourage the relevant EU stakeholders to consider whether there is really a need to completely abandon REACH’s science and fact-based approach, replacing it with broad, rapid and sweeping actions based on suppositions and which group dissimilar substances together, in contradiction to the facts collected in the REACH registration process. (2) About the relevance of the principle of “one substance – one assessment” and management of chemicals of concern in EEE – Hazards of substances should be assessed consistently by ECHA, but the management of the industrial chemicals currently used in complex articles such as EEE should be covered by sector-specific legislation such as RoHS Directive.  (3) When considering the scope and thresholds for a future restriction of substances, risk assessment should be adequately implemented for the substance(s) of concern. In particular, the difference of possibility of exposure from chemicals and from articles should be considered.  (4) It would not be feasible to impose a threshold based on detection limit of substance to the articles. Especially in case of complicated articles consisting of many parts, management of substances by analytical methods is impossible in practice. What can be practically managed by article manufacturers are threshold values on the order of 1,000 ppm.   (5) About essential use - Derogations (exemptions) from a restriction should be allowed for applications for which alternatives are not known or have not been socio-economically available to the article manufacturers yet. For EEE, the criteria for setting exemptions under RoHS Directive 2011/65/EU would be suitable and appropriate.   (6) Generally speaking, at least four or five years would be necessary as transitory period for complicated articles when a restriction of an industrial chemical currently used in such articles is proposed. Products with longer design cycle, such as production machinery or infrastructure, would need much longer transitory period.  (7) In the course of risk assessment, the fact that the end-of-life stage of EEE is managed according to WEEE Directive should be well-recognised and evaluated. We would like to ask the researchers and lawmakers to evaluate the industry’s effort and diligence to meet the sector-specific EPR legislation properly.  (8) We believe that the procedures to make it possible to use the spare parts and recycled materials should be established from the view-point of circular economy. A General exemption of spare parts without expiry date would be indispensable for complicated articles to extend their useful life, if their original products are placed on EU market before the requirement comes into force.  We would very much appreciate it if the Commission would well consider our input above.
