feedback_msg_text: The Blood Transfusion Association (BTA), an international non-profit trade association committed to promoting the correct use and safe supply of blood for transfusion, welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the IIA of the REACH regulation.  Over the years, blood supply has been hampered by population ageing, climate change, and more recently, COVID-19, due to the decrease in blood donations. This demonstrates the importance of blood storage as a vital parameter to optimise blood supply and as such, a critical aspect of safeguarding public health.  Blood bag sets with Di-2-ethylhexylphthalate (DEHP) have contributed to effectively storing blood, due to DEHP’s capacity of extending the storage life of red blood cells. However, recent developments have proposed sunsetting DEHP from medical devices on 27 May 2025, under the Annex XIV amendment of the REACH regulation.  The BTA members are committed to identifying viable alternatives for developing new materials. There is however concern among key stakeholders – including blood establishments as well as the industry - that the timeframe for sunsetting DEHP use combined with the revision of the EU Blood legislation and the potential up-classification of blood bag sets under the Medical Devices Regulation (MDR) is untenable, and would drastically reduce the availability of blood bag sets.  Blood bag sets are critical devices in the supply chain and are strictly regulated under multiple EU frameworks. Moreover, at a national level, certain countries also consider blood components as medicinal products, and are further regulated by corresponding pharmaceutical legislations. The implementation and roll out process of a new material is a lengthy process which can only start once the CE mark has been granted to the manufacturers. This CE marking also means that national bodies and blood establishments will either review the new specifications or carry out their own studies before releasing the new product. The introduction of a novel material would not only require comprehensive development efforts but also significant qualification and validation work. Therefore, substituting DEHP in blood bag sets is expected to take 6-9 years to cover the development, CE marking under MDR and the roll out into the marketplace – without taking into account the potential up-classification of blood bag sets. The application for authorisation (AfA) process foreseen within the REACH regulation does provide a tool to extend the use of DEHP, but as the IIA correctly noted, the process is highly cumbersome and costly, and introduces uncertainty on the availability of blood bag sets after the sunset date.  In the interim, the BTA also appeals to the Commission to consider extending the essential use concept to DEHP with respect to its role in the maintaining blood supplies, and the current lack of feasible alternatives. As previously mentioned, DEHP’s capacity to extend blood storage in an already limited blood reserve helps in sustaining blood supply, thus benefitting public health. Moreover, although potential alternatives to DEHP are already under investigation, existing data demonstrate that their blood storage properties do not match up to those of DEHP and their effects remain poorly understood. Therefore, by operationalising the essential use concept for DEHP until 2027-2030, blood supply and patient safety would be safeguarded.  In light of the above, concern about the envisaged timelines, BTA would like to work together with the Commission and other key stakeholders to find solutions to these pressing issues and ensure continuous blood supply across the EU. As stated in a previous consultation, BTA recommends that the phasing-out of DEHP in blood bag sets is scheduled for 2027-2030, a timeline broadly accepted by both industry and blood establishments. A joint and strong commitment to this timeframe would facilitate the transition of non-DEHP blood bag sets without compromising patient safety.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: The Test & Measurement (T&M) Coalition was created in 2005 and represents an ad-hoc group of companies active in producing T&M industrial type products. Industrial monitoring and control equipment, including chemical analysers, are essential in the enforcement of and compliance with environmental legislation, and are a key driver of innovation. Very strict reliability requirements and extended lifetime performance are met thanks to the use of very small quantities of indispensable substances. Prolonging the use phase significantly, the use of these substances contributes decisively to the circular economy. Moreover they have no impact on human health or on the environment thanks to their controlled professional and industrial use and collection of end-of-life instruments through B2B waste schemes.   In the framework of the REACH revision, the Coalition is promoting an overall legislative framework enabling transparency, coherence, predictability and legal certainty for companies. In line with the ideal for simplification and burden reduction: • The Commission must revisit the definition of an Article to return to their original vision on how REACH should be applied. The judgement of the European Court of Justice on September 10, 2015 added substantial administrative burden to producers of articles with a negligible benefit to the protection of the environment or health. This has been further exasperated by the additional administrative burden associated with SCIP data management required under the EU Waste Framework relating to SVHC presence in Articles beyond those prescribed by Article 33 of REACH. This is most acute in the EEE sector, where each individual component is itself a very complex article; with finished equipment having up to 40,000 components. This is compounded by the lack of coherence between the RoHS Directive on the need to declare SVHCs such as lead presence, allowed under the RoHS exemptions listed in Annexes III and IV: each one scientifically and technically justified. It must also be recognized that the information exchange throughout the electronics supply chain cannot rely on SDS, which instead utilizes international schema such as IPC 1752 and IEC 62474 to identify SVHC presence. • The concept of “essential use” should be implemented not only under REACH, but also more broadly under sectorial legislation (i.e. the RoHS review), for instance when considering additional substances restrictions for equipment with critical uses which would lead to premature market withdrawals. • The concept of “sustainable chemicals” criteria and its future application in REACH must build from stakeholder’s experiences of the complexities and sectorial differences to produce workable requirements.  • The use of the “one substance one assessment” principle under REACH and linked sectorial legislation which aims at rationalising the legislative framework (i.e. REACH and RoHS in the EEE sector). • The generic approach to risk management should be refined: discussions on the hazard identification, assessment and classification should indeed take place in horizontal legislation (REACH, CLP), but risk management measures should not be automatically triggered in sectoral legislation. Instead, sectoral legislation should be used to adequately manage the risk in the relevant sectors taking into account exposure, specificities, proportionality and cost-efficiency analyses for the various sub-categories.  • The presented model of a toxic-free environment in the CSS and its implementation in REACH must not contradict the objective of the Circular Economy, which encourages the extension of the active life of products through reuse and repair. Actions being taken to support extended life of equipment across multiple sectors will extend rather than reduce the need for derogations of SVHC content in recycled materials if the goal of increasing recycled materials (vs. landfill) are to be met. feedback_msg_text: As addressed within the European Green Deal we can make the EU´s economy more sustainable by turning climate and environmental challenges into opportunities. It is recognized that, to reach this target, actions by all sectors of our economy are required to innovate. Innovation and progress are coming with education, research, and autonomy. The Life Science Industry (LS) plays a key role for the future in many aspects. However, its highly specialized and innovative products face some shortcomings in the current regulations. A revision of the REACH text offers the possibility to remedy those limitations. Generally, LS has a special position between chemical production, diagnostics, Pharmaceutical and Biotechnological Industry and public/private research organizations. LS provides solutions that are special uses delivering the required tools and equipment that commonly precede the production of pharmaceuticals or are essential in laboratory applications supporting scientists and researchers. To enable innovation, R&D activities require special attention regarding upcoming regulatory measures. For example, the use of cobalt salts as essential part of some enzymes in living organisms or growth factors with natural endocrine activities are essential components in cell culture media. Such cell culture media are not only used in R&D but also in small- and large-scale biotech productions for almost all industry applications. Well-intended new regulatory measures often not sufficiently consider new and innovative technologies and products that suffer unwanted collateral damage with potential serious consequences. Therefore, special considerations and protection are required regarding restrictive regulations. Even more such substances, usually used in small amounts are essential innovation drivers and need further protection to reach the ambition goals of the EU Green Deal. The use of substances in LS are not per se covered under SR&D and hence are not exempted from REACH restrictions and authorization. Many LS products like the already mentioned cell culture media are used in the production of biopharmaceuticals and vaccines. While we are supporting the general approach to protect consumers from risks associated with chemicals, we lack a clear legislative wide definition where exemptions from restrictive measures start and end. Where a final product is used in R&D it is of course necessary to enable the production of those products in the preceding supply chain to foster innovation in Europe. A broader definition of research and development as well as exemptions for relevant and necessary uses in production processes and a continuous exemption of smaller volumes below 1 t/a is needed. The use of small quantities of chemicals with highly specific functions in a product is also very important as they are often not covered by a registration but may be subject to restrictions or prohibitions due to grouping of substances. Where groupings are only based on structural chemical similarities and an evaluation based on scientific evidence about risks is lacking, these specialty chemicals might not be used for example in preceding steps of research, diagnostics, pharmaceutical or vaccine production. This is not based on a known risk but only on unawareness of the chemicals and their use in highly critical and essential applications. REACH and its adjacent regulations focus on the management of chemical substances. One corner stone of REACH is the registration of chemicals and industry also focuses on the registration and safety of substances. Under this assumption, unfortunately the expression ‘volume’ is used like ‘relevant to market’, which certainly is not correct in all cases. Tiny amounts (kg per year in the entire EU) may be highly relevant to the market and the society. Therefore, we propose to recognize the special position that LS takes up in driving innovation and enabling the increase in scientific knowledge in the revision of REACH.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Eurocolour’s input to the inception impact assessment of the Revision of EU legislation on registration, evaluation, authorization and restriction of chemicals   The EU’s REACH Regulation in combination with the CLP Regulation are unique in such a form and extent worldwide. The collection of information on the hazard and potential risks from chemicals is a huge gain for protecting human health as well as the environment. Other countries already use REACH as a blueprint for their own chemical regulations.  The effectiveness of the regulations as well as the archived benefit for health as well as environmental protection are unchallenged. This huge success should be kept in mind when considering further steps, nor should the many – mandatory as well as also voluntary – contributions from industry be forgotten which made this success possible.  While there are several aspects that may be improved, Eurocolour would like to stress that these refinements are also considered possible within the given legal framework. Instead of tightening the legal framework with additional obligations and data demands, the already existing possibilities should be exhausted first. This paper is a shortened version of Eurocolour’s position paper. For all arguments and further explanation please see also “Eurocolour position paper on the Revision of EU’s REACH Regulation”.   Extension of registration requirements: risk of loosing chemicals without benefit  • No extension of registration requirements o particular burden for SMEs and highly specialized manufacturers of chemicals for niche applications o loss of chemicals looms o huge variety of substances is basis for innovation and thus, a fundamental requirement for the aims of the CSS • Extended information requires further animal tests o animal testing should never be required without even a hint for a hazardous property • No introduction of MAFs o current safety assessment approach already considers several safety values • No calculation of an “environmental footprint” for chemicals o impact on the environment heavily depends on the application Extension of the restriction criteria: No restriction based on non-intrinsic properties or without a defined hazard • No extension of SHVC criteria: STOT classifications, vPvM, and vPvB o No deviation from GHS  o no regulatory restrictions based on substance unspecific, non-intrinsic properties  Revision of the evaluation process: already several measures running to further improve data quality • hardly any non-compliance found in REACH Review 2018 • industry already committed to improve the quality of registration dossiers  Revision of the authorisation process: A sure instinct is required • simplification would be highly welcome, but the partially complex applications of chemicals should be treated with respective expertise  Summary Many of the proposed actions threaten the variety of the chemicals available within the EU. This is a huge innovation barrier while innovations are strongly needed to enable the transition towards a pollution and emission free economy. Bringing the EU industry in a disadvantage contradicts the aim for further resilience towards trading conflicts in sensible applications like e. g. pharmaceuticals. Besides, the proposed actions burden the industry with immense costs additional to the already spend amounts of money and resources to fulfill the REACH obligations as they are and further improve the data quality. However, as long as several important terms like ‘essential use’ or ‘substance of concern’ are not clearly described industry has no planning security and a full impact assessment for Eurocolour’s members is not possible. Therefore, Eurocolour promotes • No turning away from the risk-based approach for evaluating chemicals and their applications • No ban of chemicals without risk assessment, stakeholder participations, and cost-benefit impact assessments • Uniformly carried out enforcement within the EU and for all imports Feedback from: Eurocolour e.V. feedback_msg_text: Chemical Industry Federation Finland appreciates the opportunity to comment the Inception impact assessment document. This consultation is very valuable, as proper impact assessment is the basis for any good regulatory process.   We support the comments made by Cefic and would like to emphasize the following:   The Chemical Strategy for sustainability proposes multiple changes to REACh and CLP regulations. These changes are tightly interconnected; for example proposed new hazard classes and more precise criteria for classification would bring new substances as candidates for regulatory measures by grouping approach.  The impact assessment should cover also these interconnections and perceive the implications of all the REACH and CLP-regulation proposals as a whole. This is important, as we need a common understanding of the implications like costs and other resource needs for the authorities and industry, but as well important is to avoid unwanted consequences, when many pieces of our regulatory foundation are moving at the same time.    Resources for regulatory process and implementation: Besides the cost and resource needs for business, the Impact Assessment needs to consider the increased workload and the existing resources in  national authorities and EU institutions. The regulatory process for many big changes in REACH and CLP following  Better Regulation principles needs a lot of resources, which are already now fully engaged with the normal operations under these regulations.  When approved the implementation of the regulations is again resource intensive. The implementation phase of REACH took many years with guidance, training, interpretations and clarifications. Not to speak about enforcement. Industry needs clarity and predictability and therefore well functioning, knowledgeable and supportive authority is of utmost importance.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Orgalim, representing Europe’s technology industries, welcomes the revision of European Union legislation on registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemicals (REACH Regulation). Our technology industries, major downstream users and article manufacturers are fully committed to reducing the content of hazardous substances in their products to support a more circular economy.  Here are our key messages on the REACH revision inception impact assessment roadmap:  ➢ We call on the ECHA and the European Commission to develop better criteria for determining when authorisation and when restriction is applicable. ➢ Industry needs to be able to continue producing products using chemicals in a level playing field with non- EU countries. Therefore, a REACH restriction rather than authorisation is the preferred instrument to regulate chemicals. ➢ We urge to keep the scope of REACH Article 33 limited to Substances of Very High Concern (SVHC) and to not broaden the scope to Substances of Concern (SoC). However, if that were to be the case, we would call for a clear definition of Substances of Concern in order to ensure legal certainty and clear procedure rules. ➢ REACH should continue to be the main instrument for evaluating and identifying SVHCs with the goal of restricting or authorising them. ➢ Policymaking and decisions regarding chemicals should be risk-based not hazard-based. ➢ The use of a SVHC and its health impact on workers and consumers should be re-evaluated before a substance is put on the candidate list, with actual data provided by the affected industry accurately assessing the risk of a substance based on its probability of exposure and the health impact. ➢ Socio-economic factors should be considered earlier from the industry aspect. It should be evaluated in advance whether the consequences of a restriction or authorisation scenario are proportionate to the anticipated benefits to the environment and to health.  For additional information, please find attached our position paper. Feedback from: Orgalim, Europe’s technology industries (305.9 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Huntsman supports a targeted reopening of REACH to make the Regulation more efficient in protecting human health and the environment while enabling the sustainable innovations needed to meet the ambitions of the European Green Deal.   Huntsman has invested significantly in REACH in line with our support for sound regulation of chemicals based on robust science. Huntsman agrees with the conclusions of the 2018 REACH Review that there is scope for further improvement and simplification in REACH.  The 2018 Review concluded that the Evaluation processes are too burdensome and can result in bottlenecks. It is important to take into consideration that industry players are not all equally resourced and may be subject to parallel regulatory requirements. As such, REACH would benefit from a transparent prioritisation system to enhance predictability, ensure sufficient time for investments in data and avoid unnecessary costs. This would be in line with ECHA’s proposal to the 38th CARACAL  in March 2021 to develop a plan for the CoRAP process.  One of the key achievements of REACH is the harmonised EU single market for chemicals. The introduction of national Authorisation processes, even for small applications, would run counter to this achievement and may raise new burdens associated with a myriad of national schemes.  Huntsman still agrees with a reform of the Authorisation process and supports the policy option of integrating it with the Restriction procedure.  This should lead to a more coordinated approach to risk management which focuses on the substance itself, rather than numerous regulatory activities relating to different applications of the same substance.  Huntsman does not advocate a generic risk approach since assessment of hazard and risks are two distinct steps. The approach should remain that case-by-case risk assessments are carried out after hazard identification to determine if restrictions are needed in certain applications.  This is true in the context of professional uses, as a generic risk approach would have a disproportionate socio-economic impact on the industry. There is a need for different parts of the mechanisms to be more successful, such as more enforcement, more certifications. We need to secure safety for workers and consumers while ensuring the impact of restrictions has no disproportionate socio-economic impacts. The operationalization of the essential uses concept needs to account for innovation. If certain substances are automatically ruled out in certain uses, it could potentially stifle new technologies putting the EU at a competitive disadvantage. Huntsman supports Cefic’s position and would recommend that the essential use concept is operationalized to allow for the use of substances in R&D under controlled conditions. It should also include an option to consider new innovative uses as essential as these are developed and brought to the market. European-produced products should not be put at a disadvantage over non-EU products. Frequently, undesirable substances are used as reactive components that have completely altered their form in the final articles. That an article originates from such a substance might not be determined. Such articles could easily be produced outside of Europe and imported, while the production within Europe is hindered.  Resources should be devoted to enforcement as implementation remains a significant barrier to meeting the objectives of REACH. Huntsman strongly believes that reasonable regulation and cooperative enforcement would lead to more responsible users which would improve health and safety outcomes for all Europeans. Its important to devote more resources to this area and not only focus on revising rules on Risk Management Measures (RMM). It could be useful to implement additional RMM such as mandatory certifications, training, auditing, exposure measurements which would penalize irresponsible industry players whilst also rewarding those that are responsible.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Polskie Stowarzyszenie Przemysłu Kosmetycznego i Detergentowego (PSPKD) popiera zobowiązania polityczne podjęte w ramach CSS. Nie należy jednak przyspieszać procesów decyzyjnych dotyczących rewizji REACH, lecz zapewnić ich właściwe procedowanie, zgodnie z zasadami Better Regulation.  Wyniki  drugiego przeglądu REACH wskazują, że rozporządzenie spełnia swoje cele i zadania. Proponowana rewizja REACH powinna zatem uwzględniać ten wniosek i ograniczać się do ukierunkowanych zmian pozwalających na wprowadzenie usprawnień.   Niezwykle istotne jest zapewnienie akceptacji regulacyjnej metod alternatywnych oraz podejmowanie decyzji dotyczących bezpieczeństwa składników przy użyciu metodologii pozwalających uniknąć nowych badań na zwierzętach.   Rewizja powinna wspierać i promować innowacje poprzez utrzymanie/rozszerzenie procedury zwolnień dotyczących badań ukierunkowanych na produkt i proces oraz unikanie nieproporcjonalnego obciążenia regulacyjnego dla: polimerów, substancji występujących w małych ilościach lub wielu milionów mieszanin recepturowych na rynku UE.  Rejestracja polimerów powinna być ograniczona do tych, które rzeczywiście stanowią zagrożenie dla zdrowia ludzkiego lub środowiska podczas stosowania.   Zgodnie z zasadą, że przepisy dotyczące chemikaliów powinny odzwierciedlać dowody naukowe odnośnie stwarzanego ryzyka, środki dotyczące połączonego oddziaływania chemikaliów powinny wykorzystywać, promować i rozszerzać istniejące badania naukowe w zakresie rzeczywistego współnarażenia i interakcji chemikaliów oraz wynikających z nich niekorzystnych skutków. Zastosowanie współczynników MAF zgodnie z zasadą zbytniej ostrożności może stać się narzędziem, które sprawi, że wiele cennych chemikaliów straci praktyczne zastosowanie oraz zniechęci do prowadzenia dalszych badań naukowych w tym kierunku.   PSPKD apeluje o ostrożność przy rozszerzaniu podejścia do ogólnego zarządzania ryzykiem na nowo zdefiniowane zagrożenia, w przypadku których może brakować solidnych danych naukowych.  Podejście to powinno być stosowane w sposób ukierunkowany, w odniesieniu do substancji lub zastosowań, w przypadku których nie wykazano odpowiedniej kontroli ryzyka. Zarządzanie ryzykiem powinno opierać się na naukowo uzasadnionej ocenie danych i informacji oraz zależeć od udowodnionego ryzyka, a nie "podejrzewanych” zagrożeń. Konieczne jest wprowadzenie mechanizmów zabezpieczających, jak procedura wyłączeń w celu uniknięcia wprowadzania zakazów dla zastosowań, które są bezpieczne dla konsumentów i środowiska. Środki zarządzania ryzykiem powinny być ustalone w ramach docelowych obszarów legislacyjnych i nie powinny być rozdzielone pomiędzy REACH oraz przepisy sektorowe np. rozporządzenie kosmetyczne. Koncepcja „kluczowych zastosowań” wymaga dalszej dyskusji i prac w zakresie podstawowych kwestii związanych z tym konceptem, zanim podjęte zostaną jakiekolwiek działania zmierzające do jej wprowadzenia.  Analiza opcji zarządzania ryzykiem powinna być obowiązkowa we wszystkich regulacyjnych procesach decyzyjnych umożliwiając całościową ocenę. Ponadto, powinna uwzględniać udział dalszych użytkowników (posiadaczy istotnych danych), podobnie jak procesy oceny dokumentacji i substancji.   Proponowane rozszerzenie ogólnego zarządzania ryzykiem na użytkowników profesjonalnych jest uważane za nieproporcjonalne i mogłoby mieć negatywny wpływ na podaż skutecznych produktów na rynkach profesjonalnych. Branża detergentowa podejmuje szereg działań wspierających tych użytkowników np. poprzez specjalne uwzględnienie pracowników profesjonalnych w pakiecie map zastosowań (SWED) oraz współpracę z EFCI, w celu ułatwienia stosowania i zrozumienia dokumentów informacyjnych dotyczących bezpiecznego stosowania mieszanin (SUMI).   PSPKD popiera spójne egzekwowanie przepisów mające na celu ochronę jednolitego rynku europejskiego, w szczególności w odniesieniu do zapobiegania przywozowi niezgodnych z wymogami produktów spoza UE.
Organisation: Polskie Stowarzyszenie Przemysłu Kosmetycznego i Detergentowego
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: We appreciate the opportunity to provide feedback for improvement of REACH regulation. One of our concerns is administrative workload that is needed to comply with REACH. It would be appreciated if the future work on the regulation would take that into account. More administrative work that REACH demands increases costs and may cause delayed implementation of the legislation.    Ideal would be to investigate first how different aspects of regulation would work in practice and to provide industry time to adjust. In particular in the recent months we have noticed that industry does not get sufficient time for implementation of changes in REACH regulation, for example the system for Poison Information Centre and SCIP were available to industry in extremely late stage so it was hard to prepare well and implement any good IT-solutions. A deadline date for implementation of such systems is provided for authorities but nothing is mentioned about a ‘must have’ time for industry to prepare. Another issue in terms of administrative workload are extra features that do not provide significant aid to consumer but that put additional burden on industry. For example, recent update on safety datasheet require retailer contact details in chapter 1. This small addition puts a lot of administrative work on retailers and manufacturers with little usefulness to any user because detailed knowledge about both safety datasheet and the chemical itself stays on the manufacturer level. Hence it’s easier for all sides to omit that information and let the user contact the manufacturer directly. Another example is information duty for substances of very high concern that are exempted from restriction in REACH or RoHS. Lead is commonly used in locks and components of electrical items and yet still need information duty. As we understand, the exemptions are provided for substances for which no alternatives exist due to technical or economic reasons. The substances are hard for industry to be avoided. Again, this aspect of the legislation increases administrative work, in particular for electric items.   We would appreciate if those issues were addressed. We hope that those comments would aid you in improving REACH regulation and we look forward further consultations.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Nous saluons l'opportunité offerte par la Commission européenne de pouvoir exprimer nos attentes concernant la révision du règlement REACH. Selon notre organisation, celui-ci doit être renforcé et révisé en profondeur. C'est pourquoi nous soutenons les actions de simplification, de révision et de réforme énoncés dans la feuille de route.   Nous attendons notamment une révision en priorité des dispositions relatives à l'évaluation des dossiers et des substances. Alors que la charge de la preuve repose sur les entreprises, qui ont pour obligation de transmettre à l'Agence européenne des produits chimiques (ECHA) les informations relatives aux risques liés aux substances fabriquées et commercialisées sur le marché européen (propriétés physico-chimiques, toxicologiques et écotoxicologiques des substances, évaluation des risques pour la santé et l'environnement et mesures de gestion appropriées), il est absolument nécessaire que l'ECHA oblige les entreprises à remplir leur devoir.   Rappelons qu'en 2018, une enquête réalisée par l'Institut fédéral allemand de gestion des risques (BfR) et l'Agence allemande de l'environnement indiquait que 580 substances chimiques non conformes étaient autorisées sur le marché européen. Sur 1.814 substances chimiques analysées, 32% ne remplissent pas les critères de non-dangerosité pour la santé et l'environnement imposés par la réglementation européenne Reach. Pour 32% des substances, les entreprises n'ont pas fourni à l'Agence européenne des produits chimiques (ECHA) les informations demandées concernant l'écotoxicité, la reprotoxicité ou encore les effets mutagènes. L'ECHA doit assurer pleinement son rôle de contrôle sur la totalité des substances et devrait imposer des sanctions à l'égard des industriels qui ne remplissent pas leurs obligations légales.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: The revision of REACH should aim at meeting the ambitions in the Green Deal and the Circular Economy Action Plan. To bridge the gap between the waste legislation and the chemicals legislation, this revision need much more focus on recovered substance to be able to facilitate a Circular Economy. In particular, the application of REACH art. 2(7) “recovered” substances needs to be clarified.  This article is important to facilitate recycling, because it exempts from REACH registration substances “which are recovered” in the EU if “the substance that results from the recovery process is the same as the substance that has been registered”. Recovery often takes place in small, distributed sites owned by organisations not accustomed to chemical regulations (e.g. local authorities for sewage works) so that REACH Registration of each producer and site would be a significant obstacle to recycling, both in terms of cost (registration fee) and of administrative burden.  However, the exoneration from Registration means that there is currently no obligation to share costs for the REACH dossier preparation, management and updates, leading to difficulties in ensuring dossier updates for some recovered substances, and free-riders if one recovery operator funds the dossier and update but others do not.  We suggests that the Roadmap should aim to facilitate circularity under REACH:  - clarify the definition of a “recovered” substance under art 2(7)d to ensure that different routes for recycling are clearly covered. Some clarification is currently provided in the ECHA Guidance “in order to benefit from the exemption in Article 2(7)(d) of REACH, it is sufficient that a registration was filed for the substance by any registrant. This registrant does not have to be part of the supply chain leading to the waste generation". Clarification in the REACH regulation would avoid legal uncertainty for operators.  - specify that the obligations for data sharing and cost sharing applicable to REACH registration also apply to  producers of “recovered” substances under art 2(7)d. In order to enable implementation and enforcement of this, a system of declaration for all producers of recovered substances could be established. This would also facilitate compliance of all producers with the requirements contained in Article 2(7)(d)(ii).
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: ERM Coalition of drinking water supply associations represents the interest of 188 million people in the river basins of Rhine (IAWR, AWBR, ARW, RIWA-Rijn) and Ruhr (AWWR), Danube (IAWD), Elbe (AWE), Meuse (RIWA-Meuse) and Scheldt (RIWA-Scheldt) in clean drinking water. ERM Coalition strongly welcomes the Commission’s announcements in its Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability Towards a Toxic-Free Environment (COM/2020/667 final). - of zero-tolerance on non compliance and therefore to strengthen the principles of 'no data, no market' and the ‘polluter-pays’ under REACH, in particular by requiring compliance of all registration dossiers and revoking the registration numbers in case of non-compliance. In this context, the Commission clearly points out that only one third of the registration dossiers of the chemical substances registered by industry under REACH are fully compliant with the information requirements. Therefore, it is also of high relevance that dossiers will be checked for data quality and correctness. - to classify persistent, mobile and toxic (PMT) and very persistent and very mobile substances (vPvM) as substances of very high concern (SVHC) within REACH. - to phase out the use of PFAS in the EU, unless it is proven essential for society. In this context, we call for a narrow definition of “essential for society”.  Along with European Parliament´s resolution on the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability (P9_TA(2020)0201)  - we highlight the urgency to rapidly phase out SVHCs (No. 22). - we call for legislation, providing regulatory stability and predictability, which is key to give direction to the necessary innovation for the transition to a circular, safe and sustainable chemicals sector, including the sustainable use of renewable feedstock to support the bioeconomy, and long-term investments to achieve a toxic-free environment (No. 100). All persistent substances simply keep accumulating in water, air and soil, eventually passing every threshold if their release is unstopped. Therefore, persistent substances either have to be kept within a closed industrial cycle or be replaced by biodegradable substances which are integrated into the natural cycle of decay. This is key to a circular and sustainable chemical sector.  For public health it is essential to not only review and assess original substances but to include degradation and transformation products during registration, evaluation, authorization, and restriction processes.   Despite Art. 7.3 Water Framework Directive, drinking water suppliers are increasingly struggling to ensure the safeness of water. Upscaling technology requirements means - placing the burden of costs on the public/citizens/consumers instead of the polluters/financial beneficiaries of contaminations. - shifting towards non-sustainability due to increased energy costs and waste. - in case of technical failure there is a high risk of noncompliance with EU drinking water standards and possible impacts on public health. With regards to emerging persistent and mobile substances we particularly need to highlight the fact that even most modern purification methods are not able to eliminate such substances to 100 %.  Introducing PMT/vPvMs as SVHC will show EU´s global leadership in protecting public health and ensuring safe, sustainable and affordable drinking water supply. feedback_msg_text: In den Mitgliedsstaaten der EU ist der Vollzug von Gesetzen und Verordnungen unterschiedlich zu bewerten. Zuerst muss ein einheitlicher Vollzug geschaffen werden, bevor Gesetze und Verordnungen verschärft oder erweitert werden. Ansonsten kommt es zu einer Wettbewerbsverzerrung, die weitere Regulierungsvorhaben verbietet und dem EU-Binnenmarktartikel widerspricht. Weitere Regulierungen dürfen nur anhand detaillierter Analysen über das real zu erwartende Risiko erfolgen. Eine Regulierung aus Unwissenheit oder auf Basis reiner Annahmen muss vermieden werden. Die Lebensbedingungen der EU-Bürger:innen verbessert sich nicht durch weitere unnötige Datenerfassung bzw. -anhäufung.  Die unglaubliche Menge an denkbaren Mischungen macht es unsinnig stoffbezogene Mischungsfaktoren einzuführen, da das Verhalten in Mischungen keine Stoffkonstante ist.  Ein Wiederaufbau nach der sog. Corona-Pandemie mit gleichzeitigem Umbau zu einer nachhaltigen Industrie bzw. Gesellschaft ist dem allgemeinem Wohl zu widerlaufend, da es unrealistisch ist , dass der Lebensstandard erhalten bleiben kann, wenn diese Transformation zu kurzfristig umgesetzt wird. Gleichzeitig widerspricht die bereitwillige Hinnahme des Verlustes von vielen Arbeitsplätzen – gerade im Klein- und mittelständischen Unternehmertum – ebenfalls dem Wohle der Allgemeinheit. Dies widerspricht außerdem klar der Aufgabe der EU-Kommission zur Gleichbehandlung und zur Verfolgung der wirtschaftlichen Ziele im europäischen Wirtschaftsraum. Vor allem, da die unbegründete Hoffnung auf eine Besserung zeitlich nicht vorhersehbar ist  Es ist dann schon Hohn und Spott für die EU-Bürger, deren Arbeitsplätze einfach aufs Spiel gesetzt werden, dass aufgrund der erweiterten Regulierung davon ausgegangen wird, dass die Behörde – in diesem Fall die ECHA selbst – weiterhin finanziert oder gar vergrößert wird.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: The ZVO welcomes the opportunity to publicly comment on the EU Commission's plans for the revision of REACh. In this context, the ZVO expressly supports the objectives of sustainability and protection of human health and the environment on which the paper is based. However, the ZVO urges that all measures must be demonstrably effective as well as economically, socially and technologically acceptable and feasible. This must be considered holistically and proven by objective, public studies. Risk-risk tradeoffs must be publicly evaluated. In many of the considerations presented here concerning a revision of the "EU legislation on registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemicals", the ZVO has considerable doubts that the intentions and the intended measures will serve the common good.  Key statements derived from the detailed review (see attached document):  1. the further accumulation of unspecified and unreflected amounts of data will not lead to an improvement of the living conditions of EU citizens.   2. the introduction of substance-related mixing factors is nonsensical, since the behavior in mixtures does not represent a substance constant. To consider all conceivable mixtures will fail due to sheer quantity.  3. The claim that communication in supply chains is inefficient is unfounded. Criteria for this assessment are missing, comprehensible measures are not mentioned. Potential outcomes from the unstated measures are not assessed.   4. The Commission overlooks the fact that the insurmountable complexity of dossiers is caused on the one hand by its own specifications, and on the other hand by actual complexity in reality that defies regulatory simplification. The Commission must face this complexity. With the envisaged changes, the complexity already criticized today would again increase drastically.  5. The increasingly generic regulatory approaches based on potential hazards of substances indicate insufficient coverage of the technical issues. It is unacceptable to undertake far-reaching regulations out of ignorance or on the basis of pure assumptions without conducting detailed analyses of the real risk to be expected.   6. the enforcement of existing laws differs in the member states. It does not make sense to tighten or expand laws and regulations without first achieving uniform enforcement. If this is not possible, all further regulatory projects will be superfluous. The Commission should urgently shift its focus here from legislative to executive unification.  7. ZVO and its member companies are also working to rebuild after the Covid crisis and support the goals of the Green Deal. However, maintaining living standards in a sustainable society requires the continuation of an industry and value chain that is strong and can implement change. Struggle for survival or relocation processes outside Europe are counterproductive for these goals - both for companies and society as well as sustainability.  8. The fact that the Commission openly announces that an undisclosed number of jobs will be lost with the hope of improvement in an undated future is, in ZVO's opinion, not compatible with the mandate of the EU Commission for the common good.  9. As an argument for an extended regulation, it must not be accepted that the financing and the continued existence or even the expansion of an authority like ECHA is secured by sufficient fees. This is a false self-image as a public servant and makes a mockery of the previously accepted job losses of the general public. Here the ZVO urgently asks to correct publicly. Feedback from: Zentralverband Oberflächentechnik e.V. (350.8 KB - PDF - 10 pages) Download
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Ich unterstütze mit Nachdruck, dass mit der "Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability" eine Null-Verschmutzung erreicht werden soll. Folgende Stoffe sollen in REACH aufgenommen werden: "Endocrine disruptors, persistent, mobile and toxic and very persistent and very mobile substances as categories of substances of very high concern".  Eine Null-Verschmutzung der Umwelt ist anzustreben. Giftige Substanzen sind durch ungiftige zu ersetzen. Das betrifft vor allem den Einsatz im Lebensmittelbereich und dem direkten Einwirken auf die Umwelt. Auch die Kette von der Erzeugung bis zur Abfalleigenschaft muss stärker überwacht werden.  Eine Beteiligung der Umweltkosten bei der Freisetzung von giftigen Substanzen ist von den Inverkehrbringern einzufordern.  Um neue Erkenntnissen zu erhalten, muss der Focus auf neue Substanzen sowie bereits auf bekannte Stoffe und deren Kombinationswirkung gerichtet werden. Insbesonders dann, wenn deren ökotoxische Wirkungen nicht hinreichend erforscht sind, damit mehr wissenschaftlich abgesicherte Daten zu deren Bewertung zur Verfügung stehen.

feedback_msg_text: La révision de la réglementation REACH doit être l’opportunité d’avancer vers la fin des tests de toxicité sur les animaux.   En plus d’être inefficaces dans l’évaluation de la dangerosité des substances pour la santé humaine et l’environnement, ces tests ont déjà condamné des millions d’animaux à des expériences cruelles particulièrement douloureuses.   L’approche de la Commission doit s’inscrire dans une volonté de progrès quant à l’utilisation de méthodes substitutives, nombreuses validées par l’ECVAM (Centre européen de validation des méthodes alternatives), un partage obligatoire des données existantes, une utilisation drastiquement réduite et en dernier recours de tests sur les animaux. Ce qui n’est pas le cas aujourd’hui.   L’investissement des États membres et des institutions européennes n’est pas suffisant et entre en contradiction avec les principes même de la législation communautaire qui a notamment pour objectif le remplacement des tests sur les animaux par des méthodes alternatives.   Afin que ce programme s’inscrive dans une démarche positive en faveur de la santé humaine et de la protection de l’environnement – nous devons assumer pleinement notre responsabilité en mettant tout en œuvre pour ne pas transformer la sur-utilisation de produits chimiques en une hécatombe animale.  En 2021, il est plus que nécessaire d’évoluer face à un paradigme cruel et à rebours des avancées scientifiques et technologiques.    Association One Voice
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: Il regolamento REACH a volte non permette alle aziende di trovare soluzione ai loro quesiti perchè non risulta chiaro, non risulta facile alle aziende trovare i riferimenti e lascia loro dubbi di interpretazione.  Il fatto ad esempio di dover essere successivamente  in grado di motivare e documentare esaurientemente le proprie valutazioni e le conclusioni a cui si è giunti crea panico.  I maggiori problemi riscontrati sono relativi alla registrazione, ad avere risposte in merito a chi ha effettuato la registrazione, alla definizione di scarti o sottoprodotti o a sostanze nocive contenute in minima parte in determinati prodotti ed al loro relativo smaltimento.    Le perplessità emergono spesso anche su obblighi per gli importatori di sostanze/miscele e restrizioni.  Tramite il nostro sportello SIT REACH Veneto, gli utenti riescono ad avere risposte immediate e puntuali ma spesso ci chiedono una consulenza personalizzata. Tale servizio però non viene offerto dai SIT REACH e spesso le aziende si affidano a consulenti che danno loro risposte sbagliate o divergenti.

feedback_msg_text: De chemicaliënstrategie voor duurzaamheid en de wetgeving die daaruit ontstaat moeten juist dierproefnemers doen stoppen om met hun onwetenschappelijke methodiek te 'bewijzen' dat al die gifstoffen geschikt zijn om te gebruiken. Dierproeven zijn onbetrouwbaar en onwetenschappelijk, en zijn bovendien wreed. Dierproefnemers hebben ons verteld dat tabak veilig zou zijn, net als asbest en Chrome-X .. teflon zou zelfs veilig zijn om ons eten in te bereiden maar we weten inmiddels beter! Ook al die stoffen in de Pfas-groep waarvoor we nu de Europese bodem moeten afschrapen waren alle veilig volgens dierproefnemers .. ondertussen is al decennia bekend dat de Europese burger helemaal geen dierproeven wil, en de doelstelling van de Green Deal is om mens en planeet beter te beschermen. Met dierproeven bereiken we precies het tegenovergestelde: hoeveel nieuwe vormen van kanker zijn er nu al niet door dierproefnemers ontstaan!? Dat terwijl er in alle mededelingen en actieplannen van de Commissie over de strategie nauwelijks naar deze uiterst belangrijke kwestie wordt verwezen.  Niet alleen zijn toxiciteitstests op dieren ongelooflijk wreed, ze vormen bovendien een volstrekt ontoereikende basis voor het identificeren en beheersen van gezondheids- en milieugevaren en zouden geen plaats moeten hebben in een chemische strategie van de 21e eeuw. Dierproefnemers zijn geen wetenschappers - dierproeven voldoen niet eens aan de definitie van wetenschap. Hiermee worden de doelstellingen van de Green Deal voor de commerciële belangen van dierproefnemers gewoonweg opzij gezet.  De benadering van de Commissie en ECHA tot dusverre was om standaard uit te gaan van het nut van dierproeven, welke inadequaat, zelfgenoegzaam en achterhaald zijn - en bovendien een gevaar voor de volksgezondheid. Diervrij onderzoek kan wèl iets over de mens vertellen; doch helaas werpen de ECHA en haar dierproefnemers hoge barrières op voor het gebruik van diervrije methoden, terwijl ze toch onbetrouwbare dierproeven vereisen. In vergelijking: we vragen kindermisbruikers ook niet om regelgeving voor pederasten op te stellen.   Er moet zo snel mogelijk wetenschappelijke vooruitgang worden gemaakt die voor de mens relevante gegevens oplevert voor chemische veiligheidsbeoordeling, en worden geïmplementeerd door wetgeving of richtlijnen die voortvloeien uit de Chemische Strategie voor Duurzaamheid.   Dierproefnemers willen juist blijven vasthouden aan hun middeleeuwse onwetenschappelijke methodiek .. dierproefnemers moeten niet op deze issues worden vertrouwd want zij hebben dat vertrouwen al volop geschaad door slachtoffers te maken met hun zogenaamde veilige toxische stoffen die nu al overal in zitten - ook in onze lichamen, waar ze allerlei ongeneeslijke aandoeningen veroorzaken. Dierproefnemers horen op hun grootschalige schade aan de gezondheid van de burger juridisch te worden aangesproken, en hun slachtoffers te worden gecompenseerd zoals reeds met de slachtoffers van het DES-hormoon en Softenon is gebeurd!   Adrie van Steijn, chair/co-founder Diervriendelijk.NL
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: De strategie inzake chemische stoffen en de wetgeving die deze genereert, moeten een kans zijn om eindelijk af te stappen van de wrede, verouderde en onbetrouwbare afhankelijkheid van dierproeven in de Europese Unie - iets dat overweldigend wordt ondersteund door de Europese burgers en ook noodzakelijk is als we oprecht duurzame stappen willen zetten.  Jammer genoeg lijkt deze kans tot dusverre te zijn gemist, aangezien er in alle mededelingen en actieplannen van de Commissie over de strategie nauwelijks naar deze uiterst belangrijke kwestie wordt verwezen. Niet alleen zijn toxiciteitstests op dieren wreed, ze zijn ook een volstrekt ontoereikende basis voor het identificeren en beheersen van gezondheids- en milieurisico’s en zouden geen plaats moeten hebben in een strategie van de 21e eeuw. Miljoenen dieren hebben al geleden en zijn gestorven tijdens chemische tests. Indien we niet afstappen van dergelijke praktijken, worden de doelstellingen van de Green Deal niet gerespecteerd. De benadering van de Commissie en ECHA tot dusverre was om standaard uit te gaan van het nut van dierproeven. Deze aanpak is inadequaat en achterhaald. Er wordt algemeen erkend dat we in plaats daarvan volledig gebruik moeten maken van de volgende generatie diervrije methoden voor het genereren van regelgevende chemische veiligheidsgegevens. Helaas werpen ECHA, en veel lidstaten, hoge barrières op voor het gebruik van diervrije methoden, terwijl ze toch onbetrouwbare dierproeven vereisen. Wetenschappelijke vooruitgang die voor de mens relevante gegevens oplevert voor chemische veiligheidsbeoordeling, moet snel mogelijk worden gemaakt en geïmplementeerd door wetgeving of richtlijnen die voortvloeien uit de Chemische Strategie voor Duurzaamheid.
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: We, ADDA, as the oldest NGO in Catalonia and Spain in the defense of animals and nature, are very concerned with the proposals of the new text of the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability for the omission that is made, again, of a key concept: the respect for animals, which is also respect for the environment and nature.  We consider that The Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability and the legislation it generates should be an opportunity to finally move away from cruel, outdated and unreliable reliance on animal testing in the European Union – something supported overwhelmingly by European citizens and also necessary if we are to really achieve the Green Deal objective to better protect people and planet.  Tragically, to date, this opportunity appears to have been missed with scant reference to this critically important issue in any Commission communications and action plans on the strategy.  Not only are toxicity tests on animals unbelievably cruel, but they are also a wholly inadequate foundation for identifying and controlling health and environmental hazards and should have no place in a 21st century chemicals strategy.  Millions of animals have already suffered and died in chemicals tests. Unless these impact assessments pay full regard to the animals who continue to suffer in laboratories and the need for a fundamental shift away from animal testing, millions more will continue to suffer and die needlessly, and the goals of the Green Deal will have been betrayed.  The approach of the Commission and ECHA thus far has been to assume the utility of animal tests by default. This approach is inadequate, complacent and outdated. There is widespread acknowledgement that we should instead be making full use of the next generation of non-animal methods for regulatory chemical safety data generation. Sadly, ECHA, and many member states, are erecting high barriers to the use of non-animal methods whilst continuing to require unreliable animal tests.  Scientific advances delivering human relevant data for chemical safety assessment must be rapidly enabled and implemented by any legislation or guidelines ensuing from the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability.  Our concern is clear: what scientific argument can continue to justify the unnecessary suffering of so many animals when there are alternative, and much more precise, methods validated in this regard?
Initiative: Chemicals legislation – revision of REACH Regulation to help achieve a toxic-free environment

feedback_msg_text: AGCO SpA based in Italy, part of AGCO Corporation Group, as manufacturer of agricultural machinery, fully supports the European Commission’s initiative to harmonize road circulation requirements for mobile machinery. We detect a real necessity for harmonization of the road circulation legislation taking into account the complexity of existing technical and sector specific requirements. This legislation should pursue the same high level of on-road safety in all EU market. The company wants a full EU conformity procedure without multiple approvals anymore for placing mobile machines on the market.  AGCO SpA prefers a regulatory approach which combines self-testing for most road circulation aspects with no need for accreditation (already covered by the Machinery Directive), while third party testing should be required only for safety critical aspects directly relating to road use (for instance steering and braking). National vehicle registration (registration plate and circulation documents) would remain under Member States’ competence. The drafting and maintenance of this legislation must happen as close as possible to the Commission services having the necessary legislative expertise on machinery occupational safety (Machinery Directive). The EU type approval rules for very large production volume are not suitable for the diversity of low volume slow moving machines using public roads occasionally. These principles and procedures applying to very large volumes of on-road vehicles must be avoided. The conformity assessment procedures must be such that administration and testing requirements do not produce any unnecessary costs for manufacturers of the many low volume highly specialized machines. This harmonization has to reduce the redundant extra testing in each member state.
Initiative: Road circulation requirements for mobile machinery

feedback_msg_text: Unacea, the Italian construction equipment association, member of the European federation Cece would like to express its position regarding to the Inception Impact Assessment regarding Road Ciculation for mobile machinery. •We welcome the initiative to achieve a single market for mobile machinery. •There exist a strong need for a legislation for road circulation harmonisation that takes into account the complexity of existing technical requirements, including from occupational safety, and sector specific requirements.  •We welcome a full EU conformity procedure without multiple approvals anymore to get the permission to travel on public roads. Only having system approvals is not favoured by industry. •The conformity procedures must be such that administration and testing requirements do not produce any unnecessary costs for manufacturers and certainly of the many low volume highly specialised machines. •The new legislation should ensure a high level of on-road safety of mobile machinery. However, most aspects can be self-tested by the manufacturers without compromising safety. For this principle of self-testing no accreditation is necessary. Full third-party testing should only be done for following safety critical aspects: braking and steering. •The mobile machinery fulfilling the EU requirements should not be subject to any further technical requirements in the member states. •The drafting and maintenance of this legislation should happen as close as possible to the Commission services having the necessary legislative expertise on machinery occupational safety (Machinery Directive).  •There shall be no direct relationship to the automotive sectors. The EU type approval rules for very large volumes (100 k – 200 k) are not suitable for low volume, low speed mobile machines that use roads only occasionally. Solutions from the automotive should not be pushed for problems that are non-existing and non-suitable for mobile machines. •A dedicated working group under the lead of the Commission should be set-up (it is overall recognised that the most suitable Member States experts come from the transport ministries).  •The new legislation should state clearly that interference with machinery directive and other applicable EU legislation shall be avoid. •Mobile machinery fulfilling the EU requirements shall not be subject to any further technical requirements in the member states. •Virtual testing is a type of provision already existing for tractors and other vehicles (e.g. visibility checks, light installation, etc.) and may be a useful tool to cut the certification costs because reduces the need of physical prototypes.
Initiative: Road circulation requirements for mobile machinery

feedback_msg_text: Snam welcomes the opportunity to provide feedbacks to the EC Communication on “European vehicle emissions standards – Euro 7 for cars, vans, lorries and buses”, and would like to highlight the following: 1. The overall target to guarantee standard robustness should be always set looking to a fuel and technology neutral approach. In this respect, an evaluation of CO2 emissions on a Well-to-Wheel (WtW) approach should be considered in setting any new standard in addition to the current homologation procedures.  2. According to these principles, natural gas and biomethane have to be explicitly considered because the mobility sector needs a comprehensive approach. Due to its characteristics, natural gas leads to an immediate reduction of CO2 emissions at the exhaust and on a WtW basis, biomethane can be compared to 100% renewable electric mobility (if issued from liquid manure the overall emission balance is even negative). New standards should also include a specific focus on local pollutants (i.e. PM and NOx) and on strategic measures to reduce their emissions in order to improve air quality. Among these measures, the replacement of existing vehicles with new or retrofitted gas vehicles is a cost-effective solution since they emit less NOx (-75%) and PM (-95%) compared to traditional fuels.  3. It is shared EC view that future emissions standard should be developed on the basis of an exhaustive assessment and monitoring of the implementation of the most recent Euro6/VI standards and a deep evaluation run on independent scientific studies on air quality especially in urban areas and the impact on human health.  4. Snam fully supports the creation of clear standards that can last for an adequate amount of time. This would not only avoid continuous adaptation costs for the vehicle manufacturers and refilling infrastructures side, but also reduce new references difficult to comprehend on the end-user side. A consumer-focused approach should be a top priority offering clear and affordable solutions. 5. In the light of the deep differences between the Light Duty (vans and private cars) and Heavy Duty (lorries and bus) markets, a merging of the two regulations would not be beneficial for simplification, and therefore we suggest keeping them separated. With particular reference to Natural Gas vehicles the following needs also to be considered: - in the evaluation of exhaust emissions (as proposed in the text as non-regulated pollutants) natural gas is a completely aromatic free fuel, with an intrinsic very low attitude in forming ground-level ozone that is detrimental to the respiratory tract and for acidification. In addition, CNG and LNG produce much less NMHC, NOx, SOx and PM emissions (even ultra-fine particles) than the other currently used fuels. - It is considered more appropriate that the evaluation of GHG emissions is done in a consistent way looking at the overall GHG impact, avoiding having a limit/cap in both CO2 emission standard and in other GHG emissions.   - Once the GHG impact is addressed through CO2 equivalent emissions, the dimension of renewable fuels must also be considered. Bio & syn methane are fully compatible with NG technologies and it is very effective also to address GHG emission reduction at WtW level. Today in Europe NG vehicles are already using a blend containing 17% of bio&syn methane distributed as CNG, meaning an additional 20% WtW GHG reduction when compared to pure natural gas.  - Looking at the timeline needed for EU vehicles fleet renewal, natural gas is also a cost-effective solution when used in dedicated retrofit systems to upgrade the emissions level from older vehicles. - Compared to Diesel propulsion, natural gas engines halve the acoustic emissions, offering also ideal solutions for city overnight operations. Finally, considering also hydrogen potential for sustainable mobility, solutions and related technology evolutions should be supported enhancing their adoptions and scale-up.

feedback_msg_text: Le cas des véhicules flex-fuel E85 d'origine doit être mieux pris en compte dans les futures directives sur les émissions de polluants et de CO2 des véhicules. 2 points en particuliers devraient être corrigés.  1)           Pour les véhicules flex-fuel E85 d'origine, le CO2 est mesuré avec les carburants E10 et E85. Pour le reporting, les constructeurs automobiles ne peuvent aujourd'hui que donner la valeur CO2 mesurée avec le carburant essence E10 d'après l’Article 3(6)(b) of Regulation (EU) No 1014/2010.   Pour les véhicules fonctionnant à l'essence ou au GPL et ceux fonctionnant à l'essence ou au Gaz Naturel, les constructeurs peuvent donner les valeurs CO2 mesurées avec le GPL ou le Gaz Naturel d'après l’Article 3(6)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 1014/2010.  Par neutralité technologique entre les véhicules fonctionnant à l'E85 et ceux fonctionnant au GPL ou au Gaz Naturel, il est important de corriger l'Article 3(6)(b) of Regulation (EU) No 1014/2010 et de permettre aux constructeurs automobiles proposant des véhicules flex-fuel E85 d'origine de pouvoir dans leur reporting CO2 auprès de la Commission européenne donner la valeur CO2 mesurée avec le carburant E85.   2)           Pour les véhicules flex-fuel E85 d'origine, la mesure des hydrocarbures imbrûlés avec l'E85 à -7°C est faussée par l’appareil de mesure, le détecteur à ionisation de flammes (FID). En effet, cet appareil mesure non seulement le nombre d’atomes de carbone provenant des hydrocarbures imbrûlés mais aussi celui provenant des molécules d’éthanol. L'éthanol fait partie de la famille des alcools (CxHyOz)et non des hydrocarbures imbrûlés (CxHy). Il est important que les atomes de carbone provenant des molécules d’éthanol soient défalqués du total de la mesure de tous les atomes de carbone pour obtenir seulement les hydrocarbures imbrûlés.

feedback_msg_text: The automotive industry is gaining momentum in a new age and Webasto is actively involved in shaping the future of mobility.  Thus, Webasto welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the Commission’s inception impact assessment on the future European emission standards for road vehicles. Webasto is open to ideas for revising the current regulations and willing to assist in the ongoing process with its technical expertise.  To be effective, future regulations should:  - be based on scientific evidence; - respect the principle of fuel and technology neutrality; - reflect the effectiveness of existing and prospective regulations in a two-step approach.   Sound science and evidence are central values and of paramount importance for the European society. The further development of standards for pollutant emissions should be guided by these principles as well.  In order to truly achieve the human and environmental objectives set, new regulations need to rely on the combined contribution of all technologies and energy carriers available. Life cycle analysis should not only be limited to the mobility sector itself but also reach beyond it. No regulation should be put in place to prevent the use of alternative, renewable fuels if the limits for local emissions are met.  At this point in time, the impact of the latest emission standards is not known to its full extent. In a first step, expected effects of the current legislation should be evaluated closely within a comprehensive impact assessment. In a second step, modelling of the air quality impact of potential future regulations needs to be performed before a well-balanced framework for the future may be defined. feedback_msg_text: L’UTP se réjouit de la démarche de l’UE concernant l’évaluation des émissions des véhicules répondant à la norme Euro 6/VI, notamment pour les autobus. Toutefois, s’agissant de la mise en place d’une norme Euro 7/VII, la profession est assez réservée sur le bienfondé de cette norme pour les autobus. Depuis plusieurs années, le contexte législatif et règlementaire en Europe et en France plaide en faveur d’un renouvellement des flottes autobus par des autobus « propres » c’est-à-dire des autobus à faibles émissions voire à zéro émission. Il est à noter qu’en 2018 près de 30% des autobus circulant sur les réseaux urbains français utilisent une énergie alternative au gazole, ce pourcentage étant amené à croître dans les prochaines années. Pour faire face à ce défi, les industriels concentrent leurs investissements R&D sur des autobus « propres » depuis plusieurs années.  Si l’évolution de la motorisation Euro VI vers l’Euro VII est de la même ampleur que l’Euro V vers l’Euro VI alors l’investissement sera très lourd pour la filière. Il sera fort à parier que les avantages seront finalement limités au regard des coûts très importants de recherche et de déploiement (redéveloppement de toutes les motorisations, mise à jour des systèmes de post-traitement des émissions, nouvelles campagnes de mise au point banc et field tests dans différentes conditions climatiques, mise au point refroidissement/réchauffage urée, …). De plus, la norme Euro VII réduirait les émissions de NOX, PM, HC et CO mais en aucun cas le CO2.  Une révision des normes Euro VII impactera de manière importante cette part d’investissement, sans garantie d’un retour sur investissements puisque les autobus ne représentent qu’une économie de niche par rapport à la voiture individuelle ou aux camions de marchandises. De plus, la crise sanitaire liée au Covid-19 impactera négativement l’économie générale et les finances des collectivités locales quelle que soit leur taille. L’UTP est en faveur de la politique du Green Deal, les transports en commun ayant toute leur place à jouer. Mais, l’augmentation du prix d’acquisition d’un autobus Euro VII pourra paraitre surdimensionnée au regard des apports et risque de faire décaler les renouvellements des flottes initialement prévus. Il semble important qu’un moratoire soit mis en place afin que les finances publiques puissent se redresser et être plus saines face aux défis du changement climatique et de la baisse de la pollution dans nos villes. Par ailleurs, le surcoût inhérent à la R&D Euro VII ainsi qu’une nécessaire évolution/restylage des véhicules pour les rendre plus attractifs vis-à-vis de la précédente génération (ce qui n’apporte rien à l’exploitant à part un coût d’achat supérieur du véhicule) seraient répercutés auprès des clients opérateurs ou collectivités locales, les interrogeant sur le bienfondé d’acquérir des autobus aux normes Euro VII par rapport aux véhicules roulant au gaz, à l’électricité, à l’hydrogène, etc. Cette faisabilité pourra induire une perplexité de l’interdiction de l’énergie fossile sur les autobus d’ici 2040.  Le maintien de la norme Euro VI pour la flotte autobus, déjà très ambitieuse en termes de réductions des émissions de polluants, permettra aux industriels d’engager des ressources financières significatives dans la R&D sur les autobus propres. Une baisse des coûts de construction et de vente de ces derniers est envisagée les rendant plus accessibles pour les opérateurs de transport et les autorités organisatrices. En effet, si les constructeurs ont pour obligation d’élaborer de nouvelles motorisations Euro VII, ce sont des financements en moins pour la R&D sur les autobus propres et par conséquent retarder le déploiement de ces véhicules sur les réseaux du fait de leur coût d’achat aussi élevé. De plus, le choix d’une de ces deux énergies zéro émission nécessitera une transformation de l’outil industriel avec l’abandon des équipements pétroliers [suite & fin Pièce jointe] Feedback from: UTP - Union des Transports publics et ferroviaires (677.8 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Organisation: UTP - Union des Transports publics et ferroviaires
