feedback_msg_text: The future standards shall include the monitoring of more diverse pollutants than today, since scientific investigations and technological evolution of motorization systems show that road transportation produces much more diverse pollutants than previously expected.   Future regulation shall include Ultra Fine Particles (UFP). This is of first importance since this group of particles is believed to be responsible for a large variety of health troubles in the population. A special focus on particles which size is inferior to 23 nanometers shall be taken, since they are currently not monitored. Further categorization of particles, by size and by chemical composition shall be undertaken, since this determines their toxicity.   Emissions of NH3, which is emitted by motorizations with AdBlue system shall also be monitored, since NH3 recombine in the atmosphere with many different compounds, interfering with the NOx equilibrium and, very importantly, aggregating and producing secondary particles of the PM2.5 category.   Finally, with the growing number of electric cars, non-exhaust pollutants shall also be monitored, and especially those produced by the braking systems. Their chemical composition shall also be taken into account – certain rare metals having a strong toxicity, even at very low concentrations.
Initiative: European vehicle emissions standards – Euro 7 for cars, vans, lorries and buses

feedback_msg_text: Anglo American feedback on European Commission roadmap for Euro 7 vehicle emissions standards for cars, vans, lorries and buses  Anglo American is a leading global mining company providing the products critical to a cleaner, greener, more sustainable world. As such we have a broad interest in the development of sustainable mobility solutions (among other sectors) including platinum-group metals (PGMs) used in fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs) and catalytic converters in internal combustion engines (ICEs), as well as base metals used in battery electric vehicles (BEVs).  Anglo American supports the Commission’s intention to submit a proposal for more stringent air pollutant emissions standards for cars, vans, lorries and buses. Despite recent improvements in air quality in the EU, more needs to be done to further improve the emissions performance of the combustion engine, and transport sector as a whole, to ensure protection of human health in urban areas and prevent market distorting national and local policies (e.g. vehicle restriction zones).  Anglo American supports a future emission standard that is simple and most importantly both technology and fuel neutral. Moreover, based on our understanding of the shortcomings of Euro 6/VI, any post-Euro 6/VI emission standard should include provisions for robust real-world emission monitoring over the lifetime of a vehicle, including mandatory market surveillance and in-service conformity testing.  As such we encourage the formation of a single, technology neutral standard set equally for all fuels, including electric vehicles, with a focus on real-world emission performance. Such an approach should enable the least cost, and lowest emission path to the ultimate goal of a zero-emission transport sector. This will also ensure simplicity and predictability for consumers, investors, manufacturers and policy makers at all levels.  As tailpipe emissions continue to decrease, non-exhaust emissions (NEE) including from brake and tyre wear will become increasingly significant. According to the European Environment Agency (https://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/indicators/transport-emissions-of-air-pollutants-8/transport-emissions-of-air-pollutants-8), in 2017, the non-exhaust emissions of PM2.5 accounted for 46 % of emissions from the road transport sector, compared with 18 % in 2000, while for PM10, the contribution increased from 32% to 63%). Given that there is currently no EU legislation in place regulating NEE particles, the revision of Euro 6/VI should include provisions to limit or reduce these emissions from all vehicles, including BEVs and FCEVs.  Any post Euro 6/VI legislation must ensure cost-effective best-available environmental protection and must strike the right balance between the protection of public health and environment, and societal cost. For the revision of Euro 6/VI emission standards to have a significant and measurable impact on urban air pollution and public health, then the new limit must be challenging yet achievable for industry. To ensure that the sector invests in the necessary R&D, industry must be able to realistically imagine delivering the next generation technology capable of respecting any new target. If the price of the vehicle becomes prohibitively expensive for the consumer, the life of older and more polluting vehicles on the road will likely be prolonged.
Initiative: European vehicle emissions standards – Euro 7 for cars, vans, lorries and buses

feedback_msg_text: Air quality, especially in urban areas, is one of the key objectives to ensure health protection and reduce social costs. In this road transport sector has an important role to play together with other parallel actions to reduce traffic congestion and optimize freight logistics and personal mobility models. In view of the revision of the current emissions standards, as Gasnam we would like to highlight the following: 1. Any future emissions standard should be based on an exhaustive assessment of the implementation of the most recent Euro6/VI standards. In the recent years we have seen a fast implementation of different sublevel of standards, both in the LD and HD areas. These have been fundamentally conceived to guarantee the robustness of the systems under Real Driving Emissions, introducing PEMS measurement, and they set very stringent targets already today.  2. In parallel with the progressive penetration of tailpipe zero-emissions solutions, the role of clean fuels such as natural gas is key for several reasons: • Moving into a smaller granularity in the evaluation of the exhaust emissions, as proposed in the text when mentioning non regulated pollutants, will benefit in highlight the intrinsic properties of natural gas, a completely aromatic free fuel, with very low NMHC emissions, translating into a very low attitude in forming ground-level ozone that is detrimental to the respiratory tract and for acidification .  • Due to its gaseous nature natural gas provides homogeneous air-fuel mixture with near-to-zero particle matter emissions. With regard to PN emissions, recent experiences have demonstrated full compliancy of dedicated NG engines, even in the domain below 23nm diameter . • After-systems systems conceived for NG applications are very robust and simple; over the efficiency in converting pollutants, they are also effective in converting unburnt methane hydrocarbons. Current impact from CH4 emissions from dedicated NG engines at the exhaust is as worst case around 1-2% once converted in CO2 equivalent . • As it is mentioned to address also the GHG dimension looking to CO2 equivalent emissions, it must be reminded that bio & synthetic methane, that are fully compatible with NG technologies, is very effective way also to address GHG emission reduction at Well to Wheel level. Today in Europe NG vehicles are already using a blend containing 17% of bio & synthetic methane distributed as CNG.  • Looking to the future and the potential utilisation of natural gas-hydrogen blends, this has been demonstrated to lead to a more complete combustion process, further lowering pollutant emissions . • Looking to the timeline needed for the renewal of the EU vehicles fleet, natural gas is also a cost-effective solution when used in dedicated retrofit systems to upgrade the emissions level from older vehicles. • Compared to Diesel propulsion, NG engines halve the acoustic emissions, offering also ideal solutions for city overnight operations. 3. When reference to the simplification objective, we fully support the creation of simple standards that can last for a certain amount of time. This would avoid continuous updating, difficult to understand also by the end-user. However, because of the deep difference between the two markets, the merging of Light Duty and Heavy Duty regulation is not the correct way to achieve simplification. feedback_msg_text: COMMENTS ON “PROPOSAL FOR A LEGISLATIVE ACT TO REDUCE METHANE EMISSIONS IN THE OIL, GAS, AND COAL SECTORS” FROM LNG ALLIES  LNG Allies, the trade association of the U.S. liquefied natural gas (LNG) industry, supports cost-effective and efficient regulations to address methane emissions along the natural gas supply chain. Our members recognize the importance of continued efforts to reduce methane emissions as U.S. LNG brings climate, environmental, geostrategic, and economic benefits to the world.  LNG Allies looks forward to collaboration with the European Commission and with the International Methane Emissions Observatory, once established, on data collection and verification of methane emissions. The U.S. LNG industry has a strong record on environmental sustainability and seeks to be as transparent as possible regarding information on its efforts.  As the Commission considers possible regulation of methane emissions on fossil energy imported into the EU, we endorse the approach outlined in the Commission’s methane strategy of taking into account international dialogues as well as legislation and regulation in supplier countries. We also support the idea of closer cooperation by the Commission with the United States (as well as Canada and Mexico) “to share experiences and identify joint actions.”  The Commission’s strategy “encourages global-level voluntary and business-led initiatives to immediately close the gap in terms of emissions monitoring verification and reporting” with the ultimate target of compliance with Tier 3 methane emissions standards of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. To that end, and to reduce administrative and technical burdens on companies, we urge the Commission to consider and validate methodologies used in initiatives other than the Oil and Gas Methane Partnership that have comparable goals to increase transparency, improve data accuracy, and curtail emissions. Such initiatives include the Methane Guiding Principles, the Oil and Gas Climate Initiative, The Environmental Partnership, and ONE Future. Major international and U.S. oil and gas companies are participants in all of these programs whose objectives support observance of UNFCCC standards.   Fred Hutchison, President and CEO

feedback_msg_text: The Heinrich Böll Foundation European Union welcomes the decision of the European Commission to introduce a legislative act to reduce methane emissions in the energy sector, and would like to highlight the need to cover the energy-intensive petrochemical sector (from an energy consumption but also from a feedstock point of view), including its entire supply chain. According to the International Energy Agency, petrochemicals account for 14% and 8% of total primary demand for oil and gas, respectively, and will become the world’s biggest driver of oil demand – ahead of trucks, aviation and shipping. More must be done to ensure that the plastics and other petrochemicals that are still used do not contribute needlessly to methane emissions. Moreover, plastics degrade into methane at end-of-life when exposed to ambient solar radiation, contributions that are expected to increase as plastic accumulates in the environment, and for which measures should be advanced. Detailed feedback, elaborated in the framework of the Rethink Plastic Alliance, can be found in the attached submission. feedback_msg_text: Ember supports DG Energy’s efforts to tackle energy-related methane emissions.   We urge that the Commission put more emphasis on coal mine methane (CMM) in the strategy to rapidly address CMM abatement inside and outside of the EU.   1) ***Add CMM abatement inside Europe***  Our research on Poland’s CMM, responsible for 70% of EU’s leaks, showed that CMM emissions from Poland’s operational mines have more climate impact than CO2 emitted by Bełchatów power plant, Europe’s biggest polluter. Coal is much dirtier than we thought - in Poland methane adds on average 23% to the climate impact of burning hard coal produced by this country, even when non-methane mines are taken into account. 50% of leaks occur at mines producing coking coal. Coking coal is used for steel-making by, for example, wind industry. The EU has recently added coking coal to the list of critical materials, therefore coking coal production is unlikely to be phased out soon. Thus, coal-related methane emissions must be prioritised to ensure the least carbon-intensive pathway to electricity decarbonisation.  Poland’s example proved that coal mine methane emissions need a different treatment from oil and gas. For example MRV is already in place in operational mines due to safety measures and hence employment of further abatement measures could be fast-tracked. However, MRV needs to be improved to become more reliable and include total onsite methane emissions, and also to account for abandoned and closed sites which are exempt from reporting and thought to emit significant volumes of methane.  Quick and cheap wins are available in CMM, particularly by banning venting of ready-to-use methane from demethanisation stations. Currently ~16% of Poland’s CMM is released that way. This is despite the fact that selling it or making use of it for electricity generation would require very little investments.  We have five EU-focused suggestions to the Methane Strategy:   1. Extending the point on MRV to account for: - Strengthened quality of reporting checks - Full on-site emissions reporting - Abandoned sites, where no existing owner is liable - closed mines, to avoid creative accounting in measuring methane emissions.   2. Ensuring that the point on banning venting and flaring will immediately address methane captured by demethanisation stations .  3. Requirement for the emitters to present a clear methane emissions reduction strategy as soon as possible. The strategy should provide clear deadlines for methane reduction commitments, especially concerning ventilation air methane capture and utilisation, as technology for capturing low-level emissions (0.1-0.5%) already exists.   4. Methane Strategy should impose methane performance standard, to force the worst performers to either shut down or reduce their emissions.   5. The strategy should set a provisional date for introduction of methane into EU-ETS. This would help provide an incentive to mitigate methane emissions and prioritise closure of the biggest emitters.     2) ***CMM abatement outside Europe***  We welcome the EU’s suggestion to introduce methane emissions standards and we are keen to see a detailed pathway on introduction of these methane emissions standards for coal. The EU is a big importer of coking coal, and will be for some time. Applying methane performance standards to coal imports would stimulate MRV and abatement outside Europe. That would ideally be done with certification schemes that are being developed, for example, for oil and gas.   Therefore, methane strategy should set a clear and ambitious timeline for the introduction of methane emissions standards. Methane emissions standards would cap methane emissions along the entire supply chain for both domestic and imported coal sold and consumed in the EU.   ==== Ember is an independent climate think-tank focusing on the global electricity transition from coal to clean energy. Founded in 2008 as Sandbag.
Initiative: Climate change – new rules to prevent methane leakage in the energy sector

feedback_msg_text: Il Movimento No TAP/SNAM di Brindisi raccoglie diverse associazioni ambientaliste del territorio di Brindisi, Italia, dove c’è un hub del gas con 12 gasdotti in arrivo o partenza (TAP, Interconnessione TAP SNAM Melendugno-Brindisi, Matagiola-Massafra, Eastmed-Poseidon, Rete Adriatica SNAM, tutti inseriti nell’ultima 5th PCI List e tre centrali elettriche a turbogas, di cui Enel Power in funzione e due centrali in conversione: A2A Brindisi Nord e Enel Federico II). Il problema delle emissioni fuggitive da metano sono un vero problema non considerato finora nelle Valutazioni di Impatto Ambientale dei gasdotti TAP/SNAM e delle richieste di conversione. Apprezziamo la proposta per quanto riguarda il monitoraggio e la comunicazione delle fughe (LDAR), ma devono essere inserite anche nelle Valutazione di Impattoi Ambientale e Sanitarie nel calcolo cumulativo delle emissioni prima di autorizzate nuovi gasdotti o centrali elettriche a turbogas. Ed è ancora più necessario includere tali fughe emissive nella valutazione del rischio d’incidente industriale secondo la Direttiva UE di Seveso considerando anche tutti gli impianti a rischio dello stesso distretto industriale. A Brindisi abbiamo avuto il flaring di metano dell’impianto ENI Versalis ed EniPower per malfunzionamenti e manutenzioni per diverse volte in un anno e sappiamo che il metano disperso per fughe su un gasdotto 40 pollici da Matagiola alla zona industriale con oltre 1 miliardo di metri cubi l’anno si aggiunge al flaring… Per quanto riguarda la verifica, rilevamento e riparazione delle fughe (MRV) crediamo se sia un passo avanti per ridurre le emissioni di metano (GHG) in atmosfera, ma sembra anche un alibi per le società di gas&oil per continuare fino al 2050 a imporre nuovi gasdotti e centrali a gas con la scusa di ridurre le emissioni con MRV, perciò più sostenibili. L’incremento dell’uso di metano nel mix energetico metano non deve essere la priorità per la EU, ma il gas fossile deve essere dismesso già prima del 2030 per raggiungere l’obiettivo della riduzione delle emissioni del 55% entro il 2030, invece rischia di essere la soluzione primaria fino al 2050.  La EU deve imporre regole più restrittive all’uso del metano e non proporre nuovi gasdotti importati come nella 5. PCI List: fuori dal fossile subito e niente alibi alle società gas&oil con l’operazione di riduzione delle emissioni fuggitive.  Leave it in the ground. No new fossil infrastructures. E’ l’unico modo per ridurre le emissioni.
Organisation: Movimento No TAP/SNAM della Provincia di Brindisi

feedback_msg_text: The Energy Community Secretariat welcomes the development of a regulation to reduce methane emissions in the energy sector, as an immediate follow up of the EU Strategy on methane emissions.  The Secretariat supports the approach that all the segments within the energy industry involved in methane emissions are subject to the same standards of monitoring, reporting and verifying (MRV), as a ground for any further mandatory actions, regulated from the state and the European Union levels. The Secretariat supports the development of the MRV standards based on the Oil and Gas Methane Partnership (OGMP) framework, applicable to the full supply chain, as proposed by Option 3. This would ensure continuity within the EU boundaries, but would also include the international dimension. It is significant that the companies, which are outside the EU active in upstream and supply business as well as along transit routes will be covered by the same MRV standards.  The adoption of the new EU legislative framework for the Energy Community is a lengthy process and sometimes results in years of delay in the implementation. In the case of the European Green Deal proposals, this should be avoided to preserve the momentum of the Union’s climate ambitions in its neighborhood. Furthermore, several companies of the Energy Community Contracting Parties (in Ukraine, Moldova and North Macedonia) have already joined and continue to be actively engaged in the work of OGMP 2.0. Making this framework applicable for mandatory regulation within the EU would ensure better preparedness and a much higher level of compliance of the relevant energy companies in the Contracting Parties with the EU legislation, enabling the introduction of the same MRV standards earlier, even before mandatory implementation in the Energy Community. With the necessary capabilities in place, the Energy Community Secretariat would be the appropriate institution to monitor the implementation by the Contracting Parties. The recognition of compliance with EU standards is an essential element in preserving the integration of energy markets between the Energy Community and the Union. The proof of such compliance shall become even more important in case of policy tools for limiting carbon leakage – such as a carbon border adjustment mechanism – are introduced in the EU.  The Secretariat welcomes the intention to improve the mitigation of methane leakages on all fossil fuel-related infrastructure. However, different current starting points among the companies and countries and variety in technology developments have to be taken carefully into account when defining the leak detection and reparation (LDAR) obligations. Thus, sufficient time for implementation steps has to be considered. Further, LDAR costs have to be fairly reflected in the network tariffs, which will have an upward impact on total energy prices for consumers. On the other hand, the decrease of network losses will be beneficial for consumers and companies. All those different aspects should be considered, with all their benefits and drawbacks, when defining the threshold and granularity of LDAR regulation. The European Commission is encouraged to take into account the methane emissions targets, as defined by this Regulation when preparing the proposal for the 2030 emission reduction targets for the Energy Community.
Initiative: Climate change – new rules to prevent methane leakage in the energy sector

feedback_msg_text: KAYRROS Response to the Commission's consultation on Climate change - new rules to prevent methane leakage in the energy sector (attached file)  KAYRROS, a leading geospatial platform providing asset based economic and environmental data analytics and key contributor to the Methane Tracker of the International Energy Agency (IEA), supports the implementation of option 3 of the Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment: Translating the OGMP framework into E.U. legislation applicable to the full supply chain.  Data provided to the IEA Methane Tracker shows that the decrease of approximately 10% of global methane emissions recorded in 2020 from the oil and gas sector remains fragile. Some regions like Russia increased their visible methane emissions.  KAYRROS detections show that most large methane emission events occur during the pre-production, extraction, processing, liquefaction, and transportation processes, before the fuels reach their end-users in the European Union (E.U.).   Different operational practices among operators result in wide disparities in their ‘visible methane’ intensity (ratio of observed methane emissions to production volumes). For example, only one leak of visible methane was detected in Saudi Arabia, the world’s largest oil exporter, in 2019 and 2020. In contrast, the ‘visible methane’ intensity of Turkmenistan was 1,000 times greater. Midstream players also run the gamut from zero release, as in the case of pipelines within the E.U., to multiple emission events detected from pipelines in both the U.S. and Russia. Current regulations do not adequately incentivize high-intensity suppliers to reduce their emissions.  Thanks to the Sentinel-5P and Sentinel-2 satellites operated by the Copernicus program, KAYRROS helps operators identify super-emitters above 1t/h in near real-time. Stripping large methane emissions from the oil and gas supply chain would remove 1 Gt CO2e, which is equivalent to cutting E.U. carbon emissions by 25% on a 20-year global warming power basis.   Monitoring satellites covering the full earth with daily or near-daily revisit frequency such as Sentinel-5P and Sentinel-2, combined with Artificial  Intelligence, are the cornerstone of any comprehensive monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system. Other technologies such as aerial campaigns and mobile sensors bring added value for an OGMP 2.0 Onshore Upstream methane monitoring system.  Based on the OGMP 2.0 framework, the E.U. should establish a mandatory monitoring and reporting framework for all operators in the energy supply chain. To be fully efficient, operators should implement real-time measurement systems with a real-time alert function, a key factor to eliminate super-emitters.  Current self-reporting mechanisms should be replaced with formalized, independent certification mechanisms that can transparently guarantee whether the production of hydrocarbon energy has been deemed free of major leaks of visible methane or routine flaring. Third-party audit can contribute with objective, unbiased, and auditable measurements to the future International Methane Emissions Observatory and the Methane Supply Index.  Other environmental policies can also help achieve the E.U. Methane Strategy, by setting targets to limit CO2 emissions-equivalent instead of CO2 emissions.  Please find enclosed the full KAYRROS feedback to the consultation. Feedback from: KAYRROS (822.2 KB - PDF - 10 pages) Download
Initiative: Climate change – new rules to prevent methane leakage in the energy sector

feedback_msg_text: Honeywell welcomes the opportunity to comment on the Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment (IIA) on a ‘Proposal for a legislative act to reduce methane emissions in the oil, gas and coal sectors.’ Honeywell fully supports the aims of the proposed assessment in relation to bringing in MRV, LDAR and the consideration of ending routine venting and flaring.  In our submission, we shall be limiting our comments to LDAR, an area in which we possess great expertise and have technology already supporting leading energy companies who want to mitigate their methane emissions in a cost-effective way.   Cost-effective and continuous LDAR   LDAR has rightly been identified as a key part of the three-pronged approach the Commission is taking towards reducing methane emissions in the energy sector. We fully support and encourage the Commission’s view that “prevailing and emerging best practices” must be used in this regard. Continuous methane emissions monitoring technologies such as Gas Cloud Imaging have the potential to significantly cut methane emissions in a cost-effective way and limit the risks of undetected leaks or human errors, compared to the use of older technologies. Honeywell urges the Commission to ensure forthcoming legislation provides for the best-in-class technology to be used and incentivized.   A more detailed explanation of our position can be found in the attached position paper.  Preliminary assessment of impacts  Economic: We understand and appreciate that there will be an economic impact on the energy sector, but that this is only realistic in bringing infrastructure up to the standards needed to meet our environmental goals. However, and as highlighted by the IEA, about 40% of methane emissions in the oil and gas sector could be saved at net-costs. Getting the right LDAR technology deployed across the entire energy chain earlier, rather than later, will help the EU in going a long way to meeting the 2050 objective of being carbon neutral.   Social: The Commission has noted that the ultimate economic impact may well be on the end user, i.e. the energy customer. While it would be difficult to legislate against this, the Commission should bear in mind that the environmental benefits to all, far outweigh the spreading of the cost across a customer base. In addition, technology already exists and is being used in other parts of the world that is already leading to cost savings.   Environmental: Honeywell very much supports the Commission’s view that the benefits of legislation covering methane emissions would “increase with the scope of the legislation in terms of sector coverage and in terms of supply chain” and therefore calls on the Commission to be ambitious in this regard. Only by being ambitious, will the Commission reach its aims of seeing a significant drop in methane emissions in the EU, and this ambition needs to extend out beyond the EU’s borders. Honeywell again supports the Commission’s drive to ensure that the best-in-class practices are put in place.  Top line asks  Honeywell welcomes and is supportive of the direction in which the Commission plans to tackle methane emissions in the energy sector. A high level of ambition is needed in order to meet the ultimate aims of the Green Deal. In relation to methane in particular, Honeywell calls on the Commission to:  1) Ensure that there is continuous, real-time monitoring of the operations (downstream, midstream and upstream) to ensure that leak detection and repair works can be carried out as they are needed on an ongoing basis. 2) Provide incentives for the energy sector to invest in best-in-class technologies, with support provided especially for early adopters. 3) Ensure that all technology used is able to measure and quantify methane emissions.  Honeywell looks forward to working with the Commission and others to ensure that sensible, fit-for-the-future legislation is developed and implemented effectively in order for the energy sector to tackle methane Feedback from: Anonymous (160.5 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Per la transizione energetica necessarie azioni urgenti per ridurre le emissioni della filiera del gas naturale. Al fine di scongiurare che la nuova normativa risulti ancora appiattita su una tipica logica del profitto societario o aziendale, ormai inadeguata ai tempi dell'emergenza climatica in atto, è necessario che le disposizioni siano dotate di una Adozione di una stringente regolazione con obblighi e incentivi per la riduzione delle emissioni di metano dalle reti di distribuzione, trasporto e stoccaggio a fini di tutela climatica, oggi assente.Nella UE il 74 % delle emissioni di metano della filiera del gas naturale provengono dalle infrastrutture di trasporto e stoccaggio (21%) e dalle reti distribuzione (53%). feedback_msg_text: For the reasons given in the attached submission, I would like to see the following measures being included in the Methane Regulation:   - MRV and LDAR Methane Regulation should include petrochemicals and plastics in its compulsory measurement, reporting and verification (MRV) regime and further require leakage detection and repair (LDAR) at all sites involved in petrochemical and plastic production (this should include fossil fuels as energy sources and feedstock). Sector coverage should include full lifecycle/supply chain (upstream, midstream and downstream gas and oil, coal and biogas/biomethane – as well as natural gas liquids).   - Banning routine venting and flaring of gas along the entire supply chain.  I strongly support the Commission’s attempt to include measures to eliminate routine venting and flaring according to prevailing and emerging best practices, including from industry, across different segments of the supply chain. I also strongly support the proposal of going beyond the scope of fossil gas and also including oil, coal and biogas/biomethane – as well as natural gas liquids) and supply chain coverage (including imports).  - Mandatory full lifecycle/supply chain emissions profile for fossil fuels entering EU market (in alignment with 2030 climate targets, Paris Agreement, Single Use Plastics Directive and Circular Economy Action Plan) As the EU Commission has outlined, “most of the fossil fuels consumed in the EU are imported, and 75-90% of the methane emissions associated with these fuels are emitted before reaching the EU’s borders”. I completely agree that “methane is a greenhouse gas and an ozone-precursor that knows no borders” and “when emitted in one country, it will have a climate and air quality impact in others.” I also acknowledge that “the largest share of energy-related methane emissions associated with fossil fuels consumed in the EU are emitted outside of the EU borders, making international action necessary”.  Therefore, I support the proposal “to work on options for possible methane emission standards, targets or other incentives to tackle methane emissions in relation to fossil energy imported to the EU.” and strongly encourage the Commission to introduce a mandatory full lifecycle/supply chain emissions profile for fossil fuels entering the EU market (including as a direct feedstock or as a fossil fuels based feedstock   - Introduction of “low-leaks” procurement standards (in alignment with EU’s 2030 climate targets, Paris Agreement, Single Use Plastics Directive and Circular Economy Action Plan) In addition to the introduction of a supply chain covering emissions profile, I strongly encourage the Commission to introduce procurement standards – aiming at demanding a “low-leakage” supply chain (as a basis for eligibility to bid or as a performance condition in a contract – as also proposed by the IEA in their Methane Leaks Regulatory Roadmap and Toolkit).   - Mandatory dual global warming potential (GWP) accounting for methane As outlined above, I agree that methane is a powerful greenhouse gas that has a very significant impact on global warming – in particular over the period of 20 – 30 years which is left to achieve net zero in 2050. However, the EU and its Member States currently use only the 100-year timeframe to calculate the global warming potential of methane. Moreover, authorities use outdated numbers to calculate the CO2-equivalents of methane, which leads to a falsified climate impact of methane. I therefore encourage the Commission to introduce a dual GWP accounting for methane and to also make it mandatory for all European institutions to use the most accurate numbers as provided by the IPCC.   Finally, I ask the Commission to explore options to a) develop phase-out plans for fossil fuel infrastructure (including petrochemical facilities) and b) introduce a moratorium for new infrastructure (including petrochemical facilities) until detailed phase-out plans are being delivered. feedback_msg_text: The proposal for a legislative act to reduce methane emissions is, for the students and researchers of emergenzaclimatica.it, surely a little step towards the achievement of at least 55% reduction by 2030 in green house gas emissions, but SWD(2020) 176 final indicates that methane will continue to be the EU’s dominant non-CO2 greenhouse gas. An, if compulsory MRV at company-level should be a human right in information on fossil and biomethane energy production and transport emissions in terms of climate justice, industrial risk of accidents and health, LDAR seems to be an excuse to continue building and financing methane infrastructures and gas power plants, as evidenced in the draft of the new 5th EU Projects of Common Interest List, that includes lots of new gas pipelines, as Eastmed Poseidon, doubling TAP, Melita, Matagiola Massafra and Rete Adriatica SNAM only in Italy. And that the Communication is built on the Oil and Gas Methane Partnership (OGMP 2.0) methodology does not reassure us in terms of climate emergency. There are no International standards on methane emissions, considering that 75-90% of fossil fuels consumed in the EU are imported from outside EU countries. We think it is also necessary to regulate venting and flaring emissions and to include MRV information compulsory in the Environmental Impact Assessments needed for new methane and biogas transport and Energy production projects, specially in the evaluation for the application of the Seveso EU Directive in terms of industrial risk of accidents, where the methane leaks are not considered. The EU Seveso evaluation has to sum all cumulative impacts, since most of the last approved gas pipelines projects splitted the same pipeline in many smaller sections so to avoid the application of the Seveso EU Directive, that moreover does not consider methane leakage in the gas transport infrastructure as an industrial accident, climate and health risk. In conclusion, methane leakage regulation should have been implemented decades of years ago in upstream, midstream and downstream gas and oil, coal and biogas/biomethane sectors: it’s never too late, but EU should always have the primary target to abandon definitely fossil fuels and greenhouse gas as soon as possible, without the possibily, with this legislative act for LDAR, to postpone the EU carbon-zero target, approving new gas infrastructures, PRT and gas power plants.

feedback_msg_text: This given initiative acknowledges the importance of methane as the second powerful greenhouse gas to fuel global warming. And while the prevention of methane leakages is an important short term target for existing natural gas infrastructure, it may not be used as an argument to support the long term existing of the latter and therewith continued methane emissions. Given high CO2 emissions during combustion the additional high methane emissions in the upstream chain can possibly be reduced but can never be set to zero.While keeping in mind that the global warming potential of methane is 85-fold (over a 20-year period) compared to CO2. Therefore, it is important for this initiative to note, that existing natural gas supply needs to be phased out as soon as possible in order to significantly reduce the EU's total greenhouse impact and meet the Paris climate target of 1,5C.  We welcome the “rules to prevent methane leakage in the energy sector” as a regulating factor to include “binding rules on monitoring, reporting, verification, leak detection and repair in the energy sector” as stated the initiative. This can, however, only be a first step for the EU to end the use of all fossil fuels including natural gas and lead the transition to a 100% renewable energy system as soon as possible.  We therefore propose for this initiative to acknowledge damaging impact of any natural gas infrastructure and include the necessity of ending use of natural gas by 2030.   For further information about the climate impact of natural gas and methane in particular, take a look at our attached study from 2019. feedback_msg_text: RE: Response to Inception Impact Assessment on labelling fragrance allergens  ETRC welcomes the opportunity to contribute to DG GROW’s consultative work with regards to labelling of additional fragrance allergens following the SCCS/1459/11 ‘2012 Opinion relating to Annex III of Regulation No. 1223/2009.  While ETRC, as a retailing organisation, is not competent to assess the decision for labelling of additional fragrance allergens, ETRC would like to invite the Commission to consider Option 3: E-labelling as a way forward should the Commission introduce the obligation to label additional 62 fragrance ingredients as indicated in the IIA.  The duty-free and travel retail channel is made up of a global customer base of internationally diverse travellers, where the consumer may or may not even speak the language of the airport they are travelling through or airline or maritime vessel they are travelling on. Furthermore, many of the beauty products supplied to this channel are travel retail gifting and/or travel retail exclusives, packaged specifically for this global retail channel and not available on domestic markets.  ETRC fully supports the principle that consumers should have access to relevant and meaningful information on the products they wish to purchase and consume. ETRC has been working for many years to find a pragmatic solution to providing consumers with product information in a way that meets both the requirements of the regulators and the specificities of our unique consumer, the international traveller.  ETRC argues that e-labelling such as suggested in Option 3 of the IIA through which mandatory information can be provided in a consumer-friendly format is the optimum solution to comply fully with regulatory requirements, while enabling our channel to continue to thrive and propose iconic products targeting an international audience.  In 2018, ETRC contracted for the development of a pilot project to create a digital platform for information to consumers in duty free and travel retail, across three core categories: Food & confectionery; Alcohol beverages; and Perfumes & Cosmetics. For this pilot, initiated with the full support of our members, the consumer front-end is designed as a responsive website, and product information is accessible in several languages via a barcode on the packaging scanned by the consumer using a smartphone, scanner facilities in-store and on-line, ensuring that the information is available to all consumers at any time.  Product information is provided directly by the suppliers as the responsible business operators, focusing on regulatory information, displayed on the consumer interface in a standardised format with clear landmarks across all product categories so that consumers can easily find the information they are looking for.  As part of this pilot project, ETRC conducted a series of passenger interviews, in accordance with ISO 9241 methodology, which took place at Hamburg Airport on 12 December to collect crucial users’ feedback on the pilot platform. ETRC will be pleased to share the results with the Commission once available.   Ultimately, the acceptance by EU and national policymakers for such a solution will be crucial to our efforts in the next stages of the project. Therefore, ETRC very much welcome the current work of the Commission looking towards the possibility to enact legislation to formally allow for product information to be provided by means other than on the package or on the label to better inform consumers in the digital age.  ETRC looks forward to working together with the Commission during the consultation process, and remain available for questions. Feedback from: ETRC (685.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Labelling fragrance allergens

feedback_msg_text: Werte Kommission,  aus Sicht der Österreichischen Gesellschaft der Kältetechnik (ÖGKT) befinden wir uns auf Grund der „F-Gase-Verordnung“ derzeit in einem Wandel bei der Verwendung von Kältemitteln in Bezug auf deren Gefährlichkeit. So kommen einerseits vermehrt natürliche Kältemittel zum Einsatz die toxisch, brennbar, luftverdrängend sind oder hohe Betriebsdrücke haben. Andererseits werden schwer entflammbare anstelle von nichtbrennbaren Kältemitteln verwendet. Es zeigt sich, dass sehr viele Fachfirmen und Anlagenbetreiber damit schlicht überfordert sind, entsprechende Aus- und Weiterbildungsmöglichkeiten nur schwer zu finden bzw. sehr kostenintensiv sind.   Deshalb ersuchen wir Sie, werte Kommission, bei der Überarbeitung der „F-Gase-Verordnung“ auch den Aspekt der Aus- und Weiterbildung miteinzubeziehen und nachstehende Anregungen zu einfließen zu lassen:  1) Förderung von Lehrprogrammen für den Umgang mit natürlichen Kältemitteln (NH3, CO2, Kohlenwasserstoffe) sowie Schaffung eines entsprechenden Nachweises darüber. Jedoch unter Rücksichtnahme dadurch keine Nachteile für Unternehmen oder Betreiber entstehen zu lassen sondern durch Anreize begünstigt werden (z.B. durch entsprechende Abdeckung finanzieller oder zeitlicher Aufwendungen mit Hilfe entsprechender Förderungsprogramme.)  2) Analog dazu sollte das Personenzertifikat gemäß F-Gase-Verordnung künftig auch die geänderten speziellen Sicherheitsanforderungen z.B. auf Grund der Brennbarkeit mancher HFOs oder FKWs umfassen. Diese Kenntnisse sollten auch in regelmäßigen Intervallen nachgewiesen werden. Wobei auch hier keine Barrieren entstehen dürfen.  3) Dies alles sollte durch (finanzieller) Förderung unabhängiger Institutionen vorangetrieben werden, die auf die länderspezifische Gesetzeslage und das Ausbildungsniveau angepasste Aus- und Weiterbildungsmaßnahmen entwickeln und abhalten können.  Unsere Meinung ist, dass der nachhaltigste Weg zur Umsetzung der Ziele der F-Gase-Verordnung über den Weg gezielter Aus- und Weiterbildung geht, da so die Bewusstseinsschaffung für relevante Umweltaspekte, Effizienz und neue Technologien erfolgt und gleichzeitig Sicherheit im Umgang mit gefährlichen Stoffen für Fachfirmen und Anlagenbetreiber geschaffen wird.
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)

feedback_msg_text: E.DSO fully supports Green Deal objectives the European Commission intends to achieve. Becoming the first carbon neutral continent in 2050 is an ambitious target which can only be achieved through massive electrification of uses. European DSOs are by the nature of their activities contributing to achieve the energy transition. E.DSO’s members are involved in achieving energy transition internally, they are committed to reduce their own Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions linked to their activities.  F-Gases, SF6 in particular, are used in the distribution network equipment in switchgears installed in substations (primary, secondary). Having excellent dielectric properties, they are used for insulation (electrical insulation) and breaking (arc quenching) purposes. They allow to design compact switchgear necessary in substations of limited dimensions. Moreover, increased reliability and standardization of switchgears with SF6 has led to a high level of operational experience, decreasing the maintenance costs of the devices and increasing occupational safety.   E.DSO’s members have been taking several actions to limit their GHG emissions linked to F-Gases. For instance, by: -Shifting their purchase for F-Gases free solutions when mature and adapted solutions exist -When alternative solutions are not available yet, using low-leakage equipment (pressure sealed)  -Monitoring carefully leakage rates and contributing to constantly reducing the amount of leaks (e.g., by improving maintenance instructions for safe handling of SF6 gases) -Monitoring the end of life of their existing equipment -Promoting or carrying out themselves recycling and re-use of SF6 -Working on concepts for a complete end-of-life-treatment -Implementing pilots as part of Research and Innovation to develop alternative solutions   European regulation has to align with Green Deal ambition and Montréal protocol. To ensure the right policy measures are taken, E.DSO welcomes the willingness of the European Commission to process to an impact assessment. This assessment should cover additional aspects: • First, a mapping of all existing amounts of SF6  correlated with leakage of equipment across Europe could be established to gather valuable and reliable information easily and quickly in order to assess the effectiveness and adequacy of policy measures to adopt. For that purpose, it is necessary to rely on detailed and transparent assessment of existing mature alternative solutions. Regarding switchgears, DSOs considers suitable alternatives to SF6 or F-Gases in general are not yet totally available as has been shown by this review of the Öko-Recherche Briefing Paper ‘SF6 and alternatives in electrical switchgear and related equipment’. As associations of major DSOs in Europe, Eurelectric, E.DSO and GEODE’s pointed out important remarks - several factors have to be taken into account, such as: costs effectiveness, technical feasibility, availability of reliable alternative, energy efficiency, toxicology but also national specificities, operational requirements. Considering this, a reasonable and feasible transition period should be established.  • Relating to the toxicity of alternative solutions, in order to secure investments, it is important to analyze toxicity according to REACH regulations, taking into account the targeted masses installed and paying attention to decomposed gases.  • Moreover, a particular attention should be payed to competition matters. This aspect could be further developed in the impact assessment to avoid a dependency on foreign technology monopoly. Priority shall be given to promotion of SF6  free solutions research, innovation and competitiveness of EU market-based alternative solutions, in a framework of the European Recovery plan, promoting a more efficient incentive-based transformation instead of a cost-based prohibition only approach.  E.DSO members remain available to provide all information needed, especially about their F-Gases uses.
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)

feedback_msg_text: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,  Aus Sicht des Deutschen Kälte-und Klimatechnischen Vereins (DKV) e.V. sind folgende Punkte anzumerken:  • Die derzeitige F-Gas Verordnung wird konsequent umgesetzt, in den drei Jahren 2015-2018 wurde eine Reduktion von 37 % erreicht und nach 6 Jahren (bis 2021) wird man 55 % erzielen. Durch das Quotensystem wird eine deutliche Reduktion der in den Verkehr gebrachten F-Gase erzielt. Die Reduktionsschritte werden derzeit planmäßig umgesetzt. Würde man jetzt eine neue Verordnung einführen, würde die Arbeit von vorne starten und die Einführung der neuen Inhalte bis hin zum Anwender würde wieder Jahre benötigen.  Die nicht immer klaren und technisch logischen Regeln sind zwischenzeitlich bekannt und werden richtig umgesetzt. Die erfolgreiche Umsetzung der Ziele sollte mit der bestehenden Version kontinuierlich fortgesetzt werden. Das bedeutet auch, dass man die Verbote des Inverkehrbringens gemäß Artikel 11 (1) im Anhang III nicht verändern sollte.   • Illegales Inverkehrbringen unter Umgehung des Quotensystems führt zu einer Belastung der Umwelt und schädigt diejenigen in ihrer wirtschaftlichen Existenz, die gesetzeskonform handeln und nur Kältemittel einsetzen, die innerhalb der festgelegten Quoten in den Verkehr gebracht wurden. Ein solches kriminelles Handeln hat es in der mehr als 150 jährigen Geschichte der Kältetechnik bisher nicht gegeben. Der DKV sieht eine europäische Lösung, die die Verwerfung beim grenzüberschreitenden Warenverkehr vermeidet, als ebenso notwendig und schnellstmöglich anstrebenswert an. Dies kann aber nicht durch eine Änderung der F-Gas-V erreicht werden. Dies sollte durch gut überlegte europäische Maßnahmen grenzüberschreitend dem kriminellen Handeln ein Ende bereiten.   • Die F-Gas-VO wurde deutlich vor dem Kigali Amendment in Kraft gesetzt. Beim Vergleich stellt man fest, dass nicht alle Kriterien identisch sind. Daher ist es wohl nötig eine detaillierte Analyse durchzuführen, um damit sicherzustellen, dass auch nach 2030 keine widersprüchlichen Regelwerke bestehen.    • Es fällt auf, dass in der derzeitigen F-Gas Verordnung immer noch die Daten vom vierten Sachstandbericht AR4 (IPCC) und nicht die Daten vom fünften Sachstandsbericht AR5 verwendet werden, obwohl dieser bereits bei Erstellung der F-Gas-VO bekannt war. Es wird empfohlen, die Daten zu aktualisieren um Missverständnisse und unnötige Ausarbeitungen von Vergleichen zu vermeiden.  • Im Evaluierungsfahrplan ist zu lesen, dass die Maßnahmen des Kigali-Amendments bis 2100 die Klimaerwärmung um bis zu 0,4 °C reduzieren könnten. Gemessen an der gegenwärtig erreichten globalen Erwärmung um ca. 1 °C aufgrund der Emission aller Treibhausgase innerhalb von ca. 250 Jahren ist dieser nur auf HFKW-Emissionen zurückzuführende Wert von 0,4 °C mehr als gewaltig.  Eine Analyse des DKV hat ergeben: Diese Daten beruhen auf Projektionen des globalen HFKW-Verbrauchs der Entwicklungs- und der entwickelten Länder sowie aus daraus abgeleiteten globalen Emissionen, die sich als nicht belastbar erwiesen haben (siehe: „Das Kigali-Amendment und der Beitrag von HFKW-Emissionen zum Klimawandel“, DKV, 2017, Link). Eine Korrektur auf der Basis realistischer Randbedingungen ergab eine Reduzierung des bis 2050 kumulierten Verbrauchs von ca. 85 % und in der Folge der Emissionen und damit in der Konsequenz eine deutlich geringere globale Klimaerwärmung. Daher ist es bei einem Review der F-Gase-Verordnung dringend erforderlich, die dem Kigali-Amendment zugrundeliegenden Projektionen zu überprüfen und die Ergebnisse zu aktualisieren.
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sir or Madam   I represent Sinteco Srl, an Italian company in the distribution of gases HFC, HFO, HC in various applications  and historical operator of Fgas (Incumbent).  Surely the European Regulation CE517 / 2014 was and will be an important regulation in reducing the use of many gases in different applications, and is a milestone towards climate sustainability and a reduction in CO2 emissions. In these 5 years of Fgas much has been done both by gas distributors but also in particular by the market of end users who have and are still investing money and resources in the transformation of their production to use low gwp gases that are often flammable.  -For companies like us gas distributors, there is a big problem that is ruining the good and just policy of Fgas, it is the Illegal refrigerant gas market, it is estimated at 30% of the European market. This illegal market from non-EU countries close to the EU borders is creating considerable economic damage to sector operators. It is necessary to increase controls and make sure that Customs can interact with each other to control this wave of illegal product, which in 90% of cases arrives in illegal disposable cylinders in Europe, forbidden since 2007. (ex CE842 / 2006)  - Also on-line sales, we have noticed and pointed out to the Fgas Team that on several well-known national and international e-commerce internet portals, cylinders of illegal refrigerant gas in disposable cylinders are sold without any control.  -Additional rules should be implemented for after 2030 to provide planning certainty and provide ground for long-term investments by companies and gas distributors as well as end users.  -The current scale of decrease in Fgas quotas seems logical to us and in line with the possibilities of the market, let's not forget that a decrease or a different scale of more sudden descent could create economic damage to various companies in the sector.  - A more accurate check should be made to the thousands of NEW-ENTRYs in the Fgas system, given that many companies import products beyond the quota limit imposed and this is also evident from the latest OLAF actions around Europe between June and August 2020.  Kind Regards

feedback_msg_text: In this document you will find some thoughts related to the revision of the F-gas Regulation (517/2014). We want, as a distributor of refrigerant gases, give our contribution in the development of guidelines that could increase the efficiency of the F-gas Regulation. These first years of implementation of the Regulation have laid the foundations for a correct management of refrigerants and to raise awareness of installer/maintainer and End Users to the pollution potential of HFCs. Rivoira, therefore, wants to support the current Regulation as it has verified that the decrease in the quantities of CO2 eq. contained in the standard, they correspond to a reduction in the consumption of R404a and R507a, especially in the last year. In addition, there was an increase of retrofits for high GWP refrigerants which favored new blends. These kinds of activities started with the advent of the F-Gas Regulation and continued for actual end-user convenience in terms of energy savings. These are proofs of the correct path taken with the introduction of the EU Regulation, but we noted that there is still a lot work to be done. First of all, in our opinion, it is necessary to increase the control of the illegal product. We have evidence that part of the market, around a 30%, is covered with products coming the black market. Several investigations and studies demonstrate it, for example the EFCTC study published last June demonstrates that it is not only an economic issue but also an environmental one. So we should work all together to solve this matter.  The situation has also impacted on CO2 eq. available as the consumption of both gases is deeply related. Maybe this review of the Regulation, according to the exceeding quantity of CO2, could take in consideration the possibility of modifying the phase-down steps, anticipating or adjusting future cuts. Another issue we want to bring to your attention is the important increase of the quota called “new entrant” company which allows them to import gas from extra EU countries. Such companies import to reexport (using the T1 procedure) but they don’t do so (EFCTC studies). It could be also useful to abolish the declaration’s exemption for producers or importers of less than 100 tons of CO2 eq. of hydrofluorocarbons per year and the high GWP service exemption for system containing less than 40 T CO2 eq.  Furthermore, Rivoira brings to the attention of the Commission an important constraint that today slows down the transition from machines containing high GWP gas to new generation machines with very low GWP gas, namely the lack of a homogeneous legislation on A2L products, which are mildly flammable. The fact that A2L products are grouped together with A3, which are not at all comparable in terms of risk, contributes to slowing the transition from obsolete but well known gases to new, more performing and ecofriendly, mixtures. To conclude, we want to highlight that there is a strong will to align the EU Regulation to the Montreal Protocol in terms of timing and objective, because the studies and the consequent laws of that first global climate agreement have allowed a progressive abandonment of ozone-depleting substances and an important improvement of the ozone layer. In particular, a solution could be to review the limit of GWP of the refrigerant gas in service and maintenance activities on the HFC machines after the 2030.
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)

feedback_msg_text: TECNEA Cemafroid offre la sua esperienza indipendente nel campo della catena del freddo, della refrigerazione e del condizionamento dell'aria da oltre 70 anni. TECNEA Cemafroid svolge attività di certificazione in applicazione della Direttiva F Gas in Francia dal 2008 e in Italia dal 2014 con quasi 14.000 certificati di capacità (aziende) e 80 certificati di idoneità (persone) rilasciati.   Le questioni in gioco nella revisione della direttiva riguardante i gas fluorurati sono molteplici.   Innanzitutto, è necessario raggiungere una migliore armonizzazione europea delle pratiche, delle soluzioni tecniche e della loro implementazione.   Per quanto riguarda la certificazione di aziende e privati, il campo di applicazione del gas fluorurati dovrebbe essere esteso a tutti gli usi, in particolare alla climatizzazione automobilistica (direttiva MAC) e a tutti i fluidi, compresi quelli di "nuova generazione".   La certificazione delle persone che manipolano fluidi dovrebbe essere limitata nel tempo, come avviene attualmente in molti paesi. In Francia, i certificati di idoneità sono ormai validi a vita: ciò non è coerente con la necessità di mantenere le conoscenze normative e tecniche. Dovrebbe essere di durata limitata e il suo contenuto dovrebbe essere adattato all'uso di nuove soluzioni per la produzione a freddo. È inoltre necessario estendere la formazione a tutti i soggetti interessati (progettisti, utenti finali, ecc.), il che permetterebbe di sensibilizzare un pubblico più vasto e di raggiungere più rapidamente gli obiettivi.  Un secondo punto è la necessità di un regolare monitoraggio dell'applicazione dei gas fluorurati da parte della Commissione europea. Sono oggi disponibili pochissimi indicatori a livello europeo (numero di certificati, tasso di avanzamento dell'implementazione di F-Gas, ecc.), il che non consente di fornire una valutazione esaustiva e indipendente dell'applicazione della Direttiva F-Gas. Gli operatori del mercato sono costretti ad effettuare senza supporto la propria diagnostica. A titolo di esempio, Cemafroid ha analizzato le informazioni sulle richieste di certificazione di oltre 6.000 operatori. Questa analisi ha permesso di verificare l'applicazione della normativa in loco. È emerso che il 60% delle aziende sottoposte ad audit ha mostrato almeno una deviazione da questi requisiti normativi (Articolo RGF: Analisi delle pratiche di gestione del refrigerante degli operatori certificati).  Inoltre, un monitoraggio annuale dei nuovi fluidi (HFO, CO2, ecc...) risulta essere essenziale per condividere i dati su queste soluzioni e la quantità complessiva di fluidi trattati, per conoscere il livello di appropriazione delle nuove tecnologie e una valutazione del loro impatto ambientale.   Gli sforzi nella ricerca e nell'innovazione su soluzioni alternative di produzione del freddo più rispettose dell'ambiente e sull'uso corretto del freddo devono essere accentuati e sostenuti da finanziamenti significativi e sostenibili, anche a livello europeo. Chiediamo, pertanto, alla Commissione europea di intensificare gli sforzi nella ricerca e nell’innovazione per portare in primo piano i fluidi alternativi (compresi i fluidi "soprannaturali" come l'acqua e l'aria) e le nuove tecnologie.   Infine, da un punto di vista politico, è da evitare l'applicazione in alcuni Paesi di misure fiscali o di qualsiasi altra misura che disturbi il messaggio della direttiva F-Gas. La Francia ha recentemente votato per l'applicazione di un'imposta supplementare sugli HFC. La ragione addotta è la difficoltà di ridurre il consumo di HFC nel modo più rapido possibile. La conversione ad altri sistemi che utilizzano refrigeranti alternativi è costosa: queste misure fiscali impongono una doppia penalizzazione a un'industria che sta già affrontando un forte aumento dei prezzi degli HFC e sono controproducenti in quanto ostacolano gli investimenti in nuove tecnologie.
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)

feedback_msg_text: We as ASERCOM, the Association of European Refrigeration Component Manufacturers, reaffirmed in 2018* our commitment and engagement to accompany our industry to reach the 2030 F-gas target of CO2 emission réductions: 1.- Containment & Safety Measures:  Our industry has always led standardization committees and followed standards concerning tightness of components and safety requirements.  Significant efforts (product & software redesign; factory & laboratory investments) have been made by our industry to comply with low GWP refrigerants’ requirements and to supply components for the use of flammable, high pressure or toxic refrigerants. 2.- Phase Down Mechanism:  As one of the main new measures of the F-Gas Regulation (EU) No 517/2014, the phase down mechanism is a successful measure as it has allowed industry to optimize effort versus environmental impact for an efficient transition to sustainable options.  ASERCOM supports the EU phase down mechanism but worry and warn about illegal trade of HFCs which could impact the European F-gas and Kigali targets. 3.- Ban of Use by Applications:  The current timeline for bans is acceptable and has allowed component and system manufacturers to adapt their products to sustainable transition.  Current exemption for specific applications should remain as potential alternatives are not generally feasible (i.e. -50°C).   Additional bans will be counterproductive unless they are carefully focused on specific applications where alternative solutions have reached a certain development status. 4.- Standards & Regulations Roadblocks:  Nowadays several standards, directives and regulations are in place to cope with the use of flammable, high pressure or toxic refrigerants.  Implementation of A2L refrigerant category into all relevant standards is not fully completed and it is bringing uncertainty or even over requirements of safety measures which blocks some efficient and sustainable solution.  Assimilation by all actors and implementation at state level have been time consuming the past years.   The harmonization between standards and regulations/directives are increasing but still there are areas to be improved.  The interpretation of standards and regulations/directives are yet to be improved. For that purpose, ASERCOM members have developed a guideline for usage of components for flammable refrigerants 5.- Technician Knowledge and Training:  Training and education of operators and technicians require significant time over EU in order to set the appropriate high level of Knowledge.  6. The European Green Deal objective:   It is Important to address energy efficiency in the light of reducing GWP of refrigerants. As low GWP refrigerants are carefully selected for their purpose and application they can be considered being as efficient as the high GWP fluids. Thus, it is counterproductive and unnecessary to incentivize low GWP refrigerants by lowering efficiency demands.   ASERCOM members are engaged in the development of components for alternative technologies like heat pumps, being a crucial sector for the green deal objective and the decarbonization. In summary:   ASERCOM, the Association of European Refrigeration Component Manufacturers highlights the following facts:  Standards in place and effort of Component Manufacturers in terms of technical progress are contributing to achieve CO2 emission reduction in accordance with the current European Phase Down Timeline.  This timeline is needed for the market (all field of applications) to adapt itself in the current sanitary and economic situation.  In parallel our members have put a significant amount of investment in new motor, inverter and other part load capacity modulation developments improving significantly energy efficiency.  Training & Education remain an important area that needs more time and effort.  Sustainability is not only based on refrigerant choice, but also on Life Cycle Assessment and Energy Efficiency

feedback_msg_text: Wir begrüßen die F Gase VO. Der Ansatz die F-Gase zu reduzieren um die CO2 äquivalenten Emissionen zu reduzieren ist sehr gut. Die F Gase Verordnung hat bisher  im Bereich der Kältetechnik zu einem Umdenken und temporären Turbulenzen am Markt geführt. Neben den positiven Umstellungen zu natürlichen Kältemitteln werden die HFO Kältemittel vermehrt eingesetzt. Die Langzeitfolgen dieser, z.B. die Anreicherung von TFA im Grundwasser durch HFO Kältemittel, sind nicht absehbar und werden derzeit nicht beachtet. Gesamtheitliche Betrachtungen der Anlagen nach TEWI oder besser LCCP zeigen eine bessere Vergleichbarkeit. Bei der Klassifzierung der Kältemittel wird gerne die ASHREA Klasse A2L verwendet. Diese legt die Vermutung nahe, dass die Gefährdung dadurch deutlich kleiner sei. Allerdings werden die Verbrennungsgase z.B. HF nicht berücksichtigt.   Die Akzeptanz für den Einsatz der natürlichen brennbaren Kohlenwasserstoffe steigt durch die F Gase VO. Die natürlichen Kältemittel stellen den einzigen wirklich langfristigen Weg für Kaltdampfkompressionsanlagen dar. Die Verbreitung wird vor allem durch die verschiedenen lokal differenzierten Anforderungen des Brandschutzes und der Bewertung sowie den Transportmöglichkeiten per Luftfracht gebremst. Hier besteht deutlicher Handlungsbedarf in der Standardisierung.   Technische Lösungen für A1 Kältemittel unter T = -70 °C sind mit geringem GWP derzeit nicht vorhanden. Die Kältemittel R23 und R14 sollten von der FGase VO ausgliedert werden. Höhere Anforderungen an die Dichtheit der Anlagen wäre hierfür eine mögliche gleichwertige Alternative.   Feedback from: Peter Huber Kältemaschinenbau AG (245.6 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The F-Gas Regulation is a landmark piece of the EU climate legislation for moving away from fluorinated gases such as hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) and sulphur hexafluoride (SF6). In the years since its adoption, however, it has become clear that it requires significant improvements to safeguard our climate system namelly:  accelerate the HFC phase-down schedule, in particular by adjusting the penultimate step in 2027 to 10% and the final step in 2030 to 5%, in excess of what is required by the Kigali Amendment;  adopting a real-time per-shipment ODS-style licensing system and include exempted HFCs and HFCs in transit;  eliminate the 100t CO2e loophole;  eliminate free grandfathering and the new-entrants reserve in favour of a system based on allocation at cost through an auction or allocation fee, using the revenue to support MS implementation and enforcement and to facilitate the uptake of natural-refrigerant technologies;  improve transparency of HFC quota allocation by providing full access to the registry to customs authorities and the public;  close the loophole in the definition of “non-refillable container” and prohibit their use in the EU;  establish minimum civil penalties in the revised F-Gas Regulation, based on a multiplier of the value of the HFC seizure, to be levied by the Commission and require criminal sanctions for specific violations in MS;  strengthen the obligation on HFC-23 by-product destruction, namely by establishing a certification scheme with full traceability and transparency for HFC-23 by-product destruction and require producers and importers to report on compliance with this provision in their annual reports;  require mandatory producer responsibility schemes that meet certain minimum requirements to be detailed in the legislation with further rules adopted via implementing or delegated acts;  improve inspection and enforcement by establishing minimum inspection requirements and an EU risk-based targeting mechanism to assist MS with carrying out inspections, in addition to adopting an EU-wide market surveillance and coordination policy;  establish a fund for seized HFC shipments that may be accessed by customs authorities to dispose of seized HFC shipments in an environmentally sound manner;  require mandatory training on natural refrigerants and technologies as part of certification programmes, including practical training facilities allowing for hands-on training on relevant equipment;  update antiquated standards to allow for the introduction of safe and energy-efficient natural-refrigerant technologies relying on A3 refrigerants;  promote incentive schemes and public procurement for HFC-free alternatives;  strengthen the placing on the market prohibitions in Annex III for HFC-based equipment, including immediate bans for subsectors that could have already converted to HFC-free alternatives based on natural-refrigerant technologies available a decade ago, as identified in the Impact Assessment, and adopt prospective bans for 2025 and 2030 for the remaining subsectors (including new ones) based on a more recent analysis of natural-refrigerant and low-GWP technologies available today, including in HFC-based room air-conditioning, hydronic heat pumps and condensing units;  introduce bans and containment measures for SF6-based switchgear; and  align the revised F-Gas Regulation with the Paris Agreement and evaluate the climate impact of an accelerated EU HFC phase-down and market prohibitions in terms of GWP20 in parallel to the current GWP100 to provide policymakers and the public with an accurate snapshot of the near-term climate benefit of fast action on HFCs.  These amendments are needed to improve implementation and attain the climate ambition as set out in the European Green Deal and the EU climate neutrality target. ZERO develops its work with several partner organizations, and subscribed the same document attached to this response, giving more detail on this consultation. feedback_msg_text: Chiesi welcomes the public consultation and the opportunity to share its views and plans to achieve the goals as stated by the Montreal Protocol and the Kigali Amendment. Chiesi Group is a research-led mid-size European pharmaceutical company, registered as a Benefit Corporation since 2018. It is the largest global biopharmaceutical group to be awarded B-Corp Certification. B-Corps are companies that balance profit and purpose, meeting the highest standards of social and environmental performance, public transparency and legal accountability. Patients and planet health are at the heart of Chiesi’s current and future therapeutic solutions, in the respiratory, neonatal, rare disease and special care areas, and we are committed to maintaining access to the treatment options that patients need, while reducing their environmental impact.As an example, in the management of respiratory diseases such as asthma, this includes a range of maintenance therapies available in the two most commonly used device types pMDI and DPI. Chiesi is committed to become Carbon Neutral by 2035, ahead of the EU’s 2050 objective. As a concrete step towards this goal, we have announced the development and the transition to pMDIs containing a low Global Warming Potential (GWP) propellant by 2025, ensuring reduction of carbon footprint of nearly 90%.Chiesi has chosen to use the hydrofluoroalkane (HFA) 152a for its carbon minimal pMDIs, which is classified as low GWP propellant and is, according to the available safety and toxicology data, the most promising and advanced candidate (long-term toxicology studies to be soon completed and already cleared for first-in-human clinical trial). Chiesi supports an ambitious regulatory environment that fosters and rewards innovation in order to develop solutions that meet patients’ therapeutic needs, while reducing their impact on the environment.Therefore, Chiesi believes that the current pMDI exemption from the phase-down obligations in Regulation EU 517/2014 should be extended until 2030 to ensure all patients have access to the treatment they need. This exemption for High/Medium GWP hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) pMDIs should, however, be tied to a review clause and regular assessments should be carried out from 2025 onwards to promote the uptake of low GWP pMDI alternatives based on solid and competitive supply chains. Sector specificities have to be taken into account in order to design policies that are effective and fit for purpose.Deploying innovative products in the pharmaceutical sector requires long timelines and development is strictly regulated by sector legislation and by competent authorities.Safety and effectiveness of medicines have to be demonstrated through rigorous scientific assessments including clinical trials, as well as extensive pharmaceutical assessment with long-term stability evaluation, and systemic and standardized short- and long-term toxicological studies.In addition, patient health is key: technological developments should be assessed for specific product classes to make sure that patients have continuous access to the most suitable solutions for their conditions.Chiesi is investing in both pMDI and DPI technologies to ensure access by a broad range of patients, including the most fragile ones, while reducing the environmental impact of its products. Today pMDIs account for less than 0.1% of global GHG emissions.Most of these emissions are linked to the large use of short-acting beta-agonists (SABAs account for around 65% of pMDIs sold annually in France, 53% in Germany and 61% in the UK) that we see as a critical area for improvement in terms of environmental footprint. Chiesi believes in innovation and in collaboration between industry, governments and stakeholders including importantly the patients, as a key driver for long lasting progress.Addressing a complex and global problem such as climate change requires a regulatory environment built on mutual trust and stakeholders' cooperation. feedback_msg_text: Dear Sir or Madam,  Regulation (EU) No 517/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council (F Gas-Regulation) aims to protect the environment by reducing emissions of fluorinated greenhouse gases (F Gases). Many F Gases show a high global warming potential (GWP). Thus, a well-functioning and strictly enforced F Gas-Regulation is an important cornerstone to achieve European climate goals such as the European Green Deal.   The following points should be considered while reviewing the F Gas-Regulation. • No intensification of the phase down rules and existing restrictions. • Regulation of the period after 2030. • Strengthening the enforcement.  • Improved new-market-entry rule.  • Control of non-refillable containers.  please consider the attached document for a more in detail discussion of these points.  In conclusion, while the targets of the F-Gas regulation are already well defined, its enforcement has to be improved. With each phase down interval an illegal placing of F Gases on the market becomes more tempting. Currently, it is basically impossible for customs and enforcement authorities to prevent the illegal placement of F-Gases on the European market.    To fulfil the ambitious goals of the F Gas regulation, industry made huge investments in the last 5 years. A revision of the F Gas regulation should not change the phasing down intervals or revoke or weaken exemptions. This would jeopardise investments and put pioneers at a huge economic disadvantage. Instead, additional rules for after 2030 should be implemented to provide planning certainty and pro-vide ground for long term investments.   Kind regards Feedback from: GHC Gerling, Holz & Co.
