feedback_msg_text: Dear EU  Colruyt Group would like to share its’ extensive experience with all natural refrigerants, as a distribution company and as a retailer, because we find that natural refrigerants can replace chemical refrigerants economically in all our applications. Uniquely, Colruyt Group is also a registered refrigeration company and we would like to share our experiences with the F-gas regulation as such.  Colruyt Group uses primarily ammonia as the refrigerant in its’ distribution centers. Our own technicians design, service and these installations. Ammonia is also the refrigerant that we use to produce “liquid ice”, our unique and internally developed solution for refrigerated transport, thus avoiding all Greenhous gas emissions for this.  The meat-processing factory uses a 1MW heat pump based on ammonia, to supply heating to the nearby offices and hot tap water for cleaning. Since 2015, over 100 supermarkets have been build or rebuild, using propane as the refrigerant in compact chillers for MT-applications (0-4°C). LT-(frozen food) has always been stored in standalone chest-freezers with R600a (isobutane) or R290 (propane). These are unique choices in the market.  Contrary to common discourse, the training a minimal on the job turns out to be sufficient to get cooling technicians to work safely with flammable refrigerants and CO2.  In new shops, as a standard, heating is done by the waste heat from the refrigeration plant.  Small CO2 heat pump, based on the Japanese Ecocute design, produce hot tap water for the butcheries in new supermarkets. These heat pumps are no longer for sale in the EU, but Colruyt bought 40 on stock in order to have a solution while developing new solutions. Since 2019 R290 heat pumps provide an alternative to CO2, in order to provide hot tap water and extra heating if necessary. Contrary to often given feedback, R290 is perfectly possible and available for heat pumps in the EU.  For plugin-refrigerated cabinets we use R290 as well and we are now testing so-called water-loop systems. The building up took only two days. This is an excellent solution for small city retailers.  As a rule, Colruyt Group does not use air conditioning, yet we use it in locations with a high heat load. We are working on the introduction of split-AC with R290 and testing prototypes already. From our perspective, there is no problem to use these; they only need to become available with CE-certificate.  In larger offices, indirect adiabatic cooling is the standard. This falls outside the F-gas discussion, but the EU should promote these over systems based on chemical refrigerants.  In existing supermarkets, DX-systems based on F-gases are still in use. Here we see that our internal technical services are able to keep relative leakage ratios below 4-5%, where others report 15-30%. We are able to take back F-gases from installations that are decommissioned and to use them for maintenance. With great effort, we are able to avoid the purchase of F-gases for maintenance. All other retailers, small or large have to pay twice: for the removal of used F-gases and for the purchase of used F-gas for maintenance on their leaking systems. Here lies a major possibility to improve practices in Europe, by introducing Extended Producer Responsibility. Producers need to take back F-gases at no cost for the end-user.  The electricity that we need for our operations comes from our own Photovoltaic Panels and wind turbines on land and in the North Sea.  The uploaded document contains our concrete suggestions. feedback_msg_text: Technical Statement   Review of EU rules on fluorinated greenhouse gases     The present statement summarizes the technical evaluation of the EU rules regarding fluorinated greenhouse gases, with focus on refrigerant application on chilled water and provision cooling units from the point of view of Engie Axima Germany GmbH, as supplier of refrigeration plants for the maritime sector.    Considering the experience and expertise of Engie Axima Germany GmbH in the field of maritime refrigeration systems for many decades with respect to the actual trends towards ecological technologies and reduction of climate change potentials we come to the conclusion, that the F-gases regulations are a huge challenge but at the same time a huge chance for long overdue innovations in the maritime sector.  Besides the limited list of available substitutes for short-term solutions, such as the A2L refrigerants R1234yf, R1234ze as well as the common replacement refrigerants R513A and R448A, just to name a few, a special focus lays on the usage of natural gases and the development of adequate dimensioned, secure and efficient refrigeration units therefore.  For the technical consideration besides economical factors we can point out the major challenges for our operational sector as follows:  • Adjustment of existing ships – how to exchange components and units • Flammability of A2L (R1234yf & R1234ze) refrigerants is problematic for maritime classification societies • R1234yf derivates produce hardly organic acids which harm the groundwater  • Toxicity of NH3 (B1) requires more expensive safety concept & doesn´t allow direct expansion • CO2 plants are only efficient for sub-critical applications & require expensive plant design • NH3 & CO2 units require a more expensive cold distribution system (brine cycles) • R513A is usable for air conditioning& normal cooling but challenging for freezers • FKW/HFKW replacements (R448A etc.) provide temperature shift and limited operation limits • Often placed demand for usage of a single refrigerant is barely achievable • The prices of approved refrigerants increase significantly  • The availability of approved refrigerants decreases significantly  • Customer logistics and experiences are used to conventional refrigerants • The communication of new technologies is difficult regarding (toxicity, flammability, logistics) • New refrigerants mean high development costs • Personal and crews need to be trained • General demand for development of new efficient refrigeration plant concepts   Especially in the field of ship cooling it is important to point out, that even the most efficient cooling unit with the lowest GWP refrigerant can´t contribute for ecological improvements if it is run with conventional diesel engines. Therefore, it is evident that maritime engines are ecologically redesigned.  All the mentioned issues represent technical challenges and no principle barriers for new technologies. However, it is obvious that there is a significant amount of development and communication work to do for a sustainable and efficient refrigerant shift in the upcoming years.  Especially in the field of maritime refrigeration the state of the art yet lays way behind the existing standards on land applications, in other words here is still a huge hidden potential to be revealed. feedback_msg_text: Enedis, as the main DSO in France, operating approximately 95% of the French territory and connecting more than 36 million customers, fully supports Green Deal objectives the European Commission intends to achieve. Enedis operates 57,000 primary MV circuit breakers and more than 300,000 gas insulated MV secondary switchgears.   The company constantly committed to reduce its GES emissions in its own activities. For this reason it adopts a strong and voluntary policy on fluorinated gases. Without any obligation, Enedis committed to shift its entire purchase for medium voltage switchgears in primary substations to SF6-free solutions for new installations and in order to replace oldest ones starting in 2021. Even if they are based on a technology known to be mature such as vacuum switchgear, the selected materials were subject to additional standard requirements. These mandatory developments were financed by Enedis. Additionally, when alternative solutions are not mature enough for other appliances, Enedis, already adopted righteous measures to limit GES emissions: all new SF6 switchgears in secondary substation are sealed pressure systems under very low relative pressure (<0,4 bar) with leakage rate 10 times lower than the IEC 62271-1  standardized leakage rate of <0,1%. Then, the Enedis SF6 leaks are less than one ton per year representing less than 0.004% of French CO2 emissions. Enedis also recently included a recycling clause in its public procurement.  European regulation has to align with Green Deal ambition and to the Kigali amendment to Montréal protocol. To ensure the right policy measures are taken, Enedis welcomes the will of the European Commission to carry out an impact assessment. This assessment should cover additional aspects:  - First, a mapping of all existing amounts of fluorinated gases across Europe correlated with leakage of equipment could be establish. It would be a reliable objective tool to adopt adequate policy measures.  - Then, a detailed and transparent assessment of existing mature alternative solutions is necessary. It should take into account several factors such as: additional economic costs, space constraints, national specificities, operational requirements, potential risks and toxicity concerns regarding these alternatives solutions (to avoid a future ban of these substances). Relating to the toxicity of alternative solutions, in order to secure investments, it is important to analyze toxicity according to REACH regulations, taking into account the installed target masses and paying attention to decomposed gases. As a reminder, the MV secondary switchgears are installed in the heart of the residential areas. - A particular attention should be payed to competition matters:  This aspect could be further developed in the impact assessment to avoid any dependency to non-EU solutions and any monopoly. The revision should allow the development of EU market-based alternative solutions with regards to the European Recovery plan.   In addition, it is necessary to leave time to allow the creation of a competitive market between suppliers.  When evaluating the policy options, the European Commission could also consider as an option a specific financial support to R&I on alternative solutions to fluorinated gases for instance through EU funding.   To finish, as a major utility in Europe, Enedis remains available to provide any further information needed in the impact assessment process about its SF6 use and for interviews. The company will also take part to the next public consultation.
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)

feedback_msg_text: Dear EU, thank you for the opportunity to present views from the day-to-day national work of checking F-gas approvals. The current F-gas regulation is very good - if there is a new regulation now, the work will start all over again to implement it all the way to the consumers - a work that will take many years. The two biggest challenges right now are partly the price increases on HFC refrigerants. The quota has led to high price increases, as was intended, but the price increases have become so high that the market is flooded with illegal refrigerants at such low prices that many are tempted. And partly, the increasing number of heat pumps and AC systems means that more and more systems are also being scrapped. Plants that never reach the return systems. It is often unskilled people who take down the old plants, and if it is cumbersome or has financial consequences, the refrigerants are vented to the open air, and these are large amounts of GWP we are talking about. So please - collaborate on better control of illegal refrigerants and a better return scheme for HFC refrigerant plants - perhaps a refund scheme or more coordination with WEE and their set of rules?
Submitted by: Kim Valbum The Danish refrigeration industry's Environmental Scheme KMO
Organisation: The Danish Refrigeration Industry's Environmental Scheme KMO
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)
organisation_lower: the danish refrigeration industry's environmental scheme kmo

feedback_msg_text: Dear EU,  I was involved in the role out of the FGAS regulation in the transport refrigeration sector in the UK. We employed c150 engineers who all entered and gained the correct FGAS accreditation and it help provide them with a level of professionalism which has been lacking in our sector of the Cold Chain. But what we found on the reporting and recording side was a lack of clarity and no enforcement for the transport sector. We also found it very strange that the equipment that provided the most leakage was exempt from the regulations.   Transport Refrigeration needs to be considered as a total separate area from A/C and Cold Stores, the transport equipment moves across the EU and further unlike A/C and Coldstores.    But with no robust enforcement in this sector, operators will either forget or ignore the issue, this will then lead the OEM of the equipment not to give the focus to provide a greener or leak free system.        So make it a focused area - make the enforcement teams actually enforce - beef up the marketing to get the story home to the end users - look to ensure that on rental equipment part of the contract is the FGAS certificate (like a mot) - gather the data on the failure on the equipment and start to publish good and bad equipment including maintenance providers using the data gathered on the FGAS certs.    Make a central data base to collect and analysis the data - this will give you a fleet overview across the EU with the age and gas type and qty -then the link to GWP. You know each unit has to have a FGAS annually minimum --- so you watch for the gap and cross ref to the trailer or truck registration data from the country to see if the unit is on the road.      This will then provide feed back to EU companies about how to correct issues and also how to spot trends and recommendations on equipment and parts to use to make the best transport leak free unit possible.   For the maintenance providers use the data to drill into there engineers to look for the trends and to help retrain and to help where to send the enforcement teams. ( As with lots of data look for the exceptions - why does that dealer buy lots of gas?) etc      This is all possible. This will control the sector and provide a cleaner future for all.   I am available to help and or lead this sector project. I have over 35 year experience in this field.     Feedback from: Highnam Assist -Freelancer Cold Chain (80.2 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Fluorinated greenhouse gases – review of EU rules (2015-20)

feedback_msg_text: Les journalistes free-lance européens ne doivent pas dépendre de la loi sur la concurrence et doivent avoir droit à une négociation collective, comme tous les travailleurs. En France, les journalistes rémunérés à la pige bénéficient d'une présomption de salariat, ils sont censés avoir un contrat de travail (loi Cressard, art. L7111-1 Code du Travail). Malgré cette loi française, les journalistes salariés à la pige sont très largement exclus de la négociation collective et cela nuit à leurs conditions de rémunération et de travail. Pour la plupart, aucune revalorisation des revenus depuis 10, 15 ou 20 ans, ce qui revient à une baisse de salaire. Inacceptable ! Nous souhaitons que la réglementation européenne souligne que tous les salariés doivent bénéficier de la négociation collective, et celle-ci doit exclure l'auto-entrepreunariat quand celui-ci est illégal, comme c'est le cas en France dans le journalisme.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Kieliasiantuntijat ry, Language Experts is a professional association representing approximately 2,500 language professionals in Finland. Our members include translators and interpreters, both salaried employees and the self-employed.   Language Experts believes that the self-employed should have access to collective bargaining (both on rates and on conditions ) without competition law preventing them from doing so.  The market for self-employed translators’ and interpreters’ labour is unfairly dominated by Language Service Providers (LSPs). Language professionals are dependent on LSPs for assignments. LSPs abuse their dominant position, dictating rates and conditions. Subtitlers and public service interpreters are in a particularly weak position in this regard. Current competition law prevents the self-employed in many ways from even discussing their rate levels among themselves. The result is a year-on-year decrease in real terms of self-employed language professionals’ rates.  A discrete source of price pressure on self-employed language professionals is public tenders, which are an imperfect means of attracting bids for professional services such as translation and interpretation. LSPs participate in tenders and compete on price alone; upon winning tenders, they pass these low prices on to their subcontractors, self-employed language professionals. The right to collective bargaining would generate many benefits. It would enable an end to the continual downward price spiral, for example in interpreting and translation. This downward spiral is already making many language professionals consider changing career and therefore endangering the availability of professional translators and interpreters in future. This right would ensure a more level market position for the self-employed than at present. This right would allow self-employed language professionals to negotiate rates that provide a decent livelihood, allow them to buy equipment, and attain sufficient social and pension security. We note that pensioner poverty and uncertainty about livelihood are concerns among self-employed language professionals. Language Experts sees the right to collective bargaining agreements for self-employed language professionals as a solution. In our opinion, Option 4 from the Inception Impact Assessment would be the broadest in scope and the clearest. Option 1 is insufficient, as it would restrict collective bargaining to professionals who are assigned work via digital platforms. In today’s language services market, it is traditional LSP companies, not digital platforms, which continue to assign the majority of translation and interpreting work. Nor would Option 2 be a sufficiently broad option in our opinion. Option 2 would restrict collective bargaining in accordance with the size of the counterparty; however, many LSPs are smaller than the EU’s definition of SME (<50 employees), given their high level of outsourcing and subcontracting, and would thus fall outside the scope of Option 2. This would create unequal categories of self-employed professionals — some with the right to collective bargaining, and some without.  In conclusion, Language Experts welcomes the Commission’s initiative. We can expect to see an increase in the number of the solo self-employed in many professions, not just linguistic ones, in future, and European law should be able to protect these professionals’ interests alongside those of traditional employees. Language Experts sees Option 4 of the Inception Impact Assessment as the broadest in scope, clearest and most equitable option for securing solo self-employed language professionals’ rights to collective bargaining. Finally, Language Experts believes that professional associations should have the right to collectively bargain on behalf of the self-employed and that the initiative should state this clearly.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The Association of Architects and Designers (FAOD) is the trade union for academic architects and designers in Denmark. We fully recognize and appreciate the problems and the issues that the initiative seeks to address. FAOD organizes and maintains the labor interests of approx. 5,700 academic architects and designers in Denmark. For the majority of the architects and some of the designers, FAOD has the opportunity to maintain these interests in both the public and the private sector through the negotiation of collective agreements.  However, we experience for our designer members and for an increasing number of our architect members that they are forced to work as "freelancers" and as self-employed.  Sometimes voluntarily, but more often forced by the circumstances. In relation to our ability to take care of the interests for these members, we experience a major problem in relation to EU competition rules. This leaves these members in a situation where they experience challenges in relation to, among other things, earnings and working conditions.  Furthermore, social inconveniences arise, for example in the form of large inequalities in wages, in pension savings and in rights and opportunities in relation to maternity rights. We will thus see it as a major step forward if measures are adopted that clarifies and enables our rights to maintain interest for these participants in the labor market, both individually and collectively. Regarding the different options in the initiative, we finds that options 1, 2 and 3 are not relevant for our members and our challenges.  It is our opinion that options 1 and 2 will not sufficiently cover the problems that the initiative aim to address, as they only include platform workers and as the problems also include many other self-employed. Regarding option 3, we are concerned about the exception of regulated (and liberal) professions.  Actually we find that at least for architects and designers it is precisely in these areas (e.g. in the architectural industry and at design companies) that solo self-employment flourishes. Furthermore, there are very large differences in how trades and branches are regulated in the different member countries. Thus, we perceive that option 4 is the option that will clarify the problems and the solutions both for FAOD and in general. Especially we have noticed this text:  “Under this option it could be further analyzed whether public or semi-public professional associations that unite all professionals exercising regulated professions should be allowed to negotiate on behalf of their members”. For FAOD it is essential that we legitimately can demand the right to negotiate with companies and employers' organizations representing all our members within “The Danish Model”. Regarding this particular issue, we believe that there is a need for further clarity in the further work with the initiative.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The AVÜ (Audiovisual Translators' Association Germany) salutes the EU Initiative to enable collective bargaining agreements for the self-employed, since it is very difficult for individual audiovisual translators to obtain adequate remuneration when negotiating with agencies that are themselves under pressure of winning the bid by offering the lowest price to their clients. In most cases the translators have no leverage whatsoever and more often than not find themselves faced with the impossible choice of accepting bad prices or not getting any work at all. The option of collective bargaining seems to us a viable, if not the only way of alleviating the situation and of enabling self-employed translators not only to achieve appropriate remuneration for themselves but also to set general, industry-wide standards that one day may become a benchmark for translators and agencies alike, putting an end to precarious working conditions.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Summary of our position     The European Union should take a four-pronged approach to discussing and eventually regulating collective bargaining agreements for the self-employed at the EU level. These are:     1. Improve communication channels with the community of couriers     Creating spaces for negotiation and coordination among self-employees and digital platforms can have a significant positive impact on the couriers’ experience. It is of utmost relevance to discuss means to negotiate, elevate consensus, increase transparency, receive feedback and recommendations, and increase awareness of the views of people collaborating with digital platforms. All of the above would also help set up better communication bridges between all parties involved considering the heterogeneity of couriers’ profiles and the relevant percentage of short-time users of platforms - especially if such means are implemented in all Member States.     2. Consolidate current successful practices by companies     Riders should be provided with opportunities to give and receive feedback. For example, couriers committees can be organized on a monthly basis - sometimes even more frequently - where platform representatives meet riders to know their concerns, comments and questions and provide them with updates. Collective bargaining mechanisms would help consolidate such precedents and ensure a more fluid and continuous exchange.     3. EU's collective bargaining framework a means of harmonising social dialogue     We welcome the Commission’s initiative to work towards a framework to allow self-employed workers to collectively bargain, as this represents a step forward towards also highlighting in a bottom-up approach best practices across the continent and increasing the harmonization of regulation on social rights across EU member states.  The permanent forums that such an initiative would create can also help alleviate the regulatory fragmentation across Member States by making visible common standards and expectations that couriers share. Otherwise, riders will have different rights in each Member State and this reality makes it particularly difficult to adopt a common approach for all our markets and ensure even more of a positive social impact.  Compared to today’s reality all of the policy options contemplated in this document are well suited, as long as the legislation that will be put forward provides clear rules that can be subject to minimal interpretation. In addition, the Commission should accompany the implementation of these rules with sufficient guidance to the states, publishing guidelines and tools to interpret the legislation uniformly. Finally, the Commission should monitor that there is a coordination between national initiatives and the Commission’s work.     4. Collective bargaining that builds on European precedents: learning from the cases of France, Spain and Italy     There are some precedents among EU Member States, where regulation has addressed the legal standing of autonomous workers in situations where a higher level of protection should be considered. These can provide interesting insights on how to implement collective bargain rights for self-workers.  France has already regulated along these lines, particularly its “Social Charter”, improving self-employed workers protection while maintaining the inherent flexibility of the on-demand economy.  The Spanish legislation has a mechanism that accommodates hybrid labour realities, the ones that need flexibility but also a higher level of protection.  Italian legislation states that couriers are freelancers, but hold a number of individual and social rights as if they were employees. Feedback from: Anonymous (53 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Insinööriliitto Il ry kannattaa vahvasti sitä, että komissio toteuttaa esittämänsä lainsäädäntöhankkeen, jonka tavoitteena on mahdollistaa itsensätyöllistäjien kollektiivinen edunvalvonta EU:n kilpailuoikeuden tätä estämättä. On erittäin tärkeää selventää kilpailuoikeutta ja sen ulottuvuutta tässä tarkoituksessa.  Insinööriliiton jäsenistöstä aloitteen piirissä on mm. korkeasti koulutettuja suunnittelijoita. Tällainen työnteonmuoto koskee etenkin nuoria insinöörejä ja on tärkeää varmistaa heille riittävä toimeentulo myös tulevaisuudessa. Tällä hetkellä heidän asemansa ja neuvotteluvoimansa suhteessa toimeksiantajaan on riippuvaisuussuhteen vuoksi heikko ja heidän tulotasonsa on matala. Komissio on esittänyt neljä eri vaihtoehtoa soveltamisalaksi. Puollamme aloitteen toteuttamista mahdollisimman laajan soveltamisalan puitteissa, eli vaihtoehdon numero 4 puitteissa.  Lakihankkeessa tulee turvata myös ammattijärjestöjen asema ja oikeus neuvotella jäseninään olevien itsensätyöllistäjien puolesta.  Lisäksi tulisi erottaa myös todellisuudessa täysin riippumattomat liikkeenharjoittajat sekä nk. riippuvaiset yksinyrittäjät, mm. EUT:n tuomion FNV Kunsten (C-413/13) mukaisesti. Yksinyrittäjään tulisi soveltaa esimerkiksi EUT:n tuomion Jany (C-268/99) kriteeristöä. Tähän liittyy myös tarve määritellä työsuhde ja työntekijä riittävän tarkasti EU-tasolla. Tämä voitaisiin tehdä esimerkiksi EUT:n tuomioissa Saint-Prix (C-507/12) ja Lawrie-Blum (C-66/85) todetun tunnusmerkistön mukaisesti.  Työn ehtojen ja työolojen parantaminen neuvottelu- ja sopimustoiminnalla on mahdollistettava laajasti. Säätelyn tulee kattaa mahdollisuus sopia riittävästä palkkiosta, jonka tulee taata riittävä sosiaaliturva sekä kohtuullinen elanto. Palkkion ja työolosuhteiden oikeudenmukaisessa muodostamisessa tulee ottaa huomioon etenkin mahdollisuus maksaa itselleen riittävää eläkettä, työttömyysturvamaksua sekä mahdollisuus hankkia itselleen tarpeelliset ja turvalliset työvälineet sekä riittävät vakuutukset, kouluttautuminen ja muu osaamisen ylläpito. Myös kohtuullisesta työajasta tulee voida vapaasti neuvotella.   Kaikkien mahdollista rajoitusten tulee olla riittävän suppeita, eikä säädäntöhanketta tule rajoittaa myöskään koskemaan vain yhtä tiettyä itsensätyöllistäjien ryhmää, alustatyöntekijöitä. Huomioon tulee ottaa kaikki sellaiset työnteonmuodot, joissa henkilö työllistää itsensä ilman, että hänellä on palkattua työvoimaa, mutta että heillä voi olla esim. osakekumppaneita.  Ja vaikka säädännön taustalla on SEUT 103(2) c, tulee työmarkkinajärjestöille ja sosiaalisille partnereille antaa osallistumisoikeus lainsäädäntöprosessiin ja sen tulee kulkea normaalisti EU:n ns. sosiaalisen vuoropuhelun sekä työmarkkinajärjestöjen lausunto- ja neuvottelumahdollisuuksien kautta.  Lisäksi tulee varmistua siitä, että kansallisia voimassa olevia huonompia käytäntöjä ei sallita, vaan että tuleva sääntely asettaa alarajan myös kansalliselle sääntelylle. Kuitenkin esimerkiksi mahdollinen yleissitovuuden käsite tulee sallia, esimerkiksi silloin, kun vähintään 50 % kaikista ko. alan tarkoitetuista toimijoista on mukana sopimuksessa.  Lisäksi on tärkeää toteuttaa aloite niin, että samassa yhteydessä arvioidaan ja täydennetään myös muuten EU:n lainsäädäntöä, mukaan luettuna työlainsäädäntö, jotta soveltamisen aukkojen syntyminen rajapinnoilla estetään jo ennalta. Lisäksi myös mahdolliset vaikutukset komission työohjelmaan 2021 liittyvään sosiaaliseen pilariin tulee ottaa huomioon. Myös mahdolliset muutokset ja vaikutukset direktiiviin 91/533/ETY (written statement) tulee ottaa riittävällä tavalla huomioon.    Toteutustapoina soveltuvia ovat sekä komission tiedonanto että toteutus asetuksen kautta. Insinööriliitto kannattaa kuitenkin asetusta, koska sillä voitaisiin vaikuttaa tehokkaasti myös EU:n ulkopuolisten tahojen toimintaan niiden toimiessa EU:n alueella, mikä on tärkeää globaalitalouden oloissa.  Pidempi lausunto löytyy vielä ohesta. Feedback from: The Union of Professional Engineers (18.5 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Please find attached the actual GESAC feedback. Below is a short summary of our proposals.  GESAC proposes the following points as a feedback on this inception impact assessment and preserves the possibility to comment on this issue more broadly within the forthcoming consultation processes regarding this initiative:  1. Consideration of collective bargaining possibilities for all authors across Europe in their relations with such VOD platforms in particular, and other media companies in general, for which EU competition law should not create an obstacle, as stated in the inception impact assessment. Such collective bargaining agreements can secure one of the crucial conditions for a fair working contract, i.e.  that the royalty payments deriving from continuous use of the work based on EU copyright law cannot be prejudiced or circumvented through the terms of such working contracts, including by a choice of law;  2. Consideration of Option 4 for the forthcoming action with the widest scope and without a restriction as regards the size of the counterpart would be a better starting point. This would allow addressing the changing structures of the market without being obsolete, when new but similar business models are developed, especially in online environment where first comers capture most of the market and/or revenue based evaluations are not adapted to measure the real value and relevance of a service in the market;   3. Consideration of a wider perspective on all collective initiatives of authors and composers, including their royalty payments through collective management, when assessing, whether the ‘EU competition law needs to stand in the way’ in such initiatives that aim at improving the working conditions of freelance and self-employed creators. feedback_msg_text: Plattformsföretag är ett välkommet bidrag till innovation, flexibilitet, tillväxt och jobbskapande på arbetsmarknaden, men bara så länge de som utför arbetet, oavsett sysselsättningsform, ges möjlighet till bra villkor. Tyvärr har det visat sig att plattformsarbete inte sällan förknippas med osäkerhet för de som utför arbetet, ofördelaktiga villkor samt otillräckligt socialt skydd. Det är inte acceptabelt utan måste motverkas.  Gällande fråga om förbättrade arbetsvillkor för egenföretagare som exempelvis utför arbete via digitala plattformar måste det beaktas att det är en heterogen grupp med olika skyddsbehov och önskan om autonomi. Samtidigt är det viktigt att säkerställa att det föreligger en sund konkurrens. Artikel 101 (1) i Fördraget om Europeiska unionens Funktionssätt (FEUF) förbjuder avtal mellan företag som begränsar konkurrensen. För att egenföretagare fortsatt ska kunna konkurrera sinsemellan förutsätter det dock att de själva kan påverka villkoren och att premisserna inte sätts av allt större plattformar.   Det är av stor vikt att eventuella möjligheter för egenföretagare att förhandla tillsammans, att förhandla kollektivt, tydligt åtskiljs från kollektiva förhandlingar och kollektivavtal som avser avtal som träffas mellan arbetsgivar- och arbetstagarorganisationer gällande arbetstagares arbetsvillkor. Det måste göras en tydlig distinktion att det är olika frågor. Arbetstagare ska skyddas genom arbetsrätten och inte genom förändrade konkurrensregler.  Det är även viktigt att medlemsstaternas arbetsmarknadsmodeller respekteras. Ett initiativ som syftar till att möjliggöra för egenföretagare att förhandla kollektivt innebär ett stort osäkerhetsmoment för hur det påverkar den svenska partsmodellen. Begrepp som kollektivavtal är centralt för den kollektiva arbetsrätten.   I färdplanen anges att målsättningen med initiativet är att se till att EU:s konkurrensregler inte står i vägen för initiativ till att förbättra arbetsvillkor genom kollektivavtal för solo egenföretagare, dvs. egenföretagare utan anställda, i fall de frivilligt väljer att förhandla och ingå sådana avtal. En översyn av EU:s konkurrensregler i syfte att klargöra reglerna är av värde samt att tydliggöra existerande begrepp inom konkurrensrätten som exempelvis ’företag’ (eng. undertakings) samt vad som utgör price-fixing och kartellbildning. Däremot ska man inte inom ramen för konkurrensreglerna definiera vad som utgör kollektivavtal eller vilka som kan delta i sådana förhandlingar.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Collectief onderhandelen mogelijk maken voor alle freelance (foto)journalisten  De Nederlandse Vereniging van Journalisten (NVJ) vertegenwoordigt ruim 8000 freelancers waarvan de helft freelancer is. Een op de drie journalisten is in Nederland freelancer. Dit aantal neemt jaarlijks toe.  De NVJ zet zich in voor alle (foto)journalisten ongeacht of ze een vast dienstverband hebben of als freelancer werkzaam zijn. De NVJ signaleert al jaren dat de inkomenskloof tussen journalisten in vast dienstverband en freelancers toeneemt. Uit berekeningen blijkt dat freelancers gemiddeld genomen 50% minder verdienen dan journalisten in vast dienstverband.  Tweedeling in de Maatschappij In het rapport van de Commissie Borstlap ‘In wat voor land willen wij werken’ dat in opdracht van de overheid is ingesteld, wordt de slechte arbeidsmarktpositie van freelancers onderkent. Er wordt gewaarschuwd voor een tweedeling in de maatschappij: ‘the haves and the have nots’. In het rapport worden ook de erbarmelijke tarieven van freelance (foto)journalisten aan de kaak gesteld zie Eindrapport+CRW+-+In+wat+voor+land+willen+wij+werken.pdf. De commissie pleit voor een herstructurering van de arbeidsmarkt waar freelancers meer zekerheid krijgen zoals toegang tot collectieve verzekeringen.  Inzet NVJ De NVJ spant zich al jaren in voor ‘gelijk loon, voor gelijk werk’. Concreet betekent dit dat de NVJ zich inspant zodat freelancers minimaal 150% van het cao-loon voor journalisten krijgen.  Behaalde resultaten  Bewustwording van de inkomenskloof tussen journalisten in vast dienstverband en freelancers  Mobiliseren van freelancers - fotojournalisten hebben het werk een dag neergelegd  Gewonnen rechtszaak – waarbij rechter DPG Media opdroeg de tarieven van twee freelancers met 50% te verhogen. DPG Media is in hoger beroep gegaan. Het vonnis van de kantonrechter blijft vooralsnog staan.  Aanpassing van de Leidraad van de Autoriteit Consument en Markt (ACM) (Mededingingsrecht) – voor zij-aan-zij werkers is het mogelijk om collectieve afspraken te maken  Erkenning van de commissie Borstlap dat de inkomenskloof tussen freelancers en journalisten in vast dienstverband leidt tot een tweedeling in de maatschappij  Verhoging van de tarieven voor schrijvende journalisten bij DPG Media met 10%  Verhoging van de tarieven voor fotojournalisten met 5% door het Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau  Fair Practice Code Publieke Omroep (maar niet voor uitgeverijen of commerciële omroepen) met bodemtarieven die zijn afgeleid van de cao (150% van het cao-loon)  Beperkt geslaagd  De NVJ is niet geslaagd in het afspreken van bodemtarieven voor alle freelance (foto)journalisten terwijl dit essentieel is. Collectief onderhandelen  Er zijn drie oorzaken waarom dit tot op heden niet is gelukt:  Het Mededingingsrecht zit in de weg  Uitgeverijbedrijven willen – anders dan de Publieke Omroep – geen collectieve afspraken maken  De Minister van Media durft – anders dan zijn Ierse collega - het niet aan om een Fair Practice Code inclusief afspraken over tarieven af te dwingen bij alle mediaorganisaties.  Optie 4 De NVJ juicht toe dat de Europese Commissie zich wil inzetten om collectief onderhandelen voor alle freelancers mogelijk te maken. De NVJ vindt dat vakbonden en beroepsorganisaties in staat moeten worden gesteld om voor alle freelancers – ongeacht waar ze werken – tarief afspraken te maken die zijn afgeleid van de cao. Daarom kiest zij van de vier voorgelegde opties voor optie 4.  Verzoek aan de EU Commissie De NVJ verzoekt om in navolging van Ierland en Nederland (FPC Publieke Omroep) een uitzondering op het Mededingingsrecht te maken voor alle freelance (foto)journalisten. Freelance (foto)journalisten wachten al tien jaar op een uitzondering op het Mededingingsrecht. Nu de tarieven blijven dalen is het onverantwoord om hier langer mee te wachten. De tijd is rijp om in alle EU-landen dezelfde uitzondering mogelijk te maken.  Hoogachtend Nederlandse Vereniging van Journalisten  Feedback from: Dutch Association of Journalists (552.9 KB - PDF - 24 pages) Download
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: De 15 december 2020 opgerichte Orde van Registertolken en -vertalers vertegenwoordigt een groot aantal registertolken en -vertalers. Velen van hen zijn werkzaam voor de Nederlandse overheid. De tarieven voor vertalers zijn vanaf 1963 nooit aangepast en de tarieven voor tolken vanaf 1981 niet. Het ministerie is nu bezig met het aanbesteden van alle tolk- en vertaalopdrachten en heeft de in het Btis (Besluit tarieven in strafzaken) vermelde vaste tarieven van 1963 (vertalers) en 1981 (tolken) gewijzigd in minimumtarieven. Wij denken dat na toekenning van de percelen aan de aanbestedingsbemiddelaars, die aanbestedingsbemiddelaars alleen nog maar die minimumtarieven willen betalen en dat tolken en vertalers tegen elkaar zullen worden uitgespeeld. Onze beroepsgroep heeft tot aan de uitbraak van de coronapandemie met werkweigeringsacties voor overheidsopdrachten ervoor gestreden minimaal dezelfde redelijke tarieven te krijgen als onze collega’s in Duitsland. Veel professionals hebben de overheid nu al de rug toegekeerd, waardoor er een schijntekort aan tolken en vertalers is ontstaan. De Nederlandse overheid heeft om het ‘tekort’ aan te vullen besloten tolken met een taalniveau B2 (ERK) toe te laten tot het register en handelt daarmee ons inziens in strijd met art. 6 EVRM dat zegt dat verdachten recht hebben op een eerlijk proces. Van een eerlijk proces is geen sprake meer als de overheid toelaat dat ondeskundige, niet opgeleide tolken mogen worden ingezet en diezelfde tolken zich door hun inschrijving in het B2-register ook nog eens ‘registertolken’ mogen noemen.   Onze overheid zou bij het uitzetten in de aanbestedingsmarkt van de tolk- en vertaaldiensten ook een plafond hebben ingesteld. Aanbestedingsbemiddelaars hebben daardoor geen of nauwelijks mogelijkheden om de tolken meer te betalen dan de deels al meer dan 58 jaar onveranderde tarieven. Tolken maken per week doorgaans weinig uren en zullen binnenkort niet meer per begonnen halfuur, maar per gewerkte minuut worden uitbetaald. Dit kon straks wel eens resulteren in het uitsterven van het beroep van professioneel tolk, omdat a) deze professionele tolken nooit voldoende uren zullen draaien om met een tarief van € 43,89 uitbetaald per gewerkte minuut voldoende inkomen te genereren en b) het hen van overheidswege verboden wordt om tariefafspraken te maken. Voor veel tolken is de overheid de enige opdrachtgever. De bemiddelaars zijn niet in staat redelijke tarieven te betalen. De (C1-)registertolken en -vertalers hebben allemaal minimaal een HBO-opleiding. Velen zijn universitair geschoold. Ze zijn de slechtst betaalde groep hoogopgeleiden in ons land.  De omstandigheden voor registertolken en registervertalers leken niet slechter te kunnen worden, maar worden door de keuze van de overheid om de tolk- en vertaaldiensten niet meer in eigen beheer via het bestaande eigen netwerk van tolkenbureaus te verdelen, maar aan te besteden, nog veel slechter dan ze al waren. In het oude Btis waren nog een aantal tariefgroepen, waarbij vertalers van minder voorkomende talen hogere tarieven betaald kregen. In het nieuwe Btis is het minimumtarief voor alle talen vastgelegd op basis van het laagste tarief van de oude situatie. Een aanzienlijk deel van de tolken en vertalers zal daardoor nog slechter worden betaald dan voorheen, mede omdat ook de voorrijkosten voor gerechtstolken zijn afgeschaft.  De beloning voor hoogopgeleide (C1-)registertolken en -vertalers was al jaren slecht, maar zal door de aanbestedingen nog slechter worden. Onze Orde zou al deze registertolken en -vertalers graag aan waardige voorwaarden helpen, maar de huidige mededingingswetgeving staat het ons niet eens toe tarieven aan te bevelen. Wij willen daarom graag dat het mogelijk wordt gemaakt om collectief te onderhandelen over eerlijke tarieven, waarbij ons een indexering van de tarieven uit 1963 en 1981 naar een eerlijk prijsniveau in 2021 voor ogen staat.   Het bestuur van de Orde van Registertolken en -vertalers
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The World Employment Confederation-Europe calls for fully recognising and valuing the benefits of diverse forms of work on the European labour market. Direct employment relationships, triangular work relationships and self-employment all fulfil important and complementary functions on the labour market and in the changing world of work. It is important that people have clarity at national level on their employment status and are classified in the correct way, including the attached rights, obligations and freedoms. The World Employment Confederation-Europe acknowledges the important history, practice and regulation of collective bargaining rights by the EU Member States, including on issues of access, and given the diversity of these practices, the regulation of access by the self-employed should be left to the national level.  Feedback from: World Employment Confederation-Europe (106.9 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Der ISDV e.V. spricht sich mit allem Nachdruck gegen eine tarifvertragliche Bindung der Selbständigen in Europa aus.  Selbständige, auch die ohne Angestellte, müssen auch weiterhin als Unternehmen gemäß Artikel 101 (1) des Vertrages über die Arbeitsweise der Europäischen Union gelten. Sollte diese Definition umgestürzt werden, wird sowohl die nach Artikel 12 des deutschen Grundgesetztes gültige Selbstbestimmung in der Ausübung des Berufes konterkariert als auch die Innovationskraft der Wirtschaft unterbunden. Die bloße Behauptung, dass sich Selbständige, die im Auftrag von Plattformen aktiv sind, nicht gegen diese durchsetzen könnten, reicht nicht aus, um diese Freiheit und Selbstbestimmung in der Berufsausübung einzuschränken. Die Selbständigen würden dadurch zwangsweise zu Angestellten gemacht werden, völlig ungeachtet der Tatsache, dass sie frei entschieden haben, sich den Regeln der Plattform anzupassen. Niemand wird durch das Angebot der Plattformen dazu gezwungen, Aufträge von Plattformanbietern anzunehmen. Jeder Unternehmer kann frei entscheiden, ob ihm die Einkommenshöhe ausreicht oder nicht.  Ebenso ist es nicht richtig, dass die Menschen keine Wahl hätten. Gerade in Deutschland gibt es ein umfangreiches soziales Sicherungssystem, das jeden Menschen in Deutschland auffängt.  Das Auftragsangebot von Plattformen wird oft als Lückenfüller oder Überbrückungsangebot in Anspruch genommen oder von Studenten oder als Nebenerwerb. Es ist ein sehr einfacher Zugang zu Arbeit. Eine Regulierung über Gewerkschaften (Arbeitnehmervertretungen) wird diese Möglichkeit uninteressant machen. Dies wird weite Auswirkungen auf den Dienstleistungssektor haben. So wird z.B. Restaurants den Absatzmarkt einschränkt und vieles mehr. Nicht die Selbständigkeit ist das Problem, sondern die sozialpolitischen Rahmenbedingungen der EU, die steuerrechtlichen Unzulänglichkeiten der EU gegenüber Online-Plattformen und das Festhalten an der Anstellung als Standardsystem der Arbeitswelt.  Ein Tarifvertrag für Selbständige steht diametral der Idee der freien Marktwirtschaft gegenüber. Eine Regelung der Verdienste von Selbständigen führt unweigerlich dazu, dass nie mehr gezahlt werden wird, als im Tarifvertrag vereinbart ist. Denjenigen, die mehr verdienen könnten, wird damit das Geschäft zunichte gemacht. Dies ist gerade die Kernkompetenz der sozialen Marktwirtschaft. Die Selbständigen werden durch solche einen Vertrag nicht in die Lage versetzt, besser verhandeln zu können. Sie werden aber zu Angestellten zweiter Klasse degradiert. Das ist nicht im Sinne der EU und vor allem nicht im Sinne der Selbständigen. Der ISDV e.V. bitte die Kommission dringend darum von dieser Idee Abstand zu nehmen. Sie zerstört die Möglichkeit das Leben in der Selbständigkeit zu gestalten.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The EAEA (FIA, FIM & UNI MEI) represents workers in the Media, Arts and Entertainment sector, where there is a strong concentration of short-term project-based working and a strong culture of freelancing, often on a self-employed basis. We regard collective bargaining as the best and most efficient tool to raise standards in the sector. We emphasise that a robust social partner dialogue and collective bargaining practice makes for a nimble and well-functioning sector that is well-placed to be competitive in the global arena.  Option 1:  the scope of this option is too narrow to be meaningful and creates an arbitrary and artificial distinction between labour provided in an online context and labour provided in an offline context, even where the work itself may be identical (e.g.: in our sector performers such as voice-actors or session musicians may provide identical labour in the online or offline context). Some of the most important legal challenges and discussions regarding the obstacle to collective bargaining for certain self-employed workers arising from competition rules have arisen in relation to workers in our sector, meaning that option 1 will entirely fail to address this ongoing problem. Finally, this option risks the unintended (and highly problematic) effect of equating a solo-self-employed status with platform work.   Option 2: is unacceptable due to its scope and the cut-off point it establishes according to the size of the bargaining counterpart. This proposal fails to take account of how the ecosystem of the Media, Arts and Entertainment sector operates and the very high number of SMEs. Such companies will be the main contractual counterparts for the solo-self-employed in the sector and should not be excluded.  Option 3 is based on an unacceptable distinction between self-employed workers operating in a liberal / regulated profession and those that are not. Introducing such a distinction on the grounds that such professions “are often perceived as not being in a position of weakness” is highly arbitrary and a “perception” cannot be grounds for such a sweeping exclusion.  Option 4: we endorse this option to address the obstacles and the chill effect arising from European Competition Rules to collective bargaining for self-employed workers. It must address the issue of equal pay for equal work, without making arbitrary distinctions on the basis of status or online or offline context.  Remarks on social partner autonomy: We welcome an approach that clarifies the scope of application of competition law (in line with Option 4) and removes the possibility of intervention by national competition authorities on agreements falling outside it.  There can be no ex-ante or post factum requirement for any approval or screening of collective bargaining agreements by competition authorities. Once the scope of competition rules is clarified, unimpeded collective bargaining must be in line with Member State legislative frameworks and traditions and in full respect of social partner autonomy. The definition of collective bargaining included in footnote 6 in the Commission roadmap therefore raises serious concerns. Trade unions and employers as social partners are the only legitimate actors to engage in collective bargaining as an intrinsic element of social dialogue.  Sectoral considerations: In 2019, the EU adopted the new Directive on copyright which references collective bargaining as a mechanism in achieving fair remuneration in exploitation contracts for authors and performers. Many of these workers are self-employed or combine such activities. They must not be denied the possibility of achieving fair and proportionate remuneration for the use of their work in the online environment due to this status.   Regarding legal instrument: achieving legal clarity in the national context is key. The form of implementation selected should ensure uniform and consistent application in the member states. Further assessment is needed. Feedback from: European Arts and Entertainment Alliance (EAEA) (370.5 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Cette initiative soulève certaines préoccupations et questionnements préliminaires. De manière non exhaustives, nous pouvons relever :   - Initiative parallèle à celle visant à améliorer les conditions de travail des travailleurs de plateforme : pourquoi deux instruments différents ? ; - L’évaluation faite par la Commission constate surtout la porosité et la fragilité de plus en plus grande entre le statut de salarié et d’indépendant mais ne vise à aucun moment à clarifier la question et à s’emparer du fond du problème ; - L’évaluation faite par la Commission met en avant la volonté de vouloir assurer la clarté juridique pour des travailleurs incertains de leur statut mais en quoi le fait de s’assurer que le droit à la négociation collective reste en dehors du droit européen de la concurrence donnera plus de certitude à ces travailleurs ? De manière générale, les accords conclus entre partenaires sociaux reconnus et qui ont pour but d'améliorer les conditions de travail ne relèvent pas de l'article 101 TFUE : c'est à la question des faux-indépendant qu'il faut s'attaquer en profondeur ;  - Elargir ce droit à la négociation collective aux indépendants ne revient-il pas à dire que ces travailleurs atypiques/de plateforme/indépendants solo/économiquement dépendants ne sont pas des salariés ? ;  - La jurisprudence constante de la CJUE maintien que les conventions collectives, pour peu qu’elles soient le fruit des partenaires sociaux et que leur objet vise à améliorer les conditions de travail, ne relèvent pas du droit européen de la concurrence : l’initiative joue le jeu des entreprises qui veulent contourner les règles et saper les acquis sociaux relatifs au statut de salarié ;  - La priorité est de défendre et de promouvoir les formes d’emploi classiques et salariales ;  - Qu'en est-il de l'option que les indépendants se tournent vers les syndicats ? ; - Aucune références faites aux syndicats ou interlocuteurs sociaux ; - L’option 4 parle de « négociation collective traditionnelle », ce qui sous-entend que l’initiative mettrait en place une forme différente de négociation collective.  Etant donné le laps de temps très court, il est difficile de fournir une analyse complète et exhaustive des tenants et aboutissants de la question. Cette initiative peut avoir des répercussions dans beaucoup de domaines et il y a lieu de tous les prendre en compte. Il semble que cette initiative tente de contourner les problèmes grandissants que posent, surtout, le travail de plateforme alors que cette voie pourraient s'appliquer bien plus largement qu'aux seuls travailleurs prestant leur service pour le compte de plateformes. Ce faisant, le champ d'application et la portée de l'initiative sont incertains et portent grandement à confusion.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: With a membership of close to 8,000 translators and interpreters, BDÜ (the Federal Association of Interpreters and Translators) is the industry's largest professional association in German-speaking countries. BDÜ represents about 80% of all translators and interpreters who belong to a professional association in Germany and has been a point of contact for trade, industry, policymaking and education since 1955. The association is headquartered in Berlin.   BDÜ generally welcomes a dicsussion on introducing regulation where there is an imbalance of negotiating power. This is only the case in the so-called 'platform economy' but may also occur in other scenarios.  When discussing rules, this should not be limited to pricing alone; working conditions (including health and safety regulations) also need to be incorporated.  Regulations should provide for sufficient flexibility regarding self-employed entrepreneurs who do not require protection.  Professional associations such as the BDÜ play an important role in defining guidelines and standards for our professions. We are ready to join the dialogue in the upcoming consultation process.
Organisation: Bundesverband der Dolmetscher und Übersetzer e.V. (BDÜ)
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules
organisation_lower: bundesverband der dolmetscher und übersetzer e.v. (bdü)

feedback_msg_text: In Slovakia, as in many other European countries,  the conflict between labour law rights and competition law impedes freelance artists to bargain collectively or to set minimum working standards. As a result, the average rates for literary translation haven't changed for more than 15 years (!). While literary (or any other) translators aren't allowed to set minimum rates, there has been a silent  agreement among publishers, setting the maximum rate for translation (and licensing) of one standard page at 7 EUR. As our recent research (https://www.bridge.ff.ukf.sk/index.php/bridge/article/view/24) has shown, these rates reflect neither the genre, nor the difficulty, nor the language of the translated text, nor the experience of the translator (debuting translators earn the same as renowned experts), nor the scope of the licensing. Less than 5 % of literary translators receive royalties from their published translations.  Moreover, it is very rare that literary translators receive an advance payment of the fee. A vast majority (more than 95%) of our respondents receive the first payment for their work only after submitting the complete manuscript of the translation to the publisher or upon the publishing of the work. Which means, months of work without any salary, while still having to pay mandatory social and health security every month (amounting currently to 258 EUR monthly). The situation is even worse for freelance literary editors, who have been earning 1,5 to 2 EUR for a reviewed standard page since the 1990’s. As a result, both literary translators and editors have to have additional full- or part-time jobs, which leads to alarming de-professionalisation of literary translation and editing, and results in ever poorer quality of published translations (which still make up more than 50 per cent of books published in Slovakia). On behalf of DoSlov, Slovak association of literary translators and editors, we welcome this initiative of the European Commission. We believe that collective bargaining is the only way to negotiate fairer working contracts for freelance artists and cultural workers, and to prevent further precarisation and de-professionalisation of our work.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: From Journalist group in CCOO Spain -the main union in the country- support Option 4, to protect "all solo self-employed providing their own labour through digital labour platforms or to professional customers of any size". We strongly deffend that the iniciative should protect all kind of employees, allowing the participation of trade unions and providing a legal framework that facilitates fair collective agreements. Competition law cannot act as a shield for precariousness, bearing in mind specially media workers in Spain have been under bad working conditions, poor salaries, and a low level of social protection.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: industriAll European trade union is the European federation for national trade unions in the manufacturing sector across Europe. For our affiliates collective bargaining is a fundamental right and core business belonging to the exclusive competence of recognised social partner organisations.  Platform work has been established in a number of sectors and countries in the sense that workers find gig work in digital market places. This new form of work has also started to spread in the manufacturing industries. Precariousness, uncertainty, health risks and low wages are predominant factors in this group of workers.   Platform workers are usually registered as self-employed without the right to collective bargaining. This is an unfortunate situation as all workers should have the right to defend their collective interests through negotiations. However, we have seen some examples of recently concluded collective agreements where platform workers have been given employment contracts and guaranteed rights according to collective agreements.   An EU initiative in this field must safeguard access to collective bargaining as a fundamental right of all workers, regardless of employment status. This universal human right is recognised under international and European legal instruments. Joining a union, engaging in collective bargaining, and enjoying protection under collective agreements must not be limited by competition rules.  It must be made clear that collective agreements fall completely outside the scope of competition law, regardless of whether they protect employees, self-employed or other non-standard workers. This can be done through an EU guidance and a restrictive interpretation of Article 101 TFEU and the concept of ‘undertaking’.  The initiative must ensure all workers enjoy their fundamental right to collective bargaining without exceptions. Collective bargaining cannot be limited to only certain categories of ‘solo self-employed’ but must be ensured for genuine self-employed as well as for other non-standard workers, including workers on digital platforms. This initiative must not in any way result in additional employment categories.   Collective bargaining is an intrinsic element of social dialogue, consisting in negotiations between management and labour to improve working conditions. Competition law must not undermine such social policy objectives. Instead of adopting a ‘broader’ understanding beyond ‘traditional’ collective bargaining ‘under labour law’, the initiative should promote a restrictive interpretation of ‘undertakings’ under Article 101 TFEU. Trade unions are not cartels, and self-employed and other non-standard workers engaging in collective bargaining are not undertakings.  The initiative must align with established definitions of collective bargaining in applicable human rights instruments, ensuring full respect for national industrial systems and collective bargaining practices. The initiative must not open for social dumping by legitimising alternative bargaining actors than bona fide social partner organisations, e.g. ‘yellow’ company unions. Only recognised, representative and independent trade unions can legitimately bargain collectively on behalf of employees, self-employed and other non-standards workers.  The choice of policy instrument, possible legal basis and process must respect the autonomy of social partners. Any initiative in relation to collective bargaining should respect the Treaty-based procedure for social partner consultation and could not apply a competition legal base.  This competition policy initiative should be limited to providing guidance on the scope of Article 101 TFEU by clarifying concepts of competition law, and not by altering fundamental concepts of collective bargaining or national industrial relation systems.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Il est impensable qu'au 21ème siècle, les auteurs (dans le secteur de l'audiovisuel en ce qui me concerne) se retrouvent ainsi isolés lors des négociations de tarifs avec un client. Seuls contre une entreprise qui n'aura aucune peine à aller vers le moins-disant, qui offrira moins par manque de connaissance des tarifs ou par manque de scrupules. Tout le secteur s'en retrouve tiré vers le bas et cela nous met TOUS en péril.   Puisque cela nous concerne tous, pourquoi ne pourrions-nous pas, à l'instar d'autres acteurs du même secteur, (les comédiens de doublage, par exemple) nous entendre sur un tarif plancher ? Pourquoi n'aurions-nous pas le droit de défendre la survie même de notre activité ? Tant de tarifs sont déjà règlementés dans tant de domaines. Lorsqu'ils concernent des "entreprises" unipersonnelles, cela devrait être la norme : un tarif minimum. Ensuite, chacun pourrait négocier davantage en fonction de son expérience, de son expertise, mais qu'au moins on puisse VIVRE de son activité.   Actuellement, l'absence de tarif minimal collectif entraîne une pression constante sur nos conditions de travail (tandis que l'inflation continue, elle, de croître), conditions qui se dégradent de jour en jour, car nous sommes le seul rouage de la grande chaîne de la post-production sur laquelle nos commanditaires peuvent exercer des baisses de prix.  Pris entre le marteau et l'enclume, le quotidien et l'avenir paraissent de plus en plus sombres.  Merci d'entendre notre voix !
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Der Verband Freier Berufe in Bayern e.V. (VFB) unterstützt die Initiative, fordert aber den Zugang zu Honorar- oder Gebührenordnungen auch auf die Solo-Selbstständigen außerhalb der Plattform-Ökonomie auszudehnen.  Mit Blick auf die wirtschaftliche Situation der Solo-Selbstständigen mit vielen hybriden Beschäftigungsformen im gesamten Bereich der Kreativwirtschaft sehen wir die Option IV, verbunden mit dem Zugang zu Honorar- oder Gebührenordnungen, als geeignet an, eine Verbesserung der Verhandlungsbasis der Solo-Selbstständigen herbeizuführen. Eine klare Honorarvereinbarung und Kostenrahmen, wie sie in Deutschland für Architekten, Rechtsanwälte und Steuerberater üblich ist, könnte zu einer deutlichen Verbesserung und Stabilisierung der Einkommenssituation von solo-selbstständigen Freiberuflern führen und Transparenz für den Verbraucher schaffen.  Die Situation der Solo-Selbstständigen im Bereich der Kunst und Kreativwirtschaft ist geprägt von einem Übermaß an Einzelunternehmern mit einem Anteil von bis zu 64% der Gesamtbeschäftigtenzahl. Die durchschnittlichen Einkommen dieser Solo-Selbstständigen in der Kultur- und Kreativwirtschaft bewegt sich auf dem Existenzminimum. Dem gegenüber stehen wenige marktmächtige Verwerter der freiberuflichen Leistung von kreativer Arbeit (Brutto-Wertschöpfung KuK Bayern: 20,3 Milliarden EUR; Gesamtumsatz KuK: 37,5 Milliarden EUR). Ein funktionierender Markt aus Angebot und Nachfrage ist weitgehend nicht gegeben. Es gelingt nur wenigen Freiberuflern eine gute Verhandlungsbasis durch eine exklusive Markenbildung als Einzelunternehmer zu erreichen. Eine gleichberechtigte funktionierende Verhandlungsbasis zwischen Auftragnehmer und Auftraggeber ist in den wenigsten Fällen gegeben.  Die Verwerter von kreativer freiberuflicher Arbeit, beispielsweise Produktionsfirmen in der Film- und Fernsehindustrie lagern unternehmerisches Risiko an Freiberufler aus. Dies erfolgt über das Mittel der kurzzeitig sozialversicherungspflichtigen Beschäftigung oder von Werksverträgen an Solo-Selbstständige, die die Preisbildung nicht souverän verhandeln können.  Faire Gebühren-/Honorarrahmen durch qualifizierte berufsständische Vertretungen können den verbreiteten unlauteren Wettbewerb zurückdrängen, ohne eine grundsätzlich freie Preisgestaltung zwischen Unternehmern infrage zu stellen. Das Interesse der Betroffenen an der Ausübung des Freien Berufs als Einzelunternehmer sollte durch diese Initiative gestärkt werden.  Die Initiative der Europäischen Kommission würde die Verhandlungsposition der Berufsverbände für eine angemessene Honorarfindung stärken und die rechtlichen Rahmenbedingungen für diese Verhandlungen schaffen, wenn dadurch ein Zugang zu Honorar- oder Gebührenordnungen auch für Solo-Selbstständige erreicht würde. feedback_msg_text: HK Denmark’s position on Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application of EU competition rules  Feedback February 3rd, 2021  • HK welcomes this initiative from the Commission as the current interpretation of competition rules prevents solo self-employed (as defined by competition authorities) from pushing for collective agreements to ensure fair working conditions  • HK can confirm the overall problem definition and believes the problem goes beyond digital labour platforms as many solo self-employed find themselves in a very weak bargaining position when met with unilaterally dictated, one-sided contracts by professional customers in a comparatively overpowering bargaining position  • HK believes the initiative – depending on the options – will help eliminate or diminish the chilling effect on collective bargaining in areas where the lines between employee and solo self-employed are blurred in current competition law (not always interpreted the same way across member states)  • HK prefers a binding legislative solution  • HK would like to bring the Commission’s attention to a number of unanswered questions which we hope can be further clarified before the official hearing process  Definition of digital labour platforms: Option 1 – 4 mentions digital labour platforms. So far, many digital labour platforms have defined themselves as digital services merely facilitating transactions in which the platform takes no part. How does the Commission propose to define digital labour platforms to ensure that such platforms are defined as professional clients with a client’s responsibilities?  How does the initiative propose to deal with platforms that combine platform work with reselling of goods or sharing economy?  Regarding option 1-4: HK prefers an option that applies to all professional clients whether organized as a digital labour platform or not. As a small country where most professional clients are below the threshold of SME, option 1 and 2 would have limited impact on solo self-employed in a weak bargaining position. The challenge of option 3 is the lack of generally applicable EU definition of regulated/liberal professions. Thus at this stage, HK prefers option 4.  In option 4, the Commission states that “under this option it could be further analysed whether public or semi-public professional associations that unite all professionals exercising regulated professions should be allowed to negotiate on behalf of their members”. We would like the Commission to elaborate on this further as it is somewhat unclear to us what this means.  /Kim Simonsen Chairman of HK Denmark For further clarification or follow up, please contact Kirstine Baloti at HK Private Sector  About HK: With approximately 240.000 members, HK is Denmark’s largest union for salaried employees. Our members work in a range of white collar professions across the public and private sector. HK also organises freelancers and solo self-employed within the field. Most of our freelancers and solo self-employed members work in the field of it-services, graphic design, book keeping, administration and translation/interpretation.  https://www.hk.dk/omhk/about-hk
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Der Bundesverband Bildender Künstlerinnen und Künstler unterstützt die Initiative und fordert, den Zugang zu Tarifverträgen auch auf die Soloselbständigen außerhalb der Plattform-Ökonomie auszudehnen. Mit Blick auf die wirtschaftliche Situation in der Bildenden Kunst mit vielen hybriden Beschäftigungsformen im gesamten Bereich der Kreativwirtschaft sehen wir die Option 4 der Initiative als vordringlich an, da das Problem nicht durch die Plattformökonomie neu verursacht ist, sondern bereits in vordigitaler Zeit existiert hat. Insbesondere erwarten wir für die Bildende Kunst eine Verbesserung der Verhandlungsbasis der Soloselbständigen und ihrer berufsständischen Interessenvertretung gegenüber Ausstellungshäusern, privaten Auftraggebern, Verwertern von Kunst, den Galerien und Verbänden des Kunstmarkts. Eine klare Vereinbarung, wie z. B. die HOAI der Architekten, könnte zu einer deutlichen Verbesserung und Stabilisierung der Einkommenssituation führen und dadurch eine soziale Absicherung und Altersvorsorge erleichtern. Zudem erwarten wir von der Initiative eine Verbesserung der Verhandlungsposition zu Institutionen der Öffentlichen Hand und sehr großen Unternehmen, die aufgrund ihrer Monopolstellung bisher keine oder verschwindend geringe Honorare für freischaffende Künstlerinnen und Künstler bezahlen.  Die Situation der Soloselbständigen im Bereich der Kunst und Kreativwirtschaft ist prekär. Die Selbstvermarktung hat durch die Digitalisierung nicht zugenommen, d. h. dass die Verwerter weiterhin eine sehr große Bedeutung haben (Schulz, 2020: 025). Die Marktmacht der Verwerter kreativer Arbeit ist erdrückend. Eine gleichberechtigt funktionierende Verhandlungsbasis zwischen Auftragnehmer und Auftraggeber ist nicht gegeben. Unlauterer Wettbewerb und Preisdumping sind weit verbreitet. Die Preise orientieren sich weitgehend an gedeckelten Etats und nicht am tatsächlichen Aufwand. Die Duldung unbezahlter Arbeitsleistung stellt die Maximalform des Preisdumpings dar.  Das Ergebnis der Eurofonds-Studie aus dem Jahre 2017 – ein Viertel der Selbständigen haben ungünstige Arbeitsbedingungen einschließlich eines niedrigen Einkommensniveaus – deckt sich mit anderen Studienergebnissen in der Bildenden Kunst. Die Einkommen sind überwiegend prekär – auch, weil künstlerische Leistungen nicht oder nur teilweise vergütet werden. Deswegen fordert der Bundesverband Bildender Künstlerinnen und Künstler (BBK) mit seinen Landes- und Regionalverbänden, künstlerische Leistungen angemessen zu vergüten, wie z. B. im Zusammenhang mit Ausstellungen (Ausstellungsvergütung), Ablöse von Bildrechten, angemessene Verrechnungssätze für kreative, freiberufliche Leistungen, eine Preisbildung, die sich orientiert am tatsächlichen Aufwand. Faire Mindeststandards können den verbreiteten unlauteren Wettbewerb zurückdrängen, ohne eine grundsätzlich freie Preisgestaltung infrage zu stellen.  Die Initiative der EU KOM würde die Verhandlungsposition der Berufsverbände für eine angemessene Honorarfindung stärken und die rechtlichen Rahmenbedingungen für Verhandlungen schaffen.  Im Bereich des Urheberrechts verfügen Bildende Künstler*innen in Deutschland bereits über eine starke Verhandlungsführung auf nationaler, europäischer und internationaler Ebene durch die Verwertungsgesellschaft Bild-Kunst. Wir fordern eine weitere Stärkung der Verwertungsgesellschaften in allen europäischen Ländern. (...)  Vollständige Fassung in der angehängten Datei... feedback_msg_text: Frågorna om atypiska anlitandeformer och oklara anställningsförhållanden har präglat den europeiska och nationella diskussionen om plattformsarbete under flera år. Parallellt har vi sett en ökande flexibilsering av arbetskraften där outsourcing och falska egenföretagare har blivit vanligare. LO anser att det är en oacceptabel utveckling som för med sig en ansvarsförskjutning från företaget till individen. LO vill istället se fler trygga och goda arbeten även i plattformsekonomin. Det plattformsarbete som utförs ska regleras inom medlemsstaternas olika arbetsmarknadsmodeller. För svensk del är det den kollektiva självregleringsmodellen, där arbetsmarknadens parter bär det primära ansvaret för lön och arbetsvillkor, som måste utgöra grund för alla eventuella initiativ för att hantera plattformsarbete. LO vill lyfta fram att det redan idag finns goda exempel i Sverige på sådana regleringar.   LO anser att det arbetsrättsliga läget vid plattformsarbete ska prövas och regleras i enlighet med nationell rätt. I Sverige är arbetstagarbegreppet tvingande och har vuxit fram genom rättstillämpningen. Arbetstagarbegreppet har i Sverige varit dynamiskt och hela tiden tagit hänsyn till utvecklingen på arbetsmarknaden, vilket är ett snabbt och rörligt sätt att hantera förändringar. En tvingande legaldefinition på EU-nivå blir för statisk för att kunna hänga med i en allt snabbare utveckling. En EU-definition av arbetstagarbegreppet skulle sannolikt även både få effekter på rättsområden där medlemsstaterna har exklusiv kompetens och arbetsrätten i sin helhet. Dessutom skulle en europeisk villkorsreglering för atypiska anlitandeformer innebära ett materiellt intrång i den nationella partsautonomin.   Till detta kommer även mer rättsrealistiska överväganden. I en domstolsprocess där arbetstagarbegreppet aktualiseras finns inte tid eller utrymme att hänskjuta frågan till EU-domstolen att fastställa huruvida en anställd är arbetstagare eller ej. Svaret på frågan kommer att ges allt för sent för att vara till hjälp i tvisten.   LO vill under inga omständigheter se ett rättsligt initiativ i form av förordning på området. Det skulle få ödesdigra konsekvenser för vår kollektiva självregleringsmodell och riskera allvarliga följder för kollektivavtalsmodellen. LO ser därför ytterst allvarligt på alla EU-initiativ som direkt eller indirekt syftar till att definiera vad som är en arbetstagare eller vad som är en uppdragstagare.  För LO är det vidare viktigt att alla som arbetar, oavsett anlitandeform kan åtnjuta de fri- och rättigheter som följer av internationella konventioner såväl som nationella sociala trygghetssystem. Det är därför av största vikt att unionens medlemsländer tar sitt ansvar att säkerställa detta för sina medborgare. Detsamma gäller för medlemsländernas ansvar att tydligt sätta ner foten mot företag som använder plattformar som verktyg för att undkomma arbetsgivaransvar och därmed bidra till både villkors- och lönedumpning.   LO välkomnar Kommissionens intention att sätta fokus på den sociala agendan och stärka arbetskraftens makt. För LO är det dock av yttersta vikt att kollektivavtalsmodellerna förblir nationell kompetens och motsätter sig helt den rättsliga grund som förslaget vilar på. Vi noterar att frågan om rättslig grund ensidigt baseras på fördragets regler om konkurrens och tillnärmning av lagstiftning (artikel 103). Flera av de frågeställningar som aktualiseras av kommissionens överväganden är av en sådan karaktär att även fördragets avdelning om socialpolitik (artikel 151 och framåt) bör övervägas ingående. Förenligheten med artikel 153.1.f behöver övervägas och fördjupas närmare. LO ifrågasätter vidare Kommissionens förfarandeordning gällande detta initiativ. Kollektiva förhandlingar är som utgångspunkt medlemsstaternas exklusiva kompetens och måste ovillkorligen respekteras. Vill kommissionen gå vidare med initiativ på området behöver de begränsningar som EU-fördragen innebär respekteras.  Feedback from: Landsorganisationen i Sverige (76.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

Že v izhodišču so zato v vlogi tistega, ki ne more postavljati pogojev ali se pogajati kot enakovreden sogovornik.  -  To področje je zato treba nujno urediti in omogočiti tudi samozaposlenim enakovredno obravnavo in možnost enakovrednega sodelovanja na javnih in drugih razpisih.   - Zagotovljeno mora biti tako plačilo, ki omogoča dostojno življenje vsakemu samozaposlenemu.
