feedback_msg_text: Desde ATRAE (Asociación de Traducción y Adaptación Audiovisual de España), una asociación sin ánimo de lucro, representamos a más de 400 socios, en su mayoría autónomos, que de un modo u otro se ven afectados por los abusos de las empresas y las restricciones de la actual ley de competencia. En los últimos años, hemos vivido el aumento de la oferta y la demanda de contenido audiovisual, pero no hemos vivido el aumento de las tarifas y las mejoras de nuestras condiciones laborales. Aún es más, este aumento en la demanda por parte de los usuarios ha hecho que en muchísimos casos las empresas se aprovechen de nuestro trabajo, empeorando condiciones y reduciendo las tarifas a mínimos históricos. Situación que se ha visto aún más agravada con la pandemia que tanto ha afectado a Europa y a España.  Como resultado, muchos traductores no alcanzan una remuneración digna tras varios años de formación y práctica. Desde nuestra asociación, nos gustaría poder ayudar a que todos esos traductores tengan unas condiciones dignas, pero la actual ley de competencia ni siquiera nos permite recomendar tarifas. Por eso mismo, consideramos que negociar las tarifas de forma colectiva, ya sea a nivel nacional o europeo, nos ayudará a mantener unas condiciones de trabajo dignas, acordes con la calidad y el buen hacer que merece un trabajo tan vital para la comunicación como la traducción.
Submitted by: ATRAE Asociación de Traducción y Adaptación Audiovisual de España
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Association of Freelance Journalists in Finland (AFJ) prefers the EU-commission to move forward with the policy option 4. This should ensure the option for the trade unions to bargain collectively on behalf of all their members, also freelancers and other self-employed. This option is the widest in its scope and ensures that no self-employed worker is left unprotected. The option does not create new boundaries between the self-employed, thus giving legal certainty about the right of collective bargaining for all of them.  The self-employed journalists in Finland do not currently have the bargaining power to negotiate the terms and conditions. This has led to a situation where the freelancers only have half of the income of an employed journalist. Due to the features of Finnish social security system, but also due to the limited income, freelancers do not have the same social security as the employed journalists: most freelancers can´t afford occupational health care, and most can´t cover for full pension insurances. The collective bargaining right is an appropriate way for improving the situation.   The collective bargaining rights will become even more important issue in the future, since it is predictable, that freelance working will become more common way to earn income. Freelancers often combine self-employment and entrepreneurship with working in different platforms. Freelance-journalists also work for several customers, and many of them combine different skills at their work. Therefore the bargaining rights should cover all journalism-related work regardless of the size or the field of the buyer.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Komission hanke itsensätyöllistäjien ja ei-työsuhteisten oikeudesta järjestäytyä ja neuvotella työehdoistaan on tarpeellinen eritoten nykyisessä työelämän murroksessa. Vaikka järjestäytymisoikeus ja kollektiivineuvotteluoikeus ovat tunnustettuja perus- ja ihmisoikeuksia, törmätään sekä EU- että kansallisella tasolla jatkuvasti kilpailuoikeuden asettamiin rajaehtoihin, eikä perusoikeus käytännössä toteudu. Tämä lainsäädännöllinen ristiriita tulee ratkaista ja antaa selvät työkalut osapuolille toimia. Kilpailuoikeuteen vetoaminen on käytännössä johtanut kohtuuttomiin väitteisiin kartellien syntymisestä tai kilpailuasetelman väärinkäytöksistä, mikä ei tässä kontekstissa pidä paikkaansa, kun tarkoituksena on saattaa itsensätyöllistäjien perusoikeudet samalle tasolle työsuhteisten kanssa. Pelkkä perusoikeuksiin viittaaminen ei tähän mennessä ole johtanut itsensätyöllistäjien neuvotteluaseman parantamiseen, vaan asia tulee selkeyttää lainsäädännössä konkreettisesti.   Suomessa aloilla, joilta löytyy yhä enenevässä määrin ei-työsuhteisia työntekijöitä, on kattava verkosto järjestöjä, jotka voivat neuvotella kollektiivisopimuksia myös ei-työsuhteisten puolesta. Aikaisemmin vastaavilla aloilla on ollut työehtosopimuksia, mutta työsuhteiden vähentyessä myös työehtosopimukset ovat lakanneet. Sitä kautta on kuitenkin löydettävissä neuvotteluosapuoli joko yritys- tai järjestökohtaisesti. Neuvotteluoikeutta ei pidä rajata pelkästään alustatalouteen, koska ilmiö huomattavasti laajempi.   Kollektiivisopimusten sisällön piiriin on työehtojen lisäksi luettava mm. tekijänoikeuksista neuvotteleminen. Varsinkin luovilla aloilla tekijöiden aseman heikommuus suhteessa toimeksiantaja- ja käyttäjäpuoleen johtuu hyvin pitkälti siitä, että tekijänoikeusista ei kilpailuoikeudellisten argumenttien johdosta ole voitu neuvotella kollektiivisesti tähän mennessä.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Sindikat novinara Hrvatske (SNH) pozdravlja inicijativu za zakonodavstvo koje uključuje pravo kolektivnog pregovaranja samozaposlenih. Naš sindikat predstavlja novinare iz svih medija i aktivno pokušavamo uključiti u naše  aktivnosti freelencere i samozaposlene novinare kako bismo poboljšali njihov položaj. A zaštita njihovih prava nije na zadovoljavajućoj razini. Mnogi slobodni novinari ne mogu živjeti od svojih naknada, dakle ne mogu živjeti od svojega rada iako su mahom visokoobrazovani profesionalci, no teško mogu dostići naknadu i zaštitu radnih prava poput kolega koji su zaposleni u medijskim kućama. Sindikat novinara svojim aktivnostima pokušava upozoriti na taj nesrazmjer i pomoći u borbi za poštene naknade i jednake plaće, ali pravila tržišnog natjecanja dominiraju nad pravima iz radnog odnosa, na štetu freelancera i samozaposlenih. U većini zemalja freelanceri i samozaposleni novinari dijele sličan problem, a taj problem tišti i kolegice i kolege u Hrvatskoj - za njih se, naime,  primjenjuju pravila za poduzetnike, a ne za radnike, time su zakinuti za niz zaštitnih odredbi koju jamči kolektivni ugovor i mogućnost da kolektivnim pregovaranjem poboljšaju zaštitu svojih prava, podignu kvalitetu rada i prihoda, te naknada. Covid kriza pokazala je koliko su ugroženi slobodni i samozaposleni novinari jer su najteže stradali u ekonomskoj krizi koja je pogodila svijet uslijed pandemije, te je dodatno naglašena potreba rješavanja ovog pitanja. U našem, medijskom sektoru sve više kolegica i kolega moraju raditi kao freelanceri ili samozaposleni, jer poslodavcu odgovara takav dogovor, no to ih isključuje iz procesa kolektivnog pregovaranja. Smatramo da je važno definirati jasna rješenja koja ne ostavljaju mogućnost dvojakih tumačenja, već jasna prava slobodnih novinara i samozaposlenih u skladu sa standardima MOR-a. Smatramo da je važno jasno definirati   pravnu poziciju  samozaposlenih radnika u odnosu na njihovo pravo na kolektivno pregovaranje. Te Sindikat novinara Hrvatske  vjeruje da je  da je opcija 4 najpovoljnii izbor za buduću regulativu, pritom se zalažemo i naglašavamo važnost uloge sindikata kao sudionika socijalnog dijaloga.
Organisation: Sindikat novinara Hrvatske (Trade union of Croatian journalists )
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Onze feedback vindt u in de bijlage die wij hierbij verzenden.  Hierna volgt een verkorte versie:   Wij, Creatieve Coalitie, Platform Makers en de Kunstenbond, vertegenwoordigen ruim 50.000 Nederlandse werkenden in de Culturele en Creatieve Sector (CCS). Daar zitten werknemers bij, maar dat zijn voornamelijk zzp’ers. Logisch, want de sector bestaat voornamelijk uit zzp’ers. Veelal kwetsbare zzp’ers. Wie de internationale onderzoeken daarover bijhoudt weet dat de CCS een sector is waar al decennia lang -en wereldwijd- problemen zijn met en zorgen zijn over de arbeidsmarkt- en inkomenspositie van werkenden. (zie hiervoor onze eerdere reactie op de consultatie, waarin wij verwijzen naar rapportages van de Nederlandse SER en Raad voor Cultuur  https://www.ser.nl/nl/publicaties/verkenning-arbeidsmarkt-culturele-sector (Verkenning) en de ILO issue paper (voor Global Dialogue Forum in 2014): https://www.ilo.org/sector/Resources/publications/WCMS_240701/lang--en/index.htm  Het aanbieden van activiteiten/werk via online platforms komt beperkt voor. Het alleen toestaan van collectief onderhandelen voor aanbieden van arbeid via online platforms (OPTIE 1) valt daarmee sowieso als instrument meteen al af. Dat gaat werkenden in een groot en toenemend belangrijk deel van de EU-economie geen soelaas bieden.  De oorzaak van de bestaande kwetsbaarheid kan gezocht worden in een combinatie van factoren, die in de basis voor een belangrijk deel voortkomen uit de enorme passie waarin professionals in de CCS volledig voor ‘hun vak’ gaan. Het valt samen met hun identiteit, wie ze zijn. En dat maakt hen en al hun collega’s extra kwetsbaar.   Het overgrote deel van de aanwezige oorzaken (voor een opsomming daarvan zie bijlage) liggen buiten de omstandigheid van een relatief grote marktpartij als wederpartij/klant in de onderhandelingen. Een afbakening op grootte van de professionele klant (OPTIE 2) zal geen/volstrekt onvoldoende effect sorteren. De onderhandelingspositie is door de genoemde oorzaken ook ten opzichte van kleine klanten zwak.   Binnen de CCS zijn vele beroepen ‘vrije beroepen’, en toch behoren deze beroepsbeoefenaren tot de professionals met de laagste inkomens en tarieven. Alleen de ‘architect’ oefent een gereguleerd beroep uit. OPTIE 3 zal voor de hele CCS sector dus geen enkele verbetering geven.   Een aanpassing in het mededingingssysteem is dus heel hard nodig (zie bijlage voor een opsomming van oorzaken en gevolgen). En alleen OPTIE 4 zou voldoende zijn om daadwerkelijk van betekenis te kunnen zijn.   Wij willen nog wel een onderwerp toevoegen.   Er zal zekerheid moeten komen dat collectief onderhandelen ook het instrument van de collectieve actie omvat.  Sterker, er moet ook gekeken worden naar het opnemen van een regeling die een incentive betekent voor (grote) opdrachtgevers om in gesprek te gaan en naar de (juridische) mogelijkheden die zzp’ers straks naast het collectief onderhandelen hebben (of moeten krijgen) om daarin ook voldoende effectief te kunnen zijn.  - Vast moet komen te staan dat het woord ‘workers’ in art. 6 lid 4 ESH ook alle zzp’ers omvat.  - En er moet geborgd worden dat er voldoende effectieve mogelijkheden zijn, zoals dit ook voor werknemers geldt, om niet alleen de onderhandelingen met elke collectieve actie te onderstrepen, maar zo nodig ook (desnoods via tussenkomst van de rechter) een (grote) opdrachtgever te kunnen verbieden een bestaande actie (inclusief als ultimum remedium een werkstaking) te breken.  (zie de bijlage voor de nadere toelichting)  Caspar de Kiefte, Kunstenbond mede namens de Creatieve Coalitie en Platform Makers Feedback from: Kunstenbond/Creatieve Coalitie/Platform Makers (187.3 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: On 28.01.2021 two Latvian organisations - Civic Alliance - Latvia ("umbrella" organisation of Latvian NGOs) and Centre for Public Policy PROVIDUS organised a meeting with Latvian stakeholders on collective bargaining agreements for self-employed. We fully agree that an open public consultation is needed as part of the impact assessment process - as intended by the European Commission. We ask European Commission to design both the impact assessment and the questionnaire for the public consultation in such a way that it includes questions on: 1) different interpretations in EU member states on scope of application of EU competition rules regarding self-employed. Would creating a trade union for self-employed (in a specific member state) be acceptable or does it already constitute a risk of breaking the competition rules?  Are all kinds of collective bargaining prohibited? To what extent the self-employed in different member states are aware of such restrictions? 2) differentiation of types of self-employment based on whether it constitutes the only/largest source of income for a person or it is just a means of gaining some additional income. The impact assessment should explore to what extent this difference is relevant relating to access to collective bargaining and protection of self-employed persons. 3) whether there should be some differentiation between types of self-employment where performers are interchangeable (for example, delivery services or taxi drivers) and creative work where a unique value is created (for example, musicians, writers). Should this distinction matter in context of access to collective bargaining?
Organisation: Two organisations: Centre for Public Policy PROVIDUS, Civic Aliance - Latvia

feedback_msg_text: ACV-CSC United Freelancers (Belgium) feedback on the Commission Roadmap on Competition Law and Collective Bargaining  It is essential to ensure competition law does not in any way limit collective bargaining, but the EU initiative raises serious concerns, which are outlined below and in the attached ETUC Background Paper.  WE CALL ON THE COMMISSION TO ISSUE INTERPRETATION GUIDANCE, clarifying that collective agreements fall completely outside the scope of competition law, regardless of whether they protect employees, self-employed or other non-standard workers. This guidance should promote a human right compliant and restrictive interpretation of Article 101 TFEU and the concept of ‘undertaking’.  OBJECTIVE The initiative must safeguard access to collective bargaining as a fundamental right of all workers, regardless of employment status. This universal human right is recognised under international and European human rights instruments, including for self-employed and other non-standard workers. Joining a union, engaging in collective bargaining, and enjoying protection under collective agreements must not be conditional upon competition rules.  SCOPE The initiative must ensure all workers enjoy their fundamental right to collective bargaining without exceptions. Collective bargaining cannot be limited to only certain categories of ‘solo self-employed’ but must be ensured for genuine self-employed as well as for other non-standard workers, including workers on digital platforms, even if national legislation doesn’t allow them to be requalified as employees. Formal employment status or precarity are not decisive element in determining the scope of fundamental rights or competition law. This initiative must not in any way result in additional or intermediate employment categories.   DEFINITIONS The initiative must align with established definitions of collective bargaining in applicable human rights instruments, ensuring full respect for national industrial systems and collective bargaining practices. It is not the role of competition law to regulate working conditions, or define what constitutes collective bargaining, who can engage in such negotiations or enjoy protection under collective agreements.  Collective bargaining is the exclusive competence of social partners, representing employers’ associations and trade union organisations. The initiative must not open for social dumping by legitimising alternative bargaining actors, e.g. ‘yellow’ company unions, wage-fixing between employers, ‘workers’ forums’ or ‘charters of good work’ one-sidedly introduced by digital platforms. Only organised, representative and independent trade unions can legitimately bargain collectively on behalf of employees, self-employed and other non-standards workers.  As affirmed by the EU Court of Justice, collective bargaining is an intrinsic element of social dialogue, consisting in negotiations between management and labour to improve working conditions. Competition law must not undermine such social policy objectives. Instead of adopting a ‘broader’ understanding beyond ‘traditional’ collective bargaining ‘under labour law’, the initiative should promote a restrictive interpretation of ‘undertakings’ under Article 101 TFEU. Trade unions are not cartels, and self-employed and other non-standard workers engaging in collective bargaining are not undertakings.  FORMAT The choice of policy instrument, possible legal basis and process must respect the autonomy of social partners. Any initiative in relation to collective bargaining should respect the Treaty-based procedure for social partner consultation and could not apply a competition legal base. This competition policy initiative should be limited to providing guidance on the scope of Article 101 TFEU by clarifying concepts of competition law, and not by altering fundamental concepts of collective bargaining or national industrial relation systems. feedback_msg_text: Lösungsvorschlag vor dem Hintergrund einer Digitalisierungs-Gesamtstrategie:  Bei den von der Kommission vorgeschlagenen Optionen präferiert GISAD zur Option 4. Alle Solo-Selbständigen sollten die Möglichkeit bekommen, ihre Arbeitsbedingungen gemeinsam zu verhandeln.   Tatsächlich ist es heute mit wenig Aufwand und Kosten möglich, jedem Bürger die Möglichkeit im Internet zu geben, sich online selbst darzustellen, selbst in einem Kategoriensystem einzuordnen und so von an seiner Dienstleistung Interessierten gefunden zu werden. In einem EU-D-S könnte dieses einfache Matching kostenlos sein. Der Anbieter könnte zusätzlich entscheiden, ob er seine Arbeitskraft anonym oder mit Namen anbieten will. Trotzdem wäre im Streitfall und nach richterlicher Verfügung jederzeit das Auf-heben der Anonymität möglich. Die EU Kommission müsste so etwas wie ein Grundrecht auf ein Angebot von Dienstleistungen im EU-D-S festlegen.  Der Markt würde sich in der Weise neu regeln, dass Plattformen in ihre Geschäftsmodelle intelligente Mehrwerte einbauen, die ihre Aufschläge rechtfertigen.  Um Daten zu veredeln und damit Wertschöpfung generieren zu können, sind personalisierte Daten in den meisten Fällen nicht notwendig. Er sollte deshalb für Anbieter möglich sein, sich datensparsam in einer Plattform einzutragen. Einen Anbieter, der trotz Anonymität zuverlässig zur Verfügung steht, ist genauso gut einzusetzen.  Auch anonym mit eindeutigem Merkmal kann eine Plattform eine für sie wertige Angebotsdatenbank anlegen. Allerdings fällt die Abhängigkeit des Solo-Selbständigen weg. Die Plattform weiß nicht, in welchen weiteren Portalen ein Solo-Selbstständiger seine Dienste anbietet. Das einzige, was zählt, ist die von ihm erbrachte Qualität im Verhältnis zur Vergütung.   Über ein eindeutiges anonymes Merkmal ist es im EU-D-S ebenfalls möglich, einen Solo-Selbständigen einem Gerichtsstand des gewöhnlichen Arbeitsorts zuzuordnen. feedback_msg_text: Assessment on the Initiative:  »Collective bargaining agreements for self employed- scope of application EU Competition«   Let us first emphasise that we strongly support the initiative to start tackling the problem of regulation of collective bargaining for the self-employed in media and digital industries. Just like the EFJ, of which we are a member, we think option 4 is the best choice since it provides a broader treatment of the exemption from competition rules for the self-employed and their representatives in full scope and on all platforms.  Our trade union operates in a small and highly concentrated market characterised by oligopolies, and represents close to 40% of all full-time journalists. For over 15 years we have been striving to protect self-employed workers. They are eligible for full membership of our union and are involved in the decision-making; during the deepest crises in the past, one in three registered self-employed journalists were members of our trade union. Notwithstanding the restrictions in competition rules, we have always endeavoured in collective bargaining with media companies to put in place standards for the self-employed that would be at least to a minimum extent comparable to the rights of employed workers (equal working conditions for equal pay).  Since we were constrained and unsuccessful in bargaining for the self-employed, in practice we fully focused on court proceedings and agreements leading to the hiring of the self-employed in full-time capacity. We did that by invoking a provision of the labour relationship law which prohibits civil contracts in labour relationships were there are elements of an employment relationship. This practice resulted in more full-time employment, but we remained powerless in improving the constantly deteriorating position of workers who remain self-employed.   The labour market in media is distintcly segmented to full-time employees, the formally self-employed, and the most legally unprotected, socially and economically deprivileged group of workers on the informal market (roughly 600 are registered as self-employed, and there are an estimated 200+ journalists with an informal status). The self-employed, who work under the same conditions as full-time employees, at best receive 20% lower pay for the same work. What is more, their fees are exclusive of compulsory social security contributions and cost of equipment, their working hours are unlimited, they struggle to take sick leave or go on holiday, and they are under constant risk of losing work. Due to poor work and social conditions, fewer people opt for a journalism profession and many abandon the profession altogether. As a result, the labour market is rife with dumping practices and media houses are facing a generational gap as younger staff leave and older journalists are not  replaced with new hires. The increasing uncertainty over work conditions undermines the overall quality of journalism and the level of professional independence.  This is why our trade union is convinced that the right to collective bargaining for the self-employed could provide at least an initial push towards the improvement of the often unbearable position of the self-employed. The right to unionise is vapid without the right to collective bargaining on minimum economic, social and contractual standards. Competition rules should not restrict collective bargaining on the work conditions of individuals who are self-employed. We particularly welcome the transnational nature of this initiative given that the media and digital markets, globally and in Slovenia, are highly concentrated and display clear monopoly and oligopoly features. We are therefore convinced that treating  competition between atomised self-employed workers the same way that we treat competition between media and digital corporations is senseless and deeply unjust.   Slovenian Union of Journalists
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The Union of Journalists in Finland (UJF) welcomes the initiative to develop the legislation regarding the right for collective bargaining for self-employed. We represent 14 000 members who work for the print media, broadcasting, publishing and new communications media. One in five of our members are freelancers/self employed.  1. Context and problem  UJF agrees that there is uncertainty on number of issues, including working conditions and access to collective bargaining for freelancers and other self-employed workers. This applies both for those working outside the platform economy and through platforms. Currently the competition legislation blocks the right to collective bargaining for the self-employed, as the competition authorities compare it to prize fixing. In several EU countries competition authorities have warned unions not to even recommend any minimum rates to their members referring to Article 101 of the TEU, because the competition authorities consider them undertakings and not workers.  We also have to mention that in the spring of 2019 the Finnish National Conciliator’s Office (the office assists labor market organizations in concluding collective agreements, especially in situations where industrial peace is threatened) concluded the following during a conciliation regarding the CBA of AV translators: “To the issue the parties had regarding the commission of non-employed translators the Conciliator do not give a proposition for conciliation, as the issue would require amending the legislation and thus is in the jurisdiction of the legislator in the boundaries of EU competition law.”  The self-employed all lack of the individual bargaining power to negotiate their terms and conditions, and thus their economic position in media industry is considerably weaker than the position of their employed colleagues. Their average income in Finland is only half of the average income of the employed journalists. We consider collective bargaining is an appropriate and fair way to improve their situation.  2. Objectives and policy options  We agree to the fullest that it is timely now to ensure that EU competition law does not stand in the way of collective bargaining for all self-employed workers working, whether working in in traditional off-line environment or on platforms as well as. We note that it is said that whether or not EU competition law prevents them from bargaining collectively, legal certainty is extremely important to reduce enforcement and litigation risks.  The UJF prefers the EU-commission to move forward with the policy option 4. This should ensure the option for the trade unions to bargain collectively on behalf of all their members, also freelancers and other self-employed. This option is the widest in its scope and ensures that no self-employed worker is left unprotected. The option does not create new boundaries between the self-employed, thus giving legal certainty about the right of collective bargaining for all of them.  3. Expectations  The proposal in option 4 will have great impact in improving the working and social situation of individuals that are currently in need of protection and often in precarious working conditions. The UJF also wants to stress that the proposal should be developed bearing in mind that collective bargaining is the exclusive competence of social partners. In this respect, genuine social dialogue and collective bargaining should be understood as negotiations between organized, representative and recognized social partners in accordance with national laws and traditions, in order not to legitimize company (“yellow”) unions under the influence of employers, wage fixing practices between employers or so-called “charters for good work” one-sidedly drawn up by some online platforms.  The pandemic crisis has accelerated the need for adjusting the unfair treatment, as freelancers are the first victims of the crisis in the media sector.  On behalf of UJF  Hannu Hallamaa Lawyer
Organisation: The Union of Journalists in Finland
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules
organisation_lower: the union of journalists in finland

feedback_msg_text: As your documents state, there is no room for collective bargaining by the self-employed, as we are considered “walking firms”. Also, we have increased in number in the last decades, following the boom of ITC. Many of our regulations correspond to realities dating back to the 20th century and obligations may end up strangling us. Also, digital or otherwise, small businesses (acting as single-person firms) are in dire straits with the increase of legal advantages for bigger companies and no advance in legislation that allows for that economic and social fabric to stay in good shape. From the viewpoint of a Spanish international digital freelancer and artist, the following guidelines would improve our quality of life: - Social security and taxing obligations proportionality, accurate intermittence recognition:  Contributions to social security and state treasury are not consequent with our real needs, situations and possibilities to work. Some markets may have grown, but also has competition. This entails greater difficulty to remain in business regularly, whilst our taxation stays at a fixed rate. At the same time, there is a tight limit to how many times one can declare to be out of service for several days of weeks during the year.  - Red tape 21st-century-style digitalisation: A very unexpensive way to save time and money to the self-employed would be to honour the advancement of technologies and create a one-stop fully digitalised spot for information and obligations towards public administration (treasury, social security or other). Many of us have to either spend a substantial amount of time keeping up-to-date with complex legislation or outsource bookkeeping and tax accounting. Consultancy businesses either charge a significant rate for such service or they do not earn enough for providing it. In any case, today’s state of knowledge and technologies certainly allows for one website per country to cater for all such needs in a simplified online form. This very straightforward measure would lift the burden from both the self-employed and consultancies at a ridiculous cost of creation and maintenance. - Distinction between oligopoly prevention, unfettered competition and power retention:  Even in long standing trades, where atmosphere within is rather nice, the impossibility to issue tax recommendations, for instance, hinders any possibility to grow as a collective. Meanwhile, large oligopolist companies do hold secret meetings to make sure they hoard their market share and create non-productive ghost firms in tax havens. - Better unemployment, health deprivation and disability protection:  This explains itself. We are allowed self-exploitation galore but zero self-care. Please, fix this.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The Danish Union of Journalists (DJ) representing 18.000 journalists and media workers in Denmark whereas 25 % are freelancers, welcomes the initiative to develop the legislation to allow collective bargaining for self-employed.  A. The Problem definition DJ agrees that there is a growing uncertainty on a number of issues, including working conditions and access to collective bargaining for freelancers and other self-employed workers – both for those working through platforms and outside the platform economy mainly due to competition legislation comparing freelancers prize fixing cartels or entities. They all meet a lack of the individual bargaining power to negotiate their terms and conditions. Collective bargaining is an appropriate and fair way to improve their situation.  B. Objectives and Policy options We totally agree that it is extremely timely now to ensure that EU competition law does not stand in the way of collective bargaining for self-employed workers working on platforms as well as off-line. We note that it is said that whether or not EU competition law prevents them from bargaining collectively, legal certainty is extremely important to reduce enforcement and litigation risks.  The Danish Union of Journalists prefers the EU-commission to introduce the mechanism mentioned in option 4 as this should ensure trade unions to bargain collectively on behalf of all their members, also freelancers and other self-employed. This option also addresses that most workers do their job both offline and online mixed in their workflow.  C. Expected Impact The proposal in option 4 will have a huge impact to improve the working and living situation of individuals that are currently in need of protection and often in very precarious working conditions. The DJ also wants to stress that the proposal is in full compliance with Article 28 of the EU charter of Fundamental Rights and the ILO-terminology on self-employed and their rights for organizing and collective bargaining.  The Danish Union of Journalists, Tine Johansen, president
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: AVTE (Audio-Visual Translators Europe), a non-profit organization that unites audio-visual translation associations from 18 European countries, wholeheartedly supports the revision of the European Union's current collective bargaining rules for freelancers. Over the last two decades, with the increase in online content in need of translation, rates have been driven down as increasingly integrated international "language service providers" compete to seize their share of a continually expanding market. Freelance translators are not allowed to bargain collectively with these companies to ensure fair rates and the protection of intellectual property rights for all. Ironically, despite being European citizens, they often work for global players outside the EU and cannot benefit from the frameworks applicable within the Union.  As a result, many gifted translators throughout Europe who have spent four or five years in higher education studying languages and translation cannot make a decent living. Our rates consistently fail to keep in step, even minimally, with inflation and the current pandemic has provided yet another excuse for "providers" to drive rates down and worsen working conditions even further without any consultation of translators. In some countries, translators cannot even earn the national minimum wage by working solely in the field of audiovisual translation. The possibility to conduct collective bargaining to put an end to this imbalance and maintain the quality and high standards that we bring to our work is now more vital than ever.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The Panhellenic Federation of Journalists Union, representing all professional journalists in Greece, is welcoming the European Commission’s initiative to establish a framework allowing collective bargaining agreements for self-employed workers.  Journalists in Greece were among the first to experience the consequences of the financial crisis of the 2010-2020 decade. In many cases, this resulted to deregulation of working conditions as the Media outlets were struggling to adapt to the new economic environment. The digital shift of the Media Industry caused fundamental changes in traditional forms of journalism. Thousands of employed journalists have lost their positions and started to create journalistic content as freelancers. The Corona pandemic, by encouraging remote working, has further established labor forms that do not fall under the scheme of fully employed staff: working remotely, under precarious conditions and with controversial working contracts is becoming the new regular in the Media industry of the pandemic era..  Very few freelance journalists have the power to negotiate for adequate remuneration for the work they provide and are able to choose among possible employers. The vast majority of freelance journalists are indeed poorly paid and usually fall under the forced freelances category. They and are very poorly remunerated, as they have minimum negotiating power themselves and their contracts cannot be negotiated collectively by the sector’s Unions. Therefore, we believe it is crucial that the right of collective bargaining will be acknowledged so that a minimum level of protection can be ensured.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Collective bargaining agreements – response from the Freelance sector within the Swedish Union of Journalists (SJF) The situation of Swedish freelance journalists was dire prior to the pandemic, due mainly to the media houses' lowered budgets after a massive fall in advertising revenues over the past decade. But the pandemic has of course made conditions worse. Some publications have closed down, some have ceased buying freelance material, and others are buying much less – or demanding the same work for lower payment, something that can be difficult to resist for a solitary freelancer.  The tools our union has to collectively combat the situation are:  1. The Freelance Agreement (Frilansavtalet) between the SJF and the Media Employers organization (MF). This agreement is more of a list of intentions, but one binding point is of some use to freelancers that have been selling material continually to the same media house for more than two years. In these cases, the media house commits itself to a period of notice (four months) before stopping buying the material. During this period, the media house must pay the freelancer.  2. The Freelance Recommendation (Frilansrekommendationen) . This is a list of recommended tariffs for reporters and photographers published by SJF and updated yearly. For 2021, the recommended price per hour for reporting is SEK 1 071 (107 Euro), including a number of different taxes. Few, if any, media houses adhere to the recommendation, but some say they do, demanding that freelancers do not charge them for all the hours of work done.  3. The Freelance Calculator (Frilanskalkylatorn). This is a digital tool on the SJF website that freelancers and media houses can access. By entering a number of variables, for example the suitable equivalent in monthly salary, a suggested hourly tariff can be obtained. Few media houses use this tool, as it is seen as rather complicated. But for freelancers it is a useful tool to compare what their payment is worth in relation to employed journalists. 4. The Payment Guide (Arvodesguiden). This is a database on the SJF website, accessible to freelance members and designed for them to compare their tariffs. The idea is simple: Freelancers enter basic facts about every story they have published, including the name of the publication, the price charged, the work hours spent, and the number of characters written. The SJF administatrors rate every post with regard to the price. By far, the most common rating is an F.  We are aware that these tools give us slightly more collective power than many of our European colleagues have, but they are better in theory than in practice. In reality, most freelancers' incomes do not come anywhere near those of employed journalists.  Regarding the brain drain of the media sector because of freelancers' poor work and social conditions there are no figures available, but poor conditions will in the long run drain the media sector of the most competent journalists, who will look for better income possibilities.  Finally, there is also an urgent need to improve the social protection for Swedish freelance journalists. Today, for example, freelancers run into constant problems with the Swedish Social Insurance Agency to get an accurate sick pay or parent’s allowance.  The freelance section of The Swedish Union of Journalists represents 1 800 journalists, which is some 13 percent of SJF's members.
Organisation: Frilans Riks, freelance sector within The Swedish Union of Journalists (SJF)
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Acta is the Italian association (quasi-union according to Heckscher-Carré definition -2006) that brings together solo self-employed professionals (without employees) working in the advanced service sector  ,trade excluded. For years, we have been reporting the ongoing decline in the fees earned by these workers, for whom no minimum rates are currently set or legally established. Therefore, we welcome as commendable and urgent the Commission’s initiative, in line with our Position Paper, submitted in September 2020, on the occasion of the Open Public Consultation on the Digital Services Act.  Concerning the four Initiative’s policy options, we deem Option 4 to be preferable: all solo self-employed providing their own labour through digital labour platforms or to professional customers of any size, based on the following reasons: a) In our experience, only a small portion of the self-employed work on, or with the intermediation of, a digital platform, but all self-employed workers, expecially after the 2008 crisis, have seen their compensation and income progressively reduced; b) in our opinion, as confirmed by our experience and knowledge of the labour market, it is important to cover all professionals exercising regulated/liberal professions, since even for these workers, and particularly for the youngest ones among them, equitable fees may be difficult to negotiate for (e.g. journalists, architects and even young lawyers) c) having no restrictions as regards the size of the counterpart in the collective bargaining/agreement would make it possible to apply minimum rates even when negotiating with small and very small enterprises (as it happens in the case of collective agreements for employees). As a matter of fact, enterprises (whatever their size) can generally count on a stronger bargaining power against individual professionals. However, the introduction of fee benchmarks would help both parties to reach a mutually satisfactory agreement.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The tectonic changes taking place in the workplace under the new circumstances created by the ever-increasing application of information technology and technology, as well as the remaining pandemic, also create new challenges for legislative initiatives. The increasingly emerging new forms of employment (e.g. crowdworking, nomadic work, zero-hours contracts) create a grey area between dependent and independent work and make the need for protection and safety of freelancers increasingly urgent. Especially in the field of journalism, this need appears even greater, due to the extensive use of technology in the provision of journalistic work through the media. There is therefore an absolute need for an institutional framework of minimum guarantees and general principles of operation, given the imbalance that appears in practice between the Contracting Parties engaged in such forms of employment. In order to create this institutional framework, it is necessary to give offer to freelance workers the benefits of collective bargaining and the drawing up of collective agreements. We therefore consider the Commission's initiative to be very important in this direction. We believe that policy proposal number 4 is the most appropriate in order to allow professionals' trade unions to negotiate without restrictions with individual employers or their respective employers' organisations with a view to creating rules with institutional and wage content. We believe that the inequality, the unfair working conditions, the lack of the ability to collect a decent income do not only occur in the employment of freelancers through digital platforms and that they are independent of the size of the employer's business or the existence of a legal framework for the safeguarding of each profession.
Submitted by: ESIEMTH Journalists Union of Macedonia and Thrace
Organisation: Journalists Union of Macedonia and Thrace
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules
organisation_lower: journalists union of macedonia and thrace

feedback_msg_text: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application of EU competition rules  On 6 January 2021, the European Commission published an initial impact assessment concerning ‘Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application of EU competition rules’. Akava would like to draw attention to the following aspects. It is excellent that the European Commission has finally undertaken an initiative concerning the collective promotion of interests concerning self-employed persons. The initiative is necessary, since Finland has nearly 200,000 solo self-employed persons, and this figure indicates a clear growth trend.    Self-employed persons often hold a weaker labour-market and negotiation position than their commissioning party. Trade unions must be able to represent self-employed persons in negotiations. The EU competition rules are interpreted very differently in different countries. For example, in Germany, Denmark and Austria, these types of negotiations are possible. A simple interpretation approach to EU competition law is not enough; the competition legislation must be specifically clarified at the overall EU level so as to facilitate a common collective bargaining policy that covers all self-employed persons throughout the entire EU.  Scope of application  The proposal of the Commission includes four different options for the application of the rules. They focus particularly on persons who employ themselves using digital platforms. The matter does not concern simply those individuals who work using a platform, but more broadly, all self-employed persons who are dependent on wages from commissioning parties and who have no genuine possibility to affect the terms of their own wage.   It is Akava’s opinion that the fourth option is the best and most comprehensive solution. Option 4 is clear and provides the broadest solution without creating demarcation problems.    Content  The initiative covers negotiations on agreements between parties to determine working conditions and wages. It does not allow for any agreements on consumer prices.   The initiative clarifies that aspect of EU competition law that would enable but not oblige collective bargaining between parties. In terms of competition law, it is important to clarify the rules so that they would no longer facilitate an interpretation that competition law precludes collective negotiations.    Possibility for trade unions to represent self-employed persons  The initiative and proposed models do not separately take any stand on the position of the trade unions. The trade unions should be able to represent self-employed persons in collective bargaining negotiations, where they are, by nature, in a weaker position. This must be specified and stated clearly in the initiative.   The position of self-employed persons must be improved through labour legislation  The Commission’s initiative on competition law is one part of the broader platform economy. The Commission is currently also preparing a platform economy initiative. Those carrying out platform work are, however, only one part of the larger group of self-employed persons, whose position, working conditions and security must be improved. This is done through the development of the labour legislation. The definition of the employment relationship must be expanded to include those solo self-employed persons who are in a subordinate position. We need EU-wide regulations to minimise the margin for interpretation on the national level and to ensure that countries, entrepreneurs and self-employed persons and platform companies hold an equal position within the market.  On behalf of Akava,  Anu Tuovinen  Senior Advisor Feedback from: Akava - Confederation of Unions for Professional and Managerial Staff in Finland (50.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Organisation: Akava - Confederation of Unions for Professional and Managerial Staff in Finland
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: La position économiquement dominante des passeurs d’ordre – courtiers ou clients directs – de la traduction et de l’interprétation ont eu pour conséquence une détérioration progressive et constante des conditions de travail et de rémunération des traducteurs et des interprètes indépendants.  Contrairement aux salariés, nos membres, en tant que travailleurs indépendants, sont soumis à des tarifs imposés qui restent souvent inchangés par-delà les décennies et qui impliquent une érosion au moins équivalente à l'augmentation annuelle du coût de la vie. Cette érosion est difficilement quantifiable pour ce qui est de la traduction mais pour l'interprétation de conférence, nous avons pu établir en comparant les tarifs minima une perte de pouvoir d'achat supérieure à 50% par journée de travail sur les trois dernières décennies.  Cette situation de marché à entraîné une précarisation progressive pour nombre de nos membres. La demande, par la CBTI, d’entrer en dialogue avec les gros passeurs d’ordre se heurte systématiquement à l’argument de l’art. 101 du Traité UE. La CBTI se réjouit donc de l’initiative lancée par la Commission européenne visant à excepter les travailleurs indépendants individuels fournisseurs de prestations intellectuelles de cette disposition et, par-là, à lever cet obstacle qui s’opposait à l’instauration d’un dialogue social bénéfique, condition indispensable à la réalisation d'un marché équilibré et équitable.  Max De Brouwer vice-président CBTI https://www.cbti-bkvt.org/
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: APTIC (Associació Professional de Traductors i Intèrprets de Catalunya) está compuesta por más de 500 profesionales dedicados a la traducción, la interpretación y la corrección.  El colectivo de profesionales de la traducción y la interpretación está formado en su mayor parte por trabajadores autónomos, sin vínculos laborales con empresas.  Uno de los objetivos de la asociación es defender los intereses de sus socios y respaldarlos con la fuerza del colectivo. Lamentablemente, la Ley de la competencia española (Ley 15/2007, de 3 de julio, de Defensa de la Competencia) nos prohíbe tajantemente publicar y discutir tarifas dentro de la asociación, tanto en nuestra web como en la lista de distribución de los socios. Existen antecedentes de sanciones a asociaciones del sector por este motivo, entre las que destaca una multa de 8 000 euros a EIZIE (Asociación de Traductores e Intérpretes de Lengua Vasca) en el año 2014.  Creemos que es una injusticia flagrante que se apliquen las mismas leyes de la competencia a agentes con poderes de negociación tan dispares como las multinacionales y los traductores autónomos.  El resultado de la falta de información y de poder de negociación entre los traductores, intérpretes y correctores autónomos es un mercado con tarifas a la baja desde hace años, con el consiguiente deterioro de las condiciones laborales. Ante esta situación de indefensión, el profesional no tiene más opción que aceptar las tarifas propuestas, con el agravante de que, si está iniciándose en la profesión, no dispone de referente alguno.  APTIC agradece la iniciativa de la Comisión Europea para regularizar las condiciones laborales de los trabajadores autónomos por medio de convenios colectivos.
Organisation: APTIC (Associació Professional de Traductors i Intèrprets de Catalunya)
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: En mi campo de trabajo está totalmente prohibido hablar de tarifas públicamente, sobre todo las asociaciones, ya que pueden ser sancionados por la Ley de competencia existente en España. Debido a esto, los profesionales sufrimos tarifas abusivas por parte de empresas del sector que, pese a ser simples intermediarios, se embolsan parte de la tarifa destinada al traductor. Así, tenemos grandes empresas líderes en la subtitulación que ofrecen 1,5 € por minuto y con unos plazos imposibles de 24 horas. Pese a que cierta plataforma ha hecho públicas las tarifas que ofrece a los traductores, hay empresas intermediarias que ofrecen a los traductores menos de la mitad de esa tarifa. Así, si al trabajar directamente con un vendor de dicha plataforma, recibes una tarifa de 7 € por minuto, esas otras empresas ofrecen 3 € por minuto, por lo que se embolsan los 4 € restantes que les pertenecen a los traductores. Ciertas empresas de gran renombre que controlan la mayoría de los productos audiovisuales se niegan a pagar una tarifa decente a sus traductores y prefieren prescindir de profesionales en favor de novatos en el sector que aceptarán cualquier tarifa con tal de empezar en la profesión sin darse cuenta de cómo afecta eso a sus compañeros. En cuestiones de revisión de productos audiovisuales, la cosa está peor. Encuentras empresas que incluso ofrecen 0,80 € por minuto de revisión, lo cual resulta abusivo e inaceptable. Si nos fijamos en la accesibilidad de los productos audiovisuales, un servicio muy importante para cierto sector de la población, el desdén con el que lo tratan ciertas empresas es vergonzoso. Tarifas que van desde 0,80 € a 1,30 € por minuto en el subtitulado para sordos, sea cual sea el género del producto audiovisual. España tiene las peores tarifas en traducción audiovisual y las peores condiciones laborales, ya que los plazos que se exigen a los profesionales son inhumanos.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: there is an inherent tension between competition law and the right to unite (and then to collective bargaining). The percentage of independents within the working population has been growing steadily and in some member states even risen steeply. These independents are very often in a weak bargaining situation vis a vis employers or principals. I propose the cultural and creative sector (CCS) as an example. The percentage of independents in that sector is often more than 30% and in some subsectors, such as visual arts more than 60%. And the higher the percentage of independents the lower the mean income. That alone proves there is a large power imbalance at play. Although there are professional associations they are prohibited to bargain collectively with principals and employers or even to give advice on which prices to propose. Employers and principals take advantage because they say there are others who can do it cheaper, stimulating a race to the bottom and thus more precarious income (a majority of visual artists in the Netherlands f.e. has a below minimum income). Also social dumping takes place where employees are let go and later some of them hired back as independents. Every economic crisis has delivered more independents. This situation asks for exploring the question of how to counter this imbalance and to change competition laws in such a way that working people, especially independents, are allowed some form of collective bargaining and unite themselves. This probably cannot be applied to all independents, f.e. those with incomes above a certain threshold. Therefore I am in favour of option 4.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The core of all antitrust regulations is to protect open competition from the forces of collusion. The gig economy is broken. It is broken because it systematically utilizes “dynamic pricing” where the price for service is set by the platform against another legal entity - the gig worker. This is plain price fixing. By allowing gig workers utilize “unionized price fixing” to counter the effects of “dynamic pricing” is a deeply flawed strategy. This strategy actually legalizes price fixing and discourages free and open competition among independent contractors. This practice will further discourage new startups from entering the market with lower take rakes (Uber for example imposes up to a 40% take rake on some rides.) Without a consumer need for lower raked platforms, companies like Uber will continue to unlawfully dominate the ride hailing and delivery business with excessive take rakes.  Antitrust law generally holds that price setting activities are permissible within business firms, but bars them beyond firm boundaries. Gig platforms do not provide services to consumers directly. Instead, these platforms connect consumers and gig workers and, set service terms and collect fares. The antitrust law's firm exemption strictly applies to entities that a firm directly controls, such as employees.  In the 1951 antitrust case United States v. Richfield Oil Co., the court ruled for the government because Richfield Oil Co. exercised de facto control over "independent businessmen," in contravention of the antitrust laws, although they were not company employees. This has become the basis for delineation between the domains of labor and antitrust: if subordinate entities are "independent businessmen" and not employees, it is illegal to exercise control. The United States Supreme Court affirmed the same basic principle against coercion of non-employees by vertical supply contract in the 1964 case Simpson v. Union Oil Co. of California.  Microlabor online marketplaces like Uber, Lyft, Handy, Amazon Home Services, DoorDash, and Instacart have perfected a process where workers deal bilaterally with tasks offered by employers that assume no standard employer obligations, while the platform operates the labor market to its own benefit – what one antitrust expert called a "for-profit hiring hall."  Because gig workers are not employees and gig platforms set the terms on which they transact with customers, including prices,  this is a violation of the ban on restraints of trade.  This issue of broken gig economy can only be resolved by either making gig platforms hire the gig workforce and bear the costs of operations, or by allowing each gig worker to compete with others in a free market setting - to set their own rates.  To allow gig workers to bargain with a platform is to allow collusion to take place as a matter of fact.  It is illegal for anyone, including gig workers, to engage in price-fixing. This includes agreeing or coordinating with other gig workers on pricing. The law requires that gig workers must make decisions about pricing on their own. To merely enforce this principle is to fix the gig economy problem.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: The Association of Slovenian Film and TV Translators (Društvo slovenskih filmskih in televizijskih prevajalcev, DSFTP) strongly supports the revision of the current collective bargaining provisions, as they are weakening the already unfavourable bargaining position of self-employed in translation industry. This creates an ecosystem where individuals cannot negotiate with big language service providers and are not able even to discuss the rates, as this puts them in danger of breaching Article 101 TFEU. As a result, we are always the weaker party of any contract. Our rates have plummeted in the past 15 years, and not being able to collectively negotiate fair and decent translation rates makes the situation even worse. Many translators are unable to earn their living and there is a negative impact on the quality of their work, when translation is precisely one of the pillars of the EU's diversity.
Organisation: Association of Slovenian Film and TV Translators
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: Since 2003, in Italy it is against the law to publish reference fees for interpreting and translation. Since then, fees have been going down or at best have stayed roughly the same (although 18 years have elapsed, and taxation, social security and the cost of living have been rising) because whomever enters the market feels free to offer the lowest rates (so much for professional ethics), and customers, not having a reference fee to compare with, either assume that the lowest is the norm or simply take advantage of the situation.   In the translation market, conditions are even worse. Computer assisted translation software has brought fees down, translators waive their copyright whenever they work for companies using these tools, while their work is reused forever. This has totally distorted the market.   I may add that technology utilized to put people out of work or to lower fees instead of affording them better working conditions is disgraceful, although this is a topic that falls within a broader ethical debate that is sadly lacking.   As a minimum requirement, reference fees published by reputable sector associations ought to be reinstated, so that customers can compare with them and maybe realize that quality and professionalism do not come at rates which are, at best, insulting and harmful for real professionals.   The idea behind being self-employed is that you take more risks but this is offset by higher earnings. What is happening is exactly the reverse, and, in this profession, it is paradoxically only the interpreters and translators who work for organizations and institutions who are better off.   Collective bargaining would be most welcome.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: EUROPEAN UNION: The European Commission is undertaking a very brief consultation exercise ahead of launching a new proposed measure promoting collective agreements for self-employee workers. The problem for such a proposal is that it may contravene EU competition law. To quote the impact statement " Article 101 (i) of the Treaty of the functioning of the European Union prohibits agreements between undertakings that restrict competition. According to EU case law collective bargaining between employees and employers is outside the scope of competition law"[here the reference is to "Albany" - a spurious ECJ case that does not stand up to scrutiny - especially in respect to French sectoral wage cartels]. "However, self-employed are considered "undertakings" under EU law and an agreement between them risks being in breach of Article 101 of the Treaty". To overcome this the Commission is considering a Council Regulation or Commission Communication switching the Treaty base to Article 103 (2) c - but has still not decided how broad the net for excluding competition rules should be. What it has not appreciated is that such a device alters nothing under EU competition law, as Article 101 of the Treaty may still apply. Moreover, opening up collective bargaining to the self-employed will create a huge loophole whereby all kinds of disguised anti-competitive practices between businesses can take place - via contractor intermediaries - under the new guise of "collective bargaining" - as it does now through employee-employer sectoral collective bargaining in some countries.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: I have been working as a freelance conference interpreter based in Belgium working with clients throughout the EU for 14 years and in that period the fees have not increased as much as inflation. Colleagues who have been active for several years also confirm rates have been stagnant for several decades. Significant parts of the conference interpreting market are dominated by large corporations. As a consequence, self-employed freelance interpreters are pitted against each other and the profession is slowly eroding and becoming unsustainable. Collective bargaining for the self-employed could definitely help make the profession more sustainable and attractive to young interpreters entering the profession. This is not only in the interest of interpreters but also in the interest of their clients (who pay for their services) and their customers (who listen to and rely on their services). Many young and talented interpreters leave the profession because it has become so difficult to make a career for themselves. This leads to a brain drain in the conference interpreting industry which is detrimental for the quality of conference interpreting services. Thinking alone of all the European Works Council meetings, it is clear that conference interpreters play a crucial role in EU labour relations and the social dialogue in many industries. It is quite ironic really that despite their central role in the EU social dialogue, the social dialogue in their own industry is largely non-existent.
Initiative: Collective bargaining agreements for self-employed – scope of application EU competition rules

feedback_msg_text: En España, el 14 de diciembre de 2012, el Consejo de la Comisión Nacional de la Competencia impuso a UniCo, la Unión de Correctores, una asociación profesional sin ánimo de lucro, una multa (expediente S/0352/11) por orientar a los profesionales sobre tarifas. UniCo recibe constantemente solicitudes de información sobre cuáles son unas tarifas orientativas (con las que se pueda llegar al salario mínimo interprofesional, por ejemplo) que no podemos atender por ley. La asociación tiene prohibido orientar sobre tarifas, informar a los que empiezan a trabajar en nuestro ámbito y hablar de tarifas en su lista de correo. Esto tiene como consecuencia una situación de abuso de poder de las empresas que contratan los servicios de estos profesionales autónomos, que ofrecen tarifas irrisorias con las que trabajando 8 horas no se llega ni al salario mínimo interprofesional, en un campo de trabajo ya de por sí con características de vulnerabilidad, pero que muchos correctores autónomos aceptan por desconocimiento. La manera que tiene la Comisión Nacional de la Competencia de aplicar la Ley 15/2007, de 3 de julio, de Defensa de la Competencia supone un grave perjuicio para los trabajadores autónomos de los sectores más desfavorecidos como el nuestro.

feedback_msg_text: Le travail initié par la Commission vise à construire des conventions collectives pour les travailleurs indépendants. Cet objectif recouvrira donc un champ très large, les activités indépendantes s’étant diversifiées dans de nombreux secteurs. Ce commentaire (et le document associé) est posté au titre de l'association UNION (www.union-independants.fr) qui est une plateforme revendicative à destination de tous les travailleurs indépendants n’employant aucun salarié et hors professions réglementées. UNION dont le membre fondateur est la CFDT a pour partenaire fondateur la Mutuelle Générale et Union Services, et compte parmi ses membres ou partenaires des collectifs tels que l'APSO, l'UAE, la CDF et bien d'autres.  UNION a pour vocation de parler de tous les indépendants et pas seulement ceux régis par des plateformes d'intermédiation. Face au flou juridique résultant des traités européens pouvant amener à considérer les salariés des plateformes comme des entreprises, et donc de potentiels accords collectifs comme autant d’ententes illégales, la Commission veut permettre aux travailleurs indépendants d’accéder au droit à la représentation collective. Cette consultation est donc pour UNION importante et essentielle car elle permettra de déterminer le niveau pertinent et les modalités de représentation des travailleurs indépendants. Pour UNION deux niveaux sont nécessaires (voir document joint pour plus de détails) : le secteur qui permet de tenir compte des réalités professionnelles et le niveau interprofessionnel permettant notamment la construction d'un socle commun de droits.  Autre élément important lorsqu'il s'agit de représentativité c'est celui de l'organisation de l'élection, et en premier lieu la détermination du corps électoral (quel niveau est nécessaire pour être électeur), mais également du corps des candidats (qui et comment être candidat). Pour UNION, il est nécessaire de mettre en place des élections sous sigle et non pas sur les personnes, permettant ainsi de protéger les candidats (et futurs élus). Cette question de sigle porte celle de la représentation (aujourd'hui inexistante) et donc des critères permettant aux collectifs (ou collectifs de collectifs) de présenter des candidats sous réserve de pouvoir démontrer leur appartenance à certaines valeurs sous le modèle de la loi du 20 août 2018 ( voir document joint).  Il conviendra ensuite de mettre en place une règle commune de représentativité des accords signés, UNION propose la règle des 30%, et la règle d'application, UNION préconise une application universelle (au delà des membres et à tous le secteur visé par l'accord). feedback_msg_text: As a UK/EU competition lawyer this issue has often arisen over the last 35 years of my practising in London. I remember examples of musicians setting fees through their association  i.e. hourly rates for teaching pupils and in schools  - not lawful and  a few English lawyers wanting to return to the old system of "scale fees"  (percentage of property value) for conveyancing  (which property agents seem to have managed to retain to an extent albeit not collusively) and a number of others - again never allowed.  It would be hard and unfair to distinguish between types of individuals if the law were changed unless it were done purely by only those paid under say 20 euros an hour are allowed to collude to fix their prices. On balance my view is we  (by which I mean EU27 now, excluding the UK) should leave the law as it stands and not go for any of the four options.  There are very high earning consultants in many industries from IT to film who would love to collude and fix their fees. In the UK we had extremely highly paid private practice doctors in one case wanting to fight against very low prices imposed on them by very large medical insurers with rates so low many doctors then refused to undertake work for those insured with those insurers.  I fear it may be a "can of worms" to allow any of the options and it may be safer to leave well alone and let the market decide eg those who feel their pay is too low might change to becoming employed or build up their businesses  Susan Singleton www.singlelaw.com 6 January 2021

feedback_msg_text: Green Dictionary welcomes the findings of the European Commission that a review of the IED is necessary to improve delivery and effectiveness of its goals. The current goal is to achieve a high level of environmental protection from industrial activities, with priority to pollution prevention over control. Pursuant to the EU’s Green Deal, our economy will have to undergo a major transformation to become a circular, decarbonised (by 2040) and zero pollution economy (by 2050) with a sub-goal of achieving a toxic free environment (by 2030).  The current framework should be transformed, so that it leads to the transition to a truly sustainable industrial and energy production framework at EU level. The IED is unique in its ambition of an ‘integrated approach’ meaning to address all environmental media impacts, to set the best possible standards to prevent negative impacts from a given industrial activity. It should be transformed to become the new zero-pollution industrial production regulation. We fully support the emphasis made on preventing pollution, in full integration with circular economy and decarbonization policies.  We fully support the position of the EEB that has already identified a number of bottlenecks that require a review of the IED, as indicated in the Roadmap submission, the targeted questionnaire submission and interventions made at the focus group stakeholder meetings and in its industrial point source specific submission to the Industrial Strategy discussion. Therefore, we welcome the conclusion of the European Commission that a review of the IED is necessary, and we support the preliminary list of problems identified and - to a large extent - the objectives and policy options identified.   Further, we emphasise that the Seville Process needs to be improved so that it becomes fit for the purpose of delivering a circular, decarbonised and zero pollution economy, within the pre-2040 timescale set. This requires amendments to the IED.  In our opinion, the ‘prevention first ’principle should be rigorously implemented and prioritised over end-of pipe pollution reduction. The notion of BAT should be clarified to mean technical achievable performance levels that provide the best overall environmental protection outcomes. The EU ‘safety net’ requirements – i.e. the binding minimum requirements - should be extended and revisited to prevent negative impacts from the most polluting industrial sectors (e.g. energy intensive industries and in particular coal/lignite combustion).  We believe there is a strong case for the need to change the regulatory instrument to a “Regulation”, thereby restricting the undue flexibility (ab)used by stakeholders in defining BAT and for Member States in the implementation stage. The transition from a directive to a regulation has already proven effective in various regulatory sectors.  We support the findings of the EC as stated in the Inception Impact Assessment document, but we would argue against limiting the assessment to the E-PRTR only.  We welcome the intention to improve external and internal policy coherence and provide added value and effectiveness in their implementation. Coherence should be improved so that the revised IED framework provides added value on the following aspects to be addressed under the integrated approach: Air quality, Water quality, Circular economy, Waste management, Sustainable use of resources, Chemical risks and hazards, Energy and Climate change (decarbonisation). Any legislation referred to under Article 18 should be carefully assessed and the revised IED framework adapted so as to deliver better on those objectives. Inconsistencies / incoherence with EU legislation have been identified on the following: E-PRTR, Aarhus Convention and EU ETS / Climate change agenda. Improvements should be achieved through the revision of the legal provisions (change to “Regulation”) and possible review of relevant EU legislation.
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Detailed comments are in the document attached.  Summary  Climate Action Network Europe welcomes the European Commission found the review of the IED necessary and the need to improve its implementation, delivery and effectiveness on its objectives.  In order to align with the Paris Agreement 1.5C goal, the EU economy needs to undergo a major transformation to become a circular, decarbonised (by 2040) and zero pollution economy. The Industrial Emissions Directive (IED) has a key role to play in driving this transformation, particularly for industry sectors with high emissions levels to all environmental media. Further work is needed to lead to the transition towards climate-neutral, resource efficient and non-polluting industrial and energy production in the EU. The IED provides the opportunity to implement an ‘integrated approach’ meaning to address all environmental impacts and to set the best available standards to prevent negative impacts from industrial activities. It should prevent pollution by fully integrating the circular economy and decarbonisation policies in order to put us on track towards zero-pollution industrial production.   Thus, we welcome the conclusion by the European Commission that a review of the IED is necessary, and we support the preliminary list of problems identified. feedback_msg_text: Carbon Market Watch fully supports the comprehensive feedback provided by the European Environmental Bureau to the inception impact assessment and welcomes the opportunity to give specific views on how the Industrial Emissions Directive (IED) should be revised to support industrial decarbonisation in a complementary manner to the EU Emission Trading System.    While we support the general direction of the evaluation, we would like to highlight the need to make the Industrial Emissions Directive fit for the zero-pollution and climate neutrality objectives as outlined in the Green Deal. This entails including greenhouse gas emissions within the scope of this directive by deleting art. 9(1), and amending art. 9(2).   Regulating more than 50,000 industrial activities, the IED does not address greenhouse gas pollution and climate impacts directly, which is a major shortcoming in the current legislation.  Indeed, the regulation of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions is left to the EU Emission Trading System (ETS) Directive. However, with more than 90% of industrial greenhouse gas emissions covered by free ETS emissions allowances, this Directive provides virtually no incentive to energy-intensive industries to decarbonise. This is supported by the observation that industrial (non-power sector) GHG emissions under the EU ETS have been stagnating since 2012.  Moreover, while many Best Available Techniques (BAT) Conclusions under the IED contain performance-based energy efficiency standards, the EU ETS restricts Member States (environmental permit writers) ability to set GHG emission limits or leaves it optional to set binding energy efficiency performance-based standards as a complementary measure to the market-based approach, when those installations are covered by the EU-ETS scheme. This limitation is counter-productive and incompatible to the integrated approach of the IED to prevent (all) pollution at source. Policy recommendations  If the Industrial Emissions Directive (IED) is to be made fit for the future, it will need to work hand in hand with other policy instruments and will need to reinforce the market-based approach under the EU-ETS.  Including greenhouse gas emissions within the scope of the IED does not entail duplication of regulation vis-a-vis the ETS Directive, as stated in IED recitals 9 , because both frameworks are complementary and follow different approaches, and the EU ETS has not lead to any meaningful industrial greenhouse gas reductions for almost a decade.  In addition, the EU ETS sets a price level on carbon allowances which is not based on the Best Available Technology (BAT) concept so the IED Best available techniques Reference documents (BREFs) would be reinforcing and complementary regulation, not overlapping.   Therefore, in the next revision of the Industrial Emissions Directive, we call for:   - Deletion of IED Art. 9.1 in order  to enable a combined approach of command and control (IED) as well as market-based instruments (EU ETS);  - Amend Article 9.2 of the IED to introduce minimal binding (and not optional) energy efficiency standards based on best in class solutions within a given industrial activity (e.g. electricity, heat generation, steel, cement);  - Introduction of GHG performance standards to achieve a complete coal and lignite phase-out in the European power and industrial sectors by 2030, and industrial decarbonisation in line with achieving climate neutrality by 2040;  - Introduce a Paris Agreement compliance test for new industrial investments and major refurbishments in environmental permitting. This measure would avoid a lock-in of investments into high emitting infrastructure.   Please find a more detailed explanation of our policy asks in the document attached.
