Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Industriutsläppsdirektivet (IED) och direktivets följdkrav i form av BREF-dokument med BAT-slutsatser är generellt viktigt för att höja miljöskyddet inom EU när det gäller industriutsläpp och att harmonisera dessa krav.   När det gäller medlemsländer som har kommit längre i miljöskyddsarbetet än genomsnitts-EU-landet är det dock inte säkert att IED har någon större betydelse. I de fallen innebär IED snarare än administrativ börda och särskilt i de fallen när motsvarande krav som framgår av en BAT-slutsats redan finns reglerat i ett nationellt tillståndsvillkor.   IED tar inte heller alltid hänsyn till hur avfallshanteringen är utformad. I Sverige är det vanligt med avfallsbehandlinganläggningar där flera olika behandlingsmetoder bedrivs inom samma verksamhetsområde (t ex deponering, sortering, krossning etc).   I processen med koppling till WT BREf skickades väldigt mycket data avseende utsläpp till vatten för olika behandlingsanläggningar in till JRC från olika instanser och där är risken stor att BAT-kraven gör mer skada än nytta. I fallet med WT BREF så omfattas denna av väldigt många olika behandlingstyper som ibland kan förekomma på en och samma anläggning vilket gör det svårt att skilja vattenutsläppen åt.     Kritik förtjänar att riktas mot processen med framtagande av BREF-dokument, där det blir tydligt att de stora medlemsstaterna har betydligt större möjligheter att påverka innehållet i BREF-dokumenten och BAT-slutsatser jämfört med de mindre. Transparensen när det gäller JRCs arbete med förslag till BREF-dokument är också alldeles för låg.
Organisation: Avfall Sverige / Swedish Waste Management Association
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Technology Industries of Finland’s contribution to the Inception Impact Assessment of the revision of Industrial Emissions Directive (IED)    Technology Industries of Finland thanks for of the possibility to comment Commission’s plan, revision of Industrial Emissions Directive, in its early stage as Inception Impact Assessment is.  The Inception Impact Assessment document from commission highlights that the Directive 2010/75/EU on industrial emissions (the IED) is the main EU instrument regulating pollutant emissions from industrial installations in order to achieve a high level of protection of the environment. Various primary industrial sectors are in the scope of the IED. Permits must be issued for these installations by national authorities with conditions based on the use of Best Available Techniques (BAT). An evaluation of the IED has been carried out. Among its findings were that it largely works well but there are a number of areas where improvements might be possible in its design and implementation.  IED is one main legislation to be included to Green Deal. Technology Industries of Finland sees, that it’s important that Green Deal’s political objectives are included also in IED legislation, and IED revision is done without harming these objectives. E.g. The Green Deal’s “Zero Pollution" target must be seen only as the trend-setting vision. All the requirements must be based on the financial and technological feasibility principle – there is no idea to literally target to zero emissions – the costs of lowering emission levels will eventually be strongly disproportionate compared to the benefits. This applies also to other EU’s important goals like enhancing becoming carbon neutral and circular economy. It might be unrealistic to expect that enhancing circular economy or becoming carbon neutral automatically as such improve every health or environmental aspects, so we call for reasonable flexibility to IED legislation to cover such conflict situations, at least they don’t have conflicts with each other. This will help companies in making future investments in rewarding manner.   Article 42(1) - which defines the scope for when to apply the special provisions for waste incineration and waste co-incineration - should be clarified for different players in connection with the expected revision of the IED. In its current form, the article is so ambiguous that it causes serious problems of interpretation to authorities when granting environmental permits. This problem has e.g. blocked the introduction of waste co-gasification solutions into the EU market for well over a decade already.  Co-gasification solutions could play an important role in raising the efficiency of waste incineration, enhancing circular economy and replacing fossil fuels with new cleaner fuels, thus fostering realization of the EU climate targets. We propose that the Commission uses the possibility now at hand to correct the problem and present a clear provision in line with the Non-paper “Gasification of waste, under Directive 2010/75/EU on industrial emissions (IED)”. This would support the work of the permitting officials, give legal certainty to the investors, and allow new innovations to enter the EU market  The Inception Impact Assessment document highlight the coherence of IED with the E-PRTR Regulation 166/2006. We strongly support doing this cross check. Also, it is important, that the national implementation is done with same quality standards in each country. Furthermore, it must be carefully judged, if is meaningful to amend IED legislation to cover additional industry sectors.
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: The energy sector has been subject to a drastic strengthening of environmental requirements (LCP, IED, BAT) which will lead to further significant emission reductions. It is very challenging from the technical and economical point of view and has also a significant impact on the Member States, especially on the early stage of energy transition as the Poland is. In our view, the potential the IED revision should be considered after a comprehensive assessment of implementation (as established in the evaluate first principle in the Better Regulation Guidelines) of current provisions and after expiration of the relevant derogations set in the IED.  Please find attached our detailed position, containing:  1. Consistency between IED and the Climate policy measure The energy sector is the subject of the IED and respectively the relevant Climate policy measures. Thus, the scope of legal acts should not duplicate nor overlap - the IED should not include GHG emission reductions obligations. Moreover, in sectors governed by other EU regulations there should be consistency within established directives compliance periods.  2. Reduction of unnecessary administrative burdens Unnecessary administrative burdens which are generated by differences in terminology and compliance systems that result from the IED history (recast of 8 directives). We put forward a suggestion to resign from Annex V requirements in its present form - by removing them or changing them to be consistent with BAT-AELs (e.g. averaging periods).   3. Sectors specifics should be taken into account There are serious differences in sectors covered by the IED. The MS should have a possibility to extend 4 years period for compliance with BAT under certain conditions. This will allow to more flexible approach and taking into account economic cycles.  BAT revision cycles should differ by IED sectors – in some sectors its impossible to change environmental protection techniques every 5-6 years due to huge costs.  The number of pollutants set as BATAELs should be revised. In the energy sector there is no need to limit emissions other than dust, NOx, SO2 and mercury. Other pollutants are reduced by techniques used to avoid above mentioned emissions or are side effect of best techniques applied.  4. More flexibility for Member States Current art. 15.4 allows for the competent authorities to set a derogation from BATAELs, however, with current provisions it is unclear how to apply it. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, the MS should have the possibility to set own binding rules to more precisely address the necessity to use (or not) derogations in specific cases.  5. Sevilla process improvement The work of EIPPCB should be based on verified data from European reference plants. Moreover, political influence must be reduced – it should be a technical process, based on knowledge of industrial sectors. Political discussion should be allowed in Art. 13 forum or Art. 75 Committee only.  Because of some BAT conclusions are likely to have significant economic, environmental or social impacts according to the Better Regulation Guidelines, an Impact Assessment should be required before the final Committee meeting. Feedback from: Polish Power Plants Association (TGPE) (283.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Re: Potential inclusion of additional sectors Stockholm, 21 April 2020 Svemin is the national industry association for mines and for mineral and metal producers in Sweden, representing around 40 companies which employ 13,000 people in production, exploration and technology. Our member companies are active throughout the country, with the mines being mainly located in northern Sweden and Bergslagen.  The Commission is suggesting that, as part of the planned revision of the IED, it might be advantageous to include additional sectors in the IED. One of the sectors mentioned for potential inclusion is extractive industries. SveMin’s position is that IED is not an appropriate policy or regulatory instrument for mining and quarrying. The reasons are explained below. To successfully ensure a high level of environmental protection across Europe, the IED, based on the development of BAT reference documents, is an effective tool for sectors in which a large enough number of similar installations operate across the European Union, such that common environmental requirements can be applied to improve environmental quality overall. This also means that IED and BREF-notes is not well suited to regulate environmental protection in sectors with a limited number of installations across Europe and with technological solutions that are adapted to local conditions, such as metal mining. Metal mining is only taking place in a limited number of member states. Mining methods and treatment of ores have to be adapted to local conditions such as the geometry of ore bodies and the mineralogy of the ore. Potential environmental impacts and possible ways to minimize those impacts will also depend on the geometry and mineralogy of the ore, but also to other local factors such as climate and local surroundings. It is our understanding that this was in fact one of the main reasons why the predecessor to the IED (the IPPC Directive) was not seen as an appropriate policy instrument for mining and quarrying originally. The same reasons are as valid today as they were then.  Further, there is no regulatory gap to be filled. Mining and quarrying are fully regulated by other EU and national legislation. Environmental performance of mining and quarrying in the EU is assured by application of other EU Directives (e.g. the Water framework directive and daughter directives, the EIA directive and the Natura2000 regulations) and national mining legislation, supported by international management standards and best practice guidelines. As a more tailored alternative to the IED, the Commission developed the Extractive Waste Directive (2006/21/EC) that requires application of site-specific BAT to the management of extractive waste, and under that legislation the resulting BREF (2nd edition, 2018) is based on site specific risk. Together, these regulations require that all mining and quarrying operations achieve the highest possible level of protection of the environment with solutions adapted to their unique site-specific contexts. The inclusion of extractive industries in the IED will not bring additional protection of human health and the environment. The European mining sector, in cooperation with European technology suppliers, is world leading when it comes to the development of mining and processing technology and equipment. Looking forward, the next generation of European mines will very likely use new techniques that does not exist today. The energy transition and related technology development also give reason to believe that Europe will start to mine commodities, such as some critical raw materials, that are not mined today. This will lead to the application of technologies that are not seen in Europe today. It must remain possible to assess all proposed mining and quarrying techniques, currently existing or new, for suitability in the specific circumstances at hand.  On behalf of SveMin,   Lars-Åke Lindahl Director Environment and Coordinator EU Affairs
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: We agree that the Directive has significant EU added value and the Seville process is an important tool and should continue. For IED to interact with decarbonization and contribute to circular economy a review of the Seville process could be sufficient.    Many BREFs are neither reviewed nor implemented yet, so we don’t know the Directives full performance. Therefore, changes in IED might not be necessary at this point.   To publish the inception impact assessment before final version of Ricardo study or SWD, the EC is contradicting its own 'evaluate first' principle set out in its Better Regulation Guidelines.   It is important that the Commission addresses crisis-related matters for industry concerned and increase the timelines for replying.   Legal certainty should be ensured throughout the revision process and no new BREF review cycles should be initiated until a revised IED enters into force.   Sectoral issues   To successfully ensure a high level of environmental protection, the IED, should cover sectors with a large environmental impact and enough number of similar installations that operate across the European Union. It should be carefully assessed, balancing the environmental benefits with increased workload in Seville, the increased administrative burden for installations and the risk of delaying other BREFs.    Implementation issues   This is a key issue since we want to achieve a level playing field within Europe. In regards of the specific aspects that are to be addressed we especially support Comparability of Member States’ implementation of EU requirements, including BAT conclusions, into permits and verification and elaboration of BAT conclusions.    BREF process   We support an overview to improve the BREF process. The process should include a methodology for deriving BAT-AELs and Key Environmental Issues. We believe it is of great importance that BREFs are kept sector specific. A more systematic consideration of cross-media effects on emissions and resource use and the need for a transparent derivation methodology for the setting of BAT-AE(P)Ls should be considered.    Access to information   When improving access to information, participation in decision-making and access to justice, it is important that it complies with CBI and competition rules.   Contribution to the CE   Via the BREFs, the IED contributes to an enhanced CE via a continued relative decoupling for the use of resources (e.g. water consumption, energy efficiency). The contribution to CE in the Seville process, could be clarified in the guidance for the BREF making process. However, IED is not the main tool to use to increase resource efficiency, bearing in mind BREFs are sector specific and it is important not to create obstacles for the circular markets.   Interaction with decarbonization of industry   With regards to decarbonization efforts, IED Article 9.1 has ensured – and should continue to ensure – a pivotal role to retain the coherence of IED with ETS legislation. Decarbonization could mean an increase in electricity and we do not yet know how other emissions will be affected of this transformation. So, to assume that it is possible to achieve improvement in all other environmental aspects is unrealistic. In order to support the deployment of novel techniques IED Article 15(5) could be used more frequently and for longer periods.   Coherence with other legislation   The IED has a strong coherence with other environmental policy areas. The overall objective of IED is to address emissions to air, water and land and to prevent the generation of waste, in order to achieve a high level of protection of the environment taken as a whole. Water emissions are to a large extent regulated by other directives such as the Water framework directive and it is important to avoid overlaps.
Organisation: IKEM – Innovation and Chemical Industries in Sweden
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Danish Aquaculture strongly recommends that the revised Industrial Emissions Directive (IED) does not include aquaculture.  The Organization Danish Aquaculture fully supports the objectives and means of the European Green Deal. Specifically, the new growth strategies built in both the Farm to Fork Strategy and the Circular Economy Action Plan that aim to transform the EU into a fair and prosperous society, with a modern, resource-efficient and competitive economy.   IED is based on several pillars, in particular on an integrated approach, the use of best available techniques (BAT), flexibility, inspections and public participation (https://ec.europa.eu/environment/industry/stationary/ied/legislation.htm). Danish Aquaculture wishes to highlight that aquaculture is currently exhaustively regulated and monitored by EU, national and regional regulations, amongst others from an environmental perspective already covering the great majority of the aspects of the IED.   Aquaculture is not an industrial activity causing significant pollution, and the monitoring and control of effluents and impact from aquaculture on the environment are already taken care of by the existing regulations and directives within the scope of the Water Framework Directive (2000/60/EC), the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (2008/56/EC), the Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC), the Birds Directive (2009/147/EC) and the Environmental Impact Assessment Directive (85/337/EEC), followed by supplementary national and regional rules.   The development of additional BAT for aquaculture at EU-level is strongly advised against due to the great diversity of aquaculture (different species, different water use, different techniques, etc.) and completely different potential environment footprint impacts in the different water bodies. Furthermore, BAT and Codes of conduct are already part of aquaculture regulations in most countries.  Being the aim of the European Green Deal to achieve its objectives in the most effective and least burdensome way, Danish Aquaculture thinks that it is not appropriate to include aquaculture into the scope of the Industrial emissions Directive. If aquaculture is included in the revised IED scope its governance will become more complicated with additional unnecessary burdens which is a contradiction to the EU current strategy.   Regardless of the adoption by the European Commission of successive Strategies for the Sustainable Development of European aquaculture, reality is that aquaculture in the European Union continues to be in stagnation since the turn of the century, in strong contrast with sustained growth of aquaculture production at global level (FAO State of World Fisheries and Aquaculture http://www.fao.org/fishery/sofia/en). The main reason for this is the extremely complicated legal framework in which it must develop. The European Commission has recommended to “reduce the administrative burden on aquaculture”, and “to simplify administrative procedures and reduce licensing time for aquaculture farms” (https://www.europarl.europa.eu/factsheets/en/sheet/120/european-aquaculture).
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: The European Green Deal requires the Commission to review measures at the EU's disposal to reduce and control pollution generated by large industrial installations. One such tool is the Directive of the European Parliament and Council 2010/75/EU of 24 November 2010 (IED), which regulates the basic sectors of industry in terms of emissions from industrial installations. Permits for these installations are issued by national authorities under conditions based on the use of best available techniques (BAT). The revision of the IED directive aims to find alternative solutions that will reduce the production of pollutants to an even greater extent than before. One idea is to oblige economic sectors, not covered by the IED, to implement and apply BAT conclusions. At this point, mentioned is among others mining industry. According to Polska Grupa Górnicza S.A. the mining sector is already regulated by a sufficient number of other directives. In addition, it should be taken into account that the global crisis caused by COVID-19 pandemic and the introduction of additional restrictions in the form of changes in industrial emissions, can contribute to a sharp deterioration in the situation of energy security, which cannot be guaranteed without the participation of fossil fuels underlying the energy mix in many countries. The transition of the European economy aimed at achieving climate neutrality in 2050 will require investment costs that will be part of a sustainable development path for enterprises. Polska Grupa Górnicza S.A. aware of the costly challenges of the energy transition that is underway in the EU countries and in Poland, takes steps to ensure further development and stable operation of the company. Nevertheless, if there are restrictions on the mining industry in the proposal to update the regulations on industrial emissions related to additional costs of adjusting the mines to the new BAT guidelines, in the opinion of Polska Grupa Górnicza S.A. these initiatives should be discussed when the full picture of the likely impact of the COVID-19 crisis appears. Each subsequent proposed amendment, e.g. Directive 2010/75/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 24, 2010 (IED), taking into account its new aspects, will contribute to a too rapid transition that will deprive people of jobs, and thus, it will lead to negative social phenomena and impoverishment of mining regions. Before introducing any changes regarding industrial emissions, it is important to carry out the necessary research and studies determining the impact of regulations not only on achieving the goal of climate neutrality, but primarily on the impact on the functioning of enterprises, maintaining jobs and depletion of regions, in this case mining. In addition, EU assumptions and the IED show that Member States should be given flexibility in achieving their pollution control objectives. We cannot agree that updating the regulations on industrial emissions, which also have an impact on the circular economy, will not have major economic effects. It is necessary to thoroughly analyze the costs incurred by enterprises in order to achieve current compliance with the IED Directive, as it is very likely that in the current economic situation, the industry will not only have to make significant investments to implement or improve the functioning of BAT, but also to recover from the deep economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Organisation: Polska Grupa Górnicza S.A. (Polish Mining Group)
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Friends of the Earth Finland welcomes the findings of the European Commission that a review of the IED is necessary to improve delivery and effectiveness of its goals. The current goal is to achieve a high level of environmental protection from industrial activities, with priority to pollution prevention over control. Pursuant to the EU’s Green Deal, our economy will have to undergo a major transformation to become a circular, decarbonised (by 2040) and zero pollution economy (by 2050) with a sub-goal of achieving a toxic free environment (by 2030).   The current framework should be transformed, so that it leads to the transition to a truly sustainable industrial and energy production framework at EU level. The IED is unique in its ambition of an ‘integrated approach’ meaning to address all environmental media impacts, to set the best possible standards to prevent negative impacts from a given industrial activity. It should be transformed to become the new zero-pollution industrial production regulation. We fully support the emphasis made on preventing pollution, in full integration with circular economy and decarbonization policies.   We fully support the position of the EEB that has already identified a number of bottlenecks that require a review of the IED, as indicated in the Roadmap submission , the targeted questionnaire submission and interventions made at the focus group stakeholder meetings  and in its industrial point source specific submission to the Industrial Strategy discussion .  Therefore, we welcome the conclusion of the European Commission that a review of the IED is necessary, and we support the preliminary list of problems identified and - to a large extent - the objectives and policy options identified. feedback_msg_text: The Hungarian Aquaculture and Fisheries Inter-branch Organization welcomes the European Green Deal and fully supports its goals. However the organization would like to draw the attention several facts regarding the revision of the Industrial Emissions Directive.  The Hungarian aquaculture production based on pond farming; it covers a decisive part (81%) of the total production. The rest part of the production refers the different ways of intensive freshwater aquaculture systems, like flow-through and recirculation aquaculture systems. Here should be highlighted that pond aquaculture is based on natural processes of wetland habitats from ecological point of view. The technology aims only to fortify these natural processes. It means that the natural and artificial processes cannot be separated in the created fish pond ecosystem on the one hand and it gives a good example of circular economy renewing the natural resources on the other hand. Besides the primary products, the pond aquaculture sustains even higher natural values. Fish ponds contribute to the existence of large wetland habitats in drying regions. Fish ponds also maintain wildlife with European importance. Beside maintenance of natural values, pond aquaculture has important role in water management. The pond production is well adapted to the natural seasonal fluctuation of surface water resources. Fish ponds can retain substantial amount of water, also with the soluble nutrients and inorganic floating compartments. Although climate change results in decreasing amounts of renewable water sources and the occurrence of extreme water levels is increasing, pond aquaculture technology can buffers its effect in a certain level.  Based on the complexity of environmental and water management aspects of pond aquaculture, it cannot be compared to the industrial activity. It also means that aquaculture is not appropriate to be included into the scope of the Industrial Emissions Directive. The Hungarian aquaculture sector is regulated by the EU directives – Water Framework Directive (2000/60/EC), Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC), Birds Directive (2009/147/EC), Environmental Impact Assessment Directive (85/337/EEC) – also national environmental, water management and nature conservational regulations fitted to the EU directives. Finally should be articulated that no reason to involve the aquaculture into the Industrial Emissions Directive, because it - beside the above mentioned - will cause a parallel regulation with the existing directives.
Organisation: Hungarian Aquaculture and Fisheries Inter-branch Organization

feedback_msg_text: The Spanish Association of Fish Farmers (APROMAR) fully supports the objectives and means of the European Green Deal. Specifically by taking on and fostering the new growth strategies built in both the Farm to Fork Strategy and the Circular Economy Action Plan that aim to transform the EU into a fair and prosperous society, with a modern, resource-efficient and competitive economy where there are no net emissions of greenhouse gases in 2050 and where economic growth is decoupled from resource use.   As the united voice of the Spanish fish farming industry, APROMAR wishes to highlight that aquaculture is currently exhaustively regulated and monitored by European Union, national and regional regulations, amongst others from an environmental perspective already covering the great majority of the aspects of the Industrial emissions directive (IED).   Being the aim of the European Green Deal to achieve its objectives in the most effective and least burdensome way, APROMAR thinks that it is not appropriate to include aquaculture into the scope of the Industrial emissions Directive. Aquaculture is not an industrial activity causing significant pollution, and the monitoring and control of effluents and impact from aquaculture on the environment are already taken care of by the existing regulations and directives. The current aquaculture legal framework takes already care of these issues through obligations within the scope of the Water Framework Directive (2000/60/EC), the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (2008/56/EC), the Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC), the Birds Directive (2009/147/EC) and the Environmental Impact Assessment Directive (85/337/EEC), followed by supplementary national and regional rules.   The IED is based on several pillars, in particular on an integrated approach, the use of best available techniques (BAT), flexibility, inspections and public participation (https://ec.europa.eu/environment/industry/stationary/ied/legislation.htm).  The development of additional BAT for aquaculture at EU-level is strongly advised against due to the great diversity of aquaculture (different species, different water use, different techniques, etc.) and completely different potential environment footprint impacts in the different water bodies. Furthermore, BAT and Codes of conduct are already part of aquaculture regulations in most countries.  If aquaculture is included in the revised IED scope its governance will become more complicated with additional unnecessary burdens which is in itself a contradiction to the EU current strategy.   Regardless of the adoption by the European Commission of successive Strategies for the Sustainable Development of European aquaculture, reality is that aquaculture in the European Union continues to be in stagnation since the turn of the century, in strong contrast with sustained growth of aquaculture production at global level (FAO State of World Fisheries and Aquaculture http://www.fao.org/fishery/sofia/en). The main reason for this is the extremely complicated legal framework in which it must develop. The European Commission has recommended to “reduce the administrative burden on aquaculture”, and “to simplify administrative procedures and reduce licensing time for aquaculture farms” (https://www.europarl.europa.eu/factsheets/en/sheet/120/european-aquaculture). APROMAR strongly recommends that the revised Industrial emissions Directive does not play against this objective.
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Glass Alliance Europe (GAE) welcomes this opportunity to comment the inception impact assessment on the Industrial Emission Directive (IED) review and would like to highlight two elements that should be taken into account at the time of the impact assessment.  Firstly, while the European glass sector wants to contribute to the decarbonisation of the economy, notably by implementing GHG abatement measures on manufacturing sites, these actions and moreover their results in term of CO2 emissions are already covered by the Directive 2003/87/EC (also called EU ETS Directive). Hence, GAE, as well as many Energy Intensive Industries, rejects the option to regulate GHG emissions under an IED permitting regime, without prejudice to the article 9.1 of the IED (see enclosed EIIs Joint contribution). Secondly, the Green Deal zero pollution ambition needs a cautious implementation into the IED. Indeed, this ambition needs to be translated in a coherent way by taking into account the technologies currently available on the market, i.e. the Best Available Technics (BAT), which are at the source of the IED permitting in Europe. feedback_msg_text: We agree to the conclusion that the Directive has significant EU added value and the Seville process is an important tool and should continue. For IED to interact with decarbonization and contribute to circular economy a review of the Seville process could be sufficient.    Many BREFs are neither reviewed nor implemented yet, so we don’t know the Directives full performance. Therefore, changes in IED might not be necessary at this point.   To publish the inception impact assessment before final version of Ricardo study or SWD, the EC is contradicting its own 'evaluate first' principle set out in its Better Regulation Guidelines.   It is important that the Commission addresses crisis-related matters for industry concerned and increase the timelines for replying.   Legal certainty should be ensured throughout the revision process and no new BREF review cycles should be initiated until a revised IED enters into force.      Sectoral issues   To successfully ensure a high level of environmental protection, the IED, should cover sectors with a large environmental impact and enough number of similar installations that operate across the European Union. It should be carefully assessed, balancing the environmental benefits with increased workload in Seville, the increased administrative burden for installations and the risk of delaying other BREFs.      Implementation issues   This is a key issue since we want to achieve a level playing field within Europe. In regards of the specific aspects that are to be addressed we especially support Comparability of Member States’ implementation of EU requirements, including BAT conclusions, into permits and verification and elaboration of BAT conclusions. Industry are ready to support this e.g. by taking part of the IEEG.      BREF process   We support an overview to improve the BREF process. The process should include a methodology for deriving BAT-AELs and Key Environmental Issues. We believe it is of great importance that BREFs are kept sector specific. A more systematic consideration of cross-media effects on emissions and resource use and the need for a transparent derivation methodology for the setting of BAT-AE(P)Ls should be considered.       Access to information   We support work to improve access to information, participation in decision-making and access to justice, provided that the information in question complies with CBI and competition rules.      Contribution to the CE   Via the BREFs, the IED contributes to an enhanced CE via a continued relative decoupling for the use of resources (e.g. water consumption, energy efficiency). The contribution to CE in the Seville process, could be clarified in the guidance for the BREF making process. However, IED is not the main tool to use to increase resource efficiency, bearing in mind BREFs are sector specific and it is important not to create obstacles for the circular markets.      Interaction with decarbonization of industry   With regards to decarbonization efforts, IED Article 9.1 has ensured – and should continue to ensure – a pivotal role to retain the coherence of IED with ETS legislation. Decarbonization could mean an increase in electricity and we do not yet know how other emissions will be affected of this transformation. So, to assume that it is possible to achieve improvement in all other environmental aspects is unrealistic. In order to support the deployment of novel techniques IED Article 15(5) could be used more frequently and for longer periods.      Coherence with other legislation   The IED has a strong coherence with other environmental policy areas. The overall objective of IED is to address emissions to air, water and land and to prevent the generation of waste, in order to achieve a high level of protection of the environment taken as a whole. Water emissions are to a large extent regulated by other directives such as the Water framework directive and it is important to avoid overlaps.
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: The Federal Association of the German Glass Industry (Bundesverband Glasindustrie, BV Glas) welcomes this opportunity to comment the inception impact assessment on the Industrial Emission Directive (IED) review. In our view, the consultation comes at an inappropriate time: Firstly, the COVID-19-pandemic is currently the dominant topic and consultations should therefore be postponed. Secondly, the IED review process is not yet complete.   In the opinion of BV Glas, there is currently no need to change the IED. The objectives of this directive - to improve the quality of the environment and create a level playing field - are achieved. Furthermore, the Sevilla-process laid down in the directive even ensures that the best available techniques for industrial installations are continuously reviewed and developed. Improving the Sevilla-process makes sense, however.   If, however, the IED is revised, it should be noted that the Green Deal zero pollution ambition needs a cautious implementation into the IED. Indeed, this ambition needs to be translated in a coherent way by taking into account the technologies currently available on the market, i.e. the Best Available Technics (BAT), which are at the source of the IED permitting in Europe. Furthermore, we reject the option to regulate GHG emissions under an IED permitting regime.
Initiative: Industrial emissions – EU rules updated

feedback_msg_text: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,  um dem Klimawandel und seinen Folgen zu begegnen, kann das Management von Verpackungen eine wichtige Rolle spielen. Die Nutzung von nachwachsenden Rohstoffen ist zu bevorzugen. Holz als nachwachsender und im Zuge der Kaskadennutzung sehr langfristiger CO2-Speicher bietet hierzu ideale Voraussetzungen. Paletten aus Holz beispielsweise haben hier einen klaren Vorteil gegenüber Kunststoffpaletten. Weiterhin erzeugt der Abrieb von Holzpaletten nur Holz, der Abrieb von Kunststoffpaletten dürfte wohl als Mikroplastik in die Umwelt gelangen. Daher ist die in der Konsultation aufgeworfene Fragestellung nach der Prüfung der Notwendigkeit, Sinnhaftigkeit und sinnvoller Ersatzprodukte mehr als berechtigt. Zudem benötigt die Herstellung von Verpackungen aus Holz im Vergleich zu solchen aus anderen Materialien sehr wenig Energie. Gleichwohl ist Holz auch ein wichtiger Energielieferant, sowohl am Ende der Nutzungskakade(n) als auch als Ersatz für fossile Energieträger. Darauf sollte ein wichtiges Augenmerk gelegt werden, denn gerade für KMU in der Holzindustrie wäre es absurd den vorhandenen Brennstoff durch ausschließlich auf das Recycling ausgelegte Regulierungen zu verbieten und durch fossile Energieträger oder Gas zu ersetzen. Das Gebot der Verhältnismäßigkeit sollte eine wesentliche Rolle spielen, insbesondere wenn quasi kein Transportweg vorliegt. Weiterhin muss es möglich bleiben gebrauchte Verpackungen, die noch nicht die Abfalleigenschaft erlangt haben, einer Vorbereitung zur Wiederverwendung  durch Prüfen, Reinigen, Reparieren zu unterziehen, da die Erzeugnisse als gebrauchte ge- und behandelt bzw. bei der Wiederverwendung im allgemeinen Sprachgebrauch als aufbereitet, refurbished, recycled o. ä. bezeichnet werden. Das Recycling sollte als jedes Verwertungsverfahren, durch das Verpackungsabfälle zu Erzeugnissen, Materialien oder Stoffen entweder für den ursprünglichen Zweck oder für andere Zwecke aufbereitet werden folglich weiter möglich sein.  Der beschriebene Ansatz, den Trend zur Leichtgewichtung von Verpackungen zu verstärken ist im Bereich der Holzverpackungen (Kisten und Paletten) ebenso wenig pauschal praktikabel wie der Ansatz, das Design auf eine leichte Demontierbarkeit auszulegen. Das Primat der Sicherheit von Mensch und Umwelt im Umgang mit verpackten Waren auf Paletten oder in Kisten und Exportverpackungen, von Schrauben über Maschinen, Elektronik, chemischen Erzeugnissen, etc. darf nicht aufgegeben werden. Gerade durch die vielfältigen Transportmittel und den oft rauhen Umgang unterliegen diese Verpackungen extremen Belastungen. Dazu zählt auch das Durchqueren unterschiedlicher klimatische Bedingungen, wofür spezielle (Verbund)Folien mit sehr geringer Dampfdurchlässigkeit das die negativen Einflüsse von Salz, Wasser, Kälte und Hitze reduzieren sollen. Daher ist der beschriebene Ansatz, Ausnahmen zuzulassen statt zu pauschalieren, der einzig richtige.  Mit freundlichen Grüßen
Organisation: HPE - Bundesverband Holzpackmittel, Paletten, Exportverpackung e.V.
Initiative: Reducing packaging waste – review of rules

feedback_msg_text: Lets Do It Foundation, as the initiator of World Cleanup Day, a movement mobilizing millions of people to tackle the waste problem in their communities, welcomes this initiative and fully supports the aim that all packaging in EU should be recyclable or reusable.  Our main suggestions to this review: 1. support deposit-return schemes (DRS) to scale up reuse. In Estonia it has proven itself well in the beverage sector, but could be implemented also in other packages, such as cups, food containers etc. 2. set packaging waste reduction targets based on number of single use units and kg of packaging per person per year 3. use and stregthen the eco-modulation of EPR to favour the packages with better reusability and longer recyclability, also favour labelling to guide consumers to choose these packages 4. ensure that there is not tolerance to hazardous substances in packaging, also regards to recycled content and compostable packaging  We would also like to stress that connection between food safety, food loss, hygine and single use plastic packaging need to be critically observed. There are plenty of examples and evidence (eg Unwrapped report: https://zerowasteeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Unwrapped_How-throwaway-plastic-is-failing-to-solve-Europes-food-waste-problem_and-what-we-need-to-do-instead_FoEE-ZWE-April-2018_final.pd) that reusable systems can be safe for human health and that single use packaging does not necessarily prevent food waste.

feedback_msg_text: NRK Verpakkingen, the Dutch trade association for plastic packaging manufacturing and trade, appreciates the opportunity to give input for the public consultation “Reducing packaging waste – review of rules”.  Our main messages: 1. Sustainability is at the heart of packaging: new policies should always consider this.  2. Improve sustainability by dealing with the whole chain;  no focus on packaging only. 3. Sustainability is the goal; circular economy is (no more than) a means to achieve this. 4. Sustainability and food safety are helped by allowing for the best solution for any given challenge, rather than to ban certain materials in the first place. 5. Specific barriers where a circular use of materials is concerned: virgin vs. recyclate, quality of recyclate, substances of concern and imports, requirements hindering closed loop schemes, and the use of recyclate undermining packaging functionality. feedback_msg_text: Introduction Stiftung Initiative Mehrweg (SIM) is a German civil law  foundation which was established in 1996. It is SIMs objective to sustainably support the conservation of natural resources, to protect the environment and to promote the use of reusable systems in all economic sectors. The Executive Board of SIM is composed of mainly CEO´s and other Senior managers being active in the reuse industry. The Board of Trustees is composed of Senior managers being active in public and private institutions within the area of Re-use.  SIM welcomes the Commission’s initiative to review the requirements on packaging and packaging waste and its public consultation in that respect. SIM would like to share its feedback through this document.   SIM’s feedback:  The use of Reusable Packaging Containers (RPCs) constitutes one of the best ways to prevent (and therefore reduce) over-packaging and packaging waste in the food supply chain in the EU. (Re)use of RPCs furthermore offers a considerable potential for resource and climate protection. SIM therefore believes that RPCs should be promoted as the preferred packaging method in the fresh food supply chain.   1. Reduce packaging and food waste Fruits, vegetables and other food products can be (and are) transported and displayed in stores in the same RPCs as the RPCs in which these food products are transported, therefore without the (need for) use of additional layers of packaging. Pursuant to a study of the Fraunhofer Institute named “Determination of spoilage levels of fresh fruit and vegetables according to the type of packaging”, it was established that from the producer to the outlet, around 4% of all disposable (transport) packaging was damaged. For RPCs, the figure was just 0.1%. When extrapolated to the German market situation at the time of the study, around 36,000 tons of fruit and vegetables, with a market value of approximately €68 million, would be damaged when disposable (transport) packaging would be used for the transport of fruits and vegetables in Germany. When RPCs are used exclusively, the estimated wastage is 1,100 tons, with a market value of around €2 million .  Each RPC can furthermore be reused for years before being scrapped for recycling (reuse for the production of new RPC’s or other products).   RPC’s therefore constitute the preferred packaging method in the food supply chain to reduce packaging waste and food waste. .   2. Tax The production and use of reusable packaging such as RPCs should be rewarded through adequate financial and tax benefits and through the implementation of tax harmonization measures ensuring a swift and free movement of reusable packaging and packaged goods throughout the European Union (minimizing the administrative burden being applied to reuse and contributing to the simplification of the regulatory environment being applicable to reuse systems).   3. Emissions  A study of the Fraunhofer Institute named “Carbon Footprint of Packaging Systems for Fruit and Vegetable Transports in Europe“ clearly shows that the (re)use of RPCs results in 60% lower greenhouse gas emissions to provide the same transport performance compared to single use boxes.  SIM therefore believes that RPCs should be promoted as the preferred packaging method in the supply chain to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.   4. Introduce reuse quota/make reuse mandatory Setting legally binding targets or making reuse mandatory for transport packaging in the food supply chain will generate commitment and momentum in the packaging sector and will reduce packaging waste, food waste and greenhouse emissions.    Conclusion: Increasing the (re)use of RPC’s will reduce packaging waste, food waste and greenhouse emissions. SIM believes that further reuse of RPCs will contribute to the realization of the Green Deal in the food and other supply chains.   http://stiftung-mehrweg.de/carbonfootprint.php http://stiftung-mehrweg.de/savefoodstudie.php Feedback from: Stiftung Initiative Mehrweg (404.3 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Reducing packaging waste – review of rules

feedback_msg_text: Re: Inception Impact Assessment: Review of the requirements for packaging and other measures to prevent packaging waste (Inception Impact Assessment)    Background Areco: Asociación de Operadores Logísticos de Elementos Reutilizables Ecosostenibles (“ARECO” – Association of Logistics Operators for Eco-sustainable Reusable Items) is a Spanish industry association representing and promoting the usage of reusable packaging containers (“RPCs”) for (the transport and display of) foodstuffs in the fresh supply chain.  By means of this position paper, ARECO wishes to provide its feedback to the public consultation on the Inception Impact Assessment.   Reuse of RPCs instead of one-way packaging to prevent packaging waste ARECO supports the European Commission’s initiative to review the requirements for packaging and other measures to prevent packaging waste (the “Initiative”). Packaging waste can be prevented by increasing reuse. The use of RPCs in the food supply chain by definition leads to (a) the prevention of packaging waste and (b) a reduction of negative impacts on the environment.  Re a. Prevention of packaging waste   RPCs can be used for years in the food supply chain. Each rotation is composed of the following steps:  (i) filling the RPC with foodstuff;  (ii) transporting the RPC filled with the foodstuff to the shop/outlet where the foodstuff is sold to the consumers; (iii) picking up of the empty RPC by the owner of the RPCs;  (iv) cleaning the RPC in preparation of reuse by the next user.        RPCs are at the end of their lifetime scrapped for recycling, therefore without any packaging waste resulting therefrom: The granulate resulting from the scrapped RPCs is reused for the production of new RPCs or for the production of other durable products. The (re)use of RPCs therefore clearly prevents the generation of packaging waste.     Re b. Reduction of negative impacts on the environment Pursuant to a comparative study of the different options for distribution of fruit and vegetables in Spain by means of Life Cycle Assessment (LCA), executed by the UNESCO Chair in Life Cycle and Climate Change (ESCI-UPF) , the use of RPC’s generates less environmental impact than disposable boxes in the distribution of fruit and vegetables in Spain. This environmental advantage is reconfirmed in 2018 pursuant to the study “Carbon Footprint of Packaging Systems for Fruit and Vegetable Transports in Europe, executed by the Fraunhofer Institute of Stuttgart (Germany) . This Fraunhofer Study provides that the reuse of RPCs results in 60% lower greenhouse emissions to provide the same transport performance compared to single use boxes.   Measures to prevent packaging waste and to ensure a smooth free movement of reusable packaging (RPCs)  ARECO is of the opinion that (i) the packaging legislation needs to be amended in such a way that reuse of packaging (RPCs) within (and across the Members States of) the European Union is increased and that (ii) European and national (packaging) legislation should allow for an uninterrupted and free movement of reusable packaging (RPCs).     ARECO welcomes and supports the objectives referred to in the Initiative by the implementation of “(1) clearer, more enforceable EU level requirements on packaging, which are (2) revised to drive design for reuse and recyclability of packaging and prevent the continued growth in the generation of packaging waste” :    ARECO believes that this can be achieved by means of implementing the following measures:   A. Making reuse of packaging mandatory in the food supply chain, especially in the area of transport packaging (RPCs); B. Introducing minimum mandatory targets (reuse quota) for RPCs being used in the food supply chain; C. Developing a harmonized standard for packaging Life Cycle Analysis, thereby taking into account the waste pyramid;   D. Implementing tax harmonization measures (and minimizing administrative burdens) for reusable packaging systems, including RPCs, e Feedback from: ARECO (558.3 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: European Paper Packaging Alliance Response to the Inception Impact Assessment for the  Review of the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive    The European Paper Packaging Alliance (EPPA) is a not-for-profit food and foodservice packaging association.  EPPA’s priority is to provide efficient environmental, low carbon and health-safe products to the European population, with improved recycling solutions.   EPPA supports the efficient use of resources in all its forms and recognizes the major role that packaging, as an essential infrastructure, can play in that common objective.    The Alliance believes it is important that the review of the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive delivers in three areas:  1. The critical role of packaging’s functionality, including maintaining product safety and hygiene, reducing food waste and loss, enabling transportation and supporting consumer accessibility to food.  • EPPA believes it is fundamental that policy options must not place product safety and hygiene at risk, and that the European Food Safety Authority and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control should be consulted as part of the policy process.   2. Maintain the policy and operational integrity of the Internal Market in line with Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  • EPPA therefore welcomes the Commission’s recognition that harmonization of the rules on packaging can support sustainability.  The Alliance trusts that the PPWD review will address existing barriers (including infrastructure): “The amendment to Directive 94/62/EC on Packaging and Packaging Waste is based on Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). It is necessary to strive for full harmonization of rules on packaging across the internal market to preserve its integrity and allow for a smooth free movement of packaging and packaged goods. Uncoordinated national measures to address sustainability aspects of packaging result in obstacles to the free movement of goods and hinder the development of markets for secondary raw materials.”  3. There should be policy coherence and consistency.  • EPPA believes it is critical that policies should not conflict and that impact assessments should be holistic and evidence-driven, ensuring wider objectives are incorporated.  For example, ensuring that policies support innovation and the objectives of a Green Recovery and a net-zero-carbon economy are not jeopardized.  Objectives and policy options  EPPA notes that the real issue in relation to packaging ‘waste’ is too narrow a focus of what ‘waste’ is, which the Alliance considers is contrary to its understanding of circularity: “In a circular economy, the value of products and materials is maintained for as long as possible. Waste and resource use are minimized, and when a product reaches the end of its life, it is used again to create further value. This can bring major economic benefits, contributing to innovation, growth and job creation.”   In our view, it is fundamental that the Waste Hierarchy is correctly applied so that the use of materials is optimized, and true ‘waste’ is identified and can be reduced.  The Alliance therefore believes article 4 of the Waste Framework Directive must be fully and rigorously applied in the impact assessment and in any strategy aiming to reduce packaging waste.  Within this, both “underpackaging” and “overpackaging” needs to be clearly defined.    Again, policy options should not deliver outcomes which may be contrary to the Green Recovery and a net-zero economy.  This includes overly prescriptive requirements for packaging design, which harm innovation and therefore investment in Europe.  Impact assessment  In addition to the areas identified in the inception document, EPPA would request that the following areas are considered:    Likely economic impacts • The financial impact on industry should be included in the assessment, with sufficient consideration gi Feedback from: European Paper Packaging Alliance (218.7 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: ACE Iberia supports an ambitious implementation of the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive, as well as the new Circular Economy Action Plan. This is a unique opportunity to scale up the contributions of materials towards a circular economy and climate neutrality by incentivising the efficient use of low carbon and circular packaging.   With regard to the specific objectives of the revision of the PPWD,  • ACE strongly supports the objective of the free movement of packaging and packaged goods across EU Member States. It is an aspect that needs to preserved and guaranteed across EU.  • ACE believes that mandatory provisions on recycled content should only be considered for products or materials whose secondary markets need to be incentivized. Furthermore,  it should only apply to those markets where the use of recycled materials has proven technical and environmental benefits, and are safe for consumers in food contact materials. Paper-based packaging is recycled at a very high rate and the paper recycling value chain is a well-functioning one that does not require incentives for the uptake of recycled materials. Such mandatory requirements applied to well-functioning markets would likely be counter- productive as they would disturb the existing paper recycling value chain without bringing additional environmental benefits.  • ACE believes that the reduction of packaging waste should have a special focus on packaging waste that cannot be recycled or reused (and hence is incinerated or landfilled).  Circular packaging that contributes to climate neutrality is part of the solution. Measures established for the prevention of packaging waste must be adequate and proportional to the objective pursued and should be focused to minimize overpackaging and packaging that cannot be recycled or reused.   Reuse is one of the options to reduce residual waste but not the only one as in some cases reusable options have similar or even higher environmental impacts throughout their life cycle when considering the climate impact compared to single use options. We believe a new consumption model needs both multi- and single-use packaging as long as it takes into account climate neutrality, sustainable sourcing of raw materials, efficient use of resources, circularity as well as food safety and availability.   ACE Iberia has the following views on the options proposed to reach the objectives  • We support the revision of the Essential Requirements according to which all packaging placed on the market must be low carbon, reusable or recyclable by 2030. Requiring all packaging to be reusable or recyclable and provide an enforceable definition of what is ‘recyclable’ is the best option.  This measure can be implemented through a clear definition of “recyclable”, establishing strict provisions on separate collection of packaging to ensure high quality recycling and implementing pay-as-you throw schemes with high fees for residual waste to incentivize consumer and local authorities. Such provisions would provide a stable legislative framework for sustainable investments to meet climate and circularity targets while supporting resilient food systems.  • Restricting the use of some packaging materials to certain applications in particular when alternative reusable products or systems exist may prove to be difficult to implement and hampers innovation. Regulation should set goals and targets but abstain from being overly prescriptive on the means to meet them.  • Reducing the complexity of packaging materials including the number of polymers used does not take into consideration the functionality of the packaging and could lead to promote policy options that do not reduce environmental impact.   Some beverages or foods are highly sensitive and hence require to be packed in such a way that health & safety are preserved. Sometimes product requirements cannot be achieved through monomaterials. feedback_msg_text: Feedback to the EU Inception Impact Assessment on the initiative “Review of the requirements for packaging and other measures to prevent packaging waste”.  BillerudKorsnäs provides packaging materials and solutions that challenge conventional packaging for a sustainable future. We are a world-leading provider of fibre based packaging materials and support customers with packaging solutions for food and beverages.  BillerudKorsnäs welcome the possibility to provide input to the EU Inception Assessment on the initiative to reduce packaging waste.   We support the problem addressed in the initiative and agree • upon the problem with packaging waste and low recycling rates for some secondary materials.  • on the need to address the problem with fossil based feedstock for packaging material.  We would however like to emphasize the following  Primary and recycled fibres are part of one single system • In Europe, paper and board packaging material is one of the most efficiently recovered with high recycling rates.  • Primary and recycled fibres are parts of the same system and are mutually dependent. It is vital that any measures does not disrupt this well-functioning system.   It is positive that the consultation include that recycling shall be to high quality in a cost efficient way and not risk any increase in food waste. We would in this context emphasize that the current system for recycling paper and board packaging material is already addressing this as different types of virgin and recycled material are being used for different products with different demands.  Climate impact Different measures will be needed for various materials because the conditions and circularities differs  In order to decrease GHG emissions from fossil based packaging waste  • it is important that any new legislation distinguish between fossil based and renewable packaging material feedstock.
Initiative: Reducing packaging waste – review of rules

feedback_msg_text: As Borealis, producer of polyolefin plastic resins for packaging applications as well as active recycling company, we welcome clearer legislation on the essential requirements for packaging. This will incentivise a higher degree of circularity, whilst at the same time maintaining the principles of a unified European market, optimizing the use of natural resources in balance with content preservation, stimulating design for recycling and reuse, and introducing some mandatory elements, like incorporation of recyclates in specific applications as well as closed loop reuse systems for transport packaging or e-commerce. The updated essential requirements will also lead the way forward into a truly sustainable circular economy for plastic packaging, provided the implementation will be executed in a transparent and efficient manner.

feedback_msg_text: With regard to the roadmap, the Compost & Biogas Association Austria would like to emphasize that the reduction of packaging waste must comply with the following principles:  -Wherever possible, single use products should be replaced with reusable ones. Packaging design and extended producer responsibility are to be considered in line with the circular economy strategy. -Waste prevention is the top priority of waste policy measures. Common packaging practices should be critically examined by both manufacturers and consumers. (This may require further awareness raising measures) -Wherever it makes sense, biodegradable packaging materials should be used. It is essential that these products are certified according to EN 13432.  -Recycling must also be established for biodegradable plastics to ensure that valuable raw materials and contained enery are preserved as long as possible.

feedback_msg_text: Chemical recycling is one of the key solutions contributing to the circular economy of plastics. In addition to increasing the recycling rates of some plastics currently not being recycled, it is creating recycled content of virgin-quality which will be essential to fulfil the strong demand incentivized by the EU Plastic tax, the Circular Economy Action Plan or the EU Green Deal. This move toward a circular economy will reduce oil extraction necessary for the creation of virgin plastic, and reduce GHG in line with the Paris Agreement.   Chemical Recycling Europe represents the chemical recycling technologies necessary to enable the conversion of plastic waste into new chemical substances and/or products, supporting the circular economy for plastics and complementing traditional mechanical recycling.   We strongly support the Commission’s initiative to prevent packaging waste, promote recycling, and increase and incentivize the use of recycled content and its quality.   We would suggest the Commission to work along side the industry and platform such as the Circular Plastic Alliance (CPA) as its works overlap with the current goals and work necessary for this initiative.    Please find in our attached paper Chemical Recycling Europe's feedback based on 3 key points: 1) Design for recyclability should create a level playing field for recycling technologies and materials choice;  2) Harmonization in recyclability and collection will be key to support the recycling industry;  3) Develop policy and methodologies for recycled content to ensure the good functioning of the internal market. feedback_msg_text: Improving the essential requirements of packaging placed on the EU market to ensure that plastic packaging is reusable or recyclable is crucial to reduce the packaging waste created in the EU. We therefore warmly welcome the Commission’s initiative to assess the expected impacts of the adapted essential requirements for packaging. We would like to put emphasis on necessary policy options to boost reusable packaging in the EU. Reuse not only offers a considerable potential for resource and climate protection but also fosters economic growth and the creation of local jobs. In Germany, the reusable beverage system is associated with around 145,000 green jobs. Large one-way bottling plants require up to five times less workers than refillable plants.  DUH wants to stress the following points: Clear definition of reuse The requirements specific to the reusable nature of packaging need to be supplemented by two essential points to guarantee the actual return and reuse of those packaging: adequate logistics and appropriate incentive systems, usually by a deposit. The Commission could make use of the definition provided in the German Packaging Act. Moreover, we agree with Eunomia that specified minimum thresholds for the number of trips of reusable packaging should not be defined in the Essential Requirements. Policy options Economic incentives for waste prevention The EU urgently needs economic incentives for waste prevention. Manufacturers and distributors must be held accountable for the environmentally unfriendly packaging they put on the market, and thus the environmental impact of those single-use items must be reflected in either ecologically modulated licencing fees or a resource tax. At the same time, the production of environmentally friendly reusable packaging should be rewarded through adequate tax benefits, for example a reduced VAT rate. Additionally, effective financial steering mechanisms must be introduced to achieve a short-term reduction of the consumption of single-use items. The introduction of a levy on environmentally harmful single-use products could be a very potent policy instrument. The generated revenue could be used to support environmental protection projects, awareness campaigns and innovative reuse systems. Binding quantitative reuse targets  The COM’s consideration of making reuse mandatory for the area of transport packaging is welcome but also binding reuse targets for other packaging streams like beverage and sales packaging are necessary to prevent packaging waste. Binding reuse targets create a safe environment for investments in the associated technology and infrastructure. That applies to both SMEs and regionally operating companies, but also to big corporations.   Beverage packaging accounts for 10 % of overall packaging waste and saves half the CO2 emissions over its entire life cycle in comparison to single-use alternatives. Therefore, the COM should introduce an ambitious reuse target of at least 70 percent by 2030. Beyond beverage packaging, a reuse target of 25 percent by 2025 and 40 percent by 2030 should be set for sales packaging. For transport packaging, a reuse rate of 70 percent should apply from 2025. These targets should be attributed to all market participants along the entire value chain (producers and retailers) as it has been the case in Romania since 1 Jan 2020 and member states should be obligated to link them to effective sanctioning mechanisms in case of non-compliance.  GPP To further boost reuse, the planned minimum mandatory GPP criteria needs to consider bans on certain single-use products or orders to exclusively purchase reusable packaging for procurement offices. An increased application of reusable solutions can in turn foster a safe environment for investments in reusable alternatives.  Lastly, the environmental impacts should acknowledge the potential microplastic entry into the wastewater through the recycling of single-use plastic packaging, i.e. plastic bottles Feedback from: Deutsche Umwelthilfe e.V. feedback_msg_text: Herbalife Nutrition is a global nutrition company providing science-based nutrition solutions and a supportive community approach that inspires people to embrace a healthier, more active lifestyle. We offer weight-management, nutrition, and personal care products that can be personalised with the help of an educated and trained distributor.  Herbalife Nutrition values the European Commission’s intention to review the requirements for packaging and other measures to prevent packaging waste. We agree that the outcome of the review of the essential requirements for packaging should be a well-functioning internal market by introducing harmonised rules among Member States and preventing the possible negative impact on the environment. We also welcome the opportunity to share our feedback. The European Commission states that the reason for low volumes of recycled packaging waste is the cost of recycled materials, however, we believe that the main contributing factor is the lack of appropriate waste streams for recycled materials. We recommend that the EU Commission assesses the possibility of creating incentives for additional uses for recycled packaging, and optimised recycling processes at EU level. Legislating the requirement for recyclable packaging will not solve the demand problem. Waste streams need to be optimised or recycling will not have the desired effect. More capacity is required in the various waste streams in order to facilitate more recycling.   When examining possible restrictions of use of packaging materials to certain applications, we would like to stress the fact that the packaging, besides conveying the product to the end user, has also other functions, such as protecting the product during transportation. This needs to be considered, or the assumption that these initiatives will reduce cost might be inaccurate.   Introduction of recycled content targets for all packaging formats could be challenging and unfeasible to meet. We believe that such requirements should be given under product specific legislation to ensure that product-specific characteristics are considered. Currently, there are no authorised recycling processed for plastic food contact materials at EU level. We ask the European Commission to take authorisation of recycling processes as a priority to allow the industry to start introducing recycled content to their packaging.  Please see the attached document for further explanations from Herbalife Nutrition. Feedback from: Herbalife Nutrition (209.4 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: - The fact that the monitoring of waste packaging production is based on weight makes it complicated to monitor progress on reuse and prevention, and encourages the trend toward light-weighting initiatives, sometimes at the expense of recyclability. The review of the packaging directive could also entail a reform on the way the packaging waste policy is monitored, and improve data collection based on packaging units in addition and complementary to weight. - On reuse : Define standard reusable packaging format is key to develop refillables schemes, optimize cost and reduce environmental impact of reuse, especially in emerging markets for reuse such as food containers or jars that don't yet benefit from standard format unlike the beer sector for example.  - One obstacle to reuse is the use of glue that doesn't go away when washed. In order to promote reuse, the packaging directive could restrict the use of certain glue and stickers on glass containers that cannot be washed.   - development of prevention and reuse will require significant investments in washing and packaging facilities. Some fundings would need to be secured to ensure the development of reuse.
Initiative: Reducing packaging waste – review of rules

feedback_msg_text: Milieu (Planet) problemen die door mensen worden veroorzaakt kunnen - en zullen - ook door ons, mensen, worden opgelost!  (Het PUMA MANIFEST)  Verpakken is de activiteit van het tijdelijk integreren van een externe functie en een product om het gebruik van het product mogelijk te maken. De wereld 'doet het' 320.000 keer per seconde, wat resulteert in hetzelfde aantal verpakkingen dat per seconde wordt geleegd, zij het later in de tijd en op een andere locatie dan waar ze zijn gevuld.   NVC (opgericht in 1953) is de vereniging van meer dan 500 bedrijven wereldwijd, die de activiteit van het verpakken op een holistische manier aanpakken. Het NVC-lidmaatschap, de innovatieprojecten, de informatiediensten en het opleidingsprogramma stimuleren de voortdurende verbetering van het verpakken in Europa en daarbuiten.   NVC heeft sinds 1994 op vele manieren bijgedragen aan de implementatie en verdere ontwikkeling van de EU-richtlijn 94/62/EG betreffende verpakking en verpakkingsafval:  - het systematisch en proactief ontwikkelen van de geharmoniseerde CEN-normen en vervolgens het initiëren en voltooien van de bijbehorende wereldwijde ISO-normen  - Het bedrijfsleven wereldwijd voorzien van voldoende kennis over de ontwikkelingen op het gebied van regelgeving en wetgeving via de informatiedienst MERGE  - Het leren aan zakelijke beslissers hoe ze duurzaamheid en innovatie in verpakkingen kunnen integreren via de Live Online (No travel, global acccess, volledig interactief) workshop STIP.  - Het delen van de concepten, ideeën en inspiratie op tal van vergaderingen, conferenties, tentoonstellingen wereldwijd in sync met ongeveer 70.000 unieke zakelijke website-bezoekers per jaar en 30.000+ zakelijke volgers online wereldwijd. - Mede-initiatiefnemer van het PUMA-project (sinds 2016) met als expliciete doelstelling om  een einde te maken aan verpakkingen als een milieuprobleem wereldwijd   Deze feedback is bedoeld als inspiratie voor professionals en 'onwetende' (wat niet noodzakelijkerwijs betekent 'ongeinformeerde'!) burgers in Europa en daarbuiten die ernaar streven om gehoord te worden en een positieve bijdrage te leveren aan het proces om nu eindelijk een einde te maken aan het milieuverpakkingsdrama. Het is bedoeld als:   - Een bron van retrospectie voor beleidsmakers, industrie en consumenten op de manier waarop we in de huidige situatie zijn terechtgekomen  - Een kader voor een beter begrip, een beschrijving en daarmee uiteindelijk ook een oplossing voor de milieuproblemen waar we allemaal mee te maken hebben.  - Een referentiekader en een bron van innovatie voor toekomstige acties van beleidsmakers, het bedrijfsleven en de consumenten, zowel in Europa als daarbuiten.  Voor gedetailleerde informatie en het gratis downloaden van het bijbehorende PUMA MANIFEST (wereldwijd gelanceerd op 6 mei 2020, met speciale edities in het Nederlands, Frans, Spaans, Duits, Japans en Chinees gepland voor de jaren 202-2021) bent u gratis en van harte welkom op de PUMA-website.
Initiative: Reducing packaging waste – review of rules

feedback_msg_text: Environmental (planetary) problems caused by People can – and will - also be solved by us, People!  (The PUMA MANIFESTO)  Packaging is the activity of temporarily integrating an external function and a product to enable the use of the product. The world 'does it' 320,000 times per second, which results in the same number of packs emptied per second, albeit later in time and at a different location from where they were filled.   NVC (founded in 1953) is the association of more than 500 companies worldwide, addressing the activity of packaging in a holistic manner. The NVC membership, innovation projects, information services and education programme stimulate the continuous improvement of packaging in Europe and abroad.   NVC has contributed to the implementation and further development of EU Directive 94/62/EC on Packaging and Packaging Waste since 1994 in many ways:   - Systematically and proactively developing the harmonised CEN standards, subsequently initiating and completing the corresponding worldwide ISO standards  - Providing business worldwide with adequate knowledge on the regulatory and legislative developments via information service MERGE  - Learning business decision makers how to integrate sustainability and innovation in packaging via the Live Online (No travel, global acccess, fully interactive) workshop STIP  - Sharing the concepts, ideas and inspiration on numerous meetings, conferences, exhibitions worldwide in sync with around 70,000 unique website business visitors annually and 30,000+ business followers online worldwide - Co-initiating the PUMA Project (since 2016) explicitly aiming to make an end to packaging as an environmental issue worldwide   This feedback aims to provide inspiration for professionals and 'uninformed' (which not necessarily means 'unknowing'!) citizens of Europe and abroad who strive to be heard, to be known and to be a positive contributing factor to the process of now finally bringing the environmental packaging drama to a positive end. It is meant as:   - A source of retrospection for policy makers, industry and consumers on how we have come into the current situation  - A framework for better understanding, describing and thereby ultimate also solving the environmental challenges we all face  - A frame of reference and source of innovation in future action by policy makers, industry and consumers, both in Europe and abroad.  For detailed information and free download of the corresponding PUMA MANIFESTO (launched 6 May 2020 globally, with special editions in Dutch, French, Spanish, German, Japanese and Chinese planned for the years 202-2021) please the PUMA-website.
