feedback_msg_text: NEW DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES AS AN ENABLER OF AN EFFECTIVE PACKAGING WASTE MANAGEMENT The inclusion of new digital technologies should be considered in the directive - new technologies are important enablers of transparency, can help ensure compliance to both social and climate responsible business conduct and – at the end – help create a more effective and responsible packaging waste management system.   New digital technologies can make out the foundation for establishment of an ecosystem economy as part of strengthening incentivization for preventing waste packaging and strengthening recycling packaging. (An ecosystem economy would allow individuals, organizations and external communities to create value through the interaction among various subjects).   New digital solutions like blockchain based networks can for example be leveraged to connect recycling companies with other processing alternatives rather than landfills and help establish a bridge between packaging recycling and online marketplaces for secondary material for the purpose of generating value out of waste.   When one company has a burden of recyclable packaging materials on stock, they could reach out to the blockchain’s network to locate another member who could process the remaining materials rather than just passing it to a landfill. By creating a more efficient means of communication, blockchain could connect recycling companies to balance the burden of packaging waste. Furthermore, with new digital technologies not only companies, but also consumers can be hold accountable for the packaging waste they’ve created and lost recycling. By placing producers, consumers, and waste management operators into a network together, blockchain could help establish a view of the waste supply chain that is visible. Blockchain can support transparency and add value to companies and consumers by showing the impact to every member of the network, which again would increase incentives for recycling of the packaging.  TRACK & TRACE, BLOCKCHAIN TECHNOLOGY AND IOT DEVICES AS FOUNDATION FOR INCENTIVIZATION  By including new digital technologies packaging waste management related transactions can be registered and on a running basis monitored. Registering and monitoring must be considered as a crucial foundation of an effective packaging waste management and recycling system. Tracking and tracing technologies can be used and combined for example with blockchain technology. By combining blockchain technology with big data and IoT devices packaging waste sorting and collection can be rewarded - a system for digital tokens can be created, rewarding consumers with bonus points that can be used for example for buying public services.
Organisation: DNV GL Business Assurance Italia S.r.l.
Initiative: Reducing packaging waste – review of rules

feedback_msg_text: Cummins Inc. welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the European Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment for the Sustainable Products Initiative. Cummins shares the Commission’s goals of providing more sustainable products to consumers and reducing environmental impact; this is demonstrated through the company’s PLANET 2050 sustainability strategy, which sets quantifiable goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and using natural resources in the most sustainable way possible.   To ensure that regulatory changes proposed by the Impact Assessment are effective, changes in scope to the Ecodesign Directive, as well as any additional legislative action, should be harmonized with preexisting European Union legislation to avoid potential double regulation. In addition, the Commission should utilize appropriate lead time on new requirements to allow industry members adequate time to implement the tools and processes necessary for compliance. Finally, goals set by legislative changes should be standardized and centralized between Member States, ensuring a consistent regulatory framework throughout the European Union. Cummins looks forward to working with the Commission to produce increasingly sustainable products and build a more circular economy.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: The Fédération de la Haute Couture et de la Mode (“the Federation”) represents over a hundred French and international brands and is the voice of the creative and luxury fashion industry.   Together with its expert task force, the Federation and its members fully adhere to the European Commission’s objectives for a more circular economy.   The Federation would like to provide comments on 3 main areas:  Eco-design/Durability/Recyclability – The Federation welcomes and supports this initiative and believes that, in line with circularity principles, enhancing durability is one of the key elements necessary to eco-designing high end fashion products.   Luxury clothing and accessories embrace core notions of quality and long product lifetime as they are made from high quality and innovative materials with outstanding craftsmanship techniques and savoir-faire. Luxury products can be repaired and restored, facilitating  their capacity to be reused, given a second life, or often passed from generation to another.  The Federation is a member of the Apparel & Footwear PEF working group, actively participating in the dialogue surrounding the implementation possibilities of sustainability requirements for products which will be placed on the market. Promoting durability should go hand in hand with the establishment of standards to qualify and certify the product durability (see ongoing works by the BNITH in France defining a norm for durability).  Another secondary aspect of circularity models is to promote design for disassembly or recyclability. Efficient textile recycling relies on the implementation of collection, sorting and recycling systems at a local level – making its applicability complex for international brands.  All measures in this regard should therefore take into account local systems, product specificities and technical challenges. Allowing sufficient time for research to develop recycling solutions for the variety and complexity of the materials used in many luxury products is essential.   The Federation believes that these factors should be taken into account when establishing the compulsory or not nature of the considered measures, so that each stakeholder can best adapt the circularity objectives to the specificities of its activities.  Destruction of unsold goods – The Federation supports this initiative, a measure that has already been implemented in French “Loi Lutte contre le gaspillage et économie circulaire” in 2020.   The Federation wishes to stress that any solution provided in this regard should take into consideration the above mentioned technical challenges as well as characteristics of each sector on a level playing field. It will thus be crucial to grant sufficient flexibility to each sector and each stakeholder in order to best implement this measure taking into account their specificities.  The solutions considered also ought to be compatible with the respect of any other relevant rules such as intellectual property rights attached to unsold products, and exemptions provided for by the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation such as selective and exclusive distribution systems, avoiding the risk of diversion or counterfeiting of these products as well as feeding parallel distribution networks.  Consumer information – The Federation acknowledges the need for improved information to consumers regarding the environmental and, where appropriate, social aspects of the products.  The Federation therefore welcomes the digitalisation of such information, in the form of a digital product passport, as a practical solution which allows for more information to be communicated given certain space constraints on product labels and/ or packaging, the concrete needs of each type of consumer, depending on the sector and the type of products involved, and their locations.   The Federation will follow this impact assessment and will remain available to provide any necessary contribution in order to implement this initiative. feedback_msg_text: As a worldwide manufacturer and retailer, Decathlon is fully aware of its social and environmental responsibility. At Decathlon we strive for responsible growth that benefits both people and the planet, acting within a regenerative economy.  This element is part of our corporate vision.   Our Transition Plan 2020-2026 reflects this commitment, and we feel that the Commission’s strategy should be considered from its more general perspective, i.e. respect for Human Rights and the Environment, and appropriate value creation.  The road is long, but we’re ready to tackle the challenge alongside the European Commission. We have been working towards a trajectory designed to minimise global warming to an increase of 1.5°C and, aware of the importance of creating a decarbonised world, to complement our reduction goals (40% reduction of our carbon intensity between 2016 and 2026), we’re aiming to become a climate-positive business in 2030.  The challenges involved in developing a circular economy model relate to our products (raw materials, eco-design) with a satisfied lifetime expectancy, a response to new modes of consumption (repair, rental and second-hand), and managing the end-of-life stage of our products. We share the aims of the Green Deal and salute the decision of the European Commission to put forward solutions to ensure that products sold on the market adhere to increasingly rigorous sustainability criteria. EU product policy should help minimise the impact on the climate, as well as the environmental impacts caused by the world’s resources and energy use, production activities, and product usage. Aside from environmental considerations, we advocate the distribution of products in compliance with basic human rights, diversity and inclusion criteria.  Keeping all of these elements in mind, we are pleased to be able to present our contribution to the sustainable product policy Road Map in the attached document, which aims to support the strategies of the European Commission. feedback_msg_text: The views of the EU steel sector about the objectives, policy options and the likely impacts presented in the Roadmap can be summarised as follows. 1. Eco-Design – Circularity Requirements at the Design Stage - Eco-design can effectively act as instrument for plugging-in sustainability into products - The scope of Eco-design has to be widened - A set of minimum sustainability criteria should be defined and horizontally applied to all products; other complementary sustainability criteria should be defined as product segment specific - The sustainability criteria need to contain also circular requirements (e.g. design for recycling, disassembling…) 2. Environmental Performance - Recognising Circularity at the Beginning and End-of-Life - a common and robust LCA-based methodology which is consistent across all product groups has to be defined - a cradle-to-cradle LCA approach - full life cycle into account - should be considered - recyclability and recycled content have to be considered together as done by the Circular Footprint Formula of the Environmental Footprint approach - recyclability of products should be assessed in all product groups for its benefits, such as: softening any trade-off between extending the life-span of products and the performance improvements of newer generation products; nurturing an increment of the recycled content via the environmental benefits of closed material loops and via the preservation of the inherent properties of materials. 3. Social criteria where relevant - Social criteria of the sustainability principles should be defined only when relevant to a specific product group - The social criteria should consider the benefits of job creation in the EU and the wider contribution of manufacturing to local communities. 4. Extended Producer Responsibility with Eco-Modulated Fees when products are placed on the market - extended producer responsibility schemes can be an effective instrument via the implementation of the following aspects:         o  the use of eco-modulated fees payable at the point of placing the product on the market         o  products designed with circularity in mind should be rewarded by paying lower fees         o  responsibilities of each actor along the value chain should be clearly identified and addressed to the relevant actor 5. Communication Requirements – Transparency and Coherence of B2B and B2C Information - communication tools should be transparent and unbiased - intermediates and consumer (end)-products should have respectively B2B and B2C measures, because the purpose is different 6. Creating a Market for Green Products through Economic Incentives - EU sustainability requirements/criteria should also be applied at the EU borders (imports) - it should be made feasible to offer certified carbon 'neutral' products for customers willing to carry a 'green' premium and to have associated market incentives - a functioning sustainable products legal framework needs to support low-carbon/green materials and products via instruments such as, reference thresholds, contracts for difference, green public procurement or similar An extensive version of the input reported above is attached; the paper contains comprehensive comments and the rationale behind the views of the EU steel sector.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: The Eco-Design Directive can be a more powerful instrument in greening and creating a market for sustainable products. Its scope has to be widened in order to cover a larger number of products and to set minimum conditions for products sustainability (overarching principles). The initial scope of covering only energy-related products has proven to be effective, but now the directive has to address non-energy related endproducts in sustainability terms. 2. The actual products policy has, for the time being, a ‘lock-in’ effect because the absence of circular requirements in products design can limit or even nullifies the contribution of the waste law towards the EU circular economy goals. Moreover, the absence of a common basis for assessing the environmental profile of products hampers the transition of the market to more sustainable options. 3. Within the Eco-Design framework, a set of minimum sustainability criteria have to be established, some of which can be horizontally applied to all products, whilst others can be product group specific. These minimum criteria have to be technology and material neutral. 4. The set of minimum sustainability criteria should include product circularity requirements. Design for recycling is critical, since this will allow end-of-life recycling of materials and parts of products at their highest quality and potential. Requirements such durability, reparability and disassembling are also needed in order to extended the products life and optimise the products sustainability. It is important to note that recyclability also pays dividends when considering durability requirements, by softening any trade-off between extending the life-span of products and the performance improvements of newer generation products The environmental performance of products needs to be assessed using a common and robust LCA-based methodology which is consistent across all product groups. Then, based on a common methodology, each product group can further detail their requirements. 6. Environmental sustainability has to be assessed using a cradle-to-cradle LCA approach in order to take into account the full life cycle of the product. In particular, being the EU Sustainability Products initiative linked to the Circular Economy, the recyclability and the recycled content both have to be considered together, as done in the Circular Footprint Formula (CFF) of the Environmental Footprint approach. The CFF also recognises the greater emphasis, for metals, on design for recycling and reuse at the end-of-life, as a key measure of circularity. 7. The recyclability of products works as a big driver in reducing the negative social, health and environmental impacts of waste, such as the effects of littering. If one of the EU goals is to increase recycling of products, then using recyclable materials is essential and has to be incentivised and properly measured. Recognising recyclability, and the associated environmental benefits of closed material loops and permanent materials that retain their inherent properties, will also nurture an increase in recycled content. 8. The environmental benefits of using by-products, such as slags, and other end-of-waste materials that can equally reduce the use of primary materials. These materials also need to be recognised alongside ‘recycled content’ (where secondary raw materials are used from waste or previous use). The product acceptance criteria for these ‘alternative’ materials should be the same as that used for primary materials, for instance for the use of aggregates in road construction. This will avoid any bias towards using primary materials that exists in certain Member States Social criteria of the sustainability principles should be defined only when relevant to a specific product group. These criteria however should be inspired, for instance, by the due diligence approaches such as developed by the OECD or EU Regulation on raw materials sourcing, which already exists and is applied

feedback_msg_text: Hesus warmly welcomes the Sustainable Products Initiative and the Commission’s ambition to establish sustainability principles linked to environmental aspects. Yet, we regret that the Roadmap does not mention the construction and building sector, despite the fact that it is identified as one of the key product value chains in the New Circular Economy Action Plan (Section 3.6).   Hesus recalls that the construction industry is the largest consumer of raw materials as well as the largest producer of waste in the EU, namely 25% - 30% of all waste generated . Moreover, life cycle impacts of the construction industry – from material extraction, manufacturing of construction products, construction and renovation of buildings – show how carbon-intensive this sector is.   It is urgent for the EU to step up its regulatory efforts in this area. The construction industry holds indeed a significant potential for circularity (diminishing whole life carbon emissions; increasing use of recycled/reused materials; improving C&D waste management).   Building on this, Hesus would like to highlight three proposals that can significantly contribute to make the building sector more circular :  1. Assessing the whole life cycle of materials, including soils, used in the construction industry 2. Making the most of secondary raw materials, including excavated soils, to reduce the carbon and environmental footprint of the construction sector 3. Using data and digital tools to make the construction sector circular  Please find attached Hesus' contribution explaining in detail these proposals. feedback_msg_text: YASKAWA Europe welcomes the European Commission’s new Sustainable Products Initiative and strongly encourages a common European approach to this important field.   YASKAWA Europe is company of people pursuing their passion – driven by the vision of a smarter future with advanced technologies that save precious time and energy.  For us, any given day is a new chance to make progress. Our goal is to contribute to the evolution of society by improving the nature of its business, increasing the performance and productivity of our industry, and therefore our everyday lives.  Naturally we promote renewable resources to ensure a healthy environment – for a sustainable planet for all of us.  YASKAWA Europe thinks that the European Ecodesign Directive has served as a useful tool for increasing the energy efficiency for energy related products and YASKAWA is supporting this by providing innovative energy saving products and solutions.  These innovative and energy saving products are becoming more and more compact, resulting in less electronic losses and less material resource consumption per product.  And the smaller the components and therefore the machines, the more energy can be saved during transport and installation. Size of a product can be bee see as what carbon footprint reduction benefits from.  But, if products become smaller and smaller, then it becomes increasingly difficult to apply all the security-related data and guidance required for the lifecycle process to the product.  We think, it should be very much carefully considered which information is really must be fixed directly on the product and which not.  Recently YASKAWA recognised some issues related to the harmonisation of standards.  Experts in the standards committees are making great efforts to assist the European Commission and Parliament in the technical implementation of the legislation.  And this work has been successful for many years.  However, in recent years harmonisation process was not as efficient as it should be.  So YASKAWA calls on the European Commission  • not to create any new additional labels that shall be fixed directly on the product. • For sustainable products and legislation - propose long term regulatory certainty through a harmonised approach on requirements, methodologies and standards. • For harmonized standards timely delivered shall be possible – for that we think improved processes and better cooperation between the European Commission and the European Standardization Organizations is needed.   Best regards
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: Legislative incentives for product-service systems as a holistic approach to product sustainability  We, the Berlin regional group of the Cradle to Cradle NGO, support the Commission’s initiative. To increase the initiative’s potential impact, we would like to propose the creation of additional legislative measures. These measures would incentivize economic actors that are placing products on the EU market to adopt an approach of product sustainability known as product-service systems.  In the following, we will describe the concept and its positive effects. Our concept is in line with the Cradle to Cradle design principles. We intend to show that by nudging the manufacturing industry towards a circular economy-inspired type of servitization, we are increasing product sustainability and making the logical and necessary next step towards an innovative, climate positive, and competitive EU economic system. Our concept is intended for durable goods and not for expendable goods such as food. At the same time, our concept could generally also include the packaging of the product.  We propose to focus not only on the products themselves but on ensuring circularity along the entire value chain, including the business model. This might take shape as follows:  1. Products are designed for a defined usage scenario in an economy of closed loops, using high quality and healthy materials. 2. The products are offered as a service, meaning that they are no longer sold to and owned by the consumer; the consumer becomes merely a user. The manufacturer, in turn, remains the owner of the products throughout the lease. E.g., a manufacturer of refrigerators might offer the service “freeze the user’s goods.” Instead of selling a freezer, the service, “10 years of freezing goods,” is marketed. The consumer leases the freezer but no longer owns it. 3. If the product malfunctions during the lease or there is an innovation in the market, the machine will be either updated (e.g. a software update), repaired, or exchanged for a new device. 4. The manufacturer retrieves their product at the end of the lease to rent it out to a different customer, upgrade, refurbish or recycle it. This retention of ownership incentivizes investment in the best possible materials during the phase of product design.  Therefore, our proposed concept enables manufacturers and their suppliers to be profitable by renting out their products as a service, and thus ensuring that the valuable resources used in their products can circulate in closed loops. This increases the sustainability over the whole product lifecycle. Products do not go to waste, but are ultimately refurbished, (partially) re-used, or at least fed into the technological cycle again at the highest quality possible by the most competent institution existing: the manufacturer who knows best about their product and the materials utilized.  Products will no longer be designed for a short lifespan, but to preserve the inherent material value of the resources employed. This profound change in the design processes of the industry will not only lead to environmentally and socially beneficial product designs but will also fundamentally change consumption patterns. Servitization incentivizes service providers to deepen the relationships with their customers, e.g. by providing updates and improved life-long support, resulting in longer-term partnerships to the benefit of both sides. Business models like this are already successful for the B2B sector and should therefore be transferable in B2C contexts.  We strongly believe that the Commission's initiative should not only focus on single aspects such as energy efficiency, durability, repairability etc. but also aim to regulate product sustainability at the business model level. Encouragement of more holistic, innovative approaches like product-service systems will help to have a profound impact on the sustainability of the entire value chain including all upstream suppliers.

feedback_msg_text: The Nappy Alliance welcomes the European Commission’s proposed new Sustainable Products initiative, and is grateful for this opportunity to provide feedback to the roadmap. The EU has long been a leader in sustainability and it is important that this trend continues.  Founded in 2003, the Nappy Alliance is a coalition of independent providers of reusable nappies which exists to promote the economic and environmental benefits of reusable nappies and promotes greater consumer choice for parents. Over the years, the Nappy Alliance has made significant progress to create a growing market of environmentally friendly products, with many major supermarkets throughout the EU as stockists, and 20% of parents opting to use reusable nappies at some stage.  Our members are: Bambino Mio, Baba+Boo, Babi Pur, Close Parent, Little Lamb, MuslinZ, The Nappy Lady, The Nappy Gurus, and TotsBots. Although UK-based, Nappy Alliance members include many of the EU’s leading reusable nappy brands.  Disposable nappies are an environmental disaster, consuming vast quantities of raw materials like wood pulp and cotton, as well as rayon and viscose for the production of super absorbent polymers and plastics. Their production and disposal use huge amounts of water and energy, and produces carbon emissions. They are technically extremely difficult to recycle, given their complex composition of multiple materials. Furthermore, they are a significant problem within the marine environment as they take hundreds of years to decompose and are a cause of significant health risks when human excrement leaks into waterways. Disposable nappies are also hugely costly to consumers, and have been linked to health concerns due to the variety of chemicals used, and over-heating (which is a risk factor for testicular cancer).  So-called “eco”-disposables are gaining in popularity across Europe, despite in many cases being just as bad - if not worse - for the environment than regular disposables. Scaling up production of bio-based plastics could compete with agriculture, driving biodiversity loss and climate change. Furthermore, claims of biodegradability by “eco”-disposable companies can result in nappy waste being mismanaged, as consumers assume that these products should go in their food waste or recycling bin. In reality, many biodegradable and compostable plastics will usually only break down in industrial facilities, and most end up in landfill or incineration just like regular plastic waste.  We believe that the scope of the Sustainable Products initiative should be extended to include nappies, on the following grounds: • In 2017 across the 28-EU, around 33 billion disposable nappies were used, resulting in 6.7 million tonnes of waste and around 3.3Mt of CO2 equivalents; • If just 20 per cent of babies across the EU-28 switched to reusables full time, over one million tonnes of waste could be prevented per year • Disposable nappies are the 25th most common item of marine litter found on the seabed globally, and the 39th on land; • Families could save up to €2,000 switching to reusables, and more if they use reusables for subsequent children; • So-called “eco”-disposables are not inherently sustainable and can be worse than regular disposables; • Misleading claims around “biodegradable” “compostable” and “bio-based” disposable nappies are confusing consumers, causing littering and contaminating waste streams.  The Nappy Alliance believes that parents should have access to accurate information on which to base their choices. At present, many parents choose to use disposables or so-called “eco”-disposables unaware of the environmental and economic advantages of reusables. We believe that the Sustainable Products initiative is a great opportunity to ensure that parents have access to, and information about, the most sustainable products, and we would therefore urge the Commission to expand the scope of this initiative to include nappies. feedback_msg_text: Sympatex wholeheartedly welcomes the Sustainable Products Initiative of the European Commission, as it clearly focusses on making the EU economy “future-fit”. The Covid-19 crisis has slowed down an ever-accelerating process of economic growth that has started to threaten human survival not only in the long, but even in the short term. The main reason for concern doesn’t need to be the economic system itself, but the lack of balanced corrective factors and motivational impulses that would help to steer the outcome of industrial activities in a responsible direction while still safeguarding the overall economic success. Making ecological factors an unavoidable part of managerial economic decision making will initiate a consistent, yet controlled transformation process that might be challenging for some individual actors, while it will ensure the integrity of the overall economic system by supporting those who have already embarked on a future-fit strategy.  We want to encourage the Commission to put a special focus on Circularity starting from the design phase as this has the highest impact on both, the upstream as well as the downstream ecological impact of industrial activities. The highest impact for change of the EU initiative can be expected if not only the collateral damages caused to the Commons becomes the responsibility of the industrial players causing it, but also the ecological legacy created by products once they have been handed over to the consumer.  Criteria should therefore include e.g.:  • a clear restriction for use to those materials for which an industrial viable recycling process exist (design for recyclability) • an obligation to integrate means to allow the separation of materials post use if various materials are combined (design for dismantling) • in case of comparable material alternatives an obligation to choose those materials that have the easiest recycling technologies • an obligation to explicitly mark products that do not comply with a set minimum level of requirements in a way that this becomes clearly visible to the consumer • a process of continuous intensification of requirements  Furthermore, special support should be granted for industrial players that:  • engage into the recycling of its own waste-streams (and don’t short-cut by using easy-to-recycle leftovers of other industries) • engage in the collection and/or separation of materials • lead the circularity movement by representing a benchmark within their own industry  While the focus of the regulatory initiative should remain to initiate a turn in industrial focus, public procurement bodies should become role models for this initiative. Still today, most of the EU governmental tenders lack a clear priority on sustainability criteria as they put the decision focus on commercial parameters. Such purchasing processes should consistently contain minimum selection criteria for sustainability performance as well as a fair trade relation between ecological and cost advantages.   Finally, it is highly recommended not to rely on any voluntary industrial self-control mechanisms, as those will not lead to a timely shift in the impact. Only clear legal restrictions will initiate the required momentum for change.  The apparel industry might be a good example for such failure: while 2/3 of the industry is using synthetic material with a strong dominance of Polyester (70-80%), only a small fraction of apparel waste returns in the industrial process. In the light of existing collection processes available in the EU (50-70% of apparel waste) and a proven range of industrial recycling processes for Polyester, it’s obvious that this simply goes back to a lack of will of the industrial players involved to change their way of doing. Only clear and timed obligations will induce the required change – e.g. a 50% circularity level to be achieved by 2025 on corporate level.   We are thankful for the EU initiative to dare taking the voice of future generations.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: iFixit welcomes the Sustainable Products Initiative that aims to make sustainable goods, services and business models the norm. We strongly support reducing the environmental footprint of products on the EU market, introducing sustainability principles and extending product lifetimes with more durable and reparable products.   We’d like to raise the following points: - We support widening the scope of the Ecodesign directive as wide as possible. We also support the introduction of sustainability requirements that go beyond energy performance and address further environmental and social aspects. The existing legislative framework should be made more dynamic in light of accelerated technology and product cycles  - Horizontal measures should be set to allow for a minimum level of sustainability to be maintained on product groups not within priority categories and to save governance resources and implementation time lag.   - Products not complying with a minimum level of sustainability requirements should not have market access if sustainable goods and services are to become the norm.  - The minimum sustainability requirements should be aligned with the climate and environmental emergency, and with European commitments towards carbon neutrality and the SDGs. Societal costs of the delayed implementation or the low ambition of requirements should be taken into account.  - Reparability requirements should be considered systematically and should be extended to all product groups to increase product lifetimes and save resources. Providing unrestricted and free access to repair and maintenance information to everyone is key in removing repair barriers and reduces safety risks associated with attempting a repair without information. In addition, there should be requirements on the ease of disassembly for key parts and consumables, spare parts and diagnostic tools should be accessible to everyone, and software updates should be provided for a period of time aligned with the expected product lifetime.  - Voluntary agreements should not be considered an alternative to regulatory instruments. Existing voluntary agreements under Ecodesign have hardly challenged business as usual and have often not resulted in faster decision making processes.    - Product requirements should be adopted individually instead of bundled in packages to achieve faster adoption.   - Sustainable procurement should be the default choice for public and private organisations.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: KRAIBURG Austria als langjähriger, etablierter Spezialist für Reifen-Runderneuerung in Europa begrüßt die in der „Sustainable Products Initiative“ präsentierten Vorhaben ausdrücklich! Den Ausführungen diverser Branchenverbände für Reifen-Runderneuerung wie z.B. des BIPAVER schließen wir uns an, möchten weiters empfehlen, dass Reifen als weiteres Beispiel neben Electronics, ITC, Textiles,… in „B. Objectives and Policy options“ im vierten Absatz mit aufgenommen werden.  Reifen sind bezogen auf die technische Machbarkeit bereits ein funktionierendes Beispiel für Kreislaufwirtschaft über alle Stufen. Im Segment der Nutzfahrzeugreifen sind runderneuerte Reifen im Reifenersatzmarkt etabliert und im Sinne der Wiederverwendung die erste Stufe der Kreislaufwirtschaft. Durch billige, importierte Neureifen, die nicht wiederverwendet (=runderneuert) werden können, sind runderneuerte Reifen unter Druck gekommen, was sich in einem sinkenden Marktanteil in den letzten Jahren widerspiegelt.  Hinzu kommt, dass beim PKW-Reifen die Stufe der Wiederverwendung (=Runderneuerung) ungehindert der technischen Machbarkeit mittlerweile meist ausgelassen wird, weshalb die Attraktivität für den Fahrzeugbesitzer gesteigert werden muss und Einmalprodukte beim Neureifen, die nicht runderneuerungsfähig sind, unterbunden werden müssen.  Der Neureifen muss für ein Mehrlebenskonzept ausgelegt werden und technisch eine Runderneuerung ermöglichen. Die Initiative schafft dafür die notwendigen Voraussetzungen!  Neben den in der Initiative angemerkten Ansätzen und Aspekten wird es wichtig sein, auch die relevanten Prüfkriterien bzw. Prüfungen zur Kontrolle der geforderten Produkteigenschaften zu beschreiben sowie sicherzustellen, dass auch die verantwortlichen Prüfstellen benannt und für die Kontrolltätigkeit mit dem entsprechenden Budget ausgestattet werden, um so die volle Wirksamkeit zu erzeugen.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: Afin d’accélérer la transition écologique, il convient de réduire davantage l’impact environnemental lié à l’utilisation des produits. Pour cela, il est possible d’agir sur l’offre des entreprises en produits plus durables et sur la demande des consommateurs. Coupler le nouveau plan d’action pour l’économie circulaire avec la consultation relative à l’autonomie des consommateurs dans la transition verte constitue une approche pertinente.  Plusieurs conditions peuvent conduire à la bonne réussite de cet objectif : - S’inscrire dans le cadre du marché unique européen : c'est une échelle appropriée pour accélérer et amplifier la transition vers des produits plus durables et qui permet une mise en œuvre d’outils harmonisés; des volumes importants; une limitation de la surcharge administrative et les coûts pour les entreprises et le consommateur; une mise en cohérence des dispositifs nationaux; une juste concurrence entre les acteurs grâce à des méthodes de contrôles harmonisées et effectives.  - Optimiser la mise en œuvre des différents outils envisageables afin de les rendre les plus efficaces possible. Pour cela il faut évaluer les impacts des différentes mesures ;  définir les objectifs visés ainsi que les facteurs de réussites (délais, moyens, outils…); identifier les couples mesures/produits les plus adéquats.  - S’appuyer sur les outils existant : étendre le principe de la REP à d’autres familles de produits et à de nouveaux objectifs ; renforcer la modulation des contributions à condition qu’ils laissent toute leur place aux initiatives entre industriels ; travailler sur des critères d’éco-modulation harmonisés ; définir et évaluer la possibilité d'inclure de nouveaux critères de durabilité (réutilisation, réparabilité, recyclabilité, réincorporation de MPR, restriction de certaines substances, …) dans la directive éco-conception ainsi que dans les directives sectorielles (DEEE, VHU, piles et accu…) à condition de définir et d’adapter les critères de durabilité et les objectifs associés en fonction des spécificités des produits et selon une approche cycle de vie. Les critères devront également reposer sur des éléments objectifs, fiables, vérifiables et contrôlables de manière à garantir une possible surveillance du marché et une concurrence saine entre les acteurs. Concernant la présence de substances dangereuses dans les produits, nous souhaitons une approche harmonisée au niveau de l'UE.  En matière de demande, il existe également des outils sur lesquels il faut s’appuyer en priorité (écolabel, étiquette énergie, PEF/OEF…). Ces outils doivent être utilisés et adaptés en fonction des spécificités des produits et de leurs principaux impacts sur l’environnement. Ils doivent s’appuyer sur des méthodologies qui tiennent compte de l’empreinte environnementale des produits, mesurée sur l’ensemble de leur cycle de vie.  Informer le consommateur de l’impact environnemental de sa consommation doit lui permettre d’orienter ses choix, voire dans certains cas, de comparer les produits. Pour cela, l’information des consommateurs doit être : - simple et compréhensible du plus grand nombre ; - fiable et facilement mesurable/vérifiable pour limiter la surcharge administrative et les distorsions de concurrence ; - accessible à l’aide de supports numériques pour ne pas noyer le consommateur en veillant à ce que ces outils n’alourdissement pas de façon disproportionnée la charge administrative des entreprises.  En parallèle, il convient de sensibiliser les consommateurs sur l’impact de leurs comportements (usage raisonné des produits, économie d’énergie, tri des déchets…) et sur le rôle et les limites de l’affichage environnemental des produits.  Enfin, les achats publics constituent un levier important pour accroître la demande en produits durables à condition que les exigences soient adaptées en fonction des familles de produits et de leur pertinence environnementale. feedback_msg_text: BEUC and ANEC support the European Commission’s intention to set up an ambitious EU policy framework that would contribute to achieving climate neutrality by 2050 and agree on the crucial role of Ecodesign to make this happen. It is of foremost importance that sustainable products become the default choice for everyone, as to reduce the use of natural resources, prevent waste production and meet consumers’ needs.  We very much welcome the idea to extend the scope of the Ecodesign Framework Directive to non-energy related products and to reduce the environmental impact of these products throughout their entire life cycle. We also support the introduction of sustainability principles and requirements that go beyond mandatory energy performance standards and address further environmental and social aspects.  The current Ecodesign framework presents a series of shortcomings that need to be addressed in this legislative review. Firstly, not enough product groups and sustainability criteria are covered by the legislation, limiting the potentials of Ecodesign solely to energy-related products. Secondly, the possibility for the industry to adopt voluntary agreements in the context of Ecodesign currently undermines a thorough application of mandatory Ecodesign requirements. Finally, the current legislative process to adopt Ecodesign implementing measures by “package” has proven to be ineffective, as it postponed the adoption of several regulations and hindered their effectiveness and level of ambition.  In order to address these shortcomings and shape the future of Ecodesign at EU level, we would like to make the following suggestions:  - To review the Ecodesign Framework Directive and extend its scope beyond energy-related products, including, textiles, furniture, and ICT products.  - To discuss with the European Commission how horizontal sustainability requirements (e.g. addressing hazardous chemicals and waste disposal) can help in making sustainable consumption the norm and sustainable products the default choice by consumers.  - To systematically consider durability requirements in the Ecodesign implementing measures, rather than focusing solely on strengthening the existing durability requirements currently applicable to a very few product groups. The existing minimum durability and reparability requirements must be extended to all product groups, along with strengthened information requirements related to products’ lifetime, availability and cost of spare parts, and availability of software updates.  - To align the horizontal sustainability requirements under Ecodesign with other European Commission’s initiatives, such as the Ecolabels framework and planned initiatives to empower the consumers for the green transition. The Commission must ensure that the synergies of all product policies and instruments are optimised within a coherent framework. The Ecodesign should be implemented in greater coordination with the Energy labelling, but also with the EU Ecolabel criteria. These criteria are often developed for the same product groups, but their technical preparatory and legislative processes are not well aligned. In the future, we would like to see the EU Ecolabel as a benchmark and those criteria should become mandatory for the whole market in a staged approach and over time (top runner approach).  - To strengthen market surveillance and ensure a uniform and harmonized application of the Ecodesign requirements.  - To put an end to self-regulation under the current Ecodesign Framework Directive, in favour of mandatory requirements. Existing voluntary agreements have often not been timelier in achieving output and implementation compared to regulatory instruments.  - To avoid releasing measures by “package” and rather favour the adoption of implementing regulations individually. This will ensure a faster adoption process and avoid delays, currently undermining the effectiveness of Ecodesign requirements for certain product groups.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: Ceegon fully supports the initiative to have more sustainable products in the EU. Device manufacturers should provide information about reliability and serviceability of the products sold within the EU; without this information, it may prove difficult even for conscious consumers, to make sustainable choices. Products should be designed to be maintained, serviced and repaired to further our efforts in converting into circular economy. In order to reach this goal, these requirements must be taken into account as a part of product creation (and specifically in R&D) process.    In our view, the main points to take into consideration in the context of the initiative are as follows:   • Product specific online data including reliability and serviceability indexes, as well as information about how well spare parts are available should be maintained and kept easily accessible. If this point is adhered to, consumers have the possibility to validate those from web. Further, online stores could add the info to be part of their product specific web pages. This would help consumers to understand what they are purchasing, and hence, the impact their action has;  • Cost or repair, including spare parts and time needed for repair (cost of labour), has to be reasonable compared to buying of a new device. If repairability index includes repair cost averages, this would further help consumers to purchase devices that are repairable for a reasonable cost.   The EU could also consider higher recycling fees, in one form or another, for devices having less than average lifetime. We understand, this would require a heavy follow-up process and pre-determined way how to calculate and assess the average lifetime. However, by implementing this, device manufactures having better product quality and repairability would benefit in comparison to device manufactures with lower product quality.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: Dear Madam or Sir,  VACO, the association for the tyre and wheel industry in the Netherlands, is delighted about the European Commission’s initiative to extent the scope of the Ecodesign Directive. Extending the scope of the Ecodesign Directive to the broadest possible range of products, and beyond energy related products, is an important step in reaching the European Green Deal as well as the European Circular Economy Action Plan.    The goal of the Ecodesign Directive is to reduce the overall life-cycle climate and environmental footprint of the products placed on the EU market. For example, by achieving longer product lifetimes through more durable and reparable products, increasing circular material use rate, reducing waste and achieving higher recycling rates. VACO would like to emphasize the potential contribution of retreaded tyres. Retreading tyres saves a lot of energy as well as natural resources. In the attached infographic you can find more information about the benefits of retreading tyres.  Retreading tyres has a significant environmental impact, as shown by several studies. For example, research conducted by EY (2016), ‘The socio-economic impact of truck tyre retreading in Europe’, concludes that retreading tyres has several advantages: - 70% less depletion of natural resources compared to a low end non-renewable new tyre, - 29% less farmland for the cultivation of rubber trees, - 24% less CO2 emissions, - 21% less air pollution, and  - 19% less water consumption.  Also, retreading a tyre definitely yields a high-quality end product. Retreaded truck and bus tyres are covered by the mandatory European seal of quality, UN-ECE R109, which sets quality requirements for the production process and the casings. This implies among others that companies that retread tyres are periodically audited by authorities and end products are tested.   Thus, retreading tyres is a great example of circular economy and is in line with both the European Green Deal and the European Circular Economy Action plan.   VACO recommends the European Commission to: - (1) Add the production and distribution of tyres to the Sustainable Product Initiative and the revision of the Ecodesign Directive,  - (2) Stimulate the production of retreadable new tyres, and  - (3) Support and/or stimulate the use of retreaded tyres as sustainable products (ECO Label) in EU Green Public.   Arie Verhoef   VACO Dutch association for the tyre and wheel industry Feedback from: VACO - Dutch association for the tyre and wheel industry (272.5 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Organisation: VACO - Dutch association for the tyre and wheel industry
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: We, ALPLA, as a rigid plastic packaging converter, are working on to produce more sustainable packaging. Therefore, we would appreciate EU rules considering carbon and environmental footprint of packaging through its whole life cycle. These criteria need to be equally if not more important than circularity of packaging (reusability, recyclability). For example, reusable packaging possibilities should be investigated, however setting up EU-wide targets related to reusable packaging only might be counterproductive, a target linked to “recyclable or reusable” is preferred. Certain reusable solutions can cause more negative impact for the global warming and environment. This should be assessed case by case e.g. by referring the outcome of LCA. Implementing reuse where logistically possible does not mean it is the best option from environmental and efficiency perspective. Instead of setting up a reusable target, what might make sense as a role of the government is to establish a harmonized (EU wide) guideline describing how to assess the most sustainable packaging solution. This will help businesses assess the environmental, economic, social benefits of selecting a solution.

feedback_msg_text: ANIRP´s Feedback to the “Sustainable Product Initiative” of the European Commission  The ANIRP – Associação Nacional dos Industriais de Recauchutagem de Pneus (The Portuguese Retreading Industry Association) represents the interest of Tyre Retreader’s in Portugal and endorses the initiative of the EU in order to create and develop more sustainable goods, services and business models, reduce waste and stimulate circular economy. We were glad to know about the extension of the Ecodesign Directive within the “European Green Deal”, and in order to widen the range of products it would be valuable that the Tire Product Segment should also be covered within the scope of this extension.  In Portugal, in 2019 were produced 90.160 tons of worn tires, compared with 84.894 tons in 2018, a rising trend within the last years (ETRMA – ELT EU Data 2018)*. Retreading of TBR products (Truck and Bus Tires) actually represents a 30% market share of the aftermarket in Europe, having Portugal a retreading index around 15%.  However, this market share has been decreasing in the last 10 years due to the use of cheap and low-quality new tyres, what negatively impacts the availability of quality casings to be retreaded, as these tyres are mainly not designed to have multiple life performances.   Discard a worn tire without retreading it is to lose most of its value, as most of its value is in the tire body or casing. The tread (the portion of the tire that meets the road) represents only a percentage of the new tire cost (around 20%). Not retreading a tire also affects negatively the amount of waste produced and a loss of important resources.  According to the Ernst&Young 2016 Report (The Socio-Economic Impact of Truck Tyre Retreading in Europe – The Circular Economy of Tyres in danger**), the new tyre – retreaded tyre combination reduces the use of raw materials by 70% compared to a non-retreadable low-end tyre, besides 29% of land use, 24% in CO2 emissions, 21% in Air Pollution and 19% in Water Consumption. Accordingly, retreading is an example of how to enhance Circular Economy in Tire Product Segment. In our opinion the efforts and initiatives under the Sustainable Products Initiative should contemplate: • The “re-use” of ELT’s (End of Life Tyres) including Tyre Product Segment in this Initiative to avoid one-single use; • Encouraging Tyre Producers to produce retreadable and repairable new tyres for multi life performances; • Support Retreaded Tyres as a Green Product in EU Public procurement.  The Retreading Industry fits for a climate-neutral, resource-efficient and circular economy industry, reducing waste and ensuring the performance and safety compared to a new tyre.  José Gomes President of ANIRP  Sources:  * https://www.etrma.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Copy-of-ELT-Data-2018-002.pdf ** https://www.etrma.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/201611-ey_retreading_lr.pdf Feedback from: ANIRP (43.2 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The Sustainable Products Initiative is an important step on the way towards strengthening environmental, human and workers rights in global supply chains. The European Union is a big and developed market to ask supplying industries to deliver on much important ecological and social innovation in the delivery of their products. Public procurement has been shown to be an important mechanism to facilitate a strong impact for both environmental as well as social improvements. Public procurement can be fundamentally supportive to work toward correcting the discussed market failures by driving internalising of full cost and pushing for better supply chain transparency. However, for public procurement to deploy its full strength activities need to go beyond selection and award criteria and scoring during the tendering process. Public procurement needs to be developed into a modern dialogue and process oriented mechanism that works with suppliers and supply chains by setting strategic goals to communicate long-term development areas, using independent monitoring to understand compliance with set standards and engagement with supply chains to remediate on found risks and violations.  Only if pre-tender market engagement and contract management supplier development and engagement become the norm, will policy strategies and regulatory tools be implemented in their full strength on the ground. Public procurement has the capacity to work with suppliers and supply chains over long periods – the entire duration of a 2 to 5 years supply contract or framework agreement – providing the time scales that are necessary to work towards change and remediation, monitor how it is being implemented on the ground and feed results into next steps of engagement. One of the main point thus would be to establish the mandatory use of environmental and social criteria in public procurement. This would help both procurers and the market as expectations would be clearly set. Such a regulatory change would need to be flanked by resources to develop appropriate training capacities for public buyers as well as to enlarge procurement departments to be able to develop and implement such criteria. Transparency is a central requirement for public procurement. To be able to establish subject matter of the contract and exercise its power through set contractual obligations public buyers need to know much more and supplier have to become much swifter to provide data on factory locations, used and stored chemicals, etc. in a much higher quality.  Independent monitoring is a central tool for public procurement to be able to understand what the situation in their supply chains are and how well contractual obligations are being complied to. The highest quality data is derived from local civil society organisations that do monitoring for public buyers. This way industry independence is made possible and thus objectivity of data is ensured. Initiatives like Electronics Watch, with over 330 affiliates (public buyers from all over Europe), are showing how the integration of public buyers, contractual obligations, local civil society based monitoring and industry engagement is facilitating large scale improvements. The European Union should strive to facilitate the development of similar initiatives in sectors beyond electronics and support scaling up of existent initiatives. The Initiative should aim at finally abolishing the delineation between ecological and social goals. With areas like occupational health and safety the overlap of just and fair working conditions with lower environmental impact becomes quite evident as one realizes that every toxin endangering the environment fist endangers the workers’ bodies.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: ANIMEE totally agrees with the CEMEP position to this consultation, dated 9th October (ANIMEE is the Portuguese member of CEMEP).  Further, we want to add the following remarks:  - The measures that are planned will make the products more expensive. It is essential to think about this aspect, since the first purchase may have a value so high that it will be inaccessible to many consumers. That is why the idea of buying a service, instead of buying a product can be positive. But, in that case,  the legislations has to consider also this type of business.... can the  Ecodesign Directive do this?  - We want to stress the importance of an effective market surveillance (as CEMEP already did). This is already a great problem, that it may growth enormously if there are no measures and budget to enforce it;  - critical raw materials have to be reused. This is very important, because they are not common in Europe and they are valuable and indispensable items, mainly in the electric and in the electronic sector.
Organisation: ANIMEE - Associação Portuguesa das Empresas do Sector Elétrico e Electrónico
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: The actions for reducing waste, CO2, energy and raw materials is not a responsibility of individual countries but a common topic of concern and improvement. Finnish Tyre Specialists, Autonrengasliitto r.y. (ARL) supports an initiative to include pneumatic tyres in the list of products of sustainable design, production, application and end of life strategy. Retreaded tyres have been around as long as new ones, but they have been not considered with seriousness of ultimate green product. Retreaded tyre offers an example of class 1 environmental product as product is being returned to original service with equal or even better performance.  What is the option we have here? To fill the market with non-retreadable, cheap import tyres? Retread industry has been seriously hurt in last decade by cheap imports, that are not retreadable, wasting material and creating transport pollution globally. Retread companies are mainly SME´s and labour intensive. Companies are located close to enduser customers offering transport reductions together with significant material savings by reusing the worn out, retreadable quality casing. As retreaded tyres offer a quality product with equal or better performance compared to new one, it should definitely be included in this initiative. Unfortunately, what is missing is a common political guidance to support this European home industry. Some countries are more advanced, asking vehicles governed by state having a retread policy. Therefore, retreading quality casings again, is most cost efficient, simpliest and most sensible example of circular economy.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: BIPAVER (Bureau International Permanent des Associates de Vendeurs et Rechapeurs de pneumatiques, The European Retread Manufacturers Association) fully supports the initiative of the European Commission to increase sustainability of products in designs, production, application and end of life strategy. However, BIPAVER would like to raise the EC’s attention to an important and constantly growing “product segment”, used in private, public and commercial transport/traffic: Tyres.  Whereas the main point of interest in relation to tyres so far has been tyre/road wear in our opinion the efforts and initiatives should also consider the aspect of “re-use” of ELTs (End of Life Tyres). The last figures of ERTMA* about the volume of ELT arising in 2018 (EU 28 Countries) indicate approx. 3,15 Mio. tonnes with a constant yearly growth of about 4% over the last years. The absolute majority of these tyres are used “one-off”, meaning the have been only one time in use/application before they enter the different recycling channels. Taking into account that only approx. 20% of the overall tyre material (known as “tread”) has been worn/used and that the most energy and resource consuming part of tyre (known as tyre “casing”) remains, it is easy to imagine how many “waste” could be avoided by “re-using” the worn tyres by “retreading” the casing (replacing the worn tread by a new one).  E.g. an average truck tyre has a total weight of approx. 70 kg, between 15 and 22 kg of tread material are used/worn during application. Approx. 50 kg of high-quality rubber and steel components are left that could be re-used in the retreading process under the condition that the tyre construction is designed for a multiple life performance. In some segments of application even multiple retreading cycles are possible (e.g. aircraft tyres are often retreaded more than 5 times).  At the moment “retreading” is represented in the TBR (truck and bus tyres) segment by a worth mentioning market share of around 30% in the aftermarket in Europe. Even this retreading segment decreased in market share by nearly 10% over the last 10 years due to the use of cheap new tyres. As effect the scrap tyre volumes were rising and the prices for tyre disposal nearly doubled. To illustrate the gains of using a quality retreaded TBR tyre instead of a non-retreadable low quality new TBR tyre the Ernst&Young report** “The socia-economic impact of truck tyre retreading in Europe” highlights savings of • 70% in Resource Extraction (avoided need for tyre casing) • 29% in Land Use (avoid need of Hevea growing area [as resource for natural rubber NR]) • 24% in CO2 Emissions • 21% in Air Pollution and • 19% in Water Consumption.  Therefore, BIPAVER requests the European Commission to • integrate the Tyre segment into the Sustainable Product Initiative • animate Tyre Producers under the “Extended Producer Responsibility” program to produce retreadable and repairable new tyres (ready for multiple life application) • support the use of retreaded tyres as “green” product (ECO Label) in EU Green Public procurement (GPP) • award fleets/users using retreaded tyres by bonus schemes or “CO2 – Emission- Certificates” to reduce their “carbon footprint” • support the (mainly SME structured) Retreading Industry by considering retreaded tyres consequently as alternative to new tyre in Type Approval and general EU/UN-ECE regulations.  The Tyre Retreading Industry is prepared and able to demonstrate and prove that retreaded tyres are capable to deliver comparable performance and safety properties to new tyres to provide a substantial contribution the Circular Economy and Sustainability in the tyre segment. Therefore, the awareness and support of politics and society is a crucial matter to premise to exploit this immense potential as part of the Europe’s “Green Deal” strategy!
