feedback_msg_text: CEMEP welcomes the initiative to further develop the sustainable products policy and strongly encourages a common European approach to this important field. The Ecodesign Directive has served as a useful tool for increasing energy efficiency for energy related products and this could be further developed to support material efficiency and other product groups as well, while it is in the same time also important to reflect the short-comings of the Ecodesign Directive when it comes to a systems perspective. CEMEP remains convinced that there is still a significant, untapped potential for energy savings at the system level and also for material efficiency through better sizing of the system components.  When developing the regulatory framework for a sustainable product policy, CEMEP recommends considering that industries are different and there is no one-size-fits-all solution for a circular economy. Business-to-business industries have different market conditions from consumer product manufacturers, and therefore implementation should be done sectorial, with involvement of the sector stakeholders.  To balance the tradeoffs between material efficiency and energy efficiency and between durability and recyclability, future initiatives should be based on a “least life cycle cost” principle with focus on the measures that result in the most sustainable use of resources. As an example: For some products, reparability is useful for extending the lifetime; for other, smaller products, a focus on design for durability would be more important.  Any new regulation should be enforceable, and it is important to ensure both effective market surveillance and the tools for assessing the compliance. European harmonized standards is a strong tool to support European legislation and based on the newly developed horizontal CEN-CENELEC standards for material efficiency, the appropriate product-group specific standards should be developed to provide sector-specific measures.
Initiative: Sustainable products initiative

feedback_msg_text: Context - We strongly support that this legislation needs to give effect to the EU Green Deal. References to the EU 8th Environment Action Programme and the EU CAP and EU F2F Strategy should be included.  Problem definition – Ecosystem degradation is highlighted but its extent is underplayed. The scale of the problem, the urgency with which it needs to be tackled, the need for large scale investment and ownership of the problem by sectors, including agriculture, need more emphasis. Evaluation of the EU BDS2020 show no progress in achieving Target 3A – increase the contribution of agriculture to biodiversity recovery. The lack of a dedicated fund for biodiversity and the failure to reorient agriculture incentives in the CAP to the delivery of public goods is a significant part of the problem.   Objectives and Policy Options - The Road Map cites the general objective to restore degraded ecosystems and the twin aims of ensuring sustainable use and improving knowledge and monitoring. We support the need for legislation to achieve this. Systematic, standardised and frequent field monitoring of biodiversity outcomes is essential to check effectiveness of implementation and needs to be both required and financed. Citizen science monitoring schemes like the eBMS butterfly monitoring scheme can make a good contribution and offer excellent VFM. Better management of existing Protected Areas is also essential.  The new EU Ecosystem Restoration legislation needs to place binding commitments that ensure significant increases, across the farmed landscape (as well as in urban, peri urban, freshwater and marine areas), in biodiversity recovery, ecosystem health and ecosystem services, including pollination services (particularly from recovery of diverse and robust populations of wild pollinators and their habitats). Quality habitat creation eg in urban areas can also contribute.  Quantified targets are needed which deliver increases in habitat extent; more connectivity at landscape scale; improvements in ecological quality; and ensure recovery of species diversity and abundance. Some redundancy is needed to ensure resilience to future shocks, including climate change and increased storminess.   The lack of time bound management obligations in relation to Habitats Directive species and habitats needs to be remedied.  Listed, specialist butterflies and most of the semi natural listed grassland habitats they depend on are in unfavourable – inadequate or bad conservation status and many are still declining. Monitoring also demonstrates serious declines in widespread butterfly species, particularly those dependant on semi natural grassland. Reductions in pressures from intensive agriculture practices and reversal of abandonment of extensive grazing and mowing regimes need to be targeted. Other pollinator species, like wild bumble bees, solitary bees and hoverflies are not listed on the Habitats Directive so protection and targets for recovery of wild pollinators and their habitats, need to be added, through the new legislation.  Assessment of Impacts – this needs to acknowledge the contribution of nature and more resilient ecosystems to the reduction in risk of future human disease pandemics.  Evidence Base – this also needs to take account of the impact of the CAP on biodiversity and Reports by the EU Court of Auditors.  Implementation – an Implementation Plan, including allocated funding, will be essential.   More detailed advice regarding the proposed legislation is set out in the EHF Paper attached.
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: The primary objective of the legal instrument should be to reverse biodiversity loss, resulting in the large-scale restoration of ecosystem functioning, connectivity and resilience.  It is important to stop the ongoing fragmentation of river and stream ecosystems by building new dams. We need legal help to avoid further dam building and deterioration. The removal of dams should be led by biodiversity criteria and should include larger rivers. Legal restoration objectives should help to protect and restore rivers and streams as dynamic and free-flowing lifelines in the landscape. The restoration law should help to establish the green-blue infrastructure along our rivers, along the network of streams and along the coast. The connectivity must be in a broad area along the rivers, e.g. for the Danube as a main green-blue infrastructure for Europe it should be 20 kms. The biodiversity corridors for the Danube and its tributaries should be clearly supported by the restoration law.  The legally binding restoration targets should be formulated as a clear and quantifiable area-based target to restore 15% of the EU’s land and sea area by 2030 as well as a target to restore 15% of rivers into free flowing.   It is also important to put weight and emergency action on critically endangered species. Among them are many migrating fish species like sturgeons and the European eel, measures must be backed quite soon. There are a lot of threatened and endemic species which need help. The European Sturgeon Action Plan must be implemented to save several critically endangered sturgeon species.  Besides the losses of freshwater habitats and species the most grassland and many open land habitats and species are massively in decline. We need to have a focus on protecting a wide range of grassland species, plants, birds, insects, fungi. They must be saved not only from too intensive agriculture but also from planting trees and afforestation, e.g. for restoration or climate protection in grassland and open land habitats.  Restoration must regard to protect and keep old-grown habitats and native species at first to have a pool of species for more ambitious restoration targets. Cities and settlements have to keep green and bio-diverse areas and lawns, reducing the steady growth of buildings and settlement. Botanical gardens at regional levels and micro-reserves to save species are important, they can also help to include local people, foster participation and show to the public what is at stake.  Obligations stemming from the legal instrument setting restoration targets must be different and additional to obligations stemming from the existing directives (the Nature Directives, WFD, MSFD) and should cover areas both within and outside the Natura 2000 network.  We need strong efforts of stock-taking and  monitoring species, taxa, habitats. For this it is also necessary to support biodiversity, species and habitat knowledge in education, not only in school, reverse the trend of decline.  We support the common postion of many European environmental NGOs which is attached. Feedback from: Danube Environmental Forum (194.8 KB - PDF - 9 pages) Download
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: Wir bedanken uns für die Möglichkeit der Stellungnahme zu diesem Entwurf, dessen Analyse wir teilen. Wir können die darin formulierte Dringlichkeit konsequenten, ambitionierten und vor allem legal verbindlichen Handelns nur unterstreichen! Von der Europäischen Politik erwarten wir, dass sie ressortübergreifend in all ihren Entscheidungen den Erhalt der Artenvielfalt und den Umweltschutz mitdenkt. Sie sollten ein vorrangiger, integraler Bestandteil aller Aktivitäten der EU werden.  Naheliegende Hebel sind aktuell z.B. die GAP, das Mercosur-Abkommen, die EU-Industriestrategie bzw. Corona-Hilfen. Darüber hinaus sollten innovative Visionen und nachhaltige Konzepte durch verbindliche Gesetze, wie z.B. die in der Farm-to-Fork formulierte Pestizidreduktion unterstützt und ihnen zur raschen Anwendung verholfen werden.  Unsere Vision ist ein starker Naturschutz mit einem weiten Netzwerk großer effektiver Schutzgebiete; die Renaturierung von Wäldern, Flüssen (Staudammrückbau!) und Feuchtgebieten (Moorwiedervernässung!); Verbot des Torfabbaus und -vertriebs sowie von Rodungen in Urwäldern; Aufklärung, Sensibilisierung, Umweltbildung als Schulpflichtfach und die Umsetzung von Naturschutzmaßnahmen unter Beteiligung der Bevölkerung. Wir erwarten vor allem eine gezielte Politik zur schnellen Ökologisierung der Landwirtschaft. Dazu gehören die Förderung der Transformation, erleichterte Öko-Zertifizierungsvorschriften für familiäre Betriebe, Unterstützung zur Produktveredlung und Abbau bürokratischer Hürden, lokale Absatzmärkte sowie die Bindung von Fördergeldern an Naturschutzmaßnahmen. Wir sehen in einer guten Regionalentwicklung mit Schwerpunkt auf natur- und sozialverträgliche Kreisläufe, Energieautarkie und der Gemeinwohlförderung den wichtigsten Schritt zur Begrenzung des Ressourcenverbrauchs und der Naturzerstörung. Mutige Maßnahmen wären die Entsiegelung von Flächen zum Pflanzen von Bäumen oder dem Anlegen von Gemüsebeeten, verbunden mit Anreizen zum eigenen Gärtnern. Es wird Ihnen an Ideen und Konzepten nicht fehlen. Wir wünschen Ihnen viel Erfolg, auf dass Sie gemeinsam mit allen europäischen Institutionen und Mitgliedsländern eine lebenswerte Zukunft gestalten!
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: As the European and Central Asian chapter of the Global Youth Biodiversity Network (GYBN Europe+), we welcome the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2030 and especially the EU Nature Restoration Plan and the commitment to push for a principle of equality in the Post-2020 Global Biodiversity Framework of the CBD.  GYBN Europe+ acknowledges all the work done before us and fully supports all the points in the Position Paper, “Restoring EU’s nature”, which can be read in the attachment. We are especially supportive of the recommendation to “The restoration law should explicitly include obligations for Member States to actively engage the public” (Restoring EU’s nature, page 9).   Public participation should always include young people as a major stakeholder  Youth participation in the dialogues, decision-making and actions to tackle the environmental, societal and financial challenges, is necessary to determine whether the planetary conditions that have benefited humanity for thousands of years, will exist beyond this century. As we are entering the United Nations Decade on Ecosystem Restoration, GYBN Europe+ firmly recommends that youth involvement should be mainstreamed across all sectors and levels through different initiatives including but not limited to participation of national youth organizations in the planning process and specifically engaging local youth groups in implementation, monitoring and review efforts of restoration plans.  The youth are quick to spot the deficiencies and are in a position to hold society accountable for its promises. If the EU wishes to overturn a history of unkept promises in the environmental field, Member States should be required to grant young people access to decision-making processes. These young stakeholders can be faster to mobilise and renounce any governmental neglect compared to the EU accountability processes - however both actions are equally important and should work together to mutually reinforce their efforts.   Young people are not just willing to talk the talk but also walk the talk.  Young people’s participation in decision-making processes should not be limited to inviting them to voice their opinions, but should also allow them to claim roles in the implementation, monitoring and reporting phases that many well-intended biodiversity policies and frameworks have struggled with.   Young professionals can actively contribute to these phases, if accessible tools, grants, capacity-building and mentorship programs, which do not restrict youth autonomy or include bureaucratic hurdles, are established. Lastly, it is also crucial that the spaces created for youth engagement are also accessible to all youth, considering the different degrees of understanding, interest and access to information.  Nature is more resilient and productive with high levels of biodiversity: the environmental sector would benefit from the inclusion of a more diverse range of perspectives. Internships and entry level environmental jobs should be fairly compensated as well as inclusive and accessible for all, especially for young professionals and those from marginalised groups or low-income backgrounds. Ecosystem restoration should be a viable career for anyone and can be a great tool for combating youth unemployment and the rural exodus. NBSAPS and a possible new EU regulation should lay out how governments seek to increase the opportunity for youth employment in conservation and restoration activities, including quantitative targets.  GYBN Europe+ commitment  to support restoration GYBN Europe+ is committed to providing future generations with the best fighting chance for a resilient, equitable and sustainable world. Therefore, we pledge our support in the robust and fair implementation of the EU Nature Restoration Plan as a necessary step to address the drivers of the climate and biodiversity crises and assist nature in restoring healthy ecosystems that can nurture people’s health and livelihoods.  Feedback from: Global Youth Biodiversity Network Europe+ (191.3 KB - PDF - 9 pages) Download
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: We welcome EU Biodiversity Strategy 2030. EUBS2030 can be a powerful framework to halt the decline in biodiversity and contribute to the wellbeing of European citizens. So far, BS2030 has shown political ambition to avoid repeating past errors. We consider that any success of this agenda heavily depends on increasing the extent and quality of ecological restoration (ER), supported by adequate enforcement and financing mechanisms.   Effective ER aims at enhancing biodiversity and ecosystem functions and services by assisting and hastening natural recovery towards resilient ecosystems. The success of an EU Restoration Plan must be based on a comprehensive approach integrating multiple knowledge and framed by adaptive management.   We advocate for:  1. High quality ER  • by fostering sustainable collaboration networks between scientists, practitioners and policy makers. • by adopting standards of good practices. • by using native species and local genotypes.  • by implementing active and passive restoration measures as appropriate. • by improving the environmental quality in nature areas and reducing fragmentation. • by ensuring the long-term sustainability of ER investments. • by increasing efforts for monitoring restoration outcomes.  2. Sufficiently ambitious targets  • per MS +30% of land and sea effectively protected, +15% restored or in the process.  • +25.000 km of free-flowing rivers, scaled-up to achieve 15% of rivers restored to free-flowing state in 2030. • by adopting quantitative targets for CO2 sinks through expansion and restoration of natural ecosystems, in addition to 2030 emissions reduction target. • by increasing green infrastructure and restoring farmland biodiversity on +10% of each farm.  3. Increased political, societal and sectorial support  • by raising awareness on benefits of ecological restoration, including job creation and health. • by raising awareness on the need for transformative change in agricultural, energy and transport and tourism. • by emphasizing that a sustainable economy and biodiversity cannot be uncoupled.  4. Drastically increased funding  • by drastically increasing the available budget for LIFE projects. • by making EU sectorial subsidies dependent on efforts for protection, ER and environmental quality. • by allowing COVID19 recovery and climate funds to be used to support EUBS2030. • by unlocking funds from DG RTD to foster collaboration networks.  5. Stronger enforcement  • by increasing infringement procedures for non-compliance of MS with environmental Directives. • by developing the EU Restoration Law, with ambitious and enforceable objectives, and national restoration plans. • by aligning objectives and actions of the EU Climate law, the Farm to Fork strategy for sustainable agriculture, the EU Green Deal strategies with EUBS2030 challenges and actions.  6. Global EU leadership by example  • by globally promoting ER as a solution for tackling the climate and biodiversity crisis and their connection to prosperity and sustainability. • by collaborating with developing countries. We are convinced that these measures would contribute to protect European biodiversity and respond to climate change while fostering the growth of an emerging economic sector and contributing to the European Business for Biodiversity Movement. Our networks are available to assist in further developments at EU and MS level to plan ecological restoration, to integrate it into land-use planning, to prioritize actions, to implement evaluation programs, to find cost-effective solutions and to engage with stakeholders.  Proposed and revised by the Boards of:  Society for Ecological Restoration Europe European Federation of Soil and Water Bioengineering Centro Ibérico de Restauración Fluvial Réseau d’Échanges et de Valorisation en Écologie de la Restauration RE-Asociación Española de Ecología Terrestre Portuguese Ecological Restoration Network-Sociedade Portuguesa de Ecologia  (see extended version attached) Feedback from: Society for Ecological Restoration Europe (159.5 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: Fundacja „Fidelis Siluas” (Wierni Lasom) Ochrona przyrody w tym lasów, szczególnie lasów naturalnych, w tym szczególnie ochrona tworzenia się naturalnych zalesień jest zupełnie podstawowym i priorytetowym działaniem na rzecz strategii.  W Polsce całkowicie zarzucono ochronę środowiska naturalnego, powierzając ochronę lasów ogromnej i wpływowej korporacji „Lasy Państwowe”, której ponad 98% wpływów pochodzi z wycinki drzew. To mniej więcej tak, jak powierzyć ochronę mienia złodziejowi. Strategia powinna przede wszystkim narzucić istotną zmianę prawną mającą  za cel zwiększanie obszarów lasów naturalnych i lasów z drzewostanem starym, z zachowaniem i ochroną naturalnego charakteru. To właśnie takie lasy są najlepszą ochroną wody i bioróżnorodności. Tak się w Polsce nie dzieje. Korporacja rządowa „Lasy Państwowe” w istocie zarządza jak królestwem blisko 1/3 powierzchni Polski, całkowicie poza kontrolą. Jest organizacją korupcjogenną, której ponad połowę przychodów przepada w ogromnym mechanizmie biurokratycznym. Stykamy się z taką sytuacją walcząc o Trójmiejski Park Krajobrazowy, który z lasu naturalnego, za sprawą „Lasów Państwowych” stopniowo zamieniany jest na obszary monokultury, w dodatku niezgodnej z siedliskiem. Spada w istotny sposób ilość starodrzewu, w dodatku wycinany jest młody drzewostan. To wyjątkowy obszar, bo jest cennym lasem przy dużej aglomeracji. Spełnia ogromne zadanie dla ochrony wody, ochrony przed nawałnicami i co najważniejsze, to wspaniały teren rekreacji. Z tego powodu proponujemy jako fundacja „Fidelis Siluas” ufundowanie trzystopniowej nagrody dla miast, które w sposób szczególny (według wypracowanych standardów) działają na rzecz ochrony przyrody, głównie lasów ze wskazaniem na zwiększanie miejsca rozwoju naturalnej przyrody, zamiast ciągle wygrywającego z przyrodą betonowania. Można bowiem pogodzić rozwój miast naturalną przyrodą. W żadnym wypadku zarządca obszarów leśnych i przyrodniczych nie może czerpać zysku z ich unicestwiania, w przeciwnym razie sytuacja będzie tak zła, jak ma to miejsce w Polsce. Brunon Wołosz
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: Die Wirtschaft unterstützt das Ziel, die biologische Vielfalt zu schützen, zu fördern sowie ihre Bestandteile nachhaltig zu nutzen. Klare Zielsetzungen, Maßnahmen mit (wirtschaftlichen) Augenmaß, kohärente Instrumente und eine zuverlässige, langfristig angelegte Entwicklung eines regulatorischen Rahmens sind Voraussetzung für die Sicherung der Wettbewerbsfähigkeit und des europäischen Wirtschaftsstandortes. Zahlreiche Faktoren beeinflussen den Verlust von Biodiversität. Wichtig ist daher vor allem die Verzahnung der Ziele des Biodiversitätsschutzes mit den unterschiedlichen Politikfeldern des europäischen Grünen Deals. Dabei müssen die wirtschaftlichen Belange – im Sinne nachhaltigen Abwägung –berücksichtigt werden. Unterschiedliche Begrifflichkeiten und Doppelregulierungen sowie sich widersprechende Maßnahmen sind zu vermeiden. Maßnahmen, welche die Erreichung der Ziele des EGD konterkarieren, sind auch für den nachhaltigen Erhalt der Biodiversität zu hinterfragen.  Wirtschaftliche Tätigkeiten in der Fläche haben oft einen wesentlichen Einfluss auf Arten und Lebensräume. Die Qualität der Datengrundlage für eine zielgenaue Beurteilung der Situation in den unterschiedlichen Ökosystemen ist jedoch genauso oft lückenhaft. Während das Ziel der Erhaltung und Wiederherstellung der Natur jedenfalls zu begrüßen ist, ist der Weg dorthin derzeit unklar und wird auch durch die vorliegende Roadmap wenig erhellt. In einer Kulturlandschaft, wie sie in Europa vorherrschend ist, ist die naturschutzrelevante Aufgabe nicht die vermeintliche Wiederherstellung eines „natürlichen Urzustandes“, da viele „ursprüngliche“ Ökosysteme in ihrem Erhalt schon seit Jahrhunderten auf eine Bewirtschaftung durch den Menschen angewiesen sind. Daher ist die relevante Frage nicht, wie eine Kulturlandschaft geschützt werden soll, sondern wie und mit welchem Ergebnis sie bewirtschaftet wird. Eine bloße Forderung nach einer „Wiederherstellung der Natur“ bzw. Renaturierung greift deshalb zu kurz. Die Maßnahmen und Instrumente sind dabei auch sorgfältig auf ihre Auswirkungen auf wirtschaftliche Tätigkeiten und die Wettbewerbsfähigkeit der Wirtschaft zu prüfen. Der von der EU-Kommission vorgeschlagene Wettbewerbsfähigkeitscheck bildet hierfür eine akzeptable Grundlage. Auswirkungen auf die Wettbewerbsfähigkeit Europas sollten bereits bei der Festlegung der politischen Ziele und nicht erst bei deren Umsetzung in Form von Legislativvorschlägen und politischen Initiativen betrachtet werden.  Viele der Ziele dieser Roadmap und des Wiederherstellungsplans für die Natur könnten erreicht werden, wenn die bestehenden Mechanismen überarbeitet und in Folge konsequent und transparent umgesetzt werden. Die EU verfügt bereits über einen breiten Rechtsrahmen, Strategien und Aktionspläne zum Schutz der Natur und zur Wiederherstellung von Lebensräumen und Arten. Darum sollte die europäische Politik unter Wahrung der bestehenden Standards im Naturschutz auch darauf achten, dass bereits bestehende Vorschriften mit vertretbarem Aufwand in die betriebliche Praxis integriert werden können. Das bestätigte auch der Fitness-Check der EU-Naturschutzrichtlinien und der EU-Aktionsplan für Menschen, Natur und Wirtschaft. Darauf sollte aufgebaut werden. Die Wirtschaft ist beim Schutz und der nachhaltigen Nutzung der biologischen Vielfalt ein wichtiger Akteur und sie ist sich der wachsenden Anforderungen bewusst. Daher sollten partnerschaftliche Lösungen angestrebt werden, die den Schutz der Biodiversität und die Sicherung des Wirtschaftsstandortes Europa gemeinsam festhalten. Nur von Landbewirtschaftern und Grundbesitzern proaktiv mitgetragene Biodiversitätsmaßnahmen werden nachhaltigen Erfolg für die Zukunft bringen können, das belegen jahrelange Erfahrungen. Die Wirtschaft ist bereit, gemeinsam an Schritten für Verbesserungen der Biodiversität zu arbeiten und einen Interessenausgleich aller Betroffenen zu erreichen.
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: How Responsibly Produced Peat can contribute to restoration targets  Foundation Responsibly Produced Peat (RPP) is aware that intact peatlands are unique ecosystems and contribute to conservation of biodiversity. We believe that responsible peat production can contribute to restoration targets for degraded peatlands. This is explained in our feedback below:  RPP, officially established in 2013, developed a certification standard in the European region for peatland selection and management, during and after peat production for horticultural purpose.  Peatlands are unique and important habitats, worth being protected. At the same time, for horticulture, peat products are an important constituent for growing media The aim of the certification is to ensure that peat is extracted only from sources without high natural value and to ensure the future availability of sufficient quantities of high-quality peat for horticulture.  The main Principles are to leave High Conservation Values untouched but stimulate peat production from degraded peatland, and to secure the best possible use of the area after peat production (after-use). A very important aspect for RPP is the multistakeholder involvement; peat industry as well as environmental NGOs and scientists are represented in the Board and the Committee of Experts of the organisation.  Full stakeholder consultation is also required by the RPP-scheme for the selection of a peat production location and the after-use destination. RPP ensures that areas with a high conservation value (HCV) are identified and conserved, an environmental impact assessment (EIA) is part of the in the requirements. In areas that are severely drained and as a consequence highly degraded, biodiversity is low and peat is producing harmful CO2. RPP recommends extraction in these areas but not without implementing an after-use plan to turn production fields into areas with a positive ecological impact. The after-use plan should always demonstrate the best possible option in perspective of maximising environmental benefits, including climate mitigation.  Stakeholder consultation, including local authorities, NGOs and local communities, is an important part in this process.   Why do growers need peat for their growing media? Professional growing of vegetables and ornamentals is capital intensive and competitive. Growers need the most reliable materials for their crops, including growing media. Peat is an almost indispensable raw material for growing media because of a combination of physical, chemical and biological characteristics. Peat offers a stable structure for roots and does not decompose during the period of cultivation. The required conditions are maintained over the entire growing period, even up to years. Further peat is largely free from pests, diseases and weeds. With peat as basis, it  becomes possible to use renewable and circular raw materials, possibly with less favourable properties.  Market research by WUR (Wageningen University & Rearch), commissioned by IPS (International Peatland Society), shows that the demand for growing media is expected to quadruple in the next thirty years. The share of peat is declining relatively, due to the combined use of alternative materials, but due to the strong growth of the total market, the volume of peat required is expected to double.  The RPP-standard obliges companies to plan an appropriate after-use. Companies have the knowledge, machinery and resources to implement the after-use plan. This offers the perspective for co-operation between authorities and industry in carrying out rewetting and restoration on a very large scale.  The organisation RPP is backed by international soil scientists and NGOs such as Wetlands International and the Estonian Fund for Nature.   Secretariat RPP, Maureen Kuenen and Hein Boon

feedback_msg_text: BirdLife Cyprus welcomes the initiative for binding restoration targets and recommends the following: A. Aspects guiding the next steps 1. With this restoration initiative, the Commission should focus on binding nature restoration targets. 2. The mentioned possibility of an EU wide methodology to map and assess ecosystems and their delivery on soil, pollination etc. should be addressed with specific initiatives such as the soil strategy or the follow-up to the Biodiversity Strategy (10% biodiverse landscape features, 50% pesticides reduction).  3. Given the time needed for the legislative process with the Co-legislators and implementation in the Member States, the Commission should speed-up the process, to not only propose the law in Q4 2021 but earlier. 4. The Commission should assess putting forward the new legislation as Regulation, given that this saves transposition time. A Regulation often also leads to short, clear and thus enforceable legislation. B. Suggestions for the future restoration legislation I. Objectives 1. As the main objective, the law must contribute to halting and reversing biodiversity loss, resulting in the large-scale (nature) restoration of habitats, species and ecosystem functioning, connectivity and resilience at landscape level across the EU.  2. In order to be of added value, the new legislation must explicitly go beyond what is already required by the Habitats Directive and other EU legislation. Therefore, the new legislation cannot merely add a deadline to already existing requirements in protected areas.  3. The new legislation should put a specific focus on biodiverse ecosystems with significant carbon storage and sequestration potential. Contributing to climate change mitigation and adaptation should hence be the supportive (but not primary) objective.  II. Restoration targets The binding EU targets for nature restoration on land and sea should be expressed in quantitative and similar terms for each Member State (i.e. without effort sharing). EU-wide, the targets should be to restore by 2030: 1. at least 650.000 km2 of land and at least 1.000.000 km2 of sea (15% of the EU land and sea area, sea area to be adapted to EU27 EEZ). 2. at least 25.000 km of free flowing rivers, and to scale-up this ambition to achieve 15% of rivers restored to a free-flowing state in 2030 through inter alia barrier removal and floodplain restoration; 3. and should include a target for CO2 removal by sinks, in addition to the 2030 emissions reduction target. III. Restoration criteria 1. Restoration measures should result in permanent change aiming to restore high quality and resilient nature, with a very significant improvement from the starting condition. 2. Restoration measures must result in significant management change that puts nature on a path towards sustaining ‘high quality’.  3. Action on restoration should not discriminate between restoration activities inside or outside already protected areas.  4. Restoration measures should also increase connectivity between habitats. IV. Governance aspects 1. The new legislation should require Member States to draft national restoration plans. The plans should include clear quantitative targets in terms of locations, areas, types of ecosystems to be restored, financial tools to be used, requirements for active public participation, deadlines etc. 2. Restoration plans should be assessed by the Commission to ensure that the proposed measures contribute to the objectives of the restoration law. 3. The restoration law should explicitly include obligations for Member States to actively engage the public at the start of and throughout the restoration plan process. 4. To be effective, the restoration law must contain clear deadlines regarding the establishment of the restoration plans and the implementation of all restoration measures. 5. The restoration law further needs to include safeguards to ensure the restoration and protection of the restored habitats is permanent Feedback from: BirdLife Cyprus (191.3 KB - PDF - 9 pages) Download
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: Holmen welcomes a discussion of the need for nature restoration. Holmen’s own experience from 400 years of forest management in Sweden is that focus should be on nature conservation management activities rather than on amount of land set a side. By more effective conservation management in protected areas, securing biodiversity goals, we will at the same time enable an effective and sustainable forest management in other areas, for circular bioeconomy purposes.  Holmen is a circular bioeconomy company and our core business contributes to a better climate. Our experience is that biodiversity is mainly benefited by the way we manage our forests and protected areas, not by the amount of forest we refrain from managing. Our climate report tells us that our products that we produce from the wood from our forests contributes more to EUs climate objectives then our forests themselves.   Our aim to ensure the sustainable use of ecosystems, and to improve knowledge and monitoring will thereby be important parts of the roadmap.  Regarding the objective to restore degraded ecosystems with the most potential to capture and store carbon, primary and old-growth forests are pointed out. In this context, Holmen wishes to stress that science-based widely accepted definitions of these two concepts still is lacking. It would therefore not be appropriate to include the concepts in any suggestions for objectives. Furthermore, in relation to capturing and storing carbon, it must be reinforced that old trees does not capture carbon as well as younger forests. Instead, the most effective way to mitigate climate change is to increase forest growth and to use the biomass to produce wood-based products which can substitute fossil-based materials and energy. feedback_msg_text: The Norwegian Biodiversity Network Sabima is a Norwegian NGO working to halt the loss of biodiversity. In light of the IPBES’ 2019 Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services, and the IPCC report on Climate Change and Land, both revealing dangerous nature decline, Sabima strongly supports and applauds EU’s ambition to reverse biodiversity loss and to take a lead by example and action. Sabima also supports freshwater ecosystems as a focal area of the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2030.   European nature has been hit hard throughout the industrial revolution and the mechanisation of agriculture as well as by industrial forestry, urbanization and other polluting or land degrading activities. To set legally binding nature restoration targets to restore degraded ecosystems in the EU is therefore important and a very good starting point for reversing biodiversity loss. We support the idea to develop an EU-wide methodology for mapping and assessing ecosystems, in order to restore them, and thereby reinstate their ability to provide ecosystem services such as pollination, water regulation, soil health, climate regulation and disaster prevention.  As few states dare implement stronger environmental goals than their trading partners for fear of an un-level playing field for their industry, which probably explains why the voluntary targets as tried out in the 2011 strategy for 2020 was not successful, we fully support intervention at EU level. We believe such intervention is justified in view of the scale and transboundary nature of biodiversity-related issues, including the pressures on ecosystems.  As neither the Birds Directive nor the Habitat Directive are included in the EEA agreement, these directives are not transposed into Norwegian law. But, we wish to emphasize that the EEA agreement does include the EU Water Framework Directive, which means that the elements of the Biodiversity Strategy affecting freshwater ecosystems, free-flowing rivers, wetlands and coastal waters will apply to Norway. Thus demanding that Norway develops legally binding biodiversity restoration plans for the ecosystems covered by the EU Water Framework Directive.   Sabima agrees that greater efforts are needed to restore freshwater ecosystems and the natural functions of rivers, in order to achieve the objectives of the Water Framework Directive. It is mentioned that this can be done by removing or adjusting barriers that prevent the passage of migrating fish and improving the flow of water and sediments. The restoration of floodplains and wetlands will also be important to reach the goals of the Water Framework Directive. We also believe it would be important to link and integrate the work on restoring fresh water ecosystems and coastal waters to the development of River Basin Management Plans (RBMPs) and the work in the River Basins.   The Norwegian government is currently developing a strategy for river and watercourse restoration for the period 2021-2030. The aim of the strategy will be to contribute to fulfilling the goals of the EU Water Framework Directive in terms of restoring waterbodies whose ecological status otherwise will not meet the environmental objectives. Another aim of this national strategy is to secure that all authorities concerned contribute and do their share of the work, emphasizing cooperation and coordination as means of achieving more restoration. The national strategy will most likely have no legal status in it self, which we believe will be a weakness and we strongly believe in linking the strategy to legally cross-sectoral binding restoration targets for the ecosystems covered by the Water Framework Directive, as would be the result of the proposed Biodiversity Strategy. The Biodiversity Strategy will be an important tool in overcoming the current fragmentation between nature protection and water management.  (For our full feedback - see the attached pdf)

feedback_msg_text: Les allées d'arbres - arbres plantés en alignements le long des chemins, des routes, des rues et des canaux - contribuent à la préservation de la biodiversité. Les habitats sont ceux de lisières, avec en outre des arbres anciens: ceux-ci ayant par ailleurs une vocation sociale - embellissement -, ils ne sont pas récoltés comme en forêt, et restent plus longtemps en place. La stabilité de la structure depuis des dizaines et plus généralement des centaines d'années (stabilité de la voie) concourt à la richesse de ces habitats. Les allées constituent par ailleurs des corridors écologiques et permettent le franchissement des voies (notamment en hauteur au -dessus des voitures, par les houppiers). Ce rôle a été observé dans des milieux très différents et pour des arbres qui sembleraient 'de prime abord peu intéressants. Par conséquent, il est essentiel d'empêcher au maximum les abattages de ces arbres - obligation d'un principe de protection - et de recréer le maillage supprimé au cours de la deuxième moitié du 20ème siècle. feedback_msg_text: he initiative to develop EU nature restoration targets is laudable as the restoration of forests and other ecosystems in the EU will have a wide range of positive effects. As recognized in the Note, the first step towards restoration is to reduce the pressures causing biodiversity degradation. While biodiversity restoration can be supported through, often expensive, measures like introducing native species, these will have limited effect as long as the pressures that cause further degradation are not addressed. Reducing pressures to allow ecosystems to recover by themselves is not only a far more cost efficient approach to restoration, it also produces more resilient, long-term results. For many centuries European forests have been degraded due to, in particular, bioenergy production, conversion into agricultural land, or contamination by agrochemicals. Yet, they still have a significant potential for natural restoration, provided these pressures are dramatically reduced. Cynically, two of the biggest pressures on European forests and other ecosystems are actively supported by the EU through perverse incentives schemes: Bioenergy production, which continues to be supported through the Renewable Energy Directive, and the Common Agricultural Policy. While it was hoped 2020 would see significant policy change with the adoption of the Green Deal, the Farm to Fork Strategy and the EU Biodiversity Strategy, these voluntary strategies will remain paper tigers as long as these subsidy schemes are not aligned with them.  The draft CAP proposal that was adopted by the EU Council and Parliament in October is broadly recognized to be inadequate to achieve the goals of the above-mentioned strategies. It fails to address the  impacts of agrochemicals and nitrogen dispositions on European biodiversity, including forest soils and undergrowth (https://edepot.wur.nl/17981). By subsidizing farmers to keep land under production it also prevents such lands to regenerate into nature. Only a firm rejection of the current proposal would allow the EU’s ecosystems to recover.  The EU’s support schemes for bioenergy are highly controversial and strongly opposed by a large and growing number of environmental organizations and scientific institutions as they are harmful for both climate change and forest biodiversity. Both the IPCC and IPBES have expressed strong cautions about the risks of large-scale bioenergy production. The EU should also eliminate all financial and policy support for commercial logging and tree plantations. The so-called substitution argument that is used by the forestry sector to promote these activities is disputed by recent science (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-77527-8). Commercial logging should be strictly prohibited in all remaining old-growth forests, ICCAs (Indigenous Peoples and community conserved territories and areas) and Natura2000 areas. Such bans should be properly enforced. Forest biodiversity in Europe has also been harmed by EU support schemes for monoculture tree plantations in, for example, Spain, which are often planted on lands that were in process of natural regeneration. Nature restoration targets should include an ambitious target to convert the millions of hectares of European tree plantations back into natural forests. This can be done gradually by altering the management regime and allowing native species to grow back, or by harvesting the plantations and allow the area to naturally regenerate.  There also needs to be a target promoting rights-based, gender-responsive community conservation and restoration initiatives, including ICCAs, , which have proven to be socially and environmentally sustainable. Without addressing these obstacles to restoration, nature restoration targets will only provide evidence of the incoherence of EU policy-making. The EU does not need another set of empty targets, they first and foremost need an EU commitment to stop financing further destruction. feedback_msg_text: The new restoration law must be targeted, to avoid past failures in reaching targets, and include concrete actions leading to large-scale restoration across the EU. It is important that it builds on existing definitions to ensure rapid adoption and implementation as well as coherence. The new law should not undermine or duplicate existing EU Directives including restoration requirements but complement them. It should go beyond what is required in the Habitats, Birds, Water Framework and Marine Strategy Framework Directives. The law must create synergies between the biodiversity and the climate crises agendas by putting a specific focus on those ecosystems with high carbon storage potential.   The main objectives of the new law must be aligned to the 2030 Biodiversity Strategy. Most importantly, the law must contribute to halting and reverting biodiversity loss, resulting in the restoration of habitats, species and ecosystem functioning, connectivity, and resilience at a landscape level across the EU. The legally binding EU targets for nature restoration on land and sea should be expressed in quantitative and similar terms for each Member State. Regarding concrete restoration measures and criteria, significant improvements should be made which would be measured against specific targets for each ecosystem. The end goal of ‘high-quality nature’ would require further elaboration and definitions efforts to reduce habitat fragmentation and increase connectivity. Clearer indicators of monitoring and measuring restoration outcomes should be defined building upon the existing Directives. Emphasis must also be placed on a significant management change in the landscape/ seascape to avoid greenwashing. Short term targets can focus on that as longer term ones would take longer due to the length of ecological processes. Action on restoration should not discriminate between restoration activities inside or outside already protected areas. The restoration law should ensure that targets are additional to already existing targets under the Habitats Directive etc. Ecosystem connectivity is to be increased for more ecological coherence of mobile species. Restoration measures should specifically encourage interventions that restore natural processes, including the different methods of restoration for different ecosystems. Finally, the value of protection as an essential part of restoration needs to be recognised. Concerning governance, the law should require MSs to draft science-based national restoration plans including quantitative targets in terms of locations, types of ecosystems, and financial tools. The Commission should assess the national restoration plans to ensure that proposed measures contribute to the objectives of the law. The law should explicitly obligate MS to actively engage the public throughout all stages of the restoration plan process . In this context, youth involvement should be mainstreamed by including national youth organizations in the planning process and specifically engaging local youth groups in implementing and monitoring efforts. National Plans should also lay out how governments seek to increase the opportunity for youth employment in conservation and restoration activities, including quantitative targets. The establishment of national youth restoration stewards in MS is encouraged to coordinate youth engagement in restoration. Clear deadlines regarding the establishment of the restoration plans and the implementation of restoration measures must be contained in the restoration law. Finally, it needs to include safeguards to ensure permanent restoration and protection of restored habitats. In terms of funding, the law should create an EU obligation to co-fund effective restoration like Art.8 of the Habitats Directive. There should further be specific grants to support youth-led projects or those involving youth, and to provide training opportunities for grassroots restoration projects.
Submitted by: Biodiversity Working Group Generation Climate Europe GCE
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: The Swedish Society for Nature Conservation’s (SSNC) response to the nature restoration law.  SSNC is a member-based organization and Sweden’s largest environmental organization. SSNC works with issues ranging from climate and energy to chemicals, oceans, agriculture, forests, and biodiversity.  We welcome the proposal to set legally binding nature restoration targets and would like to highlight the following;   •Biodiversity is declining rapidly and it is crucial to put in place binding nature restoration targets as soon as possible. The legislation needs to be targeted and result in large-scale nature restoration across the EU.   •The new legislation must be ambitious  and harmonize with existing EU environmental legislation, aiming to protect or restore ecosystems such as the Birds and Habitats Directives, the Water Framework Directive, the Floods Directive, and the Marine Strategy Framework Directive.   •As primary objective, the law must aim to halt and reverse biodiversity loss. As supportive objective the new legislation should put focus on ecosystems that can provide synergies between climate mitigation and adaptation by storing or sequestering carbon.  EU-wide, the targets should be: 1. to restore by 2030 at least 15 % of the EU land and sea area, sea area to be adapted to EU27 EEZ;  2. to restore by 2030 at least 15% of the rivers into free flowing through inter alia barrier removal and, floodplain restoration;  3. to include a target for CO2 removal by sinks, in addition to the 2030 emissions reduction target.  For detailed recommendations on the approaches that should be taken we direct the EC to the joint NGO position paper on the nature restoration law, please see attached file. feedback_msg_text: In der EU- EU-Biodiversitätsstrategie ist das Ziel formuliert, 3 Mrd. Bäume bis 2030 zu pflanzen.  Seit der Wiedervereinigung setzen sich der BUND für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland e.V. (BUND) mit großem Engagement gemeinsam mit anderen Umweltverbänden und ehrenamtlichen Umweltschützern für den Erhalt von Alleen und Baumreihen als Teil der grünen Infrastruktur ein. Seit 2012 arbeiten wir auch in LIFE+ -Projekten mit unseren polnischen Projektpartnern und mit verschiedenen Partnern aus anderen europäischen Ländern zusammen.  Wir möchten erreichen, dass die „grüne Infrastruktur“ in der EU-Biodiversitätsstrategie ein größeres Gewicht bekommt. Wir möchten dort Bäume pflanzen, wo Biodiversität durch Infrastrukturentwicklung verloren ging und immer weiter verloren geht. Wir fordern das Pflanzen von Bäumen entlang der Straßen, Wasserwege, Eisenbahnen und zwischen den Feldern (Hecken) zu intensivieren.  In der EU-Biodiversitätsstrategie 2030 ist das Pflanzen von 3 Mrd. Bäumen vorgesehen. Dabei wird das Ziel, Verbesserung der grünen Infrastruktur, zwar erwähnt, nicht erwähnt wird jedoch ein Ziel, Strukturen, die historisch durch das Pflanzen von Bäumen geschaffen wurden, wie Alleen und Hecken, zu erhalten und neu anzupflanzen. Im Moment werden Bäume nur mit Wäldern in Verbindung gebracht. Die Pflanzung von Wäldern wird aber nicht alle Probleme lösen, auch nicht die Erhaltung der Artenvielfalt.  Wir möchten, dass mindestens 1 Mrd. Bäume der grünen Infrastruktur zugutekommen. Die EU-Biodiversitätsstrategie sollte als Start für ein europaweites Programm zur Wiederbelebung von Alleen genutzt werden. Diese Bäume dienen sowohl als Lebensraum als auch als ökologischer Korridor in ländlichen und städtischen Gebieten. Alte Bäume, besonders wertvoll für die biologischer Vielfalt, haben in Alleen und als Einzelbäume bessere Überlebenschancen als in Wäldern, die für die Holzwirtschaft genutzt werden. Die Nutzung von Synergien zwischen den grünen, grauen und blauen Infrastrukturen maximiert den Nutzen, den die Bäume für die Klimaanpassung, die Abschwächung des Klimawandels und die Erhaltung der biologischen Vielfalt bieten.  Die Modernisierung von Straßen hat zum Absterben vieler Alleebäume geführt. Das zeigt sich in ganz Europa, besonders aber auch in Deutschland, dessen zwei Teile jahrzehntelang unter verschiedenen Regimen standen. Vergleicht man das ehemalige Westdeutschland mit dem ehemaligen Ostdeutschland, in dem das Alleenerbe lange Zeit erhalten blieb, wird die verheerende Wirkung früherer Entwicklungspolitik deutlich: Obwohl der Westen 2,5-mal größer ist, gibt es fast fünfmal weniger baumbestandene Straßen als im Osten Deutschlands (5.200 km gegenüber 23.000 km). In Frankreich hat das Departement Seine-et-Marne heute weniger als ein Zehntel (17.500) der Bäume, die Ende des 19 hier die Straßen säumten, und dass, obwohl gerade hier sehr auf die Erhaltung des Erbes geachtet wird.  Die Fällung von Straßenbäumen, die Vernichtung ganzer Alleen, geht unter dem Druck des Straßenausbaus und überhöhter Erwartungen an die Verkehrssicherheit weiter. Die Formulierung des Ziels, 1 Mio. Bäume entlang der grauen und blauen Infrastruktur zu pflanzen, wäre ein immenser Beitrag zur Rettung der Artenvielfalt, zum Erhalt von historischen wertvollen Landschaftselementen und der Verbesserung des allgemeinen Wohlbefinden der Menschen.
Organisation: Bund für Umwelt und Naturschutzschutz Deutschland (BUND e.V.) Landesverband Mecklenburg-Vorpommern

feedback_msg_text: Nous déplorons que les efforts réalisés au cours des dernières années par les pêcheurs européens pour améliorer l’état des stocks des poissons qu’ils capturent et pour assurer le bon état écologique des espèces et habitats communautaires d’intérêt patrimonial, ne soient pas pleinement reconnus par la Commission. Ce qui prévaut ailleurs dans le monde ne nous semblent pas nécessairement valoir pour les flottes de pêche européennes.   La Commission justifie ses propositions (stratégie biodiversité 2030) par le constat d’une diminution de la biomasse des populations marines et de leur diversité sans précédent, et d’une surexploitation générale de ces ressources. Nous ne pouvons que rappeler, pour ce qui concerne les stocks de poissons gérés par l’Union dans l’Atlantique Nord-est que les quantités de poissons présents en mer se sont accrues de 50% en seulement dix ans et que la surpêche s’est parallèlement considérablement réduite. Ces progrès ont été obtenus grâce à de nombreuses années de sacrifices et à une collaboration étroite des professionnels avec les scientifiques, les pouvoirs publics et les parties prenantes.   Il est également surprenant que la Commission propose parallèlement (1) une stratégie « De la ferme à la table » qui vise à une évaluation d’ici à 2022 de la manière dont la PCP doit faire face aux risques liés au changement climatique et participe à la souveraineté alimentaire et (2) un plan d’action qui d’ici 2021 qui viserait à préserver les ressources halieutiques en ramenant notamment la mortalité par pêche à des niveaux correspondant à un niveau inférieur au RMD. Ces deux propositions prises ensemble reviendraient à réduire de potentiels volumes de captures à un niveau inférieur au niveau recommandé par les scientifiques et donc à augmenter les importations sur lesquelles nous comptons déjà pour plus de 60 % de notre consommation de produits de la mer et dont les pays d’origine ne présentent pas nécessairement les mêmes normes sociales et/ou environnementales. Recommander d’exploiter à ce niveaux n’est donc pas justifié, sauf à assumer de vouloir réduire considérablement le volume de la production halieutique communautaire, mettre à mal les économies côtières, et finalement faire dépendre l’approvisionnement européen plus encore de sources extérieures et des importations.  Nous tenons de manière générale, sinon, que les aires marines protégées ne constituent pas une solution à la lutte contre la surexploitation des populations de poissons là où elle existe, et qu’elles font rarement sens lorsqu’elles visent à protéger la diversité biologique de la colonne d’eau, comme les premiers retours d’expérience le montrent, car celle-ci ne s’inscrit pas dans des frontières établies. Nous continuons donc de penser que la fixation d’objectifs chiffrés de surface d’aires marines à instaurer, qui ignore la nécessité d’une analyse des risques avérés au cas par cas, ne répond à aucune démarche rationnelle, ni utile.   Si pour certains les AMP constituent à elles seules d’enrayer une perte de diversité biologique, il n’en demeure pas moins que les scientifiques et les décideurs auront à expliquer ce qu'ils ont l'intention de protéger, comment et pourquoi. Par cohérence, la stratégie biodiversité de l’UE ne devrait également pas venir réduire la productivité des flottes de pêche européennes en réduisant les surfaces des eaux accessibles aux activités de pêche ou en interdisant systématiquement certaines pratiques sans justifications.   Les armateurs à la pêche de France restent néanmoins soucieux que des mesures efficaces mais proportionnées puissent être mises en œuvre aux niveaux communautaire et international pour protéger la biodiversité biologique. L’économie bleue de l’UE devrait pour cela jouer un rôle fondamental pour assurer le maintien d’une exploitation durable des ressources marines tout en respectant des normes élevées en matière d’environnement, de qualité, de sécurité sociale et de traçabilité.
Organisation: UNION DES ARMATEURS A LA PECHE DE FRANCE
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the initiative which hopefully leads to improvement of the status of biodiversity and quality and quantity of ecosystems as well is good example of action for other regions outside EU.  However, it should be noted that specific measures must also be set so that EU's various policies and measures (e.g. Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), infrastructure projects) and funding mechanisms do not counter the goals of the EU's 2030 Biodiversity Strategy. A negative example in this aspect is drainage of wetlands and peatlands via support of either EU or national subsidies (e.g. CAP measures) which has led to deterioration of qualities of water bodies, enhanced carbon emissions and loss of biodiversity. In addition, it should be analysed whether a Member State should lose part of its EU funding if its actions counter to the Biodiversity Strategy. On the other hand, as sanctions are already planned under this initiative it may be perhaps too harsh an approach.  It should be also noted that granting permission for habitat destruction in one place and restoring them in another location does not justify these actions as this leads to further degradation of ecosystems as a whole.  Consortium of EU LIFE funded project  “Conservation and Restoration of Mire Habitats” (project no: LIFE14 NAT/EE/000126).

feedback_msg_text: As part of nature restoration efforts, trees should be planted on road verges, canal and river banks, dikes and dams, where technically possible, and properly cared for. Preservation of existing trees should be required in procedures for road construction projects. Excessive traffic safety concerns should not be allowed to overrule the climate, biodiversity, and landscape benefits of roadside trees.  Tree avenues are an important green infrastructure, contributing to climate change adaptation and biodiversity in Europe’s rural areas. They constitute important ecological corridors and habitats for protected species. Europe lost millions of these trees due to road upgrade and modernisation of agriculture. Tree avenues are also an important element of Europe’s cultural landscape and monuments of civil engineering.  The EU call for planting 3 billion additional trees cannot be implemented  in forests and on marginal agricultural land only (not enough planting space). As part of nature restoration efforts, trees should be planted on road verges, canal and river banks, dikes and dams, urban streets - where technically feasible. Preservation of existing trees should be required in procedures for road construction projects. Climate, biodiversity, and landscape benefits of trees should be considered when planning for infrastructure development.   JUSTIFICATION  In the largely deforested Europe, important ecosystem services are provided by trees outside forests  - the key part of green infrastructure in both urban and rural areas. They are crucial for climate change mitigation and adaptation. Urban trees make life in cities possible and those in rural landscapes protect agricultural production from drought, wind, and flooding. Trees support preservation of biological diversity serving as both habitats and ecological corridors in rural and urban areas. Green infrastructure composed of trees, permeating man-made landscapes of Europe, not only connects biodiversity hotspots, it is the hotspot of biodiversity. In these environments, ancient trees rich  in biodiversity have better chance to survive than in forests managed for timber, hence also carbon store is kept longer. Using synergies between the green, grey and blue infrastructures maximises  the benefits the trees offer for climate adaptation, mitigation, and biodiversity conservation.   Modernisation of roads has spelled the demise of many avenue trees. This phenomenon is most acutely illustrated by Germany, whose two parts for decades remained under different regimes. Comparing the former West Germany with the former East Germany, where the avenue heritage was preserved for a long period, provides a striking illustration of the devastating effects of previous development policies: even though the West is 2.5 times larger, its tree-lined roads cover nearly five times less distance than those in the East (5,200 km compared with 23,000 km). In France,  the department of Seine-et-Marne, even though it is one of the most aware of its heritage, now has less than one tenth (17,500) of the number of trees planted along its roads in the late 19th century (200,000). Annihilation of roadside trees continues under pressure from road development  and excessive traffic safety expectations.   Planting 3 billion additional trees in Europe is not possible in the framework of forest management and afforestation sectors. Foresters replant the logged sites anyway, as part of good forestry practices. Most of agricultural land stays stably under cultivation due to CAP measures. Majority of marginal, abandoned, or degraded lands have already been covered by forests, largely due to EU-supported measures. We also need to keep in mind, that of ca. 10 000 trees planted on 1 ha of a clearcut  or reforestation area, only ca. 300 survives to maturity. This means, of 3 billion trees planted as forest, only 90 thousand will live.
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: Ecologistas en Acción, a spanish nertwork of environmental activists, member of EEB among other umbrella groups, supports the commitment by the European Commission to propose legal instrument setting binding EU nature restoration targets. This action has the political backing from both the Council and the European Parliament and considering that the previous voluntary target to restore ecosystems has not been met, a legislative approach is needed. Other EU initiatives, including the reformed Common Agricultural Policy and implementation of the Farm to Fork Strategy, should also support nature restoration across the EU in addition to the action under the new legal instrument. Please see the attached paper prepared by the EEB and the European Habitat Forum for detailed recommendations. The comments below summarise answers to the questions included in the inception impact assessment.  OBJECTIVES: The primary objective of the legal instrument should be to reverse biodiversity loss, resulting in the large-scale restoration of ecosystem functioning, connectivity and resilience. As the supportive objective, the restoration law should contribute to climate change mitigation and adaptation.  BROAD ECOSYSTEM COVERAGE & URGENT ACTION: We support the general objective of the initiative to restore ecosystems with the most potential to capture and store carbon and to prevent and reduce the impact of natural and human-made disasters. A quantifiable area- based target with additional qualitative criteria can provide this broad coverage while also enabling the timely implementation of the targets. The requirement for Member States to draft plans by a clear deadline can also contribute to the speedy implementation as it ensures that all relevant aspects have been considered from the start and sets out a clear trajectory for implementation.  FORMULATION OF THE TARGETS: The legally binding restoration targets should be formulated as a clear and quantifiable area-based target to restore 15% of the EU’s land and sea area by 2030 as well as a target to restore 15% of rivers into free flowing. Member States should be required to draft restoration plans in which they set restoration measures covering a diverse range of ecosystems within their territory.  MONITORING AND REPORTING PROGRESS: Monitoring and indicators for progress should build upon existing definitions and monitoring requirements under the existing EU environmental legislation. Obligations stemming from the legal instrument setting restoration targets must be different and additional to obligations stemming from the existing directives (the Nature Directives, WFD, MSFD) and should cover areas both within and outside the Natura 2000 network.  STEP-WISE APPROACH: We welcome the policy option of a combined approach with a focused restoration law, followed by a broader ecosystem initiative.  NO DETERIORATION AFTER RESTORATION: Long-term protection and improvement of the restored habitats needs to be ensured and should contribute to reaching other EU targets on e.g. new protected areas.  GUIDANCE AND FINANCE: The legal instrument should create an EU obligation to co-fund effective restoration as well as require Member States to match their restoration plans with an investment plan from both EU, national and private funding sources.  METHODOLOGY TO MAP, ASSESS AND ACHIEVE GOOD CONDITION OF ECOSYSTEMS: While such an EU-wide methodology has the potential to improve the condition of all ecosystems across the EU, this will be a significant task that should be carried out in addition, rather than through, the legal instrument setting legally binding restoration targets. To make significant progress in turning the tide of biodiversity loss by 2030, the restoration targets should be focused, quick and easy to implement and should lead to large-scale restoration to ‘high- quality nature’ on 15% of the EU’s land and sea area, instead of aiming for incremental improvements in all ecosystems.
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: SPEA welcomes the initiative for binding restoration targets and recommends the following: A. Aspects guiding the next steps 1. With this restoration initiative, the Commission should focus on binding nature restoration targets. 2. The also mentioned possibility of an EU wide methodology to map and assess ecosystems and their delivery on soil, pollination etc. should be addressed with specific initiatives such as the soil strategy or the follow-up to the Biodiversity Strategy (10% biodiverse landscape features, 50% pesticides reduction).  3. Given the time needed for the legislative process with the Co-legislators and implementation in the Member States, the Commission should speed-up the process, to not only propose the law in Q4 2021 but earlier. 4. The Commission should assess putting forward the new legislation as Regulation, given that this saves transposition time. A Regulation often also leads to short, clear and thus enforceable legislation.  B. Suggestions for the future restoration legislation I. Objectives 1. As the main objective, the law must contribute to halting and reversing biodiversity loss, resulting in the large-scale (nature) restoration of habitats, species and ecosystem functioning, connectivity and resilience at landscape level across the EU.  2. In order to be of added value, the new legislation must explicitly go beyond what is already required by the Habitats Directive and other EU legislation. Therefore, the new legislation cannot merely add a deadline to already existing requirements in protected areas.  3. The new legislation should put a specific focus on biodiverse ecosystems with significant carbon storage and sequestration potential. Contributing to climate change mitigation and adaptation should hence be the supportive (but not primary) objective.   II. Restoration targets The binding EU targets for nature restoration on land and sea should be expressed in quantitative and similar terms for each Member State (i.e. without effort sharing). EU-wide, the targets should be to restore by 2030: 1. at least 650.000 km2 of land and at least 1.000.000 km2 of sea (15% of the EU land and sea area, sea area to be adapted to EU27 EEZ). 2. at least 25.000 km of free flowing rivers, and to scale-up this ambition to achieve 15% of rivers restored to a free-flowing state in 2030 through inter alia barrier removal and floodplain restoration; 3. and should include a target for CO2 removal by sinks, in addition to the 2030 emissions reduction target.  III. Restoration criteria 1. Restoration measures should result in permanent change aiming to restore high quality and resilient nature, with a very significant improvement from the starting condition. 2. Restoration measures must result in significant management change that puts nature on a path towards sustaining ‘high quality’.  3. Action on restoration should not discriminate between restoration activities inside or outside already protected areas.  4. Restoration measures should also increase connectivity between habitats.  IV. Governance aspects 1. The new legislation should require Member States to draft national restoration plans. The plans should include clear quantitative targets in terms of locations, areas, types of ecosystems to be restored, financial tools to be used, requirements for active public participation, deadlines etc. 2. Restoration plans should be assessed by the Commission to ensure that the proposed measures contribute to the objectives of the restoration law. 3. The restoration law should explicitly include obligations for Member States to actively engage the public at the start of and throughout the restoration plan process. 4. To be effective, the restoration law must contain clear deadlines regarding the establishment of the restoration plans and the implementation of all restoration measures. 5. The restoration law further needs to include safeguards to ensure the restoration and protection of the restored habitats is permanent. feedback_msg_text: The initiative to facilitate restoration of habitats and species is urgently needed. However, I have a couple of suggestions to add:  1) I miss a stronger emphasis on grassland ecosystems. Species living in pastureland and meadows are highly threatened and the changes in agricultural land-use (intensification, abandonment) drive these to extinction. Therefore, restoration of traditional grazing regimes should be an important target. 2) Peat bogs are probably the most important habitats in terms of carbon storage, but they are extremely difficult to restore. Nevertheless, it would be useful to name these habitats more specifically - and ideally ban peat mining.  3) I also would add a target to restore populations of threatened species using the European Red List as guidance, e.g. trying to restore all Critically Endangered species to a viable status. 4) The targets should be SMART (i.e. specific, measurable, achievable, realistic, time-bound).
Initiative: Protecting biodiversity: nature restoration targets under EU biodiversity strategy

feedback_msg_text: Zero Waste Alliance Ireland (ZWAI), established in 1999, is a Non-Government Environmental Organisation (eNGO). ZWAI has prepared and submitted to the Irish Government and to State Agencies many policy documents on waste management, and continues to lobby Government on the issue of using resources more sustainably,  and on the implementation of the Circular Economy.   The goal of Zero Waste, or environmentally sustainable materials management, requires as a basic principle, that human communities must behave like natural ones, living comfortably within the natural flow of energy from the sun and plants, producing no wastes which cannot be recycled back into the earth’s systems, and guided by new economic values which are in harmony with personal and ecological values.   The Zero Waste approach states that the only long-term sustainable solution is to completely eliminate the production of materials which cannot be re-used, recycled or naturally biodegraded.  This will result not only in a saving of scarce resources, but will re-adjust our relationship to the earth’s material assets from a linear to a cyclical one, enhancing our ability to live sustainably while reducing environmental damage.   The EU Inception Impact Assessment, Section B, Aspect 2, asks whether additional sectors or activities should be included in the E- PRTR in order to improve data capture on industrial releases/transfers.  Our response is that all industrial-scale agricultural activities should be included, together with emissions or releases from municipal wastewater treatment plants, as the latter should be considered as sources of pollutants with significant environmental and public health effects. The PRTR should also capture data on toxic pollutants in widely marketed products; shops selling such products should be required to submit an annual return.  Section B, Aspect 3, asks whether additional pollutants should be included. Our response is that pharmaceutical substances, residues of such substances (e.g., partial breakdown or decomposition products), agricultural and horticultural chemicals, and releases of micro-plastics and nano-plastics in wastewater should be included; these are of recent and increasing concern, especially as some of these substances pass through municipal wastewater treatment plants, are found in rivers and lakes, and in drinking water supplies (e.g., glyphosate in drinking water in Ireland; nano-plastics in water).  Section B, Aspect 4, asks about access to information and participation in decision making.  Our response is that the format of the existing PRTR reporting is not easy to understand, and difficult to read; and therefore the way in which information is presented should be improved to provide a clearer format, so as to make it more accessible to EU citizens without the benefit of scientific training.  Even though the Aarhus Convention theoretically provides for participation in decision making, there is a lack of clarity about public participation in decisions which may result in changes in the release of pollutants, especially the release or emission of pollutants of recent and increasing concern, such as those we have mentioned in our response to Aspect 3 above.  Section B, Aspect 5, asks about reporting modalities.  Our response is that current data on diffuse emissions and on pollutants of concern in widely distributed or marketed products are inadequate, and these data should be reported as part of the PRTR.  For example, agricultural chemicals enter water from diffuse sources; while many products contain pollutants which are released when these products are flushed into municipal wastewater collection systems.  In response to Section B, Aspect 6, ZWAI firmly believes that the PRTR must contribute to the circular economy and to the aim of zero pollution.  The PRTR should mandate the recovery of dissolved N and P in wastewater as vital components of the circular economy, instead of currently being wasted.
