feedback_msg_text: Inception Impact Assessments on Cross-border purchases of alcohol and tobacco  Response from Alkoholpolitiskt forum in Sweden  It is quite clear from extensive research that the level of per capita consumption of alcohol in a nation is associated with alcohol related social and medical harm. It is furthermore clear that the economic and physical availability of alcohol has a huge impact on consumption.   The Inception Impact Assessment correctly identifies alcohol as a significant contributor to cancer. In Sweden alcohol has been estimated to cause five per cent of all cancer fatalities, or 996 cases in 2016. Most of the mortality caused of alcohol is due to other causes however, such as cardiovascular disease, liver disease and trauma.    Prior to Sweden's EU membership travel allowances for alcohol were one litre of spirits, one litre of wine and two litres of beer. When Sweden became a member of EU the free flow of alcohol for own consumption that followed lead to a significant increase in alcohol consumption in Sweden. This was a serious blow to the public health based alcohol policies that had prevailed up until then in Sweden.   Present EU regulations provides is no restrictions to the amount of alcohol you may bring in from another EU country, as long as it is for your personal use or for your family´s use. There are indicative levels that can be applied to determine whether the importation is for personal or commercial use but these levels are very generous and allow for very high consumption. Furthermore, you may bring in larger quantities if you plan a celebration (e.g. a wedding or birthday celebration) where you will be serving alcohol.   From a public health point of view the pre-membership travel allowances would be preferable. Second best would be to apply the logic behind the prevailing cigarettes allowances. This amounts to 2000 cigarettes, which is what many smokers consume in a 100 days. Using this as a guide for alcohol travel allowances would result in one litre of spirits, two litres of fortified wine, ten litres of table wine and fifteen litres of beer.   It is the view of Alkoholpolitiskt forum that such a reduction of travel allowances would be of huge value both to public health and for the reduction of criminal imports and distribution of alcohol.
Initiative: Alcohol & tobacco bought abroad – review of tax rules

feedback_msg_text: ESTA believes that article 32 of Directive 2008/118/EC currently serves its purpose, giving Member States the flexibility and the legal clarity they need to ensure efficient implementation, ensuring that goods that are not meant to be used for personal consumption are taxed appropriately.  Article 32 and current arrangements were discussed at length during the recast of the Directive just a year ago and were already further clarified by the European Commission. Instead of ensuring proper implementation, a new proposal restricting the free movement of goods is now suggested. This Inception Impact Assessment confuses cross-border purchases by individuals for their own consumption, driven by budgetary and affordability constraints, as is their rights within the Union, with organised excise fraud and the illicit tobacco market. As the external study referred to in this Inception Impact Assessment establishes, approximately 0,20% of all EU tobacco consumption is purchased across borders in quantities exceeding current guide levels, which is far less than what illicit tobacco accounts for, especially in those Member States where cross-border purchases are deemed to be a problem. Their citizens exercising their rights, therefore, are not fuelling illicit trade.   The inception impact assessment also suggests that economic operators and relevant stakeholders were consulted in the process of the Public Consultation and while the external study was being conducted. This has not been the case, as representatives of the tobacco industry were excluded from any discussion or consultation relating to Article 32.   A more detailed feedback, including ESTA’s views and comments on the statements made in this Inception Impact Assessment is attached. feedback_msg_text: CEEV abstract contribution. The full contribution is in the file attached.  1 ABOUT CEEV  Comité Européen des Entreprises Vins (CEEV) represents the EU wine companies in the industry and trade. It brings together 23 national organisations from 12 EU MS, plus Switzerland and Ukraine, as well as a consortium of 4 leading European wine companies.  2 KEY MESSAGES Please find hereunder CEEV feedback of the public consultation based on the information presented by the European Commission in the inception impact assessment. CEEV is supportive of the status quo with a better enforcement of current legislation without changes in the guide levels.  The promotion of awareness campaigns could contribute to reduce the risk of fraud. CEEV believes in the importance of ensuring the good functioning of the single market (free movement of goods principle and the principle of non-discrimination) In relation to health concerns focus should be put of harmful use of alcohol and not on consumption per se.   3 SPECIFIC COMMENTS  • Risk of fraud o Better enforcement of existing legislation CEEV acknowledges that there are some situations of fraud, as regards acquisition by private individuals’ arrangements. A minority of people might purchase excise goods in another Member State, where these products are less taxed, for commercial purpose back in their country (e.g. re-selling or supplying their restaurants/bars). These residual fraudulent actions should be tackled down through the enforcement of existing rules and controls. We do not consider that the thresholds themselves are problematic, nor that their revision will have an impact on fraudulent actions. CEEV is thus supporting a better enforcement of the existing rules to avoid fraud.  o Fraud may also not be intentional as cross border shoppers do not always know the rules. If the population was more aware about the existing thresholds, rules and penalties in case of fraud, they might be more likely to respect the rules.  CEEV believes that the promotion of awareness campaigns could contribute to reduce the risk of fraud.  • Ensure the good functioning of Single Market When considering and exploring potential policy options, it would be essential for the EC to ensure that these options are in line with the EU legislation. These options should not hinder the good functioning of the Single Market, the free movement of people and goods principle, nor the principle of non-discrimination (especially on grounds of nationality).   • Focus on harmful use of alcohol The document suggests that any kind of alcohol consumption (in excess or in moderation, regardless the drinking and dietary patterns) is linked to an increase in health services to be provided to consumers. It would be worth noting that increased health risks are linked to harmful use of alcohol (regular excessive drinking or binge drinking) out of a healthy lifestyle). Drinking wine in moderation on a regular basis during the week within meals and adopting a balanced diet such as the Mediterranean one is not linked to any health risk increase while the consumption of the same amount of alcohol during the weekend without meals is linked to negative health effects. The vast majority of the population is consuming wine responsibly and should not be penalised by unjustified tax increases.  Harmful consumption of alcohol should be tackled within specific actions targeting the groups at risk, e.g. through education campaigns. The national pro capita consumption indicator is useless to understand national trends related to harmful use of alcohol.    • Impact of alcohol taxation increase on illegal market and use of harmful alternatives Alcohol tax increases will mainly impact responsible drinkers, the vast majority of the population, and alcohol abusers will tend to look for alternatives. Taxation increase may lead to the increase of illicit alcohol trade and substitution to harmful alternative with negative consequences on consumers health Feedback from: CEEV (272.2 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Feedback to Inception Impact Assessments on Cross-border purchases of alcohol and tobacco  The Nordic Alcohol and Drug Policy Network (NordAN) is encouraged by the current initiative and welcomes its appropriate view on the problem that cross-border trade causes for the Member States. It is very encouraging to see that the Inception Impact Assessment links the issue with the European plan to fight cancer.   Taxation of alcoholic beverages is an important part of alcohol policy. Price measures, including taxation, are well-documented strategies to reduce alcohol-related harm and one of WHO's three "best buys" in alcohol policy. Price impacts both on total consumption in the population and on consumption in risk groups, such as young people and heavy drinkers. As the Inception Impact Assessment rightly acknowledges, Member States' ability to tax alcohol based on its internal public health goals, is an essential tool and a corner-stone for evidence-based alcohol policy.   In addition, NordAN wants to stress, especially based on the experience of Finland and Estonia, cross-border trade, as it has been regulated thus far, undermines the whole alcohol policy, not only the effectiveness of excise tax as a measure. The effectiveness of alcohol policies partly rely on the population's support, but this is weakened by the situation caused by cross-border trade. It is easy to understand that citizens won't support raising alcohol taxes in a case where tens of millions of tax money is left in a neighbouring country. To a certain extent, this dissatisfaction extends to the whole alcohol policy and governments ability to introduce new measures and explain the effectiveness of different interventions.  The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the fiscal distortions and negative health effects of cross-border purchases of alcohol and tobacco. With closed borders, some member states have noted sharp increases in alcohol or tobacco excise duty income whilst reports indicate total consumption in the countries remains stable, or even, in some cases, is decreasing.  Sweden, during the period of closed borders, noted a sharp increase in excise duty income for spirits, the beverage type with the largest share of cross-border purchasing, whilst consumption data indicates that total consumption of alcohol has fallen overall.  In Norway, alcohol sales have skyrocketed as NRK reports, but according to a survey, very few Norwegians say that they drink more after the corona outbreak. The vast majority have not changed their alcohol consumption. And to the extent that it has changed, more people report lower than higher consumption. In Finland, according to the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) passenger imports of alcoholic beverages, decreased by 30% between August 2019 and July 2020 compared to the previous corresponding period. Converted to 100% alcohol, passenger imports of alcohol decreased from 6.6 million litres to 4.7 million litres. The figure is the lowest in the history of gathering this data. At the same time, THL reports that Finns' total alcohol consumption decreased last spring during the first wave of the corona epidemic and related control measures. THL estimates that total alcohol consumption in April – June was about 10 per cent lower than in the previous year's corresponding period.  NordAN support the main policy changes identified in the Inception Impact Assessment and believe that these pose a suitable starting point for the process going forward.  Our opinion with appropriate links to sources is attached as well. Feedback from: Nordic Alcohol and Drug Policy Network (111.3 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Cryptocurrencies, digital assets and blockchain technology have matured over the last few years and are here to stay. Thanks to Europe's large and excellent digital infrastructure and abundance of expertise and customer potential, many businesses have been founded in the EU, providing thousands of jobs to EU citizens. In addition, many companies from outside of the EU have chosen to expand into the EU for the same reasons.  Providing a harmonized, fair and robust tax system is important for further development. While precise and pointed regulation is needed to target illicit activity, it is important that such regulations not be overbroad and prohibitively complex so as to stifle crypto as an important component of financial services industry.  For example, the recent introduction of the 5AMLD Directive negatively impacted the crypto industry due to a lack of harmonization and measures that ended up being too far removed from the capabilities of entrepreneurial crypto businesses and too costly to implement. In the EU, this resulted in a patchwork of measures making it impossible for companies operating in multiple jurisdictions to be fully compliant. The Netherlands imposed such a strict interpretation of the rules that almost half of the Dutch-founded crypto companies will cease operations, resulting in a direct loss of workforce. Other companies have chosen to relocate their bases to more friendly EU jurisdictions, or even off-shore, and are serving Dutch customers from there. This is contrary to the purpose and intent of this Directive and ultimately defeats the primary objective of the new measures.   While we recognize the need for effective regulation of crypto businesses as a financial service, we are concerned that the DAC8 Directive could result in a similar adverse legal landscape across the EU, with prohibitive compliance burdens that stifle the industry’s development across Member States. Instead, rules and/or regulations (as opposed to a directive) should be implemented that better ensure harmonization and standardization. Such regulation should be targeted to ensure that the information needed by government authorities is collected while mitigating the compliance burdens for the nascent crypto industry.  One could think, for example, of the introduction of Intrastat back in 1993, which was efficient and harmonized. Local tax authorities would also benefit from such an approach.   Crypto should not be treated more adversely and with greater burdens that regular financial services, which present similar opportunities for abuse. Rules and reporting should be designed to provide governments with the means to ensure taxpayer integrity. More burdens and more information for the sake of more will not benefit the EU or its citizens. The rules should be tailored and defined in ways that achieve integrity and trust in the crypto economy.  The crypto industry is promising and will fulfill an increasingly important role in the EU for its citizens and institutions. Nevertheless, this industry is still in its infancy and is therefore vulnerable. It contains a multitude of initiatives headed by numerous start-ups. It is important to ensure that they can handle the measures imposed on them and that these measures do not impede the growth of the industry and its participants.  A clear, concise and targeted reporting standard ensures maximum cooperation and compliance. It is imperative to consider the impact on industry participants when drafting new measures to ensure that the EU remains a 'center of excellence' in the field of digital assets. To that end, Coinbase, as a trusted industry leader in the trading of digital assets welcomes the opportunity to engage in a dialogue and partner with the European Commission to assist with its initiative to craft and develop policies that everyone can support, promoting transparency and compliance, while enhancing the cryptoeconomy in the EU in the months and years ahead.
Initiative: Tax fraud & evasion – strengthening rules on administrative cooperation and expanding the exchange of information

feedback_msg_text: EPIF welcomes the public consultation on the European Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment pertaining to a proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards measures to strengthen existing rules and expand the exchange of information framework in the field of taxation to include crypto-assets and e-money.  E-money institutions as well as e-money are regulated through the E-Money Directive (2009/110/EC) as well as by the second Payment Services Directive (2015/2366/EU). Moreover, European e-money issuers are already subject to strict AML and KYC requirements and are already subject to reporting obligations where they have reasons to believe their products are being used for the purposes of tax evasion.   The purpose and scope of the E-Money Directive is to create the regulatory and supervisory framework for the issuance, redemption and use of e-money for payment purposes. E-money, as defined by EU legislation, is a means of payment rather than a means of storing value – both as regards to the overall value stored on average on an emoney instrument, as well as the timeframe over which this value is stored on an e-money instrument.  E-money is largely being used in the European market for low value transactions and often clearly defined payment purposes. Classical use cases are online purchases of goods and services or payments on public transport networks. Given their very specific use cases, e-money products importantly contribute to financial inclusion. Emoney products are therefore unlikely to give rise to significant risks of being used to shelter capital.  EPIF therefore maintains that reporting obligations should only apply in those use cases where the holder of e-money clearly intends to use e-money instruments as a means of storing large amounts of capital and/or over a longer timeframe. The best way to determine this is by establishing clear reporting thresholds to demarcate between those accounts used for storing money and those used for transactional purposes.  EPIF calls on the European Commission to consider e-money being exempted if the issuer implements policies and procedures either to prevent a customer deposit in excess of a specific amount (e.g. EUR 15k) or to ensure that any customer deposit in excess of that amount cannot be held by the customer for more than a specific timeframe (e.g. 30 or 60 days). This threshold would be easy to communicate to customers and would ensure that no one is holding excessive amounts of funds in e-money accounts.  EPIF strongly agrees with the European Commission Inception Impact Assessment that only the data necessary to perform the risk analysis and facilitate tax control of e-money should be collected. EPIF acknowledges the concerns that e-money products could be used to hold assets however stresses that emoney customers do not, in principle, use e-money accounts as deposits. The success of e-money products lies in the convenience to on-board and use the product to transact in a fast and cheap way in a short period of time. In addition, there is a clear demarcation between active customers and customers that register but ultimately do not use the product.  EPIF therefore calls on the European Commission to take a proportionate approach to the inclusion of emoney in scope of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation (2011/16/EU), in light of the particularities of e-money products, and consider excluding reporting obligations on low value transactions, which would be extremely burdensome for the e-money industry let alone a significant obstacle to new innovative solutions in the sector. EPIF also calls for a single home country reporting mechanism regarding the data collection by national authorities. Feedback from: Anonymous (129.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Tax fraud & evasion – strengthening rules on administrative cooperation and expanding the exchange of information

feedback_msg_text: Als EAPN Nederland vinden we het voorkomen van belastingfraude en belastingontwijking zeer belangrijk. We zijn dan ook verheugd over de installatie van een speciale commissie door het Europees Parlement. Naast het beëindigen van allerlei, vaak nationale, sluiproutes die ontwijking mogelijk maken, zien we twee belangrijke stappen die ook gezet moeten worden, naast deze nieuwe regelgeving, die we begroeten: 1. het beëindigen van de het gebruik van belastingen als concurrentiemiddel onderling, zoals dat met de profit tax gebeurt 2. het beëindigen van belastingparadijzen binnen de EU zelf. Wanneer de cijfers van de OESO richting gevend zijn, kunnen zo miljarden extra aan belastinggelden opgehaald worden. Het starten van een financiële transactiebelasting zien we als andere stap, naast het belasten van bedrijven daar waar ze winsten maken, dus niet langer mogen schuiven naar landen met lagere belastingheffing.  Het wordt tijd voor een faire wijze van belasting heffen. Om de miljarden die, door covid-19, terecht in het voorkomen van massawerkloosheid gestopt worden terug te kunnen betalen. Om lidstaten te helpen een fatsoenlijk minimuminkomen in te voeren en in te richten. Om de BTW op levensmiddelen te verlagen naar 0%. Om de grote armoede aan te pakken. En, zoals de commissie Borstlap aangeeft, het inverdienvermogen van de landen te verbeteren, waardoor de koopkracht toe neemt, waardoor de werkgelegenheid toeneemt en de armoede kan afnemen. Tot slot een nog een ander argument. Door de wijze waarop nu belastingen geheven worden, worden grote bedrijven sterk bevoordeeld. Waar het MKB, met vaak veel mensen in loondienst, haar afdrachten aan zowel de belastingen als de sociale fondsen doet, kunnen de grote bedrijven, die vaak allerlei constructies, zoals flexwerk et cetera, gebruiken om deze afdrachten te ontwijken, hun niet betaalde belastingen gebruiken om bedrijven over te nemen, waardoor ze steeds machtiger worden en er monopolie vorming ontstaat. Dit is funest voor een eerlijke competitie en werkt enorm marktverstorend. Tijd hier een eind aan te maken.
Initiative: Tax fraud & evasion – strengthening rules on administrative cooperation and expanding the exchange of information

feedback_msg_text: ACEA welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback to the Commission (EC) on this Inception Impact Assessment on the revision of the ITS Directive. Please refer to our detailed response attached to this summary.   We agree with the EC that attention should be given to the lack of interoperability and cross-border continuity of applications, systems and services. Whereas ITS services over the network (long-range) have long been successfully deployed and made interoperable across brands, the potential of short-range (V2I, V2V) has emerged as an efficient solution for offering across the board interoperable safety services. Challenges related to the implementation of these technologies are currently being solved in European standard setting bodies.  Secondly, the lack of concertation and cooperation among ITS stakeholders needs to be addressed. Problems derive from the different pace and governance levels in ITS with fragmented member states involvement, ITS road-side infrastructure roll out and EU synchronisation of national access points (NAPs). Measures should focus on the better coordination of infrastructure roll-out, integration of NAPs and improved coordination of ITS services deployment. ACEA welcomes the public support action on the federation of the NAPs.  Thirdly, as far as the availability and sharing of data supporting the ITS services is concerned, it should be left to the market players (data providers) to determine what data are best suited for given use cases and events.  Newer themes such as automated mobility, mobility platforms (MaaS), multimodality and the urgently needed advanced deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure could also benefit from EU action under the ITS Directive revision.   Additional unresolved issues have been indicated by ACEA as priorities for the future revision of the Directive. To further develop the EU ITS market/framework, we recommend legislators to:   -carry out a critical reflection on the non-adoption of the C-ITS delegated act: policymakers are now aware of the issues at stake. Our industry believes in ITS messaging and an accompanying legal framework with no mandates on technology choices -pursue the principle of technology neutrality, whereby communication technology choices are left to the market as long as interoperability, scalability and harmonisation for ITS related services is ensured -synchronise EU work and priorities for the ITS Directive revision with the UN-ECE Road Map on ITS -involve the automobile industry in a timelier and structured manner in the negotiation process of delegated acts, but also as vehicles are a fundamental component of the multimodal connected and automated mobility ecosystem -take a balanced approach between regulatory/non-regulatory measures, where non-regulatory action on safety and security is accompanied by a minimum level of standardisation in the field of cybersecurity and security of C-ITS communication -provide clarity in the field of data protection and privacy, as it is currently unclear how compliance with the GDPR/ePrivacy legislation can be ensured for data processing in the context of C-ITS -review the currently very broad scope of the powers for delegated regulations -take a holistic approach when revising this Directive and align it with other legislation (TEN-T Regulation, AFI Directive, Type Approval framework, General Safety Regulation for automated driving) -reassess some definitions in the ITS Directive and work towards a common definition for ITS, in line with Action 1 of the UN-ECE Road Map on ITS  In all these areas, we support that EU action is taken so to achieve greater harmonisation of ITS deployment. A reflection should start on which items require action at EU or rather at national/regional/local level. TEN-T is a suitable framework for EU intervention, but it could be broadened. To that end, stimulus should be given to accelerate the national ITS plans in a way that ensures uniformity and coherence among MS. Feedback from: ACEA (324.1 KB - PDF - 12 pages) Download
Initiative: Intelligent transport systems (review of EU rules)

feedback_msg_text: Currently in the EU there are no exact statistics on people with different types of disabilities. This, for instance, does not allow us to know how many people with different (or multiple) disabilities are out of the labour market and education. EUD, organisation representing deaf people in the EU, would like to highlight the importance of  the collection of EU-level data disaggregated by disability type which would play an important role supporting evidence based advocacy and create the economic rationale behind the argument to foster the inclusion of persons with all types of disabilities into the labour market in the EU. Reliable, correct and robust data disaggregated by disability type is necessary to build an (economic) argument for inclusion of each disability group in the EU.   EUD understands that data collection is the competence of the Member States in the EU, however we suggest to establish a data collection platform or network in which national statistical offices, national focal points on the United Nations  Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UN CRPD), organisations representing persons with disabilities, alongside Eurostat would collaborate on the development and use of harmonised methods and coordinate on the use of tools such as  Washington Set of Short Questions for data collection at the national level which would later be input into Eurostat’s database. Data collection is key to understanding how well the EU and its Member States are implementing the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UN CRPD) for all persons with disabilities.   Although Eurostat data on disabilities is currently disaggregated by age and gender, it is not disaggregated by disability type. At EU level, we have data that places all persons with disabilities in a single category, or distinguishes between persons with disabilities with “severe” or "some" activity limitation. This overlooks the hugely different barriers faced by persons with different types of disabilities, especially those with multiple disabilities.    To highlight once again, the collection of relevant and disaggregated data by disability type is key. Data on the unemployment of persons with different types of disabilities would allow for a clear identification of the gaps when ensuring inclusion, e.g. the gap in unemployed deaf persons in the EU, who are a potential yet unused or underused work force. More data and exact statistics of people with disabilities who are currently underused or unused work force would also allow to identify the need of certain reasonable accommodation and accessibility measures and would help to draw the attention on the need to address these areas.   The EU and all Member States are parties to the UN CRPD. Article 31 of the Convention states that information collected on persons with disabilities shall be “disaggregated, as appropriate, and used to help assess the implementation of States Parties’ obligations under the present Convention and to identify and address the barriers faced by persons with disabilities in exercising their rights.” Addressing barriers cannot be done if we do not have disaggregated data on all disability types from all the Member States.   EUD therefore calls on the EU to support the inclusion of collection of data disaggregated by disability type in the new regulatory framework for European statistics on population. Feedback from: European Union of the Deaf (EUD) (28.6 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Data collection – European statistics on population (ESOP)

feedback_msg_text: EU air quality limit values must (at least) be aligned with WHO Air Quality Guidelines and fulfilled by 2025. Hence, all EU directives and regulations that can improve air quality must be aligned to fulfill the WHO Air Quality Guidelines from 2025. Member states not fulfilling EU air quality limit values aligned with WHO Air Quality Guidelines in 2025 must be taken to court within 12 months from registration of the violation. Mandatory independent third party verification and quality control of all essential input to the Commission in relation to air pollution (related to the air quality directive, NEC directive etc.) from member states.  Especially domestic wood (and coal) burning (causing pollution with PM & BaP) and farming (polluting with NH3) is practically unregulated compared to other sectors.  Domestic wood burning: We need same particle emission limit values (including condensable particles) for small stoves/boilers per kWh as we have for new trucks (EURO VI). National air quality measuring stations (to measure PM and BaP) should be placed as well in small villages with domestic burning. On stoves should be a mandatory warning against indoor air pollution. Black carbon (from all sources) must be included in the climate reporting of all member states.    Farming: We need much stricter regulation of farming forcing all farmers to cover manure containers and use manure acidification or bio-gasification.   Each member state must inform the population about air pollution in 20 full page articles in at least 5 large national newspapers every year containing information about: How many people - and how high a share of the population in percent - die from air pollution every year as well as information about the five worst national pollution sources in relation to mortality from air pollution.
Initiative: Air quality - revision of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: I am writing on behalf of 'Clean Air in London' (CAL) in response to this consultation on 'Air quality (AQ) - revision of EU rules'.    Our most important point is to ask you please to ensure continuity and tightening of health, legal and environmental protections (see 2013 letter below for explanation).  CAL also encourages you to seek the 'highest common denominator' of outcomes between the opinions of the European Commission, European Parliament and Council of Ministers on individual aspects of the revision.  These messages are similar to those we have repeated consistently over the last 15 years during previous revisions of the Air Quality Directive(s):  2007:  https://cleanair.london/legal/clean-air-in-london-gives-conditional-support-to-new-eu-air-quality-directive/  https://cleanair.london/health/setting-and-enforcing-european-union-legal-limits-for-air-quality/  2013:  https://cleanair.london/health/year-of-air-in-2013-must-deliver-continuity-and-the-further-tightening-of-health-and-legal-protections/  2014:  https://cleanair.london/hot-topics/europe-at-its-best-takes-legal-action-against-uk-at-its-worst-on-air-pollution/  On individual points:  1. Please align fully with the WHO's new AQ Guidelines expected in 2021.  Precursors of PM2.5 such as ammonia must also be addressed.  2. As the AQ Review found, binding limit values are by far the most effective legal measure to drives action on air quality by Member States and others.  These are needed to protect public health and provide the 'certainty' for businesses to invest in innovation.  Exposure reductions targets need to be used with care since they are opaque, late and unfair because they can only be calculated by Member States, are produced long after the year-end and allow or encourage Member States to make blue skies bluer for rich people (leaving vulnerable people in hotspots).  3. Please consider the 'air' as 'One Atmosphere'.  This means thinking holistically in terms of local air pollution and greenhouse gases.  Please align fully new AQ laws with new WHO AQ guidelines and net zero greenhouse gas deadlines and trajectories.  Please address the detailed issues without conflating them under 'climate change' or 'air pollution'.  See:  https://cleanair.london/app/uploads/Climate-change_Draft-20.01.19_V2.pdf  4. We need a plan now to achieve 'zero air emissions' from road transport, building etc to comply with AQ guidelines and Paris goals.  This will also avoid lazy fudges around 'net' or 'offsets'.  5.  Please ensure that technology solutions are truly technology neutral i.e. set one emission rate not a range of stronger and weaker rate from less or more polluting technologies.  Please ensure also that lifestyle solutions/changes are considered alongside technology.  These range across a spectrum from: (i) bans; (ii) charges; (iii) campaigns to build public understanding; (iv) incentives; and (v) adoption (e.g. seat belt use).  Campaigners, policy makers and politicians can work together to make the political costs of action less than inaction e.g. as we have done in London with diesel 'bans'.  Done well, this can ensure that benefits far exceed costs.  6. Environmental justice must be at the heart of the new legislation i.e. per Aarhus, Rio etc.  7. The public needs to be better warned during air pollution episodes. It is not acceptable for Government officials or politicians to say "we don't want to worry people".  Think of warning people about smoking.  It is important to say and emphasise that many of us in the UK are extremely keen to maintain the closest contact with Europeans in every sense.  CAL would be very pleased to attend future European Commission events on 'air quality' as we did in Paris and Bratislava.  I attach a file showing London's nitrogen dioxide levels in 2020.  Last but not least, please do not let people say it's too hard or we need to take longer. We have no time lose.  Think what we did quickly with a Clean Air Act in 1956! Feedback from: Clean Air in London (76.6 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Air quality - revision of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: The Clean Air Task Force (CATF), a climate and energy organization dedicated to decarbonizing the global energy system with staff in the US and Europe, welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the revision process of the Ambient Air Quality (AAQ) Directives.  Air pollution has long been associated with detrimental impacts not only on human health but on overall ecosystems. CATF believes that the European Commission’s initiative to revise the AAQ Directives, is a key step to ensure cleaner air, protecting citizens and ecosystems.   It is imperative though that these revisions are not made in a vacuum. Air pollutants and greenhouse gases (GHG) share sources and the alignment of climate mitigation strategies making consideration of the co-benefits and trade-offs from emission reductions essential. Revisions to the AAQ directive should consider the Commission’s plan to increase the ambition of the EU’s 2030 climate goals to ensure carbon neutrality by mid-century. Methane is a critical component of transboundary air pollution because it is a precursor of O3, and the second most important GHG contributing to climate change. Reduction of global methane emissions should be a priority of the European Commission that can be tackled with proper alignment of air pollution legislation and climate mitigation instruments such as the Methane Strategy.  We would like to highlight several priorities that should be considered in the upcoming impact assessment and proposed revision of the AAQ Directive: 1. Update of Air Quality standards 2. Alignment of EU policies 3. Improved legal implementation and enforcement  4. Disseminating air quality conditions   5. Transboundary impact  6. Strengthening of air quality monitoring, modelling and plans  Please see the attached document with detailed explanation on each of these points. Feedback from: Clean Air Task Force (CATF) (123 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Air quality - revision of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: EEB, Europe's largest network of environmental citizens’ organisations, welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback to the European Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment for the revision of lists of pollutants affecting surface and groundwaters as a follow up to the fitness check evaluation of the EU water legislation.     EEB strongly supports the conclusions of the fitness check evaluation that the reason that objectives of the Water Framework Directive (WFD) have not been reached fully is largely due to insufficient funding, slow implementation and insufficient integration of environmental objectives in sectoral policies, and not due to a deficiency in the legislation. Furthermore, “as for future challenges, this fitness check finds that the WFD is sufficiently prescriptive with regard to the pressures to be addressed, and yet flexible enough to reinforce its implementation as necessary with regard to emerging challenges not mentioned in the Directive such as climate change, water scarcity and pollutants of emerging concern (e.g. micro-plastics and pharmaceuticals)” and PFAS. Thus, we believe it is time to use the review mechanisms established in the Ecological Quality Standards Directive (EQSD) and the Groundwater Directive (GD) to revise the lists of pollutants affecting surface and groundwaters and set the EQS for them.    This initiative is important for achieving the Zero Pollution ambition of the European Green Deal and should build upon the Chemicals Strategy, Strategic Approach to Pharmaceuticals in the Environment as well as revision of the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive (UWWTD) and the Industrial Emissions Directive (and E-PRTR Regulation).   Please see attached more specific comments on listing and delisting of priority substances, improving the watch list mechanism, achieving policy coherence and applying the cost recovery and polluter pays principles for tackling pollutants of emerging concern that pose risk to the aquatic environment. feedback_msg_text: Transparency International EU (TI-EU) welcomes the incept impact assessment and the issues identified with regards to Directive 2014/42/EU (Directive) and supports policy option 3. In particular, TI EU recommends the following reforms:   Problem 1: The criminal offences included under the Directive should be aligned with that of Directive on Combating Money Laundering by Criminal Law 2018.  TI EU recommends acknowledging grand corruption as a specific criminal offence for which extended confiscation can apply. Grand corruption is defined as involving high level officials and other actors in a criminal organisation with a criminal scheme to commit acts of corruption, including across borders, that cause widespread harm to a population, parts of it as well as the international community.   Problems 2 and 3: The use of non conviction-based confiscation (NCBC) should be harmonised across EUand its use extended with proper safeguards for fundamental rights (see 2020 Council of Europe Report “The Use of Non Conviction-Based Seizure and Confiscation”). This kind of measures already exists in some Member States (MSs) but application of NCBC is limited to cases where the suspected/accused person is deceased, ill or absconding. Other differences in scope and application exist that further hamper cooperation.    Problem 4: The social reuse of confiscated assets should become the norm in domestic and international cases. Principles for restitution and social reuse should be introduced to ensure a transparent, accountable and inclusive process that benefits victim individuals and populations. In international AR cases involving multiple MSs as confiscating states and a 3rd country as the receiving one, the EU could set up a EU level mechanism to pool together all confiscated assets to facilitate the restitution of the assets to the 3rd country. TI-EU has developed 10 principles for the responsible restitution of confiscated assets in transnational corruption cases involving high-level public officials in 3rd countries which could be broadened and adapted to fit other cases of restitution/social reuse.  Problem 5: TI-EU shares the assessment made of data access and sharing for AROs. Access to beneficial ownership (BO) information is key for the detection and tracing of criminal assets. Full policy coherence should be ensured between the EU AML and AR legislations. In particular, AROs should be considered as competent authorities and be given full and timely access to BO data as part of the 5th AML Directive.  Moreover, public access to BO data provided via national central registers shall further facilitate cross-border data sharing. It is important that this is done in a meaningful, efficient and harmonised way so as to facilitate the subsequent interconnexion of the 27 national registers at EU level.    Problem 6:  MSs shall be mandated to collect data concerning all the stages of the AR process (freezing, confiscation and return/social reuse) disaggregated on a case-by-case basis and make them publicly accessible in a central register. Information on frozen / confiscated / returned assets, compensations, sharing agreements or restitutions ordered should be included, as well as details of the type of offences that led to the illegal acquisition and on whether the decision to confiscate was the result of civil or criminal proceedings. . Data should be harmonised  to facilitate cross-country comparison. The EU could also draw from existing country practices such as the Spanish “Fondo de bienes decomisados”.   Final point. A final issue is that of policy coherence. Asset recovery is intertwined with the EU sanction policy, in particular the country-specific misappropriation sanction regimes or the recently adopted Global Magnitsky legislation which provides for the freezing of the targeted individuals’ assets held in Europe. For efficiency purposes, it is critical that both policy areas (foreign policy and criminal law) are better linked.
Initiative: Fighting organised crime – strengthening the mandate of EU Asset Recovery Offices

feedback_msg_text: The coherent and effective taxation of energy products should be the centrepiece of any successful energy and climate policy. It gives a clear price signal to consumers and allocates the costs of the energy transition according to the polluter-pays principle included in article 191.2 of the TFEU. With this in mind, SolarPower Europe has carefully considered the inception impact assessment published by the European Commission and wishes to make the following comments.    - First, the initiative should aim to tackle the redistribution of the cost of the energy transition and of electrification among all energy carriers (section A, ‘Problem the initiative aims to tackle’). As pointed out in the Long-Term Strategy of the European Commission, reaching carbon-neutrality in 2050 will require vast investments in renewable energy capacities but also in electrifying economic processes such as the transport and industrial sector. Yet, in many countries, renewable energy surcharge mechanisms have been borne by electricity consumers only, to the detriment of a level-playing field between energy carriers. It is therefore urgent to revise the current structure of energy taxation by introducing a CO2 component in the calculation of energy excise duties, by removing any additional levies not related to the cost of supplying the electricity to the consumer and by putting an end to all tax exemptions on fossil fuels.  - Second, the issues under scrutiny (section B) are appropriate according to SolarPower Europe. In particular:  o SolarPower Europe welcomes the proposals to review the structure of minimum excise rates calculations, and to introduce a carbon-content in the taxation. However, many approaches exist to calculate the greenhouse gases emissions content of fuels. Therefore, SolarPower Europe recommends that the European Commission clarifies what methodologies are being considered to calculate the greenhouse gases emissions of fuels, the types of greenhouse gases that will be considered, and how these methodologies contribute to reaching carbon-neutrality in 2050.   o Regarding product coverage, SolarPower Europe would like to stress that the revised Directive should acknowledge renewable electricity used in transport as well as that used to make future synthetic fuels. This will require an assessment of the electric mobility growth trajectories, and of the potential of renewable-based electric mobility. On this basis, we believe it should be possible to grant tax reductions for renewable electricity used in transport, for instance as part of a PPA or renewable self-consumption scheme. Second, a framework for the taxation of hydrogen is required. Such a framework should establish a robust taxonomy of various types of hydrogen based on their specific environmental footprint across the entire lifecycle. In line with the objective of “climate mainstreaming” established by the European Green Deal, taxation rules should incentivise hydrogen technologies with the lowest CO2 footprint, in this case hydrogen produced from renewable-based electrolysis.  o Finally, SolarPower Europe welcomes the proposal of the European Commission to address the topic of electricity storage taxation, recognizing its benefits to the national economy. Prohibiting the double taxation of electrochemical, chemical and mechanical storage is key to unlock the potential of flexibility and clean electricity on demand. It should therefore be made clear that the charging of storage facilities should not be treated as a final use. Yet, the Commission should also address the practical aspects of double taxation: in some countries, the prohibition of double taxation is conditional on the possession of expensive advanced metering systems, which are an economic disincentive, and a barrier to market for smaller storage systems.
Initiative: EU Green Deal – Revision of the Energy Taxation Directive

feedback_msg_text: To ensure a fit-for-purpose revision of the current rules, we urge for the following points to be taken into account:  1. Convergence of fiscal rules between Member States must be achieved in order to adequately contribute to the functioning of the Internal Energy Market :  The 2019 ETD Evaluation  demonstrated that the rates currently applied by MS differ significantly from each other and from the minimum rates defined in the original text. This leads to severe market fragmentation and situations in which, for example, “renewable energy can be taxed at a higher rate than a competing fossil fuel, as long as the minimum rates are respected”. While taking into account the large diversity of economies and the different starting points on path to the energy transition among Member States, such distortions must be gradually removed if Europe is to meet its climate ambitions.  2. Current disparities between energy carriers must be addressed to ensure that externalities of fossil fuels are properly reflected :  This mainly relates to externalities from GHG emissions. Currently, CO2 pricing applies to electricity through the EU ETS but only marginally to fossil alternatives in the transport and building sector, thus disincentivising the use of electricity. Taking into account the real climate impact of all energy carriers and ensuring a level-playing field between them is essential. Moreover, the current lack of harmonisation of energy taxation rates at EU level creates an uneven playing field between competing energies as it does not take into account their CO2 emissions. To tackle this, the revised ETD must integrate climatic performance of energy sources, at a level which is consistent with the EU climate objectives for 2030 and 2050.   3. Sectorial discrepancies must be tackled :  Eurelectric therefore asks that tax exemptions on aviation and maritime fuels are partially removed to encourage the switch to cleaner transportation modes. Those exemptions would then totally removed when a cleaner alternative solution will be available. Particularly for maritime, the use of shore-side electricity should be incentivised.  Other sectors which are not exposed to a meaningful carbon price signal could be incentivised either by potentially extending the ETS scope or by carbon pricing measures, using the most efficient tool for each sector. The introduction of the CO2 component must be done in coordination with EU-ETS in order to have a complementary, harmonised and holistic framework. In addition, the review should remove double taxation for flexibility tools such as storage, batteries or power-to-gas facilities, as they will play a key role in decarbonising the economy and in integrating the growing shares of renewables.   4. The ETD must be made compliant with the neutrality objectives by reviewing its scope and product coverage :  Today, the electricity bill is often used to finance a large number of low carbon policies- such as RES deployment and energy efficiency. Taxes and levies in electricity bills account for up to 70% of the bill in some Member States thus artificially increasing prices and discouraging the use of electricity based technologies and services. Limiting the weight of taxes on electricity will help make electricity more affordable for household consumers, and contribute to minimizing the social and distributional impacts which the Commission rightfully wishes to address. It would also directly boost the competitiveness of European businesses, particularly energy- and electro intensive industries.   In conclusion, Eurelectric fully supports an ambitious review of the ETD. Though it is a responsibility of the Member States, a revision of the ETD should reflect the role of electricity in decarbonisation at European level. On the ongoing discussions on the change in voting procedure, Eurelectric is currently discussing internally to define a position to be communicated in the consultation on this file in Q2 2020. Feedback from: Eurelectric (583 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download
Initiative: EU Green Deal – Revision of the Energy Taxation Directive

feedback_msg_text: The Confederation of Swedish Enterprise welcomes the Green Deal and the holistic perspective that characterize the strategy and we also support the EU ambition to become climate neutral by 2050. Both the Commission and the Member States (MS) need to commit to a long-term policy framework with realistic objectives, and simple and clear rules to provide this stable environment. The current ETD remains effective and operational, without hampering competitiveness for business and secure access to energy and feedstock at competitive prices while supporting wider EU policy objectives, such as climate. The Confederation of Swedish Enterprise believes that this must be safeguarded and do not see the need for a revision of the ETD.  Different policy areas influence each other and to reach an efficient development in line with the Green Deal the combination of regulatory measures need to be complementary. At the same time, different legislation shall not overlap each other. Hence every piece of legislation has its well-defined purpose.   The primary objective of ETD is to support the proper functioning of the internal market by avoiding double taxation and other distortions of trade and competition between energy sources and energy consumers and suppliers. As such, ETD provides MS with a tool to tax energy and indirectly support the objectives of other legislation in energy and climate policies.
Initiative: EU Green Deal – Revision of the Energy Taxation Directive

feedback_msg_text: Thank you for the opportunity to present our feedback. In our opinion, continuing with the digital levy initiative is likely to bring more negative than positive results for European businesses and consumers at the moment. Even in its present indefinite baseline scenario, this initiative is sending a wrong message at a wrong time:  1) The EC is right to notice that any imbalance in the public finance is “particularly blatant at a moment when we are facing a greater burden as they tackle the COVID-19 crisis and support a recovery”. But for the sake of this recovery effort, EC should be very reluctant to rely on a not so reliable new resource which is “likely to have an impact on businesses engaging and operating in the digital economy, and on competitiveness and GDP, as the initiative is likely to affect investment decisions and productivity”. To this add the likely increase of the tax compliance cost for both taxpayers and tax administrations. This is not the best field for growing big European digital players, especially when abroad they have to compete in an environment with different rules.    2) Any unilateral pressure from the European side in introducing a “special” treatment for the (mainly American) big digital businesses could eventually give a convenient reason to the new US Administration for not conceding on Pillar one. And the EU will give up on its leading role in designing a real functional modern framework for global taxation.   3) It’s fair to notice that EU already has a potential solution for a digital levy through the still pending CCCTB framework. Why losing energies on temporary solutions and not focusing on finding the working solutions for implementing the CCCTB which is also recognized as a political goal of the European project? A tax harmonization closed to the market rules, accompanied by an appropriate harmonisation of best administrative practices, could send a much better message to our investors that EU is really the level playing field and home of fair taxation.
Initiative: A fair & competitive digital economy – digital levy

feedback_msg_text: The Confederation of Norwegian Enterprise (NHO) and its Nordic sister organisations supports the EU/EEA ambition of net-zero greenhouse gas emissions (climate neutrality) by 2050 to reach the objectives of the Paris Agreement.  NHO would like to refer to our feedback to the parallel Roadmap of updating the EU emissions trading system (ETS) and LULUCF. These are the three main pillars of the climate framework and must be treated as such. NHO would stress that we are not fit for 55 unless he internal energy market is completed, and that harmonization rather than distortion is key to increased energy efficiency, to security of supply, to a just transition with affordable and competitive energy prices, while building pan-European infrastructure,  central-, local- and distributed networks and storage for molecules (incuding water, biogas, C02, hydrogen) and electricity, absorbing growing quantities of renewable s. Hence, EEA needs a coherent energy, industry, infrastructure and climate policy.  The low interconnection rate and national regulatory barriers affects security of supply, heavily limits the potential of resource efficiency by digitization and renewable s integration,  and, consequently, raise the costs of climate action.  NHO believes the climate target must be distributed fairly and equally between industrial sectors and non-ETS. Increased ambitions cannot be carried by the ETS sector alone. An inner-marked approach, also in the non-ETS sectors, is imperative and will provide the flexibility increasingly needed towards 2030. Hence, we question an effort-sharing based on member states GDP/capita capacity, with little flexibility among EEA members, as it does not reflect emission reduction potential. EU-ETS is based on the sound economic principle of cost-efficient mitigation, similar logic should apply to the non-ETS sectors. Towards 2030 and beyond, even full flexibility between member states may not be enough, and the scope must widen further.  Consequently, inclusion of non-ETS sectors in ETS should be considered. NHO supports the idea to let all the transportation sectors take part in the EU-ETS. Even though being millions of entities, the combustion tech/activity is uniform, price of fuel and technology is set on a global marketplace and, hence, a carbon price can be set at the pump. Distributional effects should be met by other means. This in contrast to buildings that are highly diverse, by materials, energy system and uses, geography, age, complex regulation, standard and culture. The question is rather if it should have its own trading scheme due to different elasticities compared to the industrial sectors, or a common and proportionate factor at the pump. . Carbon pricing will guide the market to invest and develop low- and emission free technologies and best practices. Compensation schemes and recycling of quota costs to r&d, the use of standards and product declarations in procurement, and infrastructure such as ccus, are all necessary tools to keep industry investing in Europe while waiting for others to price their carbon emissions.  The end-product of the society's carbon cycle is CO2, often concentrated through waste incineration or cement production. It allows for capture and storage (CCS) and the third level of carbon recycling, namely industrial conversion of CO2 using supplied renewable energy and hydrogen. Compared to using fresh biomass, level 2 (chemical recycling) recycling will retain energy, while level 3 (CCU) recycling takes advantage of the value of concentrated CO2 as raw material. It is imperative to handle the climate and biodiversity challenges in unison. A renewable only solution conflicts with biodiversity and space. We do not lack resources but energy and materials efficiency and good practices to keep resources in the loop much longer. A price on carbon emission as well as payment on removal is essential to incentivize carbon management such as industrial recycling or forest uptake.
Initiative: National emissions reduction targets (Effort Sharing Regulation) – review based on 2030 climate target plan

feedback_msg_text: The review of the ESR offers a great opportunity for a novel policy approach; one relying on incentives in the form of results-based payments against national baseline emission levels. Such a policy focusing on additional emission reductions could significantly increase the contribution of ESR sectors to emission reduction in a politically attractive and cost-effective manner and could support decarbonisation with additional financial resources.   Summarising the mechanism of the policy: • A new facility – referred to here as the European Green Fund or EGF – is established. • The EGF pays Member States annually for emission reductions that go beyond their binding reductions under the current ESR (the baseline). • An appropriate carbon price is established for these payments, creating a price signal and a strong incentive for governments to strengthen climate policies.  • The EGF finances the carbon payments by borrowing in capital markets for the long-term.  • The creditworthiness of the EGF is backed by Member States. In the future, when the liabilities of the EGF are repaid, Member States make payments to the EGF based on a predetermined allocation. The sharing of these costs could for example be based on Member States’ GDP in line with the ESR’s current approach of using economic capacity as the basis for effort sharing.   Details of the mechanism can be shaped to address policy objectives.   Such a policy offers many clear advantages: • The carbon price signal for ESR sectors would create a very strong incentive for governments to achieve additional emission reductions leading to an increased contribution of ESR sectors and ensuring the policy’s effectiveness.  • The mechanism would raise significant additional capital and channel this towards decarbonisation through policies and programs of national governments.  • The decoupling of how the mechanism’s costs are shared among Member States from how much they contribute to mitigation outcomes would align Member States with increasing their contribution to the EU’s climate targets. • The same decoupling of costs would offer flexibility to address distributional considerations among Member States without a trade-off between equity and cost-effectiveness.  • The mechanism, by deferring the financing costs to the future, would align the costs of mitigation more closely with its benefits. It would also make climate policy action politically more attractive for national governments in light of the relatively short electoral cycles and competing short-term political priorities. The mechanism offers near term carbon revenues to Member States while its costs arise over the long-term.  • The mechanism offers full policy and political flexibility for Member States to implement national policies and achieve emission reduction in a way best suited for their circumstances. This is an important advantage as Member State policies play a significant role for the sectors within the scope of ESR. • The coherence of the proposed policy with other EU climate policies could also be ensured as it builds on the current scope of the ESR. • The mechanism would strongly support the COVID-19 recovery by incentivising and providing financing for decarbonisation investments.  • Such a policy approach also offers the optionality of an expanded future scope, including a scope going beyond the EU, and could strengthen the EU’s global leadership position towards achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement. These advantages make the proposed policy a politically attractive option to strengthen the contribution of ESR sectors in a cost-efficient manner and to generate additional financial resources for the required decarbonisation.  Climate Moonshot is a non-governmental, non-commercial initiative with the vision of a world governed for a safe and just climate, focusing on creating the political will for transformational climate policies, and on making climate policies more ambitious and effective. Feedback from: Climate Moonshot Initiative (448.2 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: National emissions reduction targets (Effort Sharing Regulation) – review based on 2030 climate target plan

feedback_msg_text: ESR versus ETS  The idea to put the land transport’s fuel to the ETS system is not expedient. This measure could not mitigate the fuel consumption, but neither the increase of it. The Handbook on the external costs of transport Version 2019 – 1.1  ( https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/9781f65f-8448-11ea-bf12-01aa75ed71a1 ) says that the climate change avoidance costs are between 60 €/t CO2 equivalent and 498 €/tCO2 equivalent. From this figures the Handbook calculates 1,12 eurocents/km for the climate change external costs for petrol cars which could be collected as a part of the road toll. Counting with 100 g/km CO2 emission it is 11,2 eurocents for 1 kg CO2 emission, or 112 EUR/tCO2. Now the price is 25 EURs of one tonne CO2e emission allowance in the ETS. As we know there are plans in the EU to change the Eurovignette directive and use the CO2 emission of trucks as a base of road toll. The suggested change, the involvement of land transport fuels to the ETS, could make this change impossible. To mitigate the mobility we need to connect the CO2 emission and the burden in the users’ minds. The mobility behaviour is not fuel price sensitive.  The “you drives X kilometres and pay Y euros for the CO2 emission” is a clear message, as it is shown in some road toll tests. But “a variable part of what you pay for the fuel is spent by the oil company on the ETS allowance” is  very obscure. The ESR idea is better. The member states has targets in decreasing the CO2 emission, and they can choose their own tools to reach it. For example the introduction of road toll which is a good tool to a new financing model of road network in the era of electric power too. Moreover the nowadays system with the banning of CO2 emission of vehicles is very important to encourage car factories to expand their electric-powered supply, and to reduce their supply of internal combustion models. This system must be kept.  (this is the official opinion of the Clean Air Action Group Hungary; Transparency Register Public ID number : 351764810742-20)
Initiative: National emissions reduction targets (Effort Sharing Regulation) – review based on 2030 climate target plan

feedback_msg_text: The Swedish Forest Industries Federation (SFIF) represents companies that use forests to provide the raw materials for their products and services. This includes producers of pulp, paper, cardboard, packaging and biofuel. Similarly, sawmills producing all sorts of boards, planks, roof trusses and other prefabricated construction elements are also included. The main objective of the European climate legislation should be to minimize the use of fossil fuels while maintaining welfare by maintaining the competitiveness of European industry and agricultural sectors. We therefore strongly advice against phasing out the ESR and moving emissions to ETS and LULUCF as this could lead to increased emissions from fossil fuels and decreased competitiveness of the European industry.     Emissions from road transport and buildings do not face international competition and are less likely to face the risk of carbon leakage, why moving them to ETS will led to decreased competitiveness of the current ETS sectors. It is more efficient to decarbonize road transport and buildings through other measures than inclusion in the ETS.  Concerning taking into account synergies between the LULUCF sector and other land-related sectors, such as agriculture, SFIF opposes this. As agriculture already today is a net emitter and is projected to continue to be so, a merger of sectors will by definition result in an increased emissions load. This would have to be balanced by higher forest removals, which could lead to demand for reduced harvesting rates in existing forests. So, while perhaps the issue of non-removable agricultural emissions would be conjured away by merging sectors, limitations could instead be incurred on forests with negative effects on mitigation potentials, green growth and jobs in Europe. Even some leakage effects can be foreseen due to increased imports from outside of the EU. Feedback from: Skogsindustrierna (102.5 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: National emissions reduction targets (Effort Sharing Regulation) – review based on 2030 climate target plan

feedback_msg_text: The Netherlands Platform Sustainable Biofuels appreciates the opportunity to provide feedback on the CO2-performance of cars and vehicles.  In its feedback paper (see attached PDF-document ) the viewpoint of the Platform is that it requires both a vehicle and an energy carrier to get from A to B, and therefor the Platform argues that it is of utmost importance to include the lower carbon intensity of renewable fuels and energy carriers in the assessment of the CO2-performance of every car. This should be based on a well-to-wheel approach to prevent potential ‘carbon leakage’ to other economic sectors where energy carriers are produced.
