Initiative: CO2 emissions for cars and vans – revision of performance standards

feedback_msg_text: Der Fachverband Biogas e.V. begrüßt die Pläne der Europäischen Kommission, den Emissionsausstoß im Verkehrssektor bis zum Jahr 2050 um 90 % zu reduzieren. Um dieses Ziel zu erreichen, bedarf es jedoch eines Wechsels vom bereits etablierten „Tail-Pipe“ Ansatz, wonach ausschließlich Emissionen aus der Kraftstoffverbrennung betrachtet werden, zu einem ganzheitlichen Ansatz („Well-to-wheel“), welcher die Vorkettenemissionen der Kraftstoffe mitberücksichtigt. Zukünftig muss darüber hinaus auch die Lebenszyklusanalyse des Fahrzeugs in die Bewertung mit einfließen, um die weiteren Emissionsminderungspotentiale zu erschließen und zugleich die Wettbewerbsgleichheit der Antriebe und Kraftstoffe zu gewährleisten.   Dem schnellen Ausstieg aus dem Einsatz fossiler Kraftstoffe soll das Prinzip der Technologieoffenheit zugrunde gelegt werden. Vor dem Hintergrund des andauernden Emissionsanstiegs im Verkehr dürfen keine der bereits vorhandenen Treibhausgas(THG)-Minderungsoptionen vernachlässigt werden, die insbesondere eine schnelle Klimaschutzwirkung erzielen lassen. Die steigenden Verkehrsemissionen zeigen eindeutig, dass viele THG-Minderungsoptionen bislang kaum ergriffen wurden. Angesichts der CO2-Intensität des EU-Strommixes, die im laufenden Jahrzehnt erwartungsgemäß auf einem hohen Niveau verbleiben wird, stellt eine sukzessive und zeitnahe Erhöhung des Anteils der Biokraftstoffe als Substitut für fossile Energieträger eine wichtige Maßnahme zur THG-Minderung im Verkehr und somit auch eine wichtige Prämisse für die Erreichung der Ziele des Pariser Klimaabkommens dar. Die Bindung atmosphärischen CO2 durch die Biomasse kompensiert die Klimawirkung der Verkehrsmissionen bei Verbrennung der Biokraftstoffe. Senkung der Importabhängigkeit von seltenen Erden, Stärkung regionaler Wertschöpfung und Förderung des Technologie- und Wirtschaftsstandorts Europa gehen mit dem Ausbau lokaler Biokraftstoffproduktion einher.   Der Fachverband Biogas e.V. fordert bei der Revision der EU-Richtlinie 2019/631 den Klimaschutzbeitrag der Biokraftstoffe inklusive deren Vorkettenemissionen anzuerkennen und deren Klimaschutzbeitrag mit dem des Elektroantriebs gleichzustellen. Dies kann im Rahmen der freiwilligen Teilnahme der Fahrzeughersteller am Handel mit THG-Emissionen oder durch ein anderes Verfahren mitberücksichtigt werden. Dabei kann beispielsweise das bereits etablierte Zertifizierungssystem den Fahrzeugherstellern erlauben, deren Emissionsminderungsverpflichtung bei gleichzeitiger Vermeidung von Doppelzählungen nachzugehen.   Unter anderem bietet sich Biomethan mit seinem THG-Minderungspotential von über 200 % (RICHTLINIE (EU) 2018/2001) und bereits existierenden hohen Produktions- und Herstellungskapazitäten als eine gute THG-Minderungsoption an. Die Substitution von fossilem CNG (engl. „Compressed Natural Gas“) und LNG (engl. „Liquefied Natural Gas“) durch Biomethan ist aufgrund deren identischen physikalisch-chemischen Eigenschaften nahtlos möglich. Zudem unterliegt der Herstellungsprozess von Biomethan strengen Umweltauflagen. Dabei findet das hohe Methanemissionsminderungspotential der Biomethananlagen durch die Gemeinsame Forschungsstelle der Europäischen Kommission  seine Anerkennung. Außerdem ermöglicht der Einsatz von Biomethan im Verkehr eine signifikante Reduzierung von NOx, SOx, CO2, Feinstaub und Lärm.   Das Biomethanerzeugungspotential Europas von etwa 1.200 TWh (Guidehouse, 2020), der vorhandene Park an 18.000 Biogasanlagen wovon bereits heute schon etwa 600 Standorte Biomethan liefern und ein existierendes Tankstellennetz mit ca. 300 LNG- bzw. 4000 CNG-Tankstationen ermöglichen einen starken Zuwachs an Biomethan im Kraftstoffsektor. Zudem stellt Biomethan einen Energieträger dar, der sich im Gasnetz gut transportieren und speichern lässt. Folglich trägt dessen Nutzung der Stabilität der Energieversorgungsnetze bei.   Feedback from: Fachverband Biogas e.V. (467.4 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: CO2 emissions for cars and vans – revision of performance standards

feedback_msg_text: The eFuel Alliance fully supports the European Commission’s assessment that all sectors will have to strengthen their efforts in reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions significantly in order to achieve climate-neutrality by 2050. Especially road transport has to play a key role as it accounts for a fifth of today’s GHG emissions in the EU. Given the huge potential of promising climate-protection technologies, such as renewable hydrogen and its derivate products, which has not yet been exploited, we believe that road transport can make a significant contribution to the defossilisation efforts in Europe.     One instrument to achieve GHG reductions in the transport sector is the upcoming revision of the CO2 emission standards for cars and vans. We are convinced that a balanced mix of strict but achievable CO2 emission standards and a level-playing-field among the diversity of emission-reduction technologies will have the most positive impact on our climate. To determine the real contribution to climate protection a technology can make, the carbon footprint of a vehicle must be assessed on the basis of its entire life cycle.    Especially in the light of the Commission’s plan to raise the climate targets for 2030, it is even more important to allow a wide range of compliance options to fulfil the CO2 emission standards and to promote a diversity of climate-protection solutions helping to reach climate neutrality by 2050. With road transport being the sector with the greatest potential to use and an urgent need for climate neutral fuels, the current evaluation of the EU fleet target regulation offers a huge opportunity for a market ramp-up of hydrogen and hydrogen-derived products. In this way the enormous climate protection potential can be exploited. If the EU sets the right course in promoting the wide and cross-sectoral use of climate-neutral fuels now, a large-scale industrial production of hydrogen and hydrogen derived products like eFuels could begin shortly.  Please find attached our detailed position. Feedback from: eFuel Alliance (164.9 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download
Initiative: CO2 emissions for cars and vans – revision of performance standards

feedback_msg_text: Commitment to Climate Neutrality: Vitesco Technologies fully supports the EU target for climate neutrality in 2050 and for a carbon free road transport by 2050.  Consequence of Climate Neutrality for Road Transport: The overall goal is to manage the transformation to a climate neutral economy in 2050. Climate neutral road transport in 2050 implies that from 2035 new vehicles must be either zero emission or fully compatible with carbon neutral fuels.  Vitesco Technologies believes that in all applications where autonomy is not a major issue, battery electric powertrains will represent the major market share in the light duty segment.  The electric drivetrain will be the mainstream technology for passenger cars. Nevertheless, battery electric powertrain will not cover all applications, there will remain a market share for combustion engines with carbon free fuel, biomass based or E-fuel.  Therefore, Vitesco Technologies does not recommend an ICE ban, but prefers a technology neutral regulation, letting technology progress, cost evolution and end consumer needs drive the market under the boundary condition of climate neutrality.  Fuel Issues despite Mainstream Electrification: Fossil fuel for road transport need to be banned gradually until 2050. Specific applications in heavy-duty transport, but also for some light-duty applications, will be most likely covered by hydrogen and biomass-based fuels, in some cases E-fuels. Also, there is a huge interest to diminish the carbon footprint of the existing fleet.  The public authorities need to support the decarbonization of the automotive fuel supply including the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive (FQD) and the Renewable Energy Directive (RED II).  Consequences on CO2 Emission Targets for 2030:  If in this context it is necessary to tighten the CO2 reduction targets for 2030 in order to meet the overall 2050 target, Vitesco Technologies is prepared for higher shares of electrification and will support the OEMs in the best way.  To avoid bottlenecks within the supply chain and to increase visibility and planning security, Vitesco Technologies would prefer a more gradual path for the introduction of these targets, for example an annual decrease of the fleet targets.  Infrastructure Needs to Support the Transition to Carbon Neutrality: A major roadblock towards a generalization of electrification of passenger cars is the availability of a sufficient number of charging stations and the need to make charging more convenient for the user. This includes international standardization and interoperability of systems. Support for private charging stations, especially in multi-apartment buildings and its parking garages, is needed as well as subsidies for charging stations at the workplace and enough fast charging along major routes.   Measures Concerning Training and Education: The turn-around of the European Automotive industry needs political, financial and educational alignment across Europe. The next generation engineers need worldwide excellence in electrified, electronic and digital science for automotive application to guarantee EU leadership. Key competences in the areas of battery and fuel cells will be urgently needed to ensure that workplaces will stay in Europe. In the short-term public support is needed to retrain the workforce and adapt the skills. This burden cannot be carried by the automotive industry alone. A huge public effort is necessary. It is important that  public funding does not only target the R&D area, but also battery cell technology and production, fuel cell system R&D and manufacturing and competence for components in the electric drivetrain (i.a. e-motor, inverter, battery management systems).
Initiative: CO2 emissions for cars and vans – revision of performance standards

feedback_msg_text: As Gewerkschaft Erziehung und Wissenschaft (GEW) and Verband Bildung und Erziehung (VBE) we support the statement of the European Trade Union Committee for Education (ETUCE), which represents 127 education trade unions within 51 countries in Europe.   We welcome that the European Commission’s initiative contributes to the implementation of the 1st principle of the European Pillar of Social Rights. It is essential to enhance quality and inclusiveness in education in order to fight against early school leaving (ESL) and underachievement in learning. The European Commission should also underline how high quality of education as a public good should be guaranteed to each pupil under this initiative. The EU initiative should not only focus on measurable basic skills (reading, mathematics and science), but rather on key competences, and it should examine what kind of support teachers and education staff have received to include key competences in their teaching since the 2018 Council Recommendation and what additional support they need.   The initiative should motivate governments to set up comprehensive policy measures with effective cooperation among different ministries (education, employment and social affairs, finances, digitalization and innovation, etc) and with the education social partners to effectively fight against ESL and underachievement. We remind that mostly socio-economic disadvantages result in low achievement in schools, thus this problem should be solved with effective government policies not only on education but also on housing, welfare and healthcare. The EU Member States need to ensure sustainable national public investment to education which is an essential prerequisite to fight against ESL and underachievement. We welcome that the European Semester process will provide targeted recommendations to countries to invest to fight against ESL and that EU funds (Erasmus, ESF+, RRF) will further support this.   Democratic governance of education and collaborative leadership in schools are fundamental requirements of high quality education systems to fight against ESL and underachievement. We welcome that the initiative will focus on learning environments which need to be supportive working environments and ensure good working conditions for the teachers. As the initiative foresees reforms on curricula, pedagogies, assessment, etc., it is important that the Commission proposes effective solutions to the Member States on how to prepare teachers for the profession and make the profession attractive.   We request that the initiative also contribute to the implementation of the Council conclusions on European teachers and trainers for  the future (2020). In order to provide quality education for all and to fight effectively against ESL and underachievement, it is essential to ensure better career opportunities, high job security and social protection, decent salary for the teachers and reinforce collective bargaining. Thus, the initiative should recommend to the Member States the essential involvement of education trade unions in the framework of effective social dialogue in designing and implementing necessary educational reforms this policy will entail.    We require that the initiative encourage countries to ensure that every school has education support personnel such as psychologist and education counsellors who can provide targeted support to children with mental disorders, depression and to fight against harassment and bullying. The initiative should also take into account the impact that the use of digital technologies and ICTs in education have on underachievement and ESL. The European Commission should call on the Member States to ensure sustainable public funding to provide all the students with equal access to digital infrastructures and adequate support to integrate in digital education environment. Feedback from: GEW, VBE (137.9 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Pathways to school success – tackling underachievement in basic skills and early leaving from education and training

feedback_msg_text: Muitas escolas públicas e privadas e outras instituições de formação profissional ainda têm barreiras arquitetónicas  ao acesso de pessoas com deficiência. A igualdade no acesso a uma educação de qualidade só pode ser alcançada através de  umsistema de ensino público inclusivo, acessível  a todas as crianças,  adolescentes  e jovens adultos. As crianças, adolescentes e jovens adultos com deficiência têm um maior risco de abandonoescolar. São necessários mais professores de educação especial, mais horas disponíveis para os alunos  e mais assistentes  escolares  nas escolas para garantir a igualdade de acesso à educação. São também necessários recursos técnicos para facilitar a comunicação de  um d acesso à informação e também manuais escolares em leitura fácil,  Braile, tradução de linguagem gestual  e  legendagem em conteúdos de vídeo. Os alunos com deficiência devem ter acesso igual a todas as disciplinas  e cursos como qualquer outro aluno na escola e em formação profissional. As escolas devem ter psicólogos para aceder a problemas de saúde mental e aconselhar escolhas  de carreira de acordo com competências específicas. As competências básicas devem também incluir competências digitais para além da leitura, da matemática e da ciência, para  garantir um leque mais alargado de possíveis escolhas de carreira e garantir uma vida saudável e satisfatória. Pré-escolaridade e uma  avaliação precoce por um discurso therapist é essential para a identificação e abordar  problemas e incapacidades dando aos alunos todos os recursos, terapias e educação especial necessários em cada caso específico. feedback_msg_text: L'uso delle tecnologie multimediali, soprattutto nell'era COVID ha mutato geneticamente il DNA della formazione scolastica; spesso è stato riscontrato come gli insegnanti restavano molto indietro rispetto alla capacità di utilizzo dell'informatica rispetto al corpo docenti, questo ha creato un gap generazionale lento e spesso non recuperabile. L'uso della Intelligenza Artificiale se usato per colmare il ritardo cognitivo e supportare le esigenze sia dei docenti che degli studenti, sarebbe un importante innovazione che potremmo lasciare alla generazioni future , di certo con un miglioramento della stessa tecnologia rendendola più performante. feedback_msg_text: SLOGA, Slovene NGO platform for development, global education and humanitarian aid believes the Recommendation should:  - be aligned with the Sustainable Development Goal 4, especially SDG Target 4.7;  - recognise the interlinkages and complementarity between education for sustainable development (ESD) and other types of transformative education, such as Global citizenship Education (GCED);  - have greater importance on non-formal education and learning;  - acknowledge the importance of lifelong and life-wide learning and training through not only formal, but also non-formal and informal education;   - recognize civil society (non-formal organizations) as equal partners in development and implementation of programmes and policies   - recognize civil society (non-formal organizations) as equal stakeholders in recognition and validation of the competencies;   - reach out beyond focus on awareness raising activities, but should also tackle the root causes of not only environmental crises but economic, health, societal etc. as they are all deeply interlinked;  - seek to build synergies and partnerships with various stakeholders to ensure inclusion of all education providers and learners in the decision making, implementing and evaluating processes;  - support Member States in developing and implementing policies and mechanisms that empower learners with the competences they need to take responsible action for sustainable development and a just society for present and future generations globally;  - encourage Member states to align their educational policies and practices with Agenda 2030, particularly recognising and including the development of educational practices that are built around Global Citizenship Education (GCED) and Education for Sustainable Development (ESD), as outlined in SDG Target 4.7;  - emphasize the importance for Member States to recognise the value of the integration of transformative education as captured by SDG Target 4.7 in educational policies at all levels;  - ensure operational synergies between EU funding programmes and instruments;  - focus on policy coherence with other related EC/EU policies and recommendations.  SLOGA is a platform of non-governmental organizations (NGO), which work in the field of international development cooperation, global education and humanitarian aid. The aim of the platform is to connect and strengthen the partnerships among Slovenian NGOs, which are active in and/or raise awareness of Slovenian and European public about uneven distribution of global wealth and subsequent significance of global solidarity and interdependence.  Main task of SLOGA is to monitor and actively participate in the design, implementation and evaluation of Slovenian and European policies of international development cooperation and humanitarian aid, with the aim of advocating for the public interest on the field of social balance and responsibility, respect of human rights, equal opportunities, education, solidarity, sustainable development and greater inclusion of vulnerable social groups into decision-making processes.  SLOGA Platform is, among others, a member of FORUS, CONCORD, The North South Centre of Council of Europe, SDG Watch Europe and Bridge 47. --> www.sloga-platform.org
Organisation: SLOGA, Slovene NGO Platform for Development, Global Education and Humanitarian Aid

feedback_msg_text: With the development of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals 2030 in 2015, environmental sustainability in education has become one of the most prominently debated topics at all levels of governance. The acceleration of social, economic and cultural transformation in societies, triggered by the COVID-19 crisis, however, has revealed a significant gap when it comes to the motivation and the actual implementation of sustainable approaches. What is problematic about this gap is that it consists not only of an infrastructural deficit but also of a significant discrepancy in sustainable literacy, skills and competences in the educational context, which will be crucial to answer the growing needs of re-thinking societal and economic structures beyond the pandemic through the twin-transition.  Consequently, what is at stake for present and future generations is the mission of educational institutions to provide qualitative education, which not only matches the demands for skills and competences of the labor market but also the moral and cultural Zeitgeist of this new era.  The European Federation of Education Employers (EFEE), representing 60 institutions responsible for management of education systems at all levels of education from 26 countries, is, thus, enthused that the Commission aims to close the identified implementation gap with a Proposal for a Council Recommendation on education for environmental sustainability. Taking also the role as social partners in education, we welcome this initiative as an opportunity to close the identified gap and uphold the quality of lifelong learning across all educational levels for present as well as future generations of learners.  Taking into consideration the substantial role that the education and training sector will play in the success of Europe’s ambitious ecological transition, EFEE invites the European Commission to take its enclosed feedback into consideration to further improve the initiative.  Feedback from: European Federation of Education Employers (EFEE) (181.2 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download
Initiative: Environmental sustainability – education and training

feedback_msg_text: E' necessario prevedere alcune deroghe al Reg. 561/2006 per i viaggi turistici con autobus. E' evidente che il trasporto dei turisti ha delle esigenze completamente diverse dal trasporto merci. Infatti i viaggi turistici sono strutturati con percorrere medie di 300 km al giorno, con poche ore di guida e tanto tempo per le visite ed altre attività, come pranzi/cene. Durante le giornate in cui si effettuano i trasferimenti più lunghi, i passeggeri comunque effettuano delle soste ristoro dopo al massimo di  3 o 4 ore di guida continuativa e nonostante i bus turistici di ultima generazione offrano standard di confort e di sicurezza molto elevati per i passeggeri le soste dopo 3 o 4 ore di guida sono fisiologicamente necessarie e permettono sia ai conducenti che ai passeggeri di rendere il viaggio gradevole e meno stressante.  Pertanto le eventuali deroghe al Reg. 561/2006 non hanno l'obbiettivo di peggiorare le condizioni lavorative dei conducenti e diminuire la sicurezza dei passeggeri, ma hanno lo scopo di regolamentare meglio ed in modo più specifico l'attività di trasporto turistico con autobus, che riveste indiscutibilmente un ruolo importante nel settore del TURISMO.
Initiative: Bus and coach drivers – EU rules on driving and rest times

feedback_msg_text: Vår uppfattning är att dagens kör- och vilotidsregler redan ger mer än tillräcklig flexibilitet för branschens behov och att en utökad flexibilitet direkt skulle motverka målen med förordningen. Arbetsförhållandena i branschen kommer inte att förbättras, utan flexiblare regler kommer tvärtom att ha en negativ påverkan på säkerheten för förare, passagerare och övriga trafikanter. Ett problem i diskussionen om kör- och vilotidsreglerna är att ingen hänsyn tas till bussförarnas totala arbetstid, då endast kör- och vilotider kontrolleras av myndigheterna, inte summan av körtider och övrigt arbete. En bussförare har många andra arbetsuppgifter som alltför ofta förläggs till pauser, raster och vilotider. 75 – 85 % av bussförarna i ETF:s europeiska studie uppger att vilotid som lunchrast, pauser eller delar av dygnsvilan alltid eller ofta måste användas till att ta hand om passagerarnas olika behov och krav. Vilotider och raster inskränks av andra arbetsuppgifter som att sälja biljetter, dryck eller snacks, lasta och lossa bagage, hämta och lämna på hotell, leta efter parkeringsplats och att städa bussen.  Vi delar inte kommissionens problembeskrivning att den viktigaste orsaken till förares stress och trötthet är bristande flexibilitet i reglerna för förläggandet av bussförares arbets- och viloperioder. Det är en synnerligen tveksam slutsats att reglernas krav på pauser och viloperioder skulle orsaka stress och trötthet relaterat till svårigheter att anpassa sig efter passagerarnas behov. Tvärtom visar våra undersökningar att förarna ser att de primära orsakerna till stress och trötthet är otrygga anställningsformer och långa arbetspass, utan tid för återhämtning, i kombination med otillräcklig dygns- och veckovila. Hänvisningen till att 12-dagarsundantaget snedvrider konkurrensen mellan internationell och inrikes trafik är svår att förstå. 12-dagarsundataget är ett direkt tillmötesgående av företagens önskan att i samband med en veckolång, internationell rundtur spara in kostnaden för dubbelbemanning eller lokal inhyrning av extraförare genom att inte erbjuda föraren ordinarie veckovila inom en sjudagarsperiod. Detta behov kan inte föreligga vid inrikestrafik då veckolånga rundturer normalt sett inte begränsas till endast ett enda land och därmed är internationell och omfattas av möjligheten till undantag från kravet på veckovila.  Om det vid en inrikes bussutflykt ändå uppstår ett behov av att en förare tar ut sin veckovila, bör företagen ha goda möjligheter att byta förare.  En besvärande konsekvens av 12-dagarsundantaget är att avsaknaden av veckovilan ofta kombineras med en oroande kort dygnsvila. När turisterna lämnats för dagen måste föraren hitta en parkeringsplats som ofta ligger långt ifrån hotellet, städa bussen, ta sig tillbaka till hotellet för att därefter förbereda nästa dags resa. På morgonen måste naturligtvis föraren ta sig tillbaka till bussen för att finnas på plats hos turisterna i god tid före avresan. En uppskattning pekar på att alla dessa arbetsuppgifter förkortar förarens faktiska dygnsvila till endast 6 timmar per natt.  Denna dödliga kombination av långa arbetspass, kort dygnsvila och utebliven veckovila är enligt förarna orsaken till stress och trötthet. Forskningen visar att trötthet inte kan övervinnas genom motivation, övning, viljestyrka eller åtgärder som att dricka kaffe, småäta eller öppna fönster. Det enda botemedlet mot trötthet är tillräcklig sömn. Den rimliga åtgärden borde därför vara att avskaffa 12-dagarsundantaget, inte utöka omfattningen till inrikestrafik, samt att säkerställa att dygnsvila, rast och pauser befrias från annat arbete istället för att öka kör- och vilotidernas flexibilitet ytterligare.  Målet med initiativet sägs vara att förbättra förarnas arbetsvillkor, även avseende stress och trötthet. De specifika reglerna som föreslås i politiska alternativ 2 -4 skulle inte bidra till att uppnå dessa mål utan snarare förvärra situationen oavsett hur alternativen kombineras. feedback_msg_text: 1. This initial feedback by the General Council of the Bar of England and Wales (the Bar Council) is submitted in response to the European Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment on the Review of the Consumer Credit Directive (2008/48/EC) (the Impact Assessment) .   2. The Bar Council represents approximately 17,000 barristers in England and Wales.  It promotes the Bar’s high quality specialist advocacy and advisory services; fair access to justice for all; the highest standards of ethics, equality and diversity across the profession; and the development of business opportunities for barristers at home and abroad.   The Bar Council is also the Approved Regulator for the Bar of England and Wales. It discharges its regulatory functions through the independent Bar Standards Board (BSB).  A strong and independent Bar exists to serve the public and is crucial to the administration of justice.  3. In summary, we consider that targeted legislative action is justified in this field. Our preliminary views in relation to the specific issues raised are set out below.  Inadequate scope of the existing measure  4. We support the proposal to extend the scope of the Consumer Credit Directive (the CCD) to take account of new operators and new forms of credit, and in particular the proposal to bring credit falling below €200  within the scope of the CCD.  A reduction to the financial threshold for regulation seems sensible: credit below the €200 cap has the potential to cause harm to consumers and can lead to debts significantly in excess of that sum (as exemplified by the UK high-cost short term credit (“pay-day lending”) market).  Moreover, we note that the €200 cap was not implemented in the UK, meaning that the relevant protections already extend to loans below this value, without causing notable difficulties to lenders.   Content and disclosure of information  5. We agree that the information requirements in the CCD are out of step with technological advances and can be difficult for consumers to grasp, not least because the volume of information currently mandated by the CCD can be overwhelming and thus counterproductive. In addition to reducing and simplifying the content of information that must be provided, it seems sensible to pay due regard to context (e.g. the format and timing of information), in line with behavioural science.   Insufficient safeguards to ensure responsible lending/borrowing  6. Article 8 of the CCD is drafted in overly vague terms, making it unlikely to guarantee sufficient levels of consumer protection.  We note that the UK’s domestic credit assessment rules were recently reviewed by the Financial Conduct Authority, which extended them in 2018 to be more prescriptive.  Whilst there have been some concerns expressed by lenders regarding the overly prescriptive nature of these new rules, they do provide more protection for consumers and more certainty for lenders as to what is expected of them.  7.    However, it would not make sense to revise the CCD to be more protective than the Mortgage Credit Directive (the MCD).  Rather than prescribing factors to be taken into account as part of a creditworthiness assessment, the CCD should require Member States to determine the procedures and information on which creditworthiness assessments should be based (in common with the MCD).   Exceptional situations 8. We agree with the points made in the Feedback Response submitted by the Republic of Ireland, which highlights (a) the difficulty in anticipating appropriate regulatory responses; (b) the desirability of a consistent framework, across different related measures, for dealing with crises.   We note too that the Covid-19 outbreak has highlighted a problem that arises when overly prescriptive rules, imposed on lenders, continue to constrain them even in such unforeseen circumstances, leading to potential consumer detriment.
Organisation: General Council of the Bar in England and Wales, Brussels Office
Initiative: Consumer credit agreements – review of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: Consultation on the Inception Impact Assessment of the Waste Shipment Regulation   The Alianza Residuo Cero (Zero Waste Alliance) is an alliance of seven non-governmental organizations from Spain that work together as a national platform to empower communities and change agents to redesign their relationship with resources, adopt smarter lifestyles and sustainable consumption patterns in line with circular resource management. The Alianza Residuo Cero is a member of the Zero Waste Europe platform.  As the Alianza Residuo Cero we welcome the inception impact assessment (IIA) of the WSR stressing the intention to stop exporting waste outside the EU and revisit existing rules. According to the IIA, “International trade in waste has increased considerably. In 2016, four times more waste were traded across international borders than in 1992 and this waste had a value of around 100 billion euro. In 2016, export of waste from the EU to third countries outside the EU amounted to around 40 million tonnes, around 20% of the global export of waste. At the same time, approximately 13 million tonnes of waste were imported into the EU.”  The Circular economy set as a priority for the European Union is about designing waste out of the system. The increase of traded waste is certainly in contradiction with that objective. Additionally, it is irresponsible to delegate our waste management to outside EU countries, notably as there are strong evidences that equivalent standards for environmental sound management are not complied with ( ). Additionally, for receiving countries in Southeast Asia or Africa, the processing of the waste often takes place in an informal way, not complying with the safety guidances, thus leading to adverse social, economic and environmental impact on the surrounding communities ( ).  This lack of ‘level playing field’ also exists in the EU due to noncompliance and significant costs difference. Intensified and more dissuasive enforcement of the policy to stop dumping practices and illegal shipment is thus highly needed.  The EEB and Zero Waste Europe also remind that the objective to ‘simplify and reduce burden of the WSR implementation’ should not only target the burden for businesses, but the overall burden for society, including the enforcement burden and the human health and environmental burden. Furthermore, addressing the issues related to waste shipment is a way to close the circular economy gaps in Europe. While decreasing the pressure and the adverse impacts on the receiving communities, stringent restrictions for waste shipment outside of the EU will also lead to a more robust secondary raw material market by allowing economy of scale, marking the market price more competitive and allowing more job creation. Additionally, it will identify the type of product generating waste with no value in the circular economy, and therefore be phased-out in the long run.  Our main points are:  • Regarding EU waste shipments in general: o Stricter provisions on illegal waste shipments: better enforcement, more inspections o Full transparency and traceability via a harmonised digital system • Regarding extra-EU shipments: o A restriction of hazardous waste export complementing the Basel Convention's update o The ban of waste shipment destined for recovery outside of the EU o The ban of plastic waste export outside of the EU  • Regarding intra-EU waste export: o An application of the waste hierarchy to waste shipments o Better provisions regarding waste shipments destined for disposal (including energy recovery)  We hope you can take our feedback into consideration.   For more information, please contact:  • Daisee Aguilera Fletcher, Coordinator of Alianza Residuo Cero Tel : +34 659 30 45 87     Email : alianzaresiduocero@gmail.com   Formentera, 08 April 2020.   Main members of the Alianza Residuo Cero - Amigos de La Tierra - Ecologistas en Acción  - Retorna - Rezero - Surfriders Feedback from: ALIANZA RESIDUO CERO (267.1 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Waste shipments – revision of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: The Swedish Refrigeration & Heat Pump Association (SKVP) are in general positive towards the proposed initiative to empower the consumer in the green transition. We believe the commission have highlighted several of the important areas were the rights and empowerment could be further improved. Representing manufacturers and installers of green technology, in the form of heat pumps, we believe that it is essential that consumers can feel safe and confident in their decision to invest in green technology. For this to be realized, several of the mentioned issues must be addressed.  We believe that, not only should it be clear what possibilities consumers have to find repair services, but that the consumer must be able to trust that these repairs are professionally done without the fear of the problem resurfacing short after. There is currently a lack of legislation for consumer protection in this area.  We do not fully agree with the full description regarding the pre-failure of products as we also believe that it is important that products can be manufactured with a variety of quality levels to best serve its use case.  Product lifespan depends on several factors, many of them out of the control of the manufacturer. As such, declaring a product lifespan will be subject to such a large margin of error that the declared value will only induce confusion on the consumer level. It will also be unclear what legal status this declared value will have compared to guarantees. We do not think declared lifespans is a viable solution. With that said, we do think it is important that product guarantees better reflect the expected lifespan of different products. This becomes of outmost importance considering energy efficient products which need to operate a certain period of time to motivate, for instance, a higher investment cost.  We do not have a position regarding whether the right way forward is by amending existing consumer protection legislation or by establishing new stand-alone consumer protection instruments. However, as we do see a clear need for action, the baseline will not be acceptable. We do want to point out that the issue of spare parts has been addressed in the ecodesign revisions and that this must be considered during the upcoming process. Feedback from: Swedish Refrigeration & Heat Pump Association (75.8 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Consumer policy – strengthening the role of consumers in the green transition

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the European Commission’s initiative to prevent greenwashing and early obsolescence through empowering consumers. Consumer legislation should support the objective “to make sustainable goods, services and business models the norm”. The overall focus must be on removing unsustainable products from the EU market, in the same spirit of ecodesign regulation. Providing adequate and easily verifiable information to consumers can help make longer-lasting products the norm, but the burden to choose sustainable products shouldn't be placed on consumers.  Out of the options presented, option 2, a new dedicated regulatory instrument, would be the most appropriate to achieve this objective. The role of the EU is important, as it can also help inform regulations in other countries beyond member states.   Our work focuses on promoting repair and supporting community repair initiatives. We therefore suggest that this initiative directly address the need for better information on products' repairability. Key aspects should include:  - Ensuring that the information on products' repairability is available to consumers at the time of purchase, easy to understand and compare. Notably, this includes the provision of an EU-wide mandatory A-G repairability score on EU’s Energy Labels, building from the French repairability score index.   - Information on repairability should include unrestricted and free access to repair and maintenance information, as well as the provision of free-access diagnostic tools to all market participants including both independent professional repairers and community repair groups. This is critical to developing a thriving repair economy in Europe: community repair activities, such as repair cafes and similar initiatives, have a unique and essential role, complementing commercial repair options for small appliances and extending product lifetimes. Therefore they need complete access to repair information, spare parts and tools.  - Mandatory product-specific provisions should be developed in addition to information requirements, for products not yet covered by ecodesign regulations. These should include the introduction of ease of disassembly requirements to replace key parts, unrestricted and free access to repair and maintenance information as well as to spare parts and diagnostic tools to all market participants.  - Software locks preventing third-party repair should not be allowed.  - New horizontal rights on the mandatory minimum period of time for the availability of spare parts (minimum 10 years after the placing on the market of the last product) as well as the maximum time-limit for spare part delivery (maximum 5-7 working days) should be introduced.   - Software and security updates should be available for the entire expected lifetime of a device to both consumers and independent repairers. The case of smartphones is important, and telling for the increasing range of connected products: 40% of all current users of Android smartphones worldwide no longer receive security updates for their products. Smartphone manufacturers prefer to release new products, rather than extending software support for existing products. Regulation should set  minimum requirements for software updates - for example 5 years after placing the last unit of a product on the market. Better information would help consumers choose products considering whether manufacturers provide 5 years or more of support.   - Finally, the high cost of repairing should be addressed, by placing a cap on the maximum price of spare parts, in relation to the overall price of the product,  as well as reducing VAT charged for repair services. Consumers should also be informed about availability of all kinds of spare parts, including refurbished and third-party parts
Initiative: Consumer policy – strengthening the role of consumers in the green transition

feedback_msg_text: Je suis tourneuse sur bois.   Je fais parti des 38 000 entreprises métiers d'art du territoire français qui génèrent un chiffre d'affaire global de 8 milliards d'euros par an et représente 60000 emplois (source info Institut National des Métiers d’Art).   Je pratique le métier dans un esprit d'économie durable : la matière première que j’utilise, le bois, est par nature durable et renouvelable, ancrée dans mon territoire, souvent approvisionnée de façon éco responsable, mes circuits de distribution sont la plupart du temps des circuits courts, respectueux de l'environnement. Par son caractère unique et faite-main, ma production a vocation à être durable.   De part les caractéristiques de notre métier et surtout de la manière dont nous le pratiquons, la directive européenne 1935/2004 est difficile à appliquer en l’état. Nous nous appuyons aussi sur la note d’information 2012/93 Française de la DGCCRF.   La preuve par la conformité des matières premières utilisées et le principe des bonnes pratiques de fabrication qui sont la règle dans nos ateliers ont permis de nous approcher au plus près de la réglementation.   Le principe de créativité de nos ateliers artisanaux, reconnu dans la loi française (article 22 de la loi Artisanat, Commerce et TPE du 18 juin 2014) fait que chaque pièce sortie de notre atelier est une pièce unique. Et sachant que ce sont des petites productions, il n’est pas réaliste de faire analyser chaque pièce qui devra être ensuite détruite puisque c'est le protocole. Il ne peut en effet y avoir de notion de lots dans notre processus de fabrication tel que c’est envisagé dans cette révision (échantillonnage d’une ou plusieurs pièces pour valider un lot).   La conformité sur l'article final sera donc tout à fait impossible à appliquer pour nos entreprises artisanales puisqu’elle conduirait à détruire chaque pièce produite. Nous demandons une prise en compte de cette spécificité, d’autant que cette révision étant censée faciliter la vie des petites entreprises, l’orientation évoquée ne va pas du tout dans ce sens.   Compte tenu des disparités sur les essences autorisées d’un pays à l’autre, et pour éviter un nivellement par le bas porté par les grandes industries de l’emballage qui n’utilisent que quelques essences (chêne, peuplier, hêtre, …) au détriment de toutes les essences locales et moins répandues, il serait donc au contraire souhaitable qu’un programme ambitieux porté par la Commission valide l’utilisation d’autres essences reflétant la diversité des pratiques des pays membres, afin de valoriser au mieux des ressources locales toujours dans l’esprit de ce Green Deal.
Initiative: Revision of EU rules on food contact materials

feedback_msg_text: Our customers make our small businesses live thanks to their purchases. They expect the same level of safety from all ceramics, whether “industrial” or “craft”: introducing doubt in the level of safety legally required will kill our small businesses because customers wouldn’t purchase a ceramic FCM that can only be safely used occasionally by non-pregnant adults (as some previous feedback suggests). Hence while the small businesses specifics must be accounted for, only the MEANS to achieve the expected level of safety shall differ between small and large businesses.  Therefore I fully support the Commission decision to reconsider the current FCM regulations, because as a one-man ceramic art business I agree with your analysis that they are financially and practically impossible to meet in full for very small businesses.   Please find in the attachment some practical suggestions to meet some of the objectives you have set. Feedback from: Vincent Denoual - Céramiste (130.1 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Objet : Modèle de contribution individuelle à la consultation publique dans le cadre de la révision des règles de l’Union européenne sur les matériaux destinés à entrer en contact avec des denrées alimentaires.   Madame, Monsieur,   Je suis céramiste exerçant mon métier en France à titre professionnel en entreprise individuelle depuis 7 années.  Mon atelier d’art fait partie des 38 000 entreprises du secteur des métiers d’art en France, générant un chiffre d’affaire global de 8 milliards d'euros et représentant 60 000 emplois.   En qualité de céramiste professionnelle des métiers d’art, je suis détentrice d’un savoir-faire traditionnel et m’inscris dans une démarche de création et d’innovation perpétuelles. Comme beaucoup de mes collègues, j’utilise des matières premières locales. Mes créations et collections sont destinées à des marchés de niche, fabriquées en pièces uniques ou très petites séries. Mes créations sont destinées à être durables et transmises aux générations futures, à l’inverse de la logique de production et consommation de masse, et d’obsolescence programmée. Avec en moyenne 500 pièces fabriquées par an, ma consommation énergétique comme mon empreinte carbone restent faibles.  Depuis que j’exerce mon métier, j’ai toujours été très attentive à adopter les bonnes pratiques et respecter la réglementation en vigueur me permettant de créer, fabriquer et vendre au public les pièces issues de mon atelier.   De par les caractéristiques de mon métier et la manière dont je l’exerce, certaines réglementations, notamment le règlement 1935/2004 CE, sont complexes à mettre en œuvre pour mon atelier d’art. La preuve par la conformité des matières premières utilisées et le principe des bonnes pratiques de fabrication permettent néanmoins à nos ateliers d’art de se rapprocher au plus près de la réglementation en vigueur.  Cependant le projet actuel de révision de la réglementation au sein de l’UE, qui propose de reporter la preuve de la conformité sur le produit fini et non plus sur les substances qui le composent, est totalement inadapté à la réalité du travail des professionnels de métiers d’art dont je fais partie.  Si cette dernière voie venait à être suivie, cela aurait de grandes implications pour nos ateliers qui seront dans l’impossibilité d’effectuer des tests et analyses pour chaque pièce créé et mise en vente par l’atelier.    En effet, nos métiers d’art s’inscrivent dans une démarche de création artistique, reconnue par la loi française du 18 juin 2014, qui confère à chaque pièce issue de nos ateliers un caractère unique, réalisée en pièce unique ou à l’unité au sein d’une petite série.  Il est dès lors impossible de procéder, comme l’envisage le texte, à une analyse de chaque pièce qui devra ensuite être détruite en application du protocole.   Au-delà de l’incohérence et de l’impossibilité techniques, ce projet de révision créé au sein de notre communauté des métiers d’art un grand désarroi face à cette non prise en compte des spécificités de notre secteur créatif, innovant, laboratoire de création à l’échelle du pays, composé à 85% d’entreprises unipersonnelles et 15% de petites entreprises et manufactures d’art.  Alors que nos ateliers sont des acteurs à part entière d’une économie durable, qu’ils sont porteurs de valeurs dans ce monde perturbé, il s’agit au contraire aujourd’hui de contribuer à assurer la survie et le développement d’un secteur d’avenir, source de création d’emplois durables non délocalisables, et qui participe fortement à l’identité culturelle et à l’attractivité du pays dans lequel ils sont ancrés.   C’est pourquoi nous souhaitons que soient prises en compte les spécificités des ateliers d’art. Nous attendons de l’Union européenne un cadre de réglementation réaliste, adapté et respectueux de nos métiers qui contribuent à la richesse économique et culturelle du patrimoine européen.    Cordialement  Charline Meyer
Initiative: Revision of EU rules on food contact materials

feedback_msg_text: Madame, Monsieur  Je suis tourneur sur bois, installé en France, professionnel depuis 16 ans, et membre du conseil d'administration de l'Association Française pour le Tournage d'Art sur Bois dont j'ai été président de 2010 à 2018. Je crée majoritairement des pièces uniques ou de très petites séries, que j'exporte dans le monde entier (plus de 50% hors UE, et environ 45% en UE hors France). Mes créations sont artistiques et également utilitaires. Dans cette dernière catégorie, je m'attache à n'utiliser que des essences autorisées par la règlementation française pour usage alimentaire (le chêne) et des produits de finition homologués. Je maintiens une parfaite traçabilité, de l'arbre jusqu'à l'objet fini. De part mes créations manuelles, et uniques, la notion de lot ou de série n'a pas de sens. Même s'il m'arrive de faire plusieurs pièces dans un même arbre, chacune est une création propre, une création unique par sa forme, ses dimensions. Ainsi, la révision envisagée sur les FCM, en mettant l'accent sur l'objet final au lieu de considerer les bonnes pratiques et les éléments de matière premiere autorisés, rendra impossible cette production pour moi: chaque pièce étant unique, un test de conformité sur l'objet final, qui est par nature destructeur, reviendra à détruire 100% de ma production. Cela n'est donc pas acceptable Je me fais aussi le porte parole de mes collègues tourneurs sur bois qui font également de l'utilitaire. Nous avons tous la même problématique. Alors que nous utilisons par principe une matière renouvelable, majoritairement locale, avec une attention sur nos créations qui la place par principe dans une durabilité vis a vis de nos clients, donc s'inscrivant pleinement dans la démarche "farm to fork" de l'UE , la révision telle qu'elle est envisagée nous empechera d'exercer notre métier d'artisans créateurs, laissant la place aux grandes entreprises qui importent des bols manufacturés de provenance étrangère, fabriqués industriellement, avec des bois d'origine parfois douteuse, sans aucun caractère, sans personnalité. Puisque la révision a pour objectif de faciliter la vie des SME, elle doit prendre en compte nos spécificités par une reglementation adaptée. Un autre point concerne la liste des essences de bois autorisées: celle-ci est tres variable par pays, avec certains pays qui ont une liste, d'autres non, et les pays ayant une liste n'ont pas tous les mêmes essences. Ainsi il y a une distorsion et une complexité d'accès au marché européen par difficulté d'accès aux informations locales et des autorisations parfois contradictoires. La revision de la directive MCDA devrait s'attacher à créer une liste élargie des essences autorisée, prenant en compte les spécificités nationales et les incluant à l'échelle européenne. Cela permettra de favoriser la diversité qui encore une fois differencie les artisans des produits fabriqués industriellement dans 2 ou 3 essences très limitées. Je suis à votre disposition pour échanger sur ce sujet, et ai deja pris contact avec mes homologues tourneurs européens afin de rassembler les éléments qui pourront alimenter votre reflexion. Cordialement Pascal Oudet membre d'Ateliers d'Art de France et de l'Association Française pour le Tournage d'Art sur Bois  (AFTAB) Ancien président de l'AFTAB
Initiative: Revision of EU rules on food contact materials

feedback_msg_text: La alimentación forzada contraviene las directivas y normas europeas en materia de  bienestar animal en las que se exige una alimentación adecuada para evitar sufrimiento a los animales, como se indica en el Anexo 14:  El Reglamento (CE) 543/2008 establece en 300 gramos en el caso de los patos y en 400 gramos en las ocas el peso mínimo de los hígados para que el producto pueda denominarse foiegras. Un peso cinco veces mayor que un hígado de pato sano, solo puede conseguirse mediante alimentación forzada.  En 2012, gracias a una denuncia interpuesta con las imágenes obtenidas por Igualdad Animal, el Gobierno Vasco ordenó la paralización cautelar de la actividad de sacrificio y producción a la granja Momotegui de producción de foie gras, abriéndose un expediente sancionador a la empresa propietaria de Mugaritz, el tercer mejor restaurante del mundo.  Existen normas mínimas de la Unión para la protección de cerdos, terneros, gallinas ponedoras y pollos de engorde,  pero todavía no existe ninguna reglamentación específica con normas mínimas para la protección de los conejos.  Los conejos criados jaulas en batería, padecen graves consecuencias de bienestar animal, debido al espacio mínimo del que disponen, que impide su comportamiento natural, como el suelo de rejilla, la densidad de las jaulas y la altura de la misma, que impide incluso que los conejos adopten posturas naturales, como sentarse, estirarse enderezarse y sus orejas erguidas.   En enero de 2020, la Autoridad Europea de Seguridad Alimentaria (EFSA) presentó un informe identificando problemas serios de bienestar en las granjas de conejos españolas, concluyendo que el principal problema que sufren estos animales es la restricción de movimientos a causa del pequeño tamaño de la jaulas, y reclama que estas jaulas convencionales sean ampliadas y mejoradas.  Igualdad Animal en España presentado 72 denuncias en las que acreditamos prácticas tales como:  Operarios que matan a los conejos estampándoles contra el suelo.Conejos arrojados vivos a los contenedores. Animales con heridas abiertas e infecciones sin recibir ningún tipo de atención veterinaria. Animales muertos en estado de putrefacción dentro de las jaulas. Una Veterinaria estampando a un conejo contra el suelo reconociendo que es maltrato animal.  Además, es necesario aturdir a los conejos por completo antes de proceder al sacrificio, sin riesgo de que el animal aturdido recobre la consciencia.  Directiva 1999/74/CE por la que se establecen las normas mínimas de protección de las gallinas ponedoras   Los sistemas de cría de gallinas en jaula no pueden asegurar el bienestar de estos animales. El 82% de los huevos producidos en España provienen de gallinas que viven toda su vida enjauladas. Son mantenidas en condiciones de hacinamiento extremo, en jaulas en las que no pueden desarrollar su comportamiento natural, como darse un baño de arena o picotear. Debido a las condiciones de explotación a las que son sometidas, 1 de cada 6 gallinas morirá en la jaula.  Existe además un vacío legal en el etiquetado de los huevos procedentes de los sistemas de cría de gallinas denominados combi, cría en jaula con posibilidad de acceso al exterior a decisión del productor, que pueden llevar a confusión al consumidor preocupado por el bienestar animal. Dicho vacío requiere que la Comisión aclare que los huevos procedentes de sistemas combi corresponden a una catalogación de huevos tipo 3.  Se solicita se tenga por presentado este escrito, y consideradas las propuesta de modificación de las directivas y reglamentos que actualmente permiten la alimentación forzada, las jaulas de gallinas ponedoras y las jaulas de conejos, presentando propuestas legislativas sobre el establecimiento de normas mínimas para la protección de los conejos de cría; dándose traslado a esta parte de la decisión tomada al respecto. Feedback from: FUNDACIÓN IGUALDAD ANIMAL (133 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Animal welfare – evaluation of EU rules (fitness check)

feedback_msg_text: La Fondation Droit Animal, Éthique et Sciences se réjouit que la Commission européenne engage une évaluation de l’efficacité des normes de l’UE en matière de bien-être animal. L’amélioration de la condition des animaux d’élevage est une attente sociétale forte, comme en atteste l’Eurobaromètre de 2015 : 94% des Européens estiment qu'il est important de protéger le bien-être des animaux d'élevage et 82% pensent que le bien-être des animaux d’élevage devrait être mieux protégé. La législation européenne concernant la protection des animaux n’est pas optimale et nécessite une révision pour être améliorée en tenant compte des dernières découvertes scientifiques. Règlement transport : • De nombreuses dispositions sont inapplicables, et notamment l’incohérence entre ce règlement et celui sur les temps de conduite, de pause et de repos. • Les temps de trajets autorisés parfois très longs entrainent de sérieux problèmes de bien-être animal. • Il manque une harmonisation dans le système de sanctions entre les États membres. • Il manque des dispositions spécifiques aux espèces aquacoles, ainsi qu’aux animaux d’espèces sauvages. Règlement abattage : • L’abattage sans étourdissement est autorisé sous dérogation malgré les souffrances physiques et psychologiques pour les animaux. • Des méthodes d’abattage source de souffrances évitables sont toujours autorisées. • Les poissons ne sont pas concernés par l’obligation d’étourdissement préalable à la mise à mort et il n’y a pas de dispositions particulières concernant les méthodes de mise à mort des espèces aquacoles. Directive animaux d’élevage : • Les dispositions sont trop générales et ne permettent pas d’assurer la protection du bien-être des animaux qui ne font pas l’objet d’une directive spécifique : dindes, chèvres, moutons, poissons (nombreuses espèces différentes), vaches laitières, bovins d’engraissement, lapins, canards et oies. • Concernant le commerce international, l’UE autorise l’importation d’animaux ou de produits d’origine animale ayant subi des conditions d’élevage, de transport ou d’abattage inférieures aux normes de l’UE. Directive poules pondeuses : • Les poulettes et les parentaux sont exclus du champ d’application de la directive. • Les cages aménagées sont autorisées pour l’élevage des poules pondeuses alors qu’elles sont en contradiction avec le bien-être animal. • Des mutilations sont toujours possibles sous conditions : la coupe des becs par exemple. Directive poulets de chair : • Les parentaux sont exclus du champ d’application de la directive. • La directive autorise l’utilisation de souches de poulet à croissance rapide, qui contribuent pourtant au mal-être des animaux. • Il n’y a pas de dispositions particulières concernant l’enrichissement du milieu, la lumière naturelle ou encore l’accès à l’extérieur. • Des dérogations sont possibles pour permettre une densité encore plus élevée que la densité maximale prévue par la directive. Directive veaux : • L’élevage des veaux en case individuelle est autorisé pendant les 2 premiers mois, malgré les preuves scientifiques de l’altération du bien-être de l’animal. • L’écornage est autorisé sans prise en charge de la douleur alors que cette pratique est douloureuse pour l’animal, même au stade précoce de développement des cornes. Directive porcs : • La directive fait preuve d’incohérence entre l’interdiction de la caudectomie de façon routinière et les densités et conditions d’élevage autorisées. La coupe des queues est donc toujours pratiquée de manière routinière par une majorité d’élevages. • Les cases de gestation et de maternité vont à l’encontre des données scientifiques en matière de bien-être des truies. • Des mutilations, sources de souffrances évitables, sont autorisées sans prise en charge de la douleur : castration à vif, coupe ou meulage des dents, caudectomie. • La plupart des cochons n’ont pas accès à un extérieur enrichi leur permettant de réaliser leurs comportements naturels (ex : fouissage). Feedback from: La Fondation Droit Animal, Ethique et Sciences (LFDA) (136.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Organisation: La Fondation Droit Animal, Ethique et Sciences (LFDA)
Initiative: Animal welfare – evaluation of EU rules (fitness check)

feedback_msg_text: Compassion in World Farming Poland sees the Fitness Check of EU legislation on the welfare of farmed animals as very needed and asks here for urgent enforcement/strengthening of existing legislation but also some new legislative proposals that would improve animal welfare. Animals continue to suffer immensely during their miserable lives on farms and during transportation which has been exposed to public eye during last years many, many times due repetitive investigations, also in Poland. Farmed animals are still kept mostly in cages though it is 2020, not to mention mutilations they go during breeding though it has been banned years ago by the UE (i.e. routine tail-docking which still happens on many farms in Poland). Transport of live animals, mentioned above, is also a visible issue, as regulatory requirements of the Regulation 1/2005 clearly fail on that - repetitively in Poland we hear and see problems with vehicles, overcrowded and not properly adapted trucks. Especially during Covid19-crisis it was easy to see - queues of even 65 km long with blocked trucks with live animals in those on the Polish borders. Fish welfare is another forgotten topic amongst animal welfare issues, yet last two decades brought us many scientific evidences that fish feel and may suffer the exact same way as other farmed animals do. Yet in Poland (but also in Czechia, some parts of Germany and Hungary as well) it is still allowed to keep in small, ridiculous tanks in supermarkets and to sell then live carps before Christmas time. These sentient animals after hours and days spent in these unnatural conditions (supermarkets' bright lights, too high temperature etc.) are sold to customers who take them home and put for another long hours into a bathtub or a bowl of water before slaughtered at home. Such practices should be banned on the EU level.  What we face is on one hand failure of the current animal protection legislation, yet we clearly see that European citizens want and demand from the European bodies more. In 2020 and we stand now with a lot of established animal welfare science and the numbers speak for themselves when we think of 94% of EU citizens who think protecting the welfare of farm animals is important, according to the last Eurobarometer survey and these European citizens spoke loud and clear by giving their over 1,5 million signatures on the proposed ban on all cage farming in EU by the European Citizens’ Initiative called significant "End the Cage Age". Furthermore world's most well-known and established scientific institutions call on the immediate cut down on meat products as we, humans, facing now the climate crisis, economic crisis and pandemic crisis, can not continue business as usual and therefore our way of farming and breeding and keeping farmed animals simply must change.  What EU countries need is firstly the enforcement of existing laws but also revision and strengthening of Directive 98/58 on the welfare of farmed animals to include specific provision to phase out of all cages in EU animal agriculture. Cages must be sent to the history as soon as possible. This is the priority.   Furthermore EU still lacks and fails on the needed new species-specific legislation, including here dairy cows, rabbits, fish, broiler breeders and quail.  Since years European citizens await the ban on live transports and exports is another one. Several initiatives, petitions and projects have been proposed to the EU bodies over last years, yet so far without any decisions from their side. The ban here is a must.  Europe also needs to set up clear and strong targets for reduction (both production and consumption) of animal products.   Policymakers must look carefully at the current animal welfare legislation and we hope that the Fitness Check along with F2F strategy  will bring needed changes.
Submitted by: Fundacja Compassion in World Farming Polska Fundacja
Initiative: Animal welfare – evaluation of EU rules (fitness check)

feedback_msg_text: General remarks  Tesla welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to revise Directive 2014/94/EU on the deployment of alternative fuel infrastructure (AFID) in line with the objective to make the EU climate-neutral by 2050, for which rapid uptake of zero-emission vehicles is a key cornerstone. Such revision is particularly welcomed and needed in light of the last six years of innovative developments in electric vehicles and charging services, technologies and related business models, and ever-growing charging coverage needs.   Although the AFID has in some areas contributed to Europe-wide alignment of emobility services, much remains to be done: charger coverage is still fragmented and inadequate, making cross-border EV journeys too complex, and it is too hard for private players to design viable business models.   Tesla agrees with most of the identified problems in the Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment (IIA) and supports the objectives of ensuring a seamless charging access all over Europe. However, we believe that the IIA should identify the challenges to be prioritised based on their true impact on EV adoption among European drivers in the near term. Indeed, new rules may risk generating extra costs for operators and limiting innovation and private initiative.  Recommendations  Tesla suggests adding the following points for assessment in the context of the AFID revision:  - Assess the possibility of turning the Directive into a Regulation; - Include analysis of mandatory targets for the rollout of charging points - based on both quantitative and qualitative metrics that take into account the need of the national EV fleet as well as the need for a cross-border base network for international travellers; - Work on the definition of public chargers based on accessibility to make it explicitly possible for businesses to offer charging as a service exclusive to their customers. Currently, some Member States have an excessive definition of what is “publicly accessible “. This means e.g. hotel or restaurant owners who want to offer charging services to customers have no other choice than to offer them as a public charging point, and most of them subsequently decide not to proceed. Indeed, with accessibility to the public comes a set of requirements on access, operation and interoperability that creates additional burden and costs. There are many missed opportunities here; - When it comes to problems 3 and 4, provide an in-depth analysis of the status quo (i.e. is it really a widespread and urgent problem for which the private sector is not already providing solutions?), the consequences on EV adoption (i.e. does it really slows down consumer adoption?) and the energy system (i.e. is it truly at risk?) in order to evaluate their adequacy, and the need for regulation versus potential impact on innovation and private investment in the next 5 years. - Run a cost-benefit analysis of all new considered policy tools, focusing on the impact on customer experience, innovation and business models for private players – whether commercially interested in providing charging services or not. - Focus specifically on zero emission heavy-duty vehicles, notably on grid reinforcement and charger installation needs of resting area, depots, distribution/delivery centers and logistic hubs (E.g. access and level of power ) to support the growth of clean truck fleets across Europe.  - Assess adoption of a High Power Charging for Commercial Vehicle plug standard, based on CharIn current work, for trucks and busses beyond 1 MW. - Assess fire safety requirements in Member States underground parking and depots and the current fragmented local regulations, so that the rollout of charge points is not hampered by inconsistent rules.
Initiative: Low-emission vehicles – improving the EU’s refuelling/recharging infrastructure

feedback_msg_text: Nelfo represents the electrical contractors in Norway.   As member of the EuropeOn, representing the European electrical contracting sector, we welcomes the review of the AFID – directive, and supports the full decarbonization of the transport sector in view of climate neutrality objectives, through electrification as the most efficient pathway to clean mobility. Electrical contractors represent the companies carrying out electrical works and installations, including on electro-mobility infrastructure such as charging points.   Addressing the rising emissions of transport in due time entails a shift to zero-emissions mobility where possible. Renewable-based direct electrification should be preferred in order to harness the highest energy efficiency levels available. Additionally, electro-mobility has positive externalities such as cleaner air, as e-mobility means zero-emission mobility, and energy security as oil imports will dwindle.   Economic & Social Impacts   The Green Deal has rightfully been presented as a growth strategy for the EU and the shift to a green and sustainable transport sector fits this intention. Indeed, the move to e-mobility will lead to net job creation, more than offsetting potential job losses in fossil mobility. Over half new jobs in e-mobility will be in operation and maintenance of charging infrastructure, and these are local, green and skilled jobs, most often provided by SMEs.   There is undoubtedly a strong growth potential with e-mobility, and especially in relation to the deployment of charging infrastructure. It is, however, paramount that deployment targets are accompanied by re- and up-skilling strategies and lifelong learning opportunities to ensure the availability of qualified personnel.  AFID  Loose instruments such as the National Policy Frameworks are not conducive to the needed shift in the transport sector. Binding targets for infrastructure deployment are urgently needed, especially as e-mobility now are ready to be mainstream and the preferred choise.   Since 2014, new solutions are available or in development. The shipping sector can already now benefit from shore-side power, to curb in-port emissions and air quality, or fully electric propulsion for short-sea shipping, as developed in the H2020 ‘E-Ferry’ project. Indeed, the Green Deal specifically envisages to “oblige docked ships to use shore-side electricity”. And heavy-duty road transport will soon be electrified thanks to battery-electric trucks, electric roads and dynamic charging. Future-proofing the revised AFID means taking into account and incentivizing these new zero-emission technologies.   The ‘right to plug’ needs bolstering as approval procedures to install a charger can still last up to a full year and come on top of unreasonable costs for building or grid connection upgrades. Smart charging can help overcome capacity shortcomings, and enable energy services, but funding and support is needed for potential EV users. In such cases, deep integrated renovations are needed, for which support is lacking, and synergies with the “Renovation Wave” should be sought. Better communication frameworks with grid operators, including regulated approval procedures and available grid information, are needed to streamline the installation process.   Energy services, with smart charging and vehicle-to-grid, will only be enabled in a competitive way if an appropriate data sharing framework is established, empowering the user to sell its data on the basis of market opportunities.  About Nelfo and EuropeOn:  Nelfo represents the electrical contractors in Norway. www.nelfo.no EuropeOn is the European voice of the electrical contracting industry. www.europe-on.org
Initiative: Low-emission vehicles – improving the EU’s refuelling/recharging infrastructure

feedback_msg_text: L’UE ne doit plus consentir des contingents d’importation à droit nul pour des produits tropicaux tels que les sucres spéciaux de canne, sans analyse préalable de l’impact de ses concessions commerciales sur les productions communautaires équivalentes, qui n’existent que dans les RUP.   Aujourd’hui, compte tenu des concessions importantes et récentes accordées à de nouveaux pays tiers sur le marché des sucres spéciaux (ACP-PMA, Vietnam…), la Commission européenne doit impérativement mettre en application le concept d’« enveloppe globale » (définition d’un volume maximal de concessions à accorder – ou encore taux d’ouverture maximal du marché - par produit en Europe, pour tous les accords, en prenant en compte les concessions déjà accordées).   Le marché européen des sucres spéciaux est aujourd’hui ouvert à plus de 70% aux pays tiers, tendance qui va en s’amplifiant. Il est indispensable désormais de fixer une règle s’agissant de l’ouverture maximale aux pays tiers de ce marché, qui constitue un des principaux débouchés des filières ultramarines. Compte tenu de la situation actuelle, aucune concession ne devrait être accordée sur le marché des sucres spéciaux. En ce qui concerne les accords en vigueur, ceux-ci devraient respecter les règles de proportionnalité des marchés des sucres, à savoir la concession accordée sur le marché des sucres spéciaux ne devrait pas dépasser 1.5% de la concession accordée pour les autres sucres.   Cette règle est d’autant plus nécessaire et légitime que les DOM ont la capacité et doivent augmenter leur production de sucres spéciaux par rapport à ce qu’ils réalisent aujourd’hui.   En effet, suite à la fin des quotas sucriers et l’ouverture du marché européen du sucre, accroitre notre production de sucre spéciaux semble actuellement primordial pour rester compétitif et leader sur ce marché. De ce fait, la question de notre capacité à accéder au marché européen est encore plus cruciale qu’elle ne l’a été par le passé.  La Commission européenne doit mettre sa politique commerciale extérieure en harmonie avec sa politique intérieure et arrêter, par exemple, d’accorder des contingents d’importation de sucres spéciaux à des pays tiers avec lesquels nos régions ultramarines ne peuvent lutter à armes égales.  Aujourd’hui, les DOM seraient en capacité d’approvisionner plus de 45% du marché européen continental. Cet objectif ne saurait être atteint si l’Europe continue à maintenir l’accès sans droits et sans contingents à son marché du sucre.  Dans le cadre de la révision de l’accord Amérique Centrale-UE, les principes et termes ayant conduit à l’ouverture du marché européen sans droits, ni taxes et sans prise en compte des équilibres des différents marchés ne sauraient être maintenus.   La mise en place de contingents spécifiques et relatifs au marché des sucres spéciaux (1,5% du marché européen du sucre) est indispensable pour le rétablissement des règles d’équité et le maintien des équilibres au sein de ce marché. Pour ce faire, la Commission Européenne devra tenir compte du marché européen actuel déjà saturé et de la réalité des volumes de sucres spéciaux aujourd’hui exportés par ces pays. Cela permettra d’éviter dans le futur un effet d’aubaine et une augmentation déstabilisante des exportations de ces pays vers l’Europe.
