feedback_msg_text: The Association of European Banana Producers (APEB) believes that in order to assess the economic impact of Trade Agreements, it is necessary to consider the entire EU trade policy which has, in recent years, significantly eroded the benefits generated by the European banana sector. Their situation could be further deteriorated by the disappearance of custom tariffs applied to Latin American producers in the coming years.  Market condition Bananas play a crucial role in the economy of European Outermost Regions (ORs) and are instrumental to job and wealth creation, providing more than 17 000 direct jobs and over 20 000 indirect ones. Also, the EU is the only market outlet for ORs while Latin American bananas are also exported to the USA and Asia. In 2016, 69.6% of all bananas sold in the EU market came from Latin American countries, the remainder being split between the ORs (11.3%) and ACP countries (19.1%). As of the end of 2018, the EU market share of bananas from Latin America had risen to 75.7% while the share of ACP bananas dropped to 16% and to 8.3% for bananas from the ORs. As a consequence, ORs have experienced a fall of 11% between 2016 and 2018 while Latin American countries have enjoyed an increase of 4.5% of their already dominant market share. The massive increase in exports from Latin America have in turn significantly depressed wholesale prices, to around 15 to 20%, once corrected for inflation. This drop is generating an oversupply crisis and harming ORs’ operators.  Tariff cuts The domineering Latin American competition is further exacerbated by tariff concessions. It is therefore essential to rethink the tariff regime to enable EU and African producers to maintain their access to the market. It is estimated that Latin American producers have enjoyed cumulated savings of 2 bn € on custom duties. These trade agreements are therefore disproportionately favourable to Latin American producers, who have captured all the growth opportunities and capital gains of the EU banana market and might very soon drive EU and ACP producers out of their domestic/traditional markets. Given the current dire situation, it is safe to assume that, if bilateral negotiations between the European Commission and Latin American countries were to lead to a reduction in tariffs below the current 75€/t for third countries, the market will continue to be destabilized and European productions would inevitably be jeopardized.  Stabilisation Mechanism for Bananas This mechanism allows the European Commission, in the event of a third country exceeding its preferential tariff ceiling, to restore MFN tariffs (114€/t since 2017), on exports from such countries for a period not exceeding three months. The weakness of the sanctions available in case of a lowering of prices in green on the market does not allow for a quick recovery of the EU market, even if the mechanism was to be automatically and immediately implemented. But that is also not the case, as the Commission may decide upon review not to trigger the mechanism. Not a single threshold overrun observed to this day has led to trigger the mechanism, as the Commission has continuously determined that they do not have a significant impact on prices. However, if such an impact was to be determined, the mechanism would not in any case reverse the situation. It follows that in the event of a drop in the green price, this mechanism will not prevent the eviction of European banana producers from their own market.  Conclusions - recommendations For all these reasons, APEB recommends: - To “ring-fence” custom duties to the current 75€/t; - To replace the existing nonfunctional stabilisation mechanism by a market-regulation mechanism for bananas, to allow for continued access to this market for ACP countries and Outermost regions’ operators; - To reinforce food safety standards by requiring the same phytosanitary conditions for all banana imports in the EU. Initiative: Trade with 6 Central American countries – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: We:  The Law Society of England & Wales is the independent professional body for solicitors in England and Wales. We are run by and for our members. Our role is to be the voice of solicitors, to drive excellence in the profession and to safeguard the rule of law. On behalf of the profession, we influence the legislative and regulatory environment in the public interest. At home we promote the profession and the vital role legal services play in our economy. Around the world we promote England and Wales as a global legal centre, open new markets for our members and defend human rights.  The Law Society of Scotland is the professional body for over 12,000 Scottish solicitors and was established in 1949. We have an overarching objective of leading legal excellence, and strive to excel and to be a world-class professional body, understanding and serving the needs of our members and the public. We set and uphold standards to ensure the provision of excellent legal services and ensure the public can have confidence in Scotland’s legal profession.  The Law Society of Northern Ireland is the professional body for the solicitors' profession in Northern Ireland with the aim of protecting the public. The Law Society acts as the regulatory authority governing the education, accounts, discipline and professional conduct of solicitors in order to maintain the independence, ethical standards, professional competence and quality of services offered to the public.  Noting that:  There is currently no comprehensive international framework for the recognition and enforcement of foreign judgements in civil and commercial matters.  The difficulty enforcing judgments given by EU courts outside the EU infringes individuals and citizens right of access to justice and may deter them from engaging with trade and investment opportunities abroad.  Accession to the Hague Judgments Convention would • Enhance access to justice for EU citizens and businesses. • Encourage more international trade and transactions • Reduce the costs for EU businesses and citizens involved in International transactions and would also provide legal certainty when disputes arise between parties.  Strongly support the European Commission proposal to access the Hague Judgments Convention.

feedback_msg_text: 1. Investor protection GBIC supports the Commission’s analysis that several requirements in MiFID, which aimed to increase investor protection, prove to be extremely costly and bring little added value for investors. Banks and saving banks experienced that many clients did not welcome the changes introduced by MiFID II and complained about the amount of often unhelpful information and mandatory voice recording.   A research study by Ruhr University Bochum shows clients’ dissatisfaction with the new requirements:  • 62.3% of clients feel overwhelmed by the quantity of information presented to them. • The most active investors feel most disturbed by ex-ante cost disclosures being (in part, repeatedly) presented to them (78.1%).  • 73.8% of clients want to be able to waive the voice recording and almost half of the clients (49.1%) stated that they would not use telephone investment services because of the new rules. According to the study, voice recording and the extended information requirements have resulted in the telephone business going down by more than half. • Therefore, it does not come as a surprise that clients across all segments cleary wish for a waiver option.  Against this background, GBIC supports the following options for the review of MiFID II:  • Establishing a general exemption from some information requirements (in particular information on costs) for professional clients and eligible counterparties. • Establishing an exemption for distance communication by which investment firms are allowed to provide ex-ante cost information after the provision of the investment service. • The mandatory voice recording requirement should be dropped. At least, investors should be enabled to opt out.  • GBIC strongly opposes a ban on inducements to improve access to “investment advice on an independent basis”, which is fee-based advice. Fee-based investment advice is no valid alternative to inducement-based investment advice because it is only accessible to wealthy clients and therefore socially unjust. Inducement-based investment advice, however, facilitates access to investment advice to all investors– regardless of their respective income or social status. GBIC wants to highlight that an outright ban on inducements would lead to a decline in the offer of investment advice and an advice gap for clients with lower income and a need for investment advice.  • The Commission itself found in the impact assessment that due to the “research unbundling rules”, investment research expenditures have declined. Especially with regard to SMEs and small caps, less research is being carried out which may lead to an overall disadvantage of European SMEs taking part in the capital markets.  2. Phase-out of paper based information We fully support the idea to phase-out paper based information. Banks and savings banks have to provide tons of paper each year which runs counter the Commission`s ambitious plans on sustainability.  3.  Market infrastructure issues The introduction of MiFID II/MiFIR market infrastructure framework was a milestone in the effort to build a fully integrated market.   However, some shortcomings can be recognised that are currently not tackled by the impact assessment:   The system of transaction reporting according to article 26 MiFIR still lacks consistency as the FIRDS database is still not regarded as the “golden source” as it was meant to be. Besides that, several reporting requirements are very burdensome without adding any value in terms of preventing insider-trading or market abuse. This applies to the reporting obligation of securities transfers or class actions.   To focus the share trading obligation to EU-issuances – as described as an option in the impact assessment - would be a very helpful adjustment to the current state of legislation.   In contrary, the creation of a “consolidated tape” might be of some use to increase market transparency but is from GBICs point of view not of crucial importance.
Initiative: Review of the regulatory framework for investment firms and market operators

feedback_msg_text: The Bio Oil Group produces UCO-based biodiesel in Netherlands, Germany and Austria. We employ around 100 people within the Biodiesel sector of our group and in 2019 we produced about 175.000 t of UCO-based biodiesel with GHG reductions of up to 91 %. We are proud to make an important contribution to reducing GHG emissions of EU road transport. The Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment (IIA) “ReFuelEU Aviation - Sustainable Aviation Fuels” sets out the Commission’s early thinking about a future legislative instrument to promote so called Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF). The IIA lists several measures that could be included in the draft legislation to promote SAF, including a blending mandate and prioritization measures to direct liquid road transport fuels towards aviation, among others. Our UCO-based biodiesel (UCOME) is produced through an energy efficient production process with advantageous GHG emissions reductions compared to technologies processing UCO into aviation fuel, as established in Annex V of the Renewable Energy Directive. And, as the waste-based biodiesel production process does not destroy the fat molecule, biodiesel cannot be used as jet fuel given its cold flow properties.  Our industry characterized by medium-sized companies believes that the upcoming legislative instrument to promote SAF should exclude UCO (and animal fats) as feedstock for fuels accountable to a possible aviation target or any other similar promotion measure. In addition, prioritization measures should not target feedstocks for waste-based biodiesel production, such as UCO and animal fats, which are already successfully and efficiently used by the EU road sector. Further reasons to exclude UCO (and animal fats) from SAF incentives:  No investments in new technologies and expansion of feedstock base  If UCO (and animal fats) is (are) included in aviation incentives, given the existing feedstock volumes and technological development, they will populate the whole new aviation segment and completely disincentivise investments in novel technologies using feedstocks such as those listed in Part A of Annex IX or others not included in the Annex yet. Less GHG savings  UCO- (and animal fats)-based biodiesel production is more efficient than HVO/HEFA/HEFA+ production and results in higher GHG savings than UCO- (and animal fats) based HVO, as established in Annex V of the RED II. Actually, this difference is even higher as the values in Annex V relate to HVO for road transport and not HEFA or HEFA+, being used for aviation and being even more energy intensive to produce. Additionally, EU member states would lose waste-based biodiesel as their key tool to decarbonize existing car fleets and to reach their near term climate targets.   Economic damage  Prioritization and indiscriminate incentivization of SAF would lead to the destruction of the medium-sized waste-based biodiesel industry, creating economic damage in the majority of Member States by preventing regional added value. In addition, UCO collectors and waste management networks possibly will be negatively affected as buyers of UCO will be reduced to a handful of HVO producers in a favorable price-setting position. Initiative: Sustainable aviation fuels – ReFuelEU Aviation

feedback_msg_text: Neste Sweden (see www.neste.se) supports the Green Deal’s ambition for climate neutrality in 2050 and welcomes the opportunity given by the Commission to provide input to the publication of the Inception Impact Assessment (the Document) on the ReFuel EU aviation sustainable aviation fuels.  As mentioned in the Document, the aim has to be a stable policy framework over a sufficient time horizon to provide investors with the necessary confidence to invest in the production of sustainable aviation fuels and for airlines to pursue an efficient fuels policy.  The price gap between SAF and fossil jet fuel is the main challenge. The aim of the selected (combination of) policy options needs to be to tackle this challenge. Experience from on-road is showing that a mandate is most effectively ensuring the desired uptake, while being market-based and thus cost-efficient.  Feedstocks and Sustainability - regulation to be in place in all the options  - A wide feedstock base has to be ensured for SAF.  The document is making reference - maybe non-intentionally - only to Annex IX Part A and electro-fuels (Power-to-Liquids PtL).  However, all sustainable feedstocks under RED II need to be accepted; there are e.g. plenty of waste and residue feedstocks which are not explicitly listed in Annex IX Parts A or B. - The word Advanced biofuels should be used only in accordance with the definition created by SGAB  - Sustainability regulations of RED II are established in Europe and need to be the basis for SAF specific regulations. - It is important to decide on the upcoming Delegated Acts as soon as possible in order to bring the necessary security for the developers and investors e.g. for PtL. Existing unavoidable concentrated CO2 sources need to be eligible, and the rules for assessing the additionality of renewable power supply need to be practicable.  - Later on, if and when sustainability regulations are developed, it is necessary to look into further feedstocks without the risk of ILUC.  These can be e.g. grown on degraded or contaminated areas, as shown in the sustainability regulations of CORSIA.  Ramp-up of global and European SAF production has already started and can continue rapidly, provided that the necessary regulatory decisions are made:  - International testing and standardization of SAF started already in 2006.  The first standard was approved in 2009, and now, already 6 SAF pathways are approved, with more in the process. - Presently, there is already small scale production both in the USA and in Europe, and several production facilities are under construction and many more planned. - Member states, like Sweden and Finland, must be able to be forerunners and to implement national reduction quota for aviation to reduce emissions and show the way for an implementation on EU-level. Member states can be a driver for more production. - The ICAO SAF Stocktaking Seminar concluded on 1 May 2019 that altogether 26 producers were planning to ramp up their production rapidly, with announced projects reaching a level of about 5 million tonnes per year by 2025, and about 6.5 Mt/a by the end of this decade. - Neste is one of the producers.  Our existing SAF production capacity (in Europe) is currently 100 kt/a.  The ongoing investment in Singapore will add 1 Mt/a to this in 2022.  Additionally, the feasibility study of additional 450 kt/a SAF capacity in Rotterdam is ongoing. - A rapid ramp-up of SAF production can benefit from the existing HVO capacity.  A significant portion of the HVO production (presently about 6 Mt/a globally and growing) could on short notice be redirected to SAF, ahead of the additional capacity build-up triggered by a secured demand for SAF.  This can speed up and smoothen the transitions - It is important to ensure adequate support for new promising feedstocks that are not yet commercially viable, like CO2 and green hydrogen - see also PtL.  This can be done in several ways, and they are addressed in the text below.
Initiative: Sustainable aviation fuels – ReFuelEU Aviation

feedback_msg_text: The German Mechanical Engineering Industry Association (VDMA) is the largest European industrial association. VDMA represents more than 3.300 member companies in the SME-dominated mechanical engineering industry in Germany and Europe.  The major players in a Power-to-X (P2X) value chain are organised in VDMA: from renewable energy generation to P2X plant manufacturers (electrolysers, Fischer-Tropsch- and Methanol-to-Gasoline-synthesis, methanisation plants, etc.). It also includes the manufacturers for the use cases of hydrogen and P2X across all sectors (e.g. plant manufacturers for steel and chemicals, gas turbines, fuel cells manufacturer, mobile machines, hydrogen-based firing technology for high-temperature processes, shipping & jet engines). The VDMA platform "Power-to-X for Applications" (P2X4A) brings together all the competencies of the important stakeholders, including those from adjacent fields - such as the automotive and petroleum industries.   VDMA very much welcomes the initiative of the European Commission to reduce aviation emissions by using sustainable aviation fuels (SAF). Even if there will be fuel efficiency improvements, there are not many alternatives to make aviation climate neutral. For the foreseeable future, long range flights will not be able to fly with batteries only. The same applies for hydrogen airplanes at least for longer distances. The potential and availability of biomass is limited, and its use involves unwanted environmental and ethical side-effects. Against this background, electricity based SAF (synonyms used are electro-fuels, e-fuels, power-to–liquid, synthetic fuels) offer a very promising solution. The technological approach to produce electricity based SAF is Power-to-X (P2X): to convert renewable electricity to hydrogen, synthetic fuels or other secondary products. P2X involves several environmental benefits. Compared to biomass, the water demand in P2X is significant lower. Also, it involves significantly less land use and does not compete with food production.  P2X is the perfect candidate for generation outside Europe in deserted and arid areas with abundant renewable energy resources (wind and PV) while technology, development and asset ownership come from European players. P2X enables to replace fossil raw materials completely in the long term. Synthetic fuels produced with P2X can be distributed and used in the existing fleet stock without any further changes to the infrastructure. Together with CO2 as another feedstock, P2X-technologies enable a closed carbon cycle and contribute immensely to the reduction of CO2 emissions all over the world.  P2X is characterized by a high technology readiness level (TRL). The next stage for technology development is industrial scale-up and commercialisation – which cannot happen without an appropriate regulatory framework. To avoid lock-in investments, VDMA strongly recommends providing a regulatory framework for an early P2X market ramp-up. Only in this way the EU can create the necessary investment security for the development of the P2X value chain.  Please find enclosed our detailed submission. Initiative: Sustainable aviation fuels – ReFuelEU Aviation

feedback_msg_text: Camelina Company is an SME created in 2010 for the development of sustainable camelina oil as feedstock for the aviation biofuel industry. Our goal is introducing camelina, a resilient oil crop, as a double crop in existing farmer rotation without displacing food or feed crops. Over 10 years we have deployed +40,000 hectares of sustainable camelina plantations in Europe, working with +1,000 farmers. Sustainable camelina oil has been supplied to the biojetfuel industry (ITAKA project- FP7 supported) while camelina by-product is a high-quality protein source for animal feed. CCE has focused on a non-GMO breeding program to develop new camelina varieties for low-iLUC cultivation schemes in Europe, having protected 9 new camelina varieties for different sustainable cropping schemes.   In the near-term, the Hydrotreated Esters and Fatty Acids process (HEFA) is the only certified pathway with commercial scale in order to produce relevant SAF volumes. The HEFA process employs lipids as feedstock, including: vegetable oils, waste oils or fats. Feedstock is not only the main cost in HEFA production (as well as for other biofuels), but is typically the limiting factor when attempting to scale up SAF production. As current waste oils or fats (mainly UCO and Tallow) that can be employed in HEFA process are already currently consumed by road transport biofuels, a significant increase in SAF production should come from sustainable vegetable oils: new agricultural oil crops grown under low-iLUC cropping schemes as well as high GHG emission savings.   As defined in RED II, such sustainable feedstock includes "Intermediate crops, such as catch crops and cover crops, provided that the use of such intermediate crops does not trigger demand for additional land". New policy should ensure appropriate incentives along the value chain, especially for farmers. There is available land in Europe for the production of low-iLUC, high GHG savings vegetable oil , given the appropriate incentives are set in place. Such incentives might include, for instance, adding these sustainable feedstock in Annex IX Part A for SAF production.    There are at least two large opportunities in EU regions, contributing to improved agricultural management:    • Summer catch crop (Central Europe)  Short cycle oil crops (such as camelina), can be cultivated during the summer in Central Europe as a catch crop, i.e. a crop introduced between main crops. A catch crop versus summer fallow can significantly improve soil health while avoiding nitrogen leaching, a major concern in these agricultural areas. It also helps reducing the amount of water that drains off a field, protecting waterways and downstream ecosystems from erosion. Catch crops can also help break disease cycles and, by ensuring that fields have green cover, contribute to habitat diversity, including a new source of pollen and nectar for bees at a moment of scarcity.   --> Over 10 million hectares available in the EU, introducing a catch crop following a winter barley or winter legume harvest.   • Marginal land with high desertification risk (EU Mediterrarean region)  One of the most promising opportunities is to utilise marginal lands for drought resistant oil crop cultivation (such as camelina) and increase soil resilience towards climate change and desertification. This is particularly relevant in Southern EU/MED Countries, where strong evidence exists of irreversible desertification effects.  These are impoverished areas which are typically characterized by cereal monoculture production in rotation with fallow land. Farmers require an alternative oilseed crop to improve soil structure, nutrient cycling, fertilizer efficiency, weed control while reducing soil degradation. Better soil structure in turn improves drainage, reduces risk of water-logging during floods, and boosts the supply of soil water during droughts. --> Over 8,5 million hectares available in EU Mediterranean regions, according to S2Biom.
Initiative: Sustainable aviation fuels – ReFuelEU Aviation

feedback_msg_text: A well functioning data economy in Europe is good for the economy and society when it is grounded in strong, responsible and common values. FBNed | Familiebedrijven Nederland supports the initiative for a follow up of the Open Data Directive which regulates the use and re-use of Public Sector Information. The new initiative should find a right balance between the ease of use by start ups and SME's and the necessity to prevent dominant players in the data driven economy to misuse their position, prevent innovations by other organisations or violate ethical standards. To identify High value data sets (HDV's) and make them easy accessible for users is welcomed. However, the proposal to classify ownership information like UBO data as HDV and make that fully publicly available is going too far and a disproportionate violation of privacy and security of owners who are European citizens like anyone else. Especially owners of family businesses will experience this as a disproportionate violation if their personal information and ownership stakes will become public information. In combination with other data this may become information that puts their privacy and security at risk. For this reason, another European directive, the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, has built in measures to protect the privacy of owners because they are citizens with privacy rights. And even those measures where seen as a possible violation of privacy rights, amongst others by the European Data Protection Supervisor. For those reasons FBNed | Familiebedrijven Nederland strongly advises against marking ownership information as a High Value Data Set. Owners are citizens with the right that their privacy is protected. An ownership stake in a business is no different than having money in a bank account. And a bank account, even registered by public sector organisations like tax authorities, is no public sector information although some might see it as a high value data set. Because of privacy. FBNed calls upon the Commission and the European Parliament not to accept ownership information as a high value data set.
Initiative: Open data – availability of public datasets

feedback_msg_text: 1. Implementation Basel IV – Costs and Benefits  According to EBA and ECB (Basel III reforms: impact study and recommendations) the cost of implementing the final Basel III reforms in the EU such as possible increases in capital requirements for banks would appear to be outweighed by the benefits for the economy as a whole, in particular over the longer term. We strongly doubt this assumption of the supervisory authorities.  According to a recently published study by the economic consultancy Copenhagen Economics (EU Implementation of the Final Basel III Framework: Impact on the Banking Market and on Real Economy, November 2019) the framework will bring fewer benefits than costs for the European economy. The paper explicitly points out that the higher levels of required capital will increase the borrowing costs for European households and businesses, leading to a permanent reduction in GDP, as well as giving rise to job losses in the short to medium term. Households and SMEs are likely to be most affected as they cannot seek funding through capital markets (see page 8). We believe that European specifities, e.g. the SME-supporting-factor and the risk weight for intra-group exposures, should be maintained to avoid additional negative effects following the implementation of the “Finalisation of Basel III”. Inter alia, the following areas have been identified as areas of an additional implementation and administration burden:   •    Due Diligence  The key findings from the impact assessment of the EBA regarding the Call for advice on Basel III implementation lay down that the EBA has identified the need for proportionate guidance on the assessment methodology for the due diligence. This new requirement should be implemented in a proportionate manner for all banks.  •    LTV  Also, the introduction of LTV leads to an additional implementation burden.   •    Compliance costs  Changes in the regulatory environment trigger additional compliance and legal advisory costs.   2. EUCLID  From the description of EUCLID in the EBA’s ‘Annual Report 2017’ (page 70), it remains largely unclear, how EUCLID is going to be designed in detail in the future.  However, the required data for the fulfilment of reporting requirements differ from the data in order to fulfil disclosure obligations (e.g. in the area remuneration policy, risk management objectives, governance arrangements, NPL etc). So the risk exists that the implementation of EUCLID would cause additional reporting requirements for banks. According to the Commission Working Document ‘Fitness Check of EU Supervisory Reporting Requirements’ (November 2019) 30 % of all compliance costs are caused by the fulfilment of reporting requirements. So - in any case - it has to be ensured that additional operational burden for European banks are avoided in the course of a possible implementation of EUCLID. On the contrary, the cost caused by reporting need to be materially reduced. All in all, due to the still unclear design of EUCLID a final assessment of this project and an evaluation of its (full) impact for the institutions is not possible at this stage of the process.  However, with regard to smaller banks as defined in Article 4(1)(145) CRR II the only adequate solution would be to disapply the entire current disclosure requirements for them unconditionally. Obviously, these provisions require an inappropriate amount of staff and technical resources for small and non-complex banks for giving information which is largely irrelevant for the market participants.
Organisation: Austrian Federal Economic Chamber, Division Bank and Insurance
Initiative: Alignment EU rules on capital requirements to international standards (prudential requirements and market discipline)
organisation_lower: austrian federal economic chamber, division bank and insurance

feedback_msg_text: The OpenWrt project provides a Linux based open source firmware for embedded devices like home routers, customer premises equipment and IoT devices with a focus on security and freedom for the end user. The OpenWrt project tries to enforce the local regulatory restrictions based on the vendor provisioned data found on the device. Currently OpenWrt is used as a base for about 10% to 30% of all home routers and CPE device sold world wide. Most of the Wifi access point chipset manufacturers have an official supported SDK based on OpenWrt. OpenWrt and its derivatives have a much higher market share than the competing and much more closed solution form Google (Google Wifi) and Comcast (RDK-B). The OpenWrt project is mostly driven by people located in the EU. OpenWrt is also used by many small companies and start ups to provide services like wireless hotspots and other innovative solutions on re flashed consumer devices, because they can not afford to build their own hardware.  OpenWrt was started as a hobby project and is still mainly driven by the software engineers improving and extending the system in their spare time. This was only possible because it was easy to install software on their home routers and other wireless devices. Still today most of the development is happening on cheap consumer devices. Universities and other researcher need access to the wireless chip at a low level to perform research and create usable implementations which solve problems like airtime fairness. Currently OpenWrt supports many hundreds of different devices, support for most of these devices was added by hobbyist and not the vendors of these devices.   We see a great danger in this regulation for our project, because this would prevent us from improving the Wifi on these consumer devices and most likely make it impossible to install OpenWrt on consumer devices at all. Most of the Wifi chipsets from silicon vendors do not support a clear division between the radio part and the general purpose software. Normally the same hardware is sold worldwide and the local regulatory restrictions are implemented in the vendor software running on the main CPU in the main Linux operating system, not even in the firmware of the wifi chipset.  If the vendor is responsible to make sure that only certified software can operate the radio part of the devices the easiest and cheapest solution for the device vendor is to sign the complete firmware of the system, restrictions to only boot signed firmware images is already possible with many available chips and does not increase the costs of the hardware. Most vendors will not sign third party firmware, because it would be extra effort for them to verify the third party system and they could be liable if the signed third party system does not behave like required. Many vendors will not be interested to support third party software on their hardware because they would like to have a better control over their customers and the software and services their customers are able to use.  If the vendor has to certify all installed software, Internet security for EU citizens will be reduced because it will be more expensive for vendors to update the complex software. In addition it will be impossible for the end user to install own secure software like OpenWrt after the vendor stopped support for the hardware,  OpenWrt supports some devices since more than 10 years.  We therefore strongly urge you to adopt "Option 0" and stay without any delegated acts pursuant Article 4 or Article 3(3)(i).
Initiative: Upload of software on radio equipment

feedback_msg_text: We are a small company developing and manufacturing industrial sensors. Our products focus on innovative network applications.  We enjoy the fortunate situation of being based in a city with a university, a makerspace and a vibrant wireless community ("Freifunk"). The university is useful for giving our potential future employees a good formal basic education. But every single technical employee we hired during the last ten years, received a rich amount of informal education through the local makerspace and the local wireless community. Both places provide a fertile environment for either broad or highly specialized technical expertise that we as a company need in order to stay innovative and competitive. The local wireless community relies on the legal availability of wireless devices, that can be equipped with modern, feature-rich operating systems (e.g. OpenWrt) supporting cutting edge implementations of the most recent wireless standards. The proposed policy options 1 to 4 will put an end to the legal availability of devices required for wireless communities. It will also cause a shift of attention in other technically oriented communities (e.g. maker spaces) away from networking devices towards other mechanical or electrical devices. This will quickly drain the excellent supply of people with the gift of having acquired a broad range of informal experience in the field of networking in their youth. Small companies like ours that rely on a constant influx of in-depth and passionate experiences in new technical technologies from young employees will suffer greatly from this loss.  Additionally the regulatory options 1 to 4 will cause the effect of "Tivoization" (products being shipped based on FLOSS software while being technically restricted from upgrading these systems on their own). This condition poses a legal conflict with wide-spread software licenses like the GPL-3. This will reduce the current rich ecosystem of available software components being used by most producers of wireless devices around the world and thus hamper innovation significantly. Sadly the regulation proposal does not even mention such grave effects on the open source hardware and open source software ecosystem in its assessment of impacts.  This regulation proposal should be postponed for 20 or 30 years until the field of wireless networking moves away from being an area of intense and fruitful innovation into the field of universal disposability and uniformity. Thus the baseline option 0 is currently the best option for our society in this field of technology.
Initiative: Upload of software on radio equipment

feedback_msg_text: CINOA is the principal international confederation of art & antique dealer associations (www.cinoa.org). Established in 1935, CINOA is the global leader in representing the international art and antiques trade, setting benchmark standards for the industry and promoting a responsible art trade. In our comments below we have only addressed the wildlife control measures taken in respect to antique ivory items.  CINOA understands and appreciates the complexity of the process of considering tightening the EU rules on the ivory trade. Unfortunately, legislation to prevent and stop the illicit trade in ivory often hinders the legitimate sale of artistic or historical objects of art made of or containing ivory. CINOA insists that any legislation should promote the importance and foster efforts to safeguard objects that incorporate or are made from antique ivory. Trade should be allowed regardless of their perceived cultural, artistic and historical value as perceived significance can change with time. It would be wrong to dismiss an object now as not being of importance, since at a later date information about such objects could come to light, rendering them of cultural, artistic or historical value, by which time the original object could have been disposed of or destroyed.  Many of the objectives and priorities that are listed in the Annex of the action plan have been achieved by the Commission including a greater understanding and awareness of the issues by the business sector that we represent. We however believe that more emphasis should be placed on fact finding and use of non-biased studies from independent groups to understand the issues being discussed and considered. None of the evidence claiming to show a relationship between the trade in antique cultural objects and the practice of elephant poaching and illicit ivory trade, was from unbiased sources. There have not been any impact studies or analysis of how many objects would be affected by the measures proposed. One study that was cited by the EC and some stakeholders was carried out by Avaaz, the online campaigning organisation, who produced a report entitled “Radiocarbon Testing Illegal Ivory in Europe’s Domestic Antique Trade: Europe’s Deadly Ivory Trade” in July 2018, in collaboration with the University of Oxford (which did the testing but did not write the report’s conclusions) and the Elephant Action League. A review by Dr. McAndrew, a leading art economist, of the sampling methods used in this study to gather data, as well as of the presentation and application of the results, finds that they are both highly flawed and do not provide evidence that can be applied generally to the antiques trade in the EU.  We suggest that the facts must be collected and analyzed to ensure that further restrictions are proportionate and target a proven problem and not only a perceived problem. We further suggest that before documents can be quoted there should be some process for evaluating their validity and accuracy and in particular the methodology adopted. As shown on the page below, during the consultation period regarding ivory, there was only one listed report from 2018 which was updated in 2019  https://ec.europa.eu/environment/cites/reports_en.htm  We have experienced a courteous and constructive working relationship with officials and hope that our concerns and needs for the 5,000 SMEs that we represent will be taken into account and that we will be involved in designing any new legislation or guidelines that affect our sector.
Initiative: Wildlife trafficking – EU action plan (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: The collaborative economy has in recent years seen a surge in services and users in the European Single Market, who collectively help share commodities and utilise resources more efficiently.   Progressive change in behaviour and business models creates a need for these to find common ground with the entities and systems they are regulated by, whilst not limiting the positive development and effects.   As a collaborative economy service provider facilitating car sharing for more than 2 million individuals in the European Union, we in general support actions taken to create an efficient and transparent framework for service providers and users.     Part of securing a proper functioning Single Market with great confidence in collaborative economy services also entails creating a level playing field for providers. EU-based and non-EU-based.   If EU-based providers must deal with additional regulation and administration the same directions need to apply to non-EU-based providers operating in the Single Market. If non-EU providers fail to comply with the rules of such a framework in the Single Market, it should be ensured that their operations are shut down in the EU.   Otherwise non-EU providers will receive unfair competitive advantages, thus devaluating the marketplace of collaborative economy services and contradict the efforts of securing correct tax reporting.   Kind regards,  GoMore
Initiative: Tax fraud and evasion – better cooperation between national tax authorities on exchanging information

feedback_msg_text: Background The “Inception impact assessment for the European partnership for integrated Air Traffic Management” document provided by the European Commission is reflecting well the dimension of the challenges that Europe needs to face during the coming years, as well as their relevance and added value for the public. In line with the existing contents and complementary to them, in the following some key elements that are considered important and should be better addressed in the Inception Impact Assessment are listed, considering their high relevance for the European Union.    The Key topics  In line with the ATM Master Plan document, today, the “more autonomy and digitalization” topic is considered a key factor that can significantly improve and enhance the existing and future overall ATM system. The availability of new technologies in the domain of drones, that are entering in the air traffic, could be a real catalyst also in accelerating the evolution of the existing aircraft. A particular attention should be devoted to the possibility to perform single-pilot operations plus accommodation of increased traffic in highly congested terminals and at low/very low level altitudes in Europe and worldwide. These are both aims to be pursued over the next years, and they are expected to bring added value and benefit for the public. This can only be feasible if a dedicated effort will be devoted in the Horizon Europe, addressing the challenges in a holistic way: the regulation, that will constitute a base for the new operations; the operational aspects; the development and maturation of the critical enabling technologies. In this contest, these important key aspects for success must be taken into consideration:  • the strong cooperation among Integrated Air Traffic Management and Clean Aviation European partnership, considering that both have to work and contribute to this common objective in a complementary and synergic way; • the involvement and contribution of EASA, since the earliest phases of Horizon Europe, in order to establish, in cooperation with the other stakeholders, a common legal base under which the future technologies, platforms and operations will be conceived, designed, validated and operated; • the possibility to launch pilot/demonstration projects that are close to final application to actually test the expected benefits and overcome the challenges (complexity, risk management, etc.) for future implementation. • The increase of funding dedicated to exploratory research with respect to previous SESAR 2020
Initiative: European Partnership for integrated air traffic management (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: Kontron Transportation, formerly named Kapsch CarrierCom, is an associated member of the Shift2Rail Joint Undertaking and leads the technology demonstrator adaptable communication system within IP2. Without doubts it is essential to ensure the continuation of these actvitities started in Shift2Rail to enable the next wave of innovation and industrialization of the research work done in the ongoing program.   Kontron Transportation is convinced that an industrialized partnership (option 2) represents the most favourable framework for collaboration between the rail supply industry, infrastructure managers, railway undertakings, the academia and independent research centers while ensuring a coherent and systematic approach to address the future challenges, improve the competitiveness and increase the attractiveness of rail transport in Europe.

feedback_msg_text: Experiences from the Shift2Rail Programme funded by HORIZON 2020 have shown that this R&I programme, managed by the S2R Joint Undertaking which is an institutional partnership consisting of partners from Railways, Industry and Research Centres and supervised by European Body, catalyses and accelerates innovation.  Digital Connectivity capabilities within the Railways, especially for enabling automation and digitalization, pave the way for new and innovative applications. Within S2R, the 1st step in defining and realising a new Adaptable Communication System (ACS) aligned with the Future Railway Mobile Communication System (FRMCS) has been made. This has the potential to serve as the connectivity backbone for the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS) game changer such as Automatic Train Operation and ETCS Level 3.  The next step will be to validate and improve the new communication system in an operationally representative environment, supporting the innovations mentioned above, validating them from an end-to-end perspective and allowing earlier deployment of the new innovations, which support the reduction of energy, improve the railway capacity, reduces the life cycle costs and improves the reliability.  The team from the Innovative Programme IP2 dealing with the Technical Demonstrator TD2.1 “Adaptable Communication System” support this initiative, looking forward to further support and to drive further innovation within the Rail Sector.  Due to the success of the running S2R programme we clearly vote for Option 2 “Institutionalised partnership “ described in the Inception Impact Assessment.
Initiative: European Partnership for transforming Europe’s rail system (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: As a member of ERRAC and Shift2Rail, ÖBB welcomes that rail was included in the list of potential institutionalised European Partnerships as it is a crucial R&I area for the successful delivery on Union priorities jobs and growth, the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union and climate action. feedback_msg_text: To have a Joint Undertaking within Horizon 2020 totally dedicated to railway research (Shift2Rail) is  extremely positive for the sector. One of the main objective of next program will be  railway digitalization based on mobile communication  ensuring significant  benefits to passengers and freight transport.  Throught digitalization we are able to:   • Increase capacity; • guarantee better performance for passenger and freight transport and less disruption; • enable fast and confortable journey; • move forward predictive maintenance (reducing  cost); • enhance safety for passengers and workers. Whilst it doesn’t seem a direct benefit, the implementation of Digital Railway technologies and mobile solutions  will enable data connectivity for passengers and freight customers, as well as assets. Rail attractivity helps to move to a new “ green stage” reducing pollution, CO2  emission shifting  people and goods from other mode of transport.  Environmental benefit of trains is significantly greater than other mode of transport. In addition digitalization can  contribute  to  create new high-value jobs, improve productivity, expand European manufacturing capability and promote economic growth. Mobile communication is the glue for digitalization and for all new developments and functionalities  and it is  essential   for all step forward in rail sector.
Initiative: European Partnership for transforming Europe’s rail system (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: Contribution on behalf of the CEN and CENELEC Technical Committees related to the Railway Field:   As CEN and CENELEC Technical Committees related to Railway Field we consider this initiative very positively as it combines a top down approach setting clear directions for the evolution of railways with the needed creativity of a bottom-up approach collecting the different research proposals coming from all Europe.  In CEN and CENELEC we have a long experience in translating EC directives in widely accepted European standards allowing the spread and the wide use of state of the art technologies. In particular once a standard is established all the investments of industries and government authorities are focused only on widely accepted solutions allowing a more efficient time to market and a reduced cost for adopting a new technology.  For this reason as European Standard Organization we would like to offer our experience in this initiative with the following possible contributions: a) Setting up a clear requirement for the exploitation of projects through the request for standards at early stage that translate the R&D proposal into standard proposal that can be discussed and accepted in all European countries; b) Reviewing the project proposals in relation to the exploitation in the draft or revised standards;  c) Endorsing the standard proposals in the current standard development process involving National Standard Committees, Experts and Working Groups until the final creation of a new standard of the proposed technology.  We believe such kind of contribution can shorten the time from a research proposal to a wide adoption of its results and we are ready to support the initiative.’
Initiative: European Partnership for transforming Europe’s rail system (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: Deutsche Bahn AG as a provider of sustainable mobility and logistics solutions and as an Associated Member of Shift2Rail Joint Undertaking strongly supports the continuation of this partnership under Horizon Europe. Following the achievements of Shift2Rail, the proposed instrument – ‘’Transforming Europe’s rail system’’ – shall enable rail to become the backbone of an integrated and sustainable mobility system in Europe. To this extent, Deutsche Bahn AG agrees with the economic, environmental, social and scientific impacts that the future instrument is expected to trigger. Among the policy options outlined, Deutsche Bahn AG firmly advocates for ‘’Option 2 – Institutionalised partnership’’, pursuant to Article 187 TFEU, continuing thus the present Shift2Rail Joint Undertaking in its current form. As in the case of Shift2Rail JU, working in an Institutionalised partnership will prove to be an efficient way – for ‘’Transforming Europe’s rail system’’ – to tackle the fragmentation hurdles identified in the inception impact assessment. UNIFE agrees with the European Commission that rail sectorial challenges are better addressed at EU level by means of a common strategic research agenda and coordinated public and private R&I activities. Indeed, the opportunity to embrace the widest spectrum of the innovation ecosystem across different Member States represents an indisputable European added-value. An institutionalised partnership will be able to bring together the rail supply industry – SMEs, large companies, start-ups – , with operators, infrastructure managers, academics and Research Technology Organisations. Furthermore, the establishment of an institutionalised partnership will likely foster both medium and long-term commitment by all actors involved. For rail, such commitments are fundamental and consistent with the 2030 & 2050-Visions supported by the European Rail Research Advisory Council (ERRAC). Finally, the management-model of an Institutionalised partnership will ensure  the timeliness of the projects’ delivery and quality. triggered by high project accountability – through transparency and liability –, ecosystem peer pressure, central knowledge management and staff’s high dedication.
Initiative: European Partnership for transforming Europe’s rail system (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: MTU Aero Engines AG fully supports the statements and descriptions of this Inception Impact Assessment for the European Partnership Clean Aviation.   Context and Problem Definition The document very accurately describes the context and the need to establish such a partnership in the forthcoming EU Research Framework Program Horizon Europe. The continuation of global growth in air transport is undisputed. It is also known that, compared to other mobility industries, far fewer options are available to achieve deep decarbonization of air transport in the foreseeable future. Large scale and high risk investments in Research and Innovation (R&I) with exceptional long return on investment cycles are necessary in order to deliver meaningful success. Efforts to provide climate- and environment-friendly knowledge and technologies for aviation must therefore be further increased at the European level through the co-operation of industry, universities, large-scale research and politics. The effectiveness of European success in aviation research to date is already reflected in the fact that approximately 50% of civil passenger aircraft delivered today originate from Europe. In addition, European aviation equipment companies are an integral part of the supply chains of non-European aviation manufacturers. Therefore, European technology generates a huge impact on the environmental performance of global aviation.  Objectives and Mapping of Policy Options The European aviation stakeholders have described the challenges and objectives of European aviation as a matter of societal relevance in the joint document Flightpath 2050 and have outlined the solution in the form of the Strategic Research and Innovation Agenda (SRIA). A European partnership Clean Aviation is urgently needed in order to achieve the goals we have set together within the European network. The development of promising transformative technologies and incorporating them in highly integrat-ed demonstrators on aircraft and engine level is key to increase the sustainability of aviation. In particular for the propulsion sector different development areas like electrification, hybridization, digitalisation, the transformation to sustaina-ble fuels and radical improvements of the gas turbine are getting advanced to substantially improve the environmental impact. A prerequisite for the successful coordinated work of aviation stakeholders at Horizon Europe is the concentration of aviation activities in the Clean Aviation partnership. The European Union plays an important role in this. The establishment of Clean Aviation under the regime of an Institutional European Partnership (Article 187) is therefore, in our view, the most promising political option.  Summary MTU Aero Engines supports the ambitious goals of European aviation, which are aimed at environmental friendliness, safety and competitiveness. The increase of the R&I activity as well as an increase of the R&I budget mostly made up of grants from the EU and in-kind contributions of the industry are indispensable for this. The Clean Aviation European partnership has highest relevance for further progress of civil aviation in Europe and beyond. It is in the interest of society to make it a success.
Initiative: European Partnership for Clean Aviation

feedback_msg_text: Response on behalf of Swedish Aerospace Industries (SAI) on ‘Inception Impact Assessment for Clean Aviation Partnership. SAI is a branch organization represents the Swedish commercial aeronautics and space industries.  A European Partnership is the right step for EU aviation research and innovation. The very example of EU added value. Aviation is a strategic industry, which means that EU needs to stay a global leader in technology, design and certification.  We need a cutting edge supply chain to remain there. This will allow the EU to set the standard and take a leading role in developing solutions for a global challenge such as decarbonisation.     Decarbonisation of air transport is an important challenge, required to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement. Due to the structure of aviation sector and the global character of the business, which means that emissions are not limited to countries itself, solutions need to be addressed at a European level and in a holistic manner. Flightpath 2050 and ACARE SRIA target -75% CO2, -90% NOX and -65% noise by 2050. Businesses, universities, research institutes and governments need to work together at an EU level to bring about the innovation and impact required to meet these targets.   The complete supply chain needs to be connected. The most important contribution to decarbonisation of the commercial air transport system is a combination of reduced fuel consumption of engines and aircraft. Today the sector is achieving a pace of 1,5 to 2 % reduction per year, but this needs to be accelerated. In the short term, drop-in biofuels will also add further reduction of fossil CO2 emissions.   In the longer term first non-drop-in fuels, such as liquid hydrogen and liquid biogas (LBG) are also viable solutions. In this area cross-sectoral cooperation will be valuable.  Safety, high performance etc. should be of the highest priority.   In terms of implementation, we think an Institutionalised partnership would be the best framework as this provides for the best guarantees for results. This makes it possible for the entire innovation system including the supply chain to take part in the activities. This focus should not exclude cooperation with third countries.  The new partnership should also interact with other European partnerships on battery technologies, digitalization, ATM, hydrogen and fuel cells.  The new partnership needs to address both short and medium/long term efforts with the appropriate balance of TRL levels. It should focus on the >70 passengers medium to long range aircraft which today makes up >90% of the air transport system
Initiative: European Partnership for Clean Aviation

feedback_msg_text: United Technologies Corporation (Collins Aerospace, Pratt & Whitney, United Technologies Research Centre, and their EU-based entities) fully supports the establishment of a new European Partnership on Clean Aviation as an Institutional European Partnership (Article 187 initiative). The aeronautics industry is a cornerstone of European economic success. It supports ~0.5M high value jobs in the EU as part of a large globalised supply chain. Through the previous and current Clean Sky programs, the industry has achieved a strong level of collaboration and reduced fragmentation across funding mechanisms. By embarking on a more dynamic work program that encourages the development of high-risk high-payoff technology, embracing disruptive innovation and non-traditional players, and fostering cross-sectoral synergies, the European aeronautics industry can meet the emerging environmental challenges and targets, such as those in the Paris agreement, and to ensure its future competiveness. Recommendations: • Substantially increase the overall budget for aeronautics research in Horizon Europe to achieve the environmental challenges the aeronautics sector is tasked with addressing. • Increase the agility / flexibility of the partnership as it relates to the overhead in time and management that can impede technology acceleration. • Increase openness / mobility of the program by simplifying access to infrastructures, to innovative SMEs, new participants. The environmental impact of the program can be enhanced through fostering international collaboration. • Build on the existing links between Clean Sky, EU Regions & Member States to ensure a flourishing supply chain and employment growth. • Create an ambitious demonstrator program focussed on 5-6 technology flagships leveraging the inertia / goodwill of the existing partnership structure. This should cover the range of propulsion and air vehicle demonstrators that will have the most significant impact on aviation’s CO2 emissions. The program should be agile / responsive to external or internal opportunities / threats during its execution. • Incorporate a robust cross-sectoral program and funding stream. Technologies, approaches and ideas from outside the traditional aviation sector will be vital in addressing scalability, cost, digitization, advanced manufacturing, battery technologies, fuel cells, and a plethora of other areas where the aviation sector on its own would have to develop these again. • Enhance participation of academia in technology development, and leverage broader capabilities in economics and social sciences. Universities and Research Centres are often a key vector for start-up formation, and are a vital skills pipeline for the aviation industry. • Widen stakeholder engagement in strategic programming, with the aim of including the full supply chain of EU-based entities, as well as non-traditional players such as start-ups in a transparent manner. • Enhance the assessment methodology to consider how the program has met societal objectives using public funding in a way that industry would not be able to do alone, or in the same timescale. • Target ‘fast-fail’ / disruptive initiatives with a relevant portion of the budget, whereby breakthrough innovations (products, services, business models) are nurtured through a stage-gated innovation pipeline, with a clear mandate to stop programs where the technology maturity, business commitment, or market acceptance conditions do not warrant continuation on objective metrics. • Create an enhanced funding model that addresses product maturity, as well as technology maturity, to ensure that the market failure in the aviation industry commitment disruptive innovation is effectively mitigated. • Be a beacon for world-class R&D and a focal point for disseminating the high-tech story and excitement of the aerospace industry in Europe. This is vital as aerospace competes strongly with other industry sectors for the best brains.
Initiative: European Partnership for Clean Aviation

feedback_msg_text: Response on behalf of Innovair – the Swedish National Strategic Innovation Programme for Aeronautics, on ”Inception Impact Assessment regarding European Partnership on Clean Aviation” The issues given in the context problem definition are fully in line with the Swedish perception on both a national and industrial level. Although the present ACARE goals are challenging as they are, they cannot be expected to fully solve the environmental problems resulting from an ever expanding air traffic, and certainly not within the next few decades. Hence, our industry must perceive the increased pressure from both the general public and the political leadership to introduce also transformative solutions in addition to the incremental technical solutions already worked upon. Although the problem area is now fairly well understood with focus on CO2, NOx and noise, the full picture is not yet available. Instead new research based on in-situ measurements indicate that there are also several other emissions from aviation to consider (water vapour, aerosols and contrails) and that these operate on different time scales. Hence, although the so-called high altitude factor may be avoided by lowering flight altitude or bypassing weather conditions that give rise to contrail formation, there is yet a need for continuing to reduce Co2 as this builds up over very long time. Further research on the climate impact of aviation is needed in parallel to the mitigating technical solutions being innovated and introduced in upcoming products. The strategic innovation programme Innovair includes all the actors in our innovation system, i.e. universities, institutes, SMEs, large industries and military organizations. Hence, we see great opportunities for collaborating with our international partners at all TRL levels within an upcoming European Partnership on Clean Aviation. Tis would preferably be organized as per the proposed option 2, i.e. an institutional European Partnership on aviation research & innovation, since this makes it possible for the entire innovation system including the supply chain to take part in the activities to emerge. Clearly, the new partnership needs to interact also with other European partnerships on battery technologies, digitalization, ATM, hydrogen and fuel cells. All aircraft types may be considered, but focus must be on large aircraft (say above 80 or 100 passengers) as these contribute by far more to the total climate impact of aviation than smaller aircraft do. Feedback from: Innovair (12.7 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: European Partnership for Clean Aviation

feedback_msg_text: In addition to the current statement made in the initiative “the European Partnership on Circular bio-based Europe: sustainable innovation for new local value from waste and biomass”, TERRALIA-PASS cluster has identified the following challenges regarding bio-based products:  - Being effective for health and well-being with strong ethical values; - Safe and traceable along the whole value chain to offer security, visibility and trust necessary to the consumer; - Respectful of the environment, from sustainable agricultural production methods to eco-efficient processes with reduced and / or reusable packaging and a low carbon footprint.  To answer those challenges, TERRALIA-PASS cluster has identified four innovation axes:  - Sustainability of resources and crop production: this axis will mainly target the objectives of productivity improvement and environmental performance with the integration of digital and robotic technologies, agroecology, limitation of inputs, identification of new plant species, new production methods and valorization of biomass.  - Eco-efficient processes: this priority will focus on the development of technologies for extraction, synthesis and biosynthesis of raw materials and conservation using processes that respect man health and the environment. This axis will also aim to support production units in their digitalization and their evolution towards Plant 4.0.  - Safety and Security: technologies for detection and limitation of contaminants (physical, chemical and biological), methods for assessing toxicity and ecotoxicity as well as methods guaranteeing authenticity and traceability of products will be at the heart of this axis.  - Product performance: this axis will take into account all aspects of bio-based products and its commercialisation. It will focus also on consumer expectations and behaviour to develop new consummation modes, more efficient packaging, new uses and distribution channels.
Initiative: European Partnership for a circular bio-based Europe (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: Cetome is an independent security consultancy with a recognised expertise in IoT. We believe security and privacy in IoT must follow a holistic approach and that they must adapt to each use-case scenario with the objective to reduce business risks. For that purpose, we believe in the global harmonisation of IoT security and privacy requirements, with the definition of a cross-sector baseline that would be complemented by sectorial recommendations/good security practices.  There Radio Equipment Directive proposes a Delegated Regulation to embed baseline security requirements into radio equipment. The rationale is that IoT equipment lack security which can cause risks to users’ security and privacy. The policy maker takes the example of smartwatches and toys, that could our children. The proposed approach is to develop a list of legally-binding security requirements applicable across the EU Member States.   Whilst this proposition is understandable, Cetome is not convinced that this Delegated Act would contribute positively to improve the current status of security for IoT systems:  1. This Delegated Regulation would only apply to radio equipment, while several IoT and Industrial IoT products only communication on wired non-radio networks. Indeed, the Mirai attack used to attack CCTV cameras connected via non-radio networks to perform a distributed denial of service attack against various Internet services. These devices would not be included in the regulation while still presenting risks to security and privacy.  2. This Delegated Regulation would only apply to radio equipment within certain categories or classes. This is not defined in the current approach and there is currently no accepted standard on what constitutes these categories or classes. Moreover, the rationale on why certain categories or classes would be excluded is not explained in the current document. Should this be the case, these requirements must be well-thought to integrate technological evolution and avoid any loophole that could introduce new security or privacy risks to users.  In any cases, the development of verification steps is required before granting access to market.  3. We were surprised that the policy maker did not consider the opportunity to harmonise IoT security requirements across the EU by promoting the work of its colleagues from ETSI and ENISA. ETSI has published an IoT security standard and ENISA has been promoting IoT baseline and sectorial security requirements for several years. We also believe that the GDPR and the Cybersecurity Act (will) have appropriate requirements to secure IoT equipment before their access to market through security and privacy by design and by default.  In the light of these elements, Cetome can only recommend pursuing Option 0 or Option 1 at this time.
Initiative: Internet-connected radio equipment and wearable radio equipment

feedback_msg_text: Please find the attached comments of the Information Technology Industry Council (ITI).    In summary, ITI’s members strongly agree with the Commission’s goals of promoting interoperability and decreasing e-waste associated with data-enabled mobile phones, and they are committed to putting the most innovative technology-products on the market that meet or exceed all performance and safety regulations. However, ITI is concerned that a departure from the voluntary approach (based on interoperability standards and the existing industry Memorandum of Understanding) towards a mandatory common charger regulation would have the opposite of its intended impact—by stifling innovation, reducing consumer choice, jeopardizing product system safety and reliability, and negatively impacting industry efforts to further interoperability and e-waste reductions, as exemplified by the commitments made in the 2018 industry MoU. In addition, a common charger regulatory requirement is likely to create unintended barriers to trade by forcing global manufacturers to meet unique, technologically design prescriptive rules, running counter to the EU’s obligations under the WTO’s Technical Barriers to Trade Agreement (TBTA) to pursue the least trade restrictive option as it considers how to achieve legitimate regulatory objectives .
