Initiative: Standard chargers for mobile phones

feedback_msg_text: Life Cycle Assessment results indicate, that the environmental impacts of chargers is much more related to the AC adapter than to the power and data cable. It is therefore of much higher importance to standardize the interface on the secondary side of the adapter than to standardize also the interface between the power / data cable and the end device. This approach requires logically a detachable cable. The environmental benefit of harmonized common chargers however materializes only, if  smartphones thereafter are sold without AC adapters (or without AC adapters and power / data cable), which is done only by very few small players in the market, such as Fairphone and SHIFT. Given that the interface of the adapters is already broadly harmonised by USB Types A and C the main policy challenge is to require or incentivize not to sell new adapters with every new smartphone. Further details of this Life Cycle Analysis as undertaken in the course of the Horizon 2020 project sustainablySMART are provided in the attached short report. Feedback from: sustainablySMART (H2020 project) (111.9 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Standard chargers for mobile phones

feedback_msg_text: La Confédération des Industries Céramiques de France (CICF), qui représente les entreprises fabricantes de porcelaine, poterie, et faïence, accueille positivement le lancement l'analyse d'impact initiale sur les limites de migration du plomb, du cadmium et éventuellement d'autres métaux provenant de matériaux céramiques destinés à entrer en contact avec les denrées alimentaires. Cette étape est essentielle afin d’analyser l’impact d’une possible révision de la législation pour nos entreprises. Concernant la feuille de route proposée, nous voudrions souligner des points clés qui doivent être prises en compte par la Commission européenne (CE).   Tout d'abord, nous souhaitons souligner que la feuille de route ne précise pas les éléments suivants, qui sont cruciaux pour comprendre les futurs impacts de la révision de la législation : (1) la définition des valeurs limites ;  (2) la définition de la méthode de test ;  (3) la définition des produits traditionnels, artisanaux et de valeur culturelle ; (4) la définition et les valeurs des « métaux lourds » qui pourraient être inclus dans la révision.  Sur ce dernier élément il est important de faire la différence entre les substances naturellement présentes dans l’argile (comme l’aluminium) et les éléments qui peuvent être ajoutés afin d’effectuer de donner des caractéristiques particulières aux produits (comme le plomb ou le cadmium). Par ailleurs, concernant les pigments, la feuille de route fait un amalgame : les pigments ne sont pas dangereux. Ils peuvent cependant devenir dangereux lorsqu'ils sont mal utilisés. La différenciation devrait être clairement indiquée dans la feuille de route.  Deuxièmement, concernant les valeurs limites, il sera important d’évaluer l’impact de plusieurs valeurs limites de migration différentes.   Nous estimons qu'aucune étude scientifique ne prouve à ce jour l'effet négatif de l'utilisation de produits d'arts de la table sur la santé !    Cela est d’autant plus important que le Centre commun de recherche (CCR a fréquemment sélectionné des échantillons contenant des concentrations importantes de plomb, afin d'établir la cinétique des réactions, ce qui ne donne pas une image fidèle de la production européenne. De plus, nous voudrions signaler une erreur factuelle dans la feuille de route, le CCR n’a pas testé 6000 échantillons (comme indiqué à la page 2), le nombre fait référence à des valeurs de mesure (« Between 2013 and 2017 the JRC's European Reference Laboratory for FCMs (EURL-FCM) generated over 6000 data points on hundreds of samples provided by industry »).   Troisièmement, le même niveau de conformité entre les marchandises européennes et les marchandises importées doit constituer une priorité essentielle pour la CE. En effet, si nos membres opérant sur le plan international doivent respecter les exigences en matière de règles FCM sur les marchés européens et autres, on ne sait pas vraiment si les règles existantes sont appliquées par les services des douanes.  Quatrièmement, il faut absolument évaluer l'impact sur l'emploi. Fortement présentes localement, nos entreprises contribuent au tissu économique, culturel et social des territoires. Exemple : le bassin porcelainier de Limoges, symbole de l'art de vivre français dans le monde entier !  Nous voudrions donc que le CE définisse ce qu’elle considère comme une période de transition adéquate. Compte-tenu des investissements nécessaires, elle ne peut qu'être longue.  Enfin, nous invitons la CE à clarifier le processus législatif et le calendrier de la révision. Considérant les évolutions majeures de la législation, en ce qui concerne les limites mais aussi le champ d’application, nous considérons qu’une procédure d’acte d’exécution n’est pas un outil approprié pour effectuer la révision. Nous demandons donc qu'un processus de codécision soit suivi afin d'adopter la future législation.
Initiative: Food safety – heavy metals in ceramic, glass and enameled table and kitchenware

feedback_msg_text: Em relação ao roteiro proposto, destacamos algumas questões-chave que acreditamos deverem ser tidas em conta pela Comissão Europeia: I. O documento carece de definições cruciais sobre (1) valores-limite; (2) âmbito legislativo e (3) o método de ensaio. Quais são as definições de produtos tradicionais, artesanais e culturalmente valiosos e (4) quais serão as derrogações para estas categorias de produtos? E, (5) definição da lista e limites de quaisquer “metais pesados” adicionais que possam vir a ser incluídos na legislação revista. Com relação a este último ponto, gostaríamos de destacar que o roteiro não reconhece a diferença entre elementos que ocorrem naturalmente na argila (como o alumínio) e elementos intencionalmente adicionados (como chumbo ou cádmio).  II. Em relação aos limites, será importante avaliar o impacto de diferentes limites de migração, particularmente se forem incluídos outros elementos. Consideramos que são necessárias mais evidências sobre os estudos e os limites usados para decidir sobre se existe risco para a saúde. Especialmente porque o JRC seleccionou amostras ad hoc com concentrações significativas de chumbo e cádmio no vidro, de modo a ser possível estabelecer a cinética das reacções e, por conseguinte, não é uma representação justa e real da produção de louça na União Europeia. É importante salientar novamente que o objectivo do JRC era apenas estudar a cinética das reacções, sem a intenção de avaliar quaisquer valores limites. IV. A CE deve ter como uma das suas prioridades fundamentais assegurar o mesmo nível de conformidade entre bens europeus e bens importados. De fato, enquanto nossos membros que operam internacionalmente têm que respeitar as exigências sobre as regras de FCM do mercado europeu e de outros mercados, não está claro até que ponto as regras existentes são aplicadas a nível aduaneiro. V. O impacto no emprego e nas perdas de emprego não pode ser subestimado. As indústrias cerâmicas estão fortemente integradas localmente. As nossas empresas contribuem para o tecido económico, cultural e social dos territórios. Por conseguinte, é estritamente necessário que a CE defina um período de transição adequado. A nossa indústria vai precisar de tempo para se adaptar à futura legislação, especialmente se forem incluídos novos elementos.
Initiative: Food safety – heavy metals in ceramic, glass and enameled table and kitchenware

feedback_msg_text: Denby Pottery Co Ltd is a ceramic tableware manufacturer in the UK, where it has over 800 employees. We welcome the opportunity to provide feedback on the roadmap of the inception impact assessment and to inform the Commission on migration limits for lead, cadmium and possibly other metals from ceramic and vitreous food contact materials. We feel that it will only be possible for industry and the Commission to evaluate the impact of proposed regulatory changes if there is clarity on the key points as highlighted below:  Firstly, the inclusion of different metals and their associated limits a. The term ‘heavy metal’ is not defined and the roadmap fails to clearly recognise the difference between metals that are present as trace elements in raw materials, those that are added for technical reasons and those that are decorative.  The reasons for the use of different metal compounds needs to be clearly understood as this will have implications for how they can be controlled.  Currently the document is confused in places about the presence / use of metals. b. Clarity is required about which metal species may be deemed hazardous, the science behind these conclusions and how this is applicable to ceramics.  It should be noted that many pigments are not classed as hazardous; for e.g. stable engineered Cadmium Pigments.  Clearer distinction needs to be made between the technical/decorative product and the potential migratory element of concern. c. Migration limits must be based on sound science and the impact on industry must be assessed, particularly if phase 2 elements are to be included. We are concerned that research carried out by the JRC was not based on a fair representation of ware produced in the EU as samples with significant concentrations of lead were selected so that the kinetics of reactions could be established.  Moreover, there is a factual error in the Roadmap; the JRC did not test 6000 samples (as indicated on page 2) as ‘6000’ refers to a measurement value (“Between 2013 and 2017 the JRC's European Reference Laboratory for FCMs (EURL-FCM) generated over 6000 data points on hundreds of samples provided by industry”).  Secondly, proposed test methods Overall testing costs will increase as more samples and updated equipment will be required by the testing laboratories - ICP MS is less widely available and more expensive than AA testing. It may also lead to a reduced number of recognised testing facilities.  Thirdly, definitions for artisanal and traditional production and culturally valuable products together with derogations The document includes an objective to minimise potential adverse impacts on traditional and artisanal production and culturally valuable products, but there is no information about how these will be defined. There is also reference to 'derogations for traditional and artisanal productions' but there is no mention what these 'derogations' will be.  These definitions need to be clarified before the industry can comment on the likely impact of proposals.  Fourthly, implementation date(s) and transitional arrangements The economic impact on employment should not be underestimated; an adequate transition period is needed for the industry to adapt to the future legislation and this must be part of the impact assessment.  Finally, the management of imported products The same level of compliance between European and imported goods should be a key priority for the European Commission; it is not clear to what extent the existing rules have been enforced at a customs level.   As a final point we would like to invite the European Commission to clarify the legislative process, including the timetable. As the European Commission is planning major changes to the legislation, with regards to the limits, and scope, we consider that a procedure of an implementing act is inappropriate and request that a co-decision process is followed in order to adopt the future legislation.
Initiative: Food safety – heavy metals in ceramic, glass and enameled table and kitchenware

feedback_msg_text: Confindustria Ceramica endorse the message shared by CerameUnie here reported: The European Federation of Ceramic Table- and Ornamentalware (FEPF) welcomes the start of the “Impact Assessment on migration limits for lead, cadmium, and possibly other metals from ceramic and vitreous food contact materials”, with an inception impact assessment. We believe it is an important and necessary step, in order to assess the framework of the impact assessment. Regarding the proposed roadmap, we would like to highlight some key issues which need to be taken into consideration by the European commission.  Firstly, as a general comment, the document lacks crucial definitions on (1) limit values; (2) legislative scope and (3) the test method. What are the definitions of traditional, artisanal and culturally valuable products and (4) what will be the derogations for these product categories? And, (5) definition of the list and limits of any additional “heavy metals” that could be included in the revised legislation. Regarding this last point, we would like to highlight that the roadmap fails to recognise the difference between naturally occurring elements in clay and other naturally occurring minerals and materials (such as aluminium) and intentionally added elements (such as lead or cadmium). It should also be noted that some elements are present as natural trace elements.   Secondly, regarding the limits, it will be important to assess the impact of different migration limits, particularly if phase 2 elements are included. We consider that more evidence is needed on the studies and the limits used to define if a health effect occurs. Especially since the JRC actively selected samples created ad-hoc with significant over glazed concentrations of lead and cadmium so that the kinetics of reactions could be established and are therefore not a fair representation of the ware production in the European Union. Moreover we would like to point a factual error in the Roadmap, the JRC did not test 6000 samples (as mentioned on page 2) as the number 6000 refers to a measurement value (“Between 2013 and 2017 the JRC's European Reference Laboratory for FCMs (EURL-FCM) generated over 6000 data points on hundreds of samples provided by industry”). We would like to remark that the aim of JRC was limited to study the kinetics of reactions with no intention to evaluate any limits values. The EC will also need to take into consideration whether there will be enough laboratories available to handle the potential increase in testing costs. We also understand the JRC is currently conducting a project on bakeware, regarding the testing methodology. It should be clarified how this will be integrated into a ceramic regulation. Thirdly, the same level of compliance between European and imported goods should be a key priority for the European Commission as they represent more than 80% of the internal market. Indeed, while our internationally operating members have to respect the judicial requirements on FCM rules of the European and other markets, it is not clear to what extent the existing rules have been enforced at a customs level. Fourthly, the impact on employment and job losses should not be underestimated. Ceramic industries are strongly integrated locally. Our companies contribute to the economic, cultural and social fabric of the territories. We therefore would like the EC to outline what is an adequate transition period. Our industry will need time to adapt to the future legislation, particularly if new elements are to be included. As a final point we would like to invite the European Commission to clarify the legislative process, including the timetable. As the European Commission is planning major changes to the legislation, with regards to the limits, the scope but also the enlargement of the text to other sectors (vitreous FCM), we consider that a procedure of an implementing act is an unappropriated tool. We thus request that a co-decision process
Initiative: Food safety – heavy metals in ceramic, glass and enameled table and kitchenware

feedback_msg_text: Grundsätzlich ist die Outdoor Noise Directive 2000/14/EG (OND)  ein sinnvolles und weiterhin notwendiges Instrument zur Emissionsminderung an der Quelle von im Freien betriebenen Maschinen und Geräten.  Artikel 20 der OND veranlasst die Kommission gegenüber dem Europäischen Parlament alle vier Jahre u. a.   + zur Notwendigkeit einer Überarbeitung der Verzeichnisse der Artikel 12 und 13, ins-besondere zu der Frage, ob zusätzliche Geräte und Maschinen in Artikel 12 oder Ar-tikel 13 aufgenommen oder ob bestimmte Geräte und Maschinen von Artikel 13 in Ar-tikel 12 übernommen werden sollten und   + zur Entwicklung eines integrierten Maßnahmenpakets zur weiteren Senkung der Ge-räuschemissionen von Geräten und Maschinen Stellung zu nehmen.  Die ersten Berichte waren bis spätesten 3. Januar 2005 erforderlich. Eine Weiterentwicklung der OND ist demnach zumindest in folgenden Punkten überfällig:  + Eine regelmäßige Fortschreibung (mindestens alle 10 Jahre) unter Berücksichtigung des Standes der Technik zur Emissionsminderung ist zwingend.  + Über vorgenannte regelmäßige Fortschreibungen ist zu gewährleisten:     - Grenzwerte sind abhängig vom Stand der Technik abzusenken.     - Bei der Festlegung von Grenzwerten ist es legitim, bei den Überlegungen zum Stand der Technik neben der Machbarkeit auch Kosten-/Nutzenrelationen zu berücksichtigen.     - Große Bandbreiten bei den Emissionen vergleichbarer Maschinen bei vergleichbarer Preisklasse sind ein Indiz, dass am Markt veraltete Technik ohne technisch-/öko¬nomische Notwendigkeit angeboten wird; in diesen Fällen liegt es nahe, dass eine Grenzwert-Festlegung bzw. -Absenkung geboten ist.  + Mehr Geräte sind in die Kategorie zu Art. 12 zu übernehmen, für die Grenzwerte gelten (insbesondere solche, die verbreitet betrieben werden und häufig zu Lärmbeschwerden führen wie z. B. Laubbläser, Laubsammler, Freischneider und tragbaren Motorkettensägen).  + Neue Gerätetypen sind bei Bedarf in den Regelungsbereich aufzunehmen, wobei das künftig auch für im Freien betriebene stationäre Geräte wie Luft-Wärmepumpen ermöglicht werden soll. Feedback from: Bavarian State Ministry of the Environment and Consumer Protection, Munich (61.3 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Organisation: Bavarian State Ministry of the Environment and Consumer Protection, Munich
Initiative: Noise emission by outdoor equipment

feedback_msg_text: In its IIA the Commission alleges that the Directive (ACD) “has not fully achieved its objectives” and that it aims to tackle that “airports with significant market power misuses their market power”. ADR deems that such conclusion is ungrounded and unbalanced in favour of airlines. In short, the following can be underlined.  Legal certainty and stability are key for investors' confidence in long-term projects and result in mutual benefit to all stakeholders, ensuring that investment decisions reflect  the cost of making infrastructure capacity and can accommodate future rising demand of airport services. ADR's experience since the approval of the Economic Regulation Agreements (ERA) by the Authority (ENAC) – is one of re-start of investment cycle in adding capacity/ raising service quality and effectiveness of consultations with users. Re-start of investment cycle – For ADR charges set by Ministerial decree came to an end in Dec. 2012, when the ERA was approved and tariff revenues started to reflect the costs of regulated services of the airport, including investments in recent years. Prior to that, for more than 10 years after privatization of 2001, tariff revenues were well below costs of regulated services and regulatory uncertainty resulted in: (i) a significant slow-down of the investment spending throughout the period (from an avg EUR 88 mln in 2001-10 to 59 mln in 2012, last year before ERA approval); (ii) a deterioration of credit merit with ratings down from BBB+ (S&P) and Baa3 (Moodys) in 2005 to BB+ (S&P), Ba2 (Moodys) in 2012.  In 2013-16 ADR’s invested EUR 1.1 bln on projects approved by ENAC, allowing for a significant increase in terminal capacity (currently standing at around 47 mln in Fiumicino) while in 2016 total capex stood at EUR 429 mln and credit rating reached BBB+ for S&P and Baa1 for Moody’s. On quality of service, survey conducted by ACI shows that in H1 2017 Fiumicino achieved a passenger satisfaction index at 4.30 from 3.31 in 2013, ranking first among EU airports. Looking ahead, more investments are programmed for the purposes of (i) further expanding current terminal capacity, (ii) adding a new runway and (iii) extending the Fiumicino airport site northbound.  Effectiveness of consultations – Since the adoption of the ACD: (i) ADR and airlines have engaged in constructive consultations; (ii) ADR has shared a heavy load of information on its cost structure and replied to all requests; (iii) ENAC has acted as independent supervisor of the process.  Consultations with users occur every year in Q3/Q4 and comprise:  • proposal submitted at least 4 months ahead of implementation date • invitation to public meeting(s) with sufficient ahead notice • provision through ADR’s website of updated info on proposed changes to charges (note: ADR provides allocation keys of costs to the regulated services to enhance transparency) • meeting(s) with users and publication of the minutes  • final decision published at least 2 months before planned date for new charges. About the alleged misuse of marker power, it must be reminded that ADR is not free to set the level of the charges that are to be approved by the ISA (not connected to ADR or to users) after having overseen correct application of cost correlation and compliance with other ACD principles. Moreover, in the last 2 consultations ADR has consistently rationalized its capex plan to reflect users’ feedback, resulting in lower charges than the level initially proposed. Parallel to this, it is worth noting that in 2017 ENAC received no legal oppositions against ADR’s charges proposal. Consequently, there has been no evidence of market failure since the ACD entered into force. In conclusion, ADR deems that the ACD is achieving its objectives. EU’s main airports are subject to specific regulation which is effective in addressing market power. Furthermore, regulatory certainty is a must to allow private investments in infrastructure projects.
Initiative: Charges for the use of airport infrastructure

feedback_msg_text: We hereby thank the DG for Mobility & Transport for the opportunity to give feedback regarding the current evaluation process of the Airport Charges Directive. Self-evidently, commenting the Inception Impact Assessment is of great importance for us. However, we have serious concerns about the issues specified by the EU commission as main problems and consequently the direction of the current discussion, which concentrates mainly on airlines’ interests. As the EU commission has already identified, the aviation market has faced significant changes in the preceding years, which mandatorily have to be taken into account for a further evaluation process. Referring to the main problem mentioned in the IIA, it claims that there is a misuse of market power by airports in general and that this leads to inefficient behavior in planning of airport infrastructure and processes.  Several studies about market power of airports and airlines show that airports have been severely affected by developments such as route liberalization, consolidation of airlines and privatization of airports. Due to these developments there was a shift in market power in favor of airlines.  For instance more flexibility and the rise of available choices for airlines as well as for passengers lead to great challenges for airports to fulfill the needs of its various stakeholders alike and therefore be sustainable in competition. On the one hand an airport has to provide sufficient capacities and an adequate service quality and on the other hand the level of airport charges has to be competitive. In reality we see an essential hazard by equipping airlines with even more participation rights than they have today or establishing an even stricter regulatory framework for airports – in this case the entrepreneurial responsibility of airports is directly given to airlines or the authorities. Even today airlines with a high market share at a congested airport - thus being its main carrier - are able to block new investments by making the airport keep its charges on a lower level and this way preventing capacity expansions and an entry of new airlines. This shows that countervailing bargaining power of airport users is already existing and thus has not to be strengthened by any further regulation. We strongly oppose any approach which requires ISAs to approve or determine the maximum level of airport charges, based on the single till approach, for all airports being likely to have significant market power on the basis of applying screening criteria. Firstly there is no evidence that there is a context between a single till approach and lower airport charges.  If reducing ticket prices for passengers is the main target, translated to the airline business a single till approach would mean that e.g. airline revenues from aircraft maintenance would also have to be used for lowering air fares. Furthermore it is not proven that lower airport charges consequently result in lower air fares. The major driver of air fares are the current market conditions as clearly shown by the recent Air Berlin insolvency and its impacts on the German aviation market. On certain routes where - due to the elimination of AB flights - there is now only one remaining service provider, the ticket pricing structure significantly changed negatively for passengers. Evidently there is a high dependency between ticket prices and market mechanisms, while airport charges only represent a small percentage of airline costs. Regarding slot policy airports have no opportunity to influence how slots are distributed and to which airlines they are assigned to. Airports are only able to react to decisions taken by external forces and as a result face great challenges regarding efficient capacity planning. In summary a stricter regulation of airport charges would have a severe impact on the airports’ possibility to meet future demands and to satisfy the needs of all its clients in a non-discriminating way.
Initiative: Charges for the use of airport infrastructure

feedback_msg_text: The EACEA and EfCP are useful but not effective enough. Money is spent on various pro-EU programmes but Euroscepticism is still growing.   In order to tackle increased euroscepticism and growing nationalism, the EU should develop an attractive and well curated programme for the masses that celebrates the great many successes of the EU project. These successes are largely unknown to the masses.   Such a programme could be developed by the EU (EACEA?) in close cooperation with youth- and private organizations, to avoid the impression that these celebrations are a "self-promotion" (top-down) tool for the EU leaders, which would be criticized by the press and by the general public. It should rather be a "bottom-up" initiative, but because of the magnitude of this EU-wide initiative, there is input needed from EU agencies.  A very important date is coming up in 2020 that should be widely and massively commemorated throughout Europe. On the 9th of May 2020 we can commemorate and celebrate 75 years of peace after the end of WWII. Coincidentally, this day is also the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Day and of the Europe Day. This celebration could lead to commemorate the EU project annually, for giving us continued peace, freedom and prosperity, under the slogan: "Unity in Diversity"!  Let's embrace Europe Day by starting a new tradition of celebrating a united Europe massively every year with street festivals in all 28 EU member countries. Because why do we celebrate the National Day in every individual EU member country, like Bastille Day in France and st. Patrick Day in Ireland, but the EU has nothing to celebrate their (transnational) successes. Furthermore, let's arrange that Europe Day will be a free EU-wide public holiday in all 28 EU member countries, so the citizens can join or watch the street festivities. Luckily, the 9th May 2020 is a Saturday, so we have one more year to get member states to implement.  By involving our youth closely, we can motivate them to internalize the EU values and help preparing them to become involved EU citizens. The EU has developed successful youth focused programmes such as the Erasmus, Erasmus+ , the “Youth in Action” and the European Solidarity Corps, and has built an excellent infrastructure to mobilize the youth under an umbrella of European youth organizations. Many young EU citizens can volunteer or get a trainee-ship under these EU youth programmes in order to help organize and staff the new festivities in the 28-member countries.  The Europeace Parade initiative is preparing a programme to organize massive street festivals ("parades") in the capital cities of all 28 EU member countries starting on 9th of May 2020. For more details please visit the website:   www.europeaceparade.eu   These 28 parades could be the start of many more street festivals on Europe Day in cities and villages across the EU member countries. Enclosed a 16 slides presentation about the initiative. Feedback from: Europeace Parade foundation (u.f.) (1.1 MB - PDF - 16 pages) Download
Initiative: Interim evaluation of the Education, Audiovisual and Culture Executive Agency (EACEA)

feedback_msg_text: Estimated savings, complexity & duty cycle   Industry would caution on the increase of the estimated energy saving potential. Projecting PC usage and energy consumption growth to 2030 is meaningless; projections involving digital technology further than five years ahead provides no degree of accuracy or certainty. When considering the EU’s own estimated sales figures from PRODCOM it shows a leveling/downward trend in sales numbers for Notebooks (NB) and Desktop (DT) PCs, this is certainly a true reflection of the market over the past few years, we continue to see a declining market in the EU. Further, it’s estimated that implementation of CEC regulation and ENERGY STAR (E*) v7.0 specification will result in approximate energy efficiency improvements in Idle power of 50% for DT/AIO and NB PCs respectively. Future improvement potential will, however, diminish over time with only marginal incremental improvements in energy efficiency.   The last stakeholder meeting provided some rough estimates of active usage patterns from ONE E*compliant NB. The conclusions suggest that “estimates around how long PCs are used for vary considerably across different studies even for the same type of PC (e.g. desktop PC)”.  No data exists to quantify a creditable estimate of the duty cycle of either NBs or DTs assuming a number of usage patterns. A comprehensive duty cycle and power study assessing the significance of active power is necessary to determine active power as significant, selection of the right workloads will also be a challenge to properly measure active mode power of PCs. Without such a study, proposing an energy label based on active power metric is premature.  AFNUM would be interested in providing support to such a study that the EC initiates to assess the usage patterns and characterize a typical duty cycle from various power modes including active, idle (short & long), sleep and off.   Consideration on the Energy Label Introducing a PC Energy Label would be a complex exercise, high configurability of PC products based on active performance requires specific analysis. The existing E* label remains a well established and effective scheme for product differentiation. The E* programme serves as a significant global standard for the ICT sector, providing a stable regulatory framework and harmonization of methodologies. Furthermore the E* criteria have proven to be one of the main criteria supporting European GPP. Noting the termination of the EU-US Agreement, the ICT Industry remains committed to the E* criteria development and its continued basis for the PC regulatory review.   Scope Industry cannot support a proposal to move tablets from the regulation. There are now a number of “hybrid devices” in the market which combine NB and tablets.  Customer acceptance will increase further innovative designs. Legal uncertainty for such devices is a risk if regulated by 2 different regulations with differing requirements.  Material efficiency The IT industry had submitted comments to the draft report "Analysis of material efficiency aspects of PC product group" in February ‘17. Some of these comments have been integrated into the final report, but many proposed measures to improve the material efficiency of PCs still lack practicability and present significant documentation and manufacturing effort with no added value. Namely, the industry is concerned that labelling requirements for product parts (e.g. plastics, batteries) and information requirements on materials (e.g. CRM) will not be effective to improve material recovery rates as state of the art WEEE sorting and recycling processes make no use of the information. Industry questions whether consumers seek technical performance details such as the IP class of a device, or the battery management features. Material efficiency measures should be practicable, consistent and result in quantifiable environmental benefits.
Initiative: Energy labelling requirements for computers and computer servers

feedback_msg_text: In the elimination of barriers to investment it is necessary to remember that Article  473 "Non-discrimination" of Association Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Ukraine, of the other part (EUR-Lex – 22014A0529(01) says that:  "1. In  the  fields  covered  by  this  Agreement  and  without  prejudice  to  any  special  provisions  contained  therein: (a)   the   arrangements   applied   by   Ukraine   in   respect   of   the   Union   or   its   Member   States   shall   not   give   rise   to   any discrimination  between  the  Member  States,  their  nationals,  companies  or  firms; (b)   the   arrangements   applied   by   the   Union   or   its   Member   States   in   respect   of   Ukraine   shall   not   give   rise   to   any    discrimination  between  Ukrainian  nationals,  companies  or  firms. 2. The  provisions  of  paragraph  1  shall  be  without  prejudice  to  the  right  of  the  Parties  to  apply  the  relevant  provisions  of  their  fiscal  legislation  to  taxpayers  who  are  not  in  identical  situations  as  regards  their  place  of  residence."  Looking for ways to support the investment environment it is important to re-read Article  48 "Consideration  of  public  interest": "Anti-dumping  or  countervailing  measures  may  not  be  applied  by  a  Party  where,  on  the  basis  of  the  information  made available  during  the  investigation,  it  can  clearly  be  concluded  that  it  is  not  in  the  public  interest  to  apply  such  measures. The  public  interest  determination  shall  be  based  on  an  appreciation  of  all  the  various  interests  taken  as  a  whole,  including  the  interests  of  the  domestic  industry  and  of  users,  consumers  and  importers  to  the  extent  that  they  have  provided  relevant  information  to  the  investigating  authorities."   Additionally Article  254 "Principles of Competition" says that "the  Parties  recognize  the  importance  of  free  and  undistorted  competition  in  their  trade  relations.  The  Parties  acknowledge  that  anti-competitive  business  practices  and  transactions  have  the  potential  to  distort  the  proper  functioning  of  markets  and  generally  undermine  the  benefits  of  trade  liberalization.  They  therefore  agree  that  the  following  practices  and  transactions,  as  specified  in  their  respective  competition  laws,  are  inconsistent  with  this  Agreement,  in  so  far  as  they  may  affect  trade  between  the  Parties: (a)   agreements,   concerted   practices   and   decisions   by   associations   of   undertakings,   which   have   the   object   or   effect   of    impeding,  restricting,  distorting  or  substantially  lessening  competition  in  the  territory  of  either  Party; (b)   the  abuse  by  one  or  more  undertakings  of  a  dominant  position  in  the  territory  of  either  Party;  or; (c)   concentrations  between  undertakings,  which  result  in  monopolization  or  a  substantial  restriction  of  competition  in the  market  in  the  territory  of  either  Party. З повагою! / Kind regards, Марія Гончар / Mariia Gonchar, Architect СК №30821830, Urbanist ЗВ СК №35314556, Visual and Media Artist, Member №24316 of National Union of Journalists of Ukraine.
Organisation: National Union of Journalists of Ukraine
Initiative: Evaluation of the application of the EFSI Regulation EU 2015/1017
organisation_lower: national union of journalists of ukraine

feedback_msg_text: The Institute for Information Competence and Information Infrastructure, IICIIS (https://iiciis.org) was established by IKIS, a cross-border NGO, to bring together people and institutions who fight against disinformation/fake news, pseudo-science, marketing lies, and other misuse of information by promoting INFORMATION COMPETENCE and high-quality information products and services by national information infrastructures.  We consider information literacy a key competence in information society as well as in liberal democracy. It is underpinned by critical thinking and accompanied by media literacy and digital literacy. Information literate citizens are able to distinguish facts from propaganda, knowledge from opinions and beliefs, and how to proliferate information responsibly over social or any other media.  We do not believe in prohibiting fake news and disinformation by legislative interventions but rather in uncovering lies and misinformation by knowledgeable, information literate citizens, politicians, leaders, consumers, students, workforce, patients, parents and other decision makers.  We are prepared to participate in a multi-stakeholder dialogue planned by the Commission.
Organisation: Institute for Information Competence & Information Infrastructure IICIIS
Initiative: Communication on fake news and online misinformation
organisation_lower: institute for information competence & information infrastructure iiciis

feedback_msg_text: Die Deutsche Gesellschaft für Information und Wissen (DGI) e. V. (www.dgi-info.de) unterstützt ausdrücklich, dass die Europäische Kommission hier mit einem Diskussionspapier aktiv wird und bietet ihre Mitarbeit an.  Durch die aktuelle Diskussion über den möglichen Einfluss von Fake News und postfaktischen Behauptungen z. B. auf individuelle Wahlentscheidungen sind Fragen der Informationskompetenz in jüngster Zeit wieder verstärkt in den Fokus der (öffentlichen) Wahrnehmung gerückt. Dabei liegt das Augenmerk auf Fähigkeiten zum Erkennen von falschen Informationen und ihren Quellen, zum kritischen Umgang mit (digitalen) Informationslieferanten aller Art und der Informationsbeschaffung, –nutzung und –wirkung im alltäglichen Leben.  Informationskompetenz ist DIE Schlüsselqualifikation der modernen Informationsgesellschaft mit dem Rang einer vierten Kulturtechnik. Eine frühzeitige Vermittlung tragfähiger Konzepte, die Entfaltung der Informationskompetenz in der Schul- und Berufsbildung, sowie der Transfer der Kenntnisse in die Gesellschaft sind – aus Sicht der Informationsexperten der DGI – für eine erfolgreiche Berufskarriere und die informationelle Selbstbestimmung der Bürger in Europa unverzichtbar. Der Erwerb dieser Fähigkeit ist die Basiskompetenz für jeden mündigen Menschen in einem demokratischen Gemeinwesen. Die Sensibilisierung junger Bürger ist Voraussetzung für die Achtung demokratischer und ethischer Werte im Zeitalter allgegenwärtiger IKT. Hier leistet die DGI mit ihrer Community of Practise „Informationskompetenz“ ihren Beitrag durch die Sensibilisierung der gesellschaftlich relevanten Zielgruppen.  Im Namen des DGI-Vorstandes.  Dr. Luzian Weisel  Vizepräsident    Deutsche Gesellschaft für Information und Wissen (DGI) e.V. Windmühlstraße 3 60329 Frankfurt am Main
Organisation: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Information und Wissen (DGI) e. V.
Initiative: Communication on fake news and online misinformation
organisation_lower: deutsche gesellschaft für information und wissen (dgi) e. v.

feedback_msg_text: Concerning the evaluation of the provision of emergency support within the Union, Global Medic Force would like to recommend an increase in healthcare related preparation for emergency contingencies at the local clinical level in high risk areas pre-identified and prioritised as most likely to require emergency support within the Union.   We believe a programme of ongoing mentoring of local healthcare workers and support staff in the full spectrum of infectious and communicable diseases specifically related to the established epidemiology and conditions prevalent in emergency conditions, would incrementally empower local medical personnel to optimally treat their own resident populations (and possibly additional transitory populations due to emergency situations) from their own medical clinical resources, in addition to the obvious benefits of additional EU support.

feedback_msg_text: Costa Group, a leading European cruise operator, welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to reassess the mandate of the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA), particularly in light of the lessons learned from the COVID-19 crisis.  Costa Group supports the further definition of EMSA’s role in supporting the digital and sustainable transition of the European shipping sector and appreciates the role EMSA continues to play in coordinating safety and security measures for the benefit of the European maritime sector.   However, with regard to the need to reflect on new tasks and operational practices to ensure EMSA is fit for purpose, Costa Group believes there is one area where improvement can be made. The public health crisis brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic created an immediate challenge for the cruise industry (and passenger vessels industry at large) which became globally publicised, that of safe and swift repatriation of passengers and crews. Our repatriation efforts were made more difficult by a lack of sufficient coordination and a refusal by several EU Member States to open their ports to vessels in a situation of urgency.  We therefore call for EMSA to be mandated to manage a single coordinated repatriation plan in the event of future public health emergencies. This would be particularly well aligned with EMSA’s stated priority to make the best use of safety rules to increase the protection of human life at sea. It would also work towards increasing consumer confidence in the European shipping industry, thus supporting a critical economic sector in the EU, i.e coastal tourism. We believe that the combination of the existing EU legal framework could offer a sound basis to improve the situation in case of a future health crisis. Specifically, the TEN-T and Place of Refuge EU legal frameworks provide an excellent background for a more coordinated future approach.   Costa Group believes that the EMSA Guidance on Places of Refuge should be revised to incorporate serious public health emergencies and pandemic scenarios within the definition of cases of a “ship in distress” under EU Directive 2002/59, thus making it possible for ships to safely return to port in order to repatriate passengers and crews safely and efficiently. The existing TEN-T ports network should be closely involved in the development and contingency planning of this process as their offer a robust backbone of main ports throughout Europe. Feedback from: Costa Group (385.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: European Maritime Safety Agency – review of mandate

feedback_msg_text: TOWA remercie la Commission pour l’opportunité de partager son avis et les questions qu’elle adresse à la Commission en fin de document.   Avant toute chose, notons que la Commission utilise le terme “harmonisation” en laissant croire qu’elle serait à l’initiative d’une action vertueuse mais c’est occulter le fait que l’harmonisation n’a pas eu lieu il y a dix ans, en 2011, lorsqu’est sorti le règlement INCO car les arguments du lobby de l’alcool ont prévalu sur la santé du consommateur et son droit à l’information, et a donc rendu possible cette exception.   Selon TOWA, révoquer cette exception aujourd’hui ne signifie pas réaliser une avancée mais bien combler un retard. Et ne pas révoquer cette exception entretiendra toujours les déséquilibres, les risques de débordements dont le citoyen sera toujours victime. Révoquer cette exception plutôt que la cultiver demeure le pas indispensable pour pouvoir envisager une véritable harmonisation nécessaire à l’ambition de la politique de la Commission annoncée à ces citoyens pour ce mandat. Car le rôle de la Commission n’est pas de combler ses retards mais bien, dans son droit d’initiative, d’accompagner la vision d’une politique annoncée.    Choisir l’option 2, toutes les données ET SUR l’étiquette. C’est donc la première étape du minimum que la Commission puisse entreprendre pour rétablir une situation qui soit plus juste et en accord avec sa mission de protéger ses citoyens. Révoquer cette exception harmoniserait la situation d’il y a dix ans, en 2011, mais nous sommes en 2021 ! Le contexte a évolué et de nouvelles politiques ont été annoncées depuis. Le devoir de la Commission en termes d’harmonisation consiste à faire concorder les règles d’étiquetage avec la situation de 2021 et les objectifs annoncés pour ce mandat et qui indiquent la direction dans laquelle s’engage la Commission en y intégrant ses citoyens comme partie prenante de son succès. Le rôle de la Commission est de mettre en œuvre les outils pertinents pour augmenter les chances de succès du Green Deal et justifier les dépenses considérables qu’il va engendrer auprès des citoyens pour le financer. Or, la clé de réussite de ce Green Deal est le citoyen et la transparence que la Commission européenne met à sa disposition. C’est un incontournable. Tenir le citoyen à l’écart serait s’assurer de l’échec du Green Deal. Il est indispensable de mettre à disposition du citoyen une politique d’étiquetage pleinement transparente et multifactorielle qui permettra à celui-ci, dans son acte d’achat, d’appuyer les objectifs de la Commission dans cette transition. La  Commission a elle-même insisté largement sur le rôle déterminant que jouera le citoyen dans le succès de cette politique en pouvant effectuer un choix éclairé.  La priorité de la Commission européenne est aujourd’hui de proposer un nouveau modèle d'étiquetage intégrant des paramètres santé renforcés ainsi que des paramètres de durabilité.   Nous vous invitons à lire les questions posées par TOWA dans la pièce jointe, qui reprend l'intégralité de l'avis ainsi que la présentation de TOWA et plusieurs avis déposés sur ce sujet lors de la révision du règlement FIC qui a pris fin en février 2021. Organisation: TOWA - TRANSPARENCY FOR ORGANIC WORLD ASSOCIATION

feedback_msg_text: The Alcohol Health Alliance UK fully endorses the submission made by Eurocare. Of the options laid out, we support Option 2 to remove the exemption for alcohol products. However, as set out by Eurocare, specifically adapted legislation for alcohol products would be more suitable because alcohol is not an ordinary foodstuff. Indeed, it is the leading risk factor for death, ill-health and disability amongst 15-49 year olds worldwide.  We believe that the EU roadmap has the potential to bring about health benefits beyond the EU’s borders through setting strong new standards that other jurisdictions seek to match. Moreover, our research report “Drinking in the Dark”, which identified a serious lack of information on alcohol product labels in the UK, found that some products on sale in the UK carried guidelines from other countries.  The Alcohol Health Alliance UK is a coalition of more than 55 organisations working together to reduce the harm caused by alcohol. Members include medical royal colleges, charities and treatment providers. Improving the information that is provided to consumers on alcohol labels is a key policy priority for us, alongside reducing the affordability, availability and promotion of alcohol.
Initiative: Food labelling - revision of rules on information provided to consumers for alcoholic beverages

feedback_msg_text: L'étiquette d'une boisson alcoolisée (taux > 1,2%) doit renseigner le consommateur de la totalité des composants chimiques et adjuvants, qui la compose. Il est inadmissible que les vins échappent à cette règle commune, d'autant plus que leur élaboration et leur fabrication est une des plus consommatrices en produits chimiques divers (pesticides, intrants de vinification...). Je demande la révocation de l’exception qui évite l’étiquetage de la composition et des données nutritionnelles sur les boissons de plus d’1,2% d’alcool.  L'option 1 qui consiste à transmettre ces informations via un QRcode n'est pas satisfaisante. Les informations doivent être lisibles par le consommateur directement, comme pour toutes les autres denrées alimentaires.  Seule l'option 2 est acceptable et elle doit s'appliquer à TOUTES les boissons alcoolisées y compris les vins.
Initiative: Food labelling - revision of rules on information provided to consumers for alcoholic beverages

feedback_msg_text: Ayant toujours encouragé le financement des entreprises par fonds propres, l’AMAFI est favorable à l’introduction d’un dispositif performant destiné à réduire le biais fiscal de l’endettement. L'adoption rapide de ce type de mesure devrait permettre un renforcement des fonds propres particulièrement nécessaire en sortie de crise COVID-19.  Elle approuve donc l’initiative de la Commission et marque sa préférence pour un mécanisme s’inspirant de dispositifs performants déjà adoptés, tels que celui en vigueur en Italie (reposant sur le mécanisme « ACE » - Allowance for Corporate Equity). Un soin attentif doit être apporté au design des mesures anti-abus qui, si elles sont légitimes, ne doivent pas conférer au dispositif retenu une complexité extrême et un coût de mise en œuvre disproportionné risquant ainsi de le priver de son efficacité et d’empêcher l’atteinte des objectifs poursuivis.   En synthèse, l'AMAFI approuve l'initiative DEBRA devant conduire à la définition d'un dispositif : - Simple à mettre en œuvre, avec de coûts de conformité modérés ; - Efficace sur l’objectif de réduction du biais fiscal à l’endettement ; - Assorti de mesures anti-abus faciles à mettre en œuvre et ne privant pas le futur dispositif DEBRA de sa portée conceptuelle. Det foreslås, at benytte Art. 115 som hjemmel, det må siges at være meget tvivlsomt om en harmonisering af selskabsskatten, som der lægges op til her ikke skal gennemføres med ensstemmighed og derfor bør hjemmelen formentlig være en anden.

feedback_msg_text: We support the contribution made by France Assos Santé of which we are both members and seated on their Board of Directors.: we wish to insist on certain points.  1. It is essential that the revision of this Directive deals with the field of drugs and health products in order to review substantially the methods of assessment, restoring the balance between the drug companies and the victims of adverse reactions to the drugs : it is our wish that drugs and health products should be removed from the Directive.  1.1 During the Product Liability Conference on 20th October 2017, the associations of victims and political leaders had drawn attention to the injustice of this Directive for the victims of adverse reactions to drugs. A wide consensus had emerged among the participants (cf accompanying document – part of « Minutes Product Liability Conference » pages 2,3) and the Bulgarian Ministry of Economy had even (…) “pointed out that this issue is not new and that it was already assessed at the time of the adoption of the Product Liability Directive We take the liberty to include these discussions in the present-day issue, all the more so that, if the Final Report refers to it, the report of this day seems no longer available on the European Commission site. It was however specifically mentioned that these discussions would be mentioned during the following evaluation in 2018. This was not the case. This makes it all the more important that these debates be included in the records of this consultation, since the situation has not progressed.    1.2 In the  « Final Report - Evaluation of Council Directive 85/374/EEC on the approximation of laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States concerning liability for defective products » :  • The major difficulties consequent to the Directive, for the victims of adverse reactions to drugs.  • That the contentions concerning drugs represent the 2nd most frequent category with 16% of the contentions   • But not to mention this subject in the conclusion.  2. A silent epidemic  As a reminder, according to the European Commission itself, the adverse effects of drugs are the cause of thousands of deaths each year and represent at least 5% of hospitalisations in the European Union (1). In France, the number of deaths caused by  drugs can be estimated about 20.000 per year (2).This is about 6 times more than road mortality (3). In Great Britain according to a report made in 2004, each year  250 000 people are hospitalised from the adverse effects of drugs, which costs approximatively 550 million euros each year for the National Health Service (4).   1- European Communities Commission « Synthesis of the impact study accompanying the propositions prior to regulations and a directive concerning the pharmacovigilance of drugs for human use ». feedback_msg_text: The Whole Grain Initiative welcomes the opportunity to give feedback on the review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme. Please see attached the Whole Grain Initiative's comprehensive feedback including references, and a summary below.    There is strong and consistent considerable evidence that whole grains play a major role in healthy and sustainable dietary patterns. Compared to recommended levels, intake levels of whole grains are staggeringly low in most EU countries. According to the Global Burden of Disease study, in 2017 the low intake of whole grains was the leading dietary risk factor for NCDs in almost all WHO regions, including Europe. This surpassed low fruit and vegetable intakes, with approximately 3 million deaths and 82 million Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) worldwide and 664.000 deaths and 14.2 million DALYs in the European region attributed to a diet low in whole grains.  Childhood obesity is surging in Europe. A recent study identified that children who consumed more than 1.5 servings of whole grain every day had 40 percent less risk of being obese than children who did not consume whole grain, highlighting the potential of adequate whole grain intake in mitigating risks for childhood obesity.   Inadequate intake of whole grain is particularly evident in European children. A recent study in Italy revealed troublingly low whole grain intakes, with a mean whole grain intake of 2.1g/day in children and adolescents. France echoes this picture, with a study showing that 55% of children consume no whole grain; and among the French children that do eat whole grains, half of them eat less than 5g/day. Nineteen percent of German children and adolescents do not consume any whole grain and intakes overall remain around half the amount recommended . Although 90% of Irish children and adolescents consume some whole grains, the average intake was still only half the recommended 3 portions a day.   Although overall intake in the USA is low, research identifies that it is possible to improve whole grain intakes in children via concerted policy action, including the integration of minimum whole grain requirements into school meals. In 2012, the American national school breakfast and lunch programme mandated that at least half of grains offered were whole grain. Research has shown that since 2012, whole grain intakes in schoolchildren in the USA have steadily risen, providing strong evidence of the important role school meals play in improving children’s diets . Furthermore, research from the USDA Economic Research Service reveals that whole grain consumption at school now surpasses whole grain consumption at home. There is an opportunity to leverage and apply these learnings for the improvement of public health in Europe.  As taste preferences are often established in childhood and can persist into adulthood, exposing children to a range of whole grain foods from an early age is important. The school setting offers a suitable environment for early exposure to whole grain foods, which are crucial for establishing healthy dietary lifestyles and optimizing children’s health.    The extension of the EU’s School Fruit and Vegetables Scheme to include whole grain would be a major public health initiative to address low whole grain intakes of European children which, in turn, may help to combat alarming childhood obesity levels. Moreover, the repeated exposure to whole grain products served in schools would increase children’s preference for such foods, which may increase subsequent whole grain consumption by children outside of school and in later years. Feedback from: Whole Grain Initiative (167.2 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Schools are at the heart of children’s life and a pillar in their education, including with regard to nutrition. In this respect, the EU school fruit, vegetables, and milk scheme (hereafter EU school scheme) plays a valuable role in ‘[reconnecting] children with agriculture’ and educating them about healthy and sustainable eating habits: An important mission of the EU that the European Alliance for Plant-based Food (EAPF) fully endorses.   EAPF supports a revision of the EU school scheme to enhance its contribution to sustainable food production and consumption, while raising awareness among younger generations about nutrition and farming. In our views, the scheme should be more inclusive (food-wise), promote food products responding to children’s needs – as diverse as they are-, and enable the shift to sustainable plant-based diets, in line with the EU Farm to Fork Strategy and Beating Cancer Plan.   This is not the case of the current scheme, 40% of which is dedicated to milk and milk products (€ 100 million/school year, out of the total 250 million/year). That encourages misconceptions among children according to which cow milk and milk products are necessarily good for their health and the only available source of essential nutrients to their development. The milk component of the scheme disregards the environmental impacts of dairy, the diversity of food sources for essential nutrients, and the disadvantage of crop farmers who do not benefit from the scheme.   EAPF thus calls on the European Commission and Member States to revise the EU School Scheme and to integrate plant-based foods as part of eligible products.  We particularly encourage the EU needs to promote:  1. Food products enabling the shift to healthy and sustainable plant-based diets; 2. Schools as agents of change; 3. A level playing field for plant-based food products on the EU agri-food market. Feedback from: European Alliance for Plant-based Foods (EAPF) (180.8 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: BioNederland is dé vereniging voor biologische producenten en handel. Als zodanig ondersteunen we krachtig het initiatief van de Europese Commissie "Green New Deal" met de daaropvolgende "van boer tot bord"-strategie en het biologische actieplan. Wij waarderen het dat er aandacht is voor biologisch in het EU-schoolprogramma.    Biologische landbouw speelt in op de groeiende maatschappelijke vraag naar gezond kwaliteitsvoedsel dat wordt geproduceerd met hoge milieu- en dierenwelzijnsnormen. Het kan bijdragen aan de bescherming van de natuur en de achteruitgang van ecosystemen helpen keren en het is een belangrijk instrument in de strijd tegen de groeiende klimaatcrisis. Daarom is er een sterke behoefte om de vraag naar biologische producten te verhogen.   Het EU-schoolprogramma voor groenten, fruit en melk biedt een grote kans om de strategische verplichtingen en plannen van de EU-commissie in te vullen. Vooral omdat het de jongste generaties in contact brengt met duurzame en gezonde biologische versproducten. En zoals we allemaal weten, zal wat je op jonge leeftijd leert je de rest van je leven ondersteunen in je consumptiegewoonten.  Daarom moet het minimumaandeel van biologisch fruit, groenten en melk/drank dat in het kader van het toekomstige EU-schoolprogramma wordt aangeboden, ten minste worden vastgesteld op 25%, in overeenstemming met het biologische actieplan. Een hoger aandeel biologische producten op het niveau van 50% tot 100% zou er zelfs op wijzen dat de Commissie het echt serieus meent om het doel te bereiken en alle beschikbare middelen aan te wenden om de Farm to Fork-doelstellingen in de praktijk te brengen.  En dat moet natuurlijk hand in hand gaan met goede en aantrekkelijke educatieve informatie over biologische landbouw en voedselproductie zodat ook de ouders van deze kinderen in aanraking komen met de waarden van biologische voeding.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Związek Sadowników RP jako największa w Polsce organizacja  zrzeszająca producentów owoców takich jak: jabłka, truskawki, maliny, porzeczki, oraz borówki wnioskuje o zwiększenie dotychczasowego limitu środków na realizację programu Owoce, warzywa i mleko w szkole.       Z naszego punktu widzenia jest to kluczowe działanie mające na celu wyrobienie prawidłowych nawyków żywieniowych wśród dzieci i młodzieży, które wymierne efekty przyniesie w przyszłości w postaci zwiększenia spożycia warzyw i owoców. Należy podkreślić, iż są to artykuły spożywcze odgrywające bardzo ważną rolę w żywieniu człowieka. Są one bogatym źródłem witamin, błonnika oraz składników mineralnych.                             Z uwagi na bardzo niską energetyczność polecane są przez dietetyków osobom dbającym o odpowiednią masę ciała, co ma ogromne znaczenie w diecie dzieci, biorąc pod uwagę iż szacuje się, że 30 % dzieci w wieku wczesnoszkolnym w Polsce cierpi na otyłość.       Eksperci do spraw żywienia zalecają dzienne spożywanie warzyw i owoców w ilości około 400 g w 5 porcjach. Niestety dzienne spożycie świeżych owoców i warzyw w Polsce nie przekracza jednak 250 g, podczas gdy Europejczycy spożywają ich średnio 600 g. Tak niska konsumpcja jest przede wszystkim wynikiem spadającego systematycznie od kilkunastu lat spożycia owoców świeżych.   Mając na uwadze powyższe, Program Owoce, warzywa i mleko w szkole jest jedynym skutecznym sposobem na zatrzymanie, a nawet odwrócenie tej tendencji spadkowej, dlatego kluczowym jest zwiększenie środków finansowych na jego realizacje i zaangażowanie możliwie jak najwięcej placówek szkolnych do jego wdrażania.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Viva! response to the roadmap consultation on the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme As an organization dedicated to the promotion of animal rights, healthy eating and environmental protection, we welcome with joy the project promoting increased consumption of vegetables and fruits. For many years we have been running with success a campaign aimed at increasing knowledge about the plant-based diet.  According to many associations in the field of dietetics and nutrition, appropriately planned plant-based diets are healthy, nutritionally adequate and may provide health benefits for the prevention and treatment of certain diseases. These diets are appropriate for all stages of our life cycle, including pregnancy, lactation, infancy, childhood, adolescence, older adulthood, and also for athletes.  Vegans are at reduced risk of certain health conditions, including ischemic heart disease, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, certain types of cancer, and obesity. Vegan diets are characterised by low intake of saturated fat and high intakes of vegetables, fruits, whole grains, legumes, soy products, nuts, and seeds (all rich in fibre and phytochemicals), which lead to lower total and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels and better serum glucose control. These factors contribute to the reduction of chronic diseases.  We would like to draw attention to the potentially negative health effects of consuming milk described by the authors of many research studies. Nowadays we know that greater intake of milk and dairy products is not associated with a lower risk of osteoporosis and fractures. Dairy products are not the only source of calcium and protein in our diet. We can obtain calcium from plant foods, highly drained mineral waters and products fortified with calcium. The potential health risks appear to outweigh the potential benefits of dairy consumption.  High intakes of dairy products, milk, low-fat milk, cheese, and total (dietary and dairy) calcium, may increase prostate cancer risk. The diverging results for different types of dairy products and sources of calcium suggest that other components of dairy rather than fat and calcium may increase the prostate cancer risk.  There may also be a positive correlation between consumption of dairy foods and an increased risk of Parkinson disease, especially for men. A positive relationship between dairy, total milk, whole milk, low-fat and skim milk consumption and acne occurrence has also been found. The role of diet in acne etiology has been investigated for several years. It was established that milk and milk products can trigger acneiform lesions.  For all dairy systems negative environmental issues have been well described. Dairy industry has negative effects on: - landscape and habitat by colonisation of meadows by scrub and woodland, loss of open grassland and field boundaries and degradation of hydro geological systems; biodiversity by development of invasive herbs and loss of grassland diversity due to the increased use of fertiliser, silage production, reduced grazing and scrub encroachment, loss of both complexity and stability; - loss of soil integrity by increased use of fertilisers, feed additives and the more concentrated use of waste products like manure. High stocking rates may result in increased incidence of tramplingand subsequent erosion; - water by pollution of groundwater with nitrates and pesticides and eutrophication of surface water, consuming large amounts of water for production; - air by de-nitrification, production of methane, ammonia volatilisation and carbon dioxide.  Due to the destructive impact of dairy production on the environment and its potentially harmful effect on the human body, its consumption should not be promoted from EU funds. feedback_msg_text: The EU school fruit, vegetable and milk scheme gives the opportunity to ensure that all children have access to healthy food and in that way develop healthy eating habits and decrease disease risk (in later life). Fruit, vegetables and dairy are important products for children (as well as adults). However, other healthy and (more) sustainable agricultural products may not be forgotten. Whole grains for instance are an important part of a healthy and sustainable diet. In both NL and BE whole grains are largely present in the dietary guidelines, that will contribute to the intake of dietary fibre, vitamins and minerals. Unfortunately, the intake of whole grains as well as dietary fibre is too low in both children and adults.   Also regarding the need to move towards a more sustainable food system, whole grains deserve attention in this scheme. A large portion of grains used in whole grain products like bread is grown in the EU. In addition, whole grains fit in a plant-based and more sustainable diet. To offer children the experience to try these products and learn about them, will contribute to a healthy and sustainable way of life.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: L’association Aquatic Life Institute (ALI) remercie la Commission Européenne d’organiser cette consultation autour de l’alimentation à l’école.  La construction des habitudes alimentaires passe notamment par l’école. Nous pensons que la découverte de mets culinaires avec une grande diversité de fruits et légumes est très importante pour répondre aux objectifs de l’Union Européenne en matière de dérèglement climatique.  Notre association ALI est favorable à des aides de l’Union Européenne pour la consommation de fruits et de légumes à l’école. Nous préconisons le remplacement des produits laitiers par des alternatives végétales à la fois savoureuses, avec un faible bilan carbone et riches d’un point de vue nutritionnel. À titre d’exemple, le soja, les amandes ou les brocolis sont riches en calcium.  Par ailleurs, nous tenons à souligner l’importance de la consommation d’algues à l’école. Cela permettrait de réduire la consommation de poissons afin de pallier la pêche massive et au développement de la pisciculture intensive dans le cadre de la politique européenne pour le climat. En effet, la stratégie « De la ferme à la fourchette » envisage de favoriser la production d'une nouvelle source de protéines : les algues. Les algues contiennent des micro-nutriments importants tels que la vitamine B9, le phosphore, le zinc, le fer… Par exemple, le kelp, la kombu et le wakame crus sont d’excellentes sources de calcium.  Enfin, nous rappelons que les attentes citoyennes concernant la lutte contre souffrance animale, y compris les animaux aquatiques, sont très fortes. Nous encourageons la Commission Européenne a refusé les aides aux pratiques cruelles envers les animaux.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: PAZ se réjouit de participer à cette consultation publique concernant le programme de l'Union de la consommation de fruits, de légumes et de lait dans les écoles.  L'urgence climatique, les fortes attentes sociétales en matière de condition animale et les préoccupations relatives à la santé publique nous encouragent à soutenir massivement la consommation de fruits et de légumes dans les écoles. Nous préconisons la fin des aides de l'UE pour les produits laitiers, et plus largement tous les produits d'origine animale, dans les écoles.  Dans un rapport, le GIEC a mentionné que l'élevage de bovins laitiers était responsable de 2128 millions de tonnes de CO2.  L'état des connaissances nutritionnelles démontre l'importance fondamentale de la consommation de fruits et de légumes en particulier frais et de saison pour couvrir les besoins en vitamines. Concernant spécifiquement les besoins en calcium, rappelons que les légumes à feuilles vertes notamment, sont une excellente source.  Par ailleurs, la consommation de légumineuses doit être encouragée pour ses bienfaits nutritionnels et son faible impact sur l'environnement.  Enfin, il nous apparait urgent et nécessaire que les enfants découvrent la diversité des saveurs de la cuisine végétale à l'école et ce, dans un intérêt public (écologie, santé et condition animale).
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: L214, association française de défense des animaux, remercie la Commission européenne pour cette opportunité offerte d’exprimer notre position quant à cette révision du programme de l’UE en faveur de la consommation de fruits, de légumes et de lait dans les écoles.  La société civile et les citoyens sont très sensibles à la politique volontariste menée par la Commission en matière environnementale, particulièrement exprimée dans le Green Deal, les stratégies Biodiversité et Farm 2 Fork, et plus récemment dans le paquet législatif Fit for 55.   L’impact environnemental de l’élevage est colossal. Il est rappelé dans la Stratégie Farm 2 fork : “Agriculture is responsible for 10.3% of the EU’s GHG emissions and nearly 70% of those come from the animal sector”. L’élevage bovin a un impact particulièrement délétère : selon le rapport FAO2018 GLEAM 2.0 : “Cattle are the main contributor to the sector's emissions with about 5.0 gigatonnes CO2-eq, which represents about 62 percent of sector's emissions. Beef and dairy cattle generate similar amounts of greenhouse gases”. 65% de la destruction de la forêt amazonienne serait le fait de l’élevage bovin selon Greenpeace (2016 et 2019), pour créer des prairies mais aussi pour cultiver le soja qui nourrit le bétail européen.   Ces dernières années, le secteur du lait a mené des campagnes marketing visant à faire croire que l’élevage bovin n’impacterait pas l’environnement, voire qu’il lui serait bénéfique, parfois avec le soutien financier de l’UE (campagne REA 2017 / Promotion of agricultural products / European Milk Forum - Climate). L’argument souvent utilisé par ce secteur sur la séquestration du carbone dans les prairies est erroné : le rapport FCRN / Université d’Oxford de 2017 démontre que l’élevage en prairie est bien un émetteur net de GES.    Par conséquent, l’élevage bovin ne saurait être considéré comme “durable” et l’UE doit combattre les tentatives de l’industrie de verdir son impact environnemental. C’est aussi le souhait des citoyens européens. Dans le cadre de la consultation organisée ces derniers mois sur la révision de la politique de promotion des produits agricoles, 95% des 7000 citoyens qui ont participé ont demandé que l’UE cesse de promouvoir des produits d’origine animale et ne soit plus complice du marketing trompeur de ces industries.  Toujours au chapitre des révisions en cours au niveau de l’UE, l’analyse d’impact initiale menée dans le cadre de la révision de la législation relative au bien-être animal souligne le manque d’information sur les conditions d’élevage et le non respect du bien-être animal en Europe : “Available information indicates that there are significant shortcomings related to EU animal welfare legislation in force, which result in sub-optimal levels of animal welfare for farmed animals”. Le manque criant de transparence sur la réalité des conditions d’élevage (mises au jour par les enquêtes des ONGs) induit un réel manque d’information pour le consommateur.   La révision du programme de l’UE en faveur de la consommation de fruits, de légumes et de lait dans les écoles est l’occasion de réaligner les politiques européennes et de les mettre en cohérence avec les ambitions environnementales et sanitaires de l’UE, et avec les attentes citoyennes. L214 propose donc de diversifier les sources de calcium dans les écoles en remplaçant les produits laitiers par des alternatives végétales, ou a minima réduire la diffusion des produits laitiers en proposant systématiquement une alternative végétale pouvant parfaitement satisfaire aux apports recommandés en calcium.   La proposition de ces alternatives permettra aussi de répondre aux besoins des personnes intolérantes au lactose et des végétaliens, de diminuer l’apport en protéines et en acides gras saturés, et enfin, de permettre d’éduquer les enfants à une alimentation en accord avec les impératifs climatiques et les recommandations nutritionnelles.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Die für unsere Kinder so wertvolle Schulmilch soll an jedem Schultag zur Verfügung stehen - dafür stehen unsere Schulmilchbauern. Durch die österreichischen Schulmilchbauern ist eine flächendeckende Versorgung mit Schulmilch möglich. Darüber hinaus trägt die Schulmilch durch die kurzen Transportwege und die regionale Produktion zu einer Nachhaltigen Lebensweise und zur Stärkung des ländlichen Raumes bei. Die verschiedenen Produkte (Trinkmilch, Kakao, Vanillemilch, etc.) unserer Schulmilchbauern sind sehr hochwertig und naturnahe hergestellt und treffen die unterschiedlichen Geschmäcker unserer Kindergarten- und Schulkinder. Viele Kinder kommen tagtäglich ohne Frühstück in die Schule oder den Kindergarten - besonders dann ist eine hochwertige Pausenverpflegung aus der Region, wie die Schulmilch es ist, besonders wichtig und wertvoll. Für unsere Schulmilchbauern steht das Wohl ihrer Tiere sowie eine nachhaltige Wirtschaftsweise und gentechnikfreie Fütterung an erster Stelle. Um den Geschmackspräferenzen unserer Kinder zu entsprechen und die Motivation unserer Schulmilchbauern aufrechterhalten zu können, ist eine nationale Festlegung der Produktpalette unverzichtbar.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme
