feedback_msg_text: Ordningen bør være lettere at udnytte for medlemslandene. DK har i flere år oplevet at uddannelsesinstitutionerne ikke udnytter ordningen tilstrækkeligt, hvorved pengene ikke går til det formål, som ønskes opnået, at få børn og unge til at spise mere frugt og grønt  Man kan med fordel lave en screening af alle landes skole frugt og grønt ordninger for at finde de bedste administrerede ordninger. Nogle lande er langt bedre til administration end andre. De bedst cases bør findes og måske udmøntes i en slags best practise for ordningens administration.   DK har lavet standard priser for en lang række frugt og grøntsager konventionelt og økologisk. Standard priserne gør at ansøger i højere grad skal gætte den rigtige pris ved ansøgningen. Men når tilskuddet udbetales, er der mængderne overvurderede. Det betyder, at ordningen udnyttes dårligt. Der må findes bedre måder at gøre dette på.   Er det muligt at administrere ordningen således, at man kun skal søge pengene til udbetaling på baggrund af konkrete fakturaer evt. fra det sidste halve år?  Nedlukning med Covid19 har gjort at ordningerne i 2 år er dårligt udnyttet. Det er ekstraordinær situation. Øremærkning af pengene til ordningen kan i en periode gøre give flere penge de kommende år til bedre og sundere måltider til børn og unge.   Skolefrugt ordningen tilsiger ikke, at der gives støtte til lokal frugt og grønt. For at understøtte Farm to fork strategien og andre klima og bæredygtighedsmål burde ordningen give bedre incitament til at vælge lokal og mere bæredygtigt produceret frugt og grønt. Evt. ved højere tilskud til frugt der kommer fra lokale eller regionale producenter (indenfor en km afstand eller lignende)   Skolefrugt ordningen har til formål at give børn og unge mindst et sundt måltid om dagen. For at understøtte dette kan man med fordel tillade at frugt og grønt indgår i en ret, der tilberedes. Det er oftest lettere at få børn og unge til at spise grøntsager, hvis de indgår i en ret fremfor at de blot skal spise et stykke frisk grønt.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Education on healthy and sustainable food production, food consumption and reduction of food waste is crucial early in life to ensure better food behaviour throughout life. When reconsidering the products to include in this project I would recommend to consider adding plant-based protein sources as a both healthy and sustainable food product. Also I would recommend to include the theme of biodiversity in the programme as well.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: This is a solid proposal for evaluation. Alignment of the scheme with the environmental dimension is timely and very relevant. Also, the focus on coverage is: very important to reach the most vulnerable groups.  Specifics:  In determining the eligible products. Important to keep the focus on healthiest products (no dilution to ‘healthier’ products), and to add sustainability criteria on top of health criteria. Needless to say that ‘organic’ and sustainable are not necessarily the same, nor is ’organic’ equivalent to health.  With regard to education materials, it is important to only use validated materials from independent sources. Avoid by all means (indirect) marketing of unhealthy products to children.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Ayant été gestionnaire du programme, voici mon avis sur différents points :   Le public cible :  Ce programme permet aux enfants d'acquérir de meilleures habitudes alimentaires, de découvrir de nouveaux produits et d'améliorer leurs connaissances. Il est vecteur de justice sociale et d'éducation au goût. L'effet de groupe lève les résistances à la découverte des fruits et légumes.  Il serait intéressant d'ouvrir le programme aux crèches (0-3ans), aux clubs sportifs et activités extra-scolaires (3-18 ans), voire aux étudiants (post-bac) ainsi qu'aux centres de loisirs et colonies.  De manière occasionnelle, on pourrait même envisager un panier à emporter à ramener à la maison afin de faire le lien avec les familles et d'y importer ces nouvelles habitudes.     Les fournisseurs et les produits :  Pour les producteurs, la possibilité de favoriser l'approvisionnement local est l'opportunité d'un débouché important. Ainsi les labels nationaux devraient pouvoir être mis en avant (exemple HVE). De plus, afin de faciliter la priorité aux produits locaux, les règles de mise en concurrence devraient être adaptées. Des données sur l'origine des produits distribués pourraient figurer sur les évaluations (local, national, européen, mondial).  La question des emballages devraient être posée. A titre d'exemple, les emballages individuels ne devraient pas pouvoir être exigés.        Le volet éducatif :  Les mesures pédagogiques actives devraient être favorisées (plutôt que les leçons). Le maximum de 15% de l'enveloppe est fixé ; il conviendrait de fixer un minimum et de définir le niveau de qualité attendu.     La gestion du programme :  D'abord, il faudrait plus de stabilité dans les règles nationales et une sécurisation des demandeurs d'aides et fournisseurs, notamment sur la durée des agréments. Ensuite, une simplification administrative semble indispensable. Enfin, un système de versement d'une avance serait appréciable.     La conception du programme au niveau national :  Une démocratie participative et des retours terrains pourraient permettre de booster les effets du programme.  Un partage de bonnes pratiques des états membres les plus efficients serait judicieux.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Les objectifs de cette politique européenne consistent à améliorer la contribution des institutions scolaires européennes à la consommation d'une alimentation durable, en promouvant des produits durables et sains ("enhance the contribution of the EU school scheme to sustainable food consumption, by promoting the distribution of sustainable products and strengthening educational measures on the importance of healthy nutrition, sustainable food systems and reducing food waste, and to improve the efficiency/performance of the scheme").   Or, les études scientifiques convergent sur un point : s'ils veulent atteindre leurs objectifs en matière de climat et de préservation de la biodiversité, les pays occidentaux doivent réduire drastiquement leurs apports en protéines animales, au profit de protéines végétales et de produits d'origine animale de qualité (Poore and Nemecek, 2018).   Ceci est d'autant plus nécessaire que du point de vue sanitaire, en France, les produits d'origine végétale et les fruits et légumes en particulier constituent un véritable marqueur social (ANSES, 2017 ; Crédoc, 2018) : les enfants comme les adultes ne consomment pas suffisamment de fibres / fruits et légumes et surconsomment au contraire des protéines animales, souvent de mauvaise qualité - et ceci est particulièrement vrai dans les familles défavorisées. Les apports en calcium notamment sont largement dépassés pour les 0-3 ans et atteints pour les plus âgés (ANSES, 2017). Il est donc essentiel que l'UE favorise la consommation de fruits et légumes, mais pas celle de produits laitiers.  En particulier, les parts de fromages servis devraient être réduites au maximum, dans la mesure où ces derniers sont souvent riches en lipides, acides gras saturés et sels. Les autres produits laitiers sont de meilleurs compromis en matière de nutrition (ANSES, 2021 ; Darmon/EnScol 2020). Pour autant, comme expliqué précédemment les protéines d'origine animale sont encore prépondérantes dans les régimes des citoyens occidentaux. Il est urgent de rééquilibrer ces rapports, et ce dès le plus jeune âge. C'est le rôle de l'Union européenne que de favoriser les aliments à la fois durables et sains, comme les fruits et légumes. En revanche, au vu des urgences climatiques, environnementales et sanitaires auxquelles nous faisons face, les produits laitiers n'ont pas leur place dans ces programmes d'alimentation dite durable. En France, ceci est d'autant plus vrai que les produits laitiers sont obligatoires à tous les repas dans les écoles, il n'y a donc pas besoin de soutien supplémentaire de l'UE, car cela ne ferait que favoriser une surconsommation de ces protéines.   Ce soutien à un rééquilibrage des protéines, au profit de la qualité (car il n'est pas question ici d'exclure les produits laitiers ou les viandes, simplement de les réduire) est d'autant plus important que c'est à cet âge que les mentalités et les habitudes se forgent. Il est donc essentiel que les programmes institutionnels soient exemplaires sur le plan de la durabilité et de la santé, et qu'ils se concentrent donc sur les fruits et légumes.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: ASPROCAN coincide plenamente con los objetivos del plan escolar de la UE “para reconectar a los niños con la agricultura y enseñarles sobre hábitos alimenticios saludables“.   Los productos destinados a los alumnos que se benefician de este programa deberían cumplir los más altos estándares de calidad y sostenibilidad. Sin embargo, el programa actualmente no es coherente con los principios de preferencia comunitaria, ni en la promoción de productos sostenibles y de cercanía, y tampoco permite la participación más directa de los productores agrícolas a través de asociaciones de organizaciones de productores u organizaciones de productores como tal.   Atendiendo a los problemas identificados que relaciona la consulta pública, nuestras consideraciones son:  1. Cobertura.  En este sentido, dar cabida a esquemas de participación que permitan a los productores agrupados en Organizaciones de Productores o sus asociaciones, establecer acuerdos de suministro regular de fruta a los programas nacionales, no sólo reduciría los eslabones de intermediación, sino sobre todo, permitiría aprovechar circunstancias habituales de producción en origen para reducir el desperdicio alimentario y reconducir volúmenes para un mayor abastecimiento de frutas y hortalizas a escolares cubriendo únicamente, costes de transporte y distribución.  2. Productos elegibles  Es imprescindible que se establezcan prioridades concretas y claras en favor de productos con mayores estándares de producción de la UE como son:  A) Aplicar un valor euros/kilos diferente y superior en el caso de producciones europeas.  B) Hacer obligatorio el aprovisionamiento de producto comunitario sobre el de terceros países cuando exista la garantía de suministro de dicho producto en el Estado miembro.  C) Favorecer en la práctica la elección de productos con calidad diferenciada, conforme al reglamento europeo 1151/2012 o norma que lo sustituya.   D) Establecer criterios de calidad del producto adaptados a la producción comunitaria.   E) Distribuir prioritariamente productos que cumplan con todos los requisitos normativos aplicados por la Unión a la producción agrícola comunitaria, por ejemplo, en términos de uso de fertilizantes y pesticidas.   F) Posibilitar el establecimiento de frutas que a nivel nacional puedan vincularse como “transversales”, y por tanto, de inclusión necesaria en todo el territorio durante los meses del año en los que no existe producción de fruta de temporada.  G) Se hace urgente el diferenciar entre los productos ecológicos de producción europea de aquellos productos “ecológicos” procedentes de terceros países, pues estos últimos cuentan con unas leyes mucho más laxas en cuanto a lo necesario para considerar un producto como tal, y se da por válida la venta de dicho producto como ecológico dentro del mercado de la UE, haciendo competencia desleal a nuestros productores, que deben cumplir unos estándares mucho más altos.  3. Participación de actores.  El modelo de suministro de la fruta debe potenciar y favorecer aquellos casos en los que existan asociaciones de organizaciones de productores u organizaciones de productores con organización y suministro suficiente para acordar directamente la provisión de fruta con los actores encargados de la distribución y entrega de fruta en las escuelas.  Feedback from: Asociacion de Organizaciones de Productores de Plátano de Canarias - ASPROCAN (244.6 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Ringraziando la possibilità dataci dalla Commissione Europea, vogliamo sottolineare il potenziale di tale manovra di adeguamento.  Le più recenti pubblicazioni sottolineano l’importanza di un cambio di paradigma alimentare, per risolvere al tempo stesso i problemi inerenti alla salute pubblica e alla crisi climatica. La soluzione proposta dalla comunità scientifica internazionale consiste nel promuovere il consumo di alimenti di origine vegetale, quindi non solo frutta e verdura, ma anche cereali integrali, semi oleosi e legumi.  Promuovere un’alimentazione a base vegetale nelle scuole permette di creare una base critica di consumatori consapevoli nel futuro e centrare gli obiettivi dell’Agenda 2030, della strategia Farm to Fork e dell’agenda del Green Deal Europeo.  La scuola dovrebbe essere un luogo di formazione ed educazione super partes e un laboratorio in costante aggiornamento con l’obiettivo di guidare le famiglie verso la corretta alimentazione, che sia in grado di rimediare agli errori commessi a casa. Va altresì considerato che in Italia la povertà alimentare colpisce il 10% della popolazione, che segue una dieta a base di alimenti ultra processati e povera di frutta e verdura.  La distribuzione di frutta e verdura nelle scuole dovrebbe garantire anche un legame con il territorio, proponendo ortaggi locali, sfusi e al giusto grado di maturazione (attualmente la proposta di frutta nelle scuole italiane prevede frutta acerba, non locale e confezionata in plastica, con il risultato che non viene consumata).  La promozione del latte vaccino porta invece con sé alcune criticità, in quanto i latticini hanno un impatto ambientale molto superiore rispetto alle alternative vegetali. Dovendo promuovere alimenti sostenibili con soldi pubblici, si dovrebbero privilegiare quelli che hanno un profilo di sostenibilità migliore, come le bevande vegetali fortificate. Nel caso non si volesse fare questa scelta sarebbe perlomeno auspicabile evitare la promozione di latticini provenienti da allevamenti intensivi, in linea con quanto dichiarato nella strategia Farm to Fork.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Fresh Produce Centre from the Netherlands welcomes the European Commission´s initiative to review the EU‘s School fruit, vegetables and milk scheme. We think the following elements should be taken in account: • COVID-19 made it very clear that an healthy eating habit is very important, especially when it concerns young children. Therefore we advise to increase or stabilise the available budget , even though the current budget in the EU does not reach 100%.  • We believe in equal chances for children. Therefore we think that it is important to provide all children with fresh fruit and vegetables. However, there might be certain target groups that  need it more than others. So you could reserve a part of the budget for those groups (f.e. a fixed percentage).  • There should be a focus on healthy and fresh products, when determining which products should be considered as eligible products. (no dilution to 'healthier' products). Let 's not forget the sustainability aspect: products are not available for all year round. Children should be aware of this.  • We believe that educational measures are necessary to improve the healthy behaviour of our children (f.e. school gardens). That is why we are in favour of introducing a minimum share of at least 10% of the EU budget that Member States have to spend on educational measures.  • The fees that are paid to the suppliers of school fruit and vegetables should reflect a reasonable price. The forfaits need to be interesting enough to participate in the program. This is an important element since the supply of healthy, sustainable and fresh products for children depends on them.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: V-Entrepreneurs France, association de défense des droits et des intérêts des entrepreneurs éthiques en France, trouve très à propos cette consultation sur l’alimentation de nos enfants dans ce contexte de crise écologique et sanitaire et remercie la Commission Européenne de s’emparer de ces sujets.  Toutefois, nous notons que l’inclusion des produits laitiers dans le même groupe que les fruits et légumes ne fait pas sens, et ce pour plusieurs raisons:  Favoriser la consommation de lait est un facteur d’exclusion envers les personnes, très nombreuses, intolérantes ou sensibles au lactose.  Les produits laitiers sont largement controversés puisqu’ils contiennent des hormones de croissance, notamment l’IGF1, destinée à faire grossir les veaux rapidement. Il s’agit d’un facteur de développement de surpoids et d’obésité chez les consommateurs réguliers, ainsi que de diabète étant donné qu’il s’agit d’une hormone insulinique. Les produits laitiers contiennent également les oestrogènes des vaches gestantes. Comme chez tout mammifère, les hormones produites par la vache se retrouvent dans son lait.  Le calcium se trouve très facilement dans de nombreux aliments végétaux, notamment dans des fruits et légumes. De plus, une alimentation riche en fruits et légumes limite également les pertes de calcium de l’organisme, ce qui est tout aussi important que l’apport en lui-même.   D’un point de vue écologique, cette promotion de la consommation de produits laitiers est également incohérente avec les objectifs affichés par de l’Union Européenne. L’élevage bovin est très majoritairement extensif et non industrialisé en Europe. On pourrait donc penser que cet élevage en prairie absorbe du CO2. Pourtant, les prairies n’absorbent que 10 à 15% de la production de CO2 des bovins, et des forêts en lieu et place des pâturages capteraient infiniment plus de carbone sans en émettre. Les ruminants sont d’ailleurs responsables de plus de 60% des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) du secteur agricole. Même après la prise en compte de l’effet de stockage du CO2 dans les prairies, cela représente encore 50% des émissions du secteur.  A eux seuls, les produits laitiers sont responsables de 27% des émissions de CO2 de tout le secteur de l’alimentation alors que les produits d’origine animale (produits carnés, laitiers et ovoproduits confondus) ne fournissent que 18% de l’apport calorique mondial.   Pour toutes ces raison, la promotion des produits laitiers auprès des enfants n’est donc pas compatible avec les objectifs de l’Union Européenne en terme de santé et d’écologie et il serait bien plus approprié de donner l’information juste, comme c’est déjà le cas dans le guide alimentaire Canadien, à savoir que les produits laitiers peuvent être consommés en tant que “produits plaisir” non-essentiels.  V-Entrepreneurs France reconnaît cependant les propriétés organoleptiques des produits laitiers: en termes de goût, de textures et de variétés possibles d’utilisation, ce sont en effet, des produits agréables à manger.  Dans ce cadre, de nombreuses entreprises françaises et européennes développent des alternatives fabuleuses aux produits laitiers. En quelques années, l’offre de laits, de yaourts et de fromages végétaux est devenue pléthorique et l’élève est désormais en train de dépasser le maître puisque nombreuses sont ces alternatives qui n’ont désormais plus rien à envier aux produits laitiers d’origine animale.  Ces alternatives sont infiniment meilleures pour la santé et pour l’environnement. V-Entrepreneurs France en appelle donc au bon sens des membres de la Commission Européenne pour ne prendre en compte que les fruits et légumes parmi les produits indispensables à soutenir et à distribuer aux enfants, et à se servir de l’offre de qualité déjà existante en alternatives aux produits laitiers s’ils et elles souhaitent proposer aux enfants de bons produits agréables à manger.
Initiative: Review of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme

feedback_msg_text: Cambiar los ENFOQUES. Conceptual: las personas migrantes son VICTIMAS no OBJETO de tráfico. Los traficantes se valen de la vulnerabilidad de las y los migrantes, que se genera en sus mismos países de origen y en el engaño, ofreciendo viajes y destinos que no existen o no están disponibles. Por eso miles de personas terminan estancadas en fronteras clave como México, España, etc. Funcional: las campañas, diseño de documentos y leyes aisladas no producen un impacto real en el desarrollo de la actividad criminal de tráfico ilícito de migrantes. Unicamente funcionan los planes estructurales, como el que se propone, pero que sean realmente seguidos y apoyados por cada país y en conjunto por la ONU y sus agencias. SOCIAL: las medidas represivas o preventivas para alertar del peligro del tráfico, funcionan únicamente con acciones de desarrollo y oportunidades y de politicas migratorias eficaces.  En materia de investigación criminal: indispensable el uso de la inteligencia policial-criminal articulada y que se base en datos comprobables. Frecuentemente se habla de la presencia de cientos de organizaciones operando en espacios geográficos determinados. Lo cierto es que son pocas organizaciones con múltiples derivados, esto implica la separación entre miembros y asociados o colaboradores. La inteligencia puede aportar mucho a este proceso. Así como a la identificación geográfica referencial delos modus operandi, es decir, conocer en tiempo y espacio el desplazamiento y ubicación de las rutas, lugares de ocultamiento y medios de transporte empleado. Finalmente, es indispensable conocer las formas de pago y seguir el dinero, como dicen los expertos en tráfico de drogas. En América Latina, por ejemplo, los traficantes que dirigen las organizaciones son multimillonarios y el camino para llegar a sus patrimonios es complejo, pero necesario. Perfiles. Todas las técnicas de perfilación son importantes para identificar personas migrantes que son objetivo de las redes en lugares determinados y de traficantes, transportes, lugares, zonas de paso, medios técnicos que utilizan, etc. Esto es parte del M.O.,  pero debería analizarse con mayor detalle. Estos perfiles deben extenderse a la inteligencia de los países de origen. Por ejemplo, donde consiguen las embarcaciones, quien financia su compra, como se realiza la captación del migrante, cómo paga si no tiene efectivo, etc.  Documentos de identificación, viaje, trabajo. Es toda una industria criminal que utiliza  el tráfico y debe investigarse con mayor detalle para llegar a los lugares de fabricación, falsificación y a las formas en que son adquiridos (robo, corrupción, etc.) Delitos alternos o conexos. Migrantes usados para transporte ilícito de mercancias, drogas, armas, etc, y, migrantes que son secuestrados o utilizados en trata de personas. Con la pandemia, los tratantes y traficantes han modificado sus conductas y parte del cambio es vender directamente a las personas. El tratante ha asumido su rol primario de captar y vender y el traficante de migrantes, vender directamente algunos migrantes que no tienen recursos para llegar al destino final o que tienen un perfil optimo.  Unidades especializadas. Tanto en la policía como fiscalía. Deben asumir el delito principal y todos los delitos conexos  Judicialización. Armonizar las legislaciones, no solo en los tipos penales básicos, sino en las normas procesales y ESPECIALMENTE en las técnicasde acusación de la fiscalía. Las leyes pueden ser similares, pero el abordaje técnico del fiscal tambien debe armonizarse con las mejores prácticas que garanticen las condenas. En estos casos los manuales de judicialización e investigación deben ser regionales. Capacitación:  incluir a los jueces Coordinación. Incluir a los países de origen, estadía y destino final. Entiendo que la mayoría de estas medidas ya estén en marcha, pero por mi experiencia como consultor en este tema, se que el avance no es homogeneo.
Initiative: Fighting migrant smuggling: 2021-2025 EU action plan

feedback_msg_text: The Red Cross EU Office welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the Roadmap to the EU Action Plan against migrant smuggling (2021-2025) as it allows us to bring humanitarian concerns, based on our experience, to the attention of decision makers. The Red Cross EU Office is a membership office representing the 27 Red Cross National Societies in the EU, the Norwegian Red Cross, the British Red Cross, the Islandic Red Cross and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.  Within and beyond Europe, Red Cross Red Crescent National Societies provide support to migrants in need irrespective of their legal status. They observe, how many migrants are faced with limited options for safe and regular migration, and therefore must often embark on dangerous sea and land journeys where they frequently have to rely on the services of smugglers. The routes they take carry substantial risks, adding both physical and psychosocial trauma to their pre-existing vulnerabilities.  Respecting and protecting the human rights of all migrants should be the cornerstone of any EU strategy on migration, including when it comes to addressing smuggling. The Action Plan against migrant smuggling should guarantee that all migrants, irrespective of status, have safe and effective access to assistance and protection, including when delivered by humanitarian actors and legislation must not hamper or criminalise providing humanitarian assistance to migrants.  Red Cross Red Crescent National Societies are witnessing significant abuse at all stages of the migratory process, particularly for those who are obliged to migrate in an irregular way and have no other option but to resort to services of smugglers. This exposes them to risks that can result in physical and psychological trauma and increase their vulnerability. In the absence of a suitable legal framework to regulate the admission, stay and transit of migrants at the different stages of their journeys, they often remain invisible, which limits their access to rights and services. Migrants may have no other choice than to enter and remain in a particular country clandestinely while they are in transit or awaiting their next border crossing. They are then deemed to be in an irregular situation, which can contribute to their stigmatisation and criminalisation.  This exposes them to further risks and enhances their vulnerability to smuggling and trafficking. The Action Plan against migrant smuggling (2015-2020) aimed at setting out concrete actions to counter and prevent migrant smuggling, while ensuring the protection of the human rights of migrants. In our view however, the disproportionate focus on border management and return related measures has had a detrimental effect on migrants’ dignity and wellbeing within the EU and along the migratory route.  Based on the expertise of our members, RCEU makes the following recommendations, that should be considered in the EU Action Plan against smuggling (2021-2025): 1. Ensure that migrants have safe and effective access to relevant protection and assistance services wherever they are. 2. Enhance legal certainty and ensure the delivery of humanitarian assistance is supported and never criminalised.  3. Implement an effective framework for safe and legal migration to the EU.  For more details please see the attachment. Feedback from: Red Cross EU Office (158 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Fighting migrant smuggling: 2021-2025 EU action plan

feedback_msg_text: The EU’s Action Plan 2015-2020 included the commitment by the European Commission to make a proposal to “seek to ensure that appropriate criminal sanctions are in place while avoiding risks of criminalisation of those who provide humanitarian assistance to migrants in distress”. This was not upheld. As a consequence, hundreds of people are still criminalised on inflated charges of migrant smuggling. This includes migrants, their family members and friends, with devastating consequences on their future opportunities. This often includes their unjust exclusion from the right to apply for international protection.  ReSOMA (2017) showed that between 2015 and 2019, 171 human rights defenders were investigated or convicted on grounds related to the EU Facilitation Directive. This includes volunteers, NGOs, migrants’ family members, journalists, criminalised for saving lives at sea or providing shelter or food to people in need. The EU Facilitation Directive fails to provide legal certainty on the definition of migrant smuggling and is therefore apt to various interpretations by member states, who can prosecute activities which are carried out because of humanitarian reasons, while there is no link with transnational organised crime.  As an organisation for the defense of the rights of sex workers, among whom a certain part enter the EU by means of human smuggling, we are committed to the protection and humanitarian assistance to migrants in need while crossing the Mediterranean or after arrival in the EU.  Also, criminalising normal interactions and transactions between irregular migrants without undue financial profit, endangers the fundamental rights of migrant sex workers and other irregular migrants. Renting accomodation to irregular migrants, for instance, is considered a crime in France, and can even be considered a form of migrant smuggling. While migrants already face discrimination in the housing market, such provisions - or the fear of them - relegate people to precarious, over-crowded and unsuitable housing, often at exploitative rent prices, and increase risks of eviction, abuse and theft of rent and deposits.  Based on the experiences of migrant sex workers we are in touch with, since the hardening of EU migration policies in the 1990s, the sex industry has seen a clear degradation in terms of increasing violence, price drops and declining access to fundamental rights for sex workers. While deemed more easy before to obtain visas, since the hardening, coinciding with the establishment of the Schengen area, migrants increasingly have had to rely on smugglers. Already in 2007, their passage could imply a debt of 50,000 euros (Guillemaut, 2008), a price that has been increasing since. Migrant women, in this way, are easily seen as profitable assets as the sex sector is exempt from a clear legal framework in most EU countries. This way, a situation of human smuggling turns into a situation of human trafficking.  It is also of utmost importance to note the important gap between the way supposed ‘victims’ perceive their smugglers and how policy-makers approach the question. Indeed, migrant women perceive their smugglers and traffickers more as ‘saviors’ than ‘pimps’ because their will to migrate was strong. They know they can file complaints, but think they have more to lose than to gain. There’s a lack of trust regarding European institutions who criminalise, and this reinforces their reliance on potentially dangerous clandestine networks. Last, due to the frequent conflation, and discriminatory application of laws criminalising human trafficking, smuggling and aspects of sex work, migrant sex workers who organise themselves, and those providing accommodation to sex workers, risk prosecution. This denies migrant sex workers their right to organise collectively and exposes them to evictions, homelessness and further abuse. We fully agree with the recommendations put forward by PICUM and call for an evidence-based approach.
Initiative: Fighting migrant smuggling: 2021-2025 EU action plan

feedback_msg_text: EURODEFENSE-ESPAÑA would like to make the following comments:  1) Action against migrant smuggling must be a cenral element of a comprehensive EU policy on migration. It is also an area in which consensus among member states can be reached more easily than on other more contentious issues.  2) From the humanitarian point of view, smuggling is to be blamed for thousands of lives lost in dangerous journeys across the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. Human smuggling is also indiscriminate. According to press reports, the Canary Islands currently host 2,634 migrant minors (while only 540 in 2019), some of which are unaccompanied children. There has been tragic loss of life amongst some children who tried to reach the Islands recently.  3) Combatting criminal networks requires strong cooperation between EU member states (especially front-line states) and EU institutions (EUROPOL, EU Migrant Smuggling Center, EUROJUST, etc.). Acting to deactivate the financial channels is crucial, as many migrants are compelled to pay substantial sums of money to these networks for years.   4) Operational cooperation with countries of origin and transit to fight migrant smuggling must be a priority issue. The EU must use all elements at its disposal to encourage this cooperation, including financial assistance and personnel training, adopting retaliatory measures when these governments do not fully cooperate on this matter. The transport of illegal migrants often starts at the shores of some of these countries, whose governments tolerate the activities of the smugglers.  5) Acting effectively by the EU, in close cooperation with member states and third countries, to facilitate and encourage legal migration and punish employers of irregular migrants is a fundamental tool to combat illegal migration and smuggling. It must be recognized that the labor markets of the various member states are different, and this requires proper differentiation.   6) Although no new budgetary commitments by the EU are foreseen to fight against migrant smuggling, its importance must be considered when distributing the budget for migration management.  7) A proper review of the implementation of the EU Action Plan Against Migrant Trafficking 2015-2020 must be made, before setting-up the 2021-2025 Plan. EURODEFENSE-ESPAÑA is interested to read the report that the Commission must present soon on this matter.   8) CSDP operations in the Mediterranean Sea and other neighbor regions could also provide a valuable contribution to this effort, opening a possibility for burden-sharing by member states other than the front-line states.
Initiative: Fighting migrant smuggling: 2021-2025 EU action plan

feedback_msg_text: En tant qu'association agissant aupres des personnes exiles dans 8 villes en France et  le long de la frontiere franco-britannique, a Calais, Grande Synthe et Lille, nous souhaitons apporter des elements de reponse a la question soumise dans la consultation : en quoi la lutte contre le trafic humain a un impact criminalisant les associations qui viennent en aide aux personnes exilées à la frontière ?  - La lutte poussée contre le trafic d'etres humains rend le trafic encore plus insidueux, caché, et donc les gens qui doivent en dépendre doivent passer par des moyens de plus en plus dangereux pour rejoindre les réseaux et passer les frontières. Nous constatons que plus la surveillance et le controle sont accrus aux frontieres et plus les personnes prennent des risques supplementaires pour essayer de passer, dans des endroits ou il n'y a pas de couverture reseau pour les telephones, ou par des conditions meteorologiques mauvaises qui permettent le camouflage des embarcations. Ces informations proviennent des personnes exiles qui temoignent de leurs difficultes et strategies. Les risques pris pour effectuer les traversées de la frontière sont de plus en plus nombreux pour les personnes sans ressources qui ne pourraient pas passer par un réseau qui, malgré tout, s'éfforce de garantir un certain aprovisionnement en matériel (bateau, gilets). Les personnes sans ressources se voient forcées de prendre la mer par leur propres moyens pour passer sous le radar des passeurs, et donc de prendre des risques encore plus grands en tentant la traversée avec un matériel totalement inadapté, dont les risques sont mortels.  Au cours de nos 5 années d'expérience à la frontière franco-britannique, on a pu observer que plus la frontière était contrôlée, plus les risques liés au passage étaient grand.   - Utopia 56, sans pouvoir identifier réellement les réseaux,constatent dans le cadre des activités de terrain, que les passeurs se placent en interlocuteurs principaux et font les intermediaires avec les personnes exilées victimes du trafic.  - Chaque service mis en place par les associations est récupéré par le réseaux, monaiyé auprès des personnes victimes de trafic, ce qui rend les personnes sans ressources encore plus vulnérables car ne peuvent avoir accès aux services de base librement, et complique le travail des associations qui doivent sans cesse élargir leur services, en terme de quantité, de disponibilité, pour atteindre un maximum de personnes et ainsi éviter que cela soit "récupéré" par le réseau.  -  Utopia 56 diffuse des informations de prévention des risques liés au passage en distribuant des documents d'information avec les numéros d'urgence des secours et des recommandations pratiques. Certaines association refusent cette mission de peur d'être taxées d'aide au passage, ce qui contribue à renforcer l'ignorance de la question de la traite, et donc la vulnérabilité des personnes face aux prises de risques réelles.  - On a souvent entendu des discours officiels de certains ministres ou élus disant que les association étaient en lien étroit, et travaillaient avec les passeurs, c'est insuportable quand on connait le travail fait par les associations pour contourner les dynamiques d'emprises de ces réseaux et atteindre les personnes qui ne passent pas par ces réseaux, ou que les réseaux tentent d'isoler (par exemple les MNA).  - la lutte contre le trafic humain ne se fera pas sans une forme de cassure des frontières. Si l'Europe faisait le choix politique de transférer légalement toutes ces personnes, alors les réseaux de trafic n'auraient plus de raison d'être. Un réseau démantelé quelque part, marque simplement la naissance d'un nouveau réseau ailleurs, et toujours plus de risques.  - les personnes victimes de trafic a la frontieres ont besoin de dispositif specifique quand elles souhaient sortir des reseaux, pour les adultes et les MNA, visant notamment a les proteger des represailles.
Initiative: Fighting migrant smuggling: 2021-2025 EU action plan

feedback_msg_text: ILGA-Europe  welcomes the plan of the European Commission to assess the role that the existing EU legislation had in preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence and assessing its compliance with international human rights standards.  ILGA-Europe takes this opportunity to contribute the following recommendations for the fitness check of EU legislation improving protection against violence against women and domestic violence.   1. Informal and targeted consultation process should include LGBTI organisations LGBTI organisations directly working with violence against LBTI women and girls and LGBTI victims of domestic violence, victims support and crime reporting, coming together in the ILGA-Europe network, should be directly involved in informal and targeted consultations to ensure coherence of the fitness check results with the international legal framework. 2. Ensure that experiences of LGBTI victims of gender based violence and domestic violence are taken into account  As the EU has clearly indicated, its recent Gender Equality Strategy applies to “women and men, girls and boys, in all their diversity”. Going further, the Strategy explains that “the expression ‘in all their diversity’ is used in this strategy to express that, where women or men are mentioned, these are a heterogeneous categories including in relation to their sex, gender identity, gender expression or sex characteristics.”   In keeping with this understanding, the fitness check should systematically include inquiries into the applicability of existing legal measures to LGBTI people. An intersectional analytical framework, which uses repeated prompts throughout the analysis to ask first “does specific legislation exist” and then “does existing legislation apply to all people, regardless of sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression and sex characteristics (SOGIGESC)” is recommended. 3. Ensure intersectional lens to fitness check to include experiences of LGBTI people at the intersection of oppression LBTI women and girls, who are marginalized on account of age, race, ethnicity, religion, language, migrant status, economic status, disability, health status, among other marginalized identities, experience compounded discrimination and violence of all forms. One clear goal of the equality framework of the Commission is to address intersectional discrimination and oppression. Commitment to intersectionality requires active integration in a thorough and comprehensive way. Intersectionality is not accomplished as a framework when the issues of multiply marginalised people are only dealt with in silos. Rather, clear and crosscutting intersectional analysis not only deepens understanding of the struggles of those most marginalised, but also encourages an intersectional understanding of identities and experiences more generally. It is vital to thoroughly analyse how existing EU legislation addresses/fails the full variety of intersectional experiences of women and girls in preventing and combatting violence against women and domestic violence and what should be done to fill identified gaps in.  Please, find full list of recommendations in the attached file.  Feedback from: ILGA-Europe (308.7 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Violence against women and domestic violence – fitness check of EU legislation

feedback_msg_text: Durante la última década la Comisión Europea ha adoptado su Estrategia para la igualdad entre mujeres y hombres (2010-2015) y el Compromiso estratégico para la igualdad entre mujeres y hombres 2016-2019. Desgraciadamente, en ninguno de estos dos instrumentos se incluía o se abordaba la situación específica de las mujeres y niñas con discapacidad, y menos aún de las madres cuidadoras de personas con discapacidad, pese a ser una población que sufre discriminaciones múltiples constantes y otras violaciones graves de sus derechos fundamentales.  En 2015, en sus Observaciones finales sobre el informe inicial de la Unión Europea, el Comité de la CRPD de Naciones Unidas adoptó recomendaciones específicas que debe seguir la UE en relación con las mujeres y niñas con discapacidad. Más concretamente, el Comité recomendó a la Unión Europea que incorporara la perspectiva de las mujeres y niñas con discapacidad en la nueva estrategia de igualdad de género y en sus políticas y programas en esta materia; que igualmente incorporara la perspectiva de género en sus estrategias sobre discapacidad, y que formulara medidas de acción afirmativa para promover los derechos de las mujeres y las niñas con discapacidad. El Comité de la ONU también le solicitó a la Unión Europea que estableciera un mecanismo para supervisar los progresos realizados en la igualdad y no discriminación de esta población femenina, dedicando financiación para la investigación y la reunión de datos sobre su situación concreta. Por último, el Comité de la CRPD también recomendó a la Unión Europea que se adhiriera al Convenio del Consejo de Europa sobre Prevención y Lucha contra la Violencia contra la Mujer y la Violencia Doméstica (Convenio de Estambul) como un paso más para combatir la violencia contra las mujeres y las niñas con discapacidad.   Por todo ello, la Fundación CERMI Mujeres exige la adopción de una estrategia europea de igualdad de género ambiciosa y dotada de recursos suficientes para el periodo post-2019. La estrategia debe abordar las formas de discriminación múltiple y discriminación interseccional que padecen las mujeres y niñas con discapacidad y otros colectivos marginados. La estrategia debe basarse en los derechos fundamentales de las mujeres y niñas con discapacidad de la Unión Europea, tal y como se establecen en los tratados de la UE, la Carta de los Derechos Fundamentales y la CRPD de Naciones Unidas, de la que forman parte la UE y todos sus Estados Miembros. Asimismo, la estrategia debe ser coherente con las acciones externas de la UE y con los Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible. Feedback from: FUNDACION CERMI MUJERES (61.1 KB - PDF - 18 pages) Download
Initiative: Violence against women and domestic violence – fitness check of EU legislation

feedback_msg_text: GESBA as member of the Association of European Banana Producers believes that in order to assess the economic impact of Trade Agreements, it is necessary to consider the entire EU trade policy which has, in recent years, significantly eroded the benefits generated by the European banana sector. Their situation could be further deteriorated by the disappearance of custom tariffs applied to Latin American producers in the coming years.   Bananas play a crucial role in the economy of European Outermost Regions (ORs) and are instrumental to job and wealth creation, providing more than 17 000 direct jobs and over 20 000 indirect ones. Also, the EU is the only market outlet for ORs while Latin American bananas are also exported to the USA and Asia.   In 2016, 69.6% of all bananas sold in the EU market came from Latin American countries, the remainder being split between the ORs (11.3%) and ACP countries (19.1%). As of the end of 2018, the EU market share of bananas from Latin America had risen to 75.7% while the share of ACP bananas dropped to 16% and to 8.3% for bananas from the ORs. As a consequence, ORs have experienced a fall of 11% between 2016 and 2018 while Latin American countries have enjoyed an increase of 4.5% of their already dominant market share.   The massive increase in exports from Latin America have in turn significantly depressed wholesale prices, to around 15 to 20%, once corrected for inflation. This drop is generating an oversupply crisis and harming ORs’ operators.  The domineering Latin American competition is further exacerbated by tariff concessions. It is therefore essential to rethink the tariff regime to enable EU and African producers to maintain their access to the market.   It is estimated that Latin American producers have enjoyed cumulated savings of 2 bn € on custom duties.   These trade agreements are therefore disproportionately favourable to Latin American producers, who have captured all the growth opportunities and capital gains of the EU banana market and might very soon drive EU and ACP producers out of their domestic / traditional markets.  Given the current dire situation, it is safe to assume that, if bilateral negotiations between the European Commission and Latin American countries were to lead to a reduction in tariffs below the current 75€/t for third countries, the market will continue to be destabilized and European productions would inevitably be jeopardized.   The Stabilisation Mechanism for Bananas allows the European Commission, in the event of a third country exceeding its preferential tariff ceiling, to restore MFN tariffs (114€/t since 2017), on exports from such countries for a period not exceeding three months.    The weakness of the sanctions available in case of a lowering of prices in green on the market does not allow for a quick recovery of the EU market, even if the mechanism was to be automatically and immediately implemented.   But that is also not the case, as the Commission may decide upon review not to trigger the mechanism.    Not a single threshold overrun observed to this day has led to trigger the mechanism, as the Commission has continuously determined that they do not have a significant impact on prices. However, if such an impact was to be determined, the mechanism would not in any case reverse the situation.    It follows that in the event of a drop in the green price, this mechanism will not prevent the eviction of European banana producers from their own market.  Conclusions: For all these reasons, GESBA recommends: - To “ring-fence” custom duties to the current 75€/t; - To replace the existing nonfunctional stabilisation mechanism by a market-regulation mechanism for bananas, to allow for continued access to this market for ACP countries and Outermost regions’ operators. - To reinforce food safety standards by requiring the same phytosanitary conditions for all banana imports in the EU.  APEB’s full position is attached Feedback from: GESBA/APEB (671.8 KB - PDF - 23 pages) Download
Initiative: EU-Colombia/Ecuador/Peru Trade Agreement - evaluation

feedback_msg_text: As an African association of fruit exporters, we welcome the intention of the European Commission (“EC”) to evaluate the Trade Agreement between Colombia/Ecuador/Peru and the EU.  We believe that in order to assess its economic impact, one must consider the entire EU trade policy, including interrelation between trade agreements concluded with Latin American (“LA”) countries and EPA with ACP countries.  We observe that the implementation of this Agreement has significantly eroded the benefits of EPA whose key objectives are to contribute, through trade and investment, to sustainable development and poverty reduction. Preferential treatment provided to EPA signatories could be further deteriorated by dwindling customs tariffs applied to LA producers in the coming years. In this regard, the EU banana market is indicative of the negative impact of this agreement.  Market condition  Bananas play a crucial role in the development of ACP States and are instrumental to job creation, providing 30 000 direct jobs and 50 000 more indirect ones in Africa alone. And while the EU is the only market outlet for ACP countries LA bananas are also exported to the USA and Asia.  In 2016, Europe imported 69.6% of its bananas from LA, the remainder coming from European outermost regions (“EOR”) [11.3%] and ACP countries [19.1%]. As of end of 2018, LA bananas market share in Europe had risen to 75.7% while ACP States dropped from to 16% and EOR to 8.3%, a massive  change given maturity of this market. This oversupply has had a direct impact on volumes exported: African ACP countries experienced a 7.2% a year-on-year decline (from 600 to 557 kt) while LA countries saw an increase of 4.5% (from 4 366 to 4 563 kt) of their already overwhelming share.  This surge has in turn significantly depressed wholesale prices (15 to 20% once corrected for inflation). This drop is feeding an oversupply crisis and penalizing ACP operators whose margins are particularly sensitive to price variations and effectively prohibiting any return on investments made to compete internationally.  Tariff cuts  A rethink of the tariff regime is therefore essential to enable ACP and EOR producers to maintain critical size allowing economies of scale and close the competitiveness gap with LA producers. It is however estimated that LA producers have enjoyed total savings of 1.9 bn € on custom duties (a figure tenfold that of the accompanying measures). The trade agreement is therefore disproportionately favorable to LA producers, who have captured all the growth and value of the EU market and might very soon drive EOR and ACP producers out of their domestic / traditional markets. Given the situation, it is safe to assume that further reduction in tariffs will accentuate imbalances and inevitably jeopardize EOR and ACP producers  Stabilisation Mechanism for Bananas  A stabilisation mechanism for bananas (Reg EU 19/2013) was introduced as a counterpart to this trade agreement and set to expire by end of 2019 allowing the temporary suspension of LA preferential customs duties in order to prevent oversupply and practices reminiscent of dumping,.  This dissuasive mechanism has unsurprisingly not met its objectives, since it has never been activated despite numerous and repeated overruns. The EC: 1-considers thresholds globally and not country by country 2-monitors only the evolution of mean prices although small quantities of low price imports can have a damaging effect without affecting overall price levels 3-does not take into consideration market shares of producers Should the stabilisation mechanism be triggered, its effect will not be enough to deter other countries. For instance, Peru has continuously overrun its thresholds from 2013 to 2017.  Recommendation - Ring-fence the 75€/t custom duties - Replace the existing mechanism with a regulation of the EU market for bananas, allowing the continued access of ACP and EOR operators to the EU market.

feedback_msg_text: Oxera is pleased to provide feedback on the Commission’s initiative for an Ex Ante regulatory framework for online platforms. In the interests of transparency, we would like to state that we are currently advising several technology firms and an industry body on issues around the Digital Services Act. The feedback and opinions provided here are entirely our own.  Our feedback focuses on two questions raised by the NCT and ex ante regulation initiatives: (a) whether there is there an enforcement gap and, if so, what is the appropriate threshold for intervention?; and (b) as regards the relationship and possible tension between the goals of competition (economic efficiency) and fairness, what are the implications for the analysis and design of both initiatives?  It is clear that whichever options contained in these consultations are implemented, there will be a major step-up in enforcement action, both ex ante and ex post, in the digital sector.  We have two main observations on how this enhanced enforcement action can be given the best possible chance of delivering proportionate and effective policies that may lead to better consumer outcomes.  First, the principles and evidentiary standards of competition law should remain at the heart of any ex ante or ex post framework. In practice, this would mean rejecting regulatory options involving per se prohibitions (e.g. blacklisting certain practices) absent unambiguous evidence that a practice is proven to be harmful, as well as favouring a case-by-case analysis of platform business models, their incentives and, ultimately, the effects on consumers. This would also mean seeking to align the rationale for intervention (both in the NCT and ex ante regulation) with well-understood concepts such as dominance and robust evidence of actual or likely effects on competition and consumers.  Second, to the extent that fairness goals are pursued through one or more of these tools, the primary focus should be on fairness of process (as in the existing P2B Regulation) as opposed to fairness of outcomes. If fairness of outcomes is pursued, this must also take account of the efficiencies and the value created by platforms’ business models and practices, for consumers and other platform users.  The attached article elaborates further on these issues (also available here: https://bit.ly/3eNXp7A)  Furthermore, specifically in relation to the proposals for an Ex Ante regulatory framework for large online platforms, we would also note the following:  In relation to Option 3, given the potentially highly intrusive nature of the remedies that could follow being designated as a ‘gatekeeper’ platform, including per se prohibitions on practices (blacklisting), it is important for the Commission to clarify how the definition of a gatekeeper will be aligned with well-understood concepts from competition law such as dominance and significant market power (SMP). This is particularly important as the Commission has indicated that it may take inspiration from the telecoms regulatory framework in the design of remedies, but remedies in the telecoms sector can only be imposed following a market review process and a finding of SMP.  In addition, the SMP telecoms framework contains ‘checks and balances’ (the three-criteria test) that ensure any interventions are targeted only at enduring economic bottlenecks, when competition law has proven to be ineffective at dealing with the identified concerns, as well as allowing national authorities to take account of differences in market conditions during their market reviews. It is therefore crucial that any ex ante framework for digital also contains similar, if not stronger, ‘checks and balances’ given the fast-moving nature of competition in digital markets and the need to continue to study and understand the effects of different online platforms’ business models and practices. feedback_msg_text: Polish Business Society appreciates the Commission's efforts to address regulatory issues which appeared in recent years on the digital market and to contribute to this important debate. This initiative offers as very important and needed to solve the market distortions.  Digital market is characterized by significant dynamics. It has often been observed that digital economy is being dominated by very big players, acting on many national and product markets and having resources to expand into other markets. This situation brings a number of challenges for other market participants. Extensive geographic and products scope of operations of such entities cause challenges to   effective regulatory oversight and enforcement. Therefore, the European Union must establish and enforce common rules on the European market. Ex-ante regulatory instrument is an adequate tool for large global online platforms. The regulatory option which consists of revision the horizontal framework set in the Platform-to-Business Regulation (EU) 2019/1150 would not be envisageable. First of all, it would lead to the imposition of additional  obligations on all players (about 10,000 European platforms). It shall be underlined that such businesses have recently incurred costs related to the implementation to the Platform-to-Business Regulation will apply as of July 2020. Imposing additional obligations would result in unproportionate cost. Moreover, effects of measures introduced therein cannot yet be assessed. Secondly, given the characteristics of entities having global reach, a big number of users and resources (systemic platforms) and challenges they pose, a targeted and very well balanced solution is necessary.  In this context, option 3 which aims at the  of a new flexible ex ante regulatory framework for large global online platforms acting as gatekeepers seems to be the most appropriate. According to the Inception impact assessment this option would apply to large global platforms that benefit from significant network effects and act as gatekeepers. It is crucial in this discussion to distinguish smaller European platforms (active in only in one or few member states) from large global online platforms. The scope of the regulation ought to focus only on large global platforms acting as gatekeepers on the international level.  This measure includes (p. 3a) a set of unfair trading practices. Practice that the Commission should take into account is self-preferencing. This practice becomes an issue if the platform is a real competitor for its sellers and uses its position to their detriment. Large global platforms, especially those not having registered offices in the European Union ought to be obliged to establish authorized representative responsible for consumer, tax and product safety issues. This measure may help national authorities and the European Commission to enforce regulation ensuring level playing field. Currently, many legal obligations imposed on the European entrepreneurs are not respected by their non-EU competitors.   It should be emphasized that regulatory obligations imposed by the European regulator should also apply to platforms outside the EU. In the event of non-compliance, such a platform should not be available to consumers in Europe. This is allowed by the Regulation on market surveillance and compliance of products and Regulation on cooperation between national authorities responsible for the enforcement of consumer protection laws (…). Above mentioned regulations allow the authorities to remove content or to restrict access to an online interface or to order the explicit display of a warning to consumers when they access an online interface or to order a hosting service provider to remove, disable or restrict access to an online interface. If compliance with the EU regulation cannot be otherwise ensured, it seems to be an appropriate tool to enforce the European law. feedback_msg_text: We acknowledge the recognition that the Platform-to-Business Regulation (Regulation) is the first step to regulate the platform economy. We appreciate its focus on influencing the contractual terms and bargaining position between the platforms and the business users it hosts. However, transparency and measures of redress are not enough to deal with extraordinary platform power. For the ways in which a platform exercises power and emerges as a key market player, please see the Platform Planet Report (https://itforchange.net/sites/default/files/add/Report-Platform%20Planet_Development_in_the_intelligence_economy.pdf). Successful platform regulation would also involve regulations like (1) mandating non-discrimination, (2) data sharing, and (3) structural separations along key functional layers of digital value chains. In this regard, see enclosed paper on ‘Breaking Up Big Tech: Separation of Data, Cloud and Intelligence Layers’ (http://datagovernance.org/files/research/Regulating_data__cloud_and_intelligence_-_Paper_9-22.pdf). The paper discusses why current approaches to regulating platform power are failing, and how these can be corrected.  We endorse Option 3 as the most holistic option to regulate big platforms and curb the practices which allow a platform to assume anti-competitive size, proportion and power. The regulatory goal must also be clarified by the Commission, whether it seeks to avoid concentration of a market or seeks to regulate conduct of market entities in such concentrated markets. The suggestions are as follows: Platform conduct must be monitored to understand the ecosystem created by such platforms. In this regard, the multi-directional integration of such platforms must be assessed. For example, Uber plans to control the entire transportation sector and not just the cab business, through its expansion into food delivery, logistics and freight segment. Uber’s new financial services for drivers, based on their data, could also trap them in never-ending loan cycles, thus enslaving them forever. Platform entry into horizontal, complementary or independent businesses must be assessed and bars and caps should be instituted. Similarly, a platform’s vertical conduct should be monitored. There should be no discrimination or preferential treatment for such vertical players. Platform neutrality must be viewed as a regulatory goal to achieve through policy instruments, including structural separation of various kinds. The dominance of platforms must be measured not just through its financial capitalisation but also with regard to its data power. If a platform is able to monopolise data accumulation and data domination for further expansion then such dataset must be shared with the regulator which may be shared, sold or opened for use to other players to ensure a level playing field for all potential market entrants. Such datasets must be shared on non-discriminatory grounds.  The policy options being considered by the Commission must be based on a rights based framework such that market players, business users, unions, consumer groups have a right to seek redressal from the regulator, file potential complaints and receive access to information, consultation and assessment carried out by the regulator. This is without prejudice to the ability of the regulator to act on its own. The infrastructural setup of the platform should be divided into its structural layers and assessed. In cases deemed fit, the ownership and control rights over such layers must also be divided to ensure equity and fairness to all market players. The acquisition strategies of platforms to seek enrolment of sellers on its platforms must also be assessed, from the point of view of a layer based analysis along with a review of contractual terms. Since big platforms function as gatekeepers, the rule making power and all rules framed must be accessed by the regulator and appropriate interventions must be framed with a multi-stakeholder consultation. Initiative: Digital Services Act package – ex ante regulatory instrument of very large online platforms acting as gatekeepers

feedback_msg_text: FSB welcomes the opportunity to provide a response to the Commission’s call for evidence on the Digital Services Act package.   The Federation of Small Businesses (FSB) is the UK’s leading business organisation. Established over 45 years ago to help our members succeed in business, we are a non-profit making and non-party political organisation that is led by our members, for our members. Our mission is to help smaller businesses achieve their ambitions. FSB is also the UK’s leading business campaigner, focused on delivering change which supports smaller businesses to grow and succeed.   FSB has reviewed the European Commission’s plan to establish a fair and transparent business environment around online platforms through an ex ante regulatory instrument. We support the aim of ensuring a fair trading environment and increasing the innovation potential and capacity across online platform ecosystems, as this will support the growth and capacity of small businesses.   FSB supports the revision of the horizontal framework set in the Platform-to-Business Regulation. We would welcome the Commission to take the opportunity to: (i) provide greater clarity on what constitutes ‘clear’ and ‘unambiguous’ language; (ii) extend the modification notice period for terms and conditions from 15 to 30 days; (iii) strengthening Articles 9-12 on dispute resolution, possibly via language similar to that used in Articles 4-6 of the EU Directive on Unfair Trading Practices in B2B relationships in the Food Supply Chain, as small businesses are generally reluctant to launch a complaint against their provider of online intermediary services from fear of retaliatory measures; and (iv) review the codes of conduct, ensuring they are effective and concretely contribute to a fairer and predictable framework for small businesses trading on online platforms.   FSB supports the adoption of a horizontal framework that allows regulators to collect information from large online platforms acting as gatekeepers. FSB would welcome further transparency from large online platforms, and would hope that the data provided will allow to greater insight into the interplay between online platforms, their customers, and their business users. FSB would additionally hope that the focus on data gathering may contribute towards data being more open, portable, or interoperable between different platforms, as this could help enable more effective competition in digital markets.   FSB in theory supports the adoption of a new and flexible ex ante regulatory framework for large online platforms acting as gatekeepers through the prohibition or restriction of certain unfair trading practices by large online platforms acting as gatekeepers or adoption of tailor-made remedies addressed to large online platforms acting as gatekeepers on a case-by-case basis where necessary and justified. However, FSB would stress that the success of such measures would depend on the careful definition of the trading practices to be prohibited or remedied via regulation and thorough analysis as to the potential spill-over effects on platform business users from regulatory action. Overall, we would welcome a new framework that complements the horizontally applicable provisions of the Platform-to Business Regulation.   Throughout the process, we would like to stress the Commission’s commitment to its ‘think small first' principle.
Initiative: Digital Services Act package – ex ante regulatory instrument of very large online platforms acting as gatekeepers

feedback_msg_text: Vimeo, Inc. hereby provides the following feedback in response to the request for consultation for the Digital Services Act. Vimeo operates the Vimeo video-sharing service, which allows customers throughout the EU, including individuals, businesses, and organizations to upload, share, and view videos. We note that Vimeo provides a platform for users and is itself a user of platforms, including the Apple App Store and the Google Play Store. First of all, we believe it is important that the Commission considers the significant differences that exist between the many types of online platforms available. These differences include their size and reach; how their business models are structured; their pricing structures; what, how and how much data they collect and use; the extent to which they make use of automation/algorithmic systems for content moderation; and the existence of competitive alternatives.  Any legislative efforts and measures considered by the Commission should take these differences into account. Moreover, the Commission should ensure that regulations adopted to curb the largest, most powerful platforms do not end up entrenching those incumbents by imposing undue burdens on smaller platforms. One way to do so is to set thresholds (in terms of users or revenue) for various aspects of the law. Secondly, we agree with the Commission that it is essential to have harmonised rules and obligations across the EU. We share its concern that some EU countries may pass laws with notable differences in the obligations imposed on online platforms, and with a variety of different enforcement mechanisms. Websites are complicated enterprises, and it is difficult for companies, especially smaller ones, to comply with a multitude of regimes. This is particularly true with “notice-and-takedown” systems, which can benefit from features like structured forms and a degree of automation. We believe that EU-wide regulation, such as the GDPR, should be the model in the case of content removal obligations.  We recognize the challenges that policymakers face in trying to protect citizens from harm online. It is undeniable that some bad actors will seek to distribute illegal and harmful content. However, we must not forget that platforms host much more content that is lawful, inspiring, constructive, and value-creating. The Commission should apply a light-touch when it comes to content as highly prescriptive measures could result in less content of the good variety. In addition, if the Commission decides to create notice-and-takedown systems for certain categories of content, it should provide users who believe their content wrongfully removed with means of redress.  In line with the above, we urge the Commission to maintain key elements of the e-Commerce Directive, in particular: the limited liability provisions and the prohibition on imposing a general monitoring obligation on internet society services. These elements are essential to encouraging the development of platforms that allow citizens to express themselves creatively, engage in political discussion, access information, make a living, and purchase goods and services.  While maintaining these principles, the Commission should explore incentives and safe harbors for platforms to take a more proactive approach to content on a voluntary basis. Lastly, we would also welcome the introduction of mechanisms to strengthen collaboration between stakeholders and facilitate cooperation with relevant  authorities and ‘trusted flaggers’.  Respectfully submitted,  Michael Chea, General Counsel, and Erika Barros, Director of Policy
Initiative: Digital Services Act package – ex ante regulatory instrument of very large online platforms acting as gatekeepers

feedback_msg_text: The Danish Government welcomes the Commission’s decision to launch an impact assessment and a thorough public hearing. Since these are complicated topics, it is important to understand, in as much detail as pos-sible, the problems that the proposed instruments aim to address.   In general, the Danish Government supports the Commission’s focus on avoiding regulatory fragmentation and agree that there is a need for action to safeguard an effectively functioning digital single market where com-panies can compete and flourish. It is important to avoid a situation with multiple national initiatives aiming to address the powers of the same large platforms. The Danish Government believes that a European ap-proach will be the most efficient way to ensure legal certainty and pre-dictability for companies across Europe and will create the greatest bene-fits for European companies and consumers.   Overall, the Danish Government supports the consideration of both a re-vised horizontal framework and the consideration of addressing the spe-cific issues related to the extremely large digital platforms. It is important to ensure that the large number of smaller platforms are not regulated (excessively) since this may hinder their ability to compete.   However, the Danish Government highlights the need to prevent overlaps between traditional competition enforcement, any ex ante regulatory framework and the New Competition Tool. This seems especially im-portant if the ex ante regulatory framework is set to include a possibility to adopt tailor-made remedies on a case-by-case basis (option 3b). If not, there is a risk that some companies will face multiple regulatory regimes that has the same aim of securing a well-functioning internal market. This may limit the incentives to invest and innovate.   Therefore, the Commission should make it clear in the impact assessment if there are overlaps and where these overlaps exist. The Commission should also put forward suggestions on how to solve those overlaps and be willing to abandon one or more of the initiatives. In this regard, the Danish Government highlights the need for careful coordination between the impact assessments led by DG GROW, DG CNECT and DG COMP. feedback_msg_text: A small number of very large online platforms operated by US Internet companies have a significant impact on the European economy.  The time when data protection and privacy were the only problems of such platforms is long gone. Today it's about a lot more, it's about EU jobs and dependencies.   NUMBERS:  - In 2018, every person (from 0 years) generated an average revenue of around USD 25 on Facebook & the Google parent company Alphabet. - Alphabet is the richest company in 2019 with $ 117 billion in cash reserves. - Alphabet: Revenue rose 18% in 2019 to $ 161.9 billion, up from $ 136.82 billion in 2018. Profit of $ 34.3 billion in 2019. - Facebook: Revenue increased 26.62% to $ 70,697.00 million in 2019, compared to $ 55,838.00 million in 2018 - A study for 2018 recorded 100,000 teenagers addicted to social media in Germany alone. - An investigation of 100 German companies has shown that they use the Google advertising program, although there is already a free search entry for the desired search term. Annual costs for these measures are around EUR 45 million a year.   FACTS:  - Search results are influenced by platforms. - Social media can be addictive. - More than 90% of all search queries are made via Google. - More than 50% of all search queries are answered on Google. - Former Google & Facebook employees warn of addiction factors. - It has long been speculated which bankruptcies in recent years could be the responsibility of Google. - For large brands, Facebook's organic (natural) reach should be zero. This means that if you want to reach your own fans, you have to pay for it. - Election manipulation via social networks cannot be excluded. - Algorithms are not understandable. - People work for companies for a few cents a day through micro work.   TARGET:  It should not be the EU's goal to pursue a profit taxation of internet companies. Social media and advertisements in search engines cost companies in the EU several billion euros each year. These costs are passed on to EU citizens via product prices. Another tax would also be passed on to the consumer. The position of power remains unchanged.  Rather, the goal should be to relieve companies and thus consumers in these areas. This could save hundreds of billions of euros annually that are currently flowing into the United States. For this we need clear rules / laws and more fair competition.   SOLUTIONS:  - Funding for alternative internet platforms, 100% if they are democratic and non-profit. Funding up to EUR 20 million per project. - Immediate introduction of information obligations on platforms on addiction factors, especially in the relevant functions. - Legal ban on the use of addictive factors in online platforms, search engines and apps that use the Internet. - Law on reach in online platforms. The reach to followers must not be restricted or manipulated by online platforms. - Due to the social importance of search engines: Creation of a legal basis that the first five search results must not be advertisements, other products or paid search results, that is, these results are of organic (natural) origin. - Legally prohibited from showing ads if an organic search entry has already been delivered for the keyword. - Increase of VAT, in each case 20% above the VAT applicable in the country, for online trading and advertising on the Internet. - Information law: Online platforms have to provide users with understandable information about their business model (type of financing) and how their algorithms work. - Online platforms and search engines only get access to the EU if your employees and the employees of subcontractors comply with the minimum wage requirements of the respective countries. - Law: Organic search results may not be discriminated against for own products. - In case of violation of the aforementioned laws, a 5% penalty will be imposed. In relation to the respective annual turnover of the online platform in question.
