feedback_msg_text: Niepokoi nas, iż Komisja nie zamierza dokonać przeglądu rozporządzenia 2286/2016, a chce pozostawić zasadę RLAH także po 2022 r. Same mechanizmy w nim zawarte wymagają poprawy - nie adresują problemów wynikających ze stosowania RLAH do tanich pakietów typu „no limit” -standardowych w Polsce.  Mechanizm obserwacyjny (art.4.4)-wskaźnik przeważającego korzystania nie ma charakteru obiektywnego. Następuje nieuprawnione faworyzowanie tzw. heavy userów kosztem użytkowników o niskiej konsumpcji (krajowej i roamingowej). Np. 2 klientów z takim samym planem taryfowym i wzorcem korzystania i pobytu w roamingu, może być odmiennie naliczanych w roamingu. Stosowanie dopłaty może być tylko zależne od ilości zużytych jednostek w kraju-klient generujący wyższe koszty będzie traktowany lepiej niż ten generujący niższe.  Wskaźnik korzystania może być łatwo zmieniony przez abonenta nie tylko przez ograniczenie zużycia roamingowego, ale przez zwiększenie krajowego (dla no limit nie ma on dodatkowych kosztów). Okno obserwacji jest zbyt długie względem średnich wskaźników pobytu Polaków w UE. Należy skrócić okno obserwacyjne z 4 mies. do 1, wprowadzenie możliwości rozłącznego stosowania wskaźników pobytu i korzystania, traktowanie pobytu w kraju i w roamingu jako pobyt w roamingu lub wyłączenie z obu kategorii.  Limit danych dla OPD (art. 4.2) w nielimitowanych pakietach powinien zostać rozszerzony na inne usługi (voice, SMS, MMS). Jeden mechanizm powinien być stosowany dla wszystkich usług. Abonament, który najczęściej obejmuje wszystkie usługi, powinien być dzielony na nie proporcjonalnie według ustalonego przez dostawcę schematu. Mnożnik „2” powinien wynosić co najwyżej 1.  Kryterium formalne nie stanowi odpowiedniej ochrony-nawet gdy abonent przy podpisywaniu umowy je spełnia, to kilka dni później niekoniecznie.  M2M–obecne zasady RLAH miały mieć zastosowanie dla okresowych podróży, nie powinny mieć więc zastosowania dla usług typu M2M/IoT, które często wiążą się z permanentnym roamingiem. Należy wprowadzić możliwość opłat ryczałtowych za obsługę kart M2M w roamingu w oparciu o opłaty za M2M na rynkach lokalnych. Kursy walutowe-podwyżka cen w PLN na skutek zmiany kursu nie może umożliwiać abonentowi rezygnacji z umowy zawartej na czas określony. Należy to określić w rozporządzeniu. W Polsce nie aktualizowano cen usług w takiej sytuacji na skutek przyjętej w Polsce interpretacji prawa. Ilość zmian w zakresie cen roam. i MN powinna zostać ograniczona do 1 razu w roku-zmniejszy to obciążenia dla operatorów oraz ilości zmian dla klientów. Obecnie musimy to robić nawet 4 razy w roku. Koszty SMS/MMS MN–należy umożliwić operatorom odzyskiwanie kosztów SMS/MMS wysłanych w roamingu do krajów innych niż macierzysty. W roamingu operatorzy nie mogą obecnie odzyskać kosztu zakończenia takiego SMS = 6 cE/SMS. Ruch taki nie jest symetryczny i ma charakter arbitrażu kosztowego. Rejestr PR-Należy stworzyć Unijny rejestr numerów PremiumRate – numerów, nie podlegających maksymalnym stawkom MTR/FTR. Ruch na numery spoza takiego rejestru powinien podlegać pułapom cenowym MTR/FTR. Decyzje derogacyjne-należy usunąć warunek konieczny dla zgody na dopłaty, iż strata na roamingu> 3% marża EBIDTA. Operatorzy powinni mieć prawo odzyskania wszelkich strat związanych z RLAH. Wprowadzenie dopłat – wynikają one z Rozporządzenia - ich dodanie do cennika nie powinno uprawniać abonenta do rozwiązania umowy.  Wyjście kraju z UE–należy określić, iż w sytuacji wyjścia kraju z UE, zmiana cennika roamingowego z tym związana nie daje prawa do rozwiązania umowy przez abonenta.  Dostęp do służb ratunkowych–brak uzasadnienia dla interwencji. Brak problemów z realizacją usług 112 w roamingu. Wdrażanie innych niż połączenia 112 usług dostępu do służb ratunkowych jest różne w krajach UE. Nieuzasadnionym i przedwczesnym jest wprowadzanie zunifikowanych reguł.  QoS-Brak uzasadnienia dla interwencji w tym zakresie. Już obecne regulacje dla operatorów w Polsce wiążą się z dużym obciążeniem.

feedback_msg_text: In presenza di pendici particolarmente acclivi la conservazione del suolo agrario dipende dalle sistemazioni idraulico-agrarie tradizionali dei muretti a secco e ciglioni con associato un sistema di canalizzazione delle acque superficiali. Esse costituiscono, infatti, un fattore di riduzione dei tempi di corrivazione delle acque superficiali, favorendo un’infiltrazione adeguata a soddisfare i bisogni delle colture, oltre che costituire un rilevante elemento di contenimento sia dell’erosione della parte fertile del suolo, sia dei conseguenti rischi di alluvioni, frane o altro, particolarmente nelle sottostanti aree di pedecollina e di piano. A supporto di tutto questo inviamo "LA GESTIONE DELLE SISTEMAZIONI IDRAULICO-AGRARIE NEL MONTE PISANO" di Rizzo, Casella, Galli e Bonari a cui hanno collaborato vari enti pubblici e privati. Questa pubblicazione costituisce il manuale di gestione dei sistemi di terrazzamento del territorio dei Monte Pisano. Questo territorio, come altri con caratteristiche analoghe, non deve essere sottovalutato poiché è a forte rischio di abbandono e dalla sua manutenzione dipende anche la stabilità del territorio a valle. La conservazione del suolo deve dunque partire da qui, non solo idealmente, per estendersi nei territori meno acclivi di fondovalle e delle pianure sottostanti. Feedback from: SPORTELLO DI AGROECOLOGIA DI CALCI (4.3 MB - PDF - 30 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: La Asociación Española Agricultura de Conservación Suelos Vivos es una asociación sin ánimo de lucro e independiente, fundada en 1995, que tiene entre sus fines promover la información a agricultores, técnicos agrarios y la sociedad en general de la Agricultura de Conservación (AC) y fomentar su desarrollo, docencia e investigación. Desde esta entidad queremos contribuir a una exitosa puesta en marcha de la estrategia, aportando nuestro conocimiento y experiencia acumulada durante más de 25 años en el fomento y estudio de prácticas agracia sostenibles, fundamentales para la consecución de los objetivos que aquí se persiguen. En tal sentido, queremos compartir los siguientes comentarios:  Más del 80 % los suelos de la UE-27 afectados por tasas de erosión consideradas de moderadas a graves, se ubican en zonas agrícolas y pastizales naturales. La intensificación de la agricultura basada en el laboreo ha contribuido en los últimos 50 años a agravar los procesos erosivos y a aumentar el riesgo de desertificación de los suelos agrarios. Según la Agencia Europea de Medioambiente, las labores excesivas, así como el laboreo en condiciones de bajo contenido de humedad pueden conducir al deterioro de la estructura edáfica y a una mayor susceptibilidad a la erosión.  La AC, basada en tres principios como la supresión del laboreo, el mantenimiento del suelo cubierto por restos o cubiertas vegetales y la rotación de cultivos, constituye una de las herramientas más eficaces para hacer frente a las amenazas identificadas en la Estrategia y una alternativa viable a los sistemas de producción basados en el alboreo. Así, existen evidencias científicas que gracias a la AC se reduce la erosión en un 90% y la escorrentía en un 60%, se incrementa el contenido de la materia orgánica en el suelo, se mejora la estructura y se incrementa la tasa de infiltración de agua y, con ello, la disponibilidad de agua para el cultivo.  Por otro lado, los beneficios medioambientales de este tipo de prácticas se extienden más allá del ámbito del suelo, mitigando el cambio climático a través del secuestro del carbono y reduciendo las emisiones de Gases de Efecto Invernadero, mejorando la calidad de las aguas, reduciendo la contaminación, y mejorando la biodiversidad edáfica. Por todo ello, el fomento de este tipo de prácticas en el marco de la estrategia puede constituir una de sus líneas de actuación, para la consecución de los objetivos perseguidos.  Existen evidencias científicas de que la adopción de la AC optimiza el uso de herbicidas respecto a los sistemas de manejo basados en el laboreo; es más, según algunos de los estudios existentes en la literatura científica, con el paso de los años, es posible reducir las dosis y el número de aplicaciones realizadas en el cultivo, lo que repercute de manera positiva en la reducción de la contaminación. Para ello, los tres principios en lo que se basa la AC anteriormente mencionados son de importancia capital, particularmente la rotación de cultivos y la cubierta vegetal.  En este contexto, la adopción de AC, con todos los beneficios que ello conlleva, constituye, a través de sus tres principios, una estrategia adecuada para hacer frente a las amenazas identificadas en la Estrategia. En este sentido, los resultados positivos que puedan darse gracias a la ampliación de la AC, pueden demostrar a la sociedad en general, a los legisladores y a los reguladores la capacidad de la agricultura para responder a las preocupaciones ambientales referida al suelo en particular y a los otros recursos naturales en general, dotando a los agricultores de herramientas viables desde el punto de vista medioambiental, económico y social. feedback_msg_text: The ELO welcomes any movement towards closing this gap with information exchange, integration, and dissemination of knowledge of best practice for soil ecosystem restoration and maintenance and tools to support land managers in improving soil quality.  The ELO welcomes the commitment to “increase soil organic matter and restore carbon-rich ecosystems”. The development of “carbon farming”, as a type of certification of carbon removals, could be the most effective way of improving soil organic matter, while contributing to climate mitigation through increasing carbon sequestration in soils.    The EU should focus on these types of incentives instead of pushing for regulation previously rejected by Member States. The ELO calls on the European Commission to respect the subsidiarity of the Member States in this regard, as the environmental medium of soil has no cross-border effect, and as laws protecting soil protection are enshrined in a large number of European states, which should be sufficient for regulated soil protection. European Member States are best suited to conceptualise dedicated measures, tools, and procedures to ensure the correct management, protection, and rejuvenation of agricultural soils; especially those which are deployed within their own border, and this must be respected.  The ELO notes that is important that the goals in the roadmap be fulfilled with the full appreciation of the role that stakeholders in land management, local communities, and society as a whole provide. The land managers have been protecting and conserving their local landscape, including their own soil and river beds for centuries in the best way that knowledge and years of experience provides them. If there are mistakes made in the past then it is important that these are learnt from, but land managers must be acknowledged as the first responders and alma maters of European soils; and consulted on the future of their land, livelihoods, and lives.  Climate change has a major impact on soils, and will continue to do so unless action is taken. Since the 1950s soil moisture has significantly decreased in the Mediterranean region, while year on year it dramatically increases in northern European states. With projections showing ever increasing average temperatures and rainfall patterns becoming ever more erratic, singular issues such as soil moisture can increase the need for smaller yields, desertification, droughts, flooding, and the eventual loss of farm and forestry suitable land. As stated above, there is no consistent picture of the challenges that soils face nor the measures that are and should be taken to protect our soil health going forward. The Common Agricultural Policy has placed some emphasis on soil protection, through conditionality and Pillar II programmes, which have shown a marked improvement in soil quality and health.  The ELO welcomes the continuation of such schemes and the support of tools such as the eco-schemes under the CAP, which could encourage farmers to do more for improve soils. Climate change prevention policies often have no specific requirement to remediate or protect soils, even though the protection and restoration of strong stable soil beds are imperative to carbon sequestration practice. The Actions such as the construction of soil protection measures such as agroforestry, hedgerows, permanent grass strips in arable fields and along riverbanks have all been proven to prevent erosion, increase organic matter, and strengthen soil structure. Likewise, no tillage and precision farming must also be considered. It is important to rely on research and innovation to better manage our natural resources, as be able to use and improve our soils.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: There is substantial scientific and practical evidence to show that biochar can play a key role in helping promote healthy soils in the EU.   Biochar is characterised by its highly porous structure with micro-, meso- and macropores. The resulting high surface area and extraordinary water and nutrient absorption capacity (5 times its own weight), its high pH and pH stabilizing properties as well as its high cation exchange capacity (CAC), make it advantageous for agricultural applications. Its high sorption capacity leads to reduced nitrogen losses and increases the availability of nutrients in the soil. The low biodegradability of biochar ensures that it remains effective in the long term and acts as a permanent carbon sink, leading to a positive and measurable impact on the climate. In combination with the negative priming effect of biochar, the built-up of additional carbon in the soils, its application can turn agriculture from a major greenhouse gas emitter into a significant contributor to the creation of carbon sinks.   http://www.biochar-industry.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/EU-Soil-Fertility-Strategy-Input-V1.0.pdf  http://www.biochar-industry.com  Best regards Feedback from: Circular Carbon / European Biochar Industry Consortium EBI (146.4 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Organisation: Circular Carbon / European Biochar Industry Consortium EBI
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: COMMON FORUM on Contaminated Land in Europe (www.commonforum.eu) is a network of contaminated land policy makers, regulators and technical advisors from Environment Authorities in European Union member states and European Free Trade Association countries. Being a platform for knowledge exchange and discussion on policy and practical concepts for contaminated land management is of crucial importance defined in its mission statement.  As for the Roadmap towards a new EU Soil Strategy and its consultation process COMMON FORUM mandated its Working Group “Soil as a Resource” to review and discuss. The ongoing initiative is welcome. Soil and its natural capacities are of crucial importance as the interface where the planet, people and economic activities get balanced - or in conflict.  The results of a workshop and the entire discussion process confirm the interest of COMMON FORUM to support the Commission and processes necessary to come up with an enabling new policy framing. Hence, it also needs to admitted, that network members feel unclear about the upcoming course of actions. Furthermore considering the complexity of soils and its ecosystem services in particular the time frame (approximately ½ year, until June 2021) seems very tight and a likely critical limitation. For detailed comments please see the enclosed document.  Besides that and for discussing strategic issues in general a comparison and benchmarking of existing soil strategies in and outside the European Union might be inspiring and useful.  In this sense COMMON FORUM wants to underpin to joint interest in caring for soil and cooperating for developing our new frame to direct and transform soil policy under the EU Green Deal sustainably until 2030.  Dietmar MÜLLER-GRABHERR (General Secretary to COMMON FORUM on Contaminated Land in Europe)  Co MOLENAAR & Margot DE CLEEN (Chairs Working Group "Soil as a Resource") Feedback from: COMMON FORUM on Contaminated Land in Europe (513.7 KB - PDF - 8 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Roadmap „New Soil Strategy – healthy soils for healthy life“ Stellungnahme der Gesellschaft für konservierende Bodenbearbeitung (GKB) e.V.  Wer sind wir und was machen wir? Die GKB ist eine gemeinnützige Interessenvereinigung von rund 800 Landwirten, Beratern, Wissenschaftlern, Vertretern aus Landwirtschaftsbehörden sowie Firmenvertretern, welche deutschlandweit seit mehr als 20 Jahren zur Mulch- und Direktsaat erfolgreich tätig ist. Mit dem Ziel „Von Landwirten für Landwirte“ steht der praktische Erfahrungsaustausch und die Verbreitung und Anwendung von Boden- und klimaschonenden Anbauverfahren im Vordergrund unserer Netzwerksarbeit. Unsere Arbeit umfasst: • den Erfahrungsaustausch zu Boden- und Klimaschonende Bewirtschaftung, Humusaufbau, zwischen Landwirten, Beratern, Wissenschaftlern und Wirtschaft anzuregen und einen Wissenstransfer von Erkenntnissen und Praxisversuchen in Landwirtschaftlichen Betrieben zu fördern.  • Aufklärung bezüglich der Möglichkeiten der Minderung von Problembereichen (Bodenverdichtung, Wind- und Wassererosion, Humusverlust) in der Landwirtschaft. • Öffentlichkeitsarbeit bei Wirtschaft, Politik und Presse, um die Akzeptanz für bodenschützende und bodenschonende Bearbeitung zu verbessern. • Initiierung von Projekten zur Verbesserung des Bodenschutzes und der Bodenschonung u.a. mit Demonstrationsvorhaben für Landwirte und Berater  Unsere Gedanken zur Bodenstrategie Die klimaangepasste Landbewirtschaftung ist aus unserer Sicht die ureigenste Aufgabe der Landwirtschaft. Vor diesem Hintergrund erscheint uns die Weiterentwicklung von ressourcenschonenden Anbauverfahren, insbesondere die Reduzierung der Eingriffsintensität in das Ökosystem Boden für eine Bodenstrategie als überaus wichtig. Dazu gehört auch die kritische Abwägung, inwieweit der Ersatz von Pflanzenschutzmittel durch intensivere Bodenbearbeitung dem Ökosystem Boden mehr schadet als nützt. Die Degradierung unserer Böden gilt es entschieden einzuschränken, die Bodenfruchtbarkeit zu erhalten und den Boden vor Wind- und Wassererosion zu schützen. Hierzu kann der konservierende Ackerbau einen wesentlichen Beitrag leisten. Eine Bodenstrategie kann aus unserer Sicht nicht ein Maßnahmenpaket sein, das allen Landwirten in der EU gleichermaßen verordnet wird, hierzu sind die natürlichen Voraussetzungen in Europa zu unterschiedlich. Eine Bodenstrategie sollte messbare Ziele definieren und über ein Bonus/Malus System die Innovationskraft in der Landwirtschaft stärken. Um ein solches System erfolgreich etablieren zu können, ist es erforderlich, dass entsprechende Boni sich nicht nur an den Mehraufwendungen der Maßnahmen orientieren, sondern dem Bewirtschafter auch einen monetären Vorteil verschaffen, unabhängig davon, ob der Betrieb nach den Richtlinien des ökologischen Landbaus oder konventionell geführt wird.  Konkrete Bodenschutzmaßnahmen aus unserer Sicht - Regional angepasste Zwischenfruchtmischungen, je artenreicher umso wertvoller für das Bodenleben - Ganzjährig bedeckte Bodenoberfläche: aktiv durch Untersaaten, Begleitsaaten oder nicht eingearbeitete Zwischenfrüchte, passiv durch belassen der Ernterückstände auf der Bodenoberfläche ohne Einarbeitung. - Unterstützung bei der Umstellung auf langjährige Mulchsaat- und Direktsaatsysteme - Einführung und Beibehaltung reduzierter Bodenbearbeitung, je weniger Bodeneingriffe desto wertvoller - Maßnahmen zur gezielten Düngerapplikation durch platzierte Düngerablage (Beispiel Cultan Verfahren, teilschlagspezifische Düngung) - Schutz und Förderung der biologischen Vielfalt des Bodens durch eine fruchtfolgeangepasste Pflanzenschutzstrategie - Beratung im Bereich Boden, die das ganze System mit Fruchtfolge etc. im Blick hat (klassische Ackerbauberatung mit Fokus auf Boden und Diversität) mit langfristiger Perspektive für die Berater und Landwirte und Unterstützung bestehender Plattformen zum Bodenschutz

feedback_msg_text: OP2B Contribution – Roadmap on the New Soil Strategy  One Planet Business for Biodiversity (OP2B) members are committed to helping achieve the objectives set out in the EU Biodiversity strategy to reverse biodiversity loss by 2050. As outlined in the roadmap, “healthy soils are a key enabler to achieve the objectives of the European Green Deal”. The EU needs a comprehensive framework to protect land and soil, which recognises the crucial role that agriculture can play in soil health restoration and provides the tools to guarantee that the transition to regenerative agriculture is achieved in Europe.   Within the past 50 years our global agriculture and food system has brought an abundance of affordable consumption products to large swathes of the population, but at a considerable cost: the food system alone is responsible for around 60% of global biodiversity loss.   Regenerative agriculture is a nature-based solution that aims to transition agriculture from being, globally, a source of environmental degradation, to a primary source of regeneration of modified ecosystems. Putting soil health at the centre of the equation, regenerative agriculture involves transforming agricultural landscapes and practices, to improve the health of agricultural ecosystems and broaden the services they provide to society. It aims to restore soil health and fertility by increasing organic matter in the soil, improving water flows, increasing biodiversity and the agrobiodiversity of landscapes, and enhancing ecosystem services.  Scientific research has repeatedly shown that regenerative agricultural practices, such as cover crops or tillage reduction of perennials, have the biophysical capability to contribute significantly to both soil health and climate change mitigation. Emerging modelling exercises such as Ten Years For Agriculture and exercises based on FABLE modelling have suggested that a shift to such practices, coupled with adoption of healthier diets and end of plant protein imports, could lead to a decrease of agriculture GHG emissions of 15% at global level by 2030, and up to 40% in Europe by 2050.  OP2B members are convinced that a successful transition to regenerative agriculture practices will answer many of the objectives of the new Soil Strategy. However, the transition to these practices requires a fundamental overhaul of our current agricultural model. OP2B members therefore call on the European Commission to ensure that the new Soil Strategy provides effective regulatory solutions to:  • Provide adequate financial support to farmers as they shift to regenerative agriculture practices, and rethink its investment model by valuing the ecosystem services farmers provide through clear carbon accounting and carbon credit systems;  • Incentivise voluntary action through certification schemes that incorporate low carbon agricultural practices and on farm GHG footprinting as part of their standards, as well as other commercial incentives to improve carbon sinks; • Develop a commonly agreed clear methodology and monitoring framework to effectively monitor the impact of nature-based solutions like regenerative agriculture on ecosystems; • Develop the research to support the understanding of the interaction between crops, seeds and varieties to increase the diversity of cultures at scale and optimise crop rotation; • Enhance the resilience of crops while reducing chemical pesticides and excessive and inappropriate nutrient inputs through ambitious reduction targets; • Increase broad societal awareness and understanding of the current state of soils and biodiversity and our collective dependency on natural ecosystems.  OP2B members stand ready to work with all interested stakeholders to create an enabling European environment for the uptake of regenerative agriculture. feedback_msg_text: Soil is one of the key natural resources that sustain life on the earth. The human population burden, together with rapid industrial expansion, has seriously impacted the functioning of the soil resource. In general, soil quality depends on quantity and quality of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM is one of the most important features of soil. With the increasing use of mineral fertilizers, yields have increased by more than 100% thus the quantity of root and harvest residues on the field has increased strongly as a source of organic matter. However, in agricultural practice they are commonly removed from the field after harvest resulting in SOM decrease. In the agro-ecosystems, even the optimal cropping rotation system is not able to fully supply the loss of the organic matters in soil. Every year, the arable soil loses (by mineralization of organic matters and erosion) 2.5–4 t (sometimes 6–10 t) of the soil organic substances per 1 ha of soil. The root and after-harvest residues compensate these losses on average by 2–3 t (50–60%). The remaining 40–50% has to be supplied into soil in the form of the secondary organic fertilizers. During the last years in EU countries, the progressive degradation of SOM is observed.   Thus, this issue was reflected in the EU New Soil Strategy on which the actual reduction of SOM content was listed as one of the most important problems and the associated efforts to increase SOM as well as restore carbon-rich ecosystems. It is possible to find the solution by using other sources of organic matters, e.g. processing of the biodegradable waste from households under the economically favourable conditions. Many scrapyards in cities and villages in the SR have to solve the problem of the accumulated biological waste (grass, foliage, branches) because they do not have the technology for its processing. However, it is not necessary to devise new ways – it is enough to look into the past. The problem could be solved by composting or by processing biomass through carbonization, which considerably lowers the quantity of biological waste. If the emerged by-product is formed by pyrolysis of biological waste and does not contain any dangerous and harmful to health matters, then it can be applied into soil and bring significant benefits what is known from scientific literature.   The results of many studies showed that biochar (a charcoal that is produced by exposing the organic waste matter, such as: wood chips, crop residue or manure, to heat in an oxygen poor environment) incorporated to soil can be an effective tool for improving the soil fertility and sustainable agriculture productivity. From biochar production/application viewpoint in this issue exist a lot of knowledge gaps. For farmers is, however, essential whether the application of biochar improves soil fertility, increases crop yields and brings economic profit. Manufacture of biochar that would improve all soil characteristics and also bring the economic effect and in addition solve the environmental problems with organic wastes is not an easy task. The efficiency of biochar can be improved by its combination with application with other organic fertilizers, composts, NPK fertilizers. For this reason, fertilizer manufacturers are working to create products that combine biochar with other soil fertility enhancers in one suitable for different soil-climatic conditions.   Scientific studies and own research activities of the company Zdroje Zeme a.g. helped to developed soil amendment (biochar substrates) for activation of degraded and intensively used land named Effeco. The biochar substrates Effeco have been tested in laboratory (pot experiment in three different soil types: Luvisol, Chernozem, Regosol) as well as in field experiments (sandy soil: Arenosol, loamy soil: Chernozem) with positive effects on increasing carbon sequestration, improving the chemical and physical properties of the soil and increasing the yield of cultivated crops.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: L’Union nationale des producteurs de granulats (UNPG) salue la mise en œuvre d’une nouvelle stratégie européenne pour les sols. Les sols forment en effet un des éléments fondamentaux du fonctionnement de la vie sur notre planète. Ils sont à la fois un élément constitutif et un support avec un rôle majeur dans les cycles de l’eau, du carbone, de l’azote, pour ne citer que l’essentiel. La préservation des sols, enjeu majeur pour les pays de l’Union Européenne, revêt donc deux aspects qui doivent être considérés en même temps : une gestion surfacique rigoureuse des usages en particulier pour lutter contre l’étalement urbain du fait de la croissance démographique et une gestion qualitative des activités pour supprimer les dégradations continues observées. C’est l’ensemble de ces mesures de lutte contre l’artificialisation des territoires qui pourra assurer la résilience des milieux face aux enjeux climatiques. Une meilleure prise en compte et gestion des sols à l’échelle de l’Union européenne pourrait être menée selon les axes suivants : - Accompagner les États membres dans l’harmonisation de définitions sur l’artificialisation ayant pour effet de transformer des terrains de pleine terre (espaces naturels, jardins et parcs publics de pleine terre, terres agricoles, forêts...) en terrains à construire, en infrastructures (voiries, ouvrages d’art, parkings) ou en espaces artificiels (terrains de sports, chemins et chantiers, espaces verts artificiels). Cela doit permettre de préciser les degrés de naturalité des sols pour s’accorder sur des indicateurs pertinents et robustes. - Inciter les États membres à travailler à la reconquête des friches industrielles et sites pollués. - Développer la recherche et l’innovation sur les techniques de restauration des sols. - Encourager les acteurs économiques (agriculture, sylviculture, activités extractives, aménageurs…) à mettre en œuvre des pratiques de gestion durables des sols pour lutter contre l’érosion, la dispersion des espèces exotiques envahissantes, … - Accompagner les populations des états européens pour des nouveaux modes de vie et de consommation en correspondance avec les objectifs donnés aux acteurs économiques. Pour l’UNPG, il est essentiel de pouvoir définir les caractéristiques de l’état écologique d’un sol de façon à pouvoir qualifier les impacts ou les bénéfices des activités humaines sur la gestion des sols. Ainsi, les changements d’usage des sols ne doivent pas être systématiquement considérés comme artificialisant. Par exemple, à travers leurs réaménagements, les carrières ont la capacité de reconstituer in-situ les habitats impactés mais aussi d’en créer d’autres, souvent plus favorables à la biodiversité que les milieux présents à l’état initial. En convertissant des surfaces de terres généralement à vocation agricole en surfaces naturelles (milieux prairiaux ou boisés, zones humides, retour aux pratiques agricoles …), l’exploitation des carrières oriente positivement et durablement l’usage des sols tant du point de vue de la biodiversité (notamment pour les milieux pionniers et certaines espèces protégées) que de la séquestration de carbone. En lien avec les objectifs de cette nouvelle stratégie pour les sols, l’UNPG s’est d’ores et déjà engagée dans la promotion de pratiques de gestion durable des sols avec la publication de guides et le développement de pratiques économes des matières premières comme le tri et le recyclage des déchets inertes des activités du BTP et de l’industrie. Les réaménagements de carrières répondent à diverses attentes territoriales ou sociales qu’il est important de prendre en compte (zone de loisir, remise en pleine culture agricole…) en intégrant systématiquement les besoins surfaciques de restaurations par le remblayage de terres inertes non recyclables issues des chantiers, les nécessités écologiques de renaturation et les opportunités de séquestration carbone des sols en réponse aux enjeux de la crise climatique. feedback_msg_text: The Italian Composting and Biogas Associacion (CIC) is committed to closing the biological cycle of bio-waste and returning high quality compost to land, in order to improve and preserve the fertility of soils. Unfortunately, we are aware that the ability of soil to deliver ecosystem services - in the term of food production, as a biodiversity pool and as a regulator of gases, water and nutrients - is under severe pressure.  For this reason we strongly support the ongoing roadmap toward a comprehensive soil strategy that can put the basis for an environmentally sustainable management of this precious and limited resource. Adequate instruments, including research, formation and economic incentives, should be provided to make farmers able to shift towards agricultural practices aimed at increasing the quality of soils. Soil organic matter is for sure the keyword of soil fertility and health, that has to be supplied in the form of high quality soil improvers and by means of good agricultural practices. As memebers of the European Compost Network and co-lanchers of the "Save Organics In Soil Initiative" (http://www.saveorganicsinsoil.org) we have produced a common feedback on this roadmap, that we attach hereby. feedback_msg_text: Brussels, 10/12/2020  Euromines response to New Soil Strategy - healthy soil for a healthy life - Ares(2020)6391319:  Euromines acknowledges the main goals and problems that the initiative “New Soil Strategy” wants to tackle, especially to address soil degradation in a comprehensive way.   As already stated in our Biodiversity Strategy position paper we foresee the need that the different policies like the Biodiversity Strategy 2030 and the Zero Pollution Action Plan, but also other related policies like the Industrial Strategy and the list of Critical Raw Materials, are coherent.   The soils in Europe are characterized by a great variety of different soil types in different regions of Europe with differing characteristics such as soil fertility and buffering potential. Also, the pressure on soils is often very different in the Member states. The creation of uniform EU soil standards will be a highly difficult or even an impossible task. Many Member states already developed since the Eighties their specific (risk based) soil legislation. We therefore doubt that common EU soil standards will be the right approach. Against this background, if needed, only non-binding voluntary measures supporting member states might be considered.   With a still growing population and a demand for European raw materials we question if “no net land take” would be the most appropriate target. We think the focus should shift from “no land take” to “sustainable land use”.  Finally, a proactive dialog between our sector and EU decision makers is key to let our sector interact and bring forward best practices on soil conservation and restoration that are applied within our sector.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Rete Emergenza Climatica E Ambientale Emilia-Romagna    È giunto il momento di riconciliarsi con la natura. I cambiamenti climatici, la perdita di biodiversità, l'uso insostenibile delle risorse e la diffusione di pandemie devastanti non lasciano altra scelta.  Il Green Deal europeo può essere una tabella di marcia per rendere sostenibile l'economia dell'UE. Si potrà realizzare  questo obiettivo trasformando le problematiche climatiche e le sfide ambientali in opportunità in tutti i settori e rendendo la transizione equa e inclusiva per tutti.  PROTEGGERE LA FERTILITÀ DEL SUOLO :   si attua con una molteplicità di interventi e di attenzioni, integrate. E' necessario garantire  un grado di umidità che non ecceda i limiti di tolleranza e che non scenda al di sotto di un minimo vitale (anche con cinture di siepi frangivento) e adottare per i suoli agricoli tecniche irrigue sostenibili e scientificamente corrette, colture non intensive e criteri di rotazione.  SUOLO AGRICOLO: la vitalità del suolo è strettamente connessa all’agricoltura. L’agricoltura industriale, con l’utilizzo di fertilizzanti, pesticidi, macchinari meccanici, allevamenti intensivi  è la prima responsabile dell’impoverimento del suolo e della perdita della sua fertilità, contribuendo per oltre il 30% all’emissione di gas climalteranti.  Occorre pertanto: -Apportare modifiche al regime di condizionalità previsto dalla PAC per sospendere l'erogazione di contributi a chi pratica per qualsiasi scopo   l'incenerimento del materiale cellulosico derivante da attività agricola o selvicolturale, e introdurne il divieto; -Imporre una riduzione progressiva dell'utilizzo di prodotti di sintesi per la concimazione e per le difesa delle colture; -Incentivare significativamente la diversificazione del paesaggio agrario con la realizzazione di siepi e filari alberati  favorendo la biodiversità; ecc.( v allegato) Alla perdita di biodiversità del suolo, è legato  il tema della produzione di energia elettrica da biomasse legnose. Benché proposta come energia “green” perché teoricamente rinnovabile, la produzione energetica da biomassa legnosa  è altamente alteramente generando  molteplici danni. In primis  con il taglio e conseguente calo di assorbimento di CO2 e successivamente con la liberazione in atmosfera della CO2 immagazzinata in decenni, se non secoli. Pertanto non ha molto senso considerare la biomassa forestale una fonte di energia "a emissioni zero".  In base al principio “CHI INQUINA, PAGA”, è quindi indispensabile:   eliminare  immediatamente tutti gli incentivi economici alle biomasse solide, così come eliminare tutte le  defiscalizzazioni rispetto a stufe, caminetti, pellets e a tutta la filiera della legna da ardere penalizzare sempre più fortemente tutte le combustioni di biomasse  legnose. Incentivando al massimo le energie rinnovabili NON emissive, quali il solare e suoi  derivati (vento, onde, maree),  proteggere boschi e  foreste e disincentivarne il taglio e la combustione del legno.  RIDURRE L'EROSIONE E L'IMPERMEABILIZZAZIONE :  È indispensabile perseguire l’obiettivo Bilancio Zero per il consumo di suolo, che significa non solo non prevedere il consumo di nuovo suolo a fini urbani e infrastrutturali, ma anche rigenerare, in misura corrispondente, di suoli degradati, le urbanizzazioni dismesse, suoli inquinati o soggetti ad erosione accelerata. In particolare:  - non concedere nuove occupazioni di suolo fino a quando in un territorio ci sono aree già coperte e impermeabilizzate non utilizzate concentrare le risorse sulla demolizione di manufatti dismessi e bonifica delle aree e non costruzioni ex novo, soprattutto nelle zone a rischio. - fare raccolta separata e in purezza di tutti i rifiuti organici della catena alimentare per una loro trasformazione in compost, assicurando al massimo standard qualitativo per non incorrere in fenomeni di progressivo accumulo di sostanze inquinanti dei suoli. ecc. ecc.(v. testo completo in allegato) Feedback from: Rete Emergenza Climatica Ambientale (RECA) Emilia Romagna (147.1 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Organisation: Rete Emergenza Climatica Ambientale (RECA) Emilia Romagna
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: On behalf of the over 40 signatory organisations and persons, WWF Germany would like to draw to your attention the policy paper " The Common Basis for Agriculture and Nature Conservation is the Living Soil.” This group is committed to soil being the basis of all terrestrial biodiversity and human nutrition we are inescapably dependent on. The signees vouch for a picture soil that goes beyond a view of soil as a "raw material" (mere resource) and "service provider" for solely human needs. For the future, we consider it indispensable to understand soil protection in agriculture with the help of practice, research and education as part of nature conservation (integration strategy) and to establish an ecologically truly sustainable agriculture oriented towards the characteristics of natural ecosystems. Only if biodiversity is permitted and promoted in the soil can there also be biodiversity above ground. Arable land and grassland, together with nature conservation areas, should be understood as an integrated system.   1. For reasons of sustainability, net soil conservation is clearly the higher-priority objective than all other agricultural targets. At the end of a (preferably wide) crop rotation, the soil status shall not be in a worse condition than at the end of the preceding one.  2. The principle of restoring and improving the natural productivity of soil-plant systems which are ecologically and locally adapted. By natural productivity we mean one that is made effective by a functional diversity of life with little or no external nutrient supply, combined with area-bound animal husbandry and increased cultivation of legumes.   3. Demands for socio-political changes so that living soils can be maintained as a common ground. Environmentally friendly products shall not be at a cost disadvantage in the shop, others being cheaper because the consequences of the damage they cause are not included in the price. Instead, hitherto hidden costs caused by production, but also corresponding benefits for nature and mankind, should be made more visible (true costs). These prices must reward farmers and growers better, which in turn benefits animals, plants and the soil.  A change towards ecologically sustainable land management in agriculture requires impetus and support, also through changed social values. Today's usually sharp division between nature conservation and agriculture must also be overcome from a social and cultural perspective. This requires a new appraisal of the value of nature in agriculture.    The complete position paper can be downloaded here: https://www.wwf.de/fileadmin/fm-wwf/Publikationen-PDF/The-common-basis-for-agriculture-and-nature-conservation-is-the-living-soil.pdf   Feedback from: WWF Germany (1.6 MB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: In a world where anthropogenic pressure on ecosystems is growing dramatically, the transition towards a circular bioeconomy and towards regenerative and socially inclusive practices should be promoted, starting with: 1. a regenerative agriculture that has soil health at its center Among the practices aimed at increasing organic matter we could mention the use of compost and other high quality organic amendments, such as farm-sourced organic matter and wastewater sludge. Another topic is related to the use of multi-year crops (i.e. thistle) associated with sustainable agricultural practices in marginal lands and the recovery of residues such as surface mulch. Other key issues are related to conservative agriculture and precision agriculture; cover crops and green manure; high diversity rotation; integrated management of nutrients with organic fertilizers associated with precision agriculture; integration of pasture (and multi-year grassland crops and / or agro-forestry) into crop systems.  2. the construction of a new relationship between city and agriculture in connection with food and organic waste Within urban centers, the food system actors can play an important role in promoting the transition to the circular economy, promoting products made according to a regenerative logic, making the most of food waste, diversifying eating habits, producing less food waste and making the separate collection of organic waste. 3. the rethinking of products in an eco-design logic, so that they do not accumulate in the environment and do not release pollutants, avoiding the generation of microplastics in the organic carbon flows Biodegradability in soil or water is essential for all those products for agricultural use with accumulation problems in the environment (herbicides, lubricants, coatings for seeds, agricultural mulch films) and for those products with accumulation problems in sewage sludge and in water (additives for cosmetics and detergents).  Compostability becomes essential for all applications in which the materials used have a high probability of being polluted by food residues and which in the absence of biodegradability would pollute the organic waste that would end up in landfills, instead of becoming precious humus. This is the case of products for collective catering, coffee capsules or multilayer packaging. 4. the development and enhancement of a network of adequate industrial plants for the treatment of waste water and food residues, essential to avoid the accumulation of pollutants in the environment In order to limit the cases of non-compliance of organic waste generated by separate collection, a serious and complete communication campaign is necessary, highlighting how to properly collect the Organic Fraction and which products can be generated, ensuring participatory and training activities with the resident population, monitoring virtuous territorial examples in sustainable soil management through the enhancement of organic fertility from the recovery of organic waste. 5. the development of monitoring systems to measure the effects of such actions In order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals and expand innovation in the agricultural sector, it will be increasingly essential to strengthen the link between farmers and research. Examples are Experimental Farms, or Lighthouse Farms, in which farmers, researchers, civil society and other stakeholders plan together radically innovative future agricultural systems with the aim of drastically reducing environmental impacts and maximizing the efficient use of resources through the introduction of enabling technologies for high quality soil. Transforming farms into laboratories will not only allow for measurable and concrete results, but above all a critical mass of replicable case studies of good practices that can have a concrete and positive impact on soil health (including the quality of food and feed ) and its ability to provide high quality ecosystem services.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Il “buono stato ecologico” può essere così definito: assenza sostanziale di inquinanti di origine antropica, persistenti, permanenti, tossici, biodisponibili; presenza di comunità di invertebrati, tipici per a tipologia in esame, abbondanti e biodiversificati, alto contenuto di humus e di pabumum microbico e buona tessitura e permeabilità. Le azioni necessarie alla conservazione e/o al ripristino di un buon stato ecologico del suolo sono:  . Proteggere la fertilità del suolo: si attua con una molteplicità di interventi e di attenzioni, integrate. Garantirne un grado di umidità che non ecceda i limiti di tolleranza e che non scenda al di sotto di un minimo vitale (anche con cinture di siepi frangivento e per i suoli agricoli adottare tecniche irrigue sostenibili e scientificamente corrette e colture non intensive e criteri di rotazione);   . Ridurre l'erosione e l'impermeabilizzazione: per l’erosione è importante la prevenzione (tecniche agricole che evitino le arature per quanto possibile), la sistemazione dei suoli collinari con terrazzamenti e garantire/ripristinare le fasce protettive di vegetazione spontanea riparia di tutti i corsi d’acqua grandi e piccoli. Per l’impermeabilizzazione oltre a non produrne di più, avviare piani di decorticazione.  I parcheggi possono essere fatti con betonelle per prati erbosi drenanti rodabili.  . Aumentare la materia organica: ri-coniugare agricoltura e allevamento, estensivo, ridando alla terra il letame. Attivare, promuovere, incentivare il compostaggio della frazione organica di qualsivoglia rifiuto, per ridare carbonio al suolo, immobilizzato, ove costituisce grande fattore di fertilità, sottraendolo dal destino di divenire CO2 (per combustione o per gassificazione) che aggrava la crisi climatica. Inoltre Conservare la materia organica senza incenerirla con le pratiche dei c.d. "abbruciamenti". Apportare modifiche al regime di condizionalità previsto dalla PAC per sospendere l'erogazione di contributi a chi pratica per qualsiasi scopo l'incenerimento del materiale cellulosico derivante da attività agricola o selvicolturale.  . Identificare i siti contaminati: attraverso analisi chimiche per conoscere la composizione del fondo naturale interessato e identificare il contributo dell’inquinamento di origine antropica.  Una volta identificati procedere con la fito-bonifica (Phytoremediation).  . Ripristinare i suoli degradati: ciascun suolo degradato deve essere oggetto di una pianificazione di recupero. Il compost prodotto dalla frazione umida dei rifiuti solidi urbani conferiti separatamente in differenziata è strategico.  Altrettanto strategica è l’emanazione di linee-guida per l’applicazione delle tecniche di ingegneria naturalistica nei suoi scoscesi, nelle zone montane ove il suolo è stato eroso a seguito dei disboscamenti ed è esposto lo scheletro roccioso.  . Proteggere e incrementare il potere del suolo fertile di purificare l’aria dagli inquinanti atmosferici”  . Cessare il consumo di suolo e, viceversa, avviare piani di ripristino significativo di suolo libero eliminando ovunque possibile la tecnocrosta.  Ne deriva la necessità di introdurre - nella normativa europea - esattamente come è stato fatto per gli ambienti acquatici dalla Direttiva 60/2000/CE, un INDICE BIOTICO per la valutazione della qualità complessiva eco-biologica dei suoli. (In Italia è disponibile l'indice Qbs-AR, basato sulla disamina della componente degli invertebrati del suolo). Feedback from: GUFI - Gruppo Unitario per le Foreste Italiane (422.6 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Organisation: GUFI - Gruppo Unitario per le Foreste Italiane
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Circular bioeconomy plays an important role in developing a sustainable growth, not merely by valorizing renewable bioresources, but by proposing an integrated approach to respond to the ambition of an economic growth decoupled from resource use and GHG emissions, which is the aim of the Green New Deal and related European strategies.  In this framework, a healthy soil is of the essence not only to ensure the economic sustainability of circular bioeconomy (as a matter of fact, without soil there is not agriculture and without agriculture there is not circular bioeconomy), but -and even more importantly- to guide its development within environmental boundaries for the economic and social regeneration of territories.   This calls for collaborative initiatives engaging the agriculture, forestry, waste management, and processing industries through integrated and interconnected value chain creation to foster the spread and implementation of best practices in agriculture and forestry land management; calls for the definition and implementation of innovative technologies to increase soli fertility and carbon sequestration, to strengthen the separate collection of organic waste and its transformation in high quality compost; to revitalize agricultural and marginal land (especially those with high desertification or erosion risk), valorizing raw materials, by-products and wastes in new, added-value (bio)products.  It will be important to foster the development and implementation of integrated multi-input and multi-product biorefineries as drivers for the development of high added-value value chains, which should become demonstrators of a circular bioeconomy especially in those sectors significantly impacting soil and water resources, supporting the development of alternatives to high impact chemicals and products, and promoting the recovery of abandoned industrial sites and their integration to minimize land consumption.  Finally, stakeholder’s engagement, as well as educational and training activities, is vital to accelerate the behavioral change needed for the transition towards a sustainable circular bioeconomy which relies on a healthy soil and aims at a sustainable soil management.
Organisation: Cluster Tecnologico Nazionale della Chimica Verde SPRING
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: O solo  é o substrato básico para a produção agrícola e florestal e a manutenção ou incremento da sua qualidade, através de práticas de gestão adequadas, é uma componente chave da sustentabilidade florestal e dos ecossistemas. Os solos, a nível europeu, nacional e regional, também diferem muito, quer nas ameaças que os assolam quer ainda na capacidade de reação às perturbações a que estão sujeitos. Desta forma, a nova Estratégia Europeia de Proteção dos Solos (EEPS) tem de acautelar estas especificações nacionais e locais para que a contribuição dos solos para os objetivos do Pacto Ecológico Europeu se concretize. Sendo uma temática transversal, a EEPS deverá identificar, de forma clara, os diversos instrumentos de política sectorial com que potencialmente impactará para, assim, tornar evidente as possíveis conflitualidades que deles resultam. Consideramos importante introduzir a noção de equilíbrio entre as diversas medidas que venham a ser adotadas na EEPS, adequando os objetivos propostos no roadmap “New Soil Strategy - healthy soil for a healthy life”, mas sem detrimento das  outras funções relevantes dos solos. Com base na sua experiência e conhecimento, a NAVIGATOR defende soluções equilibradas, que promovam as funções de produção, conservação e proteção, evitando possíveis impactes em países terceiros.  Outro aspeto importante que a EEPS terá de promover é a gestão sustentável dos solos,  sendo fundamental assegurar o equilíbrio entre os serviços de suporte e de aprovisionamento que os solos conferem à produção de plantas, mas também os de regulação que também prestam, visando sempre a manutenção e/ou melhoria da sua qualidade. Também será imperioso investir na disponibilização do conhecimento sobre os solos e a sua fertilidade, na informação e sensibilização da sociedade civil para a importância da sua preservação, para a necessidade de implementação de boas práticas e eficiência no uso de nutrientes. Portugal não possui ainda uma Carta de Solos unificada que abranja todo o país, a uma escala de uso operacional e com um único sistema de classificação. A inexistência de uma Carta de Solos unificada é uma lacuna que é premente suprimir no contexto português. O conhecimento aprofundado das características do solo é essencial para a sua consequente gestão sustentável, e  neste sentido, a inovação no desenvolvimento de formas expeditas de avaliação da qualidade e fertilidade do solo a nível local deve ser apoiada.  Em linha com o Roadmap da Comissão Europeia, a proteção do solo continua ser fator central no contexto nacional face às suas especificidades: uma vez que Portugal tem em grande parte a sua floresta e ecossistemas em áreas com orografia acentuada; tem áreas importantes em zonas suscetíveis à desertificação; tem a sua floresta em grande parte em solos de baixa fertilidade e com baixa matéria orgânica; tem incêndios recorrentes que necessitam de uma abordagem imediata de proteção dos solos para evitar perdas por erosão do solo no pós-incêndio; tem havido um crescimento nos agentes patogénicos do solo, nomeadamente fungos,  sobre os quais é preciso agir de forma a promover as culturas e biodiversidade. A nova EEPS  deve ser clara e por isso expressões genéricas como ‘gestão florestal insustentável’, mesmo que extraída de relatórios públicos, devem ser evitadas ou devidamente contextualizadas e apresentar exemplos em concreto que urge corrigir e evitar.  A consciencialização sobre importância do solo, a divulgação  de conhecimento e experiências sobre a gestão e uso sustentável do recurso solo deve ser potenciada em relação com as ações nacionais resultantes da iniciativa da FAO sobre a Parceria Global do Solo e da Parceria europeia do Solo. Em resumo, a NAVIGATOR defende que a nova EEPS funcione como ponte entre as políticas nacionais e os objetivos da UE, que reforce a base de conhecimento e o aumento da sensibilização da sociedade, e que respeite o equilibrio multifuncional dos solos no espaço florestal.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Roadmap „ New Soil Strategy - healthy soil for a healthy life”  Statement of the German Scientific-technical Association for Environmental Remediation and Brownfield Redevelopment (ITVA)  ITVA welcomes that the European Commission will revise the Thematic Strategy for Soil Protection and emphasize the importance of soil as a limited resource.   European and international initiatives and agreements must be taken into account in the revision of the Thematic Strategy. These include in particular the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the European Green Deal, the EU Mission "Soil Health and Food", the EU Biodiversity Strategy, the EU Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability and the FAO Global Soil Partnership. The protection of soil biodiversity and the maintenance and improvement of soil ecosystem services in general must be integrated into all policy areas.  Beyond a revision of the Thematic Strategy for Soil Protection, it is still urgently necessary to implement a European soil framework directive in order to provide a legally binding European framework for soil protection. An EU Soil Framework Directive should be developed in a broad-based process involving all stakeholders. This also includes uniform assessment standards for soil damage, so that a uniform approach is possible without distorting competition, as is also the case with the implementation of the Water Framework Directive and air pollution control.  The Thematic Strategy for Soil Protection must contain specific binding targets for good ecological soil status, regulations on land use, specifications for EU-wide quality requirements, e.g. with regard to contamination. In addition, uniform standards (assessment, precautionary, test and limit values) should be established for a common responsible approach to soil damage.  Progress in identifying and remediating contaminated sites and address diffuse contamination must soon be achieved. Damaged soil must be restored. The polluter pays principle must be applied consistently. Special attention is currently required for per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) due to the high level of soil and water contamination in the EU and worldwide.   Soil protection cannot be carried out only locally, regionally or nationally. Climate protection/change, soil erosion, desertification, the protection of "good" soils for food security are European issues that must also be discussed and resolved at European level. There are complex interrelationships between soil and climate, some of which have increasing feedback effects. One part of the strategy must be to raise public awareness of the urgent need for soil protection.  The rate of land take, urban sprawl and sealing must be reduced significantly to achieve land degradation neutrality by 2030 and no net land take by 2050. When creating new living space, focus on brownfield redevelopment, i.e. re-use formerly built-up areas, the redensification of less used sites.  Feedback from: ITVA e.V. (198.5 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: I welcome the effort to find a roadmap toward a healthy soil. Thank you for your work in this regard. I do however miss the most important part of modern-day soil science in your attempt. The biological approach, that is best described by Dr. Elaine Ingham and others. In this approach has the micro life in the soil the first priority of interest when it comes to establish a nutrient cycling in soil that will provide so many ecosystem services: good structure, water holding capacity, nutrient rich soil, higher and healthier yields, to name a few. This modern soil microbiology is the foundation we all need for the future. If we can implement the biological approach when it comes to handling soils, we can feed the world. I realize that my tiny voice from the middle of a Swedish forest cannot persuade whoever is reading this about the importance of this. My only wish is that the work to establish this road map, will include further studies concerning soil microbiology. The life IN the soil, can save life ON this planet. ref: https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detailfull/soils/health/biology/?cid=nrcs142p2_053868 https://www.soilfoodweb.com/ https://www.globalsoilbiodiversity.org/ Best regards Ylva Arvidsson Borrabo Permakultur
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: The UNCCD very much welcomes the opportunity to comment on the European Commission’s Roadmap. Soils are the fundament of human health and human life.   Context, Problem definition and Subsidiarity Check  -Healthy soils are not only a key enabler – but the condition to achieve the objectives of the European Green Deal.  -Soil and land indeed lie at the core of most of the SDGs. The UNCCD welcomes the reference to SDG target 15.3, which includes land degradation neutrality (LDN). LDN was recognized by the UN General Assembly as an accelerator and integrator for achieving the SDGs. The IPCC has also documented, with high confidence, that policies promoting LDN can also enhance food security, human wellbeing and climate change adaptation and mitigation. The new Soil Strategy would benefit from highlighting the place of land in the SDGs and in SDGs interactions.  -The UNCCD welcomes the recommendations from the European Court of Auditors Special Report on Combating desertification in the EU. While many European countries have declared themselves affected by desertification, in 2020 – only one country has set voluntary LDN targets.   -The UNCCD welcomes the proposal of a new policy framework to update the 2006 EU Soil Thematic Strategy.  -The issue of water scarcity is absent from the draft Communication. Imbalance in supply and demand caused by drought exacerbated by land use decisions and land degradation is a recurrent feature of the European climate that affects considerable fractions of the EU population each year. Similar to LDN and land, the EU Water Framework Directive takes a pioneering landscape approach to protecting water, and the new Soil Strategy could be framed in a similarly compatible manner. As part of the Drought initiative, the UNCCD collaborated with partners in developing a Drought Toolbox that may support European countries in adapting to and mitigating the effects of drought.   B. What does the initiative aim to achieve and how   -The UNCCD welcomes the objectives of the new Soil Strategy. We note that “prevention is better than the cure”, which is the basis for the “Avoid>Reduce>Reverse response hierarchy in LDN, which could be employed to encourage conservation, sustainable land management and restoration responses.  -Promoting the adoption of sustainable soil management practices remains essential. It would be important to build on ongoing efforts or already available tools and databases.  -The draft strategy includes “improving the monitoring of soil quality” as one of the ways to implement the initiative. While this remains essential, it should not be understood on its own, but rather together with the other main functions. The LDN indicators (and associated metrics) are land cover change, land productivity dynamics and change in carbon stocks (particularly soil organic carbon (SOC) stocks). SDG indicator 15.3.1, the integration of these three sub-indicators, has been granted the highest tier classification (Tier I).  -“Steering EU global action on soil under the Rio Conventions, EU external action and development cooperation” are indeed crucial to a successful Green Deal.  -In addition to the EU Biodiversity and the Farm to Fork Strategies, it would also be important for the Soil Strategy to be in line with the new Common Agricultural Policy – to ensure positive incentives for the protection of the environment and SLM.  C. Better regulation   -The focus on restoration is essential for the implementation of the Green Deal and, in the global arena, of LDN. At the EU level, it would benefit from an alignment with existing assessments and analyses, such as the recent report from the PBL "Goals and commitments for the Restoration Decade"; And the G20 Global Initiative on Reducing Land Degradation and Enhancing Conservation of Terrestrial Habitats -Healthy land and healthy soils need to be at the center of a green recovery to build back better. This includes a restoration economy and markets for technologies Feedback from: United Nations (259.2 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: La prossima strategia comunitaria sul suolo deve partire da azioni di sensibilizzazione alla problematica sul suo consumo e degrado.  Tutti noi conosciamo cos’è il suolo ma manca ancora una adeguata percezione sull’importanza e sull’effettiva necessità ed emergenza di una sua tutela. Non è per nulla chiaro all’opinione pubblica che si tratta di una risorsa limitata, non rinnovabile e che deve quindi essere gestita alla stessa stregua di ogni altra preziosa risorsa naturale.  Si ritiene infatti che solo da una adeguata informazione e conoscenza di tale bene possa scaturire una chiara volontà pubblica di tutelare adeguatamente ed attivamente questa risorsa.  Per rendere più chiara la situazione di tale problematica è inoltre necessario distinguere chiaramente i diversi livelli di uso e degrado del suolo, differenziandoli in categorie di importanza e gravità. E’ opportuno differenziare anche i principali usi del suolo in suoli naturali (es. forestali), suoli agrari e suoli urbani e per ognuno di questi indicare dei parametri di funzionalità utili per la loro gestione e conservazione.    Necessario è anche effettuare un costante monitoraggio dello stato di consumo e degrado del suolo, ma svolto con parametri e metodi condivisi a livello comunitario. Questo è basilare per avere un confronto costante tra i diversi stati comunitari. Fondamentale sarà inoltre monitorare il fenomeno anche in termini economici e quindi monetizzare i benefici di una buona tutela del suolo o i danni di una cattiva gestione.  Per quanto riguarda i suoli agrari sottoposti ad aratura sono necessarie strategie di conservazione che si integrano con gli indirizzi della prossima PAC. In particolare, bisogna scongiurare i problemi di erosione determinati dalla meccanizzazione, che tendono a sconvolgere gli assetti degli appezzamenti in collina e montagna, promuovendo le pratiche di agricoltura conservativa.   Infine, si ritiene essenziale che la normativa comunitaria scenda nel dettaglio in merito alle azioni concrete che i vari stati possono e devono attuare per tutelare il suolo. E’ necessario che vengano individuate le azioni concrete per salvaguardare e ripristinare il suolo degradato e soprattutto ci siano direttive chiare e vincolanti sulla pianificazione urbanistica e su tutte le azioni che sottraggono suolo. L’obiettivo del bilancio zero in consumo del suolo entro il 2030 deve essere una priorità ed un obiettivo concreto da perseguire per tutti gli stati comunitari.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Commenti dell’associazione Scelte Possibili di Cadorago (CO), alla consultazione popolare indetta in UE per una nuova Strategia UE sul suolo Obiettivo dovrebbe essere quello di preservare il suolo per salvaguardare la vita e il perpetuarsi degli esseri viventi -mobili e immobili - che lo popolano, e per appagare il senso estetico di noi esseri umani  1. Individuare un sistema di misurazione del consumo di suolo che sia unico in tutta la UE e riconosciuto da tutti gli stati membri; ISPRA ne produce uno per l’Italia ma sarebbe auspicabile un’armonizzazione europea 2. Fissare obiettivi vincolanti collegati a questi standard di misurazione: azzeramento del consumo di suolo entro una data fissa e non lontana, rinaturalizzazione di una quota delle aree dismesse, ……. 3. Comunicare periodicamente agli Stati ed ai cittadini i risultati  relativi al raggiungimento degli obiettivi  4. Combattere la cementificazione:  a. censimento degli immobili inutilizzati sui territori comunali, incentivi fiscali o economici ai proprietari di tali immobili volti al loro recupero all’uso   b. protezione del territorio incrementando la parte di territorio non edificabile c. piani di governo del territorio in cui il consumo di suolo sia disincentivato e ammesso solo per gravi motivi 5. Azioni educative: partendo dal presupposto che solo un cambiamento di cultura può invertire la tendenza attuale, agire mediante più livelli educativi: a) educazione scolastica all’ambiente ed al consumo critico b) percorsi formativi di educazione ambientale per associazioni e per adulti c) incentivi alla creazione e sostegno ai gruppi di acquisto solidale d) percorsi formativi per agricoltori 6. Sostegno all’agricoltura biologica o naturale di piccole aziende che possono svolgere il ruolo di tutela dell’ambiente in cui si trovano oltre a dare occupazione, individuando criteri univoci, chiari e restrittivi 7. Inserire nel costo dei prodotti i costi ambientali dovuti al deterioramento dell’ambiente mediante la creazione di una ecotassa europea
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Stellungnahme der AlzChem Trostberg GmbH zur Bodenstrategie der EU-Kommission:  Auswirkungen von Dünge- und Pflanzenschutzmitteln realistisch bewerten!  Wir begrüßen die Initiative, ein EU-weites Bodenschutzkonzept zu entwickeln. Die anzustrebenden Maßnahmen sollten sich dabei vor allem auf die bekannten und am weitesten verbreiteten Gefährdungen (Versiegelung, Wind- und Wassererosion, Versalzung, Humusabbau durch Nutzungsänderung) fokussieren und nicht auf vermeintliche Gefahren durch Dünge- und Pflanzenschutzmittel, solange es dafür keine Belege gibt.   1. Unterscheidung zwischen Zielflächen und Nichtzielflächen Bei Dünge- und Pflanzenschutzmitteln ist bei den Auswirkungen zwischen Zielflächen (z.B. Acker) und Nichtzielflächen zu unterscheiden. Auswirkungen in den Böden von Nichtzielflächen sind zu vermeiden. Abdrift oder Abschwemmung müssen daher ebenso vermieden werden wie gasförmige Verluste von Ammoniak bei der Düngung mit Gülle, Stallmist oder Harnstoff. Der diffuse Eintrag dieses Stickstoffs führt auf Nichtzielflächen zur Veränderung von Pflanzengesellschaften sowie der Mikro- und Mesofauna im Boden.   Die Lebewesen in landwirtschaftlich genutzten Böden unterliegen dagegen regelmäßig massiven menschlichen Einflüssen (Pflügen, Hacken, Aussaat, Ernte, Düngung, Pflanzenschutz). Mikro- und Mesofauna des Bodens haben sich im Laufe der Jahrhunderte darauf eingestellt und entsprechend anpassungsfähige Populationen entwickelt. Auch natürliche Einflüsse lösen regelmäßig massive Veränderungen im Boden aus, z.B.  Hitze, Frost, Austrocknung, Staunässe, Überflutung. Düngungsbedingte Veränderungen im Boden sind daher im Kontext dieser anderen Einflüsse zu bewerten. Eine „No-effect-Düngung“, wie sie die ECHA aktuell in einem Beschränkungsverfahren zum Düngemittel Kalkstickstoff durch Anwendung des Umwelt-Risk-Assessments nach der Chemikalien-VO REACH fordert, ist weder realistisch noch sinnvoll. Ziel der Düngung ist es ja, die Bodenfruchtbarkeit zu erhalten und einer Nährstoffverarmung entgegen zu wirken. Die Zufuhr bio-verfügbarer Nährstoffe wirkt sich nicht nur auf die Pflanzen, sondern auch auf andere Bodenlebewesen aus. Die Ausdehnung der Umweltbewertung gemäß REACH auf die Düngemittelanwendung ohne Differenzierung zwischen Ziel- und Nichtzielflächen und mit der Vorgabe, einen „No-Effect-Level“ einzuhalten, leistet keinen Beitrag zum Bodenschutz und ist daher abzulehnen.  2. Wieder-Erholung berücksichtigen Ob ein Stoff unerwünschte Auswirkungen auf Bodenorganismen hat, hängt von der Konzentration und der Einwirkungsdauer ab. Verbindungen, welche in Böden und Organismen rasch abgebaut werden, lösen nur kurzfristige, nicht-chronische Effekte aus. Solche vorübergehenden Effekte sind in landwirtschaftlichen Böden tolerierbar, wenn sich die Populationen innerhalb eines angemessenen Zeitraumes – z.B. einer Vegetationsperiode - wieder dem Ausgangszustand annähern. Diese im Pflanzenschutz etablierte Sichtweise sollte bei allen Stoffen angewendet werden, die zur Ausbringung auf landwirtschaftliche Böden bestimmt sind.  3. Natürliches Vorkommen von Substanzen berücksichtigen Der moderne Pflanzenbau setzt zunehmend Stoffe ein, die auch in der Natur vorkommen. Denn die Bodenorganismen können solche Verbindungen meist rasch und rückstandsfrei abbauen. Bewertet man die Auswirkungen solcher Substanzen auf das Bodenleben, muss die zusätzliche Exposition vor dem Hintergrund der bereits natürlich auftretenden Expositionen betrachtet werden. Es ergibt keinen Sinn, eine Substanz unterschiedlich zu bewerten, je nachdem, auf welchem Wege sie in den Boden gelangt. Ein Beispiel hierfür ist Cyanamid, welches in erheblichen Mengen über eine Gründüngung mit Vogel- oder Zottelwicken oder aber durch eine Kalkstickstoffdüngung in den Boden gelangen kann. Kalkstickstoff wirkt als Dünger der Bodenversauerung entgegen, erhöht die biologische Aktivität des Bodens, fördert dadurch die Bodengesundheit und unterstützt somit die Ziele der „New EU Soil Strategy“.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Climate change, soil health, biodiversity, water quality and human health are all interlinked. The review of healthy soils must firstly account for the pathways between each system. Education of farmers and advisors is key. Farmers are the custodians of the majority of soils and they must be educated on the correct practices for the sustainable management of their land. The relevant national agricultural advisory service should be accredited to insure that the advice being given to farmers is correct and consistent. The advisory services must be funded and the funding conditional on accreditation in order to maintain consistency and standards. The key areas to be addressed: • A standard carbon calculator for all EU members is required so that carbon emissions can be objectively compared across all jurisdictions. The carbon calculator should be robust and not just user friendly. A robust carbon calculator will identify critical impacts on soil. • A comprehensive nutrient management planning tool is required at farm level. Traditionally nutrient management planning has focused on the major nutrients nitrogen, phosphorous, potassium and calcium applications (largely based on ph analysis). Excess use of nutrients particularly nitrogen and phosphorous has induced nutrient imbalances in plants and animals, contributed to organic matter loss and deteriorating water quality. Nutrient management planning must first establish an accurate baseline for the farm, identify nutrient requirements and issue nutrient allowances. The management of on farm organic manures must be a priority. The nutrient management tool must also be comprehensive and user friendly.  • The maintenance of organic matter is critical. A measure of locally available organic resources should be taken. Regional mapping programs should be formulated to identify the land areas requiring organic matter and the locally available sources. The organic sources must be evaluated to insure that they are free from contaminants. Micro plastics in particular should be analysed. Biodegradable and compostable plastics are being promoted as being environmentally friendly, however are up to 70% derived from fossil fuels. Research on micro plastics in agricultural soils is limited and needs to be urgently initiated in research institutions across member states. Micro plastics in soils potentially act as a pathway to water sources.  • Many other initiatives relating to compaction reduction, minimum cultivation techniques, catch crops, tree planting etc are required.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy
