feedback_msg_text: Le sol est une ressource non renouvelable et complexe qui remplit des fonctions de production alimentaire et de régulation des écosystèmes. Il joue également un rôle important dans la lutte contre le réchauffement climatique compte tenu de sa capacité à stocker du carbone. Il est la deuxième réserve de carbone au monde après l’eau. Les sols qui représentent une très grande diversité en Europe ne sont pourtant pas reconnus à leur juste valeur et ne bénéficient d’aucun encadrement juridique spécifique européen alors qu’il existe une directive cadre sur l’eau et l’air.  C’est pourquoi il m’apparaît aujourd’hui indispensable que l’Union se dote enfin d’une législation cadre en faveur de la protection et de la restauration des sols compte tenu de leur importance sur tout le vivant. J’estime qu’une telle initiative devrait viser à mettre en cohérence l’ensemble des politiques sectorielles communautaires et nationales qui touchent les sols. Dans cette optique je propose quatre axes d’actions.  I) Une surveillance des sols  Face aux pressions croissantes subies par le sol il m’apparaît nécessaire de pouvoir suivre l’évolution de la qualité des sols à moyen et long terme via un observatoire européen des sols prenant en compte l’état des sols et leur utilisation. Cet outil devrait aider à identifier les sols pollués, les sols devant prioritairement être protégés, et plus largement à prendre des décisions en matière de gestion durable.   II) Une protection des sols  L’absence de directive sur la protection des sols et de leur fonctionnalité est un problème crucial. Je pense que la Commission devrait s’en saisir, alors que cette ressource est un bien commun dont la dégradation et la perte de fertilité a des conséquences considérables sur l’alimentation, la santé, l’eau, la biodiversité le changement climatique. Cela nuit à la réalisation d’un grand nombre d’objectifs des politiques de l’Union.  Le cadre général sur la protection des sols doit reposer selon moi sur les principes de la prévention et du principe du pollueur payeur.      III) Une utilisation durable et la restauration des sols agricoles et forestiers  La production agricole et forestière est fortement corrélée à la santé des sols dont le principal indicateur est leur taux de matière organique majoritairement composée de carbone, lequel taux participe à 4 grands services écosystémiques : la résistance des sols à l’érosion, leur rétention en eau, leur fertilité pour les plantes, et leur biodiversité. Préserver le carbone organique des sols, restaurer et améliorer les terres agricoles dégradées en augmentant le carbone dans les sols, représentent des enjeux majeurs pour relever les défis du pacte vert : la sécurité alimentaire, l’adaptation des systèmes alimentaires, la lutte contre les dérèglements climatiques et l’atténuation des émissions anthropiques.  J’estime que, de toute évidence, la PAC se doit d’agir plus énergiquement en faveur d’une utilisation durable des sols. Cela passe par une transition en faveur de nouveaux modes de production fondés sur des structures de production à taille humaine, diversifiées (polyculture élevage) et des pratiques agricoles et forestières adaptées, reposant sur l’agroécologie, l’agroforesterie, l’agriculture biologique et s’accompagnant d’importants moyens dans la restauration de la qualité des sols.  La Commission doit exiger que les futurs plans stratégiques contiennent une stratégie sur les sols.  IV) Une utilisation durable des sols non agricoles  En Europe près de 4,4 % des sols sont aussi occupés par des espaces dits artificialisés qui correspondent à des zones urbaines, industrielles, à des réseaux de transports, des carrières, des espaces verts et sportifs. Cette artificialisation fait perdre chaque année près de 900 km2 de terres arables au sein de l’UE. Elle détruit aussi les sols en les imperméabilisant. Je propose que ces altérations des sols soient enfin pleinement prises en compte au plan européen.  Feedback from: Member of the European Parliament (17.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Subsidiarity principle stands against EU regulation of soil   The initiative of the EU Commission and various Council presidencies regarding the creation of an EU legal framework for soil protection (development of an EU soil protection framework directive) failed at the time due to resistance from the member states because the environmental medium "soil" has no cross-border effect ("subsidiarity").   In addition, the interests of soil protection are convincingly regulated in several member states, for example in the German soil protection law. It is therefore questionable why the Commission should even consider regulations on soil protection. Due to the more than 300 different soil types in Europe and the resulting large national differences, it should be left to each member state to regulate soil protection individually.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Il FORUM DELL'ARIA evidenzia la stretta correlazione tra la superficie forestale e le variazioni di CO2, stabilendo che, ad una riduzione delle superfici forestali, corrisponde sempre un minor assorbimento di CO2.  Inoltre, nella realizzazione di nuove strade dovranno sempre essere valutati anche gli impatti sanitari, visto il rapporto di causa-effetto tra patologie cardio-respiratorie sulla popolazione residente e nuove arterie di traffico automobilistico. L'agricoltura produce circa il 7% delle emissioni climalteranti e l'uso di macchinari perla coltivazione aggiunge un ulteriore 2%, in pratic 30 milioni di tonnellate di CO2 equivalente all'anno. Con procedure di agricoltura conservativa si potrebbero ottenere assorbimenti di circa 60 tonnellate di CO2 equivalente. Il legno emette più CO2 per MWh anche del carbone - come rilevato dall'IPCC - motivo per cui la maggior parte degli ambientalisti e degli scienziati calcolano diversi decenni affinchè la ricrescita delle piante riassorbisca il carbonio emesso dalla combustione del legno. Questo tempo è ovviamente troppo lungo per raggiungere gli obiettivi dell'accordo di Parigi. Quindi, non ha molto senso che la maggior parte della biomassa forestale sia considerata una fonte di energia "a emissioni zero". Chiediamo l'eliminazione graduale per la combustione del legno.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: We at National Soil Survey most sincerely and with great enthusiasm support this initiative! Finally, the Earth ecosystem seems to be complete! After the already existing Water and Air Directives and Strategies, the Soils came next. As an organization that has been involved in soil research and mapping for a long time, we will be happy to support the accompanying initiatives and offer our expertise and partnership. Over the years, we have accumulated a significant amount of information about soils and their condition from our annual surveys and constant contacts with farmers across the country. We consider of particular importance the issues related to soil monitoring, tracking and mapping of nutrients and organic matter. In addition we support such an initiative because it is imperative to note that soil degradation is an ultra-serious issue leading to long-term damage not only to soils but also to all related ecosystems and leading to a lasting impact on population nutrition and food security as whole. We can confidently say that we all recognize the importance of healthy soils for all of us and are concerned about keeping them in good health for our future generations. With best wishes for Success!
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Ritengo che sia utile mettere in evidenza anche la necessità della vigilanza del territorio e quindi anche delle aree forestali. Le regioni italiane hanno istituito le Guardie Ecologiche Volontarie (GEV) negli anni '90,  garantendo attraverso di esse la vigilanza ambientale richiesta appunto dall'Europa. In Italia questa controllo è stato delegato al Corpo Forestale dello stato oggi riformato in Carabinieri Forestali. In questo momento non riescono a sopperire a tutti i controlli cui sono demandati , anche per il numero  esiguo. Le polizie provinciali demandate per gli stessi controlli ambientali sono via via demansionate conseguentemente all'avvio della riduzione dei compiti amministrativi delle Province. Le Guardie Ecologiche  rappresentano assieme alle altre guardie volontarie circa 15000 persone (dati ISTAT 2012 settore agricoltura). Sono insediate territorialmente nelle Province di competenza e sono ben ancorate nel territorio di controllo potrebbero dare il giusto contributo all'osservanza delle leggi vigenti. Le autorizzazioni forestali sono rilasciate dalle Unioni Montane che però difettano chiaramente nella vigilanza delle stesse. Il contributo delle GEV potrebbe servire al controllo delle autorizzazioni e della corrette procedure di taglio ceduo, nonchè delle autorizzazioni alle potature ed ai singoli abbattimenti. Potrebbero intervenire per questi illeciti minori , lasciando agli altri corpi di polizia l'intervento per reati più consistenti. A mio avviso ritengo poco considerata a livello legislativo la presenza degli alberi e dei boschi sia a livello urbano che extraurbano. Occorrerebbe una azione più chiara e decisa a livello legislativo affinchè le specie arboree e vegetali nel complesso, sia maggiormente tutelate o tutelate con più chiarezza a livello nazionale e regionale. Le attuali leggi pur essendo pregevoli, per via di una delega continua vengono svalorizzate senza interventi decisi a livello sanzionatorio. Feedback from: WWF Marche (18.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Der Bundesverband Mineralische Rohstoffe e.V. (MIRO) setzt sich für die Interessen der deutschen Hersteller von Kies, Sand, Quarzkies, Quarzsand und Natursteinen ein.  Grundsätzlich begrüßen wir den EU Green Deal und die Biodiversitätsstrategie sowie damit im Zusammenhang stehende Maßnahmen.   Bodenschutz ist besonders bedeutsam. Mit Blick auf das Subsidiaritätsprinzip sprechen wir uns gegen die Einführung eines europäischen Rechtsrahmens für Boden aus. Neben dem hier gegenstehenden Subsidiaritätsprinzip ist hervorzuheben, dass die Belange des Bodenschutzes in den Mitgliedstaaten bereits überzeugend und äußerst ausdifferenziert geregelt sind.   Lediglich beispielhaft seien folgende Rechtsvorschriften in Deutschland genannt:   • Bundesbodenschutzgesetz • Bundesnaturschutzgesetz (über den Gebietsschutz) • Schutzgebietsverordnungen in den Bundesländern • Wasserrecht (in Bund und Ländern) • Denkmalrecht (Archivfunktion) • Schutz vor Übernutzung über Umweltverträglichkeitsprüfungen (UVP) und UVP-Gesetz sieht Boden als Schutzgut vor • Bundesimmissionsschutzgesetz • Bundesberggesetz • Kreislaufwirtschaftsgesetz / Deponieverordnung  Zudem werden in den Bundesländern regional von Fachbehörden (z.B. Geologischer Dienst) teilweise Karten besonders schutzwürdiger Böden erstellt, die umfassend auf die jeweilige Funktionserfüllung hinweisen. Auf Basis der Einordnung der Fachbehörden werden von den entsprechenden Plangebern Plankonzepte erarbeitet, die versuchen die Rohstoffgewinnung und die Bewertung der Bodenfunkton gemeinsam zu betrachten und in die Abwägung bei der Flächenausweisung einzubeziehen.   Der in der Roadmap genannten Moorschutz ist bereits über die FFH-Richtlinie umfassend geregelt und hat damit Eingang ins deutsche Recht gefunden. Abfallrechtliche Regelungen haben über das Abfallrahmenrichtlinienpaket in Gänze Eingang ins deutsche Gesetz, vor allem ins Kreislaufwirtschaftsgesetz und auch in die Deponieverordnung gefunden.   Aufgrund der über 300 verschiedenen Bodentypen in Europa und der daraus resultierenden großen nationalen Unterschiede ist es jedem Mitgliedstaat zu überlassen, individuelle Bodenschutzregelungen zu treffen. Zudem wollen wir darauf hinweisen, dass Kontaminationen des Bodens am wirkungsvollsten verhindert werden können, wenn die Ursachen am Ort der Entstehung verhindert werden. Dies gewährleistet das Bundesbodenschutzgesetz sowie eine Vielzahl weiterer Fachgesetze in Deutschland und in anderen Mitgliedstaaten.   Berlin, 08.12.2020 Feedback from: Bundesverband MIneralische Rohstoffe e.V. (MIRO) (124.9 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: As one of the stakeholders of the initiative “Healthy soils” and developing sustainable substrate materials technology ourselves, we welcome the new EU soil strategy roadmap and wish to form our opinion about it as follows. It’s important to consider this issue as comprehensively as possible, therefore there arises a need for pioneering new technologies and implementing them in a day-to-day choices. Various nature-based substrate substitutes and practices were explored for many years, but ecological effects have not improved much. The current soil quality situation requires a complex and bespoke technological approach to address it. It should build on already established knowledge about sustainable solutions in industries such as agriculture, horticulture, forest nurseries, potted plants and cut flowers production etc. and integrate it to formulate a universal one.  It should aim to remedy among others the issue of limiting the use of peat by introducing biodegradable waste (compost, biochar, wood fiber, plant fibre etc.) as sourcing material for the production of sustainable biodegradable substrates, instead of treating it as a biomass for energy generation (burning). Furthermore, it would be beneficial if it tackled the possibility of managing biodegradable waste, as a new fibrous feedstock, arising from agricultural / horticultural production or from manufacturing and handling in a wood-based industry.  It should also address the soil contamination problem by withdrawing or eliminating the use of harmful mediums (such as mineral wools or other inorganic material) which are used in horticulture. An improper disposal of such materials from horticulture to agriculture is a massive problem. The use of non-biodegradable mediums causes pollution of chemicals and plastic fragments accumulating in soils or rock-needles transferring into air by wind. There is a wide evidence of the fact that plant root systems can ingest microplastics and that they rise through plants to the fruits and vegetables that humans consume. Use of sustainable substitutes is needed to move forward towards less polluted soil and therefore its yield. One of the biggest threats is lack of awareness and minute willingness to switch to more planet-friendly agri or horticulture when the profit is at stake and some ways are embedded and repeated for years.  New technologies and breakthroughs in AgriTech and FoodTech need a vital support for the implementation therefore it is needed that modern cultivation solutions (such as hydroponics, aquaponics, vertical farms etc.), that will contribute to decreasing soil exploitation, are promoted and subsidized. However, such modern installations should not use peat as substrate and instead base on sustainable and eco-friendly mediums. Support from governing laws should assure that use of sustainable practices is rewarded and supported, while unsustainable ways are discouraged, mitigated or even banned.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: We welcome this initiative which is fundamental for the future of European agriculture.   This new communication should prioritize actions to improve soil health and in particular soil life. Thus, it should promote the adoption of sustainable soil management practices including the use of natural products for soil revitalization. It should also propose EU funding to implement those actions, stimulate innovation and increase knowledge about soil life (for example by strengthening research on the impact of soil microorganisms in the CIRCASA project).  The strategy should also pave the way for channeling private funding. Climate finance is a concrete solution to fund soil revitalisation actions with money from the private sector. This strategy should be ambitious in this regard and propose a European carbon credit framework for soil carbon. In addition to climate mitigation, soils can bring other benefits for water, biodiversity, food security … A European label for soil health (that could be used on food packaging for example) could be another way to value soil health and channel private funding.   Last, the EU should adopt a legislative framework on soil health. The renewal of this strategy could be the opportunity to re-start the legislative process on a possible framework Directive. It is urgent that the EU adopts at least political targets for soil improvement at the European Council and translates them  into regulatory binding targets and actions (ex: mandatory actions for soil biodiversity, soil organic matter minimum levels, …)  About Gaïago :  Gaïago is a company created in 2015 focused on providing innovative solutions - based on selective microbiology activation - to farmers, primarily on soil revitalization, but also around the Seed and the Plant. Putting the soil back at the heart of agriculture brings agronomic, economic and environmental benefits, including carbon sequestration. We bring a notion of global approach to agronomic ecosystems. As an expert in soil and plant prebiotics and probiotics, Gaïago supports the agro-ecological transition for all types of agriculture. Our solutions are referenced on 30 million hectares of arable land in the EU. For more information, please contact  charles.vaury@gaiago.eu or anais.maillet@gaiago.eu
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Hello. feedback_msg_text: • ELSA welcomes that the European Commission will revise the Thematic Strategy for Soil Protection and underlines the importance of soil as a limited resource. • ELSA sees numerous cross-links to European and international initiatives and agreements that should definitly be taken into account in the revision of the Thematic Strategy, such as Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), European Green Deal, EU Mission "Soil Health and Food", EU Biodiversity Strategy, etc. • ELSA stresses that cities, counties and municipalities are indispensable partners in soil protection and play a key role in the implementation at local and regional level. • Beyond a revision of the Thematic Strategy for Soil Protection, ELSA advocates a legally binding regulation on soil protection, e.g. in the form of an EU Soil Framework Directive. This should be developed in a broad-based process involving all stakeholders, especially landowners. • ELSA expressly emphasizes that soil protection cannot be carried out only locally, regionally or nationally. Climate protection/change, soil erosion, desertification, the protection of "good" soils for food security are European issues that must also be discussed and resolved at European level. This also includes uniform assessment standards for soil damage, so that a uniform approach is possible without distorting competition, as is also the case with the implementation of the Water Framework Directive and air pollution control.  About the objectives:  • Securing soil fertility and reducing soil erosion in order to preserve the soil as a valuable and indispensable basis for the production of food and feed, renewable raw materials, etc. in the sense of food security or food sovereignty. • Securing and increasing the humus content (Corg content) and protecting soils with a high Corg content (e.g. bogs) in order to maintain / expand the carbon storage "soil". • Reduction of land use for housing, roads, trade/industry on a European level, resulting in the destruction / removal of humus topsoil. • Adaptation of the management of agricultural soils to reduce the risk of erosion and to protect against desertification. • Creation of uniform standards (assessment, precautionary, test or limit values) as a benchmark for a common responsible approach to soil damage.
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: We have received the Roadmap towards the new Soil Thematic Strategy. This initiative, entitled “New Soil Strategy – healthy soil for a healthy life,” sets the aim of improving soil conservation at a European level. After reading through the strategy, we would like to recommend, on behalf of the Czech Society of Soil Science (CSSS), the inclusion of the following points:    - In part A of the document – Problem the initiative aims to tackle, we recommend: a) in relation to organic carbon stoks and the influence on soil diversity, the extent of these problems should be described, as is the case with other types of degradation. b) the description of types of soil degradation does not include soil compaction, which is also a serious problem on agricultural land.  - In the first point in part B, Step up efforts to protect soil fertility and reduce soil erosion, we recommend the inclusion of other types of soil degradation. - Part B also specifies how the stated aims can be achieved. In this respect, we consider it essential that the common agricultural policy looks towards upholding the principles of sustainable management of soil, which should be based on scientific research. This combination of sustainable agricultural management and soil conservation should be a fundamental condition for obtaining any subsidies whatsoever.  We are sure that the proposed initiative will help to protect the soil as the essential element of the environment it certainly is. With best regards  Prof. Bořivoj Šarapatka      Dr. Milan Sáňka    President of CSSS               CSSS Secretary
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Brussels environment salutes this very interesting initiative, which aligns with the SDGs and the Soil strategy we have been developing for Brussels. This is a necessary step for soil protection, seeing how quickly soils are being consumed and it might give member states the push and support needed to pursue their own policies for soil preservation and restoration.   Here are a few questions and remarks regarding this new STS: - Has there been an assessment of the results of the Strategy from 2006 and were the factors of success and failure identified? Correcting shortcomings and reinforcing achievements from the previous iteration seems an important first step for the upcoming strategy. - In addition to soil remediation, the focus should also be on a form of land management that takes soil quality into account to better correlate land use with soil quality. There needs to be a change in how we view soils. They are more than merely the damages they sustained, they represent opportunities and ecosystem services which need to be put to the forefront. - Another focus is that ‘soil’ as a thematic is very broad and transversal. This strategy would have an impact and be impacted by various plans, strategies, programs, policies, etc. in other thematics. - This strategy should also aim to improve knowledge of soils in the EU through research and studies. - The legal difficulties regarding land ownership should be taken into account in this strategy, as they might cause setbacks. - The ‘how’s of the strategy are still rather vague in the roadmap (milestones, concrete outcomes lack).  Suggestions to add to the STS - Urban soils: they present specific issues and suffer from a lack of knowledge (especially concerning artificialised or highly modified soils) while simultaneously being part of an urban system that has a major footprint on the environment relative to the surface area. Acting on these soils could thus have a very significant impact on climate. - Excavated soils: both for circularity and potentially as a base for restored soils - Compensation: this strategy could be an opportunity for exploring soil or soil quality compensation mechanisms on a larger scale than that of land ownership, where it is easier and more efficient to implement. - A benchmarking of existing soil strategies in and outside of the EU could be useful in developing the STS. - The training of the people who will effectively work on the strategy’s implementation is not to be neglected either. - A planning would be useful in understanding the different phases of the strategy. - Tools for decision-making and monitoring would also be useful in this strategy.   Sensibilisation aspects: - The strategy needs to give itself enough time for proper public consultation, as this is vital in gaining the engagement of not only the stakeholders but also of the general public. Public consultations for EU policies in general seem rather discreet, with few citizens taking interest in it. It could benefit from better and broader advertising. - Public consultation should also aim to gather information on the concrete needs and struggles of the stakeholders in order to better address them in the strategy. - To foster acceptance and commitment to the concepts that the soil strategy intends to promote, it is essential for the public to have access to practical tools they can use to understand their soil better. An example would be the Soil Quality Index developed by the Brussels Capital Region:  For professionals: http://agora.ibgebim.be/share/s/gIiRZtCgSSaDzyLY2PwISw  For citizens: http://agora.ibgebim.be/share/s/BcTHB3KSS-WQerylI6lc-Q
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: We strongly support this new strategy. On behalf of the ONF (National Forest Service of France), we would like to add some missing issues: -In the section A, subsection “Context”: Healthy soils are also key enabler to achieve sustainable bio-sourced materials systems. Sustainable supply systems of bio-sourced materials (both silvicultural and harvesting techniques preserving soil quality) are delivering valuables services like provision of renewable building materials, renewable energy, water purification and infiltration, carbon sequestration (in trees and bio-sourced materials), recreation, renewable clothing material (lyocell)...  -In the section A, subsection "Problem the initiative aims to tackle": increase in soil compaction, leading to agricultural (deep soil compaction) and silvicultural (area affected by rutting and compaction) productivity loss and flooding damage. (for example: agricultural soil compaction costs several hundred M€ per year for Sweden, Keller et al., 2019 : https://doi.org/10.1016/j.still.2019.104293; permanent skid trails implementation in forests in order to limit the area affected by compaction, Horn et al., 2007: doi:10.1016/j.foreco.2007.02.037).  -In the section A, subsection "Problem the initiative aims to tackle": increase in desertification risk as a result of climate change and inappropriate agricultural and silvicultural practices. For example, when harvesting declining trees due to climate change, little care to soil and vegetation may be given due to low price range for wood products. This can lead to bare soil exposure without viable tree regeneration and soil compaction during harvesting, both of them leading to increased soil erosion and desertification risk. -In the section B, objectives: step up efforts to reduce soil compaction -In the section B, By: Promoting the adoption of sustainable soil management practices by fostering a multi-uses and multi-functions vision of soils at a landscape level -In the section B, By: adapting and improving the relevant EU policy framework in line with sustainable bio-sourced materials systems
Initiative: Healthy soils – new EU soil strategy

feedback_msg_text: Nel 2009  L'Unione Europea ha messo in mora  il Governo Italiano  per non aver eseguito la VALUTAZIONE di IMPATTO AMBIENTALE sull’Area A1 del SITO di INTERESSE NAZIONALE ex A.C.N.A., considerata dalla stessa una discarica di rifiuti TOSSICO-NOCIVI.  OSSERVAZIONI - INFORMAZIONI SUL SITO EX A.C.N.A. DI CENGIO (SV)- AREA A1 La recente positiva VALUTAZIONE DI IMPATTO AMBIENTALE dell’Area A1 in base allo STUDIO DI IMPATTO AMBIENTALE effettuato  da E.N.I.- SYNDIAL su base volontaria e postuma (circa 20 anni dopo) e ufficializzata con il DECRETO MINISTERIALE 5 /4/ 2020 del 6 aprile 2020  (GAZZETTA UFFICIALE 20 APRILE 2020), ha fatto sì che  L’UNIONE EUROPEA abbia immediatamente archiviato (luglio 2020), dopo 11 anni, la procedura di infrazione nei confronti del nostro Governo, evitando le pesanti multe previste. L’Associazione per la Rinascita della Valle Bormida nasce nel 1987 ed ha sempre cercato di agire con serietà e rigore contribuendo così, in modo significativo, alla chiusura dello stabilimento A.C.N.A. in data 22-01-1999. Proprio per tutto ciò l’Associazione ritiene, in base al principio della massima precauzione e di opportune riflessioni, di sottoporre ai due Ministri firmatari del citato DECRETO MINISTERIALE,  SERGIO COSTA e  DARIO FRANCESCHINI le nostre documentate perplessità illustrate in un testo di 9 pagine supportato da 22 allegati. Il tutto è stato inviato con raccomandata A/R in data 1 settembre, ricevute dai destinatari il 7-9-2020 (la cartolina ci è giunta invece 45 giorni dopo, ovvero il 14-10-2020.  ABBIAMO COSI’ EVIDENZIATO  1- le contraddizioni che si rilevano nei documenti tecnici ufficiali  2 - le criticità relative allo strato di marna impermeabile che dovrebbe “naturalmente” impedire la fuoriuscita delle sostanze chimiche tossiche abbancate e del relativo percolato.  3 - L’incompleta tenuta dei muri perimetrali, ben documentata dal recente forte inquinamento rilevato ufficialmente dall’ARPAL,nei piezometri posti all’esterno dei muri.  4 - Il comprovato rischio idraulico dell’intero SITO DI INTERESSE NAZIONALE e quindi dell’AREA A1  5 - La presenza di POLICLOROBIFENILI, quindi elevato rischio di diossine, del resto ufficialmente trovate nel percolato liquido e nel terreno, inclusa AREA A1,con lo stabilimento ancora produttivo.  6 - L’incognita futura della manutenzione e dei controlli dell’intero Sito di Interesse Nazionale  Conclusioni: L'attuale messa in sicurezza permanente(Area A1) avallata dal DECRETO MINISTERIALE,  di permanente ha solo il rischio di disastro ambientale per  l’intera Val Bormida e le future generazioni.

feedback_msg_text: Comme nous l'avons écrit l'an dernier dans le document https://cnll.fr/media/ReponseCNLLconsultation__PacteProductifNumerique2019_Final.pdf ou il y a 8 ans dans https://cnll.fr/media/propositions_cnll_fleurpellerin.pdf  nous estimons indispensable de définir et de mettre en oeuvre une politique européenne de l'interopérabilité, notamment afin de permettre aux entreprises d'interopérer avec les systèmes d'information des administrations (y compris lors d'événements aussi triviaux, mais aussi aussi courants, que l'échanges de documents bureautiques en pièces-jointes, par exemple). Les standards ouverts devront systématiquement être imposés.  A cet égard, il est primordial de retenir une définition claire et forte des standards ouverts, afin d'éviter que des entreprises, en général non-européennes, en position dominante ne soient en position de tuer la concurrence de sociétés européenne.  Nous privilégions la définition de l'IDABC définie dans l'EIF (European Interoperability Framework) v1.0:  The following are the minimal characteristics that a specification and its attendant documents must have in order to be considered an open standard: - The standard is adopted and will be maintained by a not-for-profit organisation, and its ongoing development occurs on the basis of an open decision-making procedure available to all interested parties (consensus or majority decision etc.). - The standard has been published and the standard specification document is available either freely or at a nominal charge. It must be permissible to all to copy, distribute and use it for no fee or at a nominal fee. - The intellectual property - i.e. patents possibly present - of (parts of) the standard is made irrevocably available on a royalty free basis. - There are no constraints on the re-use of the standard.  Il est en particulier primordial, pour que la filière européenne du logiciel libre puisse implémenter librement les standards qui seront définis le cadre de l'EIF, que ceux-ci soit librement implémentables, et en particulier qu'ils ne soient pas soumis à des brevets, ou s'ils le sont, que ces brevets permettent à tout un chacun de réaliser des implémentation de manière libre et sans donner lieu à des redevances (i.e. "royalty free").  Nous réitérons nos observations passées (cf. https://cnll.fr/news/le-cnll-conseil-national-du-logiciel-libre-denonce-labandon-des-standards-ouverts-par-la/ ) que la v2 de l'EIF ne saurait être considérée à nos yeux comme un point de départ satisfaisant pour une politique européenne de l'interopérabilité, du fait notamment, que nous dénoncions il y a 10 ans, que l'expression "standard ouvert" n'y apparaît pas une seule fois.
Initiative: Interoperable digital public services – European Interoperability Framework evaluation & strategy

feedback_msg_text: To support the upcoming evaluation of the European Interoperability Framework (EIF), OpenForum Europe (OFE) is glad to contribute suggestions to improve this successful policy instrument.   The EIF is a highly relevant policy instrument providing the basis for interoperable, cross-border services, making a real world impact for citizens. The EIF has shown the EU can take the lead in shaping norms around the world, with the EIF v1 today still being used by many governments around the world.  Interoperability is not only important for the functioning of the public sector in normal times. Time and time again, during crises the need for interoperable public services has been proven. As we are seeing with COVID-tracking apps, interoperability is crucial to making national efforts part of a European response. A well established, easily implementable framework as a basis would give the European Commission an enhanced ability to be at the core of crisis mitigation in its core role of reducing barriers to cross-border services.  We thus suggest to strengthen the ambition of the EIF. With the digital transformation interoperability of government services and in general becomes more relevant than ever.  However, talking to public administrations implementing the EIF, either on the national level as National Interoperability Frameworks (NIFs) or on the local level, it is clear that the translation into concrete steps and thus the implementation is not always seen as straightforward.Supporting implementers with this process should be prioritised.  We encourage the Commission to evaluate the feasibility of the below suggested actions with the aim of increasing the impact of the EIF.  Firstly, where there is divergence between National Interoperability Frameworks the implementation of these NIFs toward the regional and local level has proven to be difficult. In addition, pilot or reference implementations on the city level could make implementation easier.  The next version of the EIF must advocate for codified design principles and encourage an API centric approach. Furthermore it should acknowledge the role of Open Source in today’s digital environment as outlined in the Commission’s recent Open Source Strategy. A definition that requires compatible licensing between standards and open source implementations would encourage the pragmatic rollout of interoperable services across Europe. To ensure the openness of services, any standard used in the context of the EIF should have at least one, though better multiple, Open Source implementations, this would also confirm that the standard is properly implementable. We encourage the European Commission to work closely with Open Source stakeholders, through its own new Open Source Programme Office, in achieving this.  Further, to support the actual interoperability of services, the EIF team could also facilitate so-called “Plugfests”, that would test and workshop interoperable services.  In addition, developing a process for assessing compliance with the EIF could encourage uptake. Having a way to signal what is an interoperable public service could provide an incentive to implementers, providing a strategic aim to deliver on their goals as well as supporting the interoperability between implementers. This could also foster an ecosystem around EIF implementation.  Finally we would like to acknowledge the achievements of the ISA program. By promoting the use of existing standards, and documenting tools and techniques for the design and implementation of interoperable solutions, ISA has made a significant impact.  We thank the European Commission for providing the opportunity to provide input into the review of the EIF and we remain eager to support the process.
Initiative: Interoperable digital public services – European Interoperability Framework evaluation & strategy

feedback_msg_text: The Interoperability Working Group of INATBA gathers expertise from a diverse range of stakeholders, which welcome the revision and evaluation of the EIF and under the broader scope of the ISA2 Programme.   Interoperability has never been as important as during this worldwide pandemic. The EIF is essential in providing the right instruments for blockchain to be an enabler during the current digital revolution. INATBA notes that many different applications fall within the scope of the EIF, specifically in regard to contactless payments, contact tracing and proof of location.  For the EIF to be successful, there is the need to have more awareness of the currently available tools for interoperable solutions provided by the ISA2 Programme. INATBA members have vast experience using the following tools: Galileo, EGNOS, EIRA (Gaia X Project), TOOP based on the once-only principle, the Once Only Initiative: Towards Cross-Border Connectivity.  Moreover, technical experimentation, training and support are needed when these tools are offered through open source models. As a unique focal point between the world of the industry, policy making and academy, INATBA is a platform which facilitates public private exchange and calls for the EU to create a joint project to accelerate the EIF leveraging INATBA’s platform.  The EIF includes 47 Recommendations, which follow 12 interoperability principles, that have the function to guide public and private parties in interoperability actions. Due to the non binding character of such principles European Member States do not implement the same recommendations at national level. This leads to fragmentation in the different levels of interoperability among the different member states. Recognising the consequences of such risks,  INATBA proposes to  convene all governments and stakeholders to foster the adoption of such guidelines and their transposition into national law.  Therefore, on the one hand INATBA requests more binding instruments or standards to facilitate interoperability solutions across member states. On the other hand, INATBA further requests to include specific reference to interoperability between blockchains.  INATBA calls for an immediate alignment of the 5 interoperability layers included by the EIF (Interoperability governance, Organisational, Integrated public service governance, Semantic interoperability, Legal interoperability, Technical interoperability) with those available in the WEF Toolkit (business model, platform, infrastructure). This will enable businesses to have consistent guidelines for interoperability, encouragement engagement and provide momentum for Europe to establish itself as a leading player for the benefit of the European Industry and European Citizens  Authors: The co-chairs of the Interoperability Working Group at INATBA and the INATBA Executive Director Marc Taverner.
Organisation: INATBA - International Association for Trusted Blockchain Applications
Initiative: Interoperable digital public services – European Interoperability Framework evaluation & strategy

feedback_msg_text: Challenges: In the various European countries there is a different speed of enforcement of eGovernment. These dif-ferences are related to general security concerns in digitalisation. Many citizens do not have so often to contact authorities for that digitalisation of public infrastructure can offer them a real advantage. The GDPR and other attempts by the EU to safeguard citizens’ rights have often led to the opposite, because the aspect of the convenience of citizens has not been taken into account. For example, those who have to click through cookie policies until they have reached a citizen-friendly portal setting, prefer to waive their civil rights and accept all cookies.  If the EIF is to be successful, it must set standards and technologies where officials and citizens see an ad-vantage for their convenience in the same way. Most cyber attacks are successful due to human failure. This failure is often due to the desire for convenience. It is more convenient to open every email than to consider whether you are allowed to open it. A communication infrastructure must be structured in such a way that it is an effort for every user to overcome IT security.  Proposal for a solution against the backdrop of an overall digitalisation strategy: Every official is also a citizen. If he has already become acquainted with an infrastructure/technology as a citizen, he will be able to use this competence as an official. Such eGovernment services will be accepted by citizens who use infrastructure/technology that citizens use in their daily lives and therefore know well. In the pre-digital world, it is natural for an official to carry his authority key and his apartment key with him on the same keychain. The principle of locking is the same. By using his key, he shows his legitimation. Nevertheless, the names of the key holder are not automatically communicated when unlocking. It is suffi-cient if the user can be identified in the event of unauthorised use of a key. In order to achieve interoperability, the human side of the human-technology interface must be designed as equal as possible for everyone. Unnoticed by the user, completely different concepts can be stored in the cloud or decentralised behind the same interface. Similar terminology in different EU languages should lead to the same standardised category. This will make it easier for EU citizens and public authorities to find together with the same concerns. In a second process, translation programs adapted to categories can remove language barriers. Due to the increasing dominance of foreign monopolists in both hardware and platform development, an unregulated open source standard must be rejected. An EU-source standard is proposed, which should only be available to European-dominated companies. Feedback from: GISAD i.G. (309 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Interoperable digital public services – European Interoperability Framework evaluation & strategy

feedback_msg_text: We ask to consider the following suggestions: Planting new trees should also take place in non-forest areas, especially along roads, in fields, between forest complexes, in rural areas, which will act as ecological corridors, will maintain connectivity between isolated forests. Planted trees in open areas will be source of seeds needed to natural succession. Apart of old growth and primeval forests (not much left in the Europe), should be protected mature and almost mature natural and semi-natural forests that appeared by natural succession and swampy, wet forests preserving water resources. Stable forests, prepared for challenges related to the climate, appearance of pathogens and invasive species  should have broad gene pool among tree populations. Foresters should use natural succession instead of plantations created from a limited number of parent trees are very susceptible to pathogens.  Size of the clear cuts should be limited.  Clear cuts should be replaced by small size logging, selective extraction. To reduce CO2 emissions and increase carbon sequestration, foresters should desist plowing, or should reduce plowing to the necessary minimum. To ensure protection of forest-related biodiversity EU members should approve conservation plans in Natura 2000 forest areas. Protection plans should have properly identified threats to protected species, habitats and adequate conservation measures.  In Poland many Natura 2000 sites, especially those covering old forests still do not have approved any documents related to Natura 2000 protection. Volume of dead wood should be increased, especially in countries where volume is very low e.g. Poland. Private forests and forests belonging to non-governmental organizations should be allowed to be protected because protection of private forest is not possible in Poland. Owners are obliged to follow forest management plans approved by authorities. Wood from forests must not be treated as a renewable energy source and used on a massive scale as an energy source. In some countries it is the main motivation for logging of valuable forests.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: NOAH-Friends of the Earth Denmark is a member of Global Forest Coalition and we support their submission (also attached here).  Coming from Denmark it is relevant to pinpoint bioenergy use as a certain threat to the forests, where Denmark plays a particularly destructive role.  In the EU, more than 60% of the renewable energy has come from biomass (mainly forest wood for electricity and heating, but also including biogas, biofuels and renewable waste). Looking at the renewable energy trajectory since 1990, the share of bioenergy has been more or less constant. In Denmark, the share is even larger than the EU average although we do not have much forest. Therefore, our country imports huge quantities of wood pellets from other European countries.  The use of bioenergy is undermining the urgent need to halt deforestation and restore the soil and plant systems as soon as possible. The removal of biomass for energy from the forests is ongoing and it will take decades, or even centuries, for the lost carbon to be re-captured by regrowth – if ever. If this practice continues, the EU is derailing its own commitments to stop runaway climate change and loss of biodiversity.  According to the European Commission’s own calculations and estimations, carbon stocks of European forests have fallen since 2010 and are expected to fall further due to, among other things, increased demand for biomass for energy. Forest management in several forest rich countries are even expected to become a source of emissions.   Healthy forests, wetlands, grasslands, coastal vegetation and farmland soils are essential carbon storage ecosystems needed to mitigate against runaway climate change. We only have a chance to reach the necessary climate goals if we, as a world community, understand and learn to restore these carbon stocks.   Therefore, to ensure the recovery of the European (and global) forests), it is of utmost importance that all incentives to use biomass for energy is removed. feedback_msg_text: Poland, Bystra 4.12.2020  Feedback on the Roadmap for the EU Forest Strategy.  Forests occupy approx. 43% of the European Union's area. After several decades of growth in recent years, the afforestation of Europe has stabilized (Forest Europe, 2015). However, the continent's stable forest cover does not fully reflect the state of European forests, the threats they are exposed to nor the challenges they face. The ongoing climatic and environmental catastrophe, manifested among other things by the increase in average surface temperatures (IPCC, 2018) and the unprecedented rate of biodiversity loss (IPBES, 2019), make it necessary to rethink the way natural resources have been managed throughout Europe. Effective protection of forest ecosystems, particularly important for the protection of biodiversity as well as carbon fixation and storage, is a key action that will allow the EU to face this crisis (IPCC, 2019). What is more, the desire of the citizens of the EU’s Member States to protect forests with important social functions is becoming increasingly apparent. Meanwhile, in recent years, we can observe an alarming trend of intensified logging on the EU scale. The total harvested forest area, the average patch size of the harvested area and the biomass loss in European forests are increasing. As a result, the amount of carbon stored in forest ecosystems decreases contributing to a significant reduction of the EU's carbon budget (Ceccherini et al., 2020). Even the last remaining parts of primary forests in Europe, which currently constitute only 0.7% of the EU's forest area, are under pressure of wood extraction. Although 89% of them are protected, only less than half strictly (Sabatini et al., 2018). In Romania, where a significant part of the preserved EU’s primary forests is located, they are cut down even in protected areas (Sabatini et al., 2020). In 2017, the violation of the Birds and Habitat Directives due to logging in the Białowieża Primeval Forest (Mikusiński et al., 2018) - the last relatively big complex of lowland forests in Europe with a large proportion of natural forest stands (Jaroszewicz et al., 2019) - was echoed throughout the world’s media. In addition to anthropogenic factors, European forests are threatened by changing climatic conditions (Dyderski et al., 2018) and disturbances related to them such as insect gradations (Pureswaran et al., 2018), fires (de Rigo et al., 2017) or hurricanes (Gregow et al., 2017). All abovementioned facts indicate the need to change the model of forest management in the European Union. The new model should take into account the role of forests in facing global environmental changes and the growing demand for social functions performed by them. Therefore, it should prioritize social, protection and regulatory functions while ensuring also the fulfilment of the necessary economic ones. Economic and legislative factors are the main drivers of the progressive intensification of wood extraction in the EU - namely increased demand for wood, as well as the introduction of the new Renewable Energy Directive (Searchinger et al., 2018), (Ceccherini et al., 2020). This shows how much political decisions can impact forest conservation issues. It also gives hope that the new European Forest Strategy can be a tool for so much needed change. Due to the urgency of the problem, it should be implemented without unnecessary delay. Below we present our postulates concerning the EU Forest Strategy together with their justifications.  Detailed position in the attached file.  Feedback from: Pracownia na rzecz Wszystkich Istot (220.5 KB - PDF - 10 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: - the priority objective of the strategy: conservation and restoration of forests as a complex and vulnerable ecosystem with diverse structure, conserving their ecological and functional elements, unity and microclimate, emphasizing the important and not replaceable role of forests, economical use needs to subordinate to the primary objective  - synergies with other EU initiatives and strategies: the new EU Forest Strategy should be in line with the targets of the European Green Deal, the Biodiversity Strategy and the Farm to Fork Strategy without overriding their ambitions, need to effectively contribute to tackling climate change and biodiversity loss, must be an additional tool which can significantly assist in the implementation of existing obligations  - content of the strategy:   o well-defined, measurable targets and tools for implementation:  significantly develop the management of existing forests and increase the area with sustainable management practices which support natural processes in the forest ecosystems and focusing on the long-term sustainability and resilience, need to increase the mature age of the existing forests;  allocating much more efforts (human and financial sources) to preserve key habitats and species;  mapping and monitoring of existing primary growth and old forest, and ensure their special protection, forbid all interventions which not directly support the conservation objectives;  establishment of new forest and planting trees should be implemented along the ecological and conservation aspects, must be guaranteed that planting of trees will not result plantations with low naturalness (selection of tree species and planting design is important) and the new afforestation will not threaten and transform other biodiverse ecosystems such as grasslands (selection of appropriate places)   o to strengthen the financial tools, make strong expectations against CAP reform

feedback_msg_text: The Interreg CENTRAL EUROPE BEECH POWER project welcomes the EU´s goal to adopt a Forest Strategy that accounts for the immense importance and benefits that forests have, especially in a future dominated by climate change. We agree that there is “a need for a comprehensive strategy to ensure that forests are addressed in a consistent manner across the different policies”. Old-growth forests take an outstanding role in this as they provide a plethora of ecosystem services that are invaluable for our wellbeing. Therefore, it is crucial to protect existent old-growth forests and extend protected forests as promised in the EU Biodiversity Strategy. Nevertheless, old-growth forests, including beech forests that are some of Europe´s most iconic heritage, come under increasing pressure by insufficient protection and a lack of ecosystem-based management.  Hence, the new EU Forest Strategy must not only demand the protection of the last remaining primary and old-growth forests, but it must define in clear terms how this protection can be achieved. While the roadmap mentions international commitments of the EU, it does not consider current tools, as e.g. the UNESCO World Heritage and Natura 2000, which already protect old-growth forests, but often require more effective management.  BEECH POWER aims to improve the integrated management of selected component parts of the transnational serial UNESCO World Natural Heritage property ‘Ancient and Primeval Beech Forests of the Carpathians and Other Regions of Europe‘. This objective is to be achieved by increasing the involvement of stakeholders and public authorities in management, integrating the component parts in regional sustainable development planning.   Beech forests provide home to a great biodiversity. They are our shared heritage and deserve transnational care. Accordingly, the BEECH POWER project recommends that the EU Forest Strategy will include the following points in line with the aims of the project: - Utilize UNESCO World Heritage sites and other existing  tools and protected area networks to secure the protection of old-growth forests, also in the regional surrounding of respective sites. - Promote old-growth forest conservation as part of an ecosystem-based sustainable development. - Emphazie the importance of regulating services of forest ecosystems (e.g. buffering of extreme temperatures) in the context of climate change. - Prioritize the protection of the microclimate in forests and the preservation and promotion of water-storing structures and soils. - Emphasize the uniqueness and worth of endemic old-growth beech forests. - Improve transboundary cooperation in the field of forest protection with trans-sectional and practical tools. - Promote an ecosystem-based sustainable forest management approach. - Bear in mind not only the importance of forests for a sustainable economy, but also their benefits for local communities and human wellbeing - Focus on the education of the young generation by promoting the benefits of forests, especially old-growth forests in the context of the ecosystem services they provide. - Include stakeholders into processes, which support managers in consensus-based decision-making. feedback_msg_text: Biodiversity should be the core priority of EU Forest Strategy. It is necessary to ensure high ambition of the EU and Member States as well as to mobilise all efforts to safeguard the biodiversity and all the ecosystem services it provides.   The EU Forest Strategy seeks to balance the need to increase forest protection and restoration efforts with different socioeconomic interests related to forests. Today, EU actively supports incentives schemes and practices that cause biodiversity degradation. Related policies in the EU Forest Strategy, both on EU and national level, must be fully compliant with the goals of the Biodiversity Strategy, the Convention on Biodiversity (CBD) and the Paris Agreement. In order to meet these goals, forestry sector interests should be completely disconnected from the EU Forest Strategy. Moreover, the EU Birds and Habitats Directives need to be fully implemented in all Member States in order to ensure the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora.  EU policy need to be based on the precautionary principle and take preventive action. We do not have full knowledge and understanding of the complexity of ecological processes and the long-term changes and effects of our actions. Scientific uncertainty should not be a justification for inaction when there is potential for serious harm. The principle must have its starting point in ecological systems and conditions.  The EU Forest Strategy will foresee measures to avoid or correct unsustainable practices. In order to do so, the EU needs to clearly define terms for so called ‘sustainable’ forestry practices, which consider the socio-ecological policies that operate within the planetary boundaries for biodiversity. Today, arbitrary and vague definitions of the word ‘sustainable’ promote clear-cutting practices and increased expansion of tree plantations, which harm the biodiversity and offset greenhouse gases.    In order to ensure a sustainable management of all forests, clear-cutting practices should be banned completely in the EU. Instead, a nature-oriented and continuous cover forestry should be fully supported in forest areas without high conservation values in order to cause less detrimental effects on biodiversity and ecosystem services, and to minimize the release of greenhouse gases. Also, a sustainable forest management option should include strict forest protection.  Protect the Forest agrees that the last remaining primary and old-growth forests in the EU need to be strictly protected. A minimum of 30 % of the forests in the EU should be protected. Commercial logging should be strictly forbidden in all remaining high conservation value forests, all nature reserves and other formally protected areas, Natura2000 areas, ICCAs (Indigenous Peoples and community conserved territories and areas), and all forest habitat types that do not A minimum of 30 % of the forests in the EU should be protected. Commercial logging should be strictly forbidden in all remaining high conservation value forests, all nature reserves and other formally protected areas, Natura2000 areas, ICCAs (Indigenous Peoples and community conserved territories and areas), and all forest habitat types that do not have a favorable conservation status under the EU Habitats Directive. The ban needs to be strictly enforced and also monitored, if possible. The EU should completely stop giving financial and policy support to commercial logging.   All protection and restoration targets must respect human rights, including ICCAs and the rights of the Sami people.   The EU should end its funding and support for monocultures and even-aged tree plantations, which are poor of species, instead of favoring natural regeneration.   To enhance prevention of disaster risk events and of damages, the EU needs to favor mixed forests with a greater proportion of deciduous trees and promote natural regeneration. feedback_msg_text: Our Association, Chemin Faisant, explores multiples ways to live on our Planet.  We are going through difficult times and this situation of crisis, due, among other things, to climate change and destruction of ecosystems, lead us to the urge of expressing ourselves and act.  We are sure that the EU will have the ambition and take the time to listen to all stakeholders and will take particular attention to choices regarding our forest. Forests have a capital impact on our survival and on the survival of life on the planet.  You are perfectly aware of the total interdependance of all living beings on earth and of the utmost importance of transforming our relationship with all living beings.  We ask you that existing natural forests are identified, counted, respected and strictly preserved with their ecosystem because they: - Stock carbon dioxide - Nest biodiversity (fauna et flora) - Protect and filter water - Regenerate the air we need to live - Protect the land guaranteeing its stability - Highly contribute to reducing climate change, lowering temperature - Offer all sort of resources, inspiration, learnings and sharing with other living beings. Industrialized forests popping-up so quickly in France, are not an answer to the above but respond to other economic needs.  Strict protection of existing natural forests is, as consequence, absolute necessity in parallel of the industrialized part.  We strongly recommend that people living nearby forests should be consulted to make sure that they can bring their contribution to this important subject.  We also recommend that our rangers, who protect our forests, are also valued, respected and protected.  We are confident that the EU will listen to our proposals keeping firmly in mind the future of our Planet.  Thank you

feedback_msg_text: La politica forestale della UE risente delle decisioni assunte al momento della firma del Trattato di Roma del 1957, allorché il settore forestale, valutato allora da un punto di vista squisitamente economico, fu completamente trascurato in ragione della valenza strategica attribuita in quel momento alle energie fossili. Le foreste in Europa, oggi, alla luce della superficie interessata (oltre il 40%) e delle plurime valenze ambientali, economiche e sociali assolte, sono al centro di una rinnovata attenzione da parte delle istituzioni comunitarie, al punto che lo stesso Green Deal, dedica massima attenzione al tema delle funzioni degli ecosistemi forestali ed alla definizione di una nuova strategia forestale. Elemento centrale è divenuta la Gestione Forestale Sostenibile (GFS), così definita in quanto in grado di svolgere rilevanti funzioni ecologiche, economiche e sociali e di garantirle nel tempo per le future generazioni a livello locale e globale. Riteniamo che proprio la GFS necessiti di un maggiore approfondimento per evitare approcci fin troppo generici da cui si possono generare conflitti e fraintendimenti. Il bosco, oltre alla produzione di legna, contribuisce alla mitigazione del clima ed allo stoccaggio del carbonio, al miglioramento della qualità dell’aria e delle acque, alla salvaguardia della natura e della biodiversità, alla protezione idrogeologica, alla caratterizzazione del paesaggio, al miglioramento della qualità della vita e del benessere delle comunità; il bosco è anche una importante risorsa rinnovabile che può alimentare circuiti virtuosi di bioenergia (ben vengano gli impianti di cogenerazione a dimensione locale con utilizzo di scarti di segherie o legna prodotta localmente, ma si evitino i sostegni alle grandi centrali elettriche da alimentare con biomasse e decentrate sul territorio perché hanno rendimenti bassi se non sono in assetto cogenerativo risultando, quindi, inefficienti e ad elevato impatto ambientale) e di bioeconomia circolare con particolare riferimento alle zone rurali. Una lungimirante strategia dovrebbe ricercare il giusto equilibrio tra gli elementi sopra elencati, avendo inoltre un riferimento fondamentale nel quadro globale, ove le risorse forestali appaiono in forte diminuzione e degradazione in molti paesi in via di sviluppo, mentre sono in marcato aumento nei paesi occidentali, Europa compresa. Quest’ultimo aspetto impone una riflessione sulla opportunità di un utilizzo sostenibile delle risorse forestali del nostro continente proprio per non contribuire ad alimentare la distruzione a carico anche di foreste primarie in particolare nel Sud America, nell’Africa centro-meridionale e in Indonesia (vedi grafici e diagrammi al seguente link: https://blogs.worldbank.org/opendata/five-forest-figures-international-day-forests  ), ove spesso si cercano nuove terre per l’agricoltura. Di qui la necessità di rafforzare le azioni di sensibilizzazione dei cittadini a consumare prodotti provenienti da catene di approvvigionamento a deforestazione zero, vale a dire che non causino deforestazione né direttamente né indirettamente (deforestazione indotta). C’è necessità di una incisiva e diffusa azione di sensibilizzazione sulle caratteristiche della GFS e sulle possibilità di utilizzo delle risorse forestali migliorandone nel tempo il loro grado di efficienza funzionale e di multidisciplinarietà. La maggiore rilevanza del settore forestale nelle politiche europee dovrà affrontare in modo ancora più incisivo i temi del loro degrado a seguito degli incendi, dei cambiamenti climatici e di possibili patogeni. Andranno potenziate conseguentemente le attività di ricerca ed introdotte forme di innovazione in grado di monitorare lo stato di salute e di uso degli ecosistemi forestali, in un’ottica di maggiore coinvolgimento e collaborazione tra gli stati membri che troppo spesso procedono con proprie strategie anche in relazione alla notevole eterogeneità presente all’interno della UE.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: “Sustainable management of all EU forests” means that their function as carbon sink is prioritized. The idea of sustainability implies not impeding future generations’ possibilities to meet their needs. Today, when the carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere is already far above the safe and sustainable level, any activity that releases more carbon dioxide is unsustainable by definition.  The forest strategy has to explicitly prioritize the carbon sink. Replacing a lost sink is much more difficult than lowering emissions. In fact, it might not be possible.   There is a need for financial incentives to encourage forest owners to manage their forests in such a way that carbon sequestration is maximised. Among other things, this means that clear-cutting should be avoided as it releases more carbon into the atmosphere than selection cutting.   There are no gains to be made by substitution of fossil-based products with biobased products. Both result in carbon dioxide emissions, and all fuels can be phased out effectively by a rising price on emissions.  The best way to reduce emissions is Carbon Fee and Dividend, a steadily rising price on all climate disruptive fuels, fossil as well as biofuels. To ensure acceptance from the general public revenues from the Fee should be distributed as direct uniform payments (dividends, also known as “climate income”) to households.   Biofuels from forests must be included in the taxed energy sources since:   - Trees sequester carbon dioxide. When trees are cut down this sequestration ceases and therefore the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere rises.  - When the trees are burned – as they soon are as paper, pellets or other forms of biofuels – levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide will of course rise even more.   For references see attached file. Feedback from: Klimatsvaret – CCL Sverige (119 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Today’s forestry in northern Europe have developed out of at the ecological disaster of the Middle ages, where the original forests were over-exploited. A period of trial and error commenced with different forest owners adopting different management methods and approaches. These methods are still being used and parallel to each other: Natural regeneration is used as well as plantings and sowings depending of the situation. Some are thinning their stand lightly, others some heavily. A variety of species are used – native as well as exotic species. You will see stands of single species as well as mixtures. Because of the very different growing and climatic conditions the variation of the forests is great. As the forest are placed where nothing better is possible the forest includes areas of low productivity but with importance for the biodiversity. With a wide variety of different forest owners and managers it guarantees a high diversity in approached and management of forests. The character of the northern European forests imply that they are well adapted to meet the multiple challenges of the future demands of the European forest:  :  • The demands of the world market for tree products will multiply 3 – 4 times in the next 30-40 years. With a net deficit of home-grown timber in Europe this emphasize the importance of increasing the EU-grown tree production. • At the same time the climate problems call for increased tree production. Tree production and the use of tree products to substitute fossil products is the most powerful and economic tool to reduce the atmospheric CO2. • The endangered species calls for methods which - at the same time as increasing the tree production – can meet this challenge. The mosaic structure of the northern European forest is the best tool we have to cope with this. • The need of recreation has as well to be solved. Here the forest of northern Europe can meet this demand. • At the time the need for clean drinking-water, O2  and other services can be met by the mosaic structured forest. The new EU forest policy needs to include a number of factors: - The main driving factor behind a multifunctional forest is the forest owner. The strategy needs to fully recognize their vital importance. - The EU has a plurality of forest ecosystems, reflecting their bio-geo-climatic diversity, and for this reason their management has always been subject to Member States’ competence through national or regional legislations. This needs to remain as well.  - The forest has vital functions for creating jobs, prosperity, multi-functionality etc. It is too important to be subordinated other policies. It must therefore remain a free-standing policy.   - The potential of the substitution effect from the use of forest products instead of fossil fuel is massive. The policy can promote the use of forest products to substitute fossil ones.  - We need actively managed and used forest in order to have access to raw material for a growing circular bioeconomy. The strategy should promote R&D within this field  - Economic and social considerations need to be the forerunners in the policy. The bioeconomy is crucial for sustaining sustainable livelihood in rural areas. A functional bioeconomy is crucial for ensuring that the forest owners can invest in biodiversity. Bioeconomy thus has a key role in ensuring the Green Deal.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sir and Madam, BUND (Friends of the Earth Germany) welcomes the upcoming EU Forest Strategy with its objectives of forest preservation, restoration and biodiversity friendly afforestation. We see compliance with the EU Biodiversity Strategy crucial for the EU Forest Strategy. Thuas, the European Commission should adopt an EU Forest Strategy that builds upon and directly contributes to the implementation of the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy for 2030. The targets and commitments of the strategy must be clear, measurable and lead to timely improvements given the urgency of the climate and biodiversity crisis.  Key objectives of the Strategy should be the protection and restoration of forests, while recognising the important role forests can play in tackling the biodiversity and climate crisis. The implementation and enforcement of existing obligations, such as the Birds and Habitats Directives, must be stepped up significantly, including by allocating more capacity and resources to protect key habitats and species as well as the rule of law. The management of existing protected areas must be improved to bring biodiversity back to forests across the EU. Existing primary and old-growth forests need to be defined, mapped and monitored for their strict protection. Criteria for strict protection should be aligned with the IUCN categories I and II and should focus primarily on non-intervention management and the protection of large-scale natural processes, excluding all extractive and habitat-altering activities, including logging.  Furthermore, any kind of tree planting must ensure the full respect of ecological principles to avoid the wrong trees being planted in the wrong places and to prevent monocultural plantations. Tree planting holds particular potential for urban and peri-urban areas, providing also climate adaptation and wellbeing benefits. In addition, it must be ensured that these additional trees are not subject to logging in the near future so that they do provide the foreseen long-term biodiversity and climate benefits.   The use of wood use is not climate neutral: burning wood releases carbon dioxide that would otherwise be captured in the forest and it is less effective for energy production than other resources. Wood biomass use is not climate neutral and has not “a low environmental impact”. It is essential that the growing interest in using forests as carbon sinks does not lead to monoculture plantations that will then be logged for commercial purposes or to the afforestation of healthy, biodiverse and carbon-storing ecosystems such as grasslands or wetlands. Instead, existing old-growth, primary and biodiverse forests must be protected, others must be left to mature to old-growth and diverse forests, while the management of all forests must be improved to focus on the long-term sustainability and ecological resilience thereof. In addition, other ecosystems, such as peatlands that store significant amounts of carbon, must also be protected and restored. The Forest Strategy should support and enable synergies with the upcoming legal instrument on the restoration of ecosystems important for biodiversity and climate. Restoration and conservation activities also provide broader social and economic benefits, including through the creation of sustainable jobs, significant investment returns through inter alia health, wellbeing and recreation benefits, while being crucial cost-effective solutions to the climate and biodiversity crisis.  The new Forest Strategy should follow the paradigm ‘All forest management activities should harm the forest ecosystem as little as possible’: It needs to contribute to habitat restoration. It needs to stabilize or improve thermoregulation, water cycle and water supply. For that, increasing native deciduous trees areas, less timber use, more deadwood, no drainage, no use of tree species that have a negative impact on the microclimate (e.g. Eucalyptus, Pinus replacing deciduous forests) is
Organisation: BUND - Friends of the Earth Germany
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Latvian Forest Owners' Association would like emphasize the important role of 16 million European citizens that are responsible for forest management in Europe. Until now they have been successfully contributing to the wellbeing of European forests, economy and citizens. It requires knowledge, resources and motivation to do the work in forests to provide renewable resources and biodiversity, manage this important resource so that European community can keep benefiting from this land use. We expect that European Commission recognize this contribution and reflect it in the upcoming Forest Strategy with clear guidelines of how MANAGED forests as land use contribute to achieving EC policies' goals - Climate, RED, Bioeconomy, Climate adaptation, Water quality, Biodiversity. One of these goals can not be set as the leading one for multifunctional forestry. In the North of Europe forestry is not short rotation, it takes decades to grow the trees at same time providing for biodiversity. We expect EC to work for its citizens and see processes in Europe as well regulated, responsible and sustainable. We expect clear guidlines in Forest Strategy on how to make our forests more productive, resilient to climate change, able to provide renewable material for Europeans needs of economy transition in line of Green Deal goals. We expect relevant measures to be reflected in CAP, and other instruments to contribute to Forest Strategy goals that should reflect the benefits of multifunctional and sustaianble forest management.
