feedback_msg_text: We welcome EU initiatives calling for European forests protection We kindly ask to consider the following suggestions and aspects: 1)The planned planting of 3 billion trees will certainly contribute to carbon sequestration, but preserving mature forests should be a priority in the Forest Strategy. We understand the need of reforestation, but afforestation should be a priority because old forests are refugee of rare species and are also more efficient as a CO2 stores. 2) Apart of old growth and primeval forests [not much left in the EU], the following forests should be protected: - natural and semi-natural that appeared by natural succession; -  wet forests preserving water resources; 3) Preparing forests for climate change and other challenges related to the appearance of pathogens and invasive species Strategy should include: - increasing the gene pool of tree populations, greater use of natural succession; plantations created from a limited number of parent trees are very susceptible to pathogens; - limiting areas and size of the clear cuts, possibly replacing the clear cuts by small size logging, selective extraction; 4) In order to reduce CO2 emissions and increase carbon sequestration, foresters should desist plowing, or reduce plowing to the necessary minimum; 5) Strengthen protection of forest-related biodiversity through: - approval of conservation plans in Natura 2000 forest areas. Protection plans should have properly identified threats to protected species, habitats and adequate conservation measures. Contents of the plans - especially those related to passive protection, retention and elimination of invasive species should be consistently applied; Comment:  In Poland many Natura 2000 sites, especially those covering old forests: PLB280006 Puszcza Borecka, Ostoja Borecka PLH 280016 or Bieszczady PLC180001 in the Carpathians  (the most important national refuge of such species as Ursus arctos, Rosalia alpine) still do not have approved any documents related to Natura 2000 protection. - supplementing the Standard Data Forms with current data related to protected species; - habitat’s protection of old growth forest species which are not included in the annexes of EU Directives, but endangered - listed in red lists, and red books ; - increasing the volume of dead wood, especially in countries where volume is very low; - eliminating forest practices that act as ecological traps for some protected species ; 6) Planting new trees should also take place in non-forest areas, especially along linear infrastructure, in fields, between forest complexes, rural areas, which will act as ecological corridors and help to maintain connectivity between isolated forest complexes; 7) Private forests and forests belonging to non-governmental organizations should be allowed to be protected; Comment: Private forest protection is not possible in Poland. Owners are obliged follow forest management plans approved by authorities and/or State Forest; 8) Europe must not give in to pressure by biomass producers. Wood from forests must not be treated as a renewable energy source and used on a massive scale as an energy source. In some countries it is the main motive for logging valuable forests.  Adam Bohdan Wild Poland Foundation ; adam.bohdan@wp.pl Feedback from: Wild Poland Foundation (44.4 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The National Wildlife Federation appreciates the opportunity to provide feedback on the EU’s proposal to prepare a new EU Forest Strategy in order to support climate change mitigation through enhanced carbon storage and sequestration.   If one of the objectives of the Forest Strategy is to “preserve stocks and increase EU carbon sinks in forests, their soils, and harvested wood products,” we urge the Commission to consider the ways that rising adoption of woody bioenergy will directly affect both stocks and sinks. According to the EU 2016 reference scenario forecasts, the net forest sink could decrease by 25% compared to early 2000’s levels (European Commission, 2016). In particular, managed forest sinks are forecast to show sharp declines (from around –350 CO2e in 2005 to around –150 Mt CO2e in 2050), due largely to the plateauing growth rates of trees in the EU’s aging managed forests but also to economic and harvest pressures “mainly driven by increasing biomass demand for energy production” until 2030 (projected to increase from 516 million m3 in 2005 to 565 million m3 by 2030; European Commission, 2016). The appetite for woody bioenergy, whetted by the perception of carbon neutrality and both direct and indirect subsidies by MS governments, continues to grow.  Research from Europe suggests intensified biomass production may impair the ability of forests to provide other ecosystem services (Verkerk et al. 2014). By encouraging intensified collection of residues, shortened rotation cycles, and collection of previously non-merchantable timber, bioenergy harvests may reduce the capacity of forests to maintain their carbon stores and even reduce their productivity in some contexts (e.g., Walmsley et al. 2009; Thiffault et al. 2011). Use of trees for bioenergy also precludes any storage of carbon in harvested woody products—instead, the carbon is instantly released to the atmosphere. It takes decades to centuries--depending on the feedstock and harvesting methods--for forests to reabsorb that carbon (Buchholz et al. 2016), and bioenergy releases more emissions per unit of energy generated than natural gas or coal (IPCC, 2006). For these reasons, experts from the European Academies Science Advisory Council reported that the "inevitable" initial impact of transitioning from coal to forest biomass would be an increase in atmospheric carbon levels (EASAC, 2017).   The Roadmap itself identifies the “increasing management intensity due to rising demand for wood, forest products and energy” as a “pressure” on Europe’s forest ecosystems. In conclusion, in creating a new Forest Strategy, the EU should carefully consider the effects of bioenergy on the ability of forests to help to mitigate climate change. feedback_msg_text: Wir unterstützen:  Notwendigkeit einer umfassenden EUFS sicherzustellen, dass die Wälder in den verschiedenen Politikbereichen einheitlich behandelt werden, EUFS baut auf einer dynamischen nachhaltigen Waldbewirtschaftung auf EUFS fördert die  Anpassung der Wälder an den Klimawandel und die Stärkung ihrer Widerstandsfähigkeit  EUFS hat eine starke wirtschaftliche Dimension EUFS ist ein wichtiger Grundstein für für Innovation und Förderung neuer Holz-Produkte für den Ersatz die fossile Materialien EUFS legt einen Schwerpunkt auf  Ausbildung, Befähigung und Jobs in der Waldbewirtschaftung EUFS fördert innovative finanzielle Anreize EUFS betont die Wichtigkeit einer effektiven Waldüberwachung.  Hauptziele Aufforstung, Wiederherstellung und Erhaltung: Die  Ziele sind  zu begrenzt und spiegeln weder das Gesamtbild der vielen Herausforderungen für die EU-Wälder noch das volle Potenzial der Ökosystemleistungen wider, die der Wald bereits für die Gesellschaft bietet. EUFS muss einen kohärenten Ansatz zwischen der in der Roadmap geforderten Innenpolitik der EU gewährleisten Es fehlt die Berücksichtigung  des dynamischen SFM-Rahmens.   Wichtige fehlende Elemente: Die EUFS sollte das zentrale Element sein, damit die Politik zur Beeinflussung der Wälder in die gleiche Richtung funktioniert. Sie soll Rahmenbedingungen schaffen für die Umsetzung nachhaltiger Waldbewirtschaftung auf nationaler Ebene, die weiterhin nationale Zuständigkeit ist. Die Rechtsgrundlage für so viele verschiedene Ziele ist unklar. In dem „Problem, mit dem sich die Initiative befassen soll“ wird in der Roadmap nicht direkt auf Wälder als Holzproduzenten hingewiesen, der der klimafreundlichste Rohstoff ist. SFM in Europa soll auf der Arbeit von Forest Europe aufbauen.Es braucht den Verweis auf die Definition, Kriterien und Grundsätze von Forest Europe SFM. Es wird nicht hervorgehoben, wie wichtig es ist, die Motivation der Waldbesitzer und -verwalter zu erhalten und zu stärken, ihre Wälder weiter zu bewirtschaften. Es wird auch nicht auf die Notwendigkeit eingegangen, an der Umsetzung der Honorierung von Ökosystemleistungen (PES) zu arbeiten und Fortschritte zu erzielen, insbesondere im Bereich des Klimaschutzes und wenn SFM politischen Beschränkungen unterliegt. Schließlich sollte das Risikomanagement in die Bewirtschaftung der Waldflächen einbezogen werden.  Notwendige Klarstellungen: - Starke Bedenken gegnüber der Forderung, „Maßnahmen zur Vermeidung oder Korrektur nicht nachhaltiger Praktiken vorzusehen“, die implizieren, dass Wälder nicht nachhaltig bewirtschaftet werden. - Wir verstehen die Forderung, den Verlust der Waldbedeckung zu verringern, nicht, da Waldflächen in der EU seit Jahrzehnten zunehmen - Es sollte eine Definition der „letzten verbleibenden Primär- und Altwälder, die möglicherweise strengen Schutz benötigen“ geben  Wir unterstützen die Ansichten des Europäischen Parlaments und der Mitgliedstaaten Wir fordern die Kommission auf, auf den Schlussfolgerungen des Rates (11. November 2020) der Entschließung des Europäischen Parlaments (8. Oktober 2020) aufzubauen. Beide Institutionen fordern einen ganzheitlichen Ansatz, um Wälder und ihre Multifunktionalität anzugehen, auf SFM im Sinne von Forest Europe aufzubauen und die Kompetenzverteilung zwischen der EU und den Mitgliedstaaten zu respektieren. feedback_msg_text: 1) The goals of the Forest Strategy can be best achieved through non-intervention areas and reassessed sustainable forest management in managed forests. Forest strategy should encompass the application of non-intervention principle in a certain proportion (up to 20%) of European forests, to replace intensive management practices by reassessed long-term sustainable forest management, and the regional, environmental, social, cultural and economic importance of forests. Let forest to flourish and regenerate! Please note, this demand is compatible with the goals of the Biodiversity Strategy, which states "10% of the land are must be strictly protected". Therefore, it is of great importance not to "dilute" the very term "strict protection" and to understand it as close as a non-intervention principle.   2) Almost all primary old-growth forest in Europe has been lost; therefore, the protection of the remaining old growth forest is a must; even if individual trees gradually slow their absorption rate, “mature” forests continue removing and cumulating carbon from the atmosphere, including through forest soil.  3) Maintaining old forests is much more important than planting new ones. It must be clearly stated in the Strategy.  4) All master plans of forests Enterprises (especially those belonging to the member states) must be actionable. The citizens must have their say during REAL, not faked, consultations.  4) Burning wood is definitely NOT any kind of pro-climate activity. Burning biomass emits CO2 to the atmosphere, just as burning fossil fuels does.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: While supporting some of its aims, as Global Forest Coalition and Biofuelwatch we strongly question the basic assumptions behind this new EU Forest Strategy, which seems to be inspired by the aim to support the European forestry industry rather than a desire to align the forest policy of the EU and its member states with the Convention on Biodiversity (CBD), the EU Green Deal, EU Nature Directives, Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15.2 and the EU Biodiversity Strategy. The proposed consultations should be free from conflicts of interests and other forms of corporate capture, especially by the forestry industry and other commercial interests, such as those of energy companies investing in biomass.  The draft rightly identifies the worsening overexploitation of due to the rising demand for wood and wood products, including for energy, as one of the main problems that needs to be addressed. But none of the proposals put forward addresses this, as it requires first and foremost an immediate phase out of all forms of financial and other support for wood-based bioenergy, which is incompatible with the Paris Agreement goals (also in light of the carbon debt generated), the CBD and the strategy of cascading use.  The latest Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) proposal permits excessive levels of agrochemicals and fertilizers, undermining forest health especially through nitrogen deposition, Furthermore, CAP rules are being implemented in different EU member states in such a way as to prevent or restrict natural forest regeneration. It should be withdrawn and a new CAP proposal must be aligned with EU policies and CBD Aichi Target 3.   The EU should actively support ICCAs and other gender-responsive community forest conservation and restoration initiatives in Europe, including in particular through respecting the forest governance rights of such communities.   Commercial logging and other industrial activities should be strictly prohibited in all areas that are subject to Effective Area-based Conservation Measures, including ICCAs and Natura2000 sites, as well as all remaining old-growth/primary forests. The substitution argument that is used to defend logging and the use of wood in bio-economies is scientifically disputed. Logging bans and regulations should be strictly enforced, and enforcement should be more consistent and prompt. There should also be a ban on cutting down and converting forests for purposes like holiday resorts and infrastructure projects.  Approaches like carbon farming and payments for environmental services are ineffective, disproportionately expensive, and they are beset by controversial and flawed accounting approaches. Strict regulation and policy support for community conservation initiatives have proven to be far more effective as forest conservation measures. We strongly caution against the intention to use forests as carbon offsets to compensate fossil fuel emissions, as the 1.5C goal requires both emission cuts and massive forest restoration.   One of the main causes of forest degradation in Europe has been the replacement of forests by monoculture tree plantations. The emphasis on “afforestation” and “reforestation” rather than the restoration and regeneration of natural forests in the proposed strategy will have devastating impacts on forest biodiversity and other ecosystems. The EU should phase out all forms of support for monoculture tree plantations and actively support the conversion of such plantations into natural mixed forests. This is also a key strategy to prevent future forest fires and make Europe’s forest more resilient in times of climate change.   Finally, although the Forest Strategy focusses on EU countries’ forests, it needs to acknowledge and address the severe impacts of EU subsidies (including the CAP and bioenergy subsidies, including for liquid biofuels) and other policies on forests elsewhere in the world.  See also our full contribution attached. Feedback from: Global Forest Coalition and Biofuelwatch (111 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: A nova Estratégia Florestal Europeia é extraordinariamente importante no sentido de poder vir a estabelecer um quadro de referência para o desenvolvimento de políticas e instrumentos nacionais pelos Estados Membros onde se privilegie coerência e integração entre as diversas políticas sectoriais com impacto na floresta. Em Portugal os espaços florestais são maioritariamente privados e desempenham um papel importante no rendimento das famílias enquanto providenciam um conjunto de serviços de ecossistemas não remunerados e produtos florestais de mercado. No âmbito do Green Deal é fácil identificar um conjunto de áreas para as quais a contribuição da floresta é importante. No entanto, a conciliação de todos os objectivos, simultaneamente no espaço e no tempo, é um exercício difícil de concretizar e que, para a segurança e estabilidade dos ecossistemas florestais é importante acautelar. Para o proprietário e gestor florestal a vontade de investir está dependente da estabilidade da política, dos mercados e das perspectivas futuras. Assim, é fundamental que: 1. Identifique de forma clara os objectivos das diversas políticas sectoriais com impacto na floresta; 2. Exemplifique e oriente formas de compatibilização de objectivos potencialmente conflictuais, assim como torne clara a necessidade de compromissos entre parte interessadas, entre interesses públicos e privados, entre políticas de protecção e de produção; 3. Identifique e oriente soluções exequíveis para valorizar os benefícios públicos resultantes da gestão florestal, de forma a que não sejam criados ónus adicionais sobre os verdadeiros agentes do território, garantindo apoios, contratos de gestão e até ao limite de expropriações; 4. Estabilize a Gestão Florestal Sustentável como o quadro de referência em vigor na Europa, de forma a não criar incertezas resultantes de definições e indicadores específicos em função de produtos diferentes originados nos mesmos espaços; 5. Assuma que o valor gerado e criado ao longo da cadeia de valor é vital para manter viva a oportunidade da gestão florestal, do emprego e da fixação de pessoas no território;  6. Não reduza a estratégia aos 3 objetivos chave identificados, florestação, restauro e preservação. Tal é redutor e limitante do verdadeiro valor e papel da floresta e do sector florestal; 7. Torne claro que apenas com uma gestão activa e com criação de valor se pode garantir a estabilidade de soluções de protecção e conservação ambiental, reforçadas e que nos permitam aumentar a presença de valores naturais, mesmo que humanizados (à semelhança da maioria dos espaços Europeus); 8. Assuma que, face às alterações climáticas, é fundamental uma atitude activa e esclarecida de intervenção para adaptar as florestas para um futuro incerto, mas seguramente mais agressivo para a estabilidade e funcionamento dos ecossistemas; 9. Tenha em consideração o identificado no recente relatório do Thunen Institute, de forma a que uma estratégia ‘cega’ de conservação das florestas Europeias não provoque danos irreversíveis no planeta por aumento da degradação ambiental, desflorestação e pobreza em países terceiros para satisfazer as necessidades em produtos florestais da Europa. Assim, entendemos que para que se consiga potenciar os objectivos do Green Deal e todo o potencial das florestas de proteção e conservação ambiental, de criação de valor na Bioeconomia, geração de riqueza e emprego reduzindo o risco de incêndios e outras calamidades bióticas e abióticas, perda de biodiversidade e redução do stock de CO2, é fundamental ter uma Estratégia Florestal Europeia, forte, enquadradora, baseada nos princípios da Gestão Florestal Sustentável, na integridade territorial, em princípios e acordos de gestão partilhada, no equilíbrio entre as funções de produção, de proteção e conservação, e a consideração e valorização de toda a cadeia de valor, da importância da economia circular e da Bioeconomia. Feedback from: Altri Florestal (136.8 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Holmen acknowledges that the EU Forest Strategy needs to be revised.   Holmen is a 400-year-old Swedish forest company. Being responsible forest owner, we have taken great care to manage our valuable forests over the years and thanks to it we have sustainable forests today and in the future. We have learned that by focusing on forest growth and circular bioeconomy combined with nature conservation management activities (rather than on amount of land set a side) we secure both climate resilience forests, biodiversity, raw material access, energy and maximize ability to combat climate change. We invest vast sums yearly in managing our forests sustainably and we do so, since we know that we will be able to benefit from those investments in 80 years, being the owner of the land.   The Strategy must be a stand-alone policy instrument in order to be able to apply a holistic perspective encompassing the entire forest-based value chains. A narrower perspective would result in a Strategy, which does not capture the full contribution from forest-based value chains to SDG, EGD and other objectives for the conversion to a sustainable society.   The starting point for any forest-based value chain is the forest itself. When sustainably managing a forest resource, the ecologic, economic and social dimensions are inevitably intertwined. The Strategy must therefore - in a balanced way – address all three dimensions. The Strategy should define that investments in sustainable forest management (SFM) are the best way of ensuring the protection and enhancement of forests, their biodiversity, health and other ecosystem services.  The Strategy should clarify that objectives on forest protection, biodiversity, wood production and other ecosystem services are not in contradiction, instead they can be combined. The Strategy should contribute positively to achieving a balance between set aside areas and productive use of forest land to assure forest-based products’ ability to contribute to overall policy objectives. If designed right, the Strategy can strike a balance that contributes to a positive biodiversity development, whilst also ensuring an increased production of biomass resources and social values.   When defining the climate neutrality contribution from forests, forestry and forest-based products, a broad perspective must be applied. It’s all about the three S’s: sequestration of carbon in growing forests, storage of carbon in wood-based products and substitution when forest-based products replace fossil-based alternatives. To maximize the contribution from all three S’s, the Strategy should focus on measures stimulating forest growth. Thereby the flow of carbon from the atmosphere, into trees and further into products can be further increased. Holmen’s business helped to reduce 5 million tonnes of CO2 from the atmosphere in 2019. The largest contribution came from our products contributing to eliminate the need to extract fossil products avoiding almost 3 million tonnes of fossil carbon dioxide to be released into the atmosphere. This is an essential contribution to Paris agreement. “Pumping and digging up fossil CO2 is bad. Having a spin on the CO2 that is the atmosphere is better”.  The Strategy must acknowledge the forest owner’s efforts and stimulate engagement. European forests are diverse, and forest owners’ goals for their forestry differs, one-size-fits-all solutions don’t exist. The Strategy needs to acknowledge this and apply a bottom-up perspective on measures, instead of sending top-down instructions.  Holmen is seriously concerned over the direction the Roadmap is leaning to. We worry that if the Commission were to continue to develop a Strategy in line with the Roadmap very few, if any, representatives for the forest-based value chains would feel engaged and inspired by it, and this would risk the Strategy losing its potential, which will limit the EU’s possibility of achieving Paris agreement, SDG, EGD and other goals. Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: The Swedish Society for Nature Conservation’s (SSNC) response to the roadmap on the EU forest strategy  On an overall level, SSNC, Sweden’s largest environmental organization, welcomes the upcoming EU Forest Strategy with its objectives of forest protection, restoration and ecologically sustainable afforestation. Healthy forest ecosystems are essential for biodiversity, society and to tackle the climate crisis.  In Sweden the predominant forestry model has transformed the majority of the country’s forests to even aged forest stands of mainly spruce or pine. The forest landscape is dominated by young forests and for the next couple of decades there is little, if any, room for an increased extraction of timber.   SSNC especially want to highlight our support that the EU Forest Strategy should recognize the need to protect primary and old-growth forests in the EU and address the need for forest restoration. Knowledge is the key to safeguard biodiversity. Finding and protecting old growth forests in Europe is crucial since they are under high logging pressure, not at least in Sweden and Finland. SSNC therefore stress the importance of a transparent mapping of biodiversity on a regional and national level as well as across the EU-borders. It is of high importance that planning of forest activities are conducted at a landscape level, with best scientific knowledge, to achieve the member states national targets as well as targets on EU-level.   The EU forest strategy must:   1. ensure that protection and restoration of forests is the primary objective of the strategy. To secure a sustainable development the forest strategy must present a forestry model where economy and social development is kept well within the framework of ecosystems.  2. be subordinate and directly contribute to the implementation of the EU’s biodiversity Strategy for 2030 and the European Green Deal. It is crucial that the Forest Strategy stress the important role forests play in tackling the interlinking biodiversity and climate crisis. The forest strategy cannot become a parallel process to legislation, other strategies, regulations, or policies that involves forests.   3. endorse and enable synergies with the upcoming legally binding restoration targets with the objective to halt and reverse biodiversity loss as well as contribute to climate mitigation and adaptation by storing or sequestering carbon.  4. contain clear, and well defined, targets that can be monitored and evaluated.  5. include transparent mapping and coordinated monitoring of forests with high biodiversity values, as well as cooperation between MS to preserve such forests at landscape level to secure knowledge-based decision making.  6. ensure transparency within the forest management to publicly available information on high biodiversity forests and management plans.   7. clearly define all terms aiming towards a sustainable forestry, protection, and restoration of forests, in line with the EU biodiversity strategy. This includes a clear and generally accepted definition of sustainable forestry as such. The forest strategy must comply with other relevant strategies, regulations and polices etc.   8. encourage sustainable forest management practices and prioritize close-to-nature forestry, based on best available knowledge.      9. ensure that the growing interest in the forest’s role as carbon sink, bioenergy, substitution for fossil fuels and materials does not lead to afforestation, loss of biodiversity or degradation of forest-or other carbon storing ecosystems. The forest strategy must offer a solution to both the biodiversity and climate crises.   10.  apply a broad definition of bioeconomy with economical sustainability for small-scale forest owners. This should also include economic activities beyond biomass production, such as tourism and outdoor activities, which would increase job opportunities in rural areas and a higher economic return for the landowner.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Die EU-Roadmap greift viel zu kurz. Denn oberstes Ziel muss die Anerkennung der ökologischen "Leistungen" europäischer Wälder werden. Denn hochkomplexe Ökosysteme wie Wälder werden sich nicht den systemrelevanten monetären Wachstumskonzepten unterordnen lassen, ohne Schaden zu nehmen.   Wie die letzten Jahre besonders deutlich gezeigt haben, ist der Einfluss der Forstwirtschaft Mitverursacher des Waldsterben 2.0 - deshalb muss sich auf diesem Gebiet dringend etwas ändern. Wälder leiden offensichtlich längst am Klimawandel mit sich ändernden Wasserresourcen etc. - besonders betroffen sind dabei die naturfernen und intensiv genutzten Forste. Deshalb ist eine Entwicklung hin zu Naturwäldern unbedingt zu fördern und der illegale Holzeinschläge in noch bestehenden Ur- und Naturwäldern sofort zu unterbinden. Auch die Rodungen für Infrastrukturanlagen (wie Autobahnen etc) und andere technische Eingriffe sind zu unterlassen.    Der Nutzen der Wälder besteht in erster Linie in ihren ökosystemaren "Leistungen" für die Biodiversität und den Wasserhaushalte u.a. Die Erhaltung der Wald-Ökosysteme muss das oberste Ziel jeder Waldnutzung und -erhaltung sein.   Das heißt aber auch: Klima- und der Biodiversitätsschutz müssen gleichrangige Ziele werden - und das so schnell wie möglich. Retten wir, was noch zu retten ist - dafür soll der Naturwald als Symbol gelten.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Opinion on the new EU forestry strategy  The Agrarian Chamber of the Czech Republic and the Federation of Forestry and Timber Industry of the Czech Republic (FFTI) with the support of the Forestry and Wood-Processing Companies Association, as important representatives of the forestry and timber sector in the Czech Republic, welcome the opportunity to comment on the roadmap of the EU forestry strategy. We would like to support the urgency of the timely adoption of a new EU forestry strategy after 2020, which would allow a more effective response to new forestry challenges in the EU Member States but also with the necessary impact on developing countries where the root causes of deforestation and forest degradation need to be mitigated. We welcome the fact that key documents such as the European Green Deal and the EU Biodiversity Strategy to 2030 recognize the need for a new EU forestry strategy. The new forestry strategy must continue to be based on the principle of a balanced approach to the social, environmental and economic aspects of forestry. At the same time, we consider it very important that the declared multifunctionality of forests is really taken into account, stated and supported in all relevant EU strategies. Their mutual content interconnection is necessary to achieve the declared ambitions and set goals. All documents must emphasize the irreplaceable importance and potential of forests, sustainable forest management and the role of foresters in achieving the various objectives set across relevant strategies and policies at EU level. We are currently facing many problems, especially those related to the negative effects of climate change on forests. We are looking for ways to new procedures in forest regeneration and forest management, which in the future will lead not only to maintaining the existing potential of forests, but especially to increasing their resilience. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the role of forestry in the bioeconomy and to support the production of higher value-added wood products. In addition, the necessary financial support will need to be provided for forest owners and managers to invest in the required measures, which in the coming years will focus on regenerating the affected forests and adapting to climate change. This is a topic not only for the Czech Republic, but for most of EU countries. At the same time, we are asking the Commission for a positive and active approach to finding other possibilities for financial support for other necessary measures, including reducing the administrative burden for state aid and purely national state aid, especially by allowing block exemptions. With regard to the above, the Federation of Forestry and Timber Industry of the Czech Republic is ready to actively participate in the next phase of the preparation of the new EU forestry strategy, which we consider to be an important step for the entire forestry and timber sector. We expect that this document will be published by the European Commission immediately in 2021, taking into account all relevant comments made as part of the preparatory process. _______________________________________________________________________ Federation of Forestry and Timber Industry  of the Czech Republic (FFTI) brings together the most important business entities in the forestry and timber sector, state-owned forest managers, institutions from the academic and research spheres, professional education and companies focused on lifelong  education and professional public education. FFTI is also a long-term member of the Agrarian Chamber of the Czech Republic, where it is involved in the advisory bodies of this organization. feedback_msg_text: The organisations of Småland’s regional forest and wood strategies[1] see the value of an updated EU forest strategy. Please find our input to a new EU forest strategy attached.   Regarding the roadmap, the following aspects are important to take into consideration: - A new EU-strategy must recognise the principle of subsidiarity, as national competence is best suited to create and put forest policy in place. This includes forest management, governance and monitoring.  - In accordance with Swedish national legislation, the economic and ecological objectives are on equal footing. We urge the EU forest strategy to also have the two objectives on equal footing. - It is positive that the value of ecosystem services is recognised. It is important that forest owners are financially compensated for providing ecosystem services such as carbon storage and nature conservation. Adequately designed measures can create strong incentives for forest owners to integrate ecosystem services in their business models and to see ecosystem services as an opportunity.  - The characteristics of forests varies between European regions. These differences need to be recognised when designing policy measures and formulating definitions, targets and criteria. In the case of old-growth forest for instance, harvest cycle should be the basis and  the limit for old-growth should not be below the cutting cycle. The harvest cycle of a tree varies greatly deepening on altitude, latitude, as well as species. - We are positive to more cooperation and actions for tackling challenges such as pests, diseases, extreme weather events and forest fires. feedback_msg_text: The world is facing an interconnected climate and ecosystem crisis. Natural forests play a crucial role for both climate change mitigation and preservation of biodiversity and ecosystem services. Europe’s forests have been affected by climate crisis born drought, storms, wild fires and insect calamities in the past years. These impacts of climate heating now combine with the failures of forest management, which is primarily based on maximized exploitation of wood resources resulting clear-cutting, even aged wood plantations , harvesting with heavy machinery, drainage and removal of critically important old and dead trees. The latest "State of Nature" report paints a bleak picture of Europe’s forests. Only 15% of forests in the Natura 2000 network are in a favourable conservation status. Less than one third are uneven aged and 30% are monocultures. Only 5% have five or more tree species. The increase of exploitation, especially for energy production, leads to a further loss of threatened species. At the same time, the rather small remains of intact natural forests are shrinking. Forests play a multifunctional role for life on earth and for human society. Therefore, the Forest Strategy needs to go beyond the promotion of the traditional wood extraction-based economy and strengthen its focus to promote ecological functions and sustainable flows of goods and services.  Sustainable forest management is more than planting at least as many trees as harvested before and needs to ensure durable ecological functioning of forest ecosystems. Even-aged monocultures or clearcutting cannot not be considered as “sustainable” from an ecological point of view and need to be banned in times of emerging climate and nature crisis. It is important, that the new Forest Strategy is kept consistent and mutually supports the Biodiversity Strategy and the Green Deal and is not turned into a “Forestry Strategy” driven forward by economic interests. The key formula for the future of Europe’s forests should be: Preserve all biodiversity rich, resilient, close to nature forests - including all remaining primary / old-growth forests - and manage the production forests in a way to enrich biodiversity, maintain and strengthen ecosystem services and improve climate stability.   We are convinced that the EU Forest Strategy must go beyond the focus on protection of “old-growth forests” and also consider preserving previously managed close-to-nature forests. This is key in particular when it comes to deciduous forests where a well shaded and cool interior is crucial to keep forests healthy and resilient in the face of increased heat and drought. Furthermore, the habitat and species protection obligations from the Natura 2000 regime need to be better enforced in the forestry sector. In many Natura 2000 sites in the EU, but in particular in countries such as Romania or Slovakia, valuable and biodiversity rich forest habitats (including old-growth / primary forests) are being destroyed or significantly deteriorated by logging – either by clear cutting or by stepwise removal of entire mature stands by shelterwood cuttings. Often, appropriate assessments are not being pursued at all or done with very poor quality and lacking a scientific basement. Without full enforcement of Natura 2000 legislation in the forest sector the EU Biodiversity Strategy will be severely undermined. The expansion of the wood biomass demand for energy production is a major driver of logging in intact, natural forests. Forest biomass burning is not climate neutral in the short to medium term, and certainly not at scale by 2050. Emissions from burning wood are seen by the atmosphere just like emissions from fossil fuels and need to be considered as such on the emissions side of the greenhouse gas accounts. The decline in the EU forest sink is a consequence of increased use of forest biomass. Forest biomass should not be considered a “renewable” source and should not be eligible for subsidies. Feedback from: EuroNatur Foundation (27 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: To be in line with the EU Green Deal and the EU Biodiversity Strategy, the post-2020 EU Forest Strategy for 2030 should: - recognize conservation/strict protection of forests (non-intervention, wilderness management, which avoids any form of commodity harvesting) as a legitimate management choice, - guarantee stronger coordination between national legislation in all relevant fields, including climate and biodiversity, with international commitments such as the CBD and Paris Agreement. National legislation should reflect these commitments, - ensure that the future of forests in Europe is built on subsidiarity and shared responsibility between the EU and MSs for setting up the irrespective frameworks for forest-related actions (Court of Justice of the European Union judgment of 25 February 1999 in Joined Cases C164/97 and C-165/97, EU:C:1999:99), - recognize that the protection and conservation of forests can provide huge economic revenues, if correctly and ecologically utilised, and that the loss of forests means not just loss of money, but functions that are impossible to value –and that is forever!, - provide a broader definition of “forest sector” to include economic activities beyond wood extraction, especially from the service and nature conservation sector, these being equally important based on the universally accepted definition of ecosystem services (TEEB), - call for regular monitoring of the real impact of forestry on forest habitats across Europe.  We believe that the EU Forest Strategy should embody the following guiding principles: 1. Climate mitigation and biodiversity values are intertwined. 2. Forest ecosystems as natural habitats are self-sustaining, and do not require active human management. 3. The higher a forest’s level of ecosystem integrity, the greater its stability, resilience, and resistance to threats, and the greater its climate mitigation benefit and adaptive capacity.  It’s time to recognize that Forest as a habitat and Forestry as an economic activity are not the same. The EU forest strategy must be a document which offers a solution to both the biodiversity and climate crises – or it will simply recapitulate the same patterns and practices that are currently degrading EU forests.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Die neue EU-Forest Strategy soll nicht der EU-Biodiversitätsstrategie untergeordnet und aus dieser nicht abgeleitet werden, sondern als EIGENSTÄNDIGE Strategie unter Einbeziehung aller RELEVANTEN (d.h. für die Zielerreichung benötigten) Akteure etabliert werden. Den (öffentlichen wie privaten) Waldbewirtschaftern und Waldeigentümern hat dabei eine große, ihrer - insbesondere wirtschaftlichen - Umsetzungsverantwortung entsprechende Bedeutung und gewichtete Integration in die Strategieformulierung zuzukommen. Bei der Strategieformulierung können und sollen Verbindungen zu anderen Sektor- oder Themenstrategien hergestellt werden, um die immer wieder eingeforderte - bisher aber ungenügende - Kohärenz sicherzustellen. Aus der vorliegenden Roadmap zur EU Forest Strategy lassen sich aus den  Zielformulierungen insbesondere konservierende und außer Nutzung stellende Maßnahmen erkennen, wohingegen der aktiven Nutzung und Verwendung des Rohstoffes Holz viel zu wenig Beachtung geschenkt wird. Der EU-Kommission muss - ebenso wie den politischen Entscheidungsträgern - bewusst sein, dass das Ziel der Transformation weg von einer fossile-based economy hin zu einer Bioeconomy, und somit das Überziel des European Green Deal für ein klimaneutrales Europa 2050, nur dann gelingen wird, wenn der Rohstoff Holz und seine Bestandteile in signifikant steigender Weise in die Produkt- und Wertschöpfungsprozesse eingebracht wird. Dabei kommt Holz als nachhaltig nachwachsendem Rohstoff eine besondere Bedeutung zu - insbesondere dort, wo  Substitution durch die aktive und vermehrte Verwendung von Holz die gewünschten, klimaneutralen Effekte erzielt werden können und CO2 in holzbasierten Produkten langfristig (oftmals über Jahrhunderte) gespeichert bleibt. Die Roadmap missachtet bisher die forstpolitisch völlig unstrittige Sichtweise, dass der Wald an sich keine Funktionen hat, sondern unterschiedlichste Interessen von Menschen und Gesellschaft an ihn - oftmals auf der selben Fläche - gerichtet werden. Waldeigentümer und Waldbewirtschafter haben diese meist unterschiedlichen  Interessen bestmöglich zu managen. Dazu braucht es entsprechende Kompetenz (Wissen & Erfahrung), um die Ziele der (i) Walderhaltung, (ii) der Stabilisierung von Waldökosystemen, (iii) der Ausrichtung auf die Herausforderungen und Folgen des Klimawandels sowie (iv) eines adäquaten Managements politischer und gesellschaftlicher Interessen an der Verwendung und Nutzung von Wald und seinen Ökosystemleistungen erreichen zu können. Nutzung, Schutz und Biodiversität von und in Waldökosystemen müssen kein Widerspruch sein. Ganz im Gegenteil beweist die integrative, multifunktionale Forstwirtschaft, dass beides zum Wohle der Gesellschaft möglich ist. Die Österreichische Bundesforste AG ist sehr gerne bereit zu zeigen, wie diese integrierte Form von Interessen managender Waldbewirtschaftung  erfolgreich funktionieren kann. All die vorgenannten Argumente wurden bereits auch im Rahmen des Events zur EU Forest Strategy am 21. Jänner 2020 im Europäischen Parlament unter dem Titel "Seeing the forest for the trees - the multifunctional role of EU forests. Beyond trees - the multifunctional role of EU forests" unter Vorsitz von MEP Petri Sarvamaa eingebracht, ganztägig erörtert und erörtert. Daher wird ersucht, diesen Argumenten bei der Entwicklung der künftigen EU-Forest Strategy  gebührenden Raum zu geben. Als "Role-Model" einer gelungenen, alle Anspruchsgruppen integrierenden Waldstrategieformulierung - insbesondere des dahinterliegenden Arbeitsprozesses - sei auf die "Österreichische Waldstrategie 2020+" verwiesen. Sehr gerne kann der dabei gewählte, methodische Ansatz übernommen werden.  Abschließend wird noch einmal mit Nachdruck empfohlen, den Waldbewirtschaftern und Waldbesitzern eine entscheidende Rolle bei der Formulierung der künftigen EU-Waldstrategie zukommen zu lassen, da diese Strategie sonst zu einer politischen Absichtserklärung verkommt. Es soll ja um die Zielerreichung gehen.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Il est plus que nécessaire que les toutes les filières et entreprises utilisant du bois (principalement le bois énergie) soient contraintes à la production de leur bilan carbone ACV et de leur coefficient d'efficacité énergétique global (intégrant la production et la consommation des bâtiments)  Ces critères doivent conditionner toute aide publique.  Sans ces données il est impossible de différentier les installations efficaces ou non. Ex: comment comparer une installation brûlant du bois vert via un réseau de chaleur pour chauffer des bâtiment mal isolés, avec une installation brûlant du bois sec dans un immeuble isolé ? Pour les petites installations il faut que l'état (ADEME) produise ce bilan global en interdisant les projets qui ne répondent pas à ces critères minimum d'efficacité. Mais aussi l'obligation pour l'existant de se conformer à un minimum. (ex: émissions carbone par m2 chauffé par an) Ceci est d'une importance cruciale car ces coefficient d'efficacité et bilans peuvent varier d'un facteur de 1 à 9 et ne sont de plus pas en faveur des grosses installation brûlant du bois vert avec 45% d'eau, utilisant des réseaux de chaleur, ou chauffant des parc immobiliers mal isolé, voir produisant uniquement de l’électricité. On a trop traîné ou freiné, disant que c'est compliqué, mais je pense que c'est bien plus important et moins compliqué que de vouloir aller sur Mars  Il s'agit de la vie de millions voir milliard d'humains qi est en jeux..
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Thank you for having consulted about the forest strategy In France we have a number of Organizations caring for forests.  We are a small informal organisation of young people caring for nature and cleaning-up our nearby forests. We are worried for our future. What will happen if all natural forests are destroyed or die because of lack of appropriate attention? Forests are under attack from everywhere. We need to protect them from trash, poisons, buildings,…  We would like to stretch that natural forests should be carefully protected.  It should be strictly forbidden to transform a natural forest in a tree plantation. They do not have the same role and objectives for our future.  We should clearly identify and make a thorough inventory of natural forests, large or small, by country.   To protect natural forests we need all our rangers who are commissioned by our state representatives to protect our forests. Strategy without protection and enforcement of laws and rules will be of no help.  Our rangers protect our precious forests with their life and against all odds. Let’s support them. Caring and respecting nature and in particular forests for should be thought in school.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Factual background The digitalization of our everyday life facilitates and enables many things that bring benefits for the people in practice. However, there are still industries leveraging partially from the digital transformation and possessing enormous potential for green growth.   As per research of APPLiA (Brussels-based trade manufacturing association) 116200000 big electric home appliances are manufactured annually in Europe. Each one of the products goes with approximately 60 pages A4 format paper user manual (with only 8%-10% recycling factor).  On the other side, one tree produces 8333 pages of A4 format paper. This means that each year over 679227 trees are used for production of user manuals only for large electric home appliances. Apart from the above, the produced user manuals are shipped to different points in the whole world amounting to 33000 tons of paper shipped annually, producing vast amounts of CO2 (above 275000 tons) emissions in the atmosphere. At the same time, the paper user manuals are one of the most rarely used items in the households, mainly due to the fact that they are provided in the form of big booklets, full with difficult to find information, listed on different languages, which in most of the cases is not precise and differs in the different language sections. The negative impacts of paper production and usage do not end to the tons of CO2 emissions released in the air. The largest waste in the production of paper is linked to the water losses. As per report of UNESCO the paper production sector is the one wasting the largest amounts of water for production of one ton of paper compared to any other production industry. For the production of the necessary paper used for user manuals produced for one year (and concerning only the large home appliances) the water wasted in the process amounts to approx. 21414150 tons.   Roadmap - Forest Strategy In the light of the importance of the transition to a sustainable, affordable and secure life, the digital transformation of our everyday activities, the technological innovation, research and development are genuine part and important drivers for achieving the climate-neutrality objectives, including the objectives of the current Forest Strategy Roadmap. The transition to climate-neutrality requires changes across the entire policy spectrum and a collective effort of all sectors of the economy and society, as illustrated by the European Commission in its Communication ‘The European Green Deal’. In order to achieve these we should invest efforts on large-scale climate initiatives but also we should take the advantages provided by the digitalisation also through more focused and narrow approaches. Example of such approach is the newest change of the horizontal standard EN 82079-1, regulating the form of the user manuals, whereas the latter explicitly provides for the possibility the user manuals to be provided in media form instead in paper. Still, the practices accumulated during the years, when the main carrier of information was the paper one, are changing with slower pace than expected, including due to the ambiguity in the wording of the legal framework regulating the form for the user manuals, which in some parts is already obsolete. With that said, the legislative acts, such as Directive 2014/35/EU (Low Voltage Directive), including the vertical EU standards based thereon (e.g. EN 60335-1) should be amended in order to explicitly set obligation for shifting to digital by default as regards the user manuals instead of wasting energy, water and forests for the production of their paper equivalents. In this regard the new Forest Strategy should impact on the economy and businesses on a horizontal base, including through initiation of legislative changes in various sectors as the one listed above. Feedback from: GR Consulting Ltd. (14.2 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Wir begrüßen, dass die neue EU-Waldstrategie den Ersatz CO2-intensiver, fossiler Materialien durch innovative Holzprodukte forciert und dass sie die Biodiversität in den Wäldern sowie die Resilienz der Wälder gegen den Klimawandel stärken will.  Kritisch müssen wir anmerken, dass die wichtige Rolle der multifunktionalen Waldbewirtschaftung und die Bedeutung der Substitution fossiler Brennstoffe durch als Nebenprodukte der Forst- und Holzwirtschaft anfallende Holzbrennstoffe zu wenig Beachtung findet. Die kürzlich von den renommiertesten österreichischen Forst- und Holzforschungsorganisationen veröffentliche Studie „CareForParis“ kommt zum Ergebnis, dass der Ersatz fossiler Rohstoffe durch Holzprodukte und die damit vermiedenen Emissionen der größte Hebel des Forstsektors für den Klimaschutz sind. Der Wald allein liefert zwar einen wichtigen Beitrag zur CO2­Speicherung, kann jedoch keine dauerhafte Senke sein. Jährlich werden durch die stoffliche und energetische Holznutzung in Österreich 12,5 Millionen Tonnen CO2 vermieden. Eine Reduktion der Holznutzung erhöht Treibhausgasemissionen, da mehr fossile Rohstoffe wie Erdöl, Kohle und Erdgas und mit hohem fossilem Einsatz erzeugte Produkte (Metalle, Beton, Kunststoffe) eingesetzt werden. Eine europäische Holzbauoffensive wäre eine wichtige Maßnahme, um durch Einsatz innovativer Holzprodukte CO2-Emissionen zu reduzieren.   Die Aussage, dass die Intensivierung der Holznutzung und die steigende Nachfrage nach Holzprodukten und Biomasse den Wald in Europa stark unter Druck bringen, ist nicht mit Fakten zu belegen und wird zurückgewiesen. Auch die Ankündigung, dass die EU-Forststrategie den Verlust der Waldfläche reduzieren soll, ist völlig unverständlich. Die aktive Bewirtschaftung der Wälder durch die etwa 16 Millionen europäischen WaldbesitzerInnen hat seit 1990 zur Ausweitung der Waldfläche in der EU um 14 Millionen Hektar (entspricht Landesfläche von Österreich, der Slowakei und Slowenien) und zu einer Erhöhung der Holzvorräte um 8 Milliarden Festmeter geführt. Die Waldbewirtschaftung in Europa erfolgt seit Generationen nach dem Prinzip der Nachhaltigkeit.   Die Wälder in der EU verfügen weltweit über die höchsten Holzvorräte pro Hektar. Zur Stabilisierung, Diversifizierung und Erziehung wertvoller Wälder sind regelmäßige Pflegeeingriffe im Rahmen einer naturnahen Waldbewirtschaftung notwendig.  Diese Eingriffe senken den Holzvorrat  kurzfristig, führen aber zum Aufbau stabiler und artenreicher Wälder. Wir weisen  darauf hin, dass eine Reduktion der Holznutzung in den nachhaltig bewirtschafteten Wäldern Europas dazu führen wird, dass die weltweit steigende Nachfrage nach Holz verstärkt durch Holzimporte aus Ländern gedeckt werden wird, in denen anstatt hoher Nachhaltigkeitsstandards bei der Waldbewirtschaftung Raubbau und illegale Abholzungen vorherrschen.  Der Haupttreiber für den Verlust der biologischen Vielfalt in Europa ist nicht die Nutzung der Wälder, sondern der vom Menschen verursachte Klimawandel durch  Verbrennung von fossilem Öl, Gas und Kohle. Wenn wir die biologische Vielfalt sichern wollen, müssen wir die Emission von fossilem CO2 einstellen und fossile Rohstoffe sofort durch erneuerbare  ersetzen. Ein zentrales Instrument zur Erreichung dieses Ziels wird Holz aus einer nachhaltigen, multifunktionalen Waldbewirtschaftung sein, mit dem Zusatzeffekt, dass Waldbesitzer zur Schaffung und Sicherung der biologischen Vielfalt beitragen, indem sie angemessene Strukturen wie Totholz oder Biotopbäume bereitstellen.   Es gilt, die Wälder rasch durch aktive Bewirtschaftung an den Klimawandel anzupassen. Dies erhöht auch die Aufnahmefähigkeit der Wälder für CO2. Zur Abschwächung des Klimawandels sind die Substitution von CO2-intensiven Materialien, die Kohlenstoffspeicherung in Holzprodukten, zuwachsfördernde Maßnahmen und die Speicherung von Kohlenstoff im Wald von großer Bedeutung. Die Waldstrategie muss dies in dieser konkreten Priorisierung widerspiegeln. Feedback from: Österreichischer Biomasse-Verband (380.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Dear Commision,   Thanks for the opportunity to give feedback.  I have no Idea if that makes any difference and to be frank - my trust is rather limited to what extent, a voice like ours counts in the end of the day.   It is nice to have lots of different strategic goals and papers with focus on green deals, biodiversity, bioecomomy, circular economy sustainable develepment and so on. But they remain nice words that mean nothing if on the other hand forest is destoyed in the name of the EU.   This is why I would like to ask the commision:  In order to move in the direction of a sustainable forest management in the EU the use of woody biomass as fuel for energy production should be  - as a first step - forbidden immediately   This his highly problematic for the following reasons:    1. Contrary to popular opinion, the burning of wood is not climate-neutral. The energetic use of wood contributes significantly to the greenhouse effect beyond the time periods relevant to tackle the climate crisis. The time needed by forests to re-absorb carbon emissions from energetic wood use may amount to many decades. At the same time, more intensive utilization reduces the ability of forests to sequester carbon in the long term. In addition, burning wood produces more CO₂ per unit of energy than burning fossil fuels.  2. To meet the raw material requirements for power plants run on woody biomass, operators are on a global shopping spree. Environmental organizations from the US or the Baltic States are already sounding the alarm because forests there could end up as fuel in power plants. Countries from the global south are also in focus here: Vattenfall narrowly failed with its plans to burn wood from Liberia in its Berlin power plants and in Hamburg bushwood from Namibia is to be used for energy production.    3. Increased demand for wood is not good news European forests either. Increased felling quantities would further weaken the local forest ecosystems and impair their functions for climate protection and biodiversity. For ecological reasons, there are no quantities of wood in countries like Germany that are still freely available. The annual growth of wood is almost completely harvested and for many years a substantial part of the harvested wood has already been burned. At the same time, deadwood is missing in the forest as an important structural element for biodiversity, nutrient availability and humus formation. We would have to leave much more wood in the forest for climate and species protection.  4. The burning of woody biomass also contradicts the principle of cascading use, to which the EU has committed itself. According to this, wood should first be used as a material in long-life products and only be burned for energy production at the end of the respective life cycle.  5. . The use of woody biomass is only made possible with massive public funding. For the conversion of the RWE coal-fired power plant in Geertruidenburg in the Netherlands, the energy giant is receiving over 1.7 billion euros in subsidies. Investors in Germany are also already speculating on generous public support for the use of biomass in energy production.  6. In this context, sustainability certificates are not suitable to adequately counter the negative effects of woody biomass combustion. Even if wood from sustainable forestry is burned, it contributes to the increase of the CO₂ content in the atmosphere and thus to the climate crisis. Furthermore, certificates do not prevent the further expansion of this unsustainable energy production. Feedback from: denkhausbremen (391.9 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: WWF-CEE is welcoming the commitment of the European Commission to develop a new Forest Strategy built in strong connection to the EU 2030 Biodiversity Strategy, aiming to foster a stronger coordination between national forest policies and the European Green Deal’s objectives. . We consider it of utmost importance to have an integrated approach to forests across policies such as climate, environment, rural development, agriculture, or disaster prevention.  Forests and the forest-based sector should preserve landscapes, culture and heritage as mentioned in the roadmap but biodiversity has to be added as well. When it comes to the mention that  EU Forest Strategy will have to foresee measures to avoid or correct unsustainable practices, we consider that the unsustainable forest management practices should be underlined. The EU forest strategy needs to clearly state that forest management should move towards sustainable forest management practices and avoid promoting forest activities that manipulate natural conditions, threaten biodiversity, risks to pollute water courses and undermine resilience. Furthermore, progressive forest management methods like closer-to-nature forestry practices should be supported and subsidized.  We want to highlight our support that the EU Forest Strategy should recognize the need to protect primary and old-growth forests in the EU and address the need for forest restoration.  Regarding the afforestation and tree planting by setting out a roadmap for planting at least 3 billion additional trees in the EU by 2030 we consider that an extensive consultation with experts and learning from past mistakes is needed in order to be in full respect of ecological principles, as mentioned in the Biodiversity Strategy for 2030 (see coniferous plantations in Central and Western Europe, the mass afforestation in Bulgaria during the 60's-70's). In addition, the pressure of providing space for afforestation can imply the risk that habitats such as pastures of conservation importance will be sacrificed for this purpose.  Proper compensation for income forgone in cases of use restriction are critical based on the experience with non-functional compensation mechanisms in Romania or the total lack of these funding solutions in the case of Bulgaria. This is why increasing the allocation of EU and national funds and integrated, harmonized public funding instruments have to be promoted. Innovative financial mechanisms such as payments for ecosystem service schemes are to be developed with strong support from the EC. We need to communicate more and better about the role of forests for nature and human societies to mobilize support for both conservation and sustainable use among urban and rural populations.  Consultation of stakeholders is another relevant point. How effective the consultation is depends on how culturally appropriate the means/channels of consultation are. If we expect rural communities to be active in these consultation processes, we need to speak their voice and collect their feedback on the ground, more informally, though meetings, debates, face to face communication. We already have many examples of poor stakeholder consultation and we see the results: lack of trust and tensions related to forest protection and protected areas in general.  Last but not least the National Forest Inventories which are good and complex sources of information related to forests can be considered as relevant input as well.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Good evening, Please find attached our feed-back  We would like to insist on the fact that “planted woods” are not the same as “natural forests”, young or old.  “Planted woods” may be compared to wheat plantation, or to any other extensive and monoculture plantation. There is no way that a “wheat field” (champ de blé) can be called a “meadow”(prairie).   Great discomfort, practical and theoretical, comes from this misunderstanding and unprecise definition.  Making this distinction is today a vital stake. Once the distinction between "natural forests" and "planted woods" is clear to all, a specific strategy for each can be drafted.  Strategy and rules may vary  as objectives and benefits of each ecosystem are different and complementary.    We shall consider that a mile stone will be reached if this difference is taken into consideration.  To the EU person reading this post: please require this distinction between "natural forests" and "planted woods" is accepted.  The EU would be giving an important and structuring signal, leading the way and showing the path to other institutions and organisations.  Thank you Le collectif Université du Bien Commun à Paris Feedback from: Université du Bien Commun (183.3 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: The following recommendations are collated from our partnership network, including our conferences in Brussels (2017) which produced an Old Growth Forest Protection Strategy and Bratislava (2019):  1) Defining areas for protection  • A clear definition structure for old growth and primary forest, identifying relevant criteria, to enable a standardised approach for protection & restoration; to be set alongside varying national definitions [see Practical Forest Definition Structure] • Strict protection for all old growth/primary forests should involve complete non-intervention - essential for such complex, fragile and irreplaceable ecosystems. This is also the most cost-effective form of management • The 4% of forests still having old growth/primary status should be framed by a further strictly protected area, generally at least twice its size, totalling c 15%. This consolidates fragmented remnants, enables buffering from ‘edge effects’, proper ecosystem functioning and linkage. Final areas can be determined by mapping. • It is important that identification and mapping of the above areas be based on standardised definition structures with a combination of EU overview with national and local implementation. Mapping should include the 4% remnant areas plus adjacent areas whose strict protection is also needed, and involve assessment of ecosystem service potential (MAES) • The remaining c 85% of forests should be subject to nature-based management: longer rotations, mixed species and age classes to enhance resilience & biodiversity, continuous cover forestry rather than clear-fell  2) Implementing protection   • Adequate monitoring is essential, combining satellite surveillance with local monitoring – with a need to develop support networks that include an Early Warning System for threats [see our LEAF and EWS proposals] • There must be adequate support for local landholders and communities to incentivise their participation, with reform of compensation systems: appropriate payments, well promoted, readily accessible • Further funding support should be enabled through full activation of the greatly under-utilised PES agenda - converting economic value into cashflow by promoting best practice and identifying entities to achieve it. This implies capacity building eg for ecosystem service valuation, enterprise implementation and funding facilitation from projects involving carbon sequestration/storage, flood mitigation, ecotourism etc  • This support should form a basis for achieving necessarily ambitious forest protection targets based on inter-sector agreement  • Illegal logging should be effectively addressed - with support for citizen app tracking, reform of EUTR, adequate enforcement and prosecution of criminal activity • The social mandate of state agencies, managing 40% of forests, requires fuller recognition, with set-aside of forest areas that are uneconomic and often only logged because of statute • Cessation of subsidies for perverse use of forest products that worsen climate change - notably commercial bioenergy - with redirection of those subsidies to genuine forms of renewable energy (wind, solar, marine), restoration of carbon rich ecosystems and improved insulation, recycling and emission suppression  3) Strategic framework  • Forest Strategy must recognise long-term, effective ecosystem conservation as a key objective, not an adjunct • The European Court of Justice adjudication of shared responsibility between the EU and Member States correlates with a recognised need for overall EU target setting and standardisation of approach • Promote similar protection and restoration where appropriate for non-EU countries, eg through Neighbour Agreements, Transition Treaties, trade & aid policy, best practice dissemination • Uphold the EU’s global reputation by ensuring EU policies for the environment, bioenergy, trade and aid do not damage overseas forests  Feedback from: WILD EUROPE (1.9 MB - PDF - 20 pages) Download
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: Die Roadmap beschreibt schon zu Beginn einen Widerspruch: Der Forstsektor soll einen Beitrag leisten zur Wachstumsstrategie des Europäischen Green Deals. Demzufolge würde die ökologische Integrität europäscher Wälder und Forsten ein nachrangiges Ziel bleiben. Ökosysteme können sich in ihrer Funktionsweise aber nicht nach unseren wechselnden und in der Regel wachsenden Ansprüchen orientieren.   Die Problembeschreibung nennt Übernutzung ebenso als Ursache, wie mangelndes Management, und auch hier ergibt sich ein Widerspruch, da Management in der Regel Eingriffe tätigt, die mehr Holzernte ermöglichen sollen. Zudem werden Kimawandel und die damit einhergehenden Folge-Schadursachen nicht mit dessen Ursache genannt: nämlich der Verbrennung fossiler Energieträger in nach wie vor gigantischem Ausmaß.  Der Forstsektor wird ausschließlich als Eingriffsmanagement beschrieben, seine Rolle als Mitursache des Artensterbens und der Degradierung von Waldökosystemen wird verschwiegen. Besonders der auch innerhalb der EU verbreitete illegale Holzeinschlag und Raubbau an Naturwäldern z.B. in Rumänien wird nicht erwähnst. Wäldern und Forsten wird eine übergroße Bürde aufgeladen, den Klimawandel mildern zu sollen, wo sie doch gerade selbst Opfer des anthropogenen Klimawandels sind. Wälder sollen alles mögliche liefern, jede denkbare Begehrlichkeit soll befriedigt werden, obwohl sie heute schon dazu nicht mehr in der Lage sind, ohne weiter zu degradieren. Was wird dieEU den Wäldern geben?  Dass Wälder nachhaltig ("sustainably") genutzt werden sollen, bleibt eine wirkungslose Phrase, mangels klarer, nachprüfbarer und einhaltbarer Kriterien, die Nutzer quasi dazu zwingen würde, die Integrität und Funktionen des Ökosystems wiederherzustellen oder mindestens zu erhalten. Die vor allem von Forst- und Holzwirtschaft unendlich häufig wiederholte Benutzung dieser Phrase alleine wirkt sich nicht günstig auf Waldökosysteme aus, sondern dient eher dazu, eigene wirtschaftliche Ziele zu verfolgen und die Öffentlichkeit über waldschädiche Praktiken zu täuschen. Dies schließt den sorglosen, ja fahrlässigen und verschwenderischen Verbrauch eines Großteils von Holzprodukten mit ein.  Was Europas Wälder brauchen, ist eine völlig andere Strategie zum Umgang mit ihnen:  1. Wirtschaftliche und Konsumptive Begehrlichkeiten müssen als absolut nachrangig behandelt werden 2. Bestehende Belastungen der Wälder müssen reduziert werden:  a Weniger Treibhausgase, Pestizid-und Stickstoffimmissionen b Abkehr von der industrialisierten Waldwirtschaft, die Holzvorräte reduziert und Waldböden massiv schädigt 3. Restaurierung  abgeholzter und geschädigter Waldökosysteme 4. Erweiterung der Zahl und Gesamtfläche holznutzungsfreien Waldgebiete, repräsentativ nach allen vorkommenden Waldökosystemtypen 5. Stopp des illegalen Holzeinschlags und -handels auch innerhalb der EU 6. Definition einer Guten Fachlichen Praxis der Waldnutzung nach messbaren Kriterien, die die Erhaltung bzw. Wiederherstellung der Funktionsfähigkeit der Waldökosysteme als oberste Priorität garantiert 7. Drastische Verringerung verschwenderischer Holznutzung (v.a. Brennholz, Papier und Kartonagen, Einwegverpackungen) 8. Beendigung waldschädlicher Subventionen, vor allem solcher, die eine Wiederbewaldung von Weideflächen (wie z.B. in Schottland) mittels solcher Agrarsubventionen fördern, die weder der Erzeugung von Nahrungsmitteln, noch nachwachsender Rohstoffe dienen 9. Die Vebrennung von Holz darf nicht mehr als klimaneutral bezeichnet oder bewertet werden, weil es einfach nicht stimmt bzw. definitiv falsch ist und den Nutzungsdruck auf die Wälder weiter steigert  10. Stoppen Sie die Pläne, die verstärkte Nutzung von Forstbiomasse weiterhin zu fördern, weil es nicht dem Klimaschutz dient. 11. Sorgen Sie dafür, dass die Holz/Biomassevorräte in Europas Wäldern deutlich erhöht werden, weil dies die wirkungsvollste Maßnahme ist, Wälder klimaschutz wirksam zu managen  László Maráz Forum Umwelt und Entwicklung
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy

feedback_msg_text: All our thanks for consulting us,  It is very important to be complete in the protection of European forests and not to have only technocratic points of view.  Thus we endure a great lack of knowledge from human sciences and perceptual arts to rethink the management of forests and other wooded landscapes in a better cohesion of human / nature relationships. In fact, there is poorly identified unconscious suffering in urban populations who find themselves more and more rooting in uprooted places and who live in rhythms of work out of step with the organic rhythms of forests. Also the people are in loss of feelings with the old natural places and live in mechanical behaviors with their environment.  In France, we are worried about the life expectancy of the tree falling more to more below the human life expectancy. It's still more striking when we compare the reduced life of trees in percentage of prevented life with regard from their natural during. We are losing a link between the organic maturity of forests and the sensitivity maturity of human beings. Having only this idea is'nt enought. We really have to be aware with the level of sensitivity lost from experiences and facts. It's important to support the organic maturity of forests and maturity of cullture and human beahaviour together...  It is necessary to have natural forest places not only to protect biodiversity and keep the references of the free evolution of ecosystems, but also for the awakening of human sensitivity more exceptional in these places than in ordinary forests. We therefore need several types of status in protected forests ... Forests in free evolution for several centuries are reference points to help us to free ourselves from the psychological conditioning of society. Complete forest ecosystems in their cycles are to be experienced as tuning forks of our progress. You need different sizes with an even distribution. It is not only necessary to plant more, but to cut less in order to maintain a stable highest maturity of forest and tree landscapes. Not only for best climate ; also  for deeper peoples' rooting and "rearthing"... It is very difficult to express this request in a few lines without having developed the relevance of the arguments. Also I wish your great investigative curiosity. It's important to include knowledeges from sylvotherapy, ecopsychology, ecotherapies, phenomenology, perceptual arts... in the european ecological rules. To complete ecological knowledges with sensitive knowledges from other disciplines, that's a great help to anticipate in best way, to get more creative answers and social energy.
Initiative: Forests - new EU strategy
