feedback_msg_text: Founded in 1973, the Fédération represents over a hundred internationally known brands and is the voice of the French creative and luxury fashion industry. The Fédération’s members are substantially impacted by the VBER and VGL as most of them rely on vertical agreements for the distribution of their products across Europe. The Fédération was highly involved in the e-commerce sector inquiry, provided its views to the DSM Task Force on the Coty ruling and participated in the Commission’s public consultation on the VBER evaluation.   The Fédération welcomes the Commission’s initiative to adapt the VBER and VGL to the key market developments from the past ten years. The Fédération wishes to share the following specific considerations on the Commission’s inception impact assessment:  • Issues resulting from the new digital world. There is a need for a uniform interpretation of case law. The Fédération encourages the consolidation of the Coty case in line with the interpretation of the Commission in its April 2018 Policy Brief and of the Paris Court of Appeal in the Stihl and Caudalie cases, including as regards the legitimacy of marketplace bans outside the luxury sector and the relevance of the Coty ruling to other distribution models. Brands would also welcome more clarity regarding (i) the circumstances under which online advertising restrictions (e.g., comparison websites, use of brands as keywords on search engines, etc.) are admissible, and (ii) the definition of ‘genuine agency’ in light of the emergence and more widespread use of hybrid sales models (e.g., marketplaces).  • Possible efficiencies resulting from RPM. There are uncertainties in the treatment of RPM in circumstances where RPM could lead to efficiencies. The VGL would benefit from further clarification regarding the compatibility of RPM, notably, for seasonal products or when launching new products.  • Tacitly renewable non-compete obligations. The Commission’s suggestion to make rules on non-compete clauses more flexible would allow for more protection of brands’ investments and know-how.  As regards the policy options for a potential revision of the VBER in certain areas:  • Dual distribution. Treating dual distribution under the vertical rather than horizontal rules is appropriate. However, the Fédération is not opposed to options 2 and 3, including if applied cumulatively, but notes that further clarification on the treatment of information exchanges in this context would be welcomed.  • Active sales restrictions. The Fédération would welcome both options 2 and 3, including if applied cumulatively. Unauthorised sales by grey market operators damage consumers (creating blurred lines between unauthorized products and counterfeited products), brands (decreasing product value and damaging sales environments) and authorized resellers (whose investments and efforts are undermined). Currently, brands struggle to enforce selective distribution against unauthorised resellers. The Fédération importantly calls for the introduction of a mechanism allowing brands to enforce selective distribution agreements against unauthorized third parties.   • Indirect measures restricting online sales. The Fédération recognizes that offline and online channels operate under different commercial conditions and cost structures. The Fédération would welcome both options 2 and 3, including if applied cumulatively. The Covid-19 outbreak significantly affected physical shops and dual pricing would be a key tool to stimulate investments. The Fédération also encourages the Commission to enable brands to apply diverging selective distribution criteria (between online and offline), and to lay down the conditions under which it is possible.  • Parity obligations. The Fédération recognises the need to have a coherent regime on parity clauses at the EU-level and stresses that diverging views at the national level lead to a lack of legal certainty regarding the legality of parity obligations.
Organisation: Fédération de la Haute Couture et de la Mode (hereinafter “the Fédération”)
Initiative: EU competition rules – revision of the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation

feedback_msg_text: CNMI represented, promoted and protected the values and the development of the Italian fashion industry in Italy and globally since 1958 and now represents almost all of the Italian fashion brands. CNMI’s members are particularly impacted by the rules of the VBER and the VGL, as they rely on vertical agreements for the distribution of products across Europe. CNMI was highly involved in the evaluation phase of the VBER review, including through the public consultation, the workshop and additional contributions.   CNMI welcomes and supports the European Commission’s initiative to amend and adapt the VBER and the VGL in order to reflect key market developments from the past ten years. In this context, CNMI wishes to share the following considerations on the Commission’s inception impact assessment:  • Issues resulting from the new digital world. There is a need for a uniform interpretation of case law. The Coty case needs to be consolidated in line with the interpretation of the Commission in its Policy Brief of April 2018 and of the Paris Court of Appeal in the Stihl and Caudalie cases, including as regards the legitimacy of marketplace bans outside the luxury sector and selective distribution. Businesses also need guidance on AdWords restrictions. It needs to be clarified under which circumstances and to what extent AdWords restrictions are admissible. The rules need to clarify and update the definition of ‘genuine agency’ in light of the emergence and widespread use of hybrid sales models (e.g., marketplaces), including by focusing on practical examples and consolidating relevant national decisional practice.  • Possible efficiencies resulting from RPM. There are uncertainties in the treatment of RPM in circumstances where RPM could lead to efficiencies. This should be clarified in the VGL, which should set out clear criteria when RPM practices can be exempted under Art. 101(3) TFEU (e.g., through a de minimis exemption or in the context of a selective distribution system).  • Tacitly renewable non-compete obligations. The Commission’s suggestion to make rules on non-compete clauses more flexible would allow for more protection of brands’ investments and know-how.  With respect to the policy options for a potential revision of the VBER in certain areas:  • Dual distribution. CNMI welcomes the current treatment of dual distribution (i.e., not purely horizontal practices). However, CNMI is not opposed to options 2 and 3, including if applied cumulatively. CNMI would also welcome clarification on the treatment of information exchanges in the context of dual distribution.  • Active sales restrictions. CNMI welcomes both options 2 and 3, including if applied cumulatively. The concept of active/passive sales should be clarified and adapted to current market trends as it is often difficult to determine in practice whether certain behavior online constitutes active or passive selling (e.g., online advertising).  • Indirect measures restricting online sales. CNMI recognizes that online sales do not need the same level of protection as required ten years ago. In this context, CNMI welcomes both options 2 and 3, including if applied cumulatively. Dual pricing would be a key tool to incentivize investment in physical shops in order to ensure consumers fully enjoy and benefit from unique and tailored shopping experiences. More guidance regarding the extent to which diverging selective distribution criteria (between online and offline) are allowed would also be useful.  • Parity obligations. CNMI recognises the need to have a coherent regime on parity obligations at the EU-level and stresses that diverging views at the national level lead to a lack of legal certainty regarding the legality of parity obligations.
Organisation: Camera Nazionale della Moda Italiana (hereinafter CNMI)
Initiative: EU competition rules – revision of the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation
organisation_lower: camera nazionale della moda italiana (hereinafter cnmi)

feedback_msg_text: A harmonisation of insolvency law cannot make a relevant contribution to the establishment of a well-functioning capital markets union. Already at this point, there lacks a compelling interrelation.  For the creation of a capital markets union, it is basically of prime importance that financing conditions in the European Union be aligned and that issuer risk be clearly identifiable. Even for investment decisions, the solvency of securities issuers is likely to be significantly more crucial than  only in exceptional cases applicable insolvency law.  Particularly problematic, moreover, is the suggestion to harmonise creditor hierarchies including the position of secured creditors while factoring in the interests of third parties in insolvency proceedings. Here, it must be borne in mind that interventions in credit collateralisation run the risk of negatively impacting the supply of credit to the economy. Furthermore, crucial interactions with banking supervisory legislation must be taken into account.   The Commission was therefore right to formulate deliberations for the protection of secured creditors against the insolvency of debtors. (“the development of secondary markets for non-performing loans and distressed assets and protection of secured creditors from borrowers’ default” (COM (2018) 134 final, COM (2018) 135 final)). Shortly, the Commission will again release a plan of action that focuses on the extension of secondary markets. In addition, since 2018, there has been proposed legislation for the acceleration of the out-of-court realisation of collateral (Accelerated Extrajudicial Collateral Enforcement Mechanism, AECE), that is currently still being discussed in the ECON committee of the European Parliament. Moreover, for this reason, Art. 5 of the European Insolvency Regulation places credit collateral under special protection. These efforts should not be foiled by weakening the position of loan securities in insolvency procedures.   It should, in addition, be borne in mind that at this point in time insolvency law is facing far-reaching changes. The directive on restructuring and insolvency is currently still being transposed into the national laws of the Member States (implementation deadline: 17 July 2021/2022). There is thus not yet any experience how the provisions of this directive will be integrated into the respective national insolvency laws and then how the courts will interpret this in their decision-making practice. At any rate, before this process is concluded, no further steps should be taken towards a full harmonisation of insolvency legislation. Only in this way can we ensure that the necessary legal certainty will be guaranteed. Otherwise, there is the risk that the barriers to investment could even be raised instead of removed.  Because of the many interactions with other fields of law, insolvency legislation will assume the particularly significant function of an economic-judicial interface. The respective insolvency laws must therefore be coordinated from a content-standpoint too with the (non-harmonised) legal requirements in these fields of law. So long as the general economic conditions of the Member States are not sufficiently aligned, a further alignment of the insolvency regulations is for this very reason not expedient.
Initiative: Insolvency laws: increasing convergence of national laws to encourage cross-border investment

feedback_msg_text: Goal of harmonisation The focus of harmonisation of insolvency laws should be to contribute to the greater economic process. Important (sub) goals grounded in notions of (distributive) justice held within different member states (rights of workers, the environment etc.) should be also reflected. These sub-goals may vary from member state to member state.  Indeed, we see in insolvency law means to achieve an economic outcome and believe that the main goal of alignment should be to achieve this outcome. Before national features can get further aligned, a careful assessment of the existing frameworks aimed at identification of the most efficient regimes in terms of economic outcomes is needed. Such assessment should consider a close interlinkage of national insolvency with the broader framework of hard and soft law and institutions. This complexity contributes to further divergences and different outcomes of insolvency in the EU. Also, the EBA in its report on the benchmarking of national loan enforcement frameworks (EBA/Rep/2020/29) demonstrates that the potential (economic) impact of changes to insolvency law is extensive, nevertheless changes in insolvency law should be done only after careful contemplation given important variations between the member states concerning recovery rate of debt, time to recovery of debt and judicial costs of recovery.  Benchmark The benchmark for harmonisation should be those EU jurisdictions which have a better recovery rate, shorter time to recovery of the debt and lower judicial costs of recovery and other economic parameters, such as the degree insolvency law prevents parties from going bankrupt in the first place. In addition, any harmonisation should still allow member states to adopt a solution that fits within their broader framework. Moreover, member states should also have the option to adopt (non-economic) (sub)goals of insolvency law. The insolvency law of member states should be predictable so that the different implications can be more easily foreseen ex ante.  Suitable subjects Given the differences in the legal system over the EU, we suggest a focused approach. A further research is required most importantly with respect to: - conditions for determining avoidance actions and effects of claw-back rights; - directors’ duties related to handling imminent/actual insolvency proceedings; - court capacity when it comes to expertise and necessary training of judges; and - asset tracing which would be relevant, in particular in the context of avoidance actions. As an additional and related topic we list the following topics: - the prerequisites for when insolvency proceedings should be commenced. - the incentives insolvency law provides to the Insolvency Practitioner, i.e. the person central to most insolvencies.   These topics are all relevant as they affect the behaviour of parties in the period shortly before any insolvency proceedings will be opened and of course the behaviour of parties during the insolvency. Distributive justice goals should not be harmonised. With regard to the EC’s considerations on the position of secured creditors in insolvency, taking into account specific needs for the protection of other creditors (e.g. employees, suppliers),  we think it will be difficult to align those positions given the differences between the national laws on security interests and the preferential rights enjoyed by some creditors. Moreover, these rules affect the behaviour of parties long before insolvency law comes into play.  Conclusion In the light of above, we believe that any attempt to align should be done for the moment by promoting principles and best practices at the EU level. Given the complexity of the EU national regimes (broader context), soft law measures, e.g. EC recommendations should be considered in the first place as the EU harmonization uniquely of the insolvency laws might not bring a desired effect.
Initiative: Insolvency laws: increasing convergence of national laws to encourage cross-border investment

feedback_msg_text: SNCF welcomes the Commission’s initiative to review the Network and Information Security (NIS) Directive and takes note of the several policy options identified in the roadmap. SNCF supports the policy option 3, which consist in introducing targeted changes to the current NIS Directive with a view to clarifying certain provisions and improving harmonisation of the current rules.  SNCF will give a comprehensive reply to the consultation but can already underline a few points at this stage :  . The implementation of the NIS Directive is left to the Operators of Essential Services (OES), however the assignment of OES is not identical across countries, which could lead to competitive disadvantage, especially for Railway Undertakings. OESs often are left without provision of additional resources in terms of budget and tools.  .The way the NIS directive is transposed into national law, in particular the way to determine which services and which operators fall under the national implementations of the NIS Directive (Annex II of the NIS Directive), is very different from country to country. However, from a cybersecurity point of view, the threats are borderless and typically, across a sector (e.g. transportation / rail) the same types of measures should be applied to protect the OES’s. Therefore, it’s wise to decide on the requirements to implement the NIS directive sector-wide instead of nationwide, including how having a faster, more efficient coordination on threats and attacks in progress.  .Guidance and sharing best practices on the measures to be taken by OES: the NIS Directive currently provides only high level description of measures to be taken; there is no harmonization in the procedures for identifying essential activities for an OES, no harmonization in risk analysis methodologies, no harmonization on technical and organizational security measures. The NIS Cooperation Group has developed some guidelines for implementation of the NIS Directive; these guidelines should be reviewed an expanded with the experience of OES on the NIS Directive.
Initiative: Cybersecurity – review of EU rules on the security of network and information systems

feedback_msg_text: The extension of the NIS Directive in scope (increase the number of essential operators) or sectors (inclusion of new sector of activity) would increase the problems already experienced: economic burden (esp. for small businesses), incomplete coverage of ecosystem in same sector, non-level playing field due to differences in Member States implementation, non-coordinated protection European wide… In our view, the NIS Directive should incorporate mandatory strategic orientations, under appropriate European coordination of CSIRTs/NIS Cyber Authorities: - Identification and protection of key “essential technological components / systems / infrastructure” which contribute to an agreed list of “essential services” for the European Citizen. - Define a minimum set of security controls based on existing standards catalogues (e.g. ISO, CEN) to decrease variability between Member States and ensure level playing field.   - Implementation of Detection and Response capacities to cyber incidents for those operators delivering “essential services” in the form of services, self-assured or provided by operators accredited / certificated by NIS Cyber Authorities. This approach would focus on relevant key technologies necessary to protect the essential services, and to some extent would better complement European legal framework: GDPR for data (content – personal data only), CyberSecurity Act (technological certification frameworks) and eIDAS (extension to private sector - EU digital identity). It would be sector independent (only the essential characteristics of the service are taken into account), could be deployed independently of size (only the technology and/or contribution to the service is accounted for) and relies on European wide detection and response to incidents which the network of CSERTs and NIS Cyber Authorities could support and coordinate. Finally, in order to further contribute to European sovereignty, Members States as well as European Union bodies should promote those standards protecting “essential services” as defined above with the view to contribute to the protection and promotion of essential sectors for the European economy and its citizen.
Organisation: DSNA French Air Navigation Service Provider
Initiative: Cybersecurity – review of EU rules on the security of network and information systems

feedback_msg_text: Bitkom strongly welcomes the integration of relevant stakeholder opinions in order to streamline public and private efforts striving for an improved cybersecurity throughout the European Union (EU). That is why we would like to seize the opportunity and provide our feedback already at an early stage of the revision of the Directive (EU) 2016/1148 concerning measures for implementing an equivalent and commonly high level of security in network and information systems across the Union (hereafter referred to as the NIS Directive). As the first milestone on the way to a revised legislative proposal scheduled for Q4 2020, we value the recently published and combined Evaluation Roadmap / Inception Impact Assessment for sharing our insights and position with the Commission.   As in past years, Bitkom strongly endorses the EU in its efforts to substantially and sus-tainably strengthen the resilience of networks and systems against cybersecurity risks across Europe whilst deepening the harmonization of the European Digital Single Market and avoiding fragmentation at the same time. Our position is guided by the urgent need to create a more coherent and harmonized common level playing field for operators of essential services (OES) as well as for digital service providers (DSP) across the Union. We are convinced that common and harmonized cybersecurity rules at EU level are the most effective way to achieve a higher level of cyber resilience.    Bitkom shares the commissions’ overall assessment that, since its adoption, the NIS Directive has enabled and further facilitated the advancement of cybersecurity capabilities within EU Member States. However, we are witnessing constantly evolving threat scenarios and expanding attack surfaces, putting network and information systems at great risk. Therefore, and in line with the Commissions line of reasoning expressed in their Roadmap, Bitkom equally sees the necessity to advance the deadline foreseen under Article 23(2) and to review the NIS Directive before the end of 2020.     In tangible terms, we endorse the third policy option, namely targeted regulatory intervention. While the empirical evidence provided by the OLS Report revealed several persisting inconsistencies that are best addressed by legal amendments, we remain cautious to adopt an entirely new legislative act. Although well-intended, the latter (policy option four) would imply a long and time-consuming process that may not keep up with the constantly evolving particularities of the cyber and IT security. Hence, we call instead for an approach that addresses the most pressing issues in the first place by revising certain aspects of the NIS Directive but still offers the private sector the necessary leeway in order to develop its own content-tailored solutions and innovative ideas to significantly strengthen Europe’s cyber-resilience. The protection of networks and systems against any form of disruption is in the innermost interest of OES and DSP.   Furthermore, the scope of the revised directive should be in accordance with the most serious threats for network and information security. In the case of OES, member states are allowed to impose stricter security and notification requirements than those enshrined in the current Directive. This does, however, not account for DSP. Bitkom contin-ues to favor a “light-touch” regulatory approach as the appropriate way forward concerning DSP, especially in view of their rapidly changing nature and innovative potential.   Please find our complete position attached as a PDF document. Feedback from: Bitkom e.V. (Federal Association for Information Technology, Telecommunications and New Media) (94.2 KB - PDF - 7 pages) Download
Organisation: Bitkom e.V. (Federal Association for Information Technology, Telecommunications and New Media)
Initiative: Cybersecurity – review of EU rules on the security of network and information systems

feedback_msg_text: ChargeUp Europe welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to review the EU rules on the security of network and information systems. ChargeUp Europe is the voice of the electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure industry and has been formed accelerate the switch to zero-emission mobility and ensure a seamless driver experience with access to high quality, readily available charging infrastructure across Europe. As of today, our member companies represent over 175.000 charging points in all 27 EU Member States.  The security of network and information systems represents one of the key foundational values of ChargeUp Europe and the revision of the NIS Directive comes at a critical time in Europe’s transformation into a smart and sustainable economy.   The uptake of EVs is developing at a very fast pace. EV drivers need to be guaranteed access to reliable and secure charging infrastructure and it is imperative that their user data is secured. Ensuring more consumer-friendly experience for EV drivers, to boost e-mobility uptake, must go hand in hand with ensuring higher privacy and security standards.  There are numerous steps in the EV charging process which involve communication between networked elements and thus the EV charging value chain should be clearly and coherently covered by the scope of the NIS Directive across Member States. The priority must be on ensuring that EV drivers feel safe and secure wherever they travel in Europe.   In this respect, EV charging infrastructure should be considered as critical infrastructure and the relevant operators should fall under the category of “operator of essential services” as laid down in Article 5(2) and illustrated in Annex II of the Directive.  In our view, the European Commission’s Impact Assessment should look at: 1. How to ensure a coherent definition of critical infrastructure in Member States. In this sense the European Commission could make recommendations on a list of what is considered as critical infrastructure. 2. How to guarantee multiple certificate issuers and multiple standards, ensure an open market, and combat potential pitfalls of monopolistic behaviors. Market operators should be able to freely choose between different encryption certificates.  3. How to ensure compliance costs will not hurt consumers, both in terms of ease of use and in terms of implementation costs. In the specific case of EV charging infrastructure, drivers will need to be guaranteed a smooth experience with new systems, without waiting for updates or system waiting times when charging their vehicles, and without paying considerable extra costs.  4. The potential benefits of a system of regulatory oversight at EU level to deal with repercussions for value chain players who do not comply with the standards.
Initiative: Cybersecurity – review of EU rules on the security of network and information systems

feedback_msg_text: ERA welcomes the opportunity to comment on the roadmap - Allocation of slots at European airports.   Although one would have hoped that after so many months the COVID pandemic would be overcome, this has sadly not been the case. Whilst the Commission has now announced it will grant a waiver for the upcoming 2020 winter season, which was very welcomed, but should really have been delivered before mid-September. We would strongly encourage the Commission to take an early view with regards to the forthcoming IATA Summer 2021 and Winter 2021/22 seasons.   In normal circumstances, planning for the Summer 2021 season would have already been well underway by now with many schedules and planning processes already very mature. However, with the recent surge in COVID cases across the globe, it is abundantly clear that it will be impossible for airlines to plan for the coming summer, and most likely into the winter 2022 season.   This is exacerbated by the benefits brought about by the Single Aviation Market not currently being in place and the haphazard manner of the implementation of border restrictions. Further application of the 80-20 rule on airlines who will be scrambling to put in place a schedule only for this to be dismantled following the application of restrictions, cannot be supported and places a huge burden on those who are already facing enormous operational and financial challenges.   Travel restrictions, in particular sudden flight bans and unilateral quarantine measures have effectively killed passenger confidence, which will take so while to be restored even after a vaccine is made available.   Thus, if the 80-20 rule were to be applied next Summer, ERA airlines will have no choice other than operating so-called ghost flights. This will be completely unacceptable, unaligned with environmental sustainability targets and against the spirit of the European Green Deal, and a drain on already lean operational resources.   ERA does not believe that there will be distortion of competition in case of a waiver for the Summer season.   During the course of the past few months, feedback suggests that ERA airlines have usually been granted any slots they wish to operate, whether in the EU or outside of it.  All regions of the world are granting waivers, as noted, the EU were quite late to formalise their position and this actually led more higher uncertainty and complexity, rather than any perceived market distortion.   With regards to the late hand-back of slots, ERA is of the opinion that if this has occurred in the past, it was primarily due to the uncertainty of the legal regime and of demand / associated constraints. In a usual planning schedule planning cycle, it is not in the interests of the airline to hand back slots late.  Given the unpredictable nature of the virus /crisis with no certainty on when we will come out the other side and start returning to 'normal' operations, having more certainty on matters that are within the gift of the Commission is of vital importance.   A continued slot waiver into next Summer 2021 / Winter 2022, will give airlines a more robust platform on which to plan with increased confidence, return slots earlier and give the Network a solid foundation by which to make their operational decisions in support of building back better.
Initiative: Allocation of slots at European airports – amended rules

feedback_msg_text: Dès le mois de mars 2020, en pleine première vague de la crise de la Covid-19, l’ensemble des décideurs européens n’a pas hésité à prendre une mesure forte pour aider les compagnies aériennes en permettant l’adoption du règlement (UE) 2020/459 du 30 mars 2020 modifiant le règlement (CEE) no 95/93 du Conseil fixant des règles communes en ce qui concerne l’attribution des créneaux horaires dans les aéroports de la Communauté, permettant ainsi le gel de l’attribution des créneaux horaires pour la période du 1er mars 2020 (ou même à partir du 23 janvier, pour les créneaux UE-Chine) au 24 octobre 2020.  Ce règlement de mars 2020 a également prévu la possibilité pour la Commission européenne de proroger ce moratoire grâce à l’adoption d’un acte délégué si, en raison de la persistance des risques sanitaires liés à la Covid-19, la baisse du niveau du trafic aérien persiste par rapport au niveau de la période correspondante de l’année précédente et est susceptible de se poursuivre.  Les compagnies aériennes européennes rencontrent exactement cette situation. La persistance de la fermeture des frontières, l’obligation de devoir effectuer des quarantaines, l’absence de visibilité sur l’évolution de la situation étant donné la propagation toujours persistante de la pandémie ou encore la crainte grandissante d’une seconde vague de la crise, justifient la prorogation de cette mesure au moins pour les prochaines saisons 2020/2021. En raison de cette situation de crise sanitaire exceptionnelle et de ces circonstances qui échappent au contrôle des transporteurs aériens, le SNPL France ALPA (Syndicat national des pilotes de ligne) est favorable à la proposition législative de la Commission européenne visant à proroger le gel des créneaux horaires, ce, au moins jusqu’en avril 2021. En effet, l’annulation volontaire ou obligatoire des services aériens par les transporteurs aériens constitue une réponse nécessaire ou légitime à ces circonstances. En particulier, les annulations volontaires protègent la santé financière des transporteurs aériens et de plus, évitent les incidences négatives sur l’environnement de l’exploitation de vols uniquement dans le but de conserver les créneaux horaires sous-jacents.
Initiative: Allocation of slots at European airports – amended rules

feedback_msg_text: STORENGY welcomes the opportunity to give our feedback and the initiative to work on the TEN-E regulation, to answer the green deal ambition. From our point of view, it should take into account the need for sector coupling and conversion of gas infrastructures to renewable gases like hydrogen. In addition, considering the need to store renewable electricity, gas infrastructures can be used for sector coupling thanks to power-to-gas which is the only known way to store massive renewable electricity quantities. In an energy system integration, gas storages will contribute to increase green gases and green power supply, optimize the energy system.  • Optimization of the cost of hydrogen supply: because hydrogen can be stored (for example in salt caverns), it can be produced or bought when the less expensive (especially when renewable electricity is the less expensive).  • Safety Supply to launch a new offer for renewable hydrogen : to develop any end-use of renewable hydrogen, hydrogen suppliers will need a stable, flexible offer for their customers. Storages will provide this offer. • Storages will contribute to the development of renewable electricity: by storing additional electricity (as renewable hydrogen) that can not be injected into the electricity grid. Storages will enable and materialized sector coupling between gas infrastructures and power system. Let’s not forget that gas storages had been conceived to optimize gas infrastructures so that less expensive investments in transmission grid were required to answer energy peak demand. The regulatory framework should be defined to support renewable gases industry and accelerate the conversion of gas infrastructures using additional funds.
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: The EU is aiming at carbon neutrality by 2050. Since only a certain level of electrification of the EU economy is possible, the decarbonisation of the different sectors will be achieved by a combination of renewable electricity and Clean Gases (renewable, decarbonised and low-carbon)  The role of Clean Gases, in particular Clean Hydrogen, in the decarbonisation should not only be seen as a subsidiary, but they should be allowed to compete on a level-playing field since they can be the most efficient solution in the long term in some industries  Enagás proposes two categories: 1. Projects aimed at enabling Clean Gases and decarbonise the gas infrastructure system. Due to the innovation required to develop and upscale these technologies, the whole value chain shall be considered with particular focus on:  a. The decarbonisation of the gas system will require new installations dedicated to (1) produce Clean Gases such as P2G plants including electrolysers; biomethane plants; and (2) the injection of those Clean Gases into the existing gas grid  b. The TEN-E should support the retrofitting/future-proofing of existing infrastructure c. In order to allow for the transport of pure H2, TEN-E could support the repurposing of existing natural gas pipelines or the construction of dedicated hydrogen infrastructure/pipelines  The European Relevance criterion for this category shall be redefined:  • Clean Gases projects substantially reduce GHG emissions have a global impact  • International consortia and agreements involving two or more Member States, regardless of the presence of a physical interconnection • Innovative project acquiring in advance a compromise of knowledge-sharing/diffusion of lessons learnt  • Projects allowing technology development and scaling up production of Clean Gases   2. Gas traditional projects as currently defined  Infrastructures and projects enabling Clean Gases are in an initial stage of implementation in Europe. Therefore the EC should adopt a flexible approach to avoid slowing down their development  • The current corridors might still be relevant for traditional infrastructures but it is too soon to assess if they will be adapted to Clean Gases • The EC should define thematic areas for the Clean Gases projects, potentially covering the whole value chain: Renewable Hydrogen/Green Hydrogen; Blue Hydrogen; Biomethane While Blue Hydrogen will play a role in the transition, the focus of the TEN-E should be on Green Hydrogen, to ensure its competitiveness in the long term. Green Hydrogen will also play a key role in providing flexibility and storage for the whole system  As regards the PCI selection criteria, Enagás supports wider climate impact and reinforced sustainability criteria. For projects aimed to enable Clean Gases and decarbonise the gas infrastructure system the following elements should be reflected in the criteria: a. Decarbonisation potential and GHG reduction (as sustainability) b. Reduction of the external dependence of supplies (as SoS) c. Innovation, technology development and scaling up benefits  As regards eligibility and criteria, the CEF shall contribute to enabling Clean Gases, considering innovation, SoS and decarbonisation potential as criteria to fund the PCI. Funds should be more accessible to innovative PCIs, updating the CBA methodology to include these benefits  Regarding the selection procedure for PCIs, an integrated sector coupling approach would facilitate the cost-optimal development of the electricity system. ENTSOG initiatives adopted to ensure coordinated planning (interlink model, the inclusion of ETRs) is the right approach. The CBA methodology also needs to be updated to assess the benefits and potential of the Clean Gases  In addition, the effectiveness of the process defined in the TEN-E should be enhanced not only as regards PCI selection but also as regards as the Investment Request procedure. A better definition of the timing & milestones, and ACER role is required Feedback from: Enagás (2.6 MB - PDF - 8 pages) Download
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines  Appropriate revision of TEN-E Regulation may become a cornerstone of the new energy system model.   The PGE Capital Group finds the European Commission’s view on the possible future shape of TEN-E Regulation properly envisaged with energy infrastructure as a key enabler for the energy transition. TEN-E Regulation seems to be outdated as its main purpose was to develop more interconnected systems, primarily through large-scale transmission investments and this challenge is mostly accomplished. Therefore, areas we believe should become more emphasized in the revised TEN-E Regulation are those pertaining to distribution grid projects both on medium and low voltage enabling further renewables integration, demand side response appliances, replacing of overhead cables with underground ones, storage, as well as smart grid development including flexibility, developed considerably over the past years due to digitalisation of the electricity sector. We believe that to assure further development of these solutions respective EU policy framework becomes fundamental. In case of large-scale transmission projects, revised TEN-E Regulation should focus on offshore grid development, including energy connection infrastructure between the offshore wind farms and onshore transmission system.   The abovementioned grid investments will contribute to the grid development necessary to foster the deployment of renewable energy. However, it is the first step to enable well-functioning internal market, which cannot be fully established without eliminating internal congestions and grid failures.         We also share the view that upcoming impact assessment should explore options in new infrastructure categories, updated priority corridors and thematic areas (especially on distribution grid level).   Yet, „no change” option as a baseline scenario for revised TEN-E Regulation should be altered. In our opinion the Regulation is outdated, thus baseline scenario should already cover the revision and „no change” option would be applied only if the impact assessment clearly shows that revision is not to deliver any significant benefits.   We also opt for relaxing the eligibility criteria for Connecting Europe Facility financial assistance instead of including enhanced environmental criteria and environment impact assessment of each potential PCI since we believe that this may be difficult to establish and not objectively justified especially for grid investments.
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: Polish Power Transmission and Distribution Association (PTPiREE) is an organization of the distribution network operators and the transmission network operator in Poland. It works for the transformation of the Polish power industry, aiming to improve the operational efficiency of the power network, as well as the quality of services and customer service. The work of PTPiREE includes a number of thematic areas, which are addressed by numerous committees and working groups that actively involve representatives of energy companies affiliated in the association. The Committee of European Funds at PTPiREE notices the need to review and update the EU regulatory framework for energy infrastructure, including the Regulation (EU) No 347/2013 on guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure (the "TEN-E Regulation").  The need to maintain the EU's competitiveness, accelerate the transition to clean energy by modernizing the European economy and the observation of changes in technology trends in the electricity market, became an inspiration for the European Union's new energy package "Clean Energy for All Europeans." The future energy market model sets tasks and roles for distribution system operators (DSOs), which are increasingly important. The operators are no longer only neutral support for the energy market. They are key enablers of the energy transition and  will soon become the leading actors in many areas - including innovation, energy storage, smart grid, energy efficiency, electromobility, cooperation with prosumers and renewable energy sources. The distribution system level will play a more important role in energy infrastructure planning also because the majority of renewable energy generation is connected to the low and medium voltage grid.  You will find an input for the possible evolutions of the TEN-E regulation in the document attached. Feedback from: Polish Power Transmission and Distribution Association (PTPiREE) (94.6 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download
Organisation: Polish Power Transmission and Distribution Association (PTPiREE)

feedback_msg_text: Deutsche Umwelthilfe (DUH) welcomes the opportunity to consult on the revision of the TEN-E regulation. The roadmap reads as a step in the right direction to make EU infrastructure planning compatible with energy and climate goals. Energy infrastructure is rightly recognized as a key enabler towards the EU’s decarbonisation objectives for 2030 and 2050.  We fully support the efficiency first principle as an important way to reinforce sustainability criteria for PCIs. Following the adoption of the fourth PCI list, the Commission has committed to include only projects contributing to achieving the Green Deal objective in future lists. It is important that the sustainability criteria, currently under development, be ready before the adoption of the fifth PCI list to ensure that new infrastructure does not hinder the EU’s climate neutrality goal.   Infrastructure projects, including priority infrastructure, must also be assessed in line with the Nature, Strategic Environmental Assessment and Environmental Impact Assessment Directives. There is a risk that fast-tracking procedures could compromise compliance with these important environmental requirements. The attribution of priority status should be carefully examined and excluded for projects, which might affect the climate, sites, or species, which are protected for their nature or biodiversity value. Cost-benefit analyses to define priority projects should assess a number of factors, including environmental and climate impacts as well as costs associated with health, environmental and nature protection.  DUH appreciates the inclusion of new infrastructure categories into the revised regulation. However, new categories must not open the door for projects that counteract climate neutrality or subsidiarity.   DUH welcomes the approach to reduce barriers linking the electricity and gas sector. While reasonable for grid management and industry, this link is not necessary for the heating sector. Key for decarbonising the heating sector are electrification, renewables and energy efficiency via decentralised (district) solutions.   It is correct that the distribution system level will play a more important role in energy infrastructure planning. When cross-border projects at distribution level are beneficial – for example if they relieve cross-border interconnectors – PCI status and funding can be appropriate. DUH also welcomes the promotion of offshore renewable installations as options for a PCI. Offshore wind in the North Sea holds great reserves for renewable capacity needed in a transition towards 100% renewables.   The TEN-E Regulation should exclude any support for “blue” hydrogen and Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS), as it merely delays the release of carbon into the atmosphere. CCS cannot technically achieve a 100% capture rate and is therefore incompatible with carbon neutrality.  Currently, only European Transmission System Operators, acting through ENTSO-E and ENTSO-G, are responsible for writing the Ten Year Network Development Plans (TYNDP), which in turn largely define the selection of priority projects. This creates an unacceptable conflict of interest resulting in high projections for future fossil gas demand and a lack of consideration of non-infrastructure solutions to energy needs.   The revision should fully remove the conflict of interest and biases inherent in the dominant role of the ENTSOs. This could be achieved by giving a more binding role to ACER and/or the establishment of an independent scientific body to develop the energy scenarios and CBA. Public participation, access to information and the role of the European Parliament in establishing TYNDP scenarios and the PCI list should be improved. The European Parliament should have the right to question or reject individual PCI projects.
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: Corre Energy (CE) develops mass-energy storage facilities which comprise assets (storage technologies) designed to provide various wholesale & retail storage solutions & services to the energy market. Designed to provide the cheapest unit cost of storage, the facilities benefit from technology diversification, smart sizing (tied to market demand) & dynamic allocation to customers when storage is most needed. CE is a thought leader in the application of energy storage solutions which address balancing requirements & system needs resulting from increased integration of intermittent RE. Built around a strategy to develop the storage market in the Netherlands, it is expanding on a pan-European basis. CE has a unique capability to assess & manage the complex interplay between markets, regulatory frameworks, technology design & stakeholders to derive commercially viable propositions for storage projects. Organised as “green hydrogen hubs” the model differs fundamentally from traditional approaches that involve single technology projects with limited use cases, which tend to result in very high storage costs. The hubs can serve multiple applications and customers. Initially, they are to be designed around large-scale air & H2 storage facilities involving underground salt caverns. CE will choose technology configurations which will meet market requirements in terms of value, cost, & reliability. Corre Energy support the overarching aim of this consultation & would ask that it is closely linked to energy sector integration – H2 (vice versa). Any strategy must first prioritise then accelerate the deployment of 100% green hydrogen-fuelled Compressed Air Energy Storage technology, H2 production & long term storage to facilitate GW scale RES integration across Europe, providing a very wide range of services to the market, especially where topographic and environmental constraints limit pumped hydro potential.  A well-constructed hydrogen strategy can provide the initial impetus needed to launch the transition to a cross-sectoral hydrogen economy that will provide a sustainable & secure energy future for Europe. By using green hydrogen to provide essential balancing and grid support services for RES integration at lowest cost, energy transition PCI’s (such as PCI 1.17) will enhance the business cases for both RES & green H2 production, thereby kick-starting the circular economy essential for the energy transition. The strategy must develop & demonstrate an innovative market-based business model for electricity storage in EU. This is essential as revenues from regulated products (system services) for the TSO are insufficient on their own to incentivise investment in energy storage solutions. Developers have new customer based business models that provide a commercial basis for new EU-wide deployment of a range of electricity storage technologies (including battery, CAES and pumped storage) with large capacities and long durations suitable to meet location specific and market-wide requirements. This strategy must maximise the use & value of Europe’s RE resource to progress the cost-effective realisation of EU mid- and long-term targets for RES integration and CO2 reduction. The strategy must promote investment in large-scale RES such as offshore wind by providing a hedge against price and volume risk, thus reducing a risk premium that may inhibit investment in such projects. This strategy can ensure EU’s position at the forefront of RE integration and energy storage technology development. By supporting the demonstration deployment of green H2 CAES technology, the right strategy will stimulate further development and export of renewable technologies and services. Finally the evaluation must ensure that the barriers to storage within the TEN-E regulation fall away to produce a regulatory framework that is cross sectoral allowing, in turn massive scale up of H2 production and storage that is complementary to the overall hydrogen value chain.
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: The general objective of the TEN E revision  must set the rules for Europe’s future energy infrastructure in a way conducive both to the economic recovery and the delivery of a robust EU Green Deal objective. The revision must guarantee that TEN E: 1. shall set the rules for Europe’s future energy infrastructure leading to a successful energy transition in line with the Paris Agreement, the European Green Deal, the Climate Law, the Climate Neutrality objective by 2050 and Nature Directives. 2. Shall exclude any new or continued investments supporting infrastructure based on fossil fuels, or on incompatible climate mitigation objectives 3. Shall support only investments in line with achieving net zero emissions as soon as possible, but not later than in 2050 4. Shall contribute to reducing energy poverty, strengthening energy security and resilience, and creating  green jobs
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: Gas Networks Ireland (GNI) and its parent company Ervia, welcome the opportunity to provide feedback on the ‘Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines consultation’.  GNI & Ervia recognise that in light of the Covid 19 crisis, the EU’s ‘Green Deal’ can aid the recovery of the EU Economy whilst also setting Europe on the pathway to sustainability.   GNI & Ervia also recognise that the TEN-E regulation should be deployed as a key mechanism to deliver the ambition set out in the Green Deal. While the focus will be on energy transition projects it is important that the achievements of the TEN-E regulation in delivering a secure and integrated energy market are maintained and built upon. Gas infrastructure has contributed to a secure and integrated energy market in the EU via the PCI process.  GNI & Ervia support the view that the revised TEN-E regulation should “foster the deployment of innovative technologies and infrastructure, such as smart grids, networks for hydrogen and other carbon neutral/renewable gases, Carbon Capture, Storage and Utilisation (CCUS), and energy storage.” The revised TEN-E Regulation can play a key role in the realisation of a decarbonised gas system in the EU.  GNI & Ervia also agree that, “smart sector integration between the power and gas systems, as well as with other sectors such as transport and industry, offers additional opportunities to decarbonise the gas grid and manage the power system more efficiently”. The truly integrated energy system should maximise the utilisation of existing assets wherever possible, and deliver a decarbonised energy system at least cost and with least disruption to end users.  It should provide security of supply and flexibility and allow energy to be conveyed via multiple carriers in an optimised manner.   Integrated system planning will be required to allow the optimisation of all assets and energy carriers. The PCI project evaluation process carried out by both ENTSOG and ENTSO-E should be fully integrated, allowing for an adequate needs assessment on an all-energy system basis.   It is also important to account for the changing dynamics of energy production, with a trend to more distributed energy production from renewable sources. This will be the case with biomethane and renewable hydrogen production. New project types will be required to enable the integration of renewable gases, including bi-directional flows between gas distribution and transmission networks and central grid injection points for renewable gases. Thus the role of distribution networks in gas and electricity should also be considered in the revised Regulation. The cross border requirement for PCI projects should also be removed once projects contribute to the achievement of the EU’s climate and energy objectives.  A range of innovative solutions is required across all sectors and across all energy carriers to meet the EU’s climate and energy targets. There will be some uncertainty around the development of key technologies, in particular as to whether certain technologies can be scaled up and costs reduced to competitive levels. Given this uncertainty, it is important not to rule out any technologies at an early stage. All technology options should be treated on an equal basis and evaluated in terms of their decarbonisation potential and costs. It is important that the treatment and categorisation of key technologies subject to full Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) across all sectors, to allow for fair comparisons of different energy transition technologies at EU level.  The role of the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) should be extended to cover R&D and innovation in key technologies i.e. biomethane, Power to Gas and CCS. The fund could be supported by ring-fencing of funds derived from the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS); directed towards the promotion of decarbonised gases.
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: European Alliance to Save Energy (EU-ASE) Response for TEN-E Consultation Roadmap  The EU Member States are under-delivering on energy efficiency and contributions planned in the national energy and climate plans are not promising, setting the Union for falling short by 4.2 percentage points on its 2030 target. To address this challenge, energy efficiency first needs to be incorporated across scenario development, project evaluation and project eligibility.    Energy efficiency for project eligibility   Several EU financing instruments and policies have already been updated to enhance energy efficiency investments – see InvestEU and EIB energy lending policy. Building or recognizing the potential of infrastructures which accommodates the deployment of these already matured technologies is equally crucial.   The next TEN E regulation needs to rethink the project eligibility. Different reports (Energy Union Choice, BPIE, RAP) highlight how aggregated building renovation projects could be considered infrastructure projects at equal footing as a supply-side measure . This could give a “delivery tool” to the upcoming Renovation Wave announced by the European Commission. The recent smart grid projects that allowed “virtual aggregation” could be an example of how to interpret this in the context of the need for a cross-border impact .  Energy efficiency first applied to scenario development and project evaluation   Infrastructure needs are currently identified by supply-side stakeholders in electricity and gas – the transmission system operators. For a changing energy system, new expertise is required to integrate in infrastructure planning the role of a more active demand side, the impact of rolling out large scale energy efficiency measures, the further integration of sectors and networks.   All ENTSOs’ scenarios raised concerns among NGOs, businesses and trade associations regarding the modest assumptions used for some mature technologies such as renewable energy growth rates, energy efficiency and demand response, while assumptions around the deployment of carbon capture technologies (CCS and BECCS) are bold. Current ENTSOs’ scenarios are linked but do not optimise the system and disregard important solutions around energy efficiency, heat networks, or demand-side management. Despite the criticsm, in its consultation roadmap the Commission does not envisage to consult energy efficiency stakeholders in the revision process.   Political choices such as these need to be informed by independent expertise, based on the latest science and evidence and taken by decision-makers with a political mandate to protect citizens’ interests. These independently provided assumptions should inform a robust assessment of the wider pool of options – across scenario building and all the way through to Cost-Benefit Analysis.     Feedback from: European Alliance to Save Energy (312.8 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Trans-European energy infrastructure – revision of guidelines

feedback_msg_text: Gasum is a Nordic energy company that operates in gas sector and energy markets. Together with our partners, we promote development towards a carbon-neutral future on land and at sea. We are the leading supplier of biogas and processer of biodegradable waste fractions in the Nordic countries. Gasum is a fully Finnish state-owned company and is committed to work towards the Global Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of the United Nations.  Gasum processes 40% of Finland’s sewage sludges. Our waste processing service enables the re-use of biodegradable waste material as energy, thereby reducing the energy lost in processes such as waste combustion or composting. We also accelerate the change to lesser the reliance on fossil-based traffic fuels and fertilizer consumption.  As a key feed component in biogas production, the upcoming? directive should steer regulation towards increasing sewage sludge use in biogas production.   Majority of sewage sludge-based biogas in Finland is produced in co-treatment plants where multiple feed stock (sewage sludge, biowaste, industrial sludges) is digestated. This is locally the most economical and environmentally feasible way to produce biogas, handle waste management and recycle nutrients.         Increase of nutrient residues and organic matter arising as a by-product in biogas production must be returned either as recycled nutrients to industry or as recycled fertilizers and organic matter to agriculture and landscaping.  The positive circular economy impact of sewage sludge-based nutrient/fertilizer production as biogas productions by-product needs to be there for highlighted and considered as an objective in directive renewal.   The quality and safety of sewage sludge feed should be monitored in its origin, and directive should develop source control. If directive should determine the contaminants and limit values, it should be based on studied facts and that can be tested by methods reliably verified. There is no need of decreasing nutrient concentrations in sewage sludges when used as feed in biogas plant.  Digestate from biogas production is approved as a fertilizer according to the EU’s fertilizer regulation but if sewage sludge is used as a feedstock, digestate approval as fertilizer is excluded. Sewage sludge based digestate should be covered by the fertilizer regulation.  More research on the safe use of sewage sludge fertilizers is needed. The limits for contaminants in the digestate need to be defined in fertilizer regulation and limits of sewage-based feedstock in sewage directive. There should not be any “grey area” where limits are not defined at all.   Directive should aim towards similar regulations, sewage sludge handling and nutrient and organic matter recycling between different countries to ensure the circular economy goals set in EU.  Katja Alhonoja, Development Manager, Gasum Oy
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Die Qualitätsgemeinschaft für nachhaltige Düngung und Ressourcenschutz  begrüßt die Initiative der EU-Kommission für eine öffentliche Konsultation zur Bewertung der EU-Klärschlammrichtlinie (EU 86/278) und bedankt sich für die Möglichkeit der Stellungnahme.  Bei der Abwasserreinigung werden dem Abwasser die Nährstoffe entzogen, die die Pflanzen zuvor aus den Böden aufgenommen haben und die mit den menschlichen Verdauungsprodukten in die Abwässer gelangen. Klärschlamm ist von daher in erster Linie eine Nährstoffsenke, die alle Nährstoffe sowie alle Spurenelemente und die humusbildende organische Substanz enthält. Diese Ressource wird zur Erhaltung der Fruchtbarkeit der Böden und zur Sicherstellung der Ernährung benötigt.  Sofern Umweltschadstoffe in Abwässer gelangen, muss ihr Eintrag an der Quelle bekämpft werden, um den natürlichen Kreislauf der Nährstoffe zu erhalten. Anthropogene Spurenstoffe, die in Abwassersysteme gelangen, werden nur teilweise an Klärschlämme gebunden und gelangen mit dem Kläranlagenablauf in Oberflächengewässer. Aquatische Lebensräume reagieren deutlich sensibler auf den Eintrag an Schadstoffen als terrestrische Lebensräume.  Die Bedrohung der  aquatischen Lebensräume, die zum großen Teil auf die Verschmutzung mit Schadstoffen zurückzuführen ist, kann zum größten Artensterben der letzten 55 Millionen Jahre führen [2]. Deshalb ist die Einleitung von anthropogenen Spurenstoffen in Abwässer und Oberflächengewässer so weit und so schnell wie möglich zu vermindern. Wenn der Eintrag von Schadstoffen über Abwässer in aquatische Lebensräume so weit vermindert wird, dass ihr Schutz gewährleistet wird, so ist davon auszugehen, dass auch der Schutz des Bodens vor einer Anreicherung von Schadstoffen aufgrund der Verwendung von Klärschlamm als Düngemittel gewährleistet ist. Mit unserer Stellungnahme zur Bewertung der EU-Klärschlammrichtlinie (EU 86/278) erläutern wir, zu welchen Punkten wir Ergänzungsbedarf bei der Überarbeitung der Richtlinie sehen und inwieweit wir eine stärkere Kohärenz zu anderen EU-Richtlinien für erforderlich halten. Feedback from: QDR e.V. (1.7 MB - PDF - 15 pages) Download
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: VEAS treats wastewater from the Oslo region in Norway. The sludge is processed into LBG (Liquified biogas) for transportation purposes, a nitrogen-liquid for fertilizer production and biosolids for agricultural use. Our vision is to create value of the waste resources and take a lead in the circular economy.  Ahead of huge, long term investments in sludge treatment technology, our position is that sludge is too valuable to be destructed.   Harvesting nitrogen and phosphorus from sludge is relatively well accepted. However also the organic matter must be utilized, to prevent or reduce loss of organic matter from soil and preserve soil fertility, which is a growing, global concern. Long term field trials outside Malmø, Sweden, demonstrates the positive effects of sludge.   On the other hand, sewage sludge reflects human life and activities. We find whatever good or harmful compounds we look for, both in the wastewater and in the sludge. This cannot be ignored.  Our messages to a possible revision of the SSD are as follows: The good intention of the SSD must be continued: To balance the utilization of the resources in SS against the (potential) harmful effects. The SSD must take SS and SS based products into the circular economy   Reusing the SS-resources, including organic matter, for agricultural and similar purposes, is a driving force for up-stream work in a wide definition. This will serve both soil- and water quality and human health.   Regulation must be based on quality, not origin. Quality requirements must be scientific based.   End of waste-criteria should be applicable for SS, as for other waste material, given that scientifically based criteria, assuring the public health, are developed to define allowed treatment methods and product purity.  Validated and approved treatment methods, and well defined quality requirements, will contribute to predictable qualities and hopefully to reassure the food industry and the public.  Communication is vital, and must include the value, the circularity, the role in the green shift – as well as the measures taken to make sure the practice is sustainable.   One size does not fit all: National, regional and local conditions are different, regarding catchments, climate, pollution status, soil-types, growths etc. Recommendations and regulations must take this into account.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: The changes that have been made over the last 35 years in the EU policies on resources efficiency and circular economy, the increasing concerns about certain types of water pollutants and sources of pollution, and the technological improvements in waste water and sewage sludge management, make it advisable if not necessary to deeply revise the current SSD. In particular, the effort should be that of overcoming the rather uneven pieces of regulation that have been produced by different Member States, or even by different regions within a single Country. Moreover, a revised directive could help to reduce the current distrust of sludges by public opinion and agricultural sector. On the one hand, efforts must be done for putting in place actions for preventing sewage sludge contamination (persistent organic pollutants and microplastics are probably the best representatives of contaminants neglected by the 1986 directive, that should be now considered and provided with stringent limits) and for the definition of a proper qualitative classification of sewage sludge, in the perspective of diversifying the possible recycling/recovery pathways. On the other hand, a revised directive should emphasize not only the concerns about sludge contamination but also, under a circular economy perspective, the potential of properly treated (i.e. composted) sewage sludge in returning organic matter to increasingly impoverishing soils, together with nutrients such as Nitrogen and Phosphorous. A further concrete proposal is to work on the inclusion in the EU Fertilizer Regulation of "biosolids", that could be defined in the SSD as the organic wastewater solids that that meet strict quality standards, abd that can be reused after suitable sewage sludge treatment processes leading to sludge stabilization such as anaerobic digestion and composting.
Organisation: CIC - Italian Composting and Biogas Association
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation
organisation_lower: cic - italian composting and biogas association

feedback_msg_text: To further improve the use of sewage sludge in agriculture we understand that there is a need  to focus on preventing harmful effects on soil, vegetation, animals and humans. Therefore, the Sewage Sludge Directive 86/278/EEC prohibited sludge spreading and promoted injection or direct incorporation into the soil. Another option is the thermal valorisation of sludges, valorizing its ashes for phosphorus recovery (sludges contain 1-2.5 % Phosphorus) and thus eliminating harmful compounds such as heavy metals, pharmaceuticals, PAH and PFAS, cosmetics or microplastics. Additionally, the calorific power of sludges enables energy generation for heat or electricity production. This directive has already been translated by numerous EU Member States and therefore there is a significant sludge thermal valorisation capacity already existing.  At SOLVAir®, we believe that the importance of protecting the environment and animals and human health has to be the major factor in future legislation. The risk of introducing harmful products in the food chain via sludge use in agriculture is too high, and some of the risks have not been evaluated as probably they have a long term impact. But all this can be mitigated with the sludge incineration. Taken into account that incineration of sludges is a proven technology with great results in terms of emission control, energy efficiency and it contributes to resource efficiency, it should be supported in the future Circular Economy Plans.  Main facts that support incineration as an excellent solution to sewage sludges:  1.Heat recovery Many dedicated plants (stand alone incinerators) are operating in Europe with great results, supplying electricity to the grid. Energy integration can be made to dry the sludges before incineration, using its own heat to dewater them before incineration: the sludge incineration process is proven to be an energy neutral or positive process.  2.Phosphorus-recovery and air pollution control During the incineration process of sewage sludges, fly ashes are generated and need to be captured via a filtration system. These ashes contain high amounts of Phosphorus oxides (P2O5) that can be further used to produce phosphoric acid or fertilisers (as explained in BAT Waste incineration, 6.4 Phosphorus recovery from sewage sludge incineration ashes).  The P-recovery degree that has been achieved today is about 60-98% depending on the technology. Fertilisers producers can control the content of other elements in the recovered ashes to make their formulations. These processes are already existing and operational at different scales (laboratory, semi-industrial and industrial).  Moreover, acid pollutants (SO2, SO3, NOx, HCl), heavy metals and organics are generated during combustion  and need to be mitigated before being vented to the atmosphere. Incinerators with a double filtration system allow to first, filtrate the P-rich fly ashes for its recovery, and secondly, use desulphurization techniques such as dry sorbent injection with bicarbonate to mitigate pollutants. The importance of this double filtration is to keep as pure as possible the fly ashes and to work at the best pollutants mitigation efficiency possible. To further advance in the circular economy ambition, dry sorbent injection residues (mostly sodium sulphate, Na2SO4) can be recycled back as a raw material for soda ash and sodium bicarbonate production or find secondary uses in the detergent or glass industries.  3. Odour control: incineration can be odourless in contrast with sludge-spreading.  4. SARS-CoV-2 control: it has been proven that the virus remains in the waste water and there are already restrictions in place to spread sludges to avoid contamination by COVID-19. Incineration is a safe way to be sure not to contaminate farmers, supply chain and final consumers.  In conclusion, and supported by the above mentioned reasons, we believe that incineration represents a good alternative to sludge spreading.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Der Verband zur Qualitätssicherung von Düngung und Substraten e.V. (VQSD) bedankt sich für die Möglichkeit unsere Anmerkungen, im Hinblick einer zukünftigen Überarbeitung der „Richtlinie über den Schutz der Umwelt und insbesondere der Böden bei der Verwendung von Klärschlamm in der Landwirtschaft“ (86/278/EEC), einfließen lassen zu können (die kompletten Anmerkungen sind als Dokument in Anlage angefügt).  Das Recycling von Pflanzennährstoffen wie Stickstoff und Phosphor sowie von organischer Substanz leistet einen wichtigen Beitrag zum Umwelt- und Ressourcenschutz. Die bodenbezogene Verwertung von Recyclingdüngern wie Klärschlamm, Klärschlammkompost und Klärschlammerde in Landwirtschaft und Landschaftsbau sind eine effektive Maßnahme, die Bodenqualität zu stabilisieren bzw. zu verbessern und müssen langfristig erhalten und rechtlich sichergestellt werden. Zur Steigerung der öffentlichen Akzeptanz sind die Qualität von Klärschlamm und dessen Aufbereitungserzeugnissen ständig zu verbessern und die Erzeugung und Verwertung transparent und nachvollziehbar darzustellen.  Im Rahmen einer zukünftigen Überarbeitung der „Richtlinie über den Schutz der Umwelt und insbesondere der Böden bei der Verwendung von Klärschlamm in der Landwirtschaft“ (86/278/EEC) sollten Qualitätssicherungsverfahren unter Teilnahme aller am Prozess Beteiligter (vom Einleiter über die Abwasserbehandlung bis hin zum Düngemittel) erarbeitet und aufgebaut werden. Angemessene Erleichterungen in der Nutzung von qualitätsgesicherten Klärschlammerzeugnissen (u.a. bodenbezogene Untersuchungspflichten, Klärschlammuntersuchungen, Vermischung von Klärschlämmen) sollten für die Teilnehmer von Qualitätsmanagementsystemen überdacht werden. Die Qualitätssicherung von Klärschlamm stellt ein geeignetes Instrument dar, um die Vorsorgeparameter (Schadstoffbelastung) als auch die Vorteilswirkungen (Nährstoffe, organische Substanz) von Klärschlamm kontinuierlich zu kontrollieren und zu verbessern.  Eine Qualitätssicherung kann dafür Sorge tragen, dass bereits im Vorfeld der Klärschlammentstehung alle Möglichkeiten zur Verminderung von Schadstoffeinträgen in das Abwasser und somit in den Klärschlamm genutzt werden. Hierzu ist ein Konzept zur Schadstoffminderung (Bewertungen der Einleiterstrukturen, Beratung und Überwachung der Indirekteinleiter, Bewertung des Einsatzes von Materialien bei der Abwasserreinigung und Schlammbehandlung) zu erstellen, an dem alle Akteure vom Kläranlagenbetreiber bis zum Verwerter beteiligt sein sollten. Die Anpassung der Richtlinie ist im Hinblick auf die eindeutige Definition von Abwässern sowie nicht behandeltem und behandeltem Klärschlamm notwendig.  Die bodenbezogene Verwertung von qualitätsgesicherten Klärschlammerzeugnissen sollte unabhängig von der Kläranlagengröße und basierend auf der Art der Einleitung (kommunales Abwasser, industrielles Abwasser) möglich sein. Eine fachliche Begründung für den oftmals angenommenen Zusammenhang zwischen Kläranlagengröße und Schadstoffbelastungen im Klärschlamm besteht nicht.  Aus Sicht des Klima-, Umwelt- und Ressourcenschutzes erscheint es sinnvoll, wenn sich der Ausbau eines technischen Recyclings von Phosphor auf Klärschlämme, die die dünge- und abfallrechtlichen Anforderungen (Grenzwerte) nicht einhalten konzentriert. Die fachgerechte bodenbezogene Verwertung von Klärschlammerzeugnissen stellt die im Sinne der Kreislaufwirtschaft anzustrebende Form des Recyclings von allen enthaltenen Pflanzennährstoffen sowie der organischen Substanz dar und muss gefördert werden.  Für alle Klärschlämme sollte eine Pflicht der Phosphor-Rückgewinnung, im Hinblick auf Kreislaufwirtschaft und Ressourcenschutz, vorgegeben werden. Eine zwingende technische Aufbereitung der Klärschlämme zur Phosphor-Rückführung muss nicht erfolgen, da die bodenbezogene direkte Nutzung von Klärschlamm als organisches NP-Düngemittel eine gute und wirtschaftliche Möglichkeit des Phosphor-Recyclings darstellt. Feedback from: VQSD - Verband zur Qualitätssicherung von Düngung und Substraten e.V. (254.6 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Organisation: VQSD - Verband zur Qualitätssicherung von Düngung und Substraten e.V.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation
