feedback_msg_text: Confservizi Cispel Toscana, in linea anche con la nota già inviata da Utilitalia, ritiene quanto mai opportuna una revisione della Direttiva, che essendo stata approvata ormai 34 anni fa, non risponde più alle esigenze e alle aspettative attuali, anche in relazione alla regolamentazione degli inquinanti potenzialmente presenti nei fanghi (c.d. “contaminati emergenti”).  E’, infatti, indubbio che lo sviluppo tecnologico, ed anche gli obiettivi di economia circolare, impongono soluzioni alternative allo spandimento dei fanghi di depurazione in agricoltura, quali il recupero di materia, del fosforo in via prioritaria, di energia (valorizzazione termica) e dei prodotti derivanti dai processi termochimici, che vadano a valorizzare il recupero della biomassa di carbonio oltre che dei macro-nutrienti presenti nei fanghi.  A tal proposito si ritiene inoltre, che la Direttiva Fanghi debba essere modificata in armonia con la recente Direttiva sui fertilizzanti e con le nuove linee di indirizzo sulle energie rinnovabili ed in linea con i principi di economia circolare.  La revisione e l’aggiornamento della Direttiva appare poi oltremodo necessaria in un contesto come quello italiano, in cui, attualmente, la normativa di riferimento è il datato D.Lgs. n. 99/1992, in minima parte modificato negli ultimi anni con interventi puntuali e non omogenei e dettati da specifiche circostanze.  Da ultimo, si auspica che i valori limite dei parametri vengano fissati in maniera univoca in sede di Direttiva Comunitaria e che tale compito non venga demandato ai singoli Stati membri.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Biomacon and Fachverband Frohnbach appreciates the work of STRUBIAS / JRC work-ing group to establish the new EU fertilizer regulation.  It is now extremely important to consider the soil-related use of carbonisation product (coal) made from municipal sewage sludge e.g. to be approved as phosphate fertilizer within the framework of the European fertilizer regulation. Because our “Zweckverband Frohnbach” has also built an innovative plant for the pyrolytic carbonisation of sewage sludge for its central wastewater treatment plant in Niederfrohna (Saxony). The con-struction has received generous funding from the European Union (EFRE). It is a model and pilot project of the Free State of Saxony. The plant went into operation January 2020 and produces germ-free, low-pollutant, phosphate-rich carbonisation product.  1.) The production of char from sewage sludge is practical and economical, while the phosphate extraction from energy intensive burned sewage sludge cannot yet be used on a large scale. The disposal of the residual materials, which would in Germany alone amount to around 692,000 tons per year, is also unclear. In addition, the pyrolysis technology is decentralized and can be applied individually to the quantities of sludge that accumulate in every sewage treatment plant.  2.) In addition, sewage sludge carbonisation product is a soil conditioner and groundwater friendly phosphate dispenser. It contains at least 20 percent of valuable and urgently needed black carbon.  3.) The central mono-incineration of the municipal sewage sludge up to the phosphate extraction of the ashes (e.g. complex acid digestion) in Germany alone would yearly mean around 434,000 truck transport journeys over a distance of 73 million km with enormous road wear. Decentralized sewage sludge pyrolysis would result in significantly less heavy traffic.  4.) The farmers are always interested in inexpensive and eco-friendly alternatives for mineral fertilizers.  Sewage sludge is always available, regardless of market influences, regardless of location and in constant large quantities. Thereby agriculture has an urgently needed means of accelerating the restoration of humus rich, water-storing and fertile soils, which does not require any further biomass from agricultural and forestry production.  5.) Pyrolysis char also permanently binds 60 percent by mass of the carbon contained in the sewage sludge, which would be released as CO2 if burned. This also speaks against sewage sludge incineration! The climate friendly effect would be enormous. For the Federal Republic of Germany alone, the potential savings in CO2 emissions are around 1.4 million tons per year. The amount corresponds to the annual binding capacity of a beech forest with around 48 million trees or a forest area of approximately 943,000 hectares. Additionally, the fixed carbon of the pyrolysis char is considered a high quality CO2 sink within the CO2 trading market. Therefore, this guarantees waste water treatment plant operators additional income from CO2 certificate trading and thus im-proves the profitability of the entire plant operation.  6.) In the recent consultation of the JRC expert group, possible drug residues from sewage sludge were raised as the latest argument against a fertilizer approval for carbonisation products from municipal sewage sludge. This statement is incorrect. On the one hand, it is absurd that under the conditions of proper pyrolysis at temperatures about 600 °C, anything organic could remain as such.  In addition, in its April 2019 report, the Umweltbundesamt (German Federal Environment Agency) found that pyrolysis completely destroyed drug residues and that a temperature of 500 °C and a relatively short period of just 3 minutes was sufficient. At the same time, it would be easy to specify a minimum temperature and a minimum dwell time for the pyrolysis of sewage sludge.  Thanks T. Hoffmann - Biomacon GmbH Dr. S. Heinrich - Zweckverband Frohnbach Feedback from: Biomacon GmbH / Zweckverband Frohnbach (13 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Kemira welcomes the decision of the European Commission to subject the Sewage Sludge Directive 86/278 / EEC (SSD) to an evaluation process. It is justified by the fact that science and technology have evolved significantly since the adoption of the Directive in 1986.  Kemira supports the basic intention of the current SSD “to encourage the correct use of sewage sludge in agriculture and to regulate its use in order to prevent harmful effects on soil, vegetation, animals and humans". We also welcome the plans to link this intention with the targets and values of the new European Green Deal and Circular Economy Action Plan.  Sewage sludge is usually a mixture of valuable nutrients, such as phosphorus, nitrogen and energy-rich organic compounds, as well as residual waste. The aim of a reviewed SSD should always be to recycle sewage sludge or its compounds with as high-quality and as environmentally friendly as possible”. Therefore, technology measures and policy options that enable the recovery or recycling of valuable sludge compounds while reducing and removing harmful pollutants must be promoted by a renewed SSD.  Kemira specifically rates the recovery potential of phosphorus from sewage sludge as very crucial to enable Europe to become more independent from industrial fertilizers, which are supplied by very limited raw material sources, mainly outside the EU. In addition, we see that the energy potential of sewage sludge in the production of biogas has not been utilized fully, so far. In order to make the wastewater treatment process more climate-friendly, this potential should be harnessed.  Depending on the respective local situation a risk-based approach can help to still recycle a nutrient-rich but low-polluted sludge directly in agriculture. In cases where the sludge quality is insufficient, targeted recovery of valuable ingredients, as mentioned above, should be promoted by the new SSD.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: The SYPREA, the French union of recycling organic matter for agricultural applications, welcomes the revision of the SSD. The SSD was a pioneering initiative in the sector when it made it possible to establish safety thresholds that are referenced in other official texts. The attempt to revise the directive in 2010 was a failure, however, the preparatory work can be resumed to serve as a basis for reflection. The evaluation report of 2014 shows that the directive has achieved its objectives, particularly with regard to the use of sludge in agriculture. However, the lack of revision of this Directive, which dates back to 1986, has led to a growing mistrust of the waste and recycling sector. Thus, practices and the desire to ensure food safety, combined with regulatory acts that have not been amended for more than 20 years, are now hindering the return of quality "biosolids" to the soil. It is now more important to promote results objectives on a scientific basis than methods. Land use criteria must be identical or at least consistent between the different fertilizing materials and crop supports (concerning the safety threshold, agronomic efficiency, dose input, etc.). The Fertiliser Regulation should therefore also be revised to address these issues in a holistic way. Moreover, the choice to add new families of substances to be controlled must be made on a scientific basis, with standardized analytical procedures. The spreading of "biosolids" on land (directly or after composting) helps to combat global warming, counteract the constant loss of soil organic matter and allow independence in the use of synthetic fertilisers. The return of sludge to the soil is a concrete example of the circular economy. This is why European regulations in this area need to be regularly reviewed to update thresholds and criteria, preserve good practices and thus reassure the public. Finally, quality controls of biosolids are indeed necessary, but it is even more necessary to control and set up upstream systems to minimize pollutants and contaminants in the environment and in water. Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: PYREG appreciates the thorough and elaborate STRUBIAS / JRC working group to establish the new EU fertilizer regulation.  We consider the suggested framework for the inclusion of biochar into the revised EU fertilizer regulation as major step forward towards as safe and sustainable circular economy and agriculture.   The authors of the STRUBIAS report decided to exclude sewage sludge as eligible feedstock for the production of pyrolysis & gasification materials. The precautionary principle advanced by the authors is rather comprehensible given the complexity and degree of contamination of biosolids. However, recent scientific papers not yet considered by JRC demonstrate that at sufficiently severe pyrolysis temperatures (> 500°C) and residence times (> 3 min), all reference organic contaminants and organic micropollutants were completely or nearly completely degraded or driven off the solid material.   Thanks to the scientific literature published since 2016 and especially during the last two years, a new risk assessment of the agricultural application of pyrolyzed biosolids became possible. We therefore would like to suggest to reconsider the inclusion of biosolids as eligible feedstock for pyrolysis & gasification materials (biochars).   To completely exclude even the possibility of including biosolids as pyrolysis feedstock would seal a huge potential of European environmental technology development and disadvantage Europe against the rest of the world in regard to nutrient and carbon recycling of sewage sludge.    Many studies are published in regard to heavy metals originated from the biosolid feedstock. We do not summarize those here as the thresholds for heavy metals suggested by the STRUBIAS report would already assure that no heavy metal contamination could occur.   Since all of the cited scientific studies including the one from the German Ministry of Environment have shown that organic pollutants from the sewage are efficiently destroyed in all investigated pyrolytic treatment processes with temperatures above 500 °C and residence times above 3 min, it can be concluded that the application of pyrolyzed biosolids to agricultural soils should be considered by EU  regulations.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: FISE Assoambiente, the Italian Association of Waste Management and Environmental Services, welcomes the revision of the SSD due mainly to the necessary update of the parameter and limit and highlight the role also of such Directive as instrument to promote circularity in farming processes. From a circular economy perspective, the sludge directive should encourage firstly the use of such sludge in agriculture before any other forms of sludge management, limiting those alternatives for sludges which don’t have the characteristics suitable for use in agriculture. The return of sludge to the soil is, in fact, a very concrete example of circularity, allowing for the refurbishment of organic matter and useful nutrients in soils as well as avoiding the use of chemical fertilisers in farming processes, while providing for safety and control for harmful substances. To this regard, we acknowledge the importance of evaluating, and potentially revising, the Directive – which crucially established safety thresholds for sewage sludge used in farming. It is also important and necessary to introduce the extended producer responsibility (EPR) principle for certain pollutants (such as microplastics used for personal care products) for which it is not fair to penalize only the sludge treatment plants or the use itself of the sludge. In particular, FISE Assoambiente highlights the following as key elements to be considered in the revision process: 1. performance targets for sewage sludge in farming should be promoted on a scientific basis,   2. land use criteria, concerning for instance safety thresholds and dose input, must be consistent among fertilizers as well as crop support groups. To ensure legislative consistency, the Fertiliser Regulation should also be revised accordingly,  3. quality controls remain paramount in ensuring the proper and safe use of biosolids. Yet, we believe that more efficient upstream control systems would be even more effective in minimising pollutants and contaminants potentially harmful for the environment and human health.  In order to provide a useful contribution and data, we hope that FISE Assoambiente, as representative of companies working in this sector, may be heard by the Commission with the start of the revision of the Directive and involved in the possible working groups that will be set up by the Commission. Feedback from: FISE Assoambiente (101.6 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Sewage sludge is a mirror for the environmental situation in a region. If you are not satisfied with the reflection you can treat the mirror thermally and the reflection will not be visible for the future. In my opinion the better option, if you are not satisfied, is to work on upstream measures until the reflection fits to your intentions. Micro-plastic is one example. It´s fully clear that in an environment, where plastics are widely used, it will be found in any media. According to the study of „Environmental Science and Technology - Magazine”, someone who drinks water only from plastic bottles for one year, will consume about 90,000 additional micro-plastic particles. That means, we accept these particles in our drinking water but we are afraid of it when it´s detected in the sludge! A decision to ban the local use of sludge in agriculture means to build central treatment facilities and to multiply transport distances including green house gases and additional micro-plastic by tire-abrasion which is well known as the most important micro-plastic emission. Let´s have a look at the reflection of our mirror and let us find sustainable solutions which ban harmful substances at the source. "Cradle to cradle" is a principle which fulfills the requirements for a circular economy. Local cycles for organics with accompanying quality assurance systems will help to create low emissions, low cost and awareness for sustainable production methods and products in our consumer world. Feedback from: Mueller Abfallprojekte GmbH (551.1 KB - PDF - 12 pages) Download
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: On the one hand we have a continual reduction in organic carbon in EU soils due to over exploitation.  Sewage sludge is one way of getting some of this organic matter back to soil and has been used as a soil  improver for centuries. Sewage sludge, either directly or though co-composting, is fed to soils across the world and is therefore already part of the soil-to-soil circular loop of the food value chain.  Losing this organic matter is a risk especially in more arid areas.  On the other hand sewage sludge is now a material containing the residues of modern society. These include plastics and microplastics, chemicals, traces of medicines and especially antibiotics and contraceptive pills, which will accumulate in soils and pass through the food chain to us. This is highly dangerous. We already know fruit and vegetables contain mircoplastics and that the sewage system is one large source of these.   The evaluation of the EU has to take the precautionary approach and establish severe and restrictive limits to contaminants in sewage sludge in order to allow this to be applied to soil.  This will mean in  most cases that sewage sludge cannot be applied to soil.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Bonjour, Je souhaiterai proposer trois suggestions pour l'évaluation de la directive 86/278/CE concernant le recyclage des boues d'épuration en agriculture.  1 - Il serait utile que l'évaluation commence par une analyse comparative du taux de recyclage des boues d'épuration en agriculture dans chaque pays membre. Il me semble en effet assez clair que l'analyse des conséquences de la directive dans un État membre qui présente un taux de recyclage en agriculture de plus de 80% de la production initiale a une portée différente de celle pour un autre qui a interdit leur usage en agriculture ou dont le taux de recyclage ne dépasse pas 20%.  2 - L'évaluation doit également tenir compte du statut administratif précis des boues d'épuration ou vérifier que la définition du statut de déchets des boues d'épuration est comparable d'un État membre à l'autre. Les contraintes réglementaires qui peuvent s'exercer sur le recyclage des boues sont directement liées aux spécifications qui permettent de catégoriser les matières/matériaux en tant que déchets ou en tant que produits commerciaux diffusables sur un marché. Dans le cas des États membres où les boues d'épuration ne peuvent initialement avoir que le seul statut de déchet, il faut impérativement  expliciter les conditions de sortie du statut de déchet.  3 - L'évaluation doit également s'intéresser au statut du sol receveur. Le mode de valorisation des sols conditionne les opportunités ou les contraintes de recyclage biologique des boues d'épuration et il est important de situer la compatibilité des modes de valorisation des sols avec un recyclage des boues  d'épuration scientifiquement et techniquement éprouvé.  Pour mémoire : la Chambre d'agriculture de Charente-Maritime participe aux projets H2020 Nutri2Cycle (ID : 773682) et NUTRIMAN (ID : 818470)
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: There is absolutly NOT any necessity of using sludge in agriculture. Mixing sludge with food is a risk totally avoidable and a moral principle. They could be used in land fill or degraded soils improvement. There is almost no control of the process and the burocratic / goverment / enterprises observation of the law.  If we DON´T use recicled water as tap / drinking water, we MUST NOT use sludge in our farming soils.  Thank you.
Initiative: Sewage sludge use in farming – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: EasyMining is an innovation company, part of the Ragn-Sells Group, dedicated to closing nutrient cycles. A sustainable legislation for circular economy should fulfil the following three criteria: a) real detoxification, i.e. removal and not dilution of contaminants, b) reduce the exploitation of virgin resources, and c)  enable recovery & recycling of products with a quality and function suitable for their applications. Fulfilling the above criteria will assure that depts are not passed on to future generations.   Consequently, a new circular legislation for sustainable sludge handling needs to be based on the above criteria with a special focus on the recovery of phosphorus which is classified as a critical raw material by the EU. Incineration is the leading technology for substantial detoxification of sewage sludge by destruction of organic pollutants, pathogens and plastics.  Mono-incineration leads to a sterile mineral concentrate – the ash - that is rich in phosphorus (~7-11%).  Sludge ash, without further processing, cannot be used as a fertilizer due to a too high metal and heavy metal content and a too low plant availability of phosphorus. Therefore and also given its heterogeneity, sludge ash is normally landfilled today.   EU is largely dependent on import of phosphorus (92%) as most phosphate mines are located outside of Europe. To decrease this dependency and to facilitate a circular economy it is crucial to establish a new legislation with high demand on recovery of phosphorus, proposing at least 80% phosphorus recovery. However, recovery demands for phosphorus will not be enough to reach the goal of a new sustainable sewage sludge legislation and a toxic-free environment. In order for new innovative technologies to reach the market producing clean recycled phosphorus products from sewage sludge ash suitable for applications as e.g. fertilisers or feed phosphates, there is a need for clear “end of waste” criteria. Foremost, these recycled products need to be accepted on the market with no legislative hindrance if the quality demands are fulfilled e.g. fertilisers and feed phosphates regulations. Today, there is a total ban on using recovered nutrients from materials “derived from domestic and industrial waste water” and “solid urban waste” in animal feed (Annex III, Regulation 767/2009). Another action to create a market for recovered phosphorus, is an quota system for blending in recycled phosphorus in fertilisers and feed phosphates.  Finally, for the recovered phosphorus to be part of the circular economy and contribute to a sustainable sewage sludge legislation, the regulations for the downstream market, e.g. fertilisers and feed phosphates, need to be transformed from linear to circular focusing on quality and not on the origin.   About us EasyMining is passionate about inventing new technology that uses intelligent chemical solutions to close nutrient cycles and to detoxify waste flows. Our objective is to create new circular material flows efficiently and commercially viable.  EasyMining has developed and patented several chemical processes and holds a great know-how in chemistry, resource efficiency, circular business models and industrial symbiosis.   EasyMining was formed in 2007 and is owned from 2014 by Ragn-Sells. Ragn-Sells is a third generation family owned waste management company, originating from 1881 with handling of latrines already in the late 1800´s and nowadays Sweden’s largest sludge treatment company. feedback_msg_text: As the European Trade Union Federation, representing 7 million workers from sectors that constitute the backbone of economic and social life in Europe, UNI EUROPA (THE EUROPEAN SERVICES WORKERS UNION) contribution to this initiative will help in improving health and safety at work, including helping to prevent workers from having accidents at work and getting avoidable work-related illnesses. We believe that the initiative will also improve productivity and contribute to preventing unnecessary health costs, such as medical or rehabilitation costs, as well as to reducing public healthcare spending, so improving the sustainability of social security systems. This requires indeed an inclusive and crosscutting strategic approach to address the main challenges which will be identified for this decade and ensure that workers in the EU can benefit from the highest standard when it comes to health and safety at work.  The fast pace of societal, technological or scientific changes has brought great benefits but also new risks, including those resulting from digitalisation or the use of robots at the workplace while at the same time the traditional risks remain, such as exposure to hazardous chemicals.   The coronavirus outbreak accentuated some risks, both linked to the virus itself and to changes in the way work is carried out, in particular with the significant rise of teleworking and work from home, which raises a new set of OSH issues to be considered and to include the following improvements of the working environment to protect workers' health and safety:  See attached Feedback from: UNI Europa (187.9 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: Health & Safety at Work – EU Strategic Framework (2021-2027)

feedback_msg_text: ELINYAE - The Hellenic Institute for Occupational Health and Safety welcomes the initiative of the EU Strategic Framework on Occupational Safety and Health (OSH). The new era in OSH comprises of new working conditions, risks and tools to deal with them. The strategy of this new era requires a paradigm shift in the whole system of OSH. This new paradigm requires a new relationship between enterprises, workers and the authorities, based more on collaboration than auditing and focused more on preventing work-related diseases and accidents, rather than compliance. New technologies can offer standardization, transparency, equality, holistic coverage, timeliness and adaptability to change in order to support this communication, as well as massive data collection to support improvement of the application of EU rules, evidence-based policy and common safety and health standards in European enterprises, not only in regulatory but also in implementation level.

feedback_msg_text: Die „Deutsche Gesetzliche Unfallversicherung“ (DGUV) ist der Spitzenverband der gewerblichen Berufsgenossenschaften und der Unfallversicherungsträger der öffentlichen Hand. Er nimmt die gemeinsamen Interessen seiner Mitglieder wahr und fördert deren Aufgaben zum Wohl der Versicherten und der Unternehmen. Der Verband vertritt die gesetzliche Unfallversicherung gegenüber der Politik auf nationaler und auf europäischer Ebene, gegenüber nationalen und internationalen Institutionen. Die gewerblichen Berufsgenossenschaften und die Unfallversicherungsträger der öffentlichen Hand haben den gesetzlichen Auftrag, Arbeits- und Schulunfälle sowie Berufskrankheiten und arbeitsbedingte Gesundheitsgefahren zu verhüten und nach Eintritt eines Versicherungsfalles den Verletzten, seine Angehörigen oder Hinterbliebenen zu entschädigen. Sie sind dabei für über 76 Millionen Versicherte und rund 3,8 Millionen Unternehmen sowie Institutionen zuständig. Die DGUV begrüßt, dass die Europäische Kommission einen strategischen Rahmen für Gesundheit und Sicherheit bei der Arbeit 2021-2027 vorlegen wird. Die Europäische Kommission wird mit diesem einen weiteren Beitrag leisten, um den hohen Arbeitsschutzstandard für Arbeitnehmerinnen und Arbeitnehmer in der EU aufrechtzuerhalten und im Sinne der „Vision Zero“ tödliche und schwere Arbeitsunfälle und Berufskrankheiten zu verringern sowie gesundheitsfördernde Potenziale bei der Arbeit zu erschließen. Die DGUV unterstützt die Europäische Kommission darin, mit einem strategischen Rahmen für Gesundheit und Sicherheit bei der Arbeit 2021-2027 zur Umsetzung der Europäischen Säule sozialer Rechte durch die EU-Mitgliedstaaten beizutragen und das Ergreifen koordinierter Maßnahmen durch die EU-Mitgliedstaaten, die Sozialpartner und andere beteiligte Stakeholder zu fördern. Die DGUV teilt die Überlegung des Rates der Europäischen Union, dass ein strategischer Rahmen für Gesundheit und Sicherheit bei der Arbeit 2021-2027 ein Anreiz zur Überarbeitung nationaler Arbeitsschutzstrategien sein kann. Die DGUV geht in ihrer als Anlage beigefügten Stellungnahme auf die „Vision Zero“ ein und schlägt der Europäischen Kommission vor, die „Vision Zero“-Präventionsstrategie mit „7 Goldenen Regeln“ für Sicherheit und Gesundheit bei der Arbeit als übergeordnetes Ziel dieses und weiterer strategischer Rahmen für Gesundheit und Sicherheit bei der Arbeit langfristig zu verfolgen. Schwerpunkte des strategischen Rahmens für Gesundheit und Sicherheit bei der Arbeit 2021-2027 können nach der Europäischen Kommission darüber hinaus die sich wandelnde Arbeitswelt einschließlich der Verhinderung von Arbeitsunfällen und Berufskrankheiten und Verbesserung der Anwendung und Durchsetzung des bestehenden Rechts sowie die Gewährleistung einer evidenzbasierten Politik im Bereich von Gesundheit und Sicherheit bei der Arbeit sein. Im Zusammenhang mit der sich wandelnden Arbeitswelt stehen für die DGUV bei ihrer Stellungnahme • die Digitalisierung, • der technologische Wandel • der Einsatz von Künstlicher Intelligenz (KI), • die Vereinbarkeit von Berufs- und Privatleben, • der Umgang mit atypischen Beschäftigungsverhältnissen, • der demographische Wandel und Erhalt der Erwerbsfähigkeit, • Muskel-Skelett- und psychosoziale Erkrankungen sowie • die Bekämpfung von arbeitsinduzierten Krebserkrankungen im Vordergrund. Die DGUV bedankt sich für die bestehende Möglichkeit, sich frühzeitig einzubringen und zu einem strategischen Rahmen der EU für Gesundheit und Sicherheit bei der Arbeit 2021-2027 Stellung nehmen zu können. Ares(2020)6089500 - 29/10/2020 – EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work [2021- 2027]The Polish Copper Employers’ Association (former Employers’ Organization of Polish Copper) (Związek Pracodawców Polska Miedź) was established in 1996. We are the biggest, independent and not-for-profit regional employers’ organization whose goal is to represent and protect employers’ interests. As the representative of the Polish metals mining, processing and smelting industry and also SME sector, we are writing to express our opinion as part of public consultations to the document "Roadmap" under the initiative "EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work [2021 - 2027]" and the provisions of Article 153 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Roadmap is a document that contains strategic goals related to maintaining and improving the health and safety of employees.  The legal basis for the Roadmap is Article 153 (1) (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It is an initiative in the area of the improvement of the working environment to protect workers' health and safety, which is a shared competence between the EU and Member States. It takes into account the risks arising from new working methods and technologies, digitization and the COVID-19 pandemic. At the same time, the continuation of the current directions of activities is indicated, including those related to limiting exposure to substances harmful to health. As part of the public consultation for the Roadmap, we would also like refer to the provisions of the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council’s conclusions on “A New EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work: Enhancing the implementation of Occupational Safety and Health in the EU” from 10 December 2019, including the statement that: “Setting binding occupational exposure limit values for priority carcinogens and mutagens has been a very important improvement in OSH legislation in recent years. Binding exposure limit values are now set for 25 substances. These exposure limits should reduce the risk of millions of workers developing cancer. Work on identifying further carcinogens and mutagens at the workplace and setting limit values for them therefore needs to continue to be a high priority.”  For several years, we have been observing changes taking place in this area, in particular changes in the CMD Directive, which consist in a sharp reduction of BOEL values. These tightenings are a multiple of the previously binding values. The following are values of BOELS referring only to our member companies, for example: The restrictions which were introduced in 2017-2019 1. Cadmium    was: 0,01 mg/m3  is: 0,001 mg/m3 2. Diesel engine exhaust emissions was: 0,5 mg/m3*   is: 0,05 mg/m3** 3. Nitrogen monoxide NO   was: 3,5 mg/m3   is: 2,5 mg/m3 *respirable fraction  **elemental carbon The restrictions planned in the coming years: 1. Lead     is: 0,05 mg/m3 proposition: 0,004 mg/m3 2. Cobalt     is: 0,02 mg/m3 proposition: 0,001 mg/m3 3. Nickel     is: 0,25 mg/m3 proposition: 0,01 mg/m3 We emphasize that the health and safety of employees is the highest value, nevertheless, we have a number of significant comments related to the process of introducing BOEL into the legal circulation in the European Union.  We also would like to draw your attention to the issues connected with personal protective equipment. feedback_msg_text: The Commission’s work to define the EU’s strategic policy orientations for the Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) 2021-2027 represents a clear opportunity to improve indoor air quality (IAQ) and therefore the health of users and occupants of commercial non-residential buildings. According to WHO statistics, it is estimated that people spend approximately 90% of their lives indoors and that poor indoor air leads to the premature death of 120,000 Europeans every year translating into an annual cost to society of EUR 260 billion. In the context of the current COVID-19 outbreak, the proper use of ventilation is a particularly important contributor to maintaining an adequate level of IAQ and to limiting the potential for aerosolised transmission via mechanical air renewal. A recent article by The Lancet, the well-known weekly peer-reviewed general medical journal, estimates that ventilation can reduce the risk of airborne infection by the SARS-CoV-2 virus by a factor of ten . In the Roadmap, it is suggested that the 2021-2027 framework should focus on setting common political objectives at the EU level with a view to stimulating coordinated action among the Member States. As such, the scope of the initiative is mostly restricted to non-binding guidance for Member States to consider in the context of their national OSH strategies. EVIA considers that such a limited scope is insufficient given the current public health context and too narrow to deal in an appropriate manner with indoor air pollutants, including but not limited to particulate matter, Carbon Dioxide (CO2),  Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) and inadequate relative humidity levels. Further, it would be a missed opportunity not to link the 2021-2027 OSH framework to policy initiatives being undertaken by the EU in other areas, particularly in relation to the legislation covering the built environment and processes to upgrade it to live up to the ambition of the European Green Deal. Therefore, to drive improvements most effectively in IAQ, the 2021-2027 framework should focus on leveraging legislative initiatives outside the traditional direct scope of EU OSH policy. The 2014-2020 OSH Strategic Framework identified “the Environment” as one policy area where synergies should be more actively explored, without making concrete references to specific EU legislation or policies. The 2020-2027 OSH Strategic Framework must leverage initiatives under the European Green Deal aimed at the built, and thus indoor, environment. Buildings, as outlined in the Commission’s Communication on a Renovation Wave, are to be a central component in achieving the European Green Deal ambitions and a driver of the economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. In its recent Communication, the EU Commission aims to double the annual renovation rate of non-residential buildings. To be successful, the Renovation Wave must at the same time address several issues alongside the energy consumption of buildings, such as ensuring an appropriate indoor air quality. Indeed, while improving energy efficiency is an important objective, renovation of the existing non-residential building stock must simultaneously be leveraged to improve IAQ as recognised in the Communication. As such EVIA, strongly urges the Commission to ensure that the 2021-2027 OSH framework is fully aligned with the Renovation Wave’s objectives and harnesses the policy initiatives under its remit to deliver on OSH as well as on energy efficiency. Failing to deliver OSH improvements via improved IAQ during forthcoming renovations could lead to long-term lock in effects to the continuing detriment of worker’s health. feedback_msg_text: Mi chiamo Lorenzo Dalla Torre il mio numero di riferimento come esperto rilasciatomi dalla Comunità Europea è  E310709M.  Mi occupo di Ricerca e Sviluppo e di Formazione sulla Sicurezza sul lavoro. Ho sviluppato un diverso approccio alla formazione sulla sicurezza che ho denominato “Approccio Globale alla Valutazione del rischio” . Questo approccio si basa su : 1/ Qualsiasi situazione anomala presenta dei rischi ignoti per l’essere umano. E’ allora importante saper riconoscere la diversità della situazione cui si deve far fronte effettuando una attenta analisi, riconoscere i nuovi rischi che la situazione anomala presenta. In secondo luogo si dovrà procedere a normalizzare la situazione, ovvero renderla compatibile se possibile con le attuali procedure di sicurezza. Se non fosse possibile normalizzare la situazione nuova che si presenta si dovrà procedere ad individuare nuove norme/procedure che consentano di effettuare le operazioni necessarie in sicurezza.  Il riconoscimento della situazione anomala potrà avvenire utilizzando l’inversa della funzione Gaussiana degli errori come funzione che misura quantitativamente il rischio. Non si potrà comunque evitare di fare ricorso ad elementi di valutazione più qualitativi in quanto la situazione potrà essere anomala sia per evidenze oggettive che per motivi soggettivi. 2/ La valutazione del rischio deve focalizzarsi non solo e non tanto sul lavoratore ma sull’essere umano ed essere oggettivamente guidata da indicatori statistici. Gli indicatori statistici ci dicono che solo nel 18 % dei casi una persona in età lavorativa muore per incidente avvenuto sul luogo di lavoro. Per il 40 % dei casi gli infortuni mortali avvengono in casa, per il restante 20 % circa avvengono in altre occasioni (sport, tempo libero, viaggi, vacanze).  Se la risorsa umana è veramente importante non ci si deve limitare ad informarla ed a formarla sui rischi dell’attività lavorativa magari solo per rispettare le leggi che impongono la formazione del lavoratore. 3/ Consideriamo poi alcuni fattori : a/Smart Working: gli incidenti domestici con esito mortale annuale in Italia sono circa 8000, gli incidenti mortali sul lavoro od in itinere sono circa 1000. Aumentando il lavoro a domicilio aumenteranno ancora di più statisticamente gli infortuni nelle abitazioni di chi normalmente trascorreva molte ore sul posto di lavoro. b/ Consideriamo poi quante persone destinate ad una fulgida carriera sono state colpite nei loro affetti più cari, magari un figlio, per un incidente. Quante di queste preziose risorse umane sono sfumate per le conseguenze psicologiche della perdita subita? c/ L’emergenza della Pandemia ha fatto emergere come l’azienda non sia impermeabile a quello che avviene all’esterno costringendola a riorganizzarsi, modificare procedure, modificare turnazioni etc.… d/ La stessa azienda può determinare problemi di salute rilevanti alle comunità circostanti e ne sono esempi tipici il mattatoio in Germania o l’azienda che produce carni di pollo in Italia che sono emersi come focolai importanti dell’infezionedi Covid -19. Nel riorganizzare il mio modo di fare formazione ho messo a sistema più di 1300 slides in power point in diverse sezioni.  Nella prima sezione introduttiva guardo all’uomo, alla società della informazione attuale, alle difficoltà di formazione dell’adulto.Dall’homo sapiens, passando per i problemi derivanti dallo sforzo fisico ( l’ “homo machina”), definisco la necessità di spazio per qualsiasi attività umana e quindi i rischi connessi allo spazio confinato. Passo poi all’”homo fragilis” e quindi ad affrontare i problemi legati allo stress in generale per scendere allo stress da lavoro mancante ed a quello da lavoro correlato. Infine ’ “homo digitalis” ed i rischi connessi alla digitalizzazione. La seconda parte "incidenti Dovunque" precede le altre parti dove si analizzano come di consueto i rischi fisici, chimici ,la legislazione, i DPI etc.seguendo sempre i criteri di rilevanza oggettivi. feedback_msg_text: The coordination team of SHAREMED fully supports the Commission’s initiative for the development of a coherent, shared, transnational, European Ocean Observation.  SHAREMED is a Interreg MED Strategic Project led by OGS– Italian National Institute of Oceanography and Experimental Geophysics, born from the specific request of the Med Secretariat, and with the specific goal to define and test the implementation of a transnational and multi-level system of observing systems, able to assess and address environmental threats in the Mediterranean Sea and along its coasts. The project answers needs identified in the framework of the Interreg Med gap analysis, and targets both the scientific and the governance components required in the definition and testing of the systems. SHAREMED is intended to support regional, sub-regional and local authorities, and the research community to jointly assess and address hazards related to the increasing presence of pollutants and coexisting environmental threats in the Mediterranean Sea. The project will be proposing a design of the future Mediterranean marine observatories and monitoring systems for assessing environmental risks as a co-ordinated and trans-national effort. SHAREMED experience highlights the need to better sustain the development and implementation of a shared observing system of systems, able to deliver coherent evidence rooted joint assessment of marine ecosystem state, and environmental threats.  This initiative would provide a  major opportunity to address topics such as a seamless integration and enhancement of current observing system, the development of proper multi-level governance frameworks, reduction of fragmentation, extension of current observing capabilities toward the biological dimension, development of evidence rooted scientific support to ocean sustainability and blue economy, integration of predictive capabilities in observing system, not to mention support to meet MFSD objectives in international waters.  Sharemed scientific coordinator (Cosimo Solidoro, OGS) can be reached at (csolidoro@inogs.it)
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: EMSO ERIC fully embraces the European Commission (EC) initiative to support integration and harmonisation of ocean observations in an interdisciplinary frame. This contribution aims to reinforce a shared common vision and contribute for optimising the use of pan-European infrastructure and sea operation resources.  EMSO ERIC, as a pan-European Distributed Research Infrastructure (RI), is supported by an integrated system of Regional Facilities (RFs) that presently involves 8 European Countries. These RFs are deployed in "key environmental sites" in the European seas, at depths down to more than 4000 m in the Atlantic, in the mid-Atlantic Ridge, through the Mediterranean basin, as far as the till the anoxic Black Sea. The scientific knowledge that EMSO provides enables users to tackle the triple environmental challenges of Marine Ecosystems, Climate Change and Geo-Hazards, and their multiple interfaces. EMSO encourages EC to consider the role of long-term European investments in the environmental RIs and their strategic role. They reduce the fragmentation of resources in ocean sciences and guarantee the return of public investments through the creation and development of exchange of new knowledge and socio-+economic growth. This is a crucial point in the optimisation of resources and assets at different geographical and action scales, as a response to the need of the Member States to achieve an efficient European ocean observation system aligned with their priorities and aimed at maximising the potential of observation and use of data for different purposes (ref. section B, Objectives and Policies). Marine RIs integrate their activities within coordination initiatives as EuroGOOS and European Ocean Observing System (EOOS). Moreover, distributed RIs represent a high added value to achieve a coherent approach as they are locally rooted, thanks to the regional nodes operating within their territories. At EMSO, this scalability from local, through national to European dimension in deep-ocean observations ensures the excellence of its scientific services, based on new technologies, by integrating the existing fixed-point ocean observation facilities around Europe. This means guaranteeing openness, maximising the benefit from data sharing, ensuring that data and information from different sites are comparable and compatible.  Thus, we propose to explicitly mention the RIs in section B. Objectives and Policies, as they can positively affect multiple systems: 1. Making policies and plans more effective by encouraging the development and implementation of a comprehensive and integrated strategy of the European RIs for Ocean Observations. 2. Strengthening the coordination of processes to integrate the academia-research system with the industry and government and to generate added value to society with a vision of environmental sustainability. This concept is well suited to the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) aimed to economic progress consistent with positive social and environmental impacts. 3. Strengthening the role of the European Research Area.  We stress the need to reinforce synergies between different scientific domains and plan common actions to develop a holistic approach to ecological and economic challenges. Strategies aimed at unique and complementary action between several RIs like EMSO ERIC, EMBRC-ERIC, ELIXIR, EURO-ARGO ERIC, LIFEWATCH-ERIC, ICOS-ERIC, JERICO-RI, Danubius-RI, Eurofleets are required. RIs represents cornerstones to optimise scientific cooperation fostering multidisciplinary approaches, looking at ocean science from several perspectives.
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: The European e-Science and Technology European Infrastructure for Biodiversity and Ecosystem (LifeWatch ERIC) receives the news on the EC initiative to achieve a coherent ocean observation approach with great enthusiasm. This has been a great challenge and many of the research communities working on the ocean observation have expressed their desire for the coordination of their efforts on sampling approaches, data management and sharing and data analytics, many times in the past.    One of the most important objects of the ocean observation is its biological component. This is because it is organized at multiple levels, ranging from molecules and cells to entire biomes and ecosystems, and observed at many geographical scales, from local to global. Therefore, by nature, the observation of the biological component involves many research communities with multiple sampling approaches, data collection, management and methods of analysis. These communities often work in isolation, develop their own models for the production of evidence-based knowledge in order to better understand and propose sustainable methods of the ocean exploitation.   LifeWatch ERIC supports the development of an e-Science research facility to help scientists to increase their knowledge and deepen their understanding of biodiversity organisation and ecosystem functions and services, which ultimately supports the whole society. This facility offers a new avenue on the landscape of ocean observation and a new approach to face today’s key planetary challenges, such as the climate change. It is also essential in breaking the current barriers among the observation communities, as it provides a continuous collaborative environment which makes use and further develops the most advanced digital technologies on the data, services, information and knowledge production. Such a collaborative environment can tremendously impact the coordination of the observation of the marine biodiversity and ecosystems by bringing scientists, administrators and managers, politicians and common people into contact and  and promotes their active cooperation. In addition, this environment provides our society with the knowledge to understand the functioning of ‘Our Life Support System’ and, therefore, with the actions required in order to achieve sustainability in the decades to come.   The Research Infrastructures (RIs) are considered as “facilities that provide resources and services for research communities to conduct research and foster innovation”. Therefore, they expand the above concept of an e-Science facility, by developing a common platform for the coordination and sustainable management of their observational assets (e.g. sampling and observational platforms, data, analytics and communities) to serve the overarching approach of the EU towards ocean observation. They are open to all interested parties (e.g. individual researchers, communities, public authorities, SMEs, industry) and provide opportunities for collaboration, sharing of observational and sampling platforms, data, tools and services, capitalisation on best practices and innovation development through the investment in the emerging “trading zones” between the areas of their operation. Many of the RIs working on the ocean observation are already on the way to develop a common understanding of the topic through their involvement in projects, organisations and initiatives (EMBRC-ERIC, EMSO-ERIC, EURO-ARGO ERIC, LifeWatch ERIC, ICOS-ERIC, JERICO-RI, Danubius-RI).   This collaboration is pivotal in supporting the new initiative on ocean observation.  Feedback from: LifeWatch ERIC (68.2 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: The Eurofleets+ Consortium welcomes the initiative of the European Commission with regard to the Inception Impact Assessment.    EUROFLEETS+ and its predecessors Eurofleets and Eurofleets2, EU funded projects have facilitated open free of charge access to an integrated and advanced research vessel fleet, designed to meet the evolving and challenging needs of the user community for Ocean Observation.   Research vessels are essential mobile observing platforms for ocean science. The infrastructure is also evolving, with fixed ocean seafloor observation and mobile surface and subsea autonomous technologies presenting challenges to the existing fleet to deploy and maintain them. Meeting the complex needs of European scientists across a wide range of disciplines and geographic locations is an expensive and complex exercise requiring coordination at national and international levels, and the use of common standards and approaches.   As an advanced Research Infrastructure Community actively engaged with other infrastructures and consortia through initiatives such as ENVRI, it is likely that other similar actions should be supported to provide the catalyst for further coordination.   Eurofleets+ would support the second directive aiming for Member States to bring all public bodies responsible for ocean observation together to develop priorities, realise opportunities for sharing effort, speak with agreed voice at EU level and facilitate coherence at a sea-basin level. Through the consolidation of efforts across member states we deliver a more cohesive approach to Ocean Observation.     The increasing ability of Research Vessels to provide remote access through telepresence technology and remote data gathering and sampling provision will lead to positive environmental impacts as a result of reduced human activity. This in turn will provide improved monitoring of marine environment by including more observations made for other purposes and therefore supporting measures to protect biodiversity.  Eurofleets+ welcomes the consolidated approach and the Commissions efforts to bring all stakeholders to the process.  The likely result of such a coordinated approach is improved knowledge and efficiency with minimised impact.
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: The following feedback represents the approach of the POSEIDON System's (HCMR, Greece) leading team:  We welcome the initiative which addresses a very important issue.  The problems listed in the inception note are significant with more characteristic in our opinion that of sustainability. Most of the observing systems today depend on short research funds which inhibit any long-term planning and most importantly quite often important systems for Climate, Ocean Health and Services are removed after significant periods of operation. Due to the sporadic nature of funding (research projects), every now and then there are opportunities to acquire expensive state of the art observation equipment but without the resources to run and maintain it.  Another problem is the unequal capacity among the member states, where in some countries marine observing systems are considered an important activity and are supported, while in other countries especially due to the financial crisis and now due to the pandemic, funds are minimum. This creates an unbalance within the EU which at the end of the day is translated to inefficient information, knowledge, services etc in particular areas, regions.  In our view one should act at two distinct levels, the national, with a Directive or a Regulation through which the necessary long-term thin funding will be ensured and the EU level at which, those systems that respond to EU and global issues will be organised, coordinated and funded. The latter will be the EU contribution to the Global efforts and the connection with the various observing networks outside the EU.  In this way the system will be more resilient, flexible, adaptable and able to address a wide range of challenges.  Regarding the various options, although they seem adequate, one could possibly add another one, which would combine "a regulation with EU funding to support observations of common benefit" or possibly, "a regulation with EU funding to support observations that address key EU and Global issues and with a contribution to global observing efforts.
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: The coordination of JERICO-RI welcomes the opportunity to react to the European Commission Inception Impact Assessment, Ocean observation – sharing responsibility.   Since its preliminary stage and in a series of 4 EU funded project, the community of JERICO-RI involves about 40 partners from 17 EU countries to elaborate an integrated pan-European multidisciplinary and multiplatform (more than 500) research infrastructure dedicated to a holistic appraisal of coastal marine system changes. It is seamlessly bridging existing continental, atmospheric and open ocean RIs, thus filling a key gap in the ESFRI landscape. As a consequence, JERICO-RI enhances collaborations with other marine RIs and initiatives as one of the key objectives of its strategy to establish the framework upon which coastal marine systems are observed, analysed, understood and forecasted. It aims to be the future coastal component of the European Ocean Observing System (EOOS), and part of the Global Ocean Observing System (GOOS). The specificities of the coastal ocean had led the consortium and EU to invest effort in a complex endeavour for the coordination and harmonisation of coastal observing capacities in view of enabling multidisciplinary observations over a wide range of spatio-temporal scales for more than 14 years (2011-2024).  Thanks to the JERICO legacy, as a mature community for coastal observation, we are convinced that the option 2 as proposed: implementation of an EU directive aiming to bring public bodies at national level will help to plan, share, harmonize, sustain and innovate will significantly help. Moreover we also noticed the increasing fragmentation induced by the multiplicity of funded initiatives which necessarily raises up the difficulty to coordinate them as an ensemble. Consequently, it is timely to organise funding to set up such a coordination at both EU and national levels as proposed in option 5.  One of the fundamental characteristics of the coastal observation is that, rather than focusing on a single specific scientific question, it addresses a complex host of interrelated scientific issues regarding the marine coastal and shelf dynamics and environment. A coordinated coastal observation helps support national policy bodies to apply national environmental policies and EU ones like the MSFD. From a single shopping point they benefit from the expertise and practices shared with other nations, access specific services, information and data. As the MFSD is based on descriptors basically operates at coastal level, the community of JERICO-RI would welcome an alignment of the regional uses of EOVs (Essential Ocean Variables) that are globally adopted among Observation infrastructures to address the descriptors.  The coastal observation platforms are scattered across the European coastline, largely based on national and regional initiatives, but to some extent also linked together for answering large scale science questions. Therefore, JERICO-RI is investigating a regional organisation that is currently tested. In the coastal domain, the Super Site model develops innovative monitoring strategies in an integrated and harmonized multiplatform way, capable of coordinated observations at nested spatiotemporal scales. In essence, the coastal regional sites are transnational and jointly address Key Scientific Challenges. We think that the JERICO-RI regional structure could be used to strategically manage coastal observation and propose strategic fundings to maintain observing systems in operation according to the site's needs.  Therefore, we welcome the DGMARE initiative which we think addresses an important issue and as a community we believe that a mixture of national and EU support mechanisms through the appropriate tools (directive, regulations) must be put forward.  The JERICO-RI coordination team (Ifremer, Puillat I., Delauney L.) is available for further information at jerico@ifremer.fr. Feedback from: JERICO-RI (316.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: The European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet) Secretariat welcomes the proposal by the EU to develop mechanisms to optimise, enhance and lead to more coherence in the coordination of ocean observation and marine monitoring at national, and trans-national levels. It is clear that European countries and the EU have already invested significantly in ocean observing infrastructure and technology (EOOS Call to Action, 2018 ), and in data management and data infrastructures such as EMODnet and CMEMS. These provide the much-needed open and free access to harmonised and standardised data sets and data products, information and knowledge to underpin evidence-based decision-making for the sustainable management and protection of the marine environment, operations at sea and weather and climate predictions and forecasts, and to meet the ambitious targets of the European Green Deal. There is an urgent need for a coordinated and comprehensive approach to the systematic observing and monitoring of our seas and oceans, and to stream-line the collection of  the crucial ocean observations and wider marine monitoring   A recent pilot study by the EMODnet Secretariat, in collaboration with the European Marine Board (EMB) which assessed the levels of coordination in ocean observing and marine monitoring at national level, highlighted that in most EU countries the responsibility for the observation is split between several ministries, departments and agencies, which can lead to duplication of effort, resources and resulting in below optimal coordination. The 2018 International European Ocean Observing Conference , coordinated by the EMODnet Secretariat, in collaboration with EMB and EuroGOOS, brought together diverse communities in ocean observing and marine monitoring to identify current challenges, bottlenecks and opportunities. In addition to the EOOS Call to Action which called countries to coordinate all national marine and coastal data collection efforts, the >250 participants of the Conference displayed motivation and appetite for enhancing dialogue and coordination across sectors.   It is clear that the baseline of no action would not deliver the required level of incentive for action that is proposed. Further mechanisms to incentivise Member States and nations to coordinate the collection, sharing and management of ocean observations – across all sectors that collect ocean data including the public and private sectors – would further streamline the marine knowledge pipeline and value chain which, ultimately, would enable the saving of costs and the faster and more operational delivery of data and information by trusted entities and initiatives such as EMODnet to users, for the benefit of wider society.    The EMODnet Secretariat also welcomes the EU proposal for further consultation with key stakeholders and the wider community, to assess the preferred options before making a decision on which mechanism(s) to implement e.g. Directive, various levels of legal regulation and potentially funding to support observations of common benefit. A future mechanism could also consider how to best promote and incentivise national data collectors and producers to share data not only at national level, but also with European data initiatives such as EMODnet, to ensure the long-term discovery of the data together with the opportunities for global impact and uptake through the integrated, standardised and harmonised data sets and data products, with rich metadata descriptions, that are offered by the EMODnet public data service, including discovery through web services that support machine-machine communication, and that are connected to global initiatives including the IODE-IOC  Ocean Info Hub, an activity of the UN Ocean Decade.      The EMODnet Secretariat stands ready to facilitate, assist and provide EC with the necessary support to take this very positive initiate forward. – secretariat@emodnet.eu. Feedback from: EMODnet Secretariat (642.4 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: The achievement of the European Green Deal is time sensitive. The seas and ocean are common resources, as water and animals are not constrained by national borders. The European Ocean Observing System framework (EOOS, http://www.eoos-ocean.eu) Steering Group (http://www.eoos-ocean.eu/eoos-steering-committee-members/) welcomes the European Commission’s efforts to achieve coherent ocean observations in Europe by coordinating within and between Member States. Although a centralized ocean observation approach would benefit all Member States and Associated Countries, we should not expect this initiative to require all Member States to agree on a common observing approach, as this is an unrealistic aim. A common and overarching understanding of ocean observations and the need for integration and data sharing will lead to a better use of technologies and information for different purposes (research, monitoring, services). This initiative would improve the efficient use of public funds for ocean observation, creating both economic and social benefits. The harmonization of information on what ocean variables are measured where, how often, and by whom, using standards such as the Essential Ocean Variables (EOVs), and what is required by different marine Directives, would get us closer to achieving the goals of the EU 2030 Biodiversity Strategy, the implementation of a Digital Twin Ocean, and the UN Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development. Current efforts exist to integrate and optimise different ocean observation initiatives (e.g. EU projects EuroSea, JERICO), but Europe and its marine environment would benefit from a harmonised and overarching approach to ocean observations, including through improved integration and increased sustainability of the observing system, and clearer reporting. We encourage the European Commission to recommend that EU Members States and Associated countries reinforce national coordination and sustainability discussions in this framework, especially given that at present only 28% of systems (https://insitu.copernicus.eu/library/reports/Sustainabilitysurveyupdatedreportfinal.pdf) have clear long-term funding to ensure their sustainability. Furthermore, increased integration and oversight at European level would help to address current imbalance in the distribution of the ocean observing system across European waters. We find the broad definition used for marine observation, including all survey/monitoring/sampling currently conducted for different purposes to be beneficial for this initiative. The system should also be fit-for-purpose, with analysis carried out to understand what this entails. In addition, the integration of different legal instruments and policies on observation activities, e.g. for MSFD and relevant conventions to which the EU is a party, could clarify their relation to the objectives of national, European, regional and international policies, and connect the competent governing bodies with interest in the ocean. Such integration will also allow a better assessment of the reasons why the current efforts to improve the health of the ocean do not translate into achieving the objectives. Lessons can be learnt from previous marine Directives (e.g. MSFD, WFD), analysing what was intended by the Directive and what was in reality achieved though implementation by Member States, to ensure that an eventual approach on ocean observations is successful in its ambitions.  In addition to the funding by Member States, who bear most of the costs of observing systems and who should continue to do so, we consider that additional direct EU funding/co-funding will be required for pan-European and global aspects as well as for coordination. There should however be consideration of where the funding would come from, to whom it would be provided, and for what purposes. International-level engagement with GOOS and GEO should be ensured, with European-level coordination and funding to support this. Feedback from: European Ocean Observing System (EOOS) (450.6 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: The International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) is and intergovernmental organization composed of 93 Member States from the five continents. The IHO works to ensure all the world's seas, oceans and navigable waters are surveyed and charted, and coordinates the activities of national Hydrographic Offices (HOs), promoting uniformity in nautical charts and documents.  The IHO issues survey best practices, provides guidelines to maximize the use of hydrographic survey data, issues Standards and develops hydrographic capabilities in Member States. And, the IHO and the European Commission signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) in April 2012 to establish a cooperative framework between the two sides in the field of integrated approach to maritime affairs. Moreover, the MoU can enable HOs to become key enablers in the development of EU and national maritime policies and facilitate the implementation of EU policies, including those regarding standards of marine data.  With reference to the standards, the recent release of the new version of the following IHO Publications:  - S 44 Ed. 6.0.0 September 2020 - Standards for Hydrographic Surveys: a set of standards for hydrographic surveys used to compile navigational charts essential for the safety of navigation, knowledge and the protection of the marine environment, and then, where and when necessary, by the HOs or organizations to define more stringent or specific requirements as national or regional realizations of the standards;  - B 12 Ed. 2.0.3 January 2020 - Guidance on Crowdsourced Bathymetry: a guidance to mariners to help them collect and contribute crowdsourced bathymetric data in a format that is useful to the broadest possible audience,  can contribute to fill the gap of a lack of standardization among the many actors involved in marine activities and the collection of hydro-oceanographic data and to construct a common strategy at regional level - i.e. European Union level - based on the commonly recognized way to approach marine data "Map once, use many times", that should drive - in the future - the exploration and the knowledge of the oceans.
Initiative: Ocean observation – sharing responsibility

feedback_msg_text: EuroCommerce welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback to the European Commission’s Inception Impact Assessment for a legislative framework for the governance of Common European Data Spaces (CEDSs). The coronavirus crisis has made the need for a fair and ethical European data ecosystem more pressing than ever. The Data Economy and its insights can help retailers and wholesalers to improve their services, but also to innovate and find new opportunities to speed up recovery. To remain competitive, retailers and wholesalers need a regulatory framework that supports strong European retail and wholesale ecosystems in a digital environment and gives them legal certainty and incentives to invest in robust omnichannel strategies.   CEDSs will encourage voluntary data sharing in strategic sectors, foster data use across industries and the European Union, and establish safe and easily accessible data environments for public bodies, companies, and individuals. EuroCommerce strongly believes that the following criteria should be taken into consideration as the foundation of a well-functioning legal framework for Data Sharing:  • Data sharing in Common European Data Spaces should remain on a voluntary basis. We strongly believe that mandatory data sharing should only be used as a last resort tool in exceptional cases of clear market failures and should carefully balance the interests of data holders/generators and data recipients. • Common European Data Spaces should be self-regulatory, as it was proven that the existing common practices are functioning very well. • Cross-sectorial data sharing should be encouraged. Retail and wholesale companies may be operating across different data spaces; it is thus essential that the approach allows for voluntary data exchange between different data spaces, within the limits of competition law. Such an approach would prevent the creation of unnecessary silos and trigger efficient data sharing practices. • Data sharing for the common good should be based on a clear harmonised definition of what constitutes public interest. • Common European Data Spaces must provide legal certainty, secure privacy, and competition safeguards and ensure an adequate level of cybersecurity. The proper implementation of existing rules will be paramount to the success of CEDSs. • Unlocking the value of public data in a useful, harmonised format has great potential to foster innovation. • Investing in skills, digital education and research should be a priority of the European Union.   Please see the document attached for more information.  Feedback from: EuroCommerce (250.5 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The Skills Alliance unites 40 organizations (universities, employers, national employment agencies, training organizations) from 6 E.U countries to experiment human centric skills data networks, share standards and governance rules. We believe in the separation of powers principle to govern the personal data spaces. The Skills Alliance has the ambition to take an active role in the construction of the skills data space. The Skills Alliance members commit to make skills data available in a human centric way, to provide better services and employment for people and better insights for the economy.  The several skills data networks being built by the Skills Alliance's members will share a same governance model to decide on the standards (legal, technical, business, UX, ethical) to use. Such a collaboration paves the way for a common european skills data space.  The Skills Alliance and its projects will produce open standards and governance frameworks for all to use. The Skills Alliance builds skills data networks following the SITRA RULEBOOK.  The Skills Alliance projects will aim to implement the separation of powers architecture for the access of personal data: the operators that handle permissions do not store or provide services on personal data, the services exchanging data do not handle permissions. This is represented by the different roles inside the data network.  Inside the data network there are different roles:  Data Source: one or several sources that provide the network with data.   Service Provider: one or several data refiners that combine data streams, refine data, and provide them further. Provides services to End-Users or as a subcontractor to other Service Providers.   End-User: one or several individuals or organizations for which a Service Provider has developed its services. Consumes, utilizes and accesses the value that is created in the data ecosystem.   Infrastructure Operator: one or several actors that provide identifiers registry management, consent management, logging, or service management services for the data network.  One organization can have one or many roles amongst the first 3 (data sources, service provider, end-user) but an infrastructure operator can only be an infrastructure operator. This is the separation of powers principle. It gives the person an independent way to manage their data in the data network. This prevents any conflict of interest or any single stakeholder taking over a network. This helps create trust.  Each project has a data network agreement, where each organization (end user, service provider, data source, infrastructure operator) participating in the data network has their responsabilities and role described.   To define the standards of such networks, there are two levels of governance inside the Skills Alliance: - one at the project level: each organization being part of a data network has one representative to decide of the standards used by the network - one at the inter-project level: each project of the Skills Alliance has one representative on the steering committee of the Skills Alliance to exchange best practices between projects and decide on standards that can be used by all project as well as to decide on conflicts and issues  In this governance model one issue regards the representation of the individual, the members are actively working on it as well as on the business model and ethical issues regarding skills data use.  The paper attached describes the feedback and propositions of the 40 members of the Skills Alliance. Feedback from: Skills Alliance - aNewGovernance (129.8 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Vodafone welcome the publication of the European Commission Roadmap Inception Impact Assessment on the legislative framework for the governance of common European data spaces. As set out in our response to the EU Data Strategy, Vodafone wholeheartedly supports the objective of the European Commission to encourage data sharing and reuse and thereby unlock the latent value of data. Our response went on to highlight our conditional support for the concept of designating a set of common European data spaces and stressed the importance of clear guidance from the Commission on data governance.  Vodafone commissioned Deloitte to model the economic benefits of B2B data sharing in a number of industry sectors, finding that the sharing of machine-generated non-personal data would add €1.4 tn in economic value to the EU economy by the year 2027.   However, today of a lack of guidance and best practice across Europe on end to end data management is holding back this potential. As such, European business are reliant on (primarily US based) service providers to develop and maintain the data assets necessary to conduct big data analytics. Clear European guidance on end to end data management, could help define standards and best practices, encourage knowledge sharing, thereby allowing European start-ups and firms to be able to compete in this space on delivery and skills differentiation, and likely achieve European excellence.    Regarding the specific policy options outlined in the roadmap, we encourage the Commission to broaden the focus on sharing and reuse of data to encompass the entire data lifecycle. What would be particularly helpful from the Commission would be a set of detailed guidance (non-legislative) on the end to end management of data throughout its lifecycle from inception to analysis, subsequent reuse and ultimate decommissioning and deletion. At each stage of the data lifecycle, further guidance should be given on the appropriate data management processes that should be employed by firms to ensure the quality and utility of the underlying data set.  Data governance mechanisms provide a means to overcome technical and procedural variations between companies in terms of how they collect, store, and process and delete data. The extent to which these governance mechanisms can be harmonised across sectors and throughout the single market will be beneficial in enabling increased data sharing and reuse.   Practical anonymisation standards facilitate the deployment of new technologies and companies’ responsible use of data, for example attribute suppression, record suppression, character masking, data perturbation, data aggregation and use of synthetic data. Such standards should include clear boundaries to reduce the perceived risk of sharing and contention with GDPR, particularly in relation to pseudonymised data. An agreed data access model, with governance controls common to all participants, to include configurable permissions management that helps assure the provenance of the data, ensures the longevity of the data feed to avoid stranding application services upstream and the rights of the seller and buyer of the data.  We believe such guidance will be an important means to help establish European excellence in the field of data analytics, intermediation and brokerage, a market segment that is currently heavily dominated by a small number of non-European providers. Crucially any such guidance should be harmonised across the single market, under a common framework for end to end data lifecycle management, to overcome national fragmentation and fully leverage the scale and opportunity of a single European data space.  Feedback from: Vodafone Group (29.3 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
