feedback_msg_text: The Center for Data Innovation is pleased to submit feedback to the European Commission’s roadmap titled “Legislative framework for the governance of common European data spaces.”  The European Commission published a data strategy in February 2020 with the goal of creating a single market for data. As part of that vision, the Commission has proposed creating “European data spaces” with clear and consistent rules across member states for access and use of data in key sectors of the economy. To that end, the Commission has invited feedback on its initial plans to propose a legislative framework that would 1) increase access to publicly held data; 2) support voluntary data sharing by individuals and organizations; 3) developing technical standards and promoting interoperability to lower the cost of data sharing; and 4) support data intermediaries to share data between different stakeholders.  In the attached submission, we provide feedback on the policy options described for each of these four goals.  Thank you for your consideration and this opportunity to contribute. feedback_msg_text: MyData Global is an award-winning international nonprofit. The purpose of MyData Global is to empower individuals by improving their right to self-determination regarding their personal data. It is based on the MyData Declaration, published in 2017.   MyData Global has nearly 90 organisation members and over 400 individual members from over 50 countries, on six continents. feedback_msg_text: A European Strategy for Data, published by the EU on February 19th, 2020 outlines a vision for a connected single digital market, where the benefits of the digital economy could enhance the lives of its citizens, residents and trade partners.   However, we now find ourselves at a very real crossroad. A post-pandemic world will be a new type of normal. Amidst the tragic loss of lives there have been breakthroughs in science, new ways of working, new digital tools embraced and a chance for our planet to breath.  Personal data linked to identity, fuelled by AI sits at the centre of three competing digital strategies; the tensions between the rights of the EU citizen, the power of the State in China and the commercial market forces of the USA. Each present new ethical, technical and societal challenges.   We are at the beginning of a new design and architectural phase where just because technology can, doesn’t mean it should. Where we go from here depends on how the European Union strikes a balance between these global competing data strategies.  The EU’s plan to establish Common European Data Spaces together with the appropriate regulatory and legal framework is a bold step towards ensuring that data rights can be respected.  However, it is critical to acknowledge that the nine data spaces are also connected horizontally by humans. The policy makers and participants that will shape and derive value from these data spaces, also bring an additional layer of value; personal data.  At Meeco we believe that enabling citizens, students, patients, employees, passengers and consumers to more equitably join the value chains fuelled by data will ultimately lead to greater trust and personalisation, resulting in a more prosperous society.  This will require new commercial models, enforceable regulation and the digital tools to transform our connected society.  The intention by the EU to develop standards for data sharing and data interoperability, as well as the technical tools and infrastructures necessary to use and exchange data could position the EU competitively for commerce and drive better societal outcomes.  However, without the explicit recognition of the critical role personal data plays in our digital economy, we risk furthering the divide and asymmetry that has resulted from American technology platforms.  We need the policy mandates to protect, connect and cultivate economic participation. Without this there is the danger that individuals will contribute by default, but not benefit by design.  It is therefore our hope that extending the strategy to include the means by which Europeans can access and use their personal data will have exponential benefits for both the post pandemic economic recovery and future generations.  Providing mandated access for individuals to data sources so that they too can move from a passive to active participant in the digital economy will deliver significant benefits. Most notably the possibility for personalised health, medicine, education, employment and finance, together with the obvious benefits of product and services delivery.  In order for this to be realised, we must empower citizens with the rights and tools to request, access, share and explicitly consent to the contextual use of their data. This is not only technically progressive; it is also the foundation for the fast approaching phygital world; the fusion of mankind and machine.  The EU Data Strategy provides the opportunity to implement the policies and infrastructure that will deliver a better society for all. One that embraces the digital citizen as foundational to innovation, growth and new models for connection and commerce.  To this end, Meeco has detailed how a human-centric approach can augment the nine designated data spaces and included this white paper as an attachment.  It is our hope that these real case studies, will be a contributing force to a more equitable digital society. Feedback from: Meeco Groep NV (1.6 MB - PDF - 39 pages) Download
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: EUROGI’s mission is ‘to promote the widespread and effective use of geospatial information and technologies in Europe’.  Given the role of location, where, in virtually all decision-making from high level policy to citizens’ day-to-day activities we believe that if well organised, geospatial information and technologies can play a significant role in improving social welfare, the economy and the protection/enhancement of the environment at all levels from the Union as a whole to the local, and across very many sectors.  We consider that an ideal situation across Europe would exist regarding geospatial information (GI) if at no cost and with no use/reuse constraints it were possible to easily discover, download and seamlessly integrate up-to-date static and real-time, high resolution, accurate, authoritative, standardised, core/high usage geospatial data for use in users own geospatial systems or for other citizen, business or government user-determined purposes.  In terms of the above ‘vision’ the current situation in Europe is very much less than adequate, and there is considerable scope for improvement.    We identify the following issues which need to be addressed.  Firstly, there are no harmonised, standardized, authoritative Europe-wide geospatial data sets available across the whole of the EU.  We agree with CLGE’s position that we often hear it said that the EU is powerless in this regard because GI is a Member State responsibility, a situation which leads to a fragmented GI availability situation.  We are aware that often official authorities rely on commercial or voluntary derived GI, even for crucial tasks including cross border security and emergency planning. We subscribe to CLGE’s position that it is likely that no other continent in the world would rely on such a fragmented and non-standardised geospatial data infrastructure.  Secondly, we are aware from our members that in some cases the cost of GI from mapping authoriteis can be prohibitively expensive.  For example, in one recent case authoritative road network data for a relatively small area in one country cost €8 850 from the relevant authority and immediately across the border similar (but not the same: see the first point above) road data cost €12 000.  From a SME perspective in particular these costs rule out the possibility of undertaking development work to produce new products or services. In short, innovation is stifled, and development of the digital market is constrained. A standardized all-EU approach regarding costing is sorely needed.  Thirdly, the focus for authoritative GI is very much on static data whereas nowadays real-time data plays an increasingly important role in many spheres, including for example regarding the Internet of Things.  It is essential that in Europe we move with the times in this regard and derive systems which can capture and make available authoritative standardized real-time geospatial data.  The abovementioned issues are presented as some examples of the may ways in which here in Europe we are very far from attaining the ‘vision’ set out above.  In fact, of the many points listed in the vision only the authoritative, cost, harmonised, and real-time aspects are highlighted in this submission.  There are also important difficulties regarding the other mentioned issues.  The reasons for the unacceptable situation in Europe can be attributed to many factors, and are complex in nature.  There is no single body/entity within the Commission or a European body, which has overall defining responsibility for all aspects of GI and its related technologies.  This is a situation which needs to be addressed.  Finally, I would like to mention that EUROGI is fully committed to engaging with EU authorities to explore the above and other relevant issues in more detail, We believe that we have useful insights to contribute.
Organisation: EUROGI - European Umbrella Association for Geographic Information
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: To Whom It May Concern,  ESBB expresses its sincere interest in the EU Data Strategy as a timely cross-sectional initiative of high impact and benefit for citizens of Europe and beyond. ESBB is fully aligned with EU’s current data strategy proposition in general and its INCEPTION IMPACT ASSESSMENT in particular. However, ESBB likes to emphasize one aspect that could widen the scope of likely environmental impacts.    For your background information, ESBB is an international non-profit organization located in Brussels, Belgium. ESBB represents all aspects of biobanking and biopreservation of biological resources (human and non-human, animal, plant and environmental samples and derivatives as well as associated (research) data; www.esbb.org). Particularly, the ESBB Working Groups on Data Standardization & Harmonization, Regulatory-Ethics-GDPR, Automation & Interfaces, Environment & Human Biomonitoring, Plant Biodiversity, Domestic & Wildlife, and Microbiome among others fit well to the incentives of the EU Data Strategy and are eager to contribute if needed.  In particular, ESBB kindly suggests to consider the following aspects in the INCEPTION IMPACT ASSESSMENT under part C (Preliminary Assessment of Expected Impacts) on Likely Environmental Impacts:  > ESBB suggests to define biodiversity as part of the Green Deal data space in more detail and to a wider extend. While the Likely Environmental Impacts through the “green deal-, energy-, and agriculture- data space” specifically point to impacts for climate change, circular economy, zero-pollution, deforestation, energy efficiency, local consumption, renewable energy resources, precision farming capacities, reduced emissions and – last but not least – biodiversity, we suggest to clarify that biodiversity comprises e.g. also domestic and wildlife animals, plants and crops, fungi, and microbiomes.  Against this background and on behalf of ESBB Council, I express our highest interest and support for implementing the EU Data Strategy and regard this INCEPTION IMPACT ASSESSMENT as quite comprehensive with the exception for the suggested addition as outlined above.  We would be delighted to support this challenging but highly valuable endeavour with our community’s broad expertise and active engagement. Please don’t hesitate to contact me if our society can be of more support.   Sincerely,  Prof. Jens K. Habermann, M.D., Ph.D. President, ESBB

feedback_msg_text: o We generally agree with the overall aim of the European Commission´s Roadmap and especially regarding the reduction of transaction costs  for data access, sharing and reuse for research and innovation activities. At the moment many Companies cannot access the data they need and they often face strict limitations when they want to (re-)use data. Unlock the value of non-sensitive data detained by public bodies and encourage private companies to share non sensitive data on voluntary basis, as well as supporting the creation of interoperability standards are all initiatives that should help to tackle these major issues.  o Many companies do not possess the necessary skills and tools for sharing their data in an economically efficient way. Therefore data intermediaries collecting and facilitating the access to existing data (APIs, etc.) could be a useful instrument in this regard.  o Since data can be a valuable and strategic asset for private companies, data sharing should only occur on a voluntary basis.  Nevertheless, the lack of incentive for private companies to provide/share their data could strongly limit the efficiency of this policy option. We strongly encourage an additional reflexion about the establishment of fair conditions for companies providing the data.   o We support the initiation of Data Intermediaries as long as their role is defined as providing metadata. The question related to the founding process  of  intermediaries as well as their governance procedures must be clearly addressed.  o In that context we think it is important that there are no new barriers trough additional regulatory rules or additional administrative burdens for European companies.

feedback_msg_text: Stiftung Neue Verantwortung is an independent think tank at the intersection of technology and society. We welcome the opportunity to reply to the Inception Impact Assessment on the legislative framework for the governance of common European data spaces. We agree with your description of the problem for the largest part and see great potential in an initiative that aims to contribute to solutions to these problems.   1. Public sector sharing: Government data sharing can set a powerful precedent, but still faces high political barriers. We consider that best-practice sharing among European governments is likely to be helpful and we recommend including the topic of benchmarks and KPIs centred around the FAIR data principles. These help to focus efforts on measures that have the largest impact on generating data value, rather than maximising the amount of data that is published.   We agree that privacy-enhancing technologies are important to limit the potential risks of making certain data open and accessible. These technologies matter not only for public data but can also help to ensure confidentiality of e.g. business secrets when sharing data among companies. Stimulating research and further adoption of these technologies is key to fostering voluntary data sharing among a broad range of organisations.  2. Data altruism: We emphasise that usability and transparency are central to making data altruism work. The current crisis has shown that citizens are willing to share significant amounts of data for the common good. When designing mechanisms to collect such data, we recommend to not only focus on individual consent as stipulated by the GDPR (and the shortcomings of which are well-known), but also include involvement of groups – consumers in general or specific consumer groups – who are likely to be affected by data collection and use (“collective/community consent”). These will help to increase acceptance and use of data altruism mechanisms.  3. Certification: While we support the intention to support, as stated in the Inception Impact Assessment, the commercial uptake of novel data intermediaries, we have reservations regarding certification for two reasons:   First, certificates and labels are often ineffective. The GDPR certification is one example of plans failing to achieve tangible results. It is important to generate momentum across stakeholders with a common understanding of the problem the certification/label is aiming to solve. Only then they will be adopted and used widely. One area to explore is concerns about intermediaries using confidential for their own benefit or even to compete with the contributors of data. For this, certification/labelling of an intermediary’s business model could be useful.  Second, certificates and labels can also have undesired side effects. Different types of intermediaries are slowly emerging and, even if problematic business models may be among them, they are likely to cause limited harm. At the early stage that we are at, it may be dangerous to try to favour some (and thereby disadvantage other) business models without a solid and evidence-based understanding of the effects they have. While this uncertainty remains, all measures should remain voluntary and there should be continuous effort to monitor potential undesired side effects.  We agree that the easiest gains are likely to be made in settings where data sharing is beneficial for all parties involved and voluntary measures to suffice. However, we stress that there are other settings where power imbalances may lead to data being shared even when it is not in the best interest of some parties (citizens, consumers, businesses) and that are beyond the scope of the GDPR and other legislation. We hope that these will be dealt with in future initiatives.
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: Nous sommes ravis de pouvoir contribuer à cette initiative ‘Legislative framework for the governance of common European data spaces’. Agdatahub a ainsi l’ambition d’aider à améliorer la performance économique, environnementale, sociale et sociétale des filières agricoles et agroalimentaires, à travers par exemple une plus grande mobilisation des données pour l’agriculture de précision, ou le développement d’outils favorisant la traçabilité des produits alimentaires. feedback_msg_text: The European Alliance for Research Excellence, a coalition of companies and research organisations formed in 2017 committed to the future of innovation and R&D in Europe, warmly welcomes the European Commission’s ambitions outlined in its Data Strategy to create common and sectoral European data spaces.   European data spaces will be key to encouraging the development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Europe, which offers vast potential for economic growth and can help generate insights to address some of society’s biggest challenges, from healthcare to the environment. There is a broad recognition from regulators and industry that making data more open and accessible is critically important to foster collaboration and help drive European research and competitiveness in AI. Opening up access to data for better research outcomes, such as making progress in medical science, and supporting Europe’s ability to bring new innovative products and services to the market for the benefit of consumers, is achievable and preferable to data being withheld by a few public or private organizations.  The creation of common European data spaces aiming to incentivise data sharing by creating clear rules for access and use of data therefore appears timely and necessary. Policy efforts should concentrate on creating coherent and easy-to-understand frameworks in order to increase stakeholders’ trust and encourage them to access and collaborate with data in an effective, fair and non-discriminatory manner, as well as open up and re-use data across Europe, in line with European values, including privacy rules.   Common data spaces will only be functional if other relevant EU-legislation is properly implemented. We call on the EU to support the effective and harmonized implementation of policies that impact the availability and use of data, such as the EU Copyright Directive’s Text and Data Mining exception, which will ease access to data across Europe, and the Directive on Open Data and Re-Use of Public Sector Information, which will decrease barriers and encourage access to public sector and publicly-funded information.   We agree with the Commission’s identification of four thematic clusters, which we believe if approached the right way can help lift existing barriers to open data. More specifically, on points i) and iii):  • i) Unlocking the value from data held by public sector bodies: In order to foster access and re-use of data held by the public sector, we support the identification of specific high-value datasets that should be made available free-of-charge, in a machine-readable format, and provided through an application programming interface (API). We also strongly support policy options that would provide easy and secure access to publicly-held data and datasets in a harmonised way across Europe; • iii) Ensuring common standards and interoperability: Data sharing should be based on the principles of interoperability of data sets and in mutual reciprocity, while maintaining an appropriate balance between public and private interests. As outlined in the IIA, established mechanisms and processes for technical standardisation already exist, and we would strongly encourage the Commission to support these efforts, be they industry-driven, or happening within inter-governmental organisations (ISO), by encouraging stakeholder dialogue to guarantee broad uptake of existing standards.  As the European Commission considers various approaches to the definition of common data spaces, we would like to reinforce the need to consider collaboration models that allow organizations to share more data while maintaining contractual control over data or without having to necessarily disclose data. These can include innovative governance structures (data trusts, data cooperatives or data commons), effective legal agreements that facilitate access to data (data sharing agreements), and the use of technologies that help protect privacy and strengthen security.
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: Market failure - data being used as an obstacle to access consumers and technical information of their vehicle  It is our opinion that national and European authorities should therefore intervene both in the interest of consumers and SMEs. Action is all the more urgent because this intervention should concentrate on ensuring free choice of customers. Craft entrepreneurs’ business model integrates consumers into the production process of their offer.  This is due to the fact that these craft-enterprises have acquired confidence of their customers through their skills and high technicality as well as the continuous adaptation to their expectations and budget. Their strength lies in their independence, consumers being much attracted by the sense of customer service and love of a good job done. Craft-enterprises know from experience that they have to constantly renew their offer to stay on the market. Determined to integrate in their business model the double ecological and digital transition and draw all the lessons from the crisis, they propose the following orientations.  To obtain access to the vehicles the independent repairers act in partnership with suppliers (manufacturers, OEMs, parts and equipment distributors), as well as business providers (roadside assistance companies and automobile insurers) to co-produce value with the customer. On the one hand, to preserve the engine and the environment through eco-maintenance of the vehicle and the traceability of circular economy parts. On the other hand, to make customers aware of the connected vehicle that might safeguard their free choice of trusted repairer to increasing their confidence in digital transformation.  Therefore it is crucial to have a legal right to access in-vehicle data for all independent repairer  Difficulties in access to vehicle inspection, maintenance and repair market, which have already been identified for the combustion engine, are focused now on the electrical system. Access to in-vehicle data also means access to motorists and automotive service market. While new technology is designed to reduce the cost of maintenance and repair, vehicle manufacturers tend to reserve the operation to their network at the expense of consumers’ choice. The exclusive and permanent connection of manufacturers with motorists entails the risk of favoring their network as consumers experience a tension between making their voice heard and understanding the true scope of the obligations imposed on them under the pretext of implementing the advanced technology. Moreover, this risk has been highlighted by the European Commission, after the study carried out by the Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (C-ITS) platform.   Answering the Consultation  The principle of free choice is of public interest. It is based on transparency. It must become a tangible reality in the automotive market. For many years we have therefore – both national and before the EU-Commission - been calling for greater market vigilance by a dedicated service being empowered to taking emergency measures to restore competition. National competition-authorities for instance need more complete powers in order to give consumers the best possible protection from anticompetitive behaviours, as stressed by Commissioner Margrethe Vestager’s statement from 22. March 2017. They need the financial and human resources to collect and go through the evidence. Besides an appropriate structure it is vital to establish a clear and predictable legal framework in order to give effect to the right to access data from another company to ensuring free choice of consumers.
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: The PHG Foundation welcomes the opportunity to comment on this proposal for the governance of common European data spaces. We have recently completed comprehensive research on the impact of the GDPR on genomic data processing in healthcare and scientific research which we have attached for consideration as part of the further evidence base. We hope this work is useful in delineating some aspects that may be best addressed at a cross-sector level and those which require much more sector (i.e. the health sector), or sub-sector (i.e. genomics sector) specific focus.   There are two particular aspects of the roadmap and European strategy for data that we would like to comment on from our perspective as specialists in health and genomic data:  First, we agree that support is needed for technologies and new services which empower individuals to exercise their data rights and facilitate voluntary data sharing. Patients and research participants in the genomics field are often highly knowledgeable, active and keen to ensure that their data is available for the advancement of medical knowledge. The improvement and development of services and technologies to support increased patient control could lead to considerable gains for healthcare and medical research. Moreover, as we considered in our research, there is significant potential for new services to manage complex genomic data and apply state of the art de-identification and security methods to facilitate the use of this data for healthcare and research.   Second, we welcome the recognition that a range of policy options could be used to reduce transaction costs in data sharing and standardise aspects of governance and regulation. In particular, as our research discusses, there is significant potential for codes of conduct and certification to be developed by sectors and sub-sectors (for example genomics researchers) or by categories of data processors and controllers (for example, third party genomic data services) to reduce barriers to data sharing across the EU-EEA and even globally. We encourage the development of both informal codes and certification to develop consensus on the appropriate application of laws and governance standards, as well as targeted development of more specific codes and certification for approval under the GDPR as more formal means of demonstrating compliance with the Regulation. We are aware that work has begun on a code of conduct for health data and that there is further work led by BBMRI-ERIC on a code of conduct for scientific research. We hope that many further, potentially more specific, codes and certification mechanisms will be developed for approval and that the relevant authorities are adequately supported to help develop and assess them in a timely manner. In our view this is the most promising way that ambiguity and uncertainty about the sectoral application of the General Data Protection Regulation can be addressed to unblock data sharing and contribute to the development of common European data spaces. feedback_msg_text: SenX is a software that proposes a global solution – Warp 10 – to manage data from sensors / IoT based on Time Series technology.  We believe the world of data will be driven by Time Series technology  in the near future. We explain why and how this is going to change the way we organize the governance of data including data sharing.   As an illustration, a recent study points out that “Time Series Analytics software market is going to witness the highest growth globally in coming years 2020-2025”. SenX has been cited as one of the “Top Companies in the Global Time Series Analysis Software Market” . Warp 10 is already used in operational conditions including use cases with more than 100 millions measurements / second and the associated data historian.  The “Study on data sharing between companies in Europe” is a very interesting document. We propose to express some comments in relation to the EU proposal.  Firstly, it focuses on six business sectors: data-generating driving, smart agriculture, smart manufacturing, telecom operators, smart living environments, and smart grids & meters. These sectors are typically the one addressed by Time Series technologies.  Secondly: it raises the growing importance of Real Time data. However, there is a major confusion about Real Time (even the definition of Real Time Data is not among the definitions at the beginning of the document).   Regarding data analytics, the key point is not the reference to Real Time but the fact that the data is timestamped. Time Series would be more appropriate to express this reality without any ambiguity. Beyond this semantic debate, we have to raise the critical importance of historians of time series data from muti-stakeholders that are the raw material to apply machine learning and deep learning models in an AI perspective.  Thirdly: the study makes a distinction between Open Data and Data Sharing. However, it does not really clear up the ambiguity regarding the understanding of what is really behind “data sharing”. The question is how to proceed to enable the fusion of - time series – data within a multi-stakeholders environment to foster the economic development of services and facilitate the usages for the citizens.  If it is the objective of public authorities to encourage the opening up of data for sharing, then this sharing will benefit above all the big digital players.   We think that it is important for EU Data Policy to support the development of data intermediaries and/or technologies that will propose to different organizations to develop cross-data analytics and applications based on data from different sources by complying to access rights defined by the organizations themselves. Companies have to keep the control of their data and this must be made clear without any ambiguity. Data-sharing has to be understood in that perspective.  By saying that, we do not want to downplay the importance of Open Data any more than we want to downplay the critical role of data governance compared to the technology. We just aim to emphasize the distinction between technology on one side and governance on the other size. It is relevant to make pressure overs players to open data related to road traffic. It does not make sense to open technical sensors data (second to millisecond period based) related to the behaviour of all components of a bus in the same traffic. These data can, however, be found in the same datalake of a bus operator. In any case, as a tech software provider, it is not for us to decide. We just propose the technology that makes it possible to comply with the decision of whoever is in charge of the data governance.  The ambition of our company is to propose the most advanced technology to share data from different sources in a high performance, scalable and secured way by respecting the access rights that the rights holders want to adopt.  The attached paper details our position including an introduction to Time Series approaches. Feedback from: SenX (710.5 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Scaleway welcomes the opportunity to input into the Commission’s consultation on Legislative framework for the governance of common European data spaces.   A data-driven Europe will lead the digital transformation leveraging data for efficiency and cutting edge technological infrastructures with governance mechanisms. It requires, as set out in the European Green Deal, an immediate change of direction towards more sustainable solutions which are resource-efficient, circular and climate-neutral.   Sovereignty needs to be a priority as fundamental for the development of best-in-class European cloud  and edge computing technologies. US and China are already holding a competitive advantage as they have extended their legal framework of data access and use across the globe (Cloud Act,..). Overregulating would limit innovation and can be difficult to enforce upon non-EU players and disadvantage EU companies, it can represent important barriers at the market entry, or in adopting new green, soverain and modern technologies, giving EU-based cloud providers only a small share of the cloud market, which makes the EU highly dependent on external providers for their vital data hubs.  The EU needs to reduce its technological dependencies in these strategic and vital non-EU infrastructures (such as the cloud and data centers) and to uptake secure, energy-efficient, affordable and high-quality data processing capacities of responsabile sovereign data centers and cloud computing that comply with essential requirements in terms of data protection, interoperability and scalability. There is frequently insufficient visibility on the market of smaller, often European, providers of innovative cloud services. Europe needs to open the market for EU actors that play an important role in technological and economical sovereignty.  Cloud-first with a secure hybrid multi-cloud service offering to avoid lock-in and thus lowering costs  Cloud computing is the backbone of the digital industry and of increasing importance to the future of both the European Union’s economy and climate commitments. There is a low cloud uptake in Europe (1 company in 4, only 1 in 5 for SME). A real cloud literacy needs to be done and an efficient communication to endorse cloud adoption, and a cloud-first approach when digital transformation is undertaken.  European businesses often experience problems with multi-cloud interoperability, in particular data portability. The EU needs to avoid vendor lock in and create a competitive European digital market where it must be easy to switch from provider, including the porting of business data involved.   Cloud computing is part of the solution to achieving the Green Deal  Shifting from enterprise servers to the public cloud will bring major energy savings and should be a key priority for the Commission. Cloud computing is necessary to achieve the goals of the European Green Deal and the European digital future, and our European data spaces should take this into account for hybrid solutions. Endorse energy-efficient data center as part of solution to achieve the goals of the Green Deal. As online traffic increases (+ 40% between February and April 2020), data centers at the cutting edge of innovation improve energy efficiency and strongly and durably limit the growth in energy demand. Technological advances in recent years have already made it possible to perform up to 4 times more calculations for the same energy footprint and to halve the PUE (Power Usage Effectiveness) index of a data center. The cloud computing revolution is certainly part of the environmental equation because once widespread, it will reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the IT industry by 95%, or 4.5 million tonnes of CO2 emissions (Global e-Sustainability Initiative 2013). Europe must encourage data centers and cloud providers to virtuous practices, both in terms of energy use and water resources!  Feedback from: Scaleway (64.1 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: Main comments: * Standardization is inevitable but the availability of standards has to improve, meaning that they should be free of charge (which calls for other financing tools for standardization organization). * There needs to be a balance between standardization and regulation vs market driven and open source. * It is a bit unclear whether the goal is to make private data available only for science, research and innovation or in general?  * We should support that private data is available in general but in line with European private and personal data protection rules. * Therefore, the EU roadmap about Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces should support that: 1) Public bodies, which process private data (personal data + private business data) should first, provide access to this data to the data owner or its legal representative. This means that the data owner should have easy and secure access to it and be able to view, store (and process in other ways) the data that belongs to this person (data owner) in line with the European personal and private data protection rules. 2) Secondly, the data owner should be able to share this data (though it is kept by public bodies and on their premises) to third parties (business, innovators, research, etc.) as easy and secure as possible and in line with the European personal and private data protection rules. 3) One transparent solution for this is consent-based data access that should be made as simple and secure as possible by the public sector to data owners and data users (which are the ones who want to access the data, e.g. businesses, researchers, innovators).  4) A working example of consent-based private (incl. personal) data exchange is Estfeed (https://www.estfeed.eu/en/home) – an organizational and technological solution developed by Elering (the Estonian TSO) to provide consent-based secure data exchange between data providers (data hubs who store data) and data users (applications who want to access this data) in the energy sector. It is a data exchange platform that provides secure privacy-controlled access to utility data. The privacy control is achieved through secure data connections and consent management that enables Estfeed to filter private data exchange according to consents given by data owners (consumers).  5) This kind of solution with same basics can be used also in other sectors where public bodies hold private data that could be of wider use and interest to data owners. Data Owners want to access and share this data with other service providers (innovators, businesses, researchers, etc.) so that the service providers could in the end provide a more personal service to the data owners and their client. * Under „Likely economic impacts“ a report about the benefits of a common European Energy Data Exchange Platform conducted by AFRY could be referred - https://afry.com/sites/default/files/2019-12/benefit_assessment_of_an_eu-wide_data_exchange_platform.pdf
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: The « context » paragraph shows how clear rules for access and use of the data are essential for the success of the Single Market for data but also how important it is to consider the features of the different sectors. GFII works for years on data produced and re-used by public and private professionals, whose end-users are also professionals. From this experience, GFII can testify that the “one size fits all” principle in terms of access and reuse rights within one or between sectors won’t generate the expected results in terms of innovation, growth or job creation. Thus we strongly encourage: - to work on the basis of real use cases in each sector as well as having a flexible and open understanding of each of them. If not, it would reduce the data flows potential; - to consider different conditions for access and re-use of data, according to the specificity of each particular sector or cross-sectoral exchanges, as well as the purpose of re-use of re-user’s end-users. Horizontal legislative actions will have to go hand in hand together with sector specific measures and other existing or future national or EU legislations, in order to avoid what has happened and is still happening with, for example, the GDPR.  That is why we insist on the idea to work from real use cases in order to fix the existing and future “grey zones” that generate difficulties for data holders and re-users. Data exchanges aren’t as important as they could be because of interoperability issues, but also because of legal/contractual ones as well as the question of the remuneration of the service provided by public or private data holders.  We fully agree with “The value of data lies in its use and re-use”.  But enabling an effective reuse of data has a cost for the data holder, public or private, in terms of data quality (all aspects), technical documentation and infrastructures, human resources.  Insufficient resourcing of public data holders may then occur in another situations than legal ones like having to ascertain requests for use of data that is in principle not accessible and the use of which is conditional on the respect of rights of others. The re-use of data has a cost for the re-user too, but it will depend on interoperability standards as well as potential fees. Interoperability and standards being key (but often forgotten til today), we strongly support the idea to establish a European coordination body, which will have to be funded.  But it is essential to keep in mind that: - this is not an “IT issue” only. The type of data must be considered, in terms of domain / sector, ie. case-law is very different from meteorological or mobility data. “Data understanding” is a key condition to make the data “speak” and should not be underestimated. - when standards will be defined, it may be necessary to require data holders and re-users to be compliant  We support the idea to encourage Member States to offer certain support services to researchers and business innovators as it may be compared to sand boxes or innovation hubs in the financial sector.  And the European body/structure that should support experts in the MS and ensure that expertise is re-used should organize the participation and contribution of the different authorities, as well as the ones of re-users across MS We are in line with the principle that BtoG data-sharing shouldn’t be mandatory. Once again, the legal/contractual issues are key, as well as the one of the remuneration of the service.  Supporting data intermediaries is interesting if they can help to resolve technical, legal, contractual and pricing issues. Criteria for voluntary labels or fully fledged certification should be defined by stakeholders, ie data holders and reusers, in a co-regulatory process. We agree that conditions to data access from outside the EU should be assessed, as access and reuse of data from Europe is a sovereignty issue. According to the sector and the type of data reciprocity might  be an option.
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: My feedback is based being the founder of the Real Time Economy program,  a founding member of MyData.org, advisor for Findy (verified data network initiative) and member of the Finnish Council of Regulatory Impact Analysis.  1. Why? The migration to a data driven economy must be speeded up to improve the competitiveness of European enterprises (with automation and data usage), improve public and private services to citizens and enterprises (especially SMEs), create the next phase of the single market, cut CO2 emissions and efficiently near-eliminate the grey economy.  2. How?  2.1. Encourage establishment of national (EU-interoperable) distributed data based public-private verified data networks (connected to centralised data - like in the Finnish Findy-initiative - described in the EU data strategy and supported by ToIP). 2.2. Ensure that the individual in all her roles has the right to empower service providers to fetch the data from public and private repositories to customers' life events they serve. Much - if not most - of this can be done without changing legislation - in several countries. But obviously this GDPR granted right must be extended also to MyData held in public repositories. 2.3. Make e-invoicing, e-receipts and automated real time VAT-reporting mandatory to enable real time accounting for SMEs and households. The combined direct cost saving for a total migration to e-invoicing and e-receipts has been estimated to nearly 4bn€/year in Finland and a real time view of financial and other data is adding other value - as is the moving of staff from administration to more productive tasks. The direct cost saving on Europe-level would be 280bn. VAT-reporting will create both an enterprise and household specific data mine and an anonymised repository of purchase data in real time that should be made available to all  reporting enterprises - and households and their service providers creating algorithms and using AI to solve needs in "life events - at home and at work".  The number of purchase lines reported in e-invoices and e-receipts will in Finland's case rise to some 20 billion - and with each line containing not only €data - but many other important data (Co2, origin, allergens, best-before, recall information etc) the sphere of usage will be immense.  2.4. Use the above line-specific spending data together with real-time income data, and realtime savings and investment data (unlisted share trading already piloted and real estate advancing) for economy forecasting.  In light of immense cost savings, service improvements and Single Market impact - so much needed in post-Covid times -  it is hard to imagine that there could be any reasons not to move very fast forward with a PSD2 model and GDPR-supported solutions for data from all sectors. Possible vested interest and protection of niche influence should be clearly identified.
Organisation: Real Time Economy Program, MyData.org and Findy
Initiative: Data sharing in the EU – common European data spaces (new rules)

feedback_msg_text: 2020-02-20    The Danish National Committee (NC) on EMC standardization has collected the following observations and inputs as a joint opinion from the members:  • In general, the EMCD fulfils its purpose. The NC finds that the overall challenges regarding the EMCD are related with very modest or missing market surveillance. The low level of market surveillance leaves large space for bringing non-compliant electronics and equipment to the market – without any consequence or risk of being caught.  • Another factor affecting the EMCD (but which is not directly under the control of the EMCD) is the lack of sufficient and updated harmonized EMC standards. The standards are needed by industry, and in many cases the documents are published by for instance IEC, CISPR and even CENELEC – however throughout an extended period they have not been accepted by EU commission regulators – to some extent due to apparent lack of useable technical content. Whatever the reason, the access to updated harmonized standards is beginning to open a gap between international standards and the EU harmonized editions of the same standards. This will be a further challenge to industry and is already - by now – causing problems and double testing for certain standards under Directive 2006/42/EC (MD).  • The NC finds that the concept of risk in the EMCD (and also LVD and RED) is not easily understood by manufacturers, and even less easily by importers and distributors. Does it concern the risk of economic following non-compliance, the risk of not fulfilling essential requirements, the risk of damaging personnel etc. or other risks? The deep understanding of essential requirements, user environments for normal and severe users (intended use, foreseeable misuse) is not always present, and it is difficult to know when enough documentation has been prepared to document the risk assessment. A clearer guidance is desired.  • The NC recognizes that the EMCD is at a lower priority level than for instance MD and RED, which take over in the case of machines and equipment containing radio.  • Very often equipment needs to comply with several directives involving EMC in addition to the EMCD itself. The products must comply with all relevant directives, but the technical requirements, test requirements and documentation procedures may be mutually conflicting. Guidance on prioritizing the requirements from several directives, which act in parallel, is desired.    Best regards  Marika Vindbjerg Senior Consultant Danish Standards
Initiative: Electromagnetic compatibility - evaluation of the EU rules

feedback_msg_text: JBCE appreciates the opportunity of commenting the roadmap for the evaluation of the EMC directive. JBCE supports the proposed roadmap but would like to submit the following comment.  JBCE believes that the EMC directive is one of the key directives for compliance of electronic product in the EEA, Switzerland, UK and some other non-EU countries. This directive is well known and understood by the industry.   JBCE sincerely believes that the provisions and the essential requirements of the EMCD are more than ever topical and corresponding to market needs and the well-being of electronic equipment users.  The principle of presumption of conformity based on harmonised standard aligned with international standard is a key factor for facilitating the trades of products. Harmonised standards define an acknowledge common understanding about how the compliance with essential requirements shall be demonstrated. Harmonised standards support efficiently the essential requirements of the directive. JBCE notices that no EMC standard has been formally objected, demonstrating the relevance of internationally developed standards supporting the European legislation.   Nevertheless, JBCE has noticed that the list of harmonised standards published in the official journal is no more updated properly by the European Commission. Some versions of standards in the Official journal are up to 3 versions behind the international version and some of those obsolete versions are already withdrawn by the national standardisation offices. JBCE encourages the European Commission to revise the list of harmonized standards in a more regular manner to better reflect the state-of-the-art standards as agreed internationally, but with keeping the principle of a reasonable transition period. The regular update of such list is essential for the support and effectiveness of the directive.  About certification of cables, JBCE understands that will be part of the evaluation of the EMC directive. Nevertheless, JBCE kindly reminds that cables are not source or victim of disturbances. Therefore, including cables in the EMC directive would affect seriously the principle of the directive, including its essential requirements. JBCE recommends a voluntary based cable certification scheme allowing an easier application by apparatus’ manufacturer of the Article 18 of the directive, rather than a compulsory certification scheme of cables within a revised EMC directive.  Based on above elements, JBCE doesn’t see the need for a revision of the directive. JBCE will take future opportunities during the public consultation phase for communicating in more details its position.
Initiative: Electromagnetic compatibility - evaluation of the EU rules

feedback_msg_text: The British Cables Association (BCA) represents manufacturers of cables and cable accessories operating in the UK.  BCA welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the Evaluation Roadmap for the EMC Directive.  The roadmap indicates that a number of past studies will be included in the evaluation, including two relating to cables.  The cable industry is of the view that cables should continue to be excluded from the scope of the EMC Directive, for the following reasons.  • Cables are components that do not have an intrinsic function and hence do not constitute apparatus as defined in the EMC Directive.  • The Guide for the EMC Directive 2004/108/EC makes it clear that cables are inherently benign equipment and are hence excluded from the scope of the EMC Directive.  Cables are not capable of generating or contributing to electromagnetic emissions in the absence of active components, and will operate without degradation of performance in their intended environment.  • It is noted that the characteristics and installation of cables and cabling can have a significant impact upon the EMC performance of equipment.  This should be taken into account by the manufacturer or designer of the apparatus or system in specifying appropriate cables and their method of installation.  • It is clear that when any component is incorporated into an apparatus or system then that apparatus or system, as a whole, will be required to comply with the EMC Regulations. The designer of the apparatus or system should specify cables and installation methods to ensure compliance with the relevant requirements.  The BCA’s position is therefore that cables should continue with their present status as regards the EMC Directive, in that they should remain excluded due to their passive and benign nature.  Where appropriate the EMC properties of cables are covered by cable product standards, for example for screening.
Initiative: Electromagnetic compatibility - evaluation of the EU rules

feedback_msg_text: EFA, the European Driving Schools Association, is a professional association representing the interest of its members who are national driver training associations from 21 European countries.   EFA considers very important the new technologies that are being used in vehicles in order to reduce road fatalities, as well as all the investigation that are being carried out regarding the automated vehicle.  But while this automated vehicle is not a complete reality, and with a spread use, the human factor is the main cause of traffic accidents, around 90 %. For that reason it is crucial to keep improving all the initiatives in relation to human beings, as drivers, pedestrians, cyclists, road users in general.  EFA suggests the following actions:  1. The candidates for a driving license must have the right attitude, skills and knowledge. To achieve these goals it is necessary that the driving teachers interact with the candidates. So there should be mandatory theoretical and practical training for candidates before exams on some specific topics: distractions, alcohol, drugs, speed, risk awareness, self-awareness, how to act in a road accident (first aids and so on), etc. To get a good and permanent result and attitude, these topics cannot be learnt online, this method (e-learning) can be used to learn other contents regarding road safety rules. This mandatory training should be taught under a regulated framework, with certified driving teachers and in quality centers with the proper facilities and tools.    2. Qualified driving teachers. The initial training and exams to become driving teachers should be the same in the EU, and it is necessary to implement a periodic training. Currently, the EU Driving License Directive deals only with testing and the examination-system. Thus the basics for examiners and their obligatory further training are regulated. The obligatory further training of driving instructors is a new topic that could be introduced at European level.  3. Code 78. This code somehow provokes that driving schools are not encourage to have automatic gear box cars for training, as long as the candidates do not want to undertake another full practical exam with a manual gear box to get rid of this limitation. So, most of driving schools do not use hybrid and electrical cars, because they are automatic, thus the ecofriendly cars are not being promoted. EFA proposes to avoid another practical exam, that the code 78 could be removed by a training of 7 hours in a manual car without exam, within a certified driving school.  4. ADAS All candidates must be trained and assessed in the right use of ADAS.  5. Lifelong Learning Process Some rules, traffic conditions, new technologies in vehicles, skills, and so on change as time goes by, so it is very important to guarantee that all drivers are updated in order to have safer drivers. A training should be given not just to obtain the driving license, but after.  6. Personal Mobility Vehicles. These means of transport are causing many accidents and problems in most of the European cities. So, it should be regulated at a European level, and training should be given before their use.
Initiative: Driving licence rules – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: At CNAE we consider that currently in force Directive 2006/126 on driving licenses has accomplished to a considerable degree the objectives to which it set out, as the number of traffic accidents has decreased since its original publication, it has facilitated citizen mobility, and fraud potential in the issuance of driving licenses has been reduced. However, we mustn’t let down our guard nor settle for these accomplishments, but rather continue working and improving in this matter in order to cut road accident fatalities down to zero.  To this end, CNAE finds it necessary to broach an amendment process that will give rise to a new directive focusing its efforts on the human factor—a factor present in 90% of accidents—by raising standards in terms of the knowledge, aptitudes, and behavior required of future drivers, and ensuring lifelong maintenance of the same; improving the quality of the driving license exams by devising computer tests that include questions on risk perception after viewing images and/or videos; and tightening up the requirements for both examiners and instructors.  Thus, this Confederation proposes the following measures be taken into account in the evaluation of the new Directive:  1. Suppression of code 78 for B+E licenses obtained on vehicles with automatic transmission. 2. Establishment of minimum obligatory training for the removal of code 78 from the b license. 3. Quality exams for obtaining corresponding driving licenses. 4. Raise entry standards both for driving examiners and instructors, periodic training for instructors. 5. Obligatory prior training of driver candidates: The CNAE considers that in order to further ensure that future drivers effectively possess such knowledge, skills, and behaviors, an obligatory training prior to the driving exam be established; on one hand, to facilitate the development of future drivers’ capacities and skills for perceiving risk and, on the other, to impart awareness of the need to adopt respectful behavior behind the wheel toward fellow road users and sensitize them to the grave consequences traffic accidents have and the driver’s responsibility in such cases. 6. Lifelong training: The CNAE deems it necessary to articulate periodic refresher courses throughout the life of the driver, courses that would serve to remind drivers of regulations and road signs, as well as raise awareness of risk factors that are causing accidents and fatalities in our country, and keep driving capabilities and skills up to date. 7. Driver’s education centers: As touched upon already in some of the preceding points, the driver training referred to in this communication needs to be imparted by quality education centers, duly authorized or accredited by the competent authority of the Member State, to which end a series of minimum requirements must be set as far as facilities, materials, and human resources. 8. Regulation of use of and driver training for personal transporters. It is necessary to establish standard minimum norms for the use and circulation of this type of vehicle on a European level, so that there be certain homogeneity in this matter across all EU countries and cities. In order to ascertain that users of personal transporters and cyclists are aware of the safety rules that affect them, as well as the risks and grave consequences inherent in breaking these rules, we suggest that the amendment of the Directive also include the requirement of passing a minimum mandatory training prior to the use of bicycles and personal transporters, and that for purposes of administrative control said training be accredited by the granting of a driving permit or license. Feedback from: CONFEDERACION NACIONAL DE AUTOESCUELAS (CNAE) (197.3 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download
Initiative: Driving licence rules – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Dear ladies and gentlemen    Thank you very much for having the chance to give you a feedback on the driving license rules in Europe. Our focus is on driving tests organized by companies or public authorities.     In Germany, specific companies with entrusted public power are allowed to take the driving tests from the candidates. Today there are four organizations that are allowed to carry out driving tests from the candidates, but only in their respectively assigned region where each of the four organizations therefore holds a monopole.    In this monopolistic structure the candidates quite often have to wait for an appointment to take the driving test and the service seems to have room for improvement. Numerous articles in the German press can be found on this topic:  https://www.stuttgarter-zeitung.de/inhalt.fuehrerschein-in-stuttgart-langes-warten-auf-die-fahrpruefung.db557fcd-df0d-45e5-af55-40af00630165.html  https://www.stuttgarter-zeitung.de/inhalt.probleme-beim-tuev-sued-stau-bei-fuehrerscheinpruefungen.145d7c99-6375-4dba-8724-70ca69392a5b.html  https://www.aachener-nachrichten.de/lokales/dueren/tuev-sagt-reihenweise-fuehrerscheinpruefungen-ab_aid-34533871 https://www.zvw.de/inhalt.rems-murr-kreis-tuev-faellt-durch-fuehrerscheinpruefung.b67c1880-3d16-4636-9231-a6b63a9a3f5d.html  https://www.soester-anzeiger.de/lokales/soest/kritik-tuev-weil-nicht-genuegend-pruefer-verfuegung-stehen-10329848.html  https://www.stuttgarter-nachrichten.de/inhalt.fuehrerschein-prueftermine-bleiben-in-stuttgart-haengepartie-tuev-ins-ministerium-zitiert.cb783ff5-ffe3-4520-86f4-30df26136188.html  https://www.abendblatt.de/hamburg/wandsbek/sasel/article209365699/Intensiv-Fahrschulkurse-zeitlich-kaum-noch-moeglich.html  https://www.wz.de/nrw/duesseldorf/fuehrerscheinpruefung-in-duesseldorf-grosser-aerger-wegen-wartezeiten_aid-35164313     We think that a lot of problems around the field of carrying out driving exams in Germany can be solved by ending the monopolistic structure of the organizations with their examiners. A lot of other business fields (e.g. testing of elevators and pressure tanks, periodical technical inspection of cars, homologation as well as type- and individual approval of motor vehicles) have been opened in the last years for a fair competition between appropriately qualified companies. These market liberalizations lead to many advantages for the citizens and businesses demanding these services in Europe.     Therefore we support the position that the future European rules for driving licenses should not set up a regime in which only one company is allowed to carry out the driving tests in a country, but that a fair competition between different providers is possible. Our market economy is based on a fair and balanced competition between companies – one of the key elements of our economic success in Europe. A continuous development of services and improvement of the quality needs competition between market participants. Monopolistic structures are not helpful and should be avoided.    In 2018 more than 1.33 Million driving licenses were issued in Germany and more than 1.71 Million practical and 1.80 Million theoretical exams were taken by candidates. The statistics are published here: https://www.kba.de/DE/Statistik/Kraftfahrer/Fahrerlaubnisse/Fahrerlaubnispruefungen/fahrerlaubnispruefungen_node.html Within the European rules for driving licenses, the minimum quality standards for driving tests and especially driving examiners (see Annex IV of the directive 2006/126/EC) should be developed further to make sure the quality level is continuously enhancing and getting on a common high level throughout the European Member States.     Best regards,   Frederik Schmidt GTÜ Stuttgart Germany
Organisation: GTÜ Gesellschaft für Technische Überwachung mbH
Initiative: Driving licence rules – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: Volunteering in orphanages is currently not explicitly outlawed by the EU Aid Volunteers Initiative. In light of the growing evidence of the harms of orphanage volunteering on children and communities, as well as the links with trafficking, we believe this should be clearly stated and that the upcoming European Solidarity Corps (2021-2027) should be aligned to the Global Standard for Volunteering for Development (2019). feedback_msg_text: EU Aid Volunteers Initiative & Orphanage Volunteering   The EU has committed to end institutionalisation and to provide support for family and community-based care. This commitment is reflected in its legal and policy frameworks, including the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the European Disability Strategy, the EU Agenda for the Rights of the Child, the European Pillar of Social Rights and the EU Guidelines for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of the Child.  It is also reflected in its funding regulations where building or renovating long-stay residential institutions are now excluded under ESIF; and funding programmes which specifically resource alternative care programmes and de-institutionalisation strategies.  However the EU Aid Volunteer Initiative was not aligned to this wider EU policy as it did not specifically exclude volunteering placements in orphanages.    Orphanage volunteering is contributing to the growth of orphanages, as institutions are created to meet the demand from well meaning tourists, volunteers and donors. Volunteering in orphanages also increases the harm of institutionalisation as the constant turnover of personnel can intensify a child’s feeling of abandonment and loss leading to emotional distress and contributes to a condition known as attachment disorder whereby the child and adult of later years struggles to develop healthy, trusting relationships. Orphanage volunteering also presents considerable child safeguarding risks as it normalises access to vulnerable children.  Many institutions lack regulation and basic child safeguarding policies and systems and child sex offenders often specifically target orphanages to gain access to children. Volunteering in orphanages may incentivise the trafficking of children in order to feed ‘the orphanage industry’ for commercial exploitation. The orphanage industry is now recognised as a form of trafficking and modern-day slavery.   The successor to the EU AVI, the European Solidarity Corps, should explicitly exclude orphanage volunteering in its programming; and criteria for the necessary accreditation process for organisations to be part of the EVS should specifically exclude children's residential care institutions. feedback_msg_text: Crypto-assets pose unique challenges for lawmakers and for supervisors.  I do stress the need for an "E-Crypto Directive" to avoid national tendency to regulate in a fragmentary way. The challenge is that crypto-assets is a so broad concept that contains cryptocurrencies, tokens and other assets that have the common point in using cryptography and DLT. I think it is not possible to define in any way CRYPTO-ASSETS because the concept includes radically opposite situations, while always sharing totally different circulation  rules with respect to the current paradigm: a. Crypto-currencies, the definition of which involves an effort to frame them, since there is no defined conceptual category, although starting from the concept of "property"; b. Crypto-assets, that have roots in the above concept, but, caused by its polymorphism, they evolve to return to known categories already covered by current, with a journey from the unknown to the known, albeit with different forms than those known (an example asset token or scrip token). An E-Crypto directive should solve these matters: 1. a clearer definition of security (Prospectus Directive), financial instruments (MiFID), and ‘financial instruments’ or ‘securities’ (CSD), and funds (EMD) for cryptoassets, to avoid national interpretation, and specific rules that considers the peculiarity (disintermediation, decentralization, clearance, etc.). 2. The introduction of the concept of TechNet – Technology Neutrality for crypto-assets and for the operator that utilizes crypto-assets. 3. Clear definition of crypto-voucher (asset token, pure utility token, scrip token) and VAT regime. 4. Introduction of a broad definition of crypto-assets that are not covered by acquis European law and introducing light law for consumers and investor protection. 5. Introduction of investor and consumer protection with clear identification of obliged entities, with consideration of decentralization, disintermediation and absence of a central point.

feedback_msg_text: The German Broadband Association, BREKO, welcomes the opportunity to comment on the Commission’s roadmap on the “Evaluation of State aid rules for broadband infrastructure deployment”. To successfully bridge the gap of Europe’s digital divide regarding broadband connectivity, it is important for the revision of the State aid rules to consider the crucial role of the competitors’ in achieving Europe’s connectivity targets and, thus, to channel public support in a pro-competitive manner.  With regards to the evaluation’s purpose and scope BREKO would like to make the following points:  1. Effectiveness: BREKO concurs with the Commission’s assessment that the State aid rules should help to bridge the broadband digital divide and to accelerate investments in high speed infrastructure in white spots if there is no commercial fibre-rollout. This must be the overarching goal of every broadband State aid programme. However, instead of focusing the evaluation on the barriers to achieving these objectives, the Commission should scrutinise which part of the existing rules actually reduced the effectiveness. Moreover, it is essential to bring the market inquiry process (i.e. roll-out requirements within 3 years) into the picture somewhere. With NGA serving as an effective tool, the MEV mechanism will increasingly deliver a false negative in an FTTH environment. This unexpected result became visible after implementing the requirements set by the State aid rules for the deployment of broadband infrastructure.  2. Efficiency: BREKO agrees with the Commission that it is important to examine to what extent the requirements set by the State aid rules have led to more efficient State expenditure. In this vein, we would like to underscore that governments will always stress for less regulation to spend State aid more efficiently. This is especially the case when economically viable areas can be included in the state aid area.  3. Relevance: BREKO would like to highlight that the State aid rules for the deployment of broadband infrastructure are already well adapted to respond to the technological and market developments. This is due to the fact that they allow to increase target products from 50 Mbit/s to Gigabit (FTTH, etc.) without difficulties.   Furthermore, BREKO would like to suggest for the Commission’s planned consultation activities to incorporate the perspective of the FTTH sector. This could be achieved by inviting FTTH industry experts and national broadband associations to play an active role in the planned technical workshop with Member State experts on broadband infrastructure deployment.  BREKO looks forward to the public consultation in the third quarter of 2020, to which we will provide further input in order to support the Commission in its successful revision of the State aid guidelines. Please note that we have also attached a document referencing our comments to the specific parts of roadmap for further clarification of the submission. feedback_msg_text: Please, find attached FEAD’s full feedback to the EC Roadmap on the Review of the CPR.   FEAD, representing the private waste and resource management industry across Europe, welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to review the Construction Products Regulation (CPR). FEAD deems enhancing the CPR (option D of the Inception Impact Assessment of the Roadmap) as the way forward to achieve coherence with other EU legislation, harmonisation of technical specifications, and better protection of health, safety and the environment, in line with the European Green Deal and the new CEAP. By improving the circular economy practices that are relevant to the construction products sector, we can achieve increased quality and quantity of recycling and reuse of materials required for construction products.   The construction works and products require significant amounts of energy and raw materials, that is why the EU legislator should take strong measures to increase the efficiency in the use of these resources by improving the following factors:  1) Strengthening the construction – demolition - renovation waste management: The construction products need to be designed, manufactured, and used in a way that ensures the sustainable use of natural resources and reinforces the recycling and/or reuse of parts or materials, while taking into consideration the need to enhance sustainability performance of construction products. This chain is interlinked with the waste management activities. 2) Promotion of the use of recyclates: Mandatory recycled content is a tool to intensify the use of recyclates, and especially, in a number of construction products, in particular for plastic pipes and inert materials, mandatory recycled content should be privileged. 3) Better information on the materials: Higher trust of the quality of recyclates requires better information on the composition of materials used in construction products, standardization of secondary raw materials, and sharing of the information among all the relevant stakeholders. 4) Setting up integrated waste management strategies: The use of recyclates in construction products in a more systematic and closed-loop way should be promoted.  5) Overcoming uncompetitive pricing for recyclates: Any activities and use of materials with low-energy content, in particular secondary raw materials, should be positively treated in the EU market compared to those manufactured products with a much higher energy content. 6) Levies: Member States or regions may consider providing price incentives to use recycled materials for construction products if they bring the desired benefits to the environment. 7) Clear end-of-waste criteria: The definition of precise, clear, and harmonized end-of-waste criteria at EU level would encourage the production of secondary raw materials and would reward those who invest in high-quality recycled construction products.  8) Green Public Procurement: Authorities at all levels can provide incentives for promoting the use of recycled materials for construction products used in public buildings.  9) Isolation and filling material affecting the plastic waste stream: The use of these isolation materials was cited by the recycling companies as an important barrier to recycling. This material cannot be removed or sorted and has a disruptive effect on the final high-quality recycling of the plastic (PVC) raw material. The use of filling materials during the installation of profiles constitutes another barrier to recycling. Thus, eco-design principles should not come at the expense of the energy/isolation requirements of construction products. 10) Energy-efficiency: A focus on the energy efficiency of construction products is also significant, through utilizing a scheme for minimum energy performance standards of the production process. This should allow for renewable energy investment also for the Waste-to-Energy sector. Feedback from: FEAD (224.9 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Construction products – review of EU rules

feedback_msg_text: Linklaters LLP welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the inception impact assessment paper published by the European Commission on the revision of the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation (the “VBER”) and accompanying vertical guidelines (the “Vertical Guidelines”). Overall, we commend the Commission on its thorough analysis of the current framework and its active engagement with businesses and other stakeholders during the evaluation phase of the VBER review process.  We also commend the Commission’s efforts to achieve a common framework of analysis for national competition authorities and national courts to enhance consistency in the application of vertical rules and its approach toward a more flexible approach towards a number of topics, including active sales restrictions, selective distribution and renewable non-compete clauses.  Finally, we believe that the Commission’s statement that the future rules would take into account the objectives of the Green Deal is pertinent in the current environment, with climate change and other ESG considerations being placed top of the agenda. Thus, we look forward to hearing from the Commission what this means in practice for businesses in the next generation VBER and Vertical Guidelines. Overall, we are of the view that the inception paper outlines an effective approach to the revision of the VBER and Vertical Guidelines. We have set out in the attached paper more targeted observations and comments on the Commission’s proposals.  In particular, our paper sets out general comments, including expected clarifications that are not expressly reflected in the inception paper, outlines a few observations on the specific issues the Commission identified as needing to be addressed (specifically, resale price maintenance and non-competes) and summarises Linklaters’ feedback on policy options on dual distribution, active sales, online sales and price parity clauses.
