feedback_msg_text: Surfrider Foundation Europe believes that the fight against climate change and for an enhanced environmental protection should remain a priority of the new EU Arctic Policy.    In this respect, we would like to attract the European Commission’s attention to 2 policy items of particular importance:   1) Offshore oil and gas drilling   Surfrider Foundation Europe reminds the European Commission that for the EU fulfill its Paris Agreement Commitments and is ambition to become climate neutral by 2050, we need to step up the efforts to cut CO2 emissions and overcome our addiction to fossil energy. One of the 1st steps would be banning offshore oil and gas drilling in European waters – starting with a ban in Arctic.   The Arctic is an example of an area where the probability of an incident occurring is higher (harsh weather, darkness), the potential damage is worse (vulnerable ecosystem with spawning areas for few, but keystone species) and the ability to clean up is lower (remoteness, slow oil degradation due to the climate). Even in other European seas, offshore drilling leads to unavoidable spills and releases, constant water pollution by drilling muds and poses substantial threat to the lives and livelihoods of coastal communities. In light of the above-mentioned factors, these dangers are even more considerable for the Arctic region and the rights of indigenous people.   As a reminder, the European Parliament called for a ban on oil drilling in icy Arctic waters of the EU and the EEA in the resolution on an integrated EU policy for the Arctic in March 2017.   2) Heavy fuels use and transport   Surfrider Foundation Europe supports the European Commission’s initiative Fuel EU Maritime to encourage the use of low-carbon fuels within the shipping sector. We must go further and ban heavy fuel in the Arctic zone completely, even for propulsion.   The use of heavy fuels is particularly dangerous in polar zones, for many reasons. The black carbon particles issued by maritime shipping in the Arctic zone in the air absorbs solar radiation and warms the atmosphere. When they are deposited on the ice, they reduce the reflection phenomenon of the floe, which accelerates global warming and ice melt. The warming effect of black carbon is 5 times higher in polar zones than in mid-latitudes zones. Heavy fuel should therefore be banned from the Arctic zone, even for propulsion.   Besides, the maritime accidents in case of use of Artic routes for shipping could have dramatical effects in the region. The climatic conditions there do strongly increase the risk of wreckage and collisions against the ice, and, therefore, the risk of dangerous oil spills for polar biodiversity.      To sum up, we urge the European Commission to: 1) propose a ban on offshore drilling and heavy fuels in the Arctic EU and EEA territory; 2) take leadership in order to put these issues on the international agenda.   Both offshore drilling and heavy fuels are harmful and dangerous both for humans and marine species. They do not fit in the Green Deal ambition of our continent and we should put an end to it in order to ensure that the EU climate leadership brings concrete results with a direct and positive impact on the Arctic environment.
Initiative: EU Arctic policy - update

feedback_msg_text: The inner parts of northern Sweden consists of mainly forest and mountain land. It´s relatively sparsely populated, but has still been populated since the end of ice-age. There are ethnic groups and indigenous peoples who manage cultural heritages and traditional knowledge since pre-historic.  The locals is in some respects not only overlooked but instead bypassed politically primarily due to national policy, and further indirectly through EU-policy.   Based on natural and cultural assets there are several possibilities for regional development, for example and not least quality-oriented primary production as assets for local supply and development of tourism.  There is a need to better meet and provide space for the area´s local and regional genuine conditions and possibilities with regard to local people, local and regional culture as actual historical background of northern Scandinavia.   Some of these basic perspectives were disussed at a conference on the future of the northern Swedish cultural landscape. The overall documentation (in swedish) is available in the attatched link. http://www.svenskakulturlandskap.se/det-nordsvenska-kulturlandskapets-framtid/  In our view, there is generally also a basic need to spread new knowledge about the pre-historic as cultural roots and basis for management of biological diversity. New findings in popular science have been presented in both Sweden and Norway and is available via public TV in attatched links. Unfortunately, none of these programs is available in english.   https://www.svtplay.se/de-forsta-svenskarna https://tv.nrk.no/serie/norske-roeter/sesong/1/episode/1  Since it generally is percieved that EU-initiatives and policy lacks desireable insights and necessary basis in term of knowledge about northern Scandinavia and the inner parts of northern Sweden´s conditions, people, culture and history, we would like to draw attention to that need. feedback_msg_text: Biedrība "Latvijas Lauku forums" ir nacionāla līmeņa organizācija, kas apvieno vairāk kā 80 biedrus (NVO) visos reģionos, pārstāvot Latvijas lauku iedzīvotāju intereses  un stiprinot pilsoniskās sabiedrības veidošanos Latvijas laukos. Mēs ļoti atzinīgi vērtējam EK iniciatīvu izstrādāt ilgtermiņa vīziju par lauku attīstību un sniegto iespēju izteikt viedokli.  Sadaļā "Iedzīvotāju un ieinteresēto personu konsultācijas” aicinām iekļaut arī tos iedzīvotājus, kas daudzkārt netiek tiešā veidā uzrunāti un nav aktīvi kā indivīdi vai nedarbojas minētajos tīklos. Lai arī formāli ikvienam ES pilsonim ir vienlīdzīgas tiesības paust viedokli, praktiski līdzdalība ir atkarīga no informācijas pieejamības un pastāvošajām iespējām, kas daudzkārt fiziski attālām un sociāli mazaizsargātām grupām ir ierobežojošas. Apzināmies, ka ES līmenī tiešā veidā nav iespējams sasniegt un gūt atgriezenisko saiti no mazaktīvo un līdz šim neiesaistīto lauku iedzīvotāju daļas, kas daudzkārt saskaras ar nozīmīgākajiem izaicinājumiem, tālab aicinām viedokļu apzināšanā un atgriezeniskās saiknes nodrošināšanā iesaistīt LEADER/SVVA īstenotājus - vietējās rīcības grupas (VRG) un zivsaimniecības vietējas rīcības grupas (ZVRG) un to apvienojošos tīklus nacionālā un Eiropas mērogā, kas varētu nodrošināt tiešu saikni ar lauku iedzīvotājiem un ir ieinteresētas iesaistīties.  Atbalstām sadaļā “Problēma, kuru plānos risināt ar iniciatīvu” ietverto, vienlaikus aicinām kā izaicinājumu ietvert arī pilsētu un lauku mijiedarbības (ne pretnostatīšanas) nozīmību. Politikā un sabiedriskajā domā pastāv spēcīga lauku un pilsētas telpu, funkciju, finansējuma sadalījuma un sabiedrības nošķirtība, daudzkārt atspoguļojot lauku telpu un tās iedzīvotājus ar negatīvu raksturojumu. Tas, savukārt, rada negatīvas sekas uz lauku sabiedrības pašapziņu, mazina savstarpējo uzticību un uzticību politikas veidotājiem, tāpat tiek samazinātas iespējas piesaistīt investorus u.c.  Sadaļā “Ko un kā vēlas sasniegt iniciatīva” aicinām līdztekus provizoriskajām rīcībām un dažādu politiku papildinātības un salāgotības nozīmībai, kas ceļa kartē jau minēta, iekļaut arī provizorisko tālāko rīcības plāna laika ietvaru un konkrētus mērķus/uzdevumus, ko plānots veikt pēc vīzijas izstrādes, norādot, vai un kā vīziju plānots salāgot/iestrādāt pašreiz izstrādes stadijā esošajās politikās un ar tām saistītajā budžetā.  Pielikumā pievienota 4. Latvijas Lauku kopienu parlamenta rezolūcija, kas tika izstrādāta 2019. gadā līdzvērtīgā dialogā starp vairāk kā 200 kopienu pārstāvjiem un politikas veidotājiem. Rezolūcija ietver  septiņus galvenos virzienus, kas būtu jāiekļauj visu līmeņu attīstības plānošanas dokumentos.
Initiative: Rural development – long-term vision for rural areas

feedback_msg_text: Preocupados por la crisis funcional del medio rural, manifestada en un proceso de despoblación que está vaciando comarcas y amenazando la existencia de muchos núcleos, y en su escasa densidad de población, un indicador más genérico, como síntomas más evidentes del gravísimo problema que sufre una parte del territorio de la Unión Europea (UE) y de manera más polarizada España: un grave desequilibrio demográfico y territorial entre las metrópolis y las áreas urbanas con elevada densidad de población y una demografía dinámica, frente a las áreas rurales y regiones despobladas con densidades muy bajas y una demografía en grave declive. Como consecuencia de este desequilibrio, una crisis estructural territorial que, prolongada durante décadas, amenaza con hacer inviable amplias áreas del territorio de la UE en términos sociales, económicos y demográficos. Desde hace décadas las áreas despobladas del medio rural en Europa sufren una tendencia demográfica negativa, efecto de un proceso histórico que se agrava, y que fue impulsado por una industrialización polarizada espacialmente y por la mecanización agraria. De manera que en casos como el de España, las dimensiones de este complejo problema demográfico, su severidad y persistencia, han convertido a la despoblación en un problema político de primer orden, que ha calado en partidos políticos y opinión pública, incluso para muchos actores sociales y políticos es una cuestión de Estado.  En este escenario de crisis demográfica y territorial, es necesario analizar con rigor los elementos clave del problema y las dinámicas territoriales, así como evaluar y repensar las políticas públicas que hasta el momento ha diseñado e implementado la UE para abordar los desequilibrios territoriales y los problemas rurales. Por ello valoramos de manera muy positiva esta consulta pública de la Comisión Europea sobre la visión a largo plazo del medio rural y sus problemas.  Consideramos que la gravedad de esta crisis demográfica y territorial en Europa, consecuencia del proceso de despoblación, desborda los objetivos y la capacidad de acción de una política (“regional” o “territorial”) específica o “ad hoc”, y que es necesario actuar desde una visión conjunta sobre dos cuestiones las políticas territoriales y la despoblación. Por ello proponemos dos pilares complementarios que deben enmarcar las líneas de acción política de la Unión Europea en el medio rural: a) Que la despoblación sea una cuestión de referencia para la UE, un marco que impregne todas las políticas de la Unión Europea, considerada en sus objetivos y en la evaluación de sus logros. b) Que las políticas territoriales desarrollen acciones específicas para promover un territorio equilibrado y sostenible, así como para catalizar la lucha contra la despoblación y corregir los desequilibrios territoriales. Consideramos un error de base realizar los cálculos sobre la repercusión de una medida política o administrativa, el alcance de un servicio o el acceso a una infraestructura en base al porcentaje de población que lo usa o disfruta. En la misma línea muchas administraciones han puesto por delante la rentabilidad económica de servicios e infraestructuras, sin valorar en su justa medida la rentabilidad social de los mismos. Como consecuencia las áreas despobladas han entrado en una espiral de decadencia en la que la falta de rentabilidad económica de los servicios básicos, la carencia de infraestructuras de transporte y de conectividad así como una creciente brecha digital, provocan que continúen perdiendo población, que los niveles de renta sean muy inferiores a los de las áreas urbanas y que la capacidad de emprendimiento sea muy baja, lo que significa que las inversiones en el medio rural serán menos rentables y el atractivo para la inversión privada desaparece. Feedback from: Plataforma de la España Vaciada (306.2 KB - PDF - 18 pages) Download
Initiative: Rural development – long-term vision for rural areas

feedback_msg_text: Wir sehen die EUTR als das richtige Tool, um das Inverkehrbringen von Holz und Holzprodukten aus illegalem Einschlag auf dem EU-Markt zu verhindern. Viele Bestimmungen der EUTR beinhalten derzeit zu große Interpretationsspielräume, sodass diese von den Mitgliedsstaaten sehr unterschiedlich umgesetzt werden. Den betroffenen Unternehmen fehlt es an einheitlichen Richtlinien, einschließlich der Prüfungsverfahren und der Akzeptanz der Zertifizierung durch Dritte. Die Bereitstellung konkreterer Leitlinien oder Guidancedokumenten könnte die Unsicherheiten für Betreiber und Behörden beseitigen.   Dazu gehören unserer Meinung nach: • Eine klare Anleitung über den Umfang und die Tiefe der Informationen, die zum Nachweis der Einhaltung der EUTR verlangt werden • Der Einfluss einer glaubwürdigen Zertifizierung als Teil des Nachweises der Einhaltung  • Ein harmonisiertes Verständnis dessen, was die Behörden von den Betreibern zum Nachweis der Einhaltung der EUTR verlangen sollten.  Nur mit einer homogenen Implementierung der EUTR kann Europa den Holzimport von illegalem Holz unterbinden.
Organisation: Associazion of the Austrian Wood Industries
Initiative: Illegal logging – evaluation of EU rules (fitness check)

feedback_msg_text: FINAL CONTRIBUTION. Illegal logging is one of the main global causes of deforestation and causes considerable environmental damage and biodiversity loss. It has serious implications for climate change, and make forests more vulnerable to fires. The European Organisation of the Sawmill Industry condemns any form of illegal logging.   The Members of the European Organisation of the Sawmill Industry (EOS) use and purchase wood coming only from the European Forests. Currently, there are no imports of logs (HS 4403 code) coming from Ukraine or Belarus due to the logs ban and the licence system put forward by Belarus. From Russia imports are relatively marginal: 1.1 million m3 in 2018 according to Eurostat (mainly birch). The European sawmill industry is the first transformer of the EU forest biomass within the forest-based sector followed by pulping industries. The implementation and enforcement of the EUTR (at the EU level) -at EU level- strongly depends on the Sawmill Industries.   European Sawmill industries are investing on the best technologies available on the market to guarantee the traceability of the purchased logs. At the same time, they are confronted with the regulation’s requirements and the interpretations of national Competent Authorities. For this reason, EOS calls for an uniform implementation of the EUTR across Europe and for concrete requirements. Two (out of 3) key elements of the due diligence, namely the “risk assessment” and the “risk mitigation”, lead to arbitrary interpretation and create uncertainty on operators and even to competitive disadvantages and market distortions for operators in different member states. EOS considers it of utmost importance that the Commission gives clear indication on respective legality risks in different countries and on the appropriate and expected risk mitigation measures for ALL market participants encountering these risks; certification could be one of them. The European sawmill industry is confident that traceability is beneficial both for companies and the consumers, providing better quality for wood and its products. Using technology to trace the movement of timber guarantees transparency reduces massively legality risks and it ensures that the supply chain data is 100% accurate from the forest to the sawmill plant. EOS considers it essential for countries with high risks of illegal logging. At the same time, it should not disregard that wood products made by EU Companies and sold on the EU market compete with non-EU products. EOS advocates for a credible, efficient and verifiable system that guarantee that all wood products entering in the EU markets are coming only from verifiable legal source.   Finally, Governance improvements such as reforms to the framework of laws and policies and institutions is a needed tool for combating illegal logging (and the often interlinked illegal wildlife trade). A collective multi-stakeholder approach to reforming governance is essential.  Improved understanding of the root causes of illegal logging is essential for developing robust policy measures which address and curb illegal logging practices. Civil society, the private sector and local communities alongside government in decision-making should be directly involved in this reform exercise.   Legal and sustainable production of timber should involve actions addressed as well both domestic producers and investors from overseas.   Regarding the current product scope of the EUTR, EOS considers that the following products categories should be included in the EUTR.   4402: Wood charcoal (including shell or nut charcoal), whether or not agglomerated; 4404: Hoopwood; split poles; piles, pickets and stakes of wood, pointed but not sawn lengthwise; wooden sticks, roughly trimmed but not turned, bent or otherwise worked, suitable for the manufacture of walking sticks, umbrellas, tool handles or the like; chipwood; 4419: Tableware and kitchenware, of wood.
Organisation: EOS: European Organisation of the Sawmill Industry
Initiative: Illegal logging – evaluation of EU rules (fitness check)

feedback_msg_text: BIPT input on the EC Roadmap for the evaluation of the Postal Services Directive  BIPT supports the roadmap proposed by the European Commission for the evaluation of the Postal Services Directive as it was originally drafted in 1997.  BIPT is pleased that the roadmap explicitly considers a targeted consultation of national sector regulators via the European Regulators Group for Postal Services.  In view of the upcoming evaluation of the PSD, BIPT is underlying the crucial work carried out by the ERGP in previous years. In particular the “ERGP Report on developments in the postal sector and implications for regulation”[1] and the “ERGP Opinion on the review of the regulatory framework”[2] among a lot of other interesting ERGP reports.  Also, BIPT has carried out interesting studies regarding consumers’ needs and preferences[3] which can also be taken into consideration in the evaluation process. Furthermore, BIPT’s latest mixed-method consumer survey, which is currently being conducted, will provide valuable insights.  In conclusion, BIPT has no comments on the proposed roadmap. feedback_msg_text: ERGP input on the European Commission Evaluation Roadmap, of the Postal Services Directive  The European Regulators Group for Postal Services (ERGP) welcomes the EC initiative for the Evaluation of the Postal Services Directive (PSD) and the opportunity to comment on the Evaluation Roadmap. ERGP is also pleased to note that the Roadmap explicitly foresees a consultation with ERGP, in the context of this Evaluation.  Part of the ERGP annual work program for the period 2018-2019 analysed developments in the postal sector and related competition issues or user needs  with a view to  i. assess whether the  current postal regulatory framework is fit-for-purpose, and ii. make recommendations as to the futureproof postal regulatory framework.   The ERGP (18) 49 “Report on developments in the postal sector and implications for regulation” identifies the main market developments and difficulties that the PSD poses to the regulatory practice and considers the implications for regulation.  The ERGP PL I (19) 12 “Opinion on the review of the regulatory framework” presents the ERGP opinion regarding a review of the PSD.  In the view of ERGP, as analysed in the documents above, the current postal regulatory framework does not and cannot be expected to address issues that have arisen in recent years related to trends and developments that did not exist when the PSD was enacted in 1997, such as digitization, platformisation and e-commerce, as well as the consequential and fundamental changes in communication, commerce and consumer behavior and demands. Hence, the scope of the EC Evaluation and recommendations, should be extensive and also consider a fundamental, market oriented greenfield approach, in which the goals and underlying concepts of the Directive will be re-examined and, where appropriate, reaffirmed.  Furthermore, the future work of ERGP will be based on the ERGP PL II  (19) 7 “Medium Term Strategy 2020-2022”, which draws on the aforementioned documents and relates to further work on a more proactive and forward-looking regulatory approach. According to the Medium Term Strategy 2020-2022, ERGP’s work in the coming years will focus on:  • Revisiting the postal sector • Promoting a competitive EU postal single market • Empowering end-users and ensuring a user oriented universal service and, ERGP’s findings and recommendations , will contribute to the EC evaluation of the PSD and the subsequent recommendations for the new regulatory framework of the postal sector.  All referenced ERGP documents can be found at: https://ec.europa.eu/growth/sectors/postal-services/ergp_en  About ERGP ERGP is an advisory group to the European Commission. It facilitates consultation and cooperation between the independent National Regulatory Authorities (NRAs) in EU countries, and between NRAs and the Commission to help consolidate the internal market for postal services and ensure the consistent application of the postal/parcel legislation.
Organisation: ERGP - European Regulators Group for Postal services

feedback_msg_text: The Norwegian Association of Disabled (NAD) is an Non-Governmental advocacy organisation of people with disabilities. Our vision is a society for all, where people with disabilities have the same opportunity as other people have to live according to their own wishes, abilities and interests  NAD refers to the European Commission evaluation of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2006 on the rights of those with disabilities and with reduced mobility when travelling by air. The question the Commission wants to have reviewed are:  • how effectively the current Regulation is applied • whether it is delivering the projected results • how it is responding to various challenges.  NAD will present the following comments.   General The EU Regulation has been implemented in Norwegian legislation through the Regulation on Universal Design of airports, and of rights for disabled and mobility impaired persons in air transport (FOR-2013-07-16-919).   Effectiveness In general the legislation is important for ensuring air passengers’ rights for persons with disabilities. Despite the existence of such legal rights, cases from among others, the Air Passenger Complaint Handling Body in Norway (see https://reiselivsforum.no/web/om_oss/fly/) has to handle a series of complaints from passengers being discriminated, for instance being refused boarding with a guide dog for blind people, or because of medical conditions being confused with drunkenness etc.  Is the Regulation delivering projected results? While the Regulation has contributed to greater awareness on the rights of passengers with disabilities, it is in our viewpoint a need for more information to both the airline companies and to the bodies regulating accessibility at airports. This is both with regards to the issue of accessibility to the airport terminals, and about the design and performance of services from personnel towards passengers with different impairments.   How is the Regulation responding to various challenges? • While we find the need to report personal needs regarding the transport, like wheelchair availability at the destination airport or assistance at least 48 hours in beforehand reasonable, we would like to point out that this makes sudden trips related to for instance work meetings, more difficult and therefor discriminating.  • There should be stated clear deadlines in EEA and national legislations for ensuring accessibility not only to new buildings and terminals, but also for presenting a plan or accessibility to existing buildings.  • There should be clear requirements to present plans for accessible boarding devices and solutions at airports to ensure equal access to planes, with non-stigmatising solutions.  • It should be requirements to both airline companies and to airports to have good training courses for staff handling passengers and luggage regarding performing services. This should be part of the HR and management policy. In some countries, like Norway, there are national standards providing clauses to develop good services ensuring equal access to airline services for all. feedback_msg_text: HLF (The Norwegian Association of the Hard of Hearing) is the biggest organization for people with disabilities in Norway, and the biggest hearing organization in the world, with 66 000 members. 14,5 % of the Norwegian population above 20 years have a hearing impairment that affect their social life, education and work  . Some need rehabilitation, others need facilitated working conditions. Estimates show that one million Norwegians will have a hearing impairment in 2020 . Hearing - Air passenger rights – people with disabilities/reduced mobility (evaluation) HLF finds that Norwegian airports are not facilitated for people with hearing impairment. High levels of noise and a lack of written information makes it difficult for all passengers, but particularly for hard of hearing people, to get information they need. This may lead to miscommunication and potentially dangerous situations, e.g. fire alarms, evacuations etc. People with hearing impairment need telecoil and all important information should be expressed in text form on screens or similar devices, where it is possible. Telecoil One of the many challenges hard of hearing travellers meet is to communicate with staff when they are checking in. The communication should be facilitated with a telecoil. HLF demands that all counters at the airport, from checking in, passport control, security control and car rental should have telecoils, and a sign marked with “telecoil installed”. Information in text form Today most airports still use the speaker system to announce warnings and information such as changes in schedule and evacuation. In a noisy environment as an airport this information is difficult to hear for people with hearing impairment. Accordingly, people with hearing impairment are at risk when it comes to dangerous situations and evacuations, as well as missing out on important travel information. The lack of textual information also increases the general stress level of hearing-impaired people while traveling. Everyone will benefit from information in text form, not only people with hard of hearing. This is an important step towards universally designed information.  Acoustics Speech recognition is difficult in airports, and HLF underlines how important it is that airports must meet higher standards for acoustics. A better listening environment will make communicating much easier. This will benefit both travelers and airport staff.  Assistance People with hearing impairment can have trouble navigating an airport and might in some cases need assistance. Accordingly, the assistants must be trained to communicate with hearing impaired people. Communication with the assisting services in all phases must be possible in text form and with telecoil enhanced speech.   If you need more information, please contact political advisor Niklas Didrik Hellum by phone: +47 92 60 63 52 or by email: hellum@hlf.no. Best regards,  HLF (The Norwegian Association of the Hard of Hearing)  Merete J. feedback_msg_text: The regulation on the rights of persons with disabilities and with reduced mobility when travelling by air was a critical step in the recognition of their fundamental rights. Nevertheless, the experience gathered by persons with disabilities during the implementation period has shown that the regulation has an important shortcomings, as follows:  1. The main problem reported by persons with disabilities in the implementation of this regulation is the disproportionate and inapproriate application of its Article 4. The special ocassions and exceptions that allow airlines, agents or tour operators to deny the boarding of a person with disability, or, some times, a group of persons with disability,  based on supposed security reasons, are used disproportionately, in unjustified cases.  The cases studied and reported by Spanish persons with disabilities and/or their representative organisations are, usually, those of airlines, agents or tour operators who deny the boarding without any real justification, sometimes based on prejudices and lack of training. Related to this matter, many persons with disabilitites have had problems, or were directly banned from carrying technical support and equipment related with their disability. Given the relevance of theses supports and equipment for their living quality, this ban must be explicitely forbidden. Also, there have been complains of persons with disabilities who have experienced inadequate or mistreatment of their personal or technical support (wheelchairs, mechanic or electric, walking aids, motorised traveling mechanic elements, breathing support, etc.) when the airline decides to board it as mere luggage. While Article 12 of the Regulation stipulates the obligation to compensate the passenger in case of loss or damage of wheelchairs or other mobility equipment or assistive devices while driving at the airport or on board the plane, complaints are intensified in cases in which the companies refuse to assume the temporary or definitive replacement of said material, or the compensation or compensation for its real cost; it is compensated as a simple baggage.  2. The second common requirement, which is not expressed in the Regulation but too many times requested by the airlines, agents or tour operators, is for the person with a disability to be accompanied or assisted. This arbitrary condition hinders the freedom of movement of the person with a disability, who should be able to travel «in the manner and at the time of their choice», as the article 20 of the UNCRPD adequately notes. Once again, the responsibility of the adaptation must lie with the provider of the service.  3. Also, the regulation, through its article 7.1, states a pre-notification of, at least 48 hours before the published time of departure of the flight. However, such a long pre-notification is difficult or impossible to fulfill for many cases, such as urgent meetings or spontaneous trips - nowadays taken more commonly due to the decrease of the flying prices-. Also, assistances should not require such a long preparation for the airlines, agents or operators, it could perfectly be prepared and pending of the need to provide a service, as operators in some places of Europe are already developing. A modification of the regulation must then consider shorter or no pre-notifications.  4. Last, it is relevant to highlight the relevance of the accessibility of the environment, as it is crucial for the person with disability when travelling by air. In this behalf, the Regulation should cover – or, given the case, refer to the existing legislation - the necessity of making accessible built environment, information of the flights, check-in machines and websites, as well as flight documents. There have been improvements of this issue, but still many airlines have not developed systems allowing passengers with disabilities to book, buy and manage plane tickets in advance, like every passenger without a disability does.
Initiative: Air passenger rights – people with disabilities/reduced mobility (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: ALSA, the leading operator in the Spanish sector of passenger transport by road, would like to express its support for legislation that contributes to improving the quality of bus and coach transport services, to attracting more users and to making more attractive a mode of transport that is key for the present and future development of safe, efficient and sustainable mobility.  In this regard, EU Regulation 181/2011 introduced important obligations for bus and coach transport companies providing regular and occasional services, establishing a legal framework that protects the traveler and reinforces and guarantees their confidence in these services.  However, given the short time since the start of application of these rules on 1 March 2013, we consider that it is not possible to carry out an effective evaluation of the application of the EU Regulation 181/2011. As the report of the European Commission of 9 of September 2016 on the application of this Regulation (COM / 2016/0619 final) shows, the Member States' experience with the implementation of these rules is limited. Therefore, most of the obstacles that currently still prevent passengers from enjoying or enforcing their rights can be overcome by applying this Regulation more effectively, and therefore, a revision or modification of the Regulation becomes unnecessary.  On the other hand, it should be noted that a total of 12 Member States granted broad exemptions from the application of the Regulation during the first four years from its entry into force, to allow operators of bus and coach to prepare for its application. To date, 10 Member States still use one or two of these exemptions (COM (2019) 179 final - Report from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council on Exemptions granted by the Member States in accordance to Regulation (EU) No. 181/2011). Therefore, the evaluation of the Regulation would only be effective once the Member States fully implement this Regulation, and results can be measured appropriately.  The application of the Regulation diverges greatly among the Member States, as shown in the latest report on the application of the Regulation. According to the report, 7 Member States did not provide any information and another 11 indicate that they have not processed or imposed any sanctions. In addition, the number of claims processed varies greatly, with countries like Spain with a high number of files opened (1194) compared to others with a very low number in comparison (Ireland: 4; France: 21; Finland: 12; Sweden: two; United Kingdom: 4), which shows that the Regulation has been applied poorly or incorrectly through the EU Member States.  That said, it is important to highlight several elements that would enable a better application of the Regulation: 1. The European Commission should promote the exchange of good practices that promote coach tourism in cities. Often, occasional transport services are affected by measures adopted by local authorities that restrict traffic, such as driving prohibitions, access restrictions and even bans on circulation in all or large part of urban areas of touristic and cultural interest. These measures restrict the capacity of tourist transport operators to comply with the provisions of the Regulation. 2. In addition, EU financial instruments should have provided funding opportunities to support the implementation of the relevant provisions of this Regulation in bus and coach terminals in order to ensure multimodal connections, facilitate renovation of existing terminals and/or build new and modern ones, as well as to improve accessibility. feedback_msg_text: Thank you for the possibility to provide feedback on this legislative evaluation. As the world’s first Mobility as a Service operator MaaS Global we see this evaluation process as valuable and important in the process to ensure robust passenger rights in the EU and to ensure European Union legislation is also in the future supportive of development of more sustainable, innovative and safe travel options and opportunities.    Firstly, we would like to recognise that passengers are increasingly utilising new types of services and transport options, such as new ticket sales channels or multi-modal transport tickets and passes. On a growing share of trips made, the operator selling the passenger a ticket, and communicating with them before and during their journey, is different to the party physically operating the transport service.    To provide optimal coverage of rights to the passenger, the European passenger rights legislation should adapt to this fact. Passengers  should be well-informed in real-time and be able to utilise all available transport options, services and technologies with confidence that their rights are respected. Therefore, it is crucial to endorse timely data sharing among all relevant stakeholders. All operators that the passengers rely on to provide them information should have access to data  such as service disruptions, accessibility of stations and carriages and other data relevant data.   Secondly, to ensure that the passenger rights are fully realised, the operator’s actual role in the journey should be reflected in their obligations towards the passenger. In practise, operator’s obligation to offer aid to the passenger should fit their actual role in the passenger journey and communication, whether it is to be an online ticketing channel or physical ferry service. This would help transport  operators to fully realise and comply with their obligations.   Thirdly, as multimodal journeys increase in number, compatibility of all European passenger rights legislations with each other becomes even more relevant.  We hope that the common principles of European passenger rights are expressed in legislation in a harmonised way.
Initiative: Sea and inland waterway transport - passengers rights (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: Dear madam or sir,  the Society for Conservation Biology (SCB) is an international organization of over 4,000 conservation professionals. The SCB Europe Section (SCB-ES) membership extends to almost every country in Europe. SCB’s Mission is to advance the science and practice of conserving Earth's biological diversity. Advance the application of conservation science to management, policy and education is one of our Strategic Priorities.  SCB-ES has long been concerned about the sharp and continuing decline of biodiversity in farmland areas and the failure of key policy instruments – primarily the Common Agricultural Policy – in reversing these trends.  Having attended some of the discussions around the CAP reform, including the Public Consultation and the „CAP: Have your say“ conference, we have seen with great concern a biased delivery and take-up of inputs; imbalance in stakeholder participation both thematically and geographically; and lack of transparency in processes, data and relevant documents.  Neither the current CAP, nor the proposed CAP post-2020, seem to have taken up on the breadth of literature and knowledge which is available for a) improving existing instruments, b) improving the CAP’s effectiveness and efficiency with respect to environmental targets, and c) employing approaches for conflict reduction especially between agricultural production and biodiversity.   Moreover, considering the context of nationalism, the commitment of the EU is more than ever essential and the Policy Committee is in favour of a strong European CAP instead of the proposed CAP for, essentially, 27 agricultural policies. The Policy Committee of SCB-ES therefore sees great importance in a fitness check of the CAP, as long as it takes up a robust approach, and includes data, instruments, and the actors that are most relevant for a comprehensive evaluation of the CAP – the scientific community being one key partner to include. We anticipate seeing a call for scientific evidence and knowledge, and an effort to directly engage the scientific community in a dialogue over the CAP’s fitness.   As a key organization holding experts in the field, SCB-ES should be a key partner for delivering such essential knowledge and networking with the scientific community. We hereby express our expectation to see that the Fitness Check includes the following elements:   1. A process toward developing and publishing a database of relevant literature including (access to raw) data and simulations by EC and JRC.  2. An assessment of whether the CAP has sufficiently taken up knowledge and tools for developing robust objectives, indicators and monitoring; as well as for identifying and addressing conflicts and tradeoffs.  3. A thorough assessment of administrative procedures linked to the implementation of biodiversity relevant agri-environment programs in particular. 4. An assessment following a DPSIR approach regarding the direct and indirect effects of the CAP on biodiversity, ecosystem functions and services as well as how all CAP instruments (including Agro-Environment-Climate Measures, Coupled and Decoupled Direct Payments but also Investments, payments for Areas of Nature Constraints etc.) affect land-use changes, intensification, and (non-) sustainable farming management. 5. A clear process to involve the scientific community in evidence collection, analysis and assessment of the CAP fitness check outcomes, including opening of the outcomes to evaluation.  We call for a transparent and robust process, which must consider and assess the Commission’s proposal for the CAP post-2020 and accordingly be used to improve the coming CAP design and implementation.  SCB-ES stands ready to participate in the much-needed science-policy dialogue and facilitate the link to the scientific community.  Stefan Kreft, Policy Committee Chair, SCB Europe
Organisation: Society for Conservation Biology (Europe Section, Policy Committee)
Initiative: EU farm policy – evaluation of its impact on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity

feedback_msg_text: Dear madam/sir,  Authors of this letter have conducted an independent Fitness-Check of the CAP, published in November 2017. This assessment was based on a literature review and trend analyses. It followed the fitness check criteria in assessing the CAP’s effectiveness, efficiency, coherence (internal and external), relevance and EU Added value. We covered a breadth of topics relating to the impacts of the CAP on a) land-use, farm structure and management, b) biodiversity, c) climate, d) soil and water, and ) other ecosystem services. We have also assessed the CAP’s contribution to sustainable agriculture and whether it can meet the UN’s SDGs.  In the process of preparing the fitness check, we have developed a comprehensive database of relevant publications for the CAP evaluation, which has further been updated and expanded over the course of 2018.  Members of our team have further evaluated the Commission’s proposal for the CAP post-2020, and examined whether published evidence and knowledge have been taken up in developing a potentially-better CAP. We hereby wish to express our deep concern that the proposed CAP fails to address the policy’s key weaknesses, and offers more risks than potentials for environmental improvements.   We strongly support the need for an evidence-based evaluation of the CAP and hence welcome the Commission’s decision to take up on the calls for a Fitness Check. We particularly welcome a Fitness Check process that builds on the existing database, and suggest look forward to seeing our comprehensive evaluation being included as one key document. A robust evaluation should build not only upon scientific evidence and knowledge, but also engage the producers of this knowledge – i.e., scientists and scientific organizations.  Accordingly, we call the Fitness Check to include:  a. a database of relevant literature, including data and documents that have so far not been shared with the public.  b. a reflection of existing evidence, reviews and knowledge, and how these have been incorporated into the policy.  c. a clear separation between direct and indirect impacts of the CAP, systematically covering all CAP instruments (including coupled and decoupled support, ANC, investments) and placing particular emphasis on assessing the effects of those instruments that are not designated toward environmental protection.  d. an analysis of national, EU and global effects of the CAP, including direct and indirect facilitation of land-use changes both in the EU and at other regions and countries (i.e., „spillover“ effects or „telecoupling“).  e. as current CAP instruments are reported to fail in delivering on sustainability, we call the fitness check to include economic, social and political analyses on the processes that are repeatedly leading to the CAP’s weak design, incoherence and inefficient implementation of CAP instruments.  f. a clear process to involve the scientific community in a direct way, including further evidence gathering and synthesis, thus increasing transparency and credibility and avoiding potential biases in interpretation resulting from the origin of evidence provided by stakeholders.  g. A comprehensive assessment of factors for success and case study examples, including both CAP implementation and monitoring, as well as citizen science potentials and their uptake and support by the CAP.  h. Finally, given the timing of the assessment, we anticipate to see a robust analysis of how the proposed CAP addresses weaknesses identified by the Fitness Check – i.e., is the next CAP going to be more fit for purpose then the current one? Here we anticipate such an assessment to include both qualitative and quantitative analysis, and not only an opinion-based evaluation.  The authors of the fitness-Check are welcoming a transparent and open dialogue throughout the process. Further material including our database are available at www.idiv.de/cap-fitness-check. feedback_msg_text: Die Ausgestaltung der Europäischen Agrarpolitik ist von maßgeblichem Einfluss auf den guten Zustand unserer Gewässer und Wasserressourcen und damit zugleich die Zielerreichung der Wasserrahmenrichtlinie (WRRL) und weiterer Richtlinie (z.B. Nitrat, Biodiversität, Meeresschutz)  Daher begrüßen wir die geplante Evaluierung. Diese kommt allerdings zu spät, da die Reform der EU-Agrarpolitik ab 2021 jetzt verhandelt wird und die Ergebnisse dieser Konsultation vermutlich keine Berücksichtigung mehr finden (vorbehaltlich Zeitplan GAP unter neuer Kommission/ neuem Parlament) und damit auch keine Wirksamkeit auf die Erreichung der Ziele der Wasserrahmenrichtlinie bis 2027 mehr entfalten. Das ist besonders bedauerlich, da die Vorschläge der EU-Kommission zur Berücksichtigung der Ziele der WRRL in den aktuellen GAP Reformvorschlägen nicht ausreichend sind.   Wir erwarten von der Konsultation, dass die zwei maßgeblichen Problembereiche adressiert: die (mangelnde) Integration der Ziele eines nachhaltigen Wassermanagements in alle relevanten Umweltgesetzgebungen und Strategien der EU und ihrer Mitgliedsstaaten, um den Eintrag von Schadstoffen in Wasserressourcen nachhaltig zu verringern und eine nachhaltige Nutzung und Verwendung von Wasser durch die Landwirtschaft sicherzustellen.  Zum zweiten muss die Konsultation auf Wege einer verbesserten Implementierung der EU-Gesetzgebung zum Schutz von Grund- und Oberflächenwasser fokussieren. Hier liegen erhebliche Defizite in allen Mitgliedsstaaten. Als Hüterin der EU-Gesetzgebung steht die EU-Kommission in der Pflicht, diese Missstände konkret zu benennen und zu beenden.  Grundsätzlich sollten die Konsultationen zum Ziel haben, die existierenden umfangreichen wissenschaftlichen Studien über die Auswirkungen der EU-Agrarpolitik sowie deren nationale Umsetzung zusammentragen und bewerten. Dabei ist zu unterstreichen, dass die Kriterien der Evaluation (Effektivität, Effizienz, Relevanz, Kohärenz, EU-Mehrwert) eine ökologische Folgenabschätzung (fehlender Integration und Umsetzung) beinhalten muss. feedback_msg_text: Sustainable management of natural resources is becoming increasingly imperative and necessary to preserve biodiversity and counteract the negative effects of climate change. Especially in agriculture, where water and soil are the main resources, high quality soil is crucial for the future of both nutrition and agriculture. EU Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is moving in the right direction by addressing the challenges that arise at European level by adopting measures to promote sustainable land use. The principle of sustainable compliance links direct payments with farmers' compliance with the basic standards of the environment and climate, food safety, animal and plant health, animal welfare and land conservation . It thus establishes a basis for environmental measures and encourages sustainable land use. Concerning the sustainable management of non-hazardous waste organic solid, the EU has for many years legislated measures that lead organic waste producers to their legal and certified management to produce useful products, such as compost, that can help increase the quality and productivity of arable land as it contains no chemicals additives to increase nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium units and is rich in organic matter (> 30%), thus addressing a persistent and chronic problem of arable soils, lack of organic matter due to the misuse and/or overuse of chemically manufactured fertilizers.
Initiative: EU farm policy – impact on sustainable management of the soil

feedback_msg_text: Die gemeinsame europäische Agrarpolitik hat in den letzten Jahren zu einer weiteren Intensivierung der Landwirtschaft geführt. Diese Intensivierung führt zu einem hohen Einsatz an Pestiziden, der sich negativ auf die Bodenorganismen und somit die Bodenfruchtbarkeit auswirkt. Der hohe Einsatz von Düngemitteln führt dazu, dass viele Böden stark mit Stickstoff versorgt sind. Die Einbringung von Stickstoff führt unter anderem zu einer Entwicklung von klimaschädlichem Lachgas. Die Phosphatdüngung, mit mineralischen Düngern sorgt für eine Anreicherung von radioaktivem Cadmium und Uran in den Böden (Umweltbundesamt 2017). Zusätzlich sind viele Böden in Deutschland nicht ausreichende mit Humus versorgt und die Humusgehalte der Böden nehmen durch die intensive Nutzung ab.  Eine weitere Folge der Intensivierung ist die Beschränkung auf wenige Feldfrüchte wie Getreide, Mais und Hackfrüchte,  welche als Humuszehrer wirken. Maßnahmen, die einen Humusaufbau fördern würden, wie vielfältige Fruchtfolgen, werden in der GAP nicht ausreichend adressiert und die Cross-Compliance-Anforderung zu einer Fruchtartendiversifizierung trägt nicht zur Entstehung vielgliedriger Fruchtfolgen bei. Nach wie vor werden auch Moorböden ackerbaulich bewirtschaftet was zu einem Verlust organischer Biomasse und der massiven Freisetzung von Klimagasen führt. Auch der Verlust von fruchtbaren Böden durch Erosion schreitet voran, vor allem die großen Bearbeitungseinheiten, entstanden als Folge der Intensivierung, verschärfen das Problem der Winderosion. Auch das Umwandlungsverbot von Grünland konnte nicht verhindern, dass Dauergrünland zur Narbenerneuerung umgebrochen wurde und danach neu eingesät. Sie sorgt für eine Verringerung der Humusauflage unter Dauergrünland und führt zu einer Freisetzung von Treibhausgasen. Die Agrarumweltprogramme sind nicht in der Lage diesen Trend zu stoppen, da sie mit zu wenigen Geldern hinterlegt und in vielen Fällen nicht zielgerichtet genug sind. Deshalb müssen die Gelder der GAP für naturverträgliche Bewirtschaftung eingesetzt werden. Im Agrarbereich sollten Gelder aus öffentlichen Kassen nur noch für öffentliche Leistungen der Landwirtschaft verwendet werden, wie die Sicherung und Förderung von Boden, Biodiversität, Wasser, Klima und Landschaft. Zusätzlich sind ausreichend ambitionierte gesetzliche Mindeststandards gefordert, die garantieren, dass die Landwirtschaft flächendeckend nachhaltig wird. Dazu bedarf es eine Zweckbindung von 15 Milliarden Euro pro Jahr der Gelder der europäischen Agrarpolitik und einem Anteil von zehn Prozent der Betriebsfläche als nichtproduktive Fläche, die zu, Beispiel durch Brachen zum Humusaufbau betragen. Auch der aktuelle Vorschlag zur nächsten Förderperiode der GAP wird nicht in der Lage sein die Biodiversität und die Böden ausreichend zu schützen (https://science.sciencemag.org/content/365/6452/449).
Initiative: EU farm policy – impact on sustainable management of the soil

feedback_msg_text: The Notice would benefit from the development of the last 23-years, in term of terminologies, legal practices and academic researches. Better regulation would also benefit from coordination of current other consultations ex: HGL many stakeholders suggested a set of clarification on the guidelines provided for defining relevant markets ( “standard market”, “technology market”) .Review of tools to assess market power, barriers to entry are welcome. A few examples: - To transpose in the Notice the §19 of the 2009 Guidance on the Commission’s enforcement priorities in applying Article 102 . Market definition applies as well to “consumer,” customers”, “user”, any actor on the “market”s - Likewise, adjustment to the notion of welfare/harm to all categories, from consumer to citizen, societal benefits, “public interest” ( T-528/93), competitive process ( C-8/08; T-461/0).    Market Power   Suggest to add and detail the measures of market power which grandly changed, to review /discuss the indicators (beyond §54 ). High market share does not necessary imply market power (eg Microsoft/Skype case), in reverse power can exists even in case of lower market share or market concentration. Courts/Academics did raise the issue of gatekeeper, the retail control of suppliers market access, be it in the off line or online. Courts rules that suppliers cannot sell their production without retail access; costs of alternatives are to be included in the assessment of power.   Data control is a market power tool, off line (ex.grocery retail with consumers scan data) or online (users behaviours in the online environment) for example. The dual role of the gatekeeper is reinforcing its market power. It is true in consumers markets such as grocery  as in other sectors (eg electricity, communication networks .etc).Such dual role has been demonstrated leading to discriminatory treatment of suppliers products versus the “gatekeeper” products. When it is combined with data control, the retail gatekeepers have access to competitors data which allow to better, uncompetitively, “compete”, position its products, to copy suppliers innovation, engage in copy cats etc... What courts have ruled against in grocery is now being investigated for platforms (Amazon). The exercise of gatekeeper/retail power is also at the origin of Unfair Trading Practices which have been demonstrated as costly practices for the European economy (ex. late payments, and many more)   To assess power, an analysis of existing of barriers to entry/lack of entrant is required. These considerations could complement the notion of potential competition (§24).   Price   As reminded in the Horizontal Guideline (§28) price is far from the only indicator of restrictive practices or issue for competition, there are many others, perhaps more crucial such as  market dynamics (ex. innovation, quality…). Yet the main tools to measure substitution and define markets are relying solely on price (eg SSNIP ).  It is even more true considering the existence of non transactional, “zero-price”market where yet competition issues appeared. It is true for digital as for the developing sustainability “markets”.   Set of academics have challenged the use of SSNIP for market definition. It should be used as one among others tools in the assessment of competitive constraints, after market is defined.  One could wonder if such reliance on price in competition law did not lead to a race to the bottom; whether the overemphasis on consumer welfare, the over-emphasis on cheap price, a strategy to support consumption is not at the origin of the drop of innovation, of industrial capacities in Europe, leading to the current crisis where our society as well as economy is depending on Asia for addressing the current Health crisis (no mask, no medical gears, no raw material for drugs, ventilators….). Competition law should allow that that the tools and concepts it uses support the existence of “product markets” in Europe . Feedback from: GUIPASQ (128.4 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU competition law – market definition notice (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: La définition du marché pertinent est centrale dans l’analyse concurrentielle, dès lors que c’est elle qui détermine le cadre de cette analyse. 1. De possibles améliorations méthodologiques La Communication a contribué à une meilleure transparence et à la sécurité juridique, ainsi qu’à une meilleure cohérence, et a apporté une plus-value. Cependant le critère d’effectivité semble présenter des lacunes importantes, ce qui conduit en retour à une insécurité juridique, à un interventionnisme excessif, et à une insuffisante plus-value. a) La réintégration de deux contraintes concurrentielles La Commission exclut deux critères de contrainte concurrentielle de l’analyse du marché pertinent (la substituabilité au niveau de l’offre et la concurrence potentielle), et ne les prend en compte qu’au stade de l’analyse de la concurrence, ce qui est susceptible d’entraîner une définition exagérément étroite du marché. Cela entraîne un interventionnisme accru du droit de la concurrence et une insécurité juridique. Par ailleurs, l’exclusion de l’analyse de la concurrence potentielle au stade de la délimitation du marché limite la prise en compte effective et rapide des évolutions des marchés. Il serait utile de faire clairement appel aux trois critères dès le stade de la délimitation des marchés. b) L’analyse de la substituabilité de la demande devrait évoluer Dans la Communication, la substitution du côté de la demande est centrée autour de l’élasticité de la demande au prix, qui apparaît aujourd’hui dépassée : la numérisation et la mondialisation de l’économie ont entraîné des changements importants dans les modes de consommation, et l’innovation est également devenue un facteur important de concurrence. Ce critère ne permet par ailleurs pas d’appréhender les activités fondées sur la gratuité et l’usage de la publicité. c) La délimitation du marché géographique ne permet pas une prise en compte effective des marchés mondiaux Le marché géographique est délimité selon une analyse au niveau national, communautaire ou de l’EEE. Cette méthodologie ne permet pas l’appréhension des marchés mondiaux, qui sont pourtant susceptibles de constituer une pression concurrentielle sur les marchés européens ou nationaux. La Commission doit tenir compte de la dimension mondiale de certains marchés au regard de la mondialisation et de la globalisation de l’économie. 2. L’évaluation de la Commission devrait également porter sur certaines modalités pratiques d’application de la Communication a) Une analyse rigidifiée  La pratique décisionnelle se fonde principalement sur les décisions antérieures. Si cela offre une certaine sécurité juridique, cela a en parallèle entraîné une rigidification excessive de la pratique décisionnelle, rendant la prise en compte des évolutions du marché difficile. La pratique décisionnelle a également développé une habitude qui consiste pour l’autorité à envisager une nouvelle délimitation de marché tout en « laissant ouverte » la question et en se référant pour l’analyse à la délimitation antérieurement définie, et qui est susceptible de porter atteinte à la sécurité juridique. b) La prise en compte d’une temporalité insuffisante pour le droit des concentrations La temporalité prise en compte est insuffisante dans le cadre de l’analyse des marchés pour les opérations de concentration : la concurrence potentielle n’est prise en compte que dans le cadre de l’analyse concurrentielle, dans la limite d’un horizon de deux ans.  Or le contrôle des concentrations supposant une analyse prospective du marché, il est indispensable d’orienter davantage cette analyse vers l’avenir. Enfin, la pratique décisionnelle restrictive en matière de délimitation de marchés conduit à désavantager l’industrie européenne par rapport aux industries concurrentes. Cette évaluation est donc l’occasion pour la Commission de définir les bases d’une nouvelle politique de concurrence. Feedback from: Vogel & Vogel (493.3 KB - PDF - 11 pages) Download
Initiative: EU competition law – market definition notice (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: HSBC Response to Commission 2020 AML Roadmap     11 March 2020    HSBC welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the European Commission’s 2020 AML Roadmap.   As acknowledged in the Roadmap, recent money-laundering scandals have highlighted weaknesses in the current EU AML framework. We welcome the prospect of a new comprehensive approach at EU level which will strengthen the resilience of the financial system to criminal abuse, both within the borders of the EU and globally.   We broadly agree with the description of the problem contained in the Roadmap document: better application of the rules by professionals across all the regulated sectors; better supervision by national authorities; stronger FIUs; and improved cooperation between competent authorities will all contribute to a more effective AML/CFT framework. The document also rightly identifies the cross-border nature of the challenge and the need for the framework to adapt to technological innovation.  In our view, however, the Roadmap has insufficient focus on promoting a deeper and more effective collaboration between all entities and authorities engaged in the fight against criminal abuse of the financial sector. We believe the Roadmap should also advocate measures that will enable information-sharing between and within financial institutions and that will promote the application of transformative technology in the fight against financial crime. In relation to supervisory reform, the Roadmap should advocate a greater focus on the effectiveness, rather than just the technical compliance, of the AML/CFT programmes of obliged entities.  We have set these issues out in more detail in the attached document (which includes this text for ease of circulation), along with suggested policy responses for consideration in the revised AML Roadmap and subsequent Policy Communication.  We look forward to participating in future discussions on this important issue. Feedback from: HSBC (56.3 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Money laundering & terrorism financing – action plan

feedback_msg_text: Europe was a leader in food irradiation research and commercial applications until the late 1990’s. As the yearly reports of the European Commission (EC) show, the quantities of food being irradiated in the EU have declined substantially since the European Directives on irradiation of food and food ingredients, 1999/2/EC and 1999/3/EC entered into force. In America (USA, Canada and Mexico), Africa (mainly South Africa), Asia-Pacific (especially in China, but also Australia, New Zealand, India, Vietnam and Thailand) and the Russian Federation the quantities of irradiated foods on sale are increasing. A dozen countries have deployed the technology to meet the sanitary and phytosanitary requirements of their trading partners. Experience outside and even inside the EU has demonstrated that many consumers are willing to buy irradiated food when they are available, i.e. when they are given an opportunity. The complexities of Directives 1999/2/EC and 1999/3/EC and the non-harmonized approach across the EU are in stark contrast to the situation for irradiated non-food commodities. For irradiated non-food items there is a diverse and buoyant market in the European Community. The legislation controlling the market in non-food products has not proven to be a barrier to the application of the irradiation process. The process is trusted to add safety for essential non-food items that include medical devices, drugs, pharmaceutical and cosmetic ingredients, packaging or pet toys, to improve the properties of industrial wires and cables, automotive parts, electronic components and plastic films, or to preserve historical artifacts.  Reputable national and international organizations including the World Health Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, and the International Atomic Energy Agency consider that irradiated food pose no toxicological, microbiological or nutritional hazard. Science and decades of experience have proven that food irradiation is safe. However, the European Directives on irradiation of food reflect a lack of confidence in the process and are much more restrictive than the Codex Alimentarius General Standard for Irradiated Foods (CODEX STAN 106-1983, REV.1-2003) that served as the model regulation in several countries.  The harmonized list of food products that can be irradiated across the EU has never been extended beyond dried aromatic herbs, spices and vegetable seasonings even though there have been several requests to extend this list. In seven Member States the national authorizations issued prior to 1999 for many irradiated foods are still in force. Therefore foods that may be legally irradiated in some Member States are banned in other Member States. This appears contrary to the spirit and principles established under the Treaty of Rome for a common market. The Association’s view is that it is not possible to be both in compliance with the Treaty and at the same time have a national restriction on the sale of a product that is safe and freely permitted in another member state of the European Union.  Despite their stated aim of adopting measures aimed at the smooth operation of the internal market 1999/2/EC and 1999/3/EC are in practice hindering the free movement of foodstuffs and creating conditions of unequal competition. The European Directives created a barrier to the trade of irradiated food within the EU and with third countries and have had a global negative effect on the expansion of a beneficial technology. They hamper the diffusion of innovative European technologies such as new compact and cost efficient recirculation electron beam units and the use of lamps producing low energy electron beams or X rays that can be used to irradiate food.   The attached letter provides comprehensive feedback from the International Irradiation Association. Feedback from: International Irradiation Association (372 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Evaluation of the EU legal framework on food irradiation

feedback_msg_text: DAFI FEEDBACK FROM NORWEGIAN HYDROGEN ASSOCIATION  About the Norwegian Hydrogen Association (Norsk Hydrogenforum - NHF) NHF has since 1996 been a non-profit members’ national association for conveying and promoting the advantages of hydrogen as an energy carrier in Norway. Our more than 55 members span Norwegian industry, universities, research institutes and other organizations engaged or otherwise interested in hydrogen. NHF actively works for stronger framework conditions for hydrogen and fuel cells, and promotes green hydrogen solutions from Norway internationally.  Norway´s 12-year framework National Transport Plan 2018-2029 sets the tightened national ambitions for zero and low emission vehicles uptake in Norway: - From 2026, all new private cars, buses and light commercial vehicles should be zero-emission. - By 2030, new heavier distribution vans, 75 % of new long-distance buses, 50 % of trucks should be zero emission. - By 2030, all goods distribution in the largest cities shall be virtually emission free. - In the maritime sector, similar strong measures shall decarbonize short sea shipping routes within the same timeline.  In order to reach these tough targets, the Norwegian Government will have to provide a broad range of intensified incentives to stimulate deployment of infrastructure and vehicles. Norway is also dependent on a faster development in the automotive industry internationally. Thus, more ambitious actions from the EU and the Member States are crucial for Norway to meet its targets.   Hydrogen-based transportation is on the verge of a global take-off and offers - together with battery-based transportation - the only two complete zero-emission tailpipe solutions. However, Europe needs to catch up and speed up efforts to promote hydrogen-based much stronger, to compete with the recent Asian and American leadership roles.  NHF's Conclusions and suggested actions: 1. The directive 2014/94 does not seem to give any significant increase in hydrogen infrastructure.   2. The relevance of 2014/94 is highly adequate! 3. European OEM auto manufacturers need to highly intensify the development and deployment of fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs). Both in the light-, medium- and heavy-duty segments. 4. There is a clearly increasing demand in the market for FCEVs. We see that strongly in Norway, particularly for commercial vehicles, where battery-based electric vehicles becomes inadequate for the diversity of demand needed in logistics, freight and business related transportation. For instance, in Norway, several companies have pre-ordered the America-based Nikola Tre fuel cell truck. We believe that the same is the situation in the EU. More hydrogen refuelling stations – and clearer national targets - will stimulate the demand side, which in turn will stimulate the vehicle manufacturers in Europe to speed up deployment. 5. The European Commission should provide funds in a larger amounts to public-private-partnership projects for deployment of infrastructure, and stimulate stronger cross-border coordination of aligned infrastructure ramp-up plans. 6. Heavy Duty Trucks are now being developed and prepared for large-scale production globally, except in Europe. The EU should stimulate much stronger the development of trucks and commercial vehicles, by setting ambitious goals for emissions from medium- and heavy duty transport, and ensuring harmonized framework conditions since transport is a highly international competitive business with limited margins. 7. Hydrogen as a fuel should be treated in line with the other alternative fuels. As a truly zero emission option that provides deep decarbonisation of transport related emissions, it is highly important that provision of infrastructure for hydrogen should be mandatory and not a voluntary option for the Member States.   Read more about NHF and our work at www.hydrogen.no
Initiative: Alternative Fuels Infrastructure — evaluation
