feedback_msg_text: Ericsson is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments in preparation for the Commission’s evaluation of the customs cooperation and mutual administrative assistance between the EU and China.  Ericsson as a global telecom infrastructure company is active in markets on all continents and with R&D sites, production facilities, repair sites and offices located within both the EU and China, we are affected by how customs operations with regard to trade and transfers between the EU and China function in practice and welcome all improvements. At the same time, we would also like to make clear that we do not identify China and its implementation of customs procedures as being a more difficult challenge than what we may experience in other countries in the world.  On current challenges that we have identified, let us just highlight some key aspects:    In China there is a difference between how the HS codes are defined in different ports and regions. This is nothing new and great improvements have been made on the Chinese side to align this better, but still we have some problems. As an example, for Spectrum Analyzers with special options for Telecommunications purpose, HS 903040 is acceptable in Shanghai Customs but not valid in other Customs including Beijing. Further work is therefore needed on the Chinese side with regard to this and EU support in identifying this as a problem would be helpful.  With the merger of China Customs Inspection and Quarantine (China CIQ) into China customs, the functions of the different customs departments have been made less clear. As an example, once used equipment have been imported into China, a physical inspection is mandatorily requested at the final destination site. This used to be a normal routine process with China CIQ, but after the merger different customs function units are now involved and the Importer of Record has a much more challenging task in identifying, contacting and interacting with the different customs units to get the necessary instructions on how to process the physical inspection. This seems to be a waste of resources for both the importers and the customs and could surely be handled in a more efficient manner.  There seems to be a lack of cooperation and communication between the China Tax Bureau and China Customs concerning Transfer Pricing audits. Currently the positions of respective agency are not the same and the company is urged to adjust its TP in a specific direction by one agency, only to receive counteracting instructions by the other agency when it carries out its own TP audit. This is of course both frustrating and potentially financially costly for the importer and a better unity on the Chinese side would greatly facilitate.  It’s possible that this specific issue will not be part of the assessment process, but we think it’s useful as an example that some of the problems on the Chinese side may stem more from a practical challenge in coordinating different government agencies positions and their practical implementation of regulations.   With regard to possible improvements on the Chinese side, let us just briefly add three more issues: 1. To enable more automation in the area of international trade and logistic data, such as flight manifest information and on-board bill of lading, etc. 2. To enable more trust to the AEO company under AEO structure, not only on physical inspection rate, but also on the customs audit and verification after clearance. 3. All Chinese shippers request “Company Codes” what they regularly call an “USCI”. This is due to Chinese customs regulation no. 56/2018 . For EU importers/consignees (who have of course no USCI) this means to provide VAT-ID number and trade registry number to the shipper upfront. This is not seen as major problem by us but any facilitation of processes are of course welcome.  We thank you again for the opportunity to provide some comments and look forward to the continued process. GF Legal Affairs - TC Feedback from: Ericsson (47.5 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: EU-China Customs Agreement

feedback_msg_text: Die Arbeitsgemeinschaft Österreichischer Verkehrsflughäfen (AÖV) nimmt die Evaluierung der RL 96/67/EG durch die Europäische Kommission zur Kenntnis und nimmt hiermit zur Roadmap Stellung. Aus Sicht der AÖV wurde die Richtlinie in Österreich durch das Flughafen-Bodenabfertigungsgesetz (FBG) korrekt, fristgerecht und zur Zufriedenheit der österreichischen Luftverkehrswirtschaft umgesetzt. Die Ergebnisse in puncto Qualität, Safety und Wettbewerb sind insgesamt sehr gut. Aus diesem Grund sollte das Ergebnis der Evaluierung nicht in einer Änderung dieses erfolgreichen Regelwerks münden. Die Rechtsform der Richtlinie ist im Bereich der Bodenverkehrsdienstleistungen zudem genau richtig gewählt, da die Umstände bzw. Marktgegebenheiten in den Mitgliedstaaten sehr unterschiedlich sind. Daher ist es zwingend notwendig, dass die nationalen Regierungen ausreichend Spielraum zur Umsetzung und Anpassung an die lokalen Gegebenheiten haben. Nur so ist ein Funktionieren der BVD-Branche in Europa sicherzustellen. Die AÖV begrüßt das Anliegen der Kommission, im Rahmen dieser Evaluierung die Bereiche der Arbeitnehmerrechte sowie des Klimawandels besonders zu beleuchten. Da die Bestrebungen zu einer weiteren Marktliberalisierung bereits aus der Vergangenheit bekannt sind, weisen wir darauf hin, dass sich diese Ziele widerstreben. Müssen verpflichtend weitere BVD-Anbieter zugelassen werden (in Österreich derzeit mindestens zwei), steigt einerseits der Druck auf die Beschäftigten der groundhandling services. BVD ist eine sehr personalintensive Branche, weshalb der Wettbewerb zwingend auch die Bezahlung und Arbeitsbedingungen der Arbeitnehmer/innen umfasst. Gerade die größeren Flughäfen, auf denen bereits Wettbewerb in der Bodenabfertigung sichergestellt ist würden durch eine verpflichtende weitere Öffnung des Marktes gezwungen werden, Abstell- und Manövierungsflächen zur Verfügung zu stellen, die eigentlich für den Flugverkehr benötigt werden. Dies gilt natürlich auch auf den saisonal extrem ausgelasteten regionalflughäfen. Andererseits wäre es schwieriger zu gewährleisten, dass alle BVD-Anbieter ihren Beitrag zur CO2-Reduktion (etwa durch Umrüstung im Fuhrpark) leisten, je mehr Anbieter an einem Standort tätig sind. Der groundhandling-Betrieb wird ineffizient, wenn zu viele Anbieter an einem Standort tätig sind, was außerdem die Schaffung von neuer Infrastruktur notwendig macht. Insgesamt ist es fraglich, ob eine Revision der Richtlinie die Ziele in den Bereichen Soziales und Umwelt überhaupt erreichen kann. Allerdings erscheint es überlegenswert in eine allfällige Novelle der BVD-Richtlinie präzisere Bestimmungen einzubauen, in welcher Form und auf welchen Zeitraum der erforderliche Schwellwert zur Zulassung weiterer Anbieter erreicht bzw. erhalten sein muss.  Schließlich sei in Hinsicht auf Marktliberalisierung darauf hingewiesen, dass es den Mitgliedstaaten ja bereits jetzt möglich ist, eine höhere Zahl an Anbietern vorzuschreiben oder zuzulassen, wo es für sinnvoll erachtet wird. Auch das spricht gegen eine Revision oder gar einen Vorschlag für eine Verordnung statt einer Richtlinie.
Initiative: Ground handling services at EU airports — evaluation (2010-18)

feedback_msg_text: Mit der Richtlinie 96/67/EG wurde 1996 der Markt der luftseitigen Bodenabfertigungsdienste grundsätzlich vollständig geöffnet, mit der Möglichkeit der Begrenzung auf maximal zwei Drittabfertiger in bestimmten Bereichen. Die Richtlinie 96/67/EG wurde in Deutschland unter Gebrauchmachung der in der Richtlinie vorgesehenen Beschränkungsmöglichkeiten, umgesetzt.   Ziel der Richtlinie 96/67/EG war eine Marktöffnung im Bereich der bis dahin in der Praxis beschränkten luftseitigen Bodenabfertigungsdienste, um „zur Senkung der Betriebskosten der Luftfahrtgesellschaften und zur Verbesserung der den Nutzern gebotenen Qualität der Dienstleistungen beizutragen“. Flughafenunternehmer wurden danach verpflichtet, generell Selbstabfertigern und Dienstleistern die Erbringung von Bodenabfertigungsdiensten zu ermöglichen (= grundsätzlicher Zugangsanspruch).  Die Marktöffnung erfolgte jedoch nicht schrankenlos, insbesondere sieht die Richtlinie die Möglichkeit einer zahlenmäßigen Beschränkung bei Gepäckabfertigung, Vorfelddiensten, Fracht- und Postabfertigung, Betankung aus Gründen der verfügbaren Kapazitäten und Flächen sowie aus Betriebssicherheitsgründen vor. Desweiteren können Einrichtungen, die in der Flughafenbenutzungsordnung als Zentrale Infrastruktureinrichtungen geführt werden, dem Wettbewerb entzogen werden. Dies sind solche Infrastrukturen, die aufgrund ihrer Komplexität bzw. aus Kosten- und Umweltgründen nicht geteilt oder in mehrfacher Ausführung geschaffen werden können.  Aus hiesiger Sicht sind die Ziele der Richtlinie erreicht und haben die in der Richtlinie vorgesehenen Beschränkungsmöglichkeiten nach wie vor ihre Berechtigung, weil die seinerzeitigen Gründe der Kapazitätsknappheit und insbesondere der Betriebssicherheit (letzteres mehr denn je) nach wie vor aktuell sind. Es darf auch nicht übersehen werden, dass es sich um Beschränkungsmöglichkeiten in nur einigen Bereichen handelt; schon jetzt können die Mitgliedsstaaten auch dort mehr Anbieter zulassen, wenn dem keine Gründe der Kapazitätsknappheit und/oder Betriebssicherheit entgegenstehen. Für eine verpflichtende Zulassung von mehr Anbietern besteht daher nach unserer Auffassung keine Notwendigkeit. Ganz im Gegenteil: Dies würde pauschal die Gegebenheiten an den einzelnen Flughäfen außer Acht lassen und zu Lasten von Betriebssicherheit, Arbeitsbedingungen und Arbeitsschutz sowie der Qualität gehen (Stichworte: noch höherer Wettbewerbsdruck, keine ausreichenden Schulungen und Ausbildung mehr, geringere Sozialstandards).   In Betracht zu ziehen ist auch, dass die EU-Kommission die EASA beauftragt hat, gemeinsame Regelungen für das sichere Erbringen von Bodenabfertigungsdiensten zu schaffen. Bevor die BVD-Richtlinie überarbeitet wird, sollte zunächst dieses Ergebnis abgewartet werden und dann in die Evaluierung einfließen.  Es hat sich in Deutschland zunehmend in den letzten Jahren gezeigt, dass das Auswahlverfahren zur Zulassung eines oder mehrerer Dienstleister in den beschränkbaren Bereichen nur unzureichend klar geregelt ist. Dies führt in der Praxis zu zahlreichen Rechtsstreitigkeiten und zu erheblicher Rechtsunsicherheit, was zu Lasten aller Beteiligten (Flughäfen, Airlines und Dienstleister) geht. Die Richtlinie enthält bisher nur ganz wenige materielle Vorgaben. Die Verfahren müssen insbesondere „sachgerecht, objektiv, transparent und nicht diskriminierend“ durchgeführt werden. Sofern eine Überarbeitung der Richtlinie erfolgt, sollte hiesigen Erachtens zwingend hier angesetzt werden und deutlich konkretere sowie rechtssicherere Verfahrensvorgaben in der Richtlinie gemacht werden. Man könnte sich hier ggf. an Regelungen der Kartellvergaberechtsrichtlinien (insbesondere der Sektoren- und Konzessionsrichtlinie) orientieren. Auch konkretere Sicherheits- , Qualitäts- und Arbeitsschutzvorgaben (verbunden mit konkreten Sanktionsmöglichkeiten bei Verstößen) in der Richtlinie wären aus Sicht des Flughafens München sinnvoll und wünschenswert.

feedback_msg_text: Since its inception in 2002, the RoHS Directive has become a global reference point for regulation of hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment (EEE). This has been effective and given the EU a competitive advantage. The worldwide impact of RoHS is significant and the undersigned associations consider that this should be considered in the roadmap for reviewing the Directive.  RoHS-type laws have been introduced or are currently being introduced in more than 40 jurisdictions outside the European Economic Area (EEA). These include China, India, the Eurasian Customs Union and the Gulf States. Sometimes RoHS is copied exactly. However, often it is not. For example, countries might introduce a completely different approach on the scope, exemptions and declaration of conformity. Each time a new “RoHS” law is proposed, industry has to establish a bi-lateral dialogue with the relevant local public authorities improving the knowledge and understanding of regulatory stakeholders based on experience with the framework legislation in the EEA. Industry continues to spend a lot of time and money to ensure alignment with EU RoHS as far as possible. This is crucial for the global and complex EEE supply chains.  The European Commission’s DG TRADE “Market Access” services have been helpful with draft laws that have been notified to the WTO and have raised concerns with the Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT) Committee as well as bi-laterally with the countries in question. A recent example was the draft legislation in the United Arab Emirates.  Each time the EU updates the legislation, for example, withdrawing, renewing or granting an exemption, adding a substance, this will have a domino effect on the rest of the world.   To this end, we urge the Commission to, at a minimum, consider dedicating more resources to a targeted outreach programme with third countries. The EU recently adopted a Regulation on responsible minerals supply chains and DG TRADE subsequently launched such outreach with the United States, China, India, United Arab Emirates, Colombia, Mexico, South Africa, Malaysia, Thailand and Canada.  We, the undersigned associations, endorse the Commission’s roadmap for the evaluation and the aim to review and improve the effectiveness, efficiency, relevance of the RoHS Directive, as well as coherence with other EU laws and policies. However, we feel this important global dimension is absent and should be incorporated into the Review. Feedback from: Various industry associations (274 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Hazardous substances in electrical/electronic equipment – evaluation of restrictions

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sir/Madam,  Thank for the opportunity to give feedback on the roadmap for the evaluation of the state subsidy rules for health and social services of general economic interest. Our organisation is a regional representation of nonprofit housing associations, working mainly in the field of social housing in the region of Amsterdam. We have a lot of experience with the application of state aid rules in the field of social housing since the implementation of regulations in 2010 and in 2015. In general we would like to underline the possibility for national and regional governments, and the related nongovernmental bodies, to establish their own proper measure to offer to citizens services of general economic interest such as health, social care, social housing, etc. Presently, we experience a lot of administrative burden from state aid rules, while market parties have never shown any interest in working for the sector of social housing. Current market pressure creates even a wider gap between de social housing sector and the commercial housing sector.  So in general, the evaluation is more than welcome to us and we hope it will present ideas and guidelines to the EU Commission to loosen up the rules.   For the road map we have the following suggestions. We welcome the questionnaire but would like to suggest that you employ other means of receiving input as well such as 1. open input in writing, statements, essays 2. public hearings, preferably in different member states 3. site visits to observe the working of de SGEI directives on state aid in situ  For the targeted questionnaire we strongly suggest that you not only target governments, national or regional or local, but also stakeholders in the field of health, social care and social housing, using their interlocuteurs such as national and regional representations.  We are able  to explain our input further,  greetings  Egbert de Vries Amsterdam federation of housing associations +31203460360 or +31654250220 dvries@afwc.nl
Initiative: State subsidy rules for health and social services of general economic interest (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: HOUSING EUROPE   Feedback on the EC evaluation of State subsidy rules for health and social services of general economic interest (complete feedback in attachment)  The 2012 SGEI Decision has provided a framework for public investment in the field of social housing. It is more than ever needed at a time when investment in public and social infrastructures is far below what would be needed.  Therefore it is crucial to maintain the existence of a specific framework for health and social services of general economic interest such as social housing.  However the Decision needs to be adapted to the evolution of housing needs and housing markets in the EU.  The housing crisis in the EU is still a harsh reality in cities. Urban areas in many member states are faced with pressured housing markets. In many cities, it has become difficult to find affordable housing at market prices.  Furthermore in some urban areas – for example Vienna - there is no sufficient supply of rental accomodation for bigger families - regardless of the rent level - since the market tends to provide only smaller apartments. Investors and other landlords offer dwellings in the private rental market, however the rental prices are often higher than many households can afford. There is an increase in  buy-to-let constructions in cities. This has a negative effect on both the affordability and the availability of housing.  Middle income households often cannot afford market priced housing in urban areas.  The increasing awareness of cities of the necessity to draft local housing policies, is further underpinned by the resolution that 30 major European cities signed stating that housing, especially social housing, is a clear issue of the Member States and their local authorities demanding the current EU-legislation to be changed in line with the principle of subsidiarity.  We welcomed the recognition of the the affordability crisis by the European Commission in the context of the European Semester.  The European Commission recently recommended to focus investment specifically on affordable housing in Ireland, Germany, Latvia, Luxemburg and Slovakia. While it was concluded that in the urban areas of the Netherlands, the private rental sector and the owner-occupied is often not affordable for middle-income households, despite reforms of the housing market that were introduced ten years ago. However until recently, there seemed to be an uncertainty about the room of manœuvre for relevant Member States authorities in the field of state aid to social housing. The Woonpunt and Woonlinie cases of 15 November 2018 acknowledges that the Commission has the power to act in case of a faulty SGEI definition. The case furthermore confirms that a clear definition of an SGEI is necessary to ensure compliance and reduce the risk of overcompensation. But it also says, that while there is an obligation for the relevant authorities to define a public need, those authorities can choose from a wide range of criteria (not only income levels) as long as it helps to define such public need. This clarification is important, since the wording of recital 11 refering to ‘disadvantaged citizens or socially less advantaged groups’ was often interepreted as an obligation to focus on low-income households. The ECJ ruling of 11/2018 reaffirms that that should not be the case. While it is important to ensure that SGEI is provided in relation to a clearly defined public need, the SGEI Decision (in line with Protocol 26 TFEU)  should clarify that this public need is to be defined by the relevant public authorities in a way that reflects the evolving local housing needs and  would cater for proportional support to housing and communities. This improved Decision is also necessary in order to bring the state aid rules in line with the European Pillar of Social Rights which states that « Access to social housing or housing assistance of good quality shall be provided for those in need". Feedback from: Housing Europe (137.6 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download
Initiative: State subsidy rules for health and social services of general economic interest (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: Après étude de la proposition d’évaluation, le FTDES exprime les demandes suivantes :  1 –Garanties sur l’indépendance de l’étude et détail du modèle d’évaluation utilisé. Nous demandons à ce que l’indépendance de l’étude soit assurée, dans la mesure où l’organisation la menant ne présente pas une idéologie notoirement néolibérale et soit dénuée de tout soupçon de conflit d’intérêt par ses financements ou la carrière professionnelle des consultants.  2 – Mettre au premier plan les conséquences économiques et sociales dans les pays concernés par les AA. Le cadre proposé évalue d’abord les impacts sur les flux commerciaux et financiers, alors que dans l’esprit de partenariat impliqué par l’AA ce sont les conséquences sur les conditions économiques et sociales des pays partenaires de l’UE qui devraient être le premier enjeu pour déterminer de leur succès ou non. La contribution des accords aux attentes des partenaires, notamment leur contribution à la croissance, à l’emploi et à l’accès au marché de l’UE devrait être identifiée. Il est essentiel que la Commission précise le modèle d’analyse qui sera utilisé afin qu’il prenne en compte l’emploi et les inégalités dans son mode de calcul.  3 – Insertion des États dans la division internationale du travail. L’évaluation devrait considérer la structuration économique des pays partenaires en termes de diversification et de solidité de leur économie, comme permise par l’Accord d’Association. Le risque de présenter une économie extravertie, ancrée dans des avantages comparatifs statiques et cantonnée par la division internationale du travail à des activités à faible valeur ajoutée et à faible qualification des emplois devrait être évalué. De plus, la destruction des activités nationales, notamment industrielles, doit aussi être évaluée.  4 – Détailler sur quoi portera les évaluations en termes sociaux, environnementaux et de droits humains. Si le cadre évoque une évaluation des conséquences sociales, environnementales et de droits humains, il se contente de mentionner ces sujets sans détailler quelles implications seront mesurées. En termes sociaux, il sera important de mesurer les conséquences sur le taux de chômage, sur la réduction des inégalités (sociales et territoriales), sur la réduction de la pauvreté. En termes environnementaux, les conséquences climatiques, de destruction de la biodiversité, de niveau de pollution, de respect de normes environnementales par les acteurs économiques devraient être nommées. Les droits humains doivent être évalués par rapport aux libertés fondamentales, individuelles et collectives, à la possibilité de se déplacer librement, et aux droits du travail notamment. De plus, ces aspects doivent être placés à importance supérieure aux conséquences économiques et commerciales, car le but affiché est le développement durable.  5 – Conséquences sur les budgets des États. La perte de recette financière dû à l’abaissement des droits de douane doit être mesuré et comparé aux potentielles recettes supplémentaires grâce à l’augmentation des flux. Les conséquences en termes de balance commerciale et de réserve des devises doivent aussi être évaluées.  6 – Évaluation de la coopération économique. Les Accords d’Association présentaient en plus des mesures de libéralisation du commerce une dimension partenariale de coopération économique qui pouvait notamment toucher à l’éducation et la formation professionnelle, à la coopération scientifique et au transfert de technologie, à l’environnement. Cette dimension est totalement absente du cadre de l’étude alors que c’est une dimension essentielle du partenariat. Il est nécessaire qu’elle soit ajoutée.   Conclusion Le cadre proposé pour cette évaluation n’est pas satisfaisant. Il se doit de garantir l’indépendance de l’étude, de mettre au premier plan les conséquences sociales et environnementales et de préciser le modèle et les sujets d’évaluation. Nous demandons donc une reformulation du projet.
Organisation: Forum Tunisien pour les Droits Economiques et Sociaux (FTDES)
Initiative: Evaluation of six Euro-Med FTAs

feedback_msg_text: Trade is a key component within the European Union and the Arab partnership; the Arab region represents 8.6% of total EU external trade. An ex-post evaluation of the EU’s free trade agreements with Arab partner countries particularly to highlight lessons learnt and identify challenges is welcome and much needed on the way to the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreements (DCFTAs). Civil society from the Arab Region, has long raised its concerns on the DCFTAs  and for overall EU trade policy. They have called for the EU-Arab partnership to ensure development-oriented trade and investment policies, through protecting policy space of developing countries and ensuring the integration of human rights and development considerations in decision-making, policy formulation, design, and implementation of these policies. With regard to purpose for the evaluation, we would like to note that the evaluation can only serve public interest, if it moves away from a traditional and limited consultation approach. The outcomes of the evaluation should be made available to the public and disseminated widely. Civil society should be considered as an important counterpart in the future discussions that will take place with partner countries. Civil society should be given more than a watch-dog role for monitoring; engaging in multi-stakeholder national dialogue that should be organized in a structured, transparent and inclusive approach. As noted by the ANND publication on  the Arab Region and Trade Liberalization Policies, “civil society no longer addresses trade issues in general terms; rather, it is involved in presenting alternatives, texts, proposals, plans, and strategies. In fact, CSOs want "in" on trade policy–they want more than to merely be listened to and politely shown the door when the time comes for serious decision making. What they are clearly seeking is rebalance, not simply to be heard.”  With regard to the issues that will be covered within the evaluation, critical issues that were already highlighted within the Sustainability Impact Assessment (SIA) undertaken for DCFTAs should be the starting point. For instance, the outcome of the Trade SIA for Tunisia pointed out that DCFTAs can breach human rights in practice, mainly at the level of economic and social rights. Therefore in addition to sectorial impacts, a key concern of the evaluation should be to assess in detail potential economic and social rights violations. On the other hand, the methodology used in the impact assessment should be revised. This is mainly because the Computable General Equilibrium (CGE) modelling used by the EU assumes labor mobility between sectors and full employment. Nevertheless, “the reliability of findings from CGE models is constrained by data limitations”.  Furthermore labor reality in partner countries does not align with CGE model assumptions; labor mobility between sectors is difficult, there is high unemployment and informal economy is a key challenge.  Therefore ex-post evaluation should not be bound by CGE modelling, with improved relevancy to context, integrating unemployment and informal labor realities in many of the partner countries. Last but not least with regard to the objectives set, intra-regional trade remains as the minor component of the ex-post evaluation, based on the assumption that the FTAs are bilateral. However, as HRVP Mogherini acknowledges “only greater regional integration can reduce the instability of the Mediterranean region and solve conflicts” . Enhancing regional integration, and intra-regional trade is key in this regard. Thus, FTAs assessment should be broad to evaluate the success and failures with regard to promotion of regionalism; should cover the level of integration in the global and regional economies; the support provided for collective regional production chains. This would be key to assess positive and negative development impacts over the regions’ geography. Feedback from: Arab NGO Network for Development (610.9 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Evaluation of six Euro-Med FTAs

feedback_msg_text: As an organization with more than two decades of experience in translating scientific discoveries into affordable, accessible public health solutions, IAVI strongly welcomes the EU’s commitment to the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership. The EDCTP has been a long-standing partner of IAVI, for advancing the development of HIV and TB vaccines, products that have been identified by both the WHO and the United Nations, through SDG3, as essential for ending the two most devastating epidemics of our time. The EDCTP has proved a powerful way of not only addressing African health challenges, but forging lasting links between scientists, academics and businesses in Europe, Africa and elsewhere.  To build on scientific progress achieved to date and apply the technologies, capacity and expertise to help advance the development of other urgent global health products, IAVI believes it is essential that the EU delivers a successor partnership which is bold, focused and well-funded. Specifically:  1. Focus: The successor partnership should retain its current focus on developing new products to fight poverty-related and neglected diseases in sub-Saharan Africa. One strength of EDCTP has been that it is closely focused on a specific area where other actors (including the private sector) have shown a limited willingness to intervene. The infectious diseases covered in the current EDCTP programme directly address the Sustainable Development Goals (goal 3: Ensuring healthy lives and promoting the well-being at all ages), and many of these diseases also impact the wellbeing of European Citizens (for example, HIV and TB).   2. Structure: Various options for the legal status of the new programme have been proposed, but IAVI believes that only an institutionalised partnership under Article 185 or 187 can provide the necessary stability and generate sufficient commitment from participating states. Crucially, an Article 187-based partnership would enable both private and public stakeholders to play a significant role. Utilizing broader funding and drawing in a wide base of support in this way can enable for example large scale and broadly collaborative programmes such as efficacy and licensure studies, and further enhance the impact that EDCTP is able to achieve.   3. Budget: Analyses have shown that EU investments in health R&D generate generous returns, including not only advances in public health, but new opportunities for European industry and reduced costs in other areas. Given this, IAVI calls on the Commission to double funding to €1.36 billion, while also securing increased contributions from other sources including private foundations and African states. We believe this target is ambitious but achievable, and commensurate with the scale of the challenge and the economic and societal benefits that can be achieved with new safe, effective, affordable and accessible health technologies.   4. Flexibility: Under the successor programme, it is essential to allow for greater flexibility so that innovative partnerships can be built on a truly global scale, drawing in expertise from Europe, Africa and elsewhere. Currently, there are strict geographic restrictions on who can participate in EU-funded research, limiting the ability of some organisations to engage. Increased flexibility can be achieved through an Article 187-based partnership, allowing EDCTP to fund projects and programmes jointly with others. Funding priorities should be set via a strategic agenda, with a portfolio approach taken to enable risk mitigation as research progresses. Translational research should be particularly supported, and funding recipients should have the flexibility to adjust their priorities in response to research outcomes. Only by doing this can we continue to reduce disease burden, promote European scientific excellence, and develop the health tools which the world so badly needs.
Initiative: EU-Africa Global Health Partnership (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: Context: As a global health nonprofit dedicated to accelerating product development for poverty-related diseases (PRDs) (i.e., malaria, tuberculosis, and neglected tropical diseases), BIO Ventures for Global Health (BVGH) applauds the European Commission’s commitment to increasing health security in sub-Saharan Africa and Europe and supports the launch of the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership as a follow-on program of the European and Developing Countries Clinical Trials Partnership (EDCTP). Biomedical advancements have improved the prevention, detection, and treatment of several devastating infectious diseases that burden sub-Saharan Africa. If we are to maintain and build upon such achievements, the global community must continue to support and drive forward research and development (R&D) for PRDs. Engaging in cross-sector, trans-national research collaborations is a well-recognized method to accelerate product development in a timely and cost-effective manner. The EU-Africa Global Health Partnership is an ideal successor to the EDCTP and will be well-positioned to foster research collaborations that accelerate product development while augmenting healthcare capacity in sub-Saharan Africa.  Disease Scope: BVGH recognizes the necessity of the EDCTP’s focus on PRDs, and we recommend that this focus be maintained by the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership. Within reason, BVGH further recommends that the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership’s disease scope be broadened to include non-communicable disease (NCD) and PRD co-morbidities. NCDs have been documented to increase the risk of certain infections, as well as result in poorer infectious disease treatment outcomes. Conversely, infectious diseases have been associated with increased risk of certain NCDs. Given the increasing incidence and prevalence of NCDs in sub-Saharan Africa, broadening the disease scope will help ensure that the data, treatments, and technologies created through the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership will have the greatest chance for wide and sustained impact.  Partnership Scope: Beyond disease scope, BVGH recommends that the European Commission consider increasing the geographic inclusivity of the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership so that non-EU and non-African entities can actively participate in and contribute to R&D and capacity building efforts targeting sub-Saharan Africa. This increased geographic inclusivity should encourage South-South and North-South-South collaborations that involve low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) from regions beyond sub-Saharan Africa. Such collaborations will encourage the sharing of best practices and experiences, which can spur novel ideas leading to innovative solutions applicable to health concerns across LMICs.   BVGH agrees with the European Commission’s recommendation to continue and expand engagement of private industry. As the recognized leaders in biomedical product R&D, pharmaceutical, biotechnology, and device companies will remain integral contributors to the development and distribution of products to combat PRDs.   Beyond the engagement of private industry, the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership should collaborate and align with the activities and strategies of other regional and global initiatives and organizations – such as the WIPO Re:Search consortium – and consider how to involve those initiatives and organizations in program planning and priority-setting. Such alignment will minimize the duplication of efforts.  Lastly, as the European Commission makes its final recommendations, BVGH strongly encourages the Commission to continue to involve the health authorities of sub-Saharan African countries in its program planning. These countries’ health leaders, in particular, should play a joint role in setting the disease scope of the EU-Africa Global Health Partnership.  BVGH lauds the EDCTP’s successes and the European Commission's commitment to improving global health.
Initiative: EU-Africa Global Health Partnership (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: The BEAM Alliance (Biotech companies from Europe innovating in Anti-Microbial resistance research) represents over 60 European SMEs that develop solutions to fight antimicrobial resistance on a European and national level. The BEAM members are collectively developing over 140 new, diversified R&D projects focused upon prevention, diagnosis and cure of microbial infections. The goal of the BEAM Alliance is to maintain and promote awareness of SME-driven innovation in the field and to support policymakers in understanding economic business models around antimicrobial resistance (AMR). The BEAM Alliance closely cooperates with all stakeholders dedicated to the fight against AMR. The BEAM Alliance is advocating for the specific SME needs with regards to investment in R&D to meet public health needs with new innovative diagnostics and treatments.   The BEAM Alliance welcomes the proposal from the Commission for an EU-Africa Global Health (GH) Partnership. EU investments in GH R&I have in the past delivered new treatments and accelerated vaccine research for several diseases; promoted the coordination and collaboration on GH R&I policies and programmes; and funded a new generation of global health researchers. The BEAM Alliance especially welcomes the proposal from the Commission to widen the mandate of the partnership to include health security and antimicrobial resistance. AMR is ranked as one of the World Health Organization’s top 10 threats to global health. The risk to send the world back to an era when life-threatening infectious diseases is real. AMR could kill 10 million people every year by 2050, more than diabetes, tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS combined. At health system level, there are numerous challenges in our attempt to implement effective and sustainable AMR programs in Africa. These challenges range from inadequate resources and weak supply chains, lack of human resources well trained in AMR surveillance treatment, and a poor or lack of commitment by facility management to embrace AMR as a healthcare issue. Although surveillance data are still scarce, the rapid spread of drug-resistant pathogens in Africa has been extensively documented, as summarized in a recent special issue of the African Journal of Laboratory Medicine Members of the BEAM Alliance together can bring many potential new antibiotic compounds or curative and preventive technologies to the development pipeline. Of these, a majority of target critical pathogens as mentioned by the WHO priority list and approximately 80% investigate new mechanisms of actions or new targets, thus representing a high diversity of innovative approaches to fight AMR, sometimes with very high cost-efficient profiles.  The new EU-Africa GH Partnership could facilitate bringing clinical research with these compounds to Africa, which is an essential step towards equitable global access to new antimicrobials, enforcing impacts on fundamental rights. This objective would under normal circumstances be very difficult to fulfill without such a partnership, especially for SMEs. The new EU-Africa GH Partnership could support local capacity building, especially in the field of AMR-related clinical development, pairing with the on-going surveillance effort (GLASS).    We hope that the proposed EU-Africa GH Partnership seeks active participation from the BEAM Alliance and its members.
Initiative: EU-Africa Global Health Partnership (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: The Global HIV Vaccine Enterprise (the Enterprise) welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the European Commission (EC) inception impact assessment (Ares (2019) 4972489).  The Enterprise, part of the International AIDS Society (IAS), aims to support stakeholders in Africa and globally to share knowledge, foster collaboration, and enable solutions towards the creation of effective partnerships, which are critical to the development of—and future access to—an HIV vaccine.  The Enterprise welcomes the European Union (EU) commitment to increase health security in sub-Saharan Africa and Europe, building on the current partnership between the EU, its Member States and sub-Saharan countries. These partnerships are essential for facilitating research, developing and improving health technologies, which in turn contributes to reducing the burden of infectious diseases.  The success of the European & Developing Countries Clinical Trials Partnership (EDCTP) 1 and 2 programmes in building and conducting clinical research in Africa is broadly recognized. Notably, the clinical evaluation of candidate HIV vaccines has been driven by partnerships that include and, in many cases, are led by African researchers.  Future partnerships must be flexible, responsive and involve African communities (research, civil society, political and others) from their inception. They will also have to appeal to the pharmaceutical industry since later stages of product development will require increased resources and increased participation by the private sector.  New partnerships should demonstrate their uniqueness, as well as how they complement existing global initiatives. They should be driven by a scientific agenda focusing on infectious diseases most relevant to sub-Saharan Africa and should be adapted to the problems they try to solve or the situations they aim to improve.  The selected partnership model should also provide for different funding schemes, not limited to large consortiums, that also support early-stage investigators in a sustainable way (such as through fellowships) and small partnerships that are able to quickly develop innovative solutions that can be tested or implemented by a larger consortium.  Schemes should avoid barriers to the creation of partnerships, especially geographical barriers; providing access to non-EU member applicants will broaden the pool of skills and resources available. Co-funding contribution should emphasise leveraging existing resources, skills, facilities and knowledge.  Selection criteria should: consider proposals that build on existing networks and structures; favour partnerships with specific, identifiable and measurable benefits for the countries and populations in which the programmatic action is conducted; include policy for data, reagents and knowledge sharing; plan and determine strategy going beyond innovation; ensure equal rights between partners; and consider implementation, health systems capacity and changes required for full benefit realization.  It is important to acknowledge that health innovation can also be hampered by discriminative and repressive laws, which are obstacles to full benefit realization. It is therefore essential to secure the political commitment of Members States to address structural and societal obstacles in order to deliver on the promises of health innovation.  Successful clinical research outcomes are only the beginning. Ensuring access will require greater involvement of country policy makers and support from the EC and other players.  The best option for future EU-Africa global health research partnerships should prioritize African leadership and ensure benefits are shared among all those involved in increasing health security in sub-Saharan Africa and beyond. Feedback from: Global HIV Vaccine Enterprise (225.8 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU-Africa Global Health Partnership (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: We support the continuation of Eurostars. The program is a helpful and important way for R&D-performing SMEs to cooperate internationally. Especially for small companies the program creates new jobs, new projects/products/services, and offers access to the market in an efficient way. We are currently participating in the EUROSTARS program and created three new fulltime jobs. We believe that adding Option 0. (funding also single organizations in addition to SME cooperation partners) would be an improvement of the existing program. Our recommendations for the future: - support also single organizations with innovative projects - reduce the administration and complexity of the processes. Reduce double reporting, make reporting easier and concentrate on results. - apply an outcome-based approach, concentrate on milestones and results / success in the project. Allow flexibility in the way participants work towards their goals - myEUREKA platform does not work properly, in our case we cannot work correctly with the platform for 17 months(!!) - follow-up programs would be important supports for innovative SMEs with successful outcome of a EUROSTARS programe to bring their results more efficiently to the market.
Initiative: European Partnership for innovative small and medium-sized enterprises (Horizon Europe programme)

feedback_msg_text: Le 22 novembre 2018 est parue au Journal Officiel de l’Union européenne une révision des Lignes Directrices relatives aux aides d’État dans le secteur de la pêche qui autorise le renouvellement des bateaux de pêche des régions ultrapériphériques (RUP) au moyen d’aides d’Etat, dans des conditions strictement définies.  Cette possibilité nouvelle accordée aux pêcheries des RUP est l’aboutissement de nombreuses années d’échanges entre les pêcheurs et les autorités européennes et il est indispensable de préserver cet acquis dans les Lignes Directrices post 2020, afin de pleinement répondre aux besoins exprimés par les acteurs de la pêche des RUP.  Cette évolution des Lignes Directrices a été justifiée par la Commission comme suit : « Compte tenu du statut particulier des régions ultrapériphériques en vertu de l’article 349 du traité et des principaux défis pour leur développement socio-économique en raison des facteurs spécifiques énumérés dans cet article, dans le cadre du suivi de la communication de la Commission sur un partenariat stratégique renouvelé et renforcé avec les régions ultrapériphériques de l’Union européenne du 24 octobre 2017 qui reconnaît le rôle de la pêche durable pour le développement de l’économie bleue de ces régions, et compte tenu de la contribution positive des aides à la PCP dans les régions ultrapériphériques, notamment la viabilité environnementale des activités de pêche, les retombées économiques, sociales et en matière d’emploi, et la sécurité de l’approvisionnement alimentaire […] »  La justification de cet amendement des Lignes Directrices se base, en outre, sur le discours du Président de la Commission Jean-Claude Juncker durant la Conférence des Présidents des RUP le 27 octobre 2017 à Cayenne : « Nous allons moderniser les secteurs traditionnels de la pêche et de l'agriculture, et nous allons faire en sorte que le soutien financier au renouvellement de la petite flotte de pêche soit repensé, y compris le régime des aides d'Etat appliqué aux secteurs de la pêche, parce que j'ai l'impression que les règles que nous appliquons sont des règles qui ne conviennent pas à vos régions. ».   Cette révision s’appuie également sur le déplacement du Directeur Général de la DG MARE, Joao Machado, à La Réunion les 3 et 4 mai 2018 qui est venu constater sur le terrain les besoins réels de renouvellement des bateaux de pêche. A cela s’ajoute une étude indépendante commandée par la Commission à un consortium de cabinets spécialisés qui a conclu à la nécessité de renouveler les flottes de pêche des RUP au moyen d’aides d’Etat.  Consécutivement à la modification des Lignes Directrices fin 2018, l’Etat français et les pêcheries des RUP françaises travaillent de manière opérationnelle à la mise en place de ces aides d’Etat afin qu’elles puissent être notifiées le plus rapidement possible à la Commission.  Dans ces conditions, il est indispensable que ce dispositif soit maintenu dans les Lignes Directrices post 2020, sans quoi cette avancée de fin 2018, tardive bien que significative, aurait finalement été privée d’effet utile.  Tous ces éléments justifient, selon nous, de préserver dans les futures Lignes Directrices cet acquis crucial accordé fin 2018, afin de pleinement répondre aux besoins exprimés par les acteurs de la pêche des RUP.
Organisation: Syndicat Maritime des Pêcheurs Professionnels de Mayotte
Initiative: State aid guidelines for fisheries – amendment
organisation_lower: syndicat maritime des pêcheurs professionnels de mayotte

feedback_msg_text: Réponse du CRPMEM Guyane à la consultation publique de la Commission européenne relative aux Aides d’Etat dans le secteur de la pêche et de l’aquaculture   Le 22 novembre 2018 est parue au Journal Officiel de l’Union européenne une révision des Lignes Directrices relatives aux aides d’État dans le secteur de la pêche qui autorise le renouvellement des bateaux de pêche des régions ultrapériphériques (RUP) au moyen d’aides d’Etat, dans des conditions strictement définies.    Cette possibilité nouvelle accordée aux pêcheries des RUP est l’aboutissement de nombreuses années d’échanges entre les pêcheurs et les autorités européennes et il est indispensable de préserver cet acquis dans les Lignes Directrices post 2020, afin de pleinement répondre aux besoins exprimés par les acteurs de la pêche des RUP, notamment en termes de meilleure répartition des navires entre la côte et le large pour une gestion durable de la ressource et pour occuper l’espace maritime face aux pilleurs de la pêche INN.   Cette évolution des Lignes Directrices a été justifiée par la Commission comme suit : « Compte tenu du statut particulier des régions ultrapériphériques en vertu de l’article 349 du traité et des principaux défis pour leur développement socio-économique en raison des facteurs spécifiques énumérés dans cet article, dans le cadre du suivi de la communication de la Commission sur un partenariat stratégique renouvelé et renforcé avec les régions ultrapériphériques de l’Union européenne du 24 octobre 2017 qui reconnaît le rôle de la pêche durable pour le développement de l’économie bleue de ces régions, et compte tenu de la contribution positive des aides à la PCP dans les régions ultrapériphériques, notamment la viabilité environnementale des activités de pêche, les retombées économiques, sociales et en matière d’emploi, et la sécurité de l’approvisionnement alimentaire […] »   La justification de cet amendement des Lignes Directrices se base, en outre, sur le discours du Président de la Commission Jean-Claude Juncker durant la Conférence des Présidents des RUP le 27 octobre 2017 à Cayenne où il a constaté la vétusté des navires crevettiers, le manque d’adaptation aux normes européennes des navires de pêche côtière et il l’absence d’infrastructures dédiées à la pêche dont les installations minimal en terme de réfrigération: « Nous allons moderniser les secteurs traditionnels de la pêche et de l'agriculture, et nous allons faire en sorte que le soutien financier au renouvellement de la petite flotte de pêche soit repensé, y compris le régime des aides d'Etat appliqué aux secteurs de la pêche, parce que j'ai l'impression que les règles que nous appliquons sont des règles qui ne conviennent pas à vos régions. ».    Cette révision s’appuie également sur le déplacement du Directeur Général de la DG MARE, Joao Machado, à La Réunion les 3 et 4 mai 2018 qui est venu constater sur le terrain les besoins réels de renouvellement des bateaux de pêche. A cela s’ajoute une étude indépendante commandée par la Commission à un consortium de cabinets spécialisés qui a conclu à la nécessité de renouveler les flottes de pêche des RUP au moyen d’aides d’Etat.   Consécutivement à la modification des Lignes Directrices fin 2018, l’Etat français et les pêcheries des RUP françaises travaillent de manière opérationnelle à la mise en place de ces aides d’Etat afin qu’elles puissent être notifiées le plus rapidement possible à la Commission.   Dans ces conditions, il est indispensable que ce dispositif soit maintenu dans les Lignes Directrices post 2020, sans quoi cette avancée de fin 2018, tardive bien que significative, aurait finalement été privée d’effet utile.   Tous ces éléments justifient, selon nous, de préserver dans les futures Lignes Directrices cet acquis crucial accordé fin 2018, afin de pleinement répondre aux besoins exprimés par les acteurs de la pêche des RUP.
Initiative: State aid guidelines for fisheries – amendment

feedback_msg_text: The European Tax Adviser Federation (ETAF) is a European umbrella organisation for more than 280.000 tax professionals from France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Romania and Hungary. ETAF thanks the Commission for the opportunity to comment on the above-mentioned roadmap. In ETAF’s view, the communication channels used by the European Commission to disseminate information on EU tax policy are sometimes lacking homogeneity which makes it difficult to find (or even be aware of) certain tools or products.  In particular, products like the Taxation Trends Report are powerful instruments that provide economic analyses and statistics on the tax revenues at EU level and on the tax systems of the 28 Member States (plus Iceland and Norway). The same can be said about the “Tax Policies in the EU survey”, the taxation papers drafted by the Commission and, more in general, the Taxes in Europe Database. However, we believe that these tools/products are not widely enough advertised by the main communication tools of the European Commission and DG TAXUD, like Twitter and LinkedIn. We would expect a more thorough and regular communication regarding these tools, that are not only limited to the day/week of presentation of these reports/papers/surveys, but more frequently in the course of the year. Furthermore, information about the status of Directives/Regulations proposed by the European Commission is sometimes hard to find. We believe that the communication tools used by the European institutions do not easily grant the access to information regarding the actual status of such proposals. For example, it would not be easy for someone who is not looking at EU tax law on a daily basis, to understand in which stage the proposals regarding the taxation of the digital economy are, without going back and forth from the DG TAXUD to the EU Council websites. It is even more complicated to figure out how many and which proposals of the “VAT Action Plan towards a single EU VAT area” have been approved. In general, we believe that the publication at regular intervals of a summary including the status of the main tax proposals would be beneficial for whoever is interested in understanding the work of the EU on tax policy. Finally, an example of how the communication tools can be used in a more effective manner is represented by this “Request for feedback” itself. There was no mention of this consultation in any of the main social media platforms used by the Commission. However, we noticed an increased presence of the European Commission on the main social networks, particularly when it comes to important topics such as taxation. We believe that initiatives like #AskMoscovici, where Commissioner Moscovici directly answered questions from users on Twitter have a positive impact in disseminating the work performed by the Commission, while bringing EU institutions closer to EU citizens.  Feedback from: European Tax Adviser Federation (ETAF) (106.7 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: EU tax policy – evaluation of communication channels

feedback_msg_text: INVESTIMENTI Importante prevedere, a determinate condizioni, l’acquisto di animali, in particolare capi bovini e suini da riproduzione. La percentuale massima dell’importo dei costi ammissibili, pari al 30 % per l’acquisto di animali da riproduzione  deve essere innalzata al 50%. Sempre per gli investimenti, è importante prevedere l’applicazione dei Costi standard. Inoltre, risulta importante maggiorazioni dell’intensità degli aiuti nel caso di Contratti di Filiera al fine di garantire un’integrazione di filiera a sostegno della tracciabilità delle produzioni “sostenibili”. I contratti di filiera sono stipulati tra aziende agricole/zootecniche ed aziende di trasformazione- distribuzione e si basano sulla copertura dei costi di produzione riconosciuti alle aziende agricole attraverso un prezzo minimo garantito, su una durata pluriennale e sul riconoscimento di un prezzo superiore rispetto alle quotazioni di mercato in grado di tutelare la sostenibilità sociale ed ambientale generata dalle produzioni. GESTIONE DEL RISCHIO Adeguamento della normativa sugli Aiuti di stato alle novità introdotte con Regolamento Omnibus circa: ‐ massimale del contributo pubblico che sale dal 65% al 70%.  ‐ soglia di applicazione degli interventi di gestione del rischio che scende dal 30% al 20% della perdita riscontrata (di prodotto o reddito a seconda dello strumento considerato, ovvero: polizze agevolate o Fondi mutualistici settoriali “IST settoriali”). CONSULENZA  Risulta importante fornire il contributo anche alle aziende agricole e prevedere l’innalzamento del contributo massimo concedibile, ad oggi pari a 1.500 € per consulenza. DIVERSIFICAZIONE PER LO SVILUPPO DI ATTIVITA’ EXTRA-AGRICOLE Prevedere, per tali aziende, l’innalzamento della soglia massima di 200 000 euro per gli aiuti «de minimis» che un’impresa unica può ricevere nell’arco di tre anni da uno Stato membro. TRASFORMAZIONE DEI PRODOTTI AGRICOLI La concessione degli aiuti nel settore della trasformazione e commercializzazione di prodotti agricoli devono essere subordinati alla presenza di un contratto di filiera tra industria ed agricoltori attraverso, ad esempio, l’attribuzione di premialità in termini di intensità dell’aiuto concedibile anche nelle misure investimenti. RISARCIMENTI DEI DANNI DA FAUNA SELVATICA Ad oggi, i risarcimenti derivanti dai danni da fauna selvatica sono assoggettati alla regola del de minimis che comporta il tetto dei 20.000/25.000 euro facilmente raggiungibile dall’agricoltore. Si ritiene pertanto che gli aiuti, dovrebbero poter essere considerati compatibili con il mercato interno al pari di quelli concessi per le calamità naturali ricollegandosi all’art. 107 del Trattato. Tale articolo, infatti, menziona oltre alle calamità naturali, “altri eventi eccezionali”. A tale fine, il reg. CE 702/2014 dovrebbe essere modificato in modo tale che i risarcimenti dei danni da fauna selvatica siano inseriti tra le categorie di aiuti esentate a priori dall’obbligo della notifica e dall’essere assoggettati alla regola del minimis in considerazione delle perdite economiche che sono da essi subite a causa di politiche di conservazione delle specie protette, i cui effetti sfuggono al controllo umano. Resta sempre la forte perplessità relativa al fatto che il risarcimento del danno sia condizionato all’obbligo da parte dell’agricoltore di adottare misure di prevenzione che hanno dei costi. SETTORE ZOOTECNICO Il Regolamento UE 702/2014 stabilisce all’art.27 “aiuti al settore zootecnico e aiuti per i capi morti” la compatibilità con il mercato interno e l’esenzione dall'obbligo di notifica di cui all'articolo 108, paragrafo 3, di diversi aiuti erogati in natura e non comportano pagamenti diretti ai beneficiari. In sede di revisione della normativa sugli Aiuti di Stato, è molto importante mantenere la possibilità, per gli Stati di finanziare le attività di miglioramento genetico mantenendo le percentuali previste ed innalzandole. Feedback from: Coldiretti (550 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Agriculture – simplified EU approval scheme (block exemption) for state subsidies (review)

feedback_msg_text: Pen & Tec Consulting welcomes the update of Regulations 1831/2003 (& 429/2008), the key documents for applicants preparing a dossier for application for authorisation of feed additives in the EU, together with the EFSA guidance documents. The risk assessment following these procedures should be transparent, as predictable as possible and should allow for innovation. In other words, these documents should clearly define which data are needed for the assessment an which data could be waived by providing a justification.   We understand that after the 12-week consultation (Q4 2017), the Feed Additive regulation will be updated, and this is anticipated at the moment for September 2018. However, by then EFSA will have already updated all the feed additive guidance documents, this procedure is underway and anticipated to finish by June 2018. In our opinion, the logical roadmap would be to first update the regulation and then start updating the EFSA guidance documents accordingly. EFSA guidance documents should not be more demanding than the EU regulations. If the requirements for building a feed additive dossier change too often, it makes it difficult for applicants to plan and generate a suitable dataset.
Initiative: Evaluation of the feed additives Regulation

feedback_msg_text: WWF SE welcomes the opportunity to comment on the public consultation on the Inception Impact Assessment. Working institutions are fundamental for sustainable development and to bring the Aarhus regulation into full compliance with the Aarhus convention would, besides safeguarding the integrity of European environmental law and access to justice in environmental matters throughout the EU, also contribute to its implementation of Agenda 2030.  Given the Aarhus Convention Compliance Committee’s findings of March 2017, it is difficult to agree with the roadmap that the legislation is “already complete”. To the contrary, amendment of the Aarhus Regulation is the only means available to the EU legislature to bring the EU into compliance with its international law obligations.   In line with the findings of the Compliance Committee, it would be important to open up the Aarhus review mechanism to members of the public beyond NGOs. The distinction between “NGO’s” and “members of the public” introduced by the Aarhus regulation (AR) [art. 10(1)] is untenable. First, no such distinction exists in the relevant AC provisions [cf. arts 9(3), 2(4), 2(5), 3(3), 3(9)]. Second, it is inconsistent with other principles of European law, such as equality before the law and the right to a good administration, which includes, inter alia, the “right of every person” – and not just ENGOs’ – “to be heard, before any individual measure which would affect him or her adversely” [cf. art. 20 and 41(2)(a) Charter of Fundamental Rights].  Especially given wide-spread ambition towards more integrated policy-making, it should also be possible to challenge administrative acts that are "relating" to the environment, not only acts "under" environmental law. “Environmental law” is a heuristic concept without clearly defined boundaries. The environmental impacts of non-strictly-environmental law must be recognized: without this recognition, the concept of “integration” of environmental protection requirements “into the definition and implementation of the Union’s policies and activities” [cf. 11 TFEU (ex 6 TEC)] becomes meaningless. “Relatedness” to the environment is a criterion which is more accurate, and amenable to administrative (and judicial) review.  The calls from Member States, The European Parliament and the EESC to comply with the findings of the ACCC and revise the Aarhus Regulation are encouraging. We hope the roadmap could be adapted to achieve such revision without the further delays extended assessments of how access to justice works may entail.
Initiative: EU implementation of the Aarhus Convention in the area of access to justice in environmental matters

feedback_msg_text: Call for a prompt amendment of the Aarhus Regulation  As per the findings of the  Aarhus Convention Compliance Committee (ACCC) the EU is unequivocally in violation of the Aarhus Convention due to not rendering its legal fora accessible to EU citizens in general.  The recommended solution to this predicament is to  either amend the Aarhus Regulation or to adopt new legislation to remedy this lacuna in the EU’s compliance with the Convention. The EU’s stance in respect of the ACCC’s decision has in fact caused a number of other State parties to express their strong reservations with regard to  such a position.  Due to current legislative limitations, NGOs across the EU have  been unable to successfully present claims for internal review of EU institutional acts in front of the CJEU, since they have consistently been denied standing under the Treaty (TFEU) with regard to complaints against actions of the EU institutions which were not directed specifically against them. This situation is clearly unacceptable, and in fact the ACCC has now declared a number of requirements  - contained in the Aarhus Regulation and being brought forward against NGOs as a barrier to proceeding further with their actions - as being  contrary to the spirit and substance of the Convention.  NT- FEE Malta therefore urges the EU to 1) avoid falling to the temptation of resorting to further delaying tactics by doing away with any suggested review of access to justice - this is not necessary since the position at law is already amply clear; 2) shoulder its legal and moral responsibilities and amend the Aarhus Regulation, given that, as a party to the Convention, the EU cannot continue to justify non-compliance with international law by invoking internal legislation; and 3) for all good intents and purposes at law, if any targeted consultations are to be held, to open up such planned consultations to the main groups exercising their rights under the Convention particularly  environmental NGOs, since the  current scope of such consultations, being limited to the ‘relevant public authorities and experts in the Member States’, is unduly and unreasonably limited given that neither of these groups qualifies as a prime user of the rights under the Convention.
Initiative: EU implementation of the Aarhus Convention in the area of access to justice in environmental matters

feedback_msg_text: In order to bring the EU law into compliance with its international obligations under the Aarhus Convention an amendment of the Aarhus Regulation is necessary. Members of the public have no standing under Art. 263 TFEU to challenge acts and omissions of EU institutions that are not addressed directly to them. Therefore, it is the Aarhus Regulation that remains for the public, but currently it is unduly restrictive. The Aarhus Compliance Committee have found that this fails to comply with the Convention. We think there is no need for further studies. The EU is party to the Aarhus Convention and in non-compliance. Real access to justice can only be granted by amending the Regulation.
Organisation: Women Engage for a Common Future
Initiative: EU implementation of the Aarhus Convention in the area of access to justice in environmental matters

feedback_msg_text: Betrifft Mehrwertsteuer Sehr geehrte Damen und Herrern,  wir sind verpflichtet nach europäischem Steuerrecht die Mehrwertsteuer im Staat des Transportbeginns abzuführen. Im onlinehandel ist dies kein problem, da Lieferort und Fiskalort identisch sind. Bei Transporten von dem Staat des Unternehmenssitz ist die Steuier in dem Land abnzuführen in dem das Unternehmen sich befindet und seinen Sitz hat. In Fällen, in denen der Transport in einem anderen EU-Staat beginnt und es sich um eine Privatperson handelt ist die dort gültige Mehrwertsteuer in dem Land abzuführen in dem der Transport beginnt. Da wir wie viele unserer Branche uns gelegentlich in nahezu allen Staaten der EU aufhalten und entsprechende Ladungen übernehmen, sind hier die Umsatzsteuern in den jeweiligen Staaten abzuführen. So haten wir unlängst 350 Euro an die Finanzbehörden zahlemn müssen. Die Kosten hierfür betragen 1.000 Euro u die Steuer zahlen zu können.  Gängige Paraxis ist, dass die Steuern entweder in EU-Staates des Unternehmens abgeführt werden - oder aber überhaupt nicht.  Das sollte aber nicht das Ziel eines freien Warenverkehrs sein.  Meiner Meinung nach, sollten die jeweiligen Steuern von den Staaten beigetrieben werden, in denen das Unternehmen ansässig ist.  Diese sollten über einen EU-Finanzausgleich abgeglichen werden. Nur dies führt dazu, dass die Umstazsteuer auch tatsächlich abgeführt werden - bzw. abgeführt werden können.  Insgesamt solte über die Mehrwertsteuer einmal nachgedacht werden. In EU-Staaten wird das Charge reverse Verfahren erfolgreich angewand. Hier spricht nichts dagegen, dass dieses ebenfalls im Binnenmarkt angewandt wird. Die Kosten des Geldverkehrs sinken und dem Betrug der Mehrwertsteuerrückerstattung aufgrund gefälschter Rechnungen wird Vorschub geleistet
Organisation: Bernhard Storck jr. GmbH Internationale Möbelspedition
Initiative: Evaluation of Administrative Cooperation in Direct Taxation
organisation_lower: bernhard storck jr. gmbh internationale möbelspedition

feedback_msg_text: Bonjour, il me semble important et urgent que la Commission Européenne se positionne fermement contre la déforestation des forêts primaires par les multinationales et propose des sanctions à hauteur des dégâts effectués. C'est important pour au moins 3 raisons : > sauvegarde de la biodiversité > réchauffement climatique > protection des populations spoliées Cordialement
Initiative: Deforestation and forest degradation – stepping up EU action

feedback_msg_text: We, Nature and Youth Sweden, welcome this initiative. Our organization has over seventy years of experience in environmental issues associated with deforestation and forest degradation.  We see that, time after time, companies’ desire to make profit triumphs over environmental rights with the consequences being loss of biodiversity and increasing numbers of endangered species. This is true not only for rainforest deforestation in South America but also for forests within Europe. Some forests have been saved in the last minute like the Ojnare forest in Sweden and the Bialowieza forest in Poland. Other areas are not so lucky; this very moment we have forests in the north of Sweden with very high natural values, habitats for many red listed and endangered species, that are planned to be cut down by the stately owned company Sveaskog, even though Sveaskog themselves have expressed the importance to save these forests before.  The biological diversity and the maintaining of our eco-systems must be prioritized, even here within Europe, deforestation and forest degradation is truly a global - and urgent - issue.   We see that it is necessary to take the following actions presented below, in order to ensure that EU reaches its currently prevailing climate objectives, such as the Convention of Biological Diversity.  - That at least 20% of the productive boreal forests, including all key biotopes, has to be excluded from forestry. First and foremost the western taiga (EU-code 9010 in the Habitat Directive), i.e. forests not affected by intense forestry like for example clearcutting, has to be protected. Secondly, areas around these forests and also forests with the potential to develop high natural values has to be protected and restored. The ability for species to spread between protected areas must be guaranteed. Great importance has to be attached to the continuity in the landscape. This should be done through increased use of ecological landscape planning. - Great emphasis must be put on ensuring the survival of endangered and/or red-listed species. - The forestry must become adapted to nature conservation and a greater share than today of the forests has to be exempted from commercial use. The forestry methods on all cultivated land must adapt to minimize negative impact on endangered species and their natural habitats. The use of clearcutting has to decrease. There should exist many different forestry methods that are adapted to the different forest-types’ natural processes and local prerequisites. Clearcutting-free forestry needs to develop and become the dominating forestry method. - Soil scarification, forest drainage, stump removal, forest fertilization, chemical control and planting of foreign (like the lodgepole pine, Pinus contorta) or genetically modified types of trees shall not occur.  - Surveys of red listed species must be mandatory before logging. This to be able to weigh biological values against values of wood biomass. In situations where small landowners are financially damaged because of this the EU could play an important role in helping them. - Forests should not be used to produce biofuels.  - Restoration of forests must increase. An example of restoration is “prescribed burns” in areas with boreal forests as forest fire is a natural disturbance in the taiga. - The proportion of deciduous trees in boreal forests has to increase. At least 20 % of the deciduous trees has to be saved at forestry activities. - We also, of course, acknowledge that our consumption within the EU contributes to the deforestation in other parts of the world. We need a global change in how we view our forests and our ecosystems all over the world - we need to go from viewing it as something purely financial to something crucial for our very survival on this planet.   Lovisa Roos (president), H Bergström, I Vahlström, F Weiser, S Rönnegård, A Helander, G Malmer et al.  Nature and Youth Sweden / Fältbiologerna
Initiative: Deforestation and forest degradation – stepping up EU action

feedback_msg_text: See also the attached file, please.   15/03/18         European Commission – Law – Have your say cf.  http://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/have-your-say_en  Item   Ex-post evaluation of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T)                                                                                             programme 2007-2013 cf.  http://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/initiatives/ares-2018-1023988_en  Our reference:   DECISION No 661/2010/EU OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 7 July 2010 on Union guidelines for the development of the trans-European transport                                                                                                                           network (recast) cf.  https://ec.europa.eu/inea/sites/inea/files/download/legal_framework/recast_decision.pdf    Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,  wir geben wie erbeten folgendes Feedback, via Internet:   Die Preliminairy Remarks der oben genannten Referenz besagen:  „(13) Authorisation for certain public and private projects likely to have a significant environmental impact should be granted only after prior assessment of that potential impact, in compliance with existing Union rules.“  und  „(14) Environmental protection requirements should be inte-­ grated into the definition and implementation of Union policy in the field of the trans-European networks in accordance with Article 11 of the Treaty on the Func­ tioning of the European Union. This entails the promotion as a priority of infrastructure for transport modes that cause less damage to the environment, namely rail transport, short sea shipping and inland waterways shipping.“  Section 2, Article 9b präzisiert:  „(b) The trans-European road network shall ...bypass the main urban centres on the routes identified by the network;“   Wir fassen dies zusammen wie folgt:  Der europäische Schwerlasttransit (heavy goods vehicle traffic) wie auch der inländische ist gehalten, die dafür ausgewiesenen TEN-Routen zu benutzen. Der  Ausbau bestehender Straßen, die nicht zum TEN gehören, als Transitstraßen durch nach europäischem Recht geschützte Naturgebiete erfüllt nicht die europäische Vorgabe. Das gilt auch dann, wenn Nicht-TEN-Routen zwar eine Abkürzung brächten, diese im europäischen Maßstab aber unbedeutend ist  z.B. 50 km.  Akuter Anlass unseres Feedback ist der in Planungsabschnitten voranschreitende vierspurige Ausbau der Bundesstraße 10, zwischen den Kreisstädten Pirmasens und Landau, quer durch das grenzüberschreitende UNESCO-Biosphärenreservat Pfälzerwald-Vosges du Nord. Vier Tunnels müssten zusätzliche Röhren erhalten auf einer bisher nur grob skizzierten Trasse. Die B10 ist keine TEN-Route; die weiter nördlich parallele A6, welche derzeit sechspurig ausgebaut wird, ist TEN-Route  Ebenfalls akut ist der offensichtlich geplante vierspurige Ausbau der Bundsstraße 9 zwischen dem frz. Lauterbourg (Dépt. Bas-Rhin) und der südpfälzischen Stadt Kandel quer durch den Bienwald (FFH- und VS-Gebiet, Naturschutzgroßprojekt). Die B9 ist nicht als TEN-Route ausgewiesen (auch nicht die nördliche A65 und die südliche frz. A35).  Wir weisen darauf hin, dass ein natur- und siedlungsverträglicher Ausbau der links-rheinischen, grenzüberschreitenden Bahnlinie nötig ist, um einen signifikanten Teil des Gütertransits per Bahn zu ermöglichen.  Bitte nutzen Sie Ihren Einfluss, damit Natur- und Landschaftsschutz im Sinne der TEN-Regelungen den Vorrang bekommen.   Mit freundlichen Grüßen,  i.A. Rudolf Ahrens-Botzong       Landgrafenstraße 51A       D 66996 Ludwigswinkel.   Dieser Sicht und Forderung schließen sich an:  NATURSCHUTZINITIATIVE e.V. (NI)  BI Bienwald e.V. BI Schützt den Pfälzerwald Feedback from: IG Landschaft Südwest , Verein gemäß §54 BGB (175.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Organisation: IG Landschaft Südwest , Verein gemäß §54 BGB
