feedback_msg_text: La politique des produits est à la base d'une économie circulaire. D'abord il faut réduire drastiquement les composants toxiques dans les produits, pour des raisons de santé pendant leur phase d'utilisation et pour pouvoir recycler la matière. Les produits contenant des toxiques doivent avoir soit un marquage soit un "passeport".  Ensuite, l'écoconception des produits doit mener à une durée de vie "illimitée" de certains produits qui sont durables, réparables, modulables etc.  Une économie de fonctionnalité, où le service rendu plutôt que la possession de l'objet est privilégié, doit être encouragée. L'éco-conception doit prendre en compte cette évolution sociétale, car elle mène à une intensification de l'usage. Cette hiérarchie peut être reformulée pour aboutir, d’ici à 50 ans, à un système de production et de consommation  fondé sur les trois principes suivants : § Zéro gaspillage des matières et des produits : les produits superflus ou pour lesquels une alternative plus durable existe ne sont plus mis sur le marché, tous les produits sont durables, déspécialisés, réparables, évolutifs et conçus avec un maximum de matériaux recyclés.  § Tout ce qui est produit est ré-employable, compostable ou recyclable en privilégiant un développement industriel de proximité. § Les composants toxiques sont réduits au strict minimum, et lorsque leur utilisation est indispensable ils sont facilement répérables (marquage). En fin de vie ces composants, ou les éléments les contenant, sont forcément isolés des autres matériaux.  VISION A 10/15 ANS + L’Union Européenne, comme les autres grandes régions économiques mondiales, importe une part infime de matières premières, uniquement celles qu’elle ne peut pas produire sur son sol et pour lesquelles le recyclage ne comble pas tous ses besoins, + L’UE n’exporte aucun déchet vers les autres grandes régions économiques mondiales Au niveau européen :  + Mise en place de modulations de la REP sur les équipements électriques et électroniques en fonction de la durée de vie, de la réparabilité, modularité, recyclabilité et de la toxicité des composants… + la garantie de longue durée est devenue la norme, l'économie de fonctionnalité se met en route (location etc.) + Mise en place de modulations de la REP sur les emballages en fonction de leur éco-conception et de leur recyclabilité + Développement de soutiens financiers des systèmes de consignes  en vue de la réutilisation des emballages  + La REP est généralisée à quasiment tous les produits, mis à part les organiques (alimentation). + Adoption d’une fiscalité européenne sur les déchets qui finance les politiques locales de prévention : TGAP suffisamment élevée pour inciter à la minimisation des déchets allant en stockage et incinération. + Une application volontaire de REACH a déjà nettement réduit les substances toxiques et éco-toxiques utilisées et produites. + Un marquage se met en route pour les produits contenant des composants toxiques. Pour réaliser cette vision, il faut agir sur la production et la consommation. On ne peut pas mettre toute la responsabilité des choix favorables à l'environnement sur le consommateur, car ceci est injuste et peu efficace. Il faut travailler surtout en amont sur la conception des produits. Les outils qui existent déjà, cités dans la feuille de route, peuvent être organisés autrement pour les baser sur des critères et des données communs. Ceci amènerait une cohérence et éviterait des redondances, réduisant le poids administratif pour les producteurs et les régulateurs. Ce "tronc commun" peut faire l'objet de consultations, évaluation des impacts etc. ce qui améliorerait et simplifierait la gouvernance. Il faudra définir les secteurs prioritaires pour élargir l'écoconception au-delà des produits concernant l'énergie. Il faut plus de transparence, avec un accès différentié à l'information obligatoirement fourni par le producteur pour les différents acteurs, avec un système européen harmonisé.
Initiative: Towards an EU Product Policy Framework contributing to the Circular Economy

feedback_msg_text: ChemSec welcomes the work the Commission is conducting on Circular Economy. However, we sense through the number of consultations and events that the important perspective of the progressive down stream users as well as the recyclers have not been given the appropriate space. Increasingly, downstream users are realising that hazardous substances mean exposing customers to a risk. Many companies see that trying to exclude hazardous substances completely from their products is the most profitable and smartest way going forward.  To be certain of the chemical content you need full material disclosure of the materials you use in production. Chemically progressive companies are usually very positive towards using recycled material, but only if it is free from hazardous substances.  That’s why recyclers must be able to show exactly what their secondary material contains. If they can’t manage that it will be tough for the industry to grow and make the circular economy successful. Simply relying on recyclers separating chemicals from recycled materials through some kind of new technical process will be extremely complicated and costly. Instead, the most rational solution would be to ensure that information on chemical content follows the product into the waste phase. Producer responsibility is crucial.   The cheapest and most efficient solution to reach a fully circular economy is by not accepting hazardous substances in products to start with. The success of the circular economy hinges on a strong REACH as well as specific product regulations included in the refit process. Tighter, more controlled chemicals legislation that builds on the precautionary principle can really skyrocket the circular economy into the future.  To summarise, there are five main principles that should be followed:  Avoid hazardous substances in products Traceability of chemical content Not all materials should be recycled Same standards for virgin and recycled material Speed up REACH and other chemicals regulations
Initiative: Towards an EU Product Policy Framework contributing to the Circular Economy

feedback_msg_text: Stanovisko Asociace producentů v audiovizi, z. s., (APA) k problematice boje proti nezákonnému obsahu online  APA vítá zvýšený zájem Evropské komise na problematice nezákonného obsahu online, neboť jedině stane-li se internet prostorem „svobody, bezpečnosti a práva“, bude lze dosáhnout konkurenceschopné unijní ekonomiky na globálním digitálním trhu legálních online služeb. Bez efektivních nástrojů zamezujících přesun organizovaného zločinu a černé ekonomiky zneužívající ztížené vymáhání práva na internetu (zejména v oblasti daňové, správní, či v oblasti práva duševního vlastnictví) do online prostředí nelze docílit úspěšného rozvoje legálních služeb.  V této souvislosti máme především za to, že nelze akceptovat názor, že různý druh nelegálního obsahu vyžaduje různou promptnost reakce či různou míru odpovědnosti poskytovatelů služeb informační společnosti (ISP). Je nerozhodné, zda je nelegální obsah povahy trestného činu proti majetku, bezpečnosti nebo mravnosti, pokaždé se bude jednat o trestnou činnost. Není tedy důvod jakéhosi „liberálnějšího“ zacházení u trestných činů na úseku práva duševního vlastnictví proti jiným trestným činům (např. mravnostním).  Jestliže je ISP schopen odstranit nelegální obsah u terorismu do hodiny, neexistuje žádný technický ani právní důvod, proč by měl být nelegální autorskoprávní obsah odstraňován několik hodin.  Nelze přitom určitý druh trestné činnosti (např. v oblasti duševního vlastnictví) bagatelizovat. Je nutné si uvědomit, že například porušování práv k duševnímu vlastnictví představuje dnes vítaný zdroj příjmů organizovaného zločinu a terorismu, jehož podíl se na aktivitách zločineckých skupin (přesunujících se čím dál více do prostředí online) zvyšuje. Je tomu tak z důvodu, že porušování práv duševního vlastnictví je velmi lukrativní trestná činnost s velmi malým rizikem odhalení a, v případě odhalení, se zanedbatelnými sankcemi. Jakákoli iniciativa bojující s nezákonným obsahem online proto nesmí být účelově omezovaná na specifické aspekty (jako terorismus), ale měla by být horizontální s cílem nastavit všeobecná pravidla odpovědnosti všech aktérů účastnících se aktivit online.  Pozornost se musí zaměřit zejména na stanovení jasné a jednoznačné odpovědnosti zprostředkovatelů nelegálního obsahu, jejichž klienti jsou často původci nelegálního obsahu, a to především v situaci, kdy je patrná vědomost zprostředkovatele o nelegálních aktivitách, jímž se propůjčuje a na nichž vydělává, včetně vědomosti nabyté z vlastních aktivit nebo získané z oznámení jiných osob (nikoli nezbytně nositele práv) a včetně případů tzv. úmyslného přehlížení (willful blindness) nelegálních aktivit (zahrnujících též odmítaní implementace technologických a jiných opatření zamezujících nahrávání či opětovného nahrávání nelegálního obsahu).  Za Asociaci producentů v audiovizi, z. s.,  Rudolf Leška, advokát v plné moci
Initiative: Measures to further improve the effectiveness of the fight against illegal content online

feedback_msg_text: The main objective of the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive (UWWTD) 91/271/EEC was to protect the environment from the adverse effects of waste water discharges from urban areas and certain industrial sectors. Now results are already observed on surface waters, however the legal context has changed and we think it's time to simplify wihtout giving up environnement goals. So we support such suggestions: - priorizing obligation of results (and not only obligation of means) - set national target in order to achieve good  status for surface, ground or coastal waters. - leaving the member state some room for manoeuvre, and a  large margin of judgement in the target.  - rationalizing the number of directives and targets  to ensure increased  efficiency,  - introducing a link between urban waste water directive and  framework directive on water,  - introducing new polluants only if it's necessary and by the water framework directive only,  - keeping in mind the notion of "excessively high cost ", giving a definition,  - keeping in mind effectiveness, in order to avoid  a succession of disputes between European Commission and states, without any results   -
Initiative: Evaluation of the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive 91/271/EEC (UWWTD)

feedback_msg_text: In the context of the Paris Agreement, the EU has set ambitious energy and climate change objectives to ensure that Europe relies on secure, affordable and climate-friendly energy. The cogeneration sector, represented by COGEN Europe, is committed to the creation of a resilient, decentralised and carbon neutral European energy system by 2050 with cogeneration as its backbone.  The EU’s 2030 climate and energy framework, currently taking shape, has re-affirmed Europe’s commitment to implementing energy efficiency first, to putting consumers at the centre and cementing Europe’s leadership in renewable energy, all while reducing CO2 and boosting competitiveness and growth.   Moving beyond 2030, EU’s Strategy for long-term EU greenhouse gas emissions reductions should:  - continue to put energy efficiency first by prioritising primary energy savings across the entire energy value chain and all energy sources;  - take an integrated approach to the energy system, promoting a mix of decarbonisation solutions across the key energy infrastructures (i.e. electricity, heating & cooling and gas). Europe’s long-term decarbonisation strategy should avoid taking a silo approach (e.g. decarbonisation through electrification alone), in order to deliver cost-effective carbon reductions for all energy consumers and the economy as a whole. In this respect, addressing ETS and non-ETS sector silos should also be prioritised to ensure that solutions like CHP are not disadvantaged, as they compete with less efficient generation under both ETS and non-ETS at the same time;  - account for the contribution of different energy consumers to the decarbonisation of the economy, empowering them to reduce CO2 at the lowest cost, while ensuring security of their heat and power supply  - pay special attention to the cost-effective decarbonisation of heat in buildings, SMEs and industry, accounting for the different ways in which heat is produced & consumed (e.g. different heat temperatures);  - develop a framework that fosters investment security for both solution providers and energy consumers. Retroactive changes to support schemes and in the regulatory frameworks at national levels have delayed in recent years important investments in CHP and other sustainable energy projects, aimed at improving the efficiency and reducing industry’s carbon intensity. A stable and predictable policy environment is needed to ensure that necessary investments are made proactively and as part of a comprehensive decarbonisation pathway.   Today cogeneration efficiently generates 11% of EU’s electricity and 15% of its heat, reducing CO2 by more than 200 million tons. Cogeneration is used in many key European industries (i.e. pulp and paper, alumina, chemicals, ceramics, glass, textiles, food & drink). Across Europe, 90 million European households enjoy local electricity and efficient heating & hot water thanks to cogeneration, via their district heating network. Over 100,000 active energy consumers like homes, hospitals and SMEs already self-generate their heat and power with on-site cogeneration, including via fuel cell micro-cogeneration.   By 2030, realising the cogeneration potential identified by Member States (equivalent to a doubling of generated electricity from CHP) would secure an additional reduction of 200-300 million tons of CO2 , contributing up to 23% of the 2030 GHG emissions target.   Beyond 2030, cogeneration should be prioritised for all thermal generation of heat and electricity, avoiding the waste of valuable resources. A doubling of cogeneration capacity in the EU energy mix by 2050 will complement the increasing share of intermittent renewable energy sources, thus ensuring system efficiency and reliability, as well as consumer empowerment.  Further details and references are available in the attached position.  Feedback from: COGEN Europe - The European Association for the Promotion of Cogeneration (345.8 KB - PDF - 6 pages) Download
Organisation: COGEN Europe - The European Association for the Promotion of Cogeneration
Initiative: Strategy for long-term EU greenhouse gas emissions reductions

feedback_msg_text: The Gas for Climate initiative is committed to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions in the EU energy system by 2050 and is convinced that renewable and low carbon gas will help to deliver this at lowest possible costs and maximum benefits for the European economy. Gas for Climate would like to present its study, published in February 2018 on www.gasforclimate2050.eu.   The Gas for Climate study, led by Ecofys, assesses the role of renewable gas used in existing gas infrastructure in a fully decarbonized EU energy system by 2050. The study concludes that (1) renewable gas (biomethane, hydrogen) can be scaled up very significantly, to more than 120 billion cubic metres of natural gas equivalent, and (2)using this gas in a smart combination with increasing quantities of renewable electricity can save about €140 billion per year up to 2050. Feedback from: Gas for Climate (2 MB - PDF - 57 pages) Download
Initiative: Strategy for long-term EU greenhouse gas emissions reductions

feedback_msg_text: Achieving further significant GHG reductions means a transformation of our entire society, with strong implications for the EU Chemical industry and the consumers it serves. For a successful transition, the EU will need buy-in from its citizens and it will need to inspire other regions of the world.  Cefic will actively participate in the stakeholder consultation process, providing constructive input. We would like to start with some preliminary comments following the publication of the Commission roadmap, describing the key principles that should underpin the Commission’s approach.  - Terminology  The EU Chemical industry strives to reduce its GHG emissions and to minimise “new” structure carbon (e.g. through recycling). We do not subscribe to such an objective as “decarbonising EU industrial production” and prefer talking about “low-carbon EU industrial production”. Carbon is and will remain an essential building block of our products and high performance materials. We turn carbon into actual value for society.  - The EU needs a coherent policy framework  Cefic welcomes the inclusion of “Reindustrialisation” as a key element of the Commission’s reflection. Climate ambition should go hand in hand with competitiveness and we would encourage the Commission to look at the impact on industrial value chains when assessing different emission reductions scenarios.  GHG emission reductions should remain the EU’s central objective and existing contradictions in the EU climate and energy framework must be addressed. For example, the decreasing limit on EU’s energy consumption towards 2030 could hamper industry’s ability to reduce GHG emissions through electrification of processes and CO₂ valorisation. These two options may, at least in the first phase, require more energy.  - Investors need a stable and innovation-friendly policy framework  The roadmap mentions a minimum objective of 40% GHG emissions by 2030. However, following the adoption of the Clean Energy Package, the Commission mentioned the possibility to increase the EU emissions reduction objective to 45%, with possible implications for the Phase IV ETS target. Whilst the Chemical industry is committed to the GHG reduction objectives, we need stable objectives in order to guide innovation and required investments, which are based on long-term cycles.  - Industrial GHG emissions must be tackled globally  EU industry emits around 7% of global fossil CO2 emissions from industrial combustion (EDGAR 2016). All parties to the Paris agreement should adopt serious commitments if they want to keep global temperature rise well below 2 degrees. The EU should maintain a competitive industry if it wants a successful transition that can inspire other global economies.  - The EU strategy must be based on solid and transparent assumptions  Models that reflect technology developments, will inform Commission scenarios and ultimately the long-term strategy. Policy choices must be based on solid data in order to be “future-proof” and avoid rectifications at a later stage. Stakeholders, including from industry, can provide useful insight about technology perspectives, challenges of far-reaching electrification, possible evolution of global markets etc. They must have easy access to the assumptions underlying different models and have the possibility to enter into a real and mutually enriching dialogue with Commission experts about those.  - Wide stakeholder consultation will be beneficial  Every EU citizen and every sector of the EU economy will be impacted by the low-carbon transition. Each of them should become an actor of the transition. Cefic welcomes the wide stakeholder consultation launched by the European Commission, which is also addressed to individuals. Cefic hopes that the responses will usefully inform Commission proposals.
Organisation: Cefic - The European Chemical Industry Council
Initiative: Strategy for long-term EU greenhouse gas emissions reductions
organisation_lower: cefic - the european chemical industry council

feedback_msg_text: GIE requests the Commission to fully consider the financial, environmental and social benefits provided by gases. The gas infrastructure can enable a robust decarbonised energy future whilst continuing to deliver EU energy and security needs.Gases and the gas infrastructure are essential elements of the EU energy system and contribute in the short to long term  to achieve energy and climate goals in very cost-efficient ways with optimal use of existing assets; inevitably as key guarantors of energy supply in the post-coal world. The gas infrastructure delivers natural gas as low-carbon fuel for power, heating and transportation and can accelerate emission reduction at low cost by replacing coal/lignite/oil used for electricity and heat production and fuels for heating, cooking and road/marine transport.This infrastructure is the turntable for future supply of decarbonised energy through the transportation/storage of renewable gases created by optimal utilisation of wind/solar power through sector coupling (co-generation & power-to-gas/liquids). Carbon capture technology for clean gases and CCS will further reduce emissions.Political goals should stimulate emissions reductions whilst addressing the needs of consumers in a socio-economic approach that balances cost with social, environmental and health needs. The development of the EU gas and electricity infrastructure should be planned in an interlinked approach;production/transport/storage of gases and electricity need to be better combined for lower carbon content and infrastructure cost.Operational management and planning of gas and electricity systems must therefore be further integrated to allow energy to move freely across borders and sectors. Provisions for network development plans and scenarios should be reviewed for feasibility of further integration at EU and national levels. Regulation should address cross-sector concepts and services including markets for green gases, integration with other industries (eg agriculture, waste, transportation) and integration between regulated and non-regulated entities.National and European regulatory frameworks and subsidy regimes should enable necessary and efficient investment in innovation and new technologies, not only focusing on established renewable sources. A fair assessment (incentivised technology-neutral approach based on maturity and purpose) of low carbon energy solutions is needed to harvest opportunities for innovative products and services. GIE believes that distinguishing between technologies and value creation is needed to ensure a transition for the entire EU system. Further alignment of regulatory approaches to projects, infrastructure ownership and innovation to facilitate decarbonised energy is needed. The gas industry can meet the challenges of modernising energy grids, storage and LNG facilities to achieve the energy transition whilst ensuring security of energy supply throughout. Therefore clear, positive signals from EU policy makers regarding the role of gas in the future energy mix are essential for continued investment in the gas sector. A flexible approach to regulation is required; the energy transition is accelerating and needs a significant step change in the short term. Opportunities exist in fostering new gas markets, products/services, carbon pricing, sector coupling and digitalisation.Coordinated national and regional approaches are essential to operate and develop a decarbonised EU energy system. Similarly it is important to cooperate beyond EU borders to capture wider network benefits.The EU should continue working towards the achievement of a well-interconnected, diversified and well-functioning internal gas market, where the situation in more developed markets is extended to other parts of Europe, to reach comparable levels of liquidity, diversification, competition and price convergence. EU institutions should ensure a level playing field to encourage primarily market-driven investments. Feedback from: Gas Infrastructure Europe (662.8 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Strategy for long-term EU greenhouse gas emissions reductions

feedback_msg_text: OceanCare considers the SEA Directive as a core piece of the EU environmental acquis. We especially welcome the fact that EIAs are now mandatory also for seismic surveys for oil and gas exploration. We believe that there is room for improvement since not all EU member states have issued an EIA or have missed doing a public consultation on such activities – especially in the Mediterranean Sea. As such the establishment of a compliance procedure might be useful.
Initiative: REFIT evaluation of the SEA Directive on Strategic Environmental Assessment

feedback_msg_text: Dear Sirs,  I would like to present comments on evaluation roadmap for fitness check on public reporting by companies, by the Polish Association of Listed Companies. The Association is an NGO representing ca. 270 companies listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange in Poland, representing ca. 85% of the market capitalization of WSE.  1. We welcome the fitness check with hope that it will bring added value to future regulations amendments and will lead to better, more coherent and harmonized regulation on public reporting.  2. The scope of fitness check presented in the evaluation roadmap doesn’t cover Market Abuse Regulation (Reg. EU 596/2014) which, in fact, influences the most how and what companies report. The most important factor implying short-termism is the requirement to publish instantly all the information which could be regarded by investors as important. Such a requirement is laid down in article 7 of MAR and entails a lot of problems for issuers (burdensome procedure and focus at shorter perspective) as well as for investors (higher market volatility). Hence, the company reporting is important not only at the level of periodical reports and the period of reporting, but also (or even first of all) at the level of current reports to the market. We will never be able to fight short-termism in case listed companies are required to publish information in ultra-short time. Relations between inside information and information contained in periodical (annual, interim) reports should be taken into consideration if the results of the fitness check are to be more long-term oriented and well balanced.  3. Digitalization of reporting is mentioned in the evaluation roadmap, but it is important to stress that such initiatives as ESEF (European Single Electronic Format) should be deeply evaluated within the fitness check before they are introduced as an obligation to public companies across the European Union.  4. The fitness check starts in Q1 2018, yet evaluation of the results of the Non-Financial Information Directive (Dir. 2014/95/EU) may be available no sooner than mid-2018, as the first months of 2018 is the period in which companies produce and publish their first non-financial report according to the provisions of the directive. As the Association we will have available data about listed companies’ compliance with the directive by the end of Q2 2018.  5. It is important that two factors are well taken into consideration in the fitness check: a) Burdens and costs of reporting regarding medium, small and micro enterprises. Reporting costs are generally fixed and are much more burdensome for smaller companies. b) Specifics of member states, especially members states having younger capital markets (as most CEE countries) which differ significantly from older, well established capital markets in the largest members states.  As an association representing listed companies we would like to take part in all stages of the fitness check and we are ready to provide the European Commission with all available data and information on the current influence of public reporting on companies, as well as with forecasts how regulation amendments may impact the companies and their stakeholders in future. We are also ready to take part in any conferences or consultation meetings planned in the fitness check process.  Yours sincerely,  Piotr Biernacki Vicepresident Polish Association of Listed Companies www.seg.org.pl
Initiative: Fitness check on public reporting by companies

feedback_msg_text: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, wir haben folgende Anmerkungen zur Roadmap zum Fitness check on public reporting by companies: A. Aus unserer Sicht ist es notwendig, Redundanzen in den Berichtspflichten abzubauen bzw. zu vermeiden. Dazu zwei Beispiele:  1. Die Meldepflicht von Finanzinstituten (FINREP) an Aufsichtsbehörden basiert auf einer anderen Taxonomie als dies zukünftig nach den Vorschlägen der European Security and Markets Authority (ESMA) im Rahmen des European Single Electronic Format (ESEF) für Jahresfinanzberichte der Fall sein wird. Hier besteht ein vermeidbarer Doppelaufwand für Finanzinstitute, die in zwei verschiedenen Taxonomien zu berichten haben.  2. Die Berichterstattung über die Solvabilität und Finanzlage (SFCR) von Versicherungsunternehmen nach Solvency II (2009/138/EG) enthält Berichtspflichten, die sich auch aus der Bilanzrichtlinie (2013/34/EU) ergeben. Viele der im SFCR geforderten Angaben – z.B. über Risikomanagement und Geschäftsverlauf bzw. wesentliche Geschäftsereignisse – sind jedoch detaillierter.  B. Speziell aus Sicht der kapitalmarktorientierten Versicherungsunternehmen ist der Zeitpunkt für den Fitness-Check darüber hinaus unglücklich gewählt, da sich diese aktuell mit der Implementierung des IFRS 17 Versicherungsverträge inkl. der derzeit laufenden Feldtests durch EFRAG befassen. Dies könnte eine Vielzahl von Versicherern daran hindern, an der bevorstehenden Konsultation teilzunehmen. Auf die Mitwirkung dieser Unternehmen kommt es jedoch wesentlich an, da sie vom Großteil der zu evaluierenden EU-Regelwerke betroffen sind.  Dessen ungeachtet erscheint der Einbezug der Bankbilanzrichtlinie (86/635/EWG) und der Versicherungsbilanzrichtlinie (91/674/EWG) in die Evaluierung grundsätzlich sinnvoll und sachgerecht. Jedoch sollten Anpassungen an diesen Regelwerken nicht dazu führen, dass IFRS-Vorgaben faktisch oder tatsächlich auch für bislang ausgenommene Finanzdienstleister zur Anwendung kommen. Wir regen an, Erfahrungen mit den IFRS abzuwarten und – darauf aufbauend – die möglichen Konsequenzen für diesen Richtlinien zu untersuchen. Auch erscheint uns eine Überprüfung der Definition der Unternehmen von öffentlichem Interesse (PiE) zielführend und angezeigt. C. Daneben bringen wir unsere Besorgnis zum Ausdruck, dass die IAS-Verordnung (EG) 1606/2002 zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt – d.h. vier Jahre nach der letzten Evaluierung – erneut einer Überprüfung unterzogen werden soll. Aus unserer Sicht ist nicht erkennbar, dass sich die Ansicht der Interessenträger diesbezüglich wesentlich geändert hat. Der Tenor der Rückmeldungen auf die öffentliche Konsultation im Jahr 2014 war, dass mit den IFRS erfolgreich eine gemeinsame Rechnungslegungssprache für die Kapitalmärkte geschaffen wurde und die Transparenz und die Vergleichbarkeit von Abschlüssen verbessert wird. Der Indossierungsprozess könne laut Abschlussbericht der EU-Kommission vom Juni 2015 (COM(2015) 301 final) zwar verbessert werden, z.B. mit dem Ziel der ganzheitlichen Beurteilung der Standards auch im Zusammenhang mit anderen Aspekten des EU-Rechts. Allerdings sei ein Übernahmeprozess weiterhin notwendig, auch wenn dieser vereinfacht werden könne.  In diesem Zusammenhang sehen wir insbesondere eine der im Abschlussbericht der High-Level-Expert Group on Sustainable Finance (HLEG) unterbreiteten Empfehlungen höchst kritisch: Die HLEG schlägt darin vor, die EU-Kommission mit erweiterten Kompetenzen auszustatten, welche es ihr ermöglichen, die vom IASB verabschiedeten IFRS im Zuge des Indossierungsprozesses zu modifizieren. Wir lehnen Eingriffe dieser Art kategorisch ab, da dadurch das Ziel weltweit einheitlicher Rechnungslegungsstandards gefährdet und am Ende obsolet würde. Dies ist weder im Interesse der Ersteller noch der Adressaten, wie die Evaluierung der IFRS aus dem Jahr 2014 deutlich gezeigt hat. Bei Rückfragen stehen wir Ihnen gerne zur Verfügung.  Prof. Dr. Andreas Barckow (Präsident)  Prof. Dr. Sven Morich (Exekutivdirektor)
Initiative: Fitness check on public reporting by companies

feedback_msg_text: Danish Agriculture and Food Council (DAFC) welcomes the opportunity to comment on EC Roadmap on transparancy and sustainability of the EU risk assessment model in the food chain and we would like to emphasize the following points:  DAFC share the analysis of the EC that challenges and areas of concern to EU Citizens in the EU food domain have shifted over time and the fact that these concerns should be addressed and dealt with.  It is important however to acknowledge that EU-food law since its inception is underpinned by sound principles e.g. on a transparent and independent risk assessment.  These principles are still true and ensure de facto a high level of protection for EU citizens and beyond. Therefore principles on must not be compromised in the legislative work lying ahead.  Acknowledging the initiatives to strenghten the transparency and independence which have been an on-going process since the birth of EFSAs it seems clear that more efforts must be done in this area. DAFC fully supports the EC Roadmap in further developing the risk communication, involving EU-citizens to actively participate in this development.   The long term scientific sustainability and capacity of EFSA must be ensured, and DAFC are happy to see that this extremly important task is at the core of the EC Roadmap. Efforts that enable EFSA to perform its duties involving even more scientific ollaboration from MS should be looked into and further developed.  According to the Road Map no full-fledged impact assessment will be carried out for this legislative initiative. DAFC suggests that an impact assessment must be performed nevertheless as is the case for new legislative proposals in general taking into account of course relevant work and findings already at hand in the REFIT-report on General Food Law.   DAFC will provide further input in the upcoming public consultation.
Initiative: Transparency and sustainability of the EU risk assessment model in the food chain

feedback_msg_text: Under 2015 framework for European cooperation in the youth field (2010-2018):  - Young people's human and social capital is one of Europe's greatest assets for the future. The European Union and its Member States need to invest in the potential that 90 million young Europeans represent in terms of skills, creativity and diversity.  - The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard. It has widened the gap between those with more and those with fewer opportunities. Some young people are increasingly excluded from social and civic life. Worse still, some are at risk of disengagement, marginalisation or even radicalisation.  Sport and physical activity contribute substantially to the wellbeing of European citizens. However, the level of physical activity is currently stagnating and even declining in some countries. The European Week of Sport (EWoS) is a response to this challenge. The lack of physical activity not only has a negative impact on society and people’s health, but also results in economic costs. In addition, sport has the potential to strengthen messages of tolerance and reinforce citizenship throughout Europe. Promoting the role of sport as a means of social inclusion will help address ongoing challenges in European society.  Giving the fact that young people represent 17,7% of the EU-28's population, EWoS is a great platform to include youth more active organisation and participation wise.   ENGSO Youth published Position Paper (2016) and Pink Paper (2017) documents where offers a set of recommendations on youth engagement in sport and in particular EWoS. It would not only equip youth with skills, creativity and diversity, but also include them into social and civic life.   EWoS reports from 2015 and 2016 show a great success. They both report over 22 000 implemented activities, more than 16 million active Europeans and only in 2016 #BeActive message potentially reached around 200 million people.  In addition, the EWoS 2015 report finds that 56% of key players consider engaging youth is the most important success factor.   Furthermore, #BeActive Challenge hooked young audience to post on social media. The EC used @EuropeanYouthEU Twitter account and European Youth Facebook profile.  The question that rises up is, if there is communication aiming at young people and priorities of the EWoS identify four areas where young workers are employed (education, workplace, sportclubs and fitness centres), why young people are not involved more in EWoS, in particular organisation wise? In case they are, there are no statistics on this.   To this end, ENGSO Youth offers recommendations in order to improve EWoS’ relevance, effectiveness, efficiency, EU added value and sustainability:  - Relevance – provide different roles (volunteering, traineeships, internships or paid stuff) in EWoS for young people especially young migrants, young people with disabilities, young unemployed people.  - Effectiveness – to provide reports on youth engagement in EWoS in order to contribute to wider sport policy context such as European cooperation in the youth field (2010-2018).  - Efficiency – engaging youth especially through different roles (volunteering, traineeships, internships or paid stuff) will not only achieve EWoS goals more efficiently, but will also equip young people with necessary skills and therefore, include in social and civic life.  - EU added value – offering different roles (volunteering, traineeship, internship or paid stuff) to youth and reporting on them during EWoS will contribute to Eurostat and Eurobarometer data for young people (e.g. Being young in Europe today; Special Eurobarometer on Sport and Physical Activity) and Europe 2020 strategy goals consequently. In particular to employment, poverty and social exclusion.
Initiative: SWD on the Evaluation of the European Week of Sport

feedback_msg_text: Utilitalia, the Italian association of water, energy and waste companies, welcomes the initiative to review the EU SME definition.  The Recommendation of the EU Commission 2003/361/EC, which excludes from SMEs the companies in which more than 25% of the capital or votes are controlled by public entities, have been almost totally received by the Italian legal system through the Ministry of Productive Activities decree of 18 April 2005 describing the “Criteria for identifying small and medium-sized enterprises". This approach, which is absolutely discriminatory for companies owned by local authorities, does not appear to be justified within the general Euro system principles, which, in fact, support the neutrality of European Union law in relation to the legal forms and the ownership structure of companies (art. 345 TFEU). It can therefore be stated that the current European definition of SMEs, unduly discriminates against publicly owned companies for the sole nature of their ownership structure. In Italy a significant proportion of companies owned by local authorities operating in public services of economic interest would fall within the definition of SMEs, with reference to the number of employees and annual turnover. Just as a result of these dimensional features, the above mentioned companies are facing the same challenges in terms of cost efficiency and access to the sources of financing of any other SME. Indeed, in virtue of the public nature of the owners, which in many cases, especially in Italy, are experiencing situations of economic and financial suffering, the companies involved often have more difficulties in accessing the financial market than the business organizations exclusively financed by private subjects. Additionally, the majority of the interested companies are characterized by a substantial undercapitalization, which further limits their attractiveness on the financial markets. This is a serious problem, especially in the context of the network services, which is characterized by strong investment needs. Nonetheless, publicly-owned companies are excluded from funding sources, made available to SMEs, both National and European. With specific reference to Italy, an example is the case of Law 232/2016, art. 1, subsection 55, which provides loans at preferential interest rates, for the purchase of new machinery, plant and equipment for the collection and weighing of waste by SMEs. It is clear that in the situation of the Italian market, where a large proportion of urban solid waste collection and disposal companies are owned exclusively (or almost) by local authorities, the exclusion above not only is not justified but is likely to have adverse effects on users, given the fact that companies will have to supply financial resources on the market at higher rates, resulting in higher tariffs. An additional tool to favor SMEs was introduced by Art. 1 of Law no. 208/2015 (Stability Law 2016), which set up, under paragraphs 199-202, the "Fund for credit to companies that are victims of missed payments". The Fund, through the granting of subsidized loans, maintains SMEs that are in a situation of potential liquidity crisis due to the lack of payments by debtor companies. This tool would be extremely useful for network service providers, which are particularly characterized by a high rate of the unpaid (especially in water services). Again, pursuant to Legislative Decree 102/2014, which regulates the obligations of energy audits in Italy, in compliance with the EU Energy Efficiency Directive 2012/27 / EU, SMEs are only encouraged but not obliged to carry out the audits, unlike all other companies, for which the obligation is binding. In view of the above, it is an opportunity to modify the current SMEs definition from Recommendation 2003/361 / EC, repealing art. 3, paragraph 4 of the Annex and expanding Whereas 13), so as to extend the definition of SMEs also to companies participated by public bodies.
Organisation: Utilitalia, Italian association of water, energy and waste companies
Initiative: Revision of the EU SME Definition
organisation_lower: utilitalia, italian association of water, energy and waste companies

feedback_msg_text: Despite all the efforts of the EC, there is no long-term solution to the basic issues and problems of rural development. Worse climatic conditions and the risk of doing business in agriculture. Further, the difference between rural and urban life is deepening. Farmers, as basic employers and job holders in rural areas, have only 40% of the average wage of other workers. This is a fundamental problem of farmers' generational change. Social and other living conditions in the country are constantly worsening and this is the reason why young people are leaving for cities. Under the European rules of the CAP, farmers become malpractice entrepreneurs. Verticals from primary production, fork, have eliminated most farmers from any influence on the quality and price of food, and on the share of profits from the final product.
Organisation: Chamber of Agricultural Advisors of the Czech Republic
Initiative: Summary of the ex-post evaluations of 2007-2013 rural development programmes

feedback_msg_text: How Pollinate Sweden can contribute to EU Pollinators Initiative: The association Swedish Bees/Svenska Bin (www.svenskabin.se) have since 2013 successfully built a platform for marketing and highlighting the Swedish beekeepers and Swedish honey.  Now Swedish Bees have also joined forces with “Pollinate Sweden/Pollinera Sverige”, with the mission to support all pollinators, wild bees and bumblebees as well as honeybees.  We are happy to realise that this national effort to raise awareness on pollination is coinciding with the launch of EU Pollinators Initiative by the European Commission. We are building a concept and a structure in Sweden that can easily be transferred to a European level and can be helpful to other countries that also want to join forces to protect and support local species of pollinators. Our position is that it is equally important to gather and share scientific expertise as well as experience and good practice performed by farmers, growers, forest- and landowners. We have made a call to gather as much knowledge as possible to solve the problem of declining insects and pollinating animals. At Pollinate Sweden’s first meeting there was a great acceptance among scientists and researchers from our universities as well as representatives from NGOs that the importance of pollinators must be communicated to the public so that protection of them can be part of common sense.   Pollinate Sweden will do this by:  – further contacting and recruiting professionals and laymen all over Sweden that are already engaged in issues regarding pollination   – engaging and collaborating with environmental and animal protection groups- and organizations who have extensive experience in communicating to the public  – processing and making all important activities and facts available to the public in a comprehensive and attractive way, for example on our homepage and in social media  – starting a national Pollination Week at the end of May, featuring World Bee Day 20 May and International Day of Biological Diversity 22 May   – creating a sponsor campaign for companies that want to take part in Pollinate Sweden and show their commitment during Pollination week  – collaborating in different projects like “Buzzing Parks” with Swedish Public Parks & Gardens and Swedish Bees  Background The founders of Pollinate Sweden have realised that despite the importance of pollination in food production, knowledge in Sweden is still too scarce on how to befriend pollinators. It is of greatest importance that politicians, farmers, food producers, constructor, landscape architects, gardeners, teachers and the public get to know how we can help the pollinators to survive in gardens, parks and fields.   Mission Our goal is that the full value of pollination shall be well known and the organisations, researchers, farmers, food producers and companies who engage in the issue will become rewarded and known for their achievements. Pollinate Sweden is funded by the National Apiculture Program in Sweden during 2017–18.  We want the question of pollination to become as important and well known as climate change, clean seas or food waste, just to mention some other areas where people have gathered together to create attention on an urgent matter.  Members of the network Swedish Bees / Svenska Bin which supports the beekeepers and honey producers in Sweden is one of the collaborators of Pollinate Sweden as well as WWF, Swedish Gardens, the Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Centre for Environmental and Climate Research/University of Lund, Swedish Beekeepers Association, the Swedish Professional Beekeepers, Bee Urban, Sigill Kvalitetssystem AB, Swedish Society for Nature Conservation, Urban Gardeners alliance and independent ecological farmers.  Pollinate Sweden is founded by Lotta Fabricius Kristiansen and Anna Lind Lind Lewin who have also been running the campaigns of the association Swedish Bees/Svenska Bin. Feedback from: Svenska Bin (64 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: EU Pollinators Initiative

feedback_msg_text: If vaccines are "unavoidable unsafe", as said in US Congress, it think it is just coomon sense to test the all children to find out who have the high risk of developing side effects after vaccinnations. Until we cannot test all the childern and provide safe vaccines for them, there cannot be any cooperation (parents cannot accept whatever vaccin is available on market).  The research concerning preventable diseases should concentrate on why the healthy people do not get the diseases. What are the good things that they are doing. Find the common thread and spread the news.
Initiative: Strengthened cooperation against vaccine preventable diseases

feedback_msg_text: NHF Sweden is sending you its feedback on the "Strengthened cooperation against vaccine preventable diseases" in the attached file. We also would like to have feedback from you on our attached document.  We are demanding:   • that studies on vaccines are carried through by independent researchers who are not associated with the pharmaceutical industry  • that health studies are conducted on vaccinated groups compared to completely unvaccinated groups that haven’t taken any vaccination of any kind  • that comparative studies should only be compared to placebo groups in which the subjects have received a completely neutral placebo and haven’t received any ingredients present in any form of vaccines  • that the effect is displayed in real power measurements and not in percent improvements compared to previous treatment  • that as soon as there is any emergency report on any vaccine, the vaccine must be withdrawn from the market and independent research must be carried out with regard to the safety of the vaccine (precautionary principle)  • the doctors receive a solid education about vaccination, risks and side effects  • that every doctor/vaccinator in the EU must always report any suspected adverse reaction (it does not need to be investigated and confirmed) which comes to its attention  • that when an injury has occurred within the timeline of a vaccination or when the injury is a known side-effect of the vaccine, it should always be regarded as a vaccination injury (this should be considered as part of the precautionary principle).  • that the European Union actively fights medical fascism and prohibits mandatory vaccination  •  that the European Union recognizes that neither the society nor science can rule over the individual and that the individual has the right to decide over his/her body  •  that the European Union recognizes and follows the European Convention on Human Rights, Article 14 (“Prohibition of discrimination. The enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in this Convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as sex, race, colour, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status” (which includes medical status) and that the European Union recognizes that no one can be forced to undergo any form of vaccination  • that the European Union recognizes and follows the right for everyones right to enjoy the highest attainable standard of physical and mental health according to the OHCHR. The freedoms include the right to control one’s health and body, including sexual and reproductive freedom, and the right to be free from interference, such as the right to be free from torture, non-consensual medical treatment and experimentation.    National Health Federation Sweden (NHF Sweden)  Mail: nhfsweden@gmail.com Feedback from: National Health Federation Sweden (385.2 KB - PDF - 12 pages) Download
Initiative: Strengthened cooperation against vaccine preventable diseases

feedback_msg_text: Geachte EP-ers, Vanuit NL perspectief is EU regulering op het ZZP dossier ons inziens dubbelop. In NL zijn al vele koepelorganisatie, de SER, diverse ministeries en belangenorganisaties bezig met de status van de zelfstandig ondernemer in fiscaal, sociaal en economisch opzicht. Het nieuw te vormen NL kabinet krijgt een aantal fisches op deze gebieden voorgelegd, waarvan de teneur in algemene zin neerkomt op een basisregulering van een sociaal vangnet (arbeidsongeschiktheidverzekering en pensioenopbouw) en eenduidige kwalificaties/criteria over ondernemerschap voor de sociale wetgeving en fiscale behandeling. Dit proces van consultaties, afstemmingen met het veld, politieke discussie heeft plaats in de typische NL verhoudingen, waarbij EU regels overbodig zijn.  VBIM is een beroepsorganisatie van ZZP-ers en DGA's in de adviesbranche met een bereik van ca. 23.000 zelfstandig ondernemers. Wij waren mede-initatiefnemers voor het ZZP pensioen, een 3e pijler regeling die in 2015 is ingegaan als eerste vangnet voorziening om zelfstandigen de gelegenheid te bieden een fiscaal gefaciliteerd en afgeschermd pensioenvermogen op te bouwen op vrijwillige basis. Sinds enige jaren trachten wij de Haagse politiek te overtuigen van het belang van een collectieve, niet verplichte, pensioenvoorziening voor DGA's en ZZP-er in de zgn 2e pijler, meer specifiek in de vorm van een PPI regeling die door flexibiliteit en transparantie bij uitstek geschikt is voor ondernemers  Wij zijn voorstander van een pensioenregeling via branche- en beroepsorganisaties, waarbij de leden verplicht zijn deel te nemen in de pensioenregeling. Echter er is geen verplichting om lid te worden van een branche- of beroepsorganisatie, het staat elke ondernemer vrij zijn werkzaamheden uit te oefenen op eigen wijze, voor eigen rekening en risico. Uiteraard hopen wij dat ondernemers die op professionele wijze werkzaam zijn zich willen aansluiten bij een beroepsorganisatie als zij voldoen aan de professionele criteria (en dus ook de aansluiting bij een AOV en pensioen collectief). In feite is dit een soort tweetraps-regeling: men blijft vrij om te kiezen, maar eenmaal lid van een beroepsorganisatie dan dient men te voldoen aan de criteria daarvan.   Wij kunnen ons voorstellen dat de wetgever aan ondernemers bepaalde fiscale faciliteiten toestaat indien men voldoet aan professionele criteria die het ondernemerschap op objectieve wijze ondersteunen.  Gaarne tot nadere toelichting bereid, met vriendelijke groet, Stg VBIM (www.vbim.nl)  Peter Jongmans, voorzitter.        Feedback from: stichting VBIM (71.5 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Access to Social Protection

feedback_msg_text: I appreciate the commission´s efforts to make the formal requirements as citizen-friendly as possible.  When we organised an ECI ourselves, we were overwhelmed by the technical hurdles which resulted in enormous additional work and financial problems, and so I warmly welcome all proposals for technical and organisational improvement.  We feel however that too little attention has been paid to the impact and political relevance of the ECI (follow-up), although during our campaign for an ECI, we repeatedly experienced that the lack of real political impact is a major issue for citizens. Plus, according to Article 11 of the Treaty, the ECI mainly aims at enabling citizens to concretely propose a legislation act to the commission - we therefore feel that the revision should aim at better integrate the ECI into the political process. ECI organisers must be confident about the impact of their work.  A    Better political impact for the ECI  - This could, for example, include the combination of an ECI with a consultation following the hearing in the EP, as a regular proceeding-. -  I would also recommend to amend the ECI regulation in such way that the EP as elected body has to deal with the initiative proposal.  -  We are however concerned about plannings to use the hearing in the EP for giving a platform to critics. However we strongly advise against this, as this would mean a major signal of disrespect to the organisers, who spend huge amounts of power, commitment, work hours and money on their ECI.   - Enhancing the admissibility would also improve the political relevance. Looking into the case of the ECI against TTIP, the European Court of Justice has already signalled that a wider approach regarding the admissibility is needed. Its demand could be met by a broader definition of admissible issues, or by partial admissions, or the transfer of the decision to a more neutral body.  B   Reducing the hurdles for organisers and signatories  A few comments on amendments for the organisers and signatories:  -   Firstly, if organisers can decide when exactly they start their collection of signatures once the ECI is accepted this will be a major improvement for them. -   Secondly, many people complained to us that they would have liked to sign our ECI but couldn´t, like British or Irish citizens living abroad. This discrimination urgently needs to be amended. (see the Treaty on discrimination of EU citizens)  - Thirdly, less personal data will result in much more approval of the ECI as such and a greater participation of the civil society. -   NGO-based online-platforms have already been developed. They are working well, supporting organisers with advisory support and as hosts for the signature collections. Many ECI organisers have been using the platforms or are planning to do so. Yet, these platforms are not mentioned in the roadmap or the consultation. We would therefore recommend to include them into the proposal for the revision of 211/2011 as they really are comfortable and trustworthy alternatives.
Organisation: Organiser of the ECI "30 km/h - making streets liveable"
Initiative: Revision of the European Citizens' Initiative

feedback_msg_text: Feedback for the proposal for the Roadmap - Ares(2021)223040: “It is reasonable to ensure that intra-Schengen travel restrictions and border checks do not complicate intra-Schengen travel of personnel engaged in the carriage of goods, especially drivers of trucks, freight trains, and barges, as well as pilots of freight planes”.   Context: Pan-European Network of Customs Practitioners (PEN-CP, Grant Agreement No 786773) is a 5-year EU Horizon 2020 funded security practitioner network project with 13 European customs administrations – both EU and non-EU – as active partners. The project is best described as a “novel customs innovation boosting network and online platform, offering valuable innovation intermediary services”.  We are well aware that border guards and police agencies are the main authorities responsible for conducting checks on passenger traffic at the internal borders in the Schengen area, when needs for such controls arise.  At the same time, given strong competence in trade facilitation, customs are in the position to provide recommendations and best practices going forward towards a stronger and more resilient Schengen Area. Customs realize that internal border controls in the Schengen area may slow traffic of goods inside the EU Customs Union and therefore undermine the functioning of the EU’s Single Market. New travel restrictions and border checks can increase waiting times at intra-Schengen borders, which come at a cost of time and money for companies and hurt time-critical business models. Most importantly, new travel restrictions should not disrupt the supply chains of critical industries and distribution of critical products, like medicines and protective equipment. And as the last point, cooperation with police and border guard authorities — especially in terms of exchange of information, intelligence, and experiences — can help the full law enforcement community to strengthen the resiliency of the Schengen Area.  Note: PEN-CP research partners would like to provide the feedback above for the proposal for the Roadmap - Ares(2021)223040. feedback_msg_text: The British vehicle rental and leasing sector (BVRLA) believes that the exemption has been most beneficial for the consumer and recommends that the regulation should be maintained but modernised because of technological advances. Without the exemption, there is a real risk that:  consumer choice could be limited, and the market become anti-competitive if our members lost the ‘end-user’ status afforded them by the regulation, as their ability to negotiate competitive prices for consumers would be removed  consumers could experience higher repair costs because main dealers charge significantly higher labour rates than their counterparts in the independent garage network  consumers could find vehicle parts more expensive because manufacturers will have a monopoly   consumers could experience severe vehicle downtimes as some main dealers have lengthy lead times  What’s working well  Lower cost of repairs for consumers The exemption has enabled the consumer to enjoy lower repair costs because independent garages charge significantly lower hourly labour rates than their counterparts in the main dealer network. Without the exemption, repair costs could rise due to ever increasing main dealer labour rates, as could the pricing for parts since manufacturers will have the monopoly again.  Consumer access to genuine OEM parts The exemption allows the consumer to access genuine OEMs parts supplied by dealers to independent garages, which helps to preserve warranties and ensure customer safety. Without the exemption, OEMs may restrict access to their parts supply, warranty and goodwill if a vehicle is not serviced within their main dealer network. Potentially, OEMs could withhold access to data required by our members, the independent network and third-party data sources such as Haynes Pro and Glasses.   Convenience and quick turnaround for consumers The exemption has enabled consumers to access quick vehicle repairs. Currently, lead times through the main dealer networks are long due to a lack of capacity. Our members have reported cases of some OEMs refusing breakdowns – add to this the ongoing difficulty main dealers are having with recruiting and training technicians. Having a choice to use independent garage networks has been helpful in reducing downtimes for consumers.  What’s not working so well  Technological advances make the exemption less powerful Advances in technology have made some vehicles quite complex. Some manufacturers are always adding in further technology to limit repairs to their own main dealer network, thus making the market anti-competitive. There is also a grey area with Hybrids and EVs in relation to the battery warranty. Some OEMs do not appear to recognise the servicing completed by independent repairers as being adequate to cover the warranty on these items.   Onerous requirements from OEMs Some OEMs have made it rather complex for an independent garage to confidently service or repair a vehicle to the exact standards requested by a manufacturer, meaning that any potential saving to the consumer is outweighed by the risk of an invalidated warranty. The requirements from OEMs seems to be getting more onerous with regards to the proof required in order for a warranty to be honoured (i.e. receipts for oil, service schedules etc.). A BVRLA member has reported cases where two OEMs have refused goodwill due to non-dealer service history, even on items such as entertainment units which do not form part of the servicing.    Unwillingness of OEMs to share data Recent experience with the introduction of WLTP has shown OEMs are at times unwilling to share vehicle CO₂ data, reinforcing the need for regulation such as the exemption. With technology advancing at such a rapid pace, unrestricted access to vehicle data is a necessity which could prove difficult in the absence of the exemption. feedback_msg_text: We provide feedback to you on behalf of the HERA project consortium (24 partners from environment, climate and health institutions across Europe covering both research institutes and health safety agencies from 15 EU countries and the World Health Organization). The consortium works through an EU Horizon 2020 project, “Health and Environment Research Agenda” (HERA) (https://www.heraresearcheu.eu), on identifying pressing research needs and knowledge gaps that EU strives to address by 2030 to fully implement its policies and improve status of all components in the health-environment and climate nexus.  We welcomed the adoption of the EU Green Deal in December 2019 and followed with interest the priority topics addressing the effects of climate change and of environmental deterioration on both human and ecosystem health through the announced Eliminating Pollution priority. We also noted that the upcoming research and innovation framework programme “Horizon Europe” included five mission areas and that the Health Cluster includes a sub section on “living and working in a health-promoting environment”, but clusters on environment, food and bioeconomy lack a health dimension despite its great relevance for action taking in those clusters. Considering that the Environment Cluster is thematically closer to the Zero Pollution Ambition affecting not just environment status but also health, omission of the health dimension in the research projects supporting action taking in the Environment Cluster is unfortunate.  Further, the major point that we would like to provide into the feedback on the Roadmap is that the “Zero pollution” action plan would need a research component, which would be essential and integral to an optimal sustainable effort to protect EU citizens. This involves environmental health research. Closing research gaps can improve the knowledge base and also help in identifying the impacts of the implementation of economic activities and policies including technological developments on ecosystems, human populations, and on society. While we agree there is a large EU-wide evidence from various monitoring activities on the levels and trends of contaminants in the air, water and soil, we believe that to remediate the environment and minimize the incidence of physical and mental diseases cases caused by pollution in Europe, additional research outcomes, including ex-post evaluations and analysis of measures, will be critical.  Indeed, in HERA stakeholder consultations, assessing and understanding the health impacts of environmental (external) exposure were among the themes most frequently mentioned as requiring further research support. We are hereby providing references to more detailed sections of the interim research agenda document (https://www.heraresearcheu.eu/hera-2030-agenda) that explain the objectives but also identify individual research needs stemming from consultations with EU stakeholders - air contamination and clean air policies (RG 2.7, page 38-39 and RG 3.2, p. 42-43), water contamination (RG 2.5, p.36-37), soil (RG 2.6, p 37- 38). In addition, zero pollution is also relevant for wastes (RG 2.8, p. 39) and effects of digitalization (RG 3.4, p. 44).  Complementing the upcoming Action Plan implementing the Zero Pollution ambition target with Innovative and creative research strategy will not not preclude immediate protective action but it will enable robust and sustainable protection of our environment and citizens. Such research strategy that aims to better understand the impact of environmental and climate stressors on health and the optimal mechanisms for the implementation of protective measures and follow-up on results with ex-post evaluations and analysis will accelerate achievement of the zero pollution ambitions in the EU.  Detailed comments provided on behalf of the HERA project consortium can be found in the attached document. feedback_msg_text: Response to roadmap for sustainable guidelines for EU fish farms (aquaculture)  Compassion in World Farming welcomes the Commission initiative to promote more sustainable practices in EU aquaculture.  As a matter of priority, we ask the Commission to include fish welfare as a core objective in the strategic guidelines. At present, welfare gets a minor mention. Compassion in World Farming’s top priorities related to fish welfare for the sustainable aquaculture guidelines are:  • introduction of new species-specific legislation for farmed fish during rearing, transport, and slaughter  • implementation of pre-slaughter stunning and humane slaughter methods for farmed fish  • mandatory labelling of seafood products including method of production, and  • to phase out of use of purpose-caught wild-caught fish to feed farmed fish • to develop a research strategy to improve fish welfare. For example, one or more fish references centres should be set up to gather information from research and industry to assess Best Practice recommendations, continue to detect research gaps and to plan training programs.   We look for more stronger sustainable commitments from the Commission to address the main environmental issues that the aquaculture sector currently faces. For example, the use of wild-caught fish in farmed fish feeds, fish escapes and lethal predator control. Blue growth should be about quality, not quantity. Expansion should be restricted to extensive production systems which provide environmental services. A key aspect of the aquaculture strategy is to convince consumers that EU farmed fish is of high quality, but it cannot be achieved if the welfare and environmental standards of much of the EU fish farming are shockingly low.
Initiative: EU fish farms (aquaculture) – updated guidelines

feedback_msg_text: The EU aquaculture sector contributes to food security and provides high quality standards, welfare and environmental protection, as well as jobs and growth in EU coastal and inland areas that produce aquaculture products.  Aquaculture plays a key role in providing sustainable food as part of the Farm to Fork Strategy under the overarching European Green Deal. Fish farmers have made concrete progress in the reduction of emissions and in the transition to more sustainable practices, and the use of cutting-edge technology in pond aquaculture is a good example of circular economy. Nevertheless, if they are to continue down this path, their efforts need to be recognised and enough flexibility guaranteed to allow for a more efficient use of natural resources whilst providing food security. In addition, the Farm to Fork Strategy for sustainable food must strike a balance between all three pillars of sustainability (economic, environmental and social). This is how the contribution of farmers, in particular that of fish farmers, to more sustainable food systems can be acknowledged in all its facets.  Internationally, aquaculture is one of the fastest growing food-producing sectors. However, growth in the EU has been slow and is even stagnating for some types of production. EU aquaculture only represents 1.2% of global production and 2% of global value. Even though demand for aquaculture products has been on the rise in recent years in the EU, most of this demand is covered by imported products (70%). Therefore, we see this as a perfect opportunity for the EU aquaculture sector to grow, since European consumers are more interested in productions methods and the EU aquaculture sector complies with the highest production standards.   While EU aquaculture complies with strict environmental, animal health and consumer protection standards, consumers are not always fully informed about these and the market does not properly acknowledge fish farmers’ sustainability efforts. Therefore, it is now essential to find ways to communicate this to consumers in order to guarantee a sustainable development of EU aquaculture. In order to unlock the potential of EU aquaculture, the future strategic guidelines should address all the points that are included in our attached contribution – Fish(19)9954.   However, fish farmers are currently facing an increasingly difficult situation due to the emergency resulting from the COVID-19 outbreak. Out-of-home consumption has dramatically decreased, due to food service closures, such as hotels, restaurants and catering. This is causing a sharp reduction of cash-flow for fish farms, which is further exacerbated by payment delays due to client liquidity issues, more expensive transport and increasing production costs due to the extended production cycles on the farms. Therefore, the aquaculture markets are experiencing a dramatic downturn, as well as difficulties with receiving supplies, distributing final products and access to seasonal workers. All these difficulties will also have a significant impact on the sector's economic returns.  Therefore, we believe that the Commission must focus as a matter of priority on solving this market crisis by alleviating the difficulties faced by the sector and maintaining a single market that functions properly. feedback_msg_text: Desde APAEMA, la asociación de productores ecológicos de Mallorca, valoramos positivamente la iniciativa de desarrollar un plan de acción para el desarrollo de la agricultura ecológica en Europa.   No obstante, creemos que ante los retos a que se enfrenta la sociedad (crisis pandémica, emergencia climática, desigualdades sociales crecientes, pérdida de recursos naturales, inestabilidad geopolítica, etc.) es imprescindible apostar por la producción agraria ecológica de una forma ambiciosa, valiente, para que este tipo de agricultura no sea una más, sino el objetivo a conseguir en un periodo razonable para afrontar estas retos globales a tiempo.  El nuevo plan de acción debe tener en cuenta las particularidades de cada territorio, sus potencialidades y debilidades, para que las políticas de fomento de la producción ecológica y el consumo ecológico sean implementadas y desarrolladas a ritmos parecidos en todos ellos. Para eso, proponemos que cada estado miembro tenga que redactar su propio plan, así como cada región. Esto tendría que significar también que las administraciones estatales, regionales e incluso locale tengan que implicarse para llegar a los objetivos marcados.  Creemos que un plan de acción sensato tendría que ir asociado a unos presupuestos específicos, suficientes y coherentes, que permitan su implementación a todos los niveles. Estos deberían dar cabida a ayudas públicas para la promoción de la agricultura ecológica, entre productores y consumidores, ayudas a la reconversión de explotaciones agrarias e industrias hacía la producción eco, ayudas a compensar los costes de control y certificación de pequeños productores, y ayudas al mantenimiento de la producción ecológica que compensen la internalización de costes y los beneficios públicos ambientales y sociales generados. Son imprescindibles también las ayudas a la creación de sistema alimentarios territorializados, infraestructuras colectivas o cooperativas, iniciativas que permitan un cambio de escala en la producción, transformación, comercialización y consumo en determinados territorios europeos. Hay que tener en cuenta, además, la importancia de la innovación, la investigación asociada y el desarrollo de nuevos métodos y tecnologías en agricultura ecológica. Mención especial a la necesidad de ayudar a mantener la ganadería extensiva frente a la caída permanente de la demanda de carne de calidad, por su importancia en el ciclo de nutrientes y energía en las fincas y reducir el coste territorial de la agricultura eco.
Initiative: Organic farming - action plan for the development of EU organic production

feedback_msg_text: Desde la SEAE-Sociedad Española de Agricultura Ecológica- pedimos un Plan de acción para el desarrollo de la producción ecológica de la UE atrevido y coherente con los objetivos de las estrategias de La Granja a la Mesa y de Biodiversidad, que implique a las administraciones de todos los niveles para asegurar coherencia de las políticas públicas con el Plan y que cuente con el sector ecológico también a todos los niveles para la definición y aplicación del mismo.  Solicitamos que se definan objetivos cuantitativos específicos y se establezca un calendario para su ejecución, que se asigne presupuesto específico y se pida a los Estados miembros que desarrollen sus propios Planes de Acción, a nivel estatal o regional, en colaboración con el sector ecológico del territorio y con la implicación de las administraciones a todos los niveles, así como de la sociedad civil y agentes del sistema alimentario local. Comisión y Estados miembros deberían acordar unos mínimos obligatorios progresivos de inclusión de productos ecológicos en las Compras Públicas Verdes, en especial en centros educativos, residencias de ancianos y hospitales, hasta llegar a un mínimo de un 25% en 2030. Para que producción y consumo crezcan a la vez, se necesitan políticas y ayudas de promoción e información a los consumidores sobre los beneficios de la producción ecológica para el medio ambiente y el bienestar animal, y para facilitar la conexión entre productores/as y consumidores/as, así como entre el campo y la ciudad. Y, a la vez, resulta imprescindible favorecer la producción y disponibilidad de todos los insumos necesarios para el crecimiento de la producción ecológica. Es necesario poner en valor y facilitar el acceso a toda la información y conocimiento generada por el sector ecológico, creando redes del conocimiento y buenos servicios de asesoramiento (libres de conflictos de intereses) y favoreciendo las redes de socialización e intercambio de conocimiento a nivel europeo y la transferencia horizontal del conocimiento campesino/a a campesino/a. Los presupuestos de investigación e innovación dedicados a la producción ecológica deben estar en consonancia con el objetivo de superficie ecológica plantead y dedicar el 25% del presupuesto de I + i agraria a la generación y gestión del conocimiento e innovación ecológicos. Es fundamental que el Plan de Acción cuente con un seguimiento y evaluación desde el principio, supervisándose su implementación por parte de la Comisión y realizándose una revisión intermedia para poder identificar las deficiencias y solucionar sus causas o reorientar las actuaciones en caso necesario. Los Planes Estratégicos de PAC, deberán contemplar las necesidades del sector ecológico y establecer un objetivo estatal en colaboración con el sector ecológico del país y la Comisión y definir una estrategia, incluyendo, como mínimo, ayudas a la conversión, mantenimiento, control y fomento de la producción ecológica. Para afrontar el problema de la omnipresencia de residuos de plaguicidas en todo el medio (viéndose doblemente perjudicado el sector ecológico) debería aumentarse el presupuesto destinado a investigación e innovación en métodos agrarios ecológicos para encontrar soluciones I + D a este problema. A su vez, deberían simplificarse el sistema de registro de productos fitosanitarios aptos para la producción ecológica, tales como las sustancias naturales y asegurar una mayor armonización en el manejo de las detecciones de residuos de plaguicidas e investigar las posibilidades de imposición de responsabilidad a los productores/as y usuarios/as de plaguicidas, sobre la base del principio de quien contamina paga y considerar la opción de exigir responsabilidades en las casos de contaminación ambiental por productos fitosanitarios o incluso contemplar la prohibición de la comercialización y uso de estas sustancias.
