feedback_msg_text: Light for the World welcomes the publication of the roadmap for a comprehensive strategy on the rights of the child as an opportunity for the EU to champion children's rights, including children with disabilities, both within the EU and across the world.   The new comprehensive strategy must leave no child behind: it should be relevant for all children in Europe and globally. Our contribution focuses on EU external action, the importance of the strategy being disability-inclusive and having an intersectional approach with strong references to the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) as well as the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC), and on ensuring coherence with other key EU strategies including the EU Disability Rights Agenda/Strategy beyond 2020.   One in ten children is a child with a disability - there is an estimated 93 million to 150 million children living with a moderate or severe disability worldwide.  Children with disabilities often face multiple and intersectional discrimination due to their disability status and continue to be at a disadvantage in most spheres of society and development, which will follow and impact them well into adulthood. Gender inequality further compounds exclusion meaning that the impact of disability is often even more pronounced for girls with disabilities. Although there is a significant lack of quality data on children and young people with disabilities, evidence shows that children and young people with disabilities continue to face barriers which create situations of multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination, including: systematic barriers in the environment and the attitudes which prevent them from having equal access to education, health care, employment and justice.  As State Parties to the CRPD, the EU and EU Member States have an obligation to ensure a strong disability perspective in the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child. In accordance with Article 4 of the CRPD they have an obligation “to adopt all appropriate legislative, administrative and other measures for the implementation of the CRPD”.   To ensure that children with disabilities are not left behind, the EU strategy on the rights of the child must have an inclusive and intersectional approach. Light for the World sees the following as key:  • Refer explicitly to the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) in all documentation related to the EU strategy on the rights of the child and include consistent references to disability.  • Ensure accessible and meaningful participation of children and young people with disabilities and their representative organisations at all stages - in the design, programming, implementation and monitoring of the strategy. • Provide adequate resources and funding to ensure full accessibility of processes and information, including reasonable accommodation.  • Apply the twin-tack approach to disability-inclusion and children’s rights. • Ensure the systematic collection of quality data, disaggregated by gender, age and disability. • Mainstream an intersectional analysis and support the design and implementation of policies and initiatives that do not adversely impact children with disabilities.  • Strengthen internal technical capacities of staff on inclusion and intersectionality to ensure that all aspects and stages of design, implementation and monitoring of initiatives are disability-inclusive and accessible for children with disabilities.  • Recognise children, including children with disabilities, as agents of change and ensure a rights-based approach.  • Commit to child rights-based and disability-inclusive participation.  • Implement the OECD DAC disability inclusion policy marker to track development finance in support of disability inclusion. • Ensure linkages with the implementation of related policies and frameworks, for instance the EU Disability Rights Agenda/Strategy beyond 2020. Initiative: EU strategy on the rights of the child (2021-24)

feedback_msg_text: ALLIANCE OF ROMANIA’S FAMILIES Str. Zmeica nr. 12, sector 4, Bucuresti Tel. 0741.103.025 Fax 0318.153.082 www.alianta-familiilor.ro office@protejarea-familiei.com       August 5, 2020  Re.: EC Consultation on the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child (2021-2024)  Greetings! I am writing on behalf of the Alliance of Romania’s Families, a grassroots movement which promotes pro-family and pro-life policies and views in Romania and internationally. We also promote parental rights, among them the fundamental right of parents to live with and raise their biological children.  The invitation to submit views is welcomed by all of us who are concerned about the wellbeing of our children, be it physical, psychological, spiritual, or of any other nature. Children are the future of the EU and we wholeheartedly join in the goal of ensuring that the EU recognizes the central role which parents have in the rearing of their children in accordance with their moral and spiritual convictions.  On behalf of the Alliance, I express several points of interest to our organization.  We  believe children need to be protected from all toxic influences which adults, mass media, and the authorities exercise in their lives, intentionally or otherwise. Children have the right to be protected from toxic influences. We request that effective and sustained measures be adopted and implemented to ensure children are not exposed to pornography, are not used to  create pornographic material, and that in general the pornography industry be held in check. Access to pornography has eased in recent years which has resulted in an increasing number of children being exposed to pornography and, simultaneously, in the number of children adversely impacted emotionally and psychologically by pornography.  Children also need to be protected from gender ideology. The, by now decades long experiment with gender ideology, has traumatized children and has destabilized them emotionally. Some of them have been impacted beyond reason, and even beyond the ability of clinics to provide the necessary support. The indiscriminate exposure of children to gender ideology is harmful.  Authorities need to ensure, in accordance with relevant international instruments, that parental rights are not undermined. Parents are the primary care givers for their children and parents need to be allowed to make the most important decisions for their children, in accordance with law.  Children have the right to a mother and a father. The natural family constitutes the most optimal social framework for the raising of children. In recent decades this fundamental right of children has been eroded to their detriment. Children raised in alternate social frameworks are disadvantaged, experience more psychological and emotional challenges, and, generally  Page 2  do worse in school than their peers raised in the natural family.  Children also have the right to be raised by their biological parents. They do best when raised by biological parents as opposed to other social arrangements.  The rise of the social family and social parenting in Europe has also undermined the wellbeing of children. The forceful taking away of children from their biological parents, under less than serious circumstances, is causing tremendous mental and emotional problems to children, and even suicides caused by the unnecessary separations have occurred. Consequently, we proffer that social parenting cannot be a substitute for the biological, natural family. The EU needs to seriously support the natural, biological family.  We respectfully request that these points, of great interest to our constituency, be considered.  Respectfully submitted,  _________________________________ Peter Costea, PhD, President Alliance of Romania's Families Feedback from: Alliance of Romania's Families (178.7 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy on the rights of the child (2021-24)

feedback_msg_text: Defence for Children International (DCI) is a leading child rights-focused and membership-based grassroots movement founded in 1979. Our mandate is to ensure effective implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC) at the local, national and international level. Our vision is that children, as human beings, are able to pursue a life in which they can enjoy their human rights with dignity, in a just and responsible society. Harnessing the voices of children, insights and expertise from community leaders across over 35 national chapters, DCI monitors and denounces child rights violations, and hold governments, communities and individuals accountable to the respect and effective implementation of all children’s rights. Defence for Children International welcomes the EU’s intention to develop a comprehensive Child Rights Strategy, to provide vision and direction at all levels of policy-making and legislation, both within the EU and abroad. DCI particularly welcomes the EU’s focus on child-friendly justice, alongside inclusive education, the prevention of all forms of violence and the promotion of inclusive societies.  DCI would like to stress the importance of championing a holistic approach to child-friendly justice for all children in contact and/or in conflict with justice systems; whether in their status of victims, witnesses, offenders or in the context of administrative procedures related to migration. With this in mind, all decisions affecting children should be guided by the best interest of the child, their right to information and to participation. This must include the complete and full eradication of instances of child detention, including in the context of immigration. The current Covid19 crisis has shed renewed light on the detrimental effects of deprivation of liberty on children’s physical and emotional well-being, with long-term devastating consequences for their successful participation in society, and equal access to opportunities. DCI calls for the full implementation by the EU of the recommendations set in the Global Study on Children Deprived of Liberty, and to ensure that children’s deprivation of liberty is a measure of last resort and that they benefit from effective access to alternatives to detention. DCI also encourages due consideration for intersectionality in the EU Strateg on the ROC and adequate measures and investment to tackle the multiple disadvantages and specific risks faced by certain categories of children. For example, child migrants should always treated first and foremost as children, and as such, benefit from the highest protection levels and full set of rights as granted to them by the UNCRC, with treatment and policies taking into account their unique vulnerability and needs. Particular attention should be paid to ensuring child-friendly justice for children in migration, for example, ensuring procedures are child-friendly and never, contrary to the prevalent use of refoulement, unadequate age assessment procedures and de facto detention across EU Member States, tolerate unlawful practices that violate their integrity and rights. Finally, DCI encourages the regular monitoring of the implementation of the EU Child Rights Strategy, for example bringing the results to the annual Child Rights Forum and reporting contributions towards progress against the Sustainable Development Goals, and specific child-related targets and indicators. Additional safeguards and monitoring mechanisms such as the adhesion of the EU to the UNCRC should also be envisaged; to encourage greater accountability against universally agreed Child Rights standards. feedback_msg_text: UNICEF welcomes the EC’s Roadmap towards developing an EU strategy on the rights of the child (2021-24). It is critical that children’s rights become part of the highest political agenda of the EU and are made an integral part of EU policies and practices in a holistic and comprehensive way with a new EU Strategy on Child Rights. New challenges and opportunities are emerging in the 21st century: the impact of climate change on children and their role as agents of change; children and new technologies, including social media; children in migration; mental health;  the impact of armed conflicts on children; and the participation of adolescents and young people in decisions that affect their lives.   We appreciate the roadmap encompasses a broad and ambitious approach anchored in the UN CRC. Nevertheless, we would suggest reinforcing the following: 1. Incorporate general principles underpinning the development of the strategy, namely:  a. Global, applicable for every child, everywhere;  b. Comprehensive and updated with specific measures to address new challenges and take advantages of newly created opportunities;  c. Mandatory for the EU and EU Member States;   d. Concrete by defining a set of measures for the planned objectives, such as a monitoring and reporting system to track EU investments in children (a Child marker);   2. Explicitly state the link between SDGs and the CRC: Prioritizing education, protection, health and well-being of children constitutes the best and most robust investment we can make to fulfil the promise of Agenda 2030.  The SDGs and the CRC go hand-in-hand: whereby children’s rights cannot be realized without the successful implementation of the SDGs — and vice versa. The strategy should contribute to the achievement of the 17 SDGs, specifically delivering on the most relevant SDGs for children, using such SDG indicators directly linked to child rights. Suggestion to include it within section A. Context, Problem definition and Subsidiarity Check. 3. Explicitly state all core principles of the CRC including non-discrimination, best interests of the child, the right to survival and development, the views of the child. Suggestion to include it within Section A. Context, Problem definition and Subsidiarity Check. 4. Explicitly include all the UNCRC provisions covering children’s rights to survival and development, protection and participation. Currently the Roadmap mentions mostly protection and participation but survival and development should be included as well considering the role of the EU as a global actor through external policies and instruments.  Suggestion to include it within Section B. What does the initiative aim to achieve and how. 5. Include the provision of a tracking mechanism (eg a Child Rights Marker) to measure and monitor EU investment as part of the EU support to children-related SDGs. Suggestion to include it within Section B. What does the initiative aim to achieve and how. 6. Recognize children as agents of change, ensuring a rights-based participation that is consultative, collaborative and child-led. Children should meaningfully participate in the design of the Child Rights Strategy as well as in its implementation at national, regional and local levels. Suggestion to include it within Section B. What does the initiative aim to achieve and how.  7. Suggested modifications in the text to make it fully child rights compliant:   Section B:  “The strategy will draw on legislation, policies, tools and programmes available at EU level and will look at how EU action can complement national measures to strengthen the respect for, promotion and protection of children’s rights in the EU and beyond.”   Section C: “No impact assessment ….. by the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, UN data and theme-specific available evidence.”  Feedback from: UNICEF- United Nations Children´s Fund (26.6 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: EU strategy on the rights of the child (2021-24)

feedback_msg_text: The international and multidisciplinary consortium Cancer Prevention Europe (CPE) was created in 2018 to develop world class prevention research to be translated into effective cancer prevention guidelines and policies at the national and international level. CPE is a consortium of leading European research institutions committed to prioritizing cancer prevention through cooperation between countries and programmes. Drawing from previous experience from the European platform for translational cancer research (EurocanPlatform) and with the focus in expanding preventive interventions (taking the measures summarised in the 4th edition of the European Code against Cancer as a starting point), CPE’s mission is to reduce morbidity and mortality from cancer in European populations through prevention and earlier detection of the disease. This will be accomplished through (1) research into optimizing the implementation of known preventive strategies, (2) the dissemination of established best practices in prevention, in order to see innovative research translated into effective cancer prevention guidelines and policies nationally and internationally, and (3) research into the identification of novel targets for prevention. CPE’s vision will be broad in scope, covering a spectrum of research from policy research through to development of novel medical preventive agents. All aspects of primary, secondary, and tertiary prevention will be encompassed, and emphasis will also be placed on the research evaluation and advocacy dimensions of the prevention agenda. A core component of CPE will be economic evaluation of the cost–effectiveness of different interventions, in relation to costs of treatment, care, and productivity loss. Specific research topics for CPE may include the following: cancer registration, cancer aetiology, development and evaluation of preventive interventions, and implementation research to maximize the effectiveness of intervention programmes. These activities will be supported by a range of platforms, networks, and infrastructures and draw together a wide network of partners. Training and capacity-building will be integral to the CPE initiative. Currently, CPE is constituted by the following 11 core partner institutions: Cancer Research UK, the Danish Cancer Society, the European Institute of Oncology (Italy), the French National Cancer Institute, the German Cancer Research Center, the Imperial College London, the Karolinska Institute (Sweden), Maastricht University (the Netherlands), the UK Therapeutic Cancer Prevention Network, the World Cancer Research Fund International, and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC/WHO). And the Full member: Cancéropôle Lyon Auvergne Rhône-Alpes (CLARA, France); and Affiliate members: Europa Donna (Italy), the Association of European Cancer Leagues (Belgium), the Institut Curie (France) and Irish Cancer Prevention Network (Ireland). Successful coordination of cancer prevention requires long-term vision, a dedicated research agenda and funding for such research, as well as a sustainable infrastructure and cooperation between countries and programmes. CPE offers the opportunity to fill gaps in the evidence-base for prevention shaping the EU cancer research agenda, to avoid common pitfalls in implementation and to share capacity for research training and quality improvement. IARC, with its large expertise in coordinating inter-disciplinary research across countries and organizations, hosts the secretariat of the CPE consortium, coordinating the development of the CPE priority actions within a 5-year Strategic Plan. Also, the close working relationship between IARC and its parent organization, WHO, allows the research findings to be translated effectively into timely policies for cancer control. Only joining forces in prevention, research and advocacy, will change these trends, producing synergistic benefits for European populations. https://cancerpreventioneurope.iarc.fr/  Feedback from: Cancer Prevention Europe (499.1 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan

feedback_msg_text: AESGP congratulates the European Commission for the focus given on Cancer and on the established roadmap. AESGP agrees that this stringent healthcare problem needs particular overarching solutions and a transversal collaboration across Member States and different levels of care.  AESGP welcomes the division of the European Beating Cancer Plan into 4 main areas: prevention, early diagnosis, treatment and care. However, AESGP feels that instead of just phases in a timeline, these areas should be considered in consecutive cycles, that follow the person with disease and multi morbidities, as well as considers cancer a high-relapsing risk disease. It is, thus, important to consider secondary and tertiary prevention tools that can minimize the impacts and consequences of cancer.  AESGP is particularly focused on the self-care products and services that are common healthcare tools for both disease prevention and helping patients to cope with: other cancer co-morbidities or temporary symptoms; side effects of established oncological therapies.  AESGP believes that “health literacy” and “citizen empowerment” are absent from the roadmap but play a decisive role in healthy lifestyles and behaviours. People with strong health literacy skills enjoy better health and well-being, while those with weaker skills tend to engage in riskier behaviour. Good health literacy skills allow an individual to interpret given information on health and disease, to select and find good sources of health information and to understand when it is poor or misleading. Moreover, it empowers people to decide when to practice self-care to manage common symptoms and when professional care should be sought. Measures targeting the lack of health literacy at a broader level should also be proposed, as it significantly drains human and financial resources in the health system.   Each person will need to play their part in the success of the plan, which means that long-lasting behavioural change will have to be operated through education, which AESGP also deems to be omitted on the Roadmap. Educational efforts by both general educators and health professionals will need to target (1) healthy citizens for prevention, (2) self-management in cancer patients with optimal therapeutic adherence, and (3) survivors to keep post-cancer measures and monitoring, to prevent and early detect reversions of the disease.   Also, the self-care industry is committed to providing effective, quality and safe products that will help people in the healthcare continuum. Long-established and innovative self-care solutions are available, side by side, for people to use and for health professionals to advise, aiming at: - preventing shortcomings of diets and providing balanced nutrient range (e.g. food supplements like vitamins and minerals; dietary fibres to improve gut health)  - protecting from environmental risk factors (e.g. minerals like potassium iodide in nuclear radiation risk areas) - modifying risk behaviours (e.g. tobacco cessation products like nicotine gums) - managing some symptoms associated to cancer (e.g. medicines such as pain relievers) - side effects of oncological therapy (e.g. medicines such as gastro-intestinal tract regulators) - delaying or impeding tumour recurrence (e.g. vitamin D in melanoma, or aspirin in colon cancer)  AESGP feels that objectives of prevention, treatment and patient care should also consider further research in the area of non-prescription medicines (NPMs) and food supplements, for two main reasons: (i) several NPMs' active principles have shown recent evidence of anticancer benefits; (ii) also, prevention and combination treatment with NPMs and food supplements might achieve higher efficacy, better adherence and better outcomes. While, repurposing medicines still faces scientific, financial and regulatory hurdles, combination only needs scientific backing that could potentially translate into better results.
Organisation: AESGP - Association of the European Self-Care Industry
Initiative: Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan
organisation_lower: aesgp - association of the european self-care industry

feedback_msg_text: The Association Végétarienne de France, in collaboration with the European Vegetarian Union, would like to highlight the strong relation between diets, food consumption and health concerns in the European Union. In France, people consume much more meat than recommended by WHO and by the European Food Safety Authority. In French school canteens, meals contain on average more than twice the meat quantity recommended by the National Health Agency (ANSES) as highlighted in a special report by Greenpeace France.  In 2015, processed meat was classified by WHO as a group 1 carcinogenic agent, meaning there is strong evidence that it causes cancer, while red meat was classified as a ‘probable cause’ of cancer.   AVF believes plant-based diets can significantly contribute to the Commission’s “Beating Cancer Plan”. A rich and varied vegetarian diet consisting of a diverse range of fruits and vegetables, legumes and fibers can offer prevention and treatment of modern lifestyle diseases, including some forms of cancer. There is now strong evidence that consumption of red meat is associated to colorectal and prostate cancer, and fruits, vegetables and fibers can help reduce the risk of colorectal, pharynx, larynx, esophagus and stomach cancer. Therefore, the consumption and production of plant-based foods need to be encouraged and promoted at European level. A great opportunity lies in public canteens, where millions of meals are distributed each day. Obligatory application of dietary guidelines should be a requirement for menu plans, which would necessarily result in cutting back on meat and offering more plant-based dishes. People should be provided with sufficient information and the option to choose healthier and more climate-friendly meals. Moreover, extensive and long-term information and image campaigns surrounding dietary guidelines, health recommendations, the climate impact of diets, and the positive aspects of plant-based foods should be launched in public spaces such as canteens and schools.  Fiscal harmonisation between meat, dairy and plant-based products, is also a very effective tool. In most EU countries plant-based products are subject to a higher VAT tax than meat and dairy products, due notably to the political choices that have been made over the Common agricultural policy (CAP) in the last decades. Poland is a striking example : plant-based products are taxed as highly as 23%, whereas meat and dairy are only taxed 5%. By harmonising taxation, the EU would create a powerful incentive for consumers to choose plant-based over meat and dairy products, thereby encouraging them to buy healthier food. It would also be relevant to reform the financial support provided by the EU to farmers as part of the CAP. Indeed, the Voluntary Coupled Support (VCS) prioritizes unsustainable (both from a health and an environmental point of view) sectors such as the beef and the dairy industry : 60% of the VCS funding goes to the beef, lamb and dairy sectors, while only 25% goes to plant agriculture. In addition to this, the EU should increase funding and provide technical support to young farmers, in order to encourage them to turn to more sustainable forms of agriculture like legume, fruit and vegetable crops.  The Association Végétarienne de France therefore strongly encourages the EU to promote plant-based diets, as this would be extremely instrumental in improving public health for European citizens.
Initiative: Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan

feedback_msg_text: Feedback from The Europeans Throughout The World (ETTW)  The Europeans Throughout The World (ETTW) contributed with an opinion to the making of the last Citizenship Report in 2017 (Opinion of ETTW on the EC's Public Consultation on the EU Citizenship Report, December 2015). Many of the points we made are still relevant. Especially the ones on Democratic and Civic Participation, where online registration of voters in the country of residence is strongly recommended along with online voting, and Crossborder Education and Training  which is considered important by diaspora groups for raising awareness of European values and the rights of EU citizenship.   But the real concerns of ETTW now are the drastic consequences of the Covid 19 pandemic for Europeans living, working and studying in another EU country. The Eurobarometer summary on EU citizenship and democracy is based on fieldwork from February and March 2020 - that is before the pandemic and its drastic consequences for the free movement of EU citizens and other citizens' rights assured in the Treaties.  ETTW has consulted its member organizations and partners on the lessons learned and experiences gained so far and recommends that the following conclusions be considered in the drawing up of the final Citizenship Report 2020:  - The crisis, the lockdowns and the closing of national borders have highlighted the extent to which migrants and expatriates depend on efficient home country functions in order to live, work and survive in their countries of residence. Renewal of passports and other consular and administrative services, health services and certificates, funding for organizational and supporting activities suddenly ceased or became problematic to obtain with lasting consequences.  - Repatriation of expats and migrants during the crisis, lockdowns and the closing of borders caused serious problems for professionals, jobseekers, students, seasonal workers and families alike .  - In countries where elections were scheduled during or after the crisis, migrants and expatriates were barred from political campaigning and participation in elections and thus derived of their rights as European citizens.  - Diaspora groups and associations have reported nationalistic, xenophobic  and discriminatory reactions to expatriates' functions and activities in their countries of residence.  - At the same time the confinements have increased and fortified digital/web-communications enormously and has made political bodies and authorities more open to proposals  from diaspora communities and organizations - and by implication from EU institutions and services - for extended digital services such as voter registration and online voting.
Initiative: 2020 citizenship report

feedback_msg_text: In 2011 the White Paper on Transport delivered a comprehensive policy roadmap for decarbonising the transport sector. With 40 action points, covering all modes of transport, this document represented a clear blueprint for policy-makers and industry alike.  Yet, even though the European Commission delivered “A European Strategy for Low-Emission Mobility” in 2016 and a series of budgetary tools and “clean mobility packages” in 2017 and 2018 to implement the white paper’s goals, many action points remained aspirational, and were not translated into concrete political action The renewed calls for climate action coming from the scientific community in the latest IPCC special report, citizens concerned by local air pollution as well as the dramatic technology developments that occurred over the last eight years are reason enough for re-opening discussions on the EU transport strategy. In this time frame, the Paris Agreement was signed, students started marches for the climate, and e-mobility solutions became a valid alternative in many transport modes. Battery prices constantly dropped while vehicles’ range increased and more technological advances are expected in the future.   But technology developments alone will not be enough. A new comprehensive roadmap for the transport sector is needed, including its synergies with the energy sector. The goals set in 2011 should be reviewed to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050: while some may still be valuable to pursue, others may not be relevant anymore, or lack ambition in view of technology development and climate urgency.    Against that background, the Platform for Electro-Mobility supports the evaluation process proposed by the European Commission, and stands ready to provide its input on future transport policy priorities.
Initiative: Evaluation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport

feedback_msg_text: Defend Democracy welcomes an ambitious European Democracy Action plan. We strongly recommend a more coherent approach regarding hybrid threats to democracy. These include, but are not limited to, foreign malign election interference and disinformation. In order to defend democracy, the EU must look beyond protecting fundamental rights and regulating technology platforms, and broaden its scope to include deterring geopolitical and security threats. This also means preventing stove-piping by: 1) crossing silos between DG Justice, DG Connect, DG Home Affairs and the European External Action Service (EEAS), and 2) aligning the European Democracy Action Plan and the new Digital Services Act with the new Security Union strategy. The EU Commission may consider a dedicated, cross-silo Defend Democracy task force or coordinator.
Initiative: Protecting European democracy from interference and manipulation – European Democracy Action Plan

feedback_msg_text: Public Libraries 2030 welcomes the European Democracy Action plan as a way to ensure that European citizens are able to fully participate in the democratic system and make informed decisions.  We call for a greater recognition of the work of civil society and public institutions such as public libraries to be recognized for their work on citizen engagement. We believe that Europe’s public libraries are a crucial democratic infrastructure and are needed to achieve the objectives set out in the roadmap especially those on democratic participation, citizen engagement, and disinformation.  Many of Europe’s 65,000 public libraries already host debates, meetings and consultations of all kinds - indeed they are well placed to do so as trusted, local spaces for the diverse communities they serve. These activities occur in many formats depending on the needs of the local community; they can range from shared learning in book clubs, to human libraries, themed events run by local organisations (examples include integration of refugees, workshops on fake news, Pride Week events), and even public events in which political representatives can debate issues with citizens.  As one of the most trusted public institutions, public libraries play a crucial role in helping communities learn the relevant media literacy skills needed to navigate the information landscape and foster democratic engagement and active citizenship. While we welcome financing and increased engagement with civil society, public libraries must also be part of this. We strongly urge the European Commission to review the Rights, Equalities and Citizenship programme to reflect the need for citizenship initiatives in public libraries and other institutions.  Meaningful citizen engagement requires a participatory democracy process that engages citizens across all policy areas beyond the ones cited in this roadmap. Ultimately, all citizens must be involved as part of the policy making process from the beginning and must be supported and encouraged to provide feedback as policies are created.  We call for the European Democracy Action plan to consider citizen engagement and participatory democracy within all of the EU’s policy areas.
Initiative: Protecting European democracy from interference and manipulation – European Democracy Action Plan

feedback_msg_text: Taking into account the above and our European Philanthropy Manifesto, which was approved in 2019 and ongoing exchange with other key civil society organisations, we put forward the following recommendations to consider in the context of the democracy action plan:  Recognise and engage in dialogue with civil society including philanthropy - Recognise the role of civil society organisations and philanthropic organisations - Improve dialogue between the EU institutions and citizens and organised civil society: Although Art. 11 TEU provides a legislative framework for citizens’ involvement in decision-making process, existing forms for citizen and civil society participation in the EU could be improved by creating a structured dialogue. The Commission should initiate an inter-institutional agreement on civil dialogue. - More meaningful and inclusive participation of civil society including philanthropy also in the context of the Future of Europe Conference and in the implementation of the EDAP and any other mechanisms and processes for the promotion and protection of of democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights.  Enable and protect civil society including philanthropy - Civic space impact assessments: Respect for freedom of expression, association and assembly should be part of all fundamental rights impact assessments for EU legislative proposals; It needs to be ensured in particular that EU level rules on tax evasion, money laundering and counterterrorism financing are proportionate to the risks they seek to address and must not unduly restrict legitimate charitable activities. - National implementation of EU laws must also be in line with the rights to freedom of association and freedom of expression. In case of breach with EU law, the EC should initiate infringement procedures. - Regular monitoring of these rights and state of democracy by the European Commission/ Fundamental Rights Agency of existing EU and national legislation. - In order to do this, there is a need for a comprehensive policy framework with guiding principles/standards on civic space (such as freedom of association and assembly) and inclusive participation should be developed. - Include fundamental rights (civic space) and democracy among the key indicators in the scope of the EU Rule of Law mechanism. The EU institutions need a mechanisms to enforce the values set out in Article 2 of the Treaty of the European Union. An interinstitutional agreement on a European Mechanism on Democracy, Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights, as proposed by the LIBE Committee could be the starting point (see draft report).  Facilitate cross-border philanthropy and public benefit work - Consider legal instruments to strengthen cross-border work of civil society and philanthropy. There are EU policy options to reduce barriers to cross-border philanthropy and wider civil society, such as the creation of a supranational legal form to facilitate European public benefit engagement. Member States and the EU should consider mutual recognition of public benefit organisations or find other ways to facilitate tax effective cross-border philanthropy, which currently still is very complex and burdensome.  Ensure effective EU funding for civil society and provide tools for philanthropy to co-grant and co-invest - In the next Multi-Annual Financial Framework (including a strong rights and values programme) and recovery schemes, the EU must ensure that resources are available for civil society organisations to develop medium to long-term plans to promote fundamental rights, rule of law and democracy.  - Within the MFF the EU could leverage the impact of private resources for public good by introducing financial instruments that: act as a catalyst for co-granting with philanthropy and stimulate co-investments by also facilitating mission-related investments of institutional philanthropy. - Maintain the proposed conditionality of funding in the next MFF. feedback_msg_text: SSR, the Dutch Training and Study Centre for the Judiciary, welcomes the Roadmap for European Judicial Training Strategy 2019-2025 and will provide its input in the upcoming consultation activities.   As regards the problem analysis that is included in the Roadmap, SSR would like to underline three points:  1) In order to develop a sound and relevant training strategy for judicial training in Europe, it is essential to conduct a sound and relevant training NEEDS assessment (TNA), to complement any lists of training WISHES. With the identification of bottlenecks for the functioning of the European judiciary, and of European judicial training, an effective strategy can be developed to tackle these issues. Furthermore, a solid TNA will facilitate the assessment and measurement of the progress made.  2) The Roadmap appropriately mentions that rule of law, independence of the judiciary and ethics are important topics to be included in European judicial training. Judges and public prosecutors, but also members of other legal professions, must be provided with opportunities to exchange views on their role and experiences with their position in a democracy governed by the rule of law.  3) Knowledge of foreign legal languages remains key to participating in cross-border activities and to maintaining contacts with judicial colleagues within the EU. The 2019-2025 Strategy should include clear ideas and tangible suggestions as to how to increase the level of foreign language knowledge, as a basis for legal language knowledge. This could be a joint effort of the member states and the EU, for instance to constitute a prerequisite for appointment in the judiciary to master a foreign language (i.e. English). In the meantime, however, sufficient funds should be allocated to enable translation into the local language for those audiences who do not have the required language level, but who would benefit greatly for participation in European judicial training activities.
Initiative: European Judicial Training Strategy 2019-2025

feedback_msg_text: 1. Visibilizar la mayor vulnerabilidad de las mujeres con discapacidad en todas las áreas contempladas en la Estrategia Europea de Discapacidad e implementar medidas de acción positiva para garantizar la igualdad entre hombres y mujeres con discapacidad. Investigaciones y evaluaciones: - Hacer análisis de resultados a partir de datos desagregados por sexo que permitan conocer las diferencias entre hombres y mujeres con discapacidad en cada cuestión evaluada. Los informes de resultados principales y de referencia deben incluir los datos desagregados por sexo en todas las áreas temáticas contempladas en la Estrategia Europea de Discapacidad. - Incluir indicadores de género y discapacidad tanto en los estudios realizados por Eurostat, evaluaciones de la Estrategia Europea de Discapacidad, como en otras investigaciones. Se deben introducir en los estudios aquellas variables que permiten medir situaciones de especial vulnerabilidad en mujeres con discapacidad, tales como las relativas a la violencia de género, maternidad, adopción, esterilización, acceso a determinados recursos sanitarios, etc. - Los informes de resultados específicos de género deben ser publicitados de forma que sean fácilmente accesibles. Medidas de acción positiva: - Incluir objetivos y acciones específicas que contribuyan a reducir la situación de desigualdad de las mujeres con discapacidad respecto a los hombres y mujeres sin discapacidad en las cuestiones principales tenidas en cuenta en la Estrategia Europea de Discapacidad. No solo en el empleo, si no en cuestiones relacionadas con salud, participación social, protección social, entre otras. - Incluir objetivos y acciones específicas relacionadas con cuestiones que afectan fundamentalmente a las mujeres. Cuestiones como la violencia de género, derechos sexuales y reproductivos, etc. Adoptar un enfoque interseccional que permita tener en cuenta variables como el índice de pobreza, el género, edad, orientación sexual, etc. Para garantizar los derechos humanos de todas las personas con discapacidad en igualdad de condiciones a las demás personas, se deberá medir y tener en cuenta el impacto que tienen la legislación, las políticas y las medidas implementadas en los diferentes países, de acuerdo a las diferentes variables de vulnerabilidad y su interacción. 2. Incluir el voluntariado como parte fundamental dentro de las organizaciones de discapacidad.  3. Ámbito de actuación “Acción exterior”  EL NUEVO CONSENSO EUROPEO EN MATERIA DE DESARROLLO «NUESTRO MUNDO, NUESTRA DIGNIDAD, NUESTRO FUTURO» La discapacidad y la Convención sobre los derechos de las personas con discapacidad de NNUU se contemplan en los “Principios y valores rectores de la acción en materia de desarrollo” y en el apartado “2.1. Las personas — Desarrollo humano y dignidad” del Marco de actuación. Esta presencia no es suficiente, es necesario contar con una estrategia de discapacidad en la cooperación para el desarrollo europea. CONVOCATORIAS DE SUBVENCIONES Para mantener coherencia con la “Estrategia Europea sobre Discapacidad 2010-2020” y cumplir con el Art. 32 de la Convención sobre los derechos de las personas con discapacidad de NNUU, en todas las convocatorias de proyectos de cooperación para el desarrollo y acción humanitaria de la UE deberían incluirse los derechos de las personas con discapacidad como un eje transversal y a ser posible, habría que incluirlos también como un lote específico.   En la actualidad sólo algunas convocatorias los contemplan como lote específico o como eje transversal. Además, habría que implementar convocatorias de proyectos orientadas específicamente a la defensa y promoción de los derechos de las personas con discapacidad. LICITACIONES DE SUMINISTROS, SERVICIOS Y OBRAS EN EL EXTERIOR Todas las empresas contratadas deben cumplir con las cuotas de contratación de personas con discapacidad de sus legislaciones nacionales. feedback_msg_text: SICOS contribution to the European Pharmaceutical Strategy Roadmap  SICOS is the national industrial sector group representing the manufacturers of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (API), excipients and intermediates located in France.  SICOS welcomes the Commission’s initiative to ensure EU citizens have full and equal access to safe, state-of-the-art therapies and appreciates the opportunity to comment on the Commission’s roadmap for its Pharmaceutical Strategy.  The pharmaceutical supply chain is both very complex and global. As a consequence of the extensive outsourcing of much of this chain, the European pharmaceutical industry is now particularly dependent on Asia, notably for the production of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (API), pharmaceutical intermediates and regulatory starting materials.  The COVID-19 crisis has highlighted the dependency and vulnerability of the raw materials supply chain.  It is critical and urgent for Europe to adopt a competitive, innovative and highly effective industrial policy.   The producers of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients, excipients and intermediates which play a central role in the pharmaceutical supply chain in Europe are ready to rise to the challenge and actively contribute to ensuring the EU’s self-reliance regarding healthcare and security of its supply of medicines.  We produce the essential building blocks for all medicines, operating within the strictest and highest quality, security and environmental standards. We have heavily invested in the best available technologies to ensure the quality of our supplies and to remain competitive at a global level. Our existing production facilities throughout Europe can adapt to variations in demand, whilst maintaining these high standards. Our technological and scientific competences and our innovation capabilities constitute the most favourable terrain on which a resilient, innovative and sustainable European pharmaceutical supply chain can be built.   We consider it essential to revitalise, modernise and develop existing industrial sites in France and Europe for this business sector.  SICOS proposals for actions are the following:  • Identify weak areas within the supply chain for critical drugs, as well as all players throughout the entire value chain from raw materials through to Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients • Record the source of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients on drug packaging • Build strategic stocks for critical Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients from European players • Give priority to European sourcing of raw materials for public tenders and reimbursable medicines (without hindering free trade). In all cases, priority should always be given to suppliers who comply with EU quality, safety, sustainability and environmental standards • Help companies invest in updating and developing the existing industrial network • Support the costs of technology transfer and development of repatriated molecules, and ensure regulatory flexibility (e.g. fast track approvals), in full compliance with regulatory standards, to prevent future shortages due to unforeseen events or surges in demand • Fund research into new and environmentally friendly processes • Strengthen more specifically the qualification criteria for foreign suppliers in terms of quality, safety and respect for the environment • Maintain and develop long-term training in Chemistry for vocational Baccalaureate, IUT and School/University studies • Develop in-service training qualifications to increase the skills and expertise required  In our future response to the public consultation on the pharmaceutical strategy itself, we will develop these proposals and present practical measures. feedback_msg_text: Independent Retail Europe is concerned by a lack of clarity relating to the Toy Safety Directive (2009/48/EC).  Isolated Cases There is a lack of consistency between the toy safety rules and the general product safety rules on what distributors should do in “isolated cases.” This is because the TSD is silent on the subject of isolated cases.  An isolated case is where a problem with only one sample of a product has been shown as the cause of a problem. In such a situation, a distributor may be unable to determine with certainty whether the source of this isolated case comes from the product itself, or from an inappropriate usage of this product by a consumer.  Under the existing toy safety rules, it would seem that to treat an isolated case, distributors should notify their competent authorities (in accordance with Article 7 (4) and chapter V of the TSD) rather than just contact the producer, as is the case for general product safety and allowed under the guidelines to the General Product Safety Directive. In accordance with the existing TSD rules, the Member State will then introduce a notification concerning the product in question under the RAPEX system, where an isolated case of a defective product has been found.   Downside of existing toy safety regime The downside of using the RAPEX system for an isolated case is significant. Where a product is publicly named as problematic/dangerous via RAPEX, for an isolated case only, it may harm a producer financially. The producer may then seek damages from the retailer, who made a notification  to the relevant competent authority before being absolutely certain of the origin of the problem, thereby souring the business relationship.  This situation does not occur under the General Product Safety Directive/guidelines, which are clear on how to deal with isolated cases. Under the general product safety rules, as mentioned above, a retailer only needs to contact the producer to warn that an isolated case has been found. The producer can then assess what follow up is necessary and proportionate. This is particularly useful where, for example, the producer can clearly identify the origin of the problem due to his knowledge of the technical specifications of the product or due to his experience of prior notifications from distributors. This avoids potential huge losses for either the producer or the retailer, which can arise from a public RAPEX alert (a disproportionate measure for such an isolated case).  Proposal In this context, the evaluation should look at whether a paragraph on “isolated cases” that repeats the general product safety rules could be added to the TSD. The objective is to clarify that, in an isolated case; distributors should only contact a producer, who can decide upon the next steps, rather than immediately entering into the RAPEX procedure. This clarification on what to do in isolated cases would be particularly helpful for the large number of SME distributors in the EU.
Initiative: Evaluation of the Toy Safety Directive

feedback_msg_text: ANEC is in favour of evaluating the Toy Safety Directive. Although the Directive certainly brought improvements to toy safety in Europe, the following issues need to be addressed in our opinion: • the chemical requirements for toys need to be strengthened significantly. This position is shared by several Member States. The lack of adequate provisions to exclude exposure to dangerous substances such as CMRs requires a fundamental revision of the chemical requirements of the Directive. A key point in this context is the broadening of the Comitology to set limits also for toys for children above 36 months of age (other than those intended to be placed in the mouth). • while the comitology procedure only applies for chemicals, it should also work for mechanical and physical requirements for toys for children under 3 years of age.  • The Directive must be updated to ensure that it is in line with the new ‘security for safety’ concept of the general legal framework. See ANEC and BEUC position on the ‘Cybersecurity of connected products’, http://www.anec.eu/images/Publications/position-papers/Digital/ANEC-DIGITAL-2018-G-001final.pdf.  • the Directive needs to be amended to regulate impulse noise levels in toys, and to set the limit to what is allowed for adults in industry according to Directive 2003/10 /EEC. We see no safety-based reason to expose children to higher levels than is allowed for adults.  • in the interest of legal certainty, specific requirements for visibility and legibility of warnings on toys (e.g. a minimum letter size) need to be introduced, in order to enable Member States to enforce these requirements in a uniform way.  • When buying toys online, consumers often don’t get the required information and warnings they would find when buying toys in a physical shop. • The Regulation on Enforcement and Compliance, proposed by the Commission in November 2017, covers toys. In this context, we reiterate the need to increase controls and market surveillance of toys; to set up a Pan-European Accident and Injury Database in order to systematically collect information about accidents and injuries that occur because of dangerous toys; to improve traceability along the supply chain, also for toys that are sold online.
Organisation: ANEC, the European Consumer Voice in Standardisation
Initiative: Evaluation of the Toy Safety Directive
organisation_lower: anec, the european consumer voice in standardisation

feedback_msg_text: More and more toys and products for children come to the market which can connect to the internet. These new functionalities create new vulnerabilities for children as has been shown by the Norwegian Consumer Council. It is of serious concern that the current legal framework and its definition for a ‘safe’ toy does not unequivocally cover Internet connecting toys and related security threats. An update of the definition and of safety evaluation methods as well as enforcement methods is urgently necessary. We elaborate on a ‘safety by design’ concept in the joint ANEC and BEUC position on the ‘Cybersecurity of connected products’ (see several hyperlinks below).   Children are still exposed to too many hazardous chemicals in toys because limit values have not been established or existing limit values are poorly enforced. Furthermore, when establishing limit values, regulators need to consider latest science such as evidence on a possible cocktail and low dose effects which is today insufficiently the case. Caution has to be taken for toys for children younger than 36 months as they often mouth toys and therefor have a higher exposure to harmful chemicals. In particular it is unclear in the current Directive how the exposure to hormone disrupting chemicals in toys can effectively be lowered.  An evaluation of the Toy Safety Directive should duly consider positive and negative experiences of the United States who have introduced since a couple of years mandatory third-party testing for toys for children under 12 years. We understand from discussions with US consumer colleagues through the network of the Trans-Atlantic Consumer Dialogue (TACD) that recall rates have been dropping and compliance has been improved. Mandatory third-party testing could therefore make an important contribution to keep children in the EU market safe.  Limit values for noise need to be introduced  Specific requirements for the visibility and legibility of warnings on toys (e.g. a minimum letter size) must be introduced into the legislation.  The European Commission has proposed on 19 November 2017 a Regulation on Enforcement and Compliance which aims to improve market surveillance, and which covers toys. As the outcome of this reform is currently uncertain, we reiterate the urgent need to 1) step up the number of controls of toys before they are placed on the market, 2) improve traceability and accountability along the supply chain including toys that are sold online and 3) better exchange at European and national level intelligence about dangerous toys and sales channels. Finally, it is important to systematically collect information about accidents and injuries that occur because of dangerous toys through a Pan-European Accident and Injury Database.  Links:  ANEC/ BEUC Position paper: Cybersecurity for connected products:  http://www.beuc.eu/publications/beuc-x-2018-017_cybersecurity_for_connected_products.pdf   BEUC letter to MEPs: Cybersecurity  Act - Consumers  need mandatory security  by design and by default  http://www.beuc.eu/publications/beuc-x-2018-024_cybersecurity_act_consumers_need_mandatory_security_by_design_and_by_default.pdf  ANEC/BEUC/CI/ICRT: Securing Consumer Trust in the Internet of Things - Principles and Recommendations  http://www.beuc.eu/publications/beuc-x-2017-137_securing_consumer_trust_in_the_internet_of_things.pdf  #ToyFail Report of the Norwegian Consumer Council:  https://fil.forbrukerradet.no/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/toyfail-report-desember2016.pdf
Initiative: Evaluation of the Toy Safety Directive

feedback_msg_text: ClientEarth welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to develop an Offshore Renewable Energy Strategy in the context of the European Green Deal.   Offshore renewable energies have a huge potential in Europe and are indeed of crucial importance for achieving the 2030 climate and energy targets of the European Union and the Member States, as well as for delivering the 2050 climate neutrality commitment.   The Offshore Renewable Energy Strategy should aim at integrating renewable offshore generation capacity in the energy system in an efficient way while respecting high standards of environmental protection, public involvement and cooperation among Member States.   In particular, the Offshore Renewable Energy Strategy must be aligned with other strategies and initiatives arising from the European Green Deal, including the Strategy for Energy System Integration, the Hydrogen Strategy, the Industry Strategy, the Biodiversity Strategy and the Circular Economy Action Plan.   To ensure its effectiveness and sustainability, the Offshore Renewable Energy Strategy must also ensure compliance and consistency with numerous existing rules, including general EU principles, sustainability and environmental laws, rules governing energy systems, as well as the different EU and international rules affecting the uses of the marine space.    Please refer to the attached document for more details on each of the issues mentioned above. Feedback from: ClientEarth (147.4 KB - PDF - 8 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Eurofinas, the voice of consumer credit providers at European level takes note of the European Commission’s evaluation roadmap of the Consumer Credit Directive. We very much value and support the Commission’s continuous work to safeguard the effectiveness and relevance of the Directive, and to strive for the coherent application and enforcement of the framework safeguarding a high level of consumer protection across the EU.  In this respect, we want to reiterate Eurofinas’ ongoing commitment to constructively contribute to the European Commission’s work on this issue and in the wider context of the Commission’s Action Plan on Consumer Financial Services.  The Commission’s 2014 Implementation Report on the CCD highlighted the importance of strong and consistent enforcement. We believe that this issue remains relevant as well as the issue of authorization and supervision of entities. We believe that enforcement, rather than regulation, is the best way to address local issues such as predatory lending or usury.  In our view, it is essential that the evaluation of the CCD is based on a holistic assessment of the implementation of the CCD, which had a structural effect on the consumer credit market in member states. In light of the developments in the market, not least driven by technological developments and changing customer expectations, we share the Commission’s view on the need to assess the framework and its relevancy, and whether the rules provide consumers with the best and most relevant protection, including in the digital environment and effectively contribute to an optimal performance of the credit system overall.  We furthermore welcome the Commission’s focus on the coherence of the Directive in relation to other relevant frameworks, such as the General Data Protection Regulation. We believe that further clarity on the interplay between the relevant existing frameworks in the field of retail financial services, consumer protection and data protection would be welcomed in order to safeguard lenders’ ability to provide consumers with the best products in a safe manner. Moreover, the existing frameworks should also be assessed in relation to quickly developing technologies, such as Artificial Intelligence and machine learning.  We would, however, caution against extending the evaluation roadmap to include “elements of national regulatory practices that may be of relevance in a cross-border context”. As the Commission’s own 2011 Study on Interest Rate Restrictions found, there was little appetite amongst member states for a cross-border approach on such issues. In addition, there are many differences in national markets and definitions, particularly in relation to what the roadmap terms ‘usury and predatory lending’. These differences would make meaningful comparison in a cross-border sense decidedly complex. We fully agree that it is appropriate that consumers are adequately protected from such practices where needed, whether in a cross-border transaction or otherwise, but we would strongly suggest that any evaluation for those purposes should be done separately to the evaluation of CCD which does not touch on such issues.  Finally, we note that the credit industry is not part of any of the expert groups that the Commission will use as sources of data and recommendations for the evaluation of the CCD. In order to support that process and to prepare a potential review of the text, we would invite the Commission to set up a horizontal expert group i.e. including public authorities, industry and consumers on consumer credit-related matters. Feedback from: Eurofinas (136.8 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download
Initiative: Evaluation of the Consumer Credit Directive

feedback_msg_text: Villaägarnas riksförbund with more than 300 000 member households throughout Sweden would hereby like to adress the commission proposal on the "renovation wave".  Improving the sustainability of our built environment is a matter of great importance for our association. In line with the views expressed in the Green Deal Communication and the Renovation Wave Roadmap, we are convinced that better performing buildings can ensure healthier and safer environments for all citizens.  However, renovation does not come without a cost, and this inevitably entails a critical challenge for European citizens and real estate companies, all the more so in light of the disruption brought by the recent pandemic. If it is true that energy efficient buildings with integrated renewable systems lower energy bills, it is also true that renovating one own’s dwelling require high upfront investments and considerable costs that many simply cannot afford. Promoting renovation – not to mention imposing it – can fall short of its social objectives unless coupled with the appropriate incentives and the necessary support.  To this end, in our view, the Renovation Wave and its action plan should focus on FACILITATING and ENABLING renovation to GET IT RIGHT, as no “wave” can take place across Europe without making sure that it does not translate into a mere economic burden but rather truly empowers citizens and companies to live in a more sustainable environment.  1. Enable renovation Enabling means making the renovation wave feasible and affordable. In line with the propositions made in the Roadmap, in our view, this necessarily requires to:  • Guarantee that cost-effectiveness is the guiding principle behind the measures and actions to be proposed.  • Tailor financial incentives to the different segments of the building sector, prioritising those more likely to trigger renovation decision.  • Foster discussions and exchanges on best practices to tackle existing barriers to renovation.   2. Faciliate renovation Facilitating renovation means supporting the appropriated structures, tools and processes to ease renovation. Taking into account the measures foreseen under the Roadmap, we deem important to: • Move from experimentation to massification of support schemes such as one-stop-shops, notably by ensuring their economic viability by encouraging Member States to earmark funds from the Recovery and Resilience Facility to set up and manage all-inclusive OSSs at local level and by streamlining EU financial support and technical assistance.  • Promote an incentive-based district approach that takes into consideration both the needs and challenges of individual homeowners and those of European neighbourhoods.  • Support the development of affordable renovation technologies and processes, that can be tailored to different segments of the building sector (including small scale, individual projects).  3. Get it right Getting it right means getting citizens and market actors on board, explore synergies and avoid burdening. In our view, this would require to:  • Promote cooperation, structural dialogue (e.g. through the European Climate Pact) and foster sectoral or local agreements to unlock the full benefits of the energy transition and address people’s concerns and needs.  • Streamline with other sectoral initiatives to prevent regulatory uncertainty, the risk of inconsistency between different policies and measures and the danger of piling measures and obligations;  • Avoid additional mandatory measures, by focusing first on the full and proper implementation of existing directives and supporting measures .   Last but not least we also would like to remind the commission that all member states have their own challanges and start from very different levels. Whatever measures the EU commission decide to put forward they have to be adaptable to 27 different countries to have any effect. I.e. they can’t be too specific to be successful.
Initiative: Energy efficiency in buildings – consultation on ‘renovation wave’ initiative

feedback_msg_text: Met betrekking tot de renovation wave zou het Verbond van Belgische Ondernemingen (VBO FEB) graag volgende bedenkingen doorgeven: - Voor het VBO mag renovatie zich niet beperken tot de energetische renovatie van (woon)gebouwen om zo via een vermindering van het energieverbruik en de CO2-uitstoot van het gebouwenpark een bijdrage te leveren aan ons klimaat. Naast energetische renovatie moet renovatie ook gaan over het verbeteren van de woonkwaliteit voor de bewoners en van de milieuprestaties van de gebouwen. Daarenboven gaat renoveren voor het VBO ook over investeringen, het stimuleren van de (lokale) economie en tewerkstelling.  Net omwille van die erg uiteenlopende doelstellingen die gerealiseerd kunnen worden, vindt het VBO de aandacht van Europa voor de renovatie van gebouwen positief, maakt renovatie een terecht onderdeel uit van de Green Deal en moet het zeker één van de stimuleringsmaatregelen zijn na de covid-19-crisis.  - Omdat Europa (met succes) het kader heeft vastgelegd voor de energievereisten in geval van nieuwbouw is het VBO van mening dat Europa ook het aangewezen niveau is om het kader uit te werken voor bestaande (woon)gebouwen. - Het VBO wil absoluut niet dat het opleggen van specifieke vereisten en regels voor bestaande woningen een woningcrisis tot gevolg zou hebben. Daarom vraagt het VBO om bij de uitwerking van het regelgevend kader oog te hebben voor de haalbaarheid en de betaalbaarheid van een renovatie. Daarnaast moet er zeker ook aandacht zijn voor: o gezinnen in energie-armoede, o verhuurders en o mede-eigenaars. - Het VBO ziet twee belangrijke drempels die mensen er van weerhouden over te gaan tot renovatie. Deze zijn een gebrek aan (1) technische kennis en (2) financiële middelen. Om de eerste drempel weg te werken stelt het VBO een uitgebreider energiecertificaat (een certificaat dat met energie, woonkwaliteit en milieuprestaties een totaalbeeld geeft van de woning) en een renovatieadvies op maat (uit te voeren stappen om de woning op alle vlakken in orde te brengen) voor. Om de tweede drempel weg te werken denkt het VBO aan het valoriseren van de energieprestatie van een (woon)gebouw. Dit betekent dat bij het toekennen van een krediet de bank niet alleen rekening houdt met de beschikbare afbetalingscapaciteit maar ook met de eventuele bijkomende kosten voor het gebruik of de renovatie van het gebouw. - Met betrekking tot het aspect van de energetische renovaties vraagt het VBO om na te denken over een juiste definitie van de klimaatdoelstelling voor (woon)gebouwen. Daarbij denk het VBO dat klimaatneutraliteit (eerder dan zero-energy) het einddoel moet zijn. - Voor het VBO moet materiaal- en technologieneutraliteit ook een uitgangspunt zijn bij de renovatie van (woon)gebouwen. Technieken en technologieën die geschikt zijn voor een bepaald type van gebouw zijn dat daarom niet op een andere locatie of voor een ander soort gebouw. - Als het renoveren van een gebouw geen efficiënte aanpak blijkt te zijn, is het VBO van mening dat sloop (en heropbouw) zeker als alternatief overwogen moet kunnen worden. Bijkomend kan via het slopen van gebouwen  mogelijk een bijdrage geleverd worden aan andere milieu-, natuur- of klimaat(beleids)doelstellingen. - Het VBO is er van overtuigd dat elke overheid een voorbeeldrol moeten opnemen door eerst en vooral het eigen patrimonium te renoveren. Voor de lokale overheden ziet het VBO nog een bijkomende belangrijke rol. Want als de overheid die het dichtste bij haar inwoners staat, is zij erg goed geplaatst om haar inwoners op weg zetten naar en te helpen bij de renovatie van hun woning. - Het VBO vindt het belangrijk dat naast het stimuleren van het renoveren van gebouwen ook de nodige aandacht gaat naar het monitoren van de vooruitgang. Hier moet een geschikt instrument voor uitgewerkt worden zodat opgevolgd kan worden of de vooropgestelde doelstellingen worden bereikt. Hiervoor is ook de opbouw van vergelijkbare data over het gebouwenpatrimonium belangrijk en nodig. Feedback from: VBO FEB (205.9 KB - PDF - 2 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Propuesta conjunta entre el Consejo Gerenal de Colegios Profesionales de Ingeniería en Informática (CCII) y la Asociación de Enseñantes Universitarios de la Informática (AENUi), a raíz del convenio de colaboración firmado entre las partes, sobre los retos educativos para el curso 2020-2021.  Durante el segundo semestre del curso 2019-2020 se ha tenido que transformar la docencia sin previo aviso y sin tiempo para el rediseño. En estas circunstancias, el profesorado ha hecho lo que ha podido o sabido a base de esfuerzo y buena voluntad, en lo que se puede denominar docencia remota de emergencia. Esta experiencia acumulada nos brinda la oportunidad de diseñar propuestas de docencia y evaluación que permitan impartir durante el próximo curso académico 2020-2021 una docencia de calidad adaptada a las posibilidades que la situación sanitaria permita.  Como reflexión sobre los retos educativos para el curso 2020-2021, CCII y AENUI presentan conjuntamente esta declaración considerando los siguientes riesgos y oportunidades, que se elaborarán a lo largo de la declaración: 1. Las normas deben ser flexibles. Se debe evitar una excesiva normativización que impida o limite soluciones adaptadas, creativas y eficientes por parte del profesorado. 2. No hay que sobrecargar al profesorado. Se debe intentar que disponga de los recursos necesarios para la adaptación a la nueva situación. 3. El foco debe ponerse en el aprendizaje. Los nuevos retos nos obligan a rediseñar el proceso de enseñanza-aprendizaje, pero no se ha de perder nunca de vista que el objetivo es un aprendizaje profundo y de calidad por parte del alumnado. 4. Hay que aumentar la formación en educación del profesorado. Se necesita conocer nuevas herramientas, pero sobre todo se necesita una profunda reflexión sobre el modelo educativo actual para realizar cambios de calado. 5. Se debe promover la equidad social. El sistema educativo que se aplique durante esta crisis o que surja de ella no debe ahondar la brecha social entre el estudiantado, sino que debería ser una oportunidad para reducirla. Feedback from: Consejo General de Colegios de Ingeniería en Informática y Asociación de Enseñantes Universitarios de Informática (104.3 KB - PDF - 5 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: The plan is clear and covers the key actions well however it is important that a European strategy references the national strategy, for example in Ireland the digital learning framework. From our experience the plan will be a failure if it doesn't do this as circumstances vary so much from country to country.   The Covid-19 crisis has clearly proven the need for investment in ICT infrastructure in education , and   the  impact of such infrastructure will be greatly improved  if it is aligned with the development of digital literacy training for  teachers as well as the specific competences required for the use of technology in education.  There are a wide range of educational tools available , most of which incorporate self-assessment which is not objective and can be a difficulty for teachers in identifying quality resources. We are asking for the plan to support initiatives that can provide validated, quality digital content that supports learning, together with online tools that can accurately measure the effectiveness of this learning.   As technology has expanded and developed, so too has the definition of digital literacy.  ICDL modules support the development of a wide range of digital skills, including computing, robotics, and information literacy  as well as the core digital competencies. We would like to see this broad digital skills development supported through the funding and promotion of programmes like ICDL that have  demonstrable outcomes, ensuring tangible results for both learners and educational institutions.   From our own experience we  believe that  professional bodies could be leveraged to promote IT as a career, drive CPD and professionalism and to grow the pipeline of talent across the EU.
Initiative: Digital education action plan (update)
