feedback_msg_text: Der Fachverband der Reisebüros in der Wirtschaftskammer Österreich ist die gesetzliche Interessenvertretung aller österreichischen Reisebüros und Reiseveranstalter (2.666 Betriebe).  Wir begrüßen die von der Kommission angekündigte Evaluierung der Mehrwertsteuerregelung für Reisebüros.  Neben den bereits in der Roadmap genannten fünf Kriterien für die Evaluierung, sollte unseres Erachtens noch insbesondere auf folgende Punkte eingegangen werden:  1) Wie können bestehende Wettbewerbsverzerrungen zwischen EU-Reiseveranstaltern und Drittstaatsanbietern außerhalb der EU bekämpft werden? EU-Regelungen wie die Mehrwertsteuerregelung für Reisebüros sollten nicht zuletzt europäischen Unternehmen nützen und sie gegen Wettbewerbsverzerrungen aus dem Nicht-EU Gebiet schützen.  2) Inwiefern ist die Judikatur des EuGH zur Mehrwertsteuerregelung für Reisebüros mit den ursprünglichen Zielen der Richtlinie vereinbar? Insbesondere die vom EuGH geforderte Berechnung der Einzelmarge ist beispielsweise so in der Praxis nicht umsetzbar und wirft Fragen der Vereinbarkeit mit den Zielen der Richtlinie auf.   Der Fachverband der Reisebüros wird sich gerne in den weiteren Evaluierungsprozess einbringen und hofft, dass es zu einer Reform der Mehrwertsteuerregelung für Reisebüros kommt.
Initiative: VAT scheme for travel agents (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: VDR e.V. - Verband Deutsches Reisemanagement - Association of German Travel Management, Germany  The Verband Deutsches Reisemanagement e.V. (VDR) is the business travel association in Germany. He represents the interests of German business enterprises with regard to the framework and competitive conditions for business travel and mobility. He is committed to providing efficient, economical, secure, unhindered, worldwide travel opportunities for businesses.  The VDR welcomes the fact that the EU Commission is carrying out an evaluation of the special VAT system for travel agencies at this time. With the ruling of the European Court of Justice (ECJ) of 8 February 2018 (C-380/16), Germany was condemned to bring its national regulations into line with EU rules. As a result, the special VAT scheme must now also be applied if the travel services are intended for the company of the service recipient - i.e. also in B2B transactions in the area of business travel.    For German companies that carry out many business trips at home and abroad, the new regulations, as implemented in Germany with the Annual Tax Act 2019, raise numerous questions that make it massively more difficult to implement them in a legally compliant manner.  In general, it is very clear that the special VAT scheme applies by default to businesses where the consumer of the trip is a physical private individual - i.e. B2C. In the private customer sector, special VAT rules have no influence on the tax treatment by the recipient. However, in B2B transactions, where the package is sold to a subsequent company, which does not directly benefit the traveller but serves to fulfil his or her mission, there are several factors that make the treatment of VAT either impossible or unclear. In addition, it is observed that Member States have implemented the special VAT system for travel agencies in the B2B area in different ways with regard to the interpretation of e.g. travel services, which does not meet the requirement of harmonisation.  The adjustments implemented in Germany are now leading to great uncertainty as to when service providers in the business travel sector will continue to be allowed to report value-added tax and whether the commissioning companies will then be able to consistently claim this as input tax. The commissioning companies could thus be forced to accept 19% higher costs than before, or they could continue to receive invoices with input tax on services, but which are actually subject to special VAT scheme and thus trigger an unjustified deduction.  If the companies then incorrectly claim the input tax shown, they would have to make enormous repayments.   From the VDR's point of view, it cannot be inferred from the ECJ ruling that special VAT scheme must be applied to all services in the travel/event industry and must also apply to intra-German trade. Uniform clarification is urgently needed here. Furthermore, a harmonised application of the special VAT scheme in the Member States is necessary to prevent distortion of competition.
Initiative: VAT scheme for travel agents (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: VAT4U (www.vat4u.com) helps companies and VAT experts in improving VAT recovery processes across de globe, with a particular focus on the EU. In this regard, we face very frequent questions linked to Travel Agents and the application of TOMS. Please find below the main areas where the current scheme triggers confusion/issues:  -  B2B transactions: in general, it is very clear that TOMS should be applied by default to companies where the consumer of the travel is a physical person (B2C). However, when it comes to B2B transactions where the package is sold to a subsequent business (B2B), there are multiple factors that make the VAT recovery either impossible or unclear (even for Tax Administrations). We experienced as well a lack of harmonisation between the different MS on this topic.  - B2B transactions for non EU businesses: Travel Agents established outside the EU and selling services in there home country encounter the same difficulty. Therefore organising an event in a country where TOMS does not apply could be financially more attractive.  Ideas: 1) An "opt-out" option for B2B transactions should improve the way companies recover VAT. 2) When the end customer is a Business, it could be allowed to reclaim VAT on an invoice if the VAT had been charged to the travel agent on the corresponding operation (having in mind that there is clear evidence of this).  Best Regards. -- Damien Moras, Managing Director M. +49 21154556502 | dmoras@vat4u.com
Initiative: VAT scheme for travel agents (evaluation)

feedback_msg_text: Please read our full feedback attached in pdf. Scope: We support the Review examining the implementation of the Anti-Torture Regulation (the Regulation), and the implementation and impact assessment, which “may-include proposals for its amendment”. We believe amendments are needed in scope of goods / activities covered and to operative measures.  As well as the Anti-Torture Coordination Group, the Review should examine all relevant mechanisms for effective implementation of the Regulation including: reviews of market / product development and amendments to lists of controlled / prohibited goods;  a coordinated urgent action process by EU Member States, to halt the transfer of new and/or currently unregulated goods; reporting / information sharing between Member States and coordinated response to prevent “undercutting”; transparency and public accountability. “will provide information on the rules on penalties applicable to infringements laid down by the Member States” - extend to include links to relevant national legislation, associated guidance, plus implementation measures introduced.  “assess the need to include the activities of Union nationals abroad” within the ambit of the Regulation - should examine brokers as well as other activities by EU nationals and organisations including: promotion/marketing of goods and services outside the EU plus through the organisation of exhibitions in third countries; provision of technical assistance / training in the use of law enforcement equipment or techniques, to military, security, or police forces, non-State actors / private security companies. Examining “relevance, EU added value, coherence and complementarity, effectiveness, and efficiency” of the Regulation - it is crucial the Regulation is placed in the context of wider EU torture prevention initiatives and the inter-relationship between: the EU Sanctions Regime and embargos on arms and para- military equipment; Council Common Position 2008/944/CFSP, defining common rules governing control of exports of military technology and equipment plus Common Military List : national measures adopted by EU Member States. The negative (or positive) impact of other activities by EU Member States and Institutions should be examined including: provision of law enforcement equipment, technical assistance and/or training by EU Member States, by EU entities or under EU funded assistance or security programmes.  “relevance, EU added value, coherence and complementarity, effectiveness, and efficiency” -  include activities undertaken by the Commission and/or EU Member States to promote national, regional or other multinational agreements controlling/prohibiting the transfer of goods and services including: provision of advice / technical assistance to facilitate  the development of national legislation in line with the Regulation;  support by the EU for initiatives in other regional organisations such as Council of Europe or the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe OSCE.  The Review should examine how experience held by the Commission and Member States through implementing the Regulation could be applied elsewhere, as part of the Alliance for Torture Free Trade or the UN process under UNGA Resolution A/73/L.94: “Towards torture-free trade:  examining the feasibility, scope and parameters for possible common international standards”.  Process of Review: Public consultation: the short notice and restricted period may not result in wide participation and recommend this period be extended by at least a month. “Public consultation may be complemented by targeted consultations with specific stakeholders”- we believe consultations are essential.  Data collection and methodology -  Information from competent national EU authorities on the implementation of the Regulation; from the Anti-Torture Coordination Group and national activity reports should be published as annexes to the report, and on a regular basis in future.  Feedback from: Omega Research Foundation (368.3 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Human rights – review of EU ‘Anti-Torture’ Regulation (2016-20)

feedback_msg_text: We support the European Commission’s commitment to the ‘absolute prohibition of capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment or punishment’.  In accordance with this commitment, we think the present instrument would become more effective if it would be reviewed in line with the following concerns:  1. The regulation should consider in the title and elsewhere ‘…goods involved in capital punishment…’ For example, as the trade on organs harvested from killed prisoners, (now legalised in Iran), is of growing importance and is thus a result rather than a tool for capital punishment, it should definitely be considered in the regulation in an explicit form. This implies a thorough technical revision of items and procedures considered in the regulation.  2. Torture is very often an instrument for extra-judicial execution. Otherwise, some means and instruments used for capital punishment are also used for torture; e.g., cranes are used in Iran to maximise the suffering of the victims in the process of execution by hanging. Therefore, we consider that both capital punishment and torture should be dealt with as much as possible in the same framework. For instance, the group considered in Article 31 should clearly address both issues.  3. As the example of cranes in the above point demonstrates, it is not always easy to identify the specific goods used for punishment. We rather suggest for the European Commission, on the basis of objective criteria, to establish a list of countries of priority concern regarding the present regulation, and to, therefore, consider the import and export of goods on the basis of the specific information existing about these countries. Using the same example, cranes should be prohibited for export to Iran for instance, but not elsewhere, as far as the final destination would not be Iran. This means a new list of goods and services that are passible of ‘dual-use’, that is, normal activity, as well as torture, should be established. However, this list should only be used for a specific list of countries of concern, as it would entail a disproportionate administrative burden otherwise. 4. A listing of countries, personal, and moral entities engaged in torture activities should be established on the basis of the European institutions own resources as well as in verifiable and confirmed data supplied by third parties. The list of countries of concern should be used for the special application of trade control on ‘dual-use’ goods and services. The list of personal and moral entities should be used for possible sanctions.  5. The present regulation should establish transparent, objective and proportionate mechanisms for managing the lists mentioned in point 4, including the mechanisms of designation and periodic review. 6. Whereas we think the European Commission shall establish its own rules of work and consultation with other institutions according to the general laws and its working criteria (as considered in article 31), we believe it is also important to fully consider the reporting by and the consultations with the civil society. It would, therefore, be important for the European Commission to produce annual reports on the application of the present regulation, and to ensure the availability of these reports to the general public as well as for various interested parties.  7. The regulation should foresee a permanent vehicle for the European citizens to report to the European institutions' cases of capital punishment and or torture, and their relation with the European trading activities. This vehicle could be used as an information source for managing the lists of entities mentioned in point 5.   (Paulo Casaca) Executive Director  Alliance to Renew Co-operation among Humankind - ARCHumankind Avenue des Arts 19 - 1210 Bruxelles Belgique BE 0831.084.518 RPM Bruxelles IBAN: BE77 3630 8165 4842
Initiative: Human rights – review of EU ‘Anti-Torture’ Regulation (2016-20)

feedback_msg_text: DigitalES appreciate the opportunity to provide feedback to the Commissions initiative regarding the light deployment regime for small-area wireless access points and consider from an industry perspective that having harmonised rules applicable at European level and national level with simpler and consistent rules should create more transparent processes, increase the predictability of the deployments and reduce the administrative approval times. From a regulatory and administrative perspective this should lead towards scalable, repeatable, and streamlined planning and approval processes for the deployment of small-area wireless access points.  We therefore suggest that the regulatory frameworks to be defined to support the deployment of small cells must consider small cells similar to Wi-Fi access and thereby:   Adopt declarations of compliance instead of local/regional permits based on standardized size and installation requirements.   Benefit from simplified national infrastructure policies and design guidelines for installation requirements and radio characteristics where categories of equipment can be declared and certified generically at national level   Follow the internationally harmonised small cell power classes when developing regulations related to compliance with radiofrequency exposure limits and accept declarations of compliance and do not require routine post installation measurement Feedback from: digitalES (126.6 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: Small Cells – PIIT Response to consultations  Polish Chamber of Information Technology and Telecommunications (PIIT) welcomes the Commission’s initiative regarding Light deployment regime for small cells. The initiative includes the establishment of uniform technical requirements, the fulfillment of which will allow for easy and widespread use of small cells throughout the whole EU. Taking into account that small cells will be crucial to achieving 5G goals, the initiative is very desirable. However, the benefits of this initiative can be seriously diminished if the parameters of such access points would differ in different countries depending on the EMF limit used in the particular country.  Against this background we are concerned with last sentence in the following statement:   Small cells have lower power levels and thus overall electromagnetic fields exposure (EMF) would be distributed more evenly. In regard to EMF limits, the EECC refers to Council Recommendation 1999/519/EC. In particular, Article 45.2(h) of the EECC calls for consistency and predictability throughout the Union regarding the way the use of radio spectrum is authorised in protecting public health on the basis of the above Recommendation. Article 58 also provides that Directive (EU) 2015/1535 shall apply as regards draft measures of the Member States that would impose different requirements than those provided in this Recommendation in regard to the deployment of small-area wireless access points. However, the light deployment regime for small-area wireless access points shall be without prejudice to the adoption of such national measures setting stricter EMF requirements.  Small area access points (small cells) should be standardized across whole EU in a similar way like Wi-Fi access points or mobile phones (or other terminals). Such access points, by definition, have low output power what allows to use them safely (with a high safety margin). Differentiation of parameters of small cells would be an additional burden for countries that already suffer from low EMF  limits. In addition it would undermine the benefits of the European single market.  Therefore we strongly encourage the European Commission to ensure that actual common/ harmonized requirements for small area access points (small-cells) are established and harmonized approach to EMF limits is ensured.  --- Polish Chamber of Information Technology and Telecommunications (PIIT) is the largest Polish chamber grouping entities from telecommunications and IT sectors.
Organisation: Polish Chamber of Information Technology and Telecommunications (PIIT)
Initiative: Light deployment regime for small-area wireless access points
organisation_lower: polish chamber of information technology and telecommunications (piit)

feedback_msg_text: PMSE needs long-term security ++++   I. Who we are  The SOS initiative represents the interests of manufacturers and users of PMSE (Programme Mak-ing and Special Events), e,g. wireless microphones and In-Ear Monitor systems. It is committed to ensuring that sufficient and suitable frequencies are available for the use of PMSE even in a digital world.  Today, communication is no longer conceivable without PMSE. The devices can be used quickly and without great effort. At the same time, the complexity of events and productions is increasing. The number of audio PMSE devices in use is growing continuously. Many events, especially in the cul-tural and creative industries, would no longer be possible without PMSE.  II. Our situation   Most modern wireless microphone and all PMSE products operate in the UHF television band. UHF-spectrum is the core band for professional productions. Typically, wireless microphones operate on unused TV channels.  During the last 10 years, wireless microphone users have lost a huge percentage of available UHF television band. All-in-all, it was a total loss of nearly 50 % of TV-UHF spectrum for use by PMSE.  For sound engineers at the front-line of modern productions, the loss of such a significant amount of clean spectrum will have a substantial impact on their day-to-day working lives. Worst still, these changes come at a time when our live events industry (and ultimately the demand for wireless mi-crophones) is greater than ever all over Europe.  Demand for wireless microphones is at an all-time high, while at the same time clean space in which to operate is rapidly shrinking. There is no replacement spectrum on offer thus far to compensate for this loss. 60 MHz cannot cover the daily requirements for communication and production.  By the use of the 700 MHz band by IMT studies, conducted by the Bayerischer Rundfunk (Germany), it has been shown that in many areas in the range of 470 - 694 MHz less than 60 MHz are availa-ble. Often it is just 32 MHz. The remaining frequencies are used by TV transmitters or are disturbed by them. The substitute spectrum cannot compensate for this.  For example, 694 – 790 MHz will be cleared in Germany from now on, and in the UK latest by May 2020, which is 18 months earlier than was originally planned. The clearance will not only affect users in 700 MHz, it will also affect users in the spectrum below 694 MHz, as DTV transmitters will need to be re-purposed in the spectrum below 694 MHz. Ulti-mately, the result is a more congested RF landscape (once again) for PMSE users.  III. EU must keep their promises regarding to their commitments and timetable  The EU has defined the UHF TV range from 470 to 694 MHz for the use of DVB-T2 and PMSE until at least 2030. Appropriate allocations have been issued for DVB-T2. Consumers of wireless assets have evacuated the 700 MHz band and invested in new equipment to meet these commitments.  Any premature departure from this timetable would shake confidence in policy decisions. Many events could not be performed anymore.  IV. SOS proposes  • Long-term planning security for manufacturers and users through the identification of suit-able spectrum for Audio PMSE.   • Securing of the UHF spectrum from 470 to 694 MHz at least until 2030 for TV and audio PMSE, all over Europe.  • The designation of replacement spectrum for Audio PMSE in 2020 and not only in 2025 to achieve sufficient transit times.  • reviewing the frequencies designated for Audio PMSE in 2030, if adequate technical solu-tions and/or frequencies are available and applicable everywhere.  Beside evolution of specific Audio PMSE solutions (e.g. WMAS), 5G technologies like 3GPP 5G or DECT-5G might offer additional opportunities for PMSE applications in future.   Please read our attached opinion for the full text. Thank you.  Feedback from: SOS - Save Our Spectrum (601 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: Light deployment regime for small-area wireless access points

feedback_msg_text: ATTENTION: EU COMMISSION FEEDBACK ON “The 2012-15 EU Strategy for Protection and Welfare of Animals”:   In regards to the above policy guidelines, we understand that the EU Strategy lays a foundation for improving animal welfare standards as well as making sure that these standards are applied and enforced equally in all European Union countries.  It is the view of the DXE group that these guidelines, while well-intentioned, are insufficient in serving the best interests of the animals in question, and we are hereby calling for a complete abolition of all commercial farms, slaughterhouses and related institutions of animal exploitation.    In the interim, and until this ultimate goal has been reached, we would expect that the EU commission, with its stated aims of reducing animal cruelty, to immediately permit the following: -- The clear legalization and authorization for any person to rescue any type of animal from a property where said animal has been suffering or will suffer in the future. -- The immediate and clear legalization and installation of surveillance of any and all properties that are involved in the commercial animal trade  -- Increased penalties, fines and jail time for any individuals found to be willingly inflicting suffering on any animals -- A declaration from the EU Commission that animals shall be considered to have equal rights of freedom as well as dignity as humans do.  -- The guidelines should further state that all forms of hunting, including fishing, are to be prohibited with substantial penalties for non-compliance.  -- Any use or exploitation of animals in circus, bullfights, rodeos or any similar events are also to be prohibited.   -- The prohibition of breeding animals for the purpose of commercial sale -- The immediate closure and prohibition of zoos, with the intent of converting existing zoos to animal sanctuaries.

feedback_msg_text: At Plumas Moradas, a platform for feminist communicators based in Belgium, we are aware that the current European legislation on media does not include specific measures to achieve gender equality. Against this backdrop, we consider it is vital to transform the media, as they are guarantors of the right to access information, weapons to combat stereotypes and labor inequality, and determinants to end violence against women.  In the same vein as our colleagues from Comunicadoras 8M, we believe that the European Commission Gender Equality Strategy 2020-2024 must include a specific section dedicated to communication, resulting in the coming years in legislative changes, specific budget lines in the context of the Multiannual Financial Framework, and support measures to Member States.  We develop four action paths in our recommendations:  - "The media as guarantors of the right to access information" would be the first one, inspired by the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. We establish the need to promotion feminist university education, as well as women’s access to management positions within the media. Informative campaigns on gender equality through the media should also constitute a public commitment, and to be of mandatory dissemination periodically. In addition, the European Union should set an example with guidelines and manuals to combat sexist content published by European institutions, with a deeper commitment than the mere use of "gender neutral" language contained in the institutions’ style guide.  - “Combatting stereotypes through the media” is the second action path, inspired by the premises adopted in the Beijing Platform for Action in 1995. Our proposals entail the creation of educational content that broadens the understanding of girls and boys and the youth regarding the harmful reification and commodification of women's bodies. It also leads us to recommend the establishment of additional requirements when approving public subsidies, and to favor the creation of observatories of sexism in the media, to become gender equality elements mainstreamed in European regulations, transposed by all Member States.  - "Labor equality in the media" is the third area we develop. The situation is still far from being achieved: gender pay gap, pay transparency, gender balance on company boards, precariousness, unequal distribution of care and work-life balance, workplace and harassment in the workplace, among others. We consider it essential to take concrete measures that combat the image stereotypes suffered by women working in communication, and the application of parity in opinion spaces and debates. Among the possible incentives, we propose equality certificates for media, as well as the obligation to create gender equality delegates within editors.   - "End violence against women" is the fourth and inalienable purpose that encourages us in these recommendations. Ending violence against women is a social responsibility in which the media, with their hat of reality creators, have a crucial role. It is important to use factual terms for the description of what is happening, such as assuming that a sexist murder is a “feminicide”, turning mandatory the registry of fatal victims, and giving them the visibility they deserve, so that the seriousness of what happens every day is known in every Member State independently of social classes or economic situation. We propose that, at the same time that a journalism which is dignified and feminist is rewarded, the media that banalise violence against women and/or favor hate speech against women is penalised.  In the attached document we develop these and other recommendations, supported by arguments and data, in the hope that they will be taken into account by the European Commission in the Gender Equality Strategy 2020-2024. Feedback from: Plumas Moradas (1.3 MB - PDF - 10 pages) Download

feedback_msg_text: 4. Equality before the Law  In EU countries, men and women are not equal before the Law. For instance, in Finland, the legislation discriminates against men; conscription only affects men. We find it awkward that EU wants to improve the situation of all women all around the world, and yet allows its own member states to enforce entirely different legal status onto its citizens depending on their gender. Gender Equality issues especially affecting men must be taken seriously, too.  5. Income Equality  A key point in EU's Gender Equality Strategy is the Gender Pay Gap between men and women. The large differences between genders that are presented correspond to Eurostat's traditional method for producing comparative data between EU member states. However, this method doesn't comply with EU's Equal Pay Directive for measuring the Gender Pay Gap.  EU shall better instruct its member states towards uniform methodology and criteria for measuring the Gender Pay Gap. The key point shall be to measure actual hours worked.
Initiative: Gender equality strategy 2020-2024

feedback_msg_text: 1. Gender Equality indicators and metrics  The key problem in EU's gender equality efforts is the indicators and metrics being utilized. Instead of indicating how men and women fare on different aspects, EIGE metrics only emphasize whether women fare worse than men on those aspects. Even though men may fare much worse than women in some areas of life, this is not reported as a gender equality issue; conclusions instead state that gender equality has been achieved. This bias in the way information is portrayed shall be eliminated.  The Gender Equality indicators that are selected in EU's Gender Equality work tell very little about issues affecting men and women in each member state. The Basic Indicator of Gender Inequality (https://bigi.genderequality.info/) is an attempt at remedying this shortcoming. It aims at evaluating how well Gender Equality has been achieved for everyone. Its conclusions emphasize how, with the exception of Italy, the situation of women is better than men's in all EU countries. Gender Equality therefore ought to be evaluated in ways that measure its achievement level for everyone, and not only using a handful of criteria that conveniently support a small elite's gendered composition.  2. Labor Market Participation  According to EU's Gender Equality Strategy, women's lesser presence on the labor markets is considered a Gender Equality issue, yet men's lesser academic success is not acknowledged as a Gender Equality issue. The Gender Equality Strategy shall pay particular attention to boys' lesser academic success and young men's social exclusion in EU countries. Gendered differences in academic success and school performance constitute a Gender Equality issue with severe long-term consequences. For instance, in Finland, one out of eight boys completing comprehensive school cannot write or read adequately. PISA rankings show that differences between boys and girls are among the widest among OECD countries, and the situation has worsened every year. Men are also visibly under-represented in higher education in all EU countries.  The share of young men in social exclusion is a significant problem in all EU countries. In Finland, as much as one fifth of 20-25 year old men is neither working or studying. We strongly believe that one cause of this symptom is that Gender Equality metrics are focused on women and Gender Equality policies are strictly focused on improving women's situation, which is why we feel that EU's Gender Equality work's focus ought to measure true Gender Equality.  3. Violence  The Finnish bird's eye view on violence shows that a far greater share of violence is against men than against women, and that the more brutal the type of violence, the more likely it is against men. The same can certainly be said for all EU countries. Men also face as much domestic violence as women (at least in Finland).  The most efficient way of preventing violence is to oppose all forms of violence against everyone, instead of only opposing violence against women. The mere existence of international treaties and initiatives on violence against women shall not be considered as an obstacle to acknowledging violence against men. The goal shall be to create a violence-free culture, instead of perpetuating the current focus on gender-based violence.  EU shall take interest in factual data on violence against both men and women, instead of perpetuating its ideological stance on the issue. Research on the manifestation of violence and on services available to victims and perpetrators must be performed from gender-neutral starting points. In order to achieve balance in its strategies, EU must commit itself to investigating the prevalence of violence against men, including domestic violence, in all EU member states.
Initiative: Gender equality strategy 2020-2024

feedback_msg_text: Comunicadoras 8M, asociación española de periodistas feministas, partiendo de los medios de comunicación como vehículo de cambio al tiempo que instrumento para perpetuar ciertas estructuras, consideramos cuatro ámbitos: los medios como garantía de acceso a la información con perspectiva de género (1), como espacio de lucha contra los estereotipos (2), en relación con la igualdad laboral (3) y decisivos para el fin de la violencia machista (4).  En el mismo sentido que nuestras colegas Plumas Moradas, estimamos que actualmente ninguna normativa europea relacionada con los medios de comunicación incluye medidas específicas para el logro de la igualdad, más allá de menciones génericas acerca de la no discriminación por razón de sexo. Por ello, consideramos que  la Estrategia de la Igualdad de la Comisión Europea ha de incluir una mención específica a la comunicación que en los próximos años derive en cambios legislativos, partidas específicas en el contexto del Marco financiero plurianual, así como medidas de apoyo a los Estados Miembros.  La Declaración de Derechos Humanos de Naciones Unidas impregna la primera vía mencionada acerca de “Los medios de comunicación como garantía de acceso a la información”, en la que establecemos la necesidad del fomento de la formación universitaria feminista, así como el acceso a puestos directivos en los medios de comunicación. Las campañas informativas sobre igualdad de género a través de los medios también deberían constituir un compromiso para su difusión de modo periódico y obligatorio. Desde la Unión Europea, además, debería darse ejemplo con guías y manuales para combatir los contenidos sexistas publicados por las instituciones europeas, con un compromiso más profundo que el mero uso del "lenguaje neutral" recogido en el libro de estilo de las instituciones.  La Plataforma de Acción de Beijing de 1995 inspira nuestras propuestas sobre lucha contra los estereotipos en los medios de comunicación, que pasan por la creación de contenidos educativos que amplíen la comprensión de niñas, niños y jóvenes respecto a la dañina cosificación y mercantilización de los cuerpos de las mujeres. Nos lleva también a recomendar exigencias adicionales a la hora de aprobar subvenciones públicas, y a favorecer la creación de observatorios de sexismo en los medios, y la correspondiente plasmación de la igualdad en la normativa europea, para su asunción por todos los Estados miembros.  La igualdad laboral en los medios está muy lejos de conseguirse: brecha salarial, techo de cristal, precariedad, desigual reparto de los cuidados, acoso laboral y sexual… Consideramos imprescindible tomar medidas concretas que combatan los estereotipos de imagen que sufren las mujeres que trabajan en la comunicación y la aplicación de la paridad en los espacios de opinión y tertulias. Entre los incentivos posibles, proponemos certificados de igualdad en los medios, así como la obligación de crear delegadas de igualdad de género.  Acabar con la violencia machista es una responsabilidad social, en la que los medios de comunicación, en su papel de constructores de la realidad, tienen un papel crucial. Es importante establecer términos justos para la descripción de lo que ocurre, como asumir que un asesinato machista es un “feminicidio”, hacer obligatorio el registro de víctimas y darle visibilidad, para que sea patente la gravedad de lo que ocurre cada día sin distinción de países, clases sociales o situación económica. Proponemos que, al tiempo que se premia el periodismo digno y feminista, se penalice a los medios que realizan una banalización de la violencia machista o que favorecen el discurso del odio contra las mujeres.  Desarrollamos en el documento adjunto éstas y otras recomendaciones, apoyadas en argumentos y en datos, con la esperanza de que sean tenidas en cuenta por la Comisión Europea en la Estrategia de Igualdad de Género 2020-2024. Feedback from: Comunicadoras 8M (1.2 MB - PDF - 11 pages) Download
Initiative: Gender equality strategy 2020-2024

feedback_msg_text: La Fundación Civio es una organización sin ánimo de lucro con sede en Madrid que lucha por la transparencia en las administraciones públicas e impulsa cambios en las mismas a través del periodismo de investigación y datos y la tecnología.  Dada nuestra naturaleza periodística y movidos por el interés de conseguir una sociedad más igualitaria entre hombres y mujeres, en 2018 analizamos más de 100 empresas públicas españolas para conocer si estaban cumpliendo la Ley Orgánica 3/2007, de 22 de marzo, para la igualdad efectiva de mujeres y hombres. Este texto legal definía que la presencia femenina en los consejos de administración tenía que ser, como mínimo, de un 40%. Civio hizo público que esto no se cumplía en 8 de cada 10 consejos de 139 empresas públicas españolas. Aquí el link al artículo:https://civio.es/quien-manda/2018/02/05/el-80-de-las-empresas-publicas-ignora-la-ley-de-igualdad-en-sus-consejos-de-administracion/.  Estas conclusiones muestran que: 1)este nuevo marco de Gender Equality Strategy 2020 debería marcar las líneas para conseguir que todos los países de la Unión Europea contaran con su propia ley de igualdad con especial atención a una representación real de las mujeres en los mandos de poder; 2)la supervisión de la UE en que los países cumplan con su propia legislación en materia de igualdad.   Además, conseguir la información para llegar a las conclusiones que exponemos más arriba no fue fácil. Supuso visitar documentos públicos sobre las empresas o mirar información en cada una de las páginas web. No existe, aun siendo entidades públicas o semi-públicas, una forma sencilla de acceder a la composición por género de las mismas o, por ejemplo, a la brecha salarial de cada empresa por género. Desde Civio, creemos que esta información debería ser pública y estar disponible para consulta de cualquier ciudadano.
Initiative: Gender equality strategy 2020-2024

feedback_msg_text: Aviation – reporting safety-related incidents Evaluation and Fitness Check Roadmap  DJI welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the evaluation of the European rules on how to report, analyse and follow up on accidents and incidents in civil aviation.  In view of the new EASA Basic Regulation, the upcoming regulatory framework for product and operational requirements for Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS), and the ongoing work to create a European Unmanned aircraft system traffic management (UTM), an evaluation and review of Regulation 376/2014 is crucial to ensuring the highest levels of safety in Europe’s skies.  Recital 85 of the EASA Basic Regulation stipulates that responsible safety investigation authorities should be competent to decide whether or not to, “taking into account the expected lessons to be drawn from the improvement of aviation safety, not to initiate a safety investigation when an accident or serious incident concerns an unmanned aircraft for which a certificate or declaration is not required under this Regulation and no person has been fatally or seriously injured.”  Meaningful data on incidents is necessary to inform next steps for regulators as well as UAS operators and manufacturers in order to ensure safety in aviation. Unfortunetly, almost all of the data available today through EASA, Member State Civil Aviation Authorities (CAA) or other competent bodies is unreliable.  The current structure, inconsistency and unrefined nature of sighting reports disproportionately exacerbate concerns about manned-unmanned interactions and do not provide industry or government with actionable data on which to base safety enhancements and regulatory or operational decision-making. The result: lots of unverified reports, plenty of media speculation, but very little information that can be used to formulate plans to make drone flight safer.   “Reporting drone sightings that cannot be verified and appear to have no safety impact does not make much sense. At a minimum these reports should be screened to eliminate those sightings that are too speculative to reach conclusions about and focus on the handful that appear to have potential safety impacts.”  Inaccurate news stories harm the process of improving safety, because they focus attention on outrageous events that did not happen, instead of on aviation risks that may be less sensational but much more prevalent.  Therefore, DJI recommends more standardized incident reporting methods in order to improve quality. As set out in recital 85 of the EASA Basic Regulation, this includes defining the thresholds but should also include standards for submitting drone sightings, identifying consistent data to be collected for each sighting, and providing for further education or traditional aircraft pilots about drones to allow them to more accurately describe what they see.  DJI would also advise to provide searchable aviation incident databases, open to independent evaluation, and calls upon EASA and other aviation safety agencies and authorities in Europe not to publish seemingly authoritative reports based on what they admit is deeply flawed data.  As drones become a more common tool for professional tasks as well as a popular category of consumer electronics, the number of authorized drone operations continues to rise. As the European Union aims to develop U-Space, its own version of a UTM, authorized drone operations in proximity to civil and general aviation will increase. A key to the successful integration of drones is the skies is therefore to closely align any U-Space regulation with tailored incident reporting obligations in order to not report drone operators that fly legally and responsibly in proximity of aircraft as an aviation incident.  As a final point, DJI underlines the importance of protecting the identity of the drone pilot, operator or any other involved actors in an incident registry. DJI expresses its full support for the wordin
Initiative: Aviation – reporting safety-related incidents (evaluation of EU rules)

feedback_msg_text: Our feedback is focused for the aviation safety reporting, in particular the reporting via ECCAIRS.  - It should be defined how an incident or accident should be classified. In case of an incident, the most credible or the worst occurrence. In case of an accident, the effective or the potentially worst event? Maybe it would make sense, when EASA provides two different risk matrixes. - Some occurrences are classified as «major” and a follow-up doesn’t make sense, because all relevant informations and conclusions are already done in the initial report. Therefore the safety expert, who sends the report, should be able to decide, if there is a follow-up necessary or not.  - The ECCAIRS reporting form should be adapted to the needs of each airport. Some categories are missing. It would be helpful, if airport partners (not only air operators also handling agents) who are involved in events could be declared.  - Respective the occurrence categories, there should be scenarios only, not causes.  - We would appreciate it, when we were informed about the outcome of our reporting. We would like to have more (regular) feedback regarding possible changes in our reported data (e.g. occurrence catefgories or risk assessment) or are there other reports on the same event? What happens to the reports? How are they summarized? Not in general like in the EASA Aviation Safety report, but for the single aerodrome.  - The cooperation and interfaces with and to national Accident investigation authorities should be improved to avoid different reports with different data.  - The definition of incident and accident should be more accurate and in line with other definitions from EU law or from ICAO.  - The deadline of 72h doesn’t make sense in that cases, where the clarification of an event comes to the conclusion, that it has to be reported – not the event itself after a first impression. Sometimes the clarification take longer than 72h, most of all when involved persons aren’t available due their shift. We recommend, that occurrences should be reported after the first clarification (and therefore not after 72h strictly). Otherwise we have to think about, how we could delete reported events (initial report). It could be possible, that we find out - after the first clarification - that the event haven’t need reported. - Generally it is a high workload to report via ECCAIRS. Not sure, if only the reporting (and unknowing follow-up) will make the aviation industry safer.
Initiative: Aviation – reporting safety-related incidents (evaluation of EU rules)

feedback_msg_text: EC Transparency Register Number: 15257643846-58   NATS notes that the regulation requires organisations to supply data compatible with ECCAIRS software and ADREP taxonomy, in an XML / XSD specification containing mandatory data fields.  These mandatory data fields are set for all disciplines reporting under the regulations, however the fields are not necessarily relevant to all reporting organisations.    As an ANSP ten of the prescribed mandatory fields for data collection would not be known to reporters / notifiers or be part of the event data routinely gathered as part of the ANSP investigation process.  The specific attributes, included in entity 4 ‘Aircraft’ and entity 24 ‘Occurrence’, are as follows:   • 232 Propulsion type • 244 Aircraft registration • 254 Serial number • 281 State of registry • 432 Highest damage • 451 Injury level • 459 Total fatalities aircraft • 463 Total injuries-ground • 468 Total minor injuries-aircraft • 471Total serious injuries-aircraft    To ensure the appropriate collection of data we would recommend making completion of the mandatory fields discipline specific  in a similar way as the occurrence reporting types are set out in Implementing Regulation 2015/1018.
Initiative: Aviation – reporting safety-related incidents (evaluation of EU rules)

feedback_msg_text: Beside the cumbersome and bureaucratic workload created to be able to comply with the regulation unclarity consists in the definition of mandatory reporting according to article 4 of 376/2014. The vague definition of the list in EU Regulation 2015/1018 classifying occurrences in civil aviation which are to be mandatory reported do not match with the provided aim of 376/2014 which likes to ensure more reporting.   One of the main principles of 376/2014 and its implementing rules is to report occurrences. In a situation where reporters employed or whose services are contracted or used by different organizations of the same reportable occurrence, all are required to report that occurrence even in the case they are working for organizations that are under the responsibility of the same member state. There is no added value to ask different organizations to report exactly the same event/case and therefore questionable.  Service providers are requested more reporting and follow up which is understood. Nevertheless, there is very marginal to none feedback of the outcome of such reporting. The industry does not receive a consolidate yearly view of reports over the member states nor a clustering of main issues reported in more detail than in actual annual safety report. This would be more in the initial aim of best practice sharing. We recommend to receive on quarterly or at least yearly basis an overview of reports, which country reports how much (i.e. ration of registered aircrafts and maintenance organizations) and main issues which are identified which could be supported by initiatives or campaigns raised by EASA.   In 376/2014 (39) it is highlighted that “without pre justice to national criminal law and the proper administration of justice” the extend of the protection of the reporter and other persons mentioned in the occurrence reports is to be clearly demarcated from pre justice or prosecution. Rulemaker of 376/2014 shall focus on obliging member states to re-visit their national criminal law in order to ensure balanced approach between safety and administration of justice instead defining a vague desired condition. In order to improve the reporting- and just culture the protection of the involved individuals must be clearly defined.
Initiative: Aviation – reporting safety-related incidents (evaluation of EU rules)

feedback_msg_text: The main problem with urban mobility in the EU, within medium and big cities, is excessive car and to a lesser extent excessive motorbike usage. This means traffic jams, air and noise pollution and abuse of the public space by motor vehicles, which can take up to 75% of total available public land area.  The best solution is not popular: to restrict the usage of private cars within cities, which automatically improves the perceived utility of already existing alternatives.  We believe it would be a good idea to establish a common European roadmap to restrict car usage at all countries at the same time. In this manner, staging some unity around such a contemptious issue, local authorities would be more compelled to act responsibly. Reducing available parking spots by a given rate every year, taxing on-street parking spots, and in some cities establishing city congestion/pollution tolls like Milan, London or Stockholm already have done are some hints of what could be done.  We don't believe that subsidies to electric cars and motorbikes are a solution. Electric cars only reduce air pollution but seem to be a 'business as usual' ersatz solution, actually preserving the rest of the problem. Plus, subsidies to people who already have the purchasing power for an electric car are regressive. Approximately 15-30% of the population either cannot afford a car, be it electric or not, or even drive, in a context of aging population. Subsidizing electric cars does not do anything for these people.  We believe non-motorized transport (or active transport), i.e. walking and cycling, is a huge part of the solution, along with improving public transit. This includes walking and bicycle usage.  There are already EU funds destined to improving cities so as to provide safe and comfortable walking and cycling infrastructures. In our opinion, there are some problems with this.   For cities, especially smaller ones, it is relatively hard to get EU funds, with lots of red tape. And European cities are competing one against the other for these. We believe it would be best to make all National or where applicable Regional governments earmark a % of their yearly infrastructure budget for the purpose of ensuring safe and comfortable walking and cycling infrastructures. This goes in line with accessibility and equality objectives.  On the other hand, there is a lack of standards with regard to what a safe and comfortable infrastructure is, which means new cycling infrastructures are too many times lacking in quality, or quickly become insufficient in capacity. A good solution would be to provide a standarised solution manual much in the way Denmark or the Netherlands already have, and link funds to the quality of the resulting infrastructure.  With regards to this, we also believe it is more necessary to include this infrastructure in metro areas than in city centers - if cars are to be used less and less, bike lanes and such are not so necessary in city centers. However they will be necessary along main roads, to connect the suburbs, industrial areas and surrounding cities, moreso than city centers themselves.  Electric scooters have been a source of contempt lately - it is urgent to establish a paneuropean classification, much in the way pedelecs are perfectly defined. Otherwise, very fast and powerful devices that pass as scooters will be a real problem very soon.  And last but not least, there is a huge concern with bicycle parking safety. It would be an excellent idea to promote the inclusion of mandatory bicycle parking in all new buildings, be them public or private. Plus, old city centers are also lacking in this sense, so standards and solutions regarding bicycle parking solutions for these would also merit attention and funding from the EU.
Initiative: Urban Mobility in the EU

feedback_msg_text: I forbindelse med EU kommissionens revision af ELV direktiv 2000/53/EC vil vi hermed påpege de uhensigtsmæssigheder, som kommissionen efter vores opfattelse, skal finde en løsning på.  Hvem er vi; Bagsværd Jernhandel A/S er en familieejet virksomhed der siden 1946 har handlet med jern- og metal. Vi har modtaget biler til miljøbehandling gennem mere end 25 år og har således oplevet de, gennem årene, følgende lovmæssige tiltag, herunder ELV direktivet.  Det er 18 år siden ELV direktivet trådte i kraft, og man må derfor stille spørgsmålstegn ved om de allerede gennemførte tiltag er de rigtige, og om de er tilstrækkelige. Vi er umiddelbart af den opfattelse, at der er behov for nye tiltag, da mere end 4.500.000 udrangerede køretøjer hvert år forsvinder i EU. Forskellen på en brugt bil (Et reparerbart brugt køretøj ) og en skrot bil (Et Ikke-miljøbehandlet udrangeret køretøj ) er ikke definerbar. Samtidig er det ”kun” skrot biler der reguleres af ELV direktivet, da en brugt bil ikke er affald. Hvis der ikke sker en koordinering mellem SKAT/toldmyndigheder og miljømyndighederne vil problemerne med ulovlig import/eksport af affald ikke blive løst.  Siden 2007 har producentansvar for biler i Danmark betydet: ”at bilproducenter og bilimportører er ansvarlige for at sikre at en bilejer kan komme af med sin skrotbil uden omkostninger. Samtidig har der I Danmark gennem de sidste 18 år været en direkte sammenhæng mellem størrelsen på skrotningsgodtgørelsen og antallet af biler der blev afleveret til godkendte autoophuggere. Jo lavere skrotningsgodtgørelse des færre biler afleveret til godkendte autoophuggere.  Det ulovlige marked stod, i 2016, for 20-25% af alle skrotninger i Danmark  og det er derfor ikke tilstrækkeligt blot at kunne aflevere bilen ”uden omkostninger”.  Vi mener, at producentansvaret skal redefineres, og det er absolut nødvendigt med et større økonomisk incitament til den sidste ejer eller indehaver, hvis man vil have flere skrot biler til at ende deres dage hos godkendte autoophuggere.  Alle godkendte autoophuggere har de sidste mange år indberettet genanvendelsesprocenter til EU for de biler de har modtaget og behandlet. Vi vil opfordre kommissionen til at lette den administrative byrde for virksomhederne og myndighederne. Baseret på de sidste mange års indberetninger, skal der udarbejdes nøgletal for affaldsfraktionerne i den enkelte bil. Herefter vil den enkelte autoophugger og det enkelte land kunne ”nøjes” med at indberette antallet af modtagne og behandlede biler. Myndighederne vil herefter kunne anvende sparede ressourcer til at identificere de ulovlige autoophug.  Sidstnævnte bør prioriteres højest, da bekæmpelse af ulovlige autoophug vil bidrage til at mindske antallet af de biler der hvert år forsvinder. Hvilket igen set ud fra et miljømæssigt perspektiv er vigtigere end indsamling og bearbejdning af data fra de godkendte autoophuggere.     1.EU CORRESPONDENTS' VEJLEDNING nr. 9 2.EU CORRESPONDENTS' VEJLEDNING nr. 9 3.Udredning af skrotningsgodtgørelsens incitamentsstruktur. Miljøstyrelsen 2016. Feedback from: Bagsværd Jernhandel A/S (16.4 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download
Initiative: End-of-life vehicles - evaluating the EU rules

feedback_msg_text: Na wstępie należy zaznaczyć, że Dyrektywa 2000/53/EC (Dyrektywa ELV) nie realizuje swoich celów w postaci osiągnięcia realnego poziomu odzysku i recyklingu. Poprzez regulacje prawne utrudniające stacjom demontażu realne rozliczenie ilości odpadów poddawanych odzyskowi i recyklingowi dane statystyczne przekazywane do Komisji Europejskiej oraz innych organów są tylko danymi wirtualnymi. Najważniejszym celem Dyrektywy ELV jest likwidacja nielegalnego demontażu pojazdów. W Polsce ten cel nie został zrealizowany. Ponad 50% pojazdów jest demontowanych w nielegalnie działających stacjach demontażu. Potencjał rynku wynosi 1 – 1,2 mln pojazdów rocznie. Demontowanych jest niewiele ponad 500 tysięcy rocznie.  Dodatkowo sprowadza się do Polski pojazdy do demontażu z krajów Unii Europejskiej (głównie z Niemiec i Wielkiej Brytanii). Pojazdy te są sprowadzane tylko i wyłącznie w celu pozyskania części. Elementy zbędne i niebezpieczne są zagospodarowywane niezgodnie z przepisami ochrony środowiska. Już same przepisy dotyczące transgranicznego przemieszczania odpadów skutecznie odstraszają przedsiębiorców od legalnego importu pojazdów wycofanych z eksploatacji. System prawny zmusza do omijania prawa. Dodatkowo koszty gospodarowania odpadami są przekazywane tylko niewielkiej liczbie przedsiębiorców (ok. 70 podmiotów na ponad 1000 stacji demontażu) i są ustalone na poziomie od 0,4 do 1 zł za każdy pojazd (co stanowi kwotę 0,25 eurocentów).  Feedback from: Polskie Stowarzyszenie Stacji Demontażu Pojazdów EKO-AUTO (187.6 KB - PDF - 1 page) Download

feedback_msg_text: AVIALTER, Asociación Profesional de la Avicultura Alternativa en España representa los intereses de los profesionales dedicados a la producción avícola en sistemas alternativos. La avicultura alternativa es una actividad enraizada en el terreno y no “deslocalizable” que aporta importantes beneficios al mundo rural y a los consumidores deseosos de productos originales y cargados de la historia, cultura y tradiciones del territorio y de sus gentes. Transmitir al consumidor los valores propios de estas producciones requiere de etiquetados claros y medidas eficientes para que quienes realmente no sean merecedores de éstos, no se los apropien indebidamente provocando así un grave perjuicio a los productores, a los consumidores, al mundo rural y a la credibilidad del sector agroalimentario en general.  Estamos a favor de mantener lo regulado en el artículo 11 a 14 y anexo V del reglamento 543/2008. Entendemos que es necesario mantener los actuales sistema de cría con identificación en la etiqueta para una correcta ordenación del mercado de la carne de pollo. Este sistema ha permitido desarrollar una importantísima actividad avicola con inversiones al alcance de un pequeño agricultor que contribuye de manera decisiva a mantener un medio rural vivo al facilitar rentas complementarias en la renta familiar. Ha permitido identificar unos modos de producción que satisfagan a los consumidores y que animan a los agricultores a invertir en su actividad agrícola. También estamos a favor de una regulación europea del término "crecimiento lento" para garantía de los consumidores y de los productores. Un real crecimiento lento no debería sobrepasar los 35 gramos de ganancia media diaria. En lo que concierne al reglamento 589/2008, la obligación de indicar el tipo de granja con los códigos numéricos  y su correspondiente mención obligatoria del sistema de cría, es esencial  para tener una segmentación buena. Estos puntos de este texto deben ser mantenidos. Para que todo esto se cumpla entendemos que es totalmente necesario establecer sistemas de control para evitar el fraude en el etiquetado, así como la inclusión de otras menciones que puedan inducir a error al consumidor.
Initiative: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]

feedback_msg_text: These statements are made on behalf of Eipro (https://eipro.de), an egg product company. Egg products are defined in No. 7.3 of Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 853/2004 laying down specific hygiene rules for on the hygiene of foodstuffs as “processed products resulting from the processing of eggs, or of various components or mixtures of eggs, or from the further processing of such processed products.”   The CMO evaluation is a welcome opportunity to look at Commission Regulation (EC) No 589/2008 on marketing standards for eggs. It provides an unique opportunity for stakeholders to comment on the Regulation before it becomes ‘Lisbonised’ and probably rigidly unchanged for years to come.   Manufacturers of egg products face a predicament when it comes to the compulsory indication of the type of farming under which laying hens are kept. Practices in the application of Regulation (EC) No 589/2008 vary between Member States (and sometimes within a single Member State) while it should be the task of the CMO to secure a level playing field across the internal market for egg products. If Union law makes the indication of the type of farming for laying hens compulsory, this uniformity should prevail across the EU notwithstanding national practices.   A further complication is the summer season that usually sees a decline in overall consumption of eggs and consequently a surplus of free-range eggs and deep-litter eggs that is not absorbed by food retail. This surplus can only be absorbed by the egg product sector if these eggs can be processed without specific indication of type of farming. However, downgrading is currently not permitted.   Given that the Commission is interested in hearing from stakeholders about the scope of the evaluation programme in this round of consultation, we would advocate including the particularities of the egg product sector and the indication of animal husbandry in the assessment of Regulation (EC) No 589/2008 that otherwise is considered generally operational. The egg product sector is keen to provide further explanations as studies progress and further market evaluations are undertaken.   Eventually we would suggest that the Civil Dialogue Group (CDG) on Animal Products – Sector “Poultrymeat and Eggs” looks into the issue.   Walter Peuker CEO
Submitted by: Walter Peuker EIPRO VERMARKTUNG GMBH UND CO. KG
Initiative: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]

feedback_msg_text: The AIJN (European Fruit Juice Association) is the European trade body representing producers of fruit and vegetables juices and nectars in the European Union. The composition of fruit juices, concentrated fruit juices, dehydrated fruit juices and fruit nectars, their reserved names, their manufacture and labelling characteristics are subject to specific Community rules under Council Directive 2001/112/EC relating to fruit juices and certain similar products intended for human consumption. These products are defined on the basis of their composition and preparation processes so as to ensure that the terms are used correctly and not misleading. The Directive also defines particular designations used in certain countries and languages. The text lists the raw materials which may be used to manufacture juice and nectar, the minimum content of fruit juice and/or fruit purée in fruit nectar as well as all authorised treatments and substances.   This Directive was amended in August 2009 by the Commission Directive 2009/106/EC and in 2012 by the Directive 2012/12/EU in order to be adapted to technical progress taking account of developments in relevant international standards, in particular the Codex Standard for fruit juices and nectars (Codex Stan 247-2005) and the AIJN Code of Practice for evaluation of quality and authenticity of juices. From the industry perspective, this directive guarantees the level-playing field for the sector and sets clear and strict product definitions. It protects product names of juices and nectars, and although there are some unintended consequences in labelling provisions of the Directive that should be changed to avoid consumer confusion (i.e. not being able to use the ‘no added sugar’ term on juices), the industry is strongly in favour of maintaining and further improving this legal text.
Initiative: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]

feedback_msg_text: A) Context of the regulations  Reg 1308/2013: 1. Regulation CE 543/2008, Art. 11, Paragraph (1),  provides: - In order to indicate types of farming with the exception of organic or biological farming, no other terms except those set out hereunder and the corresponding terms in the other Community languages listed in Annex IV may appear on the labelling within the meaning of Article 1(3)(a) of Directive 2000/13/EC, and in any case they may appear only if the relevant conditions specified in Annex V to this Regulation are fulfilled:  (a) ‘Fed with …%…’ (b) ‘Extensive indoor’ (‘Barn-reared’) (c) ‘Free range’ (d) ‘Traditional free range’ (e) ‘Free range – total freedom’ 2. Art 11, Paragraph (2):  Mention of the age at slaughter or length of fattening period shall be permitted only when use is made of one of the terms referred to in paragraph (1) and for an age of not less than that indicated in Annex V(b), (c) or (d).  3. Annex V, letter (d) “Traditional free range ”, subsection (vii), provides:      “the birds are of a strain recognised as being slow growing”.  B) Regulation 1169/2011 – on the provision of food information to consumers  “The use in the Member State of marketing of the name of the food under which the product is legally manufactured and marketed in the Member State of production shall be allowed. However, where the application of the other provisions of this Regulation, in particular those set out in Article 9, would not enable consumers in the Member State of marketing to know the true nature of the food and to distinguish it from foods with which they could confuse it, the name of the food shall be accompanied by other descriptive information which shall appear in proximity to the name of the food.”   C) Practical context/in the field: 4. Differentiated growth as against conventional broiler is developing in Europe (eg. France:  certified poultry; Holland: COT, AH, Jumbo; UK: RSPCA indoor, etc. – internal standards     recognised by Profesional Association of producers, traders and consumers) based by slow growing breed (femals), growing system wihch is not fit in regulation requirements Reg 534/2008, Art. 11. 5. Slow growing femals are used even for chicken raised up to 56 days of age (different to  annex V, letter (d), subsection (vii)). 6. This type of growing it went through Romania in the last years; chickens from slow growing  Hubbard femals are raised indoor up to 56 days of age (to get live body weights of 2.25 kg).  7. In Romania there is no other growing system recognized/standardized than industrial/  conventional growing and the one provided by Reg 534/2008, Art. 11. 8. Based on genetical differences (slow growing female parents – confirmed by the producer  by a certificate of origin), differentiated age of slaughter (minimum 56 days) and differentiated nutrition of Hubbard breed with conventional/industrial broiler, the producers should be able to use differentiating elements on label (allowed by Reg 1169/2011, Art. 17) to inform correctly the consumer that this chicken meat bring additional benefits through slow growing: taste, consistency and flavor. 9. In this context, Reg 543/2008 is restricting and it is not allowing the use of differentiating  elements beside the one that refers on growing system (Art. 11; annex V).  We propose improve/amendment of Reg 543/2008 and complete growing systems with: “indoor slow growing/differentiated system”, with minimal 56 days killed age with density conform with Directive CE 43/2007, depends on fullfiled the conditions, without restrictions from Art. 11, letter (b), annex V, subsection (i) and (ii).
Initiative: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]

feedback_msg_text: As part of the RREUSE network, AERESS would like to support the attached statement co-signed by RREUSE, ECOS, the EEB, CoolProducts, TopTen and IFixit in particular concerning resource efficiency requirements for household cold appliances. We also support the following complementary information provided by RREUSE in its submission to this consultation: To support the idea that the repairability of household cold appliances is necessary to save both energy and resources, RREUSE asked to his membership to share data related to the second-hand market of domestic refrigeration. Three social enterprises including two in Belgium and one in Italy, as well as a network of re-use centres in Spain, answered to RREUSE with the following information: • How old are the second-hand domestic refrigeration products? In Belgium and Italy, the average age of second-hand household cold appliances sold by RREUSE members is varying from an operator to another, ranging from 4 to 9 years.  In Spain, the re-use centre network has difficulties to estimate the age of the appliances received from households. However, and thanks to the EPR scheme put in place in Spain, some of their members have contracts with manufacturers allowing them to have access to products returned within the guaranty period. They estimate that the age of the appliances received through this system is around 2 years.  • Are new fridges really more energy efficient than second-hand appliances? RREUSE members find no significant differences between the fridges currently put on the market and those which are showcased in their re-use shops when it comes to compare their energy efficiency. Most of the appliances that they collect are rated between A and A+++, B being the less energy efficient that they are collecting.  However, the Italian operator noticed that it was a trend in the Italian households to replace their appliances for energy efficiency reasons. This explanation was given to justify the very early replacement (before 7 years of use) of totally functioning fridges which did not have a significantly different energy efficiency when compared to new appliances.  • Should the forecast about the improving energy efficiency of domestic refrigeration products be a reason to forget about resource efficiency requirements?  RREUSE understands that for appliances which were placed on the market before the enforcement of the Commission regulation n°643/2009, replacement can be justified. Anyway, the demand for such products being very low, re-use operators tend to let those old appliances be recycled. However, with a lack of accurate life cycle assessment for each appliance, there is a threat that a communication focused on energy efficiency could result in premature replacements of still functioning and energy efficient appliances as it is the case in Italy. This could have an overall negative impact on the environment if we take into account the energy and the resources used for their manufacturing.  The RREUSE network believes that the replaceability of domestic refrigeration products’ spare parts and their repairability could, in the future, allow for their upgrading towards better energy efficiency. This is why we welcome the possibility to change the door gaskets proposed by the Commission since it can help improve the energy efficiency of older products by maximising their insulation, even though we think that more spare parts could respect the same requirement.  Resource efficiency requirements are often described as being hindrances to innovation while we see them as drivers for innovation for the benefit of consumers and the environment. Resource and energy efficiency requirements should be considered as complementary and not opposed. Repairability, durability, upgradability and modularity are criteria that we think should be the next innovation targets of manufacturers of Electrical and Electronic Equipment.  Feedback from: AERESS (623.5 KB - PDF - 4 pages) Download
Initiative: Review of ecodesign requirements for household cold appliances

feedback_msg_text: DEKRA welcomes an update of the ErP requirements.  We would like to see a consolidation of the different regulations to simplify compliance procedures.  We would like the commission to embrace the developments on connectivity and include requirements for software compliance. Clear responsibilities on the compliance of products that contain software is needed.  DEKRA welcomes further evaluation and possibly regulations on standby power consumption of lighting controls and control devices.  We assume that further requirements like repareability and recyclability will be included in compliance requirements as needed to embrace and develop circularity in our economy.
Initiative: Review of ecodesign requirements for lighting products

feedback_msg_text: Our views on the Commission’s proposal are summarised in the attached paper: https://goo.gl/NSvjpG  We are in favour of Option 5 because Ecodesign & Energy Labelling requirements for lighting help mitigate climate change and help EU citizens save on their bills, and we strongly support the efforts made by the Commission intention to better integrate lighting in a Circular Economy, notably by introducing requirements on the removability of light sources and control gears. In our paper, we have listed additional measures we think that the European Commission should be taking or maintaining to increase lighting lifetime.
