feedback_msg_text: The Fédération Européenne des Parfumeurs Détaillants ("the FEPD") – is the umbrella organization of the national European federations and organizations in the perfumery retail trade. As well as the national federations, members include those international retail trade groups within the perfumery industry which are active in at least four European countries.  Selective distribution provides customers with a unique shopping experience in line with each brand's universe, within stores and continued online for most members of the FEPD.  The benefit of the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation, in particular of its provisions on selective distribution, has been crucial to preserve the specificity and the success of the iconic industry of luxury perfumes and cosmetics, which is one of the spear-heading industries in Europe.  Maintaining the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation and the exemption conditions is essential to sustain and further develop an activity that provides access to a wide range of luxury perfumes and cosmetics to consumers.  The ability to impose (i) an obligation to contribute to the costs of the physical distribution network by opening one or more points of sale as well as (ii) the ban on resale via third-party platforms are key prerequisites to preserve the sustainability and integrity of the relevant selective distribution networks.  The FEPD is therefore convinced that the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation and the Commission's Guidelines must be upheld on these points.  The FEPD stands ready to receive questionnaires and provide further comments and input as part of the ongoing evaluation process. Feedback from: Fédération Européenne des Parfumeurs Détaillants (349.2 KB - PDF - 3 pages) Download
Initiative: EU competition rules on vertical agreements – evaluation

feedback_msg_text: The Regulatory Institute developed an article on drone regulation (Drones: national regulations not complete http://www.howtoregulate.org/drones-national-regulations-not-complete/#more-52) and submits its regulatory research to this feedback on Detailed rules on unmanned aircrafts. We have included highlights from the article in this feedback but urge regulators to access the article online to be able to access the links.  The Regulatory Institute is an independent, not-for-profit organisation, assisting the improvement of regulation in different jurisdictions by providing support to those developing regulation. The Regulatory Institute collects methodological knowledge through comprehensive research of regulatory techniques used in many different sectors and by many different jurisdictions in different parts of the world. The Regulatory Institute makes applied methodological knowledge accessible for free through Howtoregulate.org.  The article lists all the aspects which can be regulated with regard to drones and the list is based on the various regulations we found concerning drone regulation. Although the list of possible areas to regulate is extensive, of course no regulator is obliged to cover all these aspects, merely to consider the implications to regulate or not. Furthermore, consideration could be given to regulations on the various use forms or can combine the various use forms with the list of aspects which can be regulated. Examples of such uses to be regulated include:  – Recreational use; – Use for agriculture; – Use for transport of goods; – Use for communication purposes (e.g. facilitating mobile communication during events); – Use for energy generation (wind turbines); – Use for other commercial purposes (e.g. generating pictures in a view of selling or utilising them commercially, repairing infrastructure); – Use for artistic purposes; – Use for educational or research purposes; – Use for military purposes; – Use for public inspection purposes; – Use for firefighting, rescue and relief operations (such as locating victims); – Use for other public / government purposes.  The majority of laws so far identified do not distinguish too much between these various use forms. Mostly, regulators have so far focused on recreational use. An exception hereto is the law of Unmanned Aircraft (Public Safety and Security) Act (2015) of Singapore (see the article for the link to the regulation). Furthermore the draft U.S. bill lists a range of use forms. The final bill will certainly be worth following up on.  Of course, jurisdiction can set-up the usual certification or approval requirements (more on this in our Handbook, Chapter 7). An interesting possible procedural element can be found in the law of Switzerland. Switzerland requires a “total hazard and risk assessment” as part of the application for certain flights, namely flights above gatherings or without direct eye contact.  What other good practice is worthwhile being mentioned?  – New Zealand has developed an excellent website, presenting in a simple and comprehensive way legal obligations. The second best website we found is the one from the United Kingdom. – Singapore has developed an easy to use online portal for online-applications of pilots / drivers.  For the full version of the article please access here: http://www.howtoregulate.org/drones-national-regulations-not-complete/#more-52
Initiative: Detailed rules on unmanned aircrafts

feedback_msg_text: Dear representative,  As a founder of a French Start-up dedicated of drones for intiations, lessons & certifications I'm writing a feedback about the drone's law & rules to be safe for pros & amateurs of drones.  The DGAC, which the organisation registering the rules of the aviation in France, voted for new rules for all the users of drones, pros or not. From the january first of this year each drones whose the weight is equal or superior to 800 grams has to be registrated.  For professional use, a certificate has to be passed (theorical & practical) with a registrated number and a theorical aircraft QCM. Each fly has to be registrated by the Police organisation before with a defined flight plan with a registrated drone [EAN unique registrated number]. The drone has to have a fall alarm mode and a No Fly System to avoid a sensitive zone of fly. The drone has to stay on a eye visible area for the pilote.   For non-professional use, the certificate has to be passed but only theorical with an altitude maximum of 150m. A registrated drone [EAN unique registrated number] has to be use with a fall alarm mode and a No Fly System to avoid a sensitive zone of fly. The drone has to stay on a eye visible area for the pilote.  For each use of an photograph or video 's drone, the area of fly avoid sensitive zone and public zone, the only way to fly freely a drone is on the dedicated area (clubs or flies areas). If a pilote wants to fly on different area he has to ask a form to the police department one month before the fly.  Each flight or broadcasting from drone is legal on France if the infrastructure or persons has given the autorisation to be capted by the camera lens.  The hobby's & racers drones whose weighted less than 800 grammes have no rules yet. And numbers of illegal flights on "Urbex" zones are still dangerous to detected and dangerous for non-pilote who is located on the flying area of the pilote. For all the pilots who want to fly a racer or a hobby drone, the maximum height doesn't have to be more than 50m of altitude to avoid a danger for helicopters or planes. The pilot of racers' drone has to be related to a club registrated to the national federation of drones, FFAM in France for example.  A lot of rules has to put in place to avoid a danger of those kind of flying machines, but a lot of economic opprtunities will be a main part for the future and new jobs will be created through this technology.  Thanks a lot for the consideration you will granted to my feedback.  Best regards  Matthieu Perillaud - Co-founder of DRONEEZ
Initiative: Detailed rules on unmanned aircrafts

feedback_msg_text: 1. The Belron Group of Companies ("Belron"), operating in the EU under the CARGLASS(r) trademark, is involved in the business of vehicle glass repair and replacement ("VGRR") and since 2 years in 3 EU countries also in vehicle accident repair and replacement ("ADRR"). Belron operates in 35 countries, generates with 28,000 employees (14,000 employees working in the EU) a turnover of nearly EUR 4 Billion. 2. The design protection laws in the EU are unfortunately not harmonized. Several member states have introduced a "repair clause" (e.g. United Kingdom, Belgium, Spain, Hungary and others) which provides no design protection if the visible spare part is used for the purpose of a repair, other EU countries grant design protection for spare parts (e.g. France, Austria) and in Germany, the President of the Car Manufacturers´ Association has confirmed to the German Government in writing, that the Car Manufacturers will not excercise such design rights until a harmonization of the European law is achieved. However, German car manufacturers do not respect such committment of the German Car Manufacturers` Association.  This lack of harmonization is a major barrier in trade between member states, creates high legal uncertainty, prevents the economic benefits of a single European Market and leads to economic inefficencies. 3. The above described fragmented legal sitation, contrary to the fundamental European principle of free movement of goods, leads for Belron to major issues, such as  (i) difficulties to access visible spare parts, where design protection exists, (ii) prevents the creation of a pan-European supply chain for spare parts and bears the risk of a product seizure at the border (e.g. from Spain to France, which happened to Belron already in the past), (iii) leads to significantly higher prices for visible spare parts in countries with design protection, because car manufacturers use their monopoly to increase prices in such EU countries  - according to the "The Economic Review of Industrial Design in Europe - Final Report (Markt/2013/064/D2/ST/OP) of January 2015 ("Economic Study 2015") the prices in design protected EU countries are 6.4% to 10.3% higher than in countries with a repair clause (iv) litigations with car manufacturers. Belron had already 4 litigations with car manufacturers in different EU member states and we know that in particular German and French car manufacturers are using design protection to litigate against various small and medium sized aftermarket competitors. 4. Based on the above and due to lack of harmonization in the EU, the Belron Group would welcome very much a European "repair clause" which grants full design protection for new cars, but would permit free competition in the aftermarket, if a visible spare part is replaced for the purpose of a repair. The repair clause is fully supported by the (i) The Economic Study 2015 (Markt/2013/064/D2/ST/OP), which summarizes its conclusions on page 160 as follows: "Accordingly, we recommend that the Repairs Clause be introduced at EU Level and mandated throughout the single market" sugesting the "full liberalisation is the most natural Approach" (ii) Federal Cartel Offices ("FCO") from several countries, e.g. France and Romania.  5. A full liberalisation of the aftermarket by the repair clause would lead in EU countries with design protection for visible spare parts to major benefits for (i) consumers, because due to more competition they would have more choice in the aftermarket and would pay signifcantly lower prices for a repair (ii) insurers, as they would have to pay less for a repair of an insured vehicle and, as a consequence thereof, would charge less premiums to their policyholders (iii) entrepreuneurs, as more small companies would be established (iv) employees, as the full liberalisation would lead to more employment in the EU by small and medium sized companies in the aftermarket.
Initiative: Evaluation of EU legislation on design protection

feedback_msg_text: Fondata nel 2004, ADIRA è l’associazione italiana dei distributori indipendenti di parti di ricambio per autoveicoli, ricambi di carrozzeria inclusi, 4500 ca. piccole e medie aziende che giornalmente riforniscono su tutto il territorio nazionale 75.000 ca. officine di riparazione e carrozzerie indipendenti, non vincolate cioè da accordi commerciali con le case automobilistiche. ADIRA è membro di FIGIEFA, la Federazione Internazionale dei distributori dell'aftermarket indipendente (IAM). Il nostro scopo (obbiettivo) è quello di rappresentare e difendere gli interessi della categoria dei Distributori Indipendenti ed agire con forte determinazione per affermare presso i Poteri Pubblici e le Istituzioni nazionali ed europee i valori dell’indipendenza e della libera concorrenza, nel mercato del post vendita auto. L’attuale situazione di estrema diversità tra i vari Stati membri del quadro normativo relativo ai disegni e modelli, che si traduce nella mancata armonizzazione a livello comunitario di tale disciplina, produce effetti negativi anche sul sistema distributivo. Infatti, i produttori indipendenti di parti di ricambio visibili (fornitori della distribuzione indipendente), proprio a causa dell’incertezza conseguente alla mancata introduzione della clausola di riparazione in tutti i paesi della UE, vedono in pericolo la propria capacità di fare impresa, non potendo investire quanto sarebbe necessario al fine di immettere sul mercato una gamma di prodotti completa e a prezzi concorrenziali. Fatto ancora più accentuato dalla recente tendenza delle case auto di apporre il proprio marchio su componenti quali paraurti, griglie, ecc… e ad azionarne i relativi diritti, anche con modalità di vero e proprio abuso. E’ chiaro allora il pregiudizio per la filiera distributiva che si concretizza in difficoltà di approvvigionamento nonché in un’offerta incompleta - ai consumatori - delle parti di ricambio visibili, prodotte dai produttori indipendenti ed alternative all’originale. L’armonizzazione delle legislazioni dei vari Stati membri in tema di disegno e modello industriale, è solo uno dei passaggi necessari alla creazione dell’equità concorrenziale tra case auto e aftermarket indipendente. Il che, ovviamente, si tradurrebbe in vantaggi economici, qualitativi e di sicurezza a favore degli automobilisti della UE. Infatti, l’eliminazione di ogni possibilità di abuso dei diritti di proprietà industriale sia con riferimento ai disegni e modelli quanto in riferimento ai marchi, sottende ai principi ispiratori della politica comunitaria. ADIRA accoglie con favore e supporta il progetto di valutazione della Commissione, come prossimo passo di quella procedura diretta alla complessiva analisi della legislazione in materia di disegni e modelli industriali all’interno della UE, senza tralasciare l’invito, rivolto proprio alla Commissione, di un’analisi diretta alla definitiva eliminazione di ogni ostacolo alla libera concorrenza, determinato da un’incerta normativa in materia di diritti di proprietà industriale e da un distorto utilizzo dei medesimi.
Initiative: Evaluation of EU legislation on design protection

feedback_msg_text: L’indirizzo politico comunitario dell’Unione Europea è sempre a favore di una piena liberalizzazione del mercato delle parti di ricambio visibili, in quanto un mercato libero e uniforme rappresenta la garanzia per evitare abusi di posizione dominante e costrizioni della concorrenza in danno ai consumatori. L’associazione CICRA/EAPA, in rappresentanza dei produttori europei di ricambi di carrozzeria, membra di ECAR, accoglie con estrema soddisfazione il progetto di valutazione della legislazione comunitaria in materia di disegni e modelli, soprattutto con riferimento alle parti di ricambio “visibili”. Infatti, come dimostrato dal ritiro della proposta di modifica della Direttiva 98/71, relativa all’introduzione in ogni paese membro della c.d. repairs clause (oggi presente in solo 11 Stati membri), una soluzione definitiva non è mai stata trovata tanto è che, oggi, l’argomento stesso della clausola di riparazione trova nuova attenzione. E ciò perché la mancata adozione di un regime uniforme all’interno dell’Unione, determina la persistenza di sostanziali ostacoli alla competitività dei produttori indipendenti di ricambi di carrozzeria in molti ed importanti Stati membri (Francia/Germania), ove i diritti conseguenti alla registrazione delle parti di ricambio visibili come disegni e modelli, impedisce agli operatori indipendenti la fabbricazione e la vendita delle stesse parti, destinate alla riparazione. La necessità di un preciso intervento legislativo volto all’eliminazione della frammentazione del mercato dei ricambi visibili, è stata già ribadita nei precedenti Economic review of industrial Design in Europe (2015) e Legal review of industrial design protection in Europe (2016). E’ chiaro che la previsione in tutti gli Stati membri della clausola di riparazione, con riferimento ai diritti derivanti dal disegno/modello, rappresenterebbe un auspicabile ed importante primo passo per la liberalizzazione del mercato poiché permetterebbe agli operatori indipendenti di avere, in tutto il territorio dell’Unione, la certezza che le case auto non azionino in maniera distorta i diritti derivanti dalla registrazione di un componente come disegno/modello, per impedire la sua riproduzione come pezzo di ricambio. Tuttavia, non si può tacere come le case auto – già da alcuni anni – hanno mostrato la tendenza ad apporre il proprio marchio su alcuni componenti (paraurti, griglie, ecc…) e ad azionare i relativi diritti, in alcuni casi con modalità di vero e proprio abuso (sedi di marchio fatte valere come marchio stesso), per impedire ai ricambisti indipendenti la loro attività di riproduzione dei medesimi componenti come pezzi di ricambio. Allora, una clausola di riparazione con effetti protettivi limitati esclusivamente ai disegni e modelli industriali, pur essendo già un grande passo avanti rispetto alla situazione attuale, non consentirebbe l’auspicata e completa parità concorrenziale tra case auto e produttori indipendenti, poiché rimarrebbe aperta la questione della legittima applicazione – da parte degli indipendenti - del marchio automobilistico sui pezzi di ricambio, giustificabile, come riconosciuto dalla recente giurisprudenza, in base a quella esigenza filoconcorrenziale che limita i diritti di marchio attraverso l’introduzione di prodotti alternativi sul mercato, altrimenti monopolistico, dell’aftermarket. L'azione della Commissione deve essere rivolta proprio all’eliminazione – a livello normativo comunitario e nazionale – di qualsiasi incertezza in grado di compromettere la possibilità dei produttori indipendenti di ricambi visibili di operare in un mercato libero e concorrenziale, partendo senz'altro dalla armonizzazione delle norme riferite ai disegni e modelli. CICRA/EAPA supportano gli scopi e gli obiettivi espressi dalla Commissione, con invito ad un’analisi che consideri anche il tema del rapporto tra marchio registrato apposto sul componente e pezzo di ricambio.
Initiative: Evaluation of EU legislation on design protection

feedback_msg_text: The Independent Automotive Aftermarket Federation (IAAF) was formed in 1930 to promote the interests of the independent automotive aftermarket in the UK. As a Federation we represent a cross-section of SMEs including parts suppliers, distributors, factors and garages. Our aim is to represent the needs and requirements of our members and to co-ordinate its shared strengths to promote the independent automotive aftermarket as a credible alternative for vehicle service and repair.  IAAF’s objective is the establishment of a harmonised, free and genuinely competitive European Internal Market for automotive visible replacement parts: body panels; integrated lighting; automotive glass; rear-view mirrors etc. These parts are also called “must match” visible replacement parts. What distinguishes this category of spare parts from others is that the outside appearance of such spare parts, which is to be replaced in the course of a repair, must match the design of the original component exactly.   Currently at stake is the integrity of the Euro 15 Billion after-sales market of visible “must match” replacement parts for the millions of vehicle owners and for the spare parts suppliers. By extending design protection to visible spare parts, this would create a de facto product monopoly, to the sole benefit of the vehicle manufacturers. The effect would be to eliminate consumer choice and stifle free and fair competition.   A Repairs Clause rightly and equitably gives vehicle manufacturers full protection over the design of their new cars and retains their ability to fairly compete in the aftermarket. It merely and correctly ensures that this protection is not extended to the corresponding visible spare parts. It thus leaves vehicle owning consumers free to repair their vehicles as they wish and avoids creating detrimental spare parts monopolies.   Repeated evidence-based reinforcement of the legal, safety, quality and economic case has been made and supported by the aftermarket and the Commission over the past 25 year.  However, despite the best efforts of the Commission and of the Parliament, the Repairs Clause has inexplicably not yet been included in the EU Design Directive, resulting thus in a patchwork of national design protection regimes and in an incomplete European Internal Market.   National repairs clauses already exist in 11 Member states: Belgium, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Luxemburg, the Netherlands, Poland, Spain and the United Kingdom. In the rest of the EU, visible replacement parts can only be supplied by vehicle manufacturers under monopolistic conditions.   IAAF would like to bring to the attention of the Commission the recent “Partneo scandal” revealed by Mediapart in June 2018, where PSA and Renault secretly and artificially inflated the prices of certain spare parts thanks to the use of a very sophisticated software, Partneo, provided by Accenture, which discreetly increased the price of so-called "captive" spare parts by an average of 15%. Renault and PSA would have thereby collectively gained an undue profit, estimated at 1.5 billion euros over ten years.   This scandal is yet another attempt by many vehicle manufacturers to use all the opportunities of their monopolistic situation to still and always make more money at the expense and to the detriment of motorist consumers. This scandal has been widely facilitated by the French design legislation which puts the car manufacturers in a monopolistic position in the huge market of visible spare parts.   For IAAF, the current effects of the absence of a real EU Internal Market on the thousands of independent aftermarket SMEs, which are at the heart of our local economic base, are extremely serious. IAAF therefore urges the Commission to tackle these distortions of the Internal Market and consumer rip-offs without delay.
Initiative: Evaluation of EU legislation on design protection

feedback_msg_text: With this feedback we want to rise our concerns regarding the human rights dimension of Schengen Facility Instrument (SFI) for Croatia. Although we are aware SFI is technical instrument, we have documented broad human rights violations, which we see as a consequence of introducing SFI for Croatia. Namely, due to the Ministry of Interior (MoI) commitment to SFI, we believe how MoI is parallel managing SFI through the non-legal actions against the migrants and refugees on Serbian-Croatian border as well as on the Croatian border with Bosnia and Herzegovina. We have documented numerous of illegal so called “pushbacks” exercised by Croatian police on the borders against the migrant/refugees. Pushbacks were also well documented from deep inside the Croatian territory. Please find our latest reports on pushbacks in Croatia here http://welcome.cms.hr/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Fourth-Report-on-Illegal-Pushbacks_01032018.pdf .  By such behaviour, Croatian police is disabling the right to access asylum on the Croatian territory which is against EU rule of law. MoI keeps insisting on implementing Article 13 of Schengen Border Code but ignoring Article 14 at the same time. We see pushbacks as an non-appropriate response of Croatian police to “defend” EU border. We strongly believe EU border may be “defended” without human rights violations and that SFI does not approve such behaviors and human rights violations.  Also, in our work we have noticed, poorly an unprofessional police management of  thermal imaging cameras and footage on the external borders. This was particularly visible in the tragic case of death of a six-year-old Afghan girl Madina on Croatian-Serbian border (more about this tragedy please find here:  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/08/they-treated-her-like-a-dog-tragedy-of-the-six-year-old-killed-at-croatian-border). Apparently the police “lost” all camera footage which could solve the dilemma if the Madina’s family had been or not, on the Croatian territory. The problems with the thermal imaging camera management, and with illegal treatment of migrant by police was also detected by Croatian Ombudsperson. The Ombudsperson wrote an open letter to the Croatian State Attorney  emphasizing numerous of suspicious activities in police work, including pushbacks and disappearance of thermal imaging cameras footage. Letter is attached. She also referred to this problem in her Yearly/ Annual human rights report for year 2017 (pages 223 -231, http://ombudsman.hr/hr/izvjesca-2017/izvjesce-pp-2017/send/82-izvjesca-2017/1126-izvjesce-pucke-pravobraniteljice-za-2017-godinu).  Finally, MP Pedja Grbin asked Minister of Interior, mr. Davor Božinović about the problems with the thermal imaging cameras management on the Croatian borders. Minister replied that there are numerous of problems in the camera management (see their correspondence here: https://vlada.gov.hr/UserDocsImages//Sjednice/2018/03%20o%C5%BEujak/85%20sjednica%20VRH//85%20-%2021%20c.pdf).  As a human rights organization we are very concerned that Croatian accession to Schengen has for a consequence broad violations of human rights on the Croatian borders. We strongly believe that such approach is not official stand of European Commission and we expect that all member states, including Croatia have to control EU external borders in line with the respect of national and international human rights standards.  For additional questions or clarifications, we are on your disposal.  Centre for Peace Studies Feedback from: Center for Peace Studies (97.5 KB - PDF - 9 pages) Download
Initiative: Evaluation of the Schengen Facility Instrument for Croatia

feedback_msg_text: LG Electronics wishes to provide the following feedback on the proposed draft regulations:  Scope: The scope of the proposed drafts covers all washing machines and washer dryers, irrespective of their capacity. This is problematic for appliances with small capacity, especially when taking into account that the new regulations also change how efficiency is evaluated, by including treatments with 1/4 loads in addition to 1/2 and full loads. For appliances with a capacity of 2kg and below, reduced reliability of measurements for the partial loads makes them impossible to verify. We are concerned that these challenges may destabilize the level playing field for niche products dedicated to small households, and to ensure fair competition we suggest that all machines with a rated capacity of 2kg and below are excluded from the scope of the regulations.   Definitions:  It is important to highlight that the difference between secondary drums supplied in separate casings and stand-alone machines is not limited to sharing particular connections, but also relates to the actual operation of the drum, where a secondary drum would not be able to operate at all without the presence of the main washer. We believe the definition for multi-drum appliances should acknowledge this fact, and therefore we propose it to be improved as below:   “(6) ‘multi-drum washing machine' means a washing machine or washer dryer equipped with more than one drum, whether in separate units or in the same casing. Any additional drum supplied as a separate unit shall be considered an independent appliance only if it can function in a stand-alone setting.”    ED & EL Requirements: LG supports the proposed exemption for additional drums of multi-drum machines, as they are beneficial for families with high focus on time efficiency. With the use of a secondary drum, consumers are able to run two loads of different types of laundry at the same time. As time is a valuable good, the presence of an additional drum can increase the acceptance of longer cycles at the main drum. Furthermore, in many cases the secondary drum is designed to be used for delicate laundry, its construction (e.g. vertical axis) offering protection for sensitive textiles. Due to the different orientation, these drums are able to perform very well for delicate wash and lightly soiled laundry, but are not suitable for washing normally soiled cotton. The benefits of such drums would be eliminated if they had to be redesigned to offer the programs required in the drafts. While the primary drum in these appliances is always covered by the regulations, the functionality of the additional drum is comparable to that of special programs already existent in single drum appliances. These special programs are not subject to any requirements when included in the main drum therefore secondary drums offering such programs should not be regulated either. We would also like to point out that Annex V of the ED draft may create loopholes, especially since “the most commonly used programme cycles” can be interpreted in multiple ways. To avoid any issue, we recommend adding a maximum rated capacity threshold of 4kg, together with clarification that drums offering programs able to wash normally soiled cotton are not allowed to qualify for the exemption. Our proposal is to reword the first paragraph of Annex V as below:  “Multi-drum washing machines The provisions of points 1 to 4 of Article 3 of this Regulation are applicable to each of the drums of multi-drum washing machines, except for those drums that have a rated capacity up to 4Kg, do not offer any programme cycle for normally soiled cotton laundry and are not suitable for the programme cycles used to determine compliance in accordance to Annex I of this Regulation.”   In addition, due to the absence of cotton programs, such drums should be exempted from EL obligations too. An adapted copy of the paragraph above should be introduced in the EL draft.
Initiative: Review of energy labelling for household washing machines and washer-driers

feedback_msg_text: This representation is submitted on behalf of Lough Neagh Fishermen’s Co-operative Society (LNFCS) based in N. Ireland and which is responsible for the management of the eel industry in the Lough Neagh EMU.  LNFCS controls the entire freshwater life cycle of the European eel within the Neagh/Bann RBD. It therefore has excellent insight into the particular issues which have exercised the minds of stakeholders, scientists, national authorities and Member States across the continent for many years. Lough Neagh EMU has long-since been recognised as providing excellent habitat/environment for the production of high quality, healthy fish and tight control over commercial exploitation.  LNFCS has also implemented a substantial restocking programme for more than 30 years. The EU Regulation to address the decline in eel stock is regarded as a largely positive initiative but there are elements of it which require action.  •It is imperative that all Member States co-operate fully if there is to be any success in achieving the aims of the relevant legislation.  Against a backdrop of co-operation and compliance in our own EMU it is extremely frustrating to learn of reviews being thwarted through belated or incomplete returns without any apparent sanction.   •Illegal trade in glass eels will destroy this industry if it is to continue unchecked.  More resources must be deployed in that regard.  •More support is needed for EMUs which have established compliance with the requirements of their EMP.  With its restocking programme and careful management of the resource Lough Neagh EMU continues to be a significant nett contributor to the eel as a species in terms of its recovery.  •In 2016 LNFCS hosted and contributed to the ICES WG on Eel Stocking which had been tasked with assessing the available science and providing advice on stocking as a recovery measure for eel stocks. The subsequent report highlighted that although, in 2009, most Member States had advocated the use of stocking as a recovery measure in their respective EMPs, by 2016 only five MS had actually delivered a stocking programme and in fact only two had achieved their targets. The findings echoed those of numerous ICES WGEEL reports highlighting similar concerns having analysed available statistics relating to trade in glass eels over a six year period (2011-2016).   As an advocate and end user of glass eel supplies for restocking LNFC has been able to achieve its target in that regard on just one occasion since the introduction of EMPs due to the unavailability of adequate supplies despite the fact that funding had been in place by way of internal, national and EU support.  More needs to be done to make those glass eels available to EMUs with track record in compliance and the endeavour to effect meaningful measures in addressing a recovery. ICES have reported that during this same period the target 60% of glass eel catches set aside on an annual basis for restocking has not been achieved and most alarmingly approximately 40% of declared catches of glass eel proved unaccounted-for after the point of first sale.  It is difficult to understand why it has not been possible to fully implement the requirements of Article 12 of the relevant Regulation relating to traceability.  With regard to the 40% escapement target, it is evident from an analysis of more than 100 years of recruitment and catch data available to LNFC relating to the Neagh/Bann EMU that the target is not realistic.  The target has been derived from a period of historic maxima. It has only been as a consequence of a significant restocking programme since 1984 that this EMU has been deemed compliant with the target in the longer term, one of the very few EMUs where that has been achieved.    As the controlling influence on this EMU LNFC with the expert help of scientific analysists has demonstrated that restocking is an effective measure in the recovery plan and without it we too would fail to meet

feedback_msg_text: We welcome the opportunity to provide feedback to the Commission´s Roadmap on the Evaluation of the legislation on medicines for children and rare diseases.  First, we like to point out that the number of medicines and research activities in these areas have significantly increased since the Paediatric and Orphan Drug Regulations have come into force. A major reason for that achievement is the ultimative objective of these two regulations: increase of therapeutic choices for children and patients suffering from rare diseases. Therefore, both legislation have been a success story so far.  We like to emphasise that the evaluation of regulations in general is a useful measure, if properly done. In this respect, we like to point out that this evaluation roadmap is missing essential aspects and information. This roadmap describes context, purpose and scope but a clear objective/intention is missing. Part B is entitled as "Better regulation" without explaining what that should mean. We have the opinion that such an extensive evaluation needs a clear objective. The purposes described are explaining only assessment procedures and focus but are not declaring what consequences are intended to be drawn from the results.  In our opinion, the objective of the evaluation of both regulations should be to ensure the objectives of these regulations namely to increase the therapeutic choices for children and patients suffering from rare diseases.  We like to mention that it is difficult to make concrete and helpful comments to the evaluation concept/roadmap as it provides only little information about the methodology. The section "data collection and methodology" declares that qualitative and quantitative indicators will be used. It would be helpful to have more information about that indicators as well as about planned research questions, endpoints and expected outcome.  In order to assess whether there will be a balanced representation of stakeholders in the targeted consultation it would be necessary to know how the stakeholders will be selected and what kind of consultations is planned (survey, interview etc. ..) Regarding key stakeholders identified, we like to mention that also national industry associations should be included.  We are looking forward to further engage in that evaluation and would be pleased if our comments are considered in your further proceedings.  PHARMIG Association of the Austrian Pharmaceutical Industry Garnisongasse 4/2/8, 1090 Wien office@pharmig.at
Submitted by: PHARMIG Association of the Austrian Pharmaceutical Industry
Initiative: Evaluation of the legislation on medicines for children and rare diseases (medicines for special populations)

feedback_msg_text: To meet the EU’s climate goals, live up to the Green Deal's aspirations, and ensure a habitable planet for future generations currently threatened by catastrophic and irreversible climate change, Europe must urgently act to protect the world’s forests. Addressing energy and transportation contributions to the current climate crisis will not be enough, unless forests are also taken into account.  The number one threat to forests today comes from agriculture – with the threat disproportionately concentrated in the most “high forest risk” commodities of cattle, soy, palm oil, rubber, cocoa, and coffee. These commodities are destroying forests and are also frequently associated with systemic and grave human rights abuses, ranging from child labor to indigenous rights violations and more.   The EU can take steps to interdict all imports of these commodities tied to deforestation (and human rights abuses), without placing undue financial burdens on the corporations at play or on European consumers. Absolutely central will be passing new EU regulation to ensure respect for land rights and protection of forests and ecosystems, and stop conversion of forests for agribusiness; which will require due diligence of corporations with liability and sanctions for non-compliance. Voluntary industry measures are simply not enough, nor is certification. Robust regulation of agribusiness and of the food industry is urgently needed.  Moreover, European banks and investors often finance some of the worst deforestation in the world. We thus need mandatory due diligence requirements on EU financiers and investors, barring them from financing deforestation, ecosystem conversion, or human rights violations.  Next, EU trade deals with producer countries – especially where high forest risk commodities originate from – must contain legally enforceable provisions protecting forests and rights.  In addition, by supporting meat and dairy alternatives, financing education and awareness campaigns about the well-documented health risks of excessive meat consumption, and taxing meat and dairy, as well as a host of other policy and regulatory tools, the EU can spark the much-needed reduction of European consumption of meat and dairy. This would have tremendous impacts on forest protection.   Furthermore, EU biofuels and biomass incentives and regulations must be restructured to avoid any destruction of forests or ecosystem conversion.   Links to Mighty Earth research on deforestation and ecosystem destruction linked to agribusiness : - For cocoa: http://www.mightyearth.org/chocolate/  - For soy: http://www.mightyearth.org/soy/  and http://www.mightyearth.org/rapidresponse/ - For palm oil: http://www.mightyearth.org/palm-oil/ and http://www.mightyearth.org/rapidresponse/  - For rubber: http://www.mightyearth.org/rubber/   Europe has been a major part of the problem, but it can become a key champion for the solutions this planet needs, before it is too late.
Initiative: Deforestation and forest degradation – reducing the impact of products placed on the EU market

feedback_msg_text: Max Havelaar France, membre fondateur du mouvement international Fairtrade / Max Havelaar, agit en faveur d'un commerce plus juste, respectueux des droits humains et de l'environnement.   Nous saluons l'initiative de la Commission européenne sur les liens entre déforestation et produits vendus dans l'Union européenne, ainsi que la consultation publique associée. Nous souhaitons placer cette réflexion dans le contexte plus global du manque de durabilité des modes de production et de consommation (ODD 12) dans l'Union européenne et au-delà.  En tant qu'organisation non-gouvernementale agissant en faveur d'un commerce plus juste et équitable et d'une mondialisation plus responsable, nous estimons que la réalisation et le respect des droits économiques et sociaux des populations vulnérables sont intrinsèquement liés à la protection de l'environnement, notamment dans les pays en développement et pour les populations rurales vivant dans l'extrême pauvreté. Cette extrême pauvreté est principalement due aux inégalités criantes entre acteurs des chaînes d'approvisionnement. A titre d'illustration, seulement 6% du prix payé par le consommateur européen pour une tablette de chocolat ou un paquet de café revient aux producteurs de café et de cacao dans les pays en développement. Ce niveau d'inégalités rend par essence impossible l'ambition de rendre les chaînes d'approvisionnement et les modes de production plus responsables et durables.   A l'heure actuelle, les mesures et programmes concernant les activités des entreprises multinationales sont principalement volontaires (à l'exception de quelques législations existantes dans certains Etats membres). Elles ne prennent pas en considération les besoins des populations des pays de production dont peuvent être issus les produits contribuant à la déforestation. En outre, elles n'aboutissent pas à des résultats suffisamment rapides en matière de lutte contre le changement climatique, d'érosion de la biodiversité et de respect des droits humains, en particulier pour les plus vulnérables.   Max Havelaar France préconise donc à échelle européenne des mesures contraignantes et la promotion des meilleures pratiques volontaires afin de prévenir les atteintes aux droits humains et de garantir la préservation de l'environnement, les deux étant intrinsèquement liés.  Nous appelons par conséquent l'Union européenne à :  i. adopter une législation contraignante en matière de vigilance (HRDD) des entreprises transnationales pour prévenir et réparer les atteintes aux droits humains et à l'environnement ;  ii. renforcer les programmes de solidarité et la coopération technique avec les pays et régions producteurs de matières premières contribuant à la déforestation ;  iii. prendre en compte les enjeux de justice sociale, de rémunération des agriculteurs et des producteurs dans toutes ses initiatives de durabilité, et promouvoir les modèles économiques et commerciaux contribuant à l'ODD 12 et permettant d'améliorer les conditions de vie des plus vulnérables.
Initiative: Deforestation and forest degradation – reducing the impact of products placed on the EU market

feedback_msg_text: Für den BDI und die exportorientierte deutsche Industrie ist der Zugang zu einem freien und fairen Markt von großer Bedeutung. Daher freuen wir uns über die Initiative der Europäischen Kommission zur Überprüfung des geltenden Regelwerks hinsichtlich der Marktzugangsbedingungen in der Binnenschifffahrt. In dem Zusammenhang müssen alle Befahrensabgaben auf Wasserstraßen nationaler und internationaler Art in der EU gleichermaßen abgesenkt werden. Ausnahmen hierbei aufgrund internationaler Abkommen, beispielsweise wie der Mosel, sind abzuschaffen. Darüber hinaus ist eine breite Basis von Dienstleistern Voraussetzung für einen freien und fairen Markt. Daher empfehlen wir auch weiterhin den Weg zu verfolgen, Marktzutrittshürden niedrig zu halten und neuen Teilnehmern den Markteintritt zu ermöglichen. Für einzelne Branchen, insbesondere der Chemiebranche, wird eine zunehmende Konzentration der Dienstleister als Hemmnis für den freien Markt und die Wahlmöglichkeiten für die Verlader gesehen.
Initiative: Fitness check on market access in inland waterway transport

feedback_msg_text: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren    Wir begrüssen diese erste Möglichkeit, ein Feedback zur Roadmap über die geplanten Arbeiten der EK zum Marktzugang in der europäischen Binnenschifffahrt geben zu können.   Die Schweiz verfügt über einen kurzen, aber wichtigen Abschnitt auf der internationalen Wasserstrasse, dem Rhein. Oberhalb des Dreiländerecks (DE, FR, CH) bewirtschaftet die Schweiz den letzten Hafen, bevor der Rhein nicht mehr schiffbar wird, und stellt mit den drei verschiedenen Hafenstandorten (einer in Basel-Stadt, zwei im Nachbarkanton Basel-Landschaft) den sogenannten Endhafen des Rheins dar. Der höchstgelegene Hafenstandort befindet sich zudem auf einem Rheinabschnitt, welcher sich die Schweiz und Deutschland als Grenzländer teilen.    Mit der Übereinkunft zwischen der Schweiz und dem Grossherzogtum Baden betreffend den Wasserverkehr auf dem Rhein von Neuhausen bis unterhalb Basels (Staatsvertrag DE-CH) aus dem Jahre 1879 einigte sich die Schweiz mit ihrem Nachbarn Deutschland zu einer gemeinsamen Sicherheit und Ordnung auf dem Rhein. Bekräftigt und ergänzt um patentrechtliche und schiffbautechnische Vorschriften, erlassen durch die Zentralkommission für die Rheinschifffahrt (ZKR), gelten heute in allen Mitgliedstaaten der ZKR, und damit auch der Schweiz, die identischen Vorschriften.  Die schweizerische Mitgliedschaft bei der ZKR umfasst nicht nur den völkerrechtlich garantierten Zugang zum Meer, sondern tangiert die Schweiz auch direkt, wenn bestehende Rheinregularien - wie die Festlegung der Bedingungen für die Inanspruchnahme der Regelung, die aufgrund der Revidierten Rheinschifffahrtsakte (Mannheimer Akte) den Schiffen der Rheinschifffahrt vorbehalten ist, oder die Vereinbarung über die Bestimmungen der anzuwendenden Rechtsvorschriften für die Rheinschiffer gemäss Art. 16 Abs. 1 der Verordnung (EG) Nr. 883/2004 (inkl. Zusatz) - berührt werden.     Der freie Marktzugang auf dem Rhein und die Einheit des Rheinregimes wird in der Mannheimer Akte geregelt, welche durch das Zusatzprotokoll Nr. 2 inklusive dessen Ausführungsverordnung besondere Vorschriften ergänzt wird. So finden sich darin auch die wichtigsten Rahmenbedingungen für den Erwerb einer Rheinschifffahrts-Zugehörigkeitsurkunde, die als Nachweis einer echten Verbindung mit dem Registerstaat dient. Die Schweiz hat diese internationalen Bestimmungen im Landesrecht umgesetzt und verfügt mit dem Bundesgesetz über die Schiffsregistrierung und der dazu gehörenden Verordnung über ausführliche Vorschriften zum Nachweis dieser echten Verbindung.     Als direkt betroffener Stakeholder gehen wir davon aus, dass die Schweiz auch in der nachfolgenden öffentlichen Konsultation im ersten Quartal 2020 begrüsst wird und bedanken uns bereits heute für die gute Absicht einer harmonisierten Lösung für die Marktbedingungen in der Europäischen Binnenschifffahrt.  Freundliche Grüsse Schweizerische Delegation der Zentralkommission für die Rheinschifffahrt
Initiative: Fitness check on market access in inland waterway transport

feedback_msg_text: EWWG, Europacable Winding Wire Group, the European Industrial Association for the Winding Wire Manufacturers, welcomes the opportunity to give a Feedback on this initiative:  Since the STS-BREF, most relevant for the manufacturing of winding wires, will not be finished before the end of 2019, we would propose to delay the review of IED  at least until 2020 to allow the STS-BREF changes to come into place.
Initiative: Industrial emissions - evaluating the EU rules

feedback_msg_text: VCI generally welcomes the EU COM’s commitment to ensuring the efficiency of its directives, there are however, some concerns: The timeline which has been suggested contradicts the report on the “implementation of the [IED] ..” , which DG ENV published in Dec. 2017). The report states that it is “… to early to see the practical results of the change to the IED …” (report, pg. 12) Evaluations must base on the best available data. Premature evaluations may only paint a distorted picture of the expected status quo.  We agree with the conclusion presented by DG ENV during the 12th Art. 13 Forum on Nov. 27th, 2018, that 50% of the installations have already been reviewed. but this does not mean, the conclusions of the respective BREF have already been implemented. With view onto the chemical Sector, the WGC BREF, for which the data collection has just begun, covers the majority of chemical installations. The implementation of conclusions of the LVOC BREF (Large Vol Org Chemicals) is still ongoing and the evaluation of the sector for large inorganic chemicals (LVIC) has not started.  We expect the WGC BREF will not be finished before 2021 and, BATs will not be fully implemented before 2025, the units falling under LVIC even later. An evaluation starting now would not consider the implementation of the IED in the majority of chemical plants in Europe. It would be unwise to neglect the input and results of one of the largest industrial sectors in Europe. The BREF process has undergone some significant improvements in the most recent years. Some essential questions, e.g. the derivation of BAT-AELs is not fully answered. In conclusion: All this leads to question the timeliness of the IED evaluation and we hence suggest reconsidering launching the evaluation now.  Our suggestions for additional topics to the roadmap: - Assess overlaps of the IED with other legislation. - Review the achievements reached by the IED. - Analyze whether the IED has decreased or increased the administrative burden in comparison to expectations. - Assess the process of elaborating BREFs and BAT conclusions. The VCI represents the politico-economic interests of around 1,700 German chemical companies and German subsidiaries of foreign businesses. The VCI stands for over 90 percent of the chemical industry in Germany. In 2017 the German chemical industry realised sales of more than 195 billion euros and employed around 453,000 staff.
Initiative: Industrial emissions - evaluating the EU rules
